I love the decor, it reminds me of the local brasseries in Paris. The menu is solid breakfast options and the workers here are actually compensated and give health benefits. Hats off to the owner!

St. Trope- man the salmon and hollaindaise sauce was amazing. So fresh with just the right amount of zest. 5/5

Monaco- the prosciutto blends in perfectly with the sauce. It was like heaven in my mouth. 5/5

Home fries that came with both meals are the best home fries I've had in my life. You can really taste the garlic!

Tahiti toast- this one was actually not that good. The toast wasn't as soft as I wanted versus mama on Washington. 2/5. 

Overall this place is amazing. Best benedicts I've ever had. Also no tip so it gives off the French vibe 100 percent. Excellent brunch place!
author: Kevin N.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. 

I recomend to try to grab a table on the back patio- its gorgeous! They have heaters and it is covered for the colder days. Truly makes you feel like youve stepped out of the city and into the countryside somewhere... that is until you look up and see the surrounding typical San Francisco victorian buildings. 

So casual here, and it is so cozy! Mimoas here are delicious, but so is their coffee (which is always served in cute little bowls). I always order a cappuccino with cinnamon and honey on the side. 

I have never ordered anything here i didnt like, from their coffee cake, to their benedicts, scrambles, or even their granola.... everything deserves a 5 star rating. If you havent been here yet, what are you waiting for? Its also close to GGP and Haight street, so its a good place to stop if youre checking either of those out.
author: jessica a.

description: Cute place to have brunch. The portion sizes are good and the egg plates are delicious. The one thing is the menu is overpriced.
author: Kristine C.

description: Quick girl getaway to San Francisco for the weekend. So we are all foodies in a way and don't mind searching for good places where the locals eat. We got up early so we didn't have to wait long at all. We were very satisfied with the service and the meal quality. Would recommend to anyone in the area.
author: Nisha F.

description: Zazie has the best brunch and service in the city. It's amazing what can be done in that tiny kitchen! Miracle pancakes are just that: a dang miracle. Everything on the menu is delicious.
author: An S.

description:
Ok this place is so popular. 
I personally am not a foodie who queues up on the latest or best whims, neither am I a foodie anyway. I go for usually a combination of ambiance, to be away, to bathe in the atmosphere of solitude and occasional conversation, or to carousel with good friends or special people in life. This of course requires that the food and service be good not awful as well. 

Zazie with half the hype and crowd is delectable for this. A feminine space, delicate and sunny like back courtyard, a welcome contrast to the busy bistro atmosphere of the inside restaurant or the rest of the street. Service was personable despite the madness, food standard fare, nothing to complain of particularly. A pleasant intimate place for conversats in a medium noise level and semi chaotic environment.
author: Juls C.

description: Liked this place.  Great little french bistro like menu. Service was good.  Price includes tip so you don't have to tip.  Wine list was okay but not great for food of this caliber
author: Jeff C.

description:
Finally got to try Zazie and wish I had sooner! Though I didn't rate it as 4 stars, I did enjoy the food and atmosphere.

Food: Best friend and fellow Yelper, Jen J., and I did our usual dance of getting something savory and sweet and sharing. That way, we get to try the best of both worlds. We decided on the Divorcee which was eggs benedict with avocado, bacon, and some hollandaise sauce. For sweet, we picked the French toast a la Diable which was french toast with poached bing cherries and whipped mascarpone. I liked that we got to decide on the number of eggs and slices of toast which coincided with an increase in price, of course. I liked the eggs benedict very much. You could tell it was all about the egg and didn't have an overpowering amount of sauce. The French toast was "okay" but I don't think I'd order it again. It was sweet but didn't stand out.

Atmosphere: We ended up sitting in the patio which actually seemed much more comfortable than sitting inside. The heat lamp definitely did its job even on a chilly San Francisco morning. Very cute outside.

Wait: We got there right at 9 am on a Saturday (when it opens) and waited 25 minutes. The method of calling people didn't make sense to me. They only seated an entire table when everyone was there but if people showed up late they still tried to seat them first. It was a little frustrating but understandable, I guess. It seemed like somehow, people also got reserve seating if they knew people at the restaurant(?). Not completely sure - but we did notice an instance of this. 

Overall a worthwhile place to try with great food and a cute ambience. I like that tip is included since it ends up coming out close to the same and promotes a better living wage.
author: Salma R.

description:
This is was one of my favorite brunch spots in SF! 

Today I walked in by myself to enjoy an afternoon brunch on my day off, sat down on a table for at least 15 minuets and NOT a single person from the staff came by and offered anything. 

Seems like Zazie now will only serve the white folks and leave any person of color behind. 


Very Frustrating and never coming back again...
author: Nate A.

description:
Zazie is amazing. I came with 3 girlfriends around 9:30a on a saturday for one of the best brunches I've had in a while. There's a little sign-up sheet by the door where we left our names, and since it was going to be at least a 30m wait, we walked across the street to get coffee and dip into a few nearby stores. By the time we got back about 40min later, our name was ready to be called! 

*Note: Be careful walking around the area for too long. They may call your name while you're gone, because the line moves faster than you think. When I was there, lots of people didn't walk around at all at the risk their names would be called and skipped!

We got the best seating in the back patio, surrounded by vines and flowers and immersed in natural light. Picturesque.

We all ordered the "magic mimosas," which are super cute, fizzy, sweet little drinks. For brunch, I made the best deal with my friend -- split the Omelette du Jour (apple chicken sausage, tomatoes provencale, avos, + feta) and "miracle pancakes" (bread pudding w/ grilled bananas + whipped cream). It was an epic deal in that we covered both sweet and savory, had just the right amount of food, and both got to try two special items on the menu that they seemingly run out of each day. HIGHLY recommend.

I have only great things to say about Zazie. Can't wait to come back!!
author: Katie K.

description:
Zazie always has a long line so be prepared to do some waiting and I'd recommend coming ...not on a weekend if possible.

We first wanted to try Zazie last year but due to the long line, we went elsewhere that day because homegirl wasn't trying to wait hella long to eat. We gave Zazie a try on a Thursday and again, a line but hey, maybe this is just how it has to be so we waited. It was about a 30 minute wait, another 30 minutes to get our food. The inside decor wasn't quite what I had expected but it was nice -- a nice homey vibe. We both got two eggs benedict, smoked salmon and the dungeness crab cause, I mean, why not?  I did have to wait in line for this. We also got their cream cheese coffee cake to share.

The house potatoes were pretty good. I love that they add huge gloves of garlic to to them. After eating those babies and a benedict we were already stuffed so just took the other little guys to go. Service was okay but kind of minimal since they were busy. Why oh why do all the brunch spots in SF all have to be so hyped up.
author: Annie C.
Miko B.

description:
SERVICE: We came on a Saturday morning around 10:45 (prime brunching time). The list is posted outside so we signed up knowing it would prob be a looong wait. We got coffee and pastries at La Boulangerie to
hold us over meanwhile. We got called at 45 minutes (yay earlier than expected!) The waitstaff were friendly and efficient! There's no tips expected at Zazies as they state their prices cover for their staff.

FOOD: I got the St. Tropez (salmon Benedict) with salad. I appreciated that the egg yolk wasn't too runny and instead was the perfect medium of softness. It was good but prob not worth a longer wait. The S/O got the three sampler thing of -gingerbread pancake, buttermilk pancake and French toast. I don't like ginger taste so can't comment on that. The buttermilk pancake was soft and fluffy but honestly was not that special. The French toast was pretty terrible I have to say. Tasted super plain and was not a soft texture... Weird. 

VIBE: typical SF brunch place themed French. There's an outdoor patio in the back and that looked like a fun place to sit. There are two small tables out in front of the restaurant that's first come, first serve but it might a little too up close and personal with the mass mob of hungry brunchers waiting outside to be called. 

I must also comment about the bathroom. There's only one bathroom  and a line can queue up. It is super small, reminded me of the size of an airplane bathroom! 

Overall, a good place to brunch on the weekend for a small party. Just not sure if it would be worth a 1+ hour wait!
author: Yvi L.

description: The wait was two hours to be seated and the service after was horrible! No wonder they don't ask for tips, because there is no service. The water is self pour, the cramped space is ill-fitted for a comfortable brunch, and the hollandaise is not made to order (and considering the price and wait you would expect quality). Their breakfast "fries" are bland home-style potatoes and the price is STEEP for breakfast, but hey, you're in San Francisco. While the brunch menu is classic with everything from a variety of eggs bennies, french toast, and scrambles. There will be something on the menu for everyone and every dietary restriction (which is why I gave 2 stars instead of 1). I am someone who loves brunch, but Zazie's service, quality, and price as a whole made it an awful experience.
author: Tooka Z.

description:
Went here to celebrate my birthday with my girlfriends. We got to sit in the patio and it was beautiful outside. Our server was so nice to us! He was all smiles and cracked jokes too. The food was amazing but it took a while to get to us, I am guessing it's because they wanted all the food to arrive at the same time. The restaurant doesn't take tips, they mentioned that their employees are getting enough to have a live able wage. 

The reason why it's not a 5 Star review - during our brunch, we asked one of the servers (it wasn't the one appointed to us) to turned the heater a little higher due to the cold climate, he decided to make the heater the highest it could be so we were all burning, the heat was so strong! We then asked for some hot sauce and he rolled his eyes and walked away. By the end of our brunch, my girlfriends had given the kitchen a cake to surprise me and they asked for the cake, the server brought the cake in its bag with everything inside. I was shook! Obviously, my girlfriends had asked for them to bring the cake out so it could be consumed. We were already so surprised at this person's attitude we decided to just take the cake home because why bother giving him another task right? (This was all done by the server not appointed to us, I guess he was mad it wasn't his job? But we just asked because he kept coming towards our table)
author: Yenni H.

description: Really cute and small place in SF. We went here on Saturday for brunch and I definitely would not recommend this if you are in a hurry or are really hungry. We had to wait for about and hour. The restaurant is really cozy but they also have a patio outside that is really pretty (we were too hungry to wait for that). The portions are pretty big so we shared 2 dishes along 3 people. We got the griddle flight and the La Mer Benedict. Both were so good and the flight especially was perfect to taste a little bit of everything. We also got a creme brûlée and it was perfect and not too sweet. They also had a lot of options for their mimosas. I got the mango with the tajin and my mom got the black current mimosa. I'd definitely come back if I can get a table faster
author: Julia M.

description:
If you're gonna brunch in SF, do it the right way! Zazie is the full SF brunch experience. We came in during the holidays on a weekday, and the wait was still about an hour and a half, though the front patio seating is first come first serve. We expected the wait, so no stars knocked off for this.

When we were finally seated, I was surprised that the tables were actually decently spaced out, and we had good amount of privacy. The menu is diverse with a good amount of selection for vegetarians. I definitely am not a brunch person because I dislike eggs and sweet breakfast-y items, but I saw that they had some really unique savory, non egg-centric items. I ultimately decided on the toasted baguette with cream cheese, tomato and basil (brilliantly simple item, but so good) and one Miracle Pancake. The Miracle Pancakes are accurately named because the one I had was so delicious and fluffy, without being overly sweet and decadent. I also love the option of being able to choose 1, 2 or 3 pancakes so you can venture out and try other things without a huge stack of leftover pancakes. In conclusion, as a non-brunch person, I give this meal an A+.
 
They also have a great selection of brunch drinks, I loved the Magic Mimosa and the Mango Mimosa. 

Overall, Zazie is definitely worth at least one try. Our bill came to about $40 per person, which is decent for SF considering we each ordered two drinks. The service was also AMAZING considering how overwhelming it must be to have such a huge crowd waiting outside the restaurant hungrily waiting for their names to be called. Additional bonus: the bathroom was really clean for a crowded SF joint. :P
author: Anila Y.

description: Went here a few months ago with a friend - expect a long wait for weekend brunch and expect San Francisco brunch prices, but the food is really good. I got the gingerbread pancakes (served with lemon curd and pear slices), which were to die for.
author: Kelsi K.

description: The food and service here is amazing , definitely recommend this. Came in and was seated quickly but it does get packed , the jelly by far was my favorite but all the food was delicious I got the Mexico scramble dish and thought it would be spicy but no it just had a small kick which made it great for anyone that didn't do good with spicy and it was great for a first meal of the day.
author: Noemy G.

description:
Really good food. Nice place. Servers are polite. I would recommend to all my friends. I would also return. 
Tips free place! I loved it. 
Price is ok, about 20$ per person (food only). 
I tried eggs Benedict, and you must do it to. There are many different options of it in the menu.
author: Rafael M.

description: My favorite brunch spot in SF hands down every time I'm here in the city I can't leave without having an order of the Italy Scramble. Tried there Mexico scramble had the French toast but what really blew my mind was the miracle mile pancakes with lemon curd and fresh strawberry. I got one piece to go alongside my scrambler. And it was the most tastiest pancake I've ever bitten into. The fresh and vibrant flavors make that pancake so alive. The home fries with garlic are my fav I love cracking open the garlic and spreading it on my bread. If you don't eat the garlic in the home fries your missing out on action. Yeah there's usually a wait here and weekends can get hectic but it's worth the wait your stomach will thank you. Grab a coffee from Peet's chill and wait while looking at people walking out full and happy you know your at the right spot.
author: Amit P.

description:
Brunch? Yes, please! 

Zazie is a cozy little brunch joint that offers a wide array of American and French-inspired brunch foods. My friends and I ordered the Monaco Eggs Benedict (English muffins dressed with prosciutto, provencale tomatoes, and gloriously dressed in the smoothest of Hollandaise sauces that I've tried; served with either house fries or salad) and the infamous "Miracle Pancakes." Note: Miracle Pancake flavor varies day-by-day. Ours happened to be cornmeal, which was surprisingly good! We enjoyed the nutty pancakes, topped with house-made lemon curd (yum!) and fresh strawberries.

The only thing we were bummed about was the fact that they ran out of their popular cream cheese coffee cake...apparently they didn't make any for that day...Hopefully anyone reading this may be luckier than we were, and be able to snag a slice!

Our waiter was friendly and attentive; restaurant was clean.
author: Brittany H.

description: Bloody Mary Review - Zazie's brunch menu includes a long list of eight different kinds of mimosas, including a build your own mimosa option that would even satisfy a clique of OC dude bro chicks. It also includes one very refreshing sake bloody mary made with tomato juice, horseradish and tabasco. Pair it with two thick slices of caramelized banana French Toast you'll be wishing for more breakfasts in the day. Why go? A sake bloody mary. | Price: $11
author: Shelley B.

description:
Absolutely needed to update my review after last weekend's brunch and last night's dinner at Zazie.

I moved to Cole Valley a few months ago so we've got our brunch system down by now...go put our name in then come back an hour later to be seated. We got a table outside (which is first come first served). I ordered the buttermilk pancake and 1 Florentine Eggs Benedict, with an iced coffee. Every single thing about this brunch was perfect. The ice coffee was strangely delicious, the buttermilk pancake (which i had tried before in a pancake flight but realized buttermilk was the best) was out of this world and the florentine eggs benny rocked. I honestly could not have been happier. 

Last night my dad took me and my 2 roommates here for my bday dinner which i was very excited about since i had never been here for dinner. We brought a bottle of wine and ended up ordering another one (Red Zin) in between the meal and dessert. We started off with the sampler app platter with mussels, figs fagaro, and the pate de volaille. I'm not a huge mussels fan, but gave it a try. Still not a fan. Also was not expecting to enjoy the pate but it was actually really tasty and rich. The figs fagaro (grilled black mission figs, wilted arugula, and warm chèvre
on grilled garlic levain) was by far my favorite. 

For entrees, the 4 of us split the truite meuniere (white trout w/ preserved meyer lemon butter and toasted almonds, served w/ green salad), Grilled Niman Ranch Hanger Steak (with portobello mushroom cream sauce, mashed russet potatoes, and sautéed local broccolini), and the Fresh Lemon Ricotta Raviolis (wilted arugula, melted leeks, white wine, and parmesan) and a side of mac n cheese (fresh organic pasta w/ creamy cheddar sauce and parmesan crust) because why not. oh my goodness everything was incredibly delicious. The trout was so good, not too fishy, the hanger steak was perfectly cooked and paired nicely with the mashed potatoes and broccolini, and the lemon ricotta raviolo was so unique and wonderful. Also the mac n cheese was unreal. perfect side dish. For dessert, we ordered the Cuit de Chocolat Chaud (signature "Baked Hot Chocolate" w/ golden marshmallows) and the Crumble aux Fruits (fresh fruit crumble, served warm w/ crème fraîche). The special of the night for the crumble was strawberry and we also got a side of vanilla gelato. 

Wow i cannot even fully express how awesome this meal was. Plus on monday nights they have puppy night where you get $10 off a bottle just for bringing your dog. best thing ever! Tuesdays are no corkage fee so you can bring in your own bottle of wine and not pay a corkage fee PLUS they have an adorable back patio that I have yet to sit in but am making that happen the next time I come here. Zazie is the best!
author: Ilana B.

description: A good brunch place in the city, but be prepared for the wait! I came here with my friend on a Saturday around 10:45am, and there was a big blob of people already waiting! Not a surprise since it was prime brunch time, but brunch crowds never cease to amaze me. There is street parking (meter parking right out front) and residential parking in the area, which might take some time to find. Luckily, I dropped my friend off so she could put our name down for the waitlist while I drove around to find parking. The downside to putting your name down on the waitlist is that the staff doesn't let you know how long the wait is, which I understand is hard to gauge, but it's always nice to know a time estimate. A seating tactic that my friend and I found out when we got to Zazie is that outside seating is first come first serve, so if you're lucky enough to snag a spot outside after a party has left, you will be served even if you haven't put your name down on the waitlist or if you haven't been called yet. We didn't know this, and after an hour of waiting, we snagged a seat outside. I ordered the Fontainbleau scramble and it was delicious! It's a vegetarian scramble with spinach and mushrooms, and it comes with toast and home fries, which were equally delicious. I especially loved the jam, which comes in a small jar that was on the table, so you can grab as much jam as you want! The service was quick and attentive, considering the constant business the restaurant got. This place is also tip free, so you don't have to tip since it is already covered in the cost of the dishes. Overall, this is a great brunch place, and next time, I'll be more prepared for the wait!
author: Lisa C.

description:
Small restaurant and long wait but very attentive and caring staff!

Took a little under an hour to get seated and another hour for our food to arrive around Sunday at 10am. Due to the long wait, the staff offered complimentary fruit and mimosas which I thought was extremely generous! My party of 3 ordered the French Toast, and two egg benedicts and the Grilled Ahi Tuna Sandwich. The sandwich was amazingly good--tuna melted in my mouth and the tomato was roasted to flavorful perfection. The french toast and benedicts were nothing special.

Would definitely want to go back during a less crowded time to try their other sandwich options if they're anything like the tuna one!
author: Anny H.

description:
I have been here multiple times for brunch and never had a bad experience. For starters, it is busy on the weekends. Be prepared for a wait. Second, the food is amazing and portion size is HUGE! I always make the mistake of ordering too much because everything sounds incredible.

Food:
Creme brûlée oatmeal - oh so decadent and delicious!!! The portion size was massive. Luckily I was pregnant when I ate this and was able to devour almost all of it.
Gingerbread pancakes - loved the lemon curd and pear that comes with it
Buttermilk pancake - delicious; light and fluffy
French toast - again yummy
Spinach Eggs Benedict - Poached egg was cooked perfectly. The lemon in the hollandaise was a very nice touch
Side potatoes - so crispy and it had some roasted garlic mixed in...yum yum

Service:
ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! Everyone there has been soo wonderful each time I've dined there but this last time was the best. We had 2 strollers and 3 infants in car seats and they helped us get situated with all the babies at the table, carrying them in and out of the restaurant, and helped us carry out the strollers too. The servers dropped what they were doing to help us out. The entire staff is amazing! Thank you soooo much!!!
author: Lisa D.

description: Coffee was excellent without any ads-ins. Gluten free pancakes were hearty and the Irish Oats gave them a nutty texture. Is it a trend now that restaurants add the service into their menu price? That one was new for me. A bit pricey, but service was excellent. $69 for 3 people. 3 coffees and 3 orders of pancakes.
author: Janice K.

description:
Extremely wonderful service and yummy food. Get here early if you want to get seated sooner. 

The Guava Sorbet Mimosas were delicious and fun.
author: Rose F.

description: Food was so tasty in so many ways! Friendly staffs! A delightful experience in general! Will def come back again try more dishes! We ordered muscle, pork chop and the pasta, everything was delicious! Just the portion is quite big for each order. It will be nice if they have half portion choice so customers can try more dishes at once!
author: YI Wen Z.

description:
My cousin, a local, recommended this place for breakfast. She warned us that the wait would be long but worth it, and she was right on both counts. We came on a Saturday morning and waited about 60 minutes (I lost track). It was a nice day so we walked around the block. The waiting list is posted outside so you can check on your status.
It's a little tight inside, but I guess they need to pack in the seats to meet demand. It was still bright and cheery, and as a bonus I got to check out the size of the pancakes at the neighboring table.
They sell pancakes and French toast in orders of 1, 2, 3. My son thought he could eat 3 pancakes easily, but since I had already peeped our neighbor's order, I knew they would be the size of dinner plates and limited him to 2. They were light and fluffy, just as good pancakes should be. I got the special, which was pancakes with lemon curd. OMG so delish! The French toast and omelets were also winners.

Interestingly, this is a tip-free restaurant. I've never seen that before but I'm glad the staff was getting paid a fair wage.

We will be back the next time we visit SF, despite the wait.
author: Evelyn H.

description: You got me Zazie...I have left my heart in San Francisco!  Mainly because I'll not likely return for quite some time but if I could you'd be my first stop for breakfast!!!  The cappuccino was a delicious start. It always good to see a breakfast place with great coffee!  Then the ambiance was what hit us. Such a cool vibe outside in back. Even sitting so close to folks wasn't a bother.  The ethos was so enjoyable that we didn't mind waiting for our food.  When it did arrive though...be still my heart!  The Benedict was over the top!  Fresh avocado, bacon, and the creamiest hollandaise on PERFECTLY, and I do mean perfectly, cooked poached eggs. The. The banana/walnut French toast???  Why did we order so much food???  But it too was delicious.  The banana purée in between with the walnuts mixed in was a perfect filling.  We nearly didn't even need to use the syrup!  But...not wanting to be rude...we did anyway!!!  Even the syrup was off the chain!  Give me my heart back Zazie!!!
author: Timothy D.

description: We got in right away, even with a looooong wait list.. (having a party of 2 while everyone had 4+ helped). The service was great. I got buttermilk pancakes, scrambled eggs and bacon. The pancakes were different, had an interesting after taste. The scrambled eggs were still a bit runny for my taste. Bacon was delicious. My husband had the Mexican scramble and enjoyed it. The mango juice was delicious as well. All in all I doubt we would return.
author: Kathryn S.

description:
Food was good while it lasted...

FOOD POISONING 

Immediately after my meal I ran to the bathroom in cold sweat to projectile vomit...

It was my first meal of the day as well...

So sad
author: Anna I.

description:
Brunched here on July 27, 2017.  Really good coffee.  I ordered the scrambled eggs "Cannes" style - was ok, not great. But, one of my friend's at the table ordered the "La Mer" eggs bene (with lumps of sumptuous Dungeness crab) and that was eggs-cell-ent. Make sure your entire party is present or they won't seat you, but the man coordinating the wait list was very efficient.  We arrived about 11:05 and the place was already full.  They were going to seat us, but wouldn't as we were still waiting for a friend.  There were three of us.  All in all, not much of a wait if you get there early.  We had a very nice waitress who checked in on us about three times.  We didn't feel rushed but certainly, we felt lucky to be eating while a line formed outside. :)

As for large groups: If you were four, you're ok, but larger groups can be tricky.  They could seat you in the back patio for maybe a party of 6, but be prepared for a wait.
author: Kathy N.

description: Rude staff and average food. This place is completely overrated. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY! I can't stress this enough. I live in the area and have never had a good experience at this place. So rude and so not worth it.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Zazie - 5 Stars: this was a neat find in San Francisco...very good breakfasts. Located in a simple storefront, there seems to always be a line outside. They do a nice job of moving the traffic through though without making one feel rushed. We were seated within ten minutes at the height of morning rush. The interior is an open kitchen and the tables are arranged along an exposed brick wall. A bit tight seating, but a nice room. There are also a couple of tables outside for al fresco dining. This is a 20% tip place...they have a 20% tip built into the prices so no tipping is required; they do this to provide a better life for their staff...neat idea.

One in our party had the special French toast (4 stars and very good with the topping); another had the Un, Deux, Trois (pancake, eggs, and bacon...4 stars...the pancake stood out as very nice with a touch of malt in it); another had eggs Fontainbleau (5 stars...with mushrooms, spinach, and fontina cheese); the last in our party made their own breakfast up...choosing eggs, fries, and toast (4 star stuff...nice fries for a morning meal). Service was spot on and very attentive (5 stars).
author: Rick B.

description:
It took almost 40 minutes to bring out an order of two pancakes and an eggs Benedict plate, but at least it was very tasty. This review is mainly for the service. I come from the restaurant business and understand how important service to a restaurant's success. I'm hoping that the owner will take my review in consideration that including gratuity in the food prices is a bad idea. What leads to this is lazy, inattentive servers in which all they care about is how much you order. At least our server was like this. 

We were a party of five from out-of-town that included my two daughters ages 2 and 5, my wife, my mother-in-law, and myself. My mother-in-law was not eating and my girls can barely finish one pancake between the two of them. So basically I only ordered two plates. Our waiter was beside himself for what we had ordered. He said, "That's it!? For a party of five, that's not very much food." He jotted down our order and shook his head. First off, he shouldn't worry about how much we order. It's none of his business. His attitude goes to show that he only cares about the quantity of food he puts down on his ticket. Most likely because it reflects his tips. He made us feel uncomfortable for taking up five seats and only ordering two plates. He never came to our table to ask how everything was. We felt like we were being rushed to finish so they can seat the next group. 

Zazie obviously has its followers with a crowd of people waiting outside to be seated. Their popularity seems like it has given them a free pass to not give good service. Since the servers tip is already included, it really doesn't matter to them whether they perform well or not. It's only a matter of time before it catches up to them.
author: Byron G.

description:
Loved it! My sweetheart and I shared a glorious breakfast here. 
We sat on the back patio, it's covered with plenty of seating and a relaxing, cool vibe. Love the brick walls. 
I had a delicious mimosa with rose and lavender - a must when on vacation. For a meal I had a Stuffed French Toast and a Ricotta Lemon Pancake. Both were spectacular. The French Toast had bananas and walnuts inside - so freaking good! My Lemon Ricotta Pancake was tangy and light. I love that you are able to pick one, two, or three portions. So I was able to try both the Ricotta Pancake and the French Toast. It's perfect for someone like me, o can never settle on just one thing. The sweetie had eggs with pancakes and bacon. Bacon was ON POINT - perfectly crispy. 
What I love the most, the restaurant offers it's employees a living wage and health benefits. That is reflected in the price of the food, no tip needed. This ensures that servers do not have to wonder what kind of $$ they will make for the day. Staff was super friendly, food came fairly fast. Honestly the food was bomb!
author: Natalie K.

description:
This is a lively spot on a pretty busy street. I came here for brunch on a Saturday morning around 11am. By then, it would've been at least a 1.5hr wait. However, my friend brought her dog so we sat outside, not the patio but the seats in front of the restaurant. The tables outside in the front are first come, first served. The staff is friendly, however I felt the service was slow. I felt that we were often forgotten since we were sitting outside. It took forever before someone came to take our order and I had to ask several times for one coffee refill. 

Personally, I hate going out for brunch. I think brunch is overpriced. Who would pay $15 for avocado toast, when you can make that yourself for a few dollars? But I suppose going out for brunch is more for the social aspect. Anyways, let's get back on topic...

The food is on the pricier side, but I think it's because they have a no tipping rule. The food itself was ok. I liked how they put entire garlic cloves in their potatoes. They leave the skin on so they're really crispy. My husband ate them with the skin on, but I prefer peeling them off. Other than that, I've had better. The brunch menu didn't appeal to me much, but the options for dinner looked really good. I think I would try going back for dinner instead.
author: Katherine C.

description: I love Zazie. Great service, AMAZING food. Their pancakes are the best pancakes I've ever had. Try to get there as early as possible. The longest I've had to wait was about an hour. I'm not local, but I think about Zazie often and recommend it to everyone who'll be going through SF.
author: Janene V.

description:
I have been wanting to eat here loooong before Adele made a stop when she was in town. 

THE MIRACLE PANCAKES. THEY ARE FLUFFY MIRACLES, I promise you. Lemon poppy seed miracles. French toast was equally good and if I had to choose between the two, I'd feel like a terrible parent neglecting one child. 

All the eggs Benedicts are good so just go ahead and pick one of those. 

If you're fat on the inside like me, and need a starter for brunch, please get the coffee cake. I think it may be the best coffee cake I've ever had... Which is really saying a lot. 

The wait is brutal, but put your name in for the patio and be patient. It's worth it. I went with my unofficial brunch club so we were able to order lots of dishes and share. Highly recommend.
author: Steph D.

description: great neighborhood.  Service is okay. Meal for a burger and coke came out to about 30 dollars.
author: Steven T.

description:
I can now speak to dinner at Zazie and am enthusiastically giving it 5 stars! How amazing is it to find a place that consistently serves amazing food for brunch and dinner?!

The vibe for dinner is completely different than the craziness of brunch. It becomes an intimate french bistro with an impressive wine list. I came here for a group dinner so got to experience a lot of the menu. The highlights for me was the chicken liver pate on a crustini, hanger steak with portobello cream sauce, and the trout with butter, lemon and almonds. Everything was cooked perfectly, full of flavor, and paired well with the wine our waiter recommended. 

Additionally, the desserts were out of control. You can't leave without ordering the baked hot chocolate with toasted marshmallows. It's unlike anything I've ever had before. It's honestly indescribable so just go get it. The fruit crisp was also amazing. 

On top of everything I've already said about how amazing brunch and dinner is, on Mondays you can bring your dog and have dinner on the patio, and Tuesdays there's no corkage fee. So why wouldn't you come for dinner???
author: Sophie S.

description:
This place is great for brunch! It's in a cute little neighborhood, has a great brunch menu, and is housed in a bright, sunny, adorable little restaurant. 

Make sure that you get there early if you don't want to wait for a long time, because they're very popular and can get really busy on weekends. 

Highly recommend (pretty much everything on the menu) but I really enjoy their croque madame. Amazing.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: Very cute space, fast service, and good value. The egg benedicts are worth trying. The hollandaise sauce was very tasty and the home fries were perfect. Not quite 5 stars as the dish wasn't fully warm, and the cheese and avocado portions were very small.
author: Hector S.

description:
If you have time and cash to burn this is pretty darn close to as good as it gets.  We spent $80 on breakfast for two, with one alcoholic beverage.  We loved the food.  Service was wonderful.  Ten points for the vibe.  We went on a weekday, and were seated on the patio, under a heat lamp, right away.  

I didn't think the coffee cake was all that, and I couldn't actually taste the basil in my mimosa, but I will be back again, because, mostly...vibe and staff.

It can get pretty loud, but in a good way.  Great place to get together with friends/family - super comfortable.
author: Kris L.

description: What a great find! This cute cafe had AWESOME food and was our first stop in San Francisco as we arrived in town at 8 am. We had the pancakes and eggs fountainbleau. Both delicious! It gets busy fast but we walked in as soon as they opened. Highly recommend ! It's on the "brunch district".
author: Nichole U.

description: Got a table pretty fast Food was Delicious , waiter rushing too much not enough attention but Maybe next time I get a better service..
author: Valeria M.

description: Was checking out the dinner menu outside with my husband when a woman sitting there told us the place was incredible and that she came at least once a week.  With a recommendation like that we couldn't resist and the lady was spot on.  The meal, wine, and authentic bistro ambiance were all fabulous.  Can't wait to come again and try some other dishes as  the hardest part was choosing from their pretty extensive menu.
author: Sean M.

description:
What a fantastic place in an even more fantastic part of San Fran! After reading previous reviews about this gem as well as the comments about the area, this was a must try! Oh, and here is the best part... No tipping! Their policy is that they pay their servers well, as well as offer them a ton of benefits other restaurants don't provide. Ya gotta love a joint that treats their people well!

My chick friend and I went for brunch on a Friday. Don't be scared by the wait, it goes by very quickly. Make sure to writ your name on the sheet provided by the door. The outside tables are first come first serve.

After about a 10 minute wait we were seated inside. This lovely little place is jammed pack with all things great! I ordered their signature Bloody Mary, but my friend had several questions about the ingredients due to her being a vegetarian. What I absolutely loved is that the bartender came over and answered all of them very knowledgeably.

I ordered the  poached eggs Pierre Noir. This was fantastic!!! The eggs were cooked perfectly as well was the bacon. Honestly the entire menu looked awesome!

I can't wait for my next trip back to San Fran! Zazie's is definitely on the menu!
author: Kellie M.

description:
Brunch is my favorite meal. I don't care how "basic" that makes me. There's just something satisfying about sleeping in, rolling out of bed and into my yoga pants, and out for a bloody and some eggs. Who needs three meals a day? 

San Francisco, unlike my little East Coast Portlandtown, gets that people want brunch all day erryday. And the line on a Friday morning at 1030ish here at Zazie's proved that. It's a small space, so before entering you write your own name on a clipboard hanging on the window (taking Candice G's advice, I wrote S T E F F in the nicest, most legible penmanship of my life). Check if you want inside or outside, if your whole party is there, and then stand back and wait. Don't worry, though, the wait here is not that long: they really do move people in and out. 

What tipped me over to the five star over the four star was the staff/the policies. Number one: tipping isn't necessary because the employees are paid living wages and revenue shares (and amazing benefit packages). That's amazing. You can tell they're happy and dedicated. Number two: I wanted a bloody. I asked if it was made with worcestershire (since most worcestershire contains fish, and that's no bueno to this vegetarian). They regretfully let me know that they did make theirs with it. About fifteen minutes later a manager came up to our table to tell me that he had no idea that fish was in most worcestershire, thanked me for letting him know, then proceeded to go through all of their sauces/condiments to see what was veg-safe. The worcestershire they use is fish free, and out came a beautiful drink to my table. Bravo, folks, for caring that much! 

The food itself was good, though I thought the portions were a bit small. I got the Eggs Vincent (grilled corn cake with spinach, spicy tomato-goat cheese sauce, avocado, and two over easy eggs with a side of home fries). Everything was cooked to perfection, flavorful (there could have been more goat cheese, but I'm a freak for the stuff), and I loved the big cloves of garlic in my potatoes. It was filling, but not overtly so, meaning instead of a nap afterwards, I wanted to walk (and walk I did - who wouldn't want to in such a charming neighborhood).

Yum.
author: Steff D.

description:
Main reason I came to Zazie is I was looking for a place that offered Brunch options during the week.  Upon reading the menu online I saw that Zazie is tip free as their "menu prices include a living wage, revenue share, paid family leave, fully funded health & dental insurance, paid time off, and a 401(k) with employer match for all of our hard working employees."  To me that is huge, especially in this day and age.

It was packed on a rainy Thursday at noon, but my group of 3 only waited about 30 mins.  We had a very comfortable seat and did not feel crammed in like sardines.  Table, however, was small for the amount of food we ordered.  I like that you can order 1, 2, or 3 benedicts, pancakes, french toast, etc.  I highly recommend the miracle pancakes.  I got to get my fat girl on with bread pudding pancakes, which were life changing.  The divorce benedict was good, but I've honestly had better.  And my husband really enjoyed his Croque Monsieur, which was huge.  Our waitress was also lovely.  We definitely were those a-holes that sat for awhile after our meal chatting and none of the employees made us feel that we had to get up and leave.  Would definitely come back here next time I'm in the Bay.

I'm pretty sure they have a private room in the back that can accommodate a group (we saw a wedding reception of approximately 20 people).  Not to sure on those details though.
author: Justine D.

description:
This was an incredible brunch! 

The food was slightly on the pricey stuff, but that's how SF brunches are. The benedicts are absolutely scrumptious, and the pancakes are wonderfully fluffy with fresh seasonal fruits on it. 

Wait was a little long at the door and wait was long to be served, but it was worth it!!
author: Ellie H.

description: Came here after a friend suggested going to this place for brunch. Even for a weekday, I was surprised that there was a wait which only makes me wonder how weekends must be here. That being said, may you be warned about that in advance. Came & ordered 3 different dishes: the French Toast Tahiti, St. Trop's Eggs Benedict, and Eggs Vincent. Have to say that I was indeed quite impressed with all 3 dishes. For the french toast, the toast was done quite well with great consistency & the caramelized bananas & walnut combination was bomb. The eggs benedict were also done quite well, the salmon used was fresh, and those potatoes though ... love the spices used to season them to taste. The Eggs Vincent ... the combination was a wonderful blend of sweet & savory, ingredients used were fresh, and the veggies helped soothe my conscience. Overall, a most noteworthy brunch place definitely worth visiting!
author: Jack M.

description: This place is super cute and I loved all we had. I split the French toast and Eggs Benedict with my sister, absolutely delicious! The waitress was really nice and the tips were already included in the prices. I highly recommend this place.
author: Simona S.

description:
Get here early.
With that said, the food is pretty great, the portion sizes are well-portioned, the waiters are very kind, and the service is quick. It's easy to over order since a lot of the menu items are appealing. The pancakes are pretty amazing, the seafood dishes are fresh and cooked perfectly, and those potatoes... Don't leave without trying them.
author: Mima G.

description: Great brunch place! It's quite busy, but so far haven't had to wait long. Love coming here with my close friends, even after one of us moved away. Great environment for catching up. Customer service is amazing and overall, clean place. Tried a couple things on their menu already and everything was yummy!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Brunch was great. I love that they take care of their employees with the included price(no tip allowed on cars) for 401k, baby leave, etc. 

The coffee cake was okay, more for ginger lovers. Crab cake Benedict was amazing and pancakes as well. I loved sitting outside with the heaters and we didn't wait at all since we went on a work day during brunch. Definitely recommend!
author: Eric T.

description: My two daughters and I ate here. All three meals were amazing. Pancakes, eggs and my fave eggs Benedict divorcé super yum!
author: Liz S.

description:
"Let's get two savory dishes, but let's also get a pancake on the side."
Magic words.  It's a good thing I'm not an extremely impulsive person, or I probably would've proposed to my breakfast-mate at the table.

Zazie is so solid!  Everything has been delicious every time I've been for brunch.  The eggs benedict comes in a variety of options, and they're always perfectly portioned and wonderfully flavorful.  Potatoes are crisped in butter and are the best side for any savory breakfast dish.  Their menu specials change, and it's always exciting to see what new flavors they have to offer.

The only downside is the massive crowd of San Franciscans who also thought that Sunday brunch was a unique and novel idea.  I usually wait about an hour for a table for two, and it's never not been crowded.  If you're waiting with someone who also lives in the city it's usually fine, but I've brought people from out of town and they get HANGRY.  

Tips and Tricks
-There are side orders of pancakes available, I trust you to make the right decision
-Come early!  I've seen a line even on weekdays
-Tips are included in the price on the menu!
-If you're bringing someone who's visiting, be sure to pack a cookie so they don't bite your head off when you tell them the wait time
author: Jessica L.

description: One of my favorite things about living in this neighborhood. Yes, the line is always long for brunch. Does it go relatively fast despite the crowds outside? Yes. Is the wait worth it? Absolutely yes! Grab a coffee at Peet's, Wooden or Reverie Cafe while you wait, or wait for your name to be called next door at Finnegans Wake. The food is delicious and the drinks rival the food! Bloody Mary's and mimosas a plenty! No need to tip because they've already factored the cost of "living" and health insurance in for their employees which is AMAZING. I wish more places did that!
author: Sheena C.

description:
It's so refreshing to find a restaurant that subs any meal with a gluten-free option! Personally I am not gluten free but my best friend and roommate is, and it's so sad to see her go out and barely have any options that won't irritate her stomach greatly.

Our brunch here was amazing, as was the incredible  selection of mimosas.
author: Marian L.

description:
I love great service. I live for great service. I reward great service with recommendations to my family and friends along with personal repeat visits. 

Zazie is a neighborhood gem worthy of the praise they receive.

I made a reservation via Open Table and they reserved the cute window alcove table for my group. The day I was there was bring your doggie to dinner on the heated patio in the back. I just love humans who are good to their doggies! 

The wine list offered great old world offerings, the strawberry salad was everything I could want from a summer salad, the corn cakes weren't what I thought I ordered but my daughter loved it so there's that. My daughters fiancée enjoyed the burger with bacon and cheese. 

I enjoyed a night out. A lovely healthy delicious dinner with wine. 

I enjoyed having someone else cook for me and do the dishes. 

I wasn't left to want for anything and for the time I was there? I was relaxed. 

Thank you for giving this tired mom a nice fuss free dinner in her beloved hometown. 

I recommend and I will gladly return!
author: Jennifer C P.

description:
Wow! One of my favorite restaurants in the city, thus far. My father, aunt, uncle, cousin, and I came here for dinner last night around 7pm. We made a reservation in advance (seems like that is a must) and they were extremely accommodating and flexible with making the plans! Our table was ready for us when we arrived and the service was excellent! We all ordered different things, and nobody had one bad thing to say about their food. It was all SO good! My cousin was daring and tried the Rabbit Pasta. I had a bite and it was so delicious! I opted for the steak, which was incredible and hit the spot. My cousin and I shared a mimosa and the Mac and Cheese. We had the Peach Sorbet mimosa was so unique and amazing! Their Mac and Cheese was also extremely good. Our server, who was Polynesian as we learned, was super amazing and put up with all of our bad jokes :)

I seriously recommend this place. It looks like they have an amazing brunch as well, so we will have to try that ASAP!
author: Zoe Y.

description: Awesome brunch food in a fun neighborhood. Wait wasn't to long even on a Saturday. Worth it! Excellent salmon eggs Benedict and  French toast
author: Manena H.

description:
Food: EVERYTHING on this menu is gold! AAAALLLLL the Benedict's are mouthwatering! the ingredients here are insanely fresh, and uh! the mimosas!!!! all juices are freshly squeezed. The coffee mugs are the size of a baby's head no joke.

Space: the back patio is very charming, with a secret garden feel. The inside has a mom and pop, cozy whole in the wall vibe. 

Service: fast and wonderful!

Prices: pricey but worth spoiling yourself with!
author: Brittney G.

description: Came here for a Friday lunch on a rainy day. Had a fairly short wait, about 20 minutes or so at around 12:30pm. Got a corner seat for two, and the waiter came around with the waters and specials for the day. I decided to try one, the eggs en fonte: 2 eggs over easy, with mushroom, spinach and spicy cream sauce over polenta + breakfast potatoes on side. The bf went with the classic French toast with fruit. Loved my dish, but thought that the French toast definitely needed syrup or jam on it (which is provided). Add an order of coffee with cream for me and the total came to $40, with no tips accepted. You' re one of our favorites Zazie.
author: Ally B.

description: 4.5 stars. Excellent brunch. Nice servers, a menu with lots of variety, and cooked excellent. Great pancakes. Great scrambles. Great potatoes. Mmmmm!!! I would come here again and again, but at off times because the wait for brunch is insaaaaane.
author: Jen B.

description:
This place is known for their brunch but I suggest you go for dinner! We moved into the neighborhood a few months ago and have not had the chance to make it here until now.

The ambiance is great and the service is excellent. Our waitress, Megan was so welcoming and friendly. She made great suggestions for our dinner choices. We had the appetizer trio which is a great way to try several times without large portions. The mussels were served in a rich cream sauce- super tasty! We chose to split the mushroom truffle ravioli as well- a nice portion size and the sauce was so good.

We sat in the backyard which is an awesome setting with gorgeous flowers.

One of the things I am most impressed with this place is that they do not expect tips. They have a note at the top of the menu that states that all of their employees receive benefits including Health insurance, 401(k) matching and both maternity and paternity leave.

All in all, we were very happy with our experience here and will definitely be back for brunch!
author: Sara D.

description:
I have eaten here many times in the past before, and I have only ordered the Benedict's. This time around, I was craving French toast so I decided to give it a go. I haven't eaten here in awhile so I was excited to have brunch here. I will honestly have to say, I've had way better French toast. It just wasn't that great... There was nothing about it that made it special. For $17, I expected way more. It looks good, but it tastes meh...I haven't had their Benedict's in awhile, but from what I remember, It was definitely more satisfying. I also ordered their pumpkin latte special. It was pretty good. I added some sugar to it which made it better. I like my lattes a little sweet. My friend had ordered off their special menu as well. Everything we ordered was sweet besides the potatoes. The pancake was meh too. Kind of a bummer. I feel like their savory food is better than the sweet. 
Service was good. I came on a weekday so it wasn't crazy busy at all. We got seated immediately. 

Parking was easy to find on a weekday. Weekends; however, is another story. 

I Ordered:
Sugar pie pumpkin latte: $6.50
French toast Tahiti: $17
author: Lucy L.

description: I think this place is way overrated.  I had the pancake special and the french toast.  Overpriced and nothing special.  Go somewhere else.
author: Beth K.

description:
If you happen to be in the Cole Valley neighborhood of San Francisco and are in need of an above average brunch spot, look no further because "Zazie" just might be what you're looking for. I've had this place on my radar for a very long time; not just because of the thousands (yes I said thousands) of Yelp reviews but because I've heard some very good things about their food.

Located directly on Cole St. (adjacent to Carl St.), "Zazie" has been serving quality food ever since they opened their doors back in 1992. What makes this restaurant uniquely special is that the owner takes great care of his staff and employees by providing them with full insurance, sick pay, vacation, and 401K. Additionally, they are a "no tips required" restaurant meaning every single menu item is paid out directly to the staff as revenue share. If only more places can adopt this concept, there will be many, many more happy employees!

I came here with my lovely lady on a Sunday morning around 10:45am. As I wrote my name on the waiting list, there were at least 15 names above mine. Luckily, we were able to walk to a nearby Peet's Coffee (which is only about 50 feet away) to grab our cup of Joe while we waited. I was expecting at least an hour wait; fortunately they called my name in only 35 short minutes! But when dining here, you should definitely expect to wait awhile; especially on busy weekend mornings.

Once we were seated, I noticed that the interior is relatively small (hence the reason for the long wait). However, there are a few tables in the front as well as an impressive back patio (that I only briefly saw) that can seat many parties. Some of the neat features of "Zazie" are its spiral staircase near the front, brick walls to give it a classic rustic feel, and a lot of French artwork throughout.

Within just a few minutes, our waiter takes our orders. My beverage of choice was their "Zazie Spritzer" (cranberry juice, orange juice, and Perrier water) while she opted for a freshly squeezed "Odwalla orange juice" (both priced at $3.25). My meal of choice consisted of their "Monaco Poached Egg" dish (priced at $15.00). This consisted of prosciutto and tomatoes provençales complete with Hollandaise sauce on an English muffin and a side of home fries. Her meal was a basic one egg breakfast complete with white toast and home fries (priced at $9.00).

As busy as it was, the staff were working very quickly to get everyone's dishes out in a timely manner. Our meals came out in about 20 minutes which was a respectable time considering how busy it was. As far as the presentation, my meal looked on point. It was a bit on the small side (hence the reason for deducting one star) but considering that the tip is included, I don't want to be too critical of the portion size. As far as the flavor, I loved the consistency of the prosciutto while the eggs were cooked to perfection. It wasn't the best I've ever had but definitely on the higher end of the spectrum. She also loved her meal as the garlic added a nice zest to her home fries.

I do have to say, as a first-time at "Zazie's", I was quite satisfied with my brunch. The menu is quite extensive as they offer several traditional breakfast options as well as a few unique items with that French twist. And if breakfast just isn't your thing, their dinner menu offers many eclectic entrees and desserts. I do know with the regulars and locals that frequent this place, I don't see this place going away anytime soon. So definitely check them out; the wait is well worth it!
author: Donovan H.

description: Love this restaurant!  Super food and super people.  I love Monday nights where you can bring your dog and sit on the heated outdoor patio.  They try really hard to make your visit special. This is my go to restaurant!
author: Sarah J.

description:
I was visiting a friend in Daly City and we decided to have our last meal here. We came on a Sunday for brunch which was definitely a mistake since going to brunch on a Sunday in an upscale San Francisco neighborhood seems to be an idea that a ton of people have. We ended up waiting outside for about an hour and a half until our names were finally called. 

The food was pretty good. I ordered 3 eggs Benedict with fontina cheese and bacon with a side of their home fries. It was really tasty but a little overpriced for what it was in my opinion (I paid about $25). I also had a sip of my friend's mocha (which they serve in bowls rather than cups oddly enough), and it was delicious. 

We sat in a semi-open area in the back which had a very chill vibe perfect for brunch. It got a bit crowded but there were a ton of people trying to eat and the restaurant was doing their best to seat everyone. The service was great. The waitress we had was super friendly and more than willing to help me make a good choice on the menu. Something cool about this place is that they actually recommend not tipping their employees. They list a bunch of benefits that their employees enjoy on their menu. Its always great to support a business that truly takes care of their workers. 

I had a good time here and the food was yummy, but if I ever come back I will definitely avoid the brunch rush because it wasn't really worth the hour and a half wait.
author: Miguel H.

description:
Definitely a cute place if you're looking for a cute picturesque photo spot. Back garden area is pretty with all the lights and grapes of different colors hanging down contrasting from the green vines. 

Food however, is pretty standard as to most brunch places. The selection for benedicts here is a bit larger as they have many different options, but I was surprised the classic benedict was not on the menu as I tend to like more meat. 

The food took a very long time to come out, probably around 30 to 40 minutes honestly. Really not sure what took so long. Professional restaurants should have food out around the 15 minute mark. 

I decided to order the omelet and had no problems generally, however adding more chicken sausage would have been a major plus. After the meal, I was only about 60% full, so that was a bit disappointing. 

If you want to visit the world's smallest restroom, be sure to hit this place up. Difficult to even turn around without hitting the sink. 

Overall, a solid brunch spot.
author: Scott K.

description:
Zazie is probably my favorite brunch place in town! The only complaints I have is the long wait. Often times, you have to wait for an hour or so on weekends. The tables outside are first-come-first-serve. So if you're lucky, you could be sitting down and eating in no time. Alternatively, you can also wait in the bar next door getting some drinks in first.

I love getting eggs Benedict and french toast at Zazie. They just taste so darn good!! I'm also in love with their drinks menu, both the alcoholic and non-alcoholic options. You can make your perfect lemonade here if you like :P I usually end up spending around $25-30 here with food and drinks, which is a bit expensive, but I think the it totally deserves it!

Zazie also opens for dinner though I have never tried it. I'm curious whether or not dinner will be as good as their brunch selections :)
author: Angel C.

description:
Went to Zazie this morning with my parents for brunch. We arrived at 8:30 and waited in line for 20 minutes to add our names to the waitlist. We were seated right after 9am when they open.

I always love the patio space with their outdoor tables and heat lamps. It was a cozy fall vibe. We ordered coffee cake, the Divorcee (eggs Benedict with bacon and cheese) and the omelet special with tomatoes and chicken sausage. The food is really where things were bad. The omelet was cold in the middle and SO heavy on the garlic. The eggs Benedict was warm but I wouldn't call it hot. It had a tiny amount of avocado and for $20 it's ridiculous even for SF. Service was fine but I really can't get over the logistics and the wait for barely mediocre food.
author: Emily L.

description: I love this place! Everything is amazing here. Great customer service. The brunch is one of the best in SF. The ambience is so nice.
author: Daniella B.

description: Came here on a weekday and was seated right away. However, after 15 minutes of waiting, no one came to our table. While there's no tipping, the prices were laughable. $21 for 3 plain buttermilk pancakes?!? There's no excuse for $21 pancakes unless they were perhaps topped with barrel-aged maple syrup and foie gras. I'd also say the poor service is what you get when you don't have to work for tips. By the way, after 15 minutes of waiting, we walked out. This is absolutely the SF version of Nello (if Nello was a breakfast place).
author: Daniel F.

description:
Zazie is a French-inspired restaurant located in the heart of Hayes Valley. This is a super popular brunch place in the city, reinforced by the long wait list when we came on a Sunday morning. After about two hours, we were finally seated and ordered a few dishes (which themselves took a while to arrive). I got the Eggs Maya from the special menu, which were eggs benedict on top of achiote pork, salsa, and avocado on an English muffin. The egg was perfectly poached and topped with a lemon hollandaise sauce, which was delicious; the egg yolk ran out perfectly when cut in half and enveloped the pork-salsa-avocado mixture in rich, creamy goodness. While this dish was decent, the pork was actually slightly cold (perhaps it had been sitting out for too long), and I wouldn't say that the flavors were overwhelming good or particularly special.

I also got to try the gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and poached pear, which I found to be very aromatic and definitely not overly sweet. My favorite part of this dish was the poached pear, which was tender and fruity, along with the lemon curd; while the gingerbread pancake was good, I'm sure I've had better. We also had the miracle pancake (a "bread pudding" pancake) served with caramelized banana. This pancake was unlike any other I've had--the texture was incredibly chewy and dense--very unique for a pancake!

It's also worth mentioning that Zazie doesn't expect customers to leave tips, as they pay their workers a living wage--this was certainly a plus, and we noted that the service was just as friendly as any other restaurant that does accept tips (though a little bit slow at times). Overall, this was a decent brunch restaurant, but I wouldn't say that it was necessarily worth the wait or the price. However, I would definitely be interested in visiting for dinner and checking out some of their other dishes there.
author: David K.

description: Sat us right away on a Monday at about 11:30. Weird first impression when one of their servers snapped at us to wait by the front when we'd never been there before and had no idea where we were supposed to wait to be greeted and seated (there was no sign and no one standing there.) But we witnessed the same server treat another group poorly too - we'll give him the benefit of the doubt and say he was having a bad day, because this place was great. Really full menu, excellent cappuccino, and our food came out pretty fast. Ask to be seated on the back deck if it's a nice day. It's covered and really pretty out there. So glad we didn't turn around and leave after the initial not-so-warm welcome.
author: Kaylee C.

description:
This place was amazing.  Cute little French restaurant,. We sat out in covered patio. For starters we had assiste de formagio ; cheese with fig and walnuts. A must, one of the cheese melts like butter but all 3 cheeses  are delish, notably different.  For my main entree , I tried their duck , wow!, it was delicious; #somethingnew #onpoint . It was delicious. Hands down, this place is one of my favorites. I gotta go back & try their entire menu, & word is that they switch up menu. 

I should give them 5 stars. Maybe after my second visit.
author: Michael F.

description:
Came here for girl's day brunch on a late Saturday morning and was not disappointed in the least! 
While there was a bit of a wait (40min roughly but we did get there close to 11:30) it was definitely worth it! 
We got to sit in the outside small patio area which was very cute. It's a little snug out there with the other customers but not too terrible. 
We started off with different mimosas: one with hibiscus and rose, one with just cranberry, and the last one was elderflower. While they were all very good the elderflower didn't really taste like anything besides champagne and the hibiscus and rose one only tasted like hibiscus but considering how soft a taste rose is I'm not complaining. 
Our food was definitely delicious; I had the Greek scrambled eggs with a side of salad, and one of the other girls had the Divorcee eggs Benedict with a side of the potatoes. 
We will definitely be back again in the future!
author: Tatiana S.

description:
Small cute space. Good vibe and friendly workers. 
The food is average. The flavor is there but I had a few burnt potatoes in my home fries, and they didn't actually toast my toast, while burning the edges of my friends toast. 
I went mid morning on a Monday and was lucky to find a place to seat a group of 5. Most of the tables are set up for two. 
The bathroom is extremely small and awkward, as the door does not close shut, it is just a barn style door and you can hear the workers talking right outside. 
I ordered the Greece scramble and was pleased with the flavor as well as the amount of spinach onion and feta in the eggs. 
It's a cute little place with good food, I would suggest it if you are near by looking for brunch but it doesn't hit the "must have" list for me.
author: Becca B.

description: So I've been hearing the raves from friends for ages and we finally made it here. Not even slightly disappointed and that's even with an hour wait for a table. It's totally worth it. The service is warm and friendly, the menu options are large and the food is awesome! We had the trout special with new potatoes and a side salad (brunch of course) and I had the miracle pancakes. Today's version was lemon ricotta cheese with lemon curd and raspberry sauce. Both were incredible. Clearly we need to come back for dinner but this may be as good a brunch joint as there is anywhere. Cole Valley is adorable too.
author: Jim M.

description:
Thank you, Zazie, for setting the bar for brunch food. They serve some of the most mouthwatering brunch dishes I've had yet. My boyfriend and I decided to start off our SF date here, ordering:
- Monaco poached eggs (prosciutto and tomatoes) 
- St. Trop poached eggs (smoked salmon, capers, red onions) - bursting with flavor!
- French Toast Tahiti - moist and fluffy french toast with warm caramelized bananas = YES. I'm not that big a fan of intensely sweet foods but wow, this blew my mind. It's something you've got to try to understand.

Service was unfortunately lacking so I subtracted a star from my review. They were understaffed that day and we found ourselves waiting a bunch to get our waiter's attention both to order food in the beginning and to get the check at the end. Hopefully they'll be better staffed next time!
author: Lisa C.

description: One of the best brunches in SF, and even though just in Cole Valley there seems to be very few Haight tourists make it here... I had the omelette special and it was excellent, fresh ingredients with veg that actually crunched! Staff were excellent and it is one of the growing Bay Area restaurants that the service is included... coffee only average! But then you are here for the food... would love to try for dinner next...
author: Reg B.

description: Yum, great place for breakfast, but usually a very long wait.
author: Laura D.

description: Breakfast lovers; do yourself a favor.  Walk on over to this cozy nook and order a piece of breakfast heaven.  Providing an amazing menu with amazing bites is one thing, but when you incorporate a bar with specialty drinks?  Fun days at its finest.  Not just for Sundays.  Seriously.
author: Mervin Nāea C.

description:
ONE OF THE BEST BRUNCH RESTAURANT IN SF!

My first time here and definitely worth waiting 1 hour!

Service and Food was onpoint! Staffs were super chill and friendly. They made sure you are comfy sitting and  if you had any questions about the menu they'd be more than happy to show you/explain to you. 

I ordered:

Pumpkin Spice Latte- super super delicious with lots of pumpkin flavor... definitely better than starbucks!

Miracle Pancake- MUST TRY! Have a hint taste of lemon with poppy seed. Not your ordinary pancakes!

Lobsters Benedict - lobster was super fresh and very tasty. The hollandaise sauce was not too thick or creamy. It was perfect. 

Definitely coming back to try the french toast and more pumpkin spice latte!
author: Cyndi L.

description:
Solid breakfast but nothing too special. The best part of the meal was the lovely woman who helped us with our time there. The outside areas were perfect on a sunny day. The pancakes were cooked well and tasted good - same with the french toast. The gingerbread pancake was the highlight of the meal with its tart lemon curd on top. 

Good place for brunch if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Jacob M.

description: This place is so authentically French, that even the water glasses are from France. The eggs en fonte was a good choice. Super nice people and the ambiance is great- it's small but def worth it. Next time I'm back in SF I'm coming back
author: Iliya P.

description: Rude staff!! Waited 45 mins to get a table, walked across the street for 5 mins and apparently they called our name. After coming back the staff told us if we weren't present we get crossed off. He told us it doesn't matter how long we waited and if we wanted to get back on the list it would be another 30 min wait. The guy was very rude and didn't care about customer service at all, will never go back.
author: Chris C.

description:
Lose the host, and your rating would go up!  He is a grumpy man.

The food was still worth the horrible start.  Enjoyed the ambiance and the home fries with whole garlic cloves.  The bottle of Champaign with peach sorbet was a huge hit, and the perfect way to start a Saturday!

Plan to spend some time waiting to get in on a weekend (unless you know the host, who will walk you right past the people waiting for hours, straight to a table).  

Ask for a table on the beautiful patio outside.
author: Chad D.

description:
I'd like to say I'm a bit of a croque madame/monsieur connoisseur, and this one is at the top of my list for sure. 

Everything is so fresh, the sunny side up eggs are cooked perfectly, the bread has the right ratio of crunchy to soft. I ordered them with home fries on the side because my eyes are bigger than my stomach, and that was a lot of food. But I ate it anyway because everything was so delicious!!!

Okay onto the actual restaurant... get there early. I mean like 9am early. Otherwise you could be waiting over an hour for a table (no reservations for small parties, sorry kiddies). 

Once inside you'll notice that the place is pretty small (also helps with the long wait) but they do have seating outside in the front which is first come first served, and seating in the back patio. 

Great service, great food, worth the wait.
author: Phoenix Simone W.

description: Banging breakfast in hippie town!! Beautiful setup. Highly recommend this for a Saturday brunch spot before hitting the park! Restaurant seats very quickly so don't let a wait startle you.
author: B And MJ ..

description: Worth the wait!!!! The French toast is literally to-die-for. I highly suggest the scoop of ice cream added to your mimosa. Game changer right there. Be adventurous when you eat there.. go for the wild French toast options, you will not be disappointed and don't skip the mimosas!! Service was excellent.
author: Nikki P.

description:
My quest to find unique french toast and pancakes. 

- French Toast Tahiti. CHECK!
- Gingerbread Pancakes. CHECK!
- Challah French Toast. CHECK!

My feeling towards those sweet serving was somewhat underwhelmed. The first time I had Zazie was decent. This time I had it again and was not impressed with their popular items. Even the savory omelette wasn't pleasing. 

I think I prefer Kitchen Story mascarpone stuffed deep-fried French toast or Betty's Diner soufflé pancakes much better. 

The service was still friendly and helpful. Overall, a decent breakfast joint if you don't mind the wait.
author: Owie N.
Pauline P.

description: Cute little brunch place in the Cole Valley.  I highly recommend coming here when they first open, otherwise, you'll be waiting for a loooong time for a table and food.  I like the no-tip concept and the portions are decent for the price you pay.  And yes, it's nice that you present all the food at once for the entire table, but its upsetting to know that other tables will receive their food first after being seated after us.  After being seated and our orders were promptly taken, it took about 30-45 minutes for our courses to show up.  It'll be a while until I return....if I ever return.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Enjoyed a delicious scramble (Cannes) with fresh fruit (extra $2). They have quite a brunch menu along with a mimosa/drink menu. 

The service was spot on: so friendly and welcoming. That really made the experience even better. Plus, they don't take tips. So the fact that you get great service is even more impressive. 

There is a good deal of seating. We came for brunch on a really cold day, but sitting on the patio with ample heat lamps was so enjoyable. 

Btw, we arrived at 10 on a weekday and there was plenty of seating. But when we left at 11:30, they were PACKED with a huge line waiting out front. So earlier is definitely better!
author: Susan G.

description:
We came here on a Tuesday and there was no wait so we decided to give it a try.  Even though everything was pretty decent, I have mixed feelings about this place.

I asked the waiter what he'd recommend and he didn't really have much to say, so I asked how's the un, deux, trois? He said good, so I went with it.  I didn't realize there was different types of un, deux, trois nor he explained he just got me the buttermilk pancakes, bacon and poached eggs (he did ask how I wanted my eggs cooked). It seems that the miracle pancakes are the things to get, if only I'd have known (grrrr). My fiance got a special of the day which had eggs and a mushroom base sauce. She loved her dish, as for me it was alright.  The pancake was good, however, when I saw miracle pancakes sly by me to the table next to me my brain went on overload. The un,deux,trois was nothing to brag about, if I could go back  I'd get a pancake stack.

Even though prices were a bit high, tip is included in those prices.  I will come back for the miracle pancakes.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Came here at 8:40am and there was already a line outside. There's a trick, though. Instead of waiting in line, you sign up on a clipboard that's posted on their window, so the line is pointless. There's a constant line, so you either wait or you arrive before it opens. One great thing about this restaurant is that you don't leave a tip, which is actually surprising, but pretty great. I don't mind tipping, but the fact that they don't expect it is nice. 

I got the eggs benedict with crab and avocado as well as the cream cheese coffee cake. I really liked the eggs benedict because I've never had one with crab before, so I found it pretty unique. I wish it had a little more flavor as I had to add salt, pepper, and Tabasco sauce after my first bite. The crab tasted really fresh and it paired well with the avocado. The cream cheese coffee cake is to die for. It's not too sweet, moist, and packed with great flavor. It has a hint of lemon taste to it and that's what made me fall in love with it. Definitely have to try a bite of the coffee cake even if it means taking the rest home in a box. You won't regret it!
author: Alisa H.

description:
One of the most hyped brunch spots in SF, so of course there was a wait when I came on Sunday around 11. The line moves pretty quickly though and we were seated in under an hour. 

There were lots of decadent choices, and I ended up getting the bread pudding pancakes with caramelized bananas. They were so dense and much more cake like than your average pancake.
