A friend told us you're supposed to wave them down if you have a request but I didn't see this mentioned on the menu or by the server. 

There are much better restaurants along Haight St. and with better food and service. We were impressed with the Pork Store and Parada 22.
author: Ellen Z.

description:
Can I just say how much I love Zazie? Their  "no tips required" business structure combined with great food and service makes this place a top brunch favorite for me.

I came to this popular brunch spot on a weekday and the wait was less than 10 minutes. Of course I should note that I came here an hour before it closed for brunch, hence why the wait was so short. They do have a sign in sheet near the door, but I should warn those who want to brunch on the weekends to be prepared to wait, especially if your party is big!

Zazie offers patio, indoor and outdoor seating. During winter, the store puts up heating lamps on the patio and outdoor seating area. The patio section also offers blankets for those who wish for one! The menu here at Zazie is also unique in that they offer small, medium and large portion sizes for most of their dishes here. The price for most of their food is quite fair (~$11-$20) and keep in mind that you dont have to tip, so consider this place to be WORTH.

I ordered the french toast (2 slices) with fruit for $15 and I was more than happy with my dish. The 2 slices turned out to be 4 thick, half sliced bread toppled with strawberries, cantaloupes and pineapples. I thought the french toast was great. Having the fruit ontop of the warm toast made the fruit all warm. I might suggest having fruit on the side so one does not have to eat "warm" fruit. My friends ordered a sandwich from their lunch menu and the Mexico scrambled eggs. Both looked great and I would love to try more dishes during my next visit!

Will definitely come back here again :)
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Definitely enjoyed the food and ambiance at this cute little spot!  Came here for weekday brunch on a Friday at 11.  We were expecting quite the wait for 4 but got a table in less than 5 minutes.  We sat in the back on the patio and it was just lovely.

I had the eggs fountainbleu and the eggs were creamy and flavorful, the mushrooms perfectly cooked without being mushy, and the flavors wonderfully subtle and delicious.  My friends split  the griddle flight and let me sample, and it was also delicious for folks with a sweet tooth (which I definitely am).

The only reason for a loss of star is the atrocious service.  Even the SFO native at our table was embarrassed at the level of aggressiveness needed to flag down someone - anyone - for anything - drinks, ordering, heck we even had to wait 10 minutes and flag down multiple people just to have our presence acknowledged once we were first seated.  And even then it took another 10 minutes to take drink orders.  I definitely agree with their removal of tips because I think the tipping system is antiquated, unnecessary, and a good way to screw servers, but I really do hope they have another system for reviewing server performance and rewarding them accordingly.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Get here early so that you can get in for the first seating! They won't seat you unless your whole party is there, so don't lie!

Their gingerbread pancakes give me life. That lemon curd, that delicious butter, the poached pear...perfection.

You can also order 1, 2, or 3 of any pancakes or benedicts, so you can pick and choose and sample a bunch of different dishes.
author: Christina S.

description:
Very mediocre food and service. Their clientele are stuffy and pretentious. Their scrambled eggs don't compare to my home made ones 

The only "star" was for their roasted garlic - the only redeeming thing about their restaurant

I do not recommend
author: G M.

description:
Zazie. I've only come for brunch and can attest to the benedicts and pancakes as everyone else has reviewed about. Lines can be expected for weekend brunch.

There's a daily special pancake - if you love pancakes, these are a MUST. When I came today, the special was poppyseed with lemon curd, and I forgot what it was the other time.. but the pancakes are perfectly fluffy, moist and flavorful. Kinda pricey for $9 (1 pc) or $15(?) (2 pcs) but TIPS ARE INCLUDED at this establishment so keep this in mind while ordering too. The pancakes are not HUGE but 2 was enough to satisfy me for breakfast.

I've also had the challah french toast (w/ orange cinnamon batter) - it was a bit on the small side FOR $8 but it was quite special indeed, the orange/cinnamon flavor was subtle but just enough. Nice touch.

I don't know how they do it,  but the HOUSE POTATOES are always perfect. Even the big pieces that aren't browned are really good. Always cooked thoroughly and seasoned well. ANY of the benedicts are really good. Poached eggs and hollandaise sauce always on fleek. I haven't tried any of the scrambles here but I'm sure they're good.

Most of the breakfast items start at about $9 and can go upwards to about $20. Again, this includes tip already - I think it's worth it for the quality.. and if you consider tips to already be included, it doesn't stray too far from most brunch places in the city.
author: Emily C.

description:
This is a very busy French brunch spot in the heart of Cole Valley which is not exactly touristy but filled with plenty of locals and a heartbeat away from Haight Ashbury and Golden Gate Park, so yes plenty of tourists do come! The food is solid and plentiful if nothing necessarily stands out, but then again I've only been once. Among the many fabulous places to enjoy a weekend brunch in the city this is probably in the top 15, and that still says a lot in a competitive market like San Francisco.

Zazie is a comfortable cute little bistro that specializes in brunch and lunch dishes with a French flair. And I personally love French food, mind you that none of us in our party actually got French food to dine on. The drinks are a real delight here. I had the signature refresher called Le Metro which has fortified wine, sparkling lemonade, lavender simple syrup, and champagne. I found it to be a delight that was zingy and not over powerful. My friend had the summer drink special called the Pamplune Spritz which contained rose wine with grapefruit and peach essence topped with champagne. That drink felt way too watered down and quite frankly, didn't have a kick.    

Zazie has become one of many San Francisco establishments that have done away with gratuity for their staff and have increased prices to make sure their staff is paid a decent wage by increasing their dish prices. Now I have never eaten here before, so I don't know if their was a significantly increased prices on their dishes. But the menu also says they have fully funded health and dental insurance, paid sick leave, and a 401K with an employer match for ALL of their employees. Now that says a lot for a small restaurant to do all that for all of their staff!

My friend had a dish on their summer brunch special menu called the "Eggs En Fonte" which was two over easy eggs served on a corn cake with spinach, avocados, tomato-chevre sauce all served on a iron skillet. Not sure what was French about that dish but my friend loved it none the less. I got as usual my signature Eggs Benedict dish this time called La Mer with hand picked dungeness crab, avocados, and green onions with a side of home fries. I liked my dish, it was 24 dollars even for a two egg dish, which was a good deal for the intricately pulled crab pieces. You can tell they use fresh ingredients and that is what matters here!

I like Zazie, if you're in the Cole Valley neighborhood and looking for a bite for brunch or lunch, then it's worth a visit. Not exactly sure if it's worth a drive all the way out to the western part of San Francisco, where parking can be limited. But a small locally owned restaurant with fresh ingredients and a little flair that boasts about treating their employees with dignity gets an extra star in my book.
author: Jason F.

description:
Tuesday brunch-it's a thing! Weekends are too crazy for me most of the time to get out and brunch it up, but many of the places I had bookmarked only offer brunch on weekends! Fortunately Zazie was one of the eateries open for brunch on a weekday. Zazies is a little gem, a shop on the smaller side, located in a cramped (what isn't cramped in SF) street along a hill. A friend and I went at about 12ish and there was a group of people outside waiting and a list full to the next page. Parking here is definitely a struggle, but luckily we snagged the spot right in front. It's cool that they offer the first come first serve seating right in front, in addition to a waitlist hanging on the window. Even though it looked like there were many people ahead of us on the waitlist, it went by really quickly! Our party of two was called over and man, everyone here is so friendly. Definitely one of the friendliest places I've been to! As soon as they see you walking ahead, theres someone holding the door open for you, every single employee you walk by greets you hello and goodbye, all genuinely friendly, warm smiles, and welcoming. Maybe they were lucky and just hired a great group of individuals, or their forward thinking no tip/better pay rule really makes them happier workers (which in that case, every shop should consider implementing this if they can!). 

So we walk through the restaurant to get to the back patio and it's so cramped inside that my cheeks were definitely brushing against every person and table and chair. The outside patio is a tiny bit more spacious than inside, however I still had to move my chair every so often to let the person at the next table go in and out. We ended up ordering the New York scrambled eggs, 1 miracle pancake, and 1 french toast Tahiti. Normally I like to stay benedickin' during brunches (plus poached eggs make for better egg porn), but the cream cheese in the scrambled eggs was a deal breaker for us and we had no regrets. The cream cheese complimented the salmon and the soft scrambled eggs, so it was melt in your mouth goodness. The potatoes came with garlic which I loved, but they could definitely give more potatoes and a little less garlic. The french toast was also amazing! I loved that it was actually not too sweet at all. It was not a sugary sweet, but rather just a sweetness that came from the bananas. The miracle pancakes were a miss for us, however! The miracle pancakes are a special with a weekly flavor-this week is lemon ricotta pancakes with meyer lemon curd. Lemon curd sounded amazing, WHICH IT WAS, but then it also came with a raspberry sauce on it which was overly sweet and took away from the lemony flavors. We double checked the menu and on the ingredients, it didn't even say it would come with raspberry sauce! Because of preference, we just didn't like it, but what if we were allergic to it? It really should say so on the menu in the future so people won't be confused. 

At the end of our meal we left feeling super stuffed and satisfied. Zazie's is definitely on my brunch rotation!
author: Maleah M.

description:
I can't say anything that hasn't been said. This place is fabulous. 

I went to brunch by myself and signed in. They have clear instructions, and the sign in sheet is in a clipboard outside of the entrance. You can let them know your location preference (inside or patio), party size, and if everyone is present. 

Turns out, I didn't even need to sign in. Out front, the seats are first come, first serve. After I saw a clear table, I hesitated and then checked with others waiting who confirmed the seats were free and that they didn't want them. 

I had the Monaco and the buttermilk pancake. The pancake was homemade and fluffy, with a taste similar to a crepe. The Monaco was good, and the potatoes come with roasted garlic. D-lish. 

A friend ended up joining me and had the florentine. Looked delicious.  We both had one egg, but you can choose how many you want, up to three. 

The Zazie mimosa was delicious and a great balance of champagne and fresh OJ. The bloody Marie tasted a little watery.

The service was great. Zazie makes it a point not to tip because they compensate their staff well. I like that approach. 

Fun place for brunch. I already have plans to go back.
author: Monique S.

description:
If hype was a tangible thing, Zazie would be covered in it from head to toe. I get that 3000+ Yelpers can't be wrong about delicious food but this wasn't didn't really do much for me. First, the wait is real. We waited over an hour after putting our names down for Saturday breakfast. This wasn't a really a big deal considering it was the weekend and a holiday one at that. I don't mind waiting for a delicious meal but this wasn't one worth waiting for. 

The monaco poached eggs came with prosciutto and tomatoes. It tasted like many other poached eggs I've had and wasn't truly impressive. We also shared a side of bacon, that was overcooked, and also chicken apple sausage, which honestly was probably the best item from the things we ordered. My friend liked her challah bread french toast so I'll take her word for it. Beyond that, I'm not sure much needs to be said other than that this is an average breakfast place with average offerings. I still have some high hopes for the dinner menu though.

What I love is the fact that they provide their employees with a decent wage along with benefits. All employers should do this and their efforts make it commendable. Their staff seemed happy and there's built in convenience with not having to awkwardly decide how much to tip at the end of your meal.
author: Quoc N.

description:
Best place in my opinion for brunch in the city. The food is great the wait staff is amazing. There is always a line and they do not take reservations. Try to get there early if you want a seat and especially if you have a large party. 

Try them out you will not regret it!
author: Shaneel A.

description: Good food but not worth the 30 minute wait. We got gingerbread pancake and eggnog French toast which was too subtle for our liking. The eggs Benedict was nice but again nothing was worth the wait.
author: Eni A.

description: Very popular breakfast spot. So either you get there early or be prepared to wait a bit. I will say though, the wait is worth it. Although many of the items on the menu were enticing, I finally decided on the french toast de diable - it came with poached bing cherries and whipped mascarpone cream, which is what sold it for me. I got three pieces, but the pieces were pretty big that I could've gone by with just one piece of french toast and a side of cream cheese coffee cake - which by the way, is a must when you come here. At first glance, I thought that maybe the cake could use a little more cream cheese, but after that first bite, I was secretly hoping that none of my friends would ask to try some. But it was too good, I thought that would be a crime to not let them try. Lastly, if possible, ask to be seated at their outside back patio - which had a very charming feel to it.
author: Heather S.

description: One of my favorite brunch spots in the city! The earlier you get here on a weekend morning the better, as wait times can reach 1-2 hours... Cannot say enough good things about this place. SO cozy, so delicious, and what's best is that they serve their french toast, eggs benedict, pancakes etc. in one's, two's, or three's so that you can mix and match! I've even had their dinner and it's amazing.
author: Sydney N.

description:
Not very cozy for groups more than 2.
Small portion for a brunch comparing to cost they charge.
The salad is nothing other than a sprint mix with some seasoning. 
I still cannot believe they charged me for coffee refill especially when they serve cups with refill it with a coffee pot.
I ordered Benedict Florentine which was good but not for this price
author: Ash E.

description:
This one star does not represent the food or the restaurant as a whole. It is for the server, Aidan, who gave us very bad service. 

Honestly, he totally ignored us but was charismatically servicing other tables. It felt like racial profiling. We were the Chinese table. My dad has a heavy accent. And my brother and I look younger than our age. He gave us no attention. But he was really talking it up with the other tables. 

He was very good at using his personality to cover up his poor service. We overheard the table next to us complaining about him as well. 

Besides his energy, his lack of attentiveness was very apparent. He forgot a dish in our order. We sat with empty plates on our table for about 15 minutes. We never saw him during our main course. When he did have the plates cleared, I asked for a box to take home my leftovers. I watched him walk to another table, where he was laughing and talking and schmoozing it up. We sat at our empty table with a single plate of leftovers for another 10 mins. Then he brings the box over.... No apology, just dropped the box off. 

When we paid our bill, we left two cards but he came back with the entire bill on charged on one card AND the other card was missing. This says that he saw the two cards but carelessly only charged and only returned one of them. We had to go to him and seek out the other card. 

I will definitely go back again. I love the food. I love the ambiance. It's very French and welcoming. Another plus is that the tip is included in he price on the menu. However, this makes it easy for careless servers to work at a lower standard. I will not go back if I am being served like this again. 

The host was very good at his job and kept us in the know about the status of our table. And the other waitress was very warm and gave us a lovely good bye.
author: Preston M.

description: Amazing! Signed up for brunch and was surprised how fast the line went. Super quick service etc. I got the croque madame and I wish the bread was more toasted/grilled. It wasn't as good as I'm used to, but the French toast was AMAZING!! I also loved the mocha maya -yum!!! Definitely can't wait to go back
author: Raychel J.

description: The best eggs Benedict I've have in SF so far!!! I got the Monaco and it was literally perfect. The meat and onion and tomato was so perfectly paired, the eggs so perfectly poached. The potatoes were gorgeous with crispy edges and wonderful seasoning. Thinking of it makes me drool and I can't wait to come back and have more.
author: Diane Z.

description:
My friends and I decided to come here because of Yelp, not gonna lie. It was a great decision, since the food was absolutely delicious. The wait was painful, over an hour, since we were a party of four. And you need to be there in order to keep your spot. However, there is a Peet's a few businesses down so you can have some coffee whilst you wait.

The food here is what stands out, it is more pricy, but you don't have to tip due to their policy to give workers a proper wage. We shared a cream cheese coffee cake, which was dense and not too sweet. Perfect to split into four pieces.

For my entrée I ordered the Florentine Benedict and their pancake of the day which was lemon poppy seed. The Benedict was good, nothing awe-inspiring. The garlic loaded potatoes stood out more. The most delectable item was the lemon poppy seed pancakes with lemon curd. The flavour was perfect, no syrup necessary. Would definitely go back just for those.
author: Nat K.

description:
Zazie is a great spot for Breakfast/Brunch!

I'm not sure how popular this restaurant is on the weekend, but during the week we were able to get seated right away. There is very limited seating which may serve as a problem if you're going in big groups, but it's perfect for groups no bigger than 4.

They have normal breakfast items: omelets, pancakes, french toast, etc. What I can't resist is a great eggs benedict and they provide just that. The benedicts can be bought by 1, 2, or 3 eggs. I went with 2 (an average serving size). I orderer The Divorcée which was awesome! It had english muffins topped with melted fontina cheese, avocado, crispy bacon, poached eggs, and hollandaise sauce. It was the perfect combination. The benedicts come with your choice of roasted potatoes or a green salad. I got the salad which was a nice light compliment to the heavy benedict. 

The staff was really nice. Prices seem high, but if you take in to account that you don't need to tip then it isn't bad at all. Yes, YOU DON'T NEED TO TIP! But if you're like me and know the struggle of the food industry, you might leave a tip (I couldn't not leave one lol).
author: Kristian G.

description:
it's good, but not quite worth the wait good. I don't want to mark them down for the wait because that's not their fault, it's ours. I do applaud that this joint pays its workers a fair wage that includes 401k, profit sharing, and health benefits. Good on you Zazie! If i have to pay an extra dollar or two on my bill for that I'm all for it. 

I do think you could work on updating how you queue patrons. A sign up sheet is a bit dated an inefficient, especially if you have to wait for an hour. Why not leverage some tech and allow your patrons to maybe go to the nearby park or shop around the area and get a notification when you're up next? 

As for the food, it's good it's just not Sabrina's (Philadelphia) good. Sorry, I know I shouldn't compare the new thing to the old thing -- but too late for that.
author: Leo I.

description:
Popular brunch spot - there was already a ton of people waiting outside on the waitlist and it was barely 10 AM. I think Zazie has an interesting management concept since no tips are encouraged. Rather, gratuity is included in the price of the food. These go beyond "tips" since Zazie employees get health insurance coverage and other benefits from it. You would think that service here would be compromised but our server was still very attentive and warmly gave recommendations.

The prices aren't that inflated either - I felt that my ~$15 scramble was a pretty standard price, especially in SF. I got the Avignon, which had lots of veggies such as eggplant/tomato/zucchini. It was kind of salty for my taste, and this wasn't helped by the side home fries. The side of home fries was basically crunchy and even more salty, and sautéed with whole unpeeled garlic cloves.
author: Lily C.

description:
Amazing  food and value for money. One of the best brunches in the city. 
We ordered a Florentine &  St.Trop eggs benedict and a french toast stuffed with caramelized bananas, walnuts. 
The wait lines are really long, it took us about an hour for a Saturday brunch and it also took really long for the food to arrive. But, this is totally worth the wait.
Apart from that, we enjoyed the meal and will deftly come back!
author: Wini V.

description: Zazie is my favorite breakfast destination in the city. They have the best coffee cake I have ever had. They also have great scrambles and pancakes. Great brunch location, but the wait is consistently over an hour. So show up early and bring an empty stomach!
author: Stewart P.

description: Very slow service. It took almost an hour to get a small soup and a burger, and that's given that we were one of the first customers that night. I would suggest management to focus more on customer service.
author: I C.

description: We absolutely loved Zazie and had a wonderful time there last night! The service was impeccable - everyone is incredibly kind and accomodating. It felt like we were dining with friends. On top of that, the food, wine, and dessert were delicious! And it was lovely sitting on the front patio with our dog. Definitely coming back here again and recommending Zazie to others!
author: Olga B.

description: Great food and ambiance! Added name to wait list for party of two around 10am, and waited less than 20 minutes for a table inside. Would recommend arriving early, maybe not a great place for big brunch groups.
author: Holly H.

description: Came here when it was raining but food and service here made it so much worth it! Definitely a come back again spot!
author: Christopher G.

description:
Eggs Benedict is fantastic at this place. Great place for breakfast and brunch. Get there early the line gets long. Its a small place so not good for big groups. Great for business lunch. Parking is not bad and Muni is very close. 


T would bring his buddy Macron
author: Victor Y.

description: One of the best little spots in the city. Long wait on the weekends, but Monday mornings you can likely get a table quickly. Great lattes and EB
author: Ashley K.

description:
Getting a good brunch in San Francisco on weekends is always a hassle - there are quite a few famous ones but the lines are always suuuuuuper long. Read some reviews from fellow Yelpers about how getting to Zazie at 9am on Sunday (which it opens at 9 by the way) still ended up a one-hour wait, I decided this is not going to happen to me.

Arrived on Sunday 8:25am and got the first spot in line woohoo! (sorry for being silly but I sacrifice sleep time for good food and *relatively* efficient-er use of time) But Yelpers are right the lines get crazy pretty early - at 8:50am there were about 25-30 people already and clearly, once the restaurant opened it quickly filled up.

A lot of research has been done before getting there. Quickly decided what I wanted. One thing I really like about their menu is that its flexible - for eggs you can choose 1 to 3 eggs and so do pancakes as well.

#La Mer: A-.
La Mer is a poached-egg-on-muffin dish with dungeness crab meat. I ordered one egg only since I wanted to try many dishes. The poached egg was very nicely made - perfect temperature and texture. The lemon hollandaise with muffin and avocado worked great together as well. Crab meat on the other hand was a bit disappointing - quantity is very little and perhaps the hollandaise covered it (?) I couldn't really find the crab meat taste at all. I would go for other meat type (the prosciutto one?) next time.

Each poached egg dish comes with a side - either home fries (more like potatoes) or salad. I don't know about the salad but GET THE HOME FRIES! It was so good and became highlight of the dish. The potatoes were perfectly grilled/fried and with a strong sense of garlic. In fact there was one piece of roasted garlic included (accidentally?) and it was super tasty even though I'm not really a eat-whole-piece-garlic of person. Wonderful!

#French Toast Tahiti: A-.
Ordered one toast for this. While the caramelized banana was simply within expectation, it was the walnuts filling that set a major difference. I'm a huge fan for walnut - the filling perfectly carried out the original walnut taste without being too sweet. The french toast itself was above average.

#Gingerbread Pancake: B+.
I usually like gingerbread a lot (e.g. the seasonal gingerbread latte from starbucks) and although this pancake did have a sense of gingerbread to it, I did not find it to be impressive. The texture of the pancake was fluffy and that was about it. But luckily the lemon curd saved it - it was so lemonish and this combination of lemon curd and pancakes was so brilliant.

Being a restaurant with thousands of good reviews I was expecting mediocre service - but not really. My server was super nice and willing to patiently explain the menu to the customers on next table. Very attentive as well and kept coming back to my table for coffee refill. 

I would definitely come back for other poached eggs and probably the miracle pancakes too!
author: Simon C.

description:
Amazing place for brunch! 
Super friendly staff and the best French Toast in the city !
author: Zihan Z.

description:
Every time I've passed by this place to go to the Haight, I always see a HUGE crowd of people here especially on the weekends. This place has been somewhere I've been meaning to try for years and my sister, mom and I finally made a point to come for Mother's day brunch!

As expected, we waited about an hour and 15 minutes to get seated. If you don't have much patience, they have a couple of tables in the front of the restaurant for first come, first serve smaller parties that want food right away/are possibly way behind the wait list that they can't wait too long. Do realize that if you come here on a weekend, you will be eating in front of large groups of people if you do take these seats! We wanted our privacy so we ended up with a little corner in the small garden patio towards the back.

We ordered and shared three things; the La Mer eggs benedict, New York scramble and the Tahiti French Toast. Everything was really, really good and super filling! I like how they have the options of adding however many eggs (for the benedicts) and pieces of toast (for the French Toast) so it's makes it more easier to share. I would totally recommend all three dishes, especially because they were huge portions for what it was. We were able to devour the egg dishes but ended up taking half of the french toast to go.

The service was great here too! The servers and the host were really friendly. I would come back here again (or maybe get take-out if the line is way too long) and try their other brunch dishes. Also one important aspect to note; they don't expect tips. They display on the menu along with their brunch specials that the staff here are already fully supported :) good to know their employees are being treated well here too!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Place is overrated. I'm sad to say it, but it's true. Came for a late brunch on a Thursday afternoon and there was no wait. The place is cute, but small and cramped. 

I ordered the une, duex, trois with the Tahiti French toast and my BF got the croque Madame and cafe au lait. Eggs are eggs so they were nothing special, my bacon was burnt, and my Tahiti French toast was just alright. They were nice and gave me another plate of bacon but they were still burnt, but just less burnt. Tahiti French toast was different but it wasn't as good as everyone says. Everything was served too close to room temperature too, like the caramelized spread in my French toast was cold. I think my BF liked his croque Madame, but then again, he didn't say much about it. 

People there were nice and friendly, but I doubt I'll be coming back. They're also a bit pricy. For the price you pay, other breakfast joints in the city are definitely more satisfying.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Wowowowoww. Finally tried Zazie on a Sunday morning with a couple of girlfriends. (Yes, we dared to go on Sunday morning. Beware of the line, impatient people!!!!). We arrived around 9:15 (opens at 9), put our name down, and waited a little less than an hour for a table. Seems like a while, but with good company, it really isn't so bad! Also if you're a party of 2, make sure to watch for those 4 front tables. It's a first come, first serve basis, so you can just swoop the table when another party leaves and you don't have to wait on the list!

After careful consideration, I ordered Eggs Guillame, which is an eggs benedict that comes with prosciutto and asparagus and home fries or salad. It was very hard to choose which benedict I wanted because they all sounded so good!!! But when the eggs guillame arrived and I got to try it, I was happy with my choice. The eggs were poached perfectly--like literally, perfect. The hollandaise was super tasty too even though i'm not used to it being so lemony. The earthy asparagus balanced out the salty prosciutto wonderfully and a bite of everything together was like a party in my mouth hahaha. I was also really impressed with the home fries. Usually I don't like breakfast potatoes that much, but they were crispy, hot, and garlicky! Garlic makes everything taste better. :P

I also got to try some of the famous miracle pancakes and the Tahitian french toast. Both of them were heavenly!! I can't wait to come back and try them again. One of my friends also really enjoyed her omelette, which was on the special menu as well. She said it was one of the best she's tasted!!

The service is also amazing here. Our waiter was really friendly and nice about constantly bringing us water (#thirsty), and just very personable in general. When you interact with someone in such a good mood, you get in an even better mood!! Also when a different waiter brought over my benedict, one of the poached eggs fell over to the side so all the hollandaise was on the side of my plate. I guess he saw the disappointment on my face, so he brought me a small container of hollandaise so I could pour it over that egg myself!! :') Service like that is really great to see and makes you wanna come back.

Also, there is a $1.25 charge per person for the employees health benefits and 401(k)'s. The way Zazie cares about their employees is so sweet!

I will definitely be back! Probably on a weekday when it's less crowded though, haha.
author: Tara A.

description: Really bad system for seating. It's very hard to hear the man saying the names. And he only really says a name once. If you don't hear it, too bad. They move on to the next party. They skip all around the list so you have no idea if you're next. I waited forty minutes before just walking away.
author: Kaitlyn D.

description: One of my favorite brunch places in the city! The gingerbread pancakes and the chicken apple sausages are extremely delicious!
author: Grace M.

description:
Zazie, the darling of Cole Valley.
Zazie, Cole Valley's beloved brunch beau.
Zazie, a sidewalk clogger, show stopper, line down the blocker.
Zazie, with the big name, putting on the big show for all to see on Cole Street.

Let's take a deep breath and remember some relevant dialogue from the movie Catch Me If you Can:

Frank Abagnale Sr.: You know why the Yankees always win, Frank?
Frank Abagnale, Jr.: 'Cause they have Mickey Mantle?
Frank Abagnale Sr.: No, it's 'cause the other teams can't stop staring at those damn pinstripes.

I'm not going to say Zazie is all pinstripes and hype, and I am not going to say Zazie is Mickey Mantle, but there are elements of truthiness in both. I've been to Zazie three times and had three very different experiences with respect to the main product, the food. 

The first visit was solid but not so memorable so let's fast forward to visit number two. 

My second visit I ordered the omelette of the day and it was somewhere between below-average and terrible. It was the most un-inspired, lifeless omelette I've had in a while. The only reason you could rate it above a standard diner offering is because of ingredient quality. It was like the egg and veggies, asparagus, etc. had a bad fight and didn't wanna talk to each other. The fillings just didn't gel. It fell apart physically and emotionally; we're still talking about the food. This visit really put a bad taste in my mouth, and a bad smell in my pee on top of that.

So the pressure was on for visit number three. It was make it or break it, and I really wanted Zazie to wow me. And you know what? They did. I ordered the "Eggs en Fonte":

"Grilled polenta cake w/ spinach, wild mushrooms, spicy tomato-chevre sauce, and two over easy eggs in a cast iron skill w/ home fries or salad"

This dish was the best. Five star cookin'. Delicious. I loved it. Full Mickey Mantle in the kitchen. It sounds like a lot going on between the polenta and the tomato-chevre sauce and the eggs, but there was harmony in that there skillet. 

Time to do the math:

Service: 5 stars - friendly but not too conversational - just the way I like it.
Food: Visit #1: 3.5 stars, Visit #2: 3 stars, Visit #3: 5 stars

*beep* *boop *bop* *crunch*

Zazie, a 4-star establishment.

Tip: Go for lunch on a week day with a pal-- there should be no line. Sit in the patio in the back for an intimate open-air experience.
author: Dave L.

description:
I've been meaning to try Zazie for months after hearing all the rave reviews from friends. After having tried Kitchen Story, Mama's on Washington Square, Sweet Maple, Griddle Fresh, Mission Beach Cafe, Chloe's Cafe, and the like, I've developed a pretty high standard on what good brunch is like.

I decided to stop by on a weekday in an effort to avoid the wait and managed to grab a table right away. Decided to order the florentine Benedict ($15) that comes with mushrooms and spinach. While it may seem that $15 is a bit on the pricy side for a vegetarian eggs Benedict, the fact that Zazie is "tipless" (their prices cover a living wage + employee benefits), makes it totally okay with me. 

However, the food was not totally okay with me. One of the poached eggs on my (2) eggs benedict was completely dwarf sized-- literally half the size of a regular egg. It was pretty unusual and I was surprised that they were okay serving a tiny, deformed egg next to a perfectly round poached egg. Not to mention, the dwarf egg was overcooked and not runny like the one next to it. (see pic) As a side, I had the potatoes and the portion was definitely smaller in comparison to brunch spots like Kitchen Story and Griddle Fresh. Sadly enough, a few of my potatoes were also burnt to a crisp.... like totally black.... so that was disappointing.

With tax, it came out to be $17 for a very mediocre dish in addition to spotty service. Not sure if it was just an off day, so perhaps I'll try it again sometime.
author: Marny N.

description: This place is awesome! I came here on a Saturday afternoon and I did have to put my name on the list and probably waited around 20-25 minutes for a table, but the wait was definitely worth it. I cannot remember the name of the sandwich I ordered, but it was amazing!! The service was pretty good. Our food was brought to us really fast, but afterwards our waiter didn't come to check up on us as frequently as I've experienced at other restaurants, but they are tip free and I did come on a busy day. I will definitely be returning here again.
author: Parmpreet G.

description:
Trendy French inspired cafe whose food is just ok.  Breakfast for 3 was $97.00 - excessive by my standards.
It seems that this establishment has developed a reputation to be visited when in San Francisco but it's really just an average café.  Honestly, I realize the "aged" furniture is part of the appeal but maybe a little love should be given to the place because there is a fine line between not investing money in upkeep of your space and it being worn with time (this place reflects more the first scenario).
Won't be visiting here again.
author: Maria V.

description: Amazing food .. one of my favorite brunch in the city. We had st.trop n pierrre noir and st. Trop eggs benedict so delicious also I love the miracle pancakes and Tahiti French  toast.. so amazing
author: Suzane S.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Saturday, and all I have to say is be prepared to wait! We waited for about an hour and 15 minutes before we got seated, but it must be good if there's a wait right? 

My friends and I got the La Mer, Challah French Toast with fruits, and Miracle Pancakes! We also got some mimosas and the Le Metro. Everything was amazing and delightful! The plating and food looked so pretty and delicious! You can not go wrong with La Mer; dungeness crab, avocado on an eggs benedict. It is to die for! It is more on the pricey side, but I think it's a great place to treat yourself to a fancier brunch. :)
author: Christina C.

description: Breakfast is definitely better than dinner. They are pretty pricey in general. I like that they don't want you to tip since it's included in the price. However the price is really high $30 for a small portion of stew.
author: Dee N.

description:
Every year, when searching for a place for my annual holiday outing, I consider then quickly rule out Zazie.  Their "no weekend reservations" policy coupled with the popularity of their brunch makes the place a deal breaker for that event.  But still, with more than 2,800 mostly favorable reviews, it was a place I was interested in trying.  

First, I can barely get my head around their popularity.  Cole Valley isn't exactly Valencia Street.  The fact that 2,800+ yelpers went there, found parking, and went on to write about it just about makes my brain explode.  I'd bet there's another 1,000 potential Zazie reviewers still trolling the area looking for parking.  

You would think a Monday night would be the quietest of nights.  It's the night when most people stay home and most restaurants are closed.  Well, throw that hypothesis out the window.  By 7:45 on a Monday evening, Zazie was packed.  The adorable back patio, every seat inside, and the handful of tables out front.  People were waiting on the sidewalk for a table to open.

Make that people and dogs.  Monday at Zazie is "bring your dog" night entitling you to $10 off a bottle of wine and your dog to a bowl of biscuits. Word is out.  Neighbors can't even walk their dogs by here on a Monday without them straining at the leash looking for a Zazie handout.  It's sort of amazing.

And I knew all of this why?  

Before arriving I'd spent a bit of time on their web site trying to ascertain their corkage fee.  I saw an amazing Tuesday night deal where you could bring as much wine as you like and pay zero corkage but for the life of me I could find no info on the normal fee.  But I saw the dog thing and reasoned that I'd bring her and get the discount in case the normal corkage fee was exorbitant.  It wasn't.  Corkage is $15/bottle every day except Tuesday.  

Bringing your dog here limits you to outdoor (heated) seating.  On this night, two wedding parties had rented out most of the patio which left me with front patio seating only.  It was far less charming than either the patio or the packed interior but it grew on me as the evening progressed, likely a result of the good wine, the great food, and the comped birthday combo of Chocolate Pot de Creme and Creme Brulee.  

Zazie offers a nightly fixed price menu ($29) which is not a bad deal but I wasn't tempted.  That meal provides only 1/2 portioned appetizers and 1/2 portioned desserts, and only certain ones of both.  Entrees are full-sized but also limited.I opted instead for an appetizer of mussels ($12) and an entree of rabbit in a Dijon mustard sauce with fettucini ($24).  Both were wonderful.  This is French bistro fare done perfectly; not frou frou, just rich and satisfying.  

It's clear that Zazie is not just embraced by locals.  It's something more akin to a love affair.  While finishing the last of my wine I heard a repeat customer (waiting for a table with his dog and two friends) tell them that "I've had the pork chop 3 times now and it's the best pork chop I've ever had in my life".  I'd wanted to sit on the back patio and, between the busyness of the night and the two private parties, it hadn't happened.  At the end of the evening the host came and sat down beside me to apologize, ensuring me that I'd get a seat out there "next time".  

Zazie is very confident that a one-time customer will be a return customer.  That confidence is not unfounded. .
author: Tracey A.

description:
very nice setting in the patio.
coffee was excellent, trout, on the day specials menu, was excellent too.
cream of asparagus soup could be better - but served its purpose to warm me up a bit, as the patio was chilly.
when they say service is included, they mean it, there is no room on the credit card slip to add service!
definitely a hip place and I will be back.
author: Mia S.

description: Zazie's Is just getting better and better and it is AMAZING.  The food, the Staff, the Drinks...All of it.  I am so glad I live so close and will be coming as long as they are open!
author: Amy P.

description: Zazie is definitely a great brunch spot to check out, we were lucky enough to stay at an Air BnB nearby and were told by several people that this was the must checkout brunch in the area. Pricey but worth it. They also let it be known that their employees have great benefits that I even feel like moving to the city and applying for work there. It's a great environment and spot to check out!
author: Edward P.

description:
Well. The wait on a weekend for breakfast was awful. Can't blame the restaurant if it's popular. Seating was efficient and friendly, food was terrific. It's a gem of a place, only  marred by the ridiculous crowd on a sunny Sunday morning. 

A wonderful neighborhood restaurant that is trying hard to keep everyone fed and happy in the face of their popularity.
author: Eric L.

description: Delicious place for brunch. We ended up on one of their tables by the window which was perfect because we have two small children. Though we had to wait a little for our food to come out, the service was excellent. I ordered the eggs Benedict, eggs cooked to perfection and sauce was yummy. The potatoes were crispy and salted just right.  Would definitely come back again.
author: Katrina W.

description: This place is so freaking good! The bloody Mary was delicious, the Benedict was amazing! I got the divorce! I love that you don't have to tip and that they treat their employees well! Very ethical company an awesome place to check out. It is very very small though but it kind of adds to the uniqueness of it. Just make sure to either make a reservation or get there plenty early.
author: Kendra B.

description:
So worth it.

Mac and cheese to start. Organic pasta, creamy cheddar sauce, Parmesan crust. Broke my taste buds.

Warm 'n toasty bun was then brought out, for no damn reason. And I gobbled it up.

Lemon ricotta ravioli. Exquisite. Just a dream.

To finish, petit pot de creme au chocolat. I have never. Best pot de creme I've ever had. I'm in love. I wanna marry it, 

Cozy spot, def not pretentious, def going back! Brunch is up next!
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Another food adventure. Popular brunch spot. Long waits. Great food. Could not decide between french toast or pancakes so give me both! Get here early on brunch days!! Or write your name on the list and go get a coffee nearby because you will be waiting. 

Service was friendly and good. Menu says tip is included in prices so you know they are a bit more expensive. Would definitely come back.
author: Jesse V.

description:
French Toast Tahiti (2) $15- yummmmm!
 
This was food to go. It's a small restaurant. Staff was friendly. 

I ate at a park. I just remember how tasty the French toast was. And it was a great portion. I hope to return and write a longer review :)
author: Michelle C.

description:
A bit pricey, because you don't need to tip. A very crowded brunch spot. It makes it a little awkward how the people waiting outside, stare you down for a table if you're eating outside. It's first come, first serve for outside patio so be prepared to swoop on a seat if you don't want to wait for a table inside. 

Love the theme of this place! Reminds me of a little French bistro in the middle of hipster-ville SF. The menu is as interesting as its name. 

I got the cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd and strawberries. The lemon was very tart, a little too tart, but it the flavor balanced well with the sweet strawberries. The pancakes are THICK. I'm sure I could have only ordered one and been full. The consistency has a lot of texture, kind of close to cornbread pancakes. I think I like them better than buttermilk. 

My boyfriend got the Maya benedicts. It was obviously Latin-inspired. Pulled pork with salsa, avocado, perfectly poached egg with hollandaise sauce. So savory! It also comes with a side of "home fries" which are red potatoes with cloves of roasted garlic. Mix the garlic and the potatoes together, and it's so amazing.
author: Rachelle Y.

description: Good lord the fresh porcini & truffle ravioli are insane. Probably the best ravioli I've ever had. Super sad that it's only on the specials. If it became part of the permanent menu I'd eat here probably every meal ever always forever.
author: Patrick G.

description:
Just being able to get a seat here is a full adventure on its own, but it's well worth it.

I've been hearing about the Zazie hype for a while now, so my curiosity finally got the best of me and I made my way over there- on Easter Sunday! I'm crazy right? Yes, I'm crazy. When I arrived, there was at least 50 people standing outside. I was instantly regretting my decision, until I saw that outside seating was first come first serve. Right there an then, I decided to make that my goal as many people came with a party larger than two. I managed to get a table about 30 minutes into my wait. Not bad at all. 

Anyways, the food. How was the food? Amazing! I knew off the bat I wanted the poached eggs with bacon and avocado. The eggs were perfectly poached and just absolutely tasty. I'm very impressed with the cooks dedication to really mastering poached eggs as even before I got to try it myself I heard nothing but praise. For seconds I had the French Toast with fruit, and that was just as good. I love that they give you such a hefty portion of fruits. I walked out a happy guy.

Final verdict: Zazie already has a strong reputation behind it as one of the best brunch places in the city. Now that I've tried it first hand, I completely get why. If you can get past the crazy line, everything from that point on is a masterpiece.
author: Alex B.

description:
Great weekend brunch cafe. They don't accept reservations and the waiting time can be up to 1 hour  Anyway it is worth it. 
The place is tip free.  We tried Benedict with salmon and French toasts! I love it
author: Anuta B.

description: Had the banana pudding miracle pancakes and cream cheese coffee cake. The cake was hot and fresh and beyond delicious. The pancake was moist and fluffy. The long wait was worth it.
author: Nora S.

description:
Zazie is "Tip Free." I admire their living wage model, Merci a Vous!
.
At peak times the brunch wait can be an hour. Be sure you put your name on the list hanging near the front door. 
.
At $15.00 I really enjoyed a Scrambled Egg Italie: with tomatoes, cream cheese and basil. The accompanying home fried potatoes with a few cloves of roasted garlic were perfectly prepared, mmm. And, for an additional $1 I substituted my toast for a toasted poppy seed bagel.
.
For $16.00 my friend ordered (2pieces) French Toast prepared in an orange cinnamon batter and topped with fresh fruit. I would have liked the batter to penetrate the bread a bit more but overall it was fine. 
.
For $11.00 neither of us like the Sunshine (mango) Mimosa and at $4.95 the large OJ tasted like an Oj used for mixing bar drinks, kinda sour with no pulp.  
.
I wouldn't say the food was awesome but it is better than average.
author: Caesar A.

description:
I never knew brunch was such a huge thing until I came to visit the Bay this time... everyone's brunch game is strong! I had two french brunch places as I was up here and this was one of them. Came here on Labor Day weekend and only waited about 20 minutes for a table (I think I just got lucky...)

Environment - during brunch, the place is very quaint and very nice. There's about 6 tables outside and a bunch of small tables inside. I would think this place is good for 2 people dining together; anything more than 4 for sure would be way too crowded as everything in San Francisco is a little cramped. It can get pretty loud indoors, but nonetheless, you can still hear your partner very well if you lean in a little bit. There's this cute spiral staircase to the front right of the restaurant and i wish there was seating upstairs but it's just a little office that you can see old menus hanging.

Service - the servers are very nice and no doubt enjoy what they are doing. Once they found out it was my first time there they immediately gave recommendations on what to eat.

Food - french brunch? yes please :) i definitely foresaw that it was going to be a buttery and delicious meal.

Egg with Crab Benedict - you always have an option of 1,2 or 3 yolks. My boyfriend got 1 yolk and it was definitely enough for him. I understand that Benedicts have the tendency to slide all over the place if not properly eaten... but for the sake of this one, try and cut properly and eating all layers in one bite so you can get the full taste. The crab was fresh and there was such a good amount. I would get it again, no doubt. The side of potatoes was delicious!! NOMNOM. I'm probably such a biased potato-lover. I want to eat this again.. the egg was so soft.. drool!

Miracle Pancakes - I got these because there were so many good reviews and photos on it! So like a good Yelper I was, i got it. Unfortunately, it was not my most favorite thing eaten here. I'm not sure how french pancakes are supposed to be but they were too doughy for my taste. I loved the flavor of the lemon ricotta though. It was my first time having such a flavoral pancake! :) I would hold off on smearing both the butter and syrup on in order to get the full taste.

Coffee - smooth, dark, good.

If you're in the city and looking for a nice french brunch, you should totally come here. But remember, 2 people great, 4 people okay, and no more than 4!
author: Connie V.

description: Huge line with a confusing wait list system. We were totally skipped over. The food is just ok, def not worth the wait or the money. The potatoes were half garlic, which is fine if you like to eat garlic bulbs. The "miracle pancakes" with banana on it had a single slice of banana on it. I'd skip it.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday for brunch and I would say that I will be coming back!

Parking was easy for us to find here since we went on a weekday brunch time. Literally in front of the restaurant which was a rarity here in San Francisco.

ATMOSPHERE:
This little French restaurant is one of those hidden gems in the city. I'm glad that I found this place via Yelp - you're always saving my restaurant-lust. The restaurant is a bit tiny with an outdoor and indoor seating. Before you're seated, you're required to enter your name, seating preference, number of people in your party, etc. in a form outside. We waited for about 20 minutes (which wasn't THAT bad) and we finally got to sit!

FOOD:
I ordered the scrambled eggs (Mexican) which came with potatoes and bread. The food took a bit to come out because they were hella busy, but it was fine! The food was amazing! The scrambled eggs was rich in flavor and I couldn't get enough of it. To top it off, I sprinkled it with Tobasco. It also came with garlic and oh my... I love garlic!

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
Our server was on-point! He was very attentive and I liked how he seemed to like his job.

One thing I totally loved about Zazie was that in the menu, it says that it's tip-free. Meaning that they are paying its servers a livable minimum wage with benefits such as paid time off and a 401k plan. I believe that more restaurants should digress from the traditional business model of tipping and progress with this business model. Less stress for the customers and waiters for tipping which equates into better customer service!

I highly suggest coming here and try Zazie's!
author: Aj C.

description:
I had heard the hype about this place and their long wait time, and when I found myself in Cole Valley at noon on a Saturday you better believe Zazie was a priority on my to-do list. I knew it would be busy (Saturday brunch in the city- yikes) but my god, there were nearly 30 names on the list- almost 2 pages worth! The hostess refused to even attempt formulating an estimated wait time. Naturally this made me want Zazie even more now! 

I returned the next day- the line was even longer, as expected since it was Sunday. So finally, Monday at noon became my magical hour. We waited only 10 minutes for a table and were greeted by a very friendly and efficient server. 

The menu was overwhelmingly packed with stellar choices, and after much debate I finally settled on the "Italie" scramble. The eggs were cooked to perfection and mixed with basil, tomato, and cream cheese. It was an exciting dish, but I found the basil and tomato provençales to be extremely overpowering and oily. It was so greasy that my stomach was uncomfortable for the rest of the day. My friend ordered the Fontainbleau scramble and also commented on the oil, but was thoroughly delighted with her meal. Another friend had the Le Mer poached eggs with dungeons crab and explained it as "heavenly".

Overall, the experience was fun and expensive. I found the restaurant to be very charming, but I don't think I'll ever find myself waiting for a table behind 30 other parties.
author: McKenna P.

description:
After Outsidelands, Zazie was the perfect place to go! 5 of us arrived around 1030 and got seated within a couple minutes. However, when we left around 1130, the line was very long. 

Though small, the restaurant had a warm atmosphere and they stressed a no tip policy. Right off the bat, we got coffee which was delicious, especially the iced coffee. My friends then ordered the Pierre Noir poached eggs, the ahi tuna sandwich, the Monaco poached eggs, and the omelette special. They were all very happy with their choices and are them quickly. 
I ordered the St. Trop poached eggs (2) and it was to die for. The eggs were poached to perfection and they did not skimp on the smoked salmon at all. The hollandaise sauce was soo good and brought the dish together.
It was a great place for brunch and I'd definitely go again!
author: Margaret K.

description:
This is a great breakfast/brunch spot. I took my friend here who is from out of town here and she absolutely loved it. I love how the workers here are paid a living wage. Meals are pricer here because tip is included in the cost and not expected at the end of the meal. 

The only negative I have is that you will most likely experience a way long wait, but it's not the restaurants fault that they're so popular!

Pro tip: Avoid the wait by snagging a seat at the tables in front.
author: Amanda B.

description: Decided to check this place out before spending the day at the Golden Gate Park. Everything was excellent. Great service from the moment I walked in the door. I chose a mimosa and my meal from their specials list, and the food was delicious! If I have time, I will definitely bring my man here before we leave the city!
author: Carlie G.

description:
French toast was a slice of white bread from Safeway with some egg slapped on it. Muffin was cold, not room temp, but cold on the eggs Benedict.

Remarkably unremarkable.
author: Brad G.

description:
Honestly, Tracy A is right, there is really no point for another review for this place. It's got review excess. But it was a perfect Sunday morning. And every excellent brunch place should start with the sentence of "it's a perfect Sunday morning." We crossed the meadow in GGP, walked up a bit, and there it was, a line, no mistake about it, a line and a wait list. T wrote down my name, as mine had four syllables and his got one. To which I said, "Most people call me Vic, you know." The line was long. We had plenty of time to discuss why only so few people call me by the full name and why so many decided to call me Vic. There was the Coles Hardware store selling pretty flowers across the street. There was a huge line forming after we showed up.

But her is the thing. You are not guaranteed a table just because you are there first. It appears, you could get in that day if you had 3 or more more people faster. Note to those lovebirds out there, not a date place if you can't stand the other person too long, for you may have to wait outside together and endure each other's presence just ever so slightly longer before you are seated to eat.

A 45 minute wait. Respectful for a table for 2 that day, and it was warm outside. Ordered mushroom omelette that came with exotic mushrooms, yummy. Strong and non acid coffee. Bonus. Kept that cup filled please. T ordered a ham and cheese special omelet, a bit boring imo, but perhaps it was for him to pay homage to his midwestern roots.  Surprisingly though, it was quite tasty, maybe it's the avocado that dressed it up. 

In conclusion, excellent food. Seating is tough. It will try your patience during the weekend brunch hours. Great for people watching while waiting. And if you like your companion, perfect opportunity to catch up while standing outside in your sundress and straw hat.
author: Victoria E.

description:
[NOTE: This is a review of the brunch]

Once good restaurant that's now coasting on its reputation and prominent placement in tourist guides. The food is decent, not spectacular (particularly considering the price). Nice ambience, but definitely not worth the absurd wait on weekends.

Most gallingly, however, is that the service is TERRIBLE. This would be confusing for such an upscale place if it wasn't for the "TIPS ARE ALREADY INCLUDED" emblazoned across the menu (which naturally arrives a prompt 10 minutes after being seated). Shockingly, removing the economic incentive for good service leads to ... bad service. Go figure. So there's nothing you can do but sit through the indifferent, excruciatingly slow service, stare at your watch, and dream of the coffee that might someday arrive. It's just like being in France! 

Oh, and in case you start thinking SOMEone might be interested in providing actual service, there's also a "NO SUBSTITUTIONS ... our small kitchen does its best to keep up". Poor things! Obviously the stress of running a restaurant is too much for the little darlings - best to do them the favor of not bothering them with your business.

Perhaps it's all just a ploy to give the full European experience. Personally I'd rather have unauthentically un-French service. The Pork Store on Haight has no such problems - as well as better food and shorter waits. Vive la différence!
author: Wanda T.

description:
I've always heard Zazie was a really good, must try brunch place, so I went on a Saturday morning at around 11AM. We waited for about 30-40 minutes, which I didn't think was too bad. I came specifically for the eggs benedict and was really happy to see there were so many eggs benny choices: Florentine, Pierre Noir, Monaco, Divorcee, Albert, St. Trop, & La Mer. In addition, they give you a choice of having one, two or three eggs. The dish also comes with salad or house potatoes. 

I ordered the Florentine eggs benedict with 1 egg ($12) and house potatoes. The egg was perfectly made and it was super creamy and the potatoes were super crispy and tasty as well. We also ordered 2 pieces of the Challah French Toast ($14). I personally thought the french toast had good flavor but it was not my favorite. The meal over all was really good, but not amazing. I would definitely go back, but it wouldn't be my first choice. I personally did not think it was completely worth all the hype.
author: Victoria H.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Saturday. Our friends got here around 8:30am to wait on line and we were able to get seated in the first wave. Definitely sit in the back garden patio.

We all shared the miracle pancake and it was SO good! We demolished it.

I got the Monaco eggs Benedict with potatoes. The potatoes are perfectly cooked and the hollandaise sauce wasn't too heavy. And I love that you can order 1, 2 or 3 eggs. The steel cut oats were also good.

But what makes this review 5 stars is the coffee cake. Order all the food and get this to go!
author: Bora L.

description:
I could eat here every morning for breakfast. They have so many incredible options to choose from. In fact, I was torn between two other options!

The services is awesome and the cool thing is that tip is included in the bill. The only thing I'm not a fan of is having to write your name on a first come, first serve basis when they open. You end up having 25+ people all gathered on the sidewalk waiting to be seated. Time for a bigger location to meet the demand?

This is a must visit spot when visiting the area.
author: Ryan K.

description:
We started off the day with Zazies to celebrate our 10 year anniversary. This place was cute, small, adorable and really great food! 
About the wait- for a party of 2 we waited 30 minutes not bad at all. 
Parking- pretty tough, metered parking but we got lucky. 
Ambience- was cute 
Staff- super friendly- NO TIPS REQUIRED 
Food- delectable  
We ordered a miracle pancake (cornbread with lemon curd and fresh strawberries on top) MAKE SURE YOU GET THERE EARLY OR THEY WILL RUN OUT OF THEIR MIRACLE PANCAKES. French toast Tahiti- it was scrumptious! With a plantain on top. My husband ordered La Mer poached egg, he only ordered one so it was pretty small but with all the food we had, it was definitely more than enough.  

We will definitely come back again!
author: Kathy B.

description:
Have had brunch here a few times. Main complaint is the lattes aren't hot. Today the eggs were also just not hot.  I dont mean steaming but the level of hot that makes the flavor pop
Maybe the place is losing mojo over popularity
author: Lamb C.

description:
French toast lovers rejoice! Zazie has thick and hearty slices that are perfect for drizzling in syrup.

There is always a line at this no-tip brunch spot, and that's because the food is that good and the place is so small. Worth the wait. And worth coming back.
author: Regina D.

description:
If I could give it 10 stars I would. Yes, the wait is annoying but honestly, I waited for over 2 hours on Mother's Day and it was still so worth it. There's a Peet's right next door so if you're with a couple people you can take turns hanging out in there and getting some coffee or tea. It's also in such a cute area, especially on a sunny day Cole street is so adorable. Now, onto the food...SO GOOD. The eggs Benedict was one of the best I've had because the biscuit underneath was so crispy on the outside but still nice and doughy. They have different pancake specials on different days and if you ever see that they have their bread pudding pancake, don't hesitate. I got one and I can't imagine eating more than one. It's worth it for the price because the pancakes are so rich and filling. Never mind tasty. Their iced tea is also so good. Also, the 2-3 person tables outside in the front are first come first serve so if you see a couple people getting up to leave get ready to take it so you don't have to wait. Overall definitely worth it and definitely going back!!! 
Added plus, the decor and plates are sooooooo cute!!!
author: Arianna R.

description:
Zazie is a cute little Provencale French restaurant located in the middle of Cole Valley with long wait times for brunch all the time! They do take reservations for dinner but not for lunch. I came here with my mom, dad and sister to kick off my weeklong birthday festivities! Got here by 8:45am (they open at 9am) on a Sunday morning and there was already a crowd at the door. My sister quickly jumps in and jots her name on the clipboard. We were number 13 on the list. Luckily the 12 parties ahead of us were parties of 2-3 so we made it in the restaurant in the first round! Horray!! It was mom and pops first time eating french style brunch and they loved it! 

I had the "Monaco" with proscuitto and tomatoes, topped with two poached eggs, house made hollandaise sauce on an english muffin serve with home fries. So yummy and delicious! I especially loved the whole roasted garlic in the home fries. You might think they're not edible, but if you squash it in your mouth, its creamy and delicious! 

We had the French Toast Tahiti to share and they were stuffed with caramelized banana and walnuts topped with more bananas served with butter and maple syrup. Can't beat a stack of carbs, sugar, and fat on a Sunday morning!

The staff were so friendly and were so nice to my mom and dad, and took a family picture for us. My dad loved his bowl of latte! Yes it was served in a bowl!
author: Janny S.

description: One of my favorites in all of SF. Whether it's brunch or dinner, you can't go wrong. Get there early for brunch to avoid the lines. I like sitting on the back patio.
author: Jack M.

description: This place is a gem. Their gingerbread pancake was worth the hour wait and that just means that the pancake is really good. This place is cozy and their food is phenomenal. I can't wait to visit again when I'm in SF.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
I've never reviewed Zazie's!!! This is crazy! I've been here over five times. Not acceptable!

Anyways, I discovered Zazie's threw yelp reviews and decided to stop by on a weekday morning to see what the hype was all about. (This was about two years ago when it wasn't super busy).

Their outdoor patio is really cute. Love the heated lamps, the greenery, and the table seating. 

So far I have tried:

French toast: Delish! What a french toast should be...light, fluffy and buttery.
Crab Benedict: I don't even like poached eggs, but this place get's it right. Probably one of my favorite dishes.
Lemon ricotta ravioli: Good veggie option. Love the lemon flavor.

The wait here has been a hit or miss for me in the past. Obviously i have stopped in on weekdays and had zero wait time.

 On one super late sunday the wait was only 30 minutes. 
The last time i came here,we waited over an hour! Ugh!!!!!! Man friend was not happy. 

So unless you are a early bird on the weekends, be prepared to wait. 

Still doesn't stop me from coming!
author: Nika K.

description:
solid brunch but i like this place even better for dinnertime. there isn't as much of a crowd and the back patio is something out of a dream.

even had our wedding dinner here--couldn't beat the intimate dinner party vibes.

definitely love their pricing philosophy.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
I'm up in SF nearly every month (sometimes every other week) and have been itching to hit up Zazie for brunch after getting a ton of recommendations from friends.  So I finally pulled the trigger and came with a group of friends last weekend.  

We arrived not long after 10 am (Sunday morning) and there was already a huge crowd of people waiting outside.  We thought it would be an excruciating wait but figured, "why not, we were already there and might as well give it a shot."  Little did we know, my name was called just 15 minutes after I wrote my name onto the waiting list.  

The only issue was they require everyone in your party to be present, otherwise they will only hold the table for a few minutes until everyone arrives.  Okay, fine.  We waited another half hour before the rest of our group shows up (they drove from San Bruno & San Jose) and right when we let the host know the group was here, we were seated quite quickly (about 10 minutes or so).

Once you walk inside, you'll get a feeling that you've walked into a little cozy cafe in Paris (with much better service of course).  We were greeted by our server right away and he took down our drink orders.  After having a tough time deciding between which dishes to order, he gave us a few recommendations, along with his personal opinion on each one.  

We had a hard time deciding between whether to order the French toast or gingerbread pancakes so he recommended the flight (buttermilk pancake, gingerbread pancake & French toast).  The gingerbread pancake was perfect!  There was a preserved pear right on top of it and it mixed in very well with the gingerbread flavor.  I couldn't help but hog up that particular pancake while the rest of my friends watched as I ate like a pig!  

I opted for their trout dish.  It was cooked to perfection, topped off with tomato and feta.  And it was still nice and juicy, retaining all the flavors without being too dry like other restaurants that serve trout.  

Don't be too intimidated by the long wait.  They move the tables pretty quick and people were getting called left and right so you won't be waiting too long.

Note, the tables outside by the entrance are on a first come first serve basis.  Try to score a seat there and you won't have to wait!
author: Roger M.

description:
What an amazing dinner!! While I know Zazzie is known more for its brunch, their dinner is not to be missed. The restaurant is filled with the smell of fresh baked bread and it has a wonderfully cozy atmosphere. The back patio is heated for those who want to eat outside. The service is friendly and warm. For appetizers the cheese platter and roasted veggies were both PHENOMENAL! All the dinners we got were great with the rabbit fettuccine and polenta worthy of a special nod! And though you may be full, try to squeeze in some dessert- the seasonal rhubarb crumble currently!! 
They also have a reasonable $15 corkage fee for BYOB which we loved!!! 
The restaurant isn't too noisy and perfect for catching up with old friendly- which is exactly what I did!! Can't wait to come back for the company and the food!!
author: Elle D.

description: This place is famous for great brunch, but I actually enjoy dinner better. Outdoor dining space in the back is cozy, and intimate. Needless to say that food is fantastic. My favorite is Salade Guillaume (arugla and strawberry salad), and Bourride Zazie (monkfish, mussels, and prawn soup). Katie is our favorite server, she is the best!
author: Narihiro K.

description:
Boyfriend and I had a coin toss to see whether to go to Zazies or Sweet Maple, Zazies won out and I was pretty excited since I've had the place bookmarked for the longest time. 

I have to say there isn't really anything particularly impressive about breakfast/brunch. I had the omlette du jour and while it was pretty good I had to dock points for forgetting my avocado and mediocre potatoes. Coffee was ok but was probably in the pot for a little too long since it was a little sour. 

I don't think it's worth it with the one hour wait time but the place has good service and I do like their policy for tipping employed staff. If I do go back it'd probably be for something aside from brunch or maybe try their pancakes/waffles instead.
author: Kelly Y.

description: Long wait around fellow brunch lovers slowly transitions into tight seating with a lively kitchen for a sound track. You'll get should food, quick and efficient service, but nothing that will wow you.
author: Blair B.

description:
The food is ok, not very authentic French but ok. 

They are nice but very conveniently do not tell you that you have to ask for the menu before your order, if you order items on the menu without previously telling them they will charge you full price arguing that it is full size instead of half and will not correct the bill. Nothing on the menu says you have to request it ahead.
author: Julie P.

description:
Hands down, best brunch in SF and worth all the wait!

Ok, so the wait is generally at least an hour during brunch prime time, but once you start eating, you will understand why.

My personal favorite is the Fontainebleu scramble with mushrooms, spinach and fontina served with their breakfast potatoes (cooked with whole roasted garlic!!).

Miracle Pancakes - these are the special pancakes that they change daily. I've had stone ground cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd and strawberries, as well as the pumpkin spice pancakes and both were out of this world! Fluffy, soft and the flavor profiles are always on point! I always get a savory dish plus a side of 1 miracle pancake because it's that good.

The prices seem higher but if you take into consideration that they are tip-free because they provide their employees comprehensive benefits, then the prices are still relatively comparable to other brunch places but with much better food!
author: Tanya P.

description:
AMAZING PLACE! If you're looking for delicious food in an artsy setting, this is the place for you. 

First off, the menu. It doesn't matter how picky or varied your tastes are, there is something on the menu for everybody. The food is very reasonably priced. I got the French Toast with bananas and was with heaven.

Second, the ambience! If you're seated in the back (which you should ask for) you'll find yourself in a cute, rustic area. Perfect for that Instagram aesthetic.

And last but BEST, NO TIP! That's right, tip is included in the price which is so so nice and cuts out a lot of the hassle. All the waiters are extremely cheerful and friendly. My friends and I left feeling full and happy.
author: Ankita B.

description:
I've tried to eat here a few times during the weekends with other groups, but usually the wait time is ridiculous (as a result we would walk over to Bambino's or Crepes on Cole as there aren't many other choices in Cole Valley).

Going in on a weekday for brunch is the best idea. We wrote our name down around 1130 and got a table for 2 within 15m, so there wasn't much of a wait! 

We split the French Toast Tahiti and Smoked Salmon poached eggs. Both were delicious and filling. The prices are moderate and the service is great. As others have pointed out, it is tip free as they do pay their employees a living wage and offer them health insurance, so that balances out the higher than normal prices, I suppose.

I don't think the weekend brunch waits are worth it (especially with so many other brunch options in the city), but I recommend going to Zazie on a weekday.

I also went to Zazie recently for dinner, group of 6. Yes they take reservations for dinner! Though the menu is completely different. We had the benefit of sitting in their outdoor area, which I did not even know existed. It was beautifully lit and very warm with the heat lamps despite the cold temperatures that evening, though it did rain pretty heavily that night and we started to feel tiny droplets fall on us at some point.

There are some great cocktail options on the menu, I had the Greyhound which was delicious. I had the beef bourguignon which was alright, I've had one home cooked that tasted much more fresh and aromatic than the one at Zazie.

Dessert: the portions are large for dessert so definitely consider sharing. The baked hot chocolate I'd interesting though it just tastes like chocolate sauce. The creme brulee was great. 

The dinner menu items are really pricey for the not so high end experience, but again, no tip was necessary. Overall we had a great time here, and we are glad they let us stay slightly past closing as we socialized for several hours.
author: Elisa L.

description: The host working last night is very good at his job. Food was delish. Ate too much and I felt like I was going to explode when I left, of course that's my fault.
author: D R.

description: This place definitely lives up the hype. I have been here twice and both times I got a miracle pancake. The first was a lemon poppyseed, and the second was a lemon custard. My favorite part about both pancakes was that they were so delicious but not too sweet. You are also able to get single orders of different foods. Along with the single pancake, I got an eggs Benedict that was so good.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Came here on a Sunday for brunch, so of course there was a long wait. The restaurant is pretty small, but there is seating on the back patio which is nice. 

I ended up ordering one of the poached eggs. Forgot exactly which one, but it was fine. Nothing spectacular and I wouldn't care to wait for seating just to order it. 

Interesting concept by telling patrons "no need to tip" since they pay their employees fairly with benefits. 

Overall, not a bad spot. Go early if you can.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
