(Side note: I love the fact that Zazie lets you customize your portion size.  In the mood for just a little snack?  Order just 1 egg.  Feeling gluttonous?  Order 3.  I split the difference and had 2.  I wish all restaurants let me do this.)

On the side, I had a cup of fruit (simple but delicious) and, to wash it all down, a glass of the Zazie spritzer.  I really enjoyed the spritzer, which was a blend of fruit juices with carbonated water.  It was a refreshing (and alcohol-free) alternative to the typical mimosa or bellini.

Service was fast and friendly, too.  Actually, every single aspect of breakfast at Zazie was très mangnifique!
author: David G.

description:
Arrived at 9:20 for a table of two and we were seated within 30-35 minutes, not bad for a Sunday! They open at 9am so get there 10 minutes early and you should have no problem getting a nice table. 

I would give them 5 stars but the potatoes were really greasy and kind of burnt for my taste, everything else was delicious! My gf and I shared the the poached eggs Monaco over prosciutto and tomato on an English muffin. We also ordered the French toast with fresh fruit and we loved it. I really liked their coffee I just wish they provided larger cups. 

Note for the wise: This place does not accept tips so everything on the menu is premium price! Not a complaint by any means just be prepared, a brunch for two with coffee and mimosas can run north of $70 

The service was excellent, the decor is beautiful I really enjoyed the dining experience. 

Last note: Their bathroom is really small, if you're a big girl or a big fella or your with your kid, you might have some trouble maneuvering.
author: Alex M.

description:
How to spot a popular brunch place: find the bunch of crazy people lining up outside the spot
How to spot a super popular brunch place: approach the clipboard to put your name down... Only to realize you need to flip to the next page and put your name at the very bottom of the page 

Needless to say, that was my experience at Zazie. I thought the line would be slightly shorter during Thanksgiving weekend since most people would be out of town, but I was wrong. However, I remained committed to my cause and waited! My party of 2 waited around an hour for a table, but we were rewarded with one at the outside heated patio - super cute area! 

My friend and I order the Fontainebleau scramble and the miracle pancakes (pumpkin was the flavor of the week) to share. The scramble was good but not out of this world - my friend and I enjoyed the medley of fresh greens and mushrooms in the scramble. The pumpkin pancakes were fluffy, extra points for pumpkin and the fall-ness of it all. I'm glad we split the two dishes though, because the pancakes became a little heavy after a while (and we only got 2!).

As many other yelpers have mentioned, Zazie has a slightly different pricing system in that tip is included. While the menu price may seem a little higher than usual, I assure you that the overall bill is reasonable and on par with the other brunch places in the city. 

Zazie was a solid brunch spot, but for the wait, I don't think it's that worth it. I'd try it once, but it won't be a regular spot for me.
author: Julia N.

description:
Went there on a rainy day at around 9:30 am, waited for 10 mins only! I ordered a French toast with caramelized banana and walnuts. My friend ordered a Mexican scrambled egg. They are both big portioned and good! They used bowl to serve coffee, so cute :)
Also a no tip restaurant!
author: Xuaner Z.

description: This review is for their dinner items. They have pretty good brunch. But my dinner experience was not that good. The truffle ravioli was too heavy probably because of the cream ?? I couldn't eat more than two of those heavy raviolis. The trout dish was too bland lacked flavor. The most disappointing item was their baked chocolate with marshmallows. There was really nothing good about it. Not a great place for dinner!  Better off  with brunch.
author: Raja K.

description:
Came here on a rainy Saturday and waited for about 30-45 minutes. One thing I really appreciate about this restaurant is that they give their workers a 401k and tip is already included in the bill. The waiters here were super friendly and food was solid as well. 

I ordered the la mer Benedict and the pancake of the day which was the bread pudding pancake. The crab was juicy and tender. They spent some extra time and pulled the crab apart. The hollandaise was done really well. I was a huge fan of the potatoes, they weren't dry at all and had really good flavors to it. Ketchup wasn't needed for these potatoes. The bread pudding pancake looked super dense but in reality, it was pretty light. The only thing I had against the pancake is that it wasn't as sweet as I would have liked it but that's nothing syrup can't solve. 

Great experience and service. The bathroom is extremely claustrophobic but the restaurant itself is super tiny so that was expected.
author: Colin F.

description: Food is always on point even after so many years of not going here.  It was just as good as I remember.  There were some of the same servers too and they remember me and my sister and were super friendly.  Very cute ambiance albeit small, however, they did remodel the outside patio and it is super cute.  Be prepared for a wait especially on the weekends, but well worth it.  One of my favs, can't wait to go back!
author: Megan M.

description: Excellent Saturday brunch experience this past weekend! We put our name on the list and ambled around Cole Valley and Haight St for about an hour or so. We came back to find that we had not been there when they called our name, but no problem they seated us right away on the back patio. I got one of the best Bloody Mary's of all time- the perfect level of spiciness. My friend got the mimosa with sorbet which was delicious. She enjoyed the omelette of the day and I had the decadent croque monsieur. The item that stole the show, however, was the cream cheese coffee cake. Simply incredible- definitely order it to share between 2 or 3 people.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Great food. Wonderful setting. Cheerful and friendly staff. Prices are very good, and even more impressive that tipping is not allowed. I went there for breakfast but must go back for dinner on my next trip to San Francisco. 

Considering all aspects,  I'd say that it's the best experience of any restaurant in the City.
author: Jerry Y.

description: This review is for a weekday breakfast -- I've had the miracle pancakes and the gingerbread pancakes, which are both very good. I always appreciate the fact that you can get less than a full order of pancakes, and the no tipping policy. The interior's super cute (staircase and all), but I don't know if I would wait for a weekend line. Next time, mimosas after meetings!
author: Heidi L.

description:
Zazie's is great for their food and service! I've always gone during off hours in the morning when it's quiet :) 

I enjoyed their shrimp, avocado Benedict special. The distribution of each ingredient is perfect! I love that they have one little piece of fruit to eat with your meal. I also appreciate that we can pick how many eggs you want. 

I'm not too fond of the signature tea- I can't find the words to describe why. 

I love the homey vibe with the benches and space outside in the back. I love that they provide their staff with health insurance and retirement plans so I don't need to worry about tipping. 

Come with your dog or your kids; zazie's is very welcoming!
author: hannah l.

description:
Tasty food & good employee policy, tragic mishap with my poached eggs.

Full review here: https://monniethebruin.wordpress.com/2015/10/17/restaurant-review-zazie/
author: Monica T.

description:
Love love love!

I had a friend in town and he suggested this place. We didn't wait too long and sat outside. We both ordered coffee and the eggs benedict.

Nothing beats a good eggs benedict, and this place does it perfectly. I ordered the St. Tropez with the smoked salmon which came with chunks of potatoes. Eggs were poached perfectly, eggs were not drenched with sauce-perfect amount, and the potatoes were nice and crisp. Everything was cooked to perfection and I really enjoyed my meal. 5/5!
author: Jessica S.

description:
In a town like San Francisco where brunch spots are plenty, we tried out Zazie on a Friday morning as fuel for our Land's End hike.

Be warned, the place is quite small and things fill up quickly. We beat the brunch rush and were seated in 5-10 minutes but saw the large crowd waiting throughout our whole meal.

I enjoyed the lighter French twist on brunch...lots of sandwich and salad options along with the standard offerings.

Eggs Benedict Monaco was a well done dish lightened up with them prosciutto and lemon hollandaise sauce. The home fries were well seasoned and a nice side.

Seared Ahi tuna sandwich was, again, a good light option for brunch. Flavorful with the olive tapenade.

As you'll notice as plates walk around, the pancakes are HUGE. Our group of 3 split a miracle pancake, which is smaller than the regular but was the perfect amount for us. If you're a pancake fan you'll enjoy this place.

Great for smaller groups and any occasion. The space gets lots of great light and is very nicely decorated.
author: Teresa T.

description:
Ah yes, the wonderful Zazie! Many eaters have heard of and tried their legendary ginger pancakes topped with a caramelized  slice of pear. I recommend ordering one pancake and sharing it, because it is very filling. Treat yourself to a heartwarming (literally, there's a foam heart) latte that comes in a cute mug you'd wish you could purchase at Anthropologie.

For breakfast, I ordered the Avignon scramble, which has eggplant, yellow zucchini, tomato, and provencal herbs. If you are looking for something healthy and light in the morning or for brunch, the Avignon is the way to go.
author: Joanne K.

description:
Zazie is the only "lineup brunch spot" that I keep coming back to.. but it's because I've got a secret superpower ;)

If you can snag a spot in the back patio during the day, it's worth the extra wait: it's roomier, quieter, brighter, and greener.

The service is supremely friendly once you've got a table -- perhaps it's because they have a living wage and health benefits! 

Start off with a delicious cup of _regular_ coffee. If that is not your temperament, the mimosa options are quite good as well.

I've always doubled down on the poached eggs, la mar being my favorite. I also hear good things about the pancakes. Their omelette is just OK, I'd get something more special.

Don't forget to order a delectably warm home made coffee cake! It will arrive before your meal an give you something to munch on. Pairs well with that cup o' joe you've already ordered.

Finish off without having to make up a number for tip, because they're past that terrible social construct. Zazie abolished tipping in favor of higher prices, higher wages, and health insurance.

What a fantastic place for taking your favorite out-of-towners for a non touristy experience.

Will be back and back and eventually check out their dinner service!

PS: my superpower has to do with living around the corner, and strategic waitlist timing.
author: Artem A.

description:
Came to Zazie on a Tuesday morning around 9am and surprisingly it was busy! I mean, it's a small cozy place; and it was full. I'm like.. Don't people work nowadays?

And I understood why after we ate.

Food here is ON POINT. 100% legit yummy goodness.

We found Zazie after searching for gluten-free breakfasts on Yelp. They do have gluten free substitutes which ..according to my friend was very YUMMY.

The husband and I split the Mexico Scramble and the French Toast Tahiti..
The scramble came with roasted potatoes that were to die for. I mean. it's so easy to screw up on potatos. but Zazie's are soooo GOOD and I'm not even a potato person.

The servers are hands down attentive and friendly--considering we brought our 1 year old and our friend's 3-month old baby.

Highly recommend!!!

ps: I do like the No-Tip policy; hence their prices are a bit on the higher range. But man.. a resto who gives workers benefits? That's awesome!!
author: Monica H.

description:
Always wanted to come here for lunch but got a chance to walk in for dinner and luckily some people didn't show up for their reservation. I would suggest having a reservation since the place is somewhat tiny and it gets busy quick 

I ended up having the Cassoulet piallat (which was delicious) and a Le Metro (good but too much ice). 

Definitely going to come here again for brunch sometime
author: S J.

description:
I literally felt like I was visiting a family member's house for dinner when I visited last week! e had a reservation for 6 on a thursday night for a friend's birthday. From the moment we walked in the door to the moment we left, I felt like each person in the restaurant was incredibly warm and welcoming, service I am not used to receiving in restaurants. I love their options for prie fixe for dinner ($39 for appetizer, entree and dessert) as well as a la carte. We ordered a cheese plate for the table and had brought in our own wine ($20 corkage fee) which they were accommodating of and gave no judgement! 

Our table tried a large portion of the menu from Trout, to the pasta, to seafood and beef, everyone LOVED their meals. I don't think there is any choice that will steer you wrong.

Going forward I will make sure to sit on their adorable patio and visit on a tuesday night for no corkage fee!
author: Lauren M.

description:
Recommend: divorceé poached egg 

A perfectly poached egg that oozes slowly when cut made the long wait worth it. Loved the quaint feels of this place.
author: Hanna K.

description:
This is my most recent brunch discovery in SF. Located in Cole Valley, it's easy to spot because it's the place with the line. Inside there's a nice variety of seating, including a patio area. But here's the pro tip: the tables out front are first come, first served. People will stand on the sidewalk, literally staring at an open table while the nimble simply sit down. So unless you have some compelling need to have your name called out from a list, after waiting out on the sidewalk, take a seat!

I had something called the Griddle Flight--which I think should be called the Griddle Fight because it's catchier. It's a sampler of the buttermilk pancakes, gingerbread pancakes, and French Toast. It's a great option for those days when you just need carbs and can't decide how to satisfy it! Add a side of their chicken-apple sausage and you've got the makings of some fun!

They also make their own tomatillo salsa, which is simply awesome.
author: Dave S.

description: Love their brunch! Whenever I'm back home, my friend and I always catch up and eat here! We always split the la mer Benedict and their pancakes. The staff have always been sweet and the food comes fast. It's always crowded during brunch, just a warning! But it's definitely worth it! There are tables in the front that are first come first serve, so if you don't mind sitting outside, just be diligent in spotting people leaving.
author: Veronica I.

description: Food was delicious. Service was amazing. A bit of a wait, but completely worth it. Went for brunch, but will definitely go for dinner some time. Excited to know they have a dog night, since I have a service dog. Parking can be a bit of a problem, but is a short walk from several muni lines. I consider this a great place to gather with friends or have a date night. Very close to Haight street, so a nice place to eat after shopping. A must go in the heart of the city.
author: Jamye K.

description:
Definitely a fan.

The Good
* I went on a Friday around 11am, sure there was a line, as usual, but I was dining in solo. The wait wasn't too bad, 20 minutes?
* Very quick and nice service
* I ordered the Pierre Noir (with bacon and tomatoes provençales) which is one of the Eggs Benedict options. PERFECTLY poached eggs. And the bread was soft and I didn't have to arm wrestle with the knife. I love it because it was good and simple, although they made it sound super fancy.
* They heavily advertise that they are a "tip-free" restaurant and claim that their menu prices already cover full benefits of the employee staff -- pretty cool

The Bad
* only the wait is "bad"

The Weird
* So since they heavily advertise that they are a "tip-free" restaurant, I was very skeptical because it's my nature to wonder why people wouldn't want money... So I am totally like.. yeahh... right. Ok, this is a guilt scam to make you feel like you need to tip now. BUTTTTTT when I got my check to sign, there was NO tip option, there wasn't even a place to put tip if I paid with credit card or debit card. And on the receipt it said something like.. yes, no tip, we mean it! It was only then that I realized they really meant it. PRETTY COOL if ya ask me. 

And yes, I did tip because I thought it was cool, and food and service was great.
author: Juliann C.

description:
I came here for brunch with two of my girlfriends and it was AMAZING!!! 

Ambiance: There is always a wait, but it's worth it at a good place like this. There are a bunch of tables inside, and a really cute outdoor patio out back.

Food: Everything was 5/5! We got the smoked salmon benedict, which you can get with 2 or 3 eggs, which was perfect since we were 3 people splitting everything. We also got the challah french toast dipped in a bourboun sauce (holiday special) which was so delicious. The last thing we got was an omelete with avocado and brie cheese and chicken apple sausage (a special). All portions were huge and hearty enough for 3 people.

I will definitely be coming here agin!!
author: Jenna G.

description:
TLDR: If you're looking for a stable job that takes care of you, your family, and maybe your dog/ cat/ pet cactus, apply here. If you're thinking of eating here, take consideration of price and wait time. If you proceed with your decision to come here, get the sausage, it's tasty :). Also ideal party size for quicker seating is 2.

On the scale of 1 to SF, this place gets a pretty SF.

No reservations, an hour and a half wait, signs they tell you to not ask about wait times and to calculate your own by multiplying about 3min to each table before you, coffee that comes in a bowl instead of cup, a menu that provides transparency to how Zazie is tip free since the food prices already include paid sick leave, health/dental insurance, paid maternity and paternity leave as well as 401k matching for the employees of Zazie.


We came here for brunch. We were a group of 5 and we came at 11am on a Sunday morning. It was a 1.5 hour wait.

I got the Genevieve scrambled eggs which had Black Forest ham, white cheddar, and avocados and potatoes for $16. I also added a side of sausages since I was hungrier. The eggs and cheese were okay/ avocado okay/ the potatoes were pretty good - crispy and not dry/ The extra sausages on the side were the right choice, they were juicy and tasty. The food took about 30-40 minutes to make after we ordered.

Giving this place a 3 considering the food quality when compared to meals I had of comparable price (tax + tip included).
author: Derrick C.

description: Cute little brunch spot! We ordered the Monaco benedict and miracle pancakes, which were both very delicious. The flavor of the pancakes that week were cornmeal with lemon curd and strawberries, which was a great combo. Minus 1 star for running out of the cream cheese coffee cake. We went early Monday morning, but that shouldn't be an excuse! I guess I'll just have to check it out again.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Clearly a very popular brunch location...renowned for its benedict and mimosas. Was surprised by how good the service was considering how busy it was, the food came out quicky and was very tasty. Fresh, light and flavoursome, the hollandaise was exceptional. 

Would come back.
author: James D.

description:
Got here on a busy sat at 1230 and the line was so long. Luckily it was only 2 in my party and we snatched front door seating (first come, first serve). It's a little awkward to sit up front because there are so many people standing around you waiting for a table, so they would be watching you eat but it took a long time for us to get our food and by then half the parties were seated. 

I got 1 French toast with fruits and 1 miracle pancake ($9 each). I guess they make the miracle pancakes differently on the day? I was looking forward to some poppyseed lemon curd but I got bread pudding pancakes with banana and whipped cream. Boo. They weren't bad but they just didn't taste done since its wet in the middle. French toast wasn't anything special either. The bf got the Albert poached egg ($18) and it was soggy, maybe from the salsa? 

I wouldn't come back but glad I can say I tried this place and didn't have to wait at all bc I would be angry to wait for mediocre food. No tipping is an interesting concept but the prices basically include it...and a little more. Bill came out to 40$ after tax.
author: Elle C.

description:
Hands down, best breakfast in The City.

There isn't a thing that isn't DELICIOUS here! The Mimosas, the coffee, the eggs, everything is to die for. They have three different size options for most of the breakfast items, which is AWESOME, why don't other restaurants do this???

Also, gratuity is included, so you know their employees are happy and taken care of, which is fantastic and helps when you go out with friends. 

There is a wait, be prepared! Or have an order of cream cheese coffee cake while you wait.... :D
author: D M.

description: Our crab benedict had a bunch of shells in it that we picked out and set in a pile on our plate. Are three banana pancakes had to single little slices of banana on them not enough for one. The ingredients were fresh but the staff was not. They were out and I might have just caught them on a bad day so I will give them the benefit of the doubt and say that they are inconsistent at best. There are too many good places in San Francisco to go to return. If you want a consistently good breakfast, go to plow and get anything on the menu
author: Zeke S.

description:
Zazie means business. They have bright yellow signs plastered on their window front explaining their process. Sign your name and wait to be seated. If you're wondering about the wait time, don't ask, just add 3 minutes for everyone ahead of you. Unless...you're a vulture. The seats outside of the restaurant are first come, first serve. So, if you'd rather stand over those seats as you observe people slowly eat their brunch, you could do that too. I just decided to grab some coffee than play the game. 

I stared at the menu for quite some time because I couldn't choose which eggs benedict to have. They all sounded great, but I ended up with the St. Trop, which was the salmon and man that salmon was wild. Loved every bite of it. 

I was also pleasantly surprised with their tip free policy. They don't try to trick you because there's not even a line to add a tip when you get your bill. The "tip free" is real.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Zazie's has good brunch food - there's no denying that. But is it overhyped?? YES. It is NOT worth the 2-3 hour wait even if you come right when it opens. 

I ordered their Cafe Au Lait ($4.70) and 2 Poached Eggs La Mer ($24). The roasted potatoes were awesome (see my Outerlands Post for description of how much I love potatoes). But it (the 2 poached eggs la mer style) really wasn't mindblowing. I'd say I waited for a much shorter period of time for brunch at Mission Beach Cafe and Outerlands and the food there was equally as delicious. 
The Cafe Au Lait was comforting and I liked that they served it in a bowl. Other than that, it wasn't particularly memorable as a beverage. 

We sat in their back patio and I can see why people recommend asking for that location. Its quaint and charming - A bit crowded because there is limited space but much better ambiance than sitting inside or outside with everyone waiting/watching you.

There aren't that many great tips because a wait will be inevitable unless you arrive way before it opens (but then isn't that also a wait?). No tips as the price on the menu incorporates tips in it. Credit cards are okay. Service is excellent despite the hustle and bustle of the place.

I've heard Zazie may be even better for dinner. Perhaps I'll come back and give that a go.
author: Nicole J.

description: Ordered crab Benedict! Great dish with light flavors. It gets really busy so make sure you have a back up plan while you wait! Parking in cole valley is usually free too!
author: SY T.

description:
Absolutely solid brunch...and my first in SF ever (visiting from New York). Beautiful, cozy and bright establishment in a nice neighborhood with a fun, unique menu (including challah french toast and gingerbread pancakes with powdered sugar...hell...yes...)

Everything is fresh and full of healthy flavor...not the greasy "I'm going to regret this later" type. Absolutely check Zazie out. I will be back.
author: Danny E.

description:
This place sounds like an animal name from a cat and dog adventure movie, and I'm pretty sure it's cause you'll feel Homeward Bound http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107131/ before you even order an appetizer. The inside is like a grander version of your grandma's house and has some of the better service in San Franciso I've ever received. 

Typically known for breakfast, but our group grabbed a reservation for their Tuesday night BYOB policy. They chilled our bottle, brought fresh baked bread, and made us feel super special before even asking for our order. 

Food wise, I had a delicious pasta, but it was oh so overshadowed by a French onion soup that I can't stop thinking about over a week later. Not a person in our group said anything but mmmmmm and it was super affordable since there wasn't a corkage. 

Zazie you're one coooool cat!
author: Danny W.

description: Definitely worth the wait (which wasn't long). Food was delicious, waitress was knowledgeable and friendly. Cozy little atmosphere. If sitting inside is not your thing you can wait to sit outside.
author: Malena R.

description:
Eggs cooked to perfection. So is the French toast says my daughter. Ordered the omelette du jour. asked for it to be soft inside and that is what it was exactly.
Apple sausage was exact .
A terrific experience and hope to come back
author: Ravi S.

description: The food was oily but very yummy. What made the experience a 3 star is the bearded waiter that was extremely rude and not in the service business. We sat in the back patio and honestly it was a great table.
author: Mariam A.

description:
Zazie is famous for their breakfasts - but their evening menu is also outstanding.

We came here last night for Tuesday dinner and it was lovely.

Zazie is charming at night (they even have a heat lamp adorned outside area) and their service is exceptional and personable.

They also offer no corkage fee on Tuesday - so our wonderful group organizer had the foresight to bring three bottles of wine - which our server opened right away. He even chilled the white wine for us (though I didn't partake)

I had the grilled wine salmon with parsnip puree and brussels sprouts. It was phenomenal and cooked perfectly. The salmon was so flavorful and the parsnip mash was finished quickly.

If you're looking for an intimate dinner spot with friends or a loved one - come to Zazie on Tuesday. Bring your favorite wine and your appetite (their dessert menu looks incredible) and relax.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: I took my husband for the Father's day dinner and they sure made it very special. I was very apprehensive of taking my dog as they were allowed only on the outdoor seating and I also had a baby. But they assured me that we would definitely enjoy the outdoor seating and it indeed was very cozy and warm. Despite the cold weather outside, we didn't feel any discomfort as they promised. In fact we enjoyed the outdoor seating a lot! They were kind to accommodate the food request for our fur baby Max too. She enjoyed her chicken patty made specially for her.The food was delicious. I ordered the duck and my husband the pork chops and they were just lip smacking. My 16 month old enjoyed not just his pasta but small bites of the duck too. Their house speciality dessert did end our dinner literally on a very sweet note. I would definitely recommend Zazie if you are looking for a place to dine on a special occasion or celebrate an important event. And the people who work there surely go he extra mile to make your dinner experience special.
author: Sandhya K.

description:
Here we go again. I'm about to write another incredibly dramatic but well-deserved review. But honestly, what is there to say to say that probably hasn't been written in one of the hundreds of reviews below?

Zazie is the perfect San Francisco brunch. Go ahead and start your meal off with a miracle pancake to take your early morning meal from 0 to 1000, then throw in some french toast, poached eggs, and a specialty mimosa. You'll be in heaven the rest of the day and dreaming of the perfectly fluffy and decadent pancakes. Literally, this place is flawless.  #dramaover
author: Sarah H.

description:
The wait was not nearly as bad as the line up made it seem. We were seated in 30min at prime brunch time on a Saturday. 

I had the eggs Monaco and the wifey had the eggs Florentine. Both were good, but not blow-your-mind-and-redefine-the-meaning-of-brunch good. 

If the wait had been more than an hour, I probably would not have been as happy as I was when I left. We also shared a lemon poppy sour cream pancake.

Tip - They have a homemade habanero hot sauce which was great with the homefries.
author: Matt R.

description:
ZAZIE you are a beautiful thing. Your bubbly+juice drinks fit whatever mood I'm in. You have some of the best classic brunch foods in SF, and each one is just sooo perfectly done. You're a little pricey but hey, you're well worth it. You don't need a big portion when you take your time and enjoy your food. I just wish I didn't have to fight all of SF for you, even at weird off hours.

I like you best when I get off night shift and wait outside your door with the rest of my nursing homies until you open and we're already a little drunk off sleep deprivation and then we all have a couple glasses of bubbly because man, we're gonna sleep well after this.
author: Vivian H.

description: I'm one of those guilty Yelpers that typically only hops on Yelp to flame a place for a horrible experience, so hopefully that context helps in my review of Zazie: Jen and her team, continuously go above and beyond for their patrons.  They are excellent at special occasions, and can make any birthday or anniversary memorable.  In this case, it was a double surprise, in which I figured out that the Mrs had planned a surprise anniversary dinner at Zazie (same venue as our wedding dinner). One email to Jen and she helped me scheme an over the top surprise for the Mrs.  The restaurant accepted my floral deliveries, provided champagne on arrival, and gave us dark corner on the patio (the very corner we sat in for our wedding dinner, in fact) with white table service etc.  So my surprise dinner successfully turned into my wife's surprise dinner.  Everything was executed perfectly, and communication between all of the staff was perfect.  Not one ball was dropped.  ...and as usual, the food was spectacular.  I'm not a neighborhood regular by any means, but every time I come, I feel as if I'm Zazie's number one customer.
author: Brian F.

description: me and my sis were smart enough to come on a tuesday !! we waited only 20 minutes but that's because we wanted to be seated in the lovely garden/patio area. wait was a little longer inside would've been seated in 5 min. so first of all the potatoes are yum yum yum. scrambled eggs are delightful for being scrambled eggs. the miracle pancake was a a pleasantly new experience for my mouth. i had buttermilk pancakes at 4am that same day out of a box. i still enjoyed that! but the pancake here was scrumptious and the presentation was much much better. that jam on the table was getting me so excited to eat toast. looked so good! i can't give it this place the full 5 because it is pricey and when you've had amazing brunch for cheaper and you are aware of that it somehow takes away from the experience. just a tiny dent! especially when you're the one paying lololol. but if you ain't got a problem paying $15 for one eggs benedict then power to you. i would come back over and over !!
author: Reese A.

description:
Brunch the morning away,
Down in LGBTQQIAS Paris!
Brunch the morning away,
On the Champz Aziesees!

Mais, c'est vrais...

Broken kitchen equipment.
So opening 15 mins late.
Wait inside & comp drink.

Side order was warm...ish.
Main dish wasn't.
Yet the garlic garnish was.

A popular spot for nurses.
Nurses get crunk at 8am.
Scrubs get #turntup #anns

Zut! zut! et zut!

Brunch the morning away,
Down in GBLTAIQSQ Paris!
Brunch the morning away,
Eat it hangry!
http://youtu.be/-ApY6w3o1Tc
author: Dan B.

description:
All time favorite brunch place. Must get here early to get a seat on the weekends. We were there 20 minutes early and got seating in the first round. 

My go-to dishes are the crab cake Benedict and the French toast Tahiti. Perfect to share with someone and get a savory and sweet meal. The best part about the savory dishes are the potatoes that come with it. Usually breakfast potatoes are dry and boring but these are to die for. Gingerbread pancakes are also very yummy but can get pretty dry so I prefer the super moist French toast!
Their chai latte is awesome and comes in a bowl. Fun to drink! 

Everything here is made with amazing ingredients and always turns out perfectly. Every brunch meal I've had pales in comparison to Zazie. I also love the way they compensate their employees with a living wage, 401k, paid maternity/paternity leave- Way to go! Things may seem pricey on the menu but remember- tip is included!
author: Caitlin H.

description: I waited in line for about 40 minutes, but oh lord, it was so good. I ordered the French toast Tahiti and Monaco, which is thought to be two of the best items on the menu. I started with the French toast, which was sweet and had bananas with nuts. I then followed up with the Monaco, a savory eggs Benedict with tangy tomato and potatoes on the side. Both absolutely delicious and blew me away. I hardly give out 5 stars unless I am.
author: Toni T.

description: Long wait for brunch but well worth it. The food was great. Outdoor seating is available. Portions are large as well.
author: Ruby L.

description: Pure deliciousness and their service was polite and prompt. I was put on the wait list for Saturday brunch, I went next door for a coffee while I waited, and the owner came over to get me when my table was ready. So nice. Food was fabulous - stuffed French toast is a definite do. Their chai tea is great. Would recommend to anyone.
author: Jamie G.

description:
Got here w/ a party of 8, @ 8:30AM on a rainy Saturday morning! We eventually split up into 4 per table, but knew that it was inevitable having us all together despite the small room. 

Interior: 1 Star

The inside of Zazie's was a remarkable vintage look with polished wooden tables and brick wall. Although the inside of the place was well designed with a homey vibe, a downside would be how it is less spacious than it ought to be. But The quality of the food here makes up for the crowdedness!

Service: 2 Star

The service was very quick. They were very good about accomodating to small changes our table made (so one star for quick service). Also, since they seemed pretty busy in seating a whole line of people into Zazie's I'd say they did the best they could to accomodating to others in a very respectable/friendly way (so another star for that as well).

Food: 2 Star

So I got a Poached Monaco and Hot Chocolate w/ no whip cream. The monaco was nonetheless amazingly done well, the hot chocolate was def different from general hot chocolate. The hollandaise sauce has a distinct yet quality taste as well as their prosciutto. So 2 stars for their homemade hot chocolate and monaco.

Overall, the experience here has been very memorable. So I would def be coming nack here despite their long wait. Best brunch place so far!
author: Joanne D.

description: Enjoyed the meal here for brunch- sitting in the garden was really what made it delightful. I would return for this experience but probably not to sit in the main space or out front. Nice to go somewhere that actually just puts a living wage cost into the menu prices instead of a tip system! Appreciate that. Thanks Zazie
author: J K.

description:
This place is so hyped up, so why am I even bothering to write a review? I'll be honest, it's mostly because I think it's worth pointing out that (as of June 2015) they have a really great no-tipping policy. According to their menu, "Our menu prices include a living wage, profit sharing, fully funded health & dental insurance, paid sick leave, and a 401(k) with employer match for all our hard working employees." Definitely something I'm down to stand behind, considering how broken the system of tipping is in America. Props to Zazie for being willing to raise prices in order to build in a fair wage and benefits for their employees.

No-tipping policy aside, Zazie serves up a pretty great brunch. You can tell by the lines on weekends that brunch here is serious business. Don't be scared off, though, the line moves fairly fast (probably averages an hour wait for 2-4 people), and the host is crazy efficient with the process: they really know how to run a brunch place in SF. Plus, there's a Peet's next door so you can grab coffee while you wait...but don't stray too far, they don't seat you until the whole party is there!

Anyway, enough about the lines, here's some tips (see what I did there?) about the food: Zazie is best experienced with friends. And by that I mean, grab a friend or two and split a few dishes, some savory and some sweet, so you can get the best of both brunch worlds. My personal favorites:
- Eggs La Mer: In simpler terms, this is a Crabs Eggs Benedict, and it is amazing. Everything you love about crab and avocado and poached eggs in one fantastic combination. Also comes with a side of deliciously well-seasoned home fries.
- If you're into spice, ask for the house-made hot sauce: It's really spicy and will give everything a nice kick!
- Gingerbread Pancakes: I'm not particularly into gingerbread, but this is dish is really, really good. The pancakes are soft and thick and fluffy, and the light gingerbread flavor goes really well with the poached pears and butter. It melts in your mouth in the best way.

A friend once described this place as "a San Francisco staple" and I completely understand why. Definitely come by, wait in line, and try brunch here at least once!
author: Brittany C.

description: Love the cozy, personalized decor and service in this place. Came here for dinner on a Sunday night. We didn't have trouble finding a table. Trust me this is the best way to beat Monday blues, on the Sundays when GoT is not playing :) Food is amazing - very farm to table and so fresh. I am vegetarian, there were tons of options. Highly recommend the grilled summer corn cake. So healthy and delicious! My husband tried the Moroccan Lamb Tagine and he absolutely loved it! Definitely one of our favorite places in the city :)
author: A S.

description: Be prepared to wait a long time for a table for brunch, but you can make reservations for dinner which is the meal we prefer there anyway. My worst meal was a raw, doughy monte cristo, but the cassoulet is divine, as is the Mediterranean veggie platter and desserts.
author: Nancy R.

description:
Restaurant is upside down: prices are high, food is okay, and waiters are practically invisible. 

High notes: located in the neighborhood (convenient); bus staff is friendly and courteous; free corkage night (Tues.); the ambiance is pleasant; the management's effort to pay fair wages; no rushing you out at end of meal; reservations are honored. 
 
Suggestions: (1) More table waiters--one waiter to cover the patio tables on a Friday night is just unacceptable and actually provides little to no quality control of anything; (2) Don't rush the cooking or delivery of food to table--the entrees arrived during appetizer course and the pork chop was dried out; (3) Visit the table during meal--"how's the pork chop?" "more wine?" "more water?"...nothing!; (4) When guests ask to take home half of the uneaten meal at end of evening, the waiter should make sure it isn't thrown out...but if that happens (and sometimes it does), the waiter should take the meal off the bill...especially when only half is uneaten; (5) Updated/improved wine list; (6) Pay attention, pay attention, pay attention: watch what's going on...perhaps a manager on-site, perhaps more staff, perhaps fewer customers/tables?

In short, I like Zazie and have been a customer since it opened as it's close to home but it's not cheap and because of that it should start acting like what it is: a mid- to upper-priced bistro with a nice menu in a neighborhood that's willing to visit and pay its prices. Pick up the speed. Improve quality of everything. For those of us are not able to stand in line on a weekend day for a sub-standard dining experience, please make the effort to ensure that the weeknight dinner experience attempts to exceed the (current) mediocre standard.
author: Jez M.

description:
Firstly, always expect 1-1.5 hours of waiting time for weekend brunches in San Francisco, no matter where it is. Unless you're pressed on times and want to use one of those apps where people wait for you. The waiting time here, has also to do with the extremely small seating space inside.

The only reason I'm giving this rating is probably because I've had brunch at almost all the known, famous places in SF and this one didn't really stand out in anyway (harsh, I know).

I ordered a latte and the french toast tahiti. The french toast was good, but again I've had much better at many places in SF.
author: Nitish S.

description:
This is the place for brunch in San Francisco. The dinner menu has great (and more specifically) French cuisine.  I've had most of the dinner menu and nothing dissapoints.
The restaurant is cooperatively operated with the staff (real benefits to all).  It shows because the service is always friendly and prompt.
author: Ryan I.

description:
3 1/2 really.  Long lines, horrendous parking but very nice setting.  Decent menu on the pricey side but likely the result of no tipping policy.  Food presentation was quite nice but slightly smallish.  I had the lobster Benedict that was disappointing.  Lacking flavor I thought plus the chopped lobster meat wasn't the tastiest.  My wife had the very good Tahiti French toast which again was on the smaller side.

Decent place to go to if you're in the area.
author: Joel M.

description:
I took my wife here for brunch on a weekend after a good friend recommended it and we both LOVED the food and the service. We got there early and the line was still pretty long, but we were still able to be seating within 20 minutes. I would definitely recommend coming at a less busy time though. They serve the most incredible brunch. I would say this is my favorite brunch spot.

And they have a rule where there do not accept tips and would prefer better pay (I love the forward thinking). Everyone that was working there was super friendly and polite. The ambiance is really nice as well. It has a hole-in-the-wall feel to it. It is small and quaint, but really welcoming.

The french toast and the pancakes were personally my favorite!

I would highly recommend this place!!!!
author: Umang P.

description:
One of the few times I've knowingly agreed to visit a brunch place known to have over hour long waits, because I figured, hey, I was in the good company of Alice L. Now, while the latter was true, the wait still sucked, and, with waits like this, the expectations are raised exponentially. We ended up getting a smattering of dishes (to compensate for the long wait, in a way), including:

* Brunch Flight (Challah French Toast, Lemon Ricotta Pancake, Gingerbread Pancake) - A little something our waiter helped put together for us to help us save a few bucks, since we were ordering one of each of these anyway. The Challah French toast had good texture, but was on the bland side (especially compared to the Tahiti), while the pancakes were both enjoyable, but slightly denser and sweeter than I would have preferred. 

* French Toast Tahiti - On first bite and impression, the Tahiti is a pretty tasty dish. By the second bite though, you start to find that it's a bit too sweet (even without the additional syrup), and a bit too mushy, with very little to offset the softness of both the toast and the bananas.

* Albert Eggs Benedict - Maybe I just like my savory foods more, but this was definitely the best of the bunch. Even then though, I found it a bit lacking. Also, I think this is the first time I've ever had shredded, unmelted cheese on a benedict.

So, in the end, nothing really wowed me. If not for the wait, Zazie is easily 3 stars, but, for an an hour and a half, the food better be fucking outstanding. In the case of Zazie, I can't in good conscience bring myself here again when there are tastier, shorter options elsewhere.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The venue is a bit on the tighter side, with tables arranged in such a way that they're not all accessible. That said, there's enough accessible seating that you shouldn't face any issues.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Aw shucks, Zazie's didn't live up to its hype. We were seated right away on a Sunday morning and ordered all the popular items; the tahiti french toast, miracle pancake, cream cheese coffee cake, and the divorcee poached eggs. We also had two glasses of mimosas (the mango and grapefruit) which were pretty strong, but that's a good thing!

The house potatoes that came with the poached eggs was the best part of our meal. They were actually the best house potatoes my friend and I have ever tasted! Perfect amount of flavor and they were crunchy!

Tahiti French toast: The sweetness was overpowering. Tasted more like a dessert item.
Miracle Pancakes: The texture was nice but overall it was just a basic pancake.What part was the miracle?
Cream cheese coffee cake: The filling was warm but it tasted like it was a couple days old. Had that packaging flavor...ehh
Divorcee Poached Eggs: Everything was good. I just wished the english muffin wasn't so tough. The potatoes on the side were delicious though!

I was really hoping to love Zazie's because of everything I heard about it. Sadly, it didn't play out like that. I did enjoy that you can order an order of "just one" of items. Love that concept!
author: Dara S.

description:
I really like this restaurant a lot. Its odd that I've yet to review it. Here is what you need to know:

1. There is a huge wait. (Even before they open.)
2. Everything is great.
3. There is no parking. Take a Lyft.

Everything is wonderful about this gem except that everybody knows about it and is willing to wait for it. I'm willing to wait and that says a lot. We've got too many places that fly under the radar to wait except Zazie. It's worth it. I've only come for brunch and I love it. I don't think it's five star though although I can't think of the reason right this second why. Maybe I need to come back another dozen times to figure it out.

Try the La Mer Benedict with Dungeness Crab and Avocado. Wow!
author: Justin S.

description:
When you go to these dainty-cute places like Zazie, you gotta deal with these dainty-cute situations.

Dainty-Cute Situation #1
Zazie is dead serious about NO SUBSTITUTIONS. I figured that after waiting an hour and a half for a table, asking for a substitution of cheddar cheese wouldn't be too much. But what do I know about hospitality? 

Dainty-Cute Situation #2
I ordered a Large OJ and they brought it out in a below-average sized glass. Well, sure am glad that I didn't order a small or else I would've been serve Orange Juice in a shot glass!

Dainty-Cute Situation #3
The bill comes and this is one of those places where the customer pays for the Health Coverage of the employees. Cool. The owner passes the cost of his employees on to us and he can't make an allowance for substitutions or serve reasonable sized orange juice?

With that being said, Zazie IS pretty darn dainty-cute, and their potatoes are crispy good. But those dainty-cute situations ain't really my cup of tea, so I'm not dying to go back yadada
author: Ringo M.

description:
My absolute favorite brunch spot by far! And let me tell you, I've tried my fair share. How I haven't posted a review yet is beyond me (although its probably my subconscious selfishly not wanting any more people to know about them than already do!).

Always busy and bustling, no matter what time or day of the week. I cannot speak warmly enough of the staff, but ESPECIALLY Mario!! He is fantastic and makes every visit that much better. Mario is so friendly and accommodating, always seats me out on the back patio that I love so much and sometimes even brings me a little something extra to make my morning even sweeter.

Their Monaco Benedict (with prosciutto and tomatoes provençales) has absolutely ruined me, as in I can no longer order any Benedict anywhere else because theirs is so consistently fantastic and delicious, and no other restaurant can hold a candle to them. I can't help but order this every single time I go (with maybe one or two exceptions); it's always perfect and I haven't gotten slightly tired of it in over three years!

Another favorite would be the Mexico Scramble (with chorizo, white cheddar, and salsa) which is absolutely delicious and dripping with goodness. I love their potatoes (especially the gooey, whole roasted cloves of garlic) but often choose salad instead for something light. Any of their miracle pancakes are incredible, and I have been dying to try the bread pudding ones but unfortunately these are (obviously) incredibly popular and I don't often make it in early enough! Their Oatmeal Brulee with bruleed bananas or French Toast Tahiti are both delightful sweet dishes.

This review is reaching book proportions, but I should mention their chai and espresso drinks come in giant bowls that are both impressive and delicious, though I am happy enough with just a cup of their drip coffee. 

Lastly, the owner of Zazie is a wonderful woman who also came from waiting in the service industry and has worked hard to make sure her staff is taken good care of and know they are not just interchangeable. They all receive full benefits, dental, paid sick leave, 401k, and profit sharing. They recently made news by becoming the first restaurant in San Francisco to become tip free! While this may mean a slightly steeper price for each menu item, I for one am happily go out of my way to support and frequent a restaurant that cares about the "little guy" and makes sure we service industry workers are treated right and receive a truly livable wage.

PS. If you're scared off by the line, head nextdoor to Finnegan's Wake for a drink before. Just let Mario know you'll be there, and remember to bring cash!
author: Sophie H.

description:
Another great, great place for brunch in SF!

As expected, parking is difficult around the area. Once you get within a couple blocks of the place, just start looking for parking, as you're not likely to find much very close. 

The interior of the restaurant is really small with limited seating. They do have outdoor seating both in front and back of the restaurant as well. The line seemed to move fairly quick, which was a pleasant surprise. The service was also great. Great recommendations and very friendly.

The food was amazing! It is pricey, but I believe that's because of their no tipping policy, so it's essentially built into the bill. My latte literally came in a bowl, which was pretty awesome. I tried the Monaco, which was delicious. Their lemon hollandaise sauce really is good. The home fries were also cooked perfectly with a nice crisp crunch to them. Also tried Sarah Jane's Griddle Flight. Highly, highly recommend this dish if you can't decide what kind of pancake you want. The gingerbread pancake was delicious! They let us put in the egg nog french toast as well, which was surprisingly tasty! If you like egg nog, you'll like this. 

All in all, great brunch spot in SF. A must try when you're in the city!
author: Marc H.

description:
The service was great. It was MLK day and they closed at 3pm, our party of four came at 2:30pm, our waitress was patient and in no rush. I appreciated that fact because usually other restaurants will turn you away due to kitchen closing. 

I ordered the gingerbread pancakes. They were really good and when they came the smell of gingerbread reminded me of Christmas all over again. I was ready to eat!! The pancake slices are thick and I ordered one and I was already full. It came with a slice of pear and lemon sauce that surprising paired well. I would definitely order them again. It was good I would come back again!
author: Kaycee-zhanel C.

description:
Yum!  This place was pretty good.  I don't think it was amazing to have a huge crowd outside.  It was ridiculously busy!  There must have been 20-30 people outside waiting for a table!!!  They won't seat your group unless the whole party is there.  I don't think this place was worth the wait.  Just tasted like a typical breakfast place with a very nice outdoor seating area.  I think this place is mainly for the atmosphere.  Way over hyped, but I did enjoy the environment. For breakfast, I can definitely go else where for the same or better quality.  It was pretty pricey too for the amount of food I got!  

I got the "Monaco" for $15 (before tax and tip).  Came with two eggs Benedict and a side of potatoes or salad.  My eggs were perfectly cooked, but my friend's wasn't.  His was really over cooked, yolk was practically solid.  My eggs were oozing out when I cut into it, perfect!  Flavors were good.  Had a decent amount of prosciutto.  I got my Benedict with a side of salad.  The salad was super simple! Just some super plain mixed greens and some really light dressing (no flavor in the dressing).  Definitely nothing special at all about the salad.  

Good breakfast food with a very nice atmosphere, but not worth the long wait and price for breakfast.  It's hard to mess up on breakfast, so I could definitely go elsewhere for better price and just the same or better.  Glad I got to try this place, but would probably go somewhere else next time.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Excellent customer service and the wait was not as long as I thought it would be! I ordered the Mediterranean Vegetable plate and as a vegan, it was a very good option to have. Asked for the aoili and the feta on the side and they were more than happy to accommodate. The portions are not as big for the price, which is why I am giving it 4 stars, but other than that I would definitely come back. The pricing is higher, because tip is included, so don't be alarmed at the prices. I had to order a piece of toast on the side to eat with the veggies to make a veggie toast, which I highly recommend to add more bulk to the meal and make it more filling. A little on the oily side, but not in a disgusting way.
author: Rinny S.

description:
I finally got the chance to try this place out after repeatedly seeing pictures on IG and its name mentioned in articles. I came here on a Tuesday a little before noon and had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. Not sure if all the workers were having a bad day, but they seemed unwelcoming and irritated. 

I ordered the French toast Tahiti with a side of home fries. For the price of the food, I thought the portions would be big or the food would be bomb.com but it was neither. The French toast was decent. The toast were thick and there was an oatmeal paste?? in between the slices which gave the French toast a step up from eh to decent. The caramelized bananas didn't really excite my taste buds since it was tasteless to me. The only reason I gave this review 2 stars instead of 1 was because of the home fries. They put whole garlic cloves with it which I loved. The potatoes itself was dull and disappointing. 

This place seemed overrated to me and I don't see myself coming back.
author: Cindy M.

description: Zazie was the best meal we had during our road trip vacation. The days we were in SF were filled with rain. Traveling with dogs, we were constantly eating at restaurants that has patios or sidewalk. A friend recommended Zazie. Being cold and wet (both humans and dogs) the sight of their warm and cozy patio was a wonderful treat. We came when the restaurant just opened, so the patio was only us. The steak and the duck leg dishes were exquisite. Duck was soft, not chewy, and perfectly seasoned. My s.o. is someone who is not a fan of mushroom, but the mushroom in the steak dish was seasoned so well that he finished it all. We were all very happy customers.
author: Minh N.

description:
My all-time favorite brunch spot in SF.

I ordered the La Mer  and my friend ordered the Mexican Scramble.  I thought both were excellent.

The La Mer has just the right amount of fresh crab and perfectly poached eggs.  This place is consistent every time.  You can decide on your own portions, 1-3 poached eggs.

I only come here on the weekdays due to the insanely long line on the weekends.  It's usually about 1 hr wait on Saturday/Sunday.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Lines, lines, lines! And wait, wait, wait!

But PATIO. And love of dogs. And delicious food. 

Oh, Zazie, heart you always!!
author: Elle N M.

description:
A must... Food is super good. Still haven't tried the "Miracle Pancakes" just gives me another reason to revisit this place. The buttermilk pancakes and French Toast are insanely delicious. 
Mimosa's and specialty drinks are on point!
author: Don W.

description:
Where to begin?  My family and I came here for brunch as my brother talked Zazie up as one of his favorite local spots.  There are many things I love about this place. My first impression of this quaint restaurant is that the French stylings are very classy and beautiful. The menu is unique and made me want to order everything just to try the different flavors.  We split a pancake flight and then ordered separate savory dishes to share.

I ordered a one egg combo with chicken apple sausage, garlic potatoes, and wheat bread.  The bread is made right in the restaurant and is some of the best bread I've ever tasted.  The subtle blend of apple with chicken also provided a hint of sweet and savory in each bite.  My favorite pancake was their staple gingerbread pancake as their mixture of pears, gingerbread, and lemon is the perfect blend.

Another unique favorite of mine is they do not expect tips as their employees share revenues and have fringe benefits.

You win, Zazie, you win.
author: Maita B.

description:
I would give this charming restaurant with good food a nice review, were it not for the bizarre and disturbing behavior of our waiter. He seemed friendly, casual, and hip, tall with a porkpie hat and I *think* an Australian accent, not sure about that. As we were finishing our appetizers, the couple at the table nearest us gave us their bottle of wine, which still had a third left and they didn't want to waste it. That was a nice surprise. The waiter saw the bottle on our table and came over to charge us a corkage fee, but we explained the situation. He said, "They should have given me that bottle!" We thought he was trying to be funny, but maybe he really meant it, because he went off to get himself a glass. He asked if he could taste the wine, which was already weird, but we said sure. He poured himself a WHOLE GLASS and walked off. Then, near the end of the meal, when there was still a bit of wine left in the bottle, he cleared the plates and took the bottle away, without asking us if we were done. He whisked it away--we didn't have a chance to register what he'd done and object. 
This restaurant does not expect any tips. Instead they charge more up front and give all of their staff decent pay and benefits. This is great...but I wonder if our waiter would have helped himself to our wine if it would have meant no tip. Hard to say but what he did was really really not cool.
author: Katherine E.

description:
Suzie Q's Fun Facts:

"Zazie dans le metro" (Zazie in the Metro) is the title of a 1959 French novel, known for being one of the first-ever to use colloquial, rather than formal French. 

The first word of this book is "Doukipudonktan," which is a phonetic transcription of "D'où (est-ce) qu'il pue donc tant?" ("From where does he stink so much?"). 

In the English version of the novel, this is translated as "Holifart, watastink."
=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=~=

This little French cafe is so adorable, it might as well be in Paris. 

Having visited Zazie at lunchtime on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving, I shouldn't have been surprised at the long line outside. But the waiting list moved pretty quickly; we were seated around 15 minutes after I arrived. 

While you can be seated comfortably inside, I absolutely love the little outdoor patio, as long as the weather cooperates. On this occasion, it did. 

Our waiter was super friendly and attentive. I ordered the coffee drink special (a seasonal pumpkin spice latte made with actual bits of pumpkin, yummy but refreshingly not too sweet), and then a single Egg Benedict topped with crab meat and accompanied by a mixed salad. 

While it was tasty and not too heavy, I have to admit that the price (I think $12?) for a half Benedict with some lettuce was super excessive, whether or not the thing had crab on it. I wasn't exactly full. 

But my friends loved their food, and I recall having delicious meals there in the past. Zazie is an SF treasure!
author: Suzie Q.

description:
We stumbled upon this cafe while stopping in San Francisco to pick up a vintage sofa. After reading some of the reviews on Yelp, we decided to put our name in and wait the hour + . My son saw the sign on the window that stated "first come first serve" on the outside tables. It was a beautiful day in San Fran so why not?

About a half hour later we're sitting and ordering from their tantalizing menu of French cuisine. I've never been to Paris (yet) so can't really compare to a true French cafe, but the pink grapefruit mimosa was great! I had the Sarah Jane's Griddle Flight: a sampler sized portion - 1 buttermilk pancake, 1 gingerbread pancake with bosc pears and lemon curd, and 1 French Toast. This is larger than your normal sample plate ! trust me on this one. The food was amazing!!  

I highly recommend putting Zazie's on your list when in San Francisco. They changed their brunch hours and close at 2...they stop taking names around 1:30ish.
author: Tricia F.

description:
This is a great brunch place and I like it as it's close to me.  Unfortunately, be prepared to wait anywhere from half an hour to 1.5 hours.  I recommend that you send someone in advance to put your names on their list (it's right outside the door) and then have you group make your way there.

The Coffee is great and they serve it in a little ceramic bowl which I love.  Their Eggs Florentine is my favorite which I get with a side of salad and home fries.  Also, you can't go wrong with their french toast, but that's if you fit into your skinny jeans just fine... I can't afford the extra calories.

Conclusion: Amazing place, and if you plan in advance, it's worth it.  If you have a large group and want to go last minute, I can't say it be worth the wait, but I'm not that big of a foodie.
author: Arman J.

description:
Zazie proves the point: http://www.thrillist.com/eat/nation/best-brunches

Food:
-La Mer (poached eggs with  fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados), the only dish I actually liked, mostly because I don't think it's possible to f-up the crab + poached eggs + avocados combo.
-Gingerbread pancakes, basically two thick discs of boring. Way too underwhelming and overhyped. You're better off making your own with some generic pancake mix from safeway at 1/3 of the cost.
-French toast tahiti, basically a block of generic bland bread with two sad halves of bananas thrown on top. Very underwhelming esp considering how french toast should be one of the easiest things to make (well) and to please.
-Home fries, basically fried potato chunks, some of which weren't even fried

Misc:
-Use the bathroom here only if you're toddler-sized or below. I'm pretty sure all the airplane lavatories are bigger than this.

Thank goodness we went right before they opened and didn't have to wait in line. Saving the money for cheap satisfying dimsum brunch next time.
author: Tian Q.

description:
If you wander down Cole Street any given weekend morning (and sometimes during the week) you are going to see a long line outside of a small restaurant. This line forms half an hour before opening and can stretch quite a ways down the block.

What's going on? Is someone handing hand gold bars? Free opera tickets? Bags of premium cannabis? What?

No, this is just the typical waiting line at a Cole Valley institution known as Zazie. 

The first thing to understand about Zazie is that it's basically a cult. If you live in Cole Valley you go to Zazie. There really isn't a choice, it's just the price of membership for living in this fantastic neighborhood. 

The place is small and packed, but it has a fantastic patio in back. Personally this is always my spot and is highly recommended. 

The food is very good and sometimes great. My personal favorite are the pancakes and french toasts. Sometimes the have Bread Pudding Pancakes, which are The Bomb and an absolute must if you like 1) bread pudding and 2) pancakes. 

Service is always outstanding. Zazie is an extremely well-run restaurant and you can tell they really take good care of their employees. Super busy but always attentive. 

If you're in the area this place is a must-visit!
author: Christopher J.

description: Best brunch I've ever had, hands down - totally worth the (not so long) wait. We got there around 11am on a Saturday and they told us it was a 1 hour 20 min wait, so we walked around for an hour. When we got back an hour later, they'd already called our name (they definitely underpromise, so don't get discouraged when they give you a time estimate) but I let him know we were there and we were the next table our size called. They sat us in the garden which is just so lovely with the greenery and heat lamps (it's also covered in case you go on a rainy day like us). I ordered the chai latte with steamed milk and it was absolutely delicious. I also loved how they served it in a small bowl instead of a cup. Then, I tried the Monaco eggs Benedict with prosciutto and a tomato - the eggs were poached to perfection and the tomato was so deliciously seasoned that it really made the dish. Finally, we had the Tahiti French toast with bananas and walnuts and we all loved them. For context, I don't normally like French toast and I couldn't get enough of them. Other diners in my party who love French toast and order then regularly said these were the best they'd ever have - these are a must order! Highly recommend Zazie's - do it!
author: Ana M.

description:
For those who haven't strolled around Cole Valley, Zazie always has a crowd out front. I recommend getting there before it opens and putting your name on the list. The line is intimidating but the restaurant is large so they can seat a lot of people quickly. I've heard the wait can be around 2 hours otherwise (not worth that). 

They have some unique seasonal spins on signature brunch dishes. I was very satisfied with the food but the overall experience didn't exceed my expectations. 

It is cash only and tips are included which made the overall meal a bit pricy. The service was good but the restaurant's atmosphere is nothing to write home about. 

I recommend the Miracle Pancakes & Monoco Eggs Benedict. Opt for the homefries- they are flavorful and are served with roasted garlic.
author: Caroline L.

description: Came on a MOnday night (dog night!) and we were seated in the patio. Me and my brother thought they serve brunch all day. Anyway, I got the pasta with mussels and he got the burger. Server was attentive. Food I would say I need to go back and try other stuff.
author: Michael Angelo R.

description:
Very fresh and also very hip. I like to take friends who are visiting out to lunch here! Also love that the tip is included in the price. 

I've gotten the Sarah Jane pancake flight twice, and it's definitely very sugary, but good.
I also really enjoyed the Salade Marius.
author: Tony G.

description:
Good food,  so-so service.  So my wife says she comes here all the time with her sisters. It does look like a nice,  quaint place for gabbing with the girls. It is small,  few tables out front and inside about a dozen. Apparently there is patio seating in the back as well. 

So we came for brunch and there was a bit if a line. We waited about 10 min and got a table for 3. Ordered the Oregon trout with squash, potatoes and salad. Excellent flavor and perfectly cooked. Had coffee, but took forever to get refilled. They have a living wage policy so no tipping. I would not have tipped well given it took 3 times to get a coffee refill and they never checked on us. My seat, backed against the main walkway,  kept getting bumped by both  patrons and servers. I scooted in all the way and there was plenty of space.  

$70 for 2 adults and one child. Again,  no tipping so every item was priced accordingly,  but $3.95 for regular coffee that I couldn't get a refill on?!  And my wife got a pot of tea for $6? Hard to get my mind around it. 

I most likely won't go back. Parking isn't easy in that area and most likely have to wait.
author: Jordan K.

description:
We came here for a very late weekend brunch. With nearly 3000 reviews, we weren't surprised to find the place still busy up until closing. We got there around 2:30pm, and had a bit of a wait but not huge (a bit short of 30 minutes). 

We split the French Toast Tahiti and a Gingerbread Pancake.
The French Toast was pretty standard until we reached the incredibly tasty sauce between the pieces of toast.
The Pancake was huge! Like, 3/4 inch thick! The lemon curd on the pancakes was really good.

The food was tasty, for sure. But the wait was long, it was crowded, and there are plenty of awesome brunch places closer to me, so I'm not sure that I'll go out of my way to return.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying I love brunch. The food, the ambience, and honestly the entire concept appeals to me on a very emotional level. Brunch food is therefore something I've been highly exposed to, and judge pretty harshly. Going to Zazie was a bit of an impulse decision, but my expectations were extremely high after reading the reviews.
Zazie met, exceeded, smashed my expectations.
We arrived at around 12:30 on a Tuesday, and there was a 5 minute wait time. The food arrived super quickly, and the service was awesome! We were seated in the backyard patio, and the ambience was adorable. I got the Florentine poached egg, and my friends got the French toast Tahiti. Honestly, the food was some of the best I've had. I'm definitely going back.
author: RJ S.

description: A bit overrated. Went many years ago and it was really good but went back a few months ago, waited a long time, and was very subpar. Ordered pancakes with fruit and the fruit was a super lame fruit salad that wasn't that ripe with a lot of melon. Melon with pancakes? No thank you. It definitely isn't awful but for that long of a wait, probably best to go to a different, less hyped, restaurant for the same quality.
author: AJ K.

description:
Food was good.  Nothing out of this world or anything, but tasted good.  I had one of the specials on the menu, an egg dish that had a red sauce and shared an order of the special pancakes as well.  I honestly can't remember exactly what it all was but like I said it tasted good.

Service was really spotty I thought and that could be due to the built in tip policy.  I don't want to assume that is the reason for the service lacking, but it would be hard to think otherwise since it appeared like they had plenty of staff on the floor.
author: Enrique F.

description: Pricier end but no tip.  Good scrambled eggs but small portions.  Decent French toast if you are into that.  Size of orange juice is tiny.
author: Alison D.

description:
I love Zazies for brunch! The food is great and my go tos are the egg Benedicts. I've tried all the benes there and they are all really good! 

The service is sometimes a hit or a miss, some being super friendly and attentive and others being just mediocre. I've never had a bad experience with a server, so that's a plus. 

The outdoor patio is super cute and I always try to request to be seated outside. The inside is a bit cramped for me, but it's super cozy. The wait here is extremely long when you come on the weekends, but that's a given since everyone loves brunch on weekends in SF. I would recommend coming here on a weekday to avoid the long lines. 

TIP: They don't really allow substitutes on orders since their kitchen is small and they are super busy. So don't expect for them to change or substitute much on your orders--basically DON'T BE COMPLICATED. 
& Tip is already included in the bill, so that's a plus that this place cares about their workers. 

Overall, great experience every time I brunch here and I would definitely recommend!
author: Grace T.

description:
Pros: Outdoor or indoor seating with beautiful scenery, fresh menu, employees make a living wage! Very good food!

Cons: Priced higher to accommodate providing living wage. No substitutions allowed on menu.
author: Kershee H.

description: This place is in a cute little strip. It has great light with a big sky light. Friendly staff. This place was my breakfast stop before visiting UCSF. Simply, it made me happy. We sat on the back patio that was empty when we walked out but quickly filled up in the next few minutes because it has just opened. It was so sunny and mid 70s so it was hard not to be happy. I started with the chai and the greek eggs with a side of sausage. The chai is big and is a large portion. It's a little less milky with more flaovr than most chais. The greek eggs were standard but I thoguth the chicken apple sausage was particularly flavorful and nice and HOT! which is always nice. I would rate this more of the $$$ range personally than $$ given we paid $6 for the chai if that gives an idea. We came back again when my brother in law came into town, this time on a weekend. The wait was more longer, the energy was good and at that time I got the same chai with the un deux trois which was great having a little taste of everything. I will go back again and hope to have more of these cute cozy breakfast/brunch mornings in this sunny space. Total comfort space.
author: Natasha B.

description: My husband and I were in San Francisco this week and we yelped breakfast places and this came up! We walked half way there then took lyft for the rest of the way! It was worth it! We both ordered the same thing because it sounded good and it was!!! I'd go back! yummy place!
author: Erika W.

description: OMG, try the Fontainebleau, best scrambled eggs of my life! Mushrooms are so fresh and tasty, it's perfect
author: Bertille S.

description:
My friends and I came as a group of 5 on a Monday holiday and arriving at 10:30am granted us about an hour to an hour and a half wait. Once in, it was a small and cramped place but somehow the workers seemed to maneuver through the space with no problem.

Since we had waited for a while, we were able to look over the menu and were ready to order when we sat down. I got Un, Deux, Trois with french toast instead of pancakes (1 carb, 2 eggs, and 3 pieces of bacon). That La Mer (crab benedict) was seriously pulling at me though. My favorite part of the menu was customization of the number of pieces for most of the orders that you could get (1, 2, or 3). It covers most people's stomach sizes and I liked that. My french toast was a bit of a disappointment as it didn't really have any flavor and just tasted like soggy toast to me.

Our server was pretty awesome and even though I can't remember his name, I remember that he was on point with jokes and comebacks! Plus it seemed like he could read our minds, bringing things out right when we were going to ask him for them. Our empty dishes were also cleared quickly. Great service!
author: Kat C.

description:
I absolutely love coming here for brunch. I've been here about 4 times now and every time I leave I am always satisfied!! Just a warning, be prepared to wait. My friends and I came on a Sunday at 9AM and it took about an hour to be seated!

OH! but the tables outside are on a first come first serve basis. Theres no waiting list for them! But be warned, when its a really nice day, you'll be baking out there. I sat out there once and it was ridiculously hot.

Anyway, the food here is always on point. I've had the pierre noir benedict and the tahitian french toast. Both were ridiculously amazing!! What i really like about zazie's is that they let you choose how many eggs or pieces of french toast you'd like to order. It's a great way to have variety when you're out at brunch. You really can't go wrong eating at zazies!! Love this place and i'll be returning!
author: Kelly S.

description:
I have only been to Zazie for their breakfast. I e been there three times and have had something different every time. It has all been good. This time I had the Canne egg dish. It was delicious. My daughter and I split the gingerbread pancake and it was way better than I was expecting. In past visits one of the dishes that made an impression was Janes flight, an assortment of their pancake selection. That was good and filling. The patio in the back is the big draw. It's a really nice place to sit and is mostly covered to shade you from the sun, if there is any. 
       Zazie is also one of he restaurants that started the no tip process and stuck with it. The tip, and the waiters benefits are incorporated into the price of the meal. Pretty convenient, I still feel like leaving a little something, but they let you know you don't need to leave a tip. 
        The place is hard to get into, even on a weekday. It's worth a visit and you won't be disappointed by the food. The selection of wines and mixed drinks is extensive also. I'll be going back when I get a chance..
author: Mike C.

description:
Extremely overrated.

- Food was severed cold.
- Food tasted gross
- Waitress did not come back until after our meal to see how our food was going.
- Silly long wait because everyone is clamoring over-themselves to get in 

Positives:
- Place was clean
author: Jonathan Q.

description:
Good quality food!
