BUT i wish they didn't give us a corner piece of the coffee cake. it was smaller, a little dry and lacked cream cheese filling. the table next to us got a full center piece that looked beautiful. ):
author: Samantha H.

description:
The ultimate kisses in life come from the sun, the best feelings come from a happily-plumped belly. At Zazie, you get the best of both worlds. Equipped with a delightful backyard, you can enjoy a light caressing of the breeze in the back patio. If the occasion doesn't call for it, indoor seating sets the stage for something a bit more cozy.

My favorites are the Tahiti French Toast, array of benedicts, and fluffy pancakes. I also make sure to have whatever Miracle-special they've got concocted for the day (cornmeal pancakes, berried french toast, etc). A single bite is enough to illicit the fluttering deep inside, from the sweet melting on your tongue to the melting of your heart.

Unfortunately, there is a catch: there is seemingly always an extraordinarily long line (even on weekday afternoons!). Don't fret, it's just so good that nobody ever wants to leave! It's definitely worth it.

The supper menu, however, is meh. Came with J once and we both found that our dishes were too heavily laced with overpowering wine-based sauces -- wasn't much our style. Irrespective of this, their breakfast and brunch items are exemplary. Five stars -- to infinity... and beyond! After all, nothing succeeds like excess.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Zazie is worth the wait.

I went there for brunch with friends on Memorial Day when a lot of friends had a day off. I'm from Oakland and never knew there was a neighborhood called Cole Valley but it was fun and there was residential parking with a 2 hour enforced limit not too far away.

There was a pretty long wait but they did a good job of turning around tables of 2, 3 or 4. I was part of a table of 3, we couldn't decide what to order so the server suggested a few things for us to share.

I recommend the gingerbread pancakes and the coffee cake, a friend of mine purchased the gingerbread pancake mix to go.

Everything was pretty tasty.

I wanted to mention that when a friend of mine saw me check-in there, he said he'd come down with his pregnant wife since the wifey had a craving. I put their name on the waitlist and told the host that they were coming and that my friend was pregnant, and he gave them the first available table when they got there.
author: Mike L.

description: Came here for a Monday Funday brunch with four friends. We sat on the beautiful patio on a perfect day. I was THRILLED to see gluten free bread as an option for their benedicts, French toast, etc and even MORE THRILLED when it turned out to be a delicious sourdough gf bread! Two of us shared a Bennie and a scramble which were EXCELLENT. My only wish (not a complaint) was for a second restroom as the line seems to get long.
author: Min M.

description:
Honestly, this place is a bit overhyped. That being said, I had a positive experience and delicious (albiet overpriced) food, but I wouldn't come back often considering the hour-long wait (on a weekend afternoon). 

I opted for the Salad Nicoise ($15), which came with a HUGE CHUNK-A-HUNK OF AHI TUNA. It was soo good and well seasoned. Only thing is that I wish they cut it into slices instead of serving it as a whole slab. Salad also came with green beans, baby potatoes, roasted bell peppers, and anchovies. Definitely recommend if you want something non-brreakfasty.

My friends ordered the Eggs Guillaume ($11) and some other poached egg dish. The portions looked a bit small for the price, but they said it was tasty. 

The service here is superb! The owner and waiters are extremely accommodating and even offered us blankets because we were on the patio in about-to-rain gloomy weather. I also love the vibe and super cute decor. Very home-y.
author: Samantha C.

description: The food may be good but doesn't make up for the rude service I get every time I come. It's usually the wait staff, but this time it was the host. What a pretentious ass. My husband loves this place. This is positively my last trip.
author: Bobbi C.

description:
Brunch is worth the long wait! Everything we ordered was delicious and my mouth is watering just thinking about the food again.

I came here for brunch with my husband and a friend at around 10:30 am on a Saturday and probably didn't get a table until close to 11:30 am so definitely plan ahead. Make sure you sign in by the entrance!

FOOD:
Latte & Cappuccino - Both were tasty and served in bowls without mug handles.

Albert Poached Eggs w/ Home Fries - The eggs were poached perfectly and the combination of hollandaise, salsa fresca, bacon and cheese was delicious. We ordered three eggs (one for each of us) and it worked out great. The home fries had whole cloves of roasted garlic in them which was awesome. I only wished there was more since we had to split the home fries three ways. Next time, I'd order an extra side of  home fries if sharing again.

French Toast Tahiti - OMG this was so good. The caramelized banana and walnut combined with the nice texture of the French toast was amazing. We ordered two pieces to share between three people and it was the perfect amount for tasting. I would definitely order this again.

Miracle Pancakes - These were some of the best pancakes I've ever had. The special flavor was fresh strawberries & lemon curd which was delicious. I only wish there was more lemon curd to go with each bite of pancake, but the syrup that was provided was delicious also. The pancakes had a cornmeal-y texture that I really enjoyed. We ordered two pancakes to share between three people and again, it was a good amount for tasting. I would definitely order this again.

SERVICE:
Once seated, the waiter was very friendly, quick and attentive. The food came out quickly and a bottle of water was provided on the table so we always had water stocked. What more can you ask for?

OVERALL:
I want to go back to Zazie for brunch again and again! Everything I tasted there was so yummy. I can't wait to try some the other options on their menu, but it's going to be hard to not order the same things again. Definitely go to Zazie. Or don't go, that way I can get a table faster.
author: Clarissa L.

description:
Since Zazie is known for both their pancakes and their Benedicts, it seemed like the perfect spot for brunching during my SF trip. The wait was minimal after 9 AM the Tuesday post-Memorial Day. Unfortunately, the backyard dining area was still closed since it was in the process of drying off from the earlier precipitation.

Our waitress was a cheerful and smiling gal. The atmosphere was cute and decorated with small French posters. Seating was sorta cramped. I heard more than enough of the conversations at the adjacent tables. A man at one of tables next to us had one of those voices that jabbed right into our ear canals, annoying.

The organic signature tea ($4.95) was my selection for a beverage. I thought it was for one person, but it came out in a big silver pot and was the gift that kept giving. So I would recommend it for two or more people. Thankfully you can get a to-go cup for the rest! It kind of reminds me of Sleepytime tea, wish the apricot flavor were stronger however.

My brother and I decided to share the gingerbread pancakes and the St. Trop and La Mer Benedicts. Each pancake is pretty substantial. We both loved these cakes of the pan! The lemon curd is such a wonderful complement, and the roasted pear looks like a potato but is lovely. Squeeze the orange wedge for a little extra citrus taste. And the syrup adds the just perfect touch of sweetness.

You can get one, two, or three eggs with your Benedicts, and you have your choice of home fries or salad. It was tough to decide which Benedict was better. We liked them both equally! I joked that we got West Coast ones and East Coast ones since the salmon, capers, and onions reminded me of NYC bagel accoutrements.

The kitchenside bathroom was an adventure. You pull the door closed, but it doesn't close completely. Since I had to wait to use it, I occupied my time by staring at a tremendous tower of bacon in a pan and spied on some naked Benedicts getting clothed.

Zazie's been penciled in for a return brunch when I'm back in the city!
author: Lisa H.

description: Long wait, BUT OH definitely worth the wait.  Can't wait to go back to San Francisco to go here again.
author: Tomás O.

description:
I had the best French toast I've ever had in my life, French toast Tahiti. Luckily, I found a clone recipe online that I'm trying desperately to talk my wife into making. Daily.

The place is really cool, great vibe, friendly staff, and amazing food. I love the idea that they don't accept tips because the staff is taken care of with standard benefits, but I still wanted to tip!

I knocked a star off because it's expensive for breakfast, but definitely worth trying.
author: Luke E.

description:
I had a day off, so I decided to journey across the bay and spend some time in the city. One of my friends also happened to be in the city and we really wanted brunch food, so we decided to check out Zazie. 

Although all of the other restaurants in the area were pretty empty on a Friday morning, Zazie was quite packed. My friend hadn't arrived yet, so I put our names on the list and waited with a crowd of other people. 

I had a book with me, but I couldn't resist eavesdropping on the conversations of the other people waiting outside. Basically, it seems like everyone in SF just hooks up with random people all of the time, and no one is happy about how the experience went. However, I guess the unsatisfying hook ups are not bad enough for people to change their behavior or for them to be too ashamed to tell their friends at brunch (in great detail, mind you). Well, that's SF for you, I guess. 

Eventually, my friend showed up and we were seated inside. Everything on the menu looked great, but I ended up selecting the Eggs en Fonte. This dish consists of grilled polenta cake with spinach, mushrooms, and a "spicy" tomato-chevre sauce (the quotation marks indicate that I think it wasn't actually spicy at all), all covered by two over-easy eggs baked in a cast iron skillet. I ordered my dish with home fries and bacon. 

Some elements of this dish were outstanding. The bacon was top notch. It was crispy, thick, and perfectly salty. When I cut into the eggs, the yolk oozed down into the spinach and polenta adding a richness to them. The tomato sauce was zesty, but certainly not spicy. The mushrooms just seemed to get in the way of the other flavors without really contributing anything to the dish. Overall though, I really enjoyed this. 

The service was quite French, which is to say that it was very slow. If you come here for brunch, you should definitely not have plans for at least a few hours. 

Overall, I'd probably rate this place 3 stars, but the bacon was so good that I have to give them 4. I'm not really a fan of these French brunch places that have long lines and slow service. I live a block away from La Note in Berkeley, and I've only been there four times in three years. For me, good breakfast food isn't that hard to make, and their slightly-better-than-good breakfast food at relatively high prices and with a long wait isn't really worth it. However, if you are into that and wouldn't be caught dead in a greasy spoon diner, Zazie is probably for you.
author: Ravi S.

description:
Food was great. The seasonal Lobster Benedict was light and delicious. We ordered an item off of their special menu which was also delicious: spinach, mushroom, over easy egg over fried polenta. However the best part of this place, the wait staff! My kid, probably overate and ate too fast, puked. Oh god - what a nightmare....it would had been if not for the quick action of the wait staff. Our waiter handed us a bunch of napkins and, as I was trying to rush to the bathroom to wipe down the kid, handed me a warm wet towel. Table cleaned and kid cleaned in less than 5 minutes.

Great food. Amazing wait staff! (That did not work for tips as tipping is not expected/accepted. French style)
author: Theary K.

description:
Awsome spot. Small and cozy. Service was good, service was friendly. Thankfully no wait time, then again we did come on a thursday at noon, under the rain.
The miracle pancakes were so good, fluffy, light. The lemon curd had that little zing that was balanced by the sweetness of the maple syrup. Definatly a must try. We also had the Genevieve eggs, they were creamy and yummy, took it with romaine lettuce and wheat toast (that strawberry jam with the toast were out of this world and im not a jam person, so good)
The divorce egg benedicts were also really good, crispy bacon, gooey eggs, a dream.
All in all, i would for sure come back and try their other dishes.
Thumbs up for Zazie. Yes
author: Patricia L.

description: This place usually has long wait times, but we got seated relatively quickly in about 30 mins. The service was excellent and the food came out relatively quickly. I had their eggs Benedict, miracle pancake, and French toast. The miracle pancakes and eggs Benedict were good, but the French toast was average. I have had better breakfast at brunch places in other cities and this place is not one of my favs. It would not be a bad option if there was no wait, but I prefer sweet maple over this one.
author: Muneeb K.

description:
Possibly the best brunch in the city if you're not looking for a homestyle-type meal. The best thing about this place is they allow you to order a la carte. So for those like me who can never decide between sweet and salty, you can do both! I highly recommend their french toast tahiti, which is topped with a caramelized banana and stuffed with a walnut spread, so good! Their egg's benedicts are also great, I'll usually order one of these and one of the french toast. Lots of other great options on the menu too! 

Only downsides, crazy crowded / long wait time and it's definitely pricey - but what isn't in SF? Be sure to wait by the curb though and don't go wandering off too far. My name was about 3/4 the page down and I walked around the cute neighborhood for about 20 minutes and missed being called. If you can, sit outside on the patio too!
author: Samantha C.

description: The miracle pancake was amazing! It was made of cornbread flour and had lemon curd drizzled on top. I would go back just for it.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I've been going here for a couple years, in general solid food, the price is not cheap but worth what you get on the whole. I also like how as of maybe a year ago, the tip is built into the menu prices, an attribute that I think would behoove other restaurants to emulate. Calculating tip is stressful, time-consuming, and just plain annoying, and this place I think has it right.

I do however, have a major issue. The issue is their bacon. They used to have thick, rich slabs of bacon, one of the essential reasons I began coming here at the initial recommendation of a friend. Probably the best bacon I'd ever had to be quite honest. As of maybe 6 months ago, they began using some other standardized, unexciting, extremely low-to-average tasting bacon, which, while perhaps not unusual for another restaurant, is a huge deal for my relationship with Zazie.

Because of this I don't think I'll be returning, unless I hear they bring the old bacon back, at which time I would probably bump up the review. Is it fair to downgrade them a star because of one menu item? I think so, given the fact that this was one of their marquee draws and they completely changed it with no explanation whatsoever. Very disappointed by this, but if bacon is not your thing, everything else is pretty good and I would still definitely check them out.
author: Evan L.

description: Didn't actually go in. The gentleman at the door was very rude and made us lose our interest in trying a place that was recommended by a friend. Also the 1-hour wait on Sunday morning was not worth it with multiple comparable neighboring brunch spots.
author: Nicola S.

description: My favorite breakfast spot in the bay! Try getting there right when they open bc the line can get super long! I got there 30 min after they opened and the wait was already 1.5 hours...But if you wanna sit outside its first come first serve! Their eggs benedict are seriously perfection! The hollandaise sauce is not too tart like other ones Ive tried and this is key for eggs benedict. Must try if ever in the bay :) The food is priced like any other restaurant I think the crabs benedict for 2 eggs were about $23? Worth it tho. They also have great service.
author: Sara K.

description: This place had 3.6k reviews so I had to try it... not surprised to find a mob of people waiting around for their name to be called. We put our name down and walked around height ashbury for an hour and our name had been passed! Luckily a seat opened up outside and we swooped in to take the 1st come 1st served table. The service was great and the food was delicious! Good combinations of flavors to give a unique experience.
author: Jake T.

description:
Had a great brunch here after a late night Gala the evening before.  Zazie came highly recommended by a friend and it is very clear why.  The options were almost overwhelming and everything looked so delicious.  My wife tried one of the benedicts (I forget which one) and a ginger pancake.  Both were very good.  My croque monsieur was also outstanding.

While in general I'm not the biggest breastfast fan, I can see making it a point to come back to Zazie in the future.  They have quite a few options, including a burger on the menu that I can't wait to try next time I'm not feeling breakfasty.
author: Aaron D.

description:
Now I understand why Zazie is so popular, 4 stars with almost 3k reviews! It's delicious and it's cute!

Went for brunch, and of course SF + brunch = long wait.  However, their brunch items were on point. 

- La Mer - 4 stars - dungeness crab, avocados, hollandaise, muffin.  Mmm bomb.
- St. Trop - 4 stars - smoked salmon, capers, hollandaise, muffin.  Good too, but I would prefer La Mer
- Gingerbread pancakes - 3.5 stars - exactly what it sounds like, pancakes with a gingerbread taste lol.  Good as an appetizer. What I get it again? I'd have to think about that, but definitely try it if you haven't. 

AMBIANCE: Love it!  This is what I think of when I think of brunch, a cute, outdoor place where you can enjoy breakfast/lunch on a nice, sunny day.  If it's cold, they have heated lamps, so don't worry!  They put christmas lights on the garden to light up the back patio, giving it this warm atmosphere.  Definitely sit in the back outdoor patio if you can! 

OVERALL: I would recommend this place, as the food was delicious and has a great atmosphere.  Though be prepared for a wait, but at least there are stores you can walk in to pass the time :)
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Zazie is the perfect brunch spot you want to tell no one about so the line stays short.

It's in a great part of SF in Cole Valley.

My Girlfriend and I prefer to sit outside on the back porch.

The servers are friendly and attentive. No need to worry about waiting forever for drinks, food, or the check.

I like their poached egg selection and my GF loves their pancakes. Coffee is a solid B and juice is a B+. 

Their prices include a living wage for their employees. So no tip is required. My GF and I trend around $50 bucks per outing.

After lunch we like to stroll through Golden Gate Park.
author: Will L.

description: This place was cute and quaint, best for parties of 2. Anything larger expect a wait. The cream cheese coffee cake is by far the best thing on the menu. Warm, delicious, absolutely fantastic. The French toast was a bust, dry, and without much flavor, although the description sounds good. Pancakes were pretty tasty. I wouldn't make this a trip, but if  you hap to be in the area, I would go for the cake. The service was uninteresting, fast to get you out quick, but not personable at all.
author: Char C.

description: I totally carb-loaded here with the Gingerbread pancakes garnished with lemon curd and baked pear and the French Toast Tahiti.  Everything was yum.  However, I preferred pairing the pancake with only the pear and no lemon curd since the lemony tang masked the gingerbread spices.
author: Amy J.

description:
This gem of a brunch/lunch spot.
 
You must try the oatmeal brûlée (creme brûlée and caramelized banana on oatmeal) - what an awesome combination.

The chicken sandwich with roasted garlic and tomatoes is delicious.

The challah French toast and gingerbread pancake (plate size) are equally yummy.
author: Matt W.

description: This place is a real treat for brunch. I met an old friend here for brunch recently and totally enjoyed it. The menu has plenty to choose from but not so much as to make it feel like a diner. The food and service are great, but be ready for a lengthy wait to get a table.
author: Cary R.

description: Croque Monsieur is delicious!! Cute cafe, great vibe
author: Katie G.

description: I live in the area and I have been to Zazie's twice - both were completely different experiences. My first time here was for brunch with a friend. I got a bagel with cream cheese and peppers and my friend got the poached egg. I couldn't see why people were lining up for this place as the brunch is a bit overpriced and nothing special. I decided to give Zazie's another chance and came here for dinner. I got the mussels and my sister got the chicken dish. Very very good. The service was great, food was amazing and the ambiance was perfect. I'd highly recommend Zazie's for dinner but I still don't feel it's worth the wait for brunch.
author: Mira B.

description:
My friend and I walked up to Zazie's under slightly unusual circumstances in that this particular Sunday morning it was Mother's Day, they were not taking reservations, and they opened up an hour earlier at 8am. So, I don't know if our ~40 min wait was typical. It was crazily crowded  in front of the restaurant, but the huge number of couples and families sweating it out in the hot sun in order to get a seat motivated me to see what the hype was all about. 

To get both the savory and sweet breakfast types we shared (1) the benedict special of the day, the Eggs Guillaume, which included prosciutto and asparagus, and (2) the popular French Toast Tahiti, which is a soft challah bread stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. They garnish it with caramelized bananas on top as well. I'm glad we chose to get salad instead of homefries with the eggs since it balanced out the rich hollandaise sauce well. Even though the french toast is already plenty sugary by itself, I couldn't resist dousing it with the syrup provided to serve as breakfast-dessert. Zazie is so successful not for quirky dishes but very classical and well done french food; it is tasty but not unique. Beware that Zazie automatically charges an extra $1.25 per person on top of the assortment of other fees associated with dining in SF.
author: Amy G.

description:
This is actually my 3rd time coming here, and they never failed to disappoint me! Although I wish they had at least put parsley or chives onto their eggs.. Other than that, the food was amazing! During the wait, my boyfriend and I went down a couple blocks to The Ice Cream Bar, which was good. We came back up and weren't very hungry, but still managed to finish our plates with satisfaction.

All I can say is, their food may be a bit on the pricey side, but most "good" brunches are around the same price now. They also don't expect you to leave them tips, which explains why their food is so expensive. It's enough to fill you up, so you don't feel completely bloated afterwards. Also good location, since Haight is right down the street!
author: Stacey L.

description:
Zazie's is one of those hidden gems you find in the desert full of sand, which in this case, is San Francisco brunch spots.

Coming into Cole Valley, you'll find that parking is as accessible as it is anywhere else in San Francisco, hard to find. I came around 10 AM on a Saturday and was able to find parking 4 blocks away. Come early and you'll find something.

Wait was decent; 20 minutes for a table for 2.

(+++) Latte - started off our meal with a latte... they use these nice little decorative bowls that remind me of preschool and the coffee is decent. Doesn't induce diarrhea nor does it taste cheap. Bravo, Zazie.

(+++++) Gingerbread pancakes with pears - these pancakes have it all, the spice, batter, and glaze. You get some syrup, but you'll run out because these pancakes are simply enormous. They're quite fluffy, but a little hard to keep shoving down your mouth after you've eaten half of them. THE LEMON GLAZE ON TOP IS AMAZING.... overall, very filling and delicious.

Definitely worth coming here for brunch. Don't mind the wait, it goes by fast. They don't do reservations. 

Worth noting: they pay their workers for health insurance and what not and tack on an extra dollar on your bill in service. Good job!
author: Davinci L.

description: It's good food. Nice ambience got there at 1.30 and waited 40 mins for a party of 2. Ordered the "Special" forgot their name pancakes but mine didn't come with the caramélisés bananas so make sure you ask about that. All in all it's solid but La Note in Berkeley is a better brunch spot with some better pancakes
author: Clyde A.

description: Just like any other brunch place in SF, this place was about an hour wait. My family and I got seated in the patio which had a lovely ambiance. The food is a bit pricey but that's because they already include tip in there (they don't let you pay tip for your paycheck). When you order benedicts you can choose if you want one, two, or three servings, which was nice if someone was either very hungry or didn't want to each too much. I ordered the crab benedict and it was delicious! Very light and had all the right flavors to it.
author: Chloe S.

description: Zazie is a lovely little French-inspired breakfast spot that offers a French atmosphere in a very San Franciscan building with foods like poached eggs, pancakes and sandwiches. They offer some brunch alcoholic drinks like mimosas and they have specials each day. I tried their pancake special for $9 (for 1). You can choose between 1, 2 or 3 pancakes for different prices. You can do the same with the poached egg. The pancake I had (called the miracle pancake) was poppyseed with lemon curd and some strawberries. The miracle pancake flavor changes so just ask or look @ the specials menu to find out what the flavor is. It came with some butter and syrup but the maple syrup wasn't necessary because the lemon curd made the pancake very flavorful. There weren't a lot of strawberries on top but the ones that it did have were super sweet! I think blueberries would have been a nice fruit pairing with the lemon curd and poppyseed. I also tried a poached egg with pancetta and a side salad. The poached egg was perfectly cooked and laid atop the pancetta and a 1/2 English muffin. The dish wasn't quite a benedict because it didn't have the hollandaise sauce. You had the option of having the poached egg with a spring salad or some fries. I opted with the salad which had a really light dressing. It also came with a wedge of orange (the sweetest orange I've ever tasted!). Street parking can be difficult but I lucked out. Unfortunately, where I parked, directly across the restaurant, was 30min parking only so my friend had to exit mid-meal to refill our meter. This restaurant offers indoor and outdoor seating  (both out in the back patio and in front of the restaurant). The high prices are warranted because they don't allow you to tip. Not tipping is custom in France. I tried a bite of my friend's mushroom & egg sandwich & thought it was very fresh. I really like the French posters on the wall & the skylight. The ceilings are high which makes the small space seem a little more spacious.
author: Brenda L.

description: We were so pleased to find this 25 year old restaurant. Our first time was a leisurely dinner on a Saturday evening. Never hurried by a thoughtful and welcoming staff. The Pork chop was amazing as was the duck. Starters we're also first rate. We ordered the mussels and the chicken Pate and again, absolutely delicious. Their wine list included Farm Worker Chardonnay by Maldonado. Tasty on first opening and continued to improve while it lasted. Also worth mentioning is Zazie's policy of NO TIPPING. Read their 'about' information for the full story. Whenever we're in SFO Zazie is now a must visit.
author: David S.

description: MY FAVORITE French place in SF. The restaurant is really cozy and the service is fantastic. I love their dinner a lot. I ordered the lamb shank and the duck leg dishes with my friends. Both were amazing. We also got a great red wine to pair with our yummy food. Love it a lot!! Highly recommended!
author: Clare L.

description: Was trying to go to Dottie's True Blue cafe for breakfast, but they're closed on Wednesday, and boy am I glad they were! Zazie's is phenomenal with some super interesting menu choices and some tried and true favorites! This is my new spot to come when in the city for breakfast.
author: daniel n.

description: We've had brunch here once and dinner twice. While the menu is enticing, almost every dish we ordered was average tasting at best. They include service charge in the prices, which I think is a great idea but even then the food (esp. the sides) can be overpriced. A little bowl of sauted spinach is $8 for e.g. If you want to try it out, Tuesday nights are no corking fee BYOB.
author: Shashank A.

description: Arguably, one of the best breakfasts I've had in my 30 years of life! My husband and I ordered the gluten free Tahiti french toast and you wouldn't even guess the bread was GF. We also ordered a baked egg special - Eggs de Fonte - and they were divine! The service was great, as was the atmosphere. This may just be our new San Francisco breakfast spot!
author: Chelsea D.

description: Exceptionally long wait for just two eggs benedict. Bad service and below average food quantity.
author: Yazhi G.

description:
The Good:  
-La Mer was light and lovely, perfect cocktail! 
-Gingerbread pancakes were everything a girl could ask for. MUST-HAVE!! 
-Divorcee Eggs Benedict was amazing also! Don't mess around with the side salad, the home fries are sooooo worth it! 

The Bad:
-The wait is really as horrible as everyone says. We arrived at 11:30 on a Saturday and waited a solid 45 minutes...shivering on the sidewalk was not the best way to start my brunch experience. However, the friendly servers do their best to cheer you up, because almost everyone gets grumpy during the wait. 

For real though, gingerbread pancakes will blow your mind.
author: Amanda T.

description:
I was eager to try this place out after reading so many good reviews, but I ended up being disappointed. I ordered their oatmeal brulee. It looked really good, but the only thing that was good about it was the caramelization at the top. Other than that, it was pretty bland.

Also, the service wasn't so great. I'm not sure if we were forgotten because we were seated outside rather than inside, but that's the impression we got. We hardly saw our server. We found ourselves waiting for water refills more often than not. And when my friend wanted coffee and was tired of waiting for our server to come to us, he went inside and saw that our server was sitting down eating. When he asked for coffee, our server pointed to the coffee and told him to help himself.
author: Amberlyn H.

description: Fromage and wine, can't really go wrong. The trout was pretty good, with rice and sprouts, it wasn't bad. I didn't get a ton of bones in a bite. The ravioli was heavy, but was super delicious.I wonder if it's house made, not sure, but porcini inside was really good. Service was excellent, and even let me tasted three wines before deciding which to choose. Sat outside in the back with heat lamps, so was quite intimate.
author: Minerva L.

description: Zero for Zazie. Since they have tip free service, two waiters are SO rude. It was not busy at all and they acted like it was busy. They said TIP FREE but it's all included in the meal!!! $8 for one piece of pancake? Ridiculous. Just go cheaper restaurant. It will taste the same. Also, I guess they don't have any their special own thing.
author: D J.

description: This may be one of the best brunches I have ever had! I ordered the divorcée eggs Benedict and my husband ordered the pancakes. Both were incredible! Would highly recommend this place!
author: C N.

description:
I came here with the bf for Valentine's Day dinner that had a pre-fixed menu. 

It was a horrendous experience. It cost us $69 per person.  Let me just say I've had far better tasting menus around $35 per person, I really have NO IDEA where the $150 went to, I guess it went to paying people to cut our food into heart shapes, because the food was nothing special besides that fact.

I had really high expectations for this place considering how popular it is for brunch and I am so disappointed.  

The decorations for Valentine's day were over the top in a disturbing and ugly way; everything sparkled and looked like it was bought from the dollar store or like someone let their pre-schooler decide how to decorate the restaurant.  It wasn't romantic at all, but looked like we were at a school day care decorated for valentines day.

Service:  They were nice, but oh my god they were so unorganized and kept messing up EVERYONES orders.  Since there were four courses to the menu, people all around us kept getting the wrong course, as well as the wrong dish sent to them.  They didn't even give us our first course for HALF AN HOUR.  

Also, the seating was a disaster because they squished an extra table in so we literally has to move the entire table if anyone near us needed to use the restroom.  Also, they kept messing up the orders because they kept forgetting there was an extra table there and would confuse the two tables where there was usually one table. 

Food: The food was nothing special, everything was cut into hearts and was served room temperature.   I don't particularly like room temperature soup thank you very much.  But I was't going to send it back since I waited HALF AN HOUR for it to even arrive.  

The second course was pretty bland and unexceptional, and the third course was where things got better, but not good enough to make up for the first two courses.  

The fourth course, dessert, was ok, not amazing, did not wow me. 

For $69 a person I want to be amazed, especially if you're going to include tip in my check total.  

I left pretty pissed off and dumbfounded we had just dropped that much money to be squeezed into a tiny area, with bad service, and served cold unexceptional food.

WOULD NOT recommend for any pre-fix special dinners.
author: Christina L.

description:
Phenomenal. One of my favorite brunch places in the city. Try the French Toast Tahiti which is french toast with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Absolutely delish!!

The Pierre Noir with poached eggs is divine. Just simply bacon and tomatoes but it is SO flavorful. I was pleasantly surprised. They offer mimosas as well.

Be prepared for the long wait! We put our names down, but you can check out places next door. If you go to the bar next door, the waiters from Zazie can come call you when your table is ready (make sure to write it down on the list). You can enjoy beer, Irish coffees, bloody mary's, etc next door which is very awesome while you wait!

You can also customize how much of everything you want. You can get 1 or 2 pieces of french toast or 2 or 3 poached eggs. This makes it great for one person or to even share your dishes.

Awesome staff and delicious food. GO here for brunch!! Highly recommend.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Hmmm with over 2k reviews and Zazie coming up as one of the best breakfast places in the San Fran area, I of course was super stoked to arrive - write our name on the list and wait around for a table.

We were on the 3rd page of sign-ups to be seated so I figured we'd better get cozy on the sidewalk of Cole St. because it sure was going to be awhile.

I anxiously anticipated just how fantastic our brekkie would be and perhaps that's where I screwed things up because I was not overly impressed by anything other than how smoothly folks signing in on their own is, waiting around and the host seating everyone in what seemingly was a timely manner given the amount of people there.

My son and I quickly decided we weren't going to hang back on the sidewalk the entire time so we walked across the street for coffee and a light snack before heading back and being seated shortly after.

I had the Tahiti French toast (one slice, two pieces) and a side of bacon. This was ok, but nowhere near 5 star or "the best".

My son ordered an egg sunny side up, with breakfast potatoes and toast. I had a small bite of his toast so I could try the raspberry jam on the table which was quite delish.

He had an orange juice, which he seemed to enjoy and I opted for their pomegranate mimosa which was fine enough.

All in all, this is not a breakfast place I would recommend or rush back to right away.

It was a pleasant experience but I feel the price point is a bit high for what it was. I've eaten at a couple other high rated breakfast spots (Mama's and Dottie's) both of which are significantly better tasting than Zazie.

Plenty of neighborhood parking on surrounding streets
author: Candace L.

description: Speechless.  Too good for words.  The French toast with fruit was delicious with an undertone of citrus.  The home fries...my favorite of all time.  Whole roasted garlic cloves mixed in!  Wish we came here earlier!
author: Jay P.

description:
I came here for lunch with my gf! There was a wait outside but we got seated in ten minutes! The food was pretty good especially the miracle pancakes! We also ordered the egg Benedict and it was delicious. 

The price maybe be alittle pricy but that's because you don't have to pay tip since management provide workers with good pay and 401k. Which I thought was awesome. But we def left some tip because the place was great and server was pretty nice!
author: Herman L.

description:
really trendy spot for brunch.  had a family brunch on a saturday and it was packed but we were seated quickly and without delay. 

food is solid though part of that is also the scene and the fact it is popular.  if you are after ONLY the food there are less busy places but if you are in the area, this is a good spot for brunch.
author: John O.

description: A great French restaurant located right off Haight Street and Cole. You'll never know about it unless someone recommends it like my good friend Rita. It has great fish entrees and excellent wine selections. Our server was so nice and accommodating. Easy parking right outside the restaurant located in a nice quiet neighborhood.
author: DJ Nocturna R.

description: It was definitely a long line but worth the wait. It was a little rainy out but I still sat outside and read a book while brunching. The waitress was very personable and friendly. I absolutely would eat here again! Food was outstanding!
author: Carla S.

description:
After 7 months of living in San Francisco, I have finally found a place to crown "best brunch in SF"

My favorite dishes 
-eggs monaco: adding tomato to a traditional eggs benedict makes the dish heartier and meatier, without feeling heavy. I also love that it comes with prosciutto, a lighter alternative to bacon that doesn't compromise taste 

-chai latte: comes in a big bowl! It's not too spicy and not too sweet. Definitely recommend if you like chai lattes.

-French toast tahiti: tropical twist to a sweet favorite. French toast is stuffed with caramelized bananas and topped with walnuts 

Great thing about this place is you can order 1, 2, or 3 of pancakes, french toast, or poached eggs. So if you're feeling not so hungry or SUPER hungry, you can adjust your order to satisfy your level of hunger. Another great thing is that tip is included in the price of the food so what you see is what you pay! 

Be prepared to wait, but trust me- it's with it. Service on point and food out of this world.
author: Erica L.

description:
Overall: pretty overrated. I'm not sure what sets this place so much more special than the other brunch places I've tried in San Francisco. With the type of line and prices, I would pick somewhere else for brunch.

Line: Expect a long line if you are like everyone who wants to get some brunch on a Saturday morning. 

Food: Ok, nothing special even though I got one of the specials (hah!). Their choices are similar to other brunch places'. There are eggs benedict, pancakes, potatoes etc. Your usual brunch food. So why wait in the crazy line for this restaurant?
author: Vio C.

description:
Super small location, but loved their food! They have a patio area with heater lamps, but we sat inside. They add a $1.25 charge per person that goes to the waiters full benefits. It was interesting. 
Overall I enjoyed their food. French Toast and Egg Benedict's are pretty heavy foods that get me full anywhere else, but here it sat light in my stomach. We ordered the La Mer which consisted of fresh crab and avocado, it was very light tasting and the poached egg wasn't super runny either. The French Toast Tahiti was my favorite. Sweet enough that you don't even need the syrup and the banana mush (that's the best I can describe it) in-between the toast was completely different than other places I've tried. 
This place can get packed so come earlier rather than later.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Delicious breakfast at Zazie and everyone knows it! Get there by 8:30 on the weekends to write your name on the wait list. 
We got a table outside- they are first come first served and you really can be first served if you're there when they open. We enjoyed two of the scrambles (the toast is amazing) and a slice of French toast. We enjoyed every bite!
If you're stuck in a long wait, you can get your coffee at Peet's just down the street to warm up and pass the time.
author: Meadow P.

description:
I had a late breakfast with 3 friends at Zazie on 9-9-16.  
(They pay all their employees a living wage, as well as providing them with health and dental care and 401K savings plan w/matching contributions.)
The food is delicious and the menu is interesting.  It's a rather small place but it's clear they have a loyal following of repeat customers.  Service is very good.  The place was bustling when I arrived around 11am and we had a short wait.  I had some sort of stone ground corn meal hot cakes w/lemon curd and strawberries.  I ate one and shared the 2nd one.  Very toothsome.  I would definitely return here if ever again in the San Francisco area.  I recommend giving this place a try for a wonderful something...
author: Linda C.

description: I went on an early Friday morning around 9 am and there was no wait. I ordered the miracle pancakes which were one of the best pancakes I've ever had. It did not disappoint. The fluffy pancakes went perfectly with the lemon curd (however I wish I had more lemon curd for my two pancakes). I got to try my friend's Tahiti French toast and it was amazing. It's definitely on the sweeter side but it was delicious. The walnuts were stuffed in between each slice of toast and the bananas were perfectly caramelized. The staff was very attentive and generous. Definitely plan on coming back!
author: Rachel C.

description:
I've came here a few times with a friend of mine because I crave brunch probably more than any other meal. Those few times I've came, there was never a line, lucky me? I've tried their eggs benedict, which tastes the same everywhere to me. Their French Toast Tahiti, is to die for. So yummy! I've also tried their 3 pancake special. Which included a regular buttermilk pancake, gingerbread, and pumpkin. I was not a very big fan of the pumpkin as I have hoped to be. But the gingerbread was really good. The one I would have to say was the best, is the savory skillet bread pudding. I was very skeptic to order this, only because I've never had bread pudding before and it sounded a bit off. But, the waitress said it was a favorite there. So, I decided to give it a try. To my surprise, it became my favorite!

I would definitely come back again. I recommend coming on a weekday around 11-12pm. that is when it's rarely ever busy.
author: Audrey K.

description: If you'd like brunch, and you live in SF, chances are you've heard of this place. I for one am not a brunch guy, but that being said I did have lovely time at this establishment. They do breakfast, and they do it right, between the mimosas, fresh cut fruit and the eggs. I can see why it's easy to believe the hype.
author: Ryan M.

description:
We stopped in for an impromptu brunch on an early Saturday afternoon. We put our names on the list, and were quickly at the head of the line and seated on the back patio. That was where the efficiency stopped. 

Service was very slow. We ordered quickly, but our meal took over 20 minutes to arrive, and when it finally arrived, our meals were lukewarm, probably from sitting around awaiting pickup. We ordered two egg dishes and the pancakes. The eggs arrived, but the pancakes had apparently been forgotten. At least when they finally arrived, they were hot, confirming our suspicions that the other dishes had just been set out too long, neglected by our server. The pumpkin pancakes were exceptionally delicious, very light and fluffy, with great spicy fall flavor.  The huevos rancheros and the special omelet were also good, but not enough to outweigh the less then hot temperature. 

The patio was lovely, but tables were very close together, offering little privacy from our neighbors' conversations. 

The experience today was satisfactory, but would have been greatly improved by more prompt and attentive service.
author: Arugula F.

description:
My friends and I enjoyed a wonderful New Years Eve pre-fixe dinner at Zazie. I would definitely recommend this restaurant for a romantic dinner date, but request to sit in the heated garden patio outdoors! Initially, we feared that we'd freeze outside, but they have plenty of heated lamps, as well as comfortable blankets to keep us sufficiently warm throughout the meal. Great cozy, romantic ambiance.

As for the food, I had a white bean soup, a mushroom tart, bouef bourgignone, and a chocolate tart with chocolate ganache - all for $59. The prices were very reasonable, and while most of the food was above average, what really made my Zazie experience stand out was the friendly service and amazing ambiance.
author: Kristina W.

description:
After hearing about all of the hype for this place, we were slightly disappointed overall by the quality of the food here. We came here on a Saturday morning around 11am, and we waited a little over an hour for a table for two. The atmosphere and decor is pretty nice, and the staff was very friendly despite how crowded the place was. I got three divorcee pouched eggs and my girlfriend got the Avignon egg scramble. The food took quite a while to get served so expect to spend at least an hour inside. The poached eggs themselves were pretty well prepared, but the bacon on top was overcooked and too crispy, and rest of the dish was simply unflavorful. Same goes to my girlfriends scramble, simply too plain tasting in general. 

On the plus side, this place is tip free as everything is included in the price of the meal! That was a very refreshing change.
author: Jinyan C.

description: Buttermilk pancake with fruit. Light and fluffy. I ordered only one ($9)...I'm full!! Also there's raspberry jam on the table, very tasty! Price goes up if you want more pancakes. Two pancakes would have cost $16...but I'm honestly full after just one. Cozy little place with very friendly staff!!
author: Irina C.

description: We rented out the patio for our wedding reception. The owner, Jen, was very easy to work with on everything- she was professional and always quick to respond. The food was delicious and our service was excellent; it was a generally friendly vibe all around. Their patio is small but cute, and it was definitely the ambience I wanted for our wedding brunch :)
author: Michelle D.

description:
KO'd. What a meal. 

We had: a half bottle of Bourdeaux, paté, bread, and boeuf bourgignon for him; a Poinsettia, paté, bread, boeuf bourgignon, and sauteed broccolini for me. A matched set. I was bowled over by their paté. Second time trying it. So creamy, so good--I couldn't believe chicken liver could be so tasty! Good on toast. 

Now, the entrée. Oh, the beef and mashed potatoes and side order of broccolini. What a meal. I cut up the broccolini and then did away with the fork--you certainly didn't need it for the beef or potatoes! The bread rolls deserve a mention, too...fresh from the oven, hot and with a ball of butter? Ohh, yeah. 

Packed restaurant. Relatively small. Intimate, noisy but conversation doable. Cute. Great service (friendly, attentive). Couldn't have had a better time. Wish I had room for dessert!

Congrats, Zazie. I'll be dreaming of you in the future.
author: Jasmine G.

description: We had brunch here on a Friday and the wait was maybe 10-15mins. We shared the french toast and divorcee eggs Benedict. They were sf priced but I eat french toast all the time and these were so delicious-- not trying to mask the flavor by incorporating too many things or having to add much syrup. The eggs Benedict too were made well-- hollandaise was just right!!!
author: Theresa L.

description: Delicious gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd.  Loved my cafe au lait. BUT - not worth the 1.5 hour wait and the delay in getting the food after ordering.
author: B. Y.

description:
Good brunch in this cute little store. Today was windy they closed down the garden area so we wait a bit. Inside, there are about 14 tables so they can host about 30 guests at one time. There was a big birthday party so table turn around are bit slow. 

This is a little local brunch place with excellent food and nice ambiance. I ordered La Mer (crab poached eggs with avocado). I liked they have one egg/two eggs/three eggs option. We asked for three eggs option and shared between two people. Perfect size. We also ordered one with sample of 1 French toast, 1 buttermilk pancake, and 1 gingerbread pancake. Good size meal. 

We were very satisfied. There are other dishes looks pretty good too. Definitely go back when in golden gate park area.
author: Jean P.

description: The Benedicts were amazing. We tried the le mar with crab and another one with bacon and avocado. They were both excellent. The pancake sampler was pretty good. It had an interesting gingerbread pancake with lemon curd that was delicious. We also ordered a baked hot chocolate. I didn't know this was a thing until now. It wasn't on the menu but it was a very rich, delicious dessert to our brunch!
author: Julia T.

description:
We have been going there off and on for 10 years. We live in Santa Cruz, and Zazie is no longer in our normal orbit since we stopped going to the UCSF hospital for periodic treatments. We went there tonight and it was a good as ever. 

No tipping! because they charge enough to give their employees living wage, health insurance, and 401K contributions. Even then,  I think the food is not only delicious, but a good value.
author: george p.

description: Love it! Breakfast , dinners ... all is delicious. Great service but long waiting lines.
author: Eva V.

description:
This is a brunch hot spot. Expect to wait ~30 minutes to an hour on weekends for a table. I would recommend getting seated outside in the back. Its like a wooden deck, with polished wooden booths and green hedges and has a really chill vibe. The place has a very tiny kitchen, so I'm impressed that they're able to service so many tables quickly.

Food=4.5

This was my third time here and I decided to change things up and order their burger. The burger was cooked medium rare and I got it with bacon and sunny side egg. The dish was also served with their home fries. The burger was juicy and flavorful, but the egg was a little undercooked. The potatoes were excellent!

Service=4

Our waiter was very kind and offered my friends good recommendations as it was their first time. It was a weekday and we had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. Our food came out in ~20 minutes.

Ambiance=4

The place feels very classic and rustic. The restaurant itself is quite narrow and cramped, but is quite homey.
author: Alex C.

description: My absolute favourite brunch place! The long wait is definitely always worth it. On a Saturday or Sunday morning it takes anywhere between 15-40 mins to get a table unless you want to grab the tables out front which don't require waiting in line or putting your name down. Also pets are allowed at the 2 tables out front so it's definitely a convenient option for pet owners. Come early if you want to try the miracle pancakes because they run out by the end of the day.
author: Tanvi M.

description:
Whenever I am in San Francisco, this is the first place I go when I land and my last before my flight. 
I can rant and rave about the food, service and drinks (all of them..) but I will not. 
Just go.
If you are going on a weekday morning (which is the only time I've gone) get there early. I'm talking 8 AM. Park on Cole, say hello to everyone walking their dogs and really enjoy yourself. It is my absolute favorite place and I really wish for some place like this in NY. 
Xo
author: Desiree G.

description: Lovely little restaurant. It feels cozy. The food was good, but I give the 5 starts bc the service was outstanding!  Like NYC style, only that here they don't rush you out, even when the ppl wait line goes around the block.
author: Coté M.

description: Super delicious but super duper pricey. Love their St. Trop egg's benedict! Thing that bothered me was the lack of effort for coffee refills.
author: Johnny N.

description:
Tuesday around 11ish.

No line.  We were seated on arrival, & given our choice of outside or inside.  We chose outside on the patio.

Our picks...
Eggs En Fonte.
Croque Madame with prosciutto added.
French Toast Tahiti.  To share.

The patio is very charming & cozy.  Surprisingly, it was so warm out that there was no need for the heat lamps to be on.   Love.  With the sun beaming down on us, it was hard not to revel in the moment.  So I did.

An easy A for atmosphere.  But despite Zazies's stellar reputation, I found our brunch to be underwhelming.  

The Eggs En Fonte were cooked well but lacked flavor.  They were not bad, but I expected better than not bad.

The Croque Madame w prosciutto added.  Where was the prosciutto exactly?  Eventually I did find it; a very small amount of it bunched together on one end of the sandwich.  Then there's the matter of the béchamel sauce.  It was bland.  Croque Monsieur's & all their variations are available on many menus now.  This was just haphazard & unremarkable.  Miss.

The big disappointment for me?  The French Toast Tahiti.  This was the dish that I was most looking forward to.  Thought this would be just delicious, & it just was not.  I'm sorry, but ANY French Toast at Mama's or Dottie's puts this one to shame.  I especially found the filling to be remarkably unappealing; visually, texturally, & taste wise.  It actually looks like mush.  It has an unpleasant texture in your mouth & no flavor.  Really?  Not what I was anticipating or would want.  The hype over this dish I just do NOT understand.

If you're looking for an amazing stuffed French Toast, I'd actually recommend Mimi's Cafe over this.  No joke.  

We didn't order mimosas, which I've heard rock here; but I don't use alcoholic beverages as a bar of measure for a great meal.  Neither should anyone else.  

3 stars to me is mediocre.  Not good, not bad.  And that was my experience at Zazie.  3 stars for service, ambience, & for having the neighborhood restaurant concept down.  But destination restaurant?  No.  

There are way too many better brunch alternatives in San Francisco.
author: Veronica M.

description: Although the wait was long, it was to be expected due to the fact that this was the best breakfast we had in San Fran while on vacation. I got the "Divorcee" which was an eggs Benedict topped with bacon, avocado and cheese and I must say it was the best I ever had. It was paired with a choice of home fries or salad. I chose the salad and while it was what I was expecting it was still delicious (spring mix mixed with a dressing) I would totally recommend this place to anyone and would love love love to go back!!
author: Hannah Y.

description:
Top notch breakfast experience.  Slightly pricy but so well made.  The service is friendly.  The crowd is upper crust, but who cares when the eggs are this good!

It can get crowded on any day of the week.  Trying to go to the bathroom is best done with a reservation.
author: Josh F.

description:
God the wait here is long!!! Ppl waiting out in the street just to have brunch! So like them we waited!

The cool part is when you sign your name up, you can put "bar" next to your name and go to the Irish bar next door and have a Bloody Mary! The hostess actually goes in the bar and tells you that your table is ready! --that was a great perk!

When we finally got seated we ordered Thor poached eggs (eggs Benedict) I had the florentine which is portobello mushrooms, spinach, their amazing hollandaise sauce on warm English muffin. On the side are fresh seasoned parties. My fiancé had the crab Benedict which was bomb.com! Wish I ordered it too because I practically are his whole meal :)!! 

On the side of our Benedictus we ordered their banana walnut French toast!---AMAZING! It was just the right kind of sweet! It was to too sweet or over baring! The toast was soft and moist with every bite. And there was sliced soft caramelized bananas that goes on top of it! 

I like the brunch  here! Totally a must try if your in the city!!!
author: Gloria M.

description: Food is delicious but be prepared to wait about an hour, like most places in San Francisco. I must say though, the food is worth the wait! The atmosphere is cozy and the food is prepared well. I love their spin on classic pancakes, bacon, and eggs!
author: Jessica W.

description:
Another busy brunch spot? Check! Just because there is a 2 hour wait for a table, doesn't mean it's the greatest best spot in SF, as we all know. Zazie, with its cute back and front patio, classic brunch offerings and list of stellar reviews makes this place the talk of the town. 

Arriving at 11AM on a Thursday morning we didn't think we'd have to wait for a table. Lo and behold their was a wait list and we ended up waiting 30 min for a table. Lucky for us we got seated in the back garden, which was uber cute! Surrounded by greenery and filled with happy diners, the atmosphere can't be beat. 

To order we started with the cream cheese coffee cake (yum!) since we were starving. Next I had the Divorcee Eggs Benedict. I am a huge fan of eggs benedict so was totally looking forward to it. The Divorcee is served with avocado, cheese, bacon, poached egg and hollandaise. What I ended up eating was mediocre...I didn't hate it but I didn't love it. Each dish comes with a side of hash browns or salad. We all had hash browns as a side and BOY were we disappointed...they tasted very bad. I don't know if they oil they friend them in was off or if we just didnt like the flavor but all 5 of us chose not to eat the hash browns. 

Overall, my experience at Zazie was A-OK. I had higher expectations but I also didnt hate it. The atmosphere and decor made up for everything and I am sure that the potatoes were just having a bad day. If I return, I think i'll try it for lunch / dinner.
author: Aletta B.

description:
Cute little Cole Valley neighborhood eatery that is great for brunch.  People start lining up early so don't be surprised to have to wait for an hour to get in.  There are two tables outside on the sidewalk that are squatters first come first serve if you can snag either of them, but we found the outdoor patio in the back to be particularly delightful on a sunny day...
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zazie-san-francisco?select=CgF0FRrc1Y4vV36zniioxw#pv-lgBdX5s0jxFyGrB5ObQ

Famous for their eggs benedict, my better half did a clever thing by ordering an Eggs Florentine with only one egg instead of the regular two;  this way she wouldn't feel guilty ordering one of their seasonal Gingerbread pancakes, to share of course... =)

The Eggs Florentine with fresh spinach and sauteed sliced mushrooms was pretty good, the poached eggs are pretty incredible like everyone says http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zazie-san-francisco?select=CgF0FRrc1Y4vV36zniioxw#kTmaA9wqc43WM6Z-6uirlQ.  A single egg order of these is fairly satisfying, three eggs would be a pigout...

The Gingerbread stack was good in and of itself but the little layers of sweetness puts it over the top http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zazie-san-francisco?select=CgF0FRrc1Y4vV36zniioxw#u4mU3sabIqob4odZq2WfIA.  The lemon curd dollop along with the pear slice was out of this world as the sweet tangy flavor of the lemon curd is from Meyer lemons I would bet, and the sweetness of pear is just killer.  Then there is the sweetness from the light dusting of confectioners sugar, and if this isn't enough, there is the syrupy sticky sweetness from the maple syrup.  There is also a slice of lemon strategically placed on the plate to remind the eyes that you are sensing a lemon flavor in the curd...

I'm a sucker for Croque Madame's and this one seemed a little ordinary at first until you take that first bite.  That crispy toasted brioche on the bottom is not soggy at all and does a stupendous job of holding up all of ingredients like thin sliced ham and melted gruyere cheese topped of course with the beautifully done sunny side egg with the edges just starting to brown http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zazie-san-francisco?select=CgF0FRrc1Y4vV36zniioxw#izCnr5uj0s5PzRhuoTsXPQ.  C'est magnifique...

Europeans seem to like their coffees in a bowl and my Cafe Latte was wonderful under the sunlight of the outdoor backyard deck which btw was unbearably warm in concert with the space heaters but was nice once a shadow was cast when the sun retreated behind an adjacent apartment building...
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zazie-san-francisco?select=CgF0FRrc1Y4vV36zniioxw#37rZVH5vtpKCHHeY8SDEtw

The restaurant is small but the turnover seemed fairly quick so don't let the daunting clipboard filled with names deter you from enjoying a terrific meal.  Their restroom is little more than a water closet literally,  but the ambiance is cute and delightful, particularly for two.  I was also surprised initially with the extra $1.25 per person surcharge levied on the bill until our waitress explained that it's for the "Healthy SF" requirement for the restaurant to provide health coverage for their employees.  I hadn't heard of it until this point, but I haven't been in the city for awhile and it's totally legit;  I was just a little surprised to see it enumerated on the itemized bill rather than being absorbed in the prices, but c'est la vie n'est pas...
author: Lawrence L.

description: Pretty decent place to have brunch. We came on a Tuesday and it was packed at 1pm. Street parking or take the N line from downtown. Outdoor and indoor seating. We had the French toast, cinnamon bread and lemon pancakes as one of the dishes. For the savory dish we had the crab Benedict with potatoes. Bill came out to about $50 and tip is included. I wouldn't wait to eat here but since we only waited 10 minutes for decent food it deserves 4 stars. The staff was excellent and the ambiance was cute with the brick wall background. Also the missing star is also due to not listening to our order... We said 1 egg and they have gave us two.
author: Yvonne F.

description:
Hi Zazie, I'm baaaaaack!! 

5 stars! 5 stars! 

Got there on a Saturday morning at 9:30am and only waited 10 minutes! This time we sat in the back patio. SO AMAZING! The heat lamps are perfect (not too hot).

St. Trop Benedict (4 stars) Comes with smoked salmon, capers and red onions

La Mer (5 stars) Huge chunks of crab, avo and green onion

I will continue to come back to this place. It really hits the spot. 

And btw, the guy who works there.. the one who calls your name is SO nice! He remembered my name and offered to call us cab. Thank you!
author: Jenny F.

description: absolutely amazing breakfast! it gets super busy, so expect a bit of a wait, but it's very worth it. the seating outside is first come first serve which is really convenient on a nice day. the staff was very friendly and attentive despite how busy it was, and the food was great. can't wait to go again!
author: Stevie F.

description: Wait for Sunday brunch was manageable (about 45 minutes starting at 9:45), table for four on the patio was lovely and waiter was friendly and accommodating. But food was a long time in coming and arrived lukewarm or cold. Wife's cold pancake was sent back and returned as ... a cold pancake. My French toast and eggs were unremarkable given the hype, and lukewarm to boot. Coffee refills had to be requested. Will be looking for a different brunch option next time in S.F.
author: Warren B.

description:
The Gingerbread Pancake w/ lemon curd and candied pear is one of my favorite breakfast items of anywhere I've ever been. I like to order it with the Un, Deux, Trois. One pancake, two eggs, and bacon.

I never order Chai Tea anywhere, but the Chai Tea w/ steamed milk at Zazie is memorable. Really tasty.

There's almost always a wait to sit inside, especially on weekends. However, you can put your name on the list at Zazie and go next door to Finnegan's to have a drink while you wait. The Zazie staff will come into the bar to get you when your table is ready.
author: Brandon B.

description:
This is my go to place for brunch with friends. It's popular with a lot of folks, so there is always a line to get in. I usually end up waiting about an hour or less for a table, which is completely worth it. There are tables that are outside in the front that are first come first serve as well. 

The food is delicious. I usually end up getting the divorcé, which is basically eggs benedict with avocado. The eggs are perfectly cooked, and when you take a bite out of them they run perfectly. The hollandaise sauce is the perfect thickness, and clings just enough to the eggs. The potatoes are very flavorful as well. Suffice it to say, this is the perfect breakfast and breakfast spot.

I highly recommend.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I don't know if zazilicious is a word, but it should be! The brunch was amazingly tasty and the service was nice. 

That said, the wait to get in was exorbitant. We got in around 11am and were seated about 12:10 -- you entire group must be present when they call your name, otherwise, you will need to wait for the next table. Would have been great if we got remote beepers or possibly just a text message when our table was ready so we could walk around Cole valley instead of just standing outside the door the entire time. 

Once inside, we ordered our food right away, but had to wait for about half an hour or so to get our food. The time spent outside waiting and then also waiting for food once inside hurt the experience, at the end we were starving.

To know that management also takes care of their employees with 401k plans, and other benefits, is great. The menu has more information about their setup, but you don't need to leave any tip, and it's all included in the final price.
author: Zorayr K.

description: Good brunch spot but about an hour wait and the food was not overly amazing. I got the eggs benedict with salmon and it was delicious, should have gotten 2 but I only opted for one. The place was very crowded and since we had 5 people in our group, the wait was long. Groups of 2 and 3 were seated well before us, I don't recommend venturing there is you have more than 4 people. The atmosphere was nice and if I ever go back I'll be sure to try something else, there was a large variety of things on the menu. In a city like San Francisco, I'm sure there are many great brunch spots with a shorter wait.
author: Amanda J.

description: this was one of my favorite restaurants for 10 years and we got takeout here weekly (sometimes more).  however, now that my son has a nut allergy, they refuse to make dishes without nuts under their "no substitutions" rule.  they say it's due to the size of the kitchen, but we're not asking for a large accommodation - they literally refused to not sprinkle almonds on top of the trout for a takeout order.  many other equally small/busy restaurants in SF are much more accommodating.  i won't be going here anymore out of principle, even when my son isn't with us.
author: Sari M.

description:
Just had brunch there about an hour ago. LOVED it!!  What makes this place so great is 2-fold

1.  Food is phenomenal. Simple and delicious. As someone told us while we were deciding whether to eat there, "They have the best poached eggs in SF." Note:  NO substitutions!  Make sure you ask for their habanero sauce to put on the eggs and potatoes. 

2. This place is run like a co-op...the employees have amazing benefits (as explained on the menu AND by our superb waitress, Sarah Jane). No tipping, it says. Feels weird not to tip. Anyway, these employees seem so genuinely happy to be there...and that creates such a warm and inviting atmosphere

I'll be back...even tho I live in Marin
author: Jonathan P.

description:
It's ridiculous trying to go to Zazie for brunch on Sundays at noon. The wait is 30+ minutes, but if you're the type of person who thinks superb food quality and taste is worth the time, then waiting at Zazie may be for you. But wait time for weekday brunch isn't as long.

Zazie is known for their gingerbread pancakes. I'm not really a pancake person because I find them too doughy, dry, and boring. And don't get me started with all the little holes that give me shivers and make my skin crawl!! But overlooking trypophobia, Zazie's gingerbread pancakes are so aromatic and delicious! They're slightly sweet from all the spices, but the pancake is too fluffy and thick to my liking. But the sweet lemon curd adds a nice touch.

I've tried a few Benedicts as well, including the La Mer (fresh crab and avocado), St. Trop (smoked salmon), and Monaco (prosciutto and tomatoes). My favorites by far are the La Mer and the St. Trop. The La Mer has a generous portion of fresh crab meat, most of which is in large pieces, and three small slices of avocado. The St. Trop has fresh, thin-sliced smoked salmon that is melt in your mouth silky and delicious! I'm not a big fan of raw onions and capers, so I liked how those two ingredients' tastes were very mild. Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy the Monaco because I thought the tomato flavor was overwhelming and I could barely taste the prosciutto, which is surprising because it's cured meat! The Benedict's eggs are poached perfectly, coming out nice and runny. The lemon hollandiase sauce is very mild and not too heavy, but they don't give enough of it.

I'd avoid using their bathroom. It's literally the size of an airplane bathroom, if not smaller. You can hit the sink trying to stand up (ladies, and men too for #2). Service is non-existent, so you need to flag down the waiters if you need a new water jug or anything. Overall, I love the variety of brunch items Zazie offers. It's quite expensive ($18 for two eggs in La Mer Benedict?!), but the excellent quality and taste will keep me coming back, despite the long wait times.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
The SF brunch scene is too real at Zazie: the name alone conjures dazzling connotations.  Add patio seating, unique presentation on a floral plate, a menu with gingerbread and miracle pancakes, plus the proximity to the UCSF campus heavily populated by twentysomethings addicted to brunch and propagating the pandemic on Instagram--well I am exaggerating slightly--you get an extremely popular brunch place that ends up on everyone's bucket list.  (I admit to being guilty of all of the above.)

To avoid the long wait, I would suggest going on a weekday or early on a weekend (emphasis on early if you have a large group, since the place is quite small).  On weekends, Bambino's next door is a good alternative for a backup; you just have to be okay with the more traditional name that may remind you of Bambi, and the more traditional vibe.

Before you get inpatient with my review, let me get to the food P:  Like all fancy SF brunch places, the price range is $10-$20 for a decent entree, but I do like how there are different portion options.  The pancakes, waffles, and poached eggs come in 1, 2, or 3; I suggest 1 for breakfast, maybe 2 for brunch if you are really hungry.  After doing my extensive Yelp research and getting excited over the eggs en fonte (yes, the presentation on a cast iron skillet was a factor), I was a bit disappointed when I asked about this and they said they didn't have it that day.  

I went for the French Toast Tahiti ($7 for one piece), stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  It tasted both like heaven and hyperglycemia at the same time: already-sweet-by-definition French toast, this sweet and nutty walnut paste, caramelized bananas that were sweeter than fried plantains, a drizzle of syrup.  And, if that's not bad enough, a sprinkle of powdered sugar to look extra pretty in photos.  And, to make things even worse, there is a little cup of syrup to be added PRN, but I felt like the dish was already sweet to saturation.   Sweetness complaints aside, I enjoyed my French toast--it had a good fluffy texture, was not too thick and egg-yolky, and was very tasty with the walnut sauce and bananas.  The only catch was that after trying the caramelized bananas here, I was unable to eat normal bananas for like a week afterwards because it tasted bland in comparison to the caramelized and syrupy version at Zazie's.

The ambiance is European with a bit of a quaint, small-town feel.  Somehow I'm not surprised at their quaisi-modernist-hipster elements like the water in tall aesthetic glass bottles and baked eggs served in a skillet.  The servers are friendly, similar to what you'd expect at a family-owned restaurant.  My only dissatisfaction was how upset the waitress got when I asked her to take a picture for us on my dSLR and she was confused about how to look through the viewfinnder.. if your hipster games goes strong to dSLR-level, make sure you set the screen to electronic viewfinder in order to avoid the awkwardness of my situation.
author: Edna C.

description:
Perhaps it was the long wait and  having my olfactory senses constantly stimulated by the smell of bacon and pancakes wafting in the breeze, the anticipation probably had just as much to do with how good the food actually tasted. 

La mer: I highly recommend this one of all the poached egg options. Nothing parallels  the combination of luscious runny egg yolks, hollandaise sauce, and fresh crab meat over a toasted English muffin. Soooo grood!  

Croque Monsieur: grilled Black Forest ham and melted gruyere sandwich. The gruyere cheese is so distinct, a heavy and decadent dish

French toast: not as memorable as the previous two, but a good compliment for those who want something sweet.

All of those plus reg coffee and mocha, total bill was around $60. Expect a long wait, we went on a Sat morning 11:30, got seated around 12:30. The servers were efficient and we ordered immediate after seating since we looked at the menu while waiting. If it's a nice sunny day, don't forego the opportunity to sit on the patio behind the restaurant; a quaint little oasis away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

P.s. I just absolute adore their flower plates. It Just adds to the feeling of rustic French country cooking.
author: Bin X.

description:
Zazie is a super cute, French brunch spot! 

Just like all the other top rated, brunch spots in SF, Zazie draws a large crowd on weekend mornings. I arrived at 8:45 a.m. on a Sunday, and there were already about 8-10 parties ahead of me. I would def. recommend getting there early. The staff are all really friendly and work quickly to get food out. 

My friend and I got the Challah french toast and the Divorceee poached eggs (you have the option of picking 1-3 eggs). The eggs were poached perfectly and the food came in perfect proportions. Overall the food was GOOD, but if I had to wait an 45min-1 hr for it, I wouldn't think it was worth the wait.
author: Caroline Z.

description: I would have given it 5 stars if they hadn't run out of French Toast, which I read was the bomb! I enjoyed the short wait w/a long line b/c it was just me. I was not disappointed from reading all of the reviews and then enjoying my own experience. The staff was friendly, the food was fabulous, and I liked the atmosphere. I ordered the potatoes, since I heard they were good and they were awesome! I also ordered the gingerbread pancake and everything about it was delicious. I loved the big round handle free coffee cup, more like a bowl) that my latte cane in to drink. I also ordered an egg for $2. The prices include the tip, so you get a good size portion of food and you get your moneys worth. This was the first time I saw tip is included in the prices.
author: Sheri A.

description: As an avid yelp reviewer, I've had few dining experiences that have literally left me speechless. My experience at Zazie was well worth the hour wait, heck, I would have waited 3 hours for the splendid service and bounty of brunch bliss that ensued here. Things started heating up on delightfully heated floral back patio as we began the meal with 2 sultry, spicy mimosa choices--mango chamoy (with chile tajin rim job) and a ginger mimosa complete with candied ginger garnish. Time indubitably stopped as I wrapped my lips around and sunk my teeth into their blt, and I shivered with bliss as the oven roasted tomatoes oozed and squirted all over my hands and mouth. Then came a twosome of pancakes, including the gingerbread pancake with Bosch roasted pears and lemon curd, and the aptly named "miracle pancake" with stone ground cornmeal, strawberries, and more lemon curd. I'm ready to take a bath in that lemon curd. Mmmmm. The best part of the meal--this place truly takes care of their employees. The price (which may seem a little steep to some) includes gratuity which goes towards providing all of their employees with health insurance. And hopefully life insurance too, and I certainly died and went to heaven during the course of this meal!
author: Alisa W.

description: So good and worth the wait. Service was incredible they even brought me coffee while waiting in line. I had the daily special, but the other omelets I tasted were delicious. Also I had to buy their homemade haberno hot sauce to go.
author: Daria V.

description:
