not worth an hour-long wait. food was okay, typical benedict, nothing that special about it. I did like the garden seating atmosphere - it almost had a backyard feel to it, making it pretty homey. the home fries were good and came with whole cloves of fried garlic. 

overall, not the greatest but not terrible.
author: Valentina D.

description: The best brunch spot in SF! Come early to get seated right away. Pleasant outdoor area, friendly service, and excellent food!!
author: Nicole D.

description: I am not really into western food. But after having French food at Chaumont in Beverly hills, LA, I was craving for their French toast badly. When coming back to SF, i tried to look for a really good French restaurant to go for. Zazie was in the top list! However I was pretty disappointed that their French toast was not as half good as Chaumont :-( Not to mention 1hour waiting to be seated. Now still on the hunt for a great French place in SF...
author: Thu L.

description: The tables outdoors are first come first serve. If you want to eat indoors you will have to put your name down on the list. We waited for an hour. The pancakes were large and fluffy. What amazed me the most was that the butter was soft and salty with a consistency that was perfect for spreading on toast. On the other hand, the syrup tasted standard. The strawberries were fresh and somewhat sweet and the lemon custard was fragrant. Although the pancakes were good, I don't think it was worth the price and time waiting for.
author: James S.

description: Got their St. Trop eggs benedict and French Toast Tahiti, both were ok, not amazing. Just another typical brunch spot in SF that's a bit overpriced. Great customer service though!
author: Khanh N.

description:
WOOO HOOO. 

The gingerbread pancake here was delicious!!! And I usually don't enjoy pancakes. They had this peace sauce on top of the gingerbread pancake that was ABSOLUTELY delicious. The peace sauce on top of the soft and perfectly cooked gingerbread pancake was just perfect!

the crab benedict was also delicious, but not as good as MaMas. 

My favorite thing about this place was that the service was amazing!! The best part of it was that their restaurant pays their servers fair wages, which allows their costumers to not have to leave a tip. This is customer experience done right. 5 out of 5 I will come back to this place again.
author: Micho L.

description:
There were no wait on a Wednesday afternoon which was a plus. I've been meaning to try this place and had high expectations for this place after reading the reviews. But my smoked salmon aka St. Trop Benedict didn't really wow me... It was good at best and wasn't as flavorful as I thought it would be. I only had 1 egg with a side of potatoes and that was already $16. Seems pricey to me even though they do not take tip. I only chose that since it seems to be a customer favorite and I'm a big fan of egg benedicts. My friend had the Tahiti French Toast ($16) and he really liked that dish. I tried it and it was pretty sweet and the texture was nice.

What I was really impressed with was the service! The waiters are really genuine people and kind. They always smile and they check up on you periodically. Anyway, just because I love the customer service, I will come back in the future to try other dishes and hopefully find the one that'll mesmerize my tastebuds!
author: Emily L.

description: Not from the area, so I guess it was amazing that my gf and I walked right in and got an amazing a table on the back patio. I ordered the eggs Benedict and it was fantastic... the green hot sauce was just the right amount of spice.
author: Skylar Y.

description:
Pretty good brunch place, if you're waiting to wait for minimum an hour during peak hours. They have a decent menu with the usual brunch foods: french toast, eggs benedicts, omelettes, etc. They have a lot of flavors of mimosas like blackberry, elderflower, etc. Honestly, nothing really stood out to me super much, but I would still come back!

It's pretty cool that they don't require tipping and their prices aren't extremely expensive either.
author: Carmen C.

description:
I just want to go on the record and say that I've been putting brunch on blast long before that annoying New York Times article*** did. 

FACT: There is no brunch that is better than just sleeping in.
FACT: There is no brunch that's better than a rager of a night out that causes you to not even be able to fathom waking up during brunch hours the next day. 
FACT: NYT, you should hire me because I'm way ahead of the times on what people will hate next. Haters gonna hate, but this hater won't make you wait.
FACT: Even if Johnny Cash himself came back from the dead to cook, serve, and partake in brunch, it'd still be a hard pass from me in my comfy bed with sheets stained of salsa splatters because I have a bad habit of eating nachos in bed... which is also better than brunch.

Needless to say, I won't be joining Team Brunch anytime soon, but Zazie's Crab Meat Benedict (known as La Mer on the menu) has even a brunch-hater like myself eating a bit of crow. 

It's one of those things where if you only get up early to eat once all year, this is the place to go. 

The wait can be long, so be sure you sign up on the clipboard outside the door ASAP and make absolutely positive you have your most legible writer do the John Hancock-ing because if they can't read that sh*t, they will just pass you over. I recommend writing down whomever's name is the most 'normal' in your group for ease of all. 

For example: If your name is Dostoevsky and your friend's name is Brad, go with Brad and write in big, all caps letters for priority seating. If everyone in your group has a crazy name with silent vowels, and umlauts all over the place, maybe just come up with an agreed upon faux simple name and stand by that? 

There is an area on the front patio that's first come/first serve, but you really have to be ready to duke it out in the most obnoxious way if want it. I really recommend waiting for inside (or the back beautiful back patio- which I can attest to) because even though the wait seemed like it would be all day, in reality it was probably less than 30-minutes for my group of 3. 

We were lucky enough to get a spot on the ivy-laced, shaded back patio and the worst thing about being here (besides that I was up super early on a Saturday) is trying to number down the number of dishes you want -- because you're gonna want at least 10. 

Things to know:
+ The special can run out pretty early.
+ The La Mer is pricey and worth every red cent with it's large lumps of REAL, fresh crab meat. (GET THIS)
+ You can customize the amount of food you get with a lot of dishes, depending on if you'd like 1, 2, 3, eggs, biscuits, etc. 
+ They do have beer and mimosas.
+ Their coffee was wonderful, although they will make no effort to refill your cup. 
+ The service (besides the no coffee refill thing) is perky and pretty on point, while still being pretty leisurely a dining experience.
+ Waiting for the single bathroom in the only service hallway sucks. 
+  Also, the bathroom is for skinny people only. You'll understand when you see it. I barely made it in/out.
+ Brunch with no booze will run you between $18-28 a person, but even as a skeptic, I can assure you it's worth it.
+ Don't come here with more than 4 people. It's a tight space and personally, I think it's just really show-offy if you come to brunch with more than 3-friends. Congratulations, you're popular and you don't mind waiting an hour and half for brunch. We all get it. 

*** And also, for the record, I take offense to that Julian Casablancas quote about white people having brunch. I am, for all intents and purposes, a white person, and I hate brunch. JC, Please try to be more PC (and more importantly, accurate) in your insults and note that brunch's #1 offenders are annoying white people who coupled in their mid-twenties and think they are "basically an old married couple, lol, so cute." at 32.
author: Candice G.

description: Super long brunch wait. Food good to yummy. Coffee not great. Nice atmosphere. Pleasant service.
author: Erika D.

description: Best brunch in SF in beautiful Cole Valley!!  Amazing scrambles, french toast, and by far the best breakfast potatoes (w/ cloves of garlic).  Some of my favorite scrambles are the Italie and Mexican, which come with their amazing potatoes and toast.  Being one of the most popular brunch spots in SF means you should come early (9am) if you don't want to wait a while (at least an hour) during peak times (10am-12pm).  However, it is worth the wait!
author: Kevin N.

description: Friendly staff, the wait can be long on the weekend ... the trout was great. And hey, you self centered tech turds, the sidewalk is not your goddamned meeting room/social media jerk off point. Take your clusterfuck crew and take a hike. Wake up and let people use it, next time yer getting a forearm shimmer to your selfish zombie ass head.
author: Henry K.

description:
It's been a few years since I first wrote a review for Zazie after having had dessert there, so I'm probably due for an update. 

While most people go to Zazie for brunch (which is good), I like Zazie best for dinner. You can make reservations, which is much better than waiting in the 45-minute brunch line. When we were there recently, the waiter recommended the pork chop to my husband. I normally do not really like pork chops; so often, they're dry and even tough. But not at Zazie. I didn't even know pork chops could be that good and I would definitely have it when I come back. And of course, I'll always get the baked hot chocolate for dessert (even with brunch). 

One of the best things for dinner at Zazie is the Monday night dog night on the patio. Our dog had a great time at her first night out in (well, sort of) a real restaurant.
author: Susan S.

description: My favorite brunch spot in the city! Love this place. Their benedicts are amazing. Love their specialty pancakes as well.
author: Nina M.

description: Came here for brunch once, and will not come back. We waited for an hour, but that is to be expected of brunch in SF. But what gives it 3 stars is the mediocrity of the brunch items. I was just not impressed. Felt very standard and nothing too over the top WOW. (Plow on the other hand I LOVE). We got a french toast, and an omelet. And we got a bloody mary, which was also mediocre.
author: Annie K.

description:
Waited at least 90 mins for a table, but that worked out fine since we were waiting for the rest of our people to join.

We sat in the back patio space - charming ambience. I LOVE that they pay a fair wage and don't require tipping. Brought me back to my time living in Australia. The waiter was brutally honest when we asked his opinion on some of the meals (don't try the creme brûlée oatmeal, according to him).

I had the most ridiculously delicious set of pancakes and bacon. I went for one of their specials- pumpkin pancakes- wowzers, incredible. Fresh pumpkin (not canned) and homemade cream. Still dreaming about those pumpkin fluffs of heaven.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Long-overdue review for a delicious getaway. Have only been for brunch never for dinner. If the dinner is as good as the brunch, this place has all the right moves. YUH!!

The food is always terrific. Though there can be quite a long wait (close to an hour during rush time) it's worth the wait. I've had the best pancakes of my life here on numerous occasions. Perfectly crisp exterior yet light and fluffy. They are heavenly! The miracle pancakes are even better. They come with a light lemon curd that is to die for.

The fiancé always gets the Benedict. All of the Benedicts are perfect. They really know how to poach an egg here. And the hollandaise is well-prepared. It's not heavy at all. Perfect balance of a creamy lemony sauce. If you haven't been it's a must.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
How is it that I have been coming to SF all these years and this was the first time that I actually got to go. Let's just put it out there, best place for brunch!!!

This place is packed and the line can be super ridiculous, so make a reservation or come early, but don't come too hungry because the line can be pretty bad, but what is super cool is that the outside seating is first come first serve, so if you're in a smaller party, you can totally get a seat without waiting ridiculously long.  My friend and I thought that we were going to be waiting for about 45 minutes, but a couple of seats opened up and nobody else was going for it, so we shrugged our shoulders and took a seat.

The staff was so friendly and efficient.  Even after seating ourselves, we were greeted immediately and a host kindly cleaned up the table after us and then came back with the menu.  We started off with a bottle of champagne and did a "make your own" mimosa.  We went standard and got the orange juice.  The guy came out with a bucket of ice with our champagne inside and popped it open right in front of us... so fancy.  He then came out with a cute tiny carafe which contained our orange juice, totally worth the $30. 

I ordered the La Mer, which is what most people get.  I just had to because the dungeness crab totally caught my eye. It was an english muff with gooey poached eggs on top with avocados.  I mean, can it really get better than that?  It was like biting a piece of heaven in every bite, it was so delish. I can still taste the wonderfulness right this minute.  Like I said, perfection.  I'll have to try some of their other popular dishes when i come back.

It can be a little pricey, but worth every penny.  Just be prepared to spend some money. I promise that it won't disappoint.
author: Claudette B.

description:
Zazie was one of the few places to offer brunch on a Friday, and my friends and I were ecstatic! My friend who lived in SF came to put our name down, and she said it only took 30 minutes! But be aware, they only seat you when your whole party is here, so the wait can change depending on that. 

They had 4 two seater tables on the outside, luckily with heaters! The inside decor has cute paintings and ornaments. It was very quaint and cozy, especially with the booth seating. I must say, some seating arrangements were a bit forced and awkward. (A small 1.5 diameter table for three..... hmmmm)

The three of us decided to share and we got Miracle Pancakes (cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd and strawberries), French Toast Tahiti, and the La Mer. 

I ordered the La Mer with 3 eggs, aka 3 eggs benedicts ($25). The crab itself was extremely tasty already! With the lemon Hollandaise sauce it was a party on a muffin. One of the downfalls of the eggs benedict was the avocado, because there was barely any! I was also extremely disappointed in the serving size of the potatoes, too small to enjoy its deliciousness. 

The French Toast Tahiti, WOWEEEEEEEE, I CAN EAT THE WALNUT FILLING BY THE SPOONFUL! It was extremely tasty and also very light on the sugar. From the french toast to the toasted banana, everything was on point! We ordered 2 slices of the toast and I only ate a quarter. It was extremely filling and the perfect size to get a taste of. I would definitely recommend this dish!

The Miracle Pancakes for that day (January 2, 2015) were the Cornmeal Pancakes with Lemon Curd and Strawberries. I guess I don't really like cornmeal because the texture of the pancake was too dense. My two friends enjoyed it though! 

My friend also got the Le Metro, as the special mimosa of the day was already sold out by 12pm.The Le Metro was very refreshing and herby! It also came with a cute lavender garnish.

Overall, I enjoyed my experience here at Zazie! I would love to come again and try other items on the menu.

TIPS: Lots of metered parking in the area (There's also a laundromat to get quarters!) If you're lucky, you can score a residential parking spot, free 2 hour parking!
author: Winnie I.

description:
This place always has a very long line to get in. The outdoor tables are first come first serve and almost everyone agrees the gingerbread pancakes are a solid win.

Service was good and food was good. Only compliant I have is the price. I don't think one dish of breakfast food should cost $20 and above. However in a world of IHOP/Dennys and other breakfast chains starting to hike up their prices. I guess it is somewhat sane.
author: Nathan A.

description: Them potatoes though...no matter what you order, get a side of potatoes. Great place. Staff are amazing. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Zakarya D.

description: Eating here is like eating at a friends house.  You can taste the care that goes into the food preparation. Where to begin? Boy oh boy...the gingerbread pancakes - WOW!  Light, fluffy and full of flavor, you can chose different toppings such as lemon curd, poached pears.  You can't go wrong with the poached pears.  The French toast Tahiti is another work of art challah (hall-uh) bread stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts...you will not be disappointed.
author: Carlos F.

description:
one of my favorite brunch spots in the city. small inside, very cute outdoor space. favorites: gingerbread pancakes, la mer crab Benedict, st. trop Benedict (smoked salmon). they really have delicious hollandaise, which makes all the difference in the world. 

my favorite drink is their elderflower mimosa- the austriche. 

love their new "no tip" policy, meaning that the price of the fare are adjusted accordingly to accommodate a living wage, full benefits and profit sharing package to all employees. I believe they were one of the first restaurants to do this in the city. though controversial, I do applaud them for taking care of their employees and being responsible employers- quite a courageous decision to make, especially as a small business owner. 

support your local!
author: Vanessa D.

description:
The first time we went here I had by far the best trout I have ever had. We sat out on the back patio area. The heat lamps they have are more than enough to heat your shoulders and upper half.  The service is great and the menu offers something for almost everyone, some of the vegetarian's I know like this place a lot because there are always good options for them on the menu, and besides being veggies they are also somewhat picky eaters. The setting is cozy and private. We liked this place after being there a few times we had our reception dinner out on the back patio, it was way cool. The menu we picked out was delicious and affordable. I would recommend this place for any mild size party.

One note that might bother some people - I did smell some smoke from some other
backyard - its a no smoking patio.
author: Ben M.

description: When I was first looking for brunch locations, I came across Zazie. There were a few things that attracted me to this place. One: the decor and the feel of the environment was soo inviting. Two: the place being tip free and that it included wages for the worker, dental care, paid paternity/maternity leave, and etc. Zazie not only displayed the utmost exemplary customer service, but their  food was perfect and unique. I've had a magical experience before and I've came back for more!
author: Bernice L.

description: Born and raised in sf and never knew this placed existed. Gf found this and good thing we went early or else you are not getting a seat! The coffee is amazing and the coffee cake is unreal. I order the Monaco which was probably the best eggs Benedict I've ever had. My gf ordered the crab Benedict which was good but could have used a little more flavor. Highly recommend this if you are in the area, amazing service and they don't expect tips. Keep it up guys!
author: Sam L.

description:
I made the huge mistake of coming here for dinner instead of brunch. I looked forlornly at all the photos of eggs benedict on Yelp and cried a little to myself. I will be back for your benny, Zazie. We made a last minute reservation here on a Sunday night. The interior features natural wood and high ceilings.

I ordered the Grilled Heritage Pork Chop ($23), which came on a bed of savory bread pudding (bacon, fontina, arugula, mushrooms). The food was obviously cooked with care and seasoned just right. I went in with the expectation of falling in love with savory bread pudding, but I actually couldn't tell it was bread at all - it could have been a potato base and served the same purpose. There was nothing bad about the food and the meat quality justifies the price.

With a hopeful future plan for brunch, I would usually give Zazie a 4-star rating, but the service was off. The host cheerfully offered us the window seats; then the waiter came and said the tables were already reserved, no smile or apology for the miscommunication. We asked to split the bill by person/item (we would have been totally okay without splitting it; we just thought we'd ask), and the waiter made a big deal about what a favor he was doing for us, given that this would NEVER happen during brunch. I would have appreciated a polite decline to our request, but he complained about it multiple times even when we offered to pay in one card.
author: Jessica F.

description:
SOOO worth the wait. I almost didn't mind the wait. We came on a Saturday morning around 10 AM and crowds of people waiting were already there. It was a little over an hour wait, but I guess that is pretty  common. The staff was super nice. The decor is pretty casual and cute. I love that they provide their workers with a living wage, health care, and etc. 

The food was sooooo good. We got two orders of eggs benedicts (with three eggs) and the week special, banana stuffed french toast, to share between 3 people. The Albert eggs benedict was good but the Monaco eggs benedict was probably my favorite.

It was a good way to start the day.
10/10 totally would recommend.
author: Kathy S.

description:
-Came for weekday brunch and we were seated immediately. The host came over and cleaned off a table for us. 
-Waitor came over and took our drink orders, and let us know that coffee cake was sold out. 
-Aftet we put in our order, another couple sat down next to us and ordered the coffee cake. 
-The other couple got to eat the last coffee cake and we didn't.
author: Joe B.

description:
Went here on a Sunday around 1 pm, waited for about 40 mins to get seated. The line moved pretty quickly. Didn't know there was a pretty cozy patio area in the back. 

Food: Ordered the La Mer (dungeness crab/avocado) and the Florentine (spinach/portobello mushrooms) with some Mimosas. The poached eggs were so heavenly! The potatoes were quite good as well. Next time, I'll definitely have to get it with the smoked salmon.
author: Garrick L.

description: Zazie is my favorite secret for a casual, delicious dinner in Cole Valley. Most don't know about it, but are willing to wait in line for hours for brunch. I say skip this and go for dinner on a weeknight. The warm freshly baked rolls and the French onion soup are a must to start any dinner! Love the back patio too! Great for a date or for family.
author: Frankie I.

description:
We finally got a chance to try this place out today. Walked in at 2:36pm as a party of 2 and got lucky with a table. I saw and appreciated that they still accepted people (even large parties) in or to wait until closing time at 3pm unlike Outerlands which didn't let me wait 45 minutes well before closing.

The ambiance is cute and intimate making a cute brunch date spot. Servers are nice and patient. We had the Monaco Benedict with roasted potatoes, eggs scramble with toast and salad and the Challah French toast with fresh fruit, house coffee and grapefruit juice. The only thing I would recommend is the Benedict because the eggs were poached well, hollandaise sauce and potatoes were delicious. Everything else can be skipped though. French toast is flavorless, overcooked, dry and hard, fruit was soggy, regular toast seems to be of the same bread, scramble was decent but pretty expensive at $3 more for a second egg, salad and dressing was bland, house coffee while not the worse at a cafe was watered down and grapefruit juice certainly did not taste fresh squeezed. Why are the reviews so high here?

Tips are already included in the price so $53 for an unimpressive breakfast did not make for a good Sunday brunch, unless of course it's near closing time and you're desperate for brunch food.
author: Leslie H.

description: Mine and my husbands go to breakfast place whenever we're in the mood for something special and not the ordinary breakfast. We get there before they open just so we dont have to wait (the lines are long even before they open!) Love sitting outside and having a cup of their chai (just wish it was hotter!) and their chorizo mexican breakfast! Also their crab benedict when its in season is great too! All in all, never a disappointment!
author: Kiran B.

description:
This place has a bit of a wait but it's worth it. I came here on July 4th with some friends and waited only about 30 mins. This was my 2nd time back and tried it first with my boyfriend. We love the La Mer eggs benedict. It is cool how you can chose to have 1, 2, or 3 eggs benedict and other dishes have that same option as well. I chose the one egg benedict so we can order other plates to try. I also love their Challah French toast with fresh seasonal fruit. The french toast was nice and fluffy. The orange cinnamon butter also had a nice flavor added to the french toast. 
I would say I would come here again. Brunch is my favorite meal!
author: Mabel T.

description:
The food was pretty good but be prepared to wait for a long time as well as pay big bucks. I got the eggs Benedict and my wife got the French toast Tahiti. Both were solids and I have no complains. But not sure if it was worth paying $60 for 2 for brunch food. Coffee was just plain diner coffee.

A couple of neat things: it's expensive because the employees get full benefits and it's a no tip policy. I really dig how the employees are treated well. 

Also the 4 tables in the front are first come first serve, not bad! But it's definitely not a place for big groups. 

Enjoy!
author: Ander C.

description:
This place has been on my to-do brunch list for the longest time and I finally got a chance to try it out.

There was definitely quite a wait so I suggest going early or expecting to wait a while.

The food is very very fresh.  I don't think you can go wrong with anything that you choose on the menu.
author: Michelle T.

description: Best brunch I've had in SF! Short wait, fast and friendly service. We sat on the back patio on a bit of a chilly morning but the heat lamps kept us toasty. The menu had many great breakfast/brunch options. Egg-forward dishes were a trend for my group. Lots of creative and delicious variations of poached eggs were a hit. The table also raved about the coffee cake if you need a bit of sweet to go with the savory. I went with a traditional breakfast (eggs, potatoes, bacon, toast), and it was done perfectly! Especially make sure you get a side of the home fries which include big chunks of roasted garlic. PRO TIP: If you like to spice up your eggs like I do, ask for the house-made habanero-tomatillo salsa! We will definitely be coming back!
author: Ryan H.

description: Loved it! Super cute restaurant, nice staff, and their food was great. Ask for outside seating if weather permits. Will definitely be back!
author: F D.

description:
Maybe more like 2.5 stars... Gahhh so disappointed here... the food was quite good but the service definitely killed the good vibe =/

I was really looking forward to brunch with one of my good friends, and when we arrived there weren't too many people so we didn't feel cramped. I ordered one poached egg (Pierre Noir) with bacon and tomatoes, and one gingerbread pancake. My friend ordered the French Toast Tahiti and one miracle pancake which happened to be poppy seed flavored. 

The inside of the restaurant was cute but they put the tables very close together. Our waitress only came by to take our order and deliver our food; we had to flag her down for the check when it came time. The poached egg was whatever, it was super runny and the white didn't hold up very well for some reason. The bacon and tomatoes were good though. The gingerbread pancake was massive, and the lemon curd on top was pretty tasty; you don't really need the syrup because it's already sweet. I tried a bit of my friend's french toast which was yummy with the caramelized banana, and her poppyseed pancake was tasty too, I actually kind of liked it more than my gingerbread. 

After we finished our food our waitress brought our check, and it had a fee to pay for the workers benefits which was around $3. Okay, I wasn't aware of this at the beginning of the meal but I was willing to deal with it because hey, it's to help the staff out. BUT THEN I saw that they tacked on 20% TIP for TWO people. WTF. My friend and I wanted to split the bill between our two cards, so when the waitress came back I mentioned we wanted to split the balance, then add tip later. She said this wasn't possible and we had to pay the full 20% (I thought tip was voluntary so what the heck?!). She also failed to run my debit card so I had to use a different card which was annoying. 

I don't appreciate being told how much to tip, especially when it's only a party of two, the waitress didn't come by to ask us if we needed anything, and it's BREAKFAST for goodness sake. Not cool Zazie.
author: Sam F.

description: Best Brunch Ever! The server was exceptional and the food was delicious. I gotta give it to the cooks, the kitgen is little but they make it work.I highly recommend this place and thank you Servando for being accommodating to us!
author: Gardenia H.

description: No French restaurant should be out of coq au vin at 645pm on a Saturday! That automatically lost two stars for Zazie. Otherwise it was an excellent restaurant. Two of us wanted the coq au vin and were left scrambling when we were told they were out of it. I ended up with a small salad with added chicken and nothing else as I don't eat beef or pork. My guy had the beef as did my friend while her hubby had the pork chop. They brought out fresh warm dinner rolls and I loved the stoneware dishes! The meals arrived and the three of them loved their food. For me, a salad was a salad and I could have gotten that anywhere. Disappointing but gets an AOK rating due to the others enjoying their meals. My boyfriend ordered a coffee and never got it but he got creamer. We asked where the coffee was and the waiter forgot. It happens! One great thing to mention was that there's no tipping here. Tips are included in the price which I thought was great! Not sure if I would return though. If they had chicken for my salad, why no coq au vin???
author: Sandra P.

description:
I had been meaning to try Zazie for a couple of years, but was deterred by the constant crowd and my (wrong) assumption that this place would be overrated.  Among our party of three, we shared the New York Scramble, the Monaco poached eggs and the Miracle Pancakes and all were delicious.  We also each ordered a latte or mocha and both came in a huge bowl and were really good.  One of my favorite things about this place is that they pay their employees a living wage + benefits and tip is rolled into the price of the food, which makes me feel great about patronizing this restaurant.  On top of that, the service is really good.

Tip: Outdoor seating in front of Zazie is first come first served.  The best way to bypass the wait is to snag a table in front.  Although Zazie has signs informing patrons of this policy, very few pay attention.  I managed to bypass the hour wait I otherwise would have had by noticing that a group sitting in front had just left.  None of the 30+ people waiting outside seem to notice and I was able to sit down with my party right away.  Zazie has heat lamps outside so no need to fear the cold.
author: Jessica C.

description: I absolutely liked the cinnamon flavored French toast. It came in combination with bacon and eggs. The hot chocolate was served in an oversized cup. We got there early enough to beat the long wait. Overall, a pleasant experience in Cole Valley. Attentive food servers. Definitely recommending this place.
author: Martha B.

description: The food is excellent here, despite the fact that they don't allow any modifications to their dishes. Yes, this even includes modifications for food allergies. This is a non-tipping establishment, which I thought was pretty cool. The staff here was very attentive, too. The seating was cozy and had great ambiance. Our table had the duck (best looking dish), the lamb, and the steak. Go at 5pm when they open, or place reservations in advance. Totally worth it!
author: Bree S.

description:
I've always wanted to try Zazie but never got around to it until recently because I despise waiting in long lines for brunch.  When I finally tried it, I realized I was really missing out!  I've come here twice for dinner and once for brunch in the last month.  Although I would like to try more on their brunch menu, so far I prefer the dinner menu better! 

I had my birthday dinner here and the owner, Jen, was very helpful in helping me set it up.  For parties larger than 8, I believe you have to reserve a large group party and order on a shared or set menu, which has a minimum price per person.  I had a party of 11, and decided to do the group shared menu.  They also made a cute personalized menu for all my birthday guests which was a nice touch!

We had the following items for the shared group menu (which I got to choose):

Appetizer: Strawberry Arugula Salad (Salade Guillaume)
Entrees:  Grilled Niman Ranch Flat Iron Steak, Salmon (Poisson en Papillote), and Fresh Lemon Ricotta Raviolis
Sides: Mashed potatoes and Grilled Summer Squash
Dessert: Signature Baked Hot Chocolate - very rich!

For the shared group menu for 11, they gave us enough food to feed 15.  Lots of yummy leftovers!

The food was delicious, especially the mashed potatoes and steak which had a mushroom sauce that was out of this world.  My boyfriend also really enjoyed the hot bun.  

The restaurant is quite small and quaint, and the service is very good.  There's an outdoor patio area where you can sit, or I've also seen some larger parties rent the whole outdoor area out.  The front of the restaurant also has four tables of 2 (can squeeze 3), which are first come first served.  Bon appetite!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Fabulous DINNER at Zazie! The food envy dish of the night was the pork chop served with bread pudding. Very high quality heritage pork that had been brined to create a tender, juicy pork chop that was perfect. We had a very long food geek debate about the pork chop before finally asking the waitress if we were right! Shows what a difference high quality meat can make. The bread pudding was fab too. 

I had the hanger steak which was also good (but less food envy-ish than the pork). Very tasty green beans. 

We shared the goat cheese lemon cake for dessert. This was too heavy and sweet for my liking but I could see its appeal for someone who likes their desserts like this. 

Our waitress was attentive and friendly she did a great job!
author: Ada C.

description: My family and I had a fabulous 17 person dinner there last week as our rehearsal dinner prior to our wedding. They were incredibly easy to work with and accommodated our vegetarian and non vegetarian eaters alike. The 3 kiddos were also well taken care of and the back patio was perfect (and they heaters worked!). Thank you Zazie for another wonderful experience!
author: Dena B.

description:
Great brunch place! Came here on a weekend for brunch and the wait was horrendous (1.5 hour for a group of 5). Once inside, we were seated in a corner that was super cramped, but "cozy." The food was spectacular, though! The dungeness crab eggs Benedict was amazing, though it was pricey for 3 ($22). The Tahiti french toast was also bomb - great for those with a sweet tooth like me! The Mediterranean plate was a little lackluster and the plating looked sadly sparse. Overall, no one in our group was particularly full after the rather expensive meal, so we headed across the street for a second meal at La Boulange. 

I wouldn't return for brunch unless there was a less than 10 minute line (ha!), but I have heard good things (really from Check, Please! Bay Area) about their dinners so if I'm in the area I might pop in for that. 

The wait staff was nice, but minus a star for the serving sizes/ price ratio. And the wait time, though given the small restaurant and popularity I suppose it can't be helped!
author: Angela L.

description: Best. Brunch. Ever. We loved the patio seating. Service was awesome and funny. All the food was so great! Poached eggs were perfection and splurged on the tahitian style french toast. Delicious!
author: Rachel N.

description: Hand down some of the best eggs Benedict in the city. I come every time I'm in town. They have excellent service and it's a traditional style European restaurant (from the water bottle to the tip included). I recommend the Florentine poached eggs if you're a mushroom lover like myself. Also, the mobs is to die for! Love the atmosphere and the food. Nothing says good morning like a tasty poached egg!!!
author: Jack J.

description: My bf wanted to try dinner here, since I love the brunch. To our surprise Dinner was awful. The server was very unprofessional high 5ving  his co worker while attempting to take our order. The onion soup tasted like melted butter, not what I expected. I remember reading the menu and it stated gratuity and all fees included, the server took our change from the table, we had to as another employee for confirmation gratuity was included. Definitely not returning.
author: Dee D.

description:
The food is so delicious here! Went for brunch with my parents and the garlic chunks they put in my mom's fries were THE ABSOLUTE BEST. I had ordered the gingerbread pancakes and the pancake along with the lemon curd, pear and syrup were delicious! The price may seem high but it's good to know they're paying the employees fairly.
However, they lose a star for their service, because they skipped over us on the waiting list with other parties about the same size even though we'd waited about an hour and a half for our table!
author: Jade J.

description:
With the abundance of brunch spots in SF, it is hard to decide where to go or if it will be worth the wait.  I am not a huge fan of waiting so I told my friend to meet me at 8:30 am which of course we were seated immediately.  It was such a nice day out that we chose to sit in the outdoor patio.  

We ordered the La Mer eggs benedict, oh goodness was that just a perfect combination.  The runny egg yolk combined the fresh dungeness crab combined with the avocado; it was a great start to the day.  

We also ordered the Tahiti French Toast after seeing all the amazing pictures on yelp.  For me I thought it looks better than it tastes but still worth trying if you are a french toast fan and like it on the sweet side. 

I would definitely come back again!
author: Lauren S.

description: Simple but delicious.  I had the English muffin with fresh picked crab, avocado and poached egg. On the side, perfectly roasted potatoes with crispy garlic. Expensive, but with a beautiful back patio.
author: Richard B.

description:
So Little Bit and I were in search of a possible location for a Wedding Brunch in February and this location was one on our list.

Went on a Monday a couple of weeks ago. We both enjoyed the "Eggs Divorce"! OMG  we both looked at each other across the table with our eyes wide as if it was just the most AMAZING bite we had ever had! 

Sat outside back was very nice, quaint location a bit small but in a cozy sort of way. There was a wait... but worth it. Mimosa was nice to we shared the one with Cherry Sorbet (trick - stir it up) Christyl had the one with Black Currant didn't find that as pleasing as the one with the Cherry Sorbet. Also the Gingerbread pancakes looked scrumptious as well. The other order was the Tahiti French Toast not as mind-blowing as our Eggs Divorce... 

We will be returning for sure.

Respectfully Reviewed
author: Pam S.

description: Solid weekend brunch place with outdoor seating. Arrive early as there is always a very long line.
author: Christina J.

description:
My go to brunch spot every time I am in the city.  I always take visitors here too. 
Honestly everything is amazing. I always make sure to order the stuffed french toast. They have awesome mimosas.
Amazing eggs benedict, with crab!
There is always a 30- 45 min wait to be prepared for that. I have waited an hour before, but its TOTALLY worth it. You can grab some bubbles from the bar next door.
Outside seating is so cute! Service is great. Love this place.
author: Tessa S.

description: Great service, delicious brunch! (I enjoyed the gingerbread pancake (Delicious and perfectly sweet orange marmalade like topping) and a banana foster french toast)   I was bummed that they ran out of their special for the week as they were changing up the menu the next day. But was happy with my meal! Overall delicious and sweet.  Downloaded an app called cover that helps pay for and split your check easily and got $10 off my meal!  Woohoo.
author: Mel H.

description:
Great, quaint spot for brunch! 

Expect a wait. We went on a Monday morning and still waited 20 minutes.

The service was swift and food is all very, very good. They ran out of potatoes and although tip was included, we found the food on the pricey side - our brunch cost $57 for 2 eggs benedicts (one with only one egg), a coffee, and a chai latte.

That being said, the Albert Eggs Benedict was delicious!

I am not sure we will go back on a frequent basis, but if a guest is in town, it is definitely a great, fun spot with many delicious options. And it is super cute!
author: Sophie C.

description:
The first time I went to Zazie was back in Aug 2012. I remember the food being excellent even back then, well now it's even better!

They expanded the deck so that seating is much more comfortable on the patio. I still appreciate the heat lamps, and great service too. This time I had the fettuccine plate which was HUGE, we shared the grilled squash as an appetizer and my wine paring was perfect with both dishes. 

I've always had a really great dining experience here, and when I'm back in the city I am down to come again when it's suggested. 

Oh, so what made this a 5 star raiting? How convenient Yelp made it to get reservations. Zazie has it so that you can reserve a table, which a lot of restaurants do, but when I didn't specify that I wanted outside dining I messaged the restaurant via Yelp, and someone actually replied within a few minuets. It doesn't get much better than that; convenience, excellent food & fantastic ambiance.
author: Nikki H.

description: This little gem was recommended to us by some great local friends of ours and it certainly did not disappoint. We were able to sneak in on a weekday but immediately after we sat the place went on an enormous wait, and for good reason. On the inside, the ambiance was very homey and quaint, and our server took time to walk us through some of his favorites on the menu. Our party had an array of unique mimosas to start our meal, which I highly recommend. The food came quickly and every bite was to die for. Highlights include the red velvet pancake, chicken sausage, any of the delicious omelets, and the potatoes which seem to be flavored with garlic and rosemary. Make sure to check the specials when you arrive, as there are usually some awesome things listed off the menu. A final note would be the radical approach of a non-tipping policy, as the pricing reflects to pay a living wage to all its employees. I tipped more anyway, as the meal and service was above and beyond. Kudos to this great breakfast joint. Check it out!
author: Brad B.

description: We went there twice for brunch because it was so good! They have a great outdoor enclosed patio, amazing food, definitely try their pancakes!!
author: Megan W.

description: Excellent. Great food, lots of fun. Went for brunch, sat outside.
author: Libby L.

description:
I will rate on food only because a good place is going to have a long wait but I went before it opened and got seated right away. 

It's not the type of place where you wait in line but you have to write your name down on a list. 

Service was good our server was comfortable. And food did take a little longer than I would have liked but I guess If the restaurant fills up at the moment it opens and everyone orders at the same time I guess it's inevitable. 

Food was amazing will totally come again. 
Had pumpkin cakes! Benedict!

If you don't want to wait there is first come first serve seating outside but it might be cold.
author: Esther M.

description: Very busy place on the weekend we went.  We stood for about an hour until we snagged a seat for two on the few outside tables in front that are first come first serve that we learned some younger locals can be really aggressive about o.O.  The sever was great and apologized for having us wait seated for a bit before getting to us.  Overall the food was great.  We tried that weeks miracle pancakes special and one of the scrambles with a side of fruit.  The home style potatoes were my favorite.  The mimosa we had with the peach sorbet was yummy but super sweet.  The tip is included in their prices which is good for the staff.  Don't venture off too far because they will skip you if your name is called and you're not there.  There was a coffee place next door that saved my sanity while we waited. Lol
author: Lacresha S.

description:
I remain skeptical about Zazie being ranked best brunch spot in the Haight. 

- First of, yes their food is good. I'm not gonna lie. THAT BEING SAID, I'm French and I actually have had better pancakes and better omelettes in SF. I still don't think Zazie is better than the Pork Store for example (a couple of blocks up, on Haight St.)

- The service sucks. I know, I know, it's San Francisco and it's the kind of place where you KNOW you're going to have to stand in the line but still, it's not worth it. I went there for dinner and the waiters did not treat us as they should have, considering how "up scale" this place aims to be. 

- It is a bit pricey for what you get. 

Overall I can't help thinking that this place's success is only based on how trendy it is right now. 

* GO TO PADRECITO'S, IT'S LITERALLY 15 SECONDS AWAY AND IT'S WAY BETTER AND YOU WON'T HAVE TO WAIT * 

Sorry, couldn't help it.
author: Sev G.

description:
Surely the most romantic spot I've been to lately. If you go here on a date make sure to grab a table in the back patio. They have mood lighting , heat lamps and cosy seats. They take reservations only until 4 , but they have seats for walk-ins too. And now that its cold a lot of people prefer sitting inside. 

So here is what we ate : 

- We started with cheese plate which had a selection of 3 cheeses along with fig and bread. Loved it !
- Got a carafe of wine which is great to have about a glass and a half each for two people
- Ravioli for the main course which was perfectly done, with a hint of lemon. 
- Ended with the baked chocolate desert which was heavenly. Its a big bowl of rich chocolate baked with marshmallows on top.  

Service was great, ambience was great and food was fantastic !
author: Priyanka P.

description:
I had the dungeness crab poached eggs and the cream cheese coffee cake, both of which were delicious. Completely worth it. Slightly pricey, but its great for brunch once in a while!
I'm docking one star because our waitress completely messed up. She charged me and my friend for the wrong items, which led to a ton of hassle. That upset me, as well as the fact that they have some kind of extra surcharge added for the staff...well, so now that tip is automatically included, am I still expected to tip on top?
author: Sophie L.

description:
A friend of mine took me here the day of the SF rain apocalypse because it's one of the best breakfast places in SF. NO LIE. Really good food, really awesome mimosas. I was not disappointed. It's a busy place, but doesnt feel cramped and as long as you get there before the crowd, youll get a seat. 

I had an amazing experience here. I will definitely be coming back again someday :)
author: Paige H.

description:
Anytime you must wait over an hour for a meal it is likely that the anticipation will outweigh the reality, and unfortunately this was the case for Zazie.

The breakfast was solid, don't get me wrong, but I didn't have anything that will out last the memory of how long it took to get a table. Its possible I just didn't order the magical items, but I wouldn't be able to justify the wait to try a second time. But luckily there are plenty of others who feel differently, and their business won't suffer. 

The staff was friendly, but they also seemed short handed. It took quite a while to get a menu once seated and one of the coffee refill orders never came. They only have one very small bathroom, which is located in between the back door and where the dishes are washed off. Trying to find a place to wait without being in the way or getting splash with water was almost impossible.

As an aside, I couldn't decipher what our place in the queue was from the order of the wait list, so it felt like a mystery as to when we would be seated.
author: Michael S.

description: Best breakfast and coffee.  Latte's in a bowl!  Felt like I'd made it to heaven!  Very nice staff, too.  Put this on your list of must do's!
author: Leslie S.

description:
A couple of weeks ago Tina and I (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RQiF_SRAZflu6xzRms7T-g/l.jpg) decided to meet in the morning prior to our Candlestick Park Tour. Being the foodies we are, we searched for a breakfast spot in the city. One of the more intriguing options that peaked our curiosity was Zazie. Having close to 2,500 reviews and a solid 4 star average, this sounded like a tasty place to indulge our hunger.

After looking at some of the photos, I was torn between the Gingerbread Pancakes or the French Toast Tahiti. The French Toast Tahiti seemed to set me into a trance as it was calling out my name. Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts, need I say more?  Oh, I also decided to double down on the fat boy status by adding some bacon on the side. Mmm bacon!

While the food wasn't bad, it just didn't quite live up to the hype. I didn't feel it was worth the drive from San Jose.  The French Toast Tahiti (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wVV3ODsGDMGoVybUv2Tjqg/l.jpg) has some fabulous reviews, as many have raved about it. The photos looked delicious, but once I took my first bite I immediately felt a little underwhelmed. The bread was  bland, rather heavy, and a bit on the dry side. I had buyer's remorse and wished I had ordered the Gingerbread Pancakes instead.

Summary (3 Stars): Over rated? I think so. Perhaps I was expecting too much from the number of quality reviews. The French Bistro decor and the outdoor garden patio in the back is a nice touch.  Even as we tried to have a late breakfast, there was still a long line ahead of us so except a 30-40 minute wait to be seated.
author: Mike S.

description: This place was AMAZING! Friendly service and great food. The wait was a bit long and the spot is kinda small but I guess typical for San Fran. This is French inspired joint with the most amazing French toast and mimosas. I was able to try their miracle pancake with lemon ricotta and lemon curd---delish. Fed recommend!
author: Angelica C.

description:
I would return in a heartbeat! For a Saturday morning at 10 am, we waited maybe 30 minutes for a party of 2--not bad at all!

We ordered the Florentine Benedict, Dungeness Crab Benedict, and Gingerbread Pancake. The Florentine was good, but the crab was divine. The pancake was the perfect way to end the meal. So fluffy and the lemon curd is delightfully tangy and sweet. I highly recommend the crab benedict and gingerbread pancake.

I also must applaud Zazie for providing their employees with a living wage and benefits. The price isn't even significantly higher than other brunch places.
author: Diane K.

description:
This is my favorite brunch place at SF.
The french toast tahiti is my favorite dish but the poached eggs are also great. 
Oh, and get the home fries. They are even better than the dish itself.
author: Lawrence K.

description: I've been waiting to go here for a while now and they didn't disappoint. The inside is kinda cramped and the line is a waste of time on the weekends, but the food was yummy and filling. A satisfying meal if you beat the crowd and come on a weekday instead. Brunch does get heavy though, around 1030 seems to be when the SF brunch rush comes craving their selection of mimosas and slightly overpriced meals. I will say that the french toast tahiti was way too many walnuts for me, even though the toast and bananas were great. If you're into that kind of stuff, well, go for it. Best item on their menu has got to be their baked hot chocolate though. Its on their dessert menu but you can ask for it in the morning too. A rich cup of dark chocolate ooze similar to the inside of a molten lava cake and a toasted marshmallow topping. So good.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
Came here for brunch with one of my really good friends! She raved about this place, and I was excited to give it a try. I checked out the menu online before coming, and saw that pride themselves in not accepting tips, due to them giving their staff a livable wage. I respect that! Alright, lets get talking about this cute place!

AMBIANCE/CUSTOMER SERVICE: I met my friend there, since she knew about the super long wait. Giving the place 4 stars because we ended up waiting 1 and a half hours all together. It was a super hot day too, so it wasn't enjoyable waiting for our table in the hot sun with little to no shade available. However, we rejoiced as our name was called and we were led to the back patio. It's beautiful there! With greenery and cute tables, I seriously loved the ambiance. Once seated, we got menus and out waiter asked us for beverage choices. I got an orange juice, which was delicious. However, it was a very small size for what I paid for. Waiter was extremely  friendly, and very helpful when I asked questions about the menu. My friend decided on getting the Albert Poached Eggs, while I got the French Toast Tahiti (2 pcs). The wait wasn't too long, probably around 25 minutes. When the food came out, I was amazed. Our plates looked like something from a dream, it was beautiful! 

TASTE/FOOD QUALITY: My friend loved her poached eggs. I had a bite, and it was to die for. Eggs were perfect, and the home fries were delicious. My french toast was amazing. I still dream about it sometimes. It was so decadent and sweet. Loved the caramelized bananas on top, with the walnuts. Can't recommend it enough, if you have a sweet tooth, like me. The french toast had a nice crisp on the outside, but was soft as a pillow when I cut my fork to snag a piece. The portions were generous, and I was so full when I was done. The quality of the food was great, loved it.

Overall, this is a spectacular brunch spot. The waiting situation is something to be expected, since it is a very popular spot (and for a good reason!). The food is great, and prices are more on the moderate side. Would come back again for sure!
author: Kiki C.

description:
I really love this place. Reminded me of the French-Middle Eastern joints we have out East... 

Line was long but they accommodated a sista when I told them I had a flight to catch.

Solid meal - had poached eggs, apple chicken sausage, a side salad and split the gingerbread pancakes with the bro

Coffee was on point too. Will def go back in less of a rush and try to sit in their outside area.
author: Yomna N.

description:
I heard how crowded it can get for brunch on Sunday, so we decided to come on Monday instead.  Good call.  We had ample choices of where to sit, and chose the back patio which was perfect for a nice, sunny day.  

I saw the french toast and it looked so good.  I was in the mood for something savory, so I ordered the polenta dish with mushrooms, tomato sauce, and eggs atop, and a side of home fries.  It comes with poached eggs, but I prefer scrambled.   The polenta dish was enjoyable, though the polenta by itself didn't have much flavor, and the home fries, crispy red potates with whole garlic cloves was tasty. The coffee and service was okay (coffee tasted like it was brewing a little too long).  Overall, a pleasant experience for brunch.
author: Nova P.

description:
I'm all about brunch. I always pass by this place, wanting to try it. So one day I actually decided to go on a Friday afternoon. There was a wait, and we ended up sitting outside, so I didn't really get to feel the inside atmosphere. It was a nice day, so we didn't mind outside seating. The waiter was super nice, and he gave me free rolls of bread bc I ordered the ravioli on the special menu and asked if it came with anything else. He said no, but he would throw in the bread., which was really cool. 

The ravioli was really good, but it was around $15. To me, it was too pricey for the food that didn't come with any sides or anything else. Usually for brunch, I like getting breakfast foods, you know, like pancakes, corned beef, eggs, etc. But for some reason, the menu didn't look too appealing and it was just way too overpriced for regular brunch items. I tried something different, but wasn't full. Luckily I had the bread.

I don't think I would come back here because of the long wait anyway. There are other brunch places in the city that are better. Also, there is only one bathroom and it is the tiniest bathroom ever. No changing table or any counterspace for baby. The only reason why it's not a one star is bc of the nice waiter and the location. I love this area.
author: Jamie B.

description:
This is the to-go place when I stay in SF since it's in walking distance. I love the different selections for breakfast and usually try to get my order off the special menu which changes every once in a while. 

Their orange juice is good but it's a lil overpriced for me since I imaged the cup to be twice as big from when it actually came out to be.

Seats outside is first come first served. The ones inside if crowded there will be a clipboard to fill out. 

Usually the crowd ain't that bad before 10am and after 1pm. 

They only do brunch/lunch and then dinner. There's not much parking around but good luck for those who want to drive. It's right next to muni n-judah and buses 43 and 33. Probably more but I'm not from SF sooo whoops.
author: Corie L.

description:
Zazie is one of those hip restaurants that includes tip within their prices, and everything is very reasonably priced for a restaurant like this. Brought my boyfriend's parents here for dinner and enjoyed outstanding service, an adorable and cozy ambiance and delicious food.

- French onion soup - honestly, it's pretty hard to mess up French onion soup so obviously this was super tasty
- Salad with goat cheese beets - fresh and delicious, the goat cheese was not too overwhelming
- Fresh porcini and truffle raviolis - I love truffle and mushroom, so I thought this dish was particularly good. However, the portion is not huge and there could've been more truffle flavor. 
- Grilled maple leaf duck breast - delicious, perfectly cooked duck. I especially enjoyed the yams that came with it
- Lamb tagine - tender lamb, flavorful cous cous and veggies. Seriously so good, so comforting

I've heard the brunch is phenomenal, so we tried to come here recently and the line was out of control. Will definitely try again some other time when I can get there earlier.

Strongly recommend making a reservation for dinner whether it's a date night or group outing. The servers are super friendly and the food is great.
author: Amy Y.

description: This place is amazing!! It was a little crowded but we were able to snatch an outside table because they are first come first serve.
author: Olivia O.

description: Great place for Breakfast! I was visiting SFO, and was looking for a good breakfast place. Stumbled on this one on yelp and glad I gave it a try! Had a nice French Toast! Definitely visiting next time to try other menu items.
author: Shelka U.

description:
The food is excellent and the place is very cozy and romantic !! (especially the patio)
Staff is great, very nice and efficient. Our server was Elsa the french girl and she was amazing and really sweet !!
My boyfriend and I had a great time. Food was delicious, we had the mussels (I highly recommend them) the polenta and the truite. You canno't go to Zazie without trying their signature chocolate cake, my favorite dessert ever !!! I will definitely be back, excellent french food in a super cute decor.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
I came here for the first time for Sunday brunch with some friends, and thought this place was good but nothing truly spectacular. 

Food: I ordered the La Coup, which was an eggs benedict style dish with smoked salmon replacing the traditional Canadian bacon. There was an option to select the number of eggs you wanted, and I decided on 3 eggs (for $24) and a side of home fries. The food was good, and I found the potatoes to be quite tasty, though the dish overall was just pretty standard. Nothing mind blowing, and pretty average. The presentation of the dish could have also used a bit more effort, and the colors on my plate looked rather dull and boring. I also ordered their mimosa with mango flavoring ($10), but didn't quite get any of the mango taste that I was expecting. 

Service: The host that helped to tell us wait times could have been slightly friendlier, and he always seemed rushed whenever we spoke to him. Our server was friendly when we came to sit down, but I felt was rather absent throughout the duration of our meal. For example, our water jug was never replenished, and there was no offer to do so either. 

Atmosphere: The restaurant is small inside, but interestingly decorated. I feel like things were too cramped, especially with all of the guests and wait staff that were around. Restroom facilities were clean enough, but tiny.

Zazie had average tasting food overall, but will definitely not be somewhere I come rushing back to for a visit. The wait time combined with the slightly high prices makes it difficult for me to understand the hype.
author: Daniel H.

description:
Our second brunch on my summer norcal roadtrip!
We arrived on a saturday morning around eleven am and waited about an hour for a party of seven. 
The interior is super cute, they had this cute sunflower painting at the front top of the restaurant.
I ordered the La Mer, which is a poached egg with crab and avocados. The crab was sooo fresh!! The egg was pretty good too except it was a little too runny for my taste but still tasted delicious! This dish also came with wonderfully cooked potatoes with just the right amount of seasoning!
For all the poached egg dishes you can choose the amount of eggs you want: 1, 2, or 3 eggs.
I also got the Tahiti french toast (you can also choose if you want 1, 2, or 3 pieces of toast). This was by far my favorite dish. I only got one piece and I really regretted that I didn't get 3!!!! It wasn't too sweet, the bananas were caramelized perfectly!!! And as an added bonus the walnuts gave it the perfect crunch and added good texture to the dish! I WANT MOREE.
Anyways, I would love to come here for brunch again, maybe a little earlier to avoid the lines!
author: Heidi L.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend for a Saturday brunch :) I thought it was gonna be a long wait since there was quite a bit of people waiting outside but we gotta seated within 10 minutes! 
The place was kinda small but it was really cute :) 
We ordered French toast (I forgot the name but it had berries and was on the special menu that was on the table), Albert's eggs Benedict, and miracle pancakes. 
The food tasted great but it didn't seem like anything special until I had the miracle pancakes :D they were so fluffy and full of flavor ! I couldn't get enough ! Out of the three dishes I definitely recommend the Miracle pancakes ! 
I also ordered a mimosa that had white peach sorbet . That was good but not too special either I expected to taste the sorbet but I didn't at all. 
The place may seem pricey but keep in mind that tip isn't expected because they give the workers good pay ,a 401k ,and good benefits. But we still left them a tip since service was good :)
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The brunch here is to die for !!!
The Tahiti french toast is the best french toast I've ever had. Gorgeously caramelized with BANANAS, my favorite. 

It can get crowded and you may have to wait, so come early.
author: C. C.

description: Tasty as heck. tight space inside but works with the french atmosphere. benedicts are ridiculously good. next time I'm going for a french toast.
author: Mike I.

description:
What an adorable breakfast spot!  

It's located in the quaint little neighborhood of Cole Valley... just minutes away from Haight/Ashbury, but it beats to a totally different rhythm.  I love the houses and the crisp fresh air on a brisk sunny day.  This is what makes San Francisco such a wonderful place.  Every neighborhood has its own unique culture, and I just get so excited every time I discover a new place.

This neighborhood is just perfect for Zazie.  It has a very intimate country feel, yet the place is always bustling.

Let's start with the drink menu.  They have some pretty unique choices.  The mango mimosa and the elderflower mimosa sounded very appealing.  I opted for the mango, and the flavors were very light and crisp - perfect way to start off a delicious meal.

Next, the food.  Boy oh boy, what a hard decision!  Their pancakes looked amazing.  I was really tempted to get one of their scrambles too.  However, surprise surprise, I got the poached eggs.  I never get benedicts... I don't know why, but it just never appealed to me.  However, the La Mer (hand-picked crab benedict) had such great reviews.  Being a huge crab lover, of course I had to try it.  What a great decision!  It was absolutely scrumptious!  The light hollandaise just made it perfect.   

Our waitress was such a sweetheart.  She was attentive, helpful, and patient!  We were just so absorbed with the place we totally forgot to look at the menu.

The restaurant is kind of small, and the wait can get pretty long and tedious.  Just get there early, put your name down, and go for a walk around the neighborhood.  Oh, and they do have outdoor seating.. not a lot.. but you could be one of those lucky ones :)

Happy eating!
author: Cecilia S.

description:
I've been here three times, once for brunch and twice for dinner.


While I find zazie is famous for brunch (and crazy busy) dinner is amazing too and not as crowded.


Food: the dishes here have all been pretty good.  I found that the Burger is delicious, and the pork chops are solid. Pork chops have a sweet flavor which I was pleasantly surprised with. Maybe not something I would get very often through.  Also lets not forget the amazing bread which comes "half baked" from Berkeley and then is finished just before being served.

Service: Service is normally always pretty good. In general, not to stereotype I find French places to be a little relaxed on the speed and service but not so here. 

Ambiance: Nice decor and setting inside. If possible (and weather permitting) I always vote for the backyard patio which does have heat lamps. It's got a nice European feel.
author: Shomik C.

description:
This brunch location is a couple's retreat. You'd be hard-pressed to convince me otherwise. If I was single, you would not see me here because there is nothing more Single San Franciscan than grumbling about all the happy couples that are hanging off each other waiting for a goddamn table at a sassy and trendy brunch place.

However, as in-a-relationship-now would state..it's hard not to try and vertically lay on your S.O. when the sun hits you perfectly while waiting for a seat to open (45 minutes at 1p on a Saturday).

I ordered the caramelized banana stuffed french toast, and whatever the boyfriend ordered was amazing, too. It was all good. Just the right amount of food, a wonderful lavender infused mimosa, and some wonderful coffee to go along with. It doesn't look like you can go wrong with anything on their menu, to be honest. An absolutely delicious way to start your day in SF.

Also parking sucks.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Even on a Monday the restaurant was buzzing to the brim. It was about a 10 minute wait and we were brought inside to a cute, cozy brunch spot. 

Our drinks came out in gigantic mugs -- my au lait in a big bowl where I could simulate cat drinking. The food took a little bit to come out, but it did all at once:

-YUM to the lemon ricotta raviolis. Delicious, tender, simple flavors. Plenty of garlic and arugula.
-La mer poached egg was also good. The crabmeat was large and chunky.
-Ginger pancakes, which I heard to be unique here were good, but was hoping for it to be more recognizably gingery and unique. I did appreciate the heaping of fresh fruit on top. 
-French toast standard but again, generous fresh fruit on top.

It's rare to find just straight brunch done well. It's always either overly sophisticated and fancied up, expensive or really heavy. Zazie's is a great place to come and get tasty brunch as a pair or up to 4. Service is standard.

By the way, the bathroom is a sliding door which kind of leaves a crack, ladies. You gotta shimmy past the kitchen to get in and its pretty cramped and messy navigating in the tiny stall!
author: Jen C.

description:
I really wanted to love this place, but I can't. 
 
The night before I came for bunch, I was drooling over the menu. My mind was set on 2 gingerbread pancakes with a side of home fries. I arrived the next day around 2pm. Upon arrival, I spotted a narrow black swirl staircase to the right of the entrance which I thought was absolutely adorable. Don't you ever fantasize about running up swirl stair cases as a child? 

Anyways, we were quickly seated. 
I ordered two gingerbread pancakes with a side of house fries (seasoned potatoes). HUGE mistakes. I was SO full after the first half of the first pancake. It wasn't that I was full from drinking too much water or eating too much breakfast, it was that the pancake was really dry that displeased my appetite. The potatoes were really good though. I filled up on potato and had some of my friend's omelet with bacon as he finished my pancakes. mmmMmmm 

Our bill came out to be $28 (including the $1.50 per person (I wonder if they charge for babies and toddlers...) health benefits charge for their workers)

*I wouldn't suggest this place for large groups of 4+
*quick and friendly service
*fresh produce
author: Jess W.

description: Had brunch here, with my cousin. Was so happy to see iced eal grey tea. Tried the cream cheese coffee cake, was more of a cake with cream cheese in between the layers. Not too happy with it. I had a scramble with spinach mushrooms and cheese. Was super tasty and the potatoes were some of the best I've had in a long time, perfectly seasoned. Menu had many things I will come back to try. Friendly service. I thought a little expensive but then read the no tip note and all that is offered to employees, fantastic. Left a tip anyways. Only bummer, other than the coffee cake. No parking in that area.
author: Lani P.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Great food, and usually no reservation required on a weekday evening. I've been here 4 times during the week, and never had to wait in line. 

All the dishes taste amazing - also great service. Highly recommend.
author: Dancy L.

description: Overpriced, food was ok, drinks are basic, soup was great, service was lovely, but not worth the money
author: Zade T.

description: I am not a big fan for brunch, but they have CONVINVED me to see brunch to a whole different level. Their pancakes were definitely something else. Have this place listed to bring my mom when she is in town for visit.
author: Jessica Y.

description: Great experience, welcoming staff. Prices are great considering they have the tip included because they're a full functioning business with 401k, paid sick/ vacation, and insurance for there employees. Wendy was excellent and made me feel appreciated. I highly recommend this place for that local San Francisco ambience Enjoy!
author: Rex D.

description: Wow! The wait was worth it. This is considered one of the top brunch spots of San Francisco, and luckily walking distance from where we stayed. I really enjoyed the variety in mimosas and eggs Benedict--two of my favorite things! I had the La Mer Benedict (crab meat) and it was flawless. I tried the Magic mimosa (peach sorbet and basil syrup) and Maya (mango and chamoy with a salted chili tajin rim). We got lucky and got sat in the patio area. It was a Saturday and we got here at 11:15 there were about 8 parties ahead of us and we waited 40 minutes or so. The later you arrive, the longer the wait. However the service is speedy, and we were surprised with how quick we got our drinks and food! Definitely recommend Zazie if you're a major foodie/brunch spot explorer. A++
author: Michael A.

description: Was very crowded for brunch but I got a seat. Super small restaurant but it is delicious! No wonder it gets crowded, the food is great! The pumpkin pancakes were so filling and there were pumpkin chunks in the dough. Yum. Very pricey however!
author: Crystal R.

description: Delicious scrambled eggs with various mushrooms and cheese.  A gingerbread pancake with a roasted pear.  Fairly pricey but the tip is included.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Excellent French cuisine in a cute setting. 
We noticed long lines of people in front of the restaurant during the day- a demonstration of the popularity of the restaurant for brunch.  As we seldom have brunch out, wife and I decided to try this Zazie for dinner, a very happy decision! We made reservations for an early dinner on a Saturday (Zazie does take reservations for dinner but not for brunch), and, fortunately, the restaurant was not crowded as we dislike noisy places.  The restaurant has a front section with cute little tables and wooden chairs, an open kitchen, and beyond that, a covered, semi-open section with additional tables.  We were served a freshly baked warm bread which was delightful. The menu was quite French and interesting, and they had a good choice of relatively inexpensive wines, aperitifs, and beers.  We started with kier royale, which was somewhat on the sweet side.  For appetizers, we had mussels marnieres, French onion soup, and a small salad, which were all authentic and wonderful.  I especially liked the mussels with a wonderful creamy sauce which I spooned up to the last drop.  For the main course, we both had the truite meuniere, which was cooked to perfection - the skin was crisp, and the fish melted in the mouth.  We had a bottle of French sancerre ($60) with the meal, which was quite decent.  For dessert, we had the "baked hot chocolate" - a rather creative, sweet dish, and worth a try.  The service was very friendly and prompt.  The bill came to about $200.  They pride themselves that the price of food includes the tip and that their employees have full benefits!  We fully support this practice!  Overall, this is a wonderful, authentic French bistro, a neighborhood gem.  We will definitely be back to try all the mouthwatering items on their menu.
author: Hoyle L.

description:
Deux, Deux, Trois with their signature magic pancakes.  $26 with great coffee and tip for one.  I really miss living in SF in the 90's.  This is now my go-to place for a gourmet breakfast, and Zazie absolutely blows away touristy but good: North Beach's Mama's and the pretentious yummy mummies crowding Potrero Hill's Plow with their $1500 strollers out front.  Zazie has great outdoor seating and people with their matching pet watching.  I'm still craving those lemon ricotta magic cakes!  

Tip:  Arrive at 8am sharp weekdays or "you're going to have a bad day".
author: R J.

description:
Went for brunch on a weekday: food was amazing! Everything looked great so much so that we decided to also get french toast on top of our entrees. We did not regret the decision! I had the eggs Benedict Monaco which had prosciutto and tomatoes. This place allows you to order 1, 2 or 3 eggs and same with the pancakes and French toast. I've been to a lot of restaurants and this was the first time I saw this- such a great option.
Service was very attentive and friendly. Layout of the place was welcoming and their heated patio was perfect for an afternoon date.
author: Gaby E.

description:
We had heard everything you ate here was "to die for". Well, I did want to kill my husband after he made me wait 75 minutes for brunch. Almost NO meal is worth that kind of wait, even a free meal is not worth that wait, no view! Come on. Heck, I eat out everyday, sleep in a hotel 365 days a year, travel my butt off. I cannot believe I feel for this.

Yes, I tried the Sara Jane's Pancake Flight for $19 - 1 buttermilk, 1 ginger, 1 french toast. It was good, maybe worth a 15 minute wait and the server was a very sweet man, again maybe worth another 10 minutes. The outside porch, no view, not worth the wait. The coffee and tea (which was very odd, I asked for honey, they said they were out and then said wait, I think we have a tablespoons worth! Where did they find and nope, I am good. 

Again, I have eaten at some dives that have great food, holes in the wall (with holes in the wall) with the best food, guys fighting outside over a table, etc. All kind of places from North Africa to South Bay. Again, not worth 75 minutes, you only have one life, don't waste it waiting in line. 

Go enjoy your life, make a reservation at another place and use the 75 minutes seeing an art gallery, seeing a movie, whatever floats your boat!
author: Holly K.

description: I came here in early weekday and there was no wait. SOrry, but it was just AITE, nothing special nor bad. Not as awesome as I hope it would be. Luckily, I didnt wait an hour like others or this would've been a 2 stars. We ordered the Yelp rcmd: french toast tahiti, benedict, omelette. It was good, but didnt stand out. Again, it was good, but didnt amaze me much.
author: Jackie M.

description: Zazie used to be one of my favorites until the dinner I had there recently. The food was slapped together and unappealing. My friend and I both had the prix-fixe dinner. Both meals had huge salads dressed with a load of vinegar... I could not finish eating my salad because of that and just nipped at it. The appetizer also contained more of the same salad... But back to the main course which for me was trout meuniere, a strange version of it. The trout had butternut squash pieces and goat cheese dot on top of it and those flavors were overwhelming for a delicate fish like trout. No potatoes, rice or anything similar with this dish.
