MOCHA -- SOO GOOOD!!!! pretty big bowl too so the server was nice enough to split that into 2 bowls for us! 

Gingerbread pancake - --not a gingerbread fan but boy, was this delicious! we got 2 pancakes and they were very generous with the size. its a HUGE thick pancake and the pear sauce is to DIE FOR! (who ever knew pear and gingerbread works so well together) 

Albert Poached Eggs --- our all time favorite of the day! the egg was PERFECT and everything was just so well made and super tasty! I HIGHLY recommend this dish! 

ZAZIE- I will be back!!
author: Eileen Z.

description:
Breakfast is my favorite meal of the day. Probably because I'm a total egg whore and bacon slut. I also like indulging in things like chicken fried steak, corned beef hash and buttermilk biscuits w/ gravy. Cardiac Arrest is usually what I order for breakfast because there's nothing like starting your day with a heart-stopping, artery clogging delicious meal. 

Fortunately for me, I rarely eat breakfast. Shame on me, I know. However, I usually wake up with just enough time to sh*t, shave and shower before heading out the door for work. 

Let me paint you my first and only Zazie experience. My gf and I met up with three of our friends in the city. We got to Zazie at 2:15pm this past Saturday and there was a horde of people waiting outside. For a place famous for its breakfast/brunch, I was extremely surprised patrons were still lining up well after lunch time. We put our name down after the host told us it would only be a 30 minute way. I didn't believe him but he proved me wrong. We were seated at 2:45pm.

We were lucky enough to get a table in the back patio. It's quaint, cozy and perfect for a sunny day. The girls loved it. I was hungry. Sh*t was about to get real. 

I looked over the menu to find that it didn't have my typical heart stoppers. Chicken fried steak, where are you? Corned beef hash, show yourself! Instead, Zazie's menu was littered with exotic scrambles, lovely benedicts, power pancakes, soups, salads, sandwiches and other typical brunchy items. 

EGGS DIVORCE ~ 3 stars: Not listed on the menu. This was a special that day. Sitting on top of each toasted English muffin was a poached egg, fontina cheese, avocado slices, bacon and "fabulous" lemon hollandaise. Like all scrambles and benedicts, you can order 1, 2 or 3 eggs. I went with 3 and got a side of home fries... Told you sh*t was gonna get real. The hollandaise sauce was good, but I wouldn't call it fabulous. It was pretty standard which doesn't make it a bad thing. It just tasted like typical hollandaise. The benedict was good but not great. Honestly, It tasted exactly like I expected. It didn't blow my mind. However, I really enjoyed the homefries that came with roasted garlic cloves. It's weird, garlic isn't something you ever put in your breakfast, but Zazie made it work with the potatoes. Nice touch. 

MONACO ~ 2.5 stars: My gf got this. Poached egg, hollandaise, prosciutto, tomatoes provencales on top of an English muffin. She kept it cool and only got 1. I tried it and it wasn't great. In my opinion, you should never get benedict with prosciutto because it gets lost in the yolk, muffin and hollandaise. Why get something if you can't even taste it? 

BEET SALAD w/ GOAT CHEESE ~ 4 stars: Nice salad. The beets were cooked perfectly and the dressing wasn't too heavy. 

GINGERBREAD PANCAKES ~ 3 stars: Before you get loco on my ass, let me explain. I don't like pancakes. I don't like waffles. I don't like anything sweet for the first meal of my day. It just doesn't fly with me. However, if you like pancakes, this is something you have to try. After sampling a bite, I can see why so many people love this menu item. It will absolutely satisfy your sweet tooth and tummy. 

SABE SAKE VODKA BLOODY MARY~ 4 stars: An excellent Bloody Mary with great flavor. I wish it was a bit thicker but other than that, it was almost perfect. 

One of our friends ordered a scramble and another got something else. I didn't try either one so I can't say anything about it. However, the scramble looked really good. 

I wasn't blown away by Zazie. The food was ok, not great. However, I think the ambiance is fantastic. 

Would I ever go back? Probably not... I might consider it if they put chicken fried steak on the menu though.
author: Bruce C.

description:
I don't typically enjoy brunch food, but my Greece scrambled eggs with spinach, feta, and red onions were a cut above most of the brunch places I've been to. The potatoes on the side were incredible!

Bonus points for how they treat their employees. Menu prices already include a living wage, health insurance, paid leave, etc. so there is no need to tip.
author: Geoffrey B.

description:
So now I have come here for brunch (this place was recently voted "best brunch in SF" by on of my food blogs. )

It was good, but not the best brunch I ever had. The highlight was the coffee cake for sure (DELISH and warm)

We went on a saturday around 10am and had to wait about 15 minutes for a table.
author: Amy W.

description:
This place was highly recommended by my friend and apparently highly reviewed on Yelp so it was a must-eat for me while I was in SF. I got both the La Mer and French toast Tahiti (greedy I know, but when you travel, you eat everything!)

The La Mer was pretty much an eggs benedict with perfectly poached eggs on dungeness crab and avocado. There's 3 of my favorite things on one English Muffin.

The French Toast Tahiti was one of a kind too! It's definitely big enough to share so order with caution.

Parking was a bit hard, but it's totally worth the hassle. I will be back again the next time I visit SF.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
The food is good but the service is great. Very happy with the thoughtfulness of the manager and the server. They went out of their way to help us find a seat that would fit our needs and brought us coffee while we waited. Overall - This was the best service of a place in SF that I (and my dad) has experienced. 

As for food, would recommend the Albert! Delicious.
author: Kristen B.

description: Gingerbread pancakes, is it Xmas yet???? They were so light and fluffy and felt like butter. I think anything you end up ordering on the menu will be perfect. I thought it was really cool that the tips we're already embedded in the menu prices, takes the guess work out of the game.
author: Nosheen K.

description: I'm surprised I'm giving Zazie a 3 (3.5 if that were an option), but based on my most recent experience I feel like I have to. There was a wait as usual (and this was on a Tuesday around 11:30am), but we waited only 15-20 minutes or so. The tables outside are first come first serve, so that is a cool alternative to putting your name on their wait list. The ambiance was as cute as I remembered, and we got to sit in the little alcove by the window. Service was friendly, really no complaints there. The reason for the 3.5 stars is...the pancakes weren't as fantastic as I remembered them to be. I got the 2-stack of Miracle Pancakes (today's special was Poppyseed Pancakes with Lemon Curd), and the pancakes were good, but NOT great. I've HAD great pancakes, and these just weren't. Maybe I came on an off-day, or my pancakes just happened to be prepared subpar, but consistency is important..Zazie, I've always loved you! But I guess even those we love make mistakes sometimes =/ One last interesting change is that Zazie does not require tip because they include it already in the prices.
author: Diane G.

description: I love having brunch here however I avoid the weekends because the wait is insane. For those of you non 9-5ers do a week day.
author: Genesis V.

description:
Finally come to this most popular brunch destination in town. 
Food quality is decent and delicious. 
Party of four on the Sunday before Christmas, waiting wasn't too bad. The wait list hasn't over a page yet! 
After almost an hour, we got seated at the patio which is one of the best! It's too hard to find a nice heated patio restaurant in SF. (I hate "streettio" street seats+patio) 

Another super plus at here is "you can chose the portion of your meal" nice... 
I quit brunch for a reason, too much to eat. 
Now, I'm feeling I will come back here more for brunch without overeating. 

Good quality, nice patio, customized portion and friendly service! If there's no wait......things could be perfect!
author: JustinE Y.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!! Super friendly staff and great location. They are openly proud to be tip free due to the great benefits this place offers for their staff. The wait wasn't too long to be seated, and the food came out pretty quickly. The French Toast Tahiti was heavenly!
author: Emily O.

description: Best place for brunch!! The french toast was amazing, along with the melted hot chocolate we ordered. Get here early! The only complaints I had about the place was the long wait to get seated, the long wait to get our food, the lack of air condition, and some flies flying around the table. Overall, the service was excellent and make sure you don't tip them because they won't accept it! The melted hot chocolate seemed like a baked chocolate brownie in a cup. Everything was simply delicious!
author: Michael Q.

description:
French Toast Tahiti and Eggs La Mer.

Heavenly.

Even at 10:30 AM on a Thursday, there was a line for indoor seating. And who wouldn't want to sit inside the cozy restaurant, with its high ceilings and warm tones? Those who won the first-come, first-serve scramble for the two outdoor tables. For those destined to wait, you'll want sign in on the sheet outside the door, ponder the menu choices (brunch is served for weekday breakfast as well), and drool at the dishes of those around you.

Since we were a group of 4, we had to wait 30 minutes for a table to open up. As such, we were happily surprised by the complimentary bowl full of deliciously ripe mango, mandarin oranges, honeydews, cantaloupes, apples, pears, and strawberries. If the DMV followed a similar policy, the world would be a happier place.

Our first choice was the FRENCH TOAST TAHITI, Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts, priced at $6/$11/$14/$17 (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/EMUfwwzo4GfgZ6XJVJrL6A/l.jpg). Since we asked for 4 portions, we got 2 French toastwiches cut in halves. The thick, scrumptious challah slices enveloped a nutty mush with soft, sparse chunks of walnut and were topped with a sliver of scrumptious caramelized banana (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hvFqcU-twBiCW-zSSLV_OA/l.jpg). SO. GOOD.

Our second choice was the EGGS LA MER, Eggs benedict (poached eggs on an English muffin with Hollandaise sauce) with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados, priced at $12/$19/$24/$30 (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RlaHegShuchDKigR_O91CA/l.jpg). The poached egg was perfect with its thick egg white and nice, runny egg yolk (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/lUfNmyOt4QosA4wPvnqppQ/l.jpg). The crab was fresh, a great addition. The avocado seemed too sparse to be noticeable. And I usually hate English muffins, but it was toasted just right to soak up the benedict mess without becoming too soggy. Oh, and the side of potatoes comes with huge unpeeled roasted garlic pieces, of which you are not supposed to eat the peels. Well, you could try, but you'll spit them right back out, like I did.

Our third choice, which I wish we had skipped, was the FLIGHT OF PANCAKES, which comes with one of each of their pancakes: miracle, gingerbread, and buttermilk, $14 (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/j40Ikbetb3Q3x-WURnK2Ig/l.jpg). Not only were we full from the other dishes, but the pancakes were all dense and dry. The buttermilk pancake was decent, but I couldn't help but equate it to my Krusteaz mix at home. Now, add a dollop of the raspberry jam on your table, and you've got yourself a winner. That jam is like crack! The gingerbread pancake was notably thick and heavy with subtle ginger tones. The stewed pear outshines the pancake by far. And the miracle pancake tasted a LOT like cornbread and definitely needed the lemon curd for flavor. The first few bites were offsetting, but after I readjusted my perspective, I decided that this was the tastiest cornbread I had ever had. Also, their maple syrup was less viscous than expected and not overpoweringly sweet.

Service was spot on, and water refills were frequent. They add a surcharge of $1.25 per person to all checks to provide full benefits for the staff, which totaled to a little over $20 per person for a divine breakfast. If that extra bit of money is what it takes to guarantee accommodating and prompt wait staff, I'd suggest the policy at every restaurant.

Skip the pancakes. Get the French Toast Tahiti and some type of Eggs Benedict. And have an amazing day thereafter.

[[How to do SF brunch, Adele-style]]
Seek EVERYTHING (notably SOUFFLÉ PANCAKES and SMOKED SALMON TARTINE) at Griddle Fresh
Seek FRENCH TOAST at Park Chow (more affordable) or Zazie's (more unique)
Seek PANCAKES at Park Chow
Seek EGGS BENEDICT at Zazie's
Seek HASH BROWN SANDWICHES at Art's Cafe
Seek FRITTATAS at Home Plate
Seek HUEVOS RANCHEROS at Cafe Reverie
author: Adele F.

description: Tried it again and it sucked. Should've remembered my own advice from few yrs ago. oh well....never again
author: Rouz E.

description:
Very nice place and some great food. Wife and I both had eggs benedict, and I had an extra bowl of steel cut oats. 

Showed up around 9, got a table easily. Walked by later in the morning around 10 and it was very busy.
author: David D.

description: The glass of water exploded right on the table, producing a cut on my leg from all the glass. The waiters came over, and mildly said that this happened all the time (admitting that they have faulty glassware). Nothing was done about the fact that I had a cut on my leg. Food was alright. Not as amazing as the yelp reviews contended.
author: Julia D.

description:
WOW! I have found my new favorite brunch place. A friend and I ventured to Cole Valley to check out Zazie's at 11am on a Friday. We were expecting at least a 45 minute wait, but there was NO WAIT. Upon entering the restaurant I was already impressed with the decor and overall ambiance of the restaurant.  

Poached eggs -- La Mer: Modified eggs benedict topped with dungeness crab, avocado, green onions, and hollandaise sauce... Mouth Watering. 

French Toast Tahiti: Stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. This is the best French Toast combo I have ever had in my life. Seriously... this dish wins my heart. 

Such a cute brunch place! I'll be back soon.
author: Elaine N.

description:
My cousin was getting married and she wanted to get both sides of the family together at the dinner table. Their apartment was a little too small to accommodate everybody so we walked down the street to Zazie for a lovely evening.

The menu was prix fixe and we started off the evening with some red and white wine, and sparkling lemonade, along with some fresh rolls. The appetizers consisted of pate on bread with salad and steamed mussels in a white wine sauce. The pate was great of course and the white wine sauce was awesome with the mussels. I ordered the chicken with fresh fettuccine and bacon sauce. The chicken was unbelievably tender and fell of the bone. However, the rest of the dish was a little bland to be honest. I opted for the peach cobbler for dessert with fresh cream which was incredible and was my favorite course.

Service was pretty good and we always had plenty of wine, perhaps too much. The company was amazing and it was a fun evening for all. The back patio is lovely in the evening and I'm excited to go back to try their regular menu with my girlfriend sometime. They've even got a few dog-friendly seats outside when the weather is nice and your pup is in tow. Definitely worth checking out!

Food: 8/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 9/10
author: Joe M.

description: Worth the Wait! Sunday morning my friend and I walked up the street to Zazie just to be greeted by a small crowd who were waiting to be called. 30 minutes later we were seated and immediately greeted by a super happy and helpful waiter. The Mimsoa with mango was my favorite and they weren't light on the champagne either! I got the Divorcée and I'd get it again in a heartbeat! By far my favorite place we ate in SF that weekend and probably top 2 out of all brunch places I've ever eaten at!! Highly recommend, worth the wait!!
author: Brandon O.

description: My friends and I went here for brunch, and the atmosphere and service were excellent. I got the omelette of the day, and I thought it was only ok. However, I tried the French Toast and it was delicious. I think Zazie is a place that does everything well, and a lot of things excellently well. I was able to experience both with the two dishes I tried. I would definitely recommend this restaurant as a place to try in SF.
author: Lee E.

description: Enjoyed our dinner soooo much!  Seems best known as breakfast/brunch spot but don't skip dinner here!  Wine markup seems a bit high but nice selection and Tuesday is free corkage night!! It seems a new feature is availability of reservations on Open Table so life is easy!  We shared the yummy pate then went on to the Lemon Ricotta Ravioli with added mussels and the trout, both were heavenly!  Love the no tipping policy!!  Can't wait until all restaurants take care of their employees equally...
author: Karen R.

description:
This place keeps getting better and better every time I go. It's a really cute breakfast joint. There is outdoor seating, indoor seating, AND seating in the backyard patio. On a sunny day, it is worth sitting in the patio in the back. The wait to be seated varies on the time of day you go. I usually go a little before noon and I have never waited for more than 10 minutes. Parking isn't that bad either if you park a block or two away. 

Despite being really busy during brunch, the service isn't top notch, but it isn't bad either. The French Toast is definitely a must try here! My personal favorite is the two eggs scramble with Chicken Apple Sausage and breakfast potatoes. The potatoes are AMAZING! They make their potatoes with roasted garlic so it is always jam packed with flavor. 

5 stars because the food, service and ambiance are always fantastic.
author: Lisa H.

description: Best croque Madame I've ever had. The creamy bachemel slathered between melted cheese, warm Black Forest ham, perfectly fried egg, and crispy airy toast was so euphoric. Washed it down with a bowl of hot chocolate. Ended with their Tahitian French toast for dessert which was also to die for. Staff was very nice and thoughtful. The wait was quite fast and we scored a very nice table in the backyard dining al fresco. Love zazie and all it's San Francisco charm! French breakfast at its best!
author: Charmaine L.

description:
A friend wanted to grab breakfast so I looked up a place to go and we were off. I remembered that a big foodie friend of mine told me he really enjoyed this place so I was looking forward to it. 

We got to Zazie's at around 11:30. The place was packed and there was a group of two waiting before us. We debated on leaving to eat somewhere else out of fear for my friend being late to work. Luckily some tables cleared up within ten minutes. Keep this in mind if you're planning on eating here. 

I ordered the chocolate chaud because it sounded interesting and the La Mer Benedict. My friends ordered the poached egg florentine and some other egg dish respectively. 

The chocolate chaud, although pretty in appearance, fell short on my expectations. I was told that it was just hot chocolate, but I hoped that it would be high quality hot chocolate. It wasn't.

My benedict was really good! It's kind of expensive. $8 for just one egg, but it comes with crab. I'm not even a huge fan of crab, but I found that I liked this dish a lot. I really wanted more but I didn't have the appetite for it and we were running out of time. 

My friends seemed to like their dishes, but they told me they were expecting more especially for the price.

I like this place. Although expensive and a bit out of the way, I think I would go back just to try other things on both their breakfast menu and their dinner menu.
author: Sofia R.

description: The best part of this place is honestly not having to deal with figuring out tip for your meal. Love that they provide benefits for their staff! The food is also incredible and their back patio is adorable! Highly recommend he benedicts because the hollandaise is soooo good. Will definitely be back for their 'no corkage' Tuesday evenings for dinner.
author: Erica V.

description:
Went for brunch on Saturday. I was really impressed with their line management skills. While the line is long, they were very efficient in moving through the waiting list. My group arrived at 1 and was seated by 1:30. 

I had the Fontainebleau scramble with feta cheese instead of fontina, a side of bacon, coffee and an elderflower mimosa. All were excellent. Absolutely no complaints there. 

My portion of the bill came in at $40 which I found to be quite steep for breakfast food. Tip is included to cover health care and other benefits for their employees which I respect. Still the prices seemed somewhat inflated.
author: Bukky E.

description: As one of the most popular brunch places this side of San Francisco, I had high expectations for this place. Came in middle of the morning on a Monday and there was a bit of a wait but that was to be expected. We were seated and offered drinks very quickly and the wait staff was amicable. After ordering, the food takes a bit longer than I would have hoped 25 ish minutes. The quality of the food that was brought to us definitely met my expectations. Although a bit on the pricier side, the food was excellent and tasted of fresh ingredients. I didn't mind paying the price either as it includes tip and Zazie really tries to take care of its employees.
author: Brandon N.

description:
Celebrated Mother's Day here with the family for brunch and it was wonderful. This place has been recommended by everyone so I had to try it. It was extremely crowded on Sunday and parking was hard to find. I wish that I came after the lunch rush, like around 2pm so I could skip the hour wait.

But my family and I waited an hour and it was worth the wait. All the dishes we ordered were delicious. We got the French Toast Tahiti, La Mer, St. Trop, Fountainbleu, and Croque Royale. The poached eggs for the La Mer and St. Trop were perfectly cooked. The La Mer had crab while the St. Trop had salmon underneath the egg. I prefer the La Mer and I think the rest of my family did too. The Fountainbleu omelette disappointed me because I read such great reviews on yelp. The Croque Royale tasted good but I refer the Croque Monsieur from The Butler and The Chef. I was not a fan of the French toast but the banana that came with it was amazing. Get the fries over the salad. Overall, a good meal for under $100.

What I recommend:

La Mer
Home Fries
author: Andrew W.

description:
My friends and I wanted to do Sunday brunch and I have always wanted to try this place cause I read great reviews about it. We got there at like 9am I think and waited for a good 1-1.5 hours before getting seated. We each ordered a different dish of poached eggs. I got the La Mer because I love crab and my friend had it before. I tried all of my friends' dishes and they were all amazing. You also get to choose if you want 1, 2 , or 3 poached eggs. I got 2 which I think was the right amount. The poached eggs also come with salad or home fries. Get the home fries (its delicious potatoes cut in cubes seasoned perfectly). We (3 of us total including myself) also shared the pancake special which was a poppy seed pancake with lemon curd which took me to heaven. We each got a pancake and all loved it. It was yummy without the syrup or butter. Just smear that amazing lemon curd all over the pancake and it's perfect. 

And of course, we ordered mimosas. What's a Sunday brunch without mimosas?! We got a pitcher of mimosa with magic juice. They give you the champagne and juice separately so we could proportion it out ourselves.

Will definitely come here again!
author: Anna N.

description:
Very cute SF brunch spot. Came around 10:30 AM on a Monday with no wait. We sat in the back patio which was do-able because of the nice heat lamps they put up. LOVE that they have size customization options for most dishes. A big plus in my book.

La mer benedict is definitely worth a try if you are a benedict fan. This earned a giant stamp of approval from the boyfriend. I had the Salad Betterave with one slice of Tahitian French Toast. Salad was mediocre, much more mixed greens than beets/fennel but the balsamic gorgonzola dressing was pretty delicious. As many have said however, the french toast really did it for me. Love the walnut/banana combo and would encourage everyone to give it a whirl! Last word of advice is don't get the juice, it's not fresh squeezed and I believe comes from Odwalla.
author: Christina T.

description: This place is amazing after you are finally seated. The line gets pretty long but that's always a good sign. I've been here once before and I vowed to come back for the yummy seasonal pancakes. They are AMAZING! The garden deck in the back is totally worth the wait!
author: Ana M.

description:
za-zie! this is the only reason i will leave my warm comfy bed before 9am on the weekend. 

honestly, found this place three years ago and i'm still coming back! zazie is where i take out-of-town guests, family, former SF residents (by popular demand).

i can't turn down an eggs benny if my life depended on it. there are tons of options here! 

THE BEST TIME TO GET A TABLE- arrive about 5-10 minutes before they "open" and if you're lucky you won't even need to get a coffee at Peet's a couple doors down.

i've been here mannnnnnny times and i'll keep coming back. they also write the tip into the price so splitting the check is easy, but be aware, there are only TWO cc's allowed per table. plan on cash, friendTM or venmo if there's a bunch of you.

5/7 would try again (and again and again and again)
author: Ellyn T.

description:
The food is good. It's tasty.

But that's kind all of that I'm impressed with. I love the garlic in the potatoes, the salmon eggs benedict was good, as was the Tahiti french toast. But it is quite expensive...It was almost $50 for two, for breakfast and two drinks. We didn't even order any sides. 

I like that you aren't expected to tip because Zazie covers everything for their employees, but the service was not good. Our server took our orders, dropped off our food, and came by for the check. That's it. She was also a bit curt. We weren't checked up on even once, which meant if we needed anything, we would've had to go inside (we sat outside with our dog). 

They are also kinda stingy with their potatoes...Which makes me mentally sigh. Cause I mean, potatoes are so cheap. And two eggs benedict isn't really that much food. 

Definitely not a robust enough breakfast, very pricey, service is so-so. But yes, the food is tasty and fresh. It's just not enough for me to go back. You won't leave full unless you plan on spending even more money.
author: Susie Z.

description: This was a second visit and I was not as impressed. Huge wait; more than 50 minutes, for a party of 3. Covered patio in the back, a few tables on the street and a cramped area inside. Service is great and no tipping policy, hence the higher prices. Scrambles were just ok, and Tahitian pancakes were too sweet. Variety of coffee drinks and mimosas with different juices. Coffee cake was superb! Probably wouldn't return on a weekend, but maybe again on a weekday.
author: Smart Mama F.

description: Yummy food and great service. Cute neighborhood with a great covered garden patio. Also dig how it's a no tip restaurant due to profit sharing.
author: Nicole R.

description: The pâté was so delicious that I was crying with joy. Simply amazing. The mussels were also amazing and stood up well against the pâté, which is pretty spectacular considering how delightful the former is. Ate so much that I hurt myself. No regrets.
author: Jessie N.

description:
Went here for breakfast on a Friday morning, and got seating right away. Started to get busier around 9 am. I've heard weekend brunch time means it's impossible to get a table.

Ordered a delicious, not too sweet mimosa. Had a fantastic piece of French toast with tons of fresh fruit on it. I usually order omelets or more savory than sweet items for breakfast, but the reviews on the French toast and pancakes made me curious. DELICIOUS. Not overly sweet or large.

The ambiance in the restaurant is adorable and classic. Will be back!
author: Samantha B.

description:
My friend mentioned this restaurant to me when we were both looking for a place to have breakfast. He told me it was very popular and that it was usually super busy during weekends, but since we were going on a Monday, I didn't think we would have a problem with lines or anything like that.

Boy, was I wrong. The line wasn't very big when we got there around 10:30 AM, but it was rapidly increasing as the time passed (it really made me wonder how come all those people weren't busy, oh idk, working or something). The way the line works is that you put your name in a sheet of paper attached to the window, and how many people are in your party. Then, the serves comes out, sees the list, calls your name, and sits you either inside or in the patio. The outside area is in a first come first serve basis, and you do not need to write your name down.

We got seated within 15/20 minutes, and went to eat in the patio area. The area is very cute, but the only thing that bugged me a little was how close the tables were located. I understand they need to do that in order to seat more people, but it was a little annoying to be almost rubbing elbows with our neighbors. 

They really focus on a "no tip" policy, which makes their price a little more expensive than other brunch places, but when you think about, that is also very good. I didn't have any of their poached eggs (which seems to be a favorite) because I'm a really picky eater, but had a Italie Scrambled eggs that was pretty good. I mean, you can't go wrong with scrambled eggs, so it was pretty much a given that it would be good. The salad that came on the side was also really good, as was my friend's fries. 

Overall, I think the place is a little overrated. Would I come back here? Yeah, sure. Would it be my first choice? Probably not. Would I come back during weekends? Based on the reviews and my own experience during the weekday, probably not.
author: Carolina P.

description: I came to Zazie on a Thursday around 11. We wanted to see what all of the hype was about as we saw a huge amount of people waiting for brunch on Saturday after we had brunch somewhere else. I came in with an open mind. Yes, the prices seem very expensive, but I guess the tip is included. My boyfriend ordered a burger, I ordered the Mexico scrambled eggs with soyrizo ($3 upcharge?!?) and we split 2 miracle pancakes, which we cornmeal and lemon curd. My scrambled eggs were pretty good, but for $19 I expected them to be AMAZING. I definitely wasn't blown away. The pancakes were the best part, but only if you had some lemon curd on them. If you took a bite out of the pancake without it, it seemed pretty plain. Overall, it was pretty good, but definitely not worth the wait. I'm not sure if I missed something on my order, but I don't think I would go back.
author: Laurel H.

description: Everyone always raves about their brunch, but this is my favorite dinner sport in SF! The food is amazing and the service is always top notch. My last visit was for my anniversary and they brought us a bottle of champaign! The baked hot chocolate dessert is a MUST HAVE. I literally dream about it.
author: Alexa F.

description: Definitely more on the pricey side (but no tipping expected!) but awesome quality food. On the weekends put your name down and then come back after errands for an hour and you can get seated right away. Food is worth the wait!
author: Emily G.

description:
Love this place -- for any meal! You can't go wrong. I do prefer dinner here, though, since it's much easier to get a table, and the food choices are more unique at this time than their relatively standard brunch fare. The service is amazing: waiters are always friendly, very knowledgeable, and attentive. They also know their wines, so don't be afraid to ask for advice!

I love sitting outside on their backyard patio, which also has heat lamps on whenever it's chilly. Definitely recommend opting for this since it's less crowded than their inside seating.

I've had several of their appetizers and entrees, all of which have been delicious and reasonably priced. My favorite thus far has been the Grilled Niman Ranch Flat Iron Steak -- really flavorful and perfectly cooked (I recommend rare). Our waiter that night suggested I get the portobello cream sauce on the side, which was excellent advice, as the sauce itself has a strong flavor and it was nice to titrate the amount of sauce with the meat that's already very flavorful on its own.

As for dessert... oh man. Save room. Get the Baked Chocolat Chaud. GET IT. Imagine a big mug full of rich hot chocolate, covered in a thick layer of marshmallows, then baked for a while. The end result: the hot chocolate part turns into a mousse-like substance, which is covered in perfectly toasted marshmallows -- basically a s'more without the gross graham crackers getting all up in your business. 

Can't wait to go back for more (which will likely be on a Tuesday since it's no-corkage-fee night)!
author: Justine M.

description:
Brunch spot of those in the know.  AND everyone else (hence, those lines!)

More doable for a weekday brunch, the breakfast at Zazie has it all going on.  

Location.  (Quaint Cole Valley.)
Great food.  (Gingerbread pancake w poached pears.  Tasty scrambles & perfectly rendered benedicts.  Gigantic lattes!)
Backyard patio!  (Yes, Virginia.  There IS sun behind that fog!)

Zazie is worth the wait!
author: Rachel H.

description:
My mom and I went on vacation to SF during a rainy week in December, and this place was not too far from where we stayed so we decided to give it a shot. They were pretty busy on a Wednesday morning, but we didn't even have to wait to be seated. The place is super cute and charming, and the food was amazing! Their kitchen is very small and I'm amazed all the delicious things to come out of it. If I remember, we had the French Toast Tahiti and the Poached Eggs St. Trop. The home fries that came with the eggs were the highlight of our meal - delicious and garlicky. I also ordered a mocha, which I often do with brunch, and I received a giant, delicious pool of mocha. The service was very friendly! 

We liked Zazie so much that we came back two days later on Friday. It was much busier, but we were seated in their patio pretty quickly since it wasn't raining. We got to try some of their specials! I can see why this place gets such a crowd even on a weekday. Wish I could've brought it home with me.
author: Cristina C.

description:
Went here on Sat for breakfast wanting to try a new spot. Don't understand what the long wait is for! Maybe because there isn't much else in the area. We had eggs benedict which were ok, The muffins were stale. Then my cup had egg residue on the rim and then when i got another one it smelled like egg in side but the waiter never came back to check on us. 
Pancakes and french toast were really good,

We sat outside and had to walk through the kitchen area and it was filthy.. 

Too many other options in SF that are way better.Then they had this no tipping policy, I have a hard time understanding it.
author: Miriam B.

description:
First time there with out of town visitors for brunch .and thought, can't be that good for a hour and half wait..but we waited.
 Can't say enough about our server, acted like  we were the only customers he had all day.
Good quality & amount of food  for the price. 
Tip included totally won me over.
And they do dinner????? 
Hope to go back soon.
author: Linda K.

description: Ironically, I have never been to Zazie for brunch. I just can't wait more than 20 minutes for breakfast fare; However, we live in the neighborhood and this has become one of our favorite dinner spots. Their menu has a few classic staples but otherwise rotates seasonally. So far we haven't tried anything that has not been delicious (some favorites include the fresh pasta, duck leg, stuffed chicken and seasonal fruit crisp) and the atmosphere is cozy and charming. I might even give it 5 stars if it weren't for those pesky brunch lines...
author: Molly S.

description: Didn't seem to be worth the long wait and hype. Was super overpriced for the quality and the service wasn't very good.
author: Ari R.

description:
Took my two best friends here that were visiting because the back patio looked beautiful. Cute neighborhood and easy enough to find parking. Ordered elder flower mimosa and La Mer (dungeoness crab, avocado, house lemon hollandaise sauce over poached egg on English Muffin w/ home fries which were better than the average country style potatoes.

No tips! The prices on the menu afford the employees a good living wage, health insurance, 401k etc. Pretty cool concept.
author: Zoe M.

description:
This place was superb!!!  I LOVE brunch and this spot has the BEST poached eggs I've ever had!! Get the Le Mer Benedict. You'll love it. 

We also listened to yelp and tried the gingerbread pancake with the lemon custard and poached pear- get that too. 

I also loved that you could order 1 of something!  I had 1 Le Mer Benedict egg and 1 gingerbread pancake- and it was the PERFECT amount!! New favorite brunch spot!
author: Lauren L.

description:
Listen up... if you decide to go!?!? Yes the good reviews are well deserved so read them and the menu to know for when to go!!!!
We were the 3rd name on the list, Our wait  was 6(six) minutes, sidewalk seating, at 10:00am, Monday Columbus Day, cool, overcast with no precipitation day...... So, this is it in a nutshell... 
YELP's  "great reviews " made this place the one of  "first choices" to go to, therefore, it is busier than a small place can handle. You know: QUALITY OVER QUANTITY" !!! However, the wait is worth it! It is up to you to decide how long you are willing to wait. Parking is on the streets and IT IS A NO-no!!! saving spots for anyone...as everyone knows from watching a "popular TV show" !!! 
To minimize the wait: When you get there
 (1). make sure to write your name on the list by the door.
 (2). stay close to the entrance for when they call your name 
(3) know where you want to sit (inside, back patio, sidewalk)
(4). Know or decide quickly what you want for quicker service. 
Here is what happened when My party of 3, went there this Monday, Columbus Day 10-10-2016, 
Another party of 3 was waiting and the parking spot right in front became available and the male went to get the car and bring it there, meanwhile another car pulled up and attempted to park, to which the two females told that they were saving it And by this time there were a couple more parties waiting to be seated. We all said "you can't save a parking spot!!!!" The two females walked to the corner to alert the male that the parking spot is no longer available. Then, Two things happened, One: the sidewalk table emptied and just then the Host came out and called the name of the ladies, and they were not present to answer,  so the next name on the list was called and the y wanted to wait for patio seating about 20 min... we were called  next and took the table!!! We were eating in about 15 minutes... Out to enjoy the day by 11-ish...
The two ladies came back and were told that because they missed their turn they were now at the bottom of the list... which by now was about 6 long.... TAKE NOTE AND YOU WILL HAVE A GOOD  EXPERIENCE
author: Zoe A.

description: Ordered the lobster Eggs Benedict -- Wow! Best Eggs Benedict I've ever had. The flavors were unbelievable. The service was also great. The entire staff in the restaurant was smiling and friendly. Went for Saturday brunch, the wait wasn't bad at all and was definitely worth it.
author: A V.

description:
My goodness, what a wait.  You have to check all the boxes (patio, indoor seating, first come) if you want to get a seat anytime before 1.5 hrs.  I was with someone who chose only patio seating, so I watched forlornly as everyone was seated for an hour before I realized what was happening.  Don't let this happen to you!  :::angry stomach growling:::

We had the dungeness crab eggs benedict, the eggplant and poached egg with spicy tomato sauce (my fave), and the gingerbread pancake.  For you savory breakfast lovers with a penchant for pancakes, I'd recommend getting two poached eggs how you want them (they have so many types), because they're all so distinct and delicious, and then sharing 1 gingerbread pancake between two people so you get that real Zazie experience.  I will go back and check all the boxes next time, gotta eat that pancake!
author: Terry K.

description: This place and plow are the two best brunch places in SF imo. There's usually a long wait, so my advice is to come early. The food is good, the service is great, and the ambiance is lively without being too loud.
author: Derrick W.

description: Delicious.  Great Service.  Fun and lovely ambiance.  And I LOVE that they take care of their employees with sufficient pay, insurance, etc. (to take a stand against the tip-based culture in U.S. restaurants which leans toward oppression).  It actually inspired me to give additional tips!! Thank you, Zazie!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
5 stars for service.  But overall rating (maybe more like 3.5 stars) is down for food and the wait.

We ordered the Tahiti French Toast, Le Mer, the Albert, and the BLT.

We liked the Albert the most.  They know how to cook their bacon.  Actually everything was perfectly cooked.

I can see why people like it.  It's good fresh food but not worth the wait.  Our party just wasn't into it.

We waited 90 minutes for our party of 3 on New Year's Day.

$19 for a two egg La Mer (due to the dungeness crab) is not worth it in my opinion because we didn't like it.  I'm sure the cost is for the quality products they use but it has to taste really good to pay $19 for brunch.

I'm not into the benefits surcharge but that's just because no one else does it.

The surcharge is probably why the workers were so happy and kind (because they've got a great job).  The host was especially courteous and handled all the impatient customers well.
author: Addison P.

description: This stuff was so fire, we came in on a monday and we are already seated. The kitchen makes their pancake mix with real pumkin and it was just made 5 minutes ago the place is very pretty, very pretty. Tip included and it's all bomb diggity. I spilled coffee but they were super chill about it. And the kitchen dudes are working all pro.
author: Anthony M.

description:
La Mer, thumbs up--it's hard to find good crab in the universe. Expect a wait. Sat in back patio, pretty
tight.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Looks like a normal brunch place from the outside but SIKE IT'S NOT. I kinda was like.. why da hayl am i waiting an hour for this basicass place cuz honestly, i feel like brunch food tastes the same, wherever it is. Zazies stood out to me because of the backside outdoor seating. 

If you're tryna enjoy some exceptional brunch and take some pictures with a backdrop that lets others know that you're hipster af, go to Zazies. 

-Got a something scramble with mushrooms w side salad and whole wheat toast. They weren't skimpy with the veggies in the scramble! 
-The host man was super super nice and smile a lot despite the huge crowd of impatient people waiting
author: Crystal B.

description:
I've heard the raving reviews about this place for quite some time and with Father's Day weekend being around the corner, I wanted to bring my family over to this place. To be honest, I was a little underwhelmed. Maybe it was the cramped seating inside with my large party (which I guess was my fault) or the food being subpar to what I had hoped for. Either way, I wouldn't want to return here with a party of 5 ever again. Only come to this place with a party of 2 - 4 at max. 5-6 is a little ridiculous but that's not the restaurant's fault.

The reason I'm giving a 3 star rating is because again, I was underwhelmed. The food was average for the price range. If I'm gonna be ordering the la mer eggs Benedict with crab, I'm expecting some kind of extra pizzazz. The Tahiti French toast which is also a popular dish wasn't all that great. It was too sweet for my taste. Would I return here? Maybe one more time & I'd maybe wanna try the outside seating. Meh. That's exactly how I felt about zazie's. It was meh.
author: Kai S.

description:
Fantastic food at a fantastic price. Went for dinner, and it was great! 

Be sure to try the garden in the back - very nice setting.

My favorite part: no tipping. Yes I know its baked into the price, but I love the spirit.
author: D C.

description: Yummy brunch! Waited over 90 minutes for a table but we grabbed lattes at la boulangerie to pass the time. Coffee cake to die for, lobster Benedict was good but stingy on the lobster. One star off for overall cleanliness of the restaurant.
author: Ange R.

description: Was in love! It was amazing service with delicious food! This is one of my favorite places to go in the city!
author: Kennedy V.

description: This is one of my favorite places for brunch! Everything on the menu is delicious. I love the Avignon!
author: Sara K.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF. Everything I've had is spectacular. I love their hot chai latte.
author: Allison M.

description:
I don't even know how to begin to describe what a fabulous time we had here.  Everything, service, food, ambiance, was just perfect. 

Made reservations but were a bit early, luckily there were a couple of bars nearby where we just grabbed drinks. 

The restaurant is adorable, love how intimate the setting is. Our server (Aiden? ugh wish I could remember) was great, very knowledgeable about the menu, super friendly and outgoing, and a just a joy to chat with.  He was also hilarious.  

I really enjoyed the food.  Our table shared the mussels and the fromage plate which came with three types.  Totally don't remember what the names were, but all yummy. Our table also really liked the free house bread, so much so we ended up asking for seconds.  It came out fresh and warm and one of my friends said it was the second best house bread he'd ever had...trust me that's saying a lot. 

I had the Coq au Vin de Zazie. The chicken was cooked bone-in, which is the best way to me. Amazing flavors, so tender, the meat just fell off the bone.  The pasta was also really nice and had a great texture.  My friend thought the sauce was a bit too sweet for her, but I personally liked it.  Friends ordered the Boeuf Bourguignon, Raviolis, and the daily specials. All raved about their foods.  

Afterwards, so stuffed from free bread and the entrees that we weren't able to order dessert, but our serve still gave us complementary cake, which of course we couldn't let go to waste and managed to polish off. 

Can't wait to go back, next time for brunch!
author: Wendy G.

description:
I don't really know what the hype is all about. I'm glad that we went on a Friday morning and didn't have to wait that long. The service was kinda slow and unattentive. We ordered:

Coffee cake - look way better than it tasted
Miracle pancake - bread pudding pancake with banana - pretty good 
Poached eggs with crab - okay

Nothing was particularly spectacular. I wouldn't go out of my way to come back.
author: Sharon C.

description:
Bottom line at the top: good brunch, a little basic by California standards but it isn't fussy and service is great so I bumped them up.
--
Benedicts, omelets, French toast. Everything is good but nothing is really mind blowing. The adorablee patio outside + very sweet and attentive service makes this place shine but it's a one and done kinda place considering all that SF has to offer. :)
author: Dahlia S.

description: I work nearby and went to Zazie for brunch to celebrate two colleagues birthdays.  First of all it took the waitress about 25 min to just address that we were there.  I told her that we had been waiting and she answered us sarcastically which I did not at all appreciate.  It look us another 20 minutes to order and get water.   Overall I would not go back and was very dissatisfied.  The price of the poached eggs are way too high, $29.00 for two eggs with salmon.  When I go out to restaurants I expect respect from the staff and good service. This experience was way below my standard.
author: Karen B.

description:
Went here on Sunday for the brunch :D I see why people go crazy for this place. I got the egg benedicts with prosciutto. It was SOOOOOO YUM :D but I honestly don't think the portion was big enough to fill me. I had to order 3 piece of egg benedicts and one order of the french toast to feel full here :( The other bad part was that I waited 2+ hours to eat here. And sadly this place does not even take any reservation.
P.s. The french toast here was the best one I ever gotten in SF though. I definitely recommend  the french toast here !
author: Yumi K.

description: Eggs le mer (eggs benedict with crab and avocado) is a must, along with a gingerbread pancake topped with lemon curd. A great brunch spot-- the wait looks daunting, but they're organized and it moves quickly.
author: Candace D.

description: Loved this place. The staff was so nice. The environment was great. The food was great. I'll definitely be back in the future!
author: Scott K.

description: One of my favorite places to eat! Amazing eggs Benedict and pancakes. The service is great too. Definitely worth the long wait.
author: Chris H.

description:
I heard a lot about Zazie before heading over - stuff about their dungenous crab eggs benedict, french toast, LONG wait, etc. And no joke - me & one other person waited for about 2 hours before getting seated! It's best to get here on the early or later side during brunch hours (9am-3pm) so you don't get the rush-hour crowd. But let me tell you, it was definitely worth the wait! (Plus, we were hanging out at the bar next door drinking bloody mary's & mimosas so it wasn't that bad).

The dungenous crab eggs benedict is to-die-for! They are very generous with the crab! You can choose how many eggs you want too. I only had 1 & regret it so bad because I scarfed the whole thing down so fast, it was THAT good! It also comes with avocado too - more delicious, creamy goodness!
author: Alysha K.

description:
I was pretty disappointed. I've been waiting months to finally try this place as the lines were always so long. Went on a Friday around 11ish and took about half an hour to get seated. Thought, hmm must be good if this many people are trying it! Little did I know that the portions were tiny and my food wasn't even tasty. I guess I'm comparing to Kitchen Story or Sweet Maple but this place just didn't meet the expectations. It was cute inside but too small. The service was slow since we waited another 20 minutes for food we finished in less than 5 minutes and then another 5 whole minutes for the check and we asked for it twice. 

Pros: tip free
Cons: not very tasty, overly priced (must be why they don't ask for tip since it's already included), slow service
author: Deion D.

description:
A $17 cheeseburger. 

There was only enough hamburger to cover half the bun. They were very generous with the lettuce, I counted 11 pieces to camoflage the tiny meat portion no doubt. If they used half a slice of cheese I'd be surprised.

The waiter couldn't have been less attentive if he tried. Kept us waiting for our food for 30 minutes without an update, then 15 minutes after we ate before I had to get up and walk the restaurant to find him and ask for a check.

Never again.
author: David C.

description: I love that that they don't consider tip and pay fair wages.  Staff is much more diverse as well.  Food is delicious.  Atmosphere is nice and cozy.
author: Alisa N.

description: Very good brunch place. I love their eggs Benedict and the 1-2-3. Great service. I stopped going a while ago because it became too popular and crowded. It is excellent otherwise!
author: P. C.

description:
The dishes were excellent prepared. The Mimosa with white peach was great. The French onion soup, mac & cheese, pork chops and polenta cakes were delicious. Excellent service. 

Highly recommended.
author: Glenda P.

description: Amazing. Seriously these guys nail every aspect of a great brunch experience. Food is fantastic, service is efficient and polite, and the ambience is money (the patio in the back in particular is very cool). Wait on a weekday morning was about 15 minutes. Recommend the Eggs Benedict.
author: Jordan S.

description: Really poor service. Took forever for the server to acknowledge is, food took forever to get to us, which was especially noticeable when all of the other tables were receiving their food in a timely fashion. I would not come back again, based on the poor service and cost.
author: Erica L.

description:
My sister loves this place, so I treated her out to brunch here for her birthday. My boyfriend and I arrived early, put our name on the list, and since we weren't familiar to the area, walked around for awhile. The surrounding area is very interesting and the wait wasn't so bad. The host does a good job of looking for a party before crossing their name off the list as not there anymore. 

I wasn't particularly wow-ed by the egg dish I ordered - The Albert (was a bit cold), but the side of homefries were really tasty. Boyfriend got the Croque Madame, which we both agreed we've had better at other places. My sister ordered a side of pancakes, which turned out to actually be really good (I considered buying some batter for home). Mimosa was just okay - better at Le Central Parc Bistro. 

Overall, it's a very cute place, but I don't think it lived up to the hype for me (created by my sister and 7x7) and I probably won't be coming back since it's out of the way and not worth the drive/wait to me. I can see the charm this place has for other people though and definitely glad I tried it out.
author: Ghia G.

description:
Delicious, quality, fast, amazing brunch.

Got two egg poached egg thing with dungeonous crab.
author: Lenny G.

description:
Came here for Sunday brunch. Waited about 45 min to get seated. Got to sit in the back patio area and enjoy the nice weather. Noticed they have heat lamps and cute lights strung around for nighttime.

Service was great. All of the staff were friendly, helpful, and patient, despite running a very busy establishment. I ordered a french toast with a side of chicken sausages. The french toast was delightfully fluffy and really needed nothing besides a bit of syrup. I still decided to overindulge and use the butter AND plop on loads of their berry preserve. The chicken sausage appeared burnt, but I suppose it's necessary to make sure the meat's cooked all the way through.

I also got a cole mimosa, which tasted like a regular mimosa, but with a touch of grapefruit. It was delicious and refreshing. My friend got their smoothie mimosa, which comes with a scoop of sorbet at the bottom. It's really fizzy and apparently quite creamy when you get to the end :)

I would definitely come back.
author: Chia-Fen Y.

description:
Are you craving for a coq au vin, or maybe it's a boeuf bourgignon, how about a confit de canard followed by some good French cheese with some good old Côte du Rhone !
Well this is the place to go enjoy and be marry !
Oh almost forgot, they are a socially responsible company who actually take responsibility for providing paid for benefits to their employees.
Well done. !
author: Laurent O.

description: Honestly, I don't think it's worth the wait. The food is good, not amazing, and can be problematic because it's never quite hot when it reaches the table. If you ask me, proper temperature is what can really elevate a simple dish from good to great, and they have a hard time doing that.
author: Mary R.

description:
BELIEVE THE HYPE: G I N G E R B R E A D   P A N C A K E (S)!!! FTW!!!

I am OBSESSED with ginger! There's something about the aromatic mild spicy sweetness of it that I just can't get enough of. So, if something has ginger in it, I have to have it...PERIOD!

On Friday, December 17th, my friend and I came to Zazie's around Noonish. The wait was about 15 minutes which wasn't too bad.

Reservations for brunch is ONLY accepted for WEEKDAYS for parties of 6 or more (from December 20th - January 1st, reservations are not accepted.) 

F O O D: 
*GINGERBREAD PANCAKE w/ Bosc Pears & Lemon Curd (one - $6): Generally when things are so hyped up, I end up getting disappointed when it comes time for me to try it. *GASP* I have to say, my fellow Yelpers did NOT lead me astray! Total YUMMINESS...

Evoking the texture of a sponge cake, the large gingerbread pancake was light, fluffy and soft. The medley of ginger, cloves, nutmeg and cinnamon brought out a subtle earthy, sweet, spicy and nutty flavor. The generous dollop of lemon curd added a sweet citrus punch that brightened up the pancake so there was really no need for the maple syrup.

*NEW YORK SCRAMBLE w/ Wild Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese ($12): GOOD! The eggs were perfectly scrambled to fluffy chiffon yellow clouds intertwined with loads of smoked salmon and whipped cream cheese; a good balance of salty, savory, smoky and creamy! I would have preferred that the scramble be made with lox instead of fully cooked salmon so it can maintain its richness from the Omega 3-fatty acids, but I doubt it was possible for a scramble. Nonetheless, it was still good. 

The scramble came with home fries and your choice of toast, but I steered away from because as I wanted to waste my carbs on the pancake. 

S E R V I C E:
The service at Zazie's reminded me more of your typical diner than a bistro; fast but with a lack of personality. After ordering, our food arrived promptly within 7-8 minutes. After receiving our food, I don't remember our waiter ever checking in with us after that. I liked that a glass water bottle was provided on our table so we could refill our glasses at our own leisure without having to bother the wait staff. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R:
A cozy and small French bistro with a touch of funkiness from the bright yellow and rustic brick walls, French posters, white-tiled flooring and a narrow metal spiral stair case leading to the loft area. The inside dining area was lively yet not overbearing with loud chatter. 

Since it was raining and I didn't get a glimpse of the patio, but I can imagine it would be the perfect place for brunch, lunch and dinner on a warm, sunny day. 

P A R K I N G:
Depending on the day/time, parking in Cole Valley can be difficult. Considering there will be a wait, you may want to look for 2-hr residential parking which is easiest to find during the weekdays before 6 PM.  

I'm not a huge brunch person (mainly because I can't pull myself out of bed on the weekends), but for Zazie's Gingerbread Pancakes, I give someone permission to get all WWE on me and do a "five knuckle shuffle" while I'm sleeping. :X
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Aside from the excruciating long wait, everything else was perfect. It is a really great place for brunch and mimosas. If you are fans of Benedict's, egg-type foods, and breakfast foods, you have to try this place out. 

Get La Mer and you can't go wrong. Their eggs are perfectly poached and the crab is crunchy on the outside but soft on the inside. One bite will melt in your mouth! 

Make sure to put a reservation ahead, get your group together, and enjoy this delicious joint! They have a indoor and outdoor patio-type seating area. Don't worry, for those of you going in the winter, there are heating lamps outdoors.
author: Sally H.

description: Amazing for brunch. Long wait though, would get there earlier to avoid the crowd. Would definitely come back again!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
I have been SF for two years and everyone has told me about Zazies. I have finally went and I have to say it was solid. I got the crab eggs benedict and I was happy with my selection. Zazie is not a quality brunch place so dont expect huge portions. With that said, it is pricey

Pros:
1. Great quality brunch/breakfast food
2. Nice environment and staff
3. Tipping is not allowed, since they have higher prices to pay their employees more.

Cons:
1. A little overhyped
2. Long line unless you come really early 
3. Really expensive for breakfast/brunch

Overall, the price prevents me from being a frequent customer, but if I want a treat I will frequent Zazies.
author: Soroosh A.

description: Amazing brunch spot and I love the food! Mario is a superstar and so is his entire staff!
author: Sai M.

description: Oh dear, Zazie, what has happened to you? I went for the first time in years on a week day, avoiding the hours-long weekend wait, and ended up with a pretty below average, very expensive breakfast. My eggs Vincent had no sign of a corn cake, but were instead eggs and wet spinach atop  a bed of wet corn. A spoon of yesterday's salsa, half a small, browning avocado, and a sauce of what tasted like katsup, water, and hot sauce completed the dish. I shall now ride out the stomach ache.
author: Violet H.

description: Excellent location, environment, food AND service! Highly recommend sitting in the back terrace! Heated lamps and covering, vines growing. Beautiful and tastes.
author: Teddy D.

description: Stopped here today for breakfast / brunch. Got some delicious eggs benedict with a coffee. The service was super quick and very friendly. The atmosphere was cute and bright. Andddd get this... They don't expect tips. Mind blown! Come here for a reasonable and yummy meal.
author: Petrea R.

description:
Sure, the food is good, but consistently getting bad service is not great. Look, as an SF native, I know there are plenty of places to have a wonderful one-of-a-kind breakfast/brunch experience. That being said, nobody should be subjected to such rude service. The past two times have been a stressful experience and 3 times will NOT be a charm as you have lost a customer for life...and possibly more as I will direct friends and family elsewhere.

Rude waitress this last time that rolled her eyes, was constantly short with us and just was visibly annoyed about any questions asked about the menu. Additionally, she did this in front of my family and kids. It was so bad, we actually got up and left. Previous visit to this, a different waitress was so rude to us and our friends that we actually had the next table ask.if everything was ok.

C'mon, you're in a City filled with great food and great people...quit treating your customers like trash.
author: B L.

description: My sister lives a few steps away from Zazie so I'm surprised it's taken me this long to finally try the brunch menu. I had dinner here a year ago and it was good. I enjoyed the Truffle Ravioli and a glass of wine. But the brunch food here is something I will come back again for. I ordered the Monaco and my friend ordered the Florentine. I like how you can order 1-3 eggs as I usually have a small appetite so 1 egg is perfect. The egg was poached perfectly and it went so well with the tomato, prosciutto and English muffin. I ate there this morning and I am considering going back tomorrow. It's that good. And yes, be prepared to wait especially on weekends.
author: Chi N.

description:
Bloody Mary's
Burger w/bacon and white cheddar 
Crouque Monsieur
Le Mer Benedict

Awesomeness!! Burger WON hands down! Crouque   Is second and Benedict was bland. 

So good, but worth 1.5 hours wait... ? The burger was!! Amazeballs!
author: Leslie E.

description:
Although the wait was about 30min for a party of 3 in a Sunday morning at 9:30am, it was worth the wait. The food was excellent; we all locked out plates.

The mushroom scramble looked awesome. The eggplant scramble also was great. If you decline toast, they offer both potatoes and salad. I had La Mer (poached eggs with crab meat and avocado) and it was yum yum. The hollandaise sauce was not overpowering or overwhelming at all - lemon zest.

We walked out about 11:00 or so and the line/crowd was even worse then at 9:30am. Looked like about 1hr wait. If you wanna try to place, go early on Sunday.
author: Linda K.

description:
Excellent Challah French toast and fruit.  I ordered crisp bacon and it was-- without being burnt!!! Yay someone finally got it right!!! The apple chicken sausage was very good. The buttermilk pancake was light and fluffy-- they may have made the batter from scratch.  When I make them from scratch they are similar. 
A HUGE tip:  read the little sign out front but don't HOVER over the tables waiting.  

I would recommend this for a good, solid brunch.
author: Tad H.

description:
Since I moved to SF 3 years ago I have heard of Zazies. People would rave about their brunch and tell stories of waiting a long time just to eat here. When I had tried to go a couple times I would turn around intimidated by the wait and crowds outside.
When I finally had a weekday morning free, I thought I would go. So on a Tuesday at 8:30am, my bf and me went and were seated immediately. I got their Avignon breakfast and Tahitian French toast and honestly..... it wasn't spectacular. It wasn't bad, but I was happy that I didn't wait an hour outside for it like i would have had to on the weekend. I might have even preferred to sleep in on my free weekday. The meal was just....uninspiring. 
It might also be a result of my recent obsession with chulala, so having eggs without chulala is just so boring. 
I probably wouldn't be so hard on zazies if people hadn't set my expectations so high. Or maybe I missed something? Where did I go wrong?!
author: Julianna I.

description:
Welcoming cafe with an ambiance that sets you in a local cafe in a small town. 

First time ordering Eggs en Fonte and it was alright. I felt underwhelmed after finishing my dish. Seems like the highlights of this cafe are the variety of french toasts and pancakes. A couple friends ordered the crab benedict, but it didn't look all that appealing. I don't think I will be back because nothing stood out for me. It's a quaint cafe, but my experience was only upped by the company I had. Portions were unimpressive. ALTHOUGH, the poached eggs did look like perfection...
author: Anna S.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. The service was friendly but overall the food quality was mediocre at best. 

We waited over an hour for our entrees.  When they arrived, it was so overcooked, we wanted to send it back.  However we were so hungry we decided just to eat so we could and leave. 

I will not be back for dinner. Perhaps brunch is a better option?
author: Liz A.

description:
Came here for brunch with my girlfriends, and my, it was delicious!

I ordered the La Mer which has dungeness crab and avocados. With a poached egg on top, how can you go wrong with that? The egg was runny and oooey and goooey... mmmm, it was perfect. I also shared the French Toast Tahiti with a girlfriend - it was absolutely yummy! Probably one of the best french toast dishes I've ever had. The carmelized walnuts and bananas complimented the french toast perfectly without being overly sweet.

Portions were decent-sized. With my poached egg dish and a shared french toast dish, I was completely stuffed. Oh yeah, for drinks, get "Le Metro"! It had a very unique taste to it, probably due to the lavender simple syrup.

Parking was very difficult to find and the wait to get seated was rather long (so many people during the weekend!), but if you are willing to push through those two issues, then brunch is so worth it!
author: Victoria V.

description:
Food is about as good as any other brunch place in the city. 

This was not a great experience as a family though. They crammed us into a tiny table wedged into the corner, which we were happy to take after waiting 45 minutes to be seated. My daughter's oatmeal was piping hot and, combined with the tiny table, made it very difficult to feed her and enjoy breakfast. 

Our waiter was very nice and we were served promptly. While there is a long wait, the system is fair and transparent - if you show up before they open you will be able to put your name on the list. I probably would have given this three stars if we were still just a couple, but having a family has changed my criteria. No thank you.
author: Alex L.

description: We were recommended this place by a local, she raved about it. I was excited when we got there, the decor and ambiance was super mellow. We decided to eat on the back patio which was beautiful. Since we were on vacation, we decided to get some mimosas. They were very okay, nothing special. I almost didn't even finish mine, when normally I'm gulping them down. He got one of the eggs Benedict, which is one of his favorite breakfast dishes. He poked at it, and said it was just okay. I got the one of the egg dishes-- the one with all the mushrooms, spinach, and cheese-- and again, it was just fine. We were bummed considering how much our host raved about it. But the ambiance made up for it, we loved that back patio and our waiter was very nice!
author: Shannon D.

description:
*** This review follows my appearance on "Check, Please! Bay Area" (season 5, episode 11). The other restaurants reviewed from that show are Pagolac in the Tenderloin and Della Santini's Trattoria in Sonoma. ***
_____________________________________

Zazie is the type of little French bistro that you could easily pass by if you're on a Parisian boulevard filled with similarly inviting eateries. You could even pass by it in the less bustling neighborhood of Cole Valley. Three times. I guess I'm just not that observant without a GPS. I decided to make the evening a group outing in order to try more of their menu. Other friends have come here for breakfast, but nobody I knew has tried dinner there, including me. What a loss for them. At first, I was a bit concerned the noise level would be unbearable given the tight quarters. In my head, I was imagining five bells ringing in the Chronicle listing. 

Fortunately, the four of us were seated next to the front window, which afforded us a semi-private enclave and even a vitriolic opportunity to comment on the clothing of the diners coming in and out of the restaurant. We started ambitiously by sharing five -- count 'em, five -- starters. First up were the Mussels Marinieres, which they steam very nicely in white wine, garlic, shallots, and parsley, as it all bathes in a creamy broth (see photo). The salads were quite fresh tasting. The Salade d'Ete was the more original concoction with a mix of sliced strawberries, goat cheese, toasted almonds, and even flower petals on a bed of arugula (see photo). It was a dish that seemed to announce the arrival of spring. 

Despite its daring French New Wave filmmaking namesake, the Salade Louis Malle was more conventional: spinach, caramelized walnuts, and Gorgonzola in a balsamic vinaigrette (see photo). We all more equally shared the Assiette de Fromages, a nice selection of three soft French cheeses with figs and toasted walnuts. That left me being the most selfish by ordering the intentionally hard-to-share French Onion Soup Gratinée with beef stock, a truly fine interpretation of a French classic that offers the irresistible lure of melted cheese (see photo). 

I was also able to try four of their entrees, all quite impressive in execution. With keen competition, the best had to be the Roasted Trout, which had a nice texture and an added burst of flavor from the cherry tomatoes in a basil vinaigrette and warm goat cheese (see photo). A close runner-up was the fresh Lemon Ricotta Ravioli, buttery smooth with wilted arugula, leeks, grilled prawns, garlic and aged parmesan cheese (see photo). A more traditional dish was the Lapin à la Moutarde, which was the dark meat of the rabbit braised and covered in a Dijon mustard sauce with mushrooms (see photo). Underneath was a bed of fettuccine. It was more of a stew dish than I had envisioned, as the sauce got a bit sloshy, and the little rabbit bones tough to maneuver around. 

Still, it was quite tasty. The last entree was a signature dish, the Zazie Burger with cheddar, tomatoes Provençal, and grilled Yukon gold potatoes (see photo). It was a good, juicy burger, if you are in the mood for one. We barely had any room for dessert, but for the sake of the show, I felt it was important to try at least one. We all took our spoons and dug into the Crumble Zazie, a generously sized fresh fruit cobbler that either came in a dish à la mode or in a bowl drizzled with crème anglais (see photo). Lo and behold, we had both variations in front of us, and they were the perfectly French ender to our meal. 

For what appears on the surface to be a neighborhood eatery, Zazie certainly offers a robust and eclectic menu, and there is even a prix fixe menu on select items in the menu (thus the appearance of the Zazie Burger on our table). For the most part, the waitstaff was quite nice and accommodating. The one hiccup was the selection of our wine. I went for a $32 bottle of the Chateau Horeau Cabernet Franc, definitely one of their more budget-conscious selections, and I swear I got a case of small-mouth from the waitress. 

The place was bustling for most of the evening, but as it was a weeknight, the low hum of dining activity started to die down after 9 PM. I would definitely come back to Zazie in a heartbeat. It's right off the N-Judah line on Cole, so it's a really convenient location for me. And after all, this review is all about me. By the way, several months after my visit, I was able to meet owner Jennifer Piallat and her general manager Mario quite by accident through a friend at Barbacco. They are wonderful people who feel rightfully proud about their business. 

FOOD - 5 stars...first-class French bistro but comfortable, not snooty by a long shot 
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...intimate with a nice patio 
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...great, friendly waitstaff beyond reproach 
TOTAL - 5 stars...Jennifer, you should be very proud of your place
author: Ed U.

description:
Zazie is a great weekday breakfast date spot; it offers good food, pleasant ambiance, and is located in adorable and accessible Cole Valley. 

Having said that, I wouldn't recommend Zazie for anything but weekday breakfast dates. After visiting semi-regularly over the course of a few years, I decided I was done waiting for brunch. I successfully recreated some Zazie recipes at home, for a slightly more modest price. I'm not saying that the wait time is their fault; what I'm saying is I'm not investing 45 minutes into unsuccessfully stifling noontime hanger for a stack of pretty good cinnamon pancakes. 

Again, this is a great spot if you're trying to impress someone and enjoy lovely Cole Valley. I'm visiting home in a few weeks and planning on stopping in. I love that they offer their employees a decent living wage and health insurance.
author: Alisa V.

description: OMG I love this place.  I thought the food was absolutely delicious, and the service was fabulous.  Will definitely go back.
author: Linda R.

description: According to their website, 'In 2015 Zazie was one of the first SF restaurants to spearhead a "Tip Free" business model, where all menu prices include a living wage, profit sharing, and full benefits for all of our hard working employees.' Along with delicious food, they pay their workers a living wage . As the cost of living rises in SF - seemingly on the daily - I hope that other restaurants follow suit. Thank you Zazie for thinking of the working class people.
author: John N.

description: Tried this place out for brunch because of a friend's recommendation. I was thinking either the Florentine or the gingerbread pancakes. I was craving for eggs though so I had the Florentine. It was pretty packed at the cafe but I liked the charm it had, and the service was pretty good. The Florentine was sooo good. I'm definitely coming back here! It's a little on the pricey side but it's totally worth the trip. It was exactly what I needed to start my day.
author: Andie H.

description: We ordered the French toast with melt walnut and the salmon egg benedit. The most surprising thing about the egg is the grilled garlic. It was the best garlic i have ever tried.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Hello Bay Area,

We meet again.

What could have been a better day to be in the city on the day with one of the most perfect weather that San Francisco can offer? A little windy, but loaded with sunshine. And what could be even a better day to meet friends and enjoy delicious brunch than to do those things at Zazie?

We arrived a little later than we planned, yes I blamed weekend 101-N traffic. Also, parking was a bit of a challenge within 2 blocks of the restaurant, so we had to go hunt around for a while until we successfully and legitimately steal one guy's spot. Sorry, his loss since he was not fast enough. The wait was about 20 minutes, which was not that crazy. Also, if you wish to dine in the patio, expect to wait approximately triple the time you wait for the table inside. Service was excellent, friendly, and attentive.

Everything on the menu sounds amazing, egg dishes, pancakes, french toast, sandwiches, even their brunch cocktails. My eyes are always bigger than my stomach, and I really wanted to order everything since they offer almost everything in three sizes: small, medium, and large. A plus point for that! However, since there were four of us, we ended up ordering different dishes and were still able to try each of everyone's. We had the butternut squash soup, poached eggs, omelette, scrambled eggs. Plating was simple but flavors were spot on.

Yummy in my tummy.
Til we meet again, Zazie
Best regards,
Chau
author: Chau V.

description: Meh. I like the principles of treating their employees well and the menu looks good but our dining experience was lacking. Went for breakfast on a Monday morning. Service was inattentive at best. After he took our order our server never stopped by again. Someone else delivered our food; no one ever checked in. We had to literally get up and chase someone down both to get a refill on coffee and get our check. Ordered the Tahiti French Toast which sounded better on the menu than it tasted and it arrived cold. My partner's meal was at least warm but nothing special in terms of taste.
author: Brian A.

description:
I heard about this place due to the buzz over their "no tip" policy.  Their menu states that they provide a living wage for their employees.

Because of this, I am a big fan of this restaurant.  Thank you!
author: Snow ..

description:
How can I not rate Zazie a five star place?  It is a neighborhood restaurant with friendly staff that you come to know personally.
