The back is outside and is wonderful for those sunny (albeit rare) mornings to have brunch on.  Every weekend the line is long and the seating system is based on a pencil and paper sign up sheet. Come early, put your names down and you will not regret the visit.  

While I love my brunching, I would also recommend this place for dinner.  It makes some great dishes and the setting is intimate.
author: Dan C.

description:
Yum Yum and more Yum!
Their breakfasts and brunches are real comfort food. I especially like their egg Benedict florentine which comes with spinach and mushrooms. It's a healthier version of the egg Benedict.  But I can never pass their pancakes... they are So delicious!! Especially the miracle ones! 
Be prepared for a long wait. This seems to be the theme in San Francisco. That's why I don't go there that often. 

Their dinner menu is pretty good as well and you can make reservations which is a relief. It's a sweet place to celebrate birthdays and anniversaries.
author: Schisandra S.

description: I had only been here for brunch and we decided to try out their dinner and was blown away by great service and great food!   I love the no-tip concept, but I'd almost still leave the customer an opportunity to leave a larger tip if we choose to.   I must admit it is nice to see a final bill when I get the tab.   Oh..  and the food was amazing as well.  Loved the mussels, the crispy duck was delicious.  I got the pork chop and it was super tender.  Loved it all!   And they were super accommodating to Emma and I saw a lot of families there with kids.
author: Edgar C.

description: Zazie epitomizes the classic San Francisco brunch experience of yesteryear; a menu full of delicious breakfast fare in a quiet and pleasant local business neighborhood, a few jaunts away from the main SF thoroughfares. The French inspired dishes are genuinely good. Have never been disappointed with a meal there. Zazie gets busy around the usual brunch time, but is worth the wait.
author: Tao G.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast places in the City.  Everything on the menu is incredible.  Just be ready to wait for a table.  

The French Toast Tahiti with caramelized bananas and walnuts are incredible.  The caramelized bananas really kick the dish up a few notches.  The Croque Monsieur is also super-yum.  The scrambled eggs Fontainbleau with portobello, shiitake, and porcini mushrooms is probably my favorite omelette.

Intimate dining, friendly staff, and out of this world food are some of the reasons to give this place a try.
author: Funk G.

description:
BREAKFAST! Poached Eggs. Challah French Toast. Coffee. Mimosas. MARIO! 
Haven't had breakfast there yet? GO! It's a must to try AT LEAST once. Zazie will have you keep coming back! :-)
author: Jen B.

description: Wow. Just wow. Best breakfast I've had in a very long time. Great service and fair prices. Love it.
author: Dror M.

description:
Not exactly sure why there was a long line, but Zazie definitely wasnt worth the one hour plus wait. 

The good thing was that it was around other cafe shops that you can hang out at while waiting, but that is also a con, because most likely, you are hungry and tempted to order more than just a latte, and will not be as hungry for the real breakfast/brunch.

Ordered: Gingerbread pancake, Tahiti french toast, mango mimosa, and Poached Eggs La Mer. 

The Gingerbread pancakes were light in flavor and didnt have too much of that gingerbread flavor I was expecting. I feel like even a normal gingerbread or ginger snap has more ginger flavor than this pancake did. The good thing though was that, it was not too sweet, so when paired with the maple sauce, the sweetness level is just right. I personally didnt feel as if the pear went too well with the dish though. I wasn't exactly sure why it was there.

The Tahiti french toaste was the opposite of the gingerbread pancakes because it was way too sweet, or at least a lot more than the sweetness I was expecting. It was more like a dessert than it was breakfast, and I didn't like that heavy factor about it. I would need to order a tall glass of milk or black coffee in order to gobble down this entire plate.

The Mango mimosa was a great alternative to your normal orange juice. I do wish that the mango juice was fresh though instead of tasting as if it was poured out of a minute maid carton.

At last, the La Mer was delicious and probably the most delicious menu item out of the three ordered. Not too heavy, the avocado paired well with the eggs and the crab and made a yummy eggs benedict. The portion was just right, with two english muffins and the option of salad of home frys on the side. 

Overall, I would say the breakfast at Zazie was decent, but was it spectacular? No. Memorable? Probably not either. If there wasn't a wait, I may consider coming back, but most likely, this won't be happening.
author: Luby H.

description:
The wait wasn't too bad because we stalked and hovered over some outside diners/tables - those are first come first serve. 

The other company I was with LOVED their food (all and different Benedicts as well as mimosas. On the other hand, I was not feeling like something heavy, so I just ordered the eggs and meat breakfast platter. The chicken sausage was just okay, it had a weird tang and my poached eggs were in a soup cup and a little watery - I probably should've kept to the standard french toast or Benedict's. I did LOVE the house made hot sauce, mmmmmm
author: Grace Y.

description:
Service sucks. Cold soup. Dirty table. Major attitude just to get it cleaned off. Waiter never checked on us. Ordered tea which came with a dirty cup. 
I originally asked to sit at a certain table. Waiter refused then sat two pretty girls at it. 
Been coming here since it opened. I will NEVER come back.
author: Ruby D.

description:
My 1-star is NOT based on the food. The food is pretty good. This rating is based solely off of their shady credit charge practice I experienced and their completely bad customer service (or lack thereof) given by management. If I could give negative stars, I'd give as many as possible.

Went here for brunch with a friend the Sunday morning of Bay to Breakers. We paid our bill using my friend's Amex card and left cash tip. Couple days later, she checks her account and sees that she was charged an additional $8.07 by Zazie. This was a cleared charge, it was NOT pending. I call Zazie and speak with a female "manager" who answered the phone. I tell her my concern of being charged an additional amount than what was signed for. This woman, who I failed to get the name of, tells me "Oh, sometimes credit card companies place a hold on 20% of the amount in case there's no tip left." I've never in my life heard that before, but okay, whatever. Woman proceeds to get the last 4 digits of the card used and our time and date of the transaction. She says she'll look it up and call me back in half an hour. I call my friend and tell her what I was told by Zazie and tell her to call Amex. Amex tells her that they never place a hold or charge anything additional to what was signed for. Of course, I already knew that.

I wait an hour before calling back and speak to the same woman I spoke to earlier. This woman has the nerve to give me hella attitude and say to me, "I'm busy right now. Are you really concerned about $8? I'll check later for your $8." I was livid. 

My friend ended up getting refunded the extra amount she was charged, but it's not about the $8 itself. It's about the practice of the employees there, and of this manager, to not see anything wrong with adding their own tip on top of what was already left in cash. And as a manager, a complaint of this sort should be taken seriously and a customer should be given a little more respect.

So, if you pay by card, make sure to check your charge amount days later to make sure you were charged only the amount you signed for.
author: irene f.

description:
Annoyingly, the wait is worth it.  

I live in the neighborhood, so I never come here for brunch on the weekends, because the wait is extensive.  I finally came here for breakfast, on a Monday, and it really was delish. This place is also fantastic for dinner too, so here's a combo of reviews for both, that are well overdue and deserved.

- Mexico Omelet: The chorizo was tasty,and seasoned well, served up with the most delish home fries. I know it's just home fries, but for real, these are the most delish home fries
- Pancakes; Fluffy, light and memorable.
- Mussels: My fav, well seasoned and a nice earthy broth to it. 
- Burger: Meaty and flavorful.  Yes. It's a burger, but it is just a tad bit fancy, so you feel like it's all good in the hood when you eat it. 

All in all. This place is great. Service is attentive, and they are as fast as they can be.  Brunch line is long, so definitely worth it to go during the week. Adorable patio seating in the rear, but also a nice set of tables on the sidewalk to enjoy.
author: Natalie G.

description: Not someplace to go if you're in a hurry, but the food is worth it and they won't rush you once you're seated.  2 friends and I waited an hour, but then enjoyed a very leisurely brunch.  The home fries are to die for with whole cloves of roasted garlic in them. The poached egg in my Benedict was cooked perfectly.  I would come back in a heartbeat.
author: Sheri W.

description:
I keep coming back to this place because why not? THE FOOD IS AMAZING! 

The wait can be a little rough and the parking sucks (I always ride the muni here) but it's all worth it when you sit down and enjoy your food. 
I love their coffee and the orange juice! 
The French toast is DELICIOUS!!! 

Try to sit in the patio area on a nice day. It's really beautiful and relaxing. 

Will be back. Multiple times.
author: Mariam L.

description: Great outside patio. Had mimosas and eggs Benedict. Tasted my mom's scrambled eggs and they were incredible. A fantastic brunch.
author: Lindsay K.

description: Tons of Eggs Benedict options. Great service. Worth the wait. Grab a seat outside!
author: Jonas C.

description:
We went to Zazie twice this week for breakfast. First time with my husband was great. Good service, good food, good table. The second time we came with our daughters. Out table was near the entrance and the window. Seems we were a bit forgotten by the staff. 

My recommendation is definitely to go during the week and not with a large party.
author: Joanna B.

description:
All I have to say is, don't believe the hype!

I came here because of the 2000+ reviews. Was it worth it? I thought that this place was just alright. I've eaten a lot of breakfast at many different popular breakfast spots--I don't think Zazie ranks among the best. We had the Poached Eggs Albert, Poached Eggs Florentine, and the pancake sampler thing. I was thinking about getting the crab poached eggs (La Mer), but I ended up going with the bacon one (Albert). I didn't really taste the freshness I expect from Eggs Benedict and I don't think they were put together well. In other words, I couldn't cut them neatly--they would fall apart as the knife sliced through. Maybe it's because I came first thing in the morning and they were using old ingredients? Who knows. I thought if other popular breakfast spots in SF like Mama's were better. I think I'd rather go to Mama's.

Maybe if there was no hype to this place, I'd give it 3-4 stars. But since I'm going off some high expectations, to me this place should get 2 stars for not meeting that high bar. Bottom line, I wouldn't wait more than 10 minutes for a table here. The hype and taste isn't worth it.
author: Marlon T.

description:
SUCH an AWESOME brunch place! 

If you ever get the chance to come to Zazie on a nice sunny day, be sure to ask to be seated on the patio. After spending 2 months in the cold snowy mid-west, coming to Zazie for brunch was definitely a nice reminder of how nice the Bay Area can be, in terms of weather and (most importantly) FOOD. 

I loved the fact that you can choose to order the number of eggs to pair with your eggs benedict. Be sure to get the tahiti french toast.

I also liked that you can choose different favors of mimosas..like MANGO. yumyumyum :) 

Don't be surprised if you see that there's a line when you come to this place. You can always walk to the Integrative med store right next door to pass by some time!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Nope. 1+ hour wait and $50 for cold eggs, lukewarm toast and zero refills on coffee. Do better, Zazie.
author: Ashley E.

description: Zuni has ruined eggs benedict for me. Their eggs benedict is so good, that I cannot eat it anywhere else because I always compare it to Zuni's. The Albert is probably my favorite. The flavors are fantastic. I love the salty bacon with the salsa and white cheddar. La mer would probably be my favorite, if it wasn't for the fact that the crabs freshness is a bit inconsistent. I've had it at times and loved it and also had it when it's been a bit fishy. If they ever have a special during fall or winter, get it. Pumpkin pancakes are to die for. I have also had their eggnog french toast during Christmas time and yum. I'm sure the other sweet brunch items are great, I just am a savory person and always go for eggs. I have had dinner once, and it was delicious as well. But be prepared to wait! The wait is insane.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Came here last Monday for dinner for my friend's birthday.  The customer service was excellent and the best I've seen in a long time.  The entire staff was so nice and friendly - from the host, to the bus boys, to the waitress - everybody was really pleasant to deal with.  Even the other diners were nice and friendly.  Since we had our two little dogs with us, we got a table in the back patio.  Monday nights are doggie nights, so practically every table in the back had a doggie diner.  It was a warm night, so I think the heat lamps could be on a low setting.  After a while, it was mighty toasty and we heard other people comment how warm their faces were.

The food was good.  We had a charcuterie plate, lamb tagine, Alaskan Coho salmon, and cheesecake.  I would say the atmosphere and experience is what would bring me back.  Would definitely want to try breakfast or brunch here.

One disappointing thing:  I had specified in my reservation that this dinner was for my friend's birthday.  Whenever I have mentioned a special occasion in the past, the restaurant has brought out something special - candle on your dessert or something nice.  I know they do this here because they celebrated an anniversary on our right and another birthday to our left.  So it was kind of disappointing that they didn't follow through with that for our table.  Overall, my friend still had a good time and so did the doggies.
author: Cianne M.

description: For brunch: best to get there early and try to get in for the first seating, otherwise you're looking at a 30-90 minute wait, minimum. But it's delicious and their french toast is amazing! I'm not a fan of egg bennie's, but my friends who eat em said theirs are delish.
author: Maggie F.

description:
A buddy and i tried to go grab a bite at zazie on sunday @230pm, we put our name on the waiting list, and a table became available just when it was our turn. The very professional host seated a single person on the 2 top we were waiting for. Bravo. When i mentioned to him that we have arrived before her, he said that is ok. Great customer service. Well done. We left right away and didn' even want to try this restaurant! The first impression is always the most important and it was so bad we will definitely not return. 
This comment is written by someone who works in the same industry.
author: Oliver K.

description:
We have found the food and staff to be very good. They offer a very familiar eating experience to what we have had In Paris. I would always encourage pan roasted chicken after tasting it In numerous French restaurants.

The outdoor seating in back is very nice.
author: Robert B.

description: Absolutely delicious!!!! The back patio is very nice! The service incredible thanks Mario and all the crew for a lovely breakfast!!!
author: G B.

description: The location and ambiance are good. Food portion is small and it is pricey for this portion. Tastes is okay but not impressive. Be prepared to have a long wait for food because service is a bit slow.
author: Cof Y.

description:
Overhyped! I can get better breakfast in the city. 

We had Le mar and French toast (to go, since there was at least an hour long wait). The la mar lacked flavor, hollandaise could have been better. The French toast was nice not out of the world and definitely not worth the wait.

Good thing is we had this breakfast in golden gate park overlooking stow lake!
author: Pepper T.

description: The food is good and the staff is friendly. It is always a very long wait on the weekends however. It has a nice back yard patio but it's very cramped. Great for brunch if you have time to kill and wait.
author: Cody H.

description:
Highly recommend this place. The wait time of 55 mins was worth it for a Saturday peak time brunch hour. The best part about this place was that I was able to pick whether I wanted 1 or 2 or 3 pieces of pancakes, french toasts etc. They have a few tables for outside seating too. 

Must try items are:

1. Sunshine - Mango mimosa
2. Special mimosa that had lavender and mint
3. Miracle pancake - this has poppy seeds and the lemon butter syrup at the top is just mind blowing. I have never tried anything quite like this. They are extremely fluffy pancakes. We got our food at 1 pm and they mentioned to us afterwards that we got the second to the last pancake for the day. So they DO run out. Try them while you can. 
4. French Toast Tahiti - 1 piece is enough if you are trying out other items too. This was delicious. The combination of caramelized bananas and walnuts was yummy. 
5. New York Scrambled Eggs
6. Home Fries - These are some of the best potatoes I have ever had. They are a bit oily but extremely delicious. Big chunks with grilled whole garlic.
author: Hiral P.

description:
Ratings: 4 Stars

Wait: got here around 8:50AM for a Sunday seating (opens at 9AM). Got seated on the  first round of seating :) 

Food: Ordered Divorcee Eggs Benedict and 2 pieces of the Tahiti French Toast. The Eggs Benedict were perfect and the yolk oozed out..amazing. Ask for extra garlic with the home fries if you like garlic! 

Service: quick and friendly. tip is already included in their price so they recommend that you don't tip on top of the total cost. 

Ambience: casual, friendly, and homie. 

Overall: will definitely come again early to ensure short waits!
author: Bee H.

description:
My new favorite brunch place! It sure beats Mama's wait time! I came on a Weekday around 11:30am and there was no wait for the inside! There always seem to be a wait for the patio so I would suggest coming here early if you want that patio experience. 

They have a decent variety of brunch items to choose from. What I love most about this place is their option of one, two, or three option for your item! For example, you get to choose one pancake, two pancakes, or three pancakes! Since I tend to get super full from their set amount of item per plate at other brunch places. This is perfect! 

My friends and I tried the Gingerbread Pancake and the French Toast Tahiti. I ordered one Gingerbread Pancake while my friends ordered three French Toast Tahiti to share. Their portions are huge, by the way! One was more than enough for me! Both were super yummy! Don't forget to spread the lemon and eat the pears with the pancake! The French Toast Tahiti was amazing as well! The banana and walnut together was the perfect combination with the french toast! I never imagined that a simple combination can be that good. I really want to try the poached eggs next time! Too bad this place is so far compared to Mama's or else I would come back more often. 

It's located in a fantastic location near the Haight. Great place to bring your non-San Franciscan friends if they ever come to visit so they can stop by Haight to explore before/afterwards! They are open for breakfast, lunch, and dinner! This place definitely made it to the top of my list for brunch places in San Francisco.

P.S. They do charge $1.25/person for some health benefits for their workers. And they tax that too! (Eh..)
author: Shanna C.

description:
This is a charming French bistro with good food, friendly staff and delightful atmosphere (indoor and outdoor seating)!  It was featured on food network. Great.

FOOD: Florentine poached eggs (with spinach and mushrooms on toasted English muffins and a side of cubed fries) were divine. I heard any poached egg  dishes are fab. Tahiti French toasts (stuffed with mashed banana, caramel, chopped walnuts and other dreamys) were delicious! My friend and I got two eggs and two toasts - thought that was a perfect portion for two people.

SERVICE: Everyone who works here seemed happy. My server was attentive and friendly.

ATMOSPHERE: this is equally as important to me as the food. Indoor seemed congested for me even though the interior is cute. It's a small restaurant. Any tables on the patio are nice.  

A few tips for you:
- Go early to avoid a long wait
- Sit outside on the back patio on a sunny day
- Avoid taking a car (limited street parking)
author: Eunice M.

description: Well alot of people love this place and recommend this place as best breakfast in San Fran. I ordered a meal that wasnt very large but i'll admit was very good. Maybe im too cheap but 15-16 dollars for a small quality breakfast? I can get 3 plates of breakfast food where im from for that price.
author: Brian K.

description:
Zazie is a San Francisco classic, with lines out the door for their famous brunch. Recently however the restaurant moved towards a no tipping policy - and raised the prices so servers make a "living wage." While admirable in concept the policy seems to do the opposite - servers make get a guaranteed wage but their service is so below par it ruins dining experience.  

Our server paid zero attention to which patrons arrived first, took orders in a random order, and overall was inattentive.  Our food was served cold and late.  Our server never once asked us if everything was ok (if so we would have told him it wasn't).

All in all I'm usually a fan of Zazie's but based on this experience dining here I would be hard pressed to give it another shot at $25/head for brunch and a beverage, served cold, and horrible service.

Zazie's management should bring back tipping; it would do everyone wonders.
author: Tiffany L.

description: If you love exceptionally prepared duck and an even better duck cassoulet, then Zazie is your place.  I've been here twice with my wife and friends and the service and quality are top notch. During our most recent my sister in law ordered the Coq Au Vin which had a nice, rich smokey flavor.  My wife and I ordered the duck on a bed of sweet potatoe mash with spinach.  My brother in law ordered the pork tenderloin.  For a starter we enjoyed a rustic duck pate with some very tasty accompaniments. They allowed us to bring a bottle of Ridge Montabello wine which topped off the experience. I highly recommend this establishment.  Small, quaint, and a perfect contrast to the unique cuisine you can expect to find in the city.
author: Norberto D.

description:
I chose this place based on yelp reviews for brunch. Sunday 10:30am, def 1.5 pages of names ahead of us but wait time was approx 45 min - not too bad at all - the line moves very quickly and they'll serve some drinks outside too. 
We had poached eggs Florentine and another dish with their home fries which were delicious. 
No gluten free bread which was a pity but otherwise, quite tasty!
author: Van-Anh N.

description: Sure, the breakfast was great (ordered the divorcee Benedict), but the attitude of the server killed the whole experience for us. Why come back here rather than go tow place with happier workers. This happened: Friend: 'does blah blah Benedict have avocados in it?' Server: 'it has whatever the menu says it has' Friend: 'may I then substitute mushrooms w avocados?' Server: 'no' Friend: 'may I then add it on?' Server: 'yes, I would charge you extra for that' Friend: 'that's completely fine'.   (How about after the first question he responded 'no but we can add it on for a fee if you'd like', huh?).... Minutes later me: 'may I have some more coffee?' Server with a look in his face saying don't tell me how to do my job 'I was already bringing you some'.   Seriously??? seriously....
author: Tina B.

description:
I'm trying to decide what placed 1st, the food or service....F' it  both place 1st! I've been waiting a while to try this spot and on the happy occasion of celebrating not one but three graduations we could not have picked a better place.

We had the ginger pancakes, bread-pudding pancakes, Tahitian french toast, several varieties of benedicts-with cranberry mimosas on the back patio...wow!  It was all WOW, WOW delicious.  What was great is that the place was full but we never felt over looked nor neglected. 

Before we'd even finished our meal we were already making plans to come back-now that says a lot!
author: D Marie M.

description:
Dungeness crab benedict (w/ 2 eggs): Good, but could be better! (Rating: 4/5)
Food Presentation: Average and nothing special (Rating: 3/5)
Cost: $24 (including tip + tax)
author: Jenny W.

description:
So this place didn't blow my mind in the way that one would expect with such rave reviews.  I thought about giving it 3 stars, but the food was good and the service was perfectly good. 

We came in on New Years and only waited 45 minutes, which was extremely reasonable considering that pretty much everywhere else in the neighborhood/city was closed. Everyone in my party had some version of poached eggs and they were great.  The potatoes were a little bland, they could use some seasoning. 

I think next time I might have to get some version of French toast or pancakes - they looked really incentive and delicious.  I think the sweeter dishes are what everyone is losing their mind over.
author: Alison H.

description: The Eggs Benedict here are absolutely fire! Definitely will be returning to try out more items from the menu. Well worth the wait, which can sometimes be annoying but you gotta stay strong.
author: Roberto V.

description:
After more than an hour waiting, We thought the food would be out of this world. Disappointed! We ordered the Tahiti French toast and the Monaco, French toast was small for $16/ 2 pieces, Monaco was bland for $20!! Very uninspiring. Too much hype. 
3 stars for food minus 1 star for the unreasonable long wait
author: Khoa V.

description: The food and everything is just wonderful here. I always bring my friends to Zazie for brunch, and there was never a disappointment or complain other then the super long wait haha. But i can say the food is so good that it deserves the wait.
author: Joyce H.

description: Super nice service. Fresh mimosas, very good pancakes with lemon curd and good eggs florentine!
author: Delphine L.

description:
Came here for dinner by recommendation for a friend. Romantic setting and good date spot. I had the pork chops (would order again) and my friend had the steak which was super tasty. Overall, favorite food was the french onion soup.

Corkage is $15
author: Elliot H.

description: This update is for their brunch! Also that they are one of the few establishments that give their employees full benefits and living wages! Yes I definitely support you Zazie!! Okay now for my update haha. The miracle pancakes lemon ricotta to be specific were mind blowing. The server said they have a bread pudding pancake that's even better!!! Ugh I can't wait to come back for that haha. The second best thing I've eaten here is the coffee cake! Hands down it is one of the best!!! It's moist, fluffy and dusted with just the right amount of powder sugar. The French toast Tahiti is pretty good as well. To be honest you can't even go wrong with most of the brunch options here lol. The only downside of Zazie is the wait but like all places worth eating at in SF there will always be a queue. Ohh almost forgot to mention, they have outside seating in their patio in the back of restaurant with heaters. It's a pretty awesome to sit back there with a glass of mimosa while waiting for those orgasmic pancakes!! Haha that's all folks until next time :)
author: Gina H.

description:
I came here for a business DINNER and was a bit nervous that Zazie is labelled as a breakfast / French restaurant. Were they going to serve pancakes for dinner? Do not be fooled, the dinner menu is AMAZING.

Mediterranean roasted vegetable plate - arguably one of my favorites tonight. I am a carnivore and found the eggplant to be divine - perfectly tender and flavorful. The asparagus, potatoes, and tomatoes also played strong supporting roles.

Coq au vin - if you like chicken, this is one to order. I had no idea that chicken could taste this good! The chicken was literally fall off the bone tender. 

Grilled Niman ranch hanger steak - a must have for steak lovers. Appropriately crispy coat with a warm nearly rare center. The cream sauce was a delightful compliment without taking away from the meaty steak flavor.

Rhubarb crumble with gelato - a fun, tart, sweet, somewhat light dessert that's almost whimsical.

Baked chocolat chaud - imagine s'mores meets French onion soup. It's the insides of a s'more baked in a ceramic dish with a marshmallow protective layer on top. It doesn't stand a chance once you're armed with a spoon.
author: Phong D.

description: The price is really high, but tips are included in the price.  The benedicts are really good, the best I had in San Francisco.  The French toasts are good.  Potato wedges are very nice; crispy outside and crumbles inside.  Access to the toilet is a bit tight.  While waiting for the toilet, waiters will make you feel like you don't belong there.  Be careful not to trip one of them or have dishes smash into your body or slammed in the face by the door.
author: Byron L.

description: Scored brunch here without any wait, TGIF. I ordered the french toast Tahiti (Challah toast w/ caramelized bananas and walnuts) for the kids and I got the Monaco (poached egg with with prosciutto and tomato). I thought the french toast was well executed. I personally would not order three slice on my own because it's sweet and it really doesn't need the maple syrup. Not sure why they just don't call the poached egg dishes eggs benedict. Anyways, I enjoyed my dish especially the potatoes. It may be a deal breaker for most but there's a lot of roasted garlics with the potatoes. I like breaking through the garlic peel and pop them in my mouth. They are soft enough that I would smear it on my potatoes and eggs benedict. Overall, this is definitely a top-notch brunch spot in the City.
author: Kien M.

description: French toast bliss. Of course I only know this place due to my love of Finnegains Wake being next door.
author: Rain D.

description: Love the patio out back. Always have great service and great food! Definitely happy I was lucky enough to stumble across this place and it's been my go-to brunch destination ever since!
author: Laurel H.

description:
I would say an easy five because of their breakfast. I tried their poached egged and it was really good . They open late though (like 9am on Sundays ) or weekdays at 8, doesn't make since to me.
Service and place was good too ( but honesty service shouldn't get more than 4) but overall I give them 4.5 , but since we can't have .5,  I would go with 5.
author: Mr B.

description:
The last time I ate here was a few years ago for dinner. I don't exactly remember what I had, but wasn't too thrilled. 
I saw my companions' dishes and wasn't too satisfied. 

My gingerbread pancakes were too doughy and bland. And the eggs dish looked average, something that could be made at home. The French toast seemed alright, and the salmon sandwich was just a piece of toast, a slice of salmon and undressed greens. 

Maybe I just am not aware of the hubub of this place, but Zazie is not something I'd wait in line for.
author: Bahar A.

description:
One bite of the poached eggs, and I was hooked! I'm a fan of eggs, poached in particular, so I know a good one when I see one! I got the Albert poached eggs with a side salad, and I was definitely pleased. 

For $13, The Albert consisted of 2 poached eggs (Which you can change to 1 egg for $10 or 3 eggs for $16), crispy bacon, homemade salsa fresca, and white cheddar on an english muffin with a generous amount of lemon hollandaise sauce on top. I'm drooling just thinking about it! 

Next time, I would like to try the crème brûlée oatmeal and the gingerbread pancakes! YUMMERZZZ. Although this place is a little small and cramped, it is without a doubt a gem in SF. Yay! I'm a fan, and I can't wait to come back and to bring more friends with me!
author: Christine L.

description:
I recently moved nearby this place and have been here about five times or so. I used to love it and would definitely have thought of myself as a potential regular for the amazing ambience and food. Hands down, amazing. 

But I was very put off by an experience I had today with the staff. My friend and I ordered two different meals -- one (his) was a chicken dish and mine was the pasta (I'm terrible with names). Because I'm vegetarian, I never order meat. You know, because of the whole not-eating-meat thing. After we wait for about thirty minutes, the waitress comes out with two dishes -- both the same chicken dish.

That's fine, mistakes happen. The waitress apologizes and offers a glass of wine on the house. I don't drink, so I suggested to her that perhaps I could just choose an appetizer instead. Wasn't forceful at all and was sure to use a kind tone with her because I know being in the service industry can be pretty thankless. I'm not one to make a scene over small mistakes and just thought that, because I was being offered something I couldn't consume, I'd offer an alternative. She obliges and lets me pick an item off the menu. I select the cheese dish. Everything is great, well on our way to a five-star review.

The food comes out, the cheese dish comes out about twenty minutes later. As my friend and I begin enjoying the cheese, a manager pulls out a seat next to us and sits down. He asks about our experience and says he heard we had a bad experience from the staff. I tell him what happened and said everything was fine, thanked him for the cheese dish.

He gives me a long, intense (okay, pretty angry) stare. After pausing for a few seconds, he tells me that we have a problem. He acknowledges that, while the restaurant can compensate for a mistake through a drink on the house, they cannot do so with an appetizer -- specifically, he notes, the cheese dish. He suggests we are at an impasse. We were blindsided. 

The manager then tells us that we could expense a dessert if we'd like. Ummm... what? We should pay for our own make-good but take a free dessert? My friend and I awkwardly look at each other and tell him we're not really hungry for dessert. He stumbles and says "Well we can't make-good with the cheese plate. The best we can do is... maybe cover the pasta dish you ordered... or, cover part of the dish."

Okay! Music to my ears! You don't want to cover the appetizer, but you're happy covering the more expensive menu item we ordered? Fine by me! Not sure how the math makes sense there or why I'd opt for having part of my meal covered when he just told me they would pay for all of it, but I quickly jump on his offer. Of course, judging from his response and the way he backtracked by offering to pay part of it, I could tell he was very upset with my choice. But then... why offer me that choice?

He sits back and gives me another threatening stare before slowly getting up. Which, I would COMPLETELY understand had I been demanding, caused a scene, showed to have been remotely upset or threatening to write a terrible review. I did no such thing -- I merely offered an alternative to the waitress' offer on a make-good through a menu item I cannot consume. Had she told me she couldn't honor it or just offered me a dessert to begin with, I would have been ecstatic. I was ecstatic to get a cheese plate. I love cheese. Whatever. 

The waitress certainly took her time getting her bill for us and the manager would routinely walk by our table and shoot us dirty looks. They ended up covering the cost of the pasta dish, but gave us a random "convenience fee" of $2.50 for our meal. Talk about passive aggressive. 

We definitely felt uncomfortable, and were made to feel uncomfortable because of how the staff handled a mistake that they made. I realize that it's hard to maintain a business, especially a restaurant in SF. But treating your customers well, or at least not overpromising and underdelivering and then making your customers uncomfortable because of how they went along with what you told them is probably not the best way to maintain customer loyalty. Or get people to recommend you. Or run a business. 

Would give them five stars were it not for this experience -- keeping it at two because I think quality and character are best shown not when everything is going smoothly but when things don't go well. These guys definitely don't know how to handle service when they mess up. Would've given them the lowest possible rating though had this been my first experience at Zazie. So, settling at two. 

We ended up leaving a 25% tip because I left feeling guilty (or intimidated... not sure yet) for accepting any generosity at all from them.
author: Youssif A.

description:
I love Zazie! There's really no point in singing praise for a breakfast place that is already highly loved, but let me just point out why Zazie stands out among (what I think are many over-hyped) breakfast places in SF.

THE GREAT:

--- Zazie has amazing special / seasonal pancakes & french toast
--- The above pancakes & french toast can be ordered with ONE slice only! **
--- Same thing with their egg dishes, you can get 1, 2, or 3 eggs!
--- Their special menu, my favorite is the Eggs En Fonte 
--- Very lovely decor inside. Outside patio in the back is nice too.
--- Their lattes! Goes really well with the pancakes & french toast & everything else.


THE OK:

--- Their regular drip coffee. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great.

TO AVOID:

--- Coming here on weekends. You are an idiot for waiting in line for 1 hour. Come on weekdays and there is no wait. Can't do that? Fine, bring a book or chatting friends then.


** This is super important to me. I never order pancakes or french toast for breakfast because it is UNHEALTHY to just eat sugar & carbs for breakfast. And I never want that much pancakes anyway. I always want my breakfast to be mostly proteins & veggies. By allowing just 1 slice order, I can indulge myself without feeling grossed out by massive amounts of sugar!!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Brunch with my visiting mom and sister here was perfect! Mom had the skillet eggs over easy with polenta and the flavor was outstanding! Both her eggs and mine were cooked perfectly. My Dungeness crab Benedict was very good [to my great surprise, in all honesty], though the flavor was underwhelming in comparison to my mom's Benedict. All three of us thoroughly enjoyed the potatoes and the salads. Sister had the chicken sandwich and her eyes rolled back with the first bite. The place is adorable, our waitress was excellent, and the business model is something most of us hippie locals love to support. Will absolutely recommend to all of my future visitors.
author: Phylicia G.

description:
Had a wonderful Sunday brunch. 8 people including 2 small children . Waitstaff was wonderful - efficient and eager to please.
Everybody had a variety of different items and everything hit the mark. I'll speak to things other reviewers may have passed over. Coffee fresh and not burnt. Cappuccino was served in a small bowl and was delicious. Bloody Mary's were a little spicy but hit the spot and expresso 's were great.
author: Ralph C.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for an early Valentine's dinner and we were not disappointed! The bread rolls were soft and delicious. We shared the cheese plate, and even though the French cheese names went over our head, we enjoyed it none the less. Our waiter was attentive and very funny. For main courses I had the polenta cakes, which were perfect. I'm not crazy about wilted greens, but every other part of the dish was incredible. My boyfriend had the beef bourguignon and said the meat was very soft and tender. For dessert we shared the baked hot chocolate which was decadent but tasted like brownie batter. Zazie was the perfect choice and we'll be back again!
author: Larissa S.

description:
We came here on a whim based on yelp reviews on a cold summer Saturday morning. There isn't a wait if you are in by 8:30 am but we left shortly before 10am and there was a list and a group of people waiting outside the restaurant.

The restaurant itself is pretty small but walking through the kitchen area is a patio area with several table and stand heaters to beat the foggy cold. 

I am not a fan of walking through an area where employees are working. I feel as though it disrupts work and takes away from the overall experience. This isn't Benihana folks. 

For the food, I ordered a side of scrambled eggs. The eggs are organic and without hormones. Check. I also ordered a bagel with cream cheese, tomatoes and basil. As I assumed the tomatoes and basil were incorporated the cream cheese I was surprised to note that my toasted plain bagel came out with a rationing of cream cheese, huge slices of tomatoes with sprinkled basil. The bagel also came with an ordinary side salad of mix romaine and dressing. The bagel was not my idea of appetizing but that is my fault for the assumption. 
 
My husband and I decided to get the famous French toast Tahiti. That was a very satisfying brunch item that seems very popular with the brunch crowd. A winner definitely. 

My latte was blah, the customer service was good, the crowd is a mix of family, young professionals and hipsters and the pricing was a little steep for my taste. 

I would give this restaurant a 3.5 overall but I'll be nice and round up to 4 stars
author: Ramla J.

description: So good! I wanted to try somewhere new and out of my neighborhood and heard Zazie was great so I figured we would give it a try. I got the omelet du jour with egg whites which had chicken Apple sausage, roasted pepperS, white cheddar, and avocado with a side salad. It was awesome! I also tried the French toast with banana and walnut and it was also unreal.
author: Jillian C.

description: I went here to catch up with an old friend! We went on a Friday and it was about a 10 minute wait. The waiters were friendly and the service was quick. However, the food was quite expensive! We are college students and if we ate here everyday, we'd be broke af. We couldn't even eat two full eggs because we can't afford it. It was about $25 for three egg monacos and the french toast was aight. The food was fresh, but it was similar to most brunch places. Overall, good experiences but coming again is questionable.
author: Elaze T.

description:
I arrived to see a long line for seating inside, but luckily the outdoor seating was available for first come first serve and my friends and I sat down right away. The server was so friendly and timely despite how incredibly busy they were.

On to food. I ordered the Miracle Pancake which had Meyer Lemon Curd, poppy seeds, strawberries. SO GOOD! 

They made a birthday breakfast so wonderful!
author: Kelsey M.

description:
OVERALL PROS:
- Adorable brunch spot in Cole Valley, high ceilings with giant skylight, tables out front and in the backyard on a deck. There's this spiral black staircase that goes to a small second level landing at the front. I want to buy out this restaurant and just live in this space.. but then I would never taste their delicious food again.
- The estimated 1 hour wait became only 20 minutes for the 2 of us (during brunch rush hour - 11am on a Sunday!).
- Friendly, prompt service. As I was waiting by the kitchen for the restroom, I talked to the chefs as I kept seeing dishes that looked awesome and they were really nice and told me what everything was and what was in it.
- Love love love that you can order just one slice of French toast/ pancake/ egg. It's slightly more pricey but you get to try so much more off the menu without filling yourself to the brim.

OVERALL CONS:
- A little on the pricey side, especially if you order a single toast/ pancake/ egg etc. (we did that and it was $21 before tax & tip). But... kinda worth it.

We ordered.. 

* Monaco Poached Egg (w/ prosciutto & tomatoes provencales) - WOW I had no idea I could love eggs benedict so much! I'm totally a sweet (vs. savory) brunch person, but surprisingly in this meal I liked this dish the most. Crispy, almost burnt English muffin + salty chewy prosciutto + tart squishy tomato = all of your sense are flipping out. 

* French Toast Tahiti (w/ caramelized bananas) - Incredibly soft, chewy, moist. Really great. However (Miss French Toast here - this is so my thing at brunch) it was really lacking that slight crunch on the outside of the bread. And the caramelized bananas had a kind of odd bitter aftertaste - I found myself putting it on the side so it wouldn't ruin the flavor on each bite of French toast.

* Gingerbread Pancakes (w/ lemon curd & roasted pears)- Oh my god the flavor was wonderful! Very strong but it went perfectly with the combination of sweet maple syrup + tart lemon curd + pear. It was super thick and almost cake-like, fluffy yet dense. However (me being picky again) I found it just a tad too dry - I couldn't handle a single bite without dipping the pancake in syrup or the lemon curd to make it moist. I wish I could enjoy the great ginger flavor of the pancake alone.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I came here for the first time for brunch today and it's definitely worth the wait! Also worth the wait cuz you can go to Finnegan's next door and get a Bloody Mary while you wait.

Anyway, I had one poached egg with fresh crab (definitely get roasted potties cuz they add in some roasted garlic!) and I also got one challah French toast (yum!!!). There's probably a bajillion other things I want from their brunch menu! :-)
author: Christina C.

description:
Miracle. Freaking. Pancakes... Amen.

Zazie is a gem of a French bistro in Cole Valley. Perfectly cooked poached eggs, crafty mimosas, and rotating, aptly named "miracle" pancakes highlight Zazie's exceptional brunch options.

If you're heading to Zazie for weekend brunch, expect to arrive and write your name down on their paper wait list. Lines start forming before the restaurant opens on Saturday and Sunday, so just embrace the inevitable wait. You'll be glad you did.

Pro-tip #1: parties of two rotate quickly compared to larger parties.
Pro-tip #2: there's a Peet's a few doors down, so coffee can be easily had as you wait.

The decor is charming and quaint. A harrowing walk through the narrow kitchen walkway gets you to the beautiful back patio, which was recently covered for weatherproofing. You can't go wrong with sitting either inside or outside.

Admittedly, I'm Zazie's captive audience as a CV resident, but never has captivity felt (and tasted) so good.
author: Matt T.

description:
I thought this place was super cute! I was a little bummed that they were out of the Ahi which is what I had literally planned a week in advance to order because the sandwich looked soooo good but c'est la vie! The vegetable scrambled eggs were delicious and so were the potatoes so I'm not TOO upset! Next time I hope they'll have it...TILL THEN!

A bientot Zazie!
author: Brittini S.

description:
French toast Tahiti and the fresh crab benedict are to die for. I love the tip-free policy & the staff is so friendly! 

The line was a two hour wait on Sunday at 10am (prime time) but luckily I live close so I just went home to wait. Worth every second I spent waiting because this place is phenomenal! Best brunch in SF? Maybe.

Also their dinner is amazing- all around a great place!
author: Alex R.

description:
Went here for lunch and got seated relatively fast as it was towards the end of their closing time 2pm. Sat outside on the patio very cute and cozy feeling- but when I saw a ginormous spider on the wall I had to change my seating- I HATE spiders. 

The food was amazing though. Very fresh and delicious. The coffee cake is a MUST- very light with a cream-cheese filling. One thing though is that they brought out the wrong order once and mixed up a credit card.... So I would just pay attention to that. 

Will definitely be back, but probably sit inside.
author: Y R.

description:
For years I've heard that this place is THE BEST. I've read about it in magazines, online lists, etc. and usually there's a line out the door. True story, there have been times I've wanted to go, but my GF thought we weren't dressed nice enough to go to a place like Zazie... 

Finally, we went and it was delicious, yes, but the hype took away the star. The food was good, and so was the atmosphere, but man... I was expecting French Toast by 
Zeus himself, but just got some decent pancakes. :-/
author: Ben Z.

description:
I'm going to have to jump on the Zazie fan bandwagon here - loved experiencing the food. The biggest faux pas of most breakfast places is having one flavor drown out the others (i.e. too syrupy or too eggy or too salty) but this place nailed every combinations down solid. Quick service despite the small but really friendly staff... we were in and out within 45min on a Thursday morning. 

Stuffed ourselves with:
- La Mer Benedict : impressive how the crab goes so well with the standard package, one piece is NOT enough.
- Gingerbread pancake : must buy! Lemon sauce and pear and gingercake was absolutely amazing together, mind blown. Definitely see myself desperately trying to recreate this at home and failing in the near future.
- Tahiti french toast : good balance of crispy toast and banana mix, tasty but would have liked more walnuts. 

Overall, great for trying new things as well as options for the standard breakfasts. Wish I was more local!
author: Katy Q.

description:
Good food, nice waitress but seating host Mario was very rude and invasive.  He came up to our van in front of the restaurant to say dogs are not allowed in the back patio, then later on had a fight with my husband about giving him quarters on the bill for change.  My husband emailed the owner but no response.  

You can get great Breakfast food and Service in other places, try Frjts--we went for the fries but the Breakfast and service was incredible!
author: Jem B.

description: They lied about wait time (told us 1hr when it was truly over 2) and when they made a mistake about our name, took no responsibility for their mistake and asked us to wait another half hour on top of the two hour wait we already stood right by the door for. Not at all worth it.
author: Kevin C.

description:
amazing creative breakfast dishes and great service. the only downside is the incredibly
inedible...
LONG WAIT
author: Vivienne K.

description:
If you haven' been to Zazie, you have not had a true breakfast.  Zazie boasts the best breakfast/brunch in the Haight.  I have tried a range of different dishes, but my favorite still is an "off the menu" order from their old menu, the Eggs Divorce Benedict.  I also absolutely love their cafe mocha.  

The only negative part about eating at Zazie is the wait.  Therefore, you either have to get there right when it opens (which can be a pretty early endeavor), or you have to be ready to wait.  

A pro-tip for going there is that the tables outside are first come first serve.  So, if you see someone departing the outdoor tables, swoop in right away!
author: Alyx F.

description:
You made me believe in breakfast. 

I'm not really a breakfast meal, because breakfast doesn't normally come with french fries. But man was this a good breakfast.  I went with my brother and sister in law for breakfast, it had a line but the time wasn't too bad. I had a new york scrambled egg and added a bagel. It was divine. I'm not kidding, divine. Smoked salmon, scrambled eggs, green onions and cream cheese on an everything bagel was just wonderful.

A very intimate, cute and rustic restaurant. Perfect for a date, perfect for brunch with the girls or perfect to drink a cup of coffee while reading the newspaper on the patio.
author: Shelley D.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday brunch and we had a fantastic time! We communicated with the owner beforehand as we had a large group, and although there was a slight issue seating us all together initially, we were able to all be at one table on the back patio. The mimosas were incredible, and you have the option of adding a scoop of sorbet, which many of us did. If you come with a larger group, I recommend ordering the champagne bottles and pitchers of juice. They knew it was a birthday and brought my friend a giant piece of coffee cake which we were all able to enjoy. The food I ordered was just alright, a little cold by the time it arrived, but still pretty good. Atmosphere is super cute and very betchy. Several Instagram opportunities! Would definitely return.
author: Charlotte C.

description:
Zazie's a great little place. If I had to pick, it would be my second favorite brunch place in San Francisco. The guy who takes care of the line is super nice and efficient and will take care of you. This one time I had friends visiting out of town, and even though we got there past the cut-off he let us in and order! Be prepared to wait around 45 min on a busy day. If you have a day off, they do also brunch daily. 

The service is efficient and knowledgeable. On a warm day you can sit in the outdoor patio upstairs, which is a cozy space with heaters. The overall interior is pretty small but looks like a scene from a French film (adorable). 

I always get their Mexico scramble which comes with delicious salsa. Their potato comes with garlic you can crush for even more flavor.

Although I love savory brunch food, their gingerbread pancakes with bosc pear and lemon curd is to die for; fluffy, gingery, sweet and tart all at once. Don't forget to order their cream cheese coffee cake either, which is a giant piece of soft cake with cream cheese as the frosting in between. It comes out warm and topped with powdered sugar.
author: Kate M.

description: The environment has a very nice old world feel and the personnel were very friendly. However the food is way way overpriced: $28 for eggs Benedict w/A scant 1 tablespoon of crab, maybe one 16th of avocado and an English muffin that wasn't even warm. The so-called famous  potatoes were not quite cooked and the coffee though good with not outstanding enough to warrant the high price tag. Overall just an adequate experience. We won't be going back
author: Ida D.

description:
Great discovery for us! We went there for breakfast and besides the fact that was full on a non-holiday Monday morning, which we didn't understand, it was a great experience. 

We had the "Un, deux, trois" consisting of one pancake (gingerbread and bread pudding in our case), two eggs and three stripes of bacon. Simply delicious!

They give their employees all the benefits, so it's a TIP FREE establishment! Thumbs up to them!
author: Andrés D.

description:
Still a great place for brunch and wait is still insanely long. Be prepared to wait, but worth every bite.

I had the croque madame this time, and I loved it! The gruyere was melted perfectly and wasn't too pungent. The bread was great, nice and fresh. Egg cooked perfectly where I popped it and dipped each bite of the sandwich into it. Yums!

I think I prefer to come here on the weekday, not necessarily because it's not as busy - think again, but there are more options. On the weekday you get the regular brunch menu that you get on the weekends, but you also get the weekday lunch menu. I like options :)
author: Vanessa K.

description:
We ordered The "le Metro" and Bloody Mary cocktails. The Bloody Mary was a nice tomato flavor with a subtle spice was from the horseradish. The le metro was super refreshing. Good for a hot day -- not if your looking for a stiffer drink.

For meals we ordered a greek omelette and the "le Mer" poached eggs with crab.  The poached eggs were cooked perfectly and the dish as a whole was very enjoyable.  I got the hollandaise sauce on the side as it seemed to come with quite a lot for my taste. the omelette was under seasoned and clearly needed salt. 

We also shared an order of the granola with fruit and yogurt. the yogurt was like a greek yogurt and had a grainy texture. The granola was good (had raisins).

We sat on the back patio - it was a very enjoyable environment.

We would eat here again, but the prices are a little high - so probably not until someone came in town or a friend wants to eat here.  There are other french places near by that are more affordable.
author: R M.

description:
Let's start with the pros. There are a lot of them. The food is awesome. We spent forever browsing the menu, because there was just so much that looked delicious. In the end, we got the "Miracle" Pancakes and "Albert" Poached Eggs. They were both very delicious, not foodgasm worthy, but certainly a delicious brunch well worth the price. As for the atmosphere of the restaurant, it follows the French theme of the restaurant, and it's really a nice atmosphere to be around.

I was pretty neutral to the service: it was friendly, but I wouldn't make a comment on it, positive or negative. It was pretty standard.

As for cons, the main con I felt was that the restaurant felt a little bit cramped. Also, service did not check up very much.

Only thing keeping this from a five star is that the service was very standard, and the food, while delicious, was not foodgasmic.
author: Benjamin H.

description:
Zazie, dah-ling!

Hot Steamed Chai (with soy) is the best I've had in this city so far :) Just the right amount of sweetness for this sugar-high sugar-tooth. Their fruit bowl is also plentiful and very fresh compared to a lot of other brunch spots I've traversed. 

Ginger Pancakes with bosc pears and homemade lemon curd are the YUM. I LOVE how they also price it by portion- in case you are just by yourself or with another or with a group. SMART. Their brunch special is my favorite so far - omelette with avocado, cheese, bacon, peppers, and.. good stuff.

The patio in the back is also a lovely place to get some Vitamin D on a rare sunny SF day. 

Merci!
author: Erin C.

description: Great brunch food, fantastic service.  I had the croquette Madame and tasted the French toast.  Both were good.
author: Neli M.

description:
Zazie is a French restaurant located in SF near golden gate park. It was a little hard to find, with a very small entrance. When we walked in, we noticed it was very busy. We were immediately seated and asked what we would like to drink. We stuck to waters since they didn't have bottomless mimosas. Our seats were on the back patio, which was nice but very crowded. I think that maybe they should look into an addition of some sort so that people are not so tightly crammed on the patio on busy days. 
I ordered the shrimp eggs Benedict. It was fairly small, quality was good. Don't think it was worth the 13 I paid. 
My girlfriend got the salad and crab eggs Benedict. She thought it was good but not overly impressed. We were seated before many people around us, however our orders came last. We weren't in a hurry, but it would have been nice to eat sooner rather than later.
author: Mike B.

description:
Whoa!  We were visiting from out of town and decided to give Zazie a try for dinner.  The back patio was so charming, our French waitress was fantastic, and the food was second to none.  We also were impressed with the wine list and tried a rose we had never encountered before, which was absolutely fantastic.
We had to work hard to convince ourselves that we should try a new restaurant the next night since we both really just wanted to go back to Zazie. :)
Also, really liked that they pay their staff well, so there's no tipping (which is helpful after finishing a bottle of wine).
author: Sterling K.

description: I went here for brunch on a date, and it was AMAZING. Best brunch I have ever had. Get the avocado and Dungeness crab eggs Benedict. My taste buds were in heaven! The only downside is that because it's such an awesome restaurant, the wait gets annoying. Definitely worth the extra time though!
author: Sophie N.

description: Liked this tiny little French Style restaurant. It's very simple and straight to the point. The service is alright, but the food is good. Everything is like organic or farm raised conscious. The coffee here is delightful. I had the seasonal pancake which was a lemon ricotta with an anglais. Also some sunny side up eggs. It was pretty standard, but good. I like this place because it's not fancy at all, just a chill spot to have breakfast and chat with your bestie.
author: Faith C.

description:
Um. Brunch here... blows me away. At first I wasn't exactly sure about this place, but I'm glad my friend knew what he was doing. It was cold (and a bit rainy) when we came, but luckily... because of that, no one wanted to sit outside! Outside is first come first serve... and if we had waited for a table inside, we probably would've never gotten in. The staff is incredibly friendly here... and they always seem like they would be super crowded (it was around 2 or 3 pm and there was still a line out the door).

We got their hot chocolate, which I highly recommended! It comes in a huge bowl cup... and you can get whipped cream on top... and is absolutely perfect on a miserable day. The restaurant is super cosy (two outside tables only) and not that many inside either. Luckily for us, there was an awning outside so we didn't have to sit in the drizzle. They have a great brunch menu... that looks incredibly tasty... I really want to go back and try everything on the menu because it looks so good!

Their poached eggs... holy crap... you can get one, two, or three eggs (depending on how hungry you are) which is great if you just want to get a taste and try other things. I had the Monaco... which was... AMAZING. It seems really simple, but it's really quite good. They come on English muffins with salad on the side... all the other poached egg options looked really promising too. There's just something about the crunchy English muffin soaking up the perfectly poached egg runny yolk... OMG to die for. Salivating just thinking about it now.

Pricing wasn't horribly expensive for the place; I didn't see the bill, but the egg dishes (2 eggs ~$13 average) seemed pretty reasonable for a specialty breakfast place. We had a really late lunch, and this was definitely the place to hit the spot. A bit difficult to get to (parking seemed like it would be incredibly difficult, but we walked there) but you should definitely give this place a shot!
author: Denise C.

description:
Went on a road trip with my friends to California from Washington. Looked for a nice brunch place and this seemed to be one of the highly ranked restaurants. 

Zazie is a cozy restaurant tucked away in San Francisco. The wait can be quite long, particularly for bigger parties. I believe they take reservations on the phone and write your name on the waiting list that they hang outside. You also write your name and party size on this list as well. The man who calls out the names is quite friendly and gives you an estimated time. We waited about 45 minutes to get seated for a table of 5. 

I must say though, the wait was worth it. We ordered various benedicts. For me, I specifically ordered the St. Trop Poached Eggs (with wild smoked salmon, capers, and red onions). The eggs were poached perfectly and the lox was made very nicely. The potatoes were not my favorite - just normal seasoned potatoes. However, made along with the potatoes were these cloves of garlic. Oh man, the garlic was delicious. Slightly buttery with the right amount of seasoning. The garlic was soft and could get sucked out of the skin easily. Meshed very well with the poached eggs! 

Overall, the food was very good. Wait might be a little long for some people but it's a great place to try. If I'm ever in San Fran again, I would love to try the french toast!
author: Joon K.

description:
I really like Zazie, especially their backyard outdoor seating area. 
The atmosphere it's very cozy and mellow, a deserved break from all the hipsterdom.
I love their soups and vegetarian platters.
The staff is nice and the ambiance very warm. Definitely a quieter, more romantic experience compared to some of its neighboring restaurant.
Great place for a date!
author: Amira T.

description:
This place is super crowded!!! Take any table you can get and don't be afraid to take the back patio seating (I didn't even know they had a back patio!) because it's heated and you won't feel the cold. Got the french toast and poach egg to share with my friend. Also got a small fresh squeeze orange juice and everything was excellent. The french toast was fluffy and wasn't overly sweet. We got 3 poach eggs and one of the 3 was a little over cooked so that was a bummer.

You get to customize the portion of your dishes. Things are priced by one portion, two portion, or three portion so that's a very nice touch.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Very tasty food, get it to go.

I decided to try this place when I wanted to venture out of SoMa and the Mission. It sits over in Cole Valley which is just enough distance away for me to feel like I was being a little different for once.

The place is always packed so expect a wait (we overheard 1 hour) or get your food to go like a champ. There's a splattering of parks nearby that you can sit and relax in whilst you eat your delicious food.

I ordered the Le Mer with two eggs which is more than enough with a side salad. The hollandaise sauce was nothing special but it definitely was tasty. The eggs were cooked to perfection, so much runny yolk. We also got a 2-piece French Toast which was cooked just how I like it, slightly moist in the middle, nice firm edges, with a lot of syrup on the side for you to apply how you wish. I think I might have added a little to much syrup in the end because I was feeling a little sick after eating it all.

Service was great, even in the packed conditions of their restaurant. All the staff were very polite and fast at getting you what you want. They ran out of take-out knives when we were there and they we extremely apologetic.
author: Greg C.

description:
Wow - this place is fantastic. My friend took me here on a sunny Saturday in San Francisco, the perfect weather to try out their gorgeous patio. Be prepared to wait; the line is long, but the food is worth it.

We all got variations of their poached eggs. I got La Mer, which is a poached egg on top of an English muffin topped with avocado, green onions, crab meat, and lemon hollandaise sauce with house potatoes on the side. Oh my gosh - SO GOOD! I'm usually not a fan of hollandaise sauce, but this was phenomenal. We also got an order of French Toast Tahiti, which is challah bread stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Again, I'm also not a huge fan of French toast, but I was very pleased with Zazie's version. Make sure to try the butter they put on the side of the plate - it's orange cinnamon! My friend also tried Le Muni, a non-alcoholic refresher, which was absolutely delicious. 

Everything we had was like heaven in your mouth. I could not be more pleased with a brunch spot - truly excellent.
author: Caitlin W.

description: Arrived at 1pm Friday afternoon and the wait was 5 minutes. First time at this tiny little neighborhood establishment. Good food, average portions, fair prices that range from $6-$15 depending on the dishes w/ selectable portions. Thought that was great cuz you can order based on how hungry you are. We had the poached eggs (BFF cleaned the plate!) + the Mexican Scramble. Bread that came w/ it was soft/fresh.
author: Julie L.

description:
Do you believe in Fate?

Was there a reason why I was born with the appetite of a whale with the fast metabolism of a hummingbird? Did I just so happen to live in the greatest foodventurous city in all of America? I'm sure it was also just a coincidence that I'd happen to play hooky with my girlfriend and wind up at Zazie's for breakfast.

Zazie, past the reefer influence streets of the Haight and located nearby the UCSF Medical neighborhood of Cole Valley, is a gem of a luncheonette (they also serve dinner too). The hallway sized restaurant itself is quite small but cozy, with homey decor, paintings, an awesome spiral staircase coat hanger, and available heated patio seating out in the back of the garden. First glance upon their menu and you can already tell that Zazie is something special. 

The Albert - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=7oS00AnQdPkMIJEHlW-YAA#ozr2HmIPInKnnxl-NBVMyw
Upon my first go at Zazie's, it must've been predetermined that I would order the Pouched Egg special, Albert. Your choice of 1, 2, or 3 free range eggs, it's served with bacon, white cheddar, and house salsa fresca, each on a toasty English muffin and Zazie's "fabulous" lemon hollandaise sauce. Really though, they had me at BACON. 

I opted for 3 eggs because Alberts just roll like that. And to no surprise, all three eggs were perfectly poached (see picture) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=7oS00AnQdPkMIJEHlW-YAA#0CVKzgAjJdUxsmvOxTCdEA, with that ooey-gooey yolk oozing over the bacon chedder muffin. And yes, the hollandaise sauce was truly "fabulous". 

Eggs en Fonte + Chorizo - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=7oS00AnQdPkMIJEHlW-YAA
Debating over whether to order the Eggs Divorce, my girlfriend had no regrets ordering this winner. Grilled soft polenta cake cooked with spinach, wild mushrooms, a spicy tomato sauce, and toppled with 2 over easy eggs all baked in a steamingly endless cast iron skillet, which kept the whole dish pipping hot throughout the meal. Additional for the tangy delicious chorizo; a must get. 

Zazie is one of those eateries that you'll not soon forget. Despite arriving during prime time for a late breakfast at noon (that's also how Alberts rolls) with the ever growing crowd of hungry San Franciscans at the door waiting to nab some eats, we were seated no more than 15 minutes upon arrival. More impressive was how fast each fine polished dish arrived at our table side. Furthermore was Zazie's service; our waiter was more than just polite and courteous, but he had personality. Anybody can be jolly and refill your drinks, but if you can crack jokes and get on a friendly personal level with your patrons, you know you love your job. 

Was it Fate that just so happened to bring me to Zazie's? Perhaps, but playing hooky for a hellavah breakfast was a conclusive date with destiny. I'm a believer!
author: Albert L.

description: Literally one of the best breakfasts I have ever had. The potatoes were just a little too greasy but other than that no complaints. Long wait but they were fast and when I ate I didn't feel rushed.
author: lauren s.

description: All I can say is that it was worth the wait. I enjoyed the eggs benedict with and a mimosa. The menu was focus on great variations of brunch favorites. The staff was very attentive and willing to tailor the selections to your taste. But I did not see the need to change anything. I will definitely return
author: C H.

description:
Super long wait but worth it. Went for brunch and got the challah french toast and home fries. They fry the home fries with whole cloves of garlic. It smells and tastes so good. Big portions, good price.

The dinner menu looked really good too. Want to go back and try.
author: Lilian K.

description:
Came here for my birthday brunch. The french toast tahiti with the caramelized banana is amazing. All you need is one piece really. It's so filling and you won't want to stuff yourself with all that bread. I also tried the gingerbread pancake which I thought was good as well. I'm not a huge pancake eater but I thought this was good to try. I also had the crab benedict, the "Albert" (bacon, white cheddar and salsa) and that was delicious as well. They now have a no-tip policy, but they have also increased their prices. 

1 piece of Benedict with fries (or salad) is about $13-$15! 
1 piece of French toast is $9! 

*Always an extremely long wait on the weekends
author: Laura T.

description:
This is my 2nd time here for dinner; both times were fabulous! Great to eat outside on their patio, as they have heat lamps.

The staff did a great job, especially since they were so busy. Highly recommend the Pate Zazie (chicken livers, brandy), Salade Guillaume (arugula,k almonds, strawberries, chevre), Mussels Marinieres, Salmon en Papillote, and Grilled Hanger Steak w/mushroom brandy cream sauce. 

Not sure all of the above are on the regular menu, as this was a very special wedding dinner for 12. But Zazie's is a favoorite of the bride and groom for good reason!
author: Donna E.

description: Waited for about 30 mins. Ordered the crab Benedict and french toast. Both dishes were good but nothing spectacular or exciting. I probably would come back if there was no wait but I don't have cravings for this spot.
author: Rosanna T.

description: While the family style portions were a little bit on the smaller side for some of them (we could have asked for more), it was a great place for our company's Christmas dinner! Highly recommended.
author: Olivier L.

description: Just watched several tables that sat down after us get their food before us...and what's worse is that the staff didn't even apologize for their ineptitude.  I looked at my watch and we had been there for 40 minutes and waiting at least 25-30 minutes for our food.  If you are going to automatically include tips so you can give health benefits and 401k to your employees then the least you can do for your customers is be on point and give them a good experience.  When you don't have to work for your tips you start to create a sense of entitlement where in my book tips are something that is earned and not given (at least where I come from).  The food is good, but we won't be back...and that is unfortunate.
author: Jesus H.

description:
Haven't been here in years but was itching to come back.
I remembered loving their egg dishes more than their pancakes/waffles so I picked an egg dish off their special menu.

I ordered a dish called Rue du Rosiers....it's a savory bread pudding with mushrooms and fontina cheese & eggs on top and a salad on the side. It was really good!
The salad was strangely more salty and made subsequent bites of bread pudding more bland! Otherwise, the flavors and textures were good.

My daughter's breakfast potatoes (home fries) were PERFECT. Especially because we had not-very-good ones at Just For You cafe the day before. The potatoes were
crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and I even stole a roasted garlic clove from her plate. Yum!

This will still always be one of my fave SF breakfast places to eat.
Thanks Zazie!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Not so Happy New Year... As so often happens when you go to a restaurant regularly you learn when service or food quality is excellent or has declined. Unfortunately, the decline bug struck tonight at this year's New Year's Eve dinner for us.. Keep in mind, our reservations were at 5:45pm and we were there early at 5:30pm so way too early on in the evening for the issues we encountered which will make sense later. 
We were seated promptly as usual however the owner was absent (I'm used to seeing her there as she is so cheerful and welcoming and vested but the guy was totally fine and friendly. The problems came early and continued throughout the meal.
It started out as a simple menu change which, on the website, upon return to the house after dinner, from Corvina Sea Bass en Papillotte to Mahi Mahi en Papillotte. While a working menu was stated online, it still says sea bass, this was a horrible substitution and way, way different and less special  if you ask me for a prix fixe. We ordered a bottle of champagne which was fine as how can that be bad? We also ordered iced teas. The woman sitting next to us and  her equally gross children, were sneezing and coughing without covering her mouth/nose requiring us to change tables. I wonder where her kids learned that from? When sitting 1-2 feet apart from neighbors that becomes unacceptable and had my utensils and napkin and dinner roll changed out because who wants mucous when their eating a special dinner? This is the only factor that was out of control of the staff. The starter arrived... one of each. I was shocked at the size of the soup which literally amounted to about 4-6 ounces. Barely acceptable portion size yet simultaneously not acceptable. The salad was good and portion was normal. The dinner rolls as usual were excellent and the best part of the meal looking back. Then the second course arrived. One of each again. The raviolis were as usual excellent and I would have preferred those over the choice of tarte that I had (tonight and previously). The puff pastry was not crispy and the dish was luke warm (I've had that issue here before due to the placement of the kitchen and the back door breeze so was not a huge surprise or issue at the time, I just ate it and said nothing). The flavor was good despite it being luke warm and lacking in quality assurance. The main course arrived and again I was shocked at the portion size. We both got the, "Braised Pinwheel Niman Ranch Beef Shortribs" (because again, no sea bass, only mahi mahi). The entrée should have been called Braised Pinwheel Niman Ranch Beef Shortrib... minus the s because s means plural and there was only one. While this dish was excellent in flavor, it was again not piping hot and portion for entree was horribly small. Dessert course arrives and again, we had one of each. Toasted Challah "Pain Trouvé" was not warm, it was tepid and the vanilla creme brulee that was on top was both cold and the brulee was not crispy, it was wet brulee as if it had been sitting in the refrigerator covered in plastic wrap and condensation had its way and not bruleed prior to delivery to the table. Chocolate Oblivion Cake portion was also very small. On top of the other shortfalls, they ran out of iced tea after my second glass... ran out! My other half only had one glass. How exactly has this restaurant taken a turn for the worse to such a degree? I myself am unsure but the failure of this evening without the owner present was completely tangible and would make me rethink a retry for any special occasion when this was previously always my go to place. How sad I was upon leaving the restaurant this evening.
