description:
Yes, to ambiance on the back patio. Yes, to the French inspired burger I had to have (my palate is unpredictable). Yes, to the wine and that AMAZING baked chocolat chaud for dessert. 

The pudding-like hot chocolate went straight to my veins and gave me a sugar high that I haven't experienced since I was 6. I crashed 2 hours later, tears and crankiness. Indicative of a pretty intense high,yet well worth it.
author: Alec C.

description:
I hate waiting in lines. I really do. This is one of the few lines I will put up with because I enjoy the food. 

Yesterday had the Mexican chorizo scrabble and it was damn good. Not too spicy (I'm not Mexican so I need it mild) and not too bland. 

Also had the Monaco poached eggs with prosciutto and they were delicious. 

I'm dying to go back here for dinner. On Tuesday nights it's a $22 fixed price menu with no corkage. Score!
author: Carlos A.

description:
Word to the wise:  If all you are going to do is order an omelette, you can get that anywhere.  No point in paying higher prices for eggs and toast. 

Now this is the place to go if you are looking for amazing pancakes and eggs Benedict all sorts of ways.  I'm crazy for the one with prosciutto and tomato Provençal (tomato marinated in herbs).  I've tried their cornmeal pancakes, which are not gritty whatsoever, their gingerbread pancakes, and the standard buttermilk--all just the right fluffiness and density that I love.  I was looking for a substitute for La Note in Berkeley, and while I view Zazie as a decent sub, I still prefer La Note, except for their super unfriendly staff.  

What I don't like about this place is that they charge $3 for a teensy cup of OJ that can't possibly be fresh-squeezed.  Not cool, and tastes like Tropicana.   

I like the fact that you can get small portions if you prefer.  And I think the price paid for quality of food is worth it.  

Their soy chai latte is really good.  They use the kind of soy that doesn't taste like soy and leave an icky flavor in your mouth.  

Staff is consistently kind, friendly, and helpful.  

Now if they could do fresh orange juice, berry coulis, crème fraîche pancakes, and herbed potatoes as good as La Note, I'd give 5 stars.  But 4 says a lot, coming from me, because most breakfast places in SF suck.
author: Kandi K.

description: What happened to the old wait staff that served me for the last 6 years. Did your tip free policy make them move on? VERY BUMMED. They were awesome. Foods still good, but the feelings changed, not for the better.
author: Nik D.

description:
This place has left me leaving with amazement. I'm not really a guy that loves eating breakfast that much. Possibly because of the fact that I need to wake up early to eat it but anyway I would come here over and over and over again for breakfast. Well I did come here for brunch...but breakfast is part of Brunch so yea. 

ANYWAY there are possibly two complains I have for this place. FIRST the thing I hate about this place is the wait. The wait was agonizing. I personally didn't know why I was standing out there for so long just to get myself the brunch but of course I took my words back as soon as I took my first bite. The 2nd thing I hate about this place is the fact that I find it kinda small and cramped. I didn't exactly enjoyed my seating that much...it was oddly uncomfortable.

ALTHOUGH...I learned to overlook those two big flaws in a restaurant by the taste of their food, their taste of the food, and did i mention their taste of their food? YEA....It was so great that I really want to go back right now to eat it for brunch. I've been comparing so many brunch places to Zazie and honestly they really have nothing on Zazie. Their service was quite nice and I do find it enjoyable. 

I tried the Croque Madame...oh *drool* It was sooooooo freaking delicious. It was such a nice and beautiful combination that I really don't want to share with anybody but of course I did because i wanted to try other stuff with my friends and family haha. It was all so fresh and it was just beautifully made when the yolk just slowly leaked out but it just taste so heavenly.

I personally find the French Toast Tahiti the 2nd thing I enjoyed after my Croque Madame. It was so nicely made because the banana was just roasted perfectly and the french toast was just WOWZERS. It was crispy and the roasted perfect bananas just like fuse together with wonderful taste. AH...delicious

New York Scrambled Salmon Egg was quite nice. I thought the salmon was cooked very nicely unlike the places I have tried in the past. It was seasoned well compare to many other places that I've been and it doesnt have that weird texture to it. 

Hmm..i guess i didnt find the pancakes that enjoyable. It wasn't anything that honestly blew my mind...but i dont really care about the pancakes when i could come back and get my Croque Madame again..ooohhhhhh Goddddd.

IT IS DEFINITELY MY FAVORITE BRUNCH PLACE. It kinda makes me wanna live in SF jsut for the delicious food they have.
author: Ernest Y.

description: Zazie is the more impressive place we went during the trip to SF. First we thought on a Monday morning there is not possible to have a line to wait, but who knew. There was a LINE and the place is packed. I was hungry but since it looks so promising, we stayed. The wait was worth it! Everything tasted SO GOOD, PERFECTLY MADE! We ordered poached egg with smoked salmon and green salad, chicken sausages, pancakes with french toasts and bacon. EVERYTHING IS top notch. French toast is the best I have ever had!!!!!!! The toast is thick and soft! I ate mine in 2 seconds. And I've been thinking about it since!!! Can anyone tell me a place for good FT in LA? I am craving for it!!! Nonetheless, the it's best! If you are in the area and can afford the wait, go!
author: Lei-Lei F.

description:
Sunday brunch for 2.  Arrived around 11:40am, 1+ hour wait.  Verdict: Worth it.

We tried:

1. French Toast Tahiti: Pinkie's challah bread stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Choose 1, 2,  or 3 pieces of bread ($6/ 10/ 13).  SUPER GOOD. Slightly crisp edges on the toast, not too sweet, and the banana + walnuts perfectly compliment the bread.

2. Albert Poached Eggs: with bacon, white cheddar, and homemade salsa fresca.  Choose 1, 2, or 3 eggs for $9/ 12/ 15.  This was excellent as well.  This dish came with roasted garlic. YUMMMMY!  The eggs were perfectly cooked, with slightly runny yolk.  Comes with a side salad or home fries.  We got the home fries (made with red potatoes). 

Tip:  There's a bar next door where you can wait instead of just standing around.  In addition, Haight street is just a few blocks down with little boutique shops you can browse through.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
How it's possible that I've yet to jot a review of one of my favorite breakfast spots in SF is a mystery, but hey -- it's happening now, so we don't have to worry about that little issue ever again.

Breakfast and brunch in the city can almost be characterized as a sport. It's near and dear to many 'a people's left ventricles come the weekend, and few places I've been to provide better tasting sunrise fare in a quaint, Euro setting than Zazie. With enough egg-based dishes to scare the pants off of any spring chicken, and delectable carbohydrates like the Pinkie's Challah French Toast and their signature gingerbread pancakes, every little morsel featured on their menu is a real treat. Personally, I'm all about the omelettes and benedicts, but the sweet stuff always has a Siren-esque quality, testing me to curb my inner fat kid. Even if you possess more of a savory palate, you really should indulge in their sugary offerings. 

The lines can grow pretty long on the weekends, but somehow, I can't recall ever waiting more than 30 minutes for a table. Whatever they've done to keep those table tops rotating in a timely fashion is pretty remarkable, so don't be scared when you see a gaggle of hungry locals gathering outside. Of course, no true Zazie experience is complete without stopping into Finnegan's Wake for a quick alcoholic libation as you await your name being called. Make it happen!
author: Ruggy J.

description: Very solid brunch spot.  Pretty expensive menu.  Don't think they take reservations and the line can be pretty long on weekends.
author: Anthony D.

description: Man, Zazie is a good local restaurant. It's fine to pop in and get some takeaway and for a casual dinner. Brunch is good too. BUT! I can't understand why anyone would queue for hours to get in for breakfast/brunch. To those who wait on the sidewalk can you please get out of the way of other pedestrians? Thanks! Plenty of better spots to go to in the area. Food is fine, although weirdly they would not cook my pregnant wife's salmon well done - sorry to stereotype but how very French and snobby. It's a good spot all in all, fast efficient, good food, but an easy local spot not a destination restaurant at all.
author: R M.

description:
Sunday brunch, 60' wait. Food: 4.5/5
Monaco: 5/5
Gingerbread pancakes (1): 4/5
Drinks
Enough for 2 girls :)
$25 each
author: Olivia Q.

description:
Went to Zazie's on a sunday afternoon for brunch. 
Upon arrival bf and I noticed the hoards of people standing outside. Busy is a good sign. We put our names on the list outside the front door (because they don't take reservations for brunch or lunch). We were about 20 names down the list, but we had driven all the way from Santa Clara so we waited.

Miscellaneous:
Basically the whole thing was a clusterfu**. There are two tables outside (first come, first served) so people were hovering over the people eating waiting to snatch a seat which I thought was pretty weird. Also, the host kept sneaking people he knew in before the other people on the list. I'm not one to make a stink, but I thought that was pretty lame as we had been standing in the sun for almost an hour. 

Anyway, fast forward about an hour and the host tells us "ok, you guys are the on the patio outside, second table on the left), then walks away. Uh, this is my first time here, are we supposed to wander aimlessly around the restaurant until we find our table? We eventually found the table which was directly facing another group? Basically it was four little tables, arranged into a larger square in between two corner booths, so we were literally staring at the other group the whole meal. A little awkward but not a problem. The rest of the patio was beautiful. I was surprised how cool it was as it was around 75 degrees outside. 

Food:
I ordered the french toast with the caramelized bananas and walnuts (I forget what they're called) with a side of oatmeal and coffee to drink. Overall, my food was great. The coffee was great. Service was ok, but considering it was so busy I can overlook that. 

Bf got the omelet with a shitload of mushrooms (obviously thats not what it was called but, again, I forgot the real name. ahah) and a bottle of lemonade to drink. He seemed to really like his food and loved the lemonade. 

$55 (plus tip) and 2 hours later we are on our way, full and happy as clams. We decided that we would go back but on a weekday when it wouldn't be as busy. 

Solid 3 stars.
author: Erin H.

description: Had my first Croque de Monsier here and oh my god that was life changing! French food is delicious. A bit pricey, but they have a no tip policy so it about evens out.
author: Jack P.

description:
This place was amazing!!! I hosted my mother's surprise birthday brunch here and everyone (myself included) loved it. You could tell my their empty plates by the end of the meal. The ambiance of this French bistro was very cozy and the manager and staff were very friendly and accommodating. :) 

My sister and I shared the Poached Eggs Valence. It had roasted eggplant and spicy tomato-chevre sauce. DELICIOUS! Their potatoes were also really good! What's great about Zazie is they give you 3 options for their poached egg specialties (whether you want 1, 2, or 3 eggs). We decided on getting the 3 eggs so we could each have one, and so my brother could also try! My brother ordered the Une Assiette, which was a sample platter of the french toast, gingerbread pancake and a buttermilk pancake. The french toast won hands down! 

I would definitely recommend this place to my family and friends. :)
author: Cheri T.

description: Absolutely delicious brunch menu! The french toast is a must try.
author: Nicholas F.

description: I came here with two friends for brunch, this past weekend. It had rave reviews and seemed to be very good, so we decided to try it out. The only thing is the wait is horrendous. We waited for an hour to get seated, so we were starving by the time we got seated. The host is very nice, so it does make you feel less hangry, but still. When we got seated, we ordered just glasses of champagne. Forget the juice for a mimosa, just give it to us straight, and the waiter was more than happy to oblige. I then ordered the un, deux, trois with chicken apple sausage, and a bowl of fruit on the side. The pancake and eggs were delightful. One of my friends got the Florentine, which she said was very scrumptious, and my other friend got the Pierre Noir, and she also said her's was very good. I think that may have been an understatement, because all of our plates were thoroughly cleaned. All of that came up to be less than $100. Also, they don't accept tips, its included in their prices, which is nice and kind of cool. Very good experience at Zazie. Highly recommended.
author: Carina R.

description:
A puppy friendly hipster eatery in the quaint little neighborhood of Cole Valley. They have a weird system of seating (first come first serve out front on the sidewalk, everyone else has to wait to be seated inside or in the back patio) The servers are so great and friendly, excellent service on their part tho 

We had lovely gingerbread French toast times, topped full of fruits; also eggs, potatoes with meats but I forgot what that dish actually was because it was eaten quickly  lots of coffee that kept getting refilled, and a delectable coffee cake the size of my face was then sent to us by a nice couple who let us take a table outside as they waited to be seated. Nice peoples they are. 

I might come back, this time wearing my plaid and raybans as I happily nosh on my benedict  aw yea...
author: Lauren N.

description:
I love brunch.  With the 7x7 "The Big Eat SF" List making the rounds, I met up with fellow Yelper Carol L.  to try Zazie's Big Eat List brunch item:  The Florentine Benedict:  Poached eggs, spinach and portabello mushrooms on an English muffin in hollandaise sauce..and I always love a good hollandaise.  

With my brother, cousin and Carol's bf in town, we had brunch on the patio at Zazie's on a crisp Friday morning.  We arrived around 9:30 a.m. (a bit early for brunch) but avoided the later morning rush and didn't have to wait too long for a table.  Carol L. got the gingerbread pancakes - which had a very cake-like consistency and was probably better as dessert than breakfast fare.  Every dish we saw come out of the kitchen beckoned to us and we were definitely eating other people's meals with our eyes.  My Florentine Benedict was excellent - the portabello mushrooms and the spinach didn't make me miss my usually Eggs Benedict ham at all.  Get the home fries - they are such a wonderful complement to the dish!

Zazie was a cute establishment in Cole Valley and I can see the immediate appeal with the cozy exterior, interior, and patio area.  I loved the ambiance and can only imagine what it would be like to dine there on the patio as the mid-afternoon sun sets.
author: Vy S.

description: Zazie it's a place you always feel like coming home. The food and the service are wonderful.Don't miss the mussels!
author: Marcus J.

description: Well worth the wait! Excellent service and excellent food. Plenty of vegetarian options...AND the staff is paid a living wage and has a 401(k) plan. Will return each time I'm in town, for sure!
author: Bop Girl X.

description:
My Sactown friend was visiting and what a better way to start the day than breakfast at my fave spot. 

Okay, brunch.  Since ya'll know I don't wake up early!

We arrived at noontime on a weekday and lo and behold!  there was no wait.  We headed straight for the patio.  This is where you want to be on a gorgeous sunny day, there are flowers and plants surrounding you, other folks basking in the sun, a couple who can't seem to stop kissing.

How cute.  (I'm more forgiving about that since I used to be one of those annoying kissy types) 

The only available table was of course, right next to the kissy couple.  My friend and I tried hard not to keep * looking * so we distracted ourselves by concentrating on the menu.

I already knew that I wanted eggs bene.  The hollandaise sauce is phenomenal paired with perfectly poached fresh egg. I zeroed in on the Eggs Monaco which comes with prosciutto and tomatoes provencales. My friend opted for the Eggs Mexico, scrambled eggs with roasted peppers, chorizo, white cheddar cheese and homemade salsa.  Both come with home fries and cloves of sweet roasted garlic. 

My friend also tried their chai latte and was surprised that it came in a bowl.  Spicy. Wonderfully made with foamy milk on top.  She just had to take a pic!

Although service was a bit slower this time around, we weren't in a rush.  We took the time to enjoy a rare sunny day in SF! 

Brunch food at Zazie is consistently good. You can't go wrong with this place.
author: Janice C.

description:
A long overdue review. Never had brunch here, but have gone for dinner many times. A neighborhood gem, their bistro fare is delectable. Portion size are spot on as is pricing. Parking (street) can be a PITA, but thus is SF. 

Really not much else that can be said about this place that hasn't been already.
author: Hank C.

description:
Food is great here
A bit crowded gets busy but the banana tahiti french toast is highly recommended
author: Peetas M.

description:
I have absolutely no complaints.

I love that you can order 1/2/3 sizes of pretty much everything, so you could get one sweet and one savory brunch item if you wanted. Or use mine and my boyfriend's routine: order 2 full size brunches and split them. The size order options are also an advantage if you're calorie-counting and want to eat a reasonably-sized brunch.

We had an Eggs Benedict with mushrooms and spinach, which was fantastic. The flavors really complimented each other. We also ordered their French toast with caramelized banana, which satisfied our sweet tooth.

Our waitress (wish I remembered her name) was super sweet and on top of things.

Wait time is a bit long to get seating (normal with such popular brunch places), but there's a Peet's just a few doors down or it's a nice area to walk around while you wait.
author: Krista J.

description: When it comes to restaurants, I always look for perfection of food and experience. I can say the lamb tagine I ordered was nothing short of perfect. The waiter made a mistake in taking order, but later corrected it and also gave us two complementary deserts in addition, and made us had a pleasant experience at the end of the day. Definitely recommend it if you are in sf. And oh, the resturant was tip free!!!
author: Payam V.

description:
I'm super bummed to report a jarring experience with my brunch last Sunday. The story is below if you're interested but ultimately, I'm not sure I'll want to to head back to Zazie because I'd rather not ever have have to see Suhail, the night manager.

9 am Sunday, Zazie's open for brunch. My party of 4 was glad to find that the line wasn't long, in fact there were only four names on the list before we added ours (they'd only been open a short while). As we waited, I explained to my friends that from my past experiences, their Sunday brunch is worth the wait. As my last review indicates, I got my friends excited about how the food is good and comes out quickly, service is really good and from my visits has been rather consistent. 

After 30 minutes had passed, we're still waiting and we're watching some other folks who came after us get seated. We understand that because we have a party of four, we have to wait for a table for four and we're absolutely cool with that. 

To pass the time, I walk up to the sign in sheet for a status check and notice that there are eight names crossed off below mine, including one party of 4 and and another party of 3. Uh-oh, perhaps we were accidentally skipped? I noticed that the usual guy, Mario, isn't there. It's not a big deal but worth asking the substitute host Suhail about, right? Sure.

"Hi, My name is Jen and my name is listed here. Is it possible that we might have been accidentally skipped?" I asked. I couldn't believe the response I got, which was, "I'm pretty sure I'm better at this job than you."

What?

I'm pretty sure I didn't ask you for your job. I'm pretty sure that was condescending and unnecessary. I'm pretty sure that insult spiked my heart rate. I'm pretty sure there's about 94 other ways you could've responded that would have been more appropriate and professional than the garbage that just fell out of your mouth. 

I might have felt better if any of that came to mind in that moment so I could've said it. All I could muster was "that was really rude man, I can't believe you just said that." Not a cool response but an honest one and I'm not even getting paid to handle this guy. I asked "where's the usual guy? He's cool, he's not rude and he's good at this job." At this, Suhail replied, "you can tell him yourself when he gets back." Awesome. 

Since I'm undecided about whether I'll head back to Zazie, I may not get the chance to give Mario my message so here it is for all of you fine people. I bet being the Sunday host at Zazie is a real tough job. Mario, thank you for your professionalism, your efficiency, your customer service. People wait around half their day to get into your restaurant for the fine food and service. 

To Suhail, I get that it isn't always fun to go to work but that's the job. What are you doing?  When you told me "we'll make it up to you," I'm not sure what you meant by that because I'm still waiting.  

While I just wanted to leave at this point, we continued to hang around in disbelief over the exchange that had just happened. Maybe 10 to 15 minutes later, he called my name. Well, I guess we might as well eat. I asked my friend to go in first because I was feeling pretty stung and didn't want to have to look at the guy. 

Unfortunately, he stopped us before we were able to get into the door. He made it a point to walk up to me and explain "I wasn't being rude; I was being frank." Oh Frank; don't man, you're making it worse. Please stop poking that spot you already jabbed. 

He went on to explain how seating works, how if he'd called my name then he would've written the time next to my name and when he went to point to the sign in sheet he actually hit me. He didn't mean to hit me, but he did. One of my friends started laughing; what did Suhail think was happening here? Maybe he did want to hand off his job at this point and was trying to give me instructions.

Maybe I shouldn't have asked a question. Maybe I should have just waited around longer, feeling mildly concerned that our name might have been overlooked. Maybe when I want to give an establishment my business, my endorsement and my money I should just keep my mouth shut and not ask questions. Yeah, maybe that.

Maybe the next time one of my customers asks me a question, I'll tell them "I'm pretty sure I'm better at this job than you." Maybe if I want to lose my job. 

Completely counter to Suhail, Melissa the server was kind and polite and embodied the characteristics I've come to expect from Zazie. I made sure I thanked her for her kind service; I needed her to know I appreciated her positive professionalism. Unfortunately, the good food and kind server couldn't rinse out the bitter start to my Zazie experience. I wish it did.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Came to Zazie while in San Francisco this past weekend with a group of seven people. 

Ordered:
Mocha
French toast
Greek Scrambled eggs with Toast & Home Fries

Mocha - came in a HUGE bowl coffee cup. I loved it  Great value for $4 and it kept my normally cold hands very warm.

French Toast - Hands down best part of the entire meal. Cinnamon and banana goodness...and I'm not even a huge fan of French Toast!

Greek Eggs  w/  toast and home fries - Eggs were delicious despite being a tad runny. Loved the feta cheese that came on these. Toast with jam was SO YUMMY! You must try the jam if you come here. Unfortunately, home fries were way too Garlic-y for my taste. When there is a whole garlic clove on your plate....it has the potential to take over the whole dish. Entire dish approx. $10-$15...can't complain there.

I held back two stars on this place mainly because they do have some substantial room for improvement. The biggest area in need of some help is "wait time" before being seated.  The wait here was somewhere over an hour or so - I had lost track of time standing out in the cold. Maybe if Zazie invested in a few standing heaters or a few benches, the wait would be more bearable and less noticeable. I've been to a few places in San Francisco that allow you to order drinks while you wait...maybe that would be an option for this place. Wait times are part of the business especially when you're a breakfast place with a reputation like Zazie but even then, find a way to make the time more manageable at least! If I would've been able to order a hot chocolate out there in the SF chill, I think I would have definitely given this place more stars.
author: Kara S.

description: Service was spotty, food is overpriced, and expectations were not met. We asked for water and coffee upon getting seated. Asked for water two times after that and nothing, finally had to get up and grab water and glasses on my own. Food took forever. I ordered the Croque Madame and there was no bechamel sauce in sight. Coffee was cold and no refills were given. However the two top next two use was getting 5-star service....coffee refills, water, fast and hot food. We were a table of 4 and our bill was $112.00 for BREAKFAST and mediocre service. I'm an SF native and most likely will not recommend this place to people. #disappointed
author: Spa G.

description:
I know this place is famous for their breakfast/brunch but I haven't had time to brave their long lines in the morning yet so I just got the burger. 

I haven't lived in San Francisco very long, but this was definitely the best burger I've had here by far. 

I was initially disappointed that it didn't have some kind of greens on it, but after the first bite I decided they knew what they were doing. The sweetness from super flavorful tomato blended perfectly with the taste of the cheese, not to mention an excellent bun (always a key element of a really good burger).

I still really want to try their brunch, but I will be going back for the burger again soon I'm sure.
author: Ely L.

description: Comfortable place. Delicious food. Good for groups.
author: Rachel L.

description: Amazing French toast! Long wait. Pretty expensive as well' also prepare to have others hover over you if you sit at an outdoor table
author: Marisa K.

description:
What a cute cute place for brunch!

One sunday morning, our lucky parking karma allowed me to park literally outside the restaurant (literally) which I was very happy about.  This was a good start.  (However please note parking in the area is generally DIFFICULT so you should allow at least 15 extra minutes to look for parking if you are coming here for a meal).

However, the La Mer poached eggs were totally worth the wait. I liked that you can pick the number of eggs you want. We had good cup of coffee and 2 Bloody Mary. 


Food was exceptionally tasty.  Service was very pleasant.
author: Semira J.

description: Upon my arrival, I could tell this place was very popular. I came here with co-workers of mine. We had to wait, which wasn't too bad seeing that we had 4 groups ahead of us.(20min wait). The ambiance in the restaurant was nice. I got a burger with potato fries, which was nice and light. I didn't get the bacon on my burger but if I did, my burger would have been amazing.. kinda pricey but its worth it(seeing that the employees can get proper benefits).. I would recommend!!
author: James H.

description: A friend got me a GC to this place because she raved about it. With all the Yelp reviews and long wait lines, I assumed it would be good. What is all the hype about?!? I ordered the griddle flight (sub Tahiti french toast instead of regular) and the Albert poached eggs. The poached eggs were great, grilled potatoes were lukewarm, and the pancakes were just mediocre, including the gingerbread and Tahiti French toast. I am going to add that the service was excellent which made the experience better. I've had better French toast and pancakes elsewhere, including Olea, Central Kitchen, and Plow. Same wait time but those places will fulfill your sweet palate and worth every calorie! Thanks Zazie but won't be back for breakfast/brunch. Perhaps dinner will be more impressive.
author: Ny H.

description:
One of the best poached eggs with smoked salmon I've ever had. They have an excellent selection of mimosas- i had the peach/black currant one, which I'd love to have again. My only reason for not giving them five stars is the "salad" that I decided to have instead of the potatoes was not a salad, it was mixed greens with a decent dressing. Mixed greens to me is a cheap cop out for a salad, not what I expected, but the service is perfect and the place is small with attention to the main courses and making sure the clients are happy. Again, just would love to see tomatoes or carrots or I don't know maybe a mushroom or two to call it a salad. 

Huge tip- come with plenty of time, this place is always busy with a line out the door.
author: Carolina S.

description: This place had excellent customer service and the food was pretty good. I had the florentine and my husband had one of the eggs scramble dishes. I really enjoyed the my dish but his egg scramble was a little overpowered by the cheese. For the food we would give four stars but for customer service we would give five. Overall this was a great first experience and we would definitely come back!
author: Kim T.

description: Zazie has always been one of my favorite brunch spots in the city.  Love the food and it's french charm, however today my fiance and I had a pretty bad brunch experience.  They just implemented a "No Tipping" program, which at first we thought was awesome and for a great cause.  But we noticed it comes with a catch:  POOR SERVICE!  Our waiter never once checked on us.  Our coffee was never refilled.  The water we requested was never brought the the table.  We literally only saw our waiter when he took our order and when he brought us the check.  Some staff would walk by us, however seemed so hurried that we didn't even get a chance to ask them for a coffee refill.  So we had to try to enjoy our french toast with empty coffee mugs and no water on the table.  Not so sure if this No Tipping thing is a good idea after all...
author: Melisa H.

description:
Yes, there is a wait.  However the outside front tables are first come first serve.

The food here is AMAZING, the staff is nice.  You really can't go wrong.
author: Kristin G.

description:
Booooonjour Zazie!

Oh mon ami, this place makes me want to move to Parieeee.  Since that's not likely (ce qui se passera aux calendes grecques), I may have to do some remodeling to the la maison.  The Parisian vibe in here is c'est magnifique but le moment supreme was that outdoor patio (coup de foudre).  I'm not sure how much French (perhaps as much as I parle) is infused in the menu (no pain au chocolat?...Mon Dieu!) but the french toast Tahiti was oh la la!   Mon Cher got the poached eggs Albert (c'est si bon) and we split a gingerbread pancake with bosc pear and lemon curd (bien fait).  I also ordered the special mimosa of the day - white peach with black currant (oui oui...oui).     

Merci beaucoup Zazie!  Je t'adore but if you add chocolatines (si'l vous plait) to the mix, Je serai à toi pour toujours!...Bisous!!!!
author: Stephanie E.

description: I had the Tahiti stuffed French Toast on Sunday and haven't been able to get it off my mind since.  It tastes like if you could imagine a bread pudding, but not so mushy, like the perfect french toast combo.  Had name on list before opening and were seated promptly after opening.  I am so down to visit again for this french toast, but I'll have a hard time finding anyone to drag 6.5 hours from L.A. with me.  Maybe I'll go solo ;)
author: Kay H.

description:
Charming French restaurant with a very casual, California vibe. The service was attentive and very friendly. Prices were very reasonable and portions pretty in line with what you'd expect for what you're paying. 

The mussels and fig appetizers were pretty good. The seafood stew was a bit thicker than I thought it'd be but was still overall enjoyable. 

I'd definitely stop by again if I was in the neighborhood but not something I'd go out of my way to try.
author: Victor W.

description: SUCH A CUTE PLACE!!!! Great food too!!!! Oh and lets not forget their AUHMAZING HOMEMADE SALSA......DUHLICIOUS!!!!!!!! My boyfriend and I were lucky enough to buy one of their last jars! So good!!
author: Caitlin A.

description:
Most amazing place for breakfast anywhere, ever!  I had the pancake special which was sour cream lemon poppyseed pancakes with lemon curd. This pancake was so absolutely amazing!  It was so delicate and the lemon curd was so flavorful and delicious!  I am still talking about this pancake a week later and cannot wait to visit SF again so I can visit this little cafe once more. 

We visited Zazie after catching the sunrise at Twin Peaks (which is a must! See me 5 star review on TP as well).  

As we are not folks who live in the city, we are not used to the whole street parking and it took us quite a while to find a spot. Not too much of a walk but definitely worth it!  

We got here pretty early and only a few minute wait, but there was quite a line once we got seated so try to get in early. It is definitely worth the wait so don't be deterred by this. They have an outdoor patio in the back that looked really cute but it was a tad too chilly for me that early in the AM.  Would be great in the summer!

Highly recommend visiting Zazie!
author: Julia V.

description:
Came here for a brunch date and we had fun. Perhaps it was the fact we waited for 2 minutes, or because the ambiance was just spot on?

Regardless, Zazie is a great place to eat. I do feel that the prices are a tad high for what you get, but it's SF. What can y'do.
author: Chase L.

description:
To start your day with a sense of perfection and pure love, it doesn't get much better than ZAZIE's. The selection of dishes are done well. Scrambled eggs have that perfect just-set texture, and my favorite poached eggs with bacon are just amazing. Drink a mimosa and enjoy the high-quality taste of your brunch. I can't wait to go back.
And one more thing... Mario is a great Host!
author: Andrea D.

description: Most important thing to note:  Zazie will feel expensive to you especially if you are of limited means.  Put it first in your mind that you are paying a living wage to everyone that works there, even the dishwasher and bus boy! (or girl).  The food is good, really good. What I find wonderful is that the employees have paid benefits, sick leave, and a 401K, just like I do.  Equality makes me feel better about spending a lot.  These are things that most restaurants do not have.  The tip is included, so I can have as much wine as I want and will not have to worry about calculating a tip.  The prices are very similar to what we paid in Australia when we went out.  They too pay a living wage.  Given all this, imagine eating food that is well prepared in a chic ambiance with not too long a wait.  I usually go to Zazie's during off-peak times.  Either early or late.  So, I never suffer like a lot of people do with a terribly long wait.  My favorite dish is the Lamb tagine at dinner.  I have had the beef stew and found it rich and savory with tender pieces of beef.  I haven't had a thing here that I did not like.  Save room for dessert.  And try not to eat too much bread because you will get too full.  During the week they have 1 night where you can bring your well-behaved dog to dinner and another night where there is no corkage.  Plus, the service is very attentive and friendly.  I love this place.
author: Yoko O.

description:
Really delicious spot! I've been here for brunch and dinner a few times and I feel like it's hit or miss. Sometimes I ABSOLUTELY LOVE everything I have, and then other times I feel like it's just mediocre. Overall it's never bad though, so I still give it 4 starts. Ideally it'd be a 3.5 star though.

If you have the option to eat out on the back porch on a warm night - DO IT. I love that space.
author: Bianca E.

description:
Items selected:

Sarah Jane's Pancake Flight - Buttermilk, Gingerbread with Bosc Pears, Stone Ground Cornmeal "Miracle" Pancakes with Lemon Curd

French Toast Tahiti: Orange Cinnamon Challah Stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts

Unable to resist the early morning people watching of Haight-Ashbury during a trip to San Francisco an early Wednesday breakfast led me to Zazie, a small Cali-French bistro with high ceilings, friendly service, and most importantly a well culled menu of signature breakfast and brunch staples including both the oft raved Tahiti French Toast and three types of pancakes - all of which would find their way into an admittedly gluttonous carb-fest for one.  Beginning first with the pancakes, the batter for which is sold on site, it would be hard to decide whether the Gingerbread or Cornmeal option was better but with maple syrup, pears, and lemon curd all accounted for the margin was slim and all were delicious with the texture of the cornmeal cakes toothsome yet light, an achievement not commonly achieved.  Moving next to the French toast it should seem obvious to anyone that a dish with bruleed bananas, candied walnuts, and maple syrup would be delicious but what really set this toast apart was actually the subtle hints of citrus, an unexpected twist that made the entire dish taste slightly tropical and not as overwhelmingly sweet as one might think.
author: Michael U.

description:
So, Zazie - really close to my house and a neighborhood favorite. An integral and fun part of Cole Valley. 

For brunch, there is a line that spills into the street all morning. You can wait hours before getting a table. Here's the thing - I think their brunch is overrated. I had an omelette and my friend had french toast and both were just OK. I was surprised given how packed this place gets during brunch. I wouldn't really recommend this place for brunch at all. 

That said, dinner is AMAZING. The food is delicious, the menu enticing and the wait staff excellent. They have an awesome special on Tuesday nights where you can bring your own bottle of wine. 

Best of all, they have one of the best patios in the city. Great heat lamps. Seculded and romantic. Highly, highly recommended for date nights or a fun night out with friends. During the weekdays, it's perfect if it's hot out or you want to grab lunch with a friend who is visiting from out of town.
author: Kane R.

description: The blt is phenomenal. I always want to try something different here because everything on the menu sounds so good- but I keep going back to the blt! And the outdoor patio out back is so cute! A must do on any visit to SF. The only tough part is the wait- especially when you're starving- but it's worth it!
author: amanda b.

description: Excellent food and service! Ordered the gingerbread pancake, poached eggs and a cappuccino. We sat on the back patio which us absolutely lovely.
author: Tisha N.

description: Everytime I have gone there has always been a line, but it is for a reason. Their brunch menu as well as lunch menu are to die for. I ordered the Zazie's niman burger which I believe now is my favorite. I've also had their poached eggs, french toast, and pancakes which I also find so tasty. I would not order their mimosas again. Also great service especially since there is no tip.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
The atmosphere here is casual and welcoming
The back patio is great on warmer days
Mussels always good
Chocolate dessert is heaven
It is pretty kid friendly.
author: Gabriele P.

description:
First time at Zazie's and I was very excited. Came around 11 on a Friday, no wait - 1st thought- awesome! 

We sat outside. At first I was a bit nervous seeing that it was a cool, cloudy day, but they had hearing lamps on blast. 

The bf and I ordered breakfast. We got a mango mimosa and regular mimosa. He got the 2 eggs with sausage. I got the Alberto Benedict and we shared a French toast. All in all, it was good, but nothing too special I thought. I'm a huge breakfast lover and I found this meal satisfactory. 

Oh yeah, potatoes were a bit burnt.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I loooove Zazie. If the line wasn't so ghastly long all the time, I'd surely show up every weekend. But the way I like to do Zazie is on weekdays, if I'm about to leave town and skip work that morning.

Zazie does fabulous, high-quality brunch with excellent service and consistently delicious plates. From my experience, the pancakes and french toast are where it's at. That said, no matter what I order I'm always extremely content as I stroll out the door. 

If you do find yourself committed to waiting in line on the weekend, I'd suggest grabbing a coffee (and a deep breath) and enjoying the adorable neighborhood, brimming with well-groomed dogs and well-dressed toddlers. Depending on how hungover you are, it just might warm your heart. ;)
author: Meredith C.

description:
Favorite breakfast place in San Fran!
Went on a Monday morning in the rain and it was packed with a 20 minute wait... but well worth it.
They even brought out coffee for all those waiting to help themselves.
Huge flavors come out of this tiny kitchen.
Outstanding French toast and pancakes, that were made even yummier by topping them with their homemade jam.
There seems to be something special about each item.
The chicken sausage and bacon had so much flavor... they made the meal over the top delish and are a must order!
Can't wait to come back!
author: Charley C.

description: By far our favorite breakfast place.  This is almost a weekly treat for us.  The staff knows us by name.  Everything I've had on the menu is delicious.  My son who is 3 years old, calls it "Pancake Zazie", that is what he has when we go there.
author: Alex A.

description:
What a cute cute place for brunch!

One sunday morning, my lucky parking karma allowed me to park literally outside the restaurant (literally) which I was very happy about.  This was a good start.  (However please note parking in the area is generally DIFFICULT so you should allow at least 15 extra minutes to look for parking if you are coming here for a meal).

My friend arrived at the restaurant 15 minutes prior so we just had to wait another 15 minutes to be seated.  The line on a Sunday morning at 11:30 was long.  There were a lot of people waiting! (always a good sign)

Menu looked extensive.  My friend said that their buttermilk pancakes was really good.  So we ordered this to share.  (cos Im' not a fat of eating just carbs for a meal but still enjoy pancakes as a taster.)

I was looking at the menu trying to decide and when asked what she was having and she said La Mer (eggs benedict with crab meat).  Do I need to look further? That's what I was gonna have.

She also said that their buttermilk pancake was really good so we decided to share one.  (I never order pancakes as a main - it's carb, and more carb without any protein!)

We got seated at their heated porch at the back of the restaurant.  It was like a little sanctuary in the middle of SF. Sooooo cute! 

It wasn't as noisy as the inside of the restaurant and on a beautiful day I was just happy sitting there.

Food was exceptionally tasty.  Service was very pleasant. 

Definitely coming back! 

Oh and the line was still as long if not longer when we left at 1:30pm.   

Advice: Get there early and put your name down.  Big groups may  have a harder time being seated.
author: Sujan H.

description: Delish. Sit in the back patio if it is a nice day. Bread pudding pancakes will make you lose your shit. They have amazing eggs Benedict as well. The wait can take a while so be smart about it and get a beer or cocktail next door.
author: Peter S.

description:
I came here beacuse it had a lot of reviews. But I was annoyed when I put my name in line and walked to the car to put more money in the meter, came back and the guy had already called my name. When I told him I had arrived, he said another 10 minutes and then took some other people in. FIRST RED FLAG. Turns out the put my name at the end of the list! WHO DOES THAT?! If he had said from the beginning we will take you shortly, I would have gone to the car after we'd been seated. 

There were a lot of things to order, and boy did we order a lot. However, I didn't like the regular coffee. My friend saw everyone ordering the coffee cake and she was willing to spend an extra few bucks to try it. It wasn't good, we had two bites and left the rest. Someone eye'd it asking how it tasted, but it looked better than it tasted.

Don't be fooled by all the reviews!
author: Ameera D.

description:
Zazie has the best weekend brunch in town as evidenced by hour plus long lines (so don't tell anyone else) with patrons itching for one of their savory egg dishes. My favorite is the Monaco Eggs Benedict. Also on par is the Challah French Toast. 

Pro Tip, if you get there past 11am for brunch with more than 2 people than you might as well start planning your meal somewhere else.
author: Patrick H.

description: OMG this place is amazing.  I don't think I've come across an amazing breakfast place in a while.  We were up early so headed over at 8am (this never happens).  So no waiting for us.  We were seated really fast and ordered the french toast, the gingerbread pancakes, and the poached egg benedict with crab.  The pancakes had a great flavor and the french toast was very caramelized (too sweet for me at this hour).  The benedict on the other hand was amazing- perfectly cooked egg, and great combination of flavors, plus LOVE that they have roasted garlic with the potatoes.
author: Tiffany C.

description: We went here on a Thursday morning, the waiting is short, the environment is really good. It is an above average brunch store, everything is pretty good, but won't make you feel surprised. Safe choice
author: Sunny J.

description: Still love the huge, fully enclosed cloves of garlic that come with your home fries. The fries themselves aren't as crispy as they used to be, but man do they hit the spot. So, unfortunately, the secret's been out for over a year, and if you used to be a Zazie frequent flier, you are now dealing with over an hour's wait. Your two options are then: get here incredibly early or around 2:30pm because they close for brunch service at 3. All egg dishes are fantastic here, but I particularly enjoy any they do with bacon because it's always thick and crispy. But really, you're shooting for either a fat miracle pancake or the gingerbread one. So fluffy, so airy, and the lemon curd. Bomb. Either of those will be enough to fill you up, and if you're really hungry, grab a stack of 2, but honestly, everything is good here. Staff is always super attentive, though they get your order wrong kind of often. They're really friendly though and fix things quickly. Outside tables are for swooping (first come, first served), and they no longer charge for gratuity, so you'll see a slight mark-up on their food.
author: Danny C.

description:
PEDESTRIAN.

Split two dishes: Mexican scramble and crab benedict. 

Scramble was fluffy and the fresh tomato/onion was a nice touch. Chorizio lacked flavor and any real kick. Home fries were standard fare, also included toast 6/10

Benedict was a disappointment, as I am a huge fan of them. Zazie had a nicely poached egg, soft and runny yolk which I enjoyed. But the whole point of benedict is to have a rich creamy Hollandaise, which Zazie did not deliver. Minimum amount of sauce for me to not complain but definitely skimped. Sauce itself was thin and bland. More zesty than usual but I had to really strain to experience the flavor. Muffin on the bottom was average, nothing special. Crab was decent. Fresh but again nothing special. It was just there. Didn't stand out or enhance the experience. Home fries were standard fare 5/10

The restaurant has a very quaint feel which I enjoyed. More mom and pop than uber trendy modern and it works. The staff was friendly and attentive. Also, I commend their progressive no tip policy. 

Brunch in the city has been tainted with high prices and average food, Zazie is a prime example. San Francisco is an expensive city, trust me I get it. Food here is decent, I just really question how places get away with charging $50 dollars for 5 eggs, potatoes, and coffee (really think about what you are actually paying for). Yelp has over-hyped this place, as it should rated on a whole at around 3 stars. I am practical minded and appreciate value which this place does not have. For this price range I expect an above average (not even spectacular) meal. If this is on your brunch/benedict list (as it was for mine for a couple years) do yourself a favor and skip it. Kitchen story, mission beach cafe, Stacks (my personal fav) are far superior.

Have a great day
author: Michael G.

description: Zazie is one among the many hot brunch spots in San Francisco, always with a line out the door during weekend mornings. My boyfriend and I luckily snagged one of the first come first serve tables outside and was able to avoid the wait. Zazie's brunch has a French feel to it, with classic brunch items as well as more traditional French dishes like croque monsieurs. To get a good mix of sweet and savory, we ordered the egg special of the day, which was a benedict with asparagus and prosciutto. Although on the softer side, I loved the potatoes that came with it, especially the garlicky and peppery char on the outside. The eggs were perfectly cooked and the asparagus and prosciutto was a unique addition. The hollandaise wasn't too heavy, but I would've preferred a thicker English muffin. We also had the griddle flight, featuring one piece of French toast, one buttermilk pancake, and one gingerbread pancake. The highlight of this dish is definitely the gingerbread pancake! It's doughy and almost cakey, with just the right touch of gingerbread flavor. The French toast and the buttermilk pancake were pretty standard, so I'd just go with ordering the gingerbread pancakes on their own. Overall it was a delicious meal, but definitely on the pricier side of the already expensive brunch choices in the city.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Hands down, one of the best brunch places in the city.  The food is absolutely delicious.  They have amazing breakfast specials with the freshest ingredients.  The last time I visited, I was set on a specific order even before getting seated, but I changed my mind last minute due to the tempting special: Meyer lemon pancakes.  

To add to the extraordinary food, they have the most unique alcoholic drinks for brunch. I highly suggest ordering  Le Metro which is infused with lavender, an awesome start to weekend mornings.  Parking may be a drag and the wait is usually at least 40 minutes on a Saturday or Sunday for brunch.  However, it is worth the wait.  They also call your name if you decide to drink at the bar next door.  Also, you can kill time wandering around some of the cute lotion boutiques and health stores surrounding Zazie.

Must try in the morning:

La Mer: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados 
(I enjoy that you have the option to choose the amount of poach eggs you prefer.)

and for the sweet-tooth's out there...

Sarah Jane's Griddle Flight: a sampler sized portion- 1 buttermilk, 1 gingerbread, 1 French Toast
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
I first discovered Zazie in a Runner's World article asking world class runners where to go for the best post marathon carbo recovery. Ryan Hall, American wunderkid marathoner and Stanford alum, recommended Zazie as the spot to hit up after spending several hours running the hills of San Francisco. I figure any guy who runs 26.2 miles for a living has to know his carbs and quickly put Zazie on list of places to visit. Fast forward to a couple of years later, here I am living in San Francisco and Zazie has become one of my favorite brunch spots.

The best part of the menu, many dishes are a la carte allowing you to choose exactly the size you want, 1/2/3 pancakes, eggs, french toast allow infinite customization for your brunch table. I'm a huge fan of the Gingerbread pancakes topped perfectly with lemon curd and bosc pears. I don't even want to touch these things with syrup as I think they're perfect just the way they're served.
author: Stephen S.

description:
It's not easy for me to find a Brunch place that I love. So far my favorite would probably be Cafe Aquarius in Emeryville, or Mama's in North Beach. But man, this place might have to replace Mama's long wait every weekend morning. 

I arrived at Zazie's at around noon, found street parking right across the street, SCORE! Hubby and I signed our names on the list, there was a sign on the door that says "Do not ask how long the wait is." Alrighty, we don't want to get on their bad side already. After about 20 minutes of a wait and a big cup of latte, we were seated in the back on the patio. Let me tell you how much I regretted not bringing a thicker jacket ... but fortunately they turned on the heater, +1 point for Zazie! The waiter brought us another cup of latte while we ordered. 

Pancakes were just enough fluff, poached egg were just runny enough, and my scrambled egg was made to perfection. 

Did I mention they have grape fruit mimosas?
author: Ximeng W.

description:
The girls and I had breakfast a few weeks ago.  We didn't have to wait long and the place was packed.  The hostess gave us seats in their outdoor patio as soon as our entire party arrived.  It was a nice foggy SF day so we were able to seat under their heat lamps and enjoy the typical SF day.  

I ordered their crab benedict which was a bit pricey but upon taking a bite of the food, I knew that it was worth the extra few dollars I was spending.  I also enjoyed their mimosa which was delicious and had a different twist on it.   They used a different type of juice instead of the usual orange juice which made it a bit sweeter. 

Parking can be a bit difficult and most of it is metered.  Make sure you bring plenty of quarters to feed the meter and most of all have fun and enjoy the food.
author: Christine P.

description:
My friend and I came over after walking a few feet away from the 43 Muni bus stop to see that there were groups of max 4 people standing outside. This was 2PM on a Friday, and half an hour before closing! We were seated within 10 minutes. Thank you, Yelpers, for the advice about not bringing parties larger than 4 people!

I got the Eggs Divorce w/ 2 eggs for $12 and my friend a single Gingerbread pancake topped with lemon sauce and half a pear. My friend was definitely happy with the single pancake, considering how large and thick it was! My Eggs Divorce was delicious, but as it got colder, I noticed how very salty it was. My friend's pancake was moist, but also very sweet. All in all, our brunch was still very delicious and I still miss the taste in my mouth.

Service was very pleasant, though I wonder if they generally don't refill their water bottles.

They charge $1.25 per person for full benefits for their employees, so our bill came out to be around $27.
author: Addy Y.

description:
Still haven't gotten around to getting enough patience to wait for brunch, but came for dinner one night a couple of weeks ago. 

Got the prix fixe menu and started with the mussels. I was pleasantly surprised with how many mussels we got for an appetizer. It was basically half the size of a meal portion. Got the trout for my main course and liked how well it was cooked. Maybe will go for the duck next time though, as French food tend to be lighter on the salt and spices and I prefer my fish to be more flavorful. Finished with a cobbler for dessert, which was good but not spectacular. 

The place is cute and little, and on Monday nights they allow you to bring your dog and dine in the back patio. It's charming but without any frills. And for those who aren't so charmed by the service, it's just the European way, so don't expect to be coddled to death like the waitress at your neighborhood diner. I personally like being left to my meal.
author: Rowena L.

description:
After living in San Francisco for over 10 years I had never had the opportunity to eat at Zazie.  I was always intimidated by the line of people and simply never went.  

I moved to NY in 2008 and last year was my first return visit to my love, San Francisco and we were staying on Stanyan and Waller.  

Last year we ate at Zazie 3 times in one week, twice for breakfast and once for lunch each meal exquisite.  The dungeness crab Benedict was so amazing I had it twice in 2 days.  The crisp English muffin with mounds of delicious crab meat with 2 perfectly cooked eggs and the most delicious lemony hollandaise was like heaven.  The crispy potatoes with garlic cloves- BOMB.  Wow.  And for $22 not cheap.

This year we came back for breakfast with 2 friends.  We arrived last week one morning in the rain and waited under the awning for our names to be called.  With much anticipation I ordered my go to breakfast and raved to my friends about the amazing potatoes, etc.  

Well....first this place was very busy, like any other day I'd imagine.  

Our 4 top was 2, 2 tops pushed together next to the hutch up front.  

Service was fine.  My latte was bomb. My breakfast, completely mediocre.  I was saddened by the looks of the pale potatoes on each of our plates. I apologized before we even took a bite telling our friends they were not this way last time.

My crab meat Benedict was mealy.  The English muffin soggy.  The wonderful lemony sauce, cold!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Shit.  I wanted to send it back but we were in discussion of how amazing our marriage was the day before.

The potatoes could have saved my dish but they were pale, no brown and the garlic cloves raw.

Next year we will find a new place for breakfast.  I guess Zazie can't keep up with consistency which was the ONLY reason I came back last year 3 times. 

Boo.
author: James S.

description:
Woww, this was really one of the best brunches I have had in a long time! You know it's good when it is packed with people. We came Memorial Day for brunch with a party of six. The wait was pretty long, around 45 minutes, so we just hung around, got some coffee @ Tully's, and checked out the local stores. 

The service was pleasantly wonderful throughout, something surprising to me since they were so packed! They came by with refills on coffee and water without us asking. Out of everything we ordered, I tried:

- French Toast Tahiti: I'm not a fan of roasted banana but I didn't mind eating it with this french toast! I guess it just goes to show you how delicious it was. The french toast had crispy, crunchy edges and was soft and moist inside. Yum.
- Croque Madame: I had a bite of this and it was awesome. The Gruyère was oozing out of the sandwich and the egg on top was the finishing touch. 
- New York (scrambled egg): the smoked salmon with egg was soo delish and the cream cheese was an unexpected yummy surprise. Super creamy and fresh!
- Florentine (poached egg): the mushrooms and spinach in the muffin had great flavor and their hollandaise sauce was light and lemony. I was trying to soak everything, especially the poached eggs, in my biscuit!

I also love that you can order one, two, or three slices of toast or egg, because it becomes so much easier to accommodate those who eat more or less. I didn't check out the restaurant but I saw that there was a patio outback. 

FIVE is my favorite brunch spot across the bay, and Zazie is now my favorite brunch in SF. Can't wait to come back and try it again outside!
author: Allison S.

description:
Few places around the world can match the food or atmosphere.   Deliciousness,  proper service,  kind caring and perceptive.   Consistent,  warm and comfortable.  

Date or family time, I love food and I love it here!
author: Kai W.

description: Holy coffee cake-- this brunch spot is as good as it gets! Seriously, though, the lemon curd-filled coffee cake is amaze balls and you must try it! As most popular brunch spots go, there is a healthy wait along the sidewalk, but not unreasonable. The line actually goes fairly quickly as our wait was only about 40 minutes and our waiter was prompt to get our coffee and mimosa orders as soon as we sat down. Obviously the coffee cake was amazing, but the french toast and smoked salmon benedict were also equally impressive! This place takes a nod from the french, so naturally the espresso is also tasty. Also, mimosas are not limited to orange juice here, so take your pick of elderflower, grapefruit, black currant, or pineapple. You can easily find a spot along the street within just 2-3 blocks and then promptly find the list near the doorway, add your name, and get ready to ravenously salivate as you anticipate the brunch that will make your morning! If you can, get a spot on the back patio (it's a little tight back there, so don't do it if you can't maneuver around well!), which is enclosed by some cute garden vines and is well-shaded by adjustable awnings.
author: Linnea T.

description:
Nommy in my tummy!

I grew up around this area as a kid and never noticed this place until the other day! I can't believe I've been missing out all these years! Never again! I'm coming back for more! 

Nestled in a quiet little neighborhood of Cole Valley this place sure packs in a punch. A great place for a nice brunch/lunch with about 3 people max. This place is small so if you're planning to bring lots of guests don't! They won't fit and they wouldn't enjoy the food as a large group. Food here is meant to be enjoyed by you and another friend or two. But if you must bring lots of people.. I can't stop you. It's just a suggestion after all (: Anyway, back to the food. Yum! 

I ordered a Tuna sandwich and it was tender and not over done! Finally! Great combination of flavors with what looks like a bed of salad right in your sandwich. The whole meal was as satisfying as it was delicious. This place has not seen the last of me until I've tried everything on the menu. Challenge accepted. Until we meet again Zazie!
author: Amy C.

description: We had the Albert. The Tahiti french toast, regular French toast, miracle pancakes, the Mexico and we had mimosas. Everything was amazing  I am so glad to have found this spot. We sat on he back patio which  is shaded and cool.
author: Teresa E.

description:
So, service is not the main focus for this place. Food is on the decent side, nothing that really will cause me to refer my friends over about.

We ordered the Croque Madame (2/5) which is their Croque Monsieur with a sunny side up egg on top. Regular white toast, ham was ok, egg, overall just a ham and egg sandwich that I could've made at home.

Benedict (1/5) lacked sauce, was like a drizzle compared to what I'm usually used to. It gives me the impression that they're being cheap.

French toast was decent.

Our server is the guy with glasses, poor attitude, slow service, very dry personality and seemingly blind. Passed by our table multiple times, we ordered coffee and usually you'd expect a waiter to notice an empty cup. When asked for sugar, he looked at our tray and said, are those used and starts to grab from our used sugar packs. Are you really that lazy to grab more? I had to grab packs from tables beside us because our waiter was too "busy" to grab sugar for us. We asked for extra cream too, 10min later one of the busboys came by and grabbed some for us. Guess that's why they add in the $1.25 per person rule on their menu, no one would tip such a poor service. 

Either way, food was decent, but I think I'd stick to Mama's or Butler and the Chef for much better tasting food and better service!
author: Dan Y.

description: Great staff, great food, long wait. Great ambiance. My favorite was the citron presse - you essentially mix your own lemonade at the table.
author: Cayla C.

description: Got here at 2pm and only waited 30 minutes for a table of 4. Not bad for late late late brunch in SF. Fantastic service despite being seated 30 minutes before closing. Asked for water, extra napkins and forks and all were received in minutes. My $11 mimosa was a tad small but very tasty. Friends got Challa French toast, miracle pancakes, the New York style eggs and Geneviève style eggs. Everyone loved their food. I got the Pierre Noir, the bacon was crispy and the eggs were good. My friend ordered a HUGE mocha, but it lacked a richness in chocolate, but overall really great. Loved the heated patio!
author: Kristina R.

description:
People go crazie for Zazie ;)

Came here with some friends the other day for some Sunday morning brunch. I highly recommend coming in around 9 am, anything later than 10 am and you might be waiting a mighty long time especially for larger groups. We waited around half an hour or so. 

Our waitress was extremely friendly and service was very prompt. I was very impressed at how personable she was and they definitely deserve an extra star for that. 

For drinks, I had their chai latte which was served in a small bowl. I like my chai a little spicier and this was more on the milky side, not my favorite but quite nice to look at. 
I shared two dishes with my boyfriend so that we could try multiple things at once:
- Poached Eggs with Prosciutto and Asparagus (forgot the name however it was on their specials menu): overall tasty however the poached eggs were very varied in terms of how they were cooked, one of them was very firm and another was very runny, I like my poached eggs in the middle. 
- Cornmeal Pancakes (to substitute the Miracle Pancakes) with fresh fruit and lemon sauce. This was my FAVORITE part of the meal, it was very similar to cornbread but in pancake form, the flavors were well balanced and I wish I had a stack of 10 :) 

Overall good flavors, a bit on the pricy side, however many innovative flavors. Opt for the cornmeal pancakes :O quite yummy.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description: My only complaint is they ran out of the miracle pancakes (I think that's what they're called) with ricotta cheese. But the ginger pancakes with pear was delicious! We got a table outside pretty quickly on arrival, and the wait staff were all so courteous. It was an experience I'm returning for.
author: Amy L.

description:
Yeah the wait is CRAZY on the weekend, but that's why I only come in on an early weekday morning. The perks of living nearby I guess. 

IF YOU GET CRANKY WHEN YOU'RE HUNGRY AND WAITING FOR FOOD, DO NOT COME HERE ON A WEEKEND. Just don't. 

*I'm looking at YOU--person who dared to give Zazie 2 stars*

Anyway, I was just talking to my bf about how he's too nice on restaurant reviews--just throwing 5 stars to any old place-- and I told him that it takes a REALLY legit place for me to give them 5 stars. Then he asked me what place I considered to deserve such a great rating, and the first place that came to mind was Zazie!

The food is always so DAMN good and them pancakes are the best I've ever had. My go-to order is the "Un-Deux-Trois", and my bf likes the Tahiti French Toast. That raspberry jam is also serious business, sometimes we like to order a little baguette so that we can eat up some jam before our food :)

I'm telling you, they're stirring up some magic in that little kitchen.
author: Brisa D.

description:
Oh my gosh, it's every breakfast lover's dream come true. At Zazie, I truly felt like I was swept away to a little piece of France within the hustle and bustle of the city. 

My one amigo and I experienced about a 15 minute wait time on a Saturday afternoon. There's a sign-up sheet in front of the restaurant to write down your name, and the paper also thoroughly explains how long you can expect the wait time to be. We opted for the patio or inside option, whichever was faster. However, this is one restaurant where I would actually recommend sitting outside. It's so GREEN, and with heat lamps you will still be comfortable even on a chilly San Francisco afternoon. 

The tables in the FRONT are first come, first serve. I guess sit there if you don't have a lot of time on your hands? But why you would choose to rush through an experience at Zazie is beyond me. 

Onto the food. Being in a breakfast mood, I ordered the Mexico scrambled eggs, which also came with a salad and toast for around $13. The scrambled eggs were perfectly seasoned that complimented the chorizo inside it. I heard their gingerbread pancakes are good but I'd definitely recommend the Mexico scrambled eggs if you're looking for something on the lighter side!

Our waitress was exceptionally smiley and seemed like she truly enjoyed what she was doing. AND she pointed out that she too had the same spelling of Jeanine, which I've yet to come cross. Who knew. 

However, one star off for that weird bathroom situation! It's an itty bitty room with nowhere to keep your purse or other belongings and right next to the kitchen/walkway. A little unsettling. Other than that....

Ambiance: 5...Bienvenue mes amis.  
Service: 5...Nothing better than people who love what they do and show you too!
Taste: 5...Perfectly spicy and savory in the brunch-time hours. 
Value/Price: 5...Standard restaurant price for food that is wayyy above the standard.
author: Jeanine W.

description: This is a rating for dinner. Even though this spot is more popular , the Yelp listing as brunch and lunch is not totally accurate . I love Zazie for dinner because you get amazing French fare without having to wait in line. The server told us they implemented a profit share / healthcare program that replaced tipping about 7 months ago . The service was great and the staff seems to really care about the restaurant and the customers. We had the French onion soup and the coq au vin. Both were excellent !
author: Tucker s.

description: Cute little spot. Hubby took me here for brunch during the week. Lovely ambiance , little cozy garden patio. Delicious! Genevieve scramble, love that it came with avocados :) Hubby ordered their French toast with orange cinnamon batter . We were very pleased.
author: Martha R.

description: Came here for a late brunch on my birthday and cannot complain about a single thing. From the home fries to the French toast it was all delicious!
author: Michael S.

description: Cute set up. Polite employees. Quality food at a fair price. The Greece scramble was savory and filling. Can't go wrong with any of the French toast it melts on your tongue.
author: Brittany W.

description:
Droppin a 5-bomber on this baby. This local Cole Valley brunch spot has over the top word of mouth advertising, so if you are paying a marketing firm you might throttle back because your business, service, and edibles are spot on.

A friend of mine, let's call her Lindsay, said that I must try out Zazie when I told her I was up for brunch. It was a bit of a hike from Russian Hill but totally worth it. I'm a huge nerd, so getting to use their new reservation system was awesome. A well connected set of iPads lets you enter your names and see in real  time where you are on the list. It only took us about 45 minute to get a patio table (it was gorgeous outside). We went nextdoor to Finnegans Wake to meet some neighbors while we waited.

When it was time to be seated someone at Zazie's actually came over into Finnegans Wake to let us know our table was ready... talk about freaking service. We sat next to two awesome groups of people and began to order.

This place has the most extensive mimosa list I have ever seen. Lindsay got the "Elderflower" mimosa, I got the "Cole Valley" mimosa, I would recommend the Elderflower. Lindsay got a mushroom scramble, and I got eggs florentine, both were delicious. I'm definitely going back on a sunny day and look forward to trying out new items. I heard a side of french toast is the way to go, but didn't need the sugar buzz.
author: Jason M.

description: I've been to zazies quarter dozen times. Food never disappoints. Service could be friendlier but fast and efficient. Normally 45-60 min wait times so snack before heading out lol. Prices are kind of high and adds up quick which is probably what's keeping me away for the most part.
author: Zainab J.

description: This is the second time I've been here and haven't been disappointed yet. Everything on the menu that I've tried has been awesome. I got the crabmeat eggs Benedict last time which was probably one of the best eggs Benedict I've ever had. The lemon hollandaise sauce really makes the dish and the eggs are perfectly pouched. This time I tried the New York scrambled eggs with smoked salmon, green onions and cream cheese. Awesome. It came with home fries and toast. The pancakes and French toast are never a disappointment either. Be prepared to wait awhile if you go on the weekend. They also have a nice little heated patio in the back.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 3
Service: 3

Came here on a Sunday brunch date around noon. No reservations for brunch, so we showed up, put our names down, and waited about 40 min before being seated.

1. Orange mimosa, 8
~Okay. It's a mimosa.

2. Poached eggs La Mer: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados 12/ 19/ 24
~Really good. We opted for 3 eggs, and it was delicious. Perfectly poached eggs, fresh crab, and yummy avocado to complement. Side salad was okay.

3. Side of home fries
~Okay. Came with cooked whole cloves of garlic. Some of the fries were burnt, and overall it was too oily and not crispy enough.

4. French Toast Tahiti: Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts 6/ 11/ 14
~Okay. We opted for 2 slices of toast, which ended up being more than we could eat. 

Service was pretty good, although our bottle of water ran empty.
author: David L.

description:
You might be intimidated by the multi-page sign-in sheet hanging by the door and the crowded sidewalk outside, but Zazie's is worth the wait. The overall Yelp rating and rave reviews should speak to the quality of the food and service, so instead I wanted to give you a few tips for eating at one of the best brunch places in SF:

1. If you get there between 9-10am or 2-3pm on weekends, the wait is usually a lot shorter.
2.Despite there being signs stating so, not a lot of people realize that the tables out front are first-come, first-served. Save yourself a 45-minute wait and make small talk with a table that's waiting for their check and and swoop in before the table's bussed. 
3. Try and put your name down for the back patio - it's a beautiful garden-like setting and not as crowded as the dining room.
4. If you're more than 10 names down on the list, you probably have at least 30 minutes; go get a Bloody Mary at Finnegan's Wake next door.
5. Order the eggs benedict. Better yet, one of you get La Trop and one of you get Le Mer and share.
6. If more than three of are getting mimosas, it's more fun to get a bottle of champagne and a couple little pitchers of juice and build your own.
7. If you're craving it and don't feel like waiting in line, call in a take-out order. (But add 5 minutes to the time they say it'll be ready, or go get a coffee at Peet's next door.) Bring a shopping bag with handles.

Happy Brunching!
author: Jon M.

description:
I didn't have much hope for this place since I thought we got here so late (2pm when they close at 3pm on weekends) and I just didn't know since the list was so long if we'd even be able to make it in the door.

We did make it in the store, and then swiftly out the backdoor to the cutesy patio out back at Zazie. Of course, this was less preferred by other patrons since it was quite quite cold that day but we were hungry and frankly could care less since they had heat lamps outside anyway.

We ordered everything on the menu, as always. Whenever I eat brunch, I tend to get really greedy. Like ... the kind where you want eggs, but ALSO pancakes, but the french toast looks good too, and the home made jam totally needs a side of wheat toast even though it didn't come with my dish ... kind of greedy. So we proceeded to be greedy and ordered to our stomachs' content. And boy was it good.

Everything was delicious, their poached eggs are five stars all around, since you can get them in one, two and three egg varieties. I don't even like onions and capers but the St. Trop was so yummy! Their stuffed french toast tahiti was also well balanced and not too sweet, not soggy and so well made with perfectly toasted bananas on top. The bf got a chicken sandwich which I am usually against when we are talking brunch but it was sooo flavorful! 

This place is great, simply delicious and highly recommended. Wait and all.
author: Lorrie M.

description: The wait for breakfast was way too long (over a hour) and the host was letting his friends through the line without having to go on the list.  Don't go with a large group, not worth it!
author: Don M.

description: Great food and service. Full support on owner's rant regarding kids at restaurant. Without the self righteous parents bring their annoying kids there any more, the dinning experience will be even better now.
author: K T.

description:
So this place was ok.

If you're looking for the perfect breakfast cutesy setting then this is your place.

We ordered the La Mer and the pancake sampler plate. Both were just ok. I was actually not amazed by the gingerbread pancake, but it was nice to try it. 

Come here if you want to take someone out on a date or to read a book.
author: Jen W.

description: This place is a 4 Star... But only for a hole in the wall type restaurant. You can't mix this in the same category as a typical chain restaurant. This small but cozy atmosphere possess the types of food that will satisfy your taste buds! I recommend the La Mar and get "3"!!! Very tasty! The mimosa's are tasty and their virgin Bloody Mary has a little kick to it! Don't bother using the restroom!!!! Unless you can stand up and do your business, it's so small you can sit on the toilet and wash your hands at the same time! I don't like how the kitchen is directly next to thee restroom! Lucky my food didn't stink! Overall, because of the grade and quality of their food, this place gets 4 stars from me!
author: Vita L.
