description: probably the best brunch in SF as well as a really good french comfort food casual restaurant for dinner. Great wine policy. they have a corkage free tuesday which i love. reservations a must. outdoor seating which if really nice on warm evenings and of course sunny days. good service and consistent quality, one of my favorite casual places but parking is difficult so Uber or cab it.
author: John T.

description: Waaaay too hyped up. It is just an average brunch place. The gingerbread pancakes lacked flavor and were super dry. The hot chocolate tastes ( and I am 99% sure it is) like Swiss mix only too pricey. The Tahiti French toast was good but nothing to call home about. I was very disappointed ad will never go back to this place.
author: Lady S.

description: Brunch was excellent. I like that they allow you to scale the portions (you can, for example, have 1-3 eggs, 1-3 pieces of French toast, etc.). The food came out room temperature; I could not tell if that was by design or because the food sat for too long before being served.
author: Morris R.

description: Super great!  Went in a couple weeks ago had no idea this place existed.  They have patio out back with a nice atmosphere.  Friendly staff and delicious food.  This is a place where tip is included in the listed menu price.  Awesome.  Service got a little slow at the end but overall I loved it!
author: Gillian K.

description:
Went for dinner. The brunch menu seems to be the more acclaimed menu, but dinner allows for you to get a seat at the table for ages. 

The food was pretty good, but not as exceptional as the brunch sounds like in reviews. We tried out several items, the Boeuf Bourguignon stood out the most for being a great tender stew like, while the Assiette de Charcuterie was a bit lacking in variety, with not enough items to cut the saltiness of the pate and other salted items.
author: Oliver Z.

description: Brunch here isn't bad but definitely not worth waiting over an hour for. I tried the stuffed French toast and the gingerbread pancake - both were a little dry but decent. Go during the week and early in the morning if you can. We ate here on Wednesday morning around 10:30 (no wait!) and by 11 am, there was a line already amassing.
author: E H.

description:
A tasty brunch place that serves fresh, yummy food. The prices are pretty decent as well. I ordered the French Toast with fruit and my friend ordered a Croquet sandwich. The back patio is lovely with the heaters. I remember trying to go here before but it was jam packed. The menu isn't huge but there is still plenty to choose from. The secret to getting a table is to get here before they close. It's much less crowded. Yummy.

Oh and our server had a Jawbreaker tattoo (the band not the candy people)...kudos.
author: Amy J.

description:
I drove up and saw a lot of people waiting outside but there was a parking spot literally in front of the place so I thought it was meant to be. I put my name on the list and it was called surprisingly quickly.

I know I shouldn't have ordered the Tahiti Fr. toast dish because I generally don't like sweet stuff for breakfast, but I did. And even substituted real maple for the fake stuff. Thank goddess I only ordered one slice.  They give you many choices here in how much you want to eat.  The latte was delicious, BTW. Because I'm reckless I also ordered one Florentine Benedict with home fries.  I could only get halfway through the french toast but it was wonderful.  I sent back the syrup because the filling was very sweet.

The Florentine Benedict was perfect.  It came with freshly cooked spinach and the thinnest sliced portobellos I've ever seen. I even asked the server if he could find out how they did it (Mandoline? Cuisinart?) but no, it was someone with extraordinary knife skills.

I had asked the server for salad with the egg dish but then asked which of the two choices he would recommend and he immediately said, potatoes.  OMG, he was so right.  They were perfectly cooked with caramelized garlic, a lot of them, whole cloves.  They flavored the dish incredibly well.

Another good thing: they include everything in the price of the meal so you don't have to worry about the tip.
author: Pat P.

description: My #1 bunch spot. Sure you have to queue but well worth it. Awesome atmosphere great mimosas and tasty tasty menu - pretty impressive what they manage to turn out from their tiny weeny kitchen!
author: Jenna A.

description:
Gingerbread pancakes had a nice degree of fluffy. There was a nice ginger scent and taste, but I wish it could have been a little bit stronger.  The lemon curd was also delicious, but once again, I wish there was more. The pear topping was nice.  The overall taste profile was earthy, nutty, and not too sweet. I'm not a huge fan of sugary sweets, so this was perfect.

The Challah French Toast had a nice subtle taste of orange and cinnamon, but it was also salty at the same time. I definitely preferred the gingerbread pancakes more.

The La Mer eggs benedict was pretty generous with the dungeness crab, justifiably so, especially since one egg was $12, and two were $19.  

Overall yum and worth coming back! I enjoyed the cutsey (yet eclectic) French bistro feel.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Their food DELICIOUS, their staff are very friendly, and it is a no-tip establishment. It's EXTREMELY busy for brunch on the weekends. Be prepared to wait a while, have an unexpected conversation with a friendly fellow-prospective-bruncher, and be offered a coffee, mimosa, or a chair (he notices the needs of people waiting outside) by the awesome host, Pedro. Also, no matter how busy it is, if you are a return customer, the staff remember you.
author: Rivkele F.

description: Overrated. Overprice regular brunch food. Not recommended. I was charged $28 for 5 pieces of lobster and poached eggs.
author: Nahiris B.

description:
Oh, Zazie. This is hands down my favorite place to eat on San Francisco. It's so quaint and beautiful. The porch area is my favorite area to sit. They give you blankets even! 

Every time I go I order the raviolis, and my bf and I always share the mac and cheese. It is off the chain! There is a host there, unfortunately I do not know his name (he wears glasses) but my bf and I love him so much. He is always so pleasant, kind and accommodating. The service is always great all around. We've had the same server a couple of times, he's very pleasant and prompt as well. Although I hope the host will have the opportunity to serve at Zazie as well- he would be fantastic. 

This restaurant is so magical. Wonderful place for a date night, or to catch up with your girlfriends. I highly recommend it. :-)
author: Enissa M.

description: This place is my neighbourhood fave. Just beware of the special occassion menus as they get pricey
author: Belinda W.

description: Delicious brunch of poached eggs, hollandaise, avocado, bacon, and home fries. Excellent service. Prices are high (mine with a cappuccino came to $24), but that's because of the quality and service, AND that they pay all their servers a livable wage. No tips are accepted! I like it.
author: Christopher B.

description:
Had a lovely brunch on a Sunday afternoon with some of my fave boys. The wait was a little long, but with a bajillion Yelp reviews, I expect nothing else from Zazie. We put our name down and killed time by walking around. By the time we were seated, I was starved and did not mind the splattered ketchup that was on the bench. We sat in the patio in the back and it was like heaven because the sun decided to pay us a visit. Our server was so pretty and gave us good suggestions. We settled on grapefruit mimosas, gingerbread pancakes, and several of the poached egg dishes.

I ordered the Monaco poached eggs (1 egg for $9) with prosciutto and tomatoes served with a side of home fries. Egg was perfectly poached just the way I like it and the prosciutto and tomato made the perfect combo. I also shared the gingerbread pancakes (1 pancake for $6), which was SOOO YUMMAY! It was like eating a moist cake that was not too sweet and wasn't too strong on the ginger. The lemon curd and pears on top made the pancakes 10 times better! I didn't even really need syrup, I just spread the curd around with a little butter and I was satisfied. The pancake was so huge, just one was enough for all of us to split.

After finishing the meal, I was ready for a nap. I don't know if it was the mimosas or if it was food coma, but all I know was that my tummy was satisfied. I can't wait to go back!!
author: Nicole M.

description: Delicious breakfast spot. Came here during the week with my fiancée while vacationing in the area. There was no wait since we sat outside but I could see how it can get very busy. Service was good. Everything is a little pricier since gratuity is included and tipping is not allowed, but it makes sense and was well worth it.
author: Katelin Q.

description:
Wow! OMG....sooooooooo goooooooooooooood! I came here with my friend for brunch on Easter and despite the wait which was a little intimidating but we weren't backing down! it was a good 15 min wait with about 8 parties ahead of us. The place may look small but don't be fooled. There is a patio in the back that seats a bunch of people. We had mango mimosa's that were delicious! 
 
Their menu and menu setup is pretty accommodating.  You can order a piece of pancake or order a full plate. Me and my friend decided to order a few plates each and share which was an awesome idea as there were so much good food to choose from.  We shared the Gingerbread Pancakes, French Toast Tahiti, Pierre Noir, and the Valence. They were all so good, we didn't have the heart to name our favorite. Along with our food we enjoyed Mango Mimosa's and some water served in those cork top bottles...i love those things, it adds a nice touch.

The young lady who helped us was totally kewl and wore shades. It was a very laid back scene and the other patrons were very friendly.

This by far is the best place to go for brunch. I would definitely recommend it to other people wanting to get out of downtown.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description: I had 2 types of their poached eggs, and they really weren't that amazing, especially at their prices. After a 2-hr wait for a table, I was already hungry, so it should've been easy for them to get me to think that their food's delicious, but I was not impressed. My dish was pretty bland.
author: Teresa P.

description:
Warning, this place is tiny! Be careful to not bump into any of the staff coming out of the shockingly small kitchen and I advise you to use the restroom in a different store...trust me on this one. 
Anyway, my sister and I were wandering around San Francisco looking for a good place that serves brunch so we whipped out our phones and looked for some places nearby. We chose Zazie because of the amount of positive ratings and I'm glad we did! The only downside of the place was that it was a bit cramped, other than that everything was great. Service was friendly and we were completely satisfied with the food we ordered. I ordered the latte and the La Mer Benedict. They give you a lot of the latte, it is seriously the size of a soup bowl my goodness and yes it is delicious. The La Mer Benedict was really good as well. The potatoes (House Fries I believe it was called) were amazing, crunchy on the outside and nice and soft on the inside. The benedict was fresh and full of flavor.
The outdoor eating area is a really nice atmosphere as well!
I would say I would love to come back soon but I don't live in SF and if I were to come back to the city I would try something else, but if you happen to be in the area and are looking for a place for a good breakfast/brunch, I recommend Zazie!
author: Josephine T.

description:
This place UNFORTUNATELY is about a 20 second walk from my house...all my money goes here. The breakfast here is never failing. I usually order the poached eggs alberto with the spicy green chile sauce. If not, then the Oatmeal Brulee which is oatmeal with a layer of creme brulee over it (who does that)! As well, on Tuesday nights they have a no cork fee, so it is great to bring your friends and a couple bottle of wines.

Many times and memories soon to be shared at Zazie's.
author: Gunter L.

description: I'm sadly giving zazies a one star ..... I used to love coming here but after having bad experiences 3 times I can no longer risk another cold breakfast or scraping of the end of the pan potatoes.  Also if the waiters hungry don't eat in front of customers , I understand we all got to eat but if I'm waiting for my food for more than 20 min and I see your food come out before mine and then watch you eat it while I'm starving I'm going to be pissed . Please The waiter didn't even acknowledge us or ask whether the food was fine or apologetic for the food being cold or taking forever. Ever since the no tip started is when I noticed the change . Theirs some old staff still there and they are very attentive . Ever since the no tipping started is when this place went down. Personally I like to tip . It encourage amazing service and gives motivation to the team.  Like I said I loved zazies and I hope they work on their service . Try sweet maple !
author: Andres L.

description:
I try to come here on random Fridays off with the boyfriend. This way we get to skip the line! If there is a line, that means there is time to go to Finnigan's and get a mimosa...

Anyways, we come here often for brunch. Patio seats most of the time, super cozy. I don't love pancakes and french toast, but my boyfriend does. I think he's ordered everything off the menu by now. He's a fan of getting a little bit of everything, which Zazie's menu setup is perfect for. One pancake, one french toast and one eggs bennie. I usually gravitate toward the delicious breakfast sandwiches they have. 

Usually fantastic service too! Love it!
author: Emily H.

description: Fabulous service from Mario and despite the Saturday crowd the staff were attentive, friendly and upbeat. We had poached eggs (divorce), great salads and outstanding chai. Definitely sit out back it is a lovely spot!
author: Helen M.

description:
Been wanting to try this much-raved about little spot nestled in the "heart of Cole Valley" for quite some time.

Parking in the area can be a bit of a challenge, but then again what did you expect, its SF! We got here around 9:30 on Sunday expecting to see a ton of people waiting outside, not the case this morning!! We put our name down on the waiting list hanging outside and decided to grab some coffee at Tully's just a couple doors down. To my surprise, only a ten minute wait for our party of 2! 

-Gingerbread Pancakes with Roasted Bosc Pears and Lemon Curd.  (Available in portions of one, two, or three pieces...we ordered 2 pancakes for $10)

The gingerbread pancakes were light, fluffy, and almost cake-like with just the right amount of "sweet" and ginger flavor.  The tasty lemon curd and poached pears was a unique touch!  Maple syrup served on the side for you super sweet-tooths! These are really big and thick pancakes so one is plenty for one person.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=YmyeGeHyX5xOc70wWcS-kA

-New York Scramble (3 free range eggs) with wild smoked salmon, green onions, and cream cheese served with home fries and toast...limited choice of whole wheat or white Italian ($12) 

Tender smoked salmon and eggs scrambled to savory perfection. We loved the flavorful home fries (roasted quartered red potatoes with whole cloves of garlic) yummerz!!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=8Q2qpnPIc_o66HjZVnPUzQ

J'ADORE my Café Au Lait served in a big bowl....definitely satisfied this coffee snob!  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=S8NyFDyzxmxodMnHZCMIHA

Décor was quaint and easy on the eye. Cozy and comfy atmosphere with a pleasant and friendly staff.

It was indeed, a perfect start to a Sunday morning! Will definitely be back to sample the eggs bennies and I just might try the Oatmeal Brulée!
author: Cecy M.

description:
I'm not typically a big fan of brunch - I find lunch and dinner food to be so much more interesting and flavorful.  I mean, eggs are... eggs.  That said, however, I really enjoyed Zazie.  It was a beautiful day (yes, in SF!), and my friend and I waited about 45 minutes for a seat outside on the back patio.  It was well worth it, and the host was very nice about keeping us updated and offering an indoor table earlier in case we wanted it.  

We were very hungry when we finally sat down, and decided to share two of the poached egg dishes - the St. Trop with smoked salmon and the Florentine with spinach and portobello mushrooms.  I had never had salmon with eggs before, and was a bit nervous.  I needn't have worried, as this is now one of my favorite combinations and has completely reshaped how I view brunch.  The lox was cut into tiny pieces so there were no issues with it getting caught in your teeth or accidentally getting a giant piece all at once.  The lemon hollandaise sauce was, as Zazie's menu describes, light and delicious and not at all overpowering.  The Florentine tasted like a normal omelet, but didn't have any of the wonderful flavors of the St. Trop.  I wish there had been some tomatoes or something a little bit sweeter to offset the earthy mushroom and spinach combination.

My only complaint is that the server refilled my friend's coffee once (I wasn't ready yet), but then never returned so I only had one cup.  Normally I wouldn't even mention it, but the coffee was great, and I very much wanted another cup!
author: Rachel A.

description: Came early on a weekday for bfast. No line! Challah French toast and pancakes were very tasty.
author: C W.

description:
Super cute place for brunch. I love that it's not too difficult to get to by Muni and that it's also walking distance from golden gate park (to walk off all that food!).

I was not very impressed by the host that was sitting us to the tables though... The person was pretty rude and left a negative first impression between me and my three other girl-friends. Maybe he woke up on the wrong side of the bed?

With the exception of the host, the rest of our experience was great! The server was patient and answered all of our questions.  

I cross-checked Yelp and their menu, and decided on the Un, Deux, Trois, which consists of "One buttermilk pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon". To try everyone's recommendations, I subsituted the buttermilk pancake for the French Toast Tahiti (for an additional $3), and had the poached eggs. 

The french toast is amazing - I love that walnut spread. The bacon was also done to perfection. The poached eggs felt slightly out of place. 

Note that there was a line the moment the place opened on Sunday morning, so definitely expect a wait. My friends and I waited about 45 mins, which isn't too bad - we ended up killing time by drinking coffee at another cafe across the street. Also, there is only one restroom stall for both men and women... the line for that was also really long!
author: Lucia C.

description:
It's Bay to Breakers morning and so, keeping with the spirit save for the spirits, we decided to walk 4.5 miles from our home to Zazie.

It was worth the walk. It was worthwhile not so much for my delicious chorizo scramble but rather the 3 ,mouth-watering bites of ginger pancake dressed with lemon custard, poached pear and crisp bacon my kind wife shared with me.

Ginger pancakes? Who woulda thunk.?

Delicious!!!
author: Jay D.

description: To my opinion it is totally overrated. The croque monsieur was simply a ham and cheese. The smoked salmon poached egg was a little too salty. The gingerbread pancake was the only item of value that we ordered. And they were out of the bread for French Toast.
author: Sasan A.

description:
This restaurant is hostile, rude and not customer friendly.  The servers were hostile from the second we entered the door.  The restaurant was empty and there was no reason for their hostility.

I have recommended this restaurant to many people on many occasions in the past.  Apparently there is new management.  I eat out regularly and rarely write negative reviews.  

The Japanese is Michilin rated and is fantastic.  The prices are the same, if not better.  The service was impeccable.
author: tj g.

description: Best brunch ever! A really cute restaurant with a nice patio. Wait times are long but we were surprisingly seated in 40 min on a busy Sunday afternoon. We ordered the eggs florentine and the Tahiti French toast. Both dishes were AHMAAAAAZING! I would sooo come back again. The French toast was crispy and the caramelized banana and walnut paste was to die for! The hollandaise sauce on the eggs florentine was perfect. I can't wait to come back here again!
author: Sneha S.

description: Surprisingly very friendly to kids. Food is amazing. Cornmeal pancakes were perfectly fluffy and moist. Everything is good here. We had eggs, salad, pancakes and fresh juice. Reservations are essential or show up at 8am when they first open. Otherwise expect a huge wait.
author: Christine P.

description: Great food, expensive but expected in sf.  I had the scramble with mushrooms, can't recall the name and it was delish. Expect no service. I assume this may be due to the restaurant policy of "no tips."  In a way there is no incentive for waiters to provide great service.
author: Lincy K.

description: I have to thank my friend Diane for waiting for an hour and a half while Sally and I came here. When we got here they seated us and reserved us a spot, what a nice staff. Yeah I think the $1.25 is B.S. for the employee benefits, but what can you do.  I like the pancake which was good and then the poached eggs and crab where good and tasty and fresh.  I do not know if I would have waited for an hour and a half for breakfast food and the parking is pretty bad too and the cops love to give out tickets.  Anyways good choice Diane.
author: Keven W.

description:
Another great gwu meal. 

To start off with the waiter was very engaging and cheeky; he had lots of personality and I love that! 

I really loved the special touch of a printed menu for us; it was a great touch and it made me feel special.

My Tablas Creek Grenache Blanc was delicious and perfect accompaniment to to the PEI mussels in white wine and garlic that were to die for. Sweet, bursting with flavor and the sauce was perfect for soaking up with bread. 

The strawberry, goat cheese and arugula salad was spicy and sweet. 

My entree was the trout and salad - cooked to perfection with beautiful balsamic tomatoes atop and a side salad. 

The dessert - oh wow what a special treat. That poor fruit cobbler never had a chance up against the chocolate mouse with roasted marshmallows atop.   

Overall I loved the service, very attentive, great ambiance, the patio looked great (and dog friendly) the food was amazing and very generous.

I will be back!
author: Jade W.

description:
First time I came I thought I would be disappointed by waiting... long list of names but not so long finally. 
And when I tried the Alfred Poached eggs... SO YUMMY, and the French Toasts... Ok, I was in love ;)

Really nice place for brunch
author: Claire T.

description: The divorcee' eggs Benedict is really good, and the French toast is to die for. Everything we ordered was amazing!!!! I would definitely recommend this place, the wait is worth it.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The wait to get a table wasn't so bad.  It was a weekday so it went a little faster. The wait to get our food though was really long.  Everyone's food at my table was a little tough due it being sitting out for a while before serving us. 

The ginger bread pancakes were really dry and tough to cut into.  I could only eat about a quarter of a pancake before I stopped. The only thing I could taste was tasteless pancake mix. 

I had just stepped off a 6 hour flight, my first time in SF.  My friends were really excited to take me to Zazie.  They had a good experience the last time they went.  However, this time, one friend mentioned that "it was a huge letdown."
author: Kannica P.

description:
Went for dinner on a Wed and was pleased. Service was friendly, food was decent. We had a reservation and were seated immediately. 

Having recently returned from Pairs, I would not say it's authentic French, more like French-inspired cuisine. 

Also, parking is a b*tch. Take the muni.
author: J. M.

description:
Long wait but worth it!!!  Started of with a big glass of champagne, which is always appreciated.  We got to sit in the back of the gardeny and intimate patio area beneath a heat lamp. 
After asking a few questions about the menu I had to go with the house specialty of eggs benedict and was so glad I did! The poached egg was cooked perfectly, it had just the right amount of hollandaise on top and the bacon was oh-so crispy. The potatoes were fresh and well cooked with whole garlic cloves.  A brunch to dream about...
author: Laura P.

description:
4.5 stars!! 

In short - 100x more worth it than Mama's in North Beach. Although the wait was about 1-1.5 hours total, it was well worth it. I left stuffed and satisfied - definitely a great way to start my day! Not only was the food splendid, the service was also fantastic.

French Toast Tahiti
Not overpowered with cinnamon, which is a plus. You can definitely taste it, but it didn't deter me from devouring it. I enjoyed the caramelized bananas with the golden brown french toast, but I didn't expect the pecans to be a paste-like substance. I would have like it to just be bits of pecans.

La Mer
Awesome choice for those who like crab! They don't skimp out on the crab meat, and definitely filling. I would recommend going for the 3 eggs (meaning you get three sandwiches) for just a little bit more! It's definitely a big plate, so it's good for sharing. The home fries went well with it. Definitely ask for the home-made habanero hot sauce to pair with the potatoes - delicious!!

Croque Madame
Very heavy, but it was decent (although not the best I've had). Portion is large, and will recommend sharing this plate since it is very heavy. Egg was perfectly cooked!

Omelette 
Didn't partake in the omelette, but my family enjoyed it. There were definitely one too many eggs at brunch, and I don't find omelette particularly interesting.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Came here around noon and got lucky with parking. Waited for about 20 mins. The wait wasn't so bad, the guy who was seating everyone was really attentive. I saw him offering chairs to the pregnant women and seniors waiting. The only thing bad was this guy eating at one of the outside tables was smoking while eating. He was smoking the entire time I was waiting...right in front of a baby at his table...

Anyways, we got a table in the back on the patio, which still had the cash and bill from the previous people eating on it. 

My little cousin got a big bowl of fruit which he loved but then again how can anyone mess up fruit...

My aunt got the betterave salad, which they forgot the avocado. My aunt told the waiter and he brought her a plate. She thought it was alright. I got the Monaco with the salad and two poached eggs. It was okay...

The chai here is pretty bad. It was just bland and foamy.

Overall the only one who was satisfied was my little cousin. Sigh I think this place got over hyped for me...
author: Katie M.

description: The Tuesday night "bring your own wine" is a great idea. What I don't like about Zazie's is the portions. Super small. I ordered the pork chop and that's exactly what I got:: a pork chop on a bed of something. Lentils? Cous cous? I don't know. But I was starving when I left. The chop was 28.00 and the server made it sound like I would be stuffed. My friend had the chicken breast stuffed with something. One word: TINY. Come on, beef up your portions!
author: George K.

description:
Came here with a friend around noon on a Monday. The wait wasn't long and we were seated within 10 minutes.

I ordered an Omelette Du Jour with a latte. The omelette had so much pesto that I couldn't taste anything else. The house potatoes felt like they were lacking some additional seasoning and it was sort of hard like they were sitting out for a while. The latte wasn't too bad, loved that they served it in a bowl.

My friend ordered the La Mer Benedict with a mocha. He enjoyed his dish and said he would order it again. However, he also felt the house potatoes were missing something. 

Overall, the service was alright but the food wasn't that great. Maybe it was just what I ordered. The portions here are pretty big so you'll leave pretty full.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
I'd like Zazie a lot more if I went there a lot less, I think. It gets really crowded and I know they're a small place, but it just seems like everything falls apart functionally pretty easily. Also it's more expensive than I want, and in little ways that irritate me - $2 for egg whites only, $4 for proscuitto - I know that's how restaurants go, but somehow this just strikes me as worse than many, for what it is.

But if the food's great, who cares? Well, everyone likes the pancakes & french toast, but they've never been my favorite - too sweet, maybe. My go-to brunch/lunch item is the croque madame, which I think they do quite well. I will say I think their drinks, alcoholic or otherwise, are great.
author: Lisa K.

description:
long story short, haircut appt fell thorough, day taken off wasted so I figured why not cheer myself up with some brunch. French toast and mimosas to be exact.

they ran out of French toast at 10am on a Monday morning ):

& save for a moment where the server was rude (maybe because I didn't hear clear the first time that they're out) & in which he saved himself with a plastered smile afterwards + apology (which is also why this is staying a five stars)

The service was attentive and friendly.

I got the pancakes which were delicious, I don't usually have high expectations when it comes to the pancakes but something about that batter..YUM

Mimosa was good

The home fries are crisps slices of potatoes, wish it was seasoned slightly stronger.

Love the decor, the bathroom--not so much.
author: Whitne Y.

description:
Long wait, decent poached eggs with variety of styles, and great variety of mimosas. It isn't the cheapest brunch and nothing that blew my mind and for price and wait, I'll probably not come back anytime soon. If you're in the area or live nearby it's a place to try but a little overrated for me. 

However, ambiance and cuteness factor gets a 5 and service is a 4. I value quality for $ and eh, I had better.
author: Linda L.

description: First time ever having bread pudding pancakes, so moist n delish! Its called miracle pancakes, a must try, especially if you're partial to bread pudding! Cozy atmosphere with very friendly and personable service.
author: Cindy L.

description: Great service. Wait is a little bit long since this place is popular but I really enjoyed the poached eggs and gingerbread pancakes! Home fries were also great!
author: Kevin Z.

description:
We came for an early breakfast and got there about 10 minutes before opening on Sunday morning.  Thank goodness we did, because a line started forming behind us a few minutes after we sat down on the few chairs they set out for early guests.  And not just a small line either - they definitely had a full seating before the place opened.  We got a cute little table near the window.  

My coffee came in a bowl.  No, literally a bowl.  Or a giant cup with no handle - you be the judge.  It was great, and I had to use 2 hands to drink from it.  One of the things I liked about this place is that we could choose how many eggs to get with your benny - I only got one and it was a perfect amount for me.  The food was good, and the service was quick.  Would definitely be a good place to make your local breakfast place if you live in the area.

Protip:  They have 2 tables out front that are first come, first served.  If one of them is empty, feel free to grab it even out of turn.  We saw people who looked depressed arrive late after people started being seated, who were able to grab those tables and laugh at the others around them who failed to read the signs!
author: Jenna L.

description:
A damn good brunch place.

Nothing about Zazie blew me away, but they have an outstanding menu and decent prices for the Bay Area.

Most notably, the option to get a single egg in a benedict means you don't get sick of the hollandaise before you finish, and you save a few bucks in the process!

They don't take reservations and the wait on weekends can easily top an hour or longer. Go early!
author: Nick S.

description: Love this place! Go with friends and order the 3 Benedict's and share it's amazing. The specials are always amazing. Be prepared to wait but it's well worth it!
author: Sean G.

description:
Ok. Advice. Come here on a weekday, around 10ish. Sit on the back patio. Order the gingerbread pancake with lemon curd (you have the choice of 1, 2 or 3). Order some other beautiful creation (omelette perhaps)? Share it with a friend. Dunzo. SO GOOD.

Tips: they take a while to jot down your order and serve. Juices aren't freshly squeezed, they are Oddwalla, so if you're debating on drinks, keep that in mind. I found it a bit RIDIC that Adele's chicken apple sausage is $4 a pop here. Can't you buy a package of em for that much? $1.50 extra on your bill (per person) for helping pay for benefits, etc. for the staff which is nice, but if you're going to add that to everyone's bill, at least make the menu item prices more sensible. 

In general, food was awesome. Prices could be better and service could be more attentive. Parking is easy. Ambiance is perfect!
author: Tejal D.

description: Great cozy place with delicious brunch and wonderful staff! I went in with a stroller on a weekday and they were super accommodating. The brunch drinks are delicious and refreshing :)
author: Arezou K.

description:
We, my daughter, my 16 year old grandson and one of his friends had dinner at Zazie last night Sept. 12th after touring Alcatraz as our last of the Summer, before Fall adventure. 

Having watched Check Please over 5 years ago, Zazie has been on my mind to try for a very long time. 

Being a Chef and a Pasty Chef myself, I do critique at times judgmentally. 

The only negative thing I have to say is parking or the lack of. But, being San Francisco, that should not have surprised me in any way. 

20 million Stars to the Staff for being kind, courteous and understanding that we were going to be late for our reservation. Yes we called, but could only give a estimated time frame of how late we would be as there was road work everywhere slowing us down. When I realized that I was going to have to go blocks farther out to look for parking, I texted my daughter as I knew what I wanted, so she could order for me and not slow down our already late appearance. 
*Remember, Saturday night, everyone is home and parking may be a bit of a problem. I don't mind walking, and found something about 6 blocks away. 

Now for the food. Awesome, Amazing, as Good as I thought it would be. Oh my God, can I lick the plate? They will bring out as many of those rolls to wipe your plate clean if you want. 

3 of us had the Prix Fix dinners. Good choice as then we could taste each other food. And that we did. My entree of the Fish Soup Provencale was to die for. The soup had just the right amount of soup, and the fish was very tender and I love mussels, so it all was just wonderful. 
My daughter had the Grilled Mascarpone Polenta cakes with vegetables. It also was great. I love polenta, being Italian, am fairly snobby about polenta. 

After chatting a bit with the server, I asked to pick me out a wine to go with my dinner, and he was spot on! I got the Andre Vatan "Les Charms" Sauvignon Blanc - Sancerre. My daughter got the champagne, Domaine la Grangette Picpoul de Pinet - Languedoc. All French. 

We had 3 choices of dessert. All were wonderful. Creme Brulee, Petit Pot de Creme au Chocolate and the fresh fruit crumble with creme fraiche, which tonight was Strawberry and Rubarb. I also asked for the Vanilla Gelato for 2.00 more. 

I have to say that Zazie will be added to my list of favorites when I come into San Francisco. The parking will not detour me to have some of the best French/Californian food I've had since being in France many years ago. I love the California twist, which is why I stated French/Californian. 

Thank you Zazie for for the wonderful dining experience that we could share with a couple of 16 year olds, that good food is very important to ones palette.
author: Sara C.

description:
Mmmmm...Zazie.  Food is awesome, service is great, and sitting outside on the back patio on a rare sunny SF day is perfect!

I had the pancakes off of the Specials menu, so I can't remember what they were called...but they were cornmeal pancakes with the famous lemon curd.  I am a sucker for maple syrup, so I thought I would discretely push the lemon curd to the side and slather on the syrup.....but luckily I dipped my fork and tried a taste first.  It was seriously amazing!  Sweet and light and lemony...just perfect.  So I ended up only having a little maple syrup on one side of one pancake....AFTER the delicious lemon curd had been all eaten up.

My friend and I shared the bottle of the french sparkling lemonade for $9.  Now I wouldn't usually spend $9 on lemonade, but this was actually REALLY good, and I'd consider getting it again (though I might just go with one glass for $3...good enough).  It was again light, sweet and lemony (apparently the theme of my meal!), and not at all sour or pucker-worthy, as some lemonades are.  Definitely tasted natural and was a wonderful complement to my meal.

I was there with a group of friends, and everyone's food looked amazing.  The Croque Royale was a big hit...a croque monsieur but with grilled tomatoes and an egg on top.  Another friend had the salad of the day, with strawberries that looked amazingly ripe and delicious, and lots of fresh veggies.

I wish I lived in Cole Valley, because I'd be here every day!  Sooooo good, and worth the price.

**Note: They don't take AmEx.**
author: Caroline K.

description:
We went here to show some out of town ( out of country actually ) friends a good neighborhood spot for dinner. According to most reviews it seems we should have done brunch. We had a reservation on a Fri. eve,  and got a choice window spot for four, but probably could have walked in and been seated within 15. It's a quaint  shotgun of a place, with a country French vibe and menu. 

We had a white bean soup of the day along with the French Onion, the FO was outstanding as you would hope in a French joint. Got to try the grilled Polenta, Duck breast and the Flat Iron steak, with a perfectly decent bottle of Tablas Creek red for 
$ 42-. Most  entrees in the  $ 20 range.Everyone was happy, no one raved.
They have a Prix FIxe deal- 3 courses  for  $ 27- the choices are limited though.

 I have had a lot of duck and this dish was very tender ,over smashed yams w/spinach and a port reduction.The food was good quality and well prepared. Prices were about right. Any neighborhood would be lucky to have a place like this.
Is it worth a special trip? Probably not, unless you are doing something in the area.
I'd like to return  for the brunch sometime. I can imagine it gets quite tight when full.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
I don't even know why I'm bothering to write a review as it will get muddled in with the other 2000+....but this place is great! 

Went for breakfast.

French toast with cherries- pretty good.  Not the best I've ever had but the pieces were thick and tasty. 

Fonte-  holy cow! Must have! Out came this dainty cast iron dish with Polenta with spinach and mushrooms and yummy tomato based sauce with two eggs over easy.  Wow. Only way to describe it.  

Poached eggs- pretty good selection of basically different Benedict's. I though the Hollandaise was ok but I'm a snob about Hollandaise.  My husband really liked it. 

I would definitely go back and try the rest, that is if I can tear myself away from that genius polenta egg dish.
author: Hope P.

description:
Zazie has always been my go to breakfast place when I want to wow someone from out of town *and when we have an hour to spare waiting for a table :p 
The benedicts are amazing, the roasted potatoes are perfection, the lunch is terrific! But the real treat here is dinner. I didn't try dinner at Zazie until recently, but wow! Twinkly lights and a romantic and well heated outdoor patio (not to mention tasty food) it's such a sweet surprise in the heart of the city.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Zazie Pancakes == Carb-tastic Deliciousness.

Dense but light, spicy and sweet, flavorful but with a perfect touch of ginger. As I was polishing off what I thought was the last potato from my hash, I instead scarfed down an entire half poached pear. Trust me, no matter how well you poach a pear in sugar it's still kinda gross on its own. Consider how truly great these must be if I am still a fan post-flavor-sugar-overload-poached-pear-trauma...

The poached pear ginger pancakes is what boosted Zazie from 3 to 4 stars. I mean, I'm sort of a pancake connoisseur and thank goodness I ordered a side of Banana-Walnut stuffed French Toast as well as the Ginger Poached Pear Pancakes with my Croque Madame . Wasn't so much a fan of the mushy brown gunk (walnut mash) in the french toast except when covered in raspberry preserves; but with a generous portion of those preserves I could've eaten my napkin too. The Croque was quite good (Hello, egg sandwich? Who doesn't love that?), but not the best I've had.

Moral: Save time finding a Gingerbread cookie and Pumpkin bread; eat a Zazie pancake instead.
author: Jess C.

description: Delicious food, amazing management, courteous and receptive staff, long wait time for weekend brunch.
author: Tony M.

description:
I love brunch! I can never get enough of brunch. The thing I like the most is the environment. The back garden is so tranquil and wonderful. Eating in the back is like being in someone's private party, but in the middle of the city! It almost feels surreal. 

The food is wonderful, cooked just right. I always get some form of poached egg and never failed me. Now on to the part where I don't really like about this place. The wait on the weekend is pretty ridiculous! It is ALWAYS about 1 hour wait. Although recently they have started using this online app where you can access it on your smartphone to put your name on the list before you get there to save you some waiting time. One caveat is it cost $1 every time you use the app. I really don't mind spending the extra dollar to shorten the wait time, but parking is horrendous as well! It takes 30 min to find a spot, and then parallel park, and then walk to the restaurant and wait some more. Aside from all the waiting, the food is great and with a group of good friends this place is the perfect Sunday afternoon. 

What I recommend:

La mer poached eggs
St. Trops
Stuffed french toaste
author: Jenny C.

description: Yum! So worth the wait. The french toast with bananas and walnut spread was so good. The mimosa was okay (not the best champagne) and my friends loved their food too! Long wait so get their early! the back patio is so nice on a warm day.
author: Brittany G.

description:
Best brunch in the city. The service and food here are top notch. The only downside is you have to wait around a while to get a table for brunch on the weekends.

For the food, I really like the La Mer, which as an eggs Benedict with crab and avocado. The eggs are always perfectly poached and with the crab and avocado addition the whole dish is incredibly tasty and filling. They also serve home fries cooked with fresh garlic which is also quite yummy!

For a sweet dish, I really like the Tahini french toast. Or you can try the sampler and get a little of everything.

Another really nice thing about this place is you can easily choose how much food you want. You can order one two or three poached eggs/french toast/pancakes etc. 

Finally, the service here is surprisingly good considering how busy it is. The waiters are generally really friendly and warm.
author: Kate M.

description:
Zazie is a charming restaurant located in Cole Valley. Their menu ranges from the usual American dishes to French tasties and some their own unique Zazie specialties. The interior of Zazie was a European-esque and the atmosphere had a casual, laid back vibe feel.

 After a  5+min wait, my friend and I had gotten seated to our table, in the patio, which was appropriate for the warm weather. I ordered the ginger pancakes and he ordered the Un, deux, trois. The pancakes were fluffy but I especially loved tasting the lemon curd and fresh pears that with it. My friend seemed to have liked his plate because he finished it off clean! The food was delicious but what was also an added bonus was the attentive service. Our waitress was never out of sight and our food came out pretty quickly after ordering it. 

This was my second time here and definitely not my last.
author: C M.

description: La mer eggs Benedict is so good. Made very nicely. Hollandaise sauce made just right. Their mocha was decent. Comes in a pretty big bowl. Lastly their Tahiti French toast was good but I wouldn't say amazing. Cute brunch spot for a Sunday morning. But this place is popular. Be prepared to wait!! Free street parking is available though. That helps.
author: Carrie T.

description:
Such a charming place! We heard about it from a local resident and were so glad we tried it. We went for brunch on a Saturday. The line was out the door, but it moved fast (it's much bigger than it looks from the outside). 

If you like eggs Benedict, this place has about 5 different variations... My husband and I shared the Benedict Albert and a single banana walnut pancake- it was more than enough food! Both were excellent. They also have a wide variety of mimosas and the Bloody Mary's were great, too! If you can, note the patio seating as your preference when you sign in- the back patio is so cozy!
author: Ashley S.

description: Really nice experience! My friend and I were 6th on the list but got seated pretty quickly. Service was totally friendly and the food was good. We both had the 'omelette du jour,' the 'metro' cocktail, and split some french toast. I really appreciate the no-tipping policy here and it's so important that all employees are paid a livable wage and get benefits.
author: Vika M.

description:
My boyfriend and I had Valentine's Day brunch here and it was absolutely amazing. We arrived a little after they opened so we didn't have to wait long for a table to open up. 

I ordered the Croque Madame with a side salad. The cheese was rich and melted onto the bread like they were meant to be. The ham wasn't your average deli ham; its strong taste combined with the cheesy bread was a match made in brunch heaven. Add the fried egg on top.. and you have me salivating as I write this review.

The boyfriend ordered the omelette of the day with a side of country potatoes. He loved it. He couldn't stop raving about the potatoes or how fresh the ingredients were. I have to admit, the potatoes were delicious.

We also shared an order of french toast with caramelized bananas. I'm so glad we ordered this because it was the perfect sweetness to our otherwise very hearty meal. 

Can't wait to return!
author: Donna M.

description:
I am a brunch lover, and while Zazie offers a solid, satisfying brunch, it just does not live up to its hype and wait.

The housemade cream cheese coffee cake is so decadent and a perfect way to start off your meal.

I looove all things brunch and carbs, so naturally I have tried all their pancake and french toast items.  Once again, they are all tasty but don't quite live up to their mouthwatering descriptions.  I would recommend instead the poached eggs, which have always been a big hit with my friends.

Also, as others have said, the wait can be extremely long, so either take that into consideration or line up before they open for quicker seating.
author: Carrie C.

description:
If you are willing to brave the inevitable long wait and cramped spaces once inside, then you are in a for a treat!  

*The Food: super delicious
I ordered the Florentine Poached Eggs with spinach and portobello mushrooms with a side of the French Toast Tahiti stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Mmmm mmmm mmmm, I am still dreaming about them.

I did a little taste test of the Mexico Scrambled Eggs (with chorizo, white cheddar, roasted peppers, and salsa), the Le Mer Poached Eggs, and the St. Trop Poached Eggs (with wild smoked salmon, capers, and red onions).  All three were reaaaalllyyyy good.

*The Staff: excellent!
Our server was great, checking in with us just enough times.


*The venue: super small
In other words, it's nice and cozy, both indoors and outdoors.  You may have to put aside your personal space requirements for the duration of the visit, but it'll be worth it.

Tip: 
-They don't take reservations on the weekends so get there early!
-Street parking only and most come with 2-hour limit
author: Nathalie V.

description:
On a positive note, we didn't have to wait long for our table in the back patio.  On a negative note, we were told that their back patio was full...but it wasn't even close to full when we walked back there.  WTH?

The day was perfect for some outdoor dining and I was hoping the food would be just as nice! 
 
Eh, it was okay!  

When I ask for over medium, I don't mean a gushing river of yolk!  My Eggs En Fonte was a mess! I couldn't find the sweet corn cakes amidst the salsa mixed with all the yolk.  I am glad, however, that I added bacon to this dish.  
St. Trop Benedict was on the small side, perfect for little appetites. But the wild smoked salmon was pretty damn tasty.     
The French toast Tahiti was the best thing I had with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  I should've ordered their bigger portion!

I'd love to come back on a nice day again, and hopefully will become a fan!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Finally got a chance to come here during the work week for a midday brunch. Got seated easily. Not much of a wait. 

Then...45 minutes for ONE egg that cost me $15?! I guess now that they've gotten rid of their NO-TIP policy, they can provide shitty service at exorbitant prices. And now they've taken away my chance to express how dissatisfied I am with a less than 18% tip!! I think I can get ONE EGG somewhere else for less than $15 and I wont have to wait almost an hour for it.

Definitely not like they use to be.
author: Q C.

description: As a Midwesterner I am pleasantly overwhelmed with the ambiance and quality of dining choices available to San Franciscans on a daily basis. Zazie was classic; French cuisine served by friendly French staff speaking in lovely accented English. On Tuesdays there are no corking fees. Servers are friendly and patient. The poulet a la francaise was amazing as was the DD  Mac n cheese. The pork chop is incredibly thick, tender and flavorful. Well worth the price.
author: Kris D.

description: Who wants to wait an hour and a half for brunch? The mob of people outside was insane on a Saturday at noon.
author: Pam C.

description:
Out of the hundreds of breakfast spots in the city, I have already been here twice even though I have only lived in the bay for 8 months and SF for a few weeks.  Why fix something if it ain't broke?  I have family in town and during dinner with some SF natives, I said, "lets have breakfast tomorrow morning.  I have an amazing spot I know of!"  My SF friend said, "go to Zazie." Coincidentally, or maybe not so much, this was the restaurant -I- had in mind!

I am a sucker for a good eggs benedict.  I always order the Eggs Divorcee which is your english muffin topped with a cheese, perfectly crisp bacon, 2 poached eggs (you can order 1,2, or 3 eggs), and I believe avocado.  I don't remember.  All I know is, all this deliciousness topped with their hollandaise sauce is to die for.  Today we also got the ginger pancakes for the table and of course, there were orgasmic sounds coming from everyone at our table. 

The service here is really attentive and friendly.  I cannot speak for the long waits because I have only come at 8 am everytime.  However, by the time we get up to leave from our meal, there is already a wait list made every time. 

Ambiance feels country french- cozy and bright.  I know there is outdoor garden seating, but I have not ventured back there yet.  Can't wait til the next time!
author: Cheryl C.

description:
Zazie's brunch is so so good. The Tahiti French Toast with the whipped banana walnut concoction is amazing and so are their potatoes. I always judge a brunch place by its potatoes and Zazie's is definitely some of the best I've ever had. The baked garlic pieces are perfect for smearing on toast. My most favorite dish at Zazie is not even on their regular menu - an omelette with onions, bacon, arugula and goat cheese. The cheese is practically smeared onto the omelette so its in every bite. Yum. Omgosh, I finished my entire plate, even down to the orange slice. 

I've also had the eggplant poached eggs. It comes with a tomato sauce instead of the traditional hollandaise sauce so that's a win for me because I'm not a huge fan of creamy sauces. 

The wait is terribly long for brunch but I think it's worth it! Service is always top notch there and obviously so is the food. LOVE.
author: Helen V.

description:
Mmmmmmm...lemon ricotta ravioli, and baked hot chocolate. Enough said.

Ok a couple more things...the whole menu is totally yummy so I will skip that and talk about the service and atmosphere. I have sat on the patio every time I have eaten at Zazie. It's charming. It's well heated even in chilly weather, and the service is absolutely attentive. They will bring you an extra blanket if you are still cold. Wonderful wine selection...overall some of the most enjoyable SF dining experiences I have had to date.
author: Liz R.

description:
The wait at this place takes FOREVER on weekends during brunch time! And yet, I still give them a 5-star review. I mean, even the food took a while to come to our table (you know it's been a while, when all the people at your table stop talking, and it's socially acceptable to start checking your phones).

I ordered the La Mer with one egg and one portion of the French toast Tahiti. The food was amazing.

I will definitely come back if I have a couple hours to spend waiting in line :)
author: Harry G.

description:
Love Zazie.  Brunch is of course the best, but I've had many very delicious dinners here, too.  Classic, no-frills French-style cooking with perfectly-done sauces and meat and good wine. 

I love sitting out back in the garden, even at night with the heat lamp going!  

Only drawbacks:  there are long lines for brunch, so you will be waiting for a while, and when it's really busy the service can be pretty slow; docking one star for these :/
author: Jackie O.

description:
The sun was out. I was really excited about dining in the back patio and I was looking forward to the food to match the 4 star reviews I was reading.

I wanted to like Zazie but I couldn't come up with enough reasons.

My experience was a 2.5 star (1 star for the patio dining, and 1 for the French toast.  I took off a star for bad service, 1 for stingy portions, and minus 1/2 for false advertising on the corn cakes). 

When I arrived, a waitress immediately told me that the patio was full and to get on the waiting list.  As soon as I put my name down, the host walked up to me and escorted us to the back patio where there were 5 empty tables.  It wasn't a big deal but the waitress should have double checked before telling me that there were no tables available.  Let's just say she set the tone for the entire experience.  

The food had hits and misses.  I ordered the St. Trop Benedict with wild smoked salmon, capers, and onion on an English muffin.  The egg was poached just the way how I like my eggs, with the yolk still runny.   While the portion was enough for my small appetite, it was really really really small compared to the Benedict I've had elsewhere.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=oDWEBuBPPpq4a8sGEt9Jdg

My friend didn't enjoy the Eggs en Fonte at all.  The ingredients in the dish sounded delicious but it was poorly made.  It was supposed to be housemade sweet corn cakes topped with 2 fried eggs, avocados, salsa fresca, and sour cream that was baked in an iron skillet.  The corn cakes were nowhere to be found.  The order came out with 2 over easy runny eggs and not the medium done eggs that he requested.  There was too much salsa on it.  The whole thing was mushy and runny like soup.  The waiter also forgot to ask my friend if he wanted home fries or salad that came with his order.   http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=IgtZ4ezH6AxV7WdZlF6rtA

The redeeming thing we had was the French toast Tahiti. Again the portion was an issue.  2 slices of thick French toast stuffed with mashed up caramelized banana and walnuts but the serving was only half of the sandwich.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=TX4RFDBXKEEEMMQXoihInA
author: Hannah C.

description:
I was less than impressed with my last meal at Zazie. I'd stopped in a couple of months ago for lunch and was sorely disappointed. So it was with a little trepidation that I returned for breakfast here a couple of weeks ago. I'm happy to say, though, that I was pleasantly surprised at how good breakfast was--we had a tasty breakfast and great service here. 

I ordered the gingerbread pancakes, topped with roasted pears and lemon curd. They were mighty tasty, but just a couple stops short of great. The pancakes were a little dry, honestly, but had a nice spicy gingerbread flavor. They needed more of Zazie's delicious lemon curd to balance out the dry texture of the pancakes. The pears on top were a great addition, but I would have appreciated more pears, sliced thinner and cooked more tender. And look out--this is a pretty heavy dish. Even with just two pancakes to an order, I was stuffed just halfway through my plate. 

My dining companions were likewise satisfied with their meals. The eggs Benedict with Dungeness crab was a favorite, and the eggs over polenta also got a thumbs up. We decided to split an order of the orange French toast. It was good, but didn't wow any of us.

Our service was very attentive and very friendly. We were seated outside and it was packed inside, not to mention we were a table of five. Despite this, our server never missed a beat--he stopped by our table regularly to make sure things were going OK and he brought out our food in a jiffy. 

After breakfast here at Zazie the other day, I'd definitely come back. I'm glad I gave Zazie a second chance. It wasn't the best breakfast I'd ever had, but it was certainly mighty tasty.

And here's a tip--Zazie can get pretty crowded inside with a long wait list to get a table, but the two tables just out front are apparently free for the taking first come, first served, so snag one if you can. It was great to dine outside on a sunny morning, and made breakfast that much better.
author: Raul N.

description: Stopped in for dinner with a friend. Excellent food at this quaint little restaurant. Great service. The onion soup was delicious and my ravioli entree was also delicious. Website says no tipping!
author: Will D.

description:
Not sure why this restaurant has a 4 star rating.  I want to give it 3 stars but they only really deserve 2 stars for several reasons.  I arrived on Sunday morning about 15 minutes before they opened.  Only two guests were ahead of me.  At 5 minutes prior to opening a staff person is hanging the sign in sheet and all the instructions on how to place you name on the wait list.  At this point about 15 groups are now waiting to sign up on the list.  Zazie staff didn't ask who arrived first just left the sign-up sheet to be filled out by those waiting.  After honoring those that arrived prior to me I went to place my name on the list to when two groups cut me off the place their name on the list. Not in the mood to argue just kept my mouth shut and placed my name on the list.   I thought I was at the grocery store and a new checker just opened.  

Food and Service.  With all the reviews and the number of people waiting to get in my expectations was at an all-time HIGH.  This is where the real disappointment comes in. I ordered the Croque Royale with a sunny side up egg on top.  The sandwich was bland and the egg was hard.  I would have told our server expect she never came by to check on us just to drop the check after about 25 minutes.  The side salad which you pay extra for instead of fries had little or no dressing.  Over my rating is low for the bland food and the server that was so busy could even ask me how my meal was or if we wanted anything else.
author: Kelly P.

description:
There's a reason people regularly wait two hours for this place.  The food is to die for and the service is wonderful as well.  I highly recommend the croque monsieur, best I've had since Sunday mornings when my mom made it :).

Go to the bar next door while you wait, they have a nice patio, ping pong, and a pool table.  It's usually pretty empty on a Saturday/Sunday at noon.
author: Sarina D.

description: Confusing wait system - tables out front are first come first serve - but as we were waiting we witnessed the server seat a family of 3 so we weren't sure if we could jump on the next available table. We held back and a couple two names below ours grabbed it. When we asked the manager he pointed to a sign that explained the policy (which is tiny and often blocked by the hordes of people standing out in front) the food was excellent - the special pancakes and mushroom scramble. But the wait for food was another 20-30 min. Good food, nice staff and cozy interior - but be prepared to wait on all ends
author: jennifer m.

description: Absolutely amazing dinner there last night! The trout was cooked to perfection, and the wild rice was so incredibly good (I forgot to ask the waitress what were the ingredients in it). The hamburger was unlike anything I've had in a while, and I just went to 4505 Meats. Super friendly service. The only drawback if you sit inside is the tight quarters. There were a lot of loud talkers from UCSF (talking about animal experimentation, which is highly inappropriate) and people fully immersed in their phone in the dining room, and that sort of detracted from the experience. OVERALL, excellent dining experience!
author: Adham M.

description:
Honestly was not impressed. I ordered the croque madam and my girlfriend the Albert poached eggs. ALL THREE of our eggs were over cooked with the yucky solid egg yolk. Honestly I've been to quite a few brunches around the country, but I can count with three fingers the restaurants that over cooked their poached eggs. Are you kidding me? It's hard to imagine people would line up for this. 

In short, extremely disappointed, will not come again
author: Beck C.

description:
Very european, even more than Foreign Cinema.  Tight quarters (even the bathroom) and apparently a small kitchen, so things come out at a leisurely pace. They seem to have two seatings a night rather than the three or even four that some restaurants do; very european.

We were in the back garden section. Very nice, quiet, and open.

The menu is full of variety. We had the three-appetizers-on-a-plate: paté, mussels, and the figs with Chèvre. I'm not a big fig fan, but the sourness of the cheese balanced the sweetness of the figs well. Paté was good; the mussels were in the shell with a nice sauce.

Herself had the pork chop in honeyed peaches and I had the salmon en papillote. Both were outstanding.

For dessert, I had the cheesecake (gingery and delicate) and herself had this chocolate suffelé with browned mini marshmallows on top; she seemed happy and plotted to make it at home.
author: Richard H.

description: I ate here with my brother in law and nephew a few Sunday's ago. The food was delicious, the waiters attentive and friendly, and the atmosphere pure Cole Valley San Francisco. I loved it. Would definitely be back, but I don't go into SF often! Hehe.
author: Naomi T.

description:
I was really looking forward to Zazie for Sunday brunch.  It was busy but not crazy.  It took over an hour to get us seated (2 people) and should have been more like 30 minutes.  I love the concept of the staff being paid well and taken care of so you don't have to tip (it's already included in the menu pricing).  The problem was the staff was slow and not motivated like a regular restaurant where getting tables in and out result in more money for the staff.  Things just took way too long and no sense of urgency.  Many times the servers were just chilling at the counter, often just talking or playing on their phone.  It took a long time after we were seated to get a server to take our order.  Also, coffee wasn't refilled.  The gingerbread pancakes were good.  The lobster benedict was average at best.  One egg was already broken when my dish arrived.  There was very little lobster meat (mostly claw, no tail meat) for the price ($28).  It's also ridiculous that there's only 1 single bathroom for the whole place.  We had to wait in a line of 6 people to use it.  Are you kidding?
Overall, things moved slow in this place and we waited for everything.  Decent food but get it together and pick up the pace.
author: love n.

description:
Wanted to give this place 4.5 for the sticker shock but then again, what do you expect from a high quality San Francisco gem?  Here it goes -

My buddies live up the street from Zazie and have reluctantly passed on going there weekend after weekend due to the intimidating crowd of people standing outside waiting for a table.  I finally made the executive decision to put our name down since we had heard nothing but great things about their food and I was DYING to try it.  You manually write your name down outside of the restaurant and do your own "how long is the wait?" calculation.  Roughly 3 mins/every name above yours for groups less than 5.  Estimate 5 mins for groups of 5+ (I think that's what it was).  We had a handful of people ahead of us (~45 minutes) so we put our names down and went back to the apartment.

We came back in perfect time to be seated up front against the glass in the corner.  Didn't notice until we sat down that they had a nice patio out back which I think I would rather wait for next time. The waitress, who was awesome but i unfortunately forgot her name, took down our drink order (3 bloody mary's, 1 drake's IPA, 1 mimosas and a shit ton of waters -- rough night the night before).  The bloody mary was pretty good, but nothing to write home about.  But wow, I can't stop dreaming about their heavenly food.

They had a large brunch menu with tons of options..  Will finish review shortly
author: Nik K.

description:
For 2 weekends in a row now, my husband and I have driven up to San Francisco from Redwood City to have brunch here.  For people living in the city, parking is not an issue as this restaurant is very close to an N Judah stop.  For those coming in from out of town, you may need to drive around for a while to find a decent parking spot.  Be prepared to walk a few blocks.

If you are super fortunate (i.e., you arrive with perfect timing and the SF weather is actually nice) and a table out front is available, you can just sit down and avoid the long wait.  Otherwise, you put your name on a paper list on a clipboard attached to the glass window and wait for your name to be called.  There are not many places to sit while you wait unless you're okay sitting on a large wooden planter, and if the fog is gone, you may have the sun right in your face the entire time, so be sure to have sunglasses handy.  Do not stray too far away, because they will not call your name for very long before giving up on you and moving on to the next guests on the list.  You also will not be seated until your entire party is present.

Once you get inside, you will learn that the food is well worth the wait.  It is a bit cramped and noisy, but that's part of the restaurant's charm.  Zazie makes it clear on their menu that they allow absolutely no substitutions, but you'll discover that it really won't cramp your style, as they have tons of great choices.  I've had the french toast with banana and walnuts which was incredible and I've also had a poached egg dish with eggplant.  The home fries are delicious.  My friend got the dish with a buttermilk pancake, a gingerbread pancake, and a slice of french toast.  She said it was really really good, too.  The food comes out super fast and the server staff is very friendly.

Both times we've come here, we ordered the table build-your-own mimosa kit.  Be aware (as we weren't told this the first time by the staff or didn't read the menu close enough) that you are entitled to 2 juice choices with the order.  Based on my personal preference, I would like them to serve more juice with the champagne so that I can make my mimosas a little bit weaker without hogging all of the juice for the entire table.  Being able to get 2 mini-pitchers of juice does help with this predicament, though.

The restroom is located in the back of the restaurant and the waiting area is in a hallway that is the only exit to the patio seating so be prepared to squeeze to the side to let the servers in and out.  Also, be careful if you decide to stand directly across from the bathroom door because you will likely turn on/off up to 4 wall power switches which are unfortunately located right in this area.  The bathroom was clean, although I couldn't find seat covers.
author: Danielle P.

description: I ate here a few days ago with my husband on our way to Golden Gate Park.  We got there early and had only a short wait.  Opt for outside seating.  They have a lovely patio out back.  It really had a nicer atmosphere than the noisy inside dining room.  I had the Omelette Du Jour,  It was FANTASTIC, as were the potatoes and coffee.  My husband had the Poached Benedict which was really good.  A great place to some if you are in the area.
author: Jessica E.

description: Delicious breakfast, yes. But not enough for me to wait in line for an hour and pay that much. I was really looking forward to my rare opportunity to get brunch in the city, but was seriously underwhelmed. Plus the service was slow and unprofessional. Meh. Next!
author: Susie S.

description:
Loved this place!! Brunch is my favorite meal, so I knew I had to choose wisely on a weekend trip to SF. This place did not disappoint. 

We got here about a half hour after they opened and only waited about 15 min for a table - so go on the earlier side if you don't want to wait. 

Service and staff were friendly and knowledgable and sometimes I feel like that matters as much as the food being delicious!! And it WAS delicious. 

First of all, get a Bloody Mary. I don't even like Bloody Mary's and even I could appreciate how tasty that drink was. 

To eat we shared the Tahiti French toast, the Albert poached eggs and a pumpkin pancake. It's so hard to pick what was best! All were pretty amazing. The poached eggs (this option has bacon, white cheddar and salsa) were probably my favorite. But you won't go wrong ordering any of these plates! 

I would definitely recommend this place for anyone who likes delicious food, friendly service and a cozy atmosphere. Loved it!
author: Deirdre D.

description: This restaurant is a sparkly neighborhood gem! The entire atmosphere is delightful, relaxed, cozy, with great service and a knockout French menu. Their portions are quite ample and I always have to take home half of my entree.   I don't ever remember eating such good French onion soup outside of Paris.  The cheese spills over the side of their traditional brown soup bowls and the crouton is yummy.  Everything is piping hot and flavorful.   Their couscous/lamb is complex and delicious and occasionally they offer Lapin au Moutarde (Rabbit in Mustard Sauce, a Provencal speciality) and it is incredible.  We recently tried a lemon mousse with raspberry sauce and it was a beautiful balance of sweet/tart.  My husband had their eggplant soup and it was wonderful too.  I recommend the 5 p.m. seating because at that time  we have had no problem parking.  Later it gets more difficult.  There is no tipping; the waitstaff is compensated by the owners and included in the price of the food and from what I hear employee benefits are very ample and, IMHOP, well deserved.
author: Renna U.

description:
Zazie is a french restaurant not too far from Golden Gate Park. My boyfriend and I were actually in search for a brunch food truck and when we failed at finding that we yelped up Zazie. 

We got seated at their cute little outdoor patio in the back (the space is definitely cozy and the tables close together). They have a large selection of drinks (mimosas! but not bottomless :( ) and you can tell their food is quality. Their ingredients are organic probably local (not sure about the latter). I ordered the eggs benedict with the crab with a side salad and my boyfriend ordered the same but with the shrimp. 

My salad was pretty standard the crab eggs benedict was really good though. The poached egg was perfect and everything was seasoned well. My boyfriend enjoyed his home fries and his shrimp eggs benedict. My only complaint would be that it was pretty pricey. My boyfriend only got 2 small shrimp on this benedict and his plate cost 12 or 13 bucks.. 

I like how you could choose different portion sizes. 

Oh yea..and there was a piece of spinach or whatever food on my boyfriend's fork..kind of gross but the waitress brought a new one right away.
author: Sam L.

description:
Got here around 11 a.m. for sunday brunch and got seated right away.  Actually, they were about to seat us but since not everyone in our party was present, we had to wait.  She finally arrived, but by then, there was a bunch of ppl waiting, so we ended up waiting another 30 minutes or so.  Boo.  On to brunch.  We all ordered various dishes, including yogurt with fruit, French Toast Tahiti (one slice was very large - was very sweet with not enough bananas), Eggs Saint Trop (came with salmon - friend liked it but the salmon tasted too fishy for me), Croque Madame (egg was cooked perfectly but wish they gave a bit more ham in the sandwich), and Eggs Monaco (w/ tomatoes and prosciutto - had a nice flavor).

Had to ask for water several times before getting it.  Portions were good, and I was stuffed by the end.  Food was good but probably not something I'd wait very long for again!
author: Caroline K.

description: Everything was amazing! So delicious and filling and creative. Worth the wait (be prepared to wait) and try a little of everything!
author: Aviva L.

description:
Yummy, but I must say, I'm not a huge fan.  Maybe its the hoards of prissy yuppies, mommies with double strollers, or just a general overwhelming sense of urban Caucasian snobbery that turns me off.  The servers seemed a little snippy to me, but maybe I'm just being paranoid that they were nicer to the white couple next to us...hmm...

Food was OK, not worth it for the price in my opinion.  Overall, between the vibe, the price, the quality, and the service, not one of my preferred places.  I would have had a much better experience at Kate's Kitchen on Haight.
author: Alice L.

description:
After a 30 minute wait (for a party of one...) I entered what appeared to be a comfortably decorated and cozy little cafe. The much hyped brunch menu was in full swing and everyone appeared to be eating large helpings of eggs, toast, and fruits. I ordered the Tahiti French Toast (with walnut and banana) with scrambled eggs and bacon. It took a while for the waiter to come with water, order and check, which is understandable because the place is crowded! They were fantastically friendly and helpful though. 

The food - I have no complaints. It was warm, sweet, and delicious. It's definitely very good breakfast food. However, in hindsight, I should have ordered the poached eggs  because french toast alone is too plain. 

Pros: Definitely has good food. Friendly staff, comfortable and relaxed atmosphere. 

Cons: Slightly overpriced ($2 for one egg), long wait.
author: Longwen C.

description:
Oh man. This place is great minus the wait, but it was warm so it wasn't too bad.

 Started with warm light cream cheese coffee cake with organic coffee- BEST part of the meal (going there just for that and coffee break very soon again). Split gingerbread pancakes- good but not amazing...sort of bland, couldn't taste the gingerbread part of it enough, too thick. Okay tasting pears with great lemon curd and housemade jam on the table. Perfect amount of a Side of THE best home fries ever and I am just recently become a home fries person- with chunks of soft baked garlic!! Yummm...

I missed the patio though!    Service - she was nice, but forgot the coffee after she brought our coffeecake, water was warm, no ice, and forgot my lemon for the water...No good.    

The food made up for it though - hence the four stars.
author: Candice H.

description:
I hadn't been back to Zazie in many many moons.  I'd even say that Yelp wasn't around the last time i ate here (shame on me)!

I got a scramble/skillet that consisted of eggs, prosciutto, basil and home-fried potatoes with a white cheddar  and it was decent.   Just what i would expect from a dish that had my favorite deli meat and cheese.  Very well done.

My Sister on the other hand ordered a dish called  Rue du Rosiers....it's a savory bread pudding with mushrooms and fontina cheese & eggs on top and a salad on the side.  OUT OF THIS WORLD!  The mushrooms and cheese were perfectly balanced and fresh to the hearty bread pudding.  The salad (which had some type of dressing or seasoning that i couldn't quite put my finger on) just made the whole thing taste even better by balancing out the heavy starch and protein with a fresh light aromatic green!  Culinary genius at it's best.

Great little French style cafe that's perfect for brunch and lunch.  The line tends to get pretty long so get there early and be prepared for a treat!

One of the reasons why SF is a great place for brunch!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Two words:  Eggs Benedict.  The lemon hollandaise sauce they put on top is wonderful.  And the egg was poached perfectly.  

Potatoes were a little too greasy for my liking, but I like the fried garlic they served it with.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I came here for brunch this Sunday around 10:30am with fellow Yelper Lindsay M. and another friend.  Despite it being super early (in my opinion) for brunch, there was already a big crowd outside of the place, and I put our name on the list.  The host told us it would be a 20-minute wait, at least, which wasn't too bad since there's enough stores in the area for good window-shopping while you're waiting.
