After a quick stroll around the neighborhood, we finally got our table (the wait was maybe about 30 minutes - not too bad compared to some of the other popular brunch places in the City where brunch waiting times can reach 2 hours).  We went indoors, and Lindsay and I immediately started snapping pictures of everything.  The decor was adorable - cute French paintings/posters all along the walls.  The whole place was bright, happy, and quaint.  I dig.  Add a star for the decor/environment.  

The menu is extensive, and everything sounds delicious.  I opted for the Fontainebleau, which was basically scrambled eggs with tons of different types of mushroom (porcini, shitake, and something else I can't remember), basil (my FAVRIT!), and fontina.  The dish came with a side of toast, and your choice of home fries or a salad.  I opted for the home fries after reading the Yelp reviews glorifying them.  

The whole dish was alright.  My eggs were kind of on the blander side, and those home fries were total greasebombs!  It was like each bite that I took squeezed a tablespoon of oil into my mouth while also leaving a puddle of oil on my plate.  Oh man, that amount of oil was not necessary!  It actually made me feel pretty sick afterward...but at least it was tasty enough.

I was telling myself that place was a 3.75 while I was eating, but now that I think about it, it's more of a 3.5, rounded down.  Rounded down because it's too expensive for what it is.  That egg dish was something like $11.  Ouch.

Maaaaybe I'll be back in the future, because the area and the ambiance is pretty nice.  But with the plethora of brunch places in this City, I'll probably hit up the other ones I haven't tried before making my way back here.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Best breakfast in San Francisco.

They let me keep the cool water vase thing too. :) nice.
author: Cruz K.

description:
Hands down the best place for breakfast in San Francisco.  Lunch and dinner are also good here, but I really can't give a thorough review because I've only come here for for lunch/dinner on New Year's Day. 

I normally just keep it simple with eggs and bacon here.  The potatoes are amazing, the bacon is thick and crispy, and the eggs are always to my liking.

Any type of "breakfast sweet" is completely and totally delectable.. Gingerbread/buttermilk pancakes...French Toast...all to die for.

Great coffee, espresso drinks and fresh squeezed juices.  

The back patio is unreasonably charming.
author: Angelica  C.

description: This place delivers again and again. If you can, go on a weekday to enjoy the brunch without the crazy wait. The specials are a must. Went last week and thoroughly enjoyed the polenta breakfast special served in a tiny iron skillet and the miracle pancakes.
author: Ellen S.

description:
I absolutely love Zazie. The wait is often brutal, but the food is definitely worth it. 
The lemon hollandaise cause is brilliant; it's light and flavorful, and it serves as the perfect complement to the crab and avocado on the benedict I always order. The first time I went, one of my eggs was over-poached, but the second time, both eggs were cooked perfectly.
The service is also friendly and attentive, and the spot is cute and cozy. Definitely one of my favorite brunch spots in sf.
author: Cami J.

description: This place has a lot of potential....but the wait just kills it. We had to wait about 20 minutes to get seated, which isn't terrible. But we waited 40 minutes for pouched eggs and french toast....now that is ridiculous, I could have made them myself by then. I also ordered the lemon squeeze, it was a half full cup of lemon juice + ice, I didn't get it. On the bright side, the Albert pouched eggs were delicious, and made really well. Also, the potatoes that came with them were really good, because usually they taste like soap from breakfast places. The french toast on challah was pretty good, and the honey that came on the side tasted very fresh (I love good honey). Overall, a solid breakfast.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Incredible breakfast/brunch fare. They don't cut corners with their ingredients and it's clear they take a lot of pride in each of the platings.

The egg scramble Mexico with chorizo and salsa is the best I've ever had. It's a common style scramble you see at a lot of other breakfast restaurants, but Zazie takes it to another level. I asked for hot sauce or Tabasco for the scramble, and they came back with a small jar of the homemade stuff. Awesome. I almost wanted to drink it straight up. The home fries are awesomely exceptional. Each serving is complemented by cloves of roasted garlic. I've had many a home fries in my days around the country and these are simply the best I've ever had. If you don't love garlic (sad if true) then you may not share the same enthusiasm for the home fries that I have. Finally, we shared a small plate of the French Toast Tahiti and it was divine and decadent. We gobbled up our entire meal...imagine a silicone spatula clearing our plates...sorry, nothing to compost from our plates! (We also didn't have to eat again till 7 hours later)

On the minus side, the place is crowded, and you'll have to wait outside till your name gets called, but I think the food is worth it. If you don't like crowded tables close to each other, then that's another minus...you'll clearly hear the conversation next to you, and if you are large, then you may feel claustrophobic. Yes it's a bit pricey, but again, they don't cut corners on the ingredients, so the value is in the food. 

5 stars, as the food is top tier.

-
author: Joe P.

description:
Came here for brunch and to check out the area. The wait was long - over an hour. I suppose it's common in SF now. That said, for such a long wait, the place better be good, so I had high expectations. 

We ordered la mer, French toast tahini and the burger. The crab Benedict was good but a bit thin on the crab portion - I've had better even at brickhouse in SOMA. The French toast was pretty delicious with stuffed bananas and walnuts. Worth it. The burger was juicy - better than Marlowe burger. The service was underwhelming. I'd give it a 2 star. The white waiter def had an attitude but the Hispanic staff was great. 

Overall a decent place for brunch but def not worth going out of your way for.
author: V W.

description: yummm.  Have had dinner here twice and have enjoyed it both times.  I love the living wage and insurance policy this place provides for their staff it makes me feel good about eating there.  The food has been rich but not heavy and the drinks are on point.  If you are in the area it is def a place to check out.
author: Betty W.

description: Trying to go to Zazie has always been a challenge since the place is tiny and there is usually a long wait but we went during the work week and it's much more manageable.  The staff is super friendly and the food is awesome.  I ordered the Mexico scrambled eggs and it was really good.  Definitely ask for their homemade salsa though as it have a great kick and makes the meal.
author: Blake B.

description: Yes, yes, the brunch is one of the best in the city. No arguments there. But I prefer their dinner menu and ambiance. Still a packed house, of course, just not quite as crazy as the morning rush. Their wine list is excellent, the food is consistently and drool-worthingly awesome, as well as the service (ask for Aiden's section), and don't be a fool - save plenty of room for dessert. Did I mention there's a romantic, heated patio in back? And complimentary bread and butter? And free corkage Tuesdays? And dog party Mondays? And no tipping? SF needs more Zazies. I'm a forever fan.
author: Lisa N.

description: A good brunch place...like everything there....and the turnover rate is pretty fast.... Well... I mean on a weekday brunch...
author: Chin Man L.

description:
My boyfriend and I love brunch.  Seriously love brunch.  We go out every weekend - both days - for brunch.  Since we were car-sitting a friends vehicle over the weekend, we decided to try a new brunch place that we wouldn't normally go to.  We chose Zazie's based on the number of Yelp reviews and the fact that a few of our friends has been previously and recommended it.  And I'm sure glad we did!

We were able to pick out Zazie's from the number of people lining the sidewalk waiting for open tables.  I suppose we should have anticipated there'd be a long wait based on the Yelp reviews, but it wasn't too bad.  We arrived in the later afternoon and waited between 45 minutes to an hour.  It was sunny outside so it wasn't a hardship.  

Even though parking is street side it wasn't hard to locate.  We managed parking on one of the neighborhood streets a block away but there were plenty of prime spots along Cole that opened up.  

I really enjoyed the quaint farmhouse-y vibe that Zazie had.  It was simple but still homey, welcoming and just a happy place.  I think I say this because of the pale yellow walls but I stand by it.  Service was quick, efficient and friendly.  As we were starving we ordered immediately upon sitting down.  I ordered the Un, deux, trois - slice of french toast, bacon and eggs.  My boyfriend ordered the special omelet - pesto, chicken apple sausage, cheddar cheese, mushrooms, and something else that I can't remember.   Both were exceptionally good; there wasn't even a spec of food left on either plate.  

I'm really glad that we came to Cole Valley to try our Zazie's.  Since the N muni line is just a block away, I have a feeling we will be making out way back out this way for more brunch yumminess in the future.
author: Bridget A.

description:
This place makes brunch one of the best meals ever.  Eggs Benedict? Delicious.

This place is pretty packed so expect at least a 10 minute wait.  There is a decent amount of seating indoors and outdoors in the back but when I came, they seem to be all filled as well as people outside waiting eagerly to get in.  If it's worth mentioning, their customer service is superb.  They have someone out there talking to you personally to let you know the status of the wait, as well as making small talk to make it more bearable.  But it doesn't end there, they come around often enough to make sure everything is fine when you're eating and constantly fill your glasses of water/coffee.

I got the Albert with one poached egg served with bacon, white cheddar, and homemade salsa fresca on top of an English muffin with hollindase sauce along with a choice of a salad or fries (country style potatoes) as a side.  The hollindase is delicious, not over the top creamy to allow the other toppings show off their flavor but good enough to have just on the muffin alone.  This place didn't disappoint and hours after eating it I was still complimenting my friend for a good brunch pick.

The salad was nothing special, I got it because I thought it would be french fries but had I known it was country style potatoes, I would have gotten that instead.  My friend, which did order the fries, were half and half on how they felt.  Some didn't like the abundance of garlic (the garlic was still shelled too) while others enjoyed the garlic.  They give a pretty fair ratio of garlic and potatoes so if you're not a fan of garlic, I'd probably stay away.  

And being brunch, my friends were expecting free refills with coffee, which were granted without asking.  Awesome.  I didn't leave gut busting full but I did leave very content with the food hitting the spot.  I mean brunch shouldn't put you to sleep anyway.  I'd definitely come back and this review is probably pointless because it will disappear from the front page within a few days.  I'm not surprised this place is getting so much attention and this is for sure not all hype.
author: Mike P.

description:
A-freaking-mazing. Like any girl on a diet, I was planning on picking healthier menu choices -- but my friends insisted on sharing the most popular dishes. I'm so glad they did, because YUM. A week later, I am still thinking about my brunch here.

- Tahiti french toast: mind-meltingly delicious. Not too sweet or overly rich. Just... so... great. And: I had my leftovers warmed up with ice cream. I hate using the word, but it was seriously orgasmic.
- Gingerbread pancakes: yummy, though I wasn't blown away. It's a huge, cake-like portion. The pear and lemon curd were a great accent -- more of both would've been wonderful.
- La Mer poached eggs/eggs benedict: perfectly executed. Fluffy crab, fresh avocado, deliciously runny egg, toasted sliver of English muffin.

The wait on a Saturday wasn't as bad as expected (40 minutes for a table of 3 around 11:30am), especially because a lot of folks left after putting their names down. Tip: you can swoop in and grab one of the two tables out front if you're fast enough, but we were glad we waited for our patio seats. Service was friendly and fast. Definitely a repeat spot.
author: Julie D.

description:
Local delicious French cafe, with impeccable service and lovely setting. Dine al fresco! Breakfast really is as good as the sidewalk's swarm out front every weekend implies. Lunch and dinner are also equally fantastic. 
My favorites are any of the salads, seafood specialties, pasta, desserts!
A treat and a homey place to visit, but special enough for celebrations. 
Best for smaller groups.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Wow, so good! Years ago when I lived in SF, I had friends that lived in that neighborhood.. Zazie wasn't there then....which is a good thing, because I would have been there all the time and would have gained a ton! 
Food is great, very interesting selection and so much to choose from. We went on a weekday, so our wait was only a couple of minutes. Sat out in the back patio. Small, but nice. I know the wait is super long on weekends, the place is pretty small.
Our party had a mix of breakfast and lunch items and everything was delicious and fresh. Bloody Mary was very tasty, too.
Service was attentive and friendly. I know we will be going back when we can.
You won't mind the wait once you have the food.
author: Lori L.

description:
As a vegetarian, I'm not going to lie, I was kind of sad that I couldn't participate in the 3 course set meal.  But I was able to survive off bread and my main dish.  The place is super quaint on the inside.  Best to make reservations, or you will have to sit outside.  The staff was really nice, stellar service.

Now the food.  So many flavors were going on inside my mouth.  It was like having a fireworks of flavor going on.  Portions I felt were perfect, it filled me up.  Dessert I'd have to say was the best part of the night.  Really liked the cream brulee and the chocolate pudding.

Prices:  It is easily over $25 to eat here.  So bring your credit card.
author: Michelle M.

description: Amazing pancakes. Top notch mimosas! Especially the elderberry mimosa and try the one with peach sorbet and cranberry! Delightful! Potatoes are cooked to perfection. They do amazing things in that little kitchen! Get there right when it opens as they don't take reservations for small parties. If you have to wait...WAIT! You (and your stomach) will be happy you did!!!
author: Lindsey R.

description:
there is often a long wait but it is quite easy to find reservations. 

I love it here. Basic good California French. 

Try eating here beside brunch. There is more to life than eggs benedict and mimosas children.
author: Peter M.

description: The dinner here was a little bit of hit and miss. The entrees we tried were the polenta cakes and the lemon ricotta ravioli. The polenta cake had a spicy tomato-chevre sauce that was way too sharp and pretty much ruined the dish for us. We had to eat around it. The ravioli was nice, though nothing outstanding. The desserts were great though - the crumble aux fruits and the pain perdu/bread pudding.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
4.5* Adorable little place this is!  At the same time, it felt full but not uncomfortable.  Service is a little on the slower side but I understand it is busy there.

Now onto the food..
*gingerbread pancakes w/bosc pears and lemon curd- I lack a sweet tooth for the most part, but THIS was Y-U-M.  Not too sweet and the lemon curd and pears made it more special and 'adult-like' treat that's not just for kids or the holidays.
*New York scrambled eggs (with wild smoked salmon, green onions, and cream cheese)- this was a wild party in my mouth.  My weak spot is savory foods and this was it.  There was a perfect ratio of salmon to cream cheese to egg.  Nothing was overpowered.  If anything, the egg brought out the subtle flavors of those ingredients in the scramble.  It came with perfectly cooked crisp "home fries" potatoes and roast garlic.  

I would definitely eat here again.  Next time, I am ready to try poached eggs or sandwiches for lunch.
author: Kimberly C.

description: I'm not a big fan of breakfast but oh man! I definitely fell in love with this place. Mimosa was awesome... The food was great! Just try it out! It's MUST!!
author: Michelle N.

description: Delectable and sinfully delicious. European hours but not that big of a deal.
author: Chad D.

description:
I'll keep it brief given the long list of rave reviews... I do spy a handful of bandwagon fans but hey, they're a dime a dozen, and Zazie is pretty chill, lovely, and yummy all around.

It really is a cozy, accommodating cafe.  I emphasize accommodating because my friend and I wandered in at 2:50pm, and the kitchen was doing last call for orders at 3pm.  Our server was totally chill about it, and offered that we please take our time.  That patience alone prompted me to add my voice to the 2000+ Yelp voices for this business.

BEVERAGES: my friend had the house coffee, which was a welcome cup on a windy, chilly June afternoon.  I had the VANILLA ROOIBOS tea.  I was wondering why it was priced so high, but I realize it pays for the portion, as I was given a full pot of delicious, delicious tea.  There was something so sophisticated about that vanilla edge to a typically low-bitters, calming tea.

FOOD: my friend had the soup du jour (ALWAYS VEGETARIAN), which was a CREAM OF MUSHROOM that day.  Very home-y, comfort food.  The bowl was smaller than she expected, but it ended up being a very good, appropriate portion.  She also had EGGS ANY STYLE WITH BACON, A SALAD, AND WHITE TOAST.  She actually ordered only one egg, scrambled, and the portion looked gigantic, as if it were two eggs really.  Seasoned and fluffed well nonetheless.  It was a very generous plate of food, and she didn't finish all the bread.  I went for the CHALLAH FRENCH TOAST, two slices, no fruit.  It was sliced quite beautifully.  Now I'm a French Toast purist, so while my order was cooked well, I believed the slices were a bit airy and I felt it wasn't as moist as other orders I've had elsewhere.  I had to add much more syrup than I typically would.  The flavor was just the right amount of sweet without said syrup, so with a tad more moisture, this dish would have been more phenomenal.

Quick tip: if there's a line for the restroom, you are welcome to just wander into the bar next door.  One of the employees was laidback and laughed "Oh yea, I do that all the time.  They don't mind, so feel free to skip on over."
author: Allison C.

description:
We chose Zazie for our small (~50 guest) wedding - both the ceremony and reception - and it was awesome.  Zazie doesn't usually host the ceremony (just the reception), but they worked incredibly hard to make it a great event.

Here's the condensed story:  Our first venue/caterer fell through.  We found ourselves looking for a new venue late in May with a wedding date of mid-October.  We had under 5 months to start from scratch with a limited budget.

We needed somebody to step up and that's what the folks at Zazie did.  We contacted Jen about buying out Zazie for our event and she got back to us the next day.  After working through the initial details, Suhail took over and helped us through the rest of the process.  I want to emphasize here that up to this point, we had not dealt with anybody in the wedding industry as responsive and capable as Jen and Suhail.  Committing to Zazie as our venue was a no brainer.  They helped us get back on track.

A couple months before our event, Suhail began working through the specifics with us.  He suggested Loop Flowers & Event Arts for decorations, which proved to be a great recommendation.  In addition to helping us select great food and drinks, Suhail really helped us think through the entire event with regards to timing, transitions, and all the details (sound system, procession logistics, etc.).  For example, I have this one email chain between us and Suhail that was almost 50 messages long.  He remained calm and organized throughout the planning process.

We used the patio for the ceremony, which required the removal of almost all the tables back there.  In coordination with Loop, Suhail and his crew turned the patio into a beautiful, intimate space for our ceremony.  After that, we all went inside while they converted it back into seating for dinner.  They even returned all of the table runners and decorations to their proper positions.  It was an incredible amount of work and they clearly went above and beyond.

In addition to the coordination and logistical help, the day-of service was excellent.  Our guest count and the sheer volume of food we ordered (appetizers, 3 courses with sides, desserts) must have pushed their kitchen to its limits, and yet each plate was perfectly done.  Several guests remarked at length about how nice and attentive the staff were, not to mention how mind-blowingly excellent the food was.  Event the foodies in our group were completely satisfied.

Suhail was there the whole time, checking in with us to see if we needed anything.  We got so much more from him and the rest of the super-friendly Zazie staff than we expected.  Because of them, our wedding was a complete success.  Thank you!
author: John G.

description:
My first time here & I'm floored! 

The staff are very nice !! The food is superb!! Mimosas will knock you out (full disclosure: I'm a cheap date). 

I forgot what we ordered!! Darn it! Blame it on mimosas!!
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
A single sunny day in San Francisco. The city's human species set out on a mass migration that will take them out from their 750 sq ft. apartments to fill the restaurants and bars that offer what the majority of San Franciscans only can dream of; a back patio. It's a migration with high risk and equal reward, one of probable long waits, and the chance to bask in the golden rays within the city of the golden gate. There may be no better place to migrate to than Zazie. They offer one of the best patio experiences in the city. It's lush, shaded, sunny, spacious, comfortable and adds the perfect touch of umami to your dinning experience. This morning we left our humble abode to set out and enjoy our breakfast Zazie patio style:
 
The Le Mer with poached eggs oozing with yoke and fresh hand picked dungeness crab made me wonder if their chefs moonlight as crab fisherman by early morning. The Fontainebleau scramble with portobellos, shiitake, porcinis and spinach was earthy and well balanced. Their Housemade Cream Cheese Coffee Cake, the best coffee cake since the creation of coffee cake, had us eyeing the cake on the table next to us with the kind of jealousy you might not find in someone who just finished their own generous serving of coffee cake. That's how good!

We have been to Zazie countless times. Always impressed, including everyone visiting who we brought along. There will be a wait and it will always be worth it. You can request the patio, this may add to the wait, but as the city's migration proves, this is the experience you want to have. Today we arrived before they opened, vied for position and found ourselves 3rd on the list. When we walked out, full, happy and patiofied, 20 fellow migrants waited their turn.
author: Michael R.

description: Cute cozy place in a pretty popular neighborhood. I came here with my friend pretty early, 30 min after they opened, and the place was full. Our portions were pretty good and really delicious. I had pancakes and I was pretty generous with their homemade strawberry jam. It isn't a cheap place for breakfast but definitely a notch up your standard breakfast place.
author: A K.

description: LOVE the brunch! Great service, food, drinks. Everything was top of the line. The only reason im taking off a star is because of the wait. 2 hours for food is just not normal. Please start taking reservations!!!
author: Sania M.

description:
Let me save you some time. Get the gingerbread pancakes.

I ordered some egg scramble with a copious amount of mushrooms in it; my dining partner ordered eggs florentine. Both good, but get the gingerbread pancakes.

We ordered a gingerbread pancake to share, and that is what you should get. It came with a baked pear and some lemon curd, which only served to enhance the already stellar flavor of these pancakes. Get them. You won't regret it.
author: Mike S.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars
I would've given this place 4 stars if I didn't have to wait for over 1hr to be seated on a Sunday morning for brunch.We got there at 1030am, and were seated at 11:45am.  Don't get me wrong, but I don't mind waiting for good food, but i found Zazie like any typical 3-4 starred restaurant. It was good, but not exceptionally, unforgettable GREAT.

Note: there are two tables in front of the restaurant--first come, first serve for those tables--no need to be on the waiting list!

I ordered:

 1) La Mer: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados. (i just checked their menu online, and don't see it anymore?)  (3.5/5)
2) Challah French Toast  with orange cinnamon batter (3/5)

Overall, my La Mer was good, but not worth the cost. It was around $18 for very minimal dungeness crab! The French toast was also alright.
author: Jen H.

description: It was ok - not great. I had a scramble and my husband had a veggie Benedict that he was very unenthusiastic about. He said it was dry - and it certainly looked it. Service was ok, not great. We were a little disappointed overall, given all the great reviews.
author: Suzy K.

description:
I'm good with sniffing out places because I travel a lot. I expected better from this place reading the reviews on yelp. 

Don't be tricked into thinking it's worth your time especially if you are just traveling through San Francisco. 

My boyfriend and I were traveling up from L.A. and San Fran was our last stop. We only spent a day and night there so we made sure where we were going was good. I want this place to be good, but it's not and here's why:

1. It's way too busy (over an hour wait for table of two) not only is the wait bad, the service is slow because there are just too many people. 1 star.

2. The food is NOT that good. It's a high class price for worse than diner food. Runny omelette, watered down coffee, and a poorly dressed salad is not worth the price.   The crab Benedict was fair. 2 stars.

3. The ambiance was okay, just way too busy and crowded for the type of food I was offered. I like that the walls are painted and covered with French paintings and pictures, but it doesn't make up for my awful experience. 3 stars.

The reason I give it an overall of 1 star: the WORST part was that I went to the bathroom as my boyfriend stepped outside for some air and when we came back, everything was cleared. His beer was gone and my food was gone. I have never left a bad tip, but this time I left a 5.00$ tip on 55.00 tab. 

The waiter was too busy to realize that I had gone to the restroom and didn't tell the bussers. I had even left my purse and jacket there!!! When I returned, a man was sitting in my seat where my belongings were. It was awkward and upsetting that I paid for such a bad experience.

Overall, I prefer good service and food over a hyped up café that can't even keep up with it's customers.
author: Bryanna M.

description: The food was undoubtedly delicious.  And I love the concept that they pay their employees a fair wage, 401k, health insurance etc.  I hope that the no tip policy isn't directly related to the poor service we received.  Our meals arrived. No one ever asked how they were or if we needed anything else.  My coffee sat empty for half the meal and I was never offered a refill. The only bad item I wouldn't order is the orange juice....for having such great food the OJ was blah. Great food....but there are other places with great food AND service that I would choose before Zazie.
author: Jason F.

description:
Zazie, you personify what brunch should be, anywhere. You have raised the bar to unfair heights. You leave me no choice than to leave you my first 4 and 1/2 star rating. Here are the deets my yelpers.

Food: There's great finesse in Zazie's food. From the perfect roasting in their house fries to impeccable poaching of their eggs, they are a master of their craft. The challah French toast is a revelation. It's lightly battered to perfection with hints of cinnamon and orange. Their croque monsieurs are one of the best in the city. The "Albert" with it's poached eggs, bacon, white cheddar and pico de gallo is such a flavorful combination of flavors.

Service: While the service here is always polite and courteous, it can be a bit slow or forgetful at times. It's because of this issue that has held me back from giving Zazie, a coveted 5 star rating. 

Ambience: Completely charming and inviting. The interior with its rustic French decor, creates a wonderful dining experience that transports you to the European countryside. The back patio is hands down, one of my favorite spots to eat in SF. It's like literally stumbling upon a unicorn. It's a space of beauty and relaxation.

Verdict: I couldn't imagine a life without Zazie. The world, (at least SF) is a better place because of its existence.
author: AJ V.

description: La Mer Benedict & gingerbread pancakes! Try them. Kick the syrup to the curb! The lemon curd is all you need!
author: Connie Y.

description: Came here three times for brunch, the first two times, we ended up at the crepe place across the street because the wait was too long. The third time, we came around 2 and were seated promptly. The food here is light and simple. My friend had a simple salad, I had an omelet and we shared some gingerbread pancakes. They also have excellent mimosas too. Hope to try the place again.
author: Alice W.

description: As a resident of the DC Metro area, I am very experienced when it comes to brunch. Brunching is what we do on the weekends, which normally turn into day parties for us millennials. I must say I was underwhelmed; I had such high hopes for the Tahitian French toast but there was no umph, flavors didn't stand out to me. However I did very much enjoy their hash/potatoes that had ROASTED GARLIC mixed in. Also be prepared to wait for a table, but keep in mind the outside seating is first come first serve, you see a party empty and grab the seats before someone else does. You can still put your name on the waitlist and have it removed if you are lucky enough like me to grab one of the outside tables.
author: Latavia K.

description: Best brunch in SF that I've tried so far. The wait is long, but it's totally worth it. The food is very well made and tasteful. I highly recommend it!
author: Ana Carolina J.

description:
If you decide to go to Zazie's (for whatever reason- you read it that it's a SF must on a blog ahem SF Eater, magazine, travel guide, or read the hundreds of rave reviews on Yelp) come early. By early, I'm talking between 8-8:40am. It's usually about a 40 minute wait esp. if you arrive around 11:30 (peak brunch time)

Zazie's wait will frustrate you, especially if the weather isn't pleasant and in SF, that's pretty much year round. October is the best time to go to Zazie's, it's when it's warmest in SF and you can eat outside on the patio. If you're there and waiting, you might as well note that you'd like to eat outside. I went with someone who isn't the type to take photos of where/ what she eats but she took her phone out and started clicking away. Yep, Zazie's is that kind of place.

Zazie's is known for their french toast and poached eggs. Their florentine poached eggs (with spinach & mushrooms) were incredibly tasty. I would recommend ordering 3 eggs if you're really hungry and want to come out stuffed. 

No unlimited mimosas here at Zazie's. They also charge $1.25/ per person so they can provide benefits for their employees. If that's where my $1.25 is going, I'd be happy to pay.

My bill came out to over $50 (including tip) for two poached egg dishes (2 eggs each) & 2 mimosas. 

Parking: difficult in the area.
author: Rosa L.

description: I have been here a couple of times. Not the most memorable place to have brunch. I do remember the gingerbread pancakes. It was good, but not amazing.
author: Michelle S.

description: Fell in loveee with this place when my friends and I went to SF earlier this year! The ambience and decor are inviting and super cute! We sat on the outdoor patio which was furnished with wooden tables and benches, umbrellas, flowers, etc. Such a perfect setting for an afternoon lunch on a beautiful day! I got the La Mer eggs benedict and WOW! It was simply delicious! I had never had eggs benedict before Zazie, so this experience definitely fueled my new obsession with poached eggs! Hahah I couldn't get enough of them on my SF trip! Anyways, all the food we ordered was delicious! We also shared mimosas! I had such a great time here and Zazie really kicked off my trip to a great start! (:
author: Rachel G.

description:
I have been to this place many times for brunch and it's always good food but my recent experience for dinner was still great food but terrible service. 

So 5 stars for food, be prepared for a wait. The pancakes are amazing. 
3 stars for service.
author: Melissa O.

description: YUM! YUM! YUM!  YUM! I had the poached eggs with salmon and yummy potatoes!
author: Julia G.

description:
A friend suggested Zazie in response to a request for San Francisco restaurant recommendations. It was the only breakfast spot on her list and came with specific instructions to order the coffee cake. Oh my goodness the coffee cake.... 

I wake up some mornings thinking about the coffee cake. I have written to Bon Appetit hoping they will get the recipe for their Restaurant Recipes Requested by Readers column (so far no luck). Everything else I had was very good and service was great, but obviously coffee cake is my standout.
author: A K.

description:
Stuffed french toast...two thumbs up!

Wait was long but worth it...coffee was huge and the staff was friendly
author: Alex M.

description: I've been here only once, but it was great.  I loved "La Mer" (porched eggs with Dungeness crab and avocado).  I ordered two eggs, but I could have eaten three since it was so delicious and light.  Zazie Mimosa was not so tasty to me.  Service was very good.  I'm happy to go back there if I'm in the area.
author: Akiko O.

description: I really like Zazie. The food is good, the patio is small but very enjoyable. The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is because of the wait at lunch time. That takes away from having the perfect experience.
author: Florence G.

description: Excellent brunch option especially for people who love sweets!  We had French toast and amazing pancakes. Their price includes tips and service is amazing here!  Definitely will come back!
author: Ann B.

description: Best brunch in town. My only complaint is that too many people share this belief so the lines are heinous. Pro tip if you're the drinking sort: go to Finnegan's next door and enjoy a Bloody Mary beforehand. If you're not: trek down to Stanza on Haight and have a slowly made pour over coffee, because it's gonna be a while...
author: Amity B.

description: So the 1 hour wait to get in was treacherous BUT SO WORTH IT! Don't let the "douchie bros" and "basic bitches" discourage you from enjoying the great ambiance and EXCELLENT service! I've been to various brunch spots around the city but this one by far is best! Vegetarian food and great cocktails are available to choose from making the menu more diverse and adventurous! A mushroom scramble sounds easy to make but I've had the displeasure of eating many failed attempts at other restaurants. NOT HERE! The scramble was MAGNIFICENT! I recommend the "Le Metro" *french accent* cocktail. Wine, champagne, sparkling lemonade and lavender simple syrup? What's not to love? It's crisp and semisweet! Perfection in a glass.
author: Juan C.

description:
Poached eggs on Lockdown, I'll be coming back to try some of their other combos.
 
Great service and atmosphere. Peep the patio on a nice day. Nice neighborhood.

Plan ahead, there could be a wait, you're not the only "lazy to make a delicious breakfast person." GEEEEeeezzz

Only 4 stars because who really serves french toast with melon. I may be a douche for this, but I like bananas, strawberries or blueberries with french toast, ok?

Saddle up partner, Enjoy!
author: Brendan C.

description: I had only been to Zazie once and the food was so delicious that I was yearning to go back as soon as possible. So yesterday I finally got to return to Zazie and get my brunch on. Everything was swell until I discovered a piece of glass (or really hard plastic) in my granola and yogurt. Normally I'm not super crazy about these mishaps, I'm very forgiving and understanding because shit happens. However, the waiter couldn't have cared less. He neither apologized nor comped any part of my meal. I assumed it was common courtesy to at least apologize when your customer nearly chips a tooth on a piece of glass found in the food you served her. But nope, he simply took the chunk, shrugged his shoulders, and walked away. Needless to say I won't be returning here.
author: Maria C.

description:
We had dinner here a few weeks ago, and were pretty pleased with our meal, as well as the service.. 

Prices are VERY reasonable, and I appreciated that there were some light dishes on the menu. 

I had mussels to start, and I have to say, they were some of the best mussels I've ever had. Cooked perfectly, totally luscious. Although, i didn't like that they came in such a creamy broth. I basically had to kind of tip them out and let the excess drip off. I just can't eat that amount of cream. 

For my entree i had the trout. It was also cooked perfectly, with a nice crispy skin, and topped with leeks and butternut squash. All things I love. It also came with some mixed greens. 

All in all a good meal at a cozy neighborhood place. I i lived nearby i would return, but it's not a destination restaurant.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Overall it's 4 stars, but we witnessed something that makes me bump it to 5. 

First, it's a cozy, popular French inspired place that is lovely for brunch. They have lots of delicious options, and you WILL have a hard time choosing. Everything we had was delicious, but the miracle pancakes (pancakes made out of bread pudding) will be in my dreams for years to come. 

The staff was super accommodating to our having a baby and the large stroller that comes with it. They even helped us carry the stroller to our table. They also did not bat an eye when we dined French style (i.e. staying for 2+ hours). 

Now, what bumps them to five stars from a star-greedy yelper such as myself? While we were leaving, we saw the owner/manager/whoever unload an ENTIRE truck full of presents for her ENTIRE staff. I repeat: Individually wrapped and picked presents for her staff. It was a sight to see. You can tell the owners know how important their staff is and cares about them. This was also evident in the menu note that describes an extra tax/fee they add on to provide health benefits for their staff. Wow.     (and don't worry the tax/fee was small enough that you won't mind)
author: Meghan M.

description:
How have I not reviewed Zazie's before? My first experience at Z was over 3 years ago, and of course I opted for their famous french toast. Though the wait was an hour long, it was well worth it.

I came back just the other day to have brunch with a girlfriend on their back patio, and the experience was still the same. Friendly service, amazing food, perfect portions, EXCEPT (gasp!) no wait! We waiting maybe a total of 20 minutes?! Amazing....

LOVE ZAZIE. Definitely an SF staple!
author: Meredith M.

description:
Roasted tomato and fennel soup- so good 
Seasonal pumpkin spice latte 
Le mer- bomb AF 
Buttermilk pancake 

Zazie's is always on point
author: Ari C.

description: Nice little spot with quality ingredients and a cute garden area for brunch.  However, I typically wouldn't wait an hour for this when there are a lot of other places in the area.  Ordered the poached egg on an english muffin with smoked salmon and capers.  Obviously, it's difficult to go wrong with this classic and they did it decently.  I was expecting the poach to be a bit runnier though.  The home fries were good as well, nicely seasoned but they left chunks of garlic in the potatoes which look like the potatoes at a quick glance which I think they should remove before serving.  Servers were good despite how busy it was.  Cost was higher than most brunch places but they get away with it due to good ingredients and the hype surrounding this place right now.
author: Sean S.

description: Disappointing this time around, service was down right horrible. I've been here for dinner and the wait staff in the evening is far better.
author: Martha M.

description:
I just haven't been myself lately. I was sitting at my table listening to my coffee being made and I wondered if I had made my coffee, literally ignored the sound of it dripping and freaked out. 

I forgot to set my elliptical. It was like, do you want to pedal? and I said yes. So I pedaled. Not how it works. Level 1 isn't a workout. 

And I forgot to review a restaurant. I know. I KNOW. Something is seriously wrong- I call it law school. (Don't go.) (If you're there, run fast.)

But in the midst of my mind f- of school, Jenna F. had her most lovely of birthdays. She and I met up for brunch here some day last week.

Maybe there is something wrong with me, but there was also something wrong with this. Their famous ginger pancake was bland. Their french toast was... um... is that french toast? Really? its like... puffed air with syrup. But their crab eggs benedict was good. 

Why do you put lemon in everything? 

Bottom line- its... good food? But not the best food. And I wanted to like you so much. 

* I promise to come back and review it when I am emotionally stable and my brain is not a cotton ball.
author: Emily D.

description:
Great breakfast spot off the beaten path.  Cole Valley has a charm of it's own and I think it is mostly in part to this amazing brunch spot.  Of course breakfast is almost non-existent here in the city since no one opens until the hours of 9 and 11am and people are up earlier of course.  But Zazie is definitely worth the wait for a good meal.

The servers are helpful, fun, and entertaining and the food speaks for itself.  If it's a nice day outside - sit in the back courtyard....it's worth the extra wait.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Just found out about this place even though apparently it's been there for years. A good meal at a fair price, and an awesome wine list

Pros:  location, small outdoor patio, good food/drink

Cons: service was a bit slow & borderline rude, but it was crowded on a Sunday brunch.  Parking in the area is awful. Take a cab/über/bus
author: Troy H.

description:
I can't believe I've been to SF three times with my husband and this is the first time he's taken me here. Everything is perfect--quaint little resto, beautiful back garden with vines and flowers, but most of all, the food is perfect. I don't use that term lightly!

Let's start with the coffee, served very French style in bowls, and delicious. We are total coffee snobs, so again, this is a real compliment. Secondly, the food. There was so much on the menu to choose from, but I chose the omelette of the day that was perfect in every way, especially the masses of bacon in it. 

But the potatoes on the side--oh dear lord, roasted garlic? Yes, yes, yes. Lovely, gorgeous roasted garlic cloves generously dotted throughout the potatoes. I die. 

The server was very friendly and sweet, and we went on a weekday, so we did not have any wait at all. I can imagine it's completely packed at the weekend!

Can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Acceptable food, too expensive for the overall experience.

I went to Zazie for a birthday dinner around 6pm. There were about 8 people in our party. I was not very hungry, so I just ordered a french onion soup and ate from a shared appetizer sample platter and tried some of others people's dishes.

They some people ordered from a 3 course prix fixe menu. Others ordered from the main menu. 

Entries mostly ranged from $16-$25. Overall the food was decent, but the overall experience did not match the cost. The wait staff was friendly, but ultimately not very professional and well trained. For an expensive restaurant I expect seamless service. Dishes were cleared at awkward times, dishes did not arrive together, etc. 


First we tried the appetizer platter:
Assiette de Charcuterie: paté, proscuitto, salmon rillettes, olives, cornichons, greens, spicy mustard $12
Overall, it was pretty good. I definitely recommend sharing it with a large group.

My french onion soup was decent. I have had better.

The birthday girl ordered a steak.
Grilled Niman Ranch Hanger Steak- w/ mashed potatoes, sauteed spinach, and portobello brandy cream sauce $21
It had to be sent back because it was extremely overcooked. It was much better when they brought it back. I had part of it and it was ok. The mushroom brandy sauce was surprisingly bland. 

I also tried the salmon:
Salmon en Papillote- w/ fingerling potatoes, spinach, leeks, and fennel, w/ shallot cream sauce  $16
tried steak, salmon, lamb

and the porkchops:
Grilled Niman Pork Chop- savory bacon and fontina bread pudding, Tuscan kale, cider spiked onion confit $21
Both were decent, but nothing to write home about. Some of the sides on the main courses sounded interesting on the menu, but ultimately none were particularly memorable. 

For desseert we shared a Duo of crème brûlée and a chocolate crème. Both were pretty tasty.

Overall, while the experience wasn't a bad one, but I was still slightly disappointed. Many dishes sounded exciting on the menu, but nothing ended up being particularly memorable. It might be worth checking out for lunch though.
author: Augusto T.

description: Effortless, excellent food and service staff that love their job. Aim for the patio if you can.
author: James A.

description:
Good service but I wait two hours to get in.
Don't waste your time ！The food is terrible
author: Audrey H.

description:
This place serves some delicious brunch fare.  If this review covered only the food, it would be a 5 star rating.  I shared the pancake sampler with some friends and could've died and gone to heaven.  It included: challah french toast, gingerbread pancake and buttermilk pancake.  All were delicious but the gingerbread pancake was the best and probably most difficult to find elsewhere.  The La Mer was pretty darn well made with fresh crab and ripe avocado.  Kudos to any restaurant that doesn't over pick apart crab.

Of course you'll have to take this info with a grain of salt as I was starving by the time we sat down to eat.  The wait was over an hour and half.  By then I could've eaten a piece of cardboard and given it a solid 3 stars.
author: Jenn L.

description:
You can only wait so long before the opportunity cost of the wait time exceeds the expectation of the meal. I mean, if I'm going to wait more than an hour for brunch - this place better be ridiculously glorious.

In other words, don't come here after 11:00am on the weekends unless you have absolutely no plans after. We called ahead of time and they told us that a party of 3 would take 30-45 minutes, but after our 5 minute walk there, we found ourselves waiting an hour and 15 minutes before being seated.

The place is quaint and the food is pretty good but nothing memorable in the city of brunches. I had the Pierre Noir Poached Eggs (with bacon and tomatoes provencales) and while it was tasty, I've had mind blowing tomato provencales at La Note, and better Eggs Benedict at Butler and the Chef) I did have a bite of my friend's Mexican Scrambled, and that was quite tasty!

The service is great though and there's a nice ambience! Just beware of the long wait time on a brisk winter's day.
author: May I.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant - I had the pork chop and it was incredible.  wine selection good as well.
author: Michael C.

description:
Saturday Brunch.

Yes, the wait is long, but they have it very streamlined.

The staff are very pleasant and attentive and the food is quite good.    I like that you can choose your portion size.  I had the Monaco-- nice English muffin, cute poached eggs, and just enough of a not too rich Hollandaise sauce.

The only things were I think they put a little too much vinegar in the water for their poached eggs (you could taste the vinegar) and one of the cloves of garlic in my home fries was burnt to a serious charcoaly crisp.  A little more quality control would've bumped this up a star in my book.

Very cute.  I'd definitely go back for a second shot if I lived around here...the pancakes look awesome.
author: Kes D.

description:
Zazzzziiiiieeeee, girl you delish!

St. Trop Eggs Benedict, it's a beautiful thing.  Salmon.  Capers.  Sauce.  Mmmm.
House Potatoes, oh so crunchy.  
Big Fluffy Gingerbread Pancake, I like you.

Cute Cole Valley spot.  They can get very busy but there's still quality control on the food that is coming out - so important.  This place will start your day off right.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Booked resies for 4 abdcarrived early-  initially we were to sit in the heated patio area, but the greeter let us sit in the comfy front seats by the front windows.

The service was seamless and food was quite delicious. 

What was really cool was watching a dad ride his cargo bike with his 2 kids in the front and the mom riding her own bike come in for dinner. No car or complications finding parking. Cool. We'll probably come again and try brunch-
author: Patrick S.

description:
I'm a big fan of breakfast food and Zazie did not fail on me. Came here early on a weekday, so parking was easy and we didn't have to wait in line.  

Came here with 2 other girlfriends and we shared their French Toast Tahiti (Stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts) and two plates of Monaco Benedict (proscuitto and tomatoes provencales)

Not a fan of walnuts but I will admit, their tahiti french toast rocked more than the benedict. It tastes so good with their raspberry jam!

Tried going back on a weekend and the line was insane and parking was frustrating. Now that I know, I will only go to Zazie on a weekday.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Had a lovely lunch at Zazie and immediately understood why this place is a San Francisco favorite.  The Cole Valley restaurant is small, quaint and charming.  On a Monday afternoon, it was packed and we had about a 20 minute wait for a table.  Despite how busy the place was, once seated in the front dining room, we were immediately greeted by a very nice waiter and brought menus and water.  I can't even tell you how difficult it was to decide what to order.  Everything on the menu was tempting.  I haven't been faced with such a delicious-sounding menu in quite some time.  I finally decided upon a lunch special, the lemon ricotta ravioli.

The five good-sized ravioli were served in a large bowl, swimming in a lemon butter sauce.  Ridiculously, ridiculously good.  The kind of good where you close your eyes and say "Mmmmmmmm!"  The kind of good where you stop talking to your lunch companion because you can't focus on anything but how delicious the food is.  Good.  My friend had the burger with garlic fries (whole bulbs of roasted garlic included) and was similarly enraptured.  Believe me, I am already planning my return visit for another date with those ravioli.

Service was excellent throughout the meal.  I've worked in restaurants and know how hard it is to stay cheerful when your tables are slammed.  Our waiter was friendly as can be.  On the way out, I decided to purchase some of Zazie's gingerbread pancake mix.  I can't wait to try it out this weekend.

**update: the gingerbread pancakes are RIDICULOUS.  Best pancakes ever.  I want more!**
author: Erin L.

description:
Zazie gets all 5 stars based on.. wait for it.. food! Imagine that. We really really enjoyed the food here. 

We had reservations for Friday night at 7pm, and good thing too because this place is tiny and quite popular. This place is soo cute! Very French. I love the high ceilings and that stairwell in the middle of the room. I saw the back garden area and thought it was super cute. 

We started out with an aperitif.. Le Metro. Oh I highly recommend this!! Delicious and bubbly. 
For appetizer I had the Patè de Volaille (chicken liver). They buttered the bread so generously and the patè spread on top.. perfection! Yum yum. My partner had the French Onion Soup which he thought was the best he's had. We also shared the Mac n Cheese.. très cheesy!! Oh so good. For main I had the Lamb Tagine.. another perfect dish. My partner commented how it tasted better than any Mediterranean place we've eaten at! It was served over couscous. The lamb was so tender and tasty. The sauce divine. I very highly recommend this dish! My partner had the Grilled Mascarpone Polenta Cakes. Is it too much to describe this as yet another perfect dish? If you're vegetarian this is for you. I thought it tasted so amazing, and surprisingly filling. Oh and we did share a half bottle of Malbec so we were all sorts of happy LOL. To top off the decadent evening we shared baked chocolate in a huge cup topped with golden marshmallow. Literally icing on the cake! 

I thought the food at Zazie really shined. It reminded me of a home cooked meal. . possibly somewhere in the French countryside. It just became one of my favorite resaurants in San Francisco.
author: Vol T.

description:
Zazie is my inaugural SF review, which is too bad, because there's so much better food elsewhere in this city.

Zazie is a perfect example of a frou frou brunch place. Cute decor, check. Laid back, happy staff, check. Backyard patio, check. That's great, if that's your bag, but if you're more concerned with food than ambiance, then read on.

I went to Zazie twice in one week - quite the feat considering the lines that metastasize into existence on the sidewalk outside during the weekend, but fortunately I live close by and had the week off, and so was able to take advantage of my circumstances. 

The eggs were highly touted, so on my virgin run I ordered a dish with poached eggs, bacon, avocado and hollandaise sauce on bread. This was totally fine, but really nothing special. If there were something more to it I'd be happy to go into more detail - really. I tend to avoid reading reviews without details because they don't communicate anything worthwhile - but that was it. It's not as though the eggs were so fantastic to be worth crowing about.

But then again, eggs are eggs, and it's tough to stand out with them, so I figured I'd go back once more and try something that could stand out, like, say, pancakes. A couple buttermilk pancakes with fresh fruit later and all I can say is that I was just as nonplussed as before. The pancakes are honestly no better than I could get at any old greasy spoon or diner anywhere in the country.

I realize it sounds like I'm ragging on Zazie, which I don't mean to do, only on the hype around it. There's nothing wrong with the food - except the prices: hello frou frou! I'll let that balance out the ambiance - but there's nothing great about it either, so I'm sticking with my a-ok, three star seal of approval.
author: Mike K.

description: This place really is great!  Came in on a week day with my son.  Sat outside and thoroughly enjoyed the excellent service.  Our coffee cups were refilled timely and the food was truly awesome.  My son's gingerbread pancakes are worthily of all raves on yelp.  I enjoyed PERFECT poached eggs over crab.  Put this place on your list of places to go....you will enjoy great service and great food.
author: Donna M.

description:
I wasn't impressed by Zazie's brunch (as evidenced by my earlier review) but tonight's dinner was amazing. Explanation:

The food: We started with a piping hot plain roll and a smear of butter- a really good omen for the meal. Then, onto the appetizer of figs on a garlic levain with chevre and wilted arugula- the figs were halved and pan seared or something that got them to have this jewel like, shimmering texture. soooo good! but it got even better- my mom's duck leg with fingerling potatoes had a delicious mustard cream sauce, and my pork chop with mint and pine nut cous cous, roasted chard, and a rosemary skewer of figs was seriously delicious. the pork was 98% cooked through so that it was so incredibly succulent and delicious...i was seriously surprised by the top notch dinner we had here.

The good: Zazie's, even at the mediocre brunch I had, pays great attention to the little things. There are congenial little signs like "please no substitutions, we're trying our best!" and even the little tray the check came on was painted in a French cottage esque manner.  The food has no hurried, plate and go kind of mannerism- instead it has an attentiveness to it that makes the presentation beautiful and the food absolutely yummy.

The bad: This is not a quick dinner place. My mom and I loitered for 2 + hours, chatting over our glasses of water- maybe a glass of wine would have functioned better here. That said, the slowness seems intentional to showcase the food.

Ambiance: cozy French and American fusion cafe 

Good for: DINNER, maybe I'll give brunch another try some other time.

In short: Affordable gourmet French food. Blown away by my amazing pork chops and the fig on garlic levain appetizer. This is definitely on my SF list for the long run!
author: Jackie T.

description:
Be prepared for a wait on the weekends, but it goes fast and it's definitely worth it.  Bring extra coins or an MTA card for the meter.  

-(*)French Toast Tahiti:  Stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts $ 6/ 10/ 13
(one, two, or three pieces)
-Gingerbread Pancakes:  with bosc pears (in season) and lemon curd $ 6/ 10/ 13
(one, two, or three pieces)
-Home-fries or toast $2

One piece would have been a perfet portion but since we waited 30 minutes, then I had to order extra for the road

(*) = Favorite
author: Stacey L.

description:
Woohoo!  Plus, I haven't even tried the pancakes!

Zazie's Eggs Benedicts are solid! Great tasting hollandaise. But I would skip the dungeness crab (La Mer)--the water soaks through the muffin and, in general, bland.

Their scrambled eggs are so fluffy; could scrambled eggs even be so tender?

FRIENDLY service. I also respect their respect for their workers, or at least it seems that everyone, regardless of their position in the kitchen, is appreciated.  

Dog-friendly outdoor seating. They have a back patio but I think it's only dog-friendly on certain days/evenings..

But you know what really kicks ass? Their salsa. Put that shit on everything!!!
author: Diane N.

description:
Solid French food. Attentive service from the main server. The guy who delivered the dishes, though, was a bit weird. Very shaky, and insistent, and just sort of jammed plates onto the table without paying much attention to where we were sitting &etc. Quite strange, really. The wine list was a bit short/anemic, too. Oh, and I'd have loved to see some Madeira for dessert  - it doesn't go bad, so it's a no brainer to add one!

All that said, I had a wonderful time here, and I'm sure almost anyone else would too. Really great food, great service with the one exception, and fair prices.
author: Tom G.

description:
As the search for the best brunch in San Francisco continues, I was lucky enough to stumble upon Zazie (by stumble, I mean my fiance is desperately trying to appease my desires after hearing me forlornly reminisce about the East Coast brunch scene)  and hot damn, this place is great!  

First of all, Zazie could reel in five stars for their extensive selection of eggs benedict varieties alone - the fact that they have one with smoked salmon - my all time favorite variety - pushes them to the top of my brunch list thus far.  The only thing that could make it better is if it actually tasted as good at it sounds, and the fact is, It tasted better.  In fact, Zazie makes one of the top 5 salmon benedict creations that I have had.  The rest of the menu was great - they have all the staples with some nice spins on the classics.  My fiance got a brunch sandwich, which consisted of arugula, prosciutto and a fried egg (everything is better with an egg) and we split a piece of challah french toast, because we simply couldn't help ourselves.  Another pro, they have a great selection of drinks from tasty coffee concoctions to breakfast cocktails.  

In other news, their staff was super nice and attentive.  Aesthetically, I found the space and decor very comforting, and the fact that they have a large patio for outside seating is a huge plus.  

If you're looking for a great meal at a place with a nice vibe, definitely check out Zazie!  I can't wait to return... and soon!
author: Virginia B.

description:
Zazie's always has a wait for brunch. Frequently 45 minutes to over an hour. My recommendation is to go as early as you can manage to crawl out of bed.

However, after 3 visits, I can easily say waiting for brunch is worth it every time. The beaufriend and I eat there every time I'm in SF, and it's a quick walk from the Haight St area. To be honest, I'd travel to get here.

As a vegetarian I haven't strayed from what I ate the first time: eggs florentine and skillet potatoes. The hollandaise is easily the best I've ever had. Just the right amount of lemon, and not heavy. The waiter brought us more upon request the last time we ate there. 

My companion always gets one of the styles of eggs "benedict" and always asks for avocado on top. They always oblige, even though the menu says they don't accommodate substitutions. 

The last time we went, we ordered 2 slides of the French Toast Tahiti, made with challah, supposedly from some bakery nearby though I'm not sure which. When we went around Thanksgiving, they were completely out of the challah for the weekend, so it was disappointing they hadn't planned ahead for the bakery's closing for the holiday.

The organic coffee is great, but I wish they would provide soy milk for creamer (at least ask ahead of time). 

The host (always the same guy in a zip-up athletic jacket every time I've been there) plays favorites. He'll let his friends (?) in when they're much farther down the list. Also, he once seated the two of us at a booth for 4. I even told him we didn't mind waiting for a small table so that a larger group could use the space, but he shrugged and walked away. The service also was pretty poor the last time we were there.

Also, it's a bit small, so be prepared to overhear everything everyone says in here, even out on the patio (which is charming enough to make me forget I'm 18 inches from the loud-talking girl next to me). 

Honestly, none of the complaints are enough to stop me from going back again. Not even the longest wait I've ever experienced. I'll do it again the next time I visit!
author: Jen S.

description:
Apparently pronounced "Zah-zee". Don't be a fool like me and pronounce it "Zay-zee" or "Zazzie" (rhymes with jazzy). 

Touted as the "Best Brunch in SF" for 2012, Zazie is an extremely charming little restaurant with a very warm interior atmosphere and a backyard patio with heat lamps. You want brunch? The key here is to get here as early as you can. The line starts getting pretty crazy around 11 AM. You need to put your name on a list at the front door. The alternative would be to ferociously battle other patrons for the two outside tables in the front which are first come first serve. However, you will have to sit through an awkward brunch where dozens of hungry eyes (dog eyes included) will be staring at you throughout the meal.

The eggs benedict here are great. The eggs are poached perfectly. I got the Albert, which consists of bacon and salsa fresca, with poached egg, all topped on a perfectly toasted english muffin. Do get the home potatoes. They are deliciously roasted with garlic cloves and herbs. My friend ordered the florentine, which is the poached egg with sauteed spinach and wild mushroom. Both were epic and tasty.

Enjoy a cup of coffee or a cocktail with your meal. The service was extremely friendly and prompt. The only "complaint" is that the seating in the backyard patio is pretty cramped, so you are in prime position to eavesdrop or be eavesdropped on by your dining neighbors. However, this is not Zazie's fault; they make do with their space. However, be mindful if you decide to talk about private matters.

To eat next: Gingerbread pancakes. I hear they're the bee's knees.
author: Dan K.

description:
We tried to brunch here on a few different occasions but couldn't justify the crazy wait times.  One night we dropped in for dinner and were promptly seated at quaint and cozy garden in back.  We started with the moules frites -- a dish we have a hard time saying no to anywhere we go -- and absolutely loved Zazie's take on this French staple.  Creamy white sauce that clung to every mussel, delicious right down to the last dunk of bread we mopped it up with.

For the main we had the Coq au Vin and as good as the moules were, the chicken outdid it.  Falling off the bone, flavour soaked, simple and satisfying.  We'll be back for this rustic French dish done right.

Friendly service, inviting decor, and reasonable prices made our night at Zazie a last-minute treat to remember.  Writing about it now has got me thinking a chilly SF night like tonight might be the perfect time to pay Zazie another visit.
author: Paul K.

description: My fiancé and I stopped by for brunch today. I ordered simple scrambled eggs, side potatoes, and toast. My fiancé had a polenta special. Neither was very good. Mine was too greasy and relatively tasteless. Service was awful, as it took at least 10 minutes to place our order, 25 minutes for our order to arrive, and our server didn't check on us at all after the food arrived. The check was another 10 minute wait. The restaurant was tipless, which I believed hindered the service we received, as the servers are guaranteed a wage, and therefore don't have to work hard to earn your tip. We won't be back.
author: mary g.

description:
Stopped in on Monday night, and got a cute table right in one of the front windows. You could squeeze up to 5 people in if needed! This is a very cozy and cute restaurant. On Mondays you can bring your pooch in to sit in the heated patio. Not sure why they don't do this other nights, but there was a little pooch parade around 7pm. Tuesday nights is free corkage night! Might have to try that! 

My dad had the duck breast, which was very tasty, although some may not like that it was cooked rare in the middle. I had the porcini with truffle ravioli, which was OK, although, I couldn't really taste the truffle. Nice presentation, attention but not overbearing service, and good portion sizes. Salads are very nice, and if you are in the mood for delicious vegetarian soup, get the bowl!! 

I really enjoyed it, and plan to try this place again.
author: Janette R.

description:
I saw the reviews for this place and decided to try it out. We ordered the omelet on the special menu & the poached eggs Albert. It was certainly delicious. Although prices were a bit pricey $8-$15 depending on what you order, it was not a disappoint. The poached eggs were delicious & I would definitely come back again. 

We ordered french toast as well & it was made really well. The wait was long after we got there around 930am. The service was great. They even had outdoor seating & a patio in the back too.
author: Loree T.

description: The food was delicious and the atmosphere great! I was waited on by Yonny today, and he was very attentive, friendly, and fast. Couldn't have asked for a better experience!
author: B B.

description:
We tried Zazie for New Year's/Birthday brunch this year and it did not disappoint.

We were a group of 10 so we had to wait a bit for a table but were able to sit outside with the heaters.

The eggs benedict are a staple. I prefer the La Mer with dungeness crab. Bonus - you get to choose how many eggs you want (1, 2, or if you're really hungover, 3). The French Toast Tahiti is heavy, but yum.

For dessert - the baked chocolate chaud is not to be missed. Les Deux Cremes will satisfy the creme brulee fans. My favorite, however, was the Petit Pot Du Creme Au Chocolate.

Overall, a solid brunch spot. I probably wouldn't wait 2 hours for a table, but a fantastic spot with outdoor seating for a great meal with great friends.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Zazie is mostly known for their brunch offerings but their dinner service is top-notch as well. Their charcuterie platter has a great variety of meats, cornichons, pâté, etc. The entree options are plentiful and features in-season offerings. 

Takeaways:

1. Attentive and friendly service. Nice outdoor seating is available also. 
2. Great quality and rustic presentation of awesome food. 
3. Good variety of wines as well as desserts.
author: Denny C.

description: Ate here for brunch. Got a seat on the back patio and it was a great experience. Good food, good waitstaff, and a charming back patio area. Slightly upscale without being stuffy. I'm not normally in the area for brunch or it would be a frequent brunch spot.
author: David H.

description:
I hate the wait. Even on a Wednesday at 2pm. But it is one of the best brunch places in the city. It's really hard to say no to coming here. 

Parking is awful and nonexistent, the line is quite absurd, and there aren't really places to sit and wait except for the bar next door, and it's cramped as hell inside... You would think I hate this place already, but the food completely overcomes that.

Service is quick and efficient, food is fantastic. Gingerbread pancake and poached eggs are amazing. My coffee never went past half-cup.
author: Coco C.

description: Decided to go to Zazie on a Monday morning around 10am. Didn't have to wait which was extremely nice! The menu is mouth watering and I had a really tough time making a choice! In the end I went with the "Un, Deux, Trois"...one "Miracle Pancake" which was a bread pudding pancake with a fried banana (so yummy!), two poached eggs, and 3 strips of bacon! Couldn't fault the meal or service, it was topped off with what was literally a bowl of hazelnut latte. Would definitely go back! Thanks Zazie for a great brunch!
author: Jodi E.

description: Zazie HAS to be my favorite brunch place of all time. Whenever a brunch appropriate event comes along, we go to Zazie. I love their smoked salmon Benny and chai- perfect brunch! The interior is also really cute and perfect branching atmosphere. Also, if you have a choice, I recommend the back patio!
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
I was so excited to come here for a birthday celebration with a friend and ended up being quite disappointed in the end. I kept telling her how I just adored this place and have never had a bad meal a meal and then it finally happened. Mediocrity prevailed its little head.

I didn't want to believe it, but it was bad plate after bad plate. First of all, they were out of the chicken livers, which was not a problem. So, we ordered old faithful, the charcuterie plate. We were told they were out of the pate and would add more of the other ingredients but I've had that so many times, that the portions were no bigger than normal. And to top that off with that dish, they didn't offer us the usual toasted brioche and instead gave me breakfast toast as if I wouldn't notice! I didn't even say anything, but my friend who's never even been there knew that this dish just wasn't right.

I think they were waiting for us to finish our appetizers bc one we were done with the last bite, they immediately took our plates and gave us our entrees which must have been sitting around bc they definitely were lukewarm at best. 

My salmon en papillote was overcooked and her braised beef shanks were dry. I was truly disappointed, especially when I told her this was one of my favorite restaurants!

For desserts, I ordred the fruit crumble of the day with gelato. At least that was good. She had the duo of creme, creme brulee and pot de creme. The pot de creme was way too light to be a pot de creme and creme brulee was nothing to write about.

I'm just hoping this was a bad night, bc I'd hate to not want to come back to what was one of my favorite french eateries in town.
author: Heidi L.

description:
When I see French and brunch in the same sentence: I'm game. Plus, Zagat was ALL OVER this place, so I waited the hour an half or so to test it out myself.

After the unexpectedly long wait, we were seated. I went with the La Mer eggs benedict (with dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados) and a cup o'joe. Both were, I'm sad to say, pretty meh. I mean, after all the work-up about how great it is, and standing in line for an hour or two, I guess I let my expectations get to me.

If you can, try to go with the least amount of great expectations; you may have a better experience.
author: Adena B.

description: Awesome food, service. Highly recommend a seat on the patio. it is just so pretty ! I've had their pancakes, seasonal brunch : trout fillet with goat cheese and their sandwiches : all good.
author: Jisha A.

description:
yummmy pancakes are amazing
Florentine poached eggs are good 

Small place but very cutsie place for breakfast if your in SF.  The wait might be kind of long so come early on a Sunday morning.
author: Jamie K.

description:
This has become a favorite neighborhood choice.  Great staff and always a satisfying meal.  I have enjoyed it for either a casual weekend or a celebratory dinner.

There was a large party celebrating some significant event and even with that large group it wasn't very loud.  It was easy to continue holding a conversation at my table.  Even handling this large party, staff continued to be attentive to everyone else.
author: Jennie M.

description:
This was the epitome of brunch.  It was one of those perfect Sunday mornings - sunny, not too hot, just right.  I took the Muni to Cole Valley and the timing must have been perfect. 

The wait was barely 10 minutes and a line seemed to form behind us.  I'm not the biggest egg person, but really, if it's covered in hollandaise, I'll give it a go.  We also noticed that the gingerbread pancakes were a fan favorite.  So we ordered the eggs with crab and the pancakes.  And mimosas.  

The eggs were great.  Perfectly cooked and created a fun mess on my plate, which I happily sopped up with the english muffin.  But, I think the star of the show was the pancakes.  1. they were not overly gingerbready (it's a word).  They were light with just the right amount of gingerbread flavor. 2. They came with some fantastic poached pears and lemon curd.  All together, not three flavors I would naturally think to put together, but I will from now on!  I think I could go to Zazzie every weekend.  Bonus - we got a table on the back patio and the service was great.

The staff was very nice, everything came out quickly, it really made for a great Sunday morning.
author: Lilly N.

description:
Mediocre food, long waits for sticky tables, tableware that should have been retired years and years ago, disinterested waitstaff. Seriously, the tables had layers of grime. It would appear that this place holds a grudge against cleanliness...case in point: potatoes burnt to a crisp with unpeeled garlic. Burning stuff is no substitute for cleaning the food.

I expect this sort of thing in Berkeley, the unwashed masses would eat this place up IF the restaurant used only locally sourced, organic blah blah blah. It doesn't. In fact, Zazie charges a few bucks for "real" maple syrup. How dumb are people?

Embarrassing, SF. embarrassing. Even after a half-marathon today, I couldn't stomach this place. 

Oh, I forgot...I got the BONUS coffee cup: free lipstick markings!
author: michaelangela v.

description: Minus 1 star for the long ass wait. Make sure to get there early or expect a 2 hour wait. FYI the two tables at the front are first come first serve. You're welcome. If the weather was better I would've sat there. I ordered the omelette du jour, my friends ordered the la mer and Mexican scramble. All three were delish. The home fries were just plain potatoes, get the salad. Save your carbs and order the French toast or the lemon poppyseed pancake. I had the pancakes and the lemon was just right, not too overpowering. The space is small so keep it 4 or less. We didn't sit in the back patio but I heard it was nice.
author: Tram H.

description: Oh how I despise the hipsters that swarm here with their hangovers from the night before but love Zazies bottomless mimosas. The food is pretty good.  Almost Always a line but never a very long wait.  This is a must whenever I visit the bay.
author: Jessica T.

description: Very good food, very nice back porch, very interesting no tip policy that results in prices that initially seem high but are not too bad.  The potatoes have big cloves of garlic, which I liked but my wife did not.  The bloody Mary was super horseradishy and delicious.
author: matt h.

description:
Walked in this place to find a full restaurant with people crowded together, but was pleasantly surprised to find no wait for the outdoor patio. They had the space heaters running, which was a nice touch on a chilly day. The selection of breakfast/brunch items was small but had enough variety to find something satisfying. The food was delicious and perfectly cooked. Service was friendly and I enjoyed my visit thoroughly! 

I would recommend this to anyone looking for a reasonably priced brunch in San Francisco.
author: Nick L.

description:
I don't understand why this place had such good reviews and a crazy long line of people wanting to go in. I came here on Mother's Day and was very disappointed. The manager was RUDE. I have never been to a restaurant were the person in charge doesn't treat the customers with respect or kindness. Every time we asked him a question he would become irritated and demand that we order food. 

This restaurant is small so small that the restroom feels like you are in an outhouse. If you group has more then 2 people in it avoid Zazie.

After a long wait and dealing with the incredibly rude manager, we finally ordered our food. Our table had basically ordered a little bit of everything and everything was underwhelming. I, myself, had ordered the french toast which was insanely dry and tasteless.
