We also shared the often reviewed French Toast Tahiti. Literally, an orgasm in my mouth. My favorite french toast in the city solely due to the mashed walnuts and banana cream they put in the middle of the two toast. Given that I eat french toast at every brunch, that's saying something.
author: Raina B.

description:
Get their gingerbread pancakes! They're so unique, delicious, and oh that tart lemon curd + fluffy ginger bread pairing is making my mouth water. Note that the pancake portions are HUGE, so pair up with a friend and go halfsies on the La Mer Benedict.

Of course there's a wait, but if you're willing to sit in the tables out front, you can pretty much be seated right away. I've yet to make it to their infamous back patio, but I'll deal with the hovering as long as I get my food :)
author: Ruth H.

description:
I'm happy to say i took full advantage of Zazie's 1, 2 or 3 option for ordering by getting my scrambled egg dish plus a side of french toast. It was all delicious, cheap and well worth the food coma that immediately followed.

Here's the trick: For a weekend brunch with a long wait (we got there at 10 and the waiting list was already several pages long), the tables outside are first-come-first-serve. Hover!
author: Katie C.

description:
Visited this spot thanks to the good ol 7x7 list!  It said to try the Eggs Benedict, so we did- the La Mar Eggs Benedict. It was filled w/seasoned crab, slices of avocado, poached eggs, all laid on top of an english muffin covered in Hollandaise sauce. Yum! It was really good & more than enough to share w/a friend.  BUT, I give this place 5 stars because their "Miracle Pancakes" are to DIE for! It's a bread pudding pancake, topped w/ carmelized slices of banana and a little bit of whipped cream. I am so glad the waiter recommended this.... this was the real winner and what would make me come back regularly!

The location is cute but "cozy" (which means tight). Make sure to come either early on a weekend or during the weekday to avoid the wait. I'm sure it gets crowded here, and fast!!  :)
author: Joy A.

description:
The best breakfast I've had (in a restaurant) is at Zazie's.  Make the effort to head here, as early as possible mind you, and start breakfasting!

You can't go wrong with anything on the menu and as others have mentioned, they do have a tiered portion system to fit your dietary needs.  We chose more from the specials' menu and had eggs benedict with dungeness crab (finally an EB that is better than anywhere in NYC) and the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd.

Don't bother cooking your own breakfast.  Just bring yourself here.  

The outdoor patio in back has the best seating but indoors is just as lovely.  Service was good but expect spotty when it's uber busy ~ this place should be your go-to in SF.  Yummy in the tummy!
author: Jenny K.

description:
Ok... I guess.
4 of us tried this place on a Sunday morning.  It was ok, but I'm not sure we'd ever travel a long distance to eat here again.
- Service was great.  Polite, friendly, and accommodating.
- Brunch was satisfactory. Folks at our table had either an egg dish or French toast. One egg dish was served cold. The French toast was ok, but you could tell the challah bread wasn't soaked for very long in egg, which is a bummer and takes away from the flavor and texture. We shared a piece of cream cheese coffee cake, which was simply corn bread with a layer of cream cheese and a dusting of cinnamon and confect. sugar, but it didn't have a whole lot of flavor. Overall, nothing was amazing.
-note: the wait outside on a Sunday at 9am was 45 mins. I wouldn't wait that long for this. Also, the bathroom for customers is the size of an airplane lav.
author: John B.

description: I have only been here for brunch, and it never seems to dissatisfied me. Pancakes are so delicious and I have to say the best in San Francisco. If you are an oatmeal consumer, their brûlée oatmeal with bananas is awesome.
author: Vinson H.

description: This pace is the bomb.com. The best breakfast you'll have. The vibe is really cute and "frenchie". Great pace for a morning date or a brunch with family. I recommend the French Toast! The best day to go is on a weekday, because it gets crazy packed on weekends and I mean 40 minute waits easily.
author: Jesus B.

description:
Nice cozy place to go to for breakfast, in the early morning. 
I recommend the poached egg.
author: Vanessa A.

description: Eggs benny are to DIE for. The outdoor garden patio is so charming. Would definitely come back !
author: Kendall K.

description: Came here on a Sunday at 1pm. List was long. We thought we'd wait an hour but we were seated within 15 minutes. Very pleased with that. Food was delicious. Service was very fast and friendly. Can't go wrong with the menu - all is great.
author: Hin M.

description: Love this place mostly because its a great match in dining standard. Tuesday is bring your own wine night and a great way to enjoy a really nice dinner. Make sure to make a reservation :)
author: Grace W.

description: HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!!! We were in San Fran for a week and had dinner here TWICE. So delicious-I would recommend the Pate appetizer. The wait staff was friendly and very accommodating in celebration our son's 16th birthday!!! Thank you Zazie's
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Something about the sunlight through tall windows, large bowls of lattes, and the little vase of flowers on the table that makes brunch feel so -- grown up :).  It's my favorite meal of the week, and Zazie does it right.

Came here with my gal friend for the first time last week.  Wait was about 45 min.  Not terrible for Sat, but if you get impatient, good thing about Zazie is that it's in a neighborhood of many other brunch spots...so you can always give up and go dine elsewhere.  Considering the flower shops and boutiques around -- the wait can go by easy.   Tip: I think the two tables up front are exempt from the waiting list and are first come first serve! so if you dont mind grubbing in front of long lines of people staring out of jealousy...consider it.

Coffees come in a big bowl -- just like I like it.  People seems to be ordering the French lemonade all around us, so will have to try that next time.  I ordered one of the week's special -- Procuitto Eggs Benedict ($12 for two).  You can pick between 1, 2, or 3 eggs ($9/$12/$15) -- what it actually means 1, 2, or 3 english muffins sandwiches.  So two was more than enough.  Comes with potatoes or salad too...so more than you can finish (see my pic!).  Procuitto was delish, and entired plate very savory.  

I tried the French Toast Tahiti per everyone's recommendation ($6 for one).  Should've ordered it at the end, b/c it came with my benedict and by the time i took my first bite, it was a bit cold.  Perhaps that's the reason why, but I didnt think it was THAT amazing.  Def better dishes on the menu.

Consider Zazie for your next brunch outing!
author: Kendra W.

description:
This is some of the best breakfast I've had in recent memory. Potatoes are cooked with giant roasted cloves of garlic, bread comes with delicious raspberry jam, and there are literally 8 different kinds of mimosas! Poached eggs are cooked perfectly, scrambles are served beautifully, and the server we had was so charming you would have no idea that there was a mass of impeccably dressed, hunger-crazed people outside had you not just lived through it yourself.

There was an episode of Portlandia recently about brunch and if you've been to Zazie, you could say it hits a little too close to home. All I mean is that if you want brunch on a Sunday morning, be prepared to wait. Be prepared to see another group  get the table you had your eye on and go through the seven stages of grief. May I recommend you get a coffee and make yourself comfortable? The game of brunch is not for the faint of heart, and if you want to enjoy your Sunday you need to accept that you will wait until you think you can't wait any more. 

But it'll be worth it. Oh, it'll be worth it.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Diva princess breakfast realness. Bloody mary was limp and watery. Jonathon the server rules. Huge dishes.
author: Button L.

description:
I went here around Friday morning with 2 other friends, and we were immediately seated. 

I ordered one slice of the Tahitian French Toast and one slice of the Gingerbread Pancakes. I absolutely loved the french toast. I usually don't like to drench my breakfast in syrup, and you don't need syrup for french toast because it's sweet on its own.

However, the gingerbread pancakes were another story. They were dry and somewhat gummy, didn't have a soft and  fluffy texture like the pancakes my friend ordered, and weren't as amazing as people say they are (may be I got a bad batch).  But I would go for the Tahitian French Toast over the Gingerbread pancakes if I came here again.

Service was bad.  Our waitress was rude, inattentive, and didn't seem as pleasant. 

Overall, the food (being the french toast) was good, but I definitely would not rank it as one of the top best breakfast spots in the city.
author: Heidi G.

description:
So happy I made the treck to Zazie for breakfast. There was quite the wait when we arrived (to be expected on a Sunday during peak breakfast/ brunch time). But it was worth the wait - if it is nice out SIT OUTSIDE, the back patio is awesome (and they have heat lamps... so sit out there even if it isn't that nice!) 

The bloody mary could use some help but the La Mer poached eggs: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados... so good. I loved that I had the option of 1, 2 or 3 eggs. I can never finish a whole order of eggs benny so one egg was the perfect portion!
author: Shannon H.

description:
Came here with a group of four on a weekend for brunch, and had a 30+ minute wait, which is seemingly the norm. It was worth it.

We got seated in the back patio area, which was very quaint. I ordered the gingerbread pancakes, and they were enormous. I ordered two (because I was sharing with the boyfriend), but for one person, one would suffice. I got through half of ONE before switching plates and trying the Fountainebleu scramble, which is an egg/shitakie and porcini mushroom/spinach dish, complete with a side of toast and country potatoes. The other diners ordered eggs benedict and the country apple sausage omelet (the special of the day). 

Everything was delicious. Service was prompt, ambiance was nice, I'd come again!
author: Sonia M.

description: Had an extremely good brunch here. Can't believe it took so long. Reminded me of Sarabeth's in NY's UWS. The Challah French toast was really yummy with its liquor center. The soft eggs were luscious. The coppa coffee was delish. And the bacon was memorable. All in all: HOORAY!
author: Andrew K.

description: Celebrated Friday the 13th with some girlfriends there this past week--very simply--excellent service, excellent food, an excellent evening.  Thank you, Zazie!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Got a quick brunch here today. Got a super strong specialty house-coffee while I was waiting for my lunch-date... Whoa! It woke me up! 

For my meal, I got the Eggs en Fonte with a side salad. Theb which is polenta with some cooked greens topped with two eggs over-easy. Nice runny yellow, well cooked whites, perfectly presented. The greens were cooked to perfection (which is rare, they're usually overcooked which makes them bitter). The polenta came with little oyster mushrooms, which was a nice addition. It could have been flavored a bit more, but I didn't mind a milder meal for once.

Get there early during rush hour. Go to the beauty store next door to kill time and then come back. You're going to be waiting a while.
author: Meg P.

description:
Awesome brunch! I waited about 30 minutes but as usual in situations like this, I pre-gamed. Drinks were great too, and I appreciate the fact that they have the pomegranate mimosas instead of just the typical O.J.(so blase).

There were a few too many toddlers for my taste, but c'est la vie...it's a trendy brunch place in a big city. I'd go back for sure.
author: Lauren C.

description: Excellent Mexican & Italian scrambles with Challah French Toast for a sunny Saturday late brunch on their nice outdoor deck out back. Fast efficient service. Will come again
author: Mike V.

description:
I have a favorite budget breakfast/brunch place and a favorite no-budget breakfast/brunch place.  Zazies is my favorite no-budget.
Mimosas on the back patio on a warm day is life affirming.  Everything I've eaten there is amazing.  I'm not even a poached eggs fan but I order them here all the time.  The Challa french toast is serious business.  Their espresso drinks are solid.
The only neg I've ever noticed is that I had an earl grey with a minty after taste so I think they store different tea bags too close or in the same container or something.  Not enough to drop a star though by a long shot.
author: David G.

description: Great place for breakfast. You can order 1,2 or three of anything. Anything poached is delicious. Best bloody Mary ever. Go there for breakfast!!
author: John M.

description: A week before coming to this place, i had mama's on Washington square, and i wasn't really thrilled to try this place out as i thought mama's had the best brunch. But i was wrong! I got the smoked salmon eggs Benedict and creme brulee, it was like literally the best egg Benedict i ever tried (in San Francisco) and the creme brulee was just perfect! the caramel on top was just to die for! totally recommend this place!!!1
author: Valerie H.

description:
Although the lines are out the door,  the  food is just ok.  The food is bland.  They only serve 1 type of omelette and it needed a DoOver.

They have some unique dishes. 
I might try it again. 

Pancakes and French toast looked good.
author: Val W.

description: A little pricey but the food and service is well worth the wait and the parking struggles. If you got nothing to do, keep yourself occupied and walk down Haight.  I like how they have dog days during the week. Great place!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Zazie, mon ami! I had been wanting to try this little gem of a restaurant ever since I saw it on Check Please. Of course, I had friends who had nothing but good things to say about it, so that sealed the deal for me. It was fate that we would meet!

I came here with my Dad after an outing to the Academy of Sciences museum. On a Monday at noontime, we only had to wait 10 minutes or so. We grabbed a seat inside and pored over the impressive menu of breakfast, lunch and brunch items, as well as a separate menu for specials. I ordered a mango mimosa and he had an Anchor steam, then we dove into the real thing: the food.

He ordered the basic poached eggs with spinach and portabello mushrooms, paired with a salad. I opted for the less healthy, but much more savory, eggs de la mer special - eggs benedict with real dungeness crab, avocado and a light hollandaise. Delish! The hollandaise sauce is very delicate and not overbearing - just enough to highlight the richness of the poached eggs and bring out the flavor of the crab. Insanely good. I also had a side of potatoes that came with, and they were roasted to perfection with giant cloves of garlic (did not eat those but still appreciate the flavor boost!).

I would come here again and pray there isn't a long wait. I hear that's very rare as this is such a popular spot, but it's worth it. One of the things that impressed me most about this restaurant is the owner's respect for the employees. There is a small surcharge of $1-something per customer - this ensures all the employees have full benefits. LOVE that. 


Very cute place. Come support a wonderful local business and experience some mighty delicious brunch items while you're there. I can't wait to try dining on the patio next time!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Amazing! However, I've only been here once, so I will be back to try more! It's a small place, so the wait is fairly long. It may be better to get here a little early for parking and so you don't have to wait so long. The service is great here, very friendly. Prices seem a bit high, but you really shouldn't mind considering the quality of the food here. I came here with my boyfriend, aunt, and daughter. My daughter had a short stack of their pancakes with fruit. Nice and fluffy; and I don't normally like thick pancakes, but theirs were delicious and had a bit more texture to it which I loved. My aunt, boyfriend, and I decided to order items that we could all share. The menu seems small, but there are so many good items that it was difficult to come to a consensus. So many choices, so little table space. 

I love poached eggs, so was excited to find a section of their menu dedicated to poached eggs with different choices of what goes on top. We decided on the La Mer: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados. SOOO GOOOOD!! My aunt ordered the pancake sampler which came with three different pancakes from their menu. I was not too fond of their gingerbread pancakes, but their buttermilk pancakes are great! My boyfriend ordered the Mexico scrambled eggs, which he almost devoured before my aunt and I could get a bite. A side of potatoes, their "home fries", came with the egg dishes and they were amazing! I'm not sure what it is that makes these potatoes so special, but they're addicting! I highly recommend Zazie for breakfast or brunch! Totally worth the wait and the money!
author: Lauren D.

description: I thought it was good.  Not the best I ever had, but good atmosphere and our server was nice.  We waited about 40 minutes for a table of 2 on a Saturday morning.  We ordered the Greece scramble and the Sarah sampler of French toast, pancakes and ginger pancakes.  Overall solid experience
author: Roberta M.

description:
ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE.

Only downside is its almost always Busy, but well worth the wait. 

I'd recommended the Caramelized bananas and walnut French Toast, SO GOOD. 

Also the Crab Eggs Benedict is "to Die For" from my fiance. 

If its a nice day out, even if its a bit windy/cold, outside patio is wonderful.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Craig G.

description: Ordered the croque monsieur and the pancake sampler. The food was good, not amazing or special. Overpriced i think for what you get and nickel and dime you for sides. You don't have to tip but trust the prices do include it. I probably wouldn't come back but it's a nice place if you are in the neighborhood. Service is adequate as well.
author: Am W.

description:
Breakfasts are amazing, but the dinners are nice too.

I like the pierre noir benedict.  Roasted tomato on bacon.

The potatoes are fantastic.  Especially when they're a little over cooked.  Don't forget to squish the garlics out of their shells.

The back porch is nice, especially on a sunny weekday when it's not crowded.
author: Brandon G.

description: We had dinner here on a Thursday night recently and, although it was busy, we walked right in and were seated.  The atmosphere was cozy and had a quaint French-hole-in-the-wall vibe.  The wait staff was very friendly and efficient at the same time.  The food...the food was wonderful.  Bursts of flavor made up of blended Mediterranean cuisines built on a French base.  We had the duck, the pork chops, and the hanger steak: all delicious.   Next time we'll try the patio in the back.  I'd definitely come back.
author: Rock T.

description:
Brunchtastic. The crowd is kind of terrible along with the doorman, but the food is damn right amazing. We had the Eggs Benedict and fruit with yogurt.  Everything was fantastic including the atmosphere.

My reason for the lack of stars has to do with the host. We had reservations, and we had one person running late due to N train being shut down. We lost our table twice because our party of 4 was only at 3. I understand the restaurant business and this is quite common, but this guy was just obnoxious and unwilling to listen. Staff seems extremely well trained to go by the book.
author: Lucas L.

description: Delicious breakfast. Miracle pancakes and the La Mer were worth the wait. Wait was about an hour and very crowded but food was DELICIOUS!
author: Shalayne W.

description: I love their backyard! The service is prompt and professional. Definitely best diner in Cole Valley.
author: Allie D.

description:
This is a great place for breakfast (or "Brunch" if that is your inclination). Try their French Toast Tahiti, you will not be disappointed (well, unless you hate bananas).

This is my take on it from my stupid little 'blog:

The atmosphere is fun and especially nice if you get to sit outside in their backyard patio (weather permitting, or whether permitted).

(Edit: Oops. I wasn't aware that links to my 'blog were not allowed. Sorry for the interruptions.)
author: Brian M.

description: Eh, the wait is just ridiculous. Back patio is nice, food is decent though their scrambled eggs are less than impressive. Good drink menu...just not a wow overall. Won't go back.
author: Alison M.

description: If you get there early enough there is no wait for a table.  Yummy food and friendly service.  Love the Eggs Divorcée, poached eggs, bacon instead of Canadian bacon, avocado, and hollandaise. You can choose from 1, 2, or 3 eggs and a side of potatoes or salad. YUM. One tip, pretty pricey for eggs.
author: B K.

description:
Always a pleasure to go to Zazie.  

The staff is amazing.  Their politeness is only overshadowed by their knowledge of the menu.  Good solid pairing recommendations.  The food is superb.  Brunch is crazy but worth it.  They change the diner menu seasonally and have several amazing staple choices.  If you are into slow-brazed meats, go for the shank.
author: Ben S.

description: I came with a friend who is gluten-free and vegetarian. The food is amazing and they have a good wine selection.
author: J'aime O.

description:
[ FIRST IMPRESSION ]

After hearing constant praise for Zazie by numerous people, I finally had brunch there with a couple of friends yesterday on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. 

My first thought when entering Cole Valley was: No wonder why I never come here!  The process of finding parking is unbearable!  To make matters worse, Zazie does not take reservations for lunch/brunch.  Because we arrived late at 2pm, however, the wait was only approximately 20 minutes.  Twenty minutes - to me - was manageable.

The restaurant itself is fairly small - a modest French bistro with a warm, light-hearted atmosphere.  The best part of the place is their charming patio area in the back - which was where we were seated luckily.

[ DINING EXPERIENCE ]

As an eggs benedict connoisseur, it was a given that my hungry eyes would immediately go to their "Poached Eggs" section.  I ordered the "Albert," which comes with bacon, white cheddar, and salsa fresco.  (Though, with my taste buds not feeling that adventurous this day, I asked for no salsa.)

My dish was delectable!  The poached eggs and bacon were cooked to my absolute satisfaction.  The eggs were not watery at all, and the yolk was cooked to perfection.  (Note: You can always tell how well a poached egg is cooked by examining how the yolk flows when you cut into it with your knife).

My dish was also accompanied by salad, but how much can you say about a side salad?  I picked at my frends' home fries and they were simply fair in my opinion.  They were engrossed with a nice garlic flavor, but were too soggy for my liking. 

Overall, I had a memorable meal and will definitely come back for more!  Maybe try their dinner too - which I've heard is fabulous.
author: Judy C.

description: Called in a $95.00 order....lots of breakfast items. Came to pick up...... Went inside and paid, then waited outside. The waitress was attentive enough to see 2 people sit down outside, came out to greet and set them up with water but failed to tell us our eta on our order.....we look in and see bags sitting on the counter. Bad service. Also our cup of oj was like half full.... asked her about it and she made an excuse without fixing it. Smells like a sewer outside too.
author: Jason And Brooke N.

description:
I love Zazie! 

oui, c'est l'amour

Most definitely one of the best breakfasts I've had and Zazie  holds such a bewitching charm! It was a gorgeous day so we opted to wait until 930 for a seat on the patio and with it being Tuesday, we were seated in minutes.  

The menu items are playfully named to take you from one country to the next. We chose to eat Monaco; It included free range eggs,tomatoes and prosciutto which left me flying high. It really takes someone special to perfect an Eggs Benedict and they created a flawless poached egg that's worthy enough to initiate a new category for the Nobel Prize! I wouldn't stop there, either. Make it a DUTY! RESPONSIBILITY! COMMITMENT!  to try the Gingerbread Pancakes and the Austriche Mimosa (Champagne and Elderflower). Finally, don't forget to order the "Home Fries" with your breakfast. You'll be kicking yourself, otherwise.

Parking is tough, so I would recommend having someone get out to put your name on their very COOL iPad waiting list because on the weekends it could be up to a 45 minutes wait . 

I promise. This is a breakfast you will never forget!
author: Kelly S.

description: I'm DEFFINETLY coming back to this lovely establishment. It made for one of the toughest choices I've had to make during my trip. Do I get the Miracle pancake? Or do I get the girls gingerbread pancake. Of course I chose to get one of each (which I highly recommend) to cure my curiosity. Those two pancakes went well with the Mexican eggs breakfast that I selected. Zazies is definitely going to receive my business for many years to come.
author: Kevin W.

description:
3 stars for dinner
3.5 stars for breakfast

came here on a dd on a late saturday around 930ish.  We ordered a few things.  the waiter told us the rabbit pasta and duck were good so we ordered that, the hanger steak and pork chops.  mussels to start and mac and cheese on the side.  To be honest, nothing really stuck out and was orgasmic. I got the rabbit and it was pretty dry.  we did get the trio dessert which was good though.

brunch on the other hand was better!  first of all, there was absolutely no wait (because we came on a Monday) and we got to sit out on the patio on a nice day.  we ordered the pancake flight and 2 albert benedicts and shared.  it was yumo!  I will definitely be back for brekfast/brunch!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Finally decided to brave the long wait on a leisurely Sunday Funday.  The 45 minute line seemed to move fast, especially when considering the 20+ tables in front of me on the sign-in sheet.  I had attempted to brunch at Zazie several times and decided that this was the day I would finally commit.

Long story short, I really enjoyed the food at Zazie.  It was everything I hope for in a brunch.  My friends and I shared the stuffed french toast and the eggs florentine.  Great brunch staples, and both were delicious.  I enjoyed the atmosphere, but would like to go back and sit in the back patio, since I've heard this enhances the whole experience.  I would definitely go back, but essentially think that there are places that are just as good with a much smaller wait time.
author: Bridget B.

description:
Zazie is my absolute favorite brunch place in the Bay Area.  It has a beautiful patio area for taking in sunny afternoons.  Friendly energy, and fresh ingredients mixed together into rich indulgence.  It's so rich and delicious that a walk around Golden Gate Park is often called for afterwards.

I have also been here once for dinner, which has a much more intimate, high-end dining experience atmosphere (i.e. bring a date).
author: Michael M.

description:
So basically I was starving and I thought, oh, here's a French restaurant, they should know how to make macaroni and cheese! Errr, wrong, first mistake, French people don't eat macaroni and cheese so clearly it showed. I'm convinced a non-French person made this because it was greasy and very cheesy, I felt like I was dying when I was eating it. The upside is that sin tastes delicious, but not what I was expecting. I was looking for more kraft macaroni and cheese than what I got.

After my first heart attack, I decided that my veins weren't greasy enough so I had some duck pate. Well, it was pate alright. Yummy, though by this time artery 2 was on life support and it was getting hard to see without the necessary blood filling up my brain.

Since I wasn't being self-destructive enough, I had some wine to sledgehammer what little functioning brain i had left, quickly calculated the tab with my remaining neurons and passed out at home only to discover that my unwatched golden girls episodes had been overwritten by mothers bridge tournament friends. I will burn each and every one of their homes, or perhaps, reheat the mac and cheese.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Best place to get brunch......The ambiance is cute and very busy. Every time I've gone here, it is always crowded, but they always find us a table really fast! :)

I ordered the Avignon: free range scrambled eggs w/ eggplant, tomatoes provencales, zucchini, garlic, and provencales herbs. Decent prices, not too expensive. I always love when I get seated outside in the back. Less noisy and really comfortable.

If you are in the Cole neighborhood, this is a must eat place! You won't be dissatisfied!
author: Rae R.

description: I really like the food at Zazie, but it is extremely expensive.  Still a luxuriant experience for a brunch.
author: Soo S.

description:
Random discussion the day before in the car:
Me: let's go to brunch tomorrow!
M and J: OK, where?
Me: there's a "make your own bloody mary" day at Home.  Let's go there!  Oh, I also want to try The Corner!  Oh, and, and, and...

Meanwhile, M was waiting for me to exclaim Zazie, since I couldn't stop talking about it a month ago.  Moments later it finally dawned on me.

Saturday, 2 p.m.  Perfect time to go, since the morning crowd have dissipated.  We got our seats in the back patio and went to work.

Pierre noire http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=3tz0j01ICnJdxSXAlwDyYA
French toast tahiti + st trop http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=dHLeLSj2CckKDaC7T-Pxig
La mer http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=r1RobbbdJpyedUwAAGYNvQ

The dishes were all delicious, and two eggs (or one egg and a french toast) is the perfect amount to fill you up but not have you stuffed into a food coma.  Really glad I finally made it out for brunch!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I just can't give them more than two stars because I don't see any reason to stand in a crowd for more than half an hour to get a seat for a meal. 

Their food is good, but the restaurant is tiny, and they pack as many people as they can into it which means it is very noisy, stuffy, and not a nice atmosphere for enjoying a meal. I've been there a few times (because friends like to eat there), but would not go on my own, nor would i take someone there who I want to have an intimate conversation with. 

The last time I was there they did not bring my order out with the rest,.. and I had to wait a while to get it after reminding them of my order.
author: Holiday F.

description:
What can I say? Zazie's is simply INCREDIBLE!  Then again, that is how most of the food from San Francisco is.  
Upon arrival, we waited approximately 50 minutes to be seated....
And let me tell you...It was WELL WORTH THE WAIT. 

Had a great breakfast! I had an asparagus type of omelet with french toast and coffee. High quality food for such simple items!  The service is SF casual with the bright and casual demeanor of the waitress who served us. 

I won't forget this place anytime soon!
author: Joel J.

description:
Ok, I get it SF.  I get it.  You have delicious brunch places, but waiting almost 2 hours for a table is borderline absurd.  I mean sure, people wait and you don't care, because yes...the food is absolutely amazeballs and people actually wait!  Praise jeebus there was a coffee shop across the street or else I would have probably gone rabid on some of these people. 

After waiting close to 120 minutes, we were guided to their back patio.  Since it was the most amazing day outside, this was perfection.  Oh, the front patio is first come first serve! FYI. 

We all got started with some breakfast cocktails.  You can order by the glass or bottle.  Win!  I had the poinsettia which was cran and champagne.  Friend got a bloody mary and other friend got mango juice and champagne.  

For eating I ordered the La Mer.  Fresh crab, avocado atop an english muffin topped with a poached egg and hollandaise.  What?  With fresh roasted potatoes.  Again, what?   We all ordered some poached egg dish and we all loved it.  I also ordered a fresh fruit cup and it was so fresh.  Don't you hate it when you order fruit and all their is in it honeydew and cantaloupe?  Ugh, gross.  This has strawberries, mangos, apples,  oranges...etc.  DELICIOUS!  Their french toast also looked pretty spectacular...just sayin. 

Yes, Zazie, you clearly knocked my socks off, but I don't think I'll ever wait almost 2 hours again.  If I do go back, it will be right when you open, but goodness knows I'm never up that early on the weekends.
author: Allison L.

description:
Parisian-style interior creates a great escape from Cole Valley. I visited this gem for brunch just an hour before they closed in order to skip the Disneyland-length wait lines. Since I was parched I went with savory over sweet and ordered the Smoked Salmon Benedict. The hollandaise sauce has a hint of lemon that rides well with the smoked salmon and capers. It's like they all become BFFs on top of the toasted peaks of the English muffin, and then party in your mouth.

My friend is one of those sugar princesses so she ordered the Gingerbread Pancakes. It was summertime, but she was feeling nostalgic for December. In her words, the pancakes "reincarnated Santa and brought Christmas early." I tried a bite, and the fluffy texture was impressive. I don't know how their cooks create these spellbinding circle things but they float into your mouth like sugar plum fairies. We bought the gingerbread pancake mix and made our own a few weeks later, but they just weren't the same. Our sub-par culinary skills could've made a difference too.

All in all, highly recommended. Go celebrate the holidays early.
author: Sam M.

description:
We always come to Zazie's when we visit my sister who lives in Cole Valley.  Once again.....we had a wonderful brunch.  I have found Zazie's to be consistently great.  Nice people too!

Don't let anyone fool you......there wouldn't be a wait if the food wasn't good.  if you're an impatient sort....don't go to Zazie's on Saturday or Sunday.  It is definitely worth the wait. ...any day of the week.

Enjoy!
author: Sue Ellen T.

description: Came here for a girls brunch and let me tell you - LITERALLY one of the best brunches I've ever had. The La Mer (crab and avocado benedict) was increddible.  We also split a slice of their oh so thick and tasty french toast and washed it down with some (great) coffee and a mimosa fit for a queen (peach sorbet and black currant syrup I believe). Overall we left fat and happy! Would absoltuely come back
author: Shawday B.

description:
I don't understand what all the rave is about this place? I mean, yeah its pretty good. But is it an hour long wait on thursday afternoon good? a foggy one at that..no, i don't think so..

I came here for lunch/brunch with a friend one random day. The wait for a table was literally about an hour...and its not like you have something to do in the surrounding area while you wait. theres nothing...(0.o) 

When we finally got seated, the food came out pretty quick. Pretty tasty, however, nothing that leaves a spark in your memory. I think i got the crab eggs florentine. I forget what my friend ordered, but we both had mimosas. I got the grapefruit, and he got mango. (orange juice mimosas are WAYYY better. stick to the classic). The food portion was average. I was able to finish my dish. 

Being that its so busy here, the servers are quick. Meaning, they don't have time to pay attention to you. Its an "order, eat, and go" kinda place. 

Anyway, an hour wait and a 30 minute meal later, I was short $60 for brunch. Bleh. i guess....?

I think Nettie's Crab shack on Union street is a lot better. And if theres a long wait, at least there are plenty of shops around the area for you to kill the time. IDK, just a suggestion.
author: Linh P.

description:
Love this place. Cute outdoor seating. 


Their poached egg dishes are on point. If they have the lemon ricotta pancakes, you must order them. I'm not a big pancake fan because they are usually too doughy for me and I prefer savory breakfasts, but these are light and fluffy and airy. They're awesome, but they often run out. 

Yum! Great brunch place if you're in the inner sunset/cole valley area.
author: Caroline D.

description: The La Mer was amazing. I had to have my egg cooked all the way but it was still awesome. They messed up my order a little but it's fine because the food was delish. The pumpkin pancake was awesome, and the French toast was just amazing. I probably consumed a month's worth of sugar trying all of it but it sure tasted good! They had a nice refreshing sparkling lemonade, too. Great for a warm day.
author: Brianna C.

description: Make sure to line up early as in way before they open at 9am during the weekend or be prepared to line up and wait at least an hour. But the wait is worth it. The toast, poached eggs and fruit are made perfectly with flavor compared to other cafes. A must go to.
author: Jorgeanne C.

description:
"A piece of Paris with a California twist .... very very yummy"
I've been here 4 times and I'm always surprised how consistently good it is. This a little piece of Paris with a California twist
For the sweet tooth try the French Toast Tahiti stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Or try what they call the miracle pancake. This is a weekly specialty pancake. I had the lemon ricotta pancake with a lemon curd and raspberry sauce. Best pancake I've ever had. They are light and fluffy and the lemon curd makes my mouth water. Some of the weekly miracle pancakes are:
Bread pudding pancakes with grilled bananas
Sour Cream Poppyseed Pancakes w/ meyer lemon curd and strawberries
Sugar pie Pumpkin spice pancakes 
Lemon ricotta pancakes with lemon curd and raspberry sauce

If you are looking for something salty they have classics such as Croque Madame or a Croque Monsieur. These are spot on to the dishes I've had at the Cafe Les Deux Magots in Paris. The eggs Benedict are fantastic as well. I had the La Mer with hand picked Dungeness crab and avocados. Wow, that rich hollandaise sauce over that sweet crab is delightful.
Also please try the home fries. They are simply fried potatoes with whole cloves of sweet garlic. Yum!
There is usually a wait but a couple of tips. There is a nice area in back with extra seating that has heating lamps for the chilly mornings. Sitting here will possibly cut your wait in half. That being said I've never waited more than 20 min. Also the the 2 tables out front are first come first serve if you don't mind the sun.
author: Dolph G.

description:
First off the food and coffee were delicious... I had the eggs benedict.  What killed it for me was the wait. Took about an hour to get our food! They were steady but i guess because of the small kitchen food took longer... 

What reall aggrevated me was the EXTRA $1.25 they charged PER PERSON! And that ON TO of the tip!!!On the bottom of the check it read "the $1.25/ per person surcharge added to all checks provides full benefits for our hardworking staff."  WTF??? Im sorry I have to pay for their insurance? Aren't I already giving them business??  Id like to have my insurance paid for too! 

I dont think Ill be back when I have other options of little cafes with great food w/o having to pay the employees insurance..
author: Claudia M.

description: We really loved this place, not only the food but the whole experience. I loved the baked chocolate (its a dessert not a hot beverage,we got this wrong). We didnt have to wait long because it Was a weekday but Be prepared to wait if u are going on a weekend.
author: Mariana P.

description: I mean cmon. They let us drink our mimosas outside while we waited to be seated. Winning. Ordered multiple breakfast meals as they all looked great. Was NOT disappointed. Eggs Benny was a hit along with their special  French toast Tahiti which is to die for. Be prepared to wait though and go early! Enjoy!
author: Howie H.

description:
(food 4 stars. long waits -1)
1.5 hour wait at 10am sunday

salmon eggs benedict was above average as the eggs were cooked perfectly. the salmon was fresh and muffin was fluffy. 

The bathrooms are very small almost airplane sized and the seating is very crammed almost fire hazard status. 

Overall, an above average brunch place but expect long waits during prime time.
author: Robert Y.

description:
While I'm a big fan of this place for brunch (and will go ANYTIME), a recent stop here on a weeknight disappointed me.  Which I guess is what I get for eating alone.

Although nextbus said that the the N-Judah was forthcoming, in fact, it was not.  I was starving, and had time to kill, so I decided to come here.  As I've had multiple good experiences here with the breakfast foods, I was looking forward to dinner.  

I wandered in, and apparently confused one of the waitresses, who told me to wait for the host guy.  He was also confused by the fact that I was dining alone, but offered me an inside table where I would have been stared at by all the other patrons for being a lonely fool, or outside on the gorgeous night.  

The back patio was quite full, and it seemed to overwhelm the waitress.  As someone who waited tables for many years, I know that when you get triple-sat, life sucks, but she just seemed flustered and angry instead of addressing the situation.  All she had  to say is "I'm busy, but I'll be right with you."  I also was sitting next to some of the most pretentious douches and their wives, but that wasn't the waitress' fault.  Seriously, one couple at this table didn't know what country their former nanny was from, and was bemoaning the fact that their au pair was pissed because she didn't have a car.  It was all I could do to keep from stabbing myself in the ear and bleeding on them.

ANYWAY I got the burger and roasted potatoes which is probably now my favorite burger...but I was extremely saddened by the service.  I might go back for dinner (not alone) on a Tuesday when they have their wine special for that burger, but I am not in any hurry.
author: Pam S.

description:
Our dinner took 2.5 hours on a Sunday!

+ bring your dog on Monday nights
+ great service by our waitress

- Food was good but not worth spending 2.5 hours there
author: E T.

description:
On my day off, I woke up at 7:30 AM, cleaned the condo, responded to a bunch of personal emails, responded to a handful of work emails, went back to bed for an hour and then drove to the city for brunch at Zazie's.  We were seated fairly quickly but our table of 5 grew to 7 so we all squeezed in (otherwise it would have been a 35 minute wait).  I was okay since it was Fred's left armpit that was smelly that day and I was on his right hand side.  

He got the poppyseed pancakes ... which were good as far as pancakes go.  I got the Monaco (is that pronounced Mo NAH' co or MON' a co?)  Did you know that they don't have income tax in the country of Monaco if you are a citizen?  Did you know it takes 9 generations to become a citizen?  Anywho, my Monaco was good, I could taste the free range-ness of my eggs.  Gail and I shared the French toast Tahiti since neither of us wanted to order it, but both of us wanted to try it.  It was good, but I wouldn't have wanted it as my meal.  

Monday for lunch and the place was packed.  I think if I were ever to lose my job, I would move to this neighborhood because there would be plenty of other people not working with me.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Really charming, non-pretentious French bistro in Cole Valley, and absolutely loved it.  The service was laid back, attentive, and friendly.  I ordered the french onion soup (cheese was fantastic), mussels, and creme brulee (which was amazing).  Would definitely come back -- great for a date or to come here with friends.  Seems prudent to make a reservation (we didn't, we luckily got a seat) -- and I believe it about the wait.  Definitely worth the trip!
author: Mel G.

description: Dude, what is the hype about. Whenever I wait in stupidly long lines for brunch, it's never really worth it. We waited about 45 minutes, and the food just wasn't that special. I'm pretty sure the server didn't know what vegan means, either, which was a problem for my friend and not for me, but still. We figured since yelp said it had lots of vegetarian options, we could do some substituting and make it vegan, but the menu says "NO SUBSTITUTIONS." I'd come back again, but definitely not if there's a wait.
author: Emily H.

description:
One of the best brunches I have dined so far! 

We came here on a Saturday morning around 11:00AM and the line was already ridiculous. Parking was a bit hard to find since streets surrounding Zazie was metered and 1 hour limit. I didn't use my UC Berkeley instincts so well and didn't read the sign so I was like WHAT? Why doesn't it take anymore quarters?! I had go to the local shops to ask for change. I suppose people do that a lot around here, so this lady from the antique shop automatically denied me. But Tully's was nice enough to give me change. 

The wait was about 40 minutes, which was not bad. We were seated inside. My  friends and I went for the poached eggs dish. While my 2 other friends took the sweeter route. Here is what we got:

1. I got the Pierre Nior. Which is a roasted tomato, bacon, and a perfectly cooked poached egg on top of a thin biscuit 
2. My friend got the St. Trop which is: smoked salmon, red onions, poached egg on a biscuit
3. Florentine: portobella mushrooms, spinach, and poached eggs on a biscuit
4. The Challah french toast
5. Gingerbread Pancakes

All the poached eggs dishes were mighty delish! The portions were great for me since I eat small portions in the morning. I was able to clean my plate!! Hallelujah! All the poached eggs dishes also came with either a salad or home-fries. This place has the best home-fries I ever tasted. Oppose from a red potato that a lot of restaurants uses (since it hold the form of a potato wedge better), Zazie uses an Idaho potato which is the starchiest!

I didn't find the sweet dishes to appetizing since the one layer of pancake and french toast was huge. it was so thick i felt like it was more of a bread than a pancake. But to each its own! 

The eggs rule since there are five different ways you can have your egg! Definitely a place to check out if you are into breakfast foods. 

I gave this place fours stars oppose to 5 is because I do not live in SF, I live in the the east bay, so driving all the way was a far stretched since it is in the castro area. I think that the food is great, but not great enough for me drive to the inner part of SF just to get brunch. Gas is pricey! Ya feel me?
author: Phuong V.

description:
Came for brunch on a Saturday around 11am, with a group of 5.  We were seated quickly, at at big table in the garden that could have held 8-10 people.  Our waiter was cool, but the food was just ok.  The pancakes in particular I would skip.  We got the pancake sampler, and the french toast was just ok, the ginger pancake with pear was subpar, and the buttermilk was the best of the bunch.  

The eggs benedict are a better bet, with a nicely toasted english muffin.  I would definitely skip the home fries in favor of the salad.  Some of the home fries were so dessicated that it was like trying to chew on a rock.  Those are some terrible potatoes = minus a star.
author: Olivia L.

description:
Thank you fellow yelpers for introducing this place to me!!!  With over 1700 yelp reviews averaging at 4 stars, I knew we had to try this Yelp hot spot.  I am so glad we did! :)

Came here for an anniversary breakfast date with the hubby.  I wanted to get here early because of all the reviews I read about Zazie having over an hour wait after 9am, long lines, etc.  We came on Wednesday morning around 8:45am.  Parking was a breeze...found a spot right in front of the restaurant and there was absolutely no wait once we were inside.  We went right in and got to choose where we sat.  Hooray!

Once seated, I don't think I barely looked at the menu since I already knew what we were going to order.  I ordered the famous La Mer Eggs Benedict with 2 eggs ($17) and hubby ordered the French Toast Tahiti with 3 slices ($13).  Service was fast, so the food came out in minutes.  Hubby & I split both entrees.  The La Mer looked absolutely delicious...I couldn't wait to dive in and take a bite out of it with all the dungeness crab oozing out. *drool* Check out my photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=KzJwaujsvVqxXH-Cz6Kmag
I don't think I've ever tasted a poached egg as delicious as Zazie's.  The egg, english muffin, crab, avocado and onions was heaven in my mouth.  Absolutely, positively DELICIOUS!!  I wish I was able to eat both benedicts, but I had to give the other to hubby. Shucks.  Definitely a must try item for brunch.  Hubby's dish was pretty tasty as well.  I LOVED the caramelized bananas!  It wasn't overly sweet, just perfect.  Here's a photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gqVl3RprESEqkIPeJH0yOg?select=hBClFdkWN-NlYV0b1jh1_A 
I'm not much of a french toast person, so I preferred the La Mer over the FT Tahiti.  

I was a little disappointed we didn't get to sit outside in the garden patio.  I don't think thay had opened it because it was bit of a chilly morning that day.  I will definitely be back to enjoy my meal out there next time....oh! and to try the coffee cake!  

My advice is to go there on a weekday morning if it's your first time.  I'm a little scared to see how this place is on the weekends! Lol
author: Sheila M.

description:
So definitely go here during the week. It is too popular on the weekend and you will wait forever to get a seat. For good reason of course their food is just what you need to start your day! 

Things to know: There is an outdoor seating area you should try to sit in if its warm sunny and open! The coffee can be a little bitter but is just what I need to get me going. 
The Un, Deux, Trois was reported by my boyfriend as some of the better pancakes he had ever had! He also loved the French Toast Tahiti when we returned. I on the other hand was initially a little disappointed with my Eggs en Fonte with Grilled polenta. I thought the sauce was a little bland. However, when I returned the second time I was very happy with my Fontainbleau. One of these days we are going to return for dinner too which I hear is excellent!

Bon appetit!
author: Tuesday C.

description: We are visiting from the East coast and had the most enjoyable meal here. We felt like we were in Paris from the French waitress, to the outstanding food from start to finish. We shared the cheese plate which was to die for with 2 french cheeses and a local chess and figs! We also shared the mussels which were really nice. I had the country pork entree with an apple cider reduction with parsnip and celery root puree, ohhh la la was this tasty!! My husband got the hanger steak which was cooked to perfection. We could not have been more pleased with our choice of dining here tonight. Note the portions are not small and you will certainly be most satisfied!
author: Sara M.

description:
Yes, the food is great here.  

The management obliged in extending their awning for my table out front on a rainy day.  And the latte and cappuccino came in bowl--sized mugs -- a little bit less than I usually prefer, but worked.  Kidding.

Since it's a stretch for me to come here, I will disclose this important tip:

The seats out front are seat-yourself.  Put your name on the list and patiently wait for an hour OR grab these when someone leaves!

I heard there is a back patio, but didn't get to see it.

Oh, & COLE HARDWARE is across the street!!! ...  A great place to mosey & digest
author: Stephanie F.

description: Delicious food. Amazing cafe atmosphere. Great place to bring friends when visiting the city.
author: Caroline M.

description:
I've really only ordered breakfast here, but I have tasted the egg skillets and they have all been delicious and hearty. 
I, myself, have ordered the Challah bread French toast with fresh fruit and Its like having  desert for breakfast. You seriously CANNOT go wrong.
And hands down, if you're too full for something sweet afterwards, take to go the homemade Cream Cheese Coffee Cake. 
I think you shouldn't even be allowed to eat here without paying homage. I might even go as far as saying it's a top 5 desert. Warm or cold, it's scrum-didily-umscous!!!
author: Jenn H.

description:
We were a large group of seven, and waited over an hour to be seated. Given the size of Zazie and its popularity, this was shorter than I had anticipated. We wandered down the street, got some coffee, looked in a few shops, no big deal. Once we were seated, the waitstaff was friendly and attentive and managed to get diners in and out quickly without us feeling rushed - now that's skill! (Smaller groups definitely waited over 30 minutes, but nowhere near as long as us.) 

I ordered the gingerbread pancakes. I LOVED them. They really put a unique spin on the standard french toast and buttermilk pancakes that are such standard brunch fare. The addition of the lemon curd was an unexpected (and genius) concept. I typically go for the sweeter options, but my fellow diners raved about the eggs Benedict as well. 

Be forewarned: The prices here are steep - $6 for one pancake. I definitely went home and concocted a copycat recipe of my own so that I could enjoy gingerbread pancakes anytime and spare my wallet a little hardship. That being said, I would definitely say, as a weekly bruncher, it is 100% worth it to give Zazie a try at least once.
author: Kathryn P.

description:
I had one of those rare pleasurable mornings of enjoying breakfast out on a weekday. Just a handful of  hungry people in Zazie enjoying their coffee, OJ and starting out the day with some french songs during their meal. This week they have a cornmeal pancake with lemon curd and strawberries that is divine. The challah french toast is better than homemade and bacon on the side... you just can't beat it. 

I look forward to the next time I'm late to work and enjoying a bite to eat here at Zazie.
author: Chrissy L.

description:
Helloo cute lil place! perfect to eat with your love or with a SMALL group of friends (4 or less). luckily we came on a lovely day b/c the sun was out!

we found parking 2 blocks down, not a bad walk, and oh no theres a wait! yes it took around 30 mins or so to get seated. its a sunday and 12pm, I suppose.

got seated in the back patio, very cozy with the neighbors, heard everyone's conversations.

we ordered the french toast taihiti and la mer poached eggs and mimosas. yumyum but oh so pricey!

french toast was soooo full of flavor! the caramelized bananas were really good. the poached eggs were evenn yummier!! with avocado, and crab meat andd random things. my friend and i shared and we were so full! you would think one egg and half a toast?? but it did. the mimosas gave our tummy and faces a nice warmth haha. 

service wasn't too slow, but expected it b/c of the reviews here, and spent a good 50 here for two. woulda been less without the drinks, but who could resist drinking fruity alcohol?

definitely coming here again, this time dragging the boyfriend along.
author: Christine M.

description: We had such wonderful dinner and evening at Zazie last night for Valentine's Day! The meal was amazing, the service impeccable, our seat in the patio adorable. Even more, the owner and host were so accommodating and warm when it came to taking our reservation and responding when we needed to adjust our plans. It was a very busy night for then, but they still handled us with warmth and generosity. They took excellent care of us on our double date with my boyfriend's teenage daughter and new boyfriend. The were the frosting on top of an already wonderful cake! Thank you, Zazie for making our night so memorable.
author: Shannon K.

description:
Zazie delivers a nice breakfast, but the meal we got was more filling than what we had anticipated from a typical French cafe.  A quick survey of the menu showed both French (salade nicoise) and American plates (egg scrambles), which explains the heavier dishes. That said, the double americano (served in a bowl) is a high point as is the side green salad, which was dressed perfectly.

A tip for weekend brunch...arrive 15 minutes prior to opening (at 9 am) and you will be able to get on the list and into the first round of seatings.
author: Kristina P.

description:
Challah French toast  with orange cinnamon batter; gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and a BIG cup of frothy hot chocolate = BLISS. Thats all I have to say about that! 

Always has a line but totally worth the wait.
author: S. M.

description: This is a fantastic brunch place. They have seating out back on their deck. The dinner is really good as well, although a bit pricy. We had the chicken and the beef bourguignon which was a solid 4+ stars.
author: Sofya T.

description: Our expectations for a special Christmas eve dinner were unfortunately not met.  The chef has too light a hand with the salt shaker.  Some salt is necessary during the cooking process to round out the flavors.  None of the dishes were really memorable.  The escargot appy turned out to be a tasteless schmear on top of stale puff pastry pillows.  Three of us ordered the sea bass and all found it to be likewise tasteless. I could go on but have better things to do.   I hear the brunch is great but think twice before heading out there for dinner.
author: Geoff S.

description:
Looking back at my old review, I think I owe it to Zazie and its owner to write an updated review--albeit a short and sweet one--of my latest visit.

Came here again, for breakfast/brunch, and again, we had to wait, but only for a little bit. I should have tried something different this time, but, what can I say, I love me some poached eggs. So I ordered the St. Trop, this time with two eggs. They were good--not at all cold. Our waitress was a little more attentive this time. 

Not that it can be helped, but the tables are quite close together. Be prepared. But honestly, if you've been to a lot of San Francisco restaurants, you should be used to it by now. Just take joy in eavesdropping.
author: Kym M.

description:
the noms: Eggs en Fonte (poached rather than over easy). 
~*~ spinach was fresh & the polenta was cooked just right. If you find the tomato sauce they serve with it isn't spicy enough--request for some habanero sauce. 

Their brunch cocktail special "Le Muni" is a mixture of citrus and champagne goodness. 

Ambiance: great place for brunch (during the weekday, apparently it gets more packed than a temple on the weekends). Sat out at the patio area in the back and YES there is outdoor heating.

Mini rant about the service (you can leave and order your gingerbread pancake now!):
The moment you all waited for but I do have to put my $.02 about the service as well...the wait staff is great for the most part. With the one exception of the male hostess who muttered, with incredible sass, "...next time try not to double order" when I initially asked him for hot sauce as he dashed towards the kitchen. There was dead eye contact made yet no recognition that he understood what I said before he turned the corner. Understandably, I asked our (ever so kind) waiter for some hot sauce since the hostess appeared to be busy. I don't understand people who work in customer service who have no shame in being rude to the people that could've gone somewhere else. Everyone has their version of a bad day but I'm a firm believer in not spreading negative vibes around. Quarantine it like the plague.  // end rant;
author: Kat L.

description: Zazie was really good, the wait took FOREVER! okay not forever but at least an hour and a half. Granted, we went at 11 on a Sunday so probably not the smartest move on our part. So I definitely want to go again where we go at a better time and don't have plans after so we don't feel rushed. Once when we finally got seated we sat in their back patio area which was so cute and green (great ambiance), this is where I would request to sit every time. (side note: not great for large parties for than 5 or 6 max & they don't take reservations) My boyfriend and both ordered from the poached eggs portion of the menu and it was DELICIOUS. I had eggs florentine (spinach/mushrooms included) and he had Eggs Monaco (prosciutto/tomatoes included) both were so good! The only thing my boyfriend said is that he felt the portions were a little small (he is a guy who can eat a lot so I think this might just be by his standards) and I thought it was more than enough. So all in all, this is a place to definitely try out, you won't be disappointed.
author: Samantha J.

description: My favorite brunch place in all of SF. Love their eggs florentine! Delicious bacon. Best home fries I've ever tasted to date.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
(See pic) 

Came here for late brunch after working the night before and the following morning. Definitely need something sweet, uplifting and calming. 

The wait was only about 10 to 15 minutes or so around 2pm, just enough for me to send a couple emails on my iPhone. 

I like the lemon curd on the pancakes which really lighted up the dish.

Mario was very nice knowing patrons waiting means we have the patience. Service was fantastic, friendly and prompt.

Also love the setting, the sunroof ceiling reflects the bright warm light onto my pancakes, the little attic spiral stairs to the huddled bookcases, the relaxing back garden, and the bustling kitchen, it's casual, comfortable and home feeling nice.
author: T L.

description:
Super crowded for brunch, but the line moves reasonably fast.  Wait next door at Finnegan's, and they'll come fetch you when the table's ready.

I don't normally like to wait for food, but this was worth it.  The Un, Deux, Trois with Challah French Toas was just what I needed.  

Though they were busy the entire time, the service was always attentive and friendly.
author: Ken B.

description:
Food was solid.  I ordered one serving of the gingerbread pancake and one serving of the challah french toast, and my friend ordered the eggs florentine benedict with mushrooms and spinach.  I also got their decaf mocha and my friend got their chai latte.  

All the dishes were very good. I think the texture of the gingerbread pancake and french toast were great.  They were fantastic according to my tastebuds though because am the type of person who loves saucy foods.  My friend's eggs florentine was good too.  My decaf mocha was definitely on the burnt side.  I could taste the burntness as I was nearing the bottom of my cup, which reminded me of the horrid starbucks coffees that are too sweet and always over-roasted.  I usually don't drink coffee but I had to try their mocha because the cups they served it in reminded me of the best mocha I've ever had, which was at La Note in Berkeley.  Alas, it did not live up to La Note's standard.  

The wait was ridiculous, of course.  We probably waited an hour?  We went on President's Day, which apparently is a day most people get off.  It wasn't too bad though because we just did some window-shopping at the stores nearby.  There was a super cute store called Tantrum, which was simply adorable!  We also stopped by Ace Hardware, which has a lot of stuff now.
author: Tori Q.

description: After years of watching long lines here, we finally decided to go. The experience definitely fit the "OK but not a lot better than hotel food" category. The "miracle pancakes" were doughy and heavy, not really a pleasant experience. The egg special had distinctly off flavors in it. There/s better food down the street at Cafe Reverie. Service was, well, serviceable. Not bad but not particularly notable. Unlikely to be a return visit...
author: Spike S.

description: Solid brunch spot. The wait wasn't as long as I thought it would be. The portions were big. I'm not sure it would be worth an hour plus wait but the food was good and the staff was quick.
author: Lucky B.

description:
Zazie is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco. The wonders they can whip up in their miniature kitchen continue to amaze me; Zazie exemplifies both culinary excellence and exemplary kitchen management. Well known for their brunch (complete with a exceedingly long wait on weekends before 1:30pm), Zazie also features excellent dinner entrees. 

The dinner entrees are great whether you eat in or pickup. The cassoulet piallat (crispy duck leg, french sausages, and root vegetables), grilled Niman Ranch pork chop, and fresh porcini and black truffle raviolis are especially good. The roasted trout with fresh greens is a great option for light fare.  

All of the brunch items I have had are excellent, from the fairly standard un, deux, trois (one pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon) to the handful of poached egg varieties. One of my all-time favorite brunch items anywhere is Zazie's eggs en fonte, featuring a grilled polenta cake with spinach, wild mushrooms, over spicy tomato chevre sauce, over easy eggs baked in a cast iron skillet with home fries (crispy, served with plentiful melt-in-your-mouth roasted garlic). The bottomless coffee is tasty also quite good.  

To top it off, service is friendly and fast and the atmosphere is relaxed and family-friendly (though the space is rather snug).
author: Chris T.

description:
Cute, cute, cute place.  Pale lemon paint and exposed brick; Frenchy posters from a generation ago; a narrow iron spiral staircase to a staff-only mezzanine; a gardened patio.  Even the restroom is rustically adorable.

Moreover, Zazie's exuded a strong vibe of passion, conviviality, and good cheer.  My own server was warm and pleasant, but also I could see it in the way that the staff interacted with each other, and the way that they greeted customers.  They were all HAPPY to be there.  It was sort of intangible but it created a nice, homey feeling on a cloudy Saturday morning. 

I had the omelette du jour:  mushrooms, ham, basil, fontina cheese.  Slightly undercooked, but nice simple ingredients which go well together.  Plus, some good wheat toast and plain, tasty home fries with whole cloves of roasted garlic and a few herbs.  

What was NOT simple was the gingerbread pancake with bosc pear and lemon curd.  They sell the pancakes by 1/2/3, and the fancier ones are $4.95/10/13.  Do yourself a favor and get one, or a couple of different ones to share if you have a group.  This pancake was absolutely delicious.  They serve it with syrup and butter, but the lemon curd and pear are the perfect accompaniments.  Gingerbread pancakes--who knew!

Did I mention that I had an Affligem blonde with my breakfast at 9am?  Nice.  All that for $25 and it was totally worth it.
author: David R.

description:
Zazie is POPPIN!  I love breakfast and Zazie makes some delicious breakfast.  I came here on a Friday around noon, and it was easy to find meter parking.  I heard this place gets really busy, so I was pleasantly surprised there was no wait for 2.  I sat inside, which was a little cramped; there isn't much space between tables.  Before looking at a menu, I noticed all the French posters on the wall, which was pretty cool.  

I took a quick look over the menu and everything sounded amazing, so I decided to order the omelette du jour, from the specials.  My omelette had bacon, asparagus, tomato, and white cheddar in it.  I'm not a big fan of the omelette either, but the ingredients sounded too good to pass up.  Turns out I made a great decision; the omelette was so dank.   In addition to the omelette my plate came with toast and home fries, which had garlic cloves in it. What really made me a fan was when I asked for tabasco sauce because when my server returned I not only got tabasco, but a jar of salsa verde.  Salsa verde was the icing on the cake.  I also had the chance to try the Eggs Divorcee, which was out of this world too.  It was basically like Eggs Benedict, but instead of ham, it came with avocado and bacon.  Great Idea!

Only problem I had was that the water was in this fancy bottle and it took me like 5 minutes to figure out how to open it.
author: Anthony N.

description: a very good neighborhood restaurant.  Very friendly service, Excellent breakfast,  very good French onion soup, excellent burger.  good price and good food.  but not excellent.
author: Ed Y.

description:
I have tried this place three times.  Every time I went hoping that I would like it.  My boyfriend and I just moved to this part of the city and are trying to find a new brunch place.  However, we are resigned that people who have reviewed Zazie's recently have never had good brunch.  Zazie does not make good brunch. 

This place cannot even do the basics.  Let's first look at the home fries.  They are unevenly cut and therefore unevenly cooked.  It's not rocket science.  Today one of my potatoes basically seemed it had never been heated and another was so burnt I had to spit it out.  Yes, there are garlic cloves in the potatoes.  Yes, this is yummy, but its also not that creative and not that difficult.  Second the toast is not even toasted.  I am not kidding.  Third, the ingredients in my omelet were not even chopped up. 

I left Zazies today really sad.  I wish it would have worked out, but it seems this used to be a great place that has lost its ability as its clientele has expanded. 

Normally I would give it 2 stars, but I think it needs to get knocked down in the ratings, so I am giving it a 1 star. I hope to find good brunch in this part of the city soon!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I used to love this place for brunch and dinner on their patio with twinkling lights but my last two visits were subpar. I'm no longer willing to wait in line for this place. 

The food just isn't as good as it used to be and I can't quite point out the reason. Little things aren't right like scrambled eggs that were over cooked and dry.
author: M H.

description:
Well we read a lot of Yelp reviews about this restaurant and were expecting some great French-style breakfast last Sunday. We went really early from Berkeley, since the reviews said there was always a 45 minute wait for a table on Sundays. 

To our disappointment, the food wasn't good, and was quite overpriced. 

We ordered the gingerbread pancakes, the cornmeal pancakes which was a special, the brulee steel cut oatmeal, an OJ, and a coffee. And it came to $54, after figuring in a 15% tip. We don't mind that it was a comparatively expensive breakfast. The problem is that it wasn't worth it. 

One thing that we don't understand is: why was it all the food we ordered, including the coffee, came to us lukewarm, bordering to cold? And when everything was so lukewarm rather than warm, not to say hot, it become very difficult for us to enjoy it!

I think the worst dish that we ordered was the brulee steel cut oatmeal. It was meant to be a small laddle of cream brulee put at the center of a big bowl of steel cut oatmeal with banana slices inside. Unfortunately, there was so little brulee and the oatmeal wasn't cooked well - it was  extremely thick and there was still a lot of big 1" lumps in there!  As a result, it tasted blank. Given its blankness, you would think that this would be served with a lot of hot milk and some brown sugar, if only to give it taste and  loose up the big oatmeal lumps. However, none of them came with the oatmeal and I had to ask for them. 

The special cornmeal pancake was okay, only that it was border to cold. Our first cup of coffee was also not warm either. 

Given so many quality breakfast places in SF, we could have gone to another good one.
author: Clara L.

description: Bomb, great burger, service and ambiance. A little small, but a great gem in Cole Valley.
author: Zo M.

description: Gingerbread pancakes, Eggs Benedict, Tahini French Toast nothing can disappoint you. Ridiculous lines though
author: Carleen C.

description:
The list of names of people who were waiting to eat some food was extremely long. Nonetheless, I am glad I waited.

I was contemplating to either order the La Mer or St. Trop, but it turned out to be an easy choice since they were out of the crab for La Mer. So I ordered St. Trop. I must say it was delicious. The egg was poached to perfection, the smoked salmon was so tasty salty. Their "home fries" was definitely the best potatoes I have ever tasted. It wasn't like the regular thin-cut fries fried in oil. It was bite size potatoes baked with whole garlic until everything melted together. It was so good, I could not believe I was eating whole garlic!

Next time I will try to get there early and order the La Mer. Or maybe St. Trop again.
author: Annie A.

description: Dear Zazie, you could have been my fave if I didn't have much choices in the city but you don't really worth all that wait. Brunch was just mediocre and I am not really impressed at all. Although the atmosphere is kind of cute.
author: Beril Y.

description:
I like this place.  Good eggs benedict dishes and good pancakes.  They have a cute patio, too.  Solid brunch spot... and like most solid brunch spots, expect to wait 30-60 minutes.  The upside is that you can walk around this neighborhood and check out the other shops/restaurants.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if a friend suggested it, I'd be down.
author: Erika C.

description:
Finally tried out Zazie! Really good breakfast/brunch food--TRY IT OUT!

Tip #1: Crazy crowded...my sister and I ventured here on a Thursday morning. Shouldn't have been so bad as a Friday/Saturday/Sunday morning. Unfortunately we waited a good 25 minutes only to get seated outside (it was slightly chilly). So if you want to get a good seat (and indoors), prepare to come early and wait your turn because it's pretty much crowded all the time from what i hear and what i experienced. We also arrived at 2pm, making it even weirder that it was so crowded! Basically our tips to avoid the traffic didn't do much for us :( 

Ambiance: Cute little breakfast spot in SF. There is street parking so that's nice but the restaurant itself is slightly cramped in my opinion. But regardless, the outdoor seating is cute and a great place to enjoy your brunch IF the sun is out. 

Food: Ordered my standard egg dish and split a dessert dish with my sister. I had the Fontainbleau scramble that came with with portobellos, shiitake, porcinis, spinach, fontina. For $12, yes it was a little pricey but they don't skimp on the ingredients so you get a lot of food and the whole wheat toast was soft and delicious! The scramble was heavy, but not in a bad way. I enjoyed the whole meal thoroughly. If I had to change one thing though I would make the dish a little less creamy. For some reason my egg scramble was a little less...solid? than I would like it to be. Maybe it was the cheese or the yolk not quite sure but it was too runny and so it tasted super cheesy and heavy overall. But just a nuance, overall really good dish! We also ordered a Pinkie's Challah French Toast with orange cinnamon batter. This was HEAVENLY! I am usually not a fan of sweet brunch dishes but I read good reviews about this one so I just had to try it and boy am I glad I did. Perfectly soft, gooey and sinful bites with fresh fruit on top. The cinnamon taste added a perfect kick and I love that you could order just one piece rather than a stack of the french toast (same with their pancakes). 

Drinks: Did not get anything but got a chance to taste my sister's Cole Valley Mimosa that came with orange and cranberry. A little pricey for $8, but still pretty good in taste. 

Tip $2: The restaurant has a strict no substitutions rule (unless you ask for something with meat, without, which is what my sister did).

Verdict; Definitely worth the amazing food! 1 star off for the kind of runny scramble.
author: Anu P.

description: Not worth the hour wait. Rude beyond belief! No food is that good. Life is too short and too precious to waste time with such things!  The worst part it I think it was the manager that was that rude.  Little short chunky Asian guy (I wish I got his name instead of having to describe him)  needs some manners.  If I am going to come to your place and spend my precious time and hard earned money, a little courtsy would be nice.
author: Lynn-Ann C.

description: Great place for breakfast! Good selection of benedicts and yummy pancakes! Not sure why it is French though:))
author: Merve A.

description:
Gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd = yum. Super long wait though. SUPER long. I think it was an hour and a half for us. So long that we walked to the Haight St fair that was a couple blocks away and pretty much exhausted our time there then went back to continue waiting. For that, they lose 2 stars. 1 star per 45 minutes of wait. Other than that, the back patio where we ate is exactly where you want to be on a nice day (like the one we went on). They have several flavors of mimosas, we got the mango which was really good. I like my bacon crispy and these folks did it right! The only thing that would've made it better is if they put brown sugar on it (hint hint, Zazie manager). 
Service was good, especially considering this place is packed nonstop the whole day.
author: Adam J.

description: This little place is so charming.  I came here during brunch and had the poached eggs with mushrooms and spinach.  It was prepared perfectly.  My sister had the french onion soup with a salad and she wasn't too impressed.  The service was really quick and friendly.  The food is a bit overpriced for what it is but I would definitely make a trip back.
author: Amy T.

description:
Food: 
-gingerbread pancake: pretty fluffy but it was pretty dry and the taste was pretty dull. I think they pretty much just got the texture of a pancake but not the essence. I didn't taste any of that ginger-y goodness I was expecting. Pretty disappointing. 

-La Mer (crab with poached egg on top of an english muffin): I liked it! I liked poached egg on top of chunks of crab meat all over an english muffin. You crack open the egg and all the juicy goodness of the yolk comes spilling out all over the english muffin and the crab chunks. And then the english muffin soaks up the yolk of the egg and you eat it all together into a perfect bite of happiness. Thumbs up on this dish! 

-french toast: The pieces of french toast were sandwiched between a layer of caramelized walnuts topped with some syrup covered bananas. I personally think that whole combination SOUNDS good but it was TOO SWEET for me. That's just me though.
