I don't particularly enjoy getting all sugared up that early in the morning, so I wasn't all goo goo for this dish. However, if you scrap all that caramelized sugar layer off and just eat the french toast alone, it was really good. The bread was very soft and french toasty! Hello Breakfast :) 

-organic vanilla soymilk: Taste like a good glass of silk soymilk! yay!

-hot chocolate: came in this big bowl and you had to drink it with a spoon. Very creamy and chocolately but not too sweet! Great drink to compliment a good breakfast! 

Service: Decent. No complaints but nothing worth praising either. 

Price: A bit pricey. For everything we ordered, it came out to be ~ $46. "Now that's a spicy meatball" for breakfast! X_X

Ambiance: REALLY CUTE! I've personally never been to France, but this place embodies my impression of what a cute French cafe would look like! It had this really relaxing and soothing feel to it. The whole place just sings: "it's just a lazy Sunday morning and you are just enjoying the beautiful sunshine. The morning is going to last forever, so take your time here and enjoy life." Call me crazy, but that was seriously how I felt when I ate here this morning. Loved it!! 

Overall: I'm not a huge fan of American Breakfast but this place is a winner! Come try it for yourself and enjoy your morning (or life!)
author: Amiee H.

description: Pancakes and French toast were average. Not bad, not worth the wait. Also, the St. Trip poached eggs with smoked salmon is a huge ripoff. For $14 they can afford to give mre than 4 sq inches of razor thin salmon.
author: Max C.

description:
Wonderful brunch place in a great neighborhood.
There is a wait but for the very good menu quality / selection and also the very effective and attentive service, it's worth it :-)
The host does a great job. 
I recommend this place,
 plus they have organic eggs !
author: Brand B.

description:
Dined with a group of people made my experience memorable.
We were 9 of us, sampling each others' orders. 

Gingerbread pancake is surely their signature dish but 
disappointing how the taste is just "pancake" to me...

After all, I am not an American breakfast or brunch person.

Wonderful, wonderful service despite how crowded the place was!
author: Yoshiko M.

description: Amazing food, definitely worth the wait. I had a pretty standard California breakfast and I was not disappointed. The avocados were perfectly ripe, eggs perfectly fluffy, and bacon just as I like it. Cute French countryside décor, wish I had gotten a chance to check out their famous back patio. Will definitely eat here again.
author: Kevin B.

description: I loved the crab cake benedict and the pumpkin pancakes, but the fake maple syrup? Come on Zazie - you can do better!
author: Amin S.

description: Stop by finnegan's next door and grab a Bloody Mary while you wait for a table. A great way to start off a Sunday Funday. The food is always amazing and so are the mimosas.
author: crystal r.

description: This is my first time here at Zazie. I came here because my son was hungry for pancakes, therefore, Zazie was the closest in in the area for breakfast. My son order the Un, Deux, Troix breakfast (1 pancake - that was a delish pancake, 2 scrambled eggs, and 3 pieces of bacon) and I ordered the Steel Cut Oatmeal with Bananas and Creme Brulee. "Oh Wow..." was my taste buds' reaction because it was soooo good! I never had creme brulee as a part of my breakfast but Zazie pulled it off by adding to the steel cut oats. I wouldn't mind coming back again to taste their lunch and dinner menu items. Customer Service (I'm big on that one) - Wendy, our server, was very pleasant and helpful; my son even told me she's very nice when she delivered our food. Ambience - very cozy especially where we sat - in the window corner with the sun shining thru the window. My son gives Zazie two thumbs up.
author: Ginalorie D.

description: This is a neighborhood gem.  I feel welcomed when I walk through the door to warmth and hospitality.  We didn't have a reservation, but we were given the choice inside or outside.  My friend opted outside.  There were heat lamps, but it was still cold.  Good thing I had a scarf, hood, and I was well bundled. You see, I didn't have alcohol to keep me warm like others did.  It is cool to eat outside for dinner.  We had the prixe fix, $27, starters:  mussels in great broth & chicken liver for me.  Entrees: Trout with goat cheese and salad & soup provencale for me (mussels, salmon, and a dense soup.  Dessert:  Creme Brulee (I would pass on this one.  Too starchy, not enough eggs)  & Ginger Pear Crumb (warm and perfect for cold night). The other dessert choice I was considering was the pot de creme, chocolate.  They served one warm bun and we had to ask for a second one since it was crunchy outside and warm inside.  The waiter was excellent; he was funny and made dining a happy experience.  If I was asked again, I would have opted to dine inside.  Strangely, I picked the very same items as 3 years ago.  Interesting!  One of these days, I got to wake up early to try their weekend brunch!   Beware, they add $1.25 per person for health insurance.  I don't quite get why they put it with the entrees and add tax on top of that, so the subtotal ends up with calculating the tip.  Mind puzzle.
author: Helen L.

description: I expected a wait, but 1.5 hours is extreme. I am sure the fact that it was raining and the back patio was closed didn't help. Despite the wait, the food was delicious. I had a poached egg over eggplant and an English muffin...oh my! Divine, especially with the home potatoes. Will go back if I can somehow get past the wait!
author: Lindsey R.

description:
figured i should add to the thousands of reviews
you can sit at the front 2 tables first come first serve
otherwise wait might be an hour on the weekend prime time.
best thing to add is the home made habanero sauce to the potatoes
had the omelette special and gingerbread pancake (bosc pear) and french toast tahiti with bananas, caramel, and walnut -- nice fluffy pancake, solid toast for the sweet tooth in you.  english muffins not home made.
author: Rob C.

description:
I used to have a 5 star review for this place then after my second visit had to change it to a one. 

So the first time I went to this place I could not believe how amazing all the food really was. Then when I came the second time months later it seemed as if everything had drastically changed. I had a male waiter who was just extremely rude and pretty much ruined the whole experience for me. When I told him I was gluten intolerant and could not have a muffin with my eggs benedict he did not care. I asked him if he could replace the english muffin with sourdough bread because that is the one bread I could actually eat. He then looked at me and simply said, "NO, it will be ugly." Then when I got my eggs benedict it was actually on an english muffin meaning I couldn't eat it. Then my friend received the wrong order and sent it back but the waiter once again tried to blame it on us. OFFICIALLY WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE EVER. Sadly I will never come back to this place because I do not need to be treated like an idiot by a waiter over brunch. I wish I could remember his name so I could send an email to the owner but sadly all I remember was a man who is slightly chubby and wore glasses.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: The food was delicious and be service better then excellent;-) the back patio is super romantic and they play beautiful French music. I loved the experience on every level;-)
author: Liza P.

description: Been several times now, so don't recall exact dishes but we love to bring friends and out-of-towners to Zazie and sit on their back porch. Great cozy spot to enjoy some great eats. Their brunch does a great job on sweets and savory dishes. 5-star brunch. Dinner is likely more 4-star. Solid but it's the brunch that keeps us coming back time and again.
author: David B.

description:
This place has turned me into a raving brunch monster. I've loved everything I've tried. I want to kiss whomever came up with the oatmeal brulee on the mouth(s). The potatoes have whole cloves of magical roasted garlic in them! Don't get me started on the amazing variety of pancakes, (gingerbread with poached pear?! lemon ricotta with lemon curd and raspberry sauce?!!!??) all frickin' delicious.

We've never had to wait to be seated. If you are holding out for a coveted outdoor spot, like most do, you might have to wait. I'm usually too hungry by the time I make the trek over, so I'll take the first seat available, no matter how awkwardly placed, because the food is that good, thank you very much. It might take a while for the food to come out, but if you are in good company it isn't an issue. The staff have always been super helpful and nice.

Granted, I've usually only come here with the boyfriend after one of those sleep in and hump all morning, oh crap it's noon and we haven't gotten out of bed days. And everything on those days is kind of coated in a fluffy post coital white light of happiness. But still. Eat here.
author: Chelsea W.

description: Let's just call this what it is.  The bomb.com.  It is not every day you find a great find like this little gem!  Everything was great.... Quick service... Friendly staff and fantastic food.  It was a bit pricey but great overall impression.  Would absolutely return here.
author: Leah P.

description: My ma and I chose to eat here for brunch on Easter. We knew the wait was going to be long, so it actually wasn't bad waiting, at all. After about an hour and a half we were seated outside in the garden at a perfect table! The coffee, poached eggs, and potatoes were delicious. I'd go back, but probably not on a holiday!
author: Bree G.

description:
Came here today with my girlfriend for some Saturday brunch.  I must give them props first of all for embracing technology and having the ipad at the door to take down names and party size.  We opted to go for first available seating since we were starving and weren't too picky about where we were seating.  Much to our surprise, less than five minutes after I put my name down, my name was called.  I had to double check to make sure that it was me (the curse of having a common name) but indeed it was us.

I had the special omelet (chicken sausage, roasted tomatoes, basil, and feta cheese) and my girlfriend had the un, deux, trois though she subbed in french toast and chicken sausage instead of the pancake and bacon ($4 extra).  It was all awesome!  Plump sausages, well battered french toast, and the feta cheese in the omelet took it to the next level.   I will admit the home fries weren't anything out of the ordinary but really the only small blip.  I liked the boysenberry (?) jam they had which was awesome.

Ambiance-wise, its a small shop though its not too crowded so I didn't feel like I was all up in another group's conversations.  It was well decorated but not overwhelming so it wasn't distracting at all.  Definitely a place I would go to again, perhaps to try these famous gingerbread pancakes people are talking about and to give the outdoor patio seating a try.  Recommend much.
author: Chris C.

description: Cute little place! Our waiter was friendly and his food recommendations were really good. Ordered the Florentine dish and it was delicious. It gets busy around lunch, but overall its a great brunch spot in the bay.
author: Racheal S.

description: Came here with a friend one afternoon after reading so many positive Yelp reviews. I had a polenta dish with home fries. It came on an adorably tiny little skillet. The salsa on top made everything really watery. The polenta and egg were pretty tasty but nothing out of the ordinary. My friend ordered some kind of fish dish that came with salad. She thought it was OK. We also shared a gingerbread pancake with fresh lemon curd which we both agreed was delicious. Overall OK experience. I'm willing to come back and try a few of their other dishes.
author: Sannie L.

description:
My neighborhood brunch place--always to be counted upon for a nice meal, though the wait is appalling on weekends. The food, though generally highly rated, is good but not outstanding. Highlights include the Benedicts (of which there are several versions) and the pancakes (also several versions--my advice, go for the sampler!).

The main draw, (other than my friends' overriding enthusiasm), is the place itself. With its whimsical back garden seating, its ideal for slow, sunny days.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Oh Zazie! The things you do to me!!!

Expect the line to be huge! But, every minute of waiting in line, will be worth it once you try the food. Absolutely delicious and service is usually quick and polite. I would highly recommend getting the Tahitian french toast with a side of fruits! So So delicious, my mouth is watering just remembering how good it tastes!
author: Karina A.

description:
Absolutely delicious quality breakfast/lunch! I wanted everything on the menu...and almost got everything but next time I wanna try their special ricotta pancakes, mussels, burger, and crab benedict!!!

Such a cute little place in Cole Valley with the CUTEST outdoor seating! Went at 1:30 on a Thursday and it was full in there, but we didn't hafta wait for a table for 3! 

The waitress was so sweet and super helpful! 

I order 1 slice of regular French toast and 1 slice of the Tahiti French Toast (with carmelized bananas and walnuts), my friend order the St. Trop (Smoked salmon, onions, capers benedict), my other fried order the chicken/prosciutto/fig sandwich, and we all shared the corn-cakes with overeasy eggs/avocado/sour cream and potatos (fat we are...well aware...we finished everything by the way). 

-Challah French toast (orange-cinnamon batter): delicious. Not too battery, and really got the taste of the challah! It was nice and sweet and taste bomb dot com with butter.

-Tahiti French toast: carmelized bananas and walnuts! Tastes like a very moist, chewy, doughy banana bread...very good. A little much for me to handle! But if you got a sweet tooth and a desire for some yummy banana bread, come get at this!

-St. Trop: smoked salmon benedict! AMAZING! I had this at Baker Street Bistro a while ago and their hollaindaise does not compare to Zazie's. It's super light but full of flavor. This dish isn't too heavy and the poached egg is cooked excellently; not too soft/runny so I could cut it!

-Corn-cake hash topped with an overeasy egg, avocado, salsa, cheese and potatos: The potatos are just a little side thing but omg so good. Nice and cripsy and yummy but soft at the same time but the best part is that it comes with DELICIOUS ROASTED GARLIC PIECES!!! OMNOM! So good...but the corn cake was good especially if you like the Mexican-influenced type of dishes. But it was just okay to me.

-My friends seasonal grilled fig and chicken and prosciutto sandwich (with some type of cheese): DELICIOUS! Very eclectic pick but delicious.

So down for this place.
author: Eryn K.

description:
Brunch is excellent here. It's not too heavy and not too light -- just perfect. My favorite menu items have to be the croque madame and the Eggs Benedict Monaco. It's eggs benedict with prosciutto and the best tomatoes ever. I have made so many people try this dish and they love it! That said, all the eggs benedict dishes here are fantastic. The outside patio area is also especially gorgeous in warm weather. 

Con: The wait is LONG. Quick tip: the tables up in front outside are first come, first serve so if you're desperate to eat and don't care about having a nice ambiance, stand by them so you can grab them right as the people finish eating.
author: Amy M.

description:
Food: 1.5 stars
Service: 3 stars
Value: 1.5 stars

I have no idea why this place is so popular. For the same kind of food, I have had much better experience somewhere else. Zazie did not impress me at all. In fact, it was a big disappointment.

I ordered the Fresh Grilled Ahi Tuna Sandwich. For $13, the portion is small and no side comes with it. There was only two tiny pieces of OVERCOOKED tuna with tiny bit of pesto on a piece of OVER-TOASTED levain bread. The fish was dry and unpleasant looking. The bread was tough and hard to bite. Just by looking at how their fish was done, I can tell the chef does not have good skill. A good chef will never overcook the seafood. 

After the not-so-good tuna sandwich, I was still hungry. So I ordered their Challah French Toast. For $5, all I got was a soggy piece of toast. It was the worst French Toast I've ever tried!

The only thing that I like about Zazie is using iPad for customers check in. Pretty cool, but this alone doesn't make me want to come back again. There are tons of restaurants serve better food than you.
author: F T.

description:
Was searching for a good brunch spot and Zazie was my choice. Arriving around 11:00am on a Sat I expected a wait before being seated considering this place to be popular for brunch and luckily it wasn't to bad and was seated within 10 min. We sat out in their little patio area and what a beautiful day it was too, to be out there. We started with the "Sun Shine" Mango Mimosas...yummy... 

Everything on the menu sounded so delicious... I decided to have the "Albert" which was two poached eggs on top of bacon, white Cheddar on a toasty English muffin smothered with their yummy Hollandaise Sauce that came with home fries and had a side of their apple chicken sausage too (yes I was hungry) My friend she had the "Pierre Noir" two poached eggs on top of roasted tomatoes provencales, bacon on English muffins with the same yummy sauce, with home fries. 

What a great meal it was, delicious. The waiters were great too, very friendly and attentive. The overall ambiance of the place was very warm and cozy. I'll be back here again for brunch for sure...
author: Jayne M.

description:
Line is long. If you want to sit outside on street, just grab it. No need to put your name on wait list.
I had egg on fonte which had polenta and delicious. Cream cheese coffee cake was delicious. If you come after 12:30 on weekday line moves faster since the earlier crowd start leaving. 
Portion is just right ( smaller) fore so if you want big meal you at feel as it's overpriced. But it's worth it. 
The only complain is the wait....
author: Akiko I.

description: French toast Tahit, gingerbread pancakes & La Mer  :D
author: Es S.

description:
Fantastic brunch at Zazie! The food was great, the service was good, and the environment is really cutesy/cozy for a sweet brunch date. Zazie doesn't have the most street presence so we walked passed this place a couple times. You'll find this cute restaurant under a yellow awning. It was raining on this partciular day so the lines/wait time that I read about were non-existant. Parking wasn't the easiest either but the neighborhood is mostly residential so it's not impossible. 

We ordered the prosciutto benedicts and a single gingerbread pancake. The prosciutto was so delicious and the gingerbread pancake was the perfect counter balance of sweet. Between the two of us a single gingerbread pancake was plenty to share cause they're on the thicker side. 

Our server was kind and attentive so no complaints there. The restaurant is cute with the usual mix of couples, families, and on-offs. Definitely one of my favorite brunch spots in the city. I'm sure you'll like it too. Enjoy!
author: Ken C.

description:
Q:  I know what you're all thinking...is it really that good?  
A:  Yes, my friends, it's really that good. 

Q:  Is it worth the ridiculous line?  
A:  Yes, and may I suggest having one of your generous friends wait in that atrocious line for you or for the group.  Tentative wait time on a Sunday...between 45 minutes to an hour.  First come, first served.  

Q:  Is it worth the hype? 
A:  uh-huh. 

Q:  What did you order? 
A:  The florentine eggs benedict with the garlic roasted potatoes. DELISH!

Q:  What did you order to drink?
A:  The black currant mimosa.  

Q:  Did you have a bite of their famous french toast?
A:  Yes, and it was super yummy. 

Q:  Would you go back?
A:  Only if I didn't have to wait in line. 

Q:  Do you recommend Zazie's?
A:  Yes.  Especially if you're a foodie and love to YELP!
author: Soo Jin K.

description: My friend and I had a great time there.  The toast and sandwich were impressive. We were waiting in the line for over 40 min and finished our nice brunch in 20 min. :-)))))
author: Ruo W.

description: Zazie was pretty good but not the best I've ever had. I would give it a 3.5, but in the case of the definition of each rating Zazie is "A-OK". My friend and I ordered St. Trop and La Mer so that we could try both! I thought they were both good, but not the best eggs benedict. Especially for the amount of time you have to wait just to get seated, not worth it. Their potatoes were pretty good too, but too bad some were over cooked and burned :/ It's a cute place and they have mimosas [yum] but it's $8. Overall, would I come here again? Mmm probably not, unless my friends insist on coming here. And when that does happen, Ill order something different because they have a large variety of yummy descriptive dishes on their menu!
author: Jeanette L.

description: Couldn't have wanted more from a brunch. Their poached egg menu is priced per egg, and each egg dish comes with a salad or home fries. If you want to try two different poached eggs, you get to have BOTH a salad and home fries. I had the dungeness crab benedict and the prawns benedict off the specials menu. Every bite was delicious. The menu itself is somewhat limited, but the service was great, I really like the patio, and I will definitely be back.
author: Zack B.

description:
I had the omelette special.  The potatoes were above average--lots of garlic and roasted perfectly.  Tables are small and kind of close together. The two women sitting next to us were having the loudest conversation about unemployment and going on bad dates.  Kind of unpleasant.  Service was adequate with a small dollop of friendly.

If I was in Cole Valley and hungry for breakfast, I would probably hit this place up again.  But that's probably not going to happen anytime soon so...
author: happy t.

description:
This place was highly recommended to me by a friend. I absolutely agree with all the reviews out there raving about the pumpkin pancake. it was AMAZBALLS. 

I also had the omelet and it was really good too. 

It was a long wait though! so make sure to plan accordingly when you plan to eat there.

SO WORTH THE WAIT though!!!!
author: Lillian S.

description:
This used to be our neighborhood place -- but now it has been taken over by outsiders.  I can't remember the last time we were actually able to get in for brunch.  And last night we were turned away for dinner.  I guess the secret is out.  

Guess I'll have to set my targets on Monday and Tuesday nights.
author: Matthew C.

description: I'm not sure what the hype is about.  The boyfriend and I waited for about an hour before we got seated. The service was good, the food was ok, but I've had better brunch spots without the wait. It's a good establishment, but nothing that screams "wow" in my opinion! I'd probably come here again if I knew for sure there wouldn't be a wait.
author: Heather R.

description:
Breakfast is my favorite meal of the day, only beaten by brunch because, well, its later in the day and usually implies i've gotten to sleep in.  So I'm a fairly harsh critic, having tried a lot of places, but Zazie is EASILY in my top 5 brunch places.  This review is based on the poached eggs, potatoes and excellent service.

Ill start with potatoes, or 'home fries, since usually I can judge a brunch place on the potatoes alone.  Zazie were pretty unique, a kind of fried country potatoes with whole cloves of garlic in the mix.  The potatoes were a perfect combination of crisped on the outside, but still tender.  And the garlic was surprisingly pleasant to eat whole.  Usually i prefer crispier potatoes since country potatoes aren't seasoned well enough and lack flavor, but these were really tasty.  4/5 stars.

The poached eggs were served sort of eggs benedict style.  I ordered the one with bacon and white cheddar and my brother the one with smoked salmon.  Both absolutely delicious and easily the best eggs I'd ever had prepared that way.  5 stars.

What really confirmed the 5th star for Zazie was the waiting staff.  The restaurant is fairly small and decently long waits outside every weekend.  I was late coming to meet my family and in the midst  of catching up, we probably sent the waiter away a couple of times before ordering.  But throughout our time their he was really courteous, attentive, and made the whole experience great.

Con - No fresh squeezed OJ, which was extra disappointing since I was hungover on holiday party wine and its my brunch drink of choice.
author: Dhiraj S.

description:
I think the food here is just wonderful. The best time to go would be on a weekday. The reason why I give this a 2 star rating is because going on the weekend is a nightmare. I went with my husband and daughter and when we arrived, it was busy, but not crazy. There were 3 people ahead of us. 

The problem was after a while, I noticed the host allowing the "regulars" to go ahead of us. This was ridiculous. I watched as people would come well after we did and sign in after us and get a table. And it would be groups larger than ours. I asked politely on our status and he kept assuring me it would be soon.. but we had 3 people, he said. That was ridiculous since I watched him seat his "regulars" who had groups of 4.

I wanted to leave, but we were so hungry that we knew if we went anywhere else at that point, we would be in for a longer wait.. So we ended up waiting for at least an hour and 10 minutes. This was just disappointing. 

So if you go, go EARLY or on a weekday. And of course, if you're a regular, go anytime... you'll get in way ahead of those of us that actually bother to think a sign-in method is fair.
author: Kelly F.

description:
After waiting for 50 minutes to get a table, we finally sat although it was outside at the first come first serve tables instead of inside at would have otherwise been our table if we waited another 20 minutes. There are only two tables outside but if someone is leaving as you get there grab it quickly and maybe you'll have to wait less. After so long, I was expecting greatness. Food looks really good but just tastes ok. We had gotten the following

Mimosas with mango - this was good. Heavy on the champagne but the mango adds something different to what is otherwise a normal mimosa
Florentine poached eggs with avocado- pretty good, especially if you are a vegetarian
La mer- would have liked it if my eggs weren't cold. The dish was otherwise fine. Two poached eggs is pretty filling and the crab was definitely good
French Toast Tahiti - this was good. very rich and thus filling, 2 is plenty. The banana and walnut are a great combo, recommend this if you are in the mood for something sweet
The potatoes are noteworthy, they are herb potatoes but have cloves of garlic mixed in.

On to service, we saw our waiter 3 times - when ordering, when getting the check and when he returned our cards

i would have given this place 4 stars if it weren't for the atrocious wait, my cold food and the lack of service. The menu has a lot of variety and the place is cute. I still liked it and think it is worth going, just not during peak hours so i suppose this is a 3.5 star review. It is on the better side of brunch options in SF and overall i like it
author: sasha h.

description: Nice place for brunch. The food here is super good, more diverse than most places. The service is also very good. On the pricy side.
author: Luong T.

description:
Went for the first time today with a couple friends and definitely enjoyed by experience. I ordered the Croque Madame (my friend had told me that these croque monsieurs were better than the ones at la Tartine in the mission--Pah. we'll see about that) and was impressed. The side of potatoes that it came with were BOMB. So here's a breakdown

Croque Madame-Right up there with the ones from Tartine--MIGHT even be better (I can't believe I'm saying this)

Pancakes du midi- Basically pancakes with some fruit on top--good but san fran had a lot of great pancake places

Service-Acceptable

Wait time--for a party of three--SOOO LONG! noontime brunch on a sunday--probably expected.
author: An-Nhien L.

description: Had a really pleasant brunch, here this week.  All the (adult) kids home, for a change and decided to spend the morning in San Francisco, making Zazie our first stop.  Between the 5 of us we had a great sampling: trout and potatoes, cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd, the burger and two different versions of eggs benedict.  All were very good and our server was great.  We'd absolutely go back!  My one small complaint is the bathroom--Eek!
author: Allison B.

description: The charcuterie was wonderful. Every element from the mustard to the pate and the prosciutto to the salmon and olives were excellent.  Wines were delicious.   Hanger steak while a little tough had good flavor.Love Monday nights on the patio as it is dog night and everyone brings their fourlegged children.  One thing is that it is very popular so get there early or call ahead to see how busy they are.  We got there around 7 last Monday and there was a 45 minute wait for a table on the patio.
author: Jerry W.

description:
And I finally made it to Zazie's doors.

Ok, long wait and finding parking is a challenge.  Don't mind both, Zazie is worth it.

We got to sit outside on a nice day.  We all had eggs, mine the scrambled mexico.  The home fries came with whole roasted garlic, can you believe that?  I love garlic! My plate was clean of every crumb and butter.  Yep, it was that good.

The mimosas were strong.  But cheers for a good brunch.
author: Pam S.

description: The wait during weekday brunch was between 5-15 minutes. Came in here twice in one week recently and ordered the lemon ricotta and raspberry pancakes both times. My rule about this place is: only take your favorite people here or come alone.
author: Ramona P.

description:
I came here with a couple of friends for brunch one Monday. I had the Croque Madam and my friend has the Salade Betterave with grilled chicken. The salad was good, I must admit, and I'm typically not a fan of vinaigrette dressings. I've been wanting to try a Croque Madam for years. After 5 semesters of French, I was really looking forward to it. It was definitely presented well and was quite tasty. I'd say $13 is pretty pricey for what is essentially a grilled ham & cheese sandwich with an egg and a small very basic side salad though.. 

The restaurant itself was pretty small, but it didn't feel cramped. The service was pretty good and they seemed super attentive to their regulars. Overall, it's got a nice, pretty cozy feel to it. I'd definitely like to come back and try numerous other dishes on the menu.
author: Angel D.

description:
Once you get past the wait on a Saturday or Sunday morning, prepare for the best and classiest Brunch available in Cole Valley/Haight.
I order their Florentine Benedict everytime, and can't resist a mimosa.
Prices aren't bad, atmosphere is great, staff is courteous.
This little gem is a neighborhood staple, and a must to visit. I wouldn't venture to bring more than 3/4 people with me in a group though as space is limited and there is a serious line.
author: Sarah A.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Sausage omelet (the special of the day) - twas good. but not amazing. With the "fries" which is more like potato squares. Not sure what the fuss or hype is about this place. Maybe it's the overly oiled n fried up potatoes n garlic cloves. But my taste is more of warm, mushy, comforting, filling - opposite of fried, crispy, oily. 
2.) Crab benedict - looks better than it tastes. Everything's kind of .. bland. I've had to periodically sprinkle salt on my food just to give it more flavor. 

*yar came here twice, with much fuss n hype... Sure it's good. But not great nor impressive, really. Makes me doubt the sophistication of my pallet: if everyone likes it, why don't I?? But blind sheep I am not - or rather, tastebudless sheep I am not. Will not join the masses in agreeing the King's invisible garments are wonderful. I'd rather have quantity and more taste.


SERVICE:
Good.


ATMOSPHERE:
This time got to enjoy the back patio, which was quaint cute and nice :) With a cute little feel of the neighborhood, and basking under the heat lamp. haha. As for the inside, the place is teeny tiny. Lots of character though, for instance the little toilet. lol. Very interesting. With matching sized kitchen and dishwashing sink. Walking through to the back, get to take a glimpse of behind the scenes. Four workers crammed in the little 5 foot kitchen busting out all those dishes! My background involves food business, so it's just funny n interesting to see the itty scale. The neighborhood is cute too. Noe Valley. Short distance from Haight, if you want to have a nice day to stroll through shops 21
author: Angela L.

description: Visited SF with my boyfriend last weekend and wanted to get an awesome brunch by our Airbnb. There were tons of people waiting and we thought it would take forever, but we were seated within 10 min. This is truly one of the best brunches I had ever had- we got perfectly cooked scrambled eggs, chicken sausages and the miracle pancakes (which were BREAD PUDDING FREAKING PANCAKES that will continue to haunt me for the rest of my life). Need to figure out a way to come back to SF asap so I can come back here!
author: Carmen J.

description: I recently visited this restaurant after multiple referrals from a client of mine. Though reservations can be tricky because of the size of the establishment, my date and I found a time that suited us. Both of us had the pre fixe dinner which included a half appetizer, full entree and dessert each. The trout was amazing, as were the mussels. for dessert I had the blueberry crumble which was delicious to me but my coworker had tried the same dessert and gave nothing but complaints on the crumble. My lady had ordered a pasta dish which was enormously portioned but excellent and ordered the creme brullee(which was gone so fast I didn't even get to try a bite) so i'm assuming that it was "EPIC" after realizing my GF had already finished it. I've read that the breakfast/brunch is top notch so I will soon be making an adventure to try it sometime.
author: David L.

description:
What a perfect place for dinner the other night.. I had been here before and made sure that we could sit on the patio when making the reservation. It was a gorgeous night in the city and although we had a late dinner (8:45) they did not rush us one bit. The thing I love about this restaurant is that both of the servers I have had were great- not too over the top and talk to you like you are a real group of people- not 6 year olds like some servers...!

I would always recommend this place for dinner, especially for an intimate gathering of friends. The patio is delightful and they have heaters since there is no such thing as a warm night in SF... Food recommendations:

* Lamb curry over couscous was amazing
* Trout was really good, but not too filling so might want to get a side. 
* Duck was delicious
* Honestly... everything is good...

I have never been here for breakfast but I look forward to trying it sometime soon!
author: Courtney M.

description:
French toast! French toast! French toast! French toast! French toast!

So good!
author: Gio H.

description:
This is my FAVORITE brunch spot in SF- hands down!

FOOD:  The Zazie reviews speak for itself-- amazing and delicious!  We ordered a ton of food for only ~$20/person.  There are those typical "breakfast / brunch places" and then there are those fabulous breakfast/brunch places that make you realize how much you LOVE breakfast foods like eggs (poached, scrambled, omelet-style), bacon, ham, Eggs Benedict, bagels, toast, sandwiches, juice and oatmeal.  

I had been getting into a sad rut where I loved breakfast foods but had not found a place that really showcased such breakfast items in a way that justified spending $12 on eggs and carbs and also make me think, "WOW."  Zazie changed that with their hearty yet delicate lunch that was delicious through and through!  :)

GINGERBREAD PANCAKES (4/5):  Light and delicious, the flavor of the gingerbread pancakes were brought out by a sweet lemon curd along with a slice of caramelized pear.  YUM.  A stack of 2 gingerbread pancakes will easily feed a table of four.

TAHITI FRENCH TOAST (5/5):  Yes, it's that good!  The french toast was huge and buttery soft and paired perfectly with walnut cream and caramelized strips of banana.  SO exquisite and delicious.  This French Toast doesn't make you feel like you're just eating filler carbs because this is a great dish in its own right. A definite must order with your brunch entree.

EGGS BENEDICT (5/5):  Whatever you order (the Floretine, Pierre Noire, the Albert), the poached eggs are huge and perfect!  The eggs benedict made me fall in love with breakfast all over again.  The poached eggs had the perfect consistency (not overdone, a little runny, held its perfect little shape on top of the English muffin, tomatoes and bacon). 

The roasted potatoes and garlic that accompany the egg dishes are delicious.  The potatoes are a little oily but there's some kind of intense, robust flavor that makes it hard to stop eating the potatoes and doesn't make you feel like you're just eating those typical roasted rosemary potatoes.  You really feel like you're eating a hearty, flavorful breakfast that someone took a lot of thought into preparing.  So good!  You can choose from 1 to 2 to 3 eggs at different prices ($9 / 12 / 16 (i think)).

SANDWICHES (4/5):  Very good as well!  We had the sandwich with a fried egg, ham, melted cheese and a side salad of mixed greens.  The sandwich is very good, but we found ourselves going to the eggs benedict more.  I think my friends had a delicious ahi tuna sandwich-- will definitely try that next time. 

WAIT:  We waited for approximately 30-40 minutes on a Sunday at 1 p.m.  The wait dies down significantly by 2 p.m., but that's because the restaurant closes at 2:30 p.m.  This place is worth the wait- you won't be disappointed. 

UNIQUE:  Zazie is an affordable and unique local gem that embraces SF's "go green" mentality and features a delicious brunch that'll have you talking about it the entire day (no joke!).  Zazie has two outdoor seating tables in front of the restaurant, a handful of wooden tables indoors and a beautiful backyard/patio seating area outside.  

CUTE:  Everything about this place is great!  Zazie has super cute, painted plates and a comfortable (and comforting) feel to the restaurant.  You'll find yourself spending over an hour or two eating and chatting with friends without even knowing it!  There's homemade jam (slightly sweet and tart) on the table as well.

MIMOSA:  The mimosa drinks looked delicious.  They had a fresh mango mimosa that I would definitely try. (Reminds me of what The Grape Leaf Inn served in Napa.)

DINNER:  The dinner at Zazie looks pretty darn good, especially since they pair it with community-friendly outreach-type incentives like no corkage-fee nights, dog-friendly nights and prie fix menues for ~$28.  Will definitely have to check it out next time.
author: Sunny S.

description:
My friend who is a bay-area native had planned us a San Francisco outing, starting at Zazie for what she claimed was the best brunch in the city. I met up with her about 9:30 and we were dropped off in front of the restaurant to put our names on the list so we hopefully wouldn't have to wait too long. It was a crisp 48 degrees out and we checked the "first available" box to insure we'd get a table within a reasonable time period. We were a group of five and, miraculously, were seated within about 10 minutes of putting our names on the list. We were seated inside and ordered our dishes, a build-your-own mimosa and an order of the cream cheese coffee cake. 

Surprisingly, the food came out also shockingly quickly and was shockingly good. I ordered the monaco, which is eggs benedict with proscuitto and tomato. The hollandaise wasn't overwhelmingly rich but was delicious and the potatoes were crisp and savoury as well. The mimosas (which we ordered with orange and mango juice, which was truly spectacular) were great and just enough for the five of us. The coffee cake was moist and crumbly and just the right amount of sweet and tangy. A truly great dining experience and suitable service to boot. A bit of a splurge but surely the way to go if looking for a slightly formal weekend brunch experience!
author: Lily R.

description: The food is good and creative. Gingerbread pancakes are really worth a try. Only criticism I have after numerous visits is that if you are really hungry the entrees are modest size. Service is great.
author: Terry K.

description:
My BF suggested Zazie for brunch a few weeks ago because he wanted to see if it lived up to all the hype. Because of the thunder and rain we had the previous night, I figured most people would stay in and there wouldn't be much of a wait.... Wrong!! We waited for about an hour before being seated.

I had the La Mer, which was eggs benedict with Dungeness crab and Hass avocado. Loved it! I was sad the eggy goodness was gone when I finished. It was worth the wait. I also had a couple bites of my BF's French Toast Tahiti. Not as good as the La Mer, but pretty tasty. Thick pieces of light fluffy toast that had a nice crisp on the outside. 

Long wait and parking is hard to come by, so drive by and put your name on the list before venturing off to find parking,. If you still have a long wait, go to Tully's for some coffee. Only slight complaint is service could be more attentive. I will return to try the Gingerbread Pancakes!
author: Kim V.

description: I have never been to this restaurant without having a long wait, sometimes up to two hours.  That being said, it is a cute restaurant with outdoor seating, and has some very good food.  I say "some" very good food, because there have definitely been some misses.  One would be their St. Trop (smoked salmon) benedict, which appeared to use farmed Atlantic salmon lox, which had nearly no taste to them.  The portion size on the poached eggs is also quite small.  One of my favorite dishes was a special that had: an open faced breakfast sandwich with figs and goat cheese that was amazing.  I also really like their French Toast Tahiti (challah French toast stuffed with carmelized bananas and walnuts).  For a half hour wait or less, it's worth it.  For a two hour wait, I'll come back another time.
author: Scott E.

description: I love Zazie and I don't know anyone who doesn't. French inspired brunch with a lovely garden? I'll go anytime. The only problem with Zazie is that it's not 5 times bigger - I'm sure they would still fill up. Go on a weekday to avoid the crowds.
author: Bill W.

description:
Zazie is great. I came here for brunch/lunch on a weekday, and it was pretty busy at 11:30am but I got seated right away. The staff was running around, but they were sooo incredibly nice. I had a group of 3 and most places try to squeeze you into a 2-person table, but they were all about pushing two tables together and giving us a 4-person space. And while this might seem like a trivial thing, it's the sort of stuff I really appreciate.  

The brunch menu is mouth-watering. I am always torn between a protein-filled egg dish or a sugar-carb extravaganza. This time I chose the latter and had the 3-pancake sampler. Of the 3 pancakes, all were delish but I liked the miracle and buttermilk the best. Surprisingly, the gingerbread pancake was my least favorite. I thought it lacked flavor and was a bit dry, in comparison to the other two. Also, on the sampler, they just have the pear compote topping which I actually wasn't a huge fan of - a little too sweet for me so I took most of it off. I wish they did another fruit topping option for the sampler. I had the regular coffee which was fine. My friend had a cafe au lait that looked great. I would love to try the egg dishes and poached egg specialties next time. 

I'd be fearful of the weekend brunch line, so a weekday brunch/lunch is ideal if you can make it. Street parking is also much easier on the weekday, or take the N-Judah.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I really really REALLY want to give this place a 3.5. But I guess a 3 will suffice. Sorry, Zazie. 

The Pros: 

-Zazie is such a great little breakfast/brunch spot. Right in the heart of Cole Valley and cozy and quaint. 
-The Tahitian French Toast is amazing! Sweet and nutty and banana-y and gooey and soft and crispy and delicious. But it's huge. So if you're 2 little asian girls, don't go ordering a stack of 2. Order 1, and split it. That is, assuming you're also going to be ordering the gingerbread pancakes. 
-I love the mimosa selection! It was nice to see options when deciding how to buzzed at 9:30 in the morning. Mango mimosa all the way. YUM. 

The Cons:

-Parking is ridiculous. Streets are relatively narrow and there is always some kind of construction going on. I miss the days of free street parking. 
-The wait time is also ridiculous. Luckily we got there--well, I go there--at 9am to put our name in so it wasn't too bad, but this place gets insanely crowded. 
-I wanted to love the gingerbread pancakes because everybody raves about them! But I found ours to be heavy and doughy. The marmalade on top, however, was excellent. 
-The sausages are tiny. 

Overall, Zazie is a nice neighborhood brunch spot, and I would definitely go back for the French toast and get a mimosa or two. Or three.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
Very fresh ingredients, so you can taste each individual ingredient in each dish: eggs, ham, sun dried tomatoes, lettuce, etc. The home fries were also quite unique and delicious as they use whole unpeeled garlic cloves and rosemary. 

The gingerbread pancakes were amazing along with the poaches pear. Excellent food, decent wait (~30 min), tricky parking, and good ambiance. Will be back soon!
author: Katie Y.

description:
Finally made it to Zazie, after a year of drooling over the delicioius looking photos!

Came her around 12:30, people were waiting outside but after 5 minutes we were already seated...(smaller groups= faster seating!)
There's seating indoors and outdoors (front and back patio). On a cloudy cold day we sat on the patio that was heated. It was actually so heated that I felt like I was getting a tan! But I was too hungry to move.
+*If you're unsure about your seating, the staff is happy to relocate you.*

We had the 
-French Toast Tahiti.. it's Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and    
  walnuts.... Wow best french toast I've ever had!
-Poached eggs mounted on crab with avocado, hollandaise sauce, and a side of    
  home fries (I don't remember the name, i think it's a seasonal special.) Yum!
- Zazie mimosa (regular w/ fresh oj) 
- La Groseille- black currant mimosa

BEST BRUNCH IN SF!
author: Lynn T.

description:
Everything about Zazie is pretty great- nice people, good service, delicious food. Since there are so many good reviews, I'll just leave a couple of tips:

1. If you hate lines/waiting, try going on a weekday rather than Saturday or Sunday- it can be quite busy.  (But it's still worth it!) 

2. Try the Zazie burger- exactly how it is- even if you think you wont like it! The flavors all together are really amazing and it will defy your expectations. Just do it. Just try it. It's delicious.

3. Any of the poached eggs dishes are fantastic. The hollandaise sauce is just right- not to heavy and not to sour. 

Love this place!
author: crystala t.

description: Amazing breakfast. Wonderful staff. Had french toast tahiti and the la mer. Mmmm. Worth the long wait. Quaint setting and lively! Better than mamas!
author: Loraena J.

description: Charming atmosphere, good, fresh breakfast options for those looking for something healthy or decadent.  I tried a special: polenta with eggs baked in a cast iron skillet with a chipotle chevre sauce, wilted spinach and mushrooms.
author: Misha U.

description: Absolute favorite breakfast place in the city!! I miss it already. No one makes hollandaise sauce like Zazie. Eggs la mer is my jam. :)
author: Samantha N.

description:
"What?! You're a foodie and you've never been to Zazie's???" - my coworker Linh

I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time ever since my coworker told me about it. At last, I can say I'm a satisfied customer and will be coming back very soon!

On a beautiful 75 degree Saturday in SF, my friends and I came here for brunch. The wait was about 5-10 minutes only, amazing for a weekend brunch hot spot! We sat in the back patio - a cute, intimate, feel like you're eating in someone's backyard, with partly shaded areas. It was a perfect day to have brunch outside and simply made the whole experience even better.

- Bloody Mary: bland, not enough spices, tasted mostly like tomato juice with splash of vodka, comes with a celery & string bean (interesting)

- Fontainbleu Scramble: EXCELLENT! I love mushrooms and this had the right combo of eggs, mushrooms, spinach, fontina, and seasoning. I was also able to get it with egg whites so extra points for that. comes with a thick piece of toast and I opted for the salad (average tasting mista salad).

- Spritzer: my friend insisted i write a complaint about her drink in my review, so here it is. The spritzer was supposed to be a combo of OJ, cranberry, and pellegrino, but tasted like OJ only with a weird aftertaste. There was no carbonation and no trace of cranberry whatsoever. (maybe they used old pelly that was sitting around?) However, the OJ was fresh with lots of pulp.

Service was attentive and friendly. Overall great experience. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Linda C.

description: Fantastic tasting breakfast, friendly and quick service, and inviting cozy environment. I had a mexican omlet with home fries and a cup of coffee, all delicious. Very good spot for breakfast or brunch.
author: Danny H.

description: Food is so good and totally worth the wait! Try and get there a little early on the weekend before they run out of their potatoes!
author: Nicole K.

description:
Fresh squeezed grapefruit mimosa + dungeness crab eggs benedict= perfection!  

I loved the food, the drinks, our waitress, and the environment in the tiny restaurant.  

Tip:Get there early and good luck finding parking!
author: Aimee L.

description:
I love brunch and Zazie certainly did not disappoint.

A friend and I came here on a Monday around noon and the place was packed.  I would've loved to dine outside in the patio as most yelpers have suggested, but it was just way too cold on this particular day.  Maybe next time.  

French toast Tahiti - stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts
The Monaco - prosciutto and tomatoes on an english muffin with hollandaise sauce and a side of greens
The St. Trop - smoked salmon with capers and onions on an english muffin with home fries.

3 orders split amongst the 2 of us and we were completely stuffed!

Zazie definitely lived up to its hype and I'll definitely be back.......hopefully on a gorgeous day so I can experience the nice outdoor patio next time around!
author: Carmen Y.

description:
I'm generally an impatient person, but Sunday brunch here is worth the wait.  Bring good company and grab a coffee a few doors down to pass the time - or find things you never though you needed at Cole Hardware across the street.

I had the St. Trop (wild salmon with capers, red onions and poached eggs on an english muffin) with house fries on the side and it was amazing.  A tad bit more salty than I was expecting but still all good, especially the garlic cloves that were aplenty with my potatoes!  

The food was good, as was the service.  Let's do it again!
author: Cora L.

description:
On my death bed...will someone please bring me a stack of Zazie's gingerbread pancakes?

I can see it now, a bite of fluffy pancake with lemon curd and drizzled with  devilshly good syrup. mmmmmmmmmmmm. Then off to heaven I'd go. 

Weekend brunch is the ultimate test for any hungry person's patience. So be strong and hang in there. IT IS worth the wait. 

Along with the pancakes I also ordered a plate of thier eggs with sausage and potatoes (oh man, naughty potatoes) with the most amazing slab of sourdough bread on the side.

Unfortunately I went down the street and bought coffee (lame) so I did not order a bowl--yes a bowl--of warm beverage like my 2 companions =(

I saw the reviews for dinner and will try the prix fixe next time fo' sho'!!
author: Hilda Z.

description:
Came to Zazie for dinner because I knew they had outdoor seating that our friend could bring their dog while we ate.  

For outdoor seating it's first come first serve and thank goodness a table just vacated when we arrived.  We were greeted immediately by our server and some water.  I decided on the fettuccine with prawns and the bf and had the hanger steak.  Both were delicious however the bf complained later that he was super thirsty all night (lots of salt his in dish).  

Overall good place to grab a bite and reconnect with friends.
author: Julie F.

description: I had my wedding brunch at Zazie's and it was fantastic. Jennifer and her staff are amazing. All my guests loved the food and ambience. We sat in the patio and were blessed with good weather. Must try- French toast and the BLT! I would give it another star for their good business practice of offering their employees benefits! Way to go. I am not patient to brave the weekend crowds, so if you are like me, take a day off and go during the week.
author: Lina M.

description:
We live in the neighborhood, so we make it to Zazie pretty often, both for brunch and for dinner. As everyone else has mentioned, it's pretty consistently great, and we always enjoy our time there.

For this review, though, I'm writing about our experience hosting an event at Zazie. We had about forty out-of-town wedding guests to Zazie for our rehearsal dinner, and it was one of the highlights of our wedding weekend.

We took over the back patio for the first half of the evening in late June. It's always risky planning something outside on a June evening in San Francisco, doubly so in Cole Valley. But the patio heaters and umbrellas are enough to make sure you won't have too many issues - and they have blankets out back if you need them in a pinch.

When you have a large party, they have a per-guest minimum, which is generally pretty reasonable. If you have a lot of kids coming, it might be a challenge - if they take up a seat, they get charged the same as an adult, similar to an airline. 

Our meal was awesome. They served family-style, which keeps things flexible and relaxed, which is just our style. The salad was refreshing. The meyer lemon ravioli was a hit. The steak was perfect. The steelhead trout (like salmon) had a fantastic texture. For dessert, our guests were fawning over the baked hot chocolate, and the strawberry rhubarb crumble was right up my alley. There was something for everyone - the foodies were thrilled, and there was something to please the pickiest of eaters as well.

The wine was good, but the lemonade they serve was one of the underdog winners of our night. We have to find out where to get it ourselves.

Best of all, Jen (the owner) and Jeff took great care of our group. Even as a few people arrived late and we had some logistical issues to deal with, they made sure it never felt like a big deal.

It was the perfect place to share a great meal while introducing our friends and family to our neighborhood. If you can get a space there for your event, take it - you'll be in great hands.
author: M. Jackson W.

description: The hot chocolate is amazing and the cups they serve it in is truly European! Great outdoor seating, perfect for a sunny day in SF! Portions are huge, food is fresh...the French toast and eggs benedict was amazing! Only hang up is the massive wait- def. make reservations if you can!
author: Shikha S.

description:
I might just be the cheapest bastard in the universe. 

My wife and I met one of my clients and his girlfriend for wine paring dinner featuring August Briggs Wines at Zazie. I used to live around the corner in a basement apartment that included leaky water pipes that hung from the ceiling. But that is another story for another review. 

A four course dinner with each course paired with the perfect wine for $69 per person sounded like a bargain and jumped all over a reservation. All you can drink wine is usually enough to get me calling, but when you toss in some amazing food that may be the best kept secret in San Francisco made this night truly exceptional. 

The owner/hostess was gracious and very accommodating and made sure the bottles of wine were flowing throughout the evening. She made sure that every need however small was met and did so with a smile. Her staff was professional and friendly and added to the great evening. We were seated in the back patio which I found to be very comfortable and kept warm by the strategically placed heat lamps.

The courses? 

1. Arugula salad, goat cheese, raspberries and shaved almonds. Lightly but perfectly tossed in a flavorful olive oil. 

2. Cheese and fig ravioli that may have been some the best ravioli I have ever tasted. 

3. Rabbit served over linguni and mushrooms. I opted for the vegetarian option, but according to my dinner companions they all agreed the rabbit was prepared perfectly and judging by the "oohs" and "awws" after each taste probably was pretty good. 

4. Duck,-Again I went with the vegetarian option, but my wife who usually will shy away from duck because of the "richness factor" was very impressed with the execution. 

5. Chocolate cheesecake, we ate every bite...enough said. 

A huge bonus at the end came when the restaurant announced there were a few bottles of wine leftover and would be available for sale at their cost. AWESOME! 

Zazie does not attempt to sell itself as a Gary Danko or French Laundry, but if you are looking for a fun neighborhood experience with a fun atmosphere, then look no further and do yourself a favor and check them out.
author: Rene C.

description:
This is a nice gem in Cole Valley - indoor seating make you feel like you are in a French bistrot, while outdoor patio is simply lovely. 
Food is great and I have to recommend the charcuterie to start off the right way (especially the pate'!). Wine list reserves great surprises at a very reasonable price.
Highly recommended.
author: Steve E.

description:
Great little place for brunch!  Despite the problems with parking and the inevitable crowd that will get there before you do, their food makes the wait worthwhile.

Got to come out here on a warm and sunny day, and we lucked out by getting a table out on their back patio/deck.  Starving when we got seated, we decided to split a French Toast Tahiti to satisfy our sweet tooth's and enjoy a bit of gluttony.  Sweet but not overly sweet, it was a nice contrast to our savory brunch.  Decided on their poached egg breakfast offerings, and their Eggs Monaco popped out to me.  It was fantastic.  They didn't skimp on the prosciutto, and the tomatoes weren't overly wet or soggy.  What a tasty way to start the day.

The service was on point, and our server was always right there to give us refills on our coffee.  The rest of the staff was also pretty friendly, but I would recommend keeping your party relatively small to minimize the wait.  Outside of that, I will definitely be making my way back here...
author: Mike L.

description:
My wife is from South San Francisco and we went to Zazie to celebrate her birthday at the recommendation of her brother. 

I ordered the Grilled Niman Pork Chop ($21)- w/ braised red cabbage au bacon, roasted bosc pears, and riesling reduction.  It was VERY good.  I don't know what they cooked the cabbage in but I could have eaten that by itself.  

The place is a little small and we had a bit of a wait for a table, but the food was definitely worth it.  The service was good too.  The waitress was very friendly.

About the only bad thing about the night was the bottle of apple cider we bought.  It had this weird mediciney after taste to it.  I definitely wouldn't get that again.
author: Darien G.

description:
Ok, there's usually a wait for a reason. Because the food is good! And if you have a party of 4 or more good luck! I've been here plenty of times during brunch hours to know what time to come- which is early like 8:00ish. And even then there's already customers waiting. If you're hungry and impatient then don't bother. 

I almost order the same thing which is usually the une, deux, trois. It's simple but my favorite. It comes with 1 pancake, 2 eggs and 3 sausages. What's so great about that? It has a little bit of everything from sweet to savory! I really love their pancakes- they're so fluffy and yummy! And don't even get me started on their pancake specials! I've tried both gingerbread and ricotta pancakes and let's just say that ricotta one is deelish! Also, they make their eggs benedict right! If you want something scrambled then the fountainbleu is the way to go. 

On a sunny day you can enjoy your food outside on their patio surrounded by flowers and heated lamps (if and when the weather all of sudden gets nippy).
author: Neva R.

description: Zazie's is my favorite brunch place in SF. I love their cute, French style restaurant - and the outside area is a bonus that makes you feel like you're not even in the city. Their variety of benedicts and scrambles always keeps me coming back for more. And you can't go wrong with a latte in a bowl. Love!
author: Ariana V.

description:
What a cute little place! We stumbled upon Zazie while looking up brunch spots that were open on Easter. After looking at the pictures of all the delicious food, we were sold! 

After putting my name on the waitlist, I was afraid that we would have to wait a long time, but luckily we only had a 15-20 minute wait. 

My boyfriend currently has an egg benaddiction, so after looking over the menu, that was the obvious order. They have a list of different poached egg combinations, but we both ended up ordering the same thing - the pierre noir poached eggs - poached eggs, on an english muffin, with bacon and tomato provencales. You have the option of ordering up to 3 eggs, and it comes with potatoes or a salad. 

It was delicious and really filling! The poached eggs were really delicate, the bacon was crispy (a must for me!), english muffin wasn't mushy and the tomatoes were fresh. The dressing was light and not overpowering; my boyfriend judges egg benedicts strictly on the hollandaise sauce and he said this was one of the best he's had so far here. My only complaint was that I felt that they jipped us on the potatoes - I had like 5 little chunks! 

Overall, this is another solid brunch spot and I can't wait to go back and try the pancakes and the challah french toast ;) yummm!!!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Our first time in this place and enjoyed everything we had. Mediterranean tea was delicious and soothing. Fruit cup was ok and nothing to get excited about. Both the Moca french toast and poach eggs we ordered were very good. Would defiantly come back.
author: Nima S.

description:
Had a great solo dining experience at Zazie. Arrived on a Tuesday mid morning, the place was pretty packed, but the upside of solo dining is that the wait is usually much shorter and in this instance, I got seated immediately :) 

I had the hot chocolate (Huge serving!) as well as the Miracle Pancakes (poppyseed buttlemilk pancakes topped with lemon curd and generous serving of fresh strawberries). Fluffiest tasty pancakes. Heavenly. Will definitely be back on my next visit!
author: Michelle Q.

description:
atmosphere [2 stars]
Crowded and loud since the place is so small.

service [3 stars]
There is always a wait. Always. But the servers are nice, and the owner is really friendly.

price [3 stars]

food [4.5 stars]
poached eggs albert-amazing and the salsa is a great topper
gingerbread pancakes-not as sweet as it sounds, but just as tasty as it sounds.
croque royale- meh. good if you like tomatoes, but i thought it was going to be even better than the croque madame cause of the name...not.

Definitely the best breakfast place in San Francisco. Park Chow doesn't even compare.
author: Jeanette L.

description:
A lovely place for sunday brunch.  I tried the ginger bread pancake but I'm not crazy about it.  If you love ginger bread, definitely give it a try because it's fluffy and thick.  I also tried the Tahitti French Toast, it was interesting but I think I'd love their regular french toast better.

Two thumbs up for the omelets and latte.

Worth the wait.
author: D C.

description:
I always have a nice time at Zazie. The atmosphere is cozy (which is only partially code for "small"), and the food is unpretentious and good. 

I remember when I first started going there (my boss took me there for a celebratory lunch in, geez, 1997) I thought the portions were small for the price, but I'd just moved here from Indiana so I think I thought anything not served in a trough was meager.  I'd don't know if they're serving larger meals, or if my expectations have normalized.  Why am I telling you this?  Because if you're taking a guest straight from the Midwest (as I was) there, they might react the same way.

As other reviewers have noted, the wait can be impressive, and there's no handy place to hang out besides the sidewalk.  I highly recommend making a reservation.
author: Eve B.

description:
Y'all. I have LOVED Zazie's in the past. Loved the crab benedict, loved the pancakes and in fact, I still love the food. 

However, much to my dismay, my pals and I won't be darkening their doorstep anymore. The last three meals we've eaten at Zazie's we've experienced a)poor service and b)horrific hygiene. The last two times, my friends and I have found hair in our food. The first time the waitress picked the hair off of my pancake and crumbled it in her fingers and said, "That's not a hair! That's just burned sugar!" 

Now. I may not be a genius, but I've seen burned sugar, and I've seen a fried hair. And I know the difference between the two. No offer to get me a fresh plate, no knock a couple of bucks of the bill, no nothing, just, "Oh, that's burned sugar!" 

Last weekend, friends and I went back to Zazie, because well, the food is really good. And as SOON as my friend's eggs were set down in front of him? A hair on his orange. This waitress was BETTER, (she took the offending orange and brought back a plate of fresh ones) but still. That's just gross. 

I live in the neighborhood, I've had good food there, but, burn me once shame on you, burn me twice, shame on me.  I won't be going back.
author: Emily M.

description: The best mussels mariniere hands down. We could not get enough of the wine and butter sauce. The lamb was tender and falling off the bone. Creme brulee was heavenly!! Definitely one of my favorite places to visit when coming home.
author: Nuraya G.

description:
I really wish I would of liked it more then I did. I was expected one of the best breakfast I would have but it wasn't like that at all. Not that the food wasn't good, it was, it's just that my expectations were a little bit high I guess after reading all those positive great reviews. I came in knowing I would probably order either french toast, pancakes, or croque madame. From all the pictures and reviews, those sounded the best.

After meeting up with my favs, Tracy A. and Steven T., we headed over here, had to wait just a couple minutes before a table cleared up. I really wanted to sit outside but it was a rainy day so I guess next time I come back to try the things I initially wanted to try. After getting seated, we looked through the menu. Plenty of options, their regular menu and specials that day. For some reason, when I got seated, I didn't really feel like ordering any of the food that I had wanted to and was craving... Instead, I went with one of their specials, Eggs Genevieve. I don't know if it's because I love the Ms. Yelper herself, Genevieve Y., but I ordered that. It was a omelette/scramble with white cheddar, ham, and sliced avocado with side of home fries and toast of choice. Also order a orange juice.

So, when the waitress arrives with our drinks, spills it on poor Steven T, without notice, and proceeds to place the drinks on the table. HHAHA sorry Steven for ordering OJ! It would of prob been better if it was water... So after a little bit, our food arrives. Looks amazingly good. Especially if my avocado slices weren't bruised! YAY for that! First thought, WOW these home fries are loaded with oil!!!!! First bite? WOW, there's a WHOLE handful plus of white cheddar. Overwhelming. I felt like I was eating a Squeeze omelette (Squeeze Inn's squeeze burger) Not that I don't like cheese, I love it, but it was a lot! Ham were all on one side, the side I wasn't eating yet. And by the time I got to it, I was full. Filled with cheese, and oily but yummy crispy potatoes, I didn't wanna continue eating..

All in all, food was OK. Next time, definitely gonna order 1 french toast, any flavor, 1 pancake, and a croque madame!!
author: Juliane N.

description:
I actually saw this place on Check Please, Bay Area and when deciding on brunch this weekend, my friend and I chose Zazie. We got there just before 10 so it wasn't crazy yet and we managed to get a table quickly. 
The mango mimosa was so perfect for a sunny Sunday breakfast. The place itself is adorable and I was in love with it at first glace. And then my breakfast came. I got the Monaco poached eggs which were absolutely divine! This was definitely one of the best breakfasts I've had in a while. Our server was really nice and helpful and didn't rush us one bit considering how much the wait had increased by the time we got our food.
I will definitely be making a point to spend time in the city so I can brunch at Zazie!
author: Lady P.

description: Love this every time we go! Since we are San Francisco natives we try to go during the week to avoid a long wait time, but no matter the wait time the food and service are amazing! The French Toast Tahiti is really good along with the Eggs Divorce.
author: Galina H.

description:
I'm not sure if I would put the eggs Benedict on my list of 100 things to try before I die, but they're definitely done well. Two friends and I ordered three different poached egg plates and traded so we got to try three different types. My favorite was the one I got, which was the Monaco. The flavor from the prosciutto went really well with the poached egg and the tomato. My second favorite was the Albert , which had bacon and white cheddar with a salsa. Lastly, the La Mer with the dungeness crab was more bland than I would have liked. My only complaint was the hollandaise sauce, which was tasteless and bland. 

The French Toast Tahiti stuffed with a walnut spread and topped with caramelized bananas was delicious. I think some type of walnut spread or syrup is required for good French toast. The three pieces of toast was a lot of sugar for one person so it's better to share that. I think the French toast at Brenda's with its honey walnut syrup still edges the toast here.

Was the food worth waiting over an hour to try? Probably not, but that's what we get for trying to cram 7 people into a small restaurant for Sunday brunch.
author: Bailey Z.

description: Had Eggs en Fonte this morning- with grilled polenta cake, 2 over easy eggs, mushrooms, and their tomato-chevre sauce - It's a goopy mess in a skillet, but I liked it. I wish the salad had a little less dressing. Delicious, dependable breakfasts, and they always have great, friendly service. =)
author: Hana K.

description:
Really enjoyed the atmosphere and setting. The back patio seating is pretty awesome and surprisingly warm given how cold the area can get. Ordered one $25 prix fixe selection as well as the steak entree and a side order of mac 'n cheese. 

Meal started off quite promisingly with delicious mussels and hot bread/butter to mop up the juices. Entrees were where things got spotty. Trout entree was quite good, well cooked with tender fish and crispy skin, but they brought out a chicken entree instead of steak. Apparently they gave my steak to the wrong table? Not really a big deal except it took probably 15-20 minutes to get my entree by which point the trout was consumed. I found the steak entree rather odd, mostly the sweet nutty sauce that it was presented with. Steak with mushrooms and gorgonzola works, but throwing in a sweet sauce didn't make sense to me. The mac 'n cheese was alright, I felt the pasta was a little too firm/thick for my tastes. Dessert seemed alright, they comped us the side dish for making us wait, which is cool, but I guess their kitchen is too small and busy to expedite a messed up order.

-1 star for messed up order taking too long
-1 star for not enjoying steak entree
author: Steven C.

description:
Great great food.  There is a wait but after visiting Tully, then Boulangerie and Cole Hardware to pass time and purchase coffee, pastries And hardware, in that order, the wait didn't seem bad.

You'd think with that many people waiting, inside would be crazy.  It wasn't.   tables were not crowded together and it wasn't obnoxiously loud.

One French toast Tahiti, poached eggs with prosciutto, and mushroom omelette later, I leave extremely happy and can't wait to do it all again
author: Will I A m.

description: I came here for lunch a few years ago and had a pleasant experience and good nicoise salad.  This Friday, a friend and I walked in (to what looked like a fairly empty restaurant) to see if there was a wait for a table.  We were received rudely by a waitress who told us we could wait for the host BY THE DOOR. Her tone was so impolite that we couldn't stick around to eat there.
author: Veronica C.

description: My party and I felt very rushed today and I didn't appreciate not having any wifi. I was unable to use the app to get a discount. To me that was false advertising and greed on the behalf of the owner. I am glad it was my first time. I won't be back. If you don't have wi fi then you shouldn't give people false hope that you can download an app and get a 10.00 discount.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Maybe I'm missing something, but I don't really get all of the hype surrounding this place. The brunch is just okay - nothing that you can't make at home without the 45 minute wait. Overall, the experience was an exercise in "meh".

I had La Mer benedict because I wanted to make the wait worth it. Unfortunately, the dish was cold and lacked seasoning. Too bad, because crab, eggs, and avocado should be easy enough to pull off. The coffee was remarkably bad. We also ordered the "Une, Deux, Trois", which is one buttermilk pancakes, two eggs, and bacon. Nothing to really write home about. 

We had high hopes because of the good reviews and because the eggs benedict are on the 7x7 list. I guess I can now say that I've tried the place, but won't be going back any time soon.
author: Elaine B.

description:
At times we have had to wait for a table, but it was worth it! This past time though, we did not have to wait. Yay! The service was very friendly, and the atmosphere is nice!

Yummy side of potatoes! Really enjoyed the challah french toast and gingerbread pancakes (as always)!

This is a must when visiting San Fran!
author: Lauren E.

description:
Great place for brunch, but expect to wait in line anywhere from 20minutes to 2 hours. Yes, that means it is quite popular.

The food and service both are quite remarkable. Considering how busy they are, the food gets there pretty quickly and the waiters don't seem too hassled or frustrated. The food itself is quite nice, great selection and many flavours. One tip, they don't serve REAL maple syrup unless you ask (and if you do, it's an extra $1.99, should be free in my opinion.)

Only 4/5 because I was not overly impressed by the food. I was expecting it to blow my mind, since I saw at least 50 people on the waitlist, but it didn't. Still a nice experience, and food was good enough. 

Do try the different types of mimosas they have, it's great to find a place that has OTHER juices than just orange.
author: Landon E.

description:
Tasty - Eggs with spinach and mushrooms over English muffin with garlic 'n' potato home fries.

Not so much - Their coffee is some odd Sumatra type derivative - a little sweet. I'm a fan of French Roast. Not my thing, maybe for you.
author: Mark S. I.

description:
Rainy day + breakfast with my favorite yelpers in the world = An Awesome day :]

I actually had a pretty crappy week but after spending time with Juliane N. and Steven T. at Zazie actually made me feel a little better. We got to Zazie around 12pm and the place was packed. The wait for our table wasn't long though so I'm not complaining. 

Since it was a cold day I wanted to order something hot to drink. I ordered their chocolate chaud (hot chocolate) with non fat milk. Their chocolate chaud comes in a soup bowl which made me feel awkward when drinking it. It's like drinking chocolate soup haha. Unfortunately I didn't finish the drink since it didn't taste that good. Sorry! =X

I ordered their Greece Scrambled Eggs(spinach, feta, and red onions). It came with sides of wheat bread and home styled fries. It was actually really really good. I'm usually not a big fan of feta cheese but if things with feta tastes like this then sign me up! 

Thanks to my to favorite yelpers for making me feel better.
author: Tracy A.

description: Everything about Zazie is amazing. Start with the coffee cake. Coffee is delicious. Pancake flight - absolutely wonderful. Their back patio has been closed for renovations for a while now, otherwise would be 5 stars. My first experience there was on the back patio, and the ambiance is just perfect. Very important to get there early.
author: Michael H.

description:
How do I love thee, Zazie? Let me count the ways.

1. Mario is the best. He has been there every Saturday/Sunday as far as I can tell for the past three years I've lived in this neighborhood. He's exactly the kind of host you need for a busy spot like this. 
2. The food is consistently good. My husband and I get the same thing every time. He get 's the Un, Deux, Trois and I get one piece of Pinkie's Challah french toast with fruit. Do you know why we get the same thing over and over again? Because it's that good! Every time. 
3. There are no bells and whistles with their food. It's simple and DELICIOUS. Their potatoes have FULL cloves of roasted garlic. The fruit is always fresh and what's in season. The eggs are free range and delish. The french toast has an awesome orange/cinnamon batter. 

Oh- and outdoor seating :)
author: Melissa N.

description:
I've eaten here three times for brunch, and twice for dinner, mostly because the place has a great reputation and friends want to meet there.
