First time, I got a poached egg (forget which kind, something w/ prosciutto I think) and it was really good. Came with some potatoes and even though the portions aren't to what i wanted, they are just right. You don't get too full and you're not left thinking 'where's part 2?' My second time coming back I got some scramble that had chorizo. It was very tasty and came with some toast. Thought the toast was a tad bit burnt but not enough to ruin the toast.

There is outside and indoor seating but the place isn't that big so be prepared to wait. Parking can be bad but never have to walk too far and the area is nice to walking around there isn't sketchy or anything like that..
author: edward k.

description:
More PLEASE!

Only negative is that it takes forever to get in... 

Everything else was very well priced, very well prepared, and REALLY delicious...  

(I really wanted to give this place 1 star and tell everyone that it was closed and to avoid it at all costs...  but I figured I should be honest)
author: Will W.

description:
Lets just say I don't need anything other than a Zazie breakfast to have a fantastic day. This love is serious! Their dinners are lovely too.
*I don't care that it is small. *I don't care that sometimes I have to wait.

I love their signature organic decaf tea, I always keep some in stock at home. It's a perfect blend of lemon verbena & thyme, rosehips, lavander, licorice root, tarragon and apricots.
author: Janet D.

description:
Okay, I thought this place would be overrated given its popularity, but it's pretty damned good.

I went here on an incredibly gorgeous Saturday afternoon with two other people.  We signed our names on the list outside, indicated our party size and seating preference (this is the first of many operational efficiencies at Zazie, that place churns customers like butter).

We were seated outside after only five minutes.  I didn't know the back deck was so substantial.  We passed through the tiny kitchen -- how do you make so much damned food in such a small space?

The hostess squeezed us into a table outdoors.  We were well shaded by an umbrella and trees.  Soft music played through speakers -- a great outdoor setting.

The menus arrived quickly and the food and drinks soon after.  Two of us ordered the smoked salmon sandwiches, and the other the tuna sandwich.  The salmon was moist and smokey, the bread crispy and the greens fresh.  The tuna sandwich was amazing;  a giant seared piece of tuna served with some sort of seasoned pepper.  The tuna was definitely better than the salmon sandwich, but I'm not complaining.

The mimosas were the only area of criticism.  We ordered mango mimosas, but couldn't taste the fruit against the strong flavor of the champagne.  Oh well.  Small mark against a solid dining experience.

I hate lines, and arriving at 2pm certainly helped mitigate my displeasure. For a meal this tasty, though, I'd be willing to wait a while.
author: Bill H.

description:
I've gone here multiple time since my last review - no corkage fee on Tuesday = still excellent.  I really appreciate how they don't rush you - sometimes when you're sitting in the back patio, with a bottle of wine and a good friend, you tend to lose track of time.  We were never given the *ahem* dirty look even though we were there quite a bit past closing.

On the menu now is corn cakes - perfect summer dish & it's in the same sauce (well, similar) as the polenta cakes (which I still dream about).  Their prix fixe is now 23.50 but you can't go run with mussels (in crack sauce) + entree & pot de creme (though their new cherries desert is also fantastic).

Thanks to our server Genvieve who was super friendly & awesome.
author: Helen F.

description:
My bf took me here on a Sunday evening after watching Check Please where the hosts were dining at the restaurant.  

We drove up from San Jose, walked in & were able to get a seat on the patio. Keep in mind it's 6 or 7ish in the dead of winter, but the heat lamps were great at keeping the small, intimate space warm & cozy.  Unfortunately, the only thing I remember ordering were the clams but I definitely recall them being GOOOD. haha

Our server was lovely, he made some good recommendations, was very attentive & was a total looker. Owee!  Zazie is definitely a small space, even for someone as petite as myself.

Minus one star because parking is an absolute nightmare (it's tucked away in a residential area of Cole Valley & as you can imagine...the residents don't come & go often), the seats in the patio are pretty uncomfortable (corner seat is bench style with not much cushion) & sitting in close proximity to others' while eating makes me nervous; I don't like hearing others converse & vice versa.

Other than that, I can't wait to eat brunch here! I just can't justify waking up early & driving to the city for eggs benedict.  Maybe, one day.

**Be sure to arrive 20 minutes early, if you have a reservation to allow enough time to find a spot & walk to the restaurant.
author: Tush Z.

description:
Dear Zazie,

I sought you out for my 28th birthday because you serve cassoulet, one of my favorite dishes, and not always an easy one to find outside France.  

On a very chilly night last night we arrived to be seated immediately in a warm, cozy environment at an intimate table.  You brought us wonderful little dinner rolls, a delicious cheese plate (I liked the triple creme cow's milk best) and of course my cassoulet.  A very generous kir royal helped the festive feeling.  We skipped dessert, as we had a cake at home, but I look forward to trying your chevre cheesecake and/or chocolat chaud next time!  I will definitely be back!

Oh, and it doesn't hurt that Zazie dans le metro is one of my favorite films...

Bisou,
Erin
author: Erin M.

description:
After putting our name on the long list (I'm talking at least 20 people ahead of us), we jetted over to La Boulange for a pre breakfast veggie quiche and some lattes to go.  We get back to Zazie around 20 minutes later and are still pretty far down on the list.  Boo. The two tables outside are first come, first serve, which I did not know, so thank you to the two ladies sitting there who filled us in!  We snatched up their seats as soon as they left.

Apparently, Zazie is pretty famous for eggs benny, which is on the 7x7 Big Eat List so one of had to give them a try.   After some debating, he finally decided on the Pierre Noir version, which came topped with bacon and tomatoes provencales.  He must've really enjoyed it (as did I, as neither of us offered to share!).  I was feeling more like lunch at the time, so I decided on the Croque Madame, which was amazing!  A bit on the sweeter side, which was interesting, the sandwich was typical with the grilled ham, heavenly gruyere cheese, and deliciously creamy bechemel sauce topped with a sunny side up egg.  Super gluttonous but well worth the calories.  The sandwich came with a side of greens. 

Sadly, Zazie was my last brunch as a San Franciscan, but it was definitely one of my favorites! I will have to return for dinner and a spot on the back patio when I return.  Thanks for sending me off to NYC in foodie-style!
author: Jenny W.

description: Our go-to brunch spot. Yummy fluffy pancakes and stuffed omelettes. The staff has always been super-friendly with my kids. One busy morning, we had a bit of a wait for our food, and the chef noticed my daughter getting antsy. He sent over a small snack. I was extremely grateful. There is always a line, so get there early!
author: Jenny N.

description:
Zazie! The name of the restaurant sounds like a visceral Viking battle cry! This place is an urban gem nestled in the heart of Cole Valley. Don't mind the large crowd of people outside of Zazie, this place is definitely worth the wait.

This is the perfect place for Sunday brunch. My friends and I sat in the back patio. There are beautiful leaves and plants that surround the patio as well as heat lamps to keep you nice and warm.

For savory food, I had the La Mer poached eggs. The eggs were perfectly poached and were topped with crab meat and slices of avocado. This was definitely a very "summer-y" and fresh tasting meal. The eggs were served with a side of home fries. The best part of the home fries were the delicious roasted whole garlic that came with the potatoes

For sweet food, I had the gingerbread pancake which was topped with a cooked pear and lemon curd. Good thing I only had one pancake because these were thick and almost cake like. I'm usually not a big fan of ginger, but the ginger taste was not too over powering and complimented the pear and the lemon curd very well.

Overall, Zazie is a great place for brunch especially after a long battle with neighboring warlords. ZAZIE!!
author: Allan Y.

description:
My 100th yelp review! I'm glad it ended up being Zazie, definitely worthy of my 100th. 

Got there at 10:30 am on a Sunday, and our group of 3 waited 50 minutes for a table. I was expecting this though, so it wasn't that annoying. 

The gingerbread pancakes were DELICIOUS. I loved flavors of pear, lemon, and apple all mixed into one delicious bite. Definitely get these, but beware, they're huge. 

Poached eggs-- I tried La Mer, Albert, and Florentine. La Mer was my favorite (Albert had too many tomatoes, my least favorite, and Florentine's sauce was too sweet for me).

The atmosphere is so great inside that you don't even notice the billions of people waiting outside. Was it worth the wait on a weekend? Probably not. Would I go back on a weekday? Definitely.
author: Janelle V.

description: Waited 30-45 minutes on Sunday morning around 10:30. Once we got in, the food was good. The Bloody Mary was delicious and we were hungry!! I really enjoyed the potatoes which come with TONS of roasted garlic cloves. It was fun and good people watching. Wait is worth it.
author: PK R.

description: This place was amazing. Poached eggs are where it's at and if you want something sweet it's gotta be the French Toast. Make sure you get here early, it is small and gets busy.
author: Charles R.

description: I am in love with this place for brunch and I've only gone once, so far! I had a bite of the famous gingerbread pancakes, which did not disappoint. It was like christmas in my mouth. The ginger spice was very prominent, but in a good way. They also sell the pancake mix! I ordered for myself the French Toast Tahiti (because I can't pass up anything that has the word Tahiti in it) and I was very pleased with my dish except I found that the walnut stuffing had a slightly bitter taste, which the maple syrup concealed easily. This place also knows how to cook their bacon too, perfectly scrumptious. On a Saturday morning at 9:30am, party of 6, we waited 1 hour. When we arrived, there were 13 parties ahead of us. There's a notepad at the front for you to sign in your name. Bathroom is teeny tiny without too much privacy from the kitchen.
author: Kannika L.

description:
**Review for breakfast/brunch**

**NOTE: The waiting list is hung outside of the cafe, on your left if you're facing the door.  Make sure you write your name and # of people in your party.

Things I have tried:
GINGERBREAD PANCAKES
FLORENTINE POACHED EGGS
BLT SANDWICH
FONTAINBLEAU SCRAMBLE

Everything was delicious! I've been here a handful of times and taken people who are visiting the area for Zazie.  The GINGERBREAD pancakes are so popular they sell the pancake mix.  I am definitely a returned guested.

Time your visit right, there has always been a wait for me.
author: Sunny W.

description:
Great restaurant! Only complaint - very small, no free coffee.

My wife and I visited Zazie on a Monday morning and there was a five minute wait. This is a testament to the quality of both the quality of their food, and how quickly the customer rotation is, without feeling the least bit rushed.

Food was great, service was quite timely, and price wasn't outrageous. Mimosas, and all other variations of champagne mixes we tried, were delicious. 

HIghly recommended!
author: Carson C.

description: Loved this place- quite a long line on Sunday morning but outside seating is first come first served so we ended up taking one of those tables in about 20 min. Food was amazing, my girlfriend and I split the eggs florentine and the Tahiti French toast and both were perfect. She loved the addition of roasted garlic to the homefries which was definitely unique. Would definitely come back!
author: Sharat S.

description:
Wow! My first eggs benedict experience was a very amazing one. It is, after all, on The List for SF. I thought it only appropriate to give this famous dish a whirl at Zazie. We did it up right-sat on the patio, enjoyed the beautiful day, had delightful conversation between and around us. I sipped on a peachy mimosa and my great company had a few cups of coffee, while awaiting the arrival of said dish. It really was a lovely brunch experience.

I agree with what most have said about Z. It is one of the best spots for brunch in the city, but for a price. It was on the higher end of the wallet spectrum to say the least. However, well worth it for the infamous dish on the list.
author: Nichole P.

description:
Ever since my trip to Paris a year and a half ago I've been a little in love with French cuisine.  All the butter, cheeses, sauces, fancy names like boudin noir--what's not to lust after? I decided to bring my parents to Zazie, a neighborhood eatery that's café and casual, not suit and silverware. I was almost certain it'd be good if not great because it was crowded on a Monday and had rave reviews.

Boy was I wrong and hell was I disappointed. We had Le Canard ($19; as recommended by our Josh Duhamel-look-alike waiter), the Grilled Hanger Steak ($21), and the Grilled Summer Corn Cakes ($14). The duck and corn cakes were really lame. The duck was incredibly bland and tasted more like chicken than anything. The skin, advertised as crispy and generally the best part of duck, was not crispy at all and just unremarkable. The corn cakes were bad--I expected them to be crunchy and sweet like corn fritters, but these were really soft and not really sweet. The sauce was simply unappetizing.

The steak was the saving grace of the meal--medium rare, juicy, flavorful, pre-sliced. It came with yummy mushrooms and mashed potatoes. So one star for the steak and another star for Josh Duhamel. Neither could bring me back here again, though.
author: Liz T.

description: La mer is really yummy! Very cute ambiance if you can get seating outside - the perfect way to start your Sunday!
author: S T.

description:
This place was really delicious, but a really long wait, i'd say about 40 + min on a Sunday. 

After fighting for parking in the area, we finally made our way over to the place to find there was a long, long waiting list. We wrote our names down and scooted down the block to walk around the neighborhood to kill sometime.

The place isnt really big, but they have addtional patio seating in the back..

Since I don't drink but everyone around me was getting the bloody mary- I decided to get a virgin one- this was very tasty and had the perfect amount of kick to it. 

There are many tasty treats on the menu, but I decided to try the crab eggs benedict-with hollandaise sauce served over two english muffins. It came with a good portion of fresh crab, nice and hot, on top of a overeasy egg. The gooeyness of the egg dripped onto the english muffins and sauce which made it over the top rich, but still all the flavors were really good and well worth the calories =). the highlight was the side of the potatoes- I dont know what they put on them but they were really good too!

The husband decided to try something sweet since I had savory and his choice was the french toast tahiti after being torn over the gingerbread pancakes and asking the waitress her preference, so we rolled with the french toast.

It was an excellent choice! The two of us are not huge sweets fans but man this was sinfully rich, sweet, ,moist, with the carmelized bananas oozing out between the two large syrup drenched slices of toast. A true winner in my book and complimented the salty rich flavors of my crabs benedict. 

Food came fast and service is friendly, tables are really close to each other so don't expect any privacy with your neighbors,  restrooms are crazy small and only (1) unisex...ewww..

overall a cute date place to go to for brunch, albiet the crazy line.......wouldnt recommend for large groups.
author: Petri Y.

description:
3/5 stars on the Wing Scale...  

- Quality of product: 1.5 of 3 stars
- Quality of service: 1 of 1 star
- General feelings of happiness: .5 of 1 star

We started with the mussels in white wine sauce, which was tasty and plentiful for an appetizer. I was disappointed with my duck leg with white beans. It was a casserole-type dish covered with crunchy bread crumb on top. The textures and flavors of the ingredients just didn't gel together very well. Hubby had the lamb tagine. I stole a couple bites... the lamb was tender and flavorful. I didn't particularly care for the couscous-to-sauce ratio (too much sauce), but I know that's just my preference. 

The staff is fun and attentive. Our waiter recommended a red wine and it worked well with our various dishes. The option to sit in the garden patio is a plus during these SF Indian summer nights. 

Overall, I just didn't feel like we got the bang for our buck. To be fair, we dined on the day Zazie had just switched to their Fall menu. I would come back  to try other dinner items-- the prix fixe menu sounds more than reasonable and the beet salad looked amazing at the next table.
author: Wing Y.

description:
I just moved to the neighborhood in which this restaurant resides and I have to say I am really happy I can just walk around the corner and this place is there.  Some things you need to know....  This place is ALWAYS busy so make sure to make a reservation before you arrive so you don't have to worry about waiting (besides there really is no where to stand and wait in such a small place).  

Now on to the food....  YUMMO!  Everything is amazing.  I know that doesn't really help you out if you are checking out this review and wondering whether or not you should take your first date here or not.  Well, take her.  This place is so good you will be on the top of her list by the end of dinner.  The French Onion soup is oober yummy and a really generous size.  If you are a Pate fan then you will be amazed at how this melts in your mouth.  I have ordered different fish main courses and they have all been light and satisfying.  The duck falls off the bone, the mac and cheese is heavenly, and the wines are really fantastic.  The wait staff is helpful and friendly even though you know they are working their butts off.  Amidst all of the crazy busy staff however you always feel they are willing to take the time to explain anything to you.  

Seriously....  If you don't live over on this side of the city it is still worth making a trip out here to check it out.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Zazie etait adorable!

We arrived at 9:30am, and there was already a 20-minute wait. If you happen to get up early on a weekend, I would get there at 9am sharp.

We ordered the white peach mimosa and the black currant mimosa. The black currant was sooo good. So much flavor, perfect amount of champagne to appeal to the giggle-ness factor in each of us!

Since this was our first brunch back in the U.S. after 2 months, we decided to go all out! We ordered the orance cinnamon french toast (2 pieces @ $9), the Croque Royale (grilled levain, prosciutto, tomatoes, gruyere for $13), and the Monaco (3 poached eggs for $15). The Monaco was by far our favorite. The eggs were light and fluffy, and the combination of the tomatoes, prosciutto and eggs was sublime.

Highly Recommend. Will definitely be returning :)
author: Helen D.

description:
Checked out Zazie this week because my bf loves brunch. Good reason I think. I am allergic to eggs so much of Zazie's brunch menu was off limits to me. 

I ordered the bagel with lox. It was good but a little small. Also usually bagels and lox is served with a bit of fruit on the side but not one cherry, peach slice or banana bit came with my bagel and lox. Sad. Also bagels and lox usually means tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, capers and lox. Zazie's chefs seem to have forgotten the first two toppings.

My bf got the pancakes with lemon curd and raspberry sauce. He said it was good but quite rich. I did notice however that he still finished the plate. Hmm....couldn't have been too rich I guess. 

We both ordered coffee and were disappointed by the poor quality. It was weak and undistinguishable in flavor. The waitress also took 10 minutes to bring me some non-fat milk for my coffee. C'mon...and it was a Monday at around 10am, not exactly the lunch rush.

So in conclusion, don't see what all the fuss is about this restaurant but if I am ever stuck in Cole Valley and need a place to have brunch, i guess I could give it another try.
author: Erin W.

description:
I am a fan of SF brunch spots. Zazie is easily one of the cutest brunch spots! 

Parking at noon on a Saturday was a pain and the wait for a table for two was 40 minutes but I'm glad I didn't give up!! 

French toast tahiti - very flavorful! The french toast was so soft and moist. The caramelized banana was good with the french toast. I'd definitely order this again!

La mer - eggs benedict with crab and avocado. Soooooo gewd!! I'd come back just for this.
author: Liz L.

description:
Food is ok, nothing special pancakes too dry
Service too rushy , not good vibe
good bloody mary
author: I B.

description:
Zazie is our quintessential neighborhood restaurant. When we first moved to Cole Valley five years ago, we were here once a week for dinner- didn't even try the brunch until several months later. Since then we've been hardcore regulars and the food has only gotten better.

Dinner: I love so much of the menu it is hard to pick, but my all time faves are the beef shank, the hangar steak, any preparation of duck they serve (the confit has awesome potatoes with a tangy mustard sauce). There was a pork chop on the menu at one point with bread pudding (if I remember correctly) that was what I imagine crack must be like. The Mediterranean vegetable plate is a perfect starter, along with any soup that they make. Beet salad is good too. 

Desserts range from great to earth-shattering- my favorites are the fresh fruit crumble and the godlike Baked Chocolate Chaud (baked hot chocolate). I swear this stuff is not of this world- it morphs between a cakey-brownie-like texture which quickly gives way to thick melted chocolate, with an almost pudding-like consistency. Plus it's topped with melted marshmallows. I swear it will knock your socks clean off.

Brunch is great too, but get there early, and get to know the man behind it all- Mario. The experience and often long waits become much more bearable. Of brunch fare my favorites are hands-down the Tahiti French Toast and any eggs benedict on the menu. The Gingerbread pancakes are awesome too, and if you like mimosas, get the one with the elderflower syrup.

Some of the servers have become good friends of ours in our long patronage here, and Jen is one of my favorite business owners in the neighborhood. She runs a great establishment, one where we will most definitely eat until we fall off of our chairs. Highly, highly recommended. For dinner, get reservations ahead. You will need them!
author: Nowell V.

description:
Dude, breakfast till 3pm!  How badass is that, huh?  You can wake up at noon, nurse your hangover until 1, and then stumble over to Zazie.  Sweet, right?  Yeahhh maybe.

Zazie was a post-mini-DYK brunch spot for a group of six.  We arrived at around 1:45, spent 15 minutes looking for parking, and put our name down at 2pm.  The place was packed.  We were told that there was a 1 hour wait for a table.  Okay, fine.  We came all this way from the Marina, so we might as well wait it out.  The girls ended up heading down the street to do some shopping while the rest of us waited outside.

The food itself is not bad, but the portions seem kind of small for what you're paying.  The mimosas appear to be mostly champagne with a hint of orange juice -- the only way to make a mimosa! :)  The coffee cake is not bad, but also nothing special.  It seems like the same stuff I've had at a dozen other coffee shops.  My main course was a grilled tuna steak sandwich.  The tuna was grilled just right for sandwich-based consumption.  Pretty good and definitely the star of the party.

Four stars for the food (mostly for the tuna sandwich, really), minus a star for the wait, price, and portions.
author: Andrew C.

description: Best pancakes ever, super fluffy yet super light. No post pancake regrets! Loved the atmosphere as well!
author: Matt Y.

description:
My sister and I went to Zazie for brunch on a Saturday. Our waitress was friendly and warm but unfortunately delivered some bad news: they just ran out of french toast. Nooooo!!! 

My sister ended up ordering the gingerbread pancakes with poached pears, and asked for the lemon curd on the side. The pancakes were big and pretty tasty. I got the poached eggs with tomatoes and wheat toast. I love poached eggs and these ones were cooked perfectly! The combination of runny yolk on toasted bread is pure deliciousness. I finished up the last of my toast with some of the raspberry jam they have on each table. Yummy! I took a star off because they didn't have any french toast which was what we came here for, but I'd like to come back and try it.
author: Wanda K.

description: San Francisco brunch is a zoo. Zazie made it such a nice experience. Delicious food, nice service, haven't gotten to arrogant to stop appreciating their customers. Awesome experience
author: Monica K.

description: OMG- 2 things- Challah french toast and gingerbread pancakes!!!!! End story!!
author: Michelle I.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars, but I am going to round to 4. 

When I first moved here in 2008, I asked for recommendations for brunch. Zazie was the restaurant that continued to be mentioned time and time again. Like most things that get rave reviews, you come in with high expectations, and I was waiting for a blow my mind brunch. In reality, it was solid, good but not great. 

I like Zazie since it is near my place, and you can usually find parking. The mimosas are wonderful, and I have never had a lack luster meal. However, for the price of this place it just isn't worth it. 

Don't get me wrong, I probably go here once every other month, and it's a great place for out-of-towners, but every time I get the check, I scratch my head wondering why I always return. The wait staff is nice and friendly, the ambiance is cute, but small (this is to be expected though), and the food is consistently good, just not great. 

My favorite brunch spot is foreign cinema, and I would say that Zazie would probably rank 3rd or 4th on my favorite SF brunch place.
author: Tiffany L.

description: There is obviously a reason why this place has so many great reviews, because the food is bomb. The food is most definitely 5 stars but we have had slow service a few times which was kind of a bummer. They just kind of forgot about us because they were so busy. I recommend getting there right when they open before the rush hits.
author: Matt F.

description:
Came here last night with my bf for our anniversary dinner.  We had reservations at 6pm and our table was nicely set up, ready for us.

We shared a cup of french onion soup, my bf had their steak, and I had their truffle ravioli with prawns.  Everything came without having to wait a long time.  We loved everything, I really enjoyed my dish...the sauce, mushrooms, spinach, and truffle ravioli..everything about it was delicious.

We also shared an order of their D&D mac n cheese.  Thank God we did because that thing was dense! It was good, definitely made from scratch! It ain't your velveeta mac from the box! 

I loved the ambiance of the restaurant too.  It's a small quaint restaurant, you sit pretty close to everyone..yet you don't hear everyone's conversations.  

My bf and I are both curious to see what their breakfast is like-- since they're usually known for their brunch menu. Perhaps that's an incentive for us to return.
author: Connie C.

description:
I very much wanted to love this place, just like 1200+ other Yelpers before me.  

The wait wasn't intolerable - I've waited for longer for a table at a brunch restaurant many many times before (read: Los Gatos cafe).  Besides, it gave me an excuse to develop a semi-tan from standing in the sun at the front of the place and the short stretch of Cole, dotted with cute little shops, restaurants, bars and cafes, was definitely interesting.  After 15 minutes, our table at the back patio was ready.

The service was flawless - the first table that we were seated at, in the back patio, was unfortunately the only one available, the sun was right above us and wasn't going anywhere for another couple of hours at least, and I thought I got 'just' enough tan for the day so I wasn't expecting to be under the sun throughout the duration of our meal.  As soon as we voiced our concern to our server, the host was notified and they were doing their best to accommodate us: inside table? another table on the patio? lucky for us another party of 2 just left so another table just became available.  It was cleaned out in a few seconds and we got seated rightaway.  Our server was sweet yet efficient - within minutes of taking our orders, the food arrived.

Now the food was something else.  I was perhaps expecting something more sensational from a dish that is worthy of the 7X7 Big Eat SF 2010 entry: eggs benedict with hollandaise, toasted english muffin, avocado and dungeness crab with a side of garlic potatoes.  It was unfortunately ordinary and one of the eggs' yolk was hard and overcooked.  

That said, the whole experience was enjoyable and I definitely would love to give it another try.

At least I knocked off #77 - Eggs Benedict at the back patio of Zazie and, at 25%, I still have a LONG way to go!
author: Ange L.

description: I have always loved Zazie for its great food, moderate prices, nice atmosphere and excellent service. Yesterday was my first time back since they changed their policy to include tips in the price.  A great idea - or so I thought. Unfortunately the service was anything but great. It took a long time until we could order, my coke came without ice, their signature Le Metro cocktail ($10), though pretty, had no detectable alcohol in it and wasn't really cold, the lemon ravioli were half cold and had we had to send them back to the kitchen.  We were sitting outside and during the entire meal the waiter didn't check on us even once. Though the lemon ravioli were delicious after they came back hot, the portion was tiny and at $27 seriously overpriced for pasta without anything special in it. The included tip, certainly calculated at a minimum of 20% on top of health care and a 401K, is ok with me if the service warrants it - but unfortunately this was not the case at all. It wasn't even close to a 15% tip.  Great and rich cappuccino, but overall quite disappointing.
author: Sig S.

description: We went early on a Monday morning and didn't have to wait at all. Breakfast was great and the eggnog pancakes were delicious! The service was great and we loved the small cozy feel!
author: Chelsea G.

description: On a work trip to the area, I managed to accidentally skip dinner twice in a row. So, I treated myself to a lavish breakfast here. I had the mushroom omelette (it has a fancy name that I do not remember) and it was wonderful. The service was nice and the atmosphere was really enchanting. I felt very European, dining there. Seems like a great spot to encourage intimate conversation -- not that there's much privacy: in true European (and San Franciscan) style, there's not much room between the tables. But, the ambiance is perfect for leaning in over a cup of coffee and delicately delicious treats.
author: Alexa A.

description:
That is a wonderful spot! While I have heard amazing things about their brunch, I have yet to make it in. I've tried several times but there has always been a long wait. That said, I finally did make it inside for dinner last week. The services was polite and attentive, we were seated right away for our reservation and the atmosphere was great. 

A few other great things: 1. You can bring your own wine in and they will open it for you for descent corking fee, 2. Their french onion soup is delish 3. So is their skirt steak and potatoes. Our dinner was enjoyable and I will def go back... hopefully some day I will get inside (or outside) for brunch!
author: Shanna T.

description:
Cute little French place with a decent brunch.. the wait is about 45 min for Saturday brunch, and they don't take reservations for the brunch.  When we were seated though, the service was pretty quick and friendly.   I got a French sparkling lemonade to drink and it was like an Orangina-version of lemonade, mmm.  To eat, I got one buttermilk pancake and a side of eggs.  The buttermilk pancake takes up the whole plate and is pretty thick, so I didn't really need more than one!   The pancake was ok, but my scrambled eggs were a bit runny for me.

It is slightly price-y for breakfast food (and they have a $1/person SF Healthcare Ordinance charge) but I guess that's the price you pay for going to SF for this type of stuff?  There are a good amount of brunch places in the city I wanted to try so I don't think I'll be back, but overall solid experience.

3.5 stars.
author: Alice M.

description:
Gave this place another try. Only 3 minute wait on a Friday at 11:30am! Score! I ordered the La Mer Benedict with crab and avocado and my sister order the french toast with bananas and walnuts. Both were fabulous. The eggs were perfectly runny this time just the way I like it. They also did not skimp on the crab as most places do and there was a generous amount of evenly proportioned avocado and crab on each muffin. The french toast was also yummy with walnut and banana filling and topped with bananas. 

Service was great. Our waiter was quick and attentive. Next time i will make sure I get a seat on the patio!

We got out of there a little bit before 12:30pm and there was definitely a line forming, so I suggest arriving before noon to minimize your wait time.
author: Mei C.

description: Great breakfast with really fresh arugula.  I mean really really fresh.  The waits are kind of long though.
author: Dan Q.

description:
DEVINE.

Upon looking up "san francisco" and "brunch" my friend discovered Zazie looked quaint and the food looked tasty. She suggested we go there for Sunday Brunch. I then took a look around this here yelp page. I saw some very nice photos of scrumptious looking breakfast treats and was sold. 

Jump forward a few days. My friend tells me that Zazie was just reviewed on "Check Please! Bay Area" so it's gonna be a wittle kookoonuts. She says we can go somewhere else, but I know we both still want to give it a try, so we decide to play it by ear. or eyes as the case may be.

Jump forward to Sunday morning, with a now third hungry lady in tow. We make the trip down to Cole Valley, and as expected, it is indeed kookoonuts. The funny thing about writing your name on the bottom of a long wait list is that weak willed people will flee the scene if forced to wait for longer than 20 minutes. When you think about it, you wait 20 minutes. you decide to then search for other dining options which could take another 20 minutes. you then put your name on that wait list, because, let's face it, it's Sunday Brunch. You're gonna wait, gurrrl. There was a short lull in names being called, but then all of a sudden the flood gates opened, and at least 10 parties had gone MIA. Putting me and my gals at lovely table inside after what I guess was a reasonable Sunday Brunch wait time at an small but insanely popular San Francisco bistro of about 30 minutes.

The atmosphere is absoultely adorable, quirky and, well, french.
The service was fast and friendly, and the food was outstanding. I got the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and bosch pears. my friends got the croque monsieur and omlett of the day. We were all in agreement that we were a) glad we waited and b) that it was worth the wait. we also agreed that ordering the "make your own mimosa" for us to share would be a GREAT idea. 

You made my day, Zazie. I hope we can see each other again soon.

xo
author: Caddy M.

description: I highly recommend Zazie to anyone searching for a great brunch place. There's a bit of a wait to get in, but that's obviously because of how wonderful the food is. I got the Pierre noir, which was amazing and my boyfriend got the Monica which he loved as well! The poached eggs were the best I've had in this city, and I've tried them at a bunch of different places! Check it out!
author: Little G.

description:
I had a very wonderful experience here. My friend and I walked in and immediately got a table out on the back patio which is super cute! Our waiter was very nice and efficient for how busy it was. He even got me change for my meter =) We got their homemade iced champagne/lavender/lemon drinks, I know it sounds weird but they were pleasantly refreshing! Then the waiter helped me decide on the "Monaco" which was basically a tomato and prosciutto benedict. It was awesome! What I really liked what the fact that you can get 1, 2 or 3 eggs. 

I really enjoyed my time there, but it was a tad pricey.
author: Heather B.

description:
I may be a bit biased because I LOVEEEEEEE brunch! Came here with a few of my girlfriends and we squished into the table right at the front window. This place is small but I think it adds to the charm.

I had the french toast, shared eggs benedict with JM, and we all had mimosas. Yes, I'm a brunch beast haha but I DID finish it all and it was SO GOOD! Sure, I had a slight buzz going on but I'm pretty sure it was just that good and I'll definitely be coming back here.

Edit 03.26.08: The owner messaged me to say thanks for the support. Awesome that she actually reads the reviews and tries to improve based on them -- although this place is already oozing with awesomeness, haha. Power to the Yelpers!
author: Miss H.

description:
this place was bombdiggsssss!! i came here with a couple of my friends, and got seated pretty quickly which was sweet! our server was wonderfulll too! i didn't catch her name, but she got work DONE. 
while i was waiting outside i asked my friend if this place looks tasty, and right then a grandma sitting in the window table was about to take a bite into her food when it went from her lips to her lap... i told my friend to disregard that. she must have thought it was so tasty that she drooled while the food was in transit, so it made a trip downtown. anyway...
the atmosphere is quaint and cute. yellow sunny tones. would DEFINITELY come back here again. 
the food was SCRUMPTIOUS! 
make sure you check our the daily specials.
author: Erica S.

description:
Zazie is great! I tried to get a table on Sunday but sunday brunch lines are LONG* so watch out. Plan accordingly. But I was able to go to lunch here a couple days later. 

The food is awesome. My favorite part of the meal by far was the garlic fries. It's essentially sliced red potatoes with whole garlic pieces cooked together. They were still wrapped in its skin, but when you open it you get a soft garlic that you can spread on the potatoes or even in your burger. I LOVE garlic so a major plus.

Also, the atmosphere is great! I was able to sit in the patio, which was awesome. Tables and chairs were clean. The table next to us were speaking in French, which kindof added a level of authenticity to the French cuisine they offer (though I think I was just lucky) and it seems like a popular hang out spot for the real housewives of Cole Valley. 

Other note-worthy dishes to try are the fish soup, it has a great, light seafoody flavor. The only (odd) thing to note is that the chai comes in a bowl, rather than a cup. I'm not sure of the reason why, but it tastes great according to my friend. Also, the brunch menu items seem bigger than the lunch options. Not necessarily a bad thing, just something to keep in mind when you're hungry. All in all, I had a good experience, and I'll definitely recommend this place for special events.
author: Ben H.

description:
Zazie I used to like you , but I think my most recent visit for brunch will be my last.  The service was terrible, one server for the whole restaurant?Really?  We weren't acknowledged by our waiter for atleast 15 minutes. To me, this is unacceptable.  Atleast bring us a glass of water!  
If the food was good I may have been able to overlook the poor service, but my english muffin was rock hard and eggs were underwhelming.  
It's a shame because it is a cute place in a cute neighborhood.  I would take Magic Flute over Zazie any day.
author: anne m.

description:
For a group of three, we waited 20-25 minutes for seating which is pretty much the average waiting time. We were seated on the patio which wasn't very roomy, but neither was it inside. I still preferred outdoor seating though because it's always a bit more charming and there were heating lamps so that's definitely a plus when you're dining outdoors in the winter! 

What can I say about the food? The scrambled eggs were delicious and from the looks of it,  the gingerbread pancakes were humongous! I enjoyed my Challah french toast very much, but I wouldn't order it again next time because it wasn't worth $9 for two. 

Note: The restroom is  as tight as a porta-potty and if you are lucky enough to wait in line for it, you get a fantastic front-row view of the dishwasher doing his job in the hallway.
author: Bets Y.

description:
my favorite brunch place ever! figures that its in SF.. miles and miles away from me :(

I am a lover of breakfast food, so I have yet to try anything besides brunch fare, but seriously, I don't think you can do any wrong with anything off their morning menu.

perfectly poached eggs. a hollandaise so light, it makes you want to get up and do a quick pirouette. potatoes that confuse your texture buds just right, a crisp outer shell only giving away to the softest of potatoes. and two simple words. ROASTED GARLIC.

who knew an eggs benedict could blow your mind??

pancakes are fluffy like pillows and wholesome french toast fit for a queen (or a king of course). what I wouldn't give to see Zazie try a waffle out on me.

interesting flavor combinations and texturally brilliant. a bit of a wait, but few things in life are as worth it as Zazie's. next time I'm in SF, I will definitely migrate over to Cole Valley again.
author: Mindy N.

description: SUCH a cute little French spot! Delicious gingerbread pancakes! :)
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
I have never had a bad meal at Zazie, and I have been there tons.  The waitstaff is also always wonderful.  Be forewarned, however, that the wait times for brunch on the weekend can be crazy.  Other tips:
- Monday night is dog night where you can bring your dog out to the back patio while you eat.  So cute.
- The two tables in the front are first come, first serve.  Normally those are the only tables where you can have a dog at.  
- Beef Bourginoun for dinner is flat out amazing.  
- They do have heat lamps on the patio, so even if it is a bit chilly outside, you don't get cold.
- Make sure you have them tell you the specials - I have had lots of good luck with the specials being the best meals!
author: Liz N.

description:
Good food, but because I don't live around cole valley, I most likely won't make a trip over here again.  It's quaint, but I feel like it's a better neighborhood location. That's not to say, however, if there is no wait, I'll definitely come back.

Had the chorizo scramble, banana walnut stuffed french toast, crab benedict, and the polenta eggs.  I wasn't a fan of polenta eggs, but the rest was made perfectly.  As far as brunch goes, it's not the prettiest, but it tastes good.

If you haven't tried it, it's definitely worth it. Especially those banana walnut french toasts.  Great, now I'm drooling. This is awkward...
author: Victoria L.

description:
Awesome breakfast here!  We opted to eat inside, but the patio is beautiful.  The coffee was top notch and the service was great.  

I had the New York and the eggs were cooked perfectly, right amount of salmon, cream cheese and scallions.  DEEElish.  My toast was just right, thick, quality bread and the potatoes were well seasoned and had a combination of textures.  Well done.

I would come back in a heartbeat.
author: Olivia S.

description: So good!  The poached eggs here are my favorite.  Had the B.L.T. Provencale last time I was here it was perfect. Always a good!
author: Cristina G.

description:
We tried this place while visiting San Francisco. We were staying in this beautiful neighborhood and wanted to try something new. Lucky for us there is YELP! With so many good reviews, we had to try Zazie.

After a short wait (this place is POPULAR!), we were lucky to get seated in the beautiful courtyard. The ambiance is excelent; this place is cozy, well landscaped, and picturesque. The staff very friendly as well.

There is such nice variety of dishes. We were there for a weekend brunch and I ended up ordering the Italie Scrambled Eggs--fresh basil, stewed tomatoes, cheese; a side of potatoes perfectly cooked and wheat country bread made my meal perfect. Per the majority's recommendation, my husband and I order the small portion of the French Toast Tahiti which has walnuts, bananas, and a delicious glaze. It definitely lived up to the buzz!!
author: Alex S.

description:
Love, Love, LOVE Zazie!
The people (diners and service) make it a great place all-around. The food's not bad, either.

Brunch - delicious. Gingerbread pancakes, French Toast Tahiti, Scrambled eggs Greece, all so yummy. Hot chocolate and chai tea come in bowls, yes, bowls.

The wait can be a bit much, but if you're going to stand in line for brunch, it may as well be here. Aside from their iPad app to help you out with the wait, and the tables in front are first come, first served - so snag those if they open up.

Dinner - also delicious.  Started with the soup du jour and Salade Louis Malle, which were just perfect. Then we had the Roasted White Trout and the Zazie Burger, both very flavorful and filling. We were eying the pork chops the neighboring table had, which they confirmed was superb.

P.S. They ask that you make no substitutions, but removing an ingredient or two is allowed.

P.S.S. The super-friendly staff is also super-doggie-friendly. You can sit with your dog at the storefront tables, and they bring out a little bowl of treats and water. On Monday nights, they let you bring your dog into the back patio, (which is quite charming). They have heaters out and blankets available if it's too nippy for you. And Fido gets you $10 off a bottle of wine!
author: Sharon T.

description:
The variations of eggs benedict they offer are interesting. The choice of one, two or three eggs for these dishes allows me to ALSO order a gingerbread pancake with lemon curd. This is simply heavenly. To top it off, they offer different styles of mimosas, such as elderflower or cranberry in place of orange juice. Nothing novel, but a nice touch.

What really impresses me is the staff. On one visit I was seated outside and waited almost 20 minutes before being greeted. We were too hungry and partied-out to raise a fuss, we just wanted food. The server explained the patio staff was called off earlier in the morning but the weather had suddenly cleared up so they were understaffed, but when he took our order he still seemed rushed and apathetic. I am a server, so I most stuff like that I understand, it was just disappointing...once we received our food we were fairly happy. Towards the end of our meal, the service really improved and they comped us a 2nd bottle of champagne (we ordered a first bottle with our meal) for our understanding of the wait. It was unexpected and unnecessary, but VERY much appreciated. 

Also: If you write "BAR" next to your name on the wait list, you can go to the pub next store and enjoy a pre-brunch beverage and they will look for you inside the pub once your table is ready. Zazie was the birthday girl's choice last weekend and the longish wait for a table really flew by once we discovered this trick!
author: Amanda S.

description:
I invited 18 guests to Zazie to celebrate my 40th birthday this past Saturday evening on the back patio and it was AMAZING!  I would give Zazie and staff SIX STARS if I could.  It was truly a memorable experience and no one wanted to leave, we were all having such a wonderful evening.

Thank you to the owner, Jen, who was incredibly responsive to all my detailed requests/questions and made great menu suggestions (the Fig Figaro app was a HUGE hit).  Everything was delivered by Jen as promised, if not more so.

And thank you to Aidan, the server, who seamlessly juggled all our wine glasses, plates, and late arrivals with a casual calm and smile that allowed me to concentrate on the party instead of logistics.

The ambiance outside (no one even cared about the fog) with the heat lamps and twinkly lights, homey garden setting, and beautiful tables was exactly what I'd hoped my birthday dinner would be and guests were asking me through out the dinner how I found this hidden gem.

THANK YOU FOR A PERFECT BIRTHDAY EVENING, ZAZIE!!
xoxoxoxoxoxoxoxo
author: Kathryn F.

description: I love Zazie! Recently celebrated my birthday here. Overrated for brunch, I feel - who wants to wait in line that long? Dinner at Zazie is where it's at.
author: Fiona T.

description:
Went to this place with my director and a designer after a long work meeting back in February. I don't venture out to this neighborhood but I'm glad I did!

We had no appetizers, no dessert, just entrees and based on the one dish I had, I love Zazie! I had the Braised Niman Pork Chop with red cabbage and roasted pears. The pork was cooked to perfection--so juicy and succulent. Mixed with the sour of the red cabbage and the sweetness of the roasted pears-- it was absolute perfection!

Small, cute, cozy place. I'll definitely be going back to check out the other entrees!
author: Victoria B.

description:
Alas, Zazie, we were not impressed. I think our expectations were too high though, holding Tartine and Universal Cafe as our standards for Weekend Brunch.

First, we were definitely clueless about your outdoor table policy.  For these 2 tiny 2-tops, it's first-come-first served (no need to put your name on the list). I could see where this may lead to potential disagreements?

Second, the menu just didn't seem to inspire. On a recent visit the special was a chicken-apple sausage scramble.  When a side of chicken-apple is already on the menu, putting it in a "special" made me think you were just trying to get rid of old/ aging stock.

So. On to the food - I ordered the Fontainbleu -- the mushroom - fontina - spinach scramble.  Nice selection of mushrooms (portabello and small shiitakes were included at the time), and the eggs were cooked well, but the dish needed a bit of salt/ seasoning.  The boy ordered their crab benedict which was fine and actually fairly tasty with some nice chunks of crab.

Very decent Bloody Mary - nicely spicy and tangy (but when you've got Universal Cafe in mind with their house pickled veggies, plain tomato juice and horseradish just does not compare...).  I ordered the Sunshine -- mango juice and sparkling wine -- and could barely taste the mango.

On another visit Danny was more pleased with their Mexican scramble with chorizo, red peppers and salsa.  I chose their eggs florentine with a side of the chicky-apple sausage.  Their hollandaise could have been a bit tangier.  Decent, but nothing that wowed me.

A note - when sharing the banana stuffed french toast with walnuts (Tahiti), do not take it apart the layer by layer.  You'll discover a not-so- appetizing smear of smashed bananas staring you in the face... perhaps it's better to cut crosswise first.  Oh - and we found perhaps 2 walnuts in the entire dish.  More nuts, pls.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Went for brunch on a beautiful Saturday noon. There were a lot of people in the waiting. But fast new reservation system! Feed your details and party size in the iPad at the entry and track your waiting. We were seated in 20 min.

Try to get a seat in the back patio. Its cozy and super cute!! The good weather made the experience even more delightful. 

We ordered:
1. Eggs Florentine - served with home-fries. was average.
2. St. Trop: with wild smoked salmon, capers, and red onions. Its creamy and full of salmon flavor. The BEST and highly recommend!! 
3. Gingerbread pancake- was served with slices of pears. The lemon sauce on top was freakin' delicious!!

Service was good and overall a great place for brunch.
author: Payal B.

description: Was looking for a new place to have lunch and came across this place through yelp. Got excited after seeing 4 stars rating. So I immediately think it's a must try. It's a Saturday brunch, so I already expected a wait (which is fine, thinking it's worth for the high rating food and experience).... The wait wasn't too long, about 20-30 minutes. Which is pretty good. But the negatives begin.... With a high expectation about the quality of the food and the price they charge, I would think I will fall in love with this restaurant. I ordered French toast with SEASONAL FRUITS, and the La Mer crab Benedict with homemade fries. The wait for the food seem longer than the wait for a table. Ticket time for food should not be longer than 15 minutes max! But exclude the time I have to write for our server to take our orders, I still have to wait for 20-25 minutes for my food to come. But I still give benefit of doubts cause it's 4 stars.... Can't be that bad. Once the food came, the presentation of the food was horrible. I mean HORRIBLE! Not even good enough for Instagram. For the Benedict, the crab, avocado, and poached egg was placed messily. And the "homemade fries" seems like just steamed potatoes (tasteless). My French toast wasn't bad itself but thinking the seasonal fruits is mixed fruits... It's only strawberries, sour ones too. They should describe their entree as French toast with strawberries topping instead of seasonal fruits. (My opinions). Lastly, the bill came out with a total $55. So not worth my money for sure. Never again I will come back here.
author: Carol Y.

description: Terrible serving!!! Waiting for more than 2hrs, totally ignore us. And let people cut in in line
author: Huilin S.

description: Absolutely delightful! Great food and service and love that they treat their staff right.
author: Jadey C.

description: We enjoyed brunch here. It's very similar to bistros in Paris because it is small and cozy and they don't rush you. Tip: Cafe au Lait is half coffee and half milk. Couldn't really taste the coffee because of all the milk. Cafe Latte is all milk with a shot of espresso. I can taste the espresso.
author: Alexander M.

description:
I stumbled upon the name of this little gem while looking for venues for a small private party in San Francisco last year. We ended up finding someplace else before we went to scope it out, so during another SF visit this week we decided to give their brunch a try, since the name had stuck with me. I'm SO glad we did! It was literally the best breakfast I've ever had! I had the New York scramble (smoked salmon, cream cheese, scallions) and a latte, while my husband had the Genevieve (ham, cheese, avocado) with a coffee. The food is out of this world! Perfectly cooked, generously portioned, amazing potatoes with whole cloves of roasted garlic... I could go on! I top of all this, they have a no tipping policy. Their menu outlines what they do for their employees to ensure that they make the money they need without relying on tips. Their commitment to their team shows in the remarkable customer service. 

If you're in the S.F. area, it's a must-visit! (Full disclosure, we went back again today and ordered the exact same meal. It's THAT good!) Enjoy!
author: Natasha L.

description:
I have been wanting to visit this place for a while but driving to the city has been the obstacle for me to get here. we were visiting a relative in this neighborhood so finally, I had my wish.
La Mer Benedict - 4 star, I like it, the poached egg was perfect, fresh cram meat poking out, the English muffin toasted without a hard time to "chew" it as most places prepared. I love the roasted garlic the most...finished them all..
Well, my husband ordered their "flight of pancake" and thought they were so so..the signature tea is okay only.
Our relative ordered half sandwich, and soup, he likes it, the potato, leek soup looks tasty and smooth. the veggie in the sandwich looks fresh also.
I'll go back to try other stuff when I go back next time.
author: Chi Y.

description: Six of us for dinner tonight...fell in love with Zazie, the pork chop with red cabbage and poached pears was the fave entrée, the cheese plate with port poached figs was incredible, and then we finished it all off with pots du crème and lemon soufflé.  The parking was a bit challenging, but a six-block walk to the parking lot is worth it for the incredible cuisine, warm, friendly atmosphere and excellent service.  By the way, our server, Aiden, was superb!  Highly recommend Zazie!
author: Wendy G.

description: Came here with a friend on a trip to SF for her 21st birthday, so it's safe to day our food outings also revolved around alcohol.  This place has the location, the ambience, and the quality to be one of my favorite, if not my favorite brunch place in city.  The waiter was super nice, the cocktails were very unique and reflected the freshness of the restaurant and the food.  The French toast and eggs benny were to die for! I will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu and I can't wait!
author: Jenna R.

description: When we want to celebrate or simply relax as a family over a delicious dinner Zazie is always our top choice. We used to live nearby but now that we're further away we still drive over there often. Our favorite thing to do is sit outside on the lovely garden patio and enjoy our meal. Service is always friendly and helpful, even at busy times. Our children give the kids' meals high ratings, especially the kids pasta and the mac n cheese. They also love the crayons and paper that come on request. And we love pretty much everything on the menu and the wine list. Our favorite waiter is Jeff who is always terrific with our kids.  My 5 and 7 year olds think this is the best restaurant on earth!
author: Rachel B.

description:
I've heard this is one of the best brunch places in the city, so of course I had to try it out myself.  Although, it was definitely good, I can't think of a reason that would make this place thaaaat much better than a handful of others I've been to.

The area was nice and the restaurant was very cozy.  We only had to wait for about 15 min. or so, which was definitely a plus!  Must of came on a good day!  I went with the La Mer, which was a great choice.  

I may have to come back a try a few other dishes.  I'll definitely have to make my way back here.
author: Tom Y.

description:
We ate outside in the courtyard. It's such a cute little cozy SF courtyard. Everyone's seated within a few feet from each other. You can overhear other's conversations, and they can hear yours. So, I made sure to keep my discussion topics on the spicy side :D

The service was excellent. The potatoes were good, I would have preferred it if they were cooked slightly more but they were still great! They spared on the butter for my toast, but, I didn't really need the extra calories anyway. Their portions are great.

I found this place on Yelp.. got a little lost on the way. This is the best part of the restaurant.... they freaking gave me directions on the phone from somewhere several miles away. I just caled them and said "hey I'm on the corner of Van Ness and 17th, how do I get there?" and they gave me step by step directions. I guess they had a computer or something handy?  That was soo helpful!

As for parking.. I parked a few blocks away. It's in a cute area and I didn't mind the walk. I didn't have that much trouble finding parking but maybe that's because I don't drive an SUV?
author: Kathy S.

description:
I was stoked to try Zazie's after reading great reviews, but it wasn't worth the 45 minute wait. The food was fine, and the staff were friendly- I just think that we could have had a comparable or better dining experience elsewhere for the same price. 
Also, the bill included a healthcare benefit charge which I'd never seen before - it prompted me to do some research which left me feeling conflicted.
author: A C.

description:
Another place I get to cross off my 7x7 list!! 

It was a drag to find parking; it took a good 15 minutes of driving through those tiny residential streets. My friend and I got to the restaurant a bit before 12PM, and were seated in 30-40 minutes. There were about 15 parties ahead of us on the sign-in sheet. The guy calling out names was too dedicated to his job; he went into nearby bars and shops to check if someone on the list was in there! Luckily, some people didn't show up!

We were lucky enough to get a seat on the patio (nice, on a sunny day), but I have to agree with Christine, this place is a bit squishy so it's best to come with just a few people. 

I ordered the La Mer poached eggs w/ 2 eggs (eggs benedict) since it was on the 7x7 while my friend ordered 2 pieces of the French Toast Tahiti,

(WOOT!) La Mer [$17]: It was tiny, but surprisingly good! The english muffin was cooked perfectly. It wasn't soggy or too crispy; it was perfect enough to cut through it without any difficulty. The eggs and the hollandaise complemented each other as usual, and the crab gave it an extra kick.

(WOOT!) French Toast Tahiti [$10]: It had a sort of paste with chopped nuts in between each piece of toast to give it more flavor. I probably could have eaten it without the maple syrup, but I'm just too used to pouring it all over my breakfast.

We also had the 2 mimosas ($6/glass). I forgot the names, but one had cranberry and orange juice, and the other one had mango juice. I'm a girly drink type of girl so I thought it needed more juice. I made myself down it and suffered the consequences afterwards. I had an asian glow in broad daylight from one drink! SAD, I KNOW.

The food and service was great so I'll be back here with the rest of the girls another day!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Great patio! Delicious food. They have a bring your dog to dinner thing on monday nights which i am DYING to do!  Good champagne deal.... try it with the peach sorbet SOOOOO amazing!
author: Julie B.

description: So many mimosa options. I'm embarrassed to say I go classic. Excellent sweet brunch options, including Tahitian french toast - yum!! But we are in SF so long wait times on weekends.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Zazie is like the love child of Berkeley's Venus and La Note (though it might have come before either). 

It was fairly easy getting a table for two on a weekday. You write your name on the list and someone will come out to check the list every few minutes or so. The patio is very well heated so even on a frigid day, don't hesitate to take a table in the back! They even provide fleece blankets  which is nice.  

I had the egg special with chicken apple sausage and brie cheese. Three of my favorite things put into one plate, almost impossible to not enjoy!  

I like this cozy neighborhood restaurant and would definitely come back to try more items.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Me and my girlfriend went in here for breakfast today for the third time, and I'll just put it out there now that we won't be back.

When you go into a place for breakfast you kind of expect what's on the menu or what the waiter offers you to be included in the meal. Am I just crazy? I mean when the menu says you have your choice of toast with your eggs, and the waiter offers you 2 different kinds (which is all they have), wouldn't you be a little shocked when your bill comes back with an extra charge for $1.10 for it? We were given the choice of sides with out eggs, so we chose a small fruit cup. Oh wait that's also $2.50 extra. My girlfriend didn't want cheese on her eggs (she's lactose intolerant), well that counts as a substation - another extra $1.00. For real?!?!

We obviously complained to the snobby waiter we had, so he took the bill back, and returned with a new bill where he gave us $0.75 off. No joke 75 cents!!!!!!

With how snippy the waiter was, mixed with the nickel and dime billing, and how utterly pertinacious this place is - I mean they acted like we should have been honored to be there - they won't be seeing us anymore.

The wait stuff acts like you being there is bothering them. The food selection sub par. The prices are high. The atmosphere is stuck up.

The only bright spot for Zazie was that we didn't have to wait to get in. Call me crazy, but I'm going to guess there is a correlation between no wait for a table and how crappy this place is.
author: Erik B.

description:
If you can handle the loooong wait, Zazie for brunch is worth every minute of standing outside.  The two tables outside are actually first come, first served, and seems comfortable for two.  Our inside table for 3 took an hour on a sunday morning.

We ordered the poached eggs - Monaco and Albert.  My eggs albert with bacon were so darn good.  The potato sides were delish.  For "dessert," we ordered the french toast.  Thick and fluffy, they were perfect.

Cole Valley is a fun place to just hang out and walk around.   You can kill time by moseying over to Tully's, getting a morning coffee, and reading the paper.
author: Stella K.

description: Cool place, love the vibe, very friendly staff. The food is fresh and has great flavors.
author: Mike D.

description: Poached eggs, gingerbread pancakes, smoked salmon, mimosas, their home fries, mmmmm! Definitely worth the wait, which is most likely a long one I might add. Wish it was bigger it's a bit tight but what would San Francisco be without the tightness anyways.
author: Frances P.

description: While the food is good, the wait times on weekends for brunch are ridiculous and you feel quite rushed, as so many people are waiting for a table. It's slightly overpriced as well, but it's still a nice place for dinner with friends. I would recommend asking for a table outside, it can get very crowded and warm inside. There's a service fee per person of 1.25 USD.
author: Laura D.

description:
I don't get the big hullabaloo about this place. Pretty pricey for decent food. The bacon was really good, but the eggs were so so.

The place is also really, really small and the door kept opening every 5 minutes with cold bursts of air. The waiter asked if we wanted a blanket because it was so cold.

Overall, ok food in an ok atmosphere. La Boulange  across the street is better.
author: Chris K.

description: Okay, this is going to seem a little strange on this page of five star reviews.  I live two blocks from Zazie, and have been there numerous times.  As much as I have enjoyed the food and ambiance of this lovely restaurant, I was rather disappointed the last time I dined there.  Don't get me wrong, the service was great; our waitress couldn't have been nicer or more professional.  And the menu was nicely diverse and made me hungry just looking at it.  I ordered the rabbit that was supposed to be in a mustard sauce, accompanied by fresh made linguini.  My choice was a mistake.  Neither the rabbit nor the pasta had any discernible seasoning......in fact there was very little flavor in the dish at all. (What mustard sauce??)  I love rabbit, and I'm not often able to find it on the menus of the city's restaurants.  I assumed that Zazie would get it right, but I was not correct.  Eh, better luck next time??
author: janice s.

description: They are known for their eggs benedict...which I do have to say are quite yummy. The hollandaise sauce isn't too heavy but still is quite creamy. The lemon ricotta pancakes are what I think to be the star. They are so light and flavorful. There are bites of lemon zest that just make it a nice surprise in your mouth. The lemon curd and raspberry sauce complements the pancakes quite well. One pancake is surprising quite filling. The prices of the meal was surprisingly not too bad. I think for an omelet with salad and toast came out to 14 dollars with tip and tax. Not the best but not too expensive for the area.
author: Eve C.

description:
I love the French bistro setting at Zazie's and I especially love their back patio on sunny afternoon. There usually is a wait here but I don't mind it at all. 

Their French Toast Tahiti was the reason I wanted to try this place. It's made with Challah bread stuffed with caramelized bananas, walnuts and their maple drizzle This is my favorite item on their menu - so much so that I've never been able to order anything else. Luckily, my friends like to share so I get to have my French Toast Tahiti and a little bit of whatever else they're having. Their home fries are made just the way I like: crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. I also like the fact they add roasted garlic! 

Zazie is one of my favorite brunch spots.
author: Cyndi G.

description:
My favorite brunch place in Cole Valley.

The outdoor patio is nice and cozy and the food is delicious. 

My only (tiny) complaint is that they won't sit you down if all the people in your party aren't there yet. So if you're 3 friends and the 4th is late, you'll have to wait for that person (when there is a waitlist). 

Other than that, great place!
author: Alexandre T.

description: This place is unbelievable. The laid back and friendly atmosphere complement an out-of-this-world menu perfectly. A must in Cole Valley.
author: Samuel C.

description: Came here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon, and there was a pretty long line up. We waited for almost 45 mins but it was definitely worth the wait. I had the La Mer which was basically a crab bene. It was light and simply amazing! The bf had the Florentine and it was delicious as well. I usually feel guilty after eating Benedict's but these ones certainly did not make me feel guilty at all. We also ordered the French Toast Tahiti. These puppies are the best French toasts I've ever had in my life! It was probably a whole day's worth of calorie intake but who cares! It was a nice treat :).
author: Carmen A.

description: This restaurant has an excellent menu and is one of the best places in the city to eat at. As a food critic I am extremely impressed with the pork chop, it is properly cooked and does not usually have much fat.
author: Arjun G.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for brunch for a really long time, but have never gotten to it until today.  It always comes up in my "best brunch in SF" search, so today, we finally made it around 2 pm and the wait was only 10-15 min, so we went for it. 

I was really disappointed with the food. The space was cute, the service was good...but as much hype as this place gets, it was supremely underwhelming. The poached egg dishes were good, but nothing too special. I chose mine to come with a side salad. I am always so annoyed when it says something comes with a salad and what you get is just a bunch of lettuce with absolutely nothing else. If I was a rabbit, ok, fine, but at least throw in a bit of tomato or cucumber in there and some dressing. This was the case where it was just lettuce and NOTHING else, not even dressing. My man's home potatoes were ok, really had so much better at so many other places, including Squat and Gobble. A couple of pieces he gave me were undercooked, and I love my potatoes, like any good Russian.  Then came a piece of French toast with fruit and a buttermilk pancake for my man. As soon as he tasted it, he laughed and said, wow, I grew up on this, this is DEFINITELY Aunt Jemima's mix. Really?  And the French Toast was pretty good but nothing to write home about.  Overall, extremely disappointing for a $60 brunch and their usual 1-2 hr wait. Next!!!!
author: Marina S.

description:
Had Eggs Benny (& smoked salmon) here for the first time in my life.
My friend and I both stopped just short of licking our plates clean. GO here, wait if you must, it's more than worth it.
author: Yasmin M.

description:
Cute little neighborhood restaurant/cafe in the SOMA area.  There's outdoor dining in the front and the back patio. There's always a wait- like every other great eatery in San Francisco that's worth trying out.  

I had the gingerbread pancakes topped with their own lemon curd- delicious.  The pancakes were fluffy, moist and flavorful. The lemon curd was delicious- creamy and a perfect balance of tart and sweet.

I got a chance to try out the crab florentine and a mushroom egg scramble.  Everything tasted fresh, homemade, and nicely seasoned. 

It looked like you can purchase the pancake, and other mixes to go- as well as the lemon curd.  

Nice, friendly service and the food came out quick.  Brunch is service until 3:00PM on the weekends, which is a bonus since most other places stop service at 2:00PM.   Also, unlike Mama's and Dottie's (both which I love), I like the fact that I don't have to stand in line.  You sign up and hang out in front.  The neighborhood and the cafe itself has a great ambiance and a non-hectic atmosphere.
author: Thao T.

description:
Food- 5stars; service - 5stars 

So why a 3 star rating? They really need to get in touch with reality re their brunch popularity. Either put in a park-let as pseudo waiting area OR start taking reservations. Not only would this make your eaters happy, your NEIGHBORS (like myself) would really love love love it. I am so happy for your success, I just wish I didn't have to plan an alternate route around that block (and all your business neighbors) every weekend.
author: stephanie h.

description:
Okay, so I have heard soooo many good things about this place and it is right around the corner from my house.  Every weekend I see people waiting outside to eat at this establishment.  Finally I try it out on a Saturday around 9am.  There are probably a dozen or so people waiting outside...all groups of 3 or more.  Since we were only two, we got in no problem.  I ordered the Pierre Noir.  I was super excited about this as I love eggs benedict and to think with tomatoes provencales, I AM IN!  Sadly, my eggs were overcooked but the tomatoes were delicious!  The eggs served on the side were great with whole roasted garlic cloves - YUM.

Service was crazy fast.  As I said, we were seated quickly because we were 2 but then when we ordered, we were served our meals in minutes, as if we were the only people they were cooking for.  The servers were friendly and attentive.

I am not giving up on this place though.  Too many people have good things to say and keep going back.  Maybe they just weren't having the best day.
author: Jenni S.

description:
Been here a bunch of times and the food is always awesome!

Their poached eggs and pancakes are the best ever! Never disappointed! Every time I go there I feel like overeating because it's that good.

Brian is a good server and recommends awesome dishes. He's very thoughtful and caring for making sure his customers are satisfied. He would give us time even when it's super busy. 

So the last time I was there, the restaurant was packed, and there was a billing snaffu where I was overcharged accidentally for an item. I realized it a few days later after doing expenses and so I emailed Suhail, the events coordinator, about my issue since there was no other email address I could find. A few days later, Jen, the owner, emailed me and told me she would refund me the overcharge + tips. Now that is excellent customer service! Jen and I also had a good conversation on the phone too. She's very amiable and cool. This is why I love the small, quaint restaurants in SF. Zazie's is very awesome!
author: J T.

description:
Zazie has a lot of charm going for it, and the dishes there all evoke the kind of warm, comfort food vibe of a cozy Parisian bistro.

The reason I'm only giving it 2 stars, however, is because our celebratory dinner there tonight unfortunately ended on a very negative note due to rude treatment by the owner. It was a busy Saturday night, and we had reservations for 7:30. Three of our party arrived at 7:20 and the fourth member arrived at 7:35. We had menus and water almost right away, but we weren't greeted by our waiter for at least 25 minutes (something all of us remarked on). When he did finally come by, however, he apologized for making us wait and was friendly and very helpful in guiding us through the menu. Overall, he did a great job.

Throughout the meal, however, the delays continued. We all noticed that there was a fairly slow pace to the service - with significant gaps between courses and a long delay before our dessert order was taken. We figured the kitchen was either super busy -- or it was just Zazie's way of embracing its Frenchness -- i.e., embracing the notion that meals and diners should not be rushed. Either way, we were having a good time and weren't too concerned. 

We finally finished dessert and paid our check and were wrapping up our conversation when the owner (Jen) approached our table, and without even introducing herself announced in a rude and annoyed tone, "Um, we have another reservation that needs to be seated at this table. You've been here over two hours. You need to go." And that was about all she said before turning her back on us. 

This treatment would have been frustrating in and of itself, but the fact that meal had been so long due to what appeared to be delays in either their kitchen or waitstaff made it seem truly unfair. We would have been completely understanding if Jen had approached us in a more respectful manner and politely explained that she hated to rush us but it was a very busy evening and they didn't want to keep the next reservation waiting too long. We'd totally get that. But her tone of annoyance and her implication that we, the diners, had done something knowingly wrong left all of us with a very bad taste in our mouth. Unfortunately what had been a celebratory dinner turned into a very negative experience. I expected better from them - and I certainly would have expected that the owner of the establishment would have taken better care of her customers. As it is, I'm not sure we'll be back.
author: Laura M.

description:
Zazie has been one of my favorite places for brunch. Being late to the game however, I recently discovered dinner here. I highly recommend Zazie for dinner if you are looking for something outside of the Mina, Blvd, Dankos circuit. Zazie belongs and ranks high in the Cafe Claude, La'rdoise and Bistro Central Parc club. The restaurant evokes charm and warmth and serves up delicious french influenced homestyle cooking.
