I highly suggest having dinner on the patio during a warmer night in SF (few and far between, I know). Currently (month of November), they are featuring their Autumn menu. We were able to enjoy Butternut squash soup with curry (delicious!!), a beef shank and vegetable stew, as well as the porcini mushroom ravioli dish. For dessert, we ordered the warm ginger cake with coffee gelato. This dessert was incredibly good and seasonally fitting. We were satisfied with our meal and the service. It was certainly a treat to dine at Zazie for dinner.

Bottom line: Not a trendy restaurant by any means but a homey french bistro that serves good food with fresh seasonal ingredients. Parking is a major pain since more patrons live in Cole Valley and walk here. Sub-par wine selection.
author: Annie Y.

description:
***Brunch Review***

Zazie is a cutesy Little French bistro located in Cole Valley.  We got the La Mer benedict, Gingerbread Pancake and Croque Monsieur  Everything was delish.  The gingerbread pancakes with pears and lemon curd definitely lived up to the hype....I highly recommend this!

Don't be discourage by the wait.  I came on a Sat morning and only had to wait for 20min.  You can easily past the time by taking a stroll down the block and back.
author: Michelle T.

description: Absolutely delicious! We had the dungeness crab poached eggs and the sesame pancakes with lemon curd. OMG... everything was absolutely amazing and to perfection! I devoured and fully enjoyed every single bite of all of this. I definitely want to go back for more. Our server was really cute and sweet as well! Excellent service! We tipped him well :)
author: Nari L.

description:
Moral of the story:  Get the home fries!  They're RIDICULOUSLY tasty.

We enjoyed brunch at Zazie on Friday, and the experience was well worth the walk/wait in the rain!  We were warmly greeted and seated quickly.  Overall the experience was impeccable.  From the fun, attentive and accommodating staff, to the delightful brunch combination of mimosa, eggs florentine and an explosively tasty BLT (I've completely retooled my perception of what a BLT can be!), to a finish with decadent baked chocolate and vanilla rooibos tea, this will be a brunch I won't soon forget.

I'm very happy to list this as my first recommendation as a soon to be resident of SF!  Thanks Zazie crew!  Hope to see you again soon.
author: Josh L.

description: My sister and I came back a few months later and everything was as good as the first time. The wait wasn't too bad, and the man who seated us actually came to the coffee shop next door to tell us our table was ready so we didn't have to sit right outside the entrance waiting. That was a nice touch!
author: Chelsea T.

description: Love this place! Went on a Sunday after reading the reviews - to avoid the long queues, try after 2pm. We got a table after a 10 minute wait, which was pretty good! It's small inside, but ambience is very quaint and service fast. Pancakes (especially the gingerbread ones), French toast and poached eggs with crab were all amazing. Will definitely be visiting again!
author: Pooja S.

description: Came here for Saturday brunch. Pretty amazing. The portions are large and not expensive. They give you the option of getting 1 piece, 2 piece, so you're able to try a lot of their food (pancakes and french toast are a must). There are long lines on the weekends, so come prepared to wait, but it's worth it.
author: Sharon M.

description: best bruch place of all time. so european. if the weather is nice u should try to get the seat in the back yard, really peaceful. love the egg Benedict w the so good baked garlic potatoes (ur choice of salad or fries i recommend fries n you will know why).just dont like the mimosa that much^^hope you enjoy!!!
author: Vu N.

description:
The wait here always feels like it seems long, but isn't really quite as long as you think it seems.  Right.  Anyway you can always go across to street to look at some plants in the nursery, or go to the pharmacy next door and look at some drugs (a favorite pastime of everyone, i'm sure).  The list moves pretty quickly so don't stray far.

The back patio area is really awesome, except for when you go on the one hottest day of the year, and you happen to be seated in between the shades of two umbrellas when all your friends are in the shade, and you're wearing a tank top and you forgot to put on sunscreen.  Except that.

Their pancakes are huge and fluffy and best, and their egg dishes are cooked to perfection...not too dry and not too runny.  I like the New York scramble and the Mexico scramble, both of which taste like their namesakes.

I shall continue to come here whenever I feel like brunch that's classy but not too classy, and you should too.
author: jon y.

description:
This is definitely a must try!! I'm not even a big fan of brunch/breakfast food, but this place is incredible. Here's what you have to get: start with a mimosa, ORDER THE GINGERBREAD PANCAKES, get an egg something or another, and try there freakin jam! Yums!

I will be back Zazie!!! Love it! The only downfall, which is not zazie's fault, is parking :( hate SF for that reason. But it's super close to haight street and ashbury, we walked off our food and enjoyed the shops.
author: B B.

description:
My one experience here was spectacular. Not only was Mark (the manager / owner?) super friendly right off the bat, but he also bent over backwards to accommodate my party of four when it didn't look like we'd be able to sit together.  

I recommend two things - definitely sit outside and definitely get there early unless you're prepared to wait. By 9:30 AM the place is jam packed.  Their patio is super cute, and we were lucky enough to come on one of those rare gorgeous days in San Francisco.

The food was really good- everyone at my table enjoyed it. I had their salmon eggs benedict (or whatever it's called). It was perfect! I also got to share one gingerbread pancake (yes, you can buy just one!) and that was scrumptious too. Basically, it's your standard brunch fare with a French twist, done right.

Usually, on a lovely Sat/Sun morning, I am either hungry or sleepy.  Luckily, Zazie makes getting up early worth it. 

Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Roxane W.

description: awesome french toast, but the wait is agonizing and it's bit pricy for what you get. the interior of the restaurant is also a bit crowded. they do have a cute patio in the back, though. definitely a must try at some point, but be prepared to wait
author: Lisa H.

description:
This is a great place for brunch. Yelpers never fail! Looked this place up and was lucky it was open on July 4th. Came here around 1030-11 and the line was abit long. We waited about 30 minutes which wasnt too bad, we were expecting longer. We had a great seat next to the window. 

Ordered the do it yourself pitcher of mimosas. Great deal! $32 a whole bottle of champagne and your choice of juice. I ordered the Florentine Poached Eggs. It had spinach and mushrooms with an english muffin. When your eggs are cooked the way you like it, the dish just cant go wrong! My cousin got the La Mer poached eggs. It comes with crab and avocados. The bf ordered the Pierre Noir which is poached eggs with bacon and tomatoes. Sadly, he only had one runny poached egg and the other one was over cooked =( Another friend of ours had the french toast and it was Ginormous. No one had a complaint on the taste of their dishes. I wouldnt paying this place another visit when I am in town. Yippe!
author: Thao N.

description:
Brunch at at Zazie was great. Local neighborhood place with a line, but manageable.  Loved the poached eggs, and you can get 1, 2, or 3 eggs depending on how hungry you are. Eggs come with a nice light hollandaise, very tasty. Gingerbread pancakes with pear and lemon curd were good--  lightly spiced and the lemon curd was great.

Good service despite being very busy. Still they did not rush us.

Will be back
author: Jessica B.

description:
After my trip to France, I never wanted to eat or even see another Croque Madame ever again (or croissant for that matter).

Too bad there's Zazie. I HAD to try their Croque Madame even though I was still sick of them and I'm glad I did.  It was delicious, dare I say it, better than the ones that I ate in France. 

I love it here, but I had to take away a star because they are a bit expensive for what you get and there's always a super long wait, even on the weekdays, which unfortunately is good for them but bad for me!
author: Marisa R.

description: $4 for mussel addition. Literally 4 or 5 mussels. Two of us ordered the $13 burger. Both got wrecked intestines. Overpriced, food prep needs work. Also, online reservation system doesn't work. $$$.
author: N B.

description:
Out of all of the restaurants I've been to in SF, this is my favorite! 
Amazing food, great service, a lovely patio in back (they even bring you blankets on the cold nights!). 
I've been back three times for dinner and I can't wait to come for brunch!
author: Brielle N.

description: typical hour+ wait time. I think the pancakes were not bad but I like Mama's pancakes more. nice back patio.
author: Troy V.

description:
Had brunch here this morning with several old friends.  The host was skilled at juggling the many people waiting outside, and made several table rearrangements in order to accommodate our larger group.  

The wait was well worth it!  Everyone's food was delicious, and the outdoor back patio had great atmosphere.  The whole place is charming, stylish, and comfortable.  Highly worth the wait.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Decor:  Cute and understated.
Staff:  Friendly and helpful.
Food:  Delicious!

What I ordered...
* French Onion Soup
* Croque Madame (Croque Monsieur topped with a free range sunny side up egg)
* Austriche (Mimosa w/ elderflower)
author: Sharon N.

description: Amazing breakfast foods.  had the French toast Tahiti, Greece scramble egg, and the holiday special eggs Benedict. All great.
author: Edison L.

description: This brunch spot is known among locals as the go-to place on weekends, which can been seen by the crowds waiting outside. The food is delicious -- I had the Fontainbleau scrambled eggs. Note to those not wanting to wait: the two tables outside in the front are first come first served.
author: Courtney B.

description:
UPDATE on 1/16/09: I changed my original 1-star rating up to a 4-star since Jen, the owner, contacted me via Yelp after reading about the incident here. She did it fairly soon after my posting, I just haven't had a chance to update this. 

She was apologetic and wanted to make it up to me by sending me a coupon for a free slice of coffee cake. I haven't had the chance to use it, but I really appreciate the fact that she is concerned about the reviews, both good and bad, and really reaches out to her patrons (even out-of-towners like me!) to make sure I have the best experience possible. I still don't like that it happened (which is why this is 4 instead of a 5), but Jen reacted quickly and made me feel like she wanted to make the wrong right. Which she did. Thank you and I look forward to going back!


I had to have their coffee cake. So my friend dropped me off, since parking is sooooo bad in that area, to check to see if they even had it at 5:00 pm on a Saturday. I went in, since the door was open. They were getting ready to re-open at 5:30. So I asked the guy there if they served coffee cake during dinner. He said, "Yes, I think so." And he, since I think he was helping clean up, asked the guy behind the counter if they served coffee cake at night. He asked him in Spanish, and since my four years of Spanish helps me in situations such as eating, when it's most important, I understand that he asked if they served it at night. And the guy behind the counter said yes, they do. And I said, so you'll have it tonight, right? And he said yes. So I said, okay, you're open at 5:30 tonight? And he said yes. So I said great, I'll be back at 5:30!

Well, after driving around for 35 minutes looking for parking, the parking gods were finally merciful and granted us a spot right out in front. We walked in and the talk skinny guy with glasses asked us if we were a party of two? I said, yes, then just for grins said, "You serve coffee cake right now?" To which he replied, "Oh no. We have it for breakfast, but not for dinner." And I said, "Well, I came by earlier and asked someone and they said that you did." And he said, "Well, they must've misunderstood you or something. And whoever said that should be spanked." Then I said, it's that guy right over there and pointed to the guy behind the counter. Then the guy just said, "Oh no, we don't serve it at night." Needless to say, I was a little miffed. 

Now, after driving around for 35 minutes looking for parking in the hell that is Cole Valley where parking spaces don't fit anything bigger than a tricycle AND with gas prices this high AND me being from out of town, I don't appreciate being told that I was misunderstood. Especially since I confirmed AND was dropped off just to verify this fact. 

I'm giving it 1-star for this experience, since there was no apology given for the "misunderstanding." See my review on their coffee cake though. Still delicious, although I won't be experiencing it on this visit. Hmph.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
Zazie impresses me without fail on all accords. This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, breaskfast or dinner. Honestly, I even like dinner more than their acclaimed brunch. 

From the ambiance and charm to the warm owner, Zazie's food leaves you feeling enchanted. The european feel of the place, the flavors and yummy wine list all make me smile. Zazie, you've stolen my heart!
author: Kate V.

description: Well-known brunch spot, see the hoards waiting outside, baked goods out of this world and a tasty french option for lunch and dinner. They go the extra etcetera, giving you bottomless coffee, recipes to take home and the manager's warmth makes sure you're coming back. In my humble opinion, the eggs benedict (every version) and light lemony hollandaise are perfection. Worth the wait, and the back patio garden is almost overkill perfection. Almost.
author: Doodle W.

description:
Honestly my breakfast was not up to the hype of this place. Although there was a crowd gathered in front the wait was quick. Among our table we had:

1. Zazie's Spritzer- this was alright for close to $5. It was a drink made with orange juice cranberry juice and sparkling water.

2. French Toast Tahiti- I did not like this dish it was mushy and sloppily prepared. There were suppose to be pecans or walnut or something on the French toast and I didn't taste any. 

3. The Albert Benedict- English muffin was grossly soggy. For having many poached egg options on the menu I thought their poached eggs would be perfectly poached with a semi runny inside. Instead they were practically raw and the white was runny too. The hollandaise had no flavor whatsoever and was more like melted butter!

3. La Mer Benedict- Same issues with the above. The crab and avocado were very fresh though!

4. Gingerbread Pancakes- The only saving grace to our breakfast. Fluffy, tasty and moist!

I don't think for the price this meal was up to par! Also I don't appreciate the sign up front where you write your name on the wait list that says "DO NOT ASK THE SERVERS HOW LONG THE WAIT IS, THEY DO NOT KNOW. ADD 3 MINUTES TO EVERY NAME ABOVE YOURS AND THATS HOW LONG THE WAIT IS." 
Um, then invest in a fucking hostess so she can answer with an accurate wait time. Also there is another sign on the bottom of their menu that reads "ABSOLUTELY NO SUBSTITUTIONS NO EXCEPTIONS!" WTH! Way to be accommodating! You're in the restaurant business and that sign is unfriendly ZAZIE!
author: Olivia H.

description:
Zazie's is a definite SF experience must! I've never had dinner here but i've had the brunch several times. All of the eggs benedicts were amazing. And the french toast as well as the pancakes are soooo good!! It's a very cute restaurant and has an even cuter patio area. 

I usually don't go back to restaurants but I've come here like several times and brought all of my out-of-town friends and family members here :) Everyone, and I mean everyone who I bring to Zazie's absolutely loves it! This place is an SF must!
author: Judy Y.

description:
Stop reading this Yelp review.  Go to Zazie immediately and order the Eggs Benedict...and by Eggs Benedict, I mean any of the 6-7 types of e.b. Zazie serves.

Highlights:
- it's worth the wait (and yes, you will wait for a table)
- haven't been disappointed with anything I've ordered.  I get Eggs Benedict often, but the challah french toast is to die for as well.  The potatoes served with most breakfast dishes are garlicky bites of awesomeness.
- the mimosas and glasses of champagne are heavy pours, which I don't see as a problem but thought I'd highlight nevertheless,
- service is friendly and attentive; they leave bottles of water at the table to ensure you're always hydrated, and there is no worry of running out of coffee

If you need more convincing, this is THE brunch place I take anyone coming to visit me in SF.  It never disappoints.
author: Kathleen H.

description: I had only thought of this place for brunch, given the long lines and many positive reviews for it, but tried the dinner and am so glad I did. Here's why: First, the place is really cute and warm. We made reservations and were greeted by a homemade "reserved" sign in our cozy window spot. Second, the staff is awesome. From the prompt host to the incredibly friendly waitress, we were well taken care of. Last, and most importantly, the food is excellent. All of our meals were hearty and full of flavor. Yum. I'll be back.
author: Brett B.

description:
Went here with my boyfriend last week. 

The portions are not small and tiny like you'd expect. We ordered the steak and the rabbit & I was stuffed! The mushrooms on the steak were delicious! It also came with asparagus and mashed potatoes. The rabbit meat was decent sized plus it had some kind of pasta on the bottom. 

Only thing is the rabbit had some bones in it but I guess you can't really de-bone a rabbit? 

The waitress recommended a spinach dish that was not so delicious, hence the 4 stars. Otherwise, the ambiance was nice & the prices were decent. 

A cute little after work date place :)
author: Jessica L.

description: I like plan cake but I'm not a pancake fan. The pancake here is kind of weet for me. Not bad, though.
author: Zhaoxin Y.

description:
Excellent find in Cole Valley while looking for a brunch spot post the New Year's celebrations.

Small, cozy spot so be prepared to wait or get there by 10am if you are having brunch.

Delicious menu! The omlettes, french toast, and croque madame are wonderful. The home fries are chunks of red potatoes tossed with herbs and whole garlic cloves....lovely! Truely, everything I tasted and everything I saw come out looked fantastic.

Try one of the several flavored mimosas. I liked the Corsica!  The bloody mary looked good too.

Street parking - you might have to walk a few blocks.

Warning! They do charge $1 per person at the table for the SF healthcare act. Being from Seattle I had no clue what this was nor had I noticed it before in SF.  You help pay the health insurance of the staff so that they are able to stay open and afford to do so. I didn't  mind because the staff was friendly and efficient very humble when explaining what it was.

I can't wait to come back and try the dinner menu!

Enjoy!
author: BennyLucy C.

description:
Had an incredibly tender and delicious beef shank last night! Our waiter, Jeff, was delightfully witty and handsome- Bonus!
No corkage night on Tuesdays!
author: Jen F.

description:
After a long wait on a beautiful Sunday morning, had a great brunch at Zazie. If the day wasn't so beautiful, and I wasn't with such good company, I may have been more bothered by the wait. Anyways, nice weather or not, you should be prepared for a wait.

Enough about the wait, and on to the food. I had the poached eggs with crab, and a side of garlic potatoes. They were put together beautifully, and had just the right amount of crab. I know other folks have noted the lack of crab meat, but it was more than sufficient. The touch of avocado adds a nice creaminess to the dish. Our group also shared the French Toast Tahiti, which was awesome. The walnuts and carmelized bananas were simple, but tasty. This dish is more than enough to share with a party of three. 

Anyways, a great neighborhood gem, with a strong following. Get there early, put your name on the list, and head down the street to grab a cup of coffee while you wait. A definite go to spot next time you're in Cole Valley.
author: David M.

description:
The wait was long for a patio table since the weather was fantastic, but the host was great and seemed to know the names of all the regulars.  Once we were seated, the patio was comfortable and though full, not too loud.  For such a small kitchen, they were able to get our food out fairly quickly.  Everyone I was with was pleased with their meal.  I had the pancakes, which weren't amazing, but better than most places.  The French toast was awesome and extremely filling.  Two slices would be sufficient for most people.
I definitely recommend Zazie for anyone looking for a tasty breakfast.  I will have to come back and try lunch or dinner soon.
author: Grant M.

description:
So I'm not sure what the big deal is about this place. My husband and I went to Zazie for brunch. Don't get me wrong, the food is good, but I'm not sure if it's worth the 1 hour wait! I've been to better brunch places and I'm not convinced the wait is all that necessary. I will say that we went on a beautiful Sunday day and it was nice to sit outside on the patio. Neither of the things that my husband and I order were out of this world. The banana french toast was really good!!

Just know you'll have to wait. Sorry I don't have raving reviews about this one. It's just alright.
author: LAIKA K.

description:
Located in an old schoolhouse in the heart of Cole Valley, Zazie is a restaurant that can compete with any in the city. From traditional French dishes to new-school twists, Zazie is sure to have something you'll enjoy. The decorations are classic, with French movie posters covering the deep yellow walls. Then comes the food. Zazie's Le Canard duck was perfectly cooked - tender and juicy - with Hericot Verts (green beans) and tasty fingerling potatoes in a mustard glaze. The restaurant's succulent Hanger Steak was  delicious, again grilled to perfection. 

For dessert, the Creme Brulee and Chocolate Mousse were the highlights of the day, each very smooth and creamy. Zazie deserves a try from anyone far and wide. It is a true insight into the sheer depth of the San Francisco culinary scene.
author: Garrett P.

description:
Breakfast is the meal of champions! (Or is Wheaties: The Breakfast of Champions?) Regardless- the former of these two phrases would completely sum up my mother's view on beloved breakfast. Not only is the the most important meal of the day- according to my mother, it's the only meal of the day and should be eaten for lunch, dinner, and dessert as well.

So taking my mother out to breakfast to celebrate Mother's Day was really a decision made for me. Fellow Yelpers- you did not steer us wrong with Zazie- what an amazing little place!

Zazie has a "small beach town place" feel tucked into San Francisco's very own Cole Valley. The atmosphere immediately put this small-town girl at ease- it's a comfortable, cozy, and friendly joint. It also has a local feel to it- which is always a plus in my book.

My mom and I arrived at 9:30 a.m. on a Saturday and we're seated nearly immediately. (I dropped her off, parked the car, walked back to the restaurant, and she had already been seated.) Mind you- parking in Cole Valley isn't easy...though it is doable! I can absolutely see why people recommend getting their early- as the morning meal went onwards, more and more people waited around outside for a table.

Mom ordered the special of the day- an omelette with apple-chicken sausage, red peppers, avocado and more. I ordered the 1/2/3 special (1 pancake, 2 eggs, 3 strips of bacon- which I substituted with sausage). Although I am not usually a breakfast fan, I absolutely loved my meal. Oh- and mom's potatoes? AMAZING. (Rosemary always makes roasted potatoes so good!)

I will not hesitate to tell friends and family about this place, and will certainly return with breakfast enthusiasts. :)
author: Annalise F.

description:
Sept 17 update.

Zazie is still our favorite for brunch.  It would be hard to do better in an informal setting.

Started out today on the patio in the sun.  A mimosa, huge latte, and  gingerbread pancake&eggs&sausage later, we stumbled, quite sated back into the world.

Ask for Anna, she is a star.
 
Our choice for quintessential, neighborhood breakfast/brunch spot.

Great food at bargain prices.  Gingerbread pancakes. Yum!

The staff loves working here and you can tell.  The place just feels good.

It is small inside, but the noise level is ok.  If it is not raining, sit on the heated patio.

On weekends, get there at 8:30ish and have someone in your party get out to sign the list to avoid a wait.  It opens at 9am and by then, there will be 30 people waiting.  Meanwhile you go park, which can be a challenge, but not impossible.
author: Alan B.

description:
Love it! Went there with some friends today for brunch.. The line was super long but we went on the list and went to the pub next door for a game of ping pong and a couple of drinks.

All of the staff were super attentive and friendly and the food was delicious!!!!!!! Would love to go back and try some more things.
author: Lital K.

description: BEST FRENCH TOAST!!!!! the bread was thick and fluffy, and the interior was incredibly moist. the outside had just the right amount of butter and sweetness. the whole thing melts in your mouth! the maple syrup adds extra happiness to it. i've been fantasizing about it ever since!!!
author: Jessica C.

description:
I was excited to go here with a friend last night because there a very few nice/fancy places to go to dinner in the upper haight/ cole valley. Unfortunately, I left a disappointed. I don't mind going to a nice restaurant and throwing down $50+ for food, but it needs to be good food. Zazie had good decor and service, but the food was uninspiring and at times inedible.

Patè de Volaille: chicken liver and brandy paté on grilled garlic levain - I'm not a pate fan.  It leaves a bad aftertaste in my mouth.  My friend, however, loved it.  To each their own.

Grilled Hanger Steak w/ mashed potatoes, green beans, and portobello brandy cream sauce - You can never go wrong with steak and potatoes.  The dish was good.  Very filling, but there was nothing excellent or inspiring about this dish.

Fresh Black Truffle and Porcini Raviolis w/wilted arugula, wild mushrooms, garlic, and aged parmesan - This dish looked watery. Never a good look for a pasta.  Needless to say, my friend who ordered this dish didn't finish it. 

Baked Chocolat Chaud- our signature "hot chocolate" w/ golden marshmallows - WAY too sweet.  My friend and I split this and we couldn't even finish it between the two of us.  The chocolate pudding and marshmallows were so sweet it was sickening.  I noticed other people who ordered this dessert didn't finish it either.

Decadent Vanilla Creme Brulee w/ fresh berries - I am picky about my creme brulee since it's once of my favorite desserts.  Zazie's creme brulee needed a thicker layer of crunchy sugar on top, but was totally forgettable otherwise.

Skip dinner, but definitely try this place for brunch.  All the reviews say that's the way to go.  I should have listened.
author: Lara O.

description: This place was a great find on yelp. Most reviewed and highest rated cafe in that area of San Fran. I would've rated this place 5 stars, but my delicious niman Burger that I asked to be medium was definitely rare and didn't look cooked all the way as well as the country potatoes were very hard and not cooked all the way. They didn't charge me which was great costumer service even though I was willing to pay for at least half. But the more I ate the more uncooked meat I saw. Everyone else's meals were excellent. I will come here again and get another Burger!(well done) their breakfast looks amazing too!
author: Skye J.

description: Get here early because this is not a hidden gem- 15 min after Zazie opens there will be a crazy wait for a table. That said, this place is worth the wait for us. The food is amazing and the atmosphere is exactly what you'd want in a brunch spot- friendly, boisterous (but not too loud), casual and fun. The best part for us- it's great for kids but still a place that adults want to be.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
Zazie is the least known best French restaurant in San Francisco.  Widely known for it's brunch excellence, the restaurant's dinner service has a much smaller, if not less enthusiastic, following.  The tiny kitchen produces a wide array of slow-cooked meats and excels in producing such Gallic staples as French onion soup, moules marinieres, & cassoulet.  Service is attentive & timely, and the entire staff appears to have been trained to create a warm, inviting atmosphere that caters to a loyal neighborly clientele.
A couple of pointers: if you are seeking avant garde preparation (sous vide) and artistic presentation, this is not your best bet.  Instead, make this your authentic rural French staple.  If you are overly concerned with refined ambiance that borders on snobbishness, stay away.  Oh, and do yourself a favor and request the back patio for your dinner rez; it is quite magical.
author: Tudor J.

description:
Zazie is amazing and possibly one of the best breakfast spots in the City. Since SF has some of the best food establishments in the world, that would mean Zazie is among the top breakfast places in the world. If you're been here, you know what i'm talking about. If you haven't been here, try it out soon because you're missing out.

The atmosphere is very relaxed and social and the waiter provided excellent service. On a nice day, you can sit outside and enjoy a warm summer breeze with your coffee and pancakes.

About those pancakes: Among many great choices, I decided to try the Buttermilk Pancakes with Fresh Fruit (Available as 1, 2, or 3- I had three). The pancakes are fluffy with subtle flavors, not too dry, but just moist enough to complement the butter and syrup. Actually, go lite on the syrup because they have something better. Zazie has a fresh berry jam that one must try on the pancakes! It's better than maple syrup. Regarding the "fresh fruit" aspect of the pancakes: The fruit includes sliced pare, apple, orange, and other fruits. Personnel, I prefer fresh seasonal berries (strawberries).

Overall, highly recommended and I will return.
author: Nathan E.

description:
I'd come back just to devour the French Toast Tahiti.  Oh so satisfying!!  Caramelized bananas on top with a walnut filling, drizzled with sweet, sweet syrup.  YUM.  If you're not gonna order it, that's fine.  But REALLY?  You're just gonna sit there with your poached eggs or whatnot?  It's your loss if you don't order it.  

What else is there that is not said about Zazie already?  The other items for brunch are good, not super duper fantastic.  I've only tried the La Mer and the New York scrambled eggs dish.  I'm actually not a huge fan of the La Mer, but a lot of people seem to like it.  The made-in-heaven combo of cream cheese and smoked salmon made the scrambled eggs dish a star.  I wouldn't mind having that again. Food comes with a side of home fries, which is typical.  But what I LOVE is that they give you cloves of garlic along with it.  It goes so well with the potatoes.  As a die-hard garlic fan, I actually wish they gave me a side of roasted garlic instead.  

So there is one gripe:  They don't seat you if your party is not all present.  Understandable, since they usually have a long wait list.  My friend walked away for a moment and so we got skipped.  But then later on, the guy who seats everybody proceeds to seat another group that was missing one person...ugh.  How shady.  He's an exception though.  The other servers there that I've come across are really friendly.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Holy crap. By far, the best brunch spot in San Francisco. I had the Croque Royale w/ prosciutto, roasted tomatoes, and a sunny side up egg. I wanted to write poetry to it and caress it ever so gently. It was flippin' amaze-ballz. My homegirl had the benedict... that is, until I seized it for myself. 

That's right... if you see me there, make sure your table is far removed from mine, because I cannot be held liable for random acts of food swooping. It's that good.

Sit on the patio for an authentic French boutique bistro experience. Take note of the cool little black pansies in the planters.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Wonderful location, great food, and good service!  What more can you want in a Bistro!

Went for brunch on a Saturday, sat out front, and enjoyed the view, the food and company. Sitting on the street we were able to watch the community and the other people waiting to be seated,  Very interesting group of people.

For the meal, two parties had cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd, bacon and eggs. It was excellent and a change from regular wheat pancakes.  Another had 3 eggs over easy, toast and hash browns which we also excellent. The last has a croque madame with hash browns, also excellent.  All had Kir's and coffee. It was served hot, the portions were enough for brunch and the taste of the hash browns, cooked with garlic gloves was amazing.

The service was attentive with the water and coffee being refilled without asking and unnoticed.

I would recommend this place but advise you to be prepared for a weight - have a light snack before you go so you will be able to temper the wait.
author: Bob L.

description:
What a delight!  I came here for brunch/lunch on a Saturday morning.  Located in the heart of Cole Valley, an amazing spot for brunch/lunch.  With a sunny interior with seat cushions, hardwood floors, tables for families, and couples; a back patio to enjoy your food in the sun complete with umbrellas for those who don't want to get too warm; and a front dining area on the sidewalk to people watch, I was pleased.  Although I haven't tried it for dinner, I imagine that the place dims the lights and turns it into a mood-setting spot.  Maybe romantic?  

We had the Fresh Grilled Tuna Sandwich (with tomatoes provencales, aioli, and sun dried tomato pesto with greens on toasted levain for $11) and a large size of the Gingerbread Pancakes (with bosc pears and lemon curd for $13).  I like to eat healthy/organic when I can, and everything that we had tasted fresh - like it had just been picked from the trees and the bread had been freshly baked.  Also, I appreciate that portions were not too large, so I didn't feel stuffed after.  Although it wasn't enough for a doggy bag (is that what they're called still?  take out box?), it was perfect for an afternoon meal.  I felt energized and ready to go after!  A nice afternoon treat is to walk to Golden Gate Park after - it was only about a 10 minute walk away.

Granted, Cole Valley is a residential area for families and children, this spot was a bit more mature and I didn't see any kids when I went here.  Which to me is a good thing sometimes.  Sorry moms and pops!
author: Naomi P.

description: Love this place. Came here for sunday brunch and even though the line was very long (were 20 names ahead of us) we sat down after 45 min, which was about how long the host said it would take. Once we sat down it was fast service and we did not have to wait long for the food. On that note the food was AMAZING! I am obsessed with poached eggs and I would have to say their florentine is one of the better ones that I have tried. I especially enjoyed the lemon hollandaise sauce that gave the meal some zest. Overall great atmosphere and delicious food but if you come here on a weekend make sure you have the patience to wait.
author: Adi S.

description: One of my favorite places to go for brunch and a real gem in the neighborhood.  The owner and staff are real nice and they make sure you are well taken care of.  The food is good and I particular love the potatoes.  They put whole garlic cloves in with the potatoes and It's pretty awesome if you are a garlic-lover.  I've been here several times and have tried the scrambles as well as the egg benedict.  I can't really complain because I really don't have anything bad to say about the place.  The cafe has a cute outdoor patio in the back which I love.  Be sure to come early or you will have to wait a century to go in.  I've always been lucky only because I come right when it opens.
author: Shirley T.

description: Loved this place!!! I went for dinner and got a Pre Fixe meal (one appetizer, one main dish, and one dessert for $25). It was amazing. The vibe of the place is super cool, and they have a beautiful patio out back (Mondays you get $10 if you bring your doggie on the back patio), and Tuesdays there's no cork fee! :) I've heard their brunch is delish...I'll definitely be returning to find out!
author: Melanie M.

description:
Yum is about the perfect word to sum up this place!

I have been here twice and the only downside is that its too small for large groups and they dont take reservations!

Im not a fan of waiting for a hour when i am hungry! 

This is a solid brunch place so if you are looking for some good food you should try it out!

btw: everyone raves about the gingerbread pancakes but i suggest sharing it with the table. I personally just cant handle that much for a meal.
author: Sangeeta L.

description: I'm a big fan of brunch at Zazie's. I absolutely love that you can pick out one of everything.  For instance, you can buy just one pancake! This enables me to have one sweet and one savory item thus solving brunch's eternal dilemma. Lines can be annoying but they kept the outdoor tables in the front open on a first-come, first-served basis thus if you're super hungry you feel some hope that you can take action. Overall big thumbs up and five stars!
author: Kristin S.

description:
Are you kidding me Zazie?
We waited for almost an hour to be seated, but we realize its because this place is fantastic. They were great at getting people in quickly, incredibly friendly service & the food is insanely good. This place is great for groups of friends looking for a place after a night out. Delicious mimosas!
author: Manda S.

description: The poppy sees pancake with lemon curd was awesome! I also got the poached eggs and chicken sausage which was very good but the pancakes sealed the deal! You have to try them. The wait to get seated was a little long for a late Monday morning but from what I understand thus place is quite popular. Once we wee seated the service was attentive but you could tell that they were busy and hectic.
author: Ramin P.

description:
This place is a hidden gem. Great food, good service, affordable price (considered that it is in SF), and a cute hangout place (outside patio in the back w/heat lamps).  You can make reservations for brunch/lunch during the weekday for party of 6-12 ppl (not on wknd).  Below is what we've ordered & our thoughts of the food.

- Moules Marinieres (mussels) - Delicious...highly recommended
- Ahi Salade Nicoise (make sure to request white boquerones anchovies...it complement the dish) - Delicious and quite unique w/anchovies...highly recommended
- La Mer (egg Benedict w/dungeness crab) - Good but you have to like crab though.
author: K N.

description: Great Sunday brunch selection!!!! Fantastic heated patio.  Extremely tasty food that begs for you to overeat!  Our server was a very cool hippie chick who made the experience 10 times better (so sorry forgot her name) by chatting with us about our mutual experiences living in SF.
author: April M.

description:
Came here on a beautiful Sunday morning just a little before opening.  Walked up to the the clipboard to put my name down and thought, "Crap, there's already about 12 parties in front of us!"  Little did I know, there's a bunch of tables out back and was seated along with the first seating. YES!

We had the french toast tahiti, florentine poached eggs, and mexico scrambled eggs.  

French toast=SO good.  They were stuffed with a mixture of mashed bananas, walnuts, and cream, topped with two caramalized bananas and was served with a side of syrup.   It wasn't overly sweet and the bread was nice and soft.
Florentine: I didn't take a complete bite, but I tried the sauce.  The hollandaise sauce was lemony and refreshing and the potatoes it came with were wonderful.  The potatoes also came with whole cloves of roasted garlic. HOLY MOLY.  And it was deeelicious. They use smooth waxy potatoes, which is what we like.  The eggs were slightly overcooked as the yolks weren't runny when they were cut into.
Scrambled eggs were quite tasty, but honestly it's something you can make at home.  They were scrambled with chorizo, bell peppers and some other diced veggies.

The food came out very quickly even though just about everyone was seated at the same time and probably ordered at almost the same time.  I was eyeballing the gingerbread pancakes and I'mma order them next time!
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
Welcome, Zazie! You are the newest addition to my Most Favorite Places on The Face of The Earth list, which is a short but sweet list. 

Thanks to breakfast being served on the weekdays (until 2:30 pm) I can avoid the hour long weekend brunch waiting list. I.AM.ELATED.

My four lady companions & I arrived around noon on a weekday afternoon.  We nestled into our cozy corner & pondered over the menu while sipping coffees, chai lattes & mango juices. French toast & eggs benedict creations can be ordered in quantities of 1, 2 or 3. I'm not kidding when I say this place put me in breakfast heaven.

The five of us ordered:
- (3) french toast tahiti: thick cut french toast covered in smashed bananas & walnuts. It is a must try.
- (3) eggs benedict divorcee: poached eggs, bacon, avocado, fontina cheese, hollandaise sauce: almost like a BLT but much, much better
- (2) st. trop: smoked salmon, capers, onions, poached eggs: my companions loved it (i don't eat smoked salmon)
- (1) fontainebleu scramble: 3 kinds of mushrooms, spinach, fontina: we all love mushrooms, so this one was easily a winner; so well seasoned & fluffy. best thing i put in my mouth all afternoon

Total: $85 (not including tip)

Every bite was more wonderful than the last. Even the potatoes (crunchy, seasoned) & side salad w/ mustard vinaigrette were something special. 

Our server anticipated our needs, bringing out plates & extra napkins & checked on us periodically. She was genuinely friendly & very efficient. I noticed that Zazie, in all it's French fabulousness, is larger than other SF eateries. I am NEVER in Cole Valley, but I have many reasons to come back now (gingerbread pancakes, oatmeal brulee, the avignon scramble & if I'm feeling particularly patient that day, perhaps brunch...)
author: Fancypants X.

description:
My husband and I love brunch, and so we've been slowly trying brunch places in the city. I've actually been here twice now--once by myself right after I moved (and my husband was still wrapping up his job in DC), and then a second time with my husband and a good friend who lives in the neighborhood.

The first time I went I was underwhelmed. I got the regular French toast, and while the bread was thick, good quality bread, it was pretty standard French toast. And I felt the same about the sides.

My second experience was much, much better. First, we were lucky enough to snag one of the window seats at the front of the restaurant. And the dishes I ordered were significantly more noteworthy. I ordered the scrambled eggs with tomatoes, goat cheese, and basil. The eggs were a bit loose, but this was likely partly due to the juice from the tomatoes infusing the eggs. They didn't skimp on the goat cheese (and I love goat cheese with eggs), and the basil was a great balancing note.

I also ordered the French Toast Tahiti, and it was fantastic. The thick bread absorbed the flavors from the toppings. The bananas were caramelized into sticky sweetness, and the walnuts added a nice change of texture. I'm a slow eater, and my husband remarked on how quickly I inhaled the dish. If you have a sweet tooth (which I do), this is definitely a dish to try. (The sides still weren't noteworthy, so I just ate the eggs and French toast.)

Based on my second experience, I'll definitely return to Zazie.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Amazing!  To not dine at this restaurant is probably one of the biggest mstakes you'll ever make in your lfe.  Everything is super!  The staff, the art, the tables, the wine, the FOOD.  EAT HERE IMMEDIATELY!!!  Mondays you can bring your dog as well to dine with you at their outside deck.
author: Anjali K.

description: Eat plenty of bananas before you come. The wait can be a little over an hour for two on a Sunday morning. Great food
author: Mark S.

description: Pretty amazing brunch in SF.  Came here ~10:15am on a Saturday morning and waited around 30-40 minutes for table for 2.  We went over to La Boulange across the street for a quick snack while waiting.  They were calling names for tables pretty quickly, but there were just a lot of us in line waiting for a table.  : ) Waiter was friendly and efficient.y  Once we ordered, food came a little bit slower than I expected, but it was fine.  We also didn't feel like they were rushing us to finish our meal, which was great.  Would definitely come back again but will try to come earlier to shorten the wait time.
author: Imee C.

description:
Service is great and great quality for ingredients. I like how you can easily scale your order based on your appetite.

French Toast Tahiti:  Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts    6/ 10/ 13
-Yummy. Definitely one of the better french toasts I've had in my life, but not life changing by any means. Personally, I would have liked more bananas or maybe fresh fruit on the side but I didn't doc any stars for lack of it. I think the dish is priced appropriately. 

Poached Eggs served on an English muffin with our fabulous light lemon hollandaise, with home fries or salad (made with one, two, or three free range eggs)
Albert: with bacon, white cheddar, and homemade salsa fresca9/ 12/ 15
- Pretty much this is an eggs benedict. The self described "fabulous light lemon hollandaise" is accurately named. It is fabulous and it is somehow light. Good flavor. Unfortunately the Albert part seemed a bit sparse. You have an awesome egg with awesome sauce ontop of barely anything... okay fine using the word "barely" is pushing it. But even to the eye it seems like not enough and the taste confirms. after having the french toast I was expecting the taste to prove the eye wrong. Not enough bacon, not enough white cheddar, not enough salsa. It was almost like they were trying to play the dish safe by avoiding having too much original flavor. Since the sauce was delightfully light the lack of other flavors seems even worse. With a typical decent hollandaise sauce the other flavors would have been non-existent. Maybe this review sounds a bit harsh. The dish was by no means bad.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Ok list seems very long, but just wait most of the people leave, but it was about a mile 50thars minute wait... we got the french toast and ginger bread pancakes... like everyone said on yelp... well those people suck because those items are nothing special but the egg dishes that came out looked very delicious!  We didn't try the egg dishes but unless you want a big chunk of very low flavor bread its way too big for the amount of egg Nd flavor that goes into it... pancakes plain too! Blah! Yelp you did it again and miss lead up! :(
author: Nick N Parker S.

description:
One of my favorite brunch places in San Francisco.  Slightly tight quarters, but generally, the lay out is quite pleasant, especially if you sit on the patio during a sunny SF morning.

The food is top notch.  Everything is extremely flavorful and it feels like I'm dining in a French cafe.  The eggs are great, but damn, that french toast has caused me to re-think the way I do breakfast.

And one has to adore coffee in a bowl.

The wait can be a bit long, but it's worth it.
author: Marcin M.

description:
My mom, sisters and I took a trip to San Francisco and we planned on going to Zazie for Sunday brunch. Although we waited for almost an hour, it was DEFINATELY worth it! They seat you depending on your party size, so a party of four took a while. I ordred the pancakes. SOOOOOO flavorful. They were not too fluffy, they held up to the syrup and did not get soggy. They had a slight chew to them which made them very delicious and hearty. The bacon was very good, also.
Cute ambience and a great staff!
Since we waited so long, immediately upon being seated they gave us a complimentary cream cheese coffee cake!
PLEASE GO and eat there! YOU WILL LOVE IT!
author: Jennine H.

description:
OMG the Breakfast here is soooo gooood. 

I've had their FRench toast and French Sandwich (Monseuir Conteque) forgot how to spell (excuse me)


My Boyfriend had one of their omeletes .. and it was spectacular.!!!!

We went in 10 mins b4 they were closing and felt bad. my boyfriend was saying lets go somewhere else, but i insisted him trying this place. He even admitted at the end that it was sooo goood... 

My first time here was with my sister and we sat outside, which I enjoy more because it gives you that feel of a Sunday morning Brunch =)
author: Sally Y.

description:
We ordered from the Brunch menu and were quite happy with the food. Croque Madame was delicious. The potatoes had a lovely golden crust yet were very moist on the inside. They were served with roasted cloves of garlic which I peeled and spread on the croque madame bread....fabulous! The other order of eggs benedict was also great.

If you aren't from the neighborhood, parking is a bear, but there is a muni line close by that you could use. While we did have to wait about 20 minutes, our order was promptly taken and our food arrived quickly and hot. The server was also very nice. 

I can't wait to visit again. Definitely put this one on your "To Visit" list.
author: Christine G.

description: I'm actually sad to write a mediocre review after seeing all the good ones. We chose this place based on yelp on our trip and it wasn't memorable. When we finally got seated ( a long wait makes you have high expectations I guess) we were treated to over cooked poached eggs. Lack luster chicken sausage and sorta mushy banana french toast. I've had better brunch places in Denver and SoCal but it wasn't bad. Just not as great as I hoped.
author: Pom M.

description:
Ambiance: 5
Food: 5
Service: 4.5

Deliciously satisfying for brunch.

This was my second time here, and despite it's popularity, I'm always seated right away.  The service was a tad bit slow for my taste, but it was still complete and they were always available.

I had the La Mer Benedict - two eggs.  My eggs sat atop an English Muffin and had dungeness crab and avocado.  It was also served next to some potatoes, and I love potatoes!  OH it was delightful! Of course had a glass of Mimosa which completed a delicious meal
author: Roenna N.

description:
Came here for a late lunch on a Monday, there was a wait but it was less than 10 minutes. 

 I had the Albert and a french onion soup, they were both really tasty. My friend had the oatmeal brulee which was pretty cool, never seen anything like that. The oatmeal is unsweetened so you can just mix it up and viola the oatmeal would be sweet from the brulee. 

Will definitely come again, this is my new favorite and its close to my house! I just hope I get as lucky as this time with the wait.
author: Anita L.

description: My favorite breakfast place! The wait on weekends can be crazy but the front outside tables are reservation free! I normally get the miracle pancake (the lemon is my favorite!) and a mint iced tea and eat most of my husband's potatoes. I'm not a big fan of the coffee and I love all the different mimosas. Your entire party needs to be there to be seated and I recommend getting there right as it opens. It's worth it!
author: Katie B.

description:
Excellent!  

Poulet Saute Grand-Mere
Fresh Black Truffle and Porcini Raviolis
DD's Mac and Cheese
Salmon en Papillote
author: Darrell R.

description: What a super charming place for brunch on a Sunday morning ! Lemon ricotta pancakes were amazing with house-made lemons curd, and French toast was made from challah bread baked at Pinkie's Bakery in soma.  Anna was an upbeat informative bubbly server who made pine experience even more amazing.  Try it out on your next carb day !!
author: Max G.

description:
Yummilicious. Most people comment on the brunch, which was good. Not great mind you but good. Solid. I'm sure if I order something more elaborate I'll be more impressed. And I do plan on going back to try more. 

The delicious meal was the dinner. Hearty, rustic, flavorful and filling. Lovely italian food with enough of a flair to be unique. Delicious.
author: Susie D.

description: Delicious food. Insane wait. I would personally skip the ginger pancakes next time but the poached eggs and french toast are ace. Great service as well.
author: Malkov D.

description:
Bummer they don't take breakfast reservations!! You write your name on "the list" (Tataki-style) and wait around (in the rain, like I did) for a table to open up.
The owner is incredibly amicable, and treats every patron like family. He even remembered my name when we left and thanked us for waiting in the rain for as long as we did, telling us we were "very loyal." Awwww.

Must try:
Mango Mimosa -- the mango flavoring is great, a little subtle so if you're looking for more flavor, I'd recommend the traditional mimosa.
Eggs en Printemps -- two poached eggs on top of asparagus, prosciutto, and English muffins, all topped with Hollandaise sauce. I would have ordered 2 more if I were there alone. This meal has been (in my opinion of course) the ultimate savory breakfast. Great flavors, the ingredients are all mild and complement each other.
The breakfast was enhanced significantly with a simple side of bacon as well.

Great hometown feel to this little restaurant. If you happen to enjoy the outdoors, they have tables out front, as well as a back patio that is fantastic for enjoying eggplant sandwiches for lunch!
author: Alyssa G.

description: My favorite brunch place in the city. Expect to wait for 30/45min on the weekends at least, but food is worth the wait. Amazingly good.
author: Christophe T.

description: I was really hopeful after all the great reviews we received from others about how good the food is at Zazie. Here is our experience. We got there around 7p with our 2 well-behaved kids who were exceptionally patient and we all were so hungry. They told us that it would be 10-15 minutes wait. There were three other walk in parties after us with 5-6 people. They were all seated BEFORE US! Then a couple of reservations walked in and they were seated. WTF?? It was 50 minutes before we were seated. Then we waited in our seats, 20 minutes and no waiter. I had to ask for one. She finally came over and remarked "good, now you must know the menu very well and can order quickly." We didn't appreciate her humour, at all. Overall, the grilled cheese ($10) was crappy, the french onion soup was like out of a can (6ozs for $10), the baked salmon dish was very smelly, sort of dry, bland, veggies under it was overcooked ($28), and the hamburger was bland. Seriously, my bill at Absinthe would have been far less, service would have been exceptional by this standard, and the food would have been outstanding. We will NEVER go to Zazie again. I do appreciate the progressive pricing structure and doing away with the separate tip thing. But the food is just too blah for the wait and the overall high price, especially compared to other fabulous places, tip inclusive as well.
author: r d.

description: YUMMM!!!! I had the french onion soup (standard french onion, but good), and my boyfriend had the miracle pancakes, which were to die for. They were poppyseed with lemon and strawberries.. sooo fluffy and sooooo good! The gingerbread pancakes are supposedly amazing, also. This place is small and cozy. We sat on the heated outdoor area, which was perfect. The only bad thing about Zazie is that every single thing on the menu looks so delicious that it's impossible to decide what to order. So I need to go back and try everything.
author: Kirby T.

description:
Words can't describe this place.

I've been back here 3 times for brunch, every time I try something new and every time I still want to come back for more.

Come early or come with a small party as the wait can get pretty long on the weekends, although I've never waited for more than 15 minutes. The tables out front are first-come, first-serve, so grab those if you have the chance.

And try the banana-stuffed french toast! delish
author: D F.

description:
So far so good. Arrived for Brunch at 11am on Sunday. Waited about 35 minutes, which is expected for popular brunch spots in SF. You sign the wait list yourself, much like Mission Beach Cafe. Friendly service thus far. I like that they give you a whole bottle of water for the table, even if its only 2 people.  I ordered the Lemonade, which turned out to be sparkling and tasty. Can't wait to taste the food...

10 Minutes Later...

Food was good, I ordered the Poached Eggs: Albert. I wouldn't go as far as giving this place more than 3.5 stars. I don't think it is worth the money that they charge. Maybe I need to try another dish? In all fairness, I'm not a big fan of Poached Eggs, but I decided to try something new on this occasion.  Maybe if I had ordered an omelet, pancaked or french toast, my reviews would be higher.  I will give it a try again and update my review.
author: Eric C.

description: Almost everything that needs to be said about Zazie has already been said by SF's awesome foodies but just know this place is totally awesome for people like me who enjoy a little bit of sweet and a little bit of savory when they go out for breakfast. Zazies graciously lets you order single items of their fabulous dishes (for example, one gourmet pancake, or one eggs benedict) This therefore allows you to try more and savor the restaurant in a more expansive way. For that, I thank you.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Headed to Zazie for dinner last week, and it was great.  There were three of us, seated at a tiny table, but the service was impeccable, so it didn't seem squished, because when things needed to be taken away they were.

We all ordered a variant of the pre fixe menu, and enjoyed our selections.  The sea bass in parchment was well cooked, the mushroom ravioli were delicious, and the mussels and salads were good sized portions.  The desserts were enjoyable too.  

I've had brunch here a number of times, and found it necessary to either arrive about 15 minutes before they open and wait to put your name on the list as soon as it comes outside, or go way before you're hungry, sign up, and kill time at Cole Hardware across the street.  The brunch is more reliable than the weather, so bring a coat if you're going to sit on the patio.

As much as I enjoy the brunch (a lot!), the dinner was fantastic, and it was nice and romantic and cozy during the evening.  We'll be back!
author: Kim S.

description:
I hate how 7x7 has somehow produced a ridiculously long list to make us foodies dish out more money and find a need to finish a not only inaccurate list of best things in SF, but one with 100 items ?!

However, as it may be inaccurate at some points, it got Zazie on point with the Florentine Benedict that has to be eaten in the patio, yes the patio.  

-Florentine - mmmmm, simple flavors, but all work well together
-Pinkies French Toast - French toast over pancakes anyday!

I used to think it was too hard to wake up for brunch on the weekends, but thanks to Patra B., that don't seem like the case anymore.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Zazie, what happened to you? You used to be one of my favorite brunch spots, and while your food is still delicious, your service - to be frank - blows. Big time. Your waitstaff simply do not give a crap. On recent visits, I've either been ignored for 10+ minutes before someone decides to say hi, or neglected by a server who needs four requests to replace a dirty water glass. My order is also often wrong, or it comes out on the cold side.

Food is important, but service matters too. I don't see myself going back any time soon, and this makes me sad, since  pumpkin pancakes are currently a seasonal special.
author: Beth T.

description:
Right off the bat: brunch at Zazie is really good, and probably among the best brunches in the city.  You should try it sometime.  It's delicious.

But brunch shouldn't be the main attraction here because the dinner menu puts it to shame.  How could you choose eggs and potatoes over roasted trout or hanger steak or the true king of the menu, the lamb tagine?  You can't.  Which is why you should go here for dinner  Also, you can make a reservation like a civilized person and not have to wait outside for 45 minutes.

In terms of food it's Southern French bistro fare mussels, figs and goat cheese, charcuterie, more cheese, duck, roast chicken, and the aforementioned trout, tagine, and steak.  Pair it with a good wine list and it's a tough menu to top.  It's well-prepared, very fresh, and served with a nice competent, casual style.  The patio in the back is particularly nice when summer decides to visit Cole Valley.

And did I mention the lamb tagine?  You should definitely try that.
author: Ted B.

description:
I don't know what it is about French restaurants, but I'm a sucker for their charm and delicious fare. Zazie definitely hit the mark in terms of my standards for French food. The atmosphere was quaint and cozy, the servers were polite and attentive, and the food was downright tasty.

On a recent vacation to San Francisco, we made a reservation for 7pm on a Saturday night. Upon arriving, I was happy that we made a reservation considering how small the restaurant is. There is maybe 20-30 seats in the entire restaurant, and it butts up to the kitchen which takes up about 2/3 of the space of the building. Upon being seated at our table, we were presented with a beer and wine menu, and we quickly put in an order. My boyfriend went with one of the local brews and I chose a Sonoma County Pinot Noir. We both were more than happy with our selections, and when the waitress came back we put in our order, which was as follows:

1) Charcuterie Plate- (Consisting of a paté, proscuitto, salmon rillettes, olives, greens, and a side of spicy mustard): This was a great way to start the meal. My favorite of this dish was the salmon rillettes, as the dish was more salmon vs mayo, and you could taste how fresh the salmon was. The proscuitto was next in line in terms of my favorites as it hide a nice spice to it, as well as a great balance of fat and meat. The pate missed the mark in my opinion, and normally I adore pates. It was really cold when it came out and got a little liquidy as it sat there, which was offputting texture wise and the flavor wasn't as strong as I would've liked. The mustard was also incredibly strong and overpowered any meat that it was paired with, which was unfortunate. The side of greens were wonderfully dressed in a house dressing and was a great way to cleanse our palate in between the other items on the plate.

2) French Onion Soup: This was your standard French Onion soup. It had a nice beef base that was well seasoned and loaded with onions. My only complaint is that the amount of cheese made it very difficult to eat, it was incredibly melty in the soup, but as soon as it touched the spoon it solidified making the balance of flavors nearly impossible to achieve. I ate about 3/4 of the soup before giving up.

3) Hangar Steak: We decided to split this entree, which I'm thankful for because the portions were more than generous. The steak was sliced into seven large pieces and topped with a cream based mushroom sauce. The flavors of the steak were great on their own, and a little bit of the sauce really made the dish come together. The mashed potatoes, on the other hand, were bland and uninspired. Luckily the asparagus that was served as a side to the dish were perfectly cooked and delicious.

We didn't have room for dessert, but they had a few items that looked worth indulging in. Zazie was a great find and a fantastic meal, so if you're up for an amazing French meal, make sure to hit up Zazie with a reservation.
author: Megan K.

description: Been here three times. Have only had brunch food, and I have enjoyed the pancakes (except the gingerbread), the eggs benedict of many permutations. Pancakes are delightfully fluffy with good texture and add ons. Eggs benedict is usually quite good but it depends entirely in what you get with it. The hollandaise sauce is pretty solid, and the muffin is toasted nicely, and the eggs have a well cooked white with runny yolk, but its the crab or smoked salmon that make it unique. Side note, chicken  apple sausage is small, expensive and underwhelming. The only problem is that so many people enjoy this restaurant and the wait is often over 1 hour even on a slow day. The staff are always friendly, but on weekdays they can be understaffed. The ambience is great and overall I enjoy having brunch here.
author: Lars B.

description: Worth every minute of the wait time. La Mer - Yummm, Pancakes - Yummier. I have been back twice. Indoor seating's the best. Didn't enjoy the patio seating much. I am coming back.
author: I Love Good Foo D.

description:
Zazie is very famous for their Sunday brunches but I actually prefer it for dinners (make sure to make a reservation!).
The food is excellent. Try their Truffles & porcini mushroom ravioli, it's to die for.
author: Alice G.

description: I'd been wanting to come to Zazie for some time, having driven by so often and researched it on the internet.  A friend and I decided to walk over from Diamond Heights on a lovely Friday morning.  There was quite a wait if you wanted to sit outside, but there were tables available inside so that's what we chose.  It took a good 15 minutes before our waitress came by for out drink order, then another 10-15 minutes for our breakfast order.  My friend ordered fruit and yogurt and I had Eggs Divorcee, and it was at least a half an hour before I got up and asked her if our food was going to be ready soon, because people who had come in after us were already being served.  She brought our food right away, and I think it must have been forgotten on the counter because mine was almost completely cold.  It is a charming spot and everybody was lovely, but I would have to say -- A for concept, but D for execution.
author: IVY V.

description: I came here with my roommate and loved it! Highly recommended. I couldn't decide if I wanted an egg meal or the French toast. Luckily you can order a bunch of things as sides so I got two scrambled eggs, a side of their home fries and a slice of the banana walnut French toast. Let me tell you the French toast was a pretty good size and absolutely delicious! I also couldn't get enough of the home fries. Definitely a must go to if you're looking for a good breakfast/brunch place!
author: Laura V.

description: Great food, ambience, and service.  A low key but lovely night.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
The first 2 years living here, I always walked by this place on weekends, too intimidated by their line to give it a shot. Then I started working 3-4 days a week the past 1.5 years and used that extra time to eat at popular places around town. Conclusion: best time to go here is weekday brunch for awesome service and no lines. 

You won't find more benedict options elsewhere in the city. If you're really into poached eggs and hollandaise sauciness you got to hit this place up. Also, if you're really into roasted garlic, rest assured you'll find plenty of melt-in-your-mouth garlic on the side of your potatoes.

If brunch and lines aren't your thing, there's always the prix fixe dinner menu. It includes appetizer, dinner, and dessert, everyday all-night for $23.50. No need to wait for Dine About Town for that deal. In fact, it's cheaper than DAT with no date limitations. Only downside to dinner: no escargot. Boo to that.
author: Victoria N.

description: Loved this place. Quiet and cozy. Small dining area. Shared steak and mashed potatoes and it was absolutely delicious. Wish I had a chance to go back.
author: Tracy S.

description:
Zazie was good but didn't live up to the hype (nor the line).  The eggs benedict were cold by the time they got to me but still pretty good. The buttermilk pancakes were fabulous!

I'd come here all the time if I lived in the hood.  You can avoid a long wait by using their online (iphone) reservation system.
author: T S.

description:
I like coming here on Sunday evenings. I've never had difficulty showing up about 8:15 or 8:30 and finding a table. The ambience is pleasant, whether you are inside or on the deck out back, under the heat lamps. The food is consistently good, often first-rate, and very reasonably priced. 

The Mediterranean Roasted Vegetable Plate is very nice. I recall that I find one of the vegetable a little heavy on the vinegar, but in general, the piquant flavors of this dish whet the appetite, and the whole is more than the sum of the parts. The mussels are fine; I don't know what it would take for me to be blown away by mussels (though Moulin Rouge in Monterey came close). 

On to what you should be there for, which changes with the season. On a chilly autumn night, order the beef shank on a puree of winter vegetables. Tender, juicy beef shank atop mashed parsnips (and maybe potato). The waitress raised her eyebrows when she saw how quickly I had eaten it. What can I say--I was cold and hungry, and the dish was de-lish.

Or you can have the Hangar Steak, the accompaniments of which change with the season. I had it recently with green beans, mashed potatoes, and a portobello cream sauce; tip-top. But the best time to have it is in late summer, when it comes with a baked tomato topped with cheese (was it gruyere or gorgonzola?). Somehow, the tomato, cheese, and steak produced an out-of-this-world combination of flavors. 

I hope that next summer the dessert menu also includes the cherries that I had one evening last summer. All I recall are cherries, orange zest, and a bit of cinnamon; perhaps there was vanilla ice cream as well. An exquisite light dessert--hands down, the best one I have ever had. 

One dish that isn't as good is the salmon en papillote, which simply lacks flavor. The lamb tagine is fine but not mind-blowing; perhaps I'm simply no longer a fan of couscous. The kale and butternut squash topped with parmesan CAN be a very interesting combination of flavors, provided you insist that they cook the veggies thoroughly. Those are two that simply can't be sauteed lightly.
author: Nat C.

description: Eggs divorcé were really good.  Mimosas are good.  Pretty cool area to walk around after or before you eat.  Parking is hard to come by in the area.
author: Ian P.

description: We came in with a group of five at around 11:15 with no wait, and waltzed right on into a table. The meal we had was epic, as we all kept saying to each other the whole time. I got the Un Deux Trois, which was the combination that sounded right. Usually I don't order pancakes at restaurants because I always feel that I could make them better with Bisquick. Yet these were like the pancakes of the gods or something, it was awesome. The bacon were smoky and a perfect blend of crispy and soft, I should have ordered more. Beyond the incredible food, the staff was friendly and the service efficient, whats more to love?
author: John T.

description:
There is no doubt in my mind that Zazie has to be included in the top brunch places in San Francisco. IT IS THAT GOOD! My three friends and I came on a Sunday at noon. Not the smartest move as we soon found out. We wrote our name down for a table behind already two full pages of names. We saw Tully's a few doors down and told the man in charge of the list that we would be waiting there. He said he would get us when our table was ready. Two thumbs up for customer service! After about 40 minutes, he peeked his head in the window and we were off with coffee in hand. 

The place is very quaint. It reminds me of La Note in Berkeley with the French furnished accents and posters but the food was way WAY better. All I have to say is ZAZIE KNOWS EGGS! Their poached eggs or "eggs benedict" selection was impressive with six different variations to choose from. I picked the La Mer with crab meat, green onions and avocado slices with a side salad. The poached egg was better than anyone else could make and the yolk spilled over with just the right consistency. Even the salad was perfectly dressed and fresh. Each bite was just heavenly, I was sad that I finished it so soon. 

I had a few bites of my friend's egg scramble and it was also amazing. I have a crazy urge to try everything on their menu now. Zazie rocks!
author: Julia T.

description: My crab benedict(La Mer) was pretty pricey.  I think it came out to be $13 for one.  BURNED A FAT A** Hole in my wallet.  The crab was fresh but damn I LEFT HUNGRY because it was near closing hour and I also did not want to burned my wallet completely.  Also, there is like $1.50 or so charge for each diner.  Will I be returning? Definitely NO.  UNLESS, I GET BIGGER PORTIONS OR decrease in prices(Wishful thinking).
author: Ann L.

description: Cute little French Bistro hidden away in Cole Valley.  Our group tried Eggs Divorce, Poached eggs Florentine and eggs en fonte (mmmm so good).  You are able to order 1, 2 or 3 eggs for all of the poached egg items (fantastic for anyone who is a small eater or wants a big boy serving).  The servers were very friendly.
author: M. D.

description: We got the La Mer and Une Assiette, and both amazing. Particularly the La Mer, a must get! Also, eating on the patio was a great experience, try to get a seat there if possible.
author: Gianni C.

description: Crab benedicts are absolutely delicious. Cute restaurant, friendly servers, decent portions, and worth the try
author: Brenda C.

description:
I enjoy breakfast with much enthusiasm. Zazie makes a damn good breakfast. that being said, I have had more pleasant dining experiences elsewhere, and for MUCH less cash.

my friend and I were feeling luxuriant and French last Friday, so we agreed to have lunch at Zazie. it was a lovely SF spring day - sun was blazing, and of course there was a wait. [as an aside, I really don't like the fact that the Cole Street sidewalk is overrun by inconsiderate people and their dogs and their strollers all standing shoulder to shoulder waiting for a table at Zazie].

I put my name on the list, requesting patio seating, and noted that I would be next door at Finnigan's having a beer. we finished said beer, still no table. tick tock tick tock - it's busy and a beautiful day, so I just assume the patio is going to be a bit of a wait. my friend and I decided to wait outside, assuming that the host would holler my name and then pop his head into the bar. he did not holler my name. he went to the bar and then scolded me for not being within ear-shot. I'm sorry, I don't like standing in a crowd of 25 hangry waiting people.

scolded? I am the customer. but not again. and that is for certain.
author: Rachel W.

description:
The heated garden patio decked out with christmas lights, ivy, and lion's head fountains makes me feel like I'm eating in a Madeline book--a Madeline book where we all get to drink wine.   

No corkage Tuesdays offer a perfect excuse to go out to dinner with that person you keep meaning to catch up with.  Three courses and a bottle of wine later, you're full, bonded, tipsy, and feel like you've had a three-star dining experience but only paid for two of them.
author: Dana S.

description:
Update:  
ugh - Zazie...I'm not docking a star from my original review, but I'm so bummed...I brought friends in from out of town.  We DID get seated in the garden - very nice.  BUT - I think they forgot our order or at least part of it.  Everyone's potatoes were underdone - which would be ok, but that meant the garlic hadn't reached full soft carmelization point.  bummer.  My boyfriends egg dish, which he's ordered before - the one with the cream cheese - was totally lacking in cream cheese.  

So he decided to comment to the server, who was kind and got him a fixed new plate, but tried to say, "yeah - we're just so busy on the weekends"... you mean you're so busy that brunch now is not as good as brunch at a different time?  I'm confused - are you actually saying it's not as good as it could be?  Anyway, when restaurants mess up, I wish they would just say sorry - be honest, not try and cover it up.  

We will be back because I do really enjoy it here...but I'm wary...
+++
For a nice Frenchie experience, I love Zazie.  The staff is just un-attentive enough and the brunch food is fabulous and decadent - each item I've tried has been perfect.  

I especially like that you can order the french toast, panckes and egg dishes with 1, 2 or 3 of the item.  So big and small appetites get just what they need and no food has to go to waste.  Also, this makes it great to share - order an egg dish and one challah french toast and you have your perfectly balanced breakfast.  The potatoes are divine with pan roasted whole cloves of garlic.  YUM!  

Yes there is a wait, but I don't mind as they move people through quickly and efficiently without feeling rushed.

So, why not 5 stars?  I have yet to sit on the patio and I think I should try dinner before fully committing.  The space is a bit cramped & can be loud as well - like last weekend having to listen to some guy blather on about his Mr. Smartypants thoughts.
author: Mac M.

description:
Let me start by saying this place is WAY overrated, and you're a sucker if you wait in line for their weekend brunch.  The food is good, don't get me wrong, but then again I'm not into the pancakes/french toast/dessert-for-breakfast menu that seems to be so popular here (I'm not a female).

Let me also say that I do not appreciate their $1 PER PERSON surcharge to supplement their employees health care. WTF San Francisco? Sometimes I think you're too 'progressive' for your own good.

In summation, the food is good (not remarkable) and waiting that long for food is unacceptable. Now read my review of Bambino's, which is 2 doors down, has comparable food, and no lines.
author: Damon K.

description: I love Zazie.  I have eaten here 3-4 times and ordered breakfast food each time.  It is a bit pricey, but delicious.
