It is very easy to find a seat with 1-3 people on a week day morning, but much harder for a larger group or a weekend morning.  (If going on a weekend- arrive when they open.)  The servers are busy, but friendly and helpful.  The coffee is tasty.  I really like that you can order smaller sizes of food- it is good for my food loving but portion control challenged self.
author: Christy L.

description:
It was a toss up between Zazie's and Mama's.  Since we were going to Richmond anyways, Zazie's won out.  Despite arriving with 5-6 people in front of us on the list, our wait was maybe 20 minutes tops.  Be sure to add your name on the list and have all your party members there btw.  You wont be seated until everyone is there.  We ended up getting a nice seat in the back patio area, which is by far the nicest seating area in the place.  The restroom is pretty cool too in that it's tiny and reminds me of being in the head of a tiny boat.  There's only 1 too, so you may have to wait in line.

The atmosphere is great and has a lot of flavor.  For example, there were two ladies who dropped a glass next to my foot who were talking about eating wild mushrooms in the forest.  Doesn't get much better than that!

I ordered  The Albert (White Cheddar and Bacon), with home fries, which I found to be amazing.  The eggs were perfectly poached, the hollandaise seemed fresh and the home fries have whole garlic cloves and small onions.  To drink I got the Zazie Spritzer, which is prefectly tasty for a pretty simple drink.

Highly recommended! 

Pros:
-Delicious.
-Good Drinks.
-Pretty good service (considering how busy they get on the weekend).

Cons:
-Took a long time to get menus.
-Restroom line (sometimes).
author: Hans -.

description:
After going on a long Saturday date in golden gate park, which involved going to the Japanese tea garden and around stow lake, I took my date to Zazie. I made a reservation by phone ahead of time but the only time they could guarantee me was at 7. I knew that they don't ever reserve all of their tables so I figured if we came early then we could still get a table. We arrived a little before five thirty and sat at their curbside seating until they opened their doors. We were the only people there and they didn't mind seating us right away.

The waitress got us water right away (which was awesome because it was a long walk). We were able to drink water and talk as we enjoyed the decor which included quirky photos and peculiar architecture. The people that trickled in after we did were generally older but in great spirits (especially after the spirits). The waitress came by often enough that she knew when we were ready to order and when we needed more water. The food came quickly and the complimentary bread kept the hunger at bay in the meantime.

She got the porcini ravioli. It came on a large plate so it looked nicely prepared but small. It ended up not being too small at all and maybe even a little too much if dessert is added on. I got the tomato fennel soup and the roasted trout. Honestly it was all ridiculously good. The ravioli screamed of natural umami and the trout had a super yummy crispness in the skin (also no stray bones). The soup was very flavorful and all of the veggies were nicely prepared. We also got some bread pudding for dessert and it was fantastic.

They were prompt about giving and taking the check but not pushy for us to leave so we could stay around and talk. Overall a very awesome experience and I highly recommend Zazie.
author: Stephen S.

description: Yes, you have to wait, but it is SO worth it. We had the banana french toast with the walnut cream in the middle, and I still dream of it several weeks later. We were also able to snatch up one of the front tables that are first-come, first-served, which made our experience even better. We also had savory things before (Pierre Noir benedict and Omelette du jour), and they were very good... but honestly, after I had that French toast, I just couldn't think about anything else and anything I had tasted earlier was wiped from my memory.
author: Caroline G.

description:
# 77 on 7x7's 2010 SF Big Eat List: Eggs benedict eaten the right way- outside in the cozy back patio at Zazie.  Luckily for us, we caught Zazie and eggs bennie on a nice, sunny Saturday morning. We came 15 minutes after it was open at 9am and there was already a wait, so get here early if you're not patient!

I didn't see the usual eggs benedict with the ham so I went for the eggs florentine (with one egg) instead. It wasn't drenched in too much hollandaise sauce, which I liked.  Loved the side home fries with roasted garlic, though it could have been a little crispier.  Lots of other poached egg options you could choose from, as well as other egg dishes, pancakes, french toast, soups, salads, and sandwiches. 

The restaurant space is a little tight but that is what gives it a homey feel.  The SF Health Care Ordinance charge of $1/ person is in effect here. And fyi, they don't take reservations for breakfast or lunch, dinner only.

Eating at Zazie sorta reminds me of Berkeley's La Note but scaled down in terms of breakfast/brunch options.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Great place for brunch! On a nice sunny day, get a table on the patio. Otherwise you can read the "take a risk" sign and sit outdoors with heated lamps. 

I recommend the fountainbleu scramble. My friend had the zazie spritz drink which was a mixture of mango and orange juice with sparkling water. It was refreshing!
author: Helen Y.

description:
I found it rather suspicious when I came here for the first time,  to see people hovering around this place at around 8:30 in the morning.  "Odd," I thought.  It sorta reminded me of that Mervyns commercial where the girl was saying, "Open.  Open."  

Needless to say with all this activity going on and this gut feeling in my stomach that this place was no ordinary spot, I urged my friend to get out of the car, so we can wait under the cold, gray, fog-filled sky of Cole Valley.

What a good decision on my part!  Before the restaurant even opened, the owner came out and brought out a sign-in sheet.  "A sign-in sheet," you ask?  Yes, a sigh-in sheet..  Trust me, I wasn't expecting to sign-in for breakfast.  So, with elbows ready to strike out anybody who tried to even remotely cut in front of me in line, I signed my name for a party of 2, waited around for 5 minutes and I was in!

Wow. What a darling little place this was.  And the atmosphere was cozy, as well.  The bottomless mimosas with Charles de Fere Champagne and orange/cranberry juice was amazing.   A little on the dry side, but it was good.  For breakfast, I ordered their Salmon Sandwich, which was also good.  I wish it was a little bit more hearty, because I found myself hungry afterwards.  But, what really won me over is the friendliness of the owner.  Such a hospitable man, he is!

I'm a little sad that this place is not closer to where I live, but this place is definitely worth the drive.
author: gEe C.

description: Is it worth the wait with so many great options in the city, I don't think so. My pancake was good but not great and the poached eggs benedict were just ok nothing special. I will not go back and wait for what I got.
author: Chris D.

description:
I'd like to give this place a 2.5 star rating if I could. Have been wanting to try this place for a while & finally got around to having brunch here.

Ordered their signature dish, a poached egg with fresh Dungeness crab on an English muffin. My gripe is with the egg -- I asked for it to be soft/runny and it was cooked more than I like it. Didn't want to disrupt my meal w/friends so I just ate it as is. Came with potatoes but I was expecting something more like fries. My bad for not asking.

A friend ordered the mussels which I tasted & it was pretty good. Another friend had the Niman Ranch burger & she said she could taste the better quality of the beef. Another friend had a poached egg with salad, no raves/complaints. Last friend had a generous stack of French toast with caramelized bananas dripping with syrup & I'm pretty sure he finished the whole thing. He ordered the hot/warm chocolate and although the cup was huge, it wasn't anything special. 

Long line outside on a weekday morning, so perhaps I need to try this place again and order more carefully. Service was good.
author: D L.

description:
Suuuuper delicious, I had eggs benedict and french toast - that french toast is a must!  The eggs were delish as well.

Pluses for outdoor seating.  I need to come back to try the gingerbread pancakes & all the other specials!

And as others have pointed out...it is a tad pricey depending on what you get.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Solid 4-star restaurant. Went for dinner for 4. Entree prices were a bit high, but no corkage Tuesday (and $18 Cote Du Rhone bottle) mitigated this. The (always) vegetarian soup was delicious, even though I don't like fennel that much, the salad was robust and flavorful. The mac and cheese (well, shells and cheese) was too soupy, but the flavor was there. The service was great and even though we didn't have space after dinner, we had the $5 petit pot de creme chocolat, which was decadent and delicious (3 spoons were actually enough for me!)

A good choice!
author: Ara S.

description:
The long wait is usually the thing that makes me hesitant to suggest this place. BUT it's sooo worth it.

I've had brunch here multiple times and love bringing friends here when they come to visit SF.

Their french toast tahiti is so yummy filled with gooey caramelized bananas. The addition of the walnuts give it a perfect balance to the sweetness of the bananas.

Their omelettes are always made to perfection with so many fresh ingredients.

Always check their specials. I once had this dish (I don't remember what it was called anymore) that consisted of a poached egg w/ fresh salsa and sweet corn w/ avocados and italian sausage all in a small griddle. It was to die for!

Coffee is good. Service is always friendly and consistent (even though it gets super busy). On a nice day, I recommend sitting out on the patio. They have heat lamps so it won't get too chilly.

Definitely one of my favorite brunch places in the city.
author: Hannah C.

description: People who think this place is amazing have never cooked in their life.  I gave this place a chance several times because people rave about it but I'm sorry, if you mess up eggs, it's all over, I just can't see you anymore.  SF does have a lot of great brunch places and Zazie simply isn't one of them.  It has good atmosphere and a nice patio (which is hard to find in to city) so I get the appeal.  But the food is meh at best, MEH AT BEST people!  I'm not gonna wait for 2 hours for mediocre brunch!  Every weekend, I glide right past the sheep who wait for hours for Zazie, straight down to Reverie, where the food is always amazing and I can always find a sunny outdoor table out back right away.
author: Melissa M.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better." - SOOO the right wording for this review. 

Well, "Meh. I've experienced MUCH better" is more like it. 

My mushroom and spinach omelette was mediocre (the salt and pepper I added made it taste so much better). Our mimosas weren't tasty or sweet. Ryry's potatoes were oily. Tina Y. and my friend's crab benedicts were cold! Oh man... how disappointing. And Ryry's omelette was only so-so. 

The only saving grace (regarding the food) was the gingerbread pancakes which were huge and delicious with lemon curd and poached pears. But sorry to say, Zazie's did not meet or exceed my expectations. 

Our waitress was very nice and gave us some pointers as to which were popular items - she suggested the pancakes (thank you!) And the host was nice as well... but...

Why the long 45 min. line? I don't know. 

The bang for your buck isn't there either. Waaay overpriced for average food. 

Oh yeah, and the kicker? ABSOLUTELY NO SUBSTITUTIONS. As it says on the menu. Why? Because the chefs are working really hard to make all the meals. Fine, I get it's hard. But don't you want to please your customers? Accommodations and flexibility, though hasslesome at times, are what make service at a restaurant memorable and enjoyable. If I'm going to pay for it, they should make it how I want it! Right? Right.
author: Christine C.

description:
We had a party of 5 this past Saturday morning at 9am for breakfast.  When our party arrived, the restaurant opened and started seating.  There's a back porch that seats more people with umbrella shades to block out the sun, which helped quite a bit on an unusually warm inner sunset morning.

I ordered the eggs florentine with 2 eggs (cost is per egg/pancake/waffle) and a side of bacon.  The eggs florentine came out like each individual piece was slapped on top of each other; my eggs rolled off the english muffins they were set on top of.  The bacon on the side came out less than warm and dry.

My friends ordered other items; Un, Deux, Trois pancakes, french toast... no complaints, but no distinguishing comments either.

Setting/Atmosphere - average/nice.  Outside and not many bugs.
Food quality - no screw ups, but less than average.
Price - far too high for the quality.  There are better deals elsewhere.
author: Benson F.

description: This has got to be one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. While the brunch draws big crowds and long lines, to me dinner is the highlight. All the dishes are made from scratch with fresh, seasonal ingredients. And they're delicious. Duck, lamb, pastas are all fantastic. Oh and the goat cheese cake -- holler at it. The most indulgent dessert you'll ever have. More importantly, though, you get the sense that the staff really like working at Zazie and truly care about the place. And that makes the biggest difference. Reasonable prices and  a warm neighborhood atmosphere round out the experience.
author: Gabe R.

description: Very tasty food, friendly staff, and so much fun to bring our doggie who hates to be left behind!
author: Ashley B.

description:
A must for weekends:

1) Do a quick drive by to slot your name on the wait list
2) Count # of people ahead of you
3) Multiply that number by 3 for the number of minutes you'll need to entertain yourself for.  Explore the neighborhood or wait at the bar or coffee shop next door.
4) Drive back and enjoy!
author: Christina J.

description:
Zazie, oh Zazie.  How do I love thee?  Let me count the ways....

1. I love you for your Gingerbread Pancakes with Lemon Curd.  Just the right balance of spice and tart. 
2. I love you for your French Toast Tahiti.  You remind me of a banana foster but I can have you for breakfast and not a dessert.
3. I love you for your La Mer Poached Eggs.  I'm a sucker for crab and a well cooked egg. 
4. I love you for all the different flavors of mimosa you carry.  I've only tried the mango and I can't wait to try the others!
5.  I love that you can order small/medium/large portions on almost all your dishes!  My girlfriends and I ordered several small plates to share so we could try more menu items.
6. I love your back patio on a warm sunny day in the city.  I felt like I was on vacation but I didn't have to get on a plane or in a car even! 
7. I love you so much I had to go back three days after first trying you.  You are the gift that keeps on giving!   

Not that great for large groups, but will accommodate just be prepared to wait a very, very (very) long time.  Expect a long wait on the weekend no matter what size party- longer if it's nice out!   I can't wait to go back as the line is worth the wait :)  My favorite new brunch place!  Staff is warm and friendly too.
author: Christina L.

description:
This is a sad review because I love the restaurant and love the food, but feel so strongly about what just happened to us that I cannot go back ever again on principal. I just ate there for dinner with a friend who lives a block away and has been a regular customer for years. 

We ordered wine, appetizers and two entrees. She had a simple request, she gets ill from asparagus and asked to change to the spinach which I had on my dish. The waiter refused. I asked why and all he did was pick up a menu and point to the phrase saying "no substitutions." I said that is not the reason why, how come. His snotty toned response was the kitchen is too small to make substitutions. Both my parents are chefs and I was literally raised in restaurants my whole life. I can affirm without any doubt that it takes no more effort to put a spoon of spinach on a plate as it does a few spears of asparagus.

Considering that the wildly popular EOS just went out of business a few doors down, this restaurant, no matter how loved it may be, needs to learn the lesson of what CUSTOMER SERVICE and LOYALTY to neighborhood customers means! A vegetable substitution is not a big request. But, let me explain to the owners and the management, that it indeed cost them a lot! Our bill was approx $100 that night. We eat there about once a month and sometimes more when we add in Brunch. That's $1200 a year they can say good-bye to forever. In addition, I have not stopped talking and blogging about it for days.
author: TJ T.

description:
Zazie is representative of San Francisco dining: it's a small restaurant beloved by locals, where the fare is always delicious, the decor is delightfully self-aware, and the atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming.  Having had three superlative dinners at Zazie, I'm eager to come back for their much-lauded brunch service.

Food:
The real draw of Zazie is the food; I've never disliked anything that has come out of their kitchen, over the course of three visits with friends who aren't shy about sharing.  French onion soup, salads aplenty, fruit crumbles, corn cakes, lamb curries, pork chops, and burgers with white cheddar - every dish has been expertly executed, and crafted from ingredients of the highest quality.  The flavors (across the menu) are marvelously nuanced - with every bite, you can discern the spices and foods that make it up, if you put your mind to it, but you find yourself unable to fathom how such simple parts can make such a satisfying, balanced whole.

Decor:
Cute, provincial furnishings, with lots of wood and soft yellow colors, hint at the French countryside, though maybe that tone is set more firmly by the framed French-language movie posters hanging on the walls, including a couple featuring the restaurant's namesake: the protagonist of a 1960 film by Louis Malle.  The key here, as with the cuisine, is subtlety: the design is understated, and avoids the heavy-handedness often found in themed or chain restaurants.  It feels cozy and vaguely domestic in the main room, and there's an undeniably romantic quality to the excellent outdoor patio (well equipped with greenery, strings of bare bulbs, and space heaters).

Service:
The wait staff have all been wonderful, every time.  Friendly, efficient, and attentive.

Price:
$$$

Overall:
Zazie is very, very good at what it does, and the only reason I won't give it a perfect five-star rating is because "what it does" is relatively safe.  I tend to think of five stars as denoting chefs and owners who take risks which pay off, and Zazie's team seems more intent on keeping the overall quality of the food consistently high than with wowing foodies with an always-dramatically-evolving menu.  That's not necessarily a bad thing, so don't let the four-star rating mislead you: I highly recommend Zazie for an intimate dinner (grab a table on the patio) or an evening with friends (laugh over wine and shared appetizers in the main room).
author: Will T.

description:
Walking up to this place, there were two French Bulldogs tied up outside.  I mean, come on, live props- how authentic can you get?! ;)

Seriously though, the service was great.  I was greeted and seated super quickly even though the rest of my party hadn't arrived... and the kitchen was about to close, yet nobody rushed us at all.

I had the black currant mimosa, I think called Le Groseille (served in great, sleek glasses) and the Valence.  Poached eggs, eggplant and a delicious tomato sauce over English muffins. Honestly the BEST breakfast dish I've had in at least a year, maybe longer.

We sat inside, which was cozy but nice.  I saw a very cute looking patio out back that I'm sure would be nice on a non-typical SF day.  

all in all, I can't think of a thing I would change about this place.  I'm already looking forward to making a trip back!
author: Michelle A. D.

description:
Zazie: my favorite place to have lunch in the entire city.

1.) Charcuterie plate (pate, proscuitto, salmon rilletes, olives, salad, spicy mustard, and toast)
2.) Mussels with an amazing white wine and garlic sauce 
3.) Wine, a nice resiling or chardonay on a sunny day, or a pinot or cab on a foggy day

With these three components you will have the perfect recipe for two people to enjoy a wonderful lunch.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Date/Time: Monday, 2:00pm
Occasion: Brunch
Party of: Three
Ordered:  La Mer with salad, Poached Egg Florentine with Homefries, and un, deux, trois (one pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon)
Location: Very small, urban - homey spot
Total incl gratuity: ~$60

Came here for brunch with some friends on Memorial Day.  I thought it was great!  The service is friendly and the food definitely lives up to the hype.  The La Mer is on the 100 must-eat list in SF.  It was poached egg with crab and avocado.  Not bad though I personally preferred my conventional breakfast order of the un, deux, trois.  The pancake was very fluffy and the bacon was perfect!  There was something special in the eggs that made it fluffy and extra flavorful.  If I'm back in Cole Valley, I'd definitely venture to this place again.  The food is very good and I'd be eager to try their other items.
author: Jess C.

description:
I used to think this was closer to being a 4, but I thought about it and it's a solid 3.  

The wait was about 30-40 minutes for 2 people.  I expected this, seeing as there's always an absurd crowd and the restaurant is annoying enough not to do reservations.

The food is a solid step above mediocre--my eggs were poached properly and the homefries were nicely browned all over, not just parboiled and given a quick toss in the pan.  It was pretty good.  My mango-juice mimosa was also nice.  My friend seemed satisfied with her bloody mary.

All in all,it was nice.  The wait (while not the longest ever) definitely keeps it from being a weekend favorite.  I'd love to bring friends from out of town here, but I shudder to imagine the wait time for more than 2 people.

Sorry, Zazie--you're not worth more than 30 minutes of wait time while I get a cup of coffee next door.

Ah, just remembered this:  13 bucks for 2 eggs + hollandaise sauce + HALF A PIECE of smoked salmon under each egg?  I'm sure with the crowd you guys have going on, you could spare another sliver of salmon.  Didn't really think about it at the time, now I feel a bit annoyed about that.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Backstory: When I was a graphic design major in college and tasked with designing a menu, I chose the menu from Zazie simply because it looked so amazing (even though I had never been there). I then spent a month working on this menu, drooling and craving their food. Torture.

I finished school and moved to the Bay Area, and -finally- was able to try Zazie... and it's completely lived up to my (obsession-like) expectations.

I've been there twice, and most recently I've had the La Mer eggs benedict on the recommendations of Yelp - fabulous. The crab, avocado, hollandaise, and egg paired together fabulously. My date got the Eggs Italie. I actually like the salad side more than the potatoes, but it's simply preference - neither were bad. 

We also shared a slice of french toast - thick, sweet, delicious, and went so well with the raspberry jelly served in the jar on the table. We had both lattes (I prefer creamier foam, but the rest of the latte was great) and champagne cocktails. Overall, a most delicious breakfast - I'm glad my expectations about Zazie in college came true.
author: Tracy O.

description:
My favorite breakfast place in the whole world.

They have the most amazing Tahitian French Toast which is basically two slices of toast (however many you order) spreaded with what I believe i banana butter? And carmelized bananas and walnuts drizzled on top. HEAVEN!

I also love their roasted potatoes (AKA homestyle fries). Their garlic roasted and its soo good.

And when your feeling like being in the holiday spirit (which can be any day of the year) order the gingerbread pancakes. Their GODSEND! 

Oatmeal had an interesting twist on it. It was a cross between creme brulee topping and steel cut oats which wasn't bad, but I'm not an oatmeal type of girl. 

There is always a wait at this place whether its weekday or weekend. And if your looking you can find 2 hour parking in the residential close by areas rather than meter parking!
author: Nathalie N.

description:
Had a pleasant, decadent Monday morning breakfast at Zazie today.

The place remains one of my favorite breakfast/brunch spots in the City -- bright, tranquil and comforting, while at the same time, busy and social. (The place was surprisingly busy -- almost full -- when I arrived.)

The menu (even for breakfast) is fairly extensive -- though I opted for my very predictable bacon and eggs (the comfort food choice I went there for in the first place!) A big, consistent attraction of Zazie is that the service is, almost without exception, extremely attentive and friendly. Today, I was greeted immediately when I arrived, then plied with endless cups of coffee during my meal. The egg dish was ok -- marred by an odd, slightly off-putting soggy side of Home Fries. A relatively minor quibble.

The place remains a favorite when you want to be a but indulgent - to step away from your day-to-day outside concerns for a little while...
author: donal c.

description:
I've heard Zazie is known for its brunch, but the dinner is not to be missed!

Dinner: I had the Poisson en Papillote, which was a perfect balance between light flakey fish and a richer sauce, but not so heavy it overwhelmed the dish. It came in parchment paper, sitting on a bed of spinach with perfectly cooked potatoes and leeks. Delicious. I also tasted the lamb, perfectly spiced and tender.

Service: very polite, prompt and friendly

Ambiance: I felt like we were in Julia Child's family room. Very cozy, humble and French. The outside looked magical, but alas, it was too windy and cool to be out there.

Perks: We went on a Tuesday night, and to our delight, that is no corkage fee night! They happily brought us glasses and we enjoyed our own wine. Plus, Monday is dog night. I couldn't believe that we can actually bring our pup to the gorgeous patio, get complimentary dog treats, and $10 bottles of wine. Wow. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Katie R.

description: This place is excellent, my foodie friend from the bay area suggested it and I was not disappointed. The chicken-sausage omelet was delicious.
author: Robert B.

description: Tasty food and good, social energy from clientele. Snarky host with a lot of tude. Great otherwise.
author: Hilary C.

description: Hated the long wait but the French Toast Tahiti was pretty darn good as a person who doesn't have a sweet tooth! The "La Mer" poached eggs were also heavenly!
author: Jen C.

description: Cozy place with a delicious menu- I wanted to order everything. Opted for the eggs divorcée and a slice of egg nog French toast which were both spectacular. Bloody Mary could have been a little spicier but the service is top notch!
author: Liz L.

description: This is an absolutely adorable little gem. My friend and I ordered what felt like half the menu and ended up leaving with gift pancake mix and lemon curd because everything was so good. The service was spot on, the adorable decor transports you to another world, and the food is amazing. Order anything, you can't go wrong!
author: Kari G.

description:
Been going here for 7 years. Poached eggs are delicious. Also, the waffles are to die for.

Only issue is the food is not really consistent. Also, they sometimes overcook their poached eggs and I have had to send them back to have them runny on numerous occasions. Also, they forget the garlic with their potatoes a lot of the time for some reason. 

Other then that, I love the place. Really love the back deck and mimosas also.
author: AM M.

description:
I've been here a few times since that abysmal 2-star performance.  I must have been in a really pissy mood because every other meal I've had since that day has been phenomenal.  The French toast Tahiti with the just the right sweet and tender caramelized bananas texturally went really well with the crunch of the almonds.  The New York and Greek scrambles are great for a salt lover like me.  Lunchtime fare is equally well executed.  Today, it was Croque Royale--a rich concoction of grilled bread, prosciutto, tomatoes provencale and gruyere.  It would have been perfect had it not been for the tomato slices that made the whole thing a little too wet and soggy for my taste.  A leisurely lunch at 2PM was a wise decision, as both parking and seating were both ample.  The service as usual is friendly, relaxed and casual.  At the end of my meal and after handing my empty and licked up plate to our waiter, I joked, "It wasn't very good, just kidding."  "OK then, no charge.  Just kidding," he quipped back.  

Will return for dinner.
author: Joc V.

description: food was delicious.. wait time for seats wasn't too long. i love the atmosphere in here also. cant go wrong with zazies! will definitely come back.
author: Vijith N.

description:
The brunch here is fantastic!  The best brunch I've ever had.  It is a definite stop if you're ever in SF.  

The best part about this place is that you can order by one egg, two eggs, or three eggs.  And then by slices of french toasts or by number of pancakes.  That way you can try everything! 

I had the French Toast Tahiti which is french toast stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  Those were to die for! 

And then I tried the Gingerbread Pancakes that came with a bosc pear and lemon curd.  The lemon curd is amazing and though I'm not a huge fan of gingerbread the pancakes were delicious! 

I also had the Pierre Noir Poached Eggs which come on an English Muffin and served with Hollandaise Sauce.   It was unbelieveable.  The best Eggs Benedict I've ever had! 

There is a slight wait but it's well-worth it.  You will not be disappointed!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
What a WONDERFUL experience. Our server, SO nice,helpful and great recommendations Thank you.
We were seated in a great space(next time outside!!looks cute)
The menu was wonderful,the wine list super good and the food. Wow.
Try the cheese plate and the salads fresh and flavorful
Oooh La La...great great great SF restaraunt experience!!
author: D P.

description:
This is the best brunch place in San Francisco!  The food is always delicious and well worth the 45 minute wait (which is usually more like 20-30).  My favorite: 'the Italie' - an egg scramble with tomatoes provencal, big basil leaves, and cream cheese!  I also enjoy the banana flambé french toast and the croque royale (french bread baked with gruyere, prosciutto and baked tomatoes- finished with a sunny side egg on top!).  Oh yum, hungry just thinking about it!

Make the perfect breakfast by adding a bottle of Charles de Fere with black currant syrup!  zzzzzomg.   

AND, sit outside if it is sunny!  No wind!  All sunshine!  Beats the tight indoor seating :)
author: Samantha P.

description:
Good service during our recent dinner visit.  Went for our 6:15 Saturday reservation, and there was a cute sign on our table designating it reserved.  Way more clientele came pouring in around 7ish.

We started by sharing the assiette de charcuterie, which was nice and great for sharing.  The staff was patient and attentive while we waited for the stragglers of the group.
I had a seafood soup, which was a touch cold and rather acidic, but the toasted bread and cheese was really the perfect accompaniment.  John had the prix-fixe, with a solid burger.  Tried his St. something dessert, which wasn't anything to write home about.

All in all, a satisfying dinner...but my friend said brunch is better.
author: Yushan K.

description: I wish Yelp had a "Like"button as all I can say fresh, fresh, fresh,it just does not get better.  Wish there was a Zazie in Los Angeles.
author: Shirley E.

description:
Hangry: when you or your significant other (usually any and all males involved) reaches a point of such extreme hunger, he or she actually can't talk or concentrate on anything else but the food that isn't in their stomach.

If you easily get hangry, standing in the hefty brunch line here probably won't float your boat on a weekend afternoon. But once you're in, it's smooth sailing. 

Two gingerbread pancakes (couldn't finish them, even with help from my own little mister hangry) with lemon curd and bosc pears for the win! Pancake syrup (and its plasticky nature) tends to bug me, but even the syrup tasted fresh and sweet. The mix is on sale for $10, by the way. Black-currant mimosa (pretty color a plus) to wash it all down. Standard brunch fare overall, but very, very well-prepared. $25 altogether, so it won't break your bank, but it's not exactly cheap.

Adorable, cozy, French-inspired atmo was perfect on the coldest day EVER. Another place I could live in, if they'd let me.

Plus: we were a pretty cozy fit in one of the front seating areas with the window seats. But it worked out for our friends' baby-changing needs and allowed the little one to squirm to her heart's delight. Those people outside must have been amused the whole time.
author: Tara R.

description:
Yes, the brunch is good, sometimes awesome.  But the wait can be ridiculous!!  Yeah, they have a new electronic reservation system instead of a clipboard.  But basically, its a clipboard, and the vendor wants to charge you for a fee for use of the app.

Most of the time when we go to Zazie's the line is too long, so we eat next door at Bambino's.  The food is not as good, but I'd rather not waste time on the weekends waiting in line unless we can run some errands at Cole hardware or nearby.

The food and service are 4-5 stars, but I downgrade to 3 for the wait.  Maybe others are more fortunate than us in terms of timing.  YMMV.
author: hew j.

description:
I feel all generous for giving out five stars all willy nilly but DAMN. This place deserves it. And as an added bonus to them - five stars and my 100th review!! I was saving that honor for something special and they have earned it my friends. Even though they are astoundingly awesome and popular and I'm pretty sure they just made it into the 7x7 whatever AND even though it was brunch time on a Sunday - only a 20 minute wait. I was pleasantly surprised...and almost a little nervous...and to write a fair yelp review I of course had to try nearly one of everything. Ya know. For research purposes and all. 

Down to business...got the Tahitian French Toast, Gingerbread pancake and um...what I kept calling the Jew Benadict. Because I'm Jewish and so I can get away with that and it was lox and caper deliciousness. And the french toast was with challah - even more jewliciousness!! And to ease your minds - I ordered one piece of each and shared the french toast and the pancake. It was still a shit ton of food but soooo good and worth every damn calorie. I should mention - the Tahitian French toast was described as stuffed french toast but that's not what it was. It was more of a sandwich with filling in the middle but really - big deal - it was still damn good. And another weird point - I got the salad with the single (!) benedict and the lemony dressing was fresh and kind of perfect with all the other heavy breakfast food I was shoveling down my gullet. 

And my last and final point (and a note to all other restaurants) it is fully, awesomely, amazingly fantastic that they serve things in ones, twos or threes. I have never in my life seen benedict served as one (or really a half I guess?) and it is like the coolest thing ever. It didn't cut the cost in half - and really it shouldn't since you're getting the salad or home fries - but it was the perfect amount to eat and then not feel guilty about eating a pancake also. And maybe some french toast too.
author: Sarah M.

description: One word, average. Nothing memorable except for the line we waited in for 1.5 hours (which we expected and has nothing to do with the 3 star rating). Save your sanity and yelp review for Sweet Maple in Pac Heights.
author: Jessie S.

description:
Good, solid brunch.  I think the menu is a little too skewed towards eggs (poached or scrambles) and sweet foods.  I'm a savory person, so I'm inclined towards eggs; there were many variations of eggs but I was hoping for a little more variety outside of eggs.  

Anyway, the food is great.  The line can be long but patio tables are worth it.  I had the scrambled eggs with mushrooms of course with a side order of sausage which hit the spot.

I was between 3 and 4 stars, and given the long wait on a relatively nice day, not sure if it's worth the wait.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Oh yes! Yummy french brunch food.  When we drove by, I missed the front because it has a very quaint storefront.  But when we walked in, it was packed and grew into this beautiful, cozy, approachable dining atmosphere.  And when I say cozy, I mean cozy- not to much space between tables.  The menu had so many delicious options, and we knew we'd try some kind of benedictine blessing.  We opted for the specials du jour- Eggs en Fonte (mushrooms, spinach, polenta cake, in a tomato sauce, baked with over easy eggs) and Eggs Divorcee (english muffin, bacon, avocado, fontina, with hollandaise) AND one piece of the Challah French Toast. I really like how you can order how many poached eggs you'd like - one two or three. You can really control your portions and order more to share! 

You know that feeling when you're hungry, but you don't really know if you want to eat what you're about to eat, but only because your stomach can't make up it's mind?!  That was me.  I wanted the Eggs en Fonte because it seemed different, and Eggs Divorcee because they were supposed to have good poached eggs on muffins.  That feeling of ambiguity quickly dissipated as I took my first bites of our dishes.  I was so blown away by the Eggs en Fonte!! That tomato sauce and the runny eggs were perfectly soaked up by the polenta cake.  Yum.  The Eggs Divorcee had perfectly poached eggs on a perfect crispy muffin.  And the home fries had a surprise full head of roasted garlic hiding inside.  YUMMMO.  The French Toast was what I expected.. classic, but still exceptionally done.

Friendly service and atmosphere, yummy, yet slightly pricey food. Worth the splurge for those special mornings.  Try it all, like we did, and like so many of the patrons around us. It was raining, but next time I want to see the patio.
author: Rachelle F.

description:
La cuisine zazie est délicieuse! I want to go on record saying, holy shit the French Toast Tahiti is the bomb dot com. Did I really just say that?? Zazie makes their french toast with Challah bread and stuffs it with caramelized bananas and walnuts. How could it not be the bomb????

The egg dish Italie, which consisted of scrambled eggs, tomatoes, cream cheese, and basil was less than desirable. I'd rather find a glob of cream cheese on my bagel instead of in my eggs. 

The atmosphere is quaint. The outdoor patio could use a few more umbrellas on hot days like today. My friend was getting an unwanted tan while enjoying the food. The wait is long on weekends and holidays, so get there early or be prepared to get out your iPhone for a mean game of words with friends. 

I shall return to try the gingerbread pancakes with pears and lemon curd!
author: Denise P.

description:
As I sit solemnly indoors procrastinating on my paper, I will dream of my birthday brunch a few weeks back on the nice sunny patio of Zazie. *Long sigh*

We came here on a really nice Saturday, which is rare in SF, so it was very exciting.  The wait wasn't TOO horrendous. Party of 3, I'd say we waited maybe 30-40 minutes...I don't really know, but it wasn't too bad as long as you're in good company. I was really hungry, so thus REALLY excited to order, maybe a little TOO excited.  The waiter just laughed at me while I grinned like a fool, but whatever, it's my birthday dammit!! I'll cut to the chase:

**French Toast Tahiti- Yes ma'am!! This was like a little loaf of banana bread with walnut paste. Really yum.
**Eggs Florentine Benedict - Yes sir!! I really like eggs, spinach, and mushrooms, so it was a win, win, win.
**La Mer Benedict - Meh ma'am - It was kind of bland.
**Gingerbread Pancakes - Holy! They are large - like a round fluffy little pillow, but delicious.

You choose how many slices of toast, how many pancakes, and how many eggs you want, which is pretty good.  Good thing my friend portioned out the food right or else, I would've ordered enough to feed a little family. :)

See, my glutton sinning continues...
author: Dolores L.

description: SO MANY good things here. Back patio is THE SHIT
author: Allison R.

description: Whenever I am in the Bay Area, I have to go to Zazie! I love their brunch. You have to get there super early though because the wait is very long. It can get up to three hours! I love their benedict. Especially the lobster. Only weird thing about the restaurant is the bathroom. It's located in the middle of the restaurant next to a table! I feel sorry for those sitting there. I'm sure they smell a lot of pee and poop! HAHA!
author: Denise R.

description:
it was worth the 2 hour wait to get a table outside in the back patio. Granted it was noon on a sunday, but coffee or some type of beverage while we waited would have been nice.
   Between the 4 of us, we all got some version of Zazie's incredible scrambled eggs dishes.  I got the fountainblue with three types of mushrooms, spinach and fontina. I was not impressed with the fruit bowl it came with, but the mango mimosa kept me happy while waiting for my entree.
  I ordered 1 piece of the french toast made with "holla" bread to share and it was delish!  I will be coming back to zazie's only this time will take the first available table!
author: Laura M.

description:
We went today (Saturday) around 10:15, had to wait about 30 minutes for a table of 5...went by pretty quick  actually! 
 
Quick and friendly service! Yummy mimosas, AMAZING gingerbread pancakes with the lemon curd and pears- It is the perfect combination, even better when you pour some maple syrup on top! HELLO! Fabulous french toast with a great orange essence! Definitely will be back.... for probably the exact same shit!
author: Bonnie K.

description: Though famous for brunch, Zazie is outstanding for dinner.  The outdoor seating was quaint, and great for catching up with friends.  Though I didn't sit inside, it looked a bit too close-quarters for my taste.  I had extraordinary ravioli (can't remember what they were stuffed with) and a really nice glass of red.
author: Conrad ..

description: The eggs Italie blew my mind. French toast was awesome as well...
author: Bo J.

description:
Zazie was super hyped up to me by a friend of mine...and I came in expecting a lot from this place.

But they disappointed on so many levels.

Pork chop and hanger steak were recommended but the texture was not spot on.  Veggies like the kale and butternut squash came too salty, and every dish seemed to be accompanied by...cabbage?  What the heck?  Why would I want a pile of saurkraut-like veggies underneath my salmon???!

Would not come back...
author: Jimmy K.

description: I returned to Zazie last week after having not been since the last change of hands. My brunch plate of Eggs Guillume was fine, but my Mother's dish of lemon ricotta ravioli in a white wine sauce was terrible. The eschalotte and/or garlic had not been cooked slowly to render their taste sweet, and the wine had not been reduced to rid it of the alcohol. The result was a very biting sauce of strong onion flavor overwhelmed by white wine. The lemon ricotta ravioli were indiscernable. Dommage.
author: Carol C.

description:
My boyfriend and I came on a Sunday after church. We used Yelp! to track down a good place for brunch, and came across this little treasure...

Positives:
- French Toast is PHENOMENAL (his pick)
- the mimosas were delicious
- eggs benedict was great w/side of apple sausage (my pick)

Negative:
- parking was slightly ridiculous, but that was to be expected

All in all: A+ food & experience
author: Ashley J.

description: Great food, great staff, lovely patio. Our favorite brunch place! Oh, & did I mention the build your own mimosas?
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
If you know me, you know that I am an eggs benedict connoisseur. I've had every take on the dish from salmon to crab to tomatoes.

I will never look at eggs benedict the same again! Poached eggs reach their pinnacle when they are prepared at Zazie. They can be prepared in several different ways, but the La Mer takes the cake. Imagine this; fresh San Francisco caught dungeness crab with green onions topped with a perfectly poached egg and the lightest hollandaise sauce you've ever tasted on a crisp english muffin. And it gets even better. The potatoes that are served with it have whole cloves of roasted garlic.

Look out because there is always a line, rain or shine and some people will take a long time eating their brunch especially if they ordered a bottle of champagne for their morning drink. You heard that right. Zazie offers a pitcher of juice with a bottle of champagne and you can get almost any kind of juice you can think of, even elderflower or currant.

This place is so amazing that I will drive from Burlingame to SF just to get my Zazie fix and then head back.
author: rebecca p.

description: LONG wait.  We got in early but the rest of the people were waiting for a longggg time.  The pancakes were delicious and the Morocco was awesome.  Will definitely be back again but be ready to wait for a table.
author: Tami G.

description: Amazing food. Definitely worth getting up early to beat the lines.
author: Cameron H.

description:
After 6 hours drive, we desperately need some good hearty breakfast.  Zazie is no stranger when it comes to pancakes and french toast, and so do I. This place is so cozy and cute, especially their little garden patio in the back. Breakfast was pretty solid and I'm hooked with the tahiti french toast, what's better than maple drizzled banana and thick breaded toast?

-French Toast Tahiti:  Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Extremely scrumptious... thickly breaded, sweet, and bursting flavors. I want it now!
-La Mer: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados. one of the best crab benedict I've tasted. the egg is so juicy, the yolk drizzled all over crunchy english muffin and non-chewy crab chunks.
-Gingerbread Pancakes:  with bosc pears and lemon curd. Not my cup of tea, too flavorless. I'll stick to blueberry pancakes next time. 

pics - http://www.yummycrave.com/2010/04/i-left-my-tummy-in-san-francisco.html
author: Monica W.

description:
This is a must try place. Very small quaint place. Reasonable prices and satisfactory service. I had the special called the Eggs divorcee. Pretty much like eggs benedict but with bacon and avacado. 

I think this a cool place for guys to go to since there were mostly women eating there...just saying...it ain't like Man Jose...thank God...
author: David W.

description: Zazie is bomb bomb bomb.  Savory breakfasts like the benedicts are bomb, tahitian french toast is bomb, but pancakes are phenomenal.  My personal favorites and the gingerbread with lemon curd and poached spiced pears, lemon ricotta pancake, lemon poppy seed pancake, and bread pudding pancake.  They're all very different but very tasty.  Light and fluffy pancakes that actually have flavor and are really filling, I can never eat more than two.  The breakfast potatoes here are also another fav.
author: Kash S.

description:
I'm devastated to give Zazie's a bad review. I waited all week to have brunch here and I was so disappointed! 

Obviously I was aware of the long wait ahead of thanks to all the yelp reviews. But generally the wait should precede, well, above average food... Nope!  I followed 7x7 and the waitress' recommendation and got the La Mer poached eggs and shared the Gingerbread pancakes with my party. The food came fast, maybe too fast... The crab in my La Mer was COLD! Why?!? It tasted like they just took the crab out of the fridge and put it on top of the English muffin. That just ruined the dish for me. And one of my  I quickly moved onto the Gingerbread pancakes with pear and lemon curd. YES! The pancake was so moist and fluffy. And the LEMON CURD!! It was the perfect compliment to the ginger and nutmeg in the pancake. Everything else my party got was just ok. Nothing spectacular and nothing we couldn't make ourselves. Although the pancake was good, it was not good enough to salvage this review.

So why the 2 star review?  For 7x7's stamp of approval, I expected more. For a 45 minute await, I expected more. For $17 poached eggs, I expected more.
author: Tina Y.

description: It seems that many of the reviews for Zazie are for it's stellar brunch, but having had dinner here I was blown away by each and every dish that I tried from appetizers to the dessert. Zazie is definitely a gem of Cole Valley.
author: Sonya Y.

description: Ate here for dinner. Food, service, everything was superb and worth the few extra dollars that we spent. My family had the braised chicken, duck, Nieman Ranch beef and trout. All were well prepared, seasoned, and delicious. Normally I wouldn't order trout but the wait staff said it was delicious and it really was. The trout also came with a good amount of salad, which was perfect for me. We also had the molten chocolate with the marshmallows. Also very good but a bit too sweet for my taste. Without wine, the average cost was about $30 per person. The four of us shared the chocolate dessert and it was plenty. Definitely coming back to this place.
author: Akiki A.

description:
Think about it, approximately a thousand reviews with ~ 4 stars. The rating speaks for itself already. Zazie serves delicious food, french style ambiance (not really french) and provides breakfast till 2:30 Pm :).  I just love the way they are up early and properly manages to serve amazing french toast & pancakes :) to make our stomach happy. 
I would first try the french toast served with sausage and eggs. If it is too heavy for you, you can just have pancakes. Their hot chocolate and mocha are served in a bowl. 
Since it is a popular place, parking can be hard, there's a waiting line and possibly an unfriendly looking service person since they have so many people to attend to that they forget to smile.
author: einah t.

description:
Been coming here for four years, finally getting around to writing a well-earned review.

The food here is divine... Zazie creates its own genre while still adhering to French principles.  Califrench fusion, I would call it.

Their house bubbly is better than some of the by the bottle varieties at other SF restaurants, which makes their mimosas and other juice/bubbly blends terribly, awfully, DUI-inducingly delicious.  But please, don't drink and drive.

Go for the elderberry. Oh, and note that the glasses for your mimosa blends aren't traditional (small) champagne flutes - they are much bigger, beautiful glasses in the Bodum tradition.

Speaking of drinks, if you're looking for a hangover-healing bloody mary on a weekend morning, you can get that too - made with Soju.  Deelish.

Any of their poached eggs will delight - over the past four years I've had them all.  La Mer - with crab, avocado, and their delicious, light hollandaise. 

Everything tastes fresh, clean, and hits home in the culinary gut.  

The service is also really good - which I define as:  attention when you need it, space when you need it, and pleasant all the time.  Pretty simple.  

Between Zazie and Universal Cafe, this tummy has all she needs for brunch in the city.
author: Jessie S.

description:
3.5 stars

The patio area behind the restaurant is a really cute place to dine for brunch on a nice, sunny day, which gave them the extra half star. Their eggs benedict (poached eggs) is good but not "wow" and their small OJ is SMALL. The weekend wait for brunch is horrendous. Put your name down and expect to wait 30+ minutes.
author: Tina T.

description:
My favorite brunch spot in San Francisco.

If you've never been, GO.
author: Anthony B.

description:
I'm not sure I'd wait up to an hour or even longer just to be seated in that precious back patio of theirs. Not sure if everyone knows this, but those two tables up in front are first come first serve if you want to be eating in front of the hungry masses. We waited exactly half an hour at around 1pm on a Saturday afternoon.

I would say that nothing really stood out about what we ordered - a couple of mango mimosas, an extra spicy bloody mary, eggs florentine, and salmon scrambled eggs. I'm not a huge fan of sugary breakfasts so we opted not to get the French toast or pancakes. 

I'd come back for brunch if I was in the area but definitely wouldn't wait even half an hour.
author: Leily P.

description:
Great strawberries pancakes and poached eggs.
It's really too bad the line  is horrendous on sundays.
If you want to go for brunch, go during the week.
author: Marcel C.

description:
Do you want:

-6 different takes on Eggs Benedict
-6 different takes on Mimosas
-Delightfully friendly service?

Then Zazie is your new breakfast/brunch spot!

We generally like to eat here during odd hours, so we can avoid waiting in line for hours. Sometimes even the odd hours have a wait, though, which is what happened today. I was slightly bummed about that because it was raining outside, but the kind gentleman managing the wait list brought us a delightful little freshly baked lemony cake to eat while we wait! It was still warm in the middle from the oven!

I won't even bother to tell you all about the food and mimosas, because both were amazing blah blah blah. I would like to mention that their backyard area is extremely nice to sit in when the weather is good.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I've been to this place twice now and have only one complaint.  The complaint (if you can call it that) is that I asked if my group of two could sit at a 4 person table, in the sun [i was wearing shorts on a windy day-i am, after all, an East Bayer] on a busy Sunday during brunch.  Understandably it wasn't something that was an option.  

Having said that, the first time i went they damn near comped half our meal because the eggs weren't to perfection.  Though they did take them back and promptly recooked them, with an apology and a smile.

The staff seems genuinely nice, happy and an all around pleasure.  

Love their bomb-ass brunch, especially while sitting in the back .  Just remember to wear long pants on those windy days.
author: jan s.

description:
I love anything French.  Hot dogs (or brochettes, in French), French Fries, and Brunch at Zazie.  Those Europeans really know how to eat. 

I love Zazie's little tomatoes provencales, which they serve with some of their brunch items, they taste just like a bit of heaven, with a spice of garlic!!!  I usually ask them to put a couple on my baked polenta brunch special, which I order, without fail, every time I go to Zazie.  And, they've got GREAT bacon.  Smoked, thick style stuff, worthy of note.

Service is usually pretty good, and I never feel rushed.  They refill my water when it gets low, they don't forget things or mess my order up.  I really feel like if they just ripped off the ceiling I might just feel like I am in the middle of a cute little Paris bistro.  

I have learned, though, from good and trusted sources, that to dine here on a Saturday or Sunday morning/brunch is equal to sitting in bad rush hour traffic.  The wait is LONG.  LONG.  LONG. I don't like waiting when I'm hungry so I usually just go here during the weekdays.
author: Jacquie L.

description: Such a disappointment after an hour wait. Cold eggs and patrons seated before us, who clearly arrived after us. I guess it is good to know the door guy. Last time it was great, this time was a game-changer. Normally I give a good restaurant two chances when they have a one-off situation however, this is it for Zazie. The waitress was fabulous, kind and apologetic but not enough for me to put up with the other behaviors again.
author: Stacy L.

description:
This place was recommended by many and after checking out the yelp reviews my boyfriend and I decided to venture out for Sunday brunch.  We were prepared for the long wait so when we arrived we weren't surprised to find a mass of people outside the restaurant.  Parking was tough but after a several laps we were gifted by the parking gods.

Many of the reviews raved about the Gingerbread Pancakes and Tahitian French Toast so we had to give those items a try, however, my boyfriend and I are very savory breakfast people who need our morning eggs so we also ordered the Le Mer - poached eggs, dungeness crab, avocado and hollandaise sauce.  All were very good but by the end we really wanted more of the Le Mer.

Verdict (1 being the best):  #1 - Le Mer (the other poached eggs selections looked amazing as well)
#2 - Tahitian French Toast
#3 - Gingerbread Pancakes

I definitely want to go back to try the prosciutto and tomatoes poached egg...mmmm.
author: Becca L.

description:
A favorite place of mine for brunch or just dining alone in SF. The outdoor seating is super cute!

I always get Un, Deux, Trois (One buttermilk pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon) , mocha and OJ. The French Toast Tahiti is exceptional. The French Hard Cider is quite good. 

I have also been here for dinner which was good as well.

The only con is that it is a small place, so be prepared to wait at least 30 min.
author: Jo'an R.

description:
I love Zazie. It's our favorite neighborhood restaurant. We've had a great meal every time we go.

I love the vegetarian soups, the spinach and walnut salad, the ravioli, the wines, the desserts, everything. Great service, great atmosphere.
author: Leo B.

description:
Really cute place in a quiet neighborhood.  The staff is very friendly & helpful.  I was able to eat lunch outside on the back patio where there was plenty of sunshine.

The food was very good!  I had the Fresh Grilled Tuna Sandwich, which was above average.  I also had the Provencale Fish Soup (with croutons, rouille, and swiss cheese), which was divine!

The only "negative" I would have to say is that they have the smallest bathroom in all of the Bay Area!  Nice and clean...just super small!

All in all, a great place I would recommend to anyone.
author: Austin C.

description: I've been meaning to try Zazie for a long time, but was always intimidated by the wait.  I finally went and thought it lived up to the hype.  Waited about 35 minutes for first available and then got a table inside (where it was a bit warm).  The service was very efficient and friendly.  We ordered what the server recommended - La Mer Benedict (crab), and ginger bread pancakes with lemon curd.  Both were excellent.  I also loved the option of ordering one, two or three egg omelettes and benedicts, and one, two or three pancake portions.   I noticed many tables trying out a variety of the dishes because they could order smaller portions of each.  Next time that's what we'll do!
author: Vivian W.

description: I used to live right around the corner and had many SF brunches here with friends and family. While Zazie is well-known for it's brunches, my boyfriend and I also really loved having dinner here (the wait is usually much shorter for dinner than the brunch). This is one of my favorite restaurants and the service cannot be beat. I miss you Zazie!! Please open a restaurant in Philly!
author: Laura J.

description:
The best thing about SF is that no matter what SF to which you refer, it is still so utterly SF that it amazes you. The mission is so distinct from downtown and downtown is so distinct from haight-ashbury, but all are undeniably so SF at the same time. 

When I arrived at Cole and Pamassus, it was the darling-ist thing I had seen in SF for a very long time, so different from my daily routines in SF yet so SF at the same time. A dear friend had dragged me out of bed to take me to this French cafe he had to go to because his mind was so set on it. Wanting to take advantage of this opportunity to not have to make any decisions for the next couple of hours, I jumped at the opportunity to take a little Monday morning adventure with him.

As luck would have it, he brought me to Zazie. I still think about who I can take there next till this day. The french toast was so delicious and the tomato basil bagel was unbelievably fresh. My friend had the eggs benedicts, and I think it was the fastest I had ever seen him eat.

Go there on a beautiful sunny day for the best experience, but just go!
author: Crystal Y.

description:
Well, I don't know if our experience was typical, but four out of five of us were served cold food this morning. It was a packed place, which is normal, but I still thought the service was a bit slower than expected. 

However, when we mentioned the cold food, they did bring us warmer items, and they even comped our mimosas. Given that, I'll try it again sometime.
author: Jason F.

description:
One Hour and Twenty Minute wait for Brunch.  Ridiculous.  While the food is great, I HATE waiting.  If the wait wasn't that bad, I would easily give it 4 stars.  Patience is not my virtue.  What can i say?

I had the La Mer (poached eggs, hand-picked crab, avocado, and lemon hollandaise sauce).  I opted for 3 eggs which came out to a whopping $21 dollars.  Pricey.  Good dish, but not too memorable.  

After the long wait, my hunger was out of control.  I also shared another order of French Toast Tahini and Croque Royale with my friend.  The French toast was delicious.  It was so big it reminded me of the brick toasts I would usually get at tea houses/boba shops.  The Croque Royale was good, especially with the gruyere, but I tried my friend's Croque Madame and that was one of the best Croque Madame's I have had.  

If I were to brave the treacherous wait in the rain and cold again, I would order a Croque Madame and French Toast Tahini.  Skip the Chai Tea by the way; it is a little bland.
author: Bert N.

description:
Wow, i guess i don't get out much. Thank goodness for my obsession w/ the 7X7 list as it brought me here - to apparantly one of the most popular brunch spots in the city! We lucked out as we had a wednesday day off, ended up missing our normal polk st bikram class so had to come over to the haight AND even though it rained yesterday today was warm and sunny so my hubby suggested trying zazie and getting something checked off the list. Well... we can eat out on the patio! so we went. 
OMG the eggs benedict was amazing. And the amazing thing is I've never, and I mean never liked hollandaise sauce ever in my life. So my hubby ordered and i thought I'd take a tiny bite - i ended up wishing I'd ordered it instead of my dish (scrambled eggs w/ spinach, mushrooms and cheese, still good). 
But my favorite item was irish oats with bananas and creme brule!!!!! I may just end up trying to learn how to make creme brule so I can attempt to toss it in some oatmeal at home. Delish. I definitely hope I can go back again for more treats.
author: Audrey V.

description:
Zazie is a great brunch choice for the following reasons:
1) Outdoor seating 
2) Offers the flexibility to customize breakfast entree (Depending on your appetite, you can order 1, 2 or 3 pancakes, french toasts or eggs benedicts)
3) Excellent service
4) Tasty food

Because I was forewarned about the popularity of this place and the long wait on weekends, I decided to come check out Zazie during my day off last week. Even though it was a Tuesday morning, the outdoor patio was packed w/ diners! My waitress was friendly and efficient. I devoured the pumpkin pancakes and la mar eggs benedict. Very tasty!

Overall, a great spot for brunch. However, I'm not sure this would be worth the wait on a weekend since parking can be difficult in this area and there are other equally great brunch options closer to my neighborhood.
author: Alice W.

description:
Found out about Zazie through an article about the best brunch places in the city. Mama's was still on top of my list but Zazie was higher up on that list and made me pay attention.

Dragged my friend here one Sunday and, despite the number of people waiting outside, was seated instantly. It helps to have a small party.

We were promptly given water and told the specials, which were mostly scrambled eggs. My friend tried the special while I tried the Fontainebleau, which was amazing! The eggs were cooked just right. It wasn't too runny but not well done either. And man, they did not skimp on the mushrooms! My plate was so full of food, I couldn't decide what to eat next. Of course, the first thing gone was the egg and mushroom. :D

I love the neverending coffee and I love the cozy atmosphere of the place. It's a little French bistro that feels so open and comfortable. 

I went back again and tried the French Toast Tahiti. Omigoodness. The bread was fluffy, the caramelized bananas were soft enough that it's still quite firm and the walnut paste was filled with so many walnuts! 

Zazie is such a nice place in a quiet neighborhood. You'll actually want to come in everyday and stay there all day.
author: Jaclyn A.

description:
THE SHORT STORY
If you want to be stolen from, disrespected/ignored, and eat food that servers stick their fingers in, run to Zazie.

THE NOVEL
Extremely rude and indifferent service from three different people. Also, DISHONEST - THESE PEOPLE ADDED THEIR OWN TIP ONTO MY CREDIT CARD SLIP. Had to dispute the tip amount through my credit card company. This is a matter of principle for me b/c frankly, it is a waste of my time to be making calls and faxing receipts over a small amount but I am appalled by this unethical behavior on Zazie's part.

Rudeness #1: I was accused by the host of adding my name to the top of the wait list. Our party of 2 put our name on the waiting list (wait at 10:45AM weekday was about 30 minutes). I had to move the car, and when I got back, I checked the list and thought our name had already been crossed off. I started to write my name again, saw that we were still on the list, stopped, put the list+pen back down, and then the host came, got the list, and called our name. I guess since he saw me with the pen just before he called our name, he was confused, but he was very rude - no smile, just an accusation that we jumped the line. I felt uncomfortable as I explained that I had just gotten back from moving our car. I then asked him if the spot I snagged directly in front of him was an ok spot (I'm new to SF driving), and he dismissively stated, "I can't help." WHOA -   So we're off to a bad start before even being seated. Then we get the worst seat in the house - small, right next to the door, too drafty for my 82 year old grandmother. But the host has already left.

Rudeness #2: I snag down a server's attention (not our server b/c he hasn't introduced himself yet despite our being seated for 15 minutes). This server refused to reseat us to the table front of us, away from the door's breeze. The man I asked just curtly said no, that table was intended for three people (vs. our two). I can understand that, but he wouldn't reseat us to another two-person table, despite there being two available tables. Keep in mind, we had not received our food yet, so this would have involved minimal effort on their part. I was close to leaving right then, but this place was my grandmother's choice for new brunch place to try.

Rudeness #3: We received NO SERVICE WHATSOEVER from our waiter. We were there for 90 minutes (from the moment we sat down to our drafty table to the moment I stalked out after paying) and the waiter came to our table ONLY TWICE - once to take our order and once to drop off the bill. My water glass remained unfilled for over an hour, and we only got our bill because I walked to the back and requested it from the host. The waiter never smiled at us during these two brief encounters.

Other Disgusting Behavior: I saw another server put his finger in someone else's food. The bathroom is right next to the kitchen and the serving station (gross), and as I stood waiting for the bathroom, one of the servers picked up a plate and his fingers were clearly in the eggs on that plate. Keep in mind I just saw that server handling money earlier. How unsanitary. 

Finally, I was so fed up over everything that I decided to let my money do the talking. I left a one-cent tip on my credit card slip. I have never, ever stiffed on a tip b/c I was a server for years - I know people raise their family off of tips. But this experience was too unpleasant. My grandmother, who had so looked forward to trying Zazie, had a terrible time, and said this restaurant was the worst dining experience she's had in 82 years.

Even after all of this, I was not going to write a negative Yelp review. But then I discovered their unethical behavior. 

******************Dishonesty #1: Weeks later, upon reviewing my credit card bill, I discovered someone decided to add their own tip to my credit card slip. The total I was charged did not reconcile with what I authorized. I was and still am enraged. I disputed the charge through my credit card company, and I have filed a complaint to the credit card processor.**************************************************************

Dishonesty #2: Their dishonesty with the tip leads me to believe that they are dishonest in general. The table next to ours received a bill that had several drinks on it that they did not order. They complained, and the server apologized. At the time, I assumed it was an honest mistake, but who knows? Too many coincidences. Notably, that table and I shared the same server.
author: B B.

description: I've been to Zazie for brunch a few times. This weekend, I tried it for dinner for the first time. Although all of my experiences were pretty good, my dinner experience was superb. Zazie takes reservations for dinner, which vastly improved the entire ordeal. The restaurant has a quaint, charming feel in the evenings. I enjoyed the pork chop, while my dinner companion had the hanger steak. Both meals were served promptly with great presentation. I have to recommend the pork chop for anyone that doesn't know what to order. It was delicious. We also ordered the Creme Broulee for dessert, which was fantastic. I truly have nothing constructive to say, the entire experience was top-notch. If you dine here, allow yourself two hours. You won't be able to eat here quickly, but the experience is so good that you won't mind.
author: Greg B.

description:
I had their St Tropez benedict and gingerbread pancakes. St Trop. was too salty with the smoked salmon + capers + sauce,  though, potatoes on side were nice. Pancakes were delicious, a lil' bit an OD on the rich-sweet scale from the lemon curd, but I liked it (bf didn't). Service and ambiance were both great. 

-1 star for price; all items are seriously overpriced. Over $40 for breakfast for two (2 breakfast plates + side of pancakes), w/o booz, I'd expect my benedict to not taste like salt.
author: Sara S.

description:
we give them 1 1/2 stars.... they were bad but not epic bad..

Cute quaint little restaurant, friendly service, pretty good tea (a tad pricey thou, but they do give you a whole little teapot to yourself)

as for food.... we were very very disappointed... we came with hungry stomachs and high hopes.... and left bloated and grease feeling like crap.... i really wanted to like the place.

we came for lunch (very late breakfast for us)
we shared the croque monsieur, the french onion soup, and the Mediterranean platter
both the croque monsieur and the soup had way way tooo much gruyere for the two dishes....they were smothered in gruyere... i like brie but not THAT much.....after we had scrapped about half a pound of cheese off the two dishes...we were yet disappointed... we found the food underneath to be uninspired and bland and still cheesy and greasy. 
As for the veggie plate, the grilled tomatoes and mushrooms were pretty good, but a tad oily.

looking around everyone else was eating eggs(breakfast dishes), maybe lunch is not their forte.......but we'll never find out.
author: Tara B.

description: Breakfast service was great with cheerful staff and promptly refilled coffee mugs. I really enjoyed their strong and flavorful coffee. I had their decaf and some other places make it weak, but this place it has a bold flavor. I had one item off their holiday brunch menu (challah bread pudding), and it was ok. Somehow I expected it to be more eggy than the mushy. Though it was flavorful. My friend had the New York style scramble and he enjoyed it. A little bit pricier than other places, but the ambiance, service, and good coffee make it a worthwhile alternative.
author: Matt L.

description: Overpriced and overrated. I really don't get these reviews? Must I be the one dissent? I went there during bay to breakers with a friend also vegetarian, signed on the list, waited in a long line, got skipped over so I jumped in the front first come first serve tables before the staff could even clear the plates for what? paid $60 bucks for eggs and toast and i'm having a hard time remembering it was that forgettable..umm the vegetarian egg dish auvergne? and the vegetarian sandwich with aubergine and goat cheese? priciest smallest mimosas ever. Even the people next to us commented on the let down. So disappointing. I feel sorry for the cole valley folks if this is the best you guys got. I didn't see anything on the menu to die for I had the choice between a salad, a sandwich, eggs or french toast. Go to dotties it is has way more variety, interesting, tasty and relatively inexpensive offerings for brunch.
author: Onika C.

description:
This is a Vegetarian Review.

Zazie Brunch in one word:  Meh.

The Details:  I'd heard about Zazie awhile ago, and had tried to visit once before.  But they were under construction back then and so we were forced to try again.  Went today after perusing Yelp reviews for the best options and had the Tahiti French Toast and Greek Scramble with home fries and wheat toast.

Tahiti French Toast:  Quite tasty.  Smallish portion in the two piece (medium) option, but enough to get a good taste.  I've had better french toast in the city (Brenda's, Dottie's...), and this one did not "Wow" me.  My gf felt the same.

Greek Scramble:  The eggs were fine, but not abundant.  The toast was toast.  The best thing was the potatoes, which featured whole roasted garlic cloves (still in skin, so be aware).  This entree was definitely nothing spectacular, but the eggs were soft and overall it was pleasant enough.

Coffee:  Oh lordy, what horrid coffee!  I haven't had their espresso drinks, but having had their regular coffee I would definitely recommend having something other than that.  Uck.  There's not enough sugar and cream in the world to make slightly burnt coffee taste good.  Also they only offer packets of white sugar as your non-diet sweetening option.

Overall I'd say - Go to Zazie if you're in it for the potatoes, happen to be right outside the door when hunger hits you, or you just don't have the energy to find somewhere better.  For Vegetarians I'd recommend Boogaloo's, Dottie's or Brenda's French Soul Food as awesome alternatives.
author: K W.

description:
I love this place. Let's see, its something about feeling like you're eating in a really cool converted sf house with the kitchen within eye view and you get great oven baked smells, that even you non hipsters start to get the cool cole valley neighborhood vibe. The outside seating in the back is awesome for brunch when its sunny or even at night with the heat lamps. 

I recently came back for dinner a week ago, and I totally forgot how good the food was here. Of course, me and my obsession with french food, but I had the porkchops and wow, talk about melts off the bone deliciousness. It must have been slowcooked for hours it was so good.  I actually ate more than I should have since we also added in the cheese plate and meat/pate plate which were nice.

Definitely make reservations beforehand and come early to find parking,  but its such a great place for dinner with friends, casual and hip atmosphere for dinner. The staff was also friendly and helpful.
author: SF Diner A.

description: It was worth the 2 hour wait in the rain! I would have given 5 stars if their stuffed french toast was tastier (but it was okay). The two stars of my brunch was the Eggs Benedict with crab (La Mer) and the Gingerbread Pancakes--they should be available year round and with extra curd and pears. I ravenously tried all 3 dishes because you can control how much of the items you want (1, 2, or 3 eggs) and the roasted potatoes comes with WHOLE CLOVES of roasted garlic which made them taste like heaven.
author: lily l.

description: Wait is long, it's San Francisco on a Sunday. The bar next door serves up some yummy bloody marys while you wait. Service is poor because it's so busy. Poor in the way that you wait 15-20min between seeing your server for anything so if you need anything don't expect it right away. Food is good, but they are always out of half the menu. Like no French toast one day or out of this or that. Overall not worth it, but it wasn't terrible. One last thing was that I didn't read that the Bloody Mary at zarie was soju (which is my fault) and it was terrible. The server rolled his eyes at me when I told him I didn't like it when he asked how everything was. It was a legit answer, I was still going to pay for it(and did), but why the attitude? Hmmm
author: Zack V.

description:
Do yourself a favor and come here for brunch. You deserve it! I must admit though, the wait can be pretty nasty on a weekend. If the weather is nice, wear your shades and shoot for the patio. It's furnished with some nifty heat lamps. So even if the weather isn't quite perfect you can still enjoy the sweet ambiance of the outdoors. The inside is nice too, it features exposed brick walls, a spiral staircase, and a cozy environment. 

Their poached egg dishes are delish, but so is the challah french toast. I recommend that you and your dinning buddy each get an egg dish, and share the french-toast. Prepare yourself to have an overall delightful dinning experience.
author: Brittani M.

description: Cute and simple atmosphere. For breakfast, I had the La Mer (poached egg with fresh crab and avocado topped with hollandaise sauce) served with home fries with roasted garlic cloves.  Yummy.  Definitely would go back.
author: Veronica E.

description:
