Best. Brunch. Ever. You will wait. But it is so worth it. You will want everything on the menu and will end up getting sides and having to taste something from everyone's plate.

Cream cheese coffee cake, ginger bread pancakes with lemon curd, eggs florentine. 

You can't go wrong. I am dying to go for lunch and dinner. Maybe one day I will have all three!
author: Sonia S.

description:
Even though Zazie is only a few blocks away from The Haight, it's like an entire world away. This place is an oasis and the outdoor seating is not overcrowded with tables.

Zazie has a wonderful dinner menu that changes frequently. The Figs Figaro appetizer was delicious - it had very tasty goat cheese and the mission figs were delightful. I had the lemon ricotta ravioli and my spouse had the summer corn cakes. Both entrees were absolutely delicious, flavorful and fresh. We ended our meal with dessert and it was absolutely worth it. My spouse had the raspberry chevre cheesecake - so good. And I had the cherries, almonds and flower petals with a lovely creme fraiche - very light and so delightful. The staff there is amazingly attentive and the service is very friendly. I will definitely return to Zazie in the near future and I've already recommended it to several friends traveling to the Bay Area - what an amazing gem in Cole Valley!
author: Katy J.

description:
We were seated in the patio, which is very beautiful. So 1 star for lovely ambience.

The menu has quite a variety of breakfast/brunch treats. I like how you can choose the size portions - it allows you to mix & match sweets and savouries. I had a cafe au lait which was very delicious. Its also huge, so for $4 or $5 its a good deal. Another star

I was with two other people and we shared a plate of eggs benedict with tomato and prosciutto - it was very tasty (third star). For myself, I ordered a toasted baguette with butter and jam.  Food takes a long time to arrive - which is nice if you want to have a slow meal but not ideal if you are rather hungry. The hot meals the other two had ordered came and after about a 5 minute wait, I caught the attention of the hostess to ask if my toast was still on its way. A few minutes later it arrived without jam. Ha. So I asked another waiter for jam. That was definitely disappointing - I figured something as basic as my order would not be so delayed. Its always a bit awkward waiting around for the final plate on the table to arrive.

All in all, the food/menu is great and the setting is cozy but it was a mediocre experience as far as service went.
author: Marie J.

description: My wife and I love Zazie. When we visit San Francisco, this is our number one neighborhood, bistro-style restaurant. First and foremost, the food is fantastic. Second, the service is friendly and attentive. And, finally, it's very reasonably priced for a city that is generally an expensive dining experience. Zazie is in Cole Valley, one of The City's nicest neighborhoods. Parking can be an adventure, but, if you arrive for an early dinner, you can usually find a non-metered parking space within a couple of blocks. On our last visit, I had their soup du jour and the fish soup entree. Many restaurants over salt their soup, but Zazie served a perfectly balanced tomato-based, white bean and kale soup. The fish stew can best be described as a cross between a bouillabaisse  and a cioppino. My wife had a delicious cheese ravioli with a lemon-wine sauce. The menu offers lots of option including a very reasonable fixed price choice of three courses. There's a very nice selection of wines that are not over priced. Try this restaurant for a intimate dinner with your sweetie or bring the whole family.
author: Barry V.

description: Completely overrated and inconsistent. I'm convinced it's a cult on weekends that enjoy parading in front of the restaurant waiting up to an hour for a seat to order the specialty, poached eggs, which often arrives at the table cold or over cooked. Get a life people, cause a sidewalk blocked full of zombies waiting to eat a somewhat decent breakfast on the weekends is really annoying.
author: Dian N.

description: Une, deux, trois.... that what we all had and it was terrific! (That one pancake, two eggs and bacon).  Coffe was very good too,  I will definitely go again.
author: Kathy P.

description:
I'm always intimidated by the line in front of Zazie for brunch on the weekends even though I live in the neighborhood. 

Braved the crowd this past weekend and had a great meal! My friend and I ordered the special of the day: Chicken apple sausage and white cheddar omelet with avocado and home fries on the side. It was very tasty. I also had a black currant mimosa which I highly recommend. Our other friends ordered the gingerbread pancakes and a poached egg meal.  

Our server was very nice and did not complain or look pissed when we handed him 4 credit cards. I will definitely brave the crowd again.
author: Erica H.

description:
OH MY!  Eggs benedict galore!  I love eggs benedict and theirs rocks!  They have several kinds.  I had one proscuitto and one crab benedict.  Served with either salad or home fries.  I have to say the eggs were poached to perfection and there was just the right amount of hollandaise sauce.  I love that the home fries are served with whole roasted garlic cloves!  And they have several flavors of mimosas!!

The decor is cute and very frenchy.  Staff is very nice as well.  I'm not a huge breakfast fan, but I have to say this is the place to go for eggs benedict!  I would wake up just to come here again.
author: Gina S.

description: Wonderfull place! Love the eggs, and they make a really good bloody mary!
author: Gori V.

description:
Zazie is a little nook of a restaurant. The dining area is cramp with chairs back to back when fully occupied with satisfied customers. Zazie is very cozy, homey, and warm, which is clearly reflected on their food!

Eggs benedicts, pancakes, and their potato hash is all delish. With bacon, sausage, and other breakfast goodies to compliment the meal, Zazie has seriously perfected breakfast. A step above from squat and gobble with friendlier and fast wait staff, slightly better prices, and homey atmosphere, Zazie is now my first choice, if not only choice for breakfast or a lazy sunday brunch!

Unique menu options too like their pumpkin pancakes that everyone is talking about. I haven't tried it yet, but I'm planning a second trip!
author: Alex C.

description:
Not that Zazie needs another rieview, but here it is anyway.  I'll just list the yummies.

Irish Oatmeal.  I mean, yeah it's oatmeal, but it's really delicious.
Pierre Noir eggs
Croque Monsieur
Mexico scramble with chorizo
Gingerbread Pancakes
do-it-yourself mimosas

I heart you Zazie!!!!
author: Boots B.

description:
Am dieing to return to this gem of a brunch spot....salivating just thinking about it.

The Wait: 2 pages deep when we got there. It's placed outside on the window to self sign in, I don't know how I missed it when we got there, oh that's right, there were 30 people standing around blocking it... 
One of the small tables out front in the midst of the crowd opened up (first come, first serve seating out front..I think only 2-3 tables fit for 2 folks), and we sat it down. Felt a tad too in the street, but waiting a whole 5 minutes in all, can't complain when you show up at 10:30a on a Saturday. 

Service: On the ball, friendly and attentive.

Food: Ordered Tahitian french toast, eggs florentine, eggs pierre noir, side of bacon and coffees, roughly $50 with tip, On the $$$ end I suppose for brunch, but def a good splurge. French toast was easily the best I've ever had, would bathe in it if I could. Eggs Florentine/Pierre Noir were prepared and plated excellently, great flavors. Would say I would prefer more Hollandaise on my plate, they went a little light. The bacon was thick and crispy, delicious.

I wouldn't bring a large party here, 4 or less to get in, cause they churn you out fast!

I've told droves of folks about this spot, it's a must brunch at joint. Enjoy!
author: Sital P.

description:
I wanted to love this place as much as everyone else... but it was just a-ok. Cute little spot.  Came on a Monday AM, so there was no wait and parking was really easy to find. I can see why the wait can be a drag. 

Had the eggs florentine and gingerbread pancakes ("it tastes like a little piece of Christmas!"). 

I'll give you another chance sometime, Zazie.. but for now, you get 3 from me.
author: Rosemarie d.

description:
If this place was near my house, they'd probably get a lot of business from me. Thank God theyre so far away from me! Their food is by far AH-MAZING! I had their banana french toast - and fell in love. 

Only con: I felt the street parking was more expensive than my food!
author: On The G.

description: One of the most quaint and enjoyable places to eat in San Francisco. Their french onion soup is to die for and they always have amazing bigger meals and specials. If you can bare the incredibly long wait on the weekend for brunch, they're known for it. I generally like to go on weeknights with family and loved ones for a more intimate gathering.
author: Bay M.

description:
I HAVE BEEN MISSING OUT ALL THESE YRS!

I lived in san francisco all my life, shopped on haight street countless of times, and always ate at the nearby Mcdonalds afterschool during highschool years and NEVER realized there was a great brunch place LIKE ZAZIE. 

There is a wait. The wait wasn't long since we got there at 1pm. I wanted everything on the menu, especially the french toast tahiti, but of course I had to be on a diet right now. damn! So i ordered a veggie sandwich and it was delicious. I added roasted tomatoes on my sandwich YUM, My friend had the La Mer Benedict. She liked it too but it was a bit small compared what I have seen at other places. 

I won't be going to Mc Donalds anymore cuz there is ZAZIE. haha
author: K L.

description:
Went here for my husband's birthday on a Tuesday night. The restaurant was busy enough considering it was Tuesday, and everything turned out to be really lovely.

The vibe is very warm and inviting, especially on a cold night, and the food was all quite hearty (lots of braises when it's cold out). There were a number of choices, I was concerned because one of us was vegetarian, and we were all really happy.

The service is relaxed and friendly. Just the right amount of attention. We were never wondering where the waitress was. 

I had Cassoluet which was delicious and only needed just a trifle more salt. The beans were perfectly cooked and the duck was tender and juicy.The chicken liver pate was also quite nice, but I would've preferred to spread it on the bread myself, rather than having it come to the plate partly melted on the warm toast. It's a minor quibble. 

Others at our table had salmon in parchment over spinach a dish called Chicken with Grandma Sauce (it sounds better in French) and Polenta cakes. Everyone seemed to love everything they had. 

The wine we wanted turned out to be on special that night and the bottles were $10 off, so we had two! None of the wine is more than about $40 and most is in the mid-20s which I think is pretty good for SF.

All in all highly recommended.
author: Mike F.

description:
I love breakfast, but hate having to choose between savory and sweet (Do I want waffles/pancakes, or something more substantial, like eggs and bacon?).  At Zazie, you can order both without a huge monetary penalty! There are lots of things that you can split into 1/2/3 servings, so you can mix and match to your breakfast loving heart's desire.

Got one Eggs Florentine, one piece of French Toast Tahiti (the one with caramelized bananas and walnuts), and a mocha.  Eggs Florentine was excellent, and being able to choose salad on the side was a definite plus.  The french toast was good, but not amazing, so I'd probably order gingerbread pancakes or something next time.

Wait wasn't too long (around 1pm on a Saturday); got a table within 5 minutes. :)  Will definitely be back again.
author: Stephanie L.

description: This was an amazing brunch. I got poached eggs with prosciutto and avacado in a delicious hollandaise sauce with home fries  with a freshly squeezed lemon drink with natural sweetener. The server and service was amazing and it is definitely worth the wait to be seated!
author: Abby T.

description: Zazie knows (and maybe the only brunch spot in SF that does know) how to poach an egg.  There. That's enough.
author: Luke M.

description: I love this place for brunch but it is also a great place for dinner. I had a wonderful dinner here with friends and was very pleased with the serves, food and price.
author: Camilla B.

description: The brunch here was amazing! I had the Un, deux, trois and I loved loved the buttermilk pancake. We had to wait about 45 minutes for a table but this restaurant was worth the wait. It was clear to me that everyone else waiting outside thought so goo. Our waiter was also pleasant and served our check in perfect timing. Overall wonderful experience!
author: D T.

description:
I'm a newbie to the brunch scene, but I've heard this is one of the best spots, complete with their outdoor patio. I had the "Monaco" poached eggs with prosciutto and tomato. Topped with light hollandaise over a toasted English muffin, this was absolute perfection.

The Americano was nice and rich, with just the right amount of water. 

Worth the wait.
author: Derrick V.

description: Long wait guaranteed on weekends.... but so worth the wait for the eggs benedict!
author: Amanda H.

description: Great brunch spot in the Haight! Go on a sunny day and sit in the back patio. Perfect way to start off a Saturday or Sunday. The food is good, and my servers have always been attentive and pleasant, even when dealing with a group. The seating is a bit cramped though with your neighbors practically sitting right on top of you. There will be a wait if you get there during the height of bruch time, but it's worth it considering there's always a wait at every good brunch spot in the city.
author: Amanda R.

description: Excellent Povencal BLT with French Onion soup yesterday for lunch at this bustling little neighborhood gem of a restaurant. I can't to go back and explore the menu more!
author: Trey B.

description: Yes, five stars for a brunch place. But, you'd be surprised how easy it is for people to f*** up a good eggs benedict. This one was probably one of the best I've ever had. perfectly cooked eggs over avocado and dungeness crab (as a recent SF transplant, this was actually my first ever consumption of dungeness, and I have to say, I'm a fan). The hollandaise wasn't glumpy or non-acidic. In short, a brunch worthy of all the hype. Plus, the service was super, even though it was a holiday and more hectic than a Monday is usually.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Likes: ate here for breakfast, had the la mer poached eggs with side salad, beautiful outdoor seating, pomegranate mimosa, i'd come here again on a beautiful day :)

Dislikes: the wait for seats and getting check and credit card taken and returned took a long time
author: Karen M.

description:
really it should get 2.5 stars but that isn't an option and it's closer to 2 stars than 3.

breakfast at zazie is very pricy. when the food is pricy i have higher expectations. therefore good but certainly not great when combined with high expense yields an average rating. 

details:

ordered eggs benedict with smoked salmon and capers. i think they call it the st. trop. portion size is small, but the eggs are perfectly poached, the salmon and capers tasty and the unremarkable hollandaise sauce is at least homemade. the problem with this dish is that it came with sliced red onions and they were cut into huge chunks. not at all what you would expect if paying $14 for a 2 egg dish. the pieces of onion were far too large for dish and needed to be almost all removed, very poor preparation for an expensive dish.

the side home fries had excellent flavor (nice garlic buzz there) but some were undercooked to the point of being slightly crunchy. again, poor preparation and quality control.

the caramelized banana stuffed french toast was rather disappointing all around. far too bready, not eggy enough, odd somewhat bland "stuffing" and the caramelized bananas were sad mushy things that even a novice chef would be embarrassed to claim as their own. trust me, caramelized bananas are easy and quick to make even for the cooking-challenged. the mushy pile of bread matter under the woeful bananas left both of us underwhelmed to the point of sadness.

the coffee (at $3 a cup!) was slightly burned and bitter. the side of bacon was magical (and also $5). 

overall the meal felt like a disappointment at the price (over $40 for 2 dishes, a side of  bacon and 2 coffees), even though some of it was very tasty. the lack of preparation detail was quite unpleasant.

they could benefit by making the place less crowded too. there are an absurd number of tables crammed into the restaurant and the back patio.
author: Drew D.

description:
Recently discovered this place while at brunch with a friend from out of town and it was a delight. There was a very long wait, but it was nothing that a quick walk around the neighborhood didn't take care of. By the time we came back it was our turn to sit. I had the callah bread french toast and it was delish! I can't wait to try out other dishes. I am not typically excited about breakfast, but I am willing to be a convert and enjoy the morning goodies by going back to this place. 

The service was great too, I never felt rushed even though it was very busy... this was a plus. I can see where a large group could prove to be difficult t seat since the place is pretty narrow, but I am sure they can try to accommodate. 

I am looking forward to my next visit.
author: Amelia M.

description:
I went to Zazie with my wifey for a nice brunch.  The weather was dull but we were determined to check this place out . . . especially due to their hype.  So after we found parking (we got lucky), we walked up a few blocks toward a crowd lingering in front of the restaurant.  Right when I saw the crowd, I knew we were in for a long wait . . . which was expected.  

Upon arrival, we put our name down on the list that was hanging near the door.  After waiting for about 1 hour, we were seated outside in the patio behind the restaurant.  It was a cool morning/afternoon but they have heating lamps.  Unfortunately, I was seated directly below the heat lamp so I felt like I was a piece of KFC chicken under a warming lamp.  

I ordered the French Toast Tahiti. It was pretty good.  The description stated that it had caramelized walnuts, but I only found 2.  =(  I recommend ordering the two piece as it was very filling and I didn't even finish it.  But then again, for a guy, I can't eat that much.  

Wifey ordered the La Mer.  She let me try a bite and I must admit, it was delicious!  Soooo good!  It's basically a poached egg dish with Dungeness crab with avocado.  Seemed like she liked it a lot.

Tips:

1.  Parking is very difficult.  Either take the N line in because it stops right next to it or prepare to circle around and around looking for parking.  

2.  Since there is such a long wait, go to Tully's (right next door) and grab a coffee.  It'll help you get through the pain.
author: Manton R.

description: Excellent breakfast, best eggs benedict i've had in SF! Also, really good pancakes!
author: Nicolas M.

description:
Took myself here for brunch on Thursday of last week.  The host was super sweet as I had my roller with me and he stowed it for me w/o hesitation.  I sat in the garden in the back and looked over the menu. Not too many items but a good selection of food.  I had the grilled polenta with eggs over medium with a red mushroom sauce.  I mean, YUM!  I don't know what it's called but it was served in a small cast iron pan so it's still sizzling when it comes out to you.

Once I began eating I couldn't stop.  It filled me up, it had whole porcini mushrooms and a bit of a spice in the red sauce, all balanced flavors.  The polenta had good consistency and mixed well with the egg, sauce and mushrooms.  For a drink I had water with a lemon.  $15 with tip, lovely outside garden, at this time it was not packed but I have heard that it gets crazy busy for dinner and for brunch on the weekends.
author: Erica L.

description:
Came here with co-workers for lunch on a Thursday afternoon and thankfully we called ahead to reserve a table for 8 because that place gets PACKED. I figure this is probably due to the popular brunch options and breakfast still goes on till 2:00 p.m.!

I had the Niman Ranch Burger on the special menu and a Sparkling Lemonade. My first thought at the arrival of my lemonade, "that's it?!?!" It came in a teensy cup by American standards but at the end of my meal, I was glad for the smaller portion. It was just enough, no overkill at all. 

The Niman Burger was also deeeelicious and was it just me...or did the bun taste like a stick of butter. No joke, when you bit into that load full of carbs all you could taste was BUTTER. I was a bit blown away but couldn't help but finish my whole plate with potatoes. 

I wish they weren't so packed all the time so I could take my boyfriend and try brunch stuff but remember everyone, call in! Much better than getting there and having to sign up. 

Bon Appetite!
author: Crystal C.

description:
This is a nice, cozy brunch place!  

We came here because their eggs benedict is on the "100 things to try in SF before you die"

So of course we tried that and the miracle pancakes, french toast and french onion soup.

Eggs Benedict - very good, but not earth shattering.

Miracle Pancakes - extremely light and yummy and their fresh strawberries were especially sweet!!

French Toast - just ok, but in any case I've never liked French Toast

French Onion Soup - a bit oily, but quite good as well

I also had their signature tea which tasted like it had hints of rosemary.

We'll come back here to try the other non-breakfast items on their menu.  Price is not cheap though, our bill was almost $50!
author: Rossini P.

description:
Slampig moved to New York.  But, before she left she introduced me to Zazie.

Slammy & I walked over to Zazie, in the heart of the Cole Valley (breeder land) and signed up on the wait list (no rezzies, apparently).  Slammy warned me that the wait could be long but I didn't expect it to be an hour.  Yikes.  I probably would've left, but because we were in the middle of Cole Valley, there weren't a whole lot of other options.  So we waited...

...and I'm glad we did!

We got seated on a lovely (if a teeny bit cramped) back patio in the sunshine.  We were quite mesmerized by the menu, so while we perused the options we both ordered a mimosa.  Zazie has a nice array of mimosas - I don't remember all of them, but Slammy ordered a guava mimosa and I ordered a black currant mimosa.  Yummy!

We were both so torn about what to order that we decided to split a medium order of the gingerbread pancakes (medium was the rec of our server & I VERY much appreciate her warning:  we couldn't finish the medium, and never would have made a dent in the large we initially intended to order).  We also ordered a side of bacon, two orders of two eggs (for each of us) and an order of their DELICIOUS coffee cake as an appetizer of sorts.

Everything was quite good.  I don't know that I would order the pancakes again (they were so very rich), but I am glad that I tried them.  Our service was impeccable and the drinks were so tasty that we ordered a second round.

The only things that stop me from giving Zazie a full 5 stars are the wait (and lack of a reservation system) and the cramped nature of the seating.  I didn't particularly want to be privy to the conversation on my left...but with the seating as it was, I really didn't have much of a choice.

***NOTE:  Zazie was so yummy, Slammy and I hit it one more time the day before she flew away (*sniffle*).  She had a scramble & I had an omelet (both on the specials menu).  Again - both were yummy.  And, because we went on a weekday, there was no wait AND only a few other parties on the patio so we weren't cramped.  Yay!
author: Christopher S.

description: Couldn't be any better! Great atmosphere and the food is A++ perfect. My favorite dish here is the rabbit. I've had brunch here also which was very impressive. The only bad thing is parking and there is always a long wait.
author: C C.

description:
You gotta have a lot of patience for this place.  There's always a wait.  My friends and I showed up super-early* on the coldest wettest Saturday of the year and still had a half hour wait.  And parking sucks around here.  

All for delicate mango mimosas, delectable crab and salmon benedicts, fluffy pancakes, and awesome bacon**.  

Will I do it again?  yes.
Am I in any rush to do this again?  no.

*super-early in my world is anytime before 10 a.m.
** bacon is always awesome
author: Yeeman N.

description:
I love Zazie's! OK, you do have to wait for a long time to get brunch but I think that's part of the fun.  I love the decor inside, it's very charming and surprising calm after the 'scene' outside. 
The gingerbread pancakes with bosc pears and lemon curd are to die for, plus I love that they serve their latte's in latte bowls. My favorite place for brunch in SF!
author: Leigh M.

description: You will wait a looooooong time to get in, but their waiting list process isn't bad, and occasionally you can wait in the bar next door, so the wait goes by faster. I saw someone get their Zazie food delivered in the bar! But I don't know how, or IF that's even normal. The gingerbread pancakes are amazing, and if you like mochas, you'll love these! The ambiance is crowded, but quaint, and once you sit down, you're much more comfortable. The specials I have tried so far, have all been great!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I think one of the greatest and simple pleasures in life is having Sunday brunch with good friends. Trish the Brunch Dish was in town and the rare Ligaya Time was set! 

My ginger pancakes (x2) with Bosch pear and lemon sauce was delicious, though I would recommend getting just one pancake instead of two since it's a lot of carbs and getting eggs or other items with it instead. 

The menu was set up so that you can have a la carte on a little of everything instead of just eating 7 French toasts by yourself. 
Ligs' poached eggs looked delicious! I'm totally getting those next time! 

The wait is definitely more bearable than Brenda's. The two front small tables, the inside, and the patio made it accommodating, especially with heating lamps in the patio. The restroom was clean and decorative as well!  I even got the "remember" from a staff because I forgot to zip my fly (I was....um....getting "fresh air").
author: Kenny L.

description:
What a great brunch place! 

We went to Zazie on our way home from Bay to Breakers. Figuring it would be a long wait, we put our name down and prepared ourselves. However, we were seated within 15 minutes, which is awesome considering the typical wait for a popular brunch locale in the city (lucky us we were only a party of two though).

We ordered the gingerbread pancakes with the lemon curd and bosc pears, as well as the Florentine Benedict (had to cross one off of the list for the 7x7!). The Benedict was great - lighter hollandaise sauce, perfectly poached free range eggs and uber-garlicy home fries. The gingerbread pancakes were equally amazing: oversized ginger bread pancake served with a huge dollop of lemon curd and half a poached bosc pear. The flavor combination was heaven! 

The atmosphere at Zazies is very cute: French cafe with sky lights and an unforgettable back patio. This is an excellent brunch choice!
author: Amanda D.

description:
How is this place not 5-star? Or even 4 1/2-star?  I'm extremely critical when it comes to my reviews and don't take them lightly.  I was extremely surprised when I came here to say the least.

Two of my friend's and I came here on mother's day this year.  As I arrived with one friend, we had the option of sitting outside as it was first-come-first-serve.  Luckily, a table had just gotten up.  Within a matter of moments the table was cleared and we were given menus.  When my third friend arrived, the server walked out immediately with another menu for him as well.  

As far as service is concerned, our server was amazing.  He seemed to know exactly when to come by.  Any time a dish was finished we showed up to clear it.  Any time we needed a refill, he was there.  Even better was how he handled dessert.  He brought out our check and asked if we wanted to see the dessert menu.  When we said no, he had the check so we didn't have to wait for him to go back and retrieve it.  This is one of the key characteristics of an excellent server.  Amazing....

As for the food, I was really impressed.  All of our dishes were excellent.  The croque royale, eggs benedict, and such were to-die-for.  We ordered a bit of french toast as our dessert to share when we placed our brunch order.  It was quite excellent as well.

There were only 2 things I didn't like about this place.  Firstly, they don't take Amex.  This can be easily remedied, but we shall see.  Secondly, I don't really like the fact that the bathroom is right next to the food expedition window, but the place is small so I can understand.  While waiting for the bathroom, in fact, I saw they had scored a health score rating of 100, so that made me feel better.

If you're looking for a brunch place and have not come here, you're missing out!
author: Brent A.

description:
I love brunch and what's more, I love French inspired brunch. So when we needed a place to try in the city when visiting friends, this was it. 

I have been on a poached egg kick lately and was happy to see that they had a lot of choices. I ended up with the "Albert" with home fries. Mostly because it had bacon on it. 

The eggs were poached perfectly and the hollandaise was so nice and light. I loved my dish. There was a subtle tartness from the salsa, but that just added to it. 

I had a little of my friend's pancake too. It was moist, flavorful and delicious. Home fries were spot on, not over cooked and perfectly seasoned. 

This is a good brunch place. Although because it's so hyped, the line was a little ridiculous on this chilly day. Other than that great meal.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Pros:  Yes, the food will make your mouth weep with joy.  Had the eggs benedict when we were there and saw the face of Dog.

Cons:  Nearly fainted from exhaustion/hunger while waiting.  The "good" news - my wallet was waaaay lighter when I left, so it wasn't as taxing to carry it. (For those that don't do well with subtlety - it's expensive)
author: Amber M.

description:
Wow! What better way to refuel after a sweaty 90 minute Bikram Yoga class? Yep, Head to Zazie and cross off #77 on the 7x7 Big Eat SF. #77 Eggs Benedict on the back patio... 

Before I get into how great our food was let me tell you about the patio. It was a beautiful day out so there was plenty of sun. We arrived at 11 and were second couple seated so we had our choice of spots which was GREAT! The waitress was adorable and such a doll for being so patient with my wife and I. There were so many treats on the menu it was impossible to make a decision.

Now on the the good stuff...

The special today was the La Mer Eggs Benedict... This included some tasty crab, avocado and some other treats, but I devoured it before I could really remember everything else that was on top of that slightly toasted English Muffin.  There was a side of roasted or fried potatoes, either way, they were tasty!

My wife had the Fontainbleau: with portobellos, shiitake, porcinis, spinach, fontina... DELICIOUS! The three types of mushrooms came together wonderfully.. The eggs were a little runny, but still made for a delightful breakfast. This was also served with those crunchy potatoes and toast.

We also shared a bowl of Oatmeal with bananas and Wait For it......
Creme Brule!!!!!! Who thinks of adding that amazing addition to a bowl of oats! This was so tasty the group (well the mom in the group next to us, who apparently just got off the plane from Chicago) could not wait to hear how good it was. Well, we are no stranger to taste testing other peoples meals at the table, we offered the lovely lady a bite... Yep she loved it too! 

I will definitely be back with the wife or a group of friends to enjoy another Breakfast, Brunch, or Lunch... Keep up the great work Zazie!
author: Miguel V.

description: I love the menu. You can mix and match to your hearts content. The line is ridiculous but worth the wait. Its a quaint spot and the service is on point. I had the pierre noir and my group split the sampler, sooo goood - i didnt want to share!
author: Sofia R.

description: Arrived at 2 p.m. on a Sunday afternoon and fortunately only had to wait 40 seconds, as quoted by the host. Ordered the French Toast Tahiti, the famous gingerbread pancakes, a special-of-the-day egg scramble, and the Zazie spritzer. Food came within a reasonable time frame (about 15-20 minutes). The French Toast Tahiti was amazing, and I definitely recommend this if you like bananas and walnuts (some people hate bananas, crazy I know) because this dish was the highlight of the meal. The gingerbread pancakes were very dense and probably the worst pancakes I've ever had in my life. Fortunately, the waiter did not charge us for these substandard pancakes so kudos for that. And finally, the egg scramble was made of red peppers, Aidell's chicken-apple sausage (a complete fail), and onions.The scramble was extremely greasy and lacked good flavor. Order the home fries because they are actually some really good potatoes and not fries as the name would lead you to believe. The Zazie spritzer was a sparkling beverage made of cranberry and orange juice. It was really good, and I recommend it if you're looking for a non-alcoholic mimosa-like beverage. Nice neighborhood but can be difficult to find parking.
author: Katherine Y.

description:
ambiance//***
loud and bustling!!

service//***
the service was alright...
unfortunately the recommendations were only ok =\

food//***
what i had was alright but nothing jaw dropping...mostly because the AMAZING pancakes were SO good it sold out....sad times...so i'll just trust that it's awesome!

~*~
the wait was relatively decent for the food, but i went on a weekday
i'm not sure i'd be happy w/ the alternatives or sold out pancakes for a weekend wait though =T
author: Donna S.

description:
I dreamed about this place last night, so I had to write a review. I'm a big fan of brunch, and despite having tried dozens of great places all over the area, I always return to Zazie. The wait is usually long as the place is small-ish, but we usually get a spot on the patio in the sun, and it seems to be worth it. 
My favorites are the French toast Tahiti with caramelized walnuts and bananas and the New York scrambled eggs with salmon and cream cheese. I also really like their raspberry jam.
author: Ai K.

description: Happen to just randomly eat here on Sunday night. This place is truly wonderful. Great service, fantastic food! Everyone's dinner plate was really well prepared and each dish has its own nuance to make it signature. I notice most come here for brunch, I'll pass. Nothing worse than waiting 2 hours to eat 30 dollar eggs but as for dinner this place is golden!
author: Ethan S.

description: Such a cute little french cafe.  Took the bride-to-be here for a brunch with her bridesmaids and enjoyed a lovely brunch together over some much needed girl-talk.  We shared four dishes and split a lovely bottle of champagne with black currant juice.  All of the dishes were delish and can't wait to come back and try some more.  The pancake sampler was the perfect amount of sweet and the lemon curd was quite the hit.  Being the egg slut that I am, all the other dishes hit the spot with the right amount of savory.  When a cafe makes you want to go back to Paris you know it's definitely hit the spot.
author: Evie B.

description:
I work late and I get off late, so by the time I wake up I've already missed breakfast! Well I've might missed breakfast, but not BRUNCH.

People aren't lying about their ginger pancakes because they're absolutely amazing.  Yummmy .... plus you can even purchase their mix if you want to make some at home!

I tend to always over order because I want to try almost everything on the menu.  So after the pancakes comes the mexican omelet; I ended up not even finishing it.  It was tasty, but it didn't left me at awe. 

Well if you're coming here on a sunny afternoon, try to dine outside their patio.  It's a cool spot to have brunch at, just hope the sun is not blinding you, of course.
author: Sophia S.

description:
brunch is my favorite meal and if necessary i would wait in line for a ridiculous amount of time just to get some.  with that said, a friend and i met up here for brunch on a saturday.  the crowd out there was intimidating but we were seated within 20 minutes.

i totally appreciate how you can order one piece of pretty much anything on the menu, this way you get to try more than one item.  for someone like me who want a bit of savory and a bit of sweet, this one piece ordering deal was money.  i got a piece of the tahiti (stuffed french toast with bananas and caramel) and a piece of the florentine (eggs benedict with spinach and mushrooms) and a bloody mary.  yes, that's all for one person.  :)  my friend got the carrot/ginger soup of the day and the french toast.  everything was delicious.  my bloody mary had the perfect amount of spice and booze.  the egg was poached perfectly as other yelpers have commented on but the thing that knocked my socks off was the stuffed french toast.  OMG if i had known how wonderfully delicious it was going to be, i would've totally gone for the whole shabang and ordered three pieces of that.  well, there's always next time.
author: Sally T.

description:
What an adorable place! We came for Sunday brunch and sat in the back outside patio area. Even though it was freezing out, the patio was nice and toasty with the heated lamps. 

The kitchen is tiny! But I was amazed at the amount and variety of dishes it churned out. You have the option of picking 1, 2 or three eggs or pancake/frenchtoast for your order which was great for me because everything sounded so good, I just couldn't decide! I finally settled on Pinkie's Challah French Toast AND the Gingerbread Pancakes with lemon curd. One each! The french toast was light and fluffy, pleasantly surprising! And the pancake was divine (and huge! one was definitely enough) and the lemon curd was a perfect complement, even sans syrup. 

Definitely looking forward to going back. Just make sure you get there early.. and allot time to look for parking (it's rough).
author: tessie n.

description:
Finally went there after having heard a lot about this place.

I liked the old French look they put into it and it's bistrot feeling.
But I was disappointed by the food. I got some poached eggs "St Trop." style and felt the combination was odd. It came with raw onions which ended up overtaking the taste of the dish (I believe pan fried one would have give them a more balanced taste with the rest of the ingredients). 
It was on some bagel type of bread which wasn't particularly tasty, but I am probably just the wrong crowd for this as I have never enjoyed any bread in SF. ;-)
Last it had a side of salad, which is a great idea, but NOT with a vinaigrette sauce on it!! This became a terrible combination of flavor (try eating salmon with vinegar to get an idea).

I want to believe I picked the truly odd dish from the menu and that the rest will make me change my opinion. So I will still come back at some point, but won't go St Trop style. ;-)
author: Jean T.

description: wowza. great service, food and atmosphere! I had the burger which was outstanding. it was my second burger of the day and it blew the earlier one out of the water! We shared the fruit (peach and blueberry) crumble and vanilla gelato for dessert and it was delish! Our seat outside was lovely and our server was too. A neighboring table was allowing their child to crowd and bother us and she stepped in to make sure we weren't bothered. great wine list as well. I'll be back even though it's not in my 'hood.
author: Nicole O.

description:
The absurd paeans that fill Yelp for this restaurant confuse me. 

Yes, it's all very good food, but it's not THAT amazing. Plainly, it's not worth the wait or the crowd. Simply put, go somewhere else - you're not missing out. 

My biggest beef with the food is that it's all too prepared. It feels very heavy and processed: to me it lacked the light hand of a home-kitchen, which is what I'd expect from a SF mom-and-pop joint.

Specifically, though, I had the universally acclaimed gingerbread pancakes, french toast tahiti, and the home fries. All were quite good. 

The pancakes were a tad dense, the pears added nothing special and the lemon curd didn't complete the flavors well. A fine pancake dish, but I've had better.

The french toast tahiti was fine as well. It's a bit more interesting, and indeed may be among the better french toasts I've had, but still lacked a depth/complexity that some simple modifications could have provided.

The home fries were good. I loved the cloves of garlic and the overall composition of the dish. The major problem here was execution: it was erratic and uneven. The cloves sometimes had skins that couldn't be chewed, but otherwise had ones cooked through. Likewise, the potatoes ranged from barely-finished to burnt. Not attentive cooking here. 

On the whole, no major complaints. A fun place to have brunch, but if, like me, you'd like a comfortable place to kick back and have a leisurely weekend brunch, this isn't best-in-class. Come here if you will, don't if you won't. Nothing to write home about, as they say.
author: Joe S.

description:
Zazie is such a cute little french-inspired cafe in the heart of Cole Valley.  The hubby and I went for Sunday brunch and only had to wait about 20 minutes for a table.  

It's a tiny restaurant with a small, specific menu.  Again, we were only there for brunch.  What we liked about Zazie is the choice of either 1, 2 or 3 eggs - at most places you get a set amount and the servers get annoyed if you just want to have 1 pancake.  

My husband got 2 poached eggs with spinach and garlic home fries.  Delicious.  I had the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd sauce (which was awesome) and pear.  It was sweet enough with the lemon curd sauce that i didn't even need the syrup, which was served on the side.  It was not too sweet, just enough.  I would like to try their scrambles dish - there is also an option between a green salad and potatoes too.  

Next time I will go for an egg based dish and get a single pancake or french toast, which I have heard is amazing.
author: three's company M.

description:
Zazie isn't Gary Danko or the Dining Room at the Ritz Carlton.  Zazie is only a local restaurant.  A neighborhood place where you can sit comfortably and eat well.  None of the plates I had was perfect.  I could nitpick each one.  Yet I liked each and every one.  

A six dollar bowl of lentil soup screamed I'm home made.  The large bay leaf in the bowl betrayed this; likewise the tomatoes and onion bits.  And the lentils were firm and tasty.  

A salad of augula, red and gold beets, fennel, and avocados in a white balsamic gorgonzola  vinaigrette was really nice, especially for eight dollars.  This wasn't the best composed salad I have ever had, but I enjoyed it thoroughly.

The duck in the cassoulet I had for my main course was not crisped.  But it did fall off the bone into the surrounding sausage and beans that were topped by crisped bread.  And yes, while not crisped the duck was tasty and as a plate of food the cassoulet worked quite well indeed. 

Service, like the food, was rough and tumble.  But in the end it was friendly and competent.  

The whole place, especially the food, speaks of home made love.
author: David D.

description: The sweet breakfast options are great, but I usually prefer the crab benedict.
author: Eric K.

description:
Fan-freaking-tastic!!!!

I don't know if I was hoped up on the holiday mood or what, but my dinner here was superb. 

Zazie got one thing right before I even stepped foot in the place, and that was allowing me to bring my own bottle of wine with no corkage fee. Genius. Packed on a Tues is clearly nothing new to these guys. Good work - I hope your simple idea catches on elsewhere. 

The next thing to note was the great atmosphere and wait staff. Good lighting, nice music at a good volume, and Christmas decorations to boot. 

What we ordered: 
- Mussels Marineires
- Braised Beef Shanks
- Grilled Niman Ranch Pork Chop
- Side of sauteed tuscan kale and roasted butternut squash
- Hot chocolate dessert thingie
- Tawny port

Bill came to something like $90 including tip. 

All food was to die for, no joke. Go there now. Why are you still reading this? Get outta here, now!
author: Morgan F.

description:
The fiancee and I went here for Sunday brunch.  Parking was surprisingly easy to obtain (for SF), but we ended up waiting for an hour to get a table for two.  My fiancee got the Fontainbleau scrambled eggs and I got the La Mer poached eggs.  

I though the Fountainbleau was a solid dish with just the right ratio of fixins' to eggs; a very solid dish, overall.  What stood out for me was that poached eggs weren't your typical "enjoy the gooey yolk" deal.  They were cooked in such a way where the whites and yolk were equally creamy.  Unfortunately, I didn't think that the dungeness crab part was anything particularly special, especially for the price paid.  So if anything, I highly suggest getting another type of poached egg.

TL;DR: 3 stars for a long wait time and a disappointing experience with my particular order.
author: Ritchie B.

description:
I bring every visitor I have for a brunch here. I love it. Eggs benedict a la mer. Gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and bosch pear. Heaven. 

This is a go-to local place for a relaxing, homely, tasty dinner.

Wonderful staff.
author: Sarah F.

description: I love love love this place. I have been for both breakfast and dinner and every meal has been outstanding. They don't take reservations for breakfast but it is well worth the wait. The place is cozy, casual and a hint of hipster. About as SF as it gets :) The La Mer eggs with crab is one of my favorites and having lived in Maryland I have high expectations when it comes to crabs. The mimosas are unique and delicious, their coffee is strong and the coffee cake is warm and savory. For dinner we split the french onion (omg yum) and the Salade Guillaume with melt in your mouth chervre cheese. We also split the salmon, hanger steak and raviolis and everything was amazing. The cream sauce over the salmon makes my mouth water thinking about it. The ambiance is perfect for a first date, girls night out, family, etc, etc. Check out the weekly specials as well. I think tuesdays is free corkage on wine and who can pass up pup on the patio night. Will certainly continue to rave over this place!
author: Michelle R.

description:
This is simply a brunch review as I've only been here once.  They have an extensive brunch menu with everything from classic American breakfast dishes to unique Zazie features.  There's plenty to choose from and they all looked scrumptious - I'll definitely be back to further explore their menu.Make sure to try the build your own mimosa with MANGO JUICE - made my day.

The service was spectacular, especially for an extremely busy cafe.  I apologize for not remembering the name of our server - but the slender brunette with shoulder-length hair was amazing and very helpful.  I had the special - omelet with chicken apple sausage, avocado and red peppers - DE-LISH!

Definitely expect a wait if you're going on a Saturday or Sunday brunch.  BUT, the host is great and very fair - make sure to write your name on the sign in sheet by the front door and add 3 minutes for every person in front of you to estimate the wait. ALSO keep in mind the tables out front are first-come first-serve.
author: John S.

description: Tight quarters, but seriously good food! I loved sitting on the back patio on a nice day in the City chowing down on some of the best pancakes EVER!
author: Yvonne L.

description: The owner (the mexican host with glasses claimed) of the place is super rude. Just right after I put down my name on the check-in list, he glanced at me with an unpleasant look. I was the second on the list but me and my son needed to use the restroom and they only have one which was always occupied. I noticed there's no space outside the restroom for waiting, not only i left my stroller outside but also went outside  3 times to see if he called my name while waiting for the restroom. So after going back and forth a few times and since we were still not able to use the restroom, I decided to go next door to the sushi place for restroom. After I came back, I informed him that I was the next one on the list. He berated me for not being there when he called my name. I explained to him  the reason for my absence. He didn't care and was like whatever, it's not important anyways. I saw a table by the front window was emptied out so I told him that I wanted that table. He told me the table was for 3 or more people and tried to sit me down at a corner table nearby the kitchen. I told him that I just saw two girls sitting there and preferred that table instead. He said "Do you wanna go home????!!!! Or, do you want me to call the police?????  !!!!!!!" @@
author: Kelly H.

description:
Zazie is such a lovely brunch place - a most-see for all Bay Area brunchers! Sit in the back on a sunny day!

It has a lovely French feel, with Edith Piaff playing and old French posters etc on the wall. They serve coffee the French way, i.e. a huge bucket of a latte, and have many French items on the menu. I particularly love all the different 'benedict' options they have here, such as the 'Monaco' (proscuitto and tomatoes provencales) and 'La Mer' (dungeness crab and avocado). Yum yum. I once had bread-pudding pancakes here, which were so amazing, but I think that must have been a temporary special on the menu.
author: Sarah F.

description: So update! Today, my mom and I brought my dad to Zazie since he's been wanting to try the restaurant. Long story short, our food was great but the waitress, Leslie (I think?) left a bad taste in my parents mouths. We gave her the benefit of the doubt because she might've just had an off day, but she was so expressionless. She forgot my dad's coffee and never smiled once. I personally didn't pay much attention to it until they started complaining once we left, but none the less my parents said they won't return because of it. If you read my previous review, the waitress we had that day was so sweet and awesome! Zazie still has four stars from me because of their great food.
author: Rachel M.

description: Not worth the wait. I mean is good but not wow. I def had better...sorry.
author: jasmin t.

description: I have been to Zazie 3 times (for dinner) and am always impressed. I usually gravitate towards the very fresh seafood, salads and soups. Zazie is the place that sparked my recent interest in French style bistros. The outdoor seating in the back, is very special and romantic. Service is friendly, although sometimes a little slow. I'm looking forward to trying brunch in the near future.
author: Karen J.

description:
This review is for their dinner. My friend and i got there at about 8:30pm last saturday night. The wait was half an hour. The server recommended us to hang out at the wine bar for a drink. Right when we got our drink, our table was ready. I told the server to please give us another call when the next table was ready and he did! The wait was about half an hour total. Not bad

Service: Overall, service was pretty good. We sat in the patio. Atmosphere was nice, we were warm. Our waiter was friendly.
 
Food: We had the Patè de Volaille( chicken liver pate on toast) it was yummy! I ordered the Cassoulet Piallat (crsipy duck leg w/ white beans) this dish was good. I enjoyed it. It wasn't anything fancy for $21 and probably not worth $21 but it was like a big bowl of comfort food. I loved the crispy croutons on top and the sausages and the beans were flavorful and well seasoned. My friend had the salmon. I'm not a big fan of cooked salmon, so to me it was only ok. 

Overall, 4 stars. I will definitely come back and I will try their brunch next time!
author: A L.

description:
I've been flip flopping about writing this review for a while now. I love Zazie but I don't love the wait times. Anyway, here's my story:

A few weeks ago I came here for dinner on my bike and I had forgotten the keys to my bike lock at home. The staff were amazing. One of the waiters, rather than asking me to either go home and get my keys or to leave my bike unlocked outside, brought my bike through the crowded restaurant and stored it safely out back. 

The service gets a five star, the brunch gets a five star but I wasn't in love with my vegetarian option for dinner. 
 
That's ok, I'm still in love with Zazie.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
In our party of four, we all reluctantly agreed by the end that the food was sub par. For $20+ a plate, I except respectable food, not something I could have made hung over at home myself. 

My steamed spinach was inedible. It hadn't been seasoned properly and was bitter like collard greens. That's pretty hard to mess up.

The burger (OK, I admit, if you order a burger in a French restaurant, that's asking for it) was greasy and bland. Actually, everything we ordered was bland, including the mac and cheese, fish soup... duck was flavorless, etc.

Best thing I have to say is that the wait staff is super friendly, but I would never eat here again. Sad to say, but most of Cole street is overpriced and not very good.
author: Aaron G.

description: Rather disappointed for a place with such a great rep.Doughy lemon ricotta pancakes, flavorless bacon, OJ was concentrate or mixed. Place seemed like it needed a good cleaning - Bird  trapped in filthy skylight kept on knocking dust down on us.
author: Michael B.

description:
Small intimate place with great food, service, and atmosphere.

I love small neighborhood places that let you make an evening of dinner.

The prix fix menu makes it a steal!
App: 
+ Pate healthy portions, w/ wonderful little salad w/ light rasp. vin. :)
+ Mussels were delicious
Entrees: 
+ Mussel soup w/ tasty sides 
+ Hazelnut trout was well-balanced and slightly crispy
+ Pork chop is BIG
Dessert
+ Pot de creme for you chocolate lovers, but not toooo sweet
+ Rhubarb crumble, a favorite for our group

++ Service: Attentive and warm

We'll be back to try brunch!
author: Angel L.

description: The Bloody Marys here command attention, featuring a slow creeping heat that starts at the back of your throat.  Zazie also deconstructs Eggs Benedict several ways (the Pierre Noir feeling balanced with its punchy bacon and sweet tomatoes), but the real treat was their Pumpkin Pancakes.  Best orange smeared invention this side of Tim Lincecum's change-up.
author: Michael D.

description: I usually get the salmon or the portobello benedict. Super yum. Their potatoes have whole pieces of roasted garlic, their coffee is pretty good, their serves are always friendly. The only downside is the wait on the weekends. Their back patio is a super sweet spot and I know they have bring your pooch and no corkage days too.
author: Kat M.

description:
First time for brunch.

My brother, sister-in-law, two nephews and two lifelong friends of my brother met up in SF this week and invited me to brunch.  As more of a foodie than the rest of the gang (and more of a local), I was asked to choose a restaurant.

We all had a wonderful time, with everyone ordering something different and raving about the quality.  I had the vegetarian sandwich and it was a delight.

A big part of what makes Zazie such a fine experience is the ambiance -- neighborhood, décor, and patrons (largely a grad student and faculty crowd from UC, I presume).
author: Francisco G.

description:
On my last birthday, my sisters gave a gift certificate to Zazie. It included brunch for two and came with a tasty selection of plates and beverages (choice of coffee and mimosas, both of which were outstanding). 

Despite the long line that builds up for brunch, Zazie's flawless service ensures that you won't wait long for a table (at least if you're with a small party). And besides, there are far worse places to loiter than sunny Cole St. on a Saturday. 

We took a seat on the sun-dappled patio, beneath a tangle of bright pink blossoms and vines leaning elegantly off the fence. Our server was courteous and cheerful, exactly like everyone else who works at Zazie. 

The most memorable dish was by far the eggs Monaco - poached eggs with proscuitto and tomatoes provencales. Fantastic. 

Zazie also has a variety of scrambled egg dishes, pancakes, French toast, etc.

A great birthday gift!
author: Andrew K.

description:
I am a fan!  The food is great and the service was excellent despite all the brunch time craziness.  Fortunately, a friend of ours signed us in early so we only had to wait about 15 minutes for a table for 11.

My friends and family like to share and taste each others dishes so I was able to get a taste of a lot of different brunch dishes.  I was able to taste the La Mer, the Spanish Omlette and the French Toast.  

I may get some hate for this but I was slightly disappointed with the La Mer.  It's a great dish and I love how you can see actual bits of fresh crab meat, however, the dish was a little bland to me (even with a splash of tobasco).  I think I'm used to a cafe in LA that has the best crabcake eggs benedict I've ever had so my expectations were a little high when I had this dish.  I also note the difference between fresh crab meat vs. a crab cake but I was slightly underwhelmed over all.

The challah french toast was amazing.  I'm not a huge french toast fan but I've tried a lot and this was so good that I took a few more bites than I normally do of it.

Lastly, the mexican omlette was absolutely delicious.  This omlette truly tasted like a Mexican omlette to me.  I LOVED the strong Mexican flavors of the dish... the chorizo, the peppers, and whatever else they threw in there were all mixed in to perfection.  

Overall, the Zazie experience was excellent.  I'd definitely come back here to try their other dishes.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Wonderful place in Cole Valley for yummy, flavorful food.  The yelp category listing says "Breakfast & Brunch" but don't pass up this place for dinner.  Make sure to try the "Assiette de Fromages" appetizer which are cheeses and warm figs on toast.  Amazing!  This is a great place to go for a date or a social visit with friends or coworkers.  

It's popular so to avoid a wait try to arrive early or late in evening.
author: Michael S.

description:
I wish I could rate Zazie's brunch and dinner separately, but alas.

Their dinner is actually amazing, and everything I've tried has been a pleasant surprise. They have good drinks and awesome food, and the service is attentive but not overbearing. Easily a five-star dinner.

Brunch, on the other hand, was completely underwhelming and absolutely not worth the ridiculously long wait. It's almost as though everyone has convinced themselves that Zazie brunch is incredible, and no one is willing to admit that the mediocre food wasn't worth waiting two hours for.
author: Brian D.

description:
I'm not your typical brunch girl -- meaning, I don't normally indulge in your average brunch menu items -- but Zazie has got a robust brunch menu going on that aims to please many a' varied palates, myself included. 

My old roommate and I hopped on the N somewhat on a whim and decided to see what was going on at Zazie considering that we both had never been before but had always wanted to give it a try. 

Sure, the wait is pretty atrocious, but I'd say it's worth it. Plus, lucky for us it was a beautiful day in the city and we were able to bask in the sunshine as we waited for an open table, sipping casually on our Tully's coffees, which is conveniently located just a few shops down.

Our waiter was super cute and attentive [methinks he had a crush on my redheaded friend, which doesn't surprise me at all because she's cute as a button] and our food came out timely and tasty! I'd come back, especially now that I know that their brunch items aren't restricted to just the weekends -- score!
author: Katie C.

description:
Zazie Za Za Ziiing!

Birthday Breakfast is a thing of beauty. I wanted Hollandaise. I wanted poached eggs. I wanted toasty english muffins and crispy home potatoes. Now that I knew what I wanted, where to go, where to GO?

Research left me with 2 definite choices, and Zazie pulled ahead by a menu. Poached eggs of all sizes (chose 1, 2, or 3) and flavors. I was all 'bout it. Parking right out front, we knew that we were destined for poached perfection. 

It was Eggs Florentine for me, seated outside on this chilly San Francisco morning, but so warm on the back patio and sipping my English Breakfast tea, yes I decided - Florentine was the way to go and this was my first time.

Ma decided much of the same, hers with potatoes, mine with salad and we were off! Hunger had set and though we were waiting outside for longer than it took us to wolf down our well-chosen treat, we were happy with every mouthful. Eggs a joy with hollandaise so light and such a slight touch of lemon, this was Italian Pleasure on a Plate. Mama always shares, so slightly salted crispy and crunchy potatoes soon found their way to my plate and I gobbled them too, as a potato in a crispy jacket is never to be overlooked by a Katie with Curls. 

Yes, we were in and out in an alarmingly quick fashion - but not for lack of ambiance or love of the fare. I will be back, and soon all varietals of poached eggs will be tried by moi!
author: Katie W.

description: I was really looking forward to Zazie.  To be honest I was completely underwhelmed.  The service was just as mediocre as the food.  3 stars for the awesome bloody mary.
author: Kristi K.

description:
I've heard so much about this place and read up on the reviews before we went. I had the La Mer Benedict with a side of bacon. It. Was. Incredible. The crab meat was fresh, the eggs were cooked perfectly (not too runny, not watery) and the bacon was the right kind of crispy to put a smile on my face. My friend and I also had the French Sparkling lemonade with a side of the elderflower syrup- perfect refreshment for a sunny brunch. 

The only reason that this place gets four stars and not five:
When we were about to pay the bill, the waitress came to our table (we were seated outside) and started complaining about the people that were standing inside the restaurant waiting to be seated. I understand that perhaps it was a busy crazy day, but I found it unprofessional and weird that she'd complain to us about the other patrons. Especially when I'd consider myself a patron as well. Also, it wasn't just a snide remark. She hung out with us for a while complaining how she was fed up and wanted to slam the door into the people waiting. Awk-ward.

But regardless of that little flaw, the food is remarkable, the service (otherwise) was good. Just don't stand inside the restaurant to be seated or else table 2 will hear all about it from their wait staff.
author: Jenn Z.

description:
This place makes a damn fine breakfast.  I've been here twice, and the food was superb each time. I've tasted their eggs benedict (they have a ton of varieties on this theme, pick one that sounds appetizing) and found their hollandaise was good, but perhaps not as tangy as I like it (a minor complaint, it was delicious). Also have had their pancakes and especially enjoyed the pumpkin pancake; super pumpkin, but without the super dense texture that sometimes accompanies a pumpkin pancake. By far, my favorite dish was one of their specials, a challah bread pudding with fontina cheese and fried eggs on top that was out of this world. The PERFECT use of cheese in a dish. 

As for the atmosphere, I must say... well... the wait can be pretty painful. Go early, avoid the line if you can. I would dock a star for this, but honestly, that challah bread pudding deserves 6 stars and will keep me coming back to this place every time I have out of town company (and any other time in between I can squeeze in).
author: Phil C.

description:
After reading all of the great reviews, I was excited to check out Zazie.  I've come twice now in the past 6 weeks - once with girl friends, the other with the man, and I had a great time on both occasions.  

The wait really isn't THAT long.  Sure, they don't take reservations, but you put your name on the list, hang out outside for 15-20 mins, and voila you're seating and enjoying an enormous latte (excuse me, I ordered the LARGE cappuccino!).

I requested patio seating both times and didn't experience a longer than normal wait either time (1030am with the girls, 1p with the man).  It's worth it to sit in the beautiful back patio, though you have to pass through all the puppy dog looks from the people who just got seated in front of you that are sandwiched in little tables inside.  

I got the Greece omelet both times, love the garlic potatoes, and all of the other dishes look absolutely amazing (french toast looks to die for).  I also thoroughly enjoyed my LARGE soy latte(did I mention it was huge?!?!), and a grapefruit mimosa on the other occasion.

I can't wait to dine again!
author: Alice H.

description: Good stuff. We arrived around 8:30 so there was no wait. We ordered the Challah French Toast with fruits (came with lots of fruits!), French Toast Tahiti, Miracle Pancakes (that day's special was made with cornmeal), Fountainbleau scrambled eggs, and Monaco Poached Eggs. Everything was good, but my favorites were probably the french toast tahiti and miracle pancakes. Service was satisfactory.
author: Jess L.

description: Great brunch spot in Cole Valley with fresh ingredients and organic coffee.  I got the pinot noir benedict.  It was excellent and came with potatoes.  The cafe au lait there comes in a huge bowl big enough for two, so for you people trying to cut down on costs, that will definitely suffice.  The ambiance is welcoming and has a very San Francisco feel to it.  Seating is limited so get there early. You can also choose to sit in the back.  I highly recommend this joint for a great Sunday morning meal!
author: Alex G.

description:
I absolutely ADORE THIS PLACE.

The breakfast is the most exquisite I've had in a long time.  However, sometimes the potatoes here can be a bit overcooked, I just give those pieces of crunchy goodness to my other half!  lol

Be prepared for a wait!  Period.  this place has small seating and if you get there late, you will NOT be happy.  Just write your name down on the list and stay out front, they will skip over you.  Bon Apetite!
author: Wel S.

description:
Oh my gahhhh! So worth the wait. Just wake up early and beat (most of) the rush around 11ish.

Pancake sampler = amazing. And parking's not bad. I'll be back!
author: Olivia G.

description:
I came here for Sunday brunch on a gorgeous and rare summer day in San Francisco.  The fact that the weather was great made the 45 minute wait for a 2-person table a little less painful.  

Once seated, I ordered a latte and the St. Trop, an eggs benedict dish with wild smoked salmon, capers, and red onions.  A great thing about this place is that the eggs are free range eggs, and so you know it did not come from that salmonella factory that everyone is talking about.  Also they use wild salmon as opposed to farm raised salmon.

Overall I enjoyed the balanced flavors of the St. Trop.  Nothing was overdone.  The salad tasted crisp and evenly covered in dressing, not drenched and not dry.  The eggs benedict were good on their own, and the salmon and red onion went very well with it.

My only complaint is that the food did not arrive hot.  My latte was lukewarm at best and the eggs benedict barely had heat in them. 

I would return for brunch if only a 45 minute wait is not required.  But given the popularity of this restaurant, that opportunity may never arise!
author: Erica D.

description:
I don't normally bother writing a review, but given the multitudes of raving reviews I thought I'd throw this in to balance it out.

My buddy and I went for brunch shortly before 10 am (which just barely avoids the long lines in case you do decide to go). I tried both the buttermilk pancake and the ginger pancake, while my buddy ordered the french toast, both of us as part of their "Un Deux Trois" meal (one main, two eggs, and three bacon).

The low rating centers on my buddy's french toast which tasted horrible (when my buddy offered me a sample). We alerted the waiter who looked at it and conceded that the egg was undercooked. He offered to bring a replacement. In the meantime I finished the pancakes (which were okay, nothing that has made me hunger to go back). However, the replacement french toast came back and it still tasted sour. We caught the waiter and he simply sniffed that these were meant to taste this way. What really grates me was that even after the screw-up they charged us the full amount for the french toast.

Bottom-line, not worth the wait as there are other brunch places in SF that are more worth your time, at least if you're looking for pancakes or french toast.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I can attest that this place will *always* be crowded, early or late, rain or shine.  Instead of a hostess, guests have a sign in sheet, where they can see how many groups are above them.  There's an estimate to convert that to a wait time.  I for one appreciated the transparency.

...And I thought the wait was well worth it.  There's an awesome variety of eggs for brunch -- poached, omelet, with bacon, smoked salmon, crab, cheese, veggies, almost any variation you could imagine.  It's impressive how their kitchen can churn out so many picture-perfect poached eggs.  There are also intriguing pancake and french toast options, although they weren't quite as amazing.  All in all, not a bad way to spend a nice weekend morning.
author: Dano W.

description:
I enjoyed my Sunday brunch experience here.  I came here with my wife and some friends, 5 of us total.  Although there was a wait, the list seemed to move pretty quickly, as they have a nice big backyard seating area to compliment the small, cozy indoor part of the restaurant.  The staff seemed well equipped to handle the crowds and did so very nicely.

I was also impressed with the kitchen's efficiency.  Our food was at our table within 10 or 15 minutes of placing the order.  Impressive feat considering they were feeding a lot of people that afternoon.  In keeping with my "tradition" at french places within the city 
(and because I was still full from an all-you-can-eat sushi dinner the night before), I kept things lite and ordered the Nicoise Salad.  It was excellent.  It came with a whole seared tuna "steak" on top of some delicious greens, as well as all the standard Nicoise components.  I went out on a limb and added the anchovies, which were all they were billed to be: salty and rather fishy tasting.  I'm still not sure whether or not I'm an anchovies fan but I thought they worked well with the salad.

Zazie is completely worth the trip to Cole Valley.  If you're coming with a group, I recommend that one of you get there a little early to put your name down on the list.
author: Tim N.

description:
My wife and I went there for lunch on Saturday. The initial wait outside was OK, as the weather was nice. We were seated at the first table inside, along the long bench, next to a bookcase. The waiter, obviously busy, was at first attentive, but he seemed mostly intent on getting us to sign up for the spiffy new app that lets you pay online without waiting for the bill (I think). He did quickly bring us our Mimosa-variant drinks, and took our order from the menu  (I had the French toast with fruit).
     So, as we talked and nursed our drinks, we noticed our food was slow in coming. VERY SLOW. Then my wife commented that some couples who were seated after us had already been served. Then I noticed that one of those couples was already preparing to leave. Where was our food?
    I flagged down the waiter and asked that question. With a sort of "Oh shit" look on his face, he said he would inquire. Five minutes later he returned with plate of fruit (gratis), then stammered out that the place was busy and the kitchen crew overlooked our orders.
     Now wait. It's the kitchen's fault that our food was not prepared in a timely manner?? The waiter who interacts with us is not responsible for attending to our needs (in this case, wanting to eat)? That is NOT the case in any good restaurant I've ever been in.
     The food itself was perfectly acceptable, but we ate in a bummed out mood, paid conventionally, and left.
     Finally, this bit about adding a separate fee that apparently is for the staff's healthcare benefits is, in a word, ridiculous. It just smacks of the owner wanting to get kudos from liberals and progressives for her "caring and evolved" attitude toward her staff. BS. Just incorporate the fee into the prices of the meal. Zazie will succeed or fail on the food and the service, period.
author: R M.

description: I love breakfast so much and this place made me remember why.  When we got there, my friends and I were a bit discouraged because there was a huge crowd on a Saturday morning.  But we entertained ourselves with the local stores nearby.  We waited around 1.5 hour for a party of 3.  Not bad since we didn't get there until 10am.  This place is popular for a reason!  After a while of internal debate, I got the St Trop poached eggs and was so happy.  I got 2 eggs and it was so filling!  The salmon was really fresh and potatoes were so good too.  I tried my friend's French Toast Tahiti - stuffed french toast with banana and walnuts.  That was really good but sooo sweet.  I thought the portions were decently sized.  The wait staff was really nice.  I will definitely go back but probably not a weekend
author: Tammy N.

description:
I'm gonna be honest.. I do not recall what I ordered as my main dish. I do recall what Ligaya and I shared. Challah french toast stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. ::drool:: Oh man, I'm a huge fan of challah.. and this.. this was unlike any challah deliciousness I've ever had. 

Do yourself a favor and bring a tiny bit of a snack and your favorite people to brunch. There is a bit of a wait on the weekend, but it can go by quickly if you've got some friends to chat with. After you're in, the food comes out quickly.
author: Trish F.

description:
I normally go to Zazie for brunch, but I just had dinner there and it was fantastic. They had a vegetarian corn cakes entree that was insanely good - I know I'm going to crave it soon!

I appreciated the selection of reasonably priced wine ($30/bottle). 

The service was a little low/distracted, which was mostly fine since we weren't in a rush.

And yes, they take reservations, so this place is perfect when you want a chill dinner - sometimes, I just can't handle waiting, getting smooshed at the bar, loads of cash, etc. I know, that's make me old.  :)
author: Shal J.

description:
Unlike most people, we came here for DINNER. I got the hanger steak and my friend Ray got the beef shank. The atmosphere was quite nice and they were accommodating with the large luggage that my friend had. This place has so much potential to be a five star place, but the food falls just a bit short.

First, they give you some rolls that they warm in a little toaster oven. I thought this was a cheap trick to make the mediocre bread better. 

We got the fig appetizer. It wasn't too impressive and I think I've made better fig appetizers on my own.

The hanger steak with mashed potatoes and spinach was good but rather oily. I felt my plate was awash in oil and butter. The steak was also not the most impressive.
author: Ryan C.

description: i've been here so many times i do even remember anymore! great food, good service and their outside patio is charming. i've been here for brunch and dinner and all options are great. for brunch i recommend the greek scramble and banana french toast. if you go for dinner then be sure to try their pot de creme with marshmallows! it's to die for. seriously.
author: Ilma K.

description: I have lived around here for a while now and finally had the pleasure to drop in.  Probably the best poached eggs I have had in the city and the outside patio is a great place to sit on a beautiful day.  If you Cole Valley and looking for a place for great brunch or to bring a date, I would totally recommend giving this a look.  Make reservations if you can.  Trust me.
author: Vinh N.

description:
I have mixed reviews.  I had hear a ton of great things about Zazie, decided to try it out on the weekend, knowing there would be a long wait.  We waiting an hour to be seated, which we knew. The staff was very nice and accomidating throughout the waiting and our meal. 

Unfortunately, the food didnt carry its weight.  I had the special omelet, it was pretty poor, tough eggs, no flavor, the potatoes were soggy.  Someone else got the scramble with similar lack luster results.

Overall, to wait an hour on Sunday for breakfast, there better be some darn great food.  Zazie failed to deliver.
author: JD D.

description:
OMG can french toast taste anymore amazing?!!! I highly doubt it.  Got the French Toast Tahiti which was challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnut.  I dont even LIKE french toast but I must say it tasted heavenly.  I was really tempted to give this place a 5 star but I am hesitant to give 5 stars for places Ive only tried once.  I want to come back here for dinner sometime and see how it compares to their great brunch!

stay tuned for an updated review.
author: Paran Y.

description: The legendary line on a weekday for brunch was worth it - tangy beet salad in a splash of colours, a fig sandwich to die for... really quite delicious. Did take a while to be seated and for our food to come, but was soon forgotten in between delicious bites.
author: Adriana K.

description:
Zazie is a great hidden gem in San Francisco.  It's located right in the heart of Cole Valley, which is just about the only decent neighborhood that has not yet been invaded by tourists.  

The place is as quaint and small as Cole Valley itself.  Stop by and put your name on the list.  The note posted next to the list informs you that you might be waiting awhile, since their "best guess" is 3 minutes of wait time for each party on the list.  We showed up at 9:20 am on a Saturday and waited about 5-7 minutes.  The people who showed up at 10 loitered on a sidewalk. waiting for their name to be called.  It looked like it could take awhile.
