Zazie looks like a real French bistro.  There are tiny wooden tables that have seen better days.  There is a tiny spiral staircase that seemingly leads nowhere.  There is a tiny patio that is always full.  There are tiny French movie posters that add a flair of sophistication.  You can almost imagine yourself having breakfast in Paris . . .  

[snaps fingers].  Snap out of it and look around!  Sleepy American couples, sporting bed hair, pajama pants and once-white t-shirts, are drinking coffee trying to wake up.  You know what helps me wake up in the morning?  A shower!  Dorothy, I don't think we're in Paris anymore . . .   Actually, given what they think about showers in Paris . . . Ah, forget it.

I ordered their Un, Deux, Trois special.  The special includes un pancake, deux eggs any style and trois bacon strips for $8.95.  I added un more pancake because I am not French and I like having hearty breakfasts.  While waiting for our food, my friend and I took the time to catch up and enjoy our drinks.  I had regular coffee served in small cups, which our waitress refilled early and often.  My friend had a mocha in a giant bowl with no handles, which looked like something you might make in a beginning pottery class at a community college.  Not sure what kind of coffee they served, but it was really good.

My meal was just OK.  Everything seemed to be slightly overcooked.  My pancakes, both of them, were charred on the bottom just enough to taste the bitterness of blackened dough.  The pancakes were very fluffy, but I just couldn't get over their burnt taste.  The scrambled eggs were a bit too hard, and even bacon was way too crispy.  Oh, and they didn't have sugar-free pancake syrup.

Zazie is a nice neighborhood place with a pleasant European vibe, solid service and decent food.  I live nearby, and I would probably come back here for an early breakfast some other time.  Maybe I'll even get a table on the patio . . .
author: Yan G.

description: This place is seriously going downhill day by day..breakfast used to be fabulous here but the eggs benedict are over cooked and smelly..the dinner service was very mediocre with most of the dishes lacking salt and spice..used to be our go to breakfast place and now am definitely not going back
author: Anam S.

description:
We came here Sunday Morning for some breakfast. I had called during the week and was told that there was going to be a wait for breakfast so to get there early. So when I got there and had to add my name to the bottom of a list I wasnt surprised. The place was packed! We waited about 30-40 mins. Once we got in the place is tiny! I had to literally climb over the couple sitting next to us so I could sit at the table. THIS is the reason I give it 4 stars. We might as well have sat together at one table that was how close we were to each other. 

Now the food is amazing! I had the french toast tahiti style. So good and thick! Filled with bananas and walnuts. I got two slices and that was more than plenty. My better half got the Albert eggs benedict. This would be the reason why I will come back! Egg benedict filled with bacon and fresh salsa! So freaking good! The coffee came in cute bowls and it was plenty. Its a tad pricey for being a breakfast spot but its totally worth it! The only thing is the space. Even walking out we had to wait for the line of waitresses to get the food from the line and move. Besides that I am a fan and will be back for sure!
author: Edwina M.

description:
Mom got the La Mer benedict, which consisted of dungeoness crab and avocado and other usual ingredients. She said it was really good.

I got one gingerbread pancake. Glad I only got one because it was huge (though of course, I could easily finish two with no effort.) It was served with pear and lemon curd, butter and syrup supplied on the side. The pancake itself was alright, nice and fluffy, but nothing TOO special (ginger was too subtle.) What made it good, though, was their house made lemon curd. I usually don't like lemon curd, but I ended up using all of the lemon curd in lieu of the maple syrup.

Didn't find anything special about their jam. Coffee was strong. Latte was great.

I went home with a bag of their gingerbread pancake mix. The recipe requires coffee, buttermilk, butter and eggs. Interesting.

I liked the vibe at Zazie's though - definitely had a European feel to it. 

Server was friendly and attentive.

Will highly return! I want to try their dinner...
author: Grace C.

description:
Came here for dinner instead of brunch (next time if I get the chance). We had the french onion soup, hanger steak and the pork chop. The french onion soup was a bit heavy but overall very nice, a lot of cheese. Towards the middle/end I was getting quite sick of it.

Hanger Steak was great. I had mine medium rare, it was done quite well although a bit more sauce would have made it even better.

Pork chops on the other hand was a bit tough but very very juicy. The spinach was fresh and went well with the pork chops.

Both entrees came with mashed potato which tasted pretty standard.

The place is beautiful, we sat outside on the heated patio and the decorations were very well done. Service was great too.
author: Kevin T.

description: We got into Zazie's minutes before it closed which allowed us to skip the normally long lines. I ordered the La Mer (poached eggs, avocado, and crab meat topped with Hollandaise sauce).  It was excellent and made my top 5 brunch entrees of all time.  My wife really enjoyed her French Toast Tahiti with the toasted banana topping.  The food gets 5 stars.  The indoor ambiance is not great.  Try to sit outdoors if you can. And what is up with the bathroom?  You basically have to walk through the kitchen area to a little postage size closet with a sliding door that doesn't close all the way.  You feel like you're doing your business along with the kitchen staff.  Not a good thing.  I would go back again...but drink a little less coffee.
author: Fran M.

description:
Went to Zazie for the first time this morning - been wanting to go for years - and had a really lovely meal that was well worth the thirty-five minute wait time in the rain (under a awning so we stayed dry).
The Eggs Albert were the best version of Eggs Benedict I've ever had with bacon and chedder and garlic roasted potatoes. The Warm Chai was serven in a bowl (ah, the French) and the French Toast was also really tasty. The service was warm, friendly and efficient and all very reasonably priced.
author: Jimmy G.

description: Zazie never disappoints in their culinary breakfast making skills. Ask for their home made habanero hot sauce!
author: Joe M.

description:
Came by on a weekday morning with Dr. P so the wait was only about 15 minutes.  We were seated outside and when the sun peeked out, it was pretty nice.  

I had the Eggs Monaco which was a benedict with prosciutto and tomatoes provencales.  I love tomatoes provencales.  Dr. P had the La Mer which was a benedict with dungeness crab.  Both were delicious with a very light and lemony- hollandaise sauce.  So good.  We also split one gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and poached pears.  I am not one for sweets but I could eat this anytime.

The place is super charming and the service was good.  I'll be back soon.
author: Seong P.

description:
Went for brunch today with the bf and enjoyed the sun on their lovely little patio out back. Today's specials were an omelet with chicken apple sausage, heirloom tomatoes, basil and mozzarella and then cornmeal pancakes with their amazing lemon curd on top. Naturally, I got both and quite naturally they were both dee-lish. So good. Best brunch I've had in a good long while. 

Oh, and to the two lovely gay men at the table next to us - Yes, my boyfriend is cute. Thank you for noticing. :-)
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I looooooooooooove brunch, and their La Mer poached eggs were fabulous! Dungeness crab with avocado and hollandaise sauce? What more can you ask for? They also have amazing Tahitian stuffed French Toast yum!

There was about an hour wait for a table of 5 on a Sunday afternoon, but it was definitely worth the wait.
author: May W.

description: Be patient, there is always a wait. I think the locals love this place because it is the only breakfast place around this neighborhood with variety in its menu. I have been here a couple of times for brunch to meet friends who live in the city. I had to drive in. I have not been impressed by the food. I know tons of better breakfast places both in and out of the city that cost less. Breakfast with coffee cost me $22 including tax, tip, and health tax. I had one of the breakfast specials today, the Eggs En Fonte (?), which came in a skillet about 4 inches in diameter. The amount of food that occupied the skillet did not fill in this tiny area. It basically was one tiny, thin square piece of  polenta topped with bits of mushroom and spinach with a splash of tomato sauce topped with two eggs. The taste was not awful, but I would not crave it again and would not recommend it to anyone. It came with choice of salad (just lettuce sprinkled with olive oil) or home fries. I opted for salad, but my friend chose home fries which amounted to a small pile of whole roasted garlic cloves and about three chunks of potato. The restaurant has a cool vibe. Tables are a little crowded for me, but I am a little claustrophobic. Service was odd, not quite friendly and somewhat temperamental (waitress seemed pissed off when we got there, but her mood improved by the end). Price and quality would not make me want me to return again.
author: Carrie W.

description:
I lived across the street from Zazie and it is still my favorite breakfast in SF. There is usually a wait in front but the wait isn't bad. Sign your name up and specify your next door. Head into Finnegan's Wake and  sip on a bloody while you wait for your table. the host will pop his head in and call your name. 

You can't go wrong with anything here. As with most of their orders, you can order a full, half, 1, 2 or 3 eggs. Some of my favorite dishes are the poached eggs: Albert, St. Trop and Monaco. Gingerbread pancake and the French Toast Tahiti w/ stuffed caramelized banana's and walnuts.  To finish it off, eggs dishes come with roasted garlic cloves.  

Although I've only been there once for dinner, the roasted duck excellent
author: Brandon D.

description:
You know how you go to a place and the line is RIDICULOUSLY long and you wonder if it's really worth it?

This place is totally worth it!

Eggs benedict can be ordered with one, two, or three eggs, which makes sharing so incredibly easy. Roasted garlic with your potatoes. Fresh juices. Cute French atmosphere with skylights. This place is the perfect combination of charm and delicious food. 

I love it!
author: Chung N.

description:
Midweek vaca to the City gave C and I a chance to really take in the city. Main goal for the trip was the De Young's Impressionist exhibit on loan from the d'Orsay. 

Anyhow, while at breakfast we asked our friendly barista for a recommendation for lunch near GGPark and she mentioned Zazie's with a hands down affinity for the French cafe. 

Cole Valley proved a very pleasant neighborhood and pretty accessible to the park as it is not too far from Haight or Lincoln. The address is small and quaint, while a busy flow gave the lunch crowd a good vibe. Service is casual and competent and the menu tempts indulgence. I have sworn to eat a Monte Cristo whenever I encounter one, but broke from this practice when noticing the Croque Monsieur on the sandwich list. (I just ate at Mollie's again the previous Saturday, u know!) 

I shot for the Nicoise as it has been quite a while since the days of Elements in Santa Barbara and their incredible red wine vin and haricot verts. Zazie sears a favorable portion of Ahi for their Nicoise and citrus zests their green beans. TDF. Wish the olives were pitted, but it is always good to encounter a challenge.

C ordered the amazing Fig Figaro Sandwich special that is unjusticed by description. There is a garlic butter fry to the toast and the prosciutto is "silk teddy sexy" while the chevre has the perfect tart cream nature to coax the fig into sweet splendor. Awesome sandwich and great accent for texture with the wilted spinach. 

Be sure to start with their french onion soup as we did to share. Can't pass that up. 

Their wine list is modest but well selected and the garden patio would have totally enhanced our experience if there was seating available, but I cannot complain as we lucked out choosing the sunniest days in the City for the entire year. We'll stroll back their next visit and I will surely go for the Croque Monsieur!
author: Nathaniel M.

description: Probably one of the best eggs benedit I've had.  So playful with different combos and well executed.  I picked the Albert..it had tomatoes (seasoned with something that made them firey and yummier than usual) with bacon and cheddar plus hollandaise sauce.  Really good combo.  Can't say much of the home fries, they were good.  It was tasty and well priced.
author: Maylin G.

description:
I had heard great reviews of Zazie and was excited to try it this weekend for my birthday brunch. We wrote our names on the list and waited for about an hour for our table. The two adjacent restaurants were almost completely empty, while Zazie was overflowing with hungry patrons. 

I got the Zazie hot tea and an elderflower mimosa, both of which were delicious. Jeremy ordered a bagel and spinach salad with walnuts, gorgonzola and pear, which he deemed "very good." My bff and I each ordered a benedict with two eggs. I ordered the benedict with bacon, white cheddar and salsa and asked for my eggs to be poached easy and bff ordered the benedict with prosciutto and tomatoes provencale. I also ordered a cup of the white bean soup with kale. This is where things started going downhill. 

The benedicts came before the soup and were lukewarm upon arrival. Both of our eggs were poached medium-hard, neither of our english muffins were toasted thoroughly, and the cheese was not even close to being melted. The potatoes were decent, though uninspiring and the soup (after cooling off for 20 minutes) would have been better if the beans were slightly more tender and the broth properly salted. To top it off, the server left the check on the table halfway through the meal without offering another mimosa or asking how our meal was. 

That said, we went at the tail end of a busy Sunday. My bff and I both agreed that, properly prepared, the dishes had great potential. All ingredients were fresh and the hollandaise was light and tasty. When I return, during the week when they are not as busy, I vowed to order the same dishes so that I can hopefully update my review with a more positive assessment. For now, all I have to say is it really isn't worth the wait - unless you are having a bagel and a salad.
author: Erin K.

description:
I went for Sunday brunch today. Reviews about their chill atmosphere, garden patio and rustic feel led us here. Our table for 6 had to wait 30+min. Excepted since this place gets so many 4+stars. No problem there. 

Ok but then we had two coffee spills from two different waiters. I had their La Mer poached eggs. Eggs were slightly cold and c'mon anyone could've made this. Nothing special or interesting about the meal at all. 

If i lived within walking distance, I'm sure I'd go again. But it's not something extra effort deserves. Go here if you want an ok atmosphere, and ahh ok whatever food experience. Their whole appeal wears off after the first 10 min you're there. 

Moving on....
author: Francine T.

description: Popoular for Breakfast and Brunch on weekends.  Not a fain of waiting.  I prefer off ours and lunch.
author: Taylor M.

description:
Zazies is fantastic and a local favorite.  It's one of my top fav places for brunch.  I think the best menu items are their eggs benedict (I try them everywhere and this is one restaurant that can make hollandaise) and their BLT sandwich (best in town).  Really cute atmosphere, although cramped, but the outdoor patio is best if weather permits.

Zazies only gets four stars because the wait is out of control.  Its usually around an hour.  Sometimes more and once in a while less.  However, hungry people become angry people and I've had some very unenjoyable meals there due to the wait.  It's not the fault of Zazie at all.  They handle it quite well.  However, keep this in mind if you want to go here on the weekends.  Eat another meal to hold you over until you get sat. 

On average weekend brunch in SF is about a 3-4 hour ordeal.  Not sure why everyone finds that acceptable.  I'm over it!
author: Doxie M.

description:
It was my friend's birthday and her birthday wish was for all of us to spend the day at the Academy of Science at Golden Gate Park. The birthday brunch was our other friend's idea.

Date: April 27, 2009 @ 10:20 AM

Girls:  Me, Alexis, Jannette and Heather. 

Occasion:  Alexis' Birthday Brunch/Pre-Academy of Science Brunch where we spent the rest of the day celebrating her birthday.

Decor:  Very cute, very small country kitchen with brick walls and high ceiling. Courtyard dining weather-permitting.

Ambiance: Cozy like having brunch at your grandma's kitchen in Provence.

Service:  Efficient and friendly.

Social Scene: Cole Valley  Morning People 

What we ordered:
Salud!:  2 mimosas
               2 hot tea in  cool metal teapots
Shared:  French Toast Tahiti stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts topped with grilled bananas.
Me:  La Mer:  Poached eggs with dungeness crab and avocados
Alexis:  New York Scramble(Scrambled eggs with smoked salmon and cream cheese)
Heather:  Eggs Pierre Noirre (Poached eggs with bacon and tomatoes provencale)
Jannette:  Eggs Italie-(crambled eggs with roasted tomatoes, cream cheese and basil)
*All the above came with roasted potatoes and english muffin

Tab:  $102.00 including tax and tip

Overall:

1. That French Toast, yes that French Toast Tahiti  has made me and my girlfriends speechless. It was so delicious! Thick bread. Light. Sweet with the right amount of mashed bananas and walnut and those wonderful grilled bananas on top.  Good thing I live across the Bay, otherwise I will be eating lots of French Toast Tahiti at this place.
2. All the egg breakfasts were delicious. The poached eggs were perfectly cooked with the yolk perfectly done.
3. I will skip the La Mer with dungeness crab.  It didn't have enough crab on it and I barely tasted the crab.  Not worth the $16 we paid for.


We gave Alexis her presents:  candles, Anthropologie mug, and a bunch of cute girlie stuff.  We all had a great time on a Monday morning all looking cute in our summer dresses (and freezing) and had a fun time in the City instead of working our butts.

This place is so cute it has become one of my fave brunch places and will not hesitate to get my sleepy butt out of bed to drive across the Bay to sink my teeth into Zazie's  French Toast.  Given that I'm not a morning person, that says a lot! Yes, it's that yummy!!!!

Good job, Heather, for finding this place for our girls' day.
author: Leah E.

description: Maybe the 75 minute wait for a table put me into an off mood to start, but I also think that maybe  I just did not order the best options available for the place... to start off, after that long of a wait, you've got to expect manna from heaven in every sip/bite that you take. I on the other hand went in with I thought, optimistic expectation. Ordered a cup of coffee (2.95/cup)...it was weak and flat and tasted kind of like dirty water for me... I'm not even a big coffee snob, but sheesh, SF has some expectations. My work has a 16 cup pot of Starbucks which at least tastes like a remnant of coffee. Also, my boyfriend ordered a bloody Mary, to which they said they were out of, only to see roughly 30 minutes later, 3 bloody Mary's being poured out on the kitchen counter. Then my Monaco Eggs were good, but really lacking in flavor. The potatoes were very good. Crispy, brown, garlicky and well seasoned. I also, due to my dismay of coffee choice, ordered a blackberry mimosa. It was really syrupy in the bottom and just wasn't as refreshing as I'd hoped. Anyway, Zazie left me a little wanton after brunch... Cute decor; nice staff...not worth the wait.
author: Brianna S.

description:
Zazie IS part of this complete breakfast, go here to get your fancy tickled beyond belief. To get the negatives out of the way first: be prepared for a possible 30-45 minute wait and silly expensive mimosas. Nevertheless, the poached egg dishes are the tastiest things; I highly recommend the one with bacon, salsa fresca and white cheddar, and next time I plan on getting the one with prosciutto and tomatoes. 

The waiters are amazingly friendly and attentive considering the chaos, and they never ignored my coffee and water cups. 

Overall, Zazie is a lovely place, be sure to stop by.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
I have been craving American breakfast / brunch for a while. A friend easily picked Zazie after I begged her to go a breakfast with me.  

I used to be a big breakfast person, but no long! A light and warm breakfast is a delight of my day. Zazie has a ton of choices.

We picked a window-side seat and made ourselves comfortable to fit this homey dinning environment.   

I was happy about the food. The Gingerbread pancake I had was baked perfectly. A mouth-full bite of the pancake mixed with butter, pure maple syrup, and few ginger slices hit the peak. The portion of the meal was just about right for me, but I wish I could have a side dish such as spinach & portobello mushroom salad because it's fresh and flavorful. Yes, I did go cross the table and 'steal' some of my friend's mushroom. Yumm. 
   
The only concern I have is the long waiting time. We waited for about 25 mins after placing three orders...it's 10 am Friday morning. My friend was even wondering what he has done to that lovely waitress. :) She is super nice and friendly by the way. 

I will def. go back again for both breakfast, lunch, or brunch.
author: Jade L.

description:
My first time at Zazie will forever be marked by the bittersweet goodbye of my work colleague Lauren.  I was honored to be invited by the three coolest ladies from the third floor to partake of "breakfast at lunch".  I couldn't help but order the "la mer benedict"-- I mean, how can you pass up dungeness crab and hollandaise sauce? For dessert, we all shared a poppyseed pancake with lemon curd. 

au revoir good friend.
author: Lisa R.

description:
I come here for brunch anytime a friend from out of town comes to visit. My fave thing from here is definitely the scrambled eggs avignon with eggplant, zucchini, and tomatoes provencale, which is only available on weekdays. I love the herbs in the dish and the home fries are always amazing with big pieces of soft garlic. My mom likes the gingerbread pancakes which are HUGE (the size of my face!) and has amazing gingerbread flavor. I could never finish 2 gingerbread pancakes but they taste great as a snack anyways! I've also had their croque madame before which I didn't LOVE. It was decent but not creamy or grilled enough.
Definitely, the next time I come back, I want to try the eggs la mer, which are definitely on the pricey side. 
Side note, service can be patchy here but that is definitely due to the crowds of people who wait here for breakfast, lunch, or brunch.
author: Fiona N.

description:
I don't mind waiting if there is light at the end of the tunnel, and this place came through in the clutch. My party of 4 waited about an hour for our table, but we eventually were seated at a nice table by the window. The service was prompt (not rushed), seeing as though they have scores outside waiting to come in.

At our table, I got the fountainebleu scramble, which was, in my opinion, the best thing at the table. Other items included the Mexico scramble, very good, the poached eggs Monaco, excellent, and then, randomly the fourth person in our group got granola. Boooooo. We all shared a french toast, which was sublime, but we meant to get the French Toast Tahiti and ended up getting regular french toast, but that was our fault on the ordering.

Left satisfied and hope to return, but if you don't like waiting, don't bother.
author: Brian B.

description: Doesn't get any better than this. One of the best breakfast spots in the city. Try the warm cream cheese coffee cake IF its not sold out.
author: Sofia O.

description:
I went today for brunch and, yes, big lines and their eggs Benedict are good and interesting - I had La Mer and the crab and avocado combination ans well as the fries and the garlic coming with them were good. Service was good as well.
However, as other yelpers noticed, it becomes pricey for what it is and the waiting is another problem so not sure when I will go back...
Same for their dinner - food is good and everything is great but overall not the place I would go very often...
author: VIORICA C.

description:
wow. There is always a huge line outside Zazie on the weekends, but the wait goes fast and is worth it. Incredible menu, great service. I shared the Mediterranean plate and a salad. Will definitely be returning many, many times.

Gorgeous back patio with heaters is worth requesting and waiting for. I hear it is even more romantic at night... lit up with white lights.
author: Betsy F.

description:
I almost feel as though I am unworthy of reviewing such a great restaurant,  a charming,  excellent place to dine, enjoy and relax. The food is wonderful, try the Coq a Vin, the fresh large salads, beautiful desserts. It doesn't get any better then this, plan a trip to the Cole Valley neighborhood, visit Zazie and the boutique shops on Cole Street for a pleasant experience. And Zazie is a ROMANTIC place for a date.
Recommended highly!!!
author: Rich G.

description:
In the heart of Cole Valley hides this hidden little treasure....I'm just sad I didn't find it until I moved out of the city. :( But better late than never, I guess.

So it's Sunday brunch and the girls and I decide to check out Zazie. Of course it's Pride weekend, and luckily it seems as if everyone has gone somewhere else and there is no wait...

Since we are famous for being indecisive about food, the girls and I decide to get a little bit of everything and try it. Everything was AMAZING! I'm not a huge fan of hollandaise, but the stuff they have here is light, fluffy, and delicious. We had the "La Mer" which was a fresh crab benedict, and the one with the prosciutto and the tomatoes provencale. Yummz.... Both were equally as delicious. We also shared a gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and pear. 

My friend Vivi had the french toast and bananas and walnut which I couldn't help but stare at, but I was so happy with my own meal I have made a mental note to come back and try it. 

We had mango mimosas and elderflower mimosas. They also have a "Build your Own Mimosa" kinda deal, but I wasn't in the mood to serve my own mimosas...so I just went with mango. Can ANYTHING mango, NOT be delicious? 

I didn't plan on spending that much on brunch, but hands down worth every penny. The service was impeccable and everyone was awesome!

Will be making a trip back here soon to try all the other stuff on the menu...

5 Yummerz stars!!!
author: Ann T.

description:
... maybe a 3.5...

i used to go crazy about coming here for brunch. I guess it was the fact that people were always lining up! 
I've come here several times despite the long wait and honestly I wasn't as impressed as I imagined I would be. Don't get me wrong, its good... but it just doesn't seem that special. Perhaps it was all the expectations i had!

Things I would recommend: 
- gingerbread pancakes - fluffy, sweet, flavorful, and I like the lemony custard on top and pear! 
- the un, deux, trois - comes with some arrangement of one pancake, 2 pieces of bacon, and 3 eggs
- croque madame 
- eggs benedict - esp the florentine and pierre noire 
the homefries are big thick cut pieces of potatoes usu. cooked and flavored well. 
They also have a pretty nice drink menu for brunch including mimosas and other sake cocktails. 

I love sitting in the little back patio on a sunny morning/afternoon! That being said, i love the neighborhood of cole valley in general. 
I will say that this is the best french food in the near vicinity.
author: Tim B.

description:
Short wait. Great cozy atmosphere. Eggs were perfection. French toast Tahiti was a little slice of heaven although I'd never be able to eat more than one sweet, sweet bite. 
The wait staff is delightful, quick, and attentive.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Zazie is a fantastic place for brunch. I have never been for dinner, so this review is for brunch only. I have been here multiple times and have always had fantastic food (favorites are the french toast tahiti, the poached egg with spicy tomato sauce and the spinach scramble) with great service. My only complaint would be the amount of garlic in the potatoes, sometimes my portion is almost all garlic, with a few potatoes thrown in. 

If you can get a spot on the patio, this just heightens the experience. Be prepared for a wait, but a wait that's definitely worth it. If you can, get there early on a weekend for a better possibility of fast seating. In all, a really stellar experience.
author: Rachel K.

description: Gorgeous, light and bright, outdoor seating, super cute, fabulous brunches!, with plenty for vegetarians to choose from, and reasonable time to wait (grab coffee and check out the super cute Cole Valley stores). I started going to Zazie since 1999. As all Yelpers have said, the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd are amazing!!! As are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, and the poached eggs -- hollandaise sauce is hard to make, and they do it perfectly, which tells me that they keep everything FRESH -- except the service, which is friendly & attentive! Awesome, awesome!
author: Heather S.

description:
My boyfriend of 2 1/2 years took me here for our first date, so this place holds a dear place in my heart.  We've been here for each anniversary and have brought family here because it's such a charming French restaurant- the food, atmosphere and staff are wonderful.

Mmm, how can you resist a hot roll?  I don't usually eat white bread, but when it's fresh, I'm totally enamored.  I think the mussels are really one of the best I've ever tried- ask for more bread to dip in the leftover cream sauce!  My favorite is the grilled hanger steak w/ mashed potatoes.  I also really like the spinach stuffed chicken and the coq au vin.  The baked hot chocolate is fantastic!  It's definitely to be shared because you can only really take a few bites of it.  The pot de crème and crème brulee are pretty delicious also.

Yesterday, our server noticed that my boyfriend opened a birthday card.  We didn't even ask, but when our dessert came, she brought crème brulee with a lit candle- free of charge!  How thoughtful!

I imagine coming here many times in the future.

Side note:  When I eat out, I like to have really rich food (I have a salad everyday for lunch!), and Zazie serves a pretty decadent dinner.  I came here for brunch once and ordered the crab cakes benedict.  The hollandaise was just too light for me...haha
author: Teena O.

description: This little bistro in Cole Valley is a total win in my book. Very good food and service.  I had the Benedict, and it was excellent.  I doesn't hurt that the coffee is also excellent and free flowing,  Neat, quaint decor with great people-watching window seats.
author: Arnold Y.

description:
"Would you like to sit inside sir? Or on the patio outside?"
" Patio please"

I weave through a few tables, criss-cross a few bus boys and step onto the small, yet amazingly beautiful patio area. The maître d tells me to pick any seat as he hands me my menu. Sorry sir, but I already know what I want. I've been eye-fucking this specific menu for the past few days. No need to wait for me! And then my waitress comes...

wow..WOW! She's beautiful :)! She has short hair, a beautiful smile, and a tattoo on her arm that's half covered - which was kind of cute because it gave this whole "I really should cover up this tattoo, since I'm at work. BUT I guess I can get away with showing half "

After enjoying the scenery, the evenly tanned man handed me a plate of the St. Trop. Holy hell! This looks great! But how does it taste? I slice the yolk, letting the golden dew flow over the salmon.

Oh. My. God. I'm a picky eater, but I have to admit...this was the single best breakfast item I've ever had.. The tender salmon was perfectly complimented by the sweetness of the onions, the salty capsules of capers, the light yet warm English muffin, and the perfectly poached egg. This was amazing. The home fries were teased with a pinch of seasoning, while still maintaining the warm flavor of the potato. Everything was there: flavor, texture, salt, sweet.

After having an orgasm in my mouth, I left the restaurant feeling incredibly good.

Great decor, good quality ingredients, great service, amazing flavors. By far the best breakfast I've ever had (so far).

I give Zazie a tremendous 4.1 out of 5.
author: Ray M.

description:
The Niman Ranch burger: clearly the way that dead cow is meant to be cooked and served (on a rather delicious bun with aioli, white cheddar, grilled tomatoes, and arugula, served with potatoes and roasted garlic).

Hello, Zazie, my name is Jennie, and I would like to have ten million of your babies.  We have so much in common: you like food, I like food, we both spell our names with an "ie" at the end...

I went on Friday afternoon around noon, and ended up having to wait about ten minutes for a table.  We were seated in the backyard patio on a perfectly warm and sunny afternoon.  Wine was ordered.  Food was the subject of much debate - do we split 20 dishes between the two of us?  Do we find a sugar daddy so that we can order one of everything?  (Prices are pretty okay - about $11 for main dishes on the average.)

I have a hard time making decisions about food when everything looks good and I'm starving.  I ended up with the burger and splitting the mediterranean plate (grilled eggplant, tomatoes, mushrooms, green beans, feta, etc), but there was lemon-ricotta tortellini with white wine sauce that tempted me greatly.  (In the end, I'm a girl who likes her meat.)

We stayed an awfully long time, but the server was nice about it.  She was also nice to the jerk who piled an extra plate on her arm and said, "Atta girl."  

It doesn't hurt that it's right next to the N-Judah Carl & Cole stop.  Actually, it does hurt.  It hurts my wallet, and it's going to hurt my soul everytime I go by and can't afford to stop.
author: Jennie K.

description:
I love Zazie and it's probably one of my most frequented places for brunch.

Location: It's in an ok location on Cole Valley. There are other restaurants, little bars and small shopping spaces around. Not too amazing for those taking public transit. Good parking though.

Space: Nice, brunchy, above-dinner decor. I love, love, love their back yard space. On a sunny Sunday, with the sun beaming down at you...amazing. Definitely a place for friends, not dates.

Ambiance: Fun people from everywhere in the city. Everyone is here at brunch. 

Service: There's a super cute waiter with dark-rimmed glasses and a perpetual smile...I love him. The wait time for brunch can sometimes be more than one can bear...up to an hour at times. 

Food/Drink: The food is nice and delicious. Nothing too, too special, but great for brunch with friends. Amazing mimosa selection. Meaning they bring you over a bottle of champagne and syrups of your choice ...including elderflower! Their home fries also have roasted garlic cloves in there...amazing!

Overall: Great place to come for some weekend (or weekday for the unemployed) brunch. Who doesn't wanna get drunk by noon?
author: SF N.

description:
I am on a constant quest to find the best brunch place in every town I visit often--namely, New York + Philly (Carmen's Country Kitchen, baby!). As a native San Franciscan, I struggled to find the best brunch place. I have one rule for what defines great breakfast/brunch joint for me: they must make dishes I can't/am too lazy to make at home. 

I can't believe it took me all of my 21 years to finally make it to Zazie in Cole Valley! For years I would drive by on the weekends and see masses of people leaning on parking meters and just plain loitering on the sidewalk desperate to get in. I finally dragged my boyfriend there on a Wednesday morning to avoid the brunch rush. We got there at around 10:40am and the place was pretty full but there was no wait. By 11:30, people began to sign their names on the waiting list and take their usual places outside. 

 I ordered an omelet with portobello  mushrooms, brie, and chicken apple sausage. mmmm there is nothing more decadent than melted brie. My bf ordered the deux deux troix (two pillowy and huge buttermilk pancakes, two eggs, three chicken apple sausages). We had the best time, the place is so cute and our waitress was incredibly sweet and helpful. Definitely planning to make it back soon, this time with the whole fam!
author: Sara L.

description:
I went here for breakfast a couple of weekends ago. I went because of the great reviews and because I was awake well before they opened...I do not like waiting an hour for any restaurant. 

I am not too sure why it is so popular. The food was okay, I mean pretty good breakfast food; but nothing extraordinary. I like the fact that we got to pick wherever we wanted to sit since we were 2nd on the waiting list before they even opened their doors. But it is very crowded in there; kudos for the person who wanted to arrange the table plan based on fitting as much people possible at a time to make the most money. But for me, I felt like it was too cramped. 

I don't think I would give them another try based on the info I mentioned above; I am just so happy I didn't have to wait an hour like some people.

Just For You Café still remains my favorite breakfast spot in  the city...
author: Kimberly H.

description: The patio was a great place to be seated, the food was great, very tasty, however if you have a gluten allergy be careful as I don't think our waiter knew what that meant, and a reaction ensued.  Fortunately, were OK.
author: Paul D.

description:
This place is great for brunch. If you are a lover of eggs benedict like i am you will love this place. I got their Eggs Benedict with crab and it was the best Eggs Benedict's I have ever had! The wait is pretty long so make sure to get there 40 minutes before you actually want to start eating. It's pretty popular. 

I believe there are some nights where you can bring your dog with you and sit outside on the back porch and enjoy a wonderful meal under little white christmas like lights. It is a great place and I can't wait to go back!
author: Jessica D.

description: Came here on Father's day with the family. Got there early to get our names on the list outside the door and really only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table for 6. Service was great, our waitress was very friendly and provided wonderful service. I had the Mexico scramble which was ok...not that great but my mother had the french toast which was wonderful, and my father and daughter had the pancakes which were also good. I personally thought it was a hit or miss, I would go again but my breakfast wasn't really that great. I truly just thing it was a poor choice on my part, but the rest of my party enjoyed their food.
author: Tori M.

description:
Zazie is also wonderful for dinner, it turns out. Why am I not surprised? Even though we didn't have a reservation, they took us from the waiting list just at the time we said we'd be available and let us stay through all three courses well past their closing time. 

What we had to start....
*SALAD BETTERAVE- a good salad, featuring golden beets! (which are rare to find in food, but so delicious)

*PATE- mmmm....when is Pate ever bad? I thought the bread it was served on could have been a little more interesting that what seemed like plain toasted breakfast bread.

*MUSSELS MARINIERES- OUTSTANDING!!! Perfectly cooked, seasoned, and served warm.

What we had for mains... (only two dishes, as the three of us are small/slow eaters and could hardly finish these despite their brilliance)....

*MOROCCAN LAMB STEW- well, I make a moroccan stew at home. its not bad. but its not this good either. the lamb is soooo tender, in perfect (large) spoon sized chunks to pair with bites of flavorful couscous and ALMONDS (the apparent trick to good moroccan stew!)

*GRILLED RANCH HANGER STEAK- not the most French thing on the menu, but cooked just right, with fresh asparagus (its the season, don't ya know!) and fluffy, not too buttery, mashed potatoes.

We indulged in the three desserts for a fixed price- even though we all claimed to be entirely stuffed from the meal and 2 bottles of wine (Côtes du Rhône is a great inexpensive red that I buy often at the market and that Zazie happily carries). I can't remember exactly what their contents included, but one was a bread pudding (3/4 stars), another was a chocolate mousse (4/4 stars), and the third was some sort of berry fruit tart concoction that deserves 5/4 stars. 

Yeah...Zazie is pretty damn good.
author: Raquel C.

description:
Comme Ci, Comme Ça 

I had an okay time.  The food was okay, but not great.  I'd come here again, but probably not all the time.  When I compare this to La Note in Berkeley, I'd rather go to La Note.
author: George U.

description:
First, I think the hype around this place was what ultimately led to my disappointment. The food was good, but not great, and quite frankly it's way overpriced. Our table shared a variety of things, and nothing was so spectacular that I would come here again. 

But the real reason this place is getting 2 stars is the general attitude of the staff. The host was extremely rude to both my party and the one in front of us, for absolutely no reason. The mentality was as if we should be honored to be allowed to eat here, not that we were paying customers. On top of that, our waiter was clumsy, forgetful, and didn't bring us anything we asked for (we had to get a bus boy to refill our water after sitting empty for 20 minutes).  There's better food to be had, at a better price, with better service elsewhere in the city.
author: Henry S.

description:
I LOVE this place.  He had the Eggs Florentine, I had the Tahiti French Toast aaaand we decided to go crazy and order a pancake to share. We originally went to Zazie to try the magical seasonal pumpkin pancakes but we had just missed them by a day.  Alas, Zazie pumpkin season was over.  Noooooooo!  Why oh why??!  So we opted for the gingerbread pancakes.  Boy oh boy everything was delicious and we were stuffed up to our eyeballs.  The lattes were served deliciously hot and generously in those bowl cups.  

It's definitely a cute little place and they really maximize the space.  On a nice day try and score a patio table in the back but make sure you don't sit next to umbrella hogs.  The sun was pretty strong and our neighbors kept and re-positioning and moving the umbrella leaving the sun shining straight into my eyes.  The service is really friendly and they offer their pancake mix and other goodies for sale.

Can't wait to go back this fall and really try the pumpkin pancakes!
author: Steph N.

description:
I had heard good things about this place so we checked it out for Friday morning brunch. The place was hopping, but not too crowded, no wait for a table and the food came out in decent time. I was excited to try the Challah French Toast and Gingerbread Pancakes and I loved that you can order just 1 piece of each (the whole menu is priced 1 item/2item/3item)! I also tried the standard Egg/Homefries and Toast plate. 

The french toast with fruit is superb, the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and pears are incredible, but nothing could outshine their AMAZING homefries! So garlicky and delicious, I've been having dreams about them ever since! Did I mention they were amazing? Also, I don't know how they did it, but their toast was also incredible...I mean really, how do you make toast incredible?? 

This place is definitely worth a visit and lives up to the hype! I'll be back for sure.
author: Tiffany O.

description: This is a review of their brunch:  101 ways to dress a poached egg and they do this right.  Also, mimosas served as a bottle of bubbly and a carafe of juice - yes please!  The outdoor area is romantic and the staff is on it.  The wait can be daunting, but it is usually quicker than it looks.
author: Tia B.

description: ZOMFG.  I might move back to SF so that every morning of my life I can stand in the fog with the 25 or so other people who are also waiting for Zazie to open.  Somehow I had never had a poached egg before, and the St. Trop eggs with wild smoked salmon, capers, and red onions BLEW MY FRICKING SOCKS OFF.  If I had been able to peel my face off of my plate long enough, I probably would have attacked the neighboring diners, because everything looked and smelled so damn delish.  Well done, Zazie...well done.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Admittedly, if it weren't for a girl's night and NO CORKAGE Tuesdays, and being out in the Castro already for Yoga Tree, I would not have come to Cole Valley (because it is on the other side of the city for me!) but I am so glad I came to Zazie's last night for dinner, and will certainly be back for their brunch service. They have such a charming back patio, and last night, I'm sure the weather was in the mid-50s, but their well-engineered heat lamps helped us forget we were outdoors in a SF restaurant! Love the no corkage policy! We brought in several bottles of wine, and they were so hospitable in giving us their different glasses that were appropriate for the certain pours we had - a petite syrah, a cab, and flutes for our prosecco... and the best thing? An ice bucket for the prosecco. Who wants to have warm prosecco, right??? 

We had a great server, Christine (very knowledgeable and personable), and a server-in-training (who was French, nice touch!) but was very good about checking up on us, and making sure we had a great time. Given, I have the most fun group of girlfriends to dine with, all open-minded in regards to trying new foods, so we always have a fabulous time together, but the restaurant was so warm, and we started very late. I got out of yoga late, and we didn't put our orders in until at least 9:15pm when we were all settled (and the restaurant closes at 9:30pm!), but they were so attentive, up until 10:45pm. Sorry guys! We just had a good time, and so much wine to enjoy, we didn't want to leave! We'll just have to start earlier next time! Didn't really take a careful look at the dining room, but it was quite packed for a later dinner hour on a Tuesday. Not much going on in Cole Valley, but diners who know what's up. Plus, they have a strong Zagat following (which I discovered on my way out!) and I wholeheartedly feel they deserve it.

Menu items we enjoyed - the French onion soup, mmmm! It was the perfect size, and the gruyere (I think) that coated it was gooey, but caked on. I was at a French bistro, so I had to have French onion, right?! My friends had the rabbit (Le Lapin- slowly braised Sonoma rabbit w/mustard sauce, mushrooms, and fettuccine persillad) which was not gamey at all, and I enjoyed the Salmon en Papillote- w/ fingerling potatoes, spinach, leeks, and fennel, w/ shallot cream sauce. I've probably had better salmon elsewhere, but the portion size was perfect, and the experience made it exceptional.

Zazie is a great restaurant that is no-frills, and even with limited offerings on their menu, they do it all well. It is a great place for a girls night out, and a first date! It's casually elegant, and the prices are very reasonable. They even feature a prix-fixe  so you can get a starter, main course, and dessert, all for $23.50! Bring some bottles of wine and you have a fun, affordable night!

The best thing about French restaurants??? Their desserts! We ended our night on a very sweet note with the Souffle Gateau Zazie- meyer lemon and white chocolate molten cake w/ berry coulis and fresh strawberries! Best thing ever, and ample size for 4 girls. They are so careful about their precision, that if there is one minute flaw, they will re-do the souffle (which they admitted to us). It was so delightful!!!

My only complaint??? They don't take reservations for Brunch (that's their biggest crowd) and they don't take AMEX....  I will be back Zazie!
author: Tammy H.

description: This is probably my favorite places to dine at. And one of my favorite things to do in the city is try new restaurants. It also helps that its in my neighborhood so I can stroll over for brunch or dinner anytime I get a craving. The brunch here is amazing! But expect a long wait since they don't allow reservations. Also they have a Prix fixe dinner, every night, all night for $25. Which is a really good deal. They have such a nice patio so if its a nice day I highly recommend sitting outside. In the evening they have lights draped about making it a romantic date place. Everything I've tried on the menu has been amazing so really you can't go wrong.
author: Melissa V.

description:
I have always loved Zazie for brunch (on weekdays b/c I'm not patient enough for weekends) -- bread pudding pancakes, helLO.

Really just compelled to write a review after the stellar service we received tonight. The wait staff has always been tremendously friendly -- and our waiter tonight took the cake. Charming man with a bit of a UK (not sure which) accent -- very attentive, slightly theatrical, and all-around awesome waiter. We blindly ordered a bottle of red and he recommended a different bottle. Sure enough, the recommendation was maybe $2 different but dramatically better, and he brought us a taste of our original order to compare.

Obviously if you're a San Franciscan who hasn't been to Zazie yet -- for brunch OR dinner -- you need to remedy that, stat. And I'm here to tell you that if you swing by on a Monday night, you may just have one of the best meals of your life.
author: Kate S.

description:
I was going to give it 4 stars, but I'm downing Zazie to 3 because...we came here with a party of 7 and yes, I know, we shouldn't have. Limit yourselves to only 4 people MAX. Anyway, we put our name down for 7 people and waited 1.5 hours only to find out that the host was going to split us up into a table of 2 then 5. Why didn't he tell us this earlier? Every 10 minutes he would go back to the chart and look at who was signed up and I'm sure he could have told us. We were disappointed that we couldn't sit together. 

Now onto the food, which wasn't bad at all...

FRENCH TOAST TAHITI
The walnut paste that comes with it is delicious! I like how you can get 1, 2 or 3 slices of big fatty toast. It's one slice of bread, walnut paste, bread, bananas, etc. Comes with a side of syrup which honestly doesn't need to be used b/c this dish was flavorful enough.

CROQUE MADAME
This was somewhat messy. The cheese was a bit on the watery side so it was hard to cut my sandwich and keep it a sandwich. It soon turned into a pile of bread, cheeses, ham, and runny egg. It was still good. I didn't even bother touching the side of greens on my plate. 

BENEDICTS
I believe Zazie is the only place I know of in SF where you can get 1, 2 or 3 benedicts. THREE?? HELL YEAH. Three of my buds ordered 3 different kinds and ended up swapping. I was able to try three kinds: ALBERT (bacon, white cheddar, salsa), MONACO (prosciutto and tomatoes), and the LA MER (crab, avos, green onions). 

ALBERT - The bacon was definitely very flavorful and thus took over the taste of the benedict. Nonetheless, it was still good.
MONACO - the prosciutto was a bit chewy but I think this was the best benedict. The flavors of the prosciutto wasn't over powering and everything went well together.
LA MER - Bland!! Since the hollandaise sauce is a light lemoney sauce, this definitely did not help that the crab wasn't very flavorful, and the fact that avos don't really have much of a taste to it. This was just mushy from the avos and sauce, and stringy from the crab.

7x7.com states that you have to have a benedict at Zazie before you die, but I honestly beg to differ. The poached eggs on the la mer benedict was overdone. It wasn't runny at all. We should have had them change it but we already waited so long for food we didn't really care. The hollandaise sauce for the benedicts could have been a tad bit more flavorful, but I do appreciate how it wasn't overpowering. 

All in all, Zazie is a good place to come to brunch if you want to control the portions you eat for breakfast since you an order 1, 2 or 3 pieces of french toast and same goes with benedicts. YAY FOR PORTION CONTROL! Too bad that wasn't practiced.
author: Heidi C.

description: The egg benedict with prosciutto is delish! Wait time is a bit long, but totally worth it.
author: Monique T.

description:
Just had dinner here with a guy I'm seeing and we had a great time.  We walked right in and greeted be a friendly host.  Our server was on top of everything without hovering.  The food was D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S!  I had the steak with grilled asparagus and the best damn mashed tators ever!  My friend had the lamb stew which he loved...he didn't want to share but I took a bite anyways.  

I haven't been here for brunch and from the sounds of it, it's a nightmare but the dinner is "kick ass!"
author: Ben M.

description:
Faaaaaabulous!  One of the best brunches in SF, for sure.  Everything I've ever had there (and I've had many brunches there) was deeeelicious.  On Sundays, they will give a bit of 'tude if you try to make a substitution (like scrambled for poached eggs in one of their Benedict dishes---I don't like poached eggs!!!), but if you're there early, they'll comply.  And yes, please get there early (as in before they open) unless you want to be left out on the sidewalk waiting forever.  And make sure you get a sunshine mimosa as your eye opener for the day.

On a nice day, their little patio out back is wonderful.  And their dinner is actually quite good as well.  

Go here.  Go here often, and go here early.
author: Danielle B.

description:
Generally, I'm a delight to be around, but not before noon.  So, to protect society at large from my morning bouts of grumpiness, I don't do brunch without a reservation - unless, of course, it's at Zazie.

On the weekend, my pal, Emily, stumbles to the storefront window, slaps our name on the list, and we park it on the sidewalk and salivate.  But soon enough, we're in and so painfully hungry, we just close our eyes and pick from a list of crazy rich egg concoctions and gentrified flapjack delights, all stuffed with curd or other sweet funk.  

Indeed, Zazie is the reason why breakfast is the most important meal of the day.
author: Vanessa C.

description: really nice, casual environment, comfortable setting.. good date spot !
author: Alli L.

description:
La Mer Eggs Benedict was delicious.  French Toast Tahiti was delicious.  Fountainbleau Scramble was delicious.  

On a side note, I really liked that you could order in portions for most of the standard brunch items.  I always want to try everything and being able to order one portion of this and one portion of that to make an amazing meal is pretty ingenious.  Other places should def catch onto this...

There's not much left to say given the 1000+ reviews of goodness.
author: Kristine B.

description: Zazie is an over-rated restaurant with pretentious service. The food is good but it's not worth the long wait. I had been invited by  a friend and I stood for almost an hour for the sake of our friendships but boy, is it painful to trick your stomach when it's screaming for breakfast? To make the experience even more uncomfortable our server seemed to be in a rush and couldn't answer our questions properly. That was the least I expected from a place with such good raves. Zazie is off of my list.
author: Rosana S.

description:
Love this place. Atmosphere is warm, cozy and friendly. We came here for breakfast on a cold foggy weekday morning, there was no wait and plenty of tables. 

Service, as others have said, is very attentive. 

Parking wasnt too bad, we found some 2 hour street parking around the neighborhood a block away.

I had the Eggs en Fonte (Eggs over a polenta cake with mushrooms and spinach). It was a bit oily but Ive never had this before so Im not sure if its supposed to be like that. Regardless it was really tasty though.

My wife had some poached eggs over avocado and crab and it was great.

We liked it so much we wanted to come back one more time before we leave to try some of the other things on the menu (we're only in San Fran for 4 days). By the way you'll be staring at the menu for a while, everything looks good.
author: Leo L.

description:
Went here for brunch on a Sunday morning.  After reading the reviews, I was a little worried about the wait, but we got there at around 10:45 and probably only waited around 30 minutes for a party of 2.  Compared to Brenda's, Dottie's and Mama's, the wait at Zazie's was like child's play.  

We were seated at a table in the back, and soon after, a party was seated at the table next to us, making it pretty much impossible to get out.  But, you're at a small restaurant in San Francisco, so what can ya do.

The gingerbread pancakes are AMAZING, and I'm not even really a pancake person.  Also tried the French Toast Tahiti stuffed with carmelized bananas and walnuts, which was also good, but I thought the pancakes were better.  French toast was a tiny bit dry.  

The croque monsieur was extra cheesy and could have used a little bit more ham - the cheese to ham ratio was a bit overwhelming.  I got a side of home fries with my sandwich, and they were fantastic!  I usually prefer hash browns, but the home fries were crispy and garlicky and delicious!  

All in all, I would definitely come back.
author: Jenny R.

description:
My friend and I came here on a weekday for some lovely brunch.  We even asked for patio seating because it was recommended on the 7x7.  I couldn't handle an eggs benedict as my first meal, so I ordered the "Un, doux, Tois" which consists of French toast, two slices of bacon, and two eggs (scrambled).  It's a perfectly filling meal for me. Their french toast was really good, a bit on the doughy side, but I like them that way to begin with. 

The service was nice and the patio seating was nicer.  I loved the informality of eating on a back patio with the sun shining on me at 11am.  It was a sweet moment to savor.
author: Rosanne L.

description:
7x7: Zazie's Eggs Benedict (Too cold to go to the patio)

Arrived on a cold Monday at 11AM. Ordered the Sunshine cocktail - mango and champagne. It was a bit strong. Couldn't taste the mango. Next time, I'll order it with soju. :)

Ordered the Two Egg St. Trop - Poached eggs on English muffin slices with Hollandaise sauce and smoked salmon, red onions, and capers. Side of homefries, ordered crispy. My sauteed potatoes should be crispy!!!

Beautifully poached eggs. Fluffy whites that were trimmed, with yolks that oozed when I popped them. The Hollandaise was not too thick, and well flavored, with just the right amount of fish and condiments. The only drawback to the Benedict was that the English muffins had lost their crisp by the time carving into them. But all in all, the best Benedict I've had. 

The home fries were crisp, I'l give them that, albeit some of them were burnt. I'd rather withstand charred potato than soft potato.

I would recommend coming on a weekday, just to avoid the lines people seem to be complaining about. 

I'll most definitely come back to try something else. :)
author: Melissa C.

description:
I'm really sorry to write this review because I've had very good experiences in the past with the food at Zazie....good enough for my husband and I to select Zazie for a low-key, romantic birthday dinner this year.   

Our experience there a few days ago was really disappointing service-wise and capped off my birthday in a pretty negative way.  I need to eat gluten- and dairy-free and I called in advance to make sure they could use olive oil in the food preparation instead of butter.  Not all restaurants -- especially small ones -- have the flexibility to do this because some dishes are prepped in advance, so made sure to call first.  I was connected to the kitchen and the woman assured me that they could make their trout dish, including the sides, with olive oil -- "no problem."  Great!  We make the reservation and I'm looking forward to it all day on my birthday.  

We settled in at Zazie and I ordered the trout dish, mentioning that I spoke with the kitchen the day before about dairy free.  The server came back after our orders were placed and said, in a relatively nonchalant way, "Oh, well, we can only give you the fish and a side salad -- the sides listed cannot be made without butter because they are all made in advance.  There really isn't much on the menu to substitute, either, because nearly everything is made with butter."  Great.  If I had wanted just a piece of fish and some greens, I could have prepared that at home.  I felt totally duped. 

I don't automatically expect that restaurants can prepare things dairy-free, but when I specifically call in advance and am assured that they can for a specific dish, only to arrive and find out that they won't and seem relatively uncaring on a special evening for us -- that's pretty disappointing.
author: Jen H.

description:
I literally told out waitress that I wanted to lick my plate. It is that good.

I ordered Pinkie's french toast - I had no idea how huge the serving was going to be - next time I'll order one! The toast was great - not to eggy with a delish orange and cinnamon batter. I also had a great  side of bacon. My boyfriend ordered the Albert poached eggs - NOM. I don't love eggs, but had a bite - they were incredible. His eggs were served with home fries - maybe the best I have ever had.

Needless to say - I'll be back!
author: Christy D.

description:
Zazie gets five stars for the quality of their poached eggs and the roasted garlic that comes with the breakfast potatoes.  They do these things fantastically and that's sufficient for five stars.

The drawback is the 60 - 90 minute wait every day, but that's the price you pay for fame.  Dinner not quite as good, stick with breakfast.  Also highly recommended are the pancakes.
author: Eric M.

description:
5 stars for the burger! Best brioche-bun-to-burger ratio I've experienced!

Come to think of it, the back patio and Francophile-infused decor have a way of transporting me right out of my beloved San Francisco and into the Left Bank somewhere. Not a bad way to justify 5 stars! And actually, if you think about it, I couldn't have gotten the burger in France anyway.

Oh.... did I forget to mention the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes?

My prescription to bliss:  Zazie's back patio, Burger for lunch and Lemon Ricotta Pancakes for dessert. Call me bourgeoise!
author: Lorna M.

description:
Brunch is the new Beyonce and everybody's trying to get a piece of it. (Yes, I know that was an extremely horrible analogy but its 7am in the morning and I am yelping... :-)) 
I'm not that big of a fan of this place to be honest with you. I've heard that it was comparable to Mama's (hellllls no!!) but I am going to have to agree to disagree with this one. I love bloody mary's and could write a book alone on this topic but they really disappointed me. I think it was because they made it with soju. (Don't get me wrong, I love soju. Just not at 11am in the morning! And not mixed in with my mary!!) I had some kind of benedict dish but without the hollandaise. I'm not really sure why because I don't like poached eggs. It musta been the soju talking... Would I come here again? That's a negative ghostrider, I'm on to the next brunchery. Or back to Mama's, mmmm...
author: Andrea Y.

description:
The fact that I haven't reviewed this place SHOCKED me! 
Really? Zazie is one of the best place in San Francisco to get brunch!
Well, I might find better brunch in the future.. but I will not forget u, Zazie!
Because you showed me how delicious brunch can be.....
And also because of you, I got hooked up with brunch :)

First of all, head to patio, it's awesome plus they have heater too.

Order, whatever u see~! What I love about Zazie is that we can choose to have one, two, or three of anything.. I usually get only one poached egg and one pancake, and sometimes I wondered why I didn't order more~ 

Gingerbread pancake is a 5******
Poached egg with whatever ingredients is SUPER GOOD too~
The service is alright :)
There's always a wait, but it goes our pretty soon.
I've been here couple times and never waited for more than 20min, so not bad~!
author: Marlis T.

description:
This place is adorable! I went there for dinner alone while BF was at a conference. Was happily greeted by Shawn(?), who went far out of his way to get me a nice table altho I had no resy and it was busy.
The food was great, the prix fixe is an amazingly good deal.
My pate and poisson soupe was excellent.
Service was attentive and pleasant.
The wine selection was good, service was great, food yummy.
I would definitely come back and try out the brunch on the patio as well as dinner.
author: Karin G.

description:
First time I came here was pretty good... I hit it up again on a RAINY day (no patio seating... boo). Waited over an hour to be sat, standard for Zazie I suppose. So upon being sat, we ordered and were starving. Waiter was reasonably nice... seemed hurried. Ordered one of the benedicts, french toast and featured omelette. Our benedict and omelette came out luke warm and on the cold side. In my mind... after waiting THAT LONG to be sat and get our food, the LAST thing I want is my food to come out less then stellar. He fixed it, but it seems like the benedicts still came out not fresh.

Long story short... will not be back to wait an hour and get lukewarm to cold breakfast. Nasty.
author: Sarah A.

description:
I only knew Zazie for their awesome brunch menu; however, I was recently wooed by their divine dinner selection.

We chose to order from their Prefix menu, which was surprisingly affordable for all that you get. We ate mussels for the appetizer, salmon with fingerling potatoes for the entree and a strawberry rhubarb crumble for dessert. We also ordered polenta cakes as our other entree The mussels were memorable- truly the best I've ever had.

I love the ambiance here; it's so relaxing and quaint. A must see if you're ever in Cole Valley!
author: Lauren T.

description: I've had brunch here a couple of times sitting both indoors and their back patio...I prefer the back patio on a nice afternoon. The brunch items I've had (ie variations of omelettes) were all pretty good.  Food is served fresh and quite quickly and generally seems somewhat healthy.  The food is not too heavy so I was ready to eat again within a few hours.
author: Kent W.

description:
Cute cute cute little cafe in Cole Valley. Hard to believe but Zazie is my first dining experience in this part of the neighborhood. It was an amazingly sunny day with lots of relaxed middle-aged to older diners living the life of seeming luxury. My excuse for being out and about in the middle of the day is being unemployed, which didn't stop me from enjoying a delightful brunch with a good friend.

It was both our first foray to Zazie but had excellent praises. We glanced at the menu, and though while it was just after 12p, we still opted to try the breakfast foods since that was what Zazie was known for. 

We were both taken with the Daily Specials menu which included the Miracle Pancakes and the Eggs en Fonte. Sad to say, they ran out of both of these items! Disappointed we tried 2 other dishes instead:
- Eggs Albert (poached eggs with bacon)
- Challah French Toast (4 halves of thick egg bread with stewed bing cherries)

Both were solid brunch dishes. The the eggs had a nice tang from the chopped marinated red onions. Not overly done on the hollandaise which is great. The side of roasted potatoes were nicely browned on the edges, though I prefer my actual potato to be a bit softer.

The french toast was good too, not too eggy nor dense. The stewed cherries were a complementary seasonal touch and added a sense of difference.

Both dishes ranged about $11 or $12. Not the cheapest but you pay for the better quality of ingredients and care made in the food.

I can see why Zazie is a favorite weekend brunch destination. I'm happy I snuck in on a weekday.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Ok- I usually LOVE Zazie. I just moved to Cole Valley and I very much enjoy everything about it: the ambience, the food, the selection, I even enjoy the people that typically frequent the restaurant. 

However, last weekend I went to the restaurant with my younger sister. After waiting a good hour or so, we were seated. We waited. And Waited. And Waited. And were ignored. We watched 4 tables be seated after us. Then we watched all four tables be greeted and offered the daily special. Then they were given water. Then they ordered. We waited so long to be spoken to that people seated AFTER us were brough their food before anyone took noticed. Only after I grabbed the HOST were we given menus, then water, and were we able to order. Until a food came up did any of the actual wait-staff acknowledge us. Then the waitress' effort was shitty at best. 

I usually love this restaurant, and their Gingerbread pancakes and Benedicts are to die for. That said, however, I do believe that I must give credit when credit is due...and ONLY then. We had a terrible experience that day at Zazie, and I put this up here knowing that it will probably get lost among the great reviews the restaurant usually gets, but it's worth a try. Maybe someone from the restaurant actually peruses these reviews from time-to-time and maybe they'll do a better job of accounting their guests the next time we come by. Because, yes, their food is good enough that a next time WILL happen, but if I am treated like that again, it will be my very last.
author: Melissa H.

description:
I have been there twice now and haven't been disappointed at in any form.  Super cozy, delicious food and yummy mimosas.  

Great spot for a special date or a leisurely brunch.  Loyal customer here.
author: J J.

description:
Such a happy place to be on a Sunday morning, I'm willing to overlook that brunch was nothing to write home about. Well, maybe I'd send a short postcard (you know, with a picture of the French countryside, and a couple of efficient sentences), but not really a ful-blown effusive letter. I mean, it was fine. Good even. The potatoes with massive garlic cloves were even a mite better than good. But still, for the legendary reputation, I was expecting more than just good omelettes and sweetened challah. 
Am fully willing to admit I may have ordered the wrong things. Shall be back to try the eggs benedict. Keep the fancy letter paper handy.
author: Purnima M.

description: The wait was not worth it. Person at front door kept telling us 25 min. Went away fro 15 and our reservation was cancelled. Guy - general manager - at front door very rude. Food was mediocre - won't go back.
author: Doug C.

description: We had to wait about 50 minutes for a table for 3, but after tasting that French toast I have to say it was worth the wait. Warning: out front (outside) seating is first come, first serve.
author: Captain B.

description:
Don't bother with the benedicts, you can do so much better.

Continuing my hunt for good eggs benedict in the city, this morning Diner-in-Crime, T-Diner, and I headed out to Zazie. We had all been there before and enjoyed those previous experiences... and I could have sworn I ordered a benedict then too, but I sure won't bother after this attempt.

Zazie has great "bready" breakfasts, like french toast and pancakes. They also have an extensive mimosa menu, and you can't go wrong there. But the savory dishes just don't do it for me. To start with, they don't have a straight-up eggs benedict (a growing trend, it would seem). What they do have is a long list of variations, many of which are served with tomatoes. Seriously folks, tomatoes have no place on a benedict and I made sure to avoid those that listed tomatoes. Imagine my surprise when I discovered that, yes, my benedict (the "Albert" for those playing along at home) came with undisclosed tomatoes. In addition, the entire dish was in the "just sort of warm" band of the heat spectrum.

Much like my Park Chow review, I'm giving four stars today because it's been good before, so I'm not giving up just yet. But if the next time turns out less than spectacular, I'm docking a star.
author: Sean K.

description:
Dear Zazie,

I love your food.  I mean, I really really love your food.  Your poached eggs are beautiful, and the French toast (any way you make it) is really lovely.  I tried your gingerbread pancake, and wished it were winter.  The lemon curd and pear wasn't quite light enough to make it summer fare.

I would like to dock you a star, however, for service.  Every person I've met who's worked there has been kind of snooty.  Equally so, actually.  

Most recently, after being told that the wait for a table was going to be about 45 mins to an hour, my friends from out of town and I decided to take a short trip around the block to see some of SF's sights.  We came back 25 minutes later to see that we had already been passed by.   

This would have been really cool if we had been better informed of when to come back, or maybe if we had decided to stick around with the other 30 people waiting outside, but instead we took a short walk and almost missed out on eating with you folks.  I really appreciated that you got us a table ten minutes later, but I didn't appreciate being glared at for the rest of our stay.
author: Kate K.

description:
The food is delicious.  I got the poached egg, with a great hollandaise sauce and delicious bacon.  Also, on recommendation from Yelp, my friend and I got the gingerbread pancake.  Now, I don't like pancakes and this one was just ok.  BUT, the lemon curd on top of it was to die for.

Also, the backyard patio makes everything better.
author: Liz B.

description:
I went here for breakfast one morning while visiting San Francisco - I didn't realize I'd actually been here a few years before until I saw the back patio. The food was absolutely delicious, but you certainly pay for it.
I ordered one poppyseed pancake and one poached egg (I forget the exact type, there are about 5 varieties). I like that you can choose how many of each to order, it adds a nice flexibility to the menu. The poppyseed pancake was amazing, it comes with a large dollop of lemon curd and sprinkled with powdered sugar. It's everything you'd want in a pancake :)
author: Jonathan W.

description:
StinkyArmPit.

it was good brunch.

we were late, so late.
But we have a friend who lives close by and he was in the line and talked to the manager guy to keep his name is still exist.

StinkyFrenchBitch'sArmPit.

I had a great eggs benedict with smoked salmon.
1 egg benedict= 8 bucks.
2 eggs benedict = 11 bucks
3 eggs benedict = 13 bucks.

I ordered ONE. I eat "light" these days. 

roasted garlic potatoes was good.
Banana stuffed french toast was fantastic.

StinkyFrenchSonofaBitch'sArmPit.

Our waiter was such a nice guy. He was a guy who is really show that enjoy working there or great pretender. He was quick, bringing water and coffee for us but he gave us time to order, and he came back for coffee refill.
Yes, we were so lucky to get a great service like that.

StinkyFrenchSonofaBitch'sArmPit.

The long line socks.
But it's worth going even though the line stinks like SonofaBitch.

Btw, is it true that French people get excited when they don't take shower for few days?
I take shower twice a day, morning and night, I am not French.
author: Nobu K.

description: WORTH THE WAIT. Yeah it sucks waiting over half an hour on an early Saturday afternoon for some food when you're ravenous. I almost wrote a sonnet to my New York scramble, that's how beautiful and delicious it was. If you can manage to sit outside on a nice day, I would recommend it. It's gorgeous out there. There's still so much I want to try. Gingerbread pancakes, the Tahiti french toast thing, oh, how I look forward to you! Service was attentive and polite. I love this place so hard.
author: Lilia M.

description:
Came here w/  my friend b/c the reviews seemed pretty good. There was a wait but it wasn't bad for a SF breakfast spot on a Sat morning. We both got the La Mer and it was DELICIOUS. However, it was the smallest SMALLEST breakfast I've ever seen. Granted they give you the choice of how many eggs you want,..but considering we paid $40 I expected a bit more than an undercooked poached egg on half an english muffin and 5 cubes of fruit.  
Our waiter was unhelpful to say the least. We wanted to trade our fruit/potato option for something for my friends baby and he was like..."no...we don't do that" and when we were like OK...can we get like a small side of oatmeal (the kid is only 9 mos. for heavens sake!!)?
"No we only serve whole bowls of oatmeal ($10)"   

IF I go back....no.. I don't think I will.
author: Angie A.

description:
I love crab. I love avocado. I love eggs. I love garlic. Zazie has combined these four ingredients, and tossed in some delicious potatoes into the mix, and a lovely sauce... which results in the best eggs benedict I've ever had. Whoever I go with, it tends to be the favorite dish of all involved.

Plus, I adore the "create your own" lemonade they have... which I'm far too uncultured and lazy to know or look up the name. Some pressé I believe.

The challah french toast is brilliant. I usually come for breakfast, but I came for lunch once and had a fabulous beet salad that tasted like summer. Never tried their dinner, but at those prices, I'd rather stick with their relatively affordable breakfast foodage that I know I love.

But yes, what everyone says is true. Don't go on an empty stomach, or the lines will destroy you and make you a bitter person. Just bring a snack to nibble on while you wait. Don't drive there, unless you like to spend an hour looking for parking (on a bad day). And have your whole party there at once... they won't seat you without it.

Go in with a positive attitude, and you'll leave with a smile from ear to ear.
author: Adam A.

description:
I just got back from having a delicious brunch at Zazie's with my best friend and her family and it was great! My friend and I shared the French Toast Tahiti and one of the brunch specials of the day which was an Omelette with prawns, white cheddar cheese, and salsa fresca. 
Both dishes were delicious and a good portion to share both of them. The french toast was really sweet almost like a dessert, which is what I treated it as after I had my portion of the omelette!
