I'm definitely coming back here to try some more of the dishes, I think the next one I'll try is the gingerbread pancakes.. and I also want to try this place out for dinner sometime!
A great place for brunch, and although the wait was 30 minutes and it was raining outside the wait was well worth it!
author: Ingrid F.

description: The wait is definitely long... but at least you can put your name down and then go walk around for a bit and then come back.  A friend was visiting and wanted to check this place out so a group of us went on a Sunday morning.  I was pretty starved by the time we got seated and our food, but the food was good.  I got the Mexican and substituted soyrizo in it and the home fried.  I typically don't care much for home fries but these were good!  And the food was spiced well!  I think next time I may want to try the french toast or something to get an idea of their sweet dishes but my first experience was definitely tasty!
author: Rachana S.

description:
Limited seating means this isn't a good place for large parties and combined with good food, the line extends far into the streets.

They include a $1.25 surcharge per person for the meal, which doesn't seem like a lot, but I've noticed that the actual cost of the meal is (meal cost + surcharge) x tax x gratuity.  It really adds up in the end.

Besides those points, Zazie is a great place for breakfast foods.  The various types of eggs are some of the strong points.  A friendly and attentive wait staff keeps everyone happy.  No fuss over separate checks at the same table, whether with cash or credit, definitely seals the deal.
author: Wilson L.

description: The food was very good and the staff was quite knowledgable.  The only complaint I have is how freakin packed the place was!  At least 10 people bumped into me or my daughter's high chair because it was crowded and they weren't paying attention.  I would definitely go back when it's not so crowded.
author: Kelly C.

description: I've been coming to Zazie since I was a young person in SF almost 20 years ago. A good friend grew up in Cole Valley and she introduced it to me. It was our spot to get brunch and feel all grown up. For that reason, it's always held a nostalgic place in my mind. Unfortunately, I had a reality check today that was disappointing. I ordered the Avignon scramble with tomatoes, eggplant, gruyere cheese and all I can say is that it looked like something I would make in my kitchen. When I go out to brunch and order something -- even if it's a scramble -- I want the eggs to be light, fluffy, with vibrant colors and excellent taste. As in, something I couldn't quite concoct in my kitchen with my humble cooking skills. Everything looked pretty brown-ish on my plate and I am not kidding when I say that it was bland. I'm not heavy handed with salt and I really needed to give those eggs some love. My dining partner also ordered the Florentine Benedict and the poached eggs were overcooked and the mushrooms were slimy. We were hungry and so we ate the food, but I won't be coming back. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing, but what good is a menu if only certain items are stellar, while the others are lackluster? So long, Zazie. I hope that you can extend your skills to include all items on the brunch menu.
author: Cristina M.

description:
Oh, I love Zazie so much that this review could go on forever. Instead, to save you the trouble, I'll keep it as short as I can, and tell you that: 1) This is hands down my favorite brunch place in the nation's densest brunch city; 2) They have a patio with tiny speakers that play scratchy Edith Piaf; 3)They have a whole menu of poached eggs; 4) Item #3 bears repeating; 5) Most brunch places treat their fried potatoes as an afterthought, and Zazie's are delicious, and perfectly seasoned.

If I could afford to eat out more often and I had to pick only one SF brunch place, I'd eat at Zazie every single weekend.
author: Alisa R.

description:
I haven't been to Zazie's in a while but we were headed to Cole Hardware when hubby spied that "there are no lines" in front of Zazie's, it was "let's go!"  Wow, no lines, pinch me, really hard!   
I tried their special of the day, lemon ricotta pancakes (order 1, 2 or 3) 7 inch pancakes, topped with a tart berry sauce and huge amt of lemon curd.  The cakes were good, too much curd, too tart.  Should've had the curd on the side, I love lemon curd but not that much.  I couldn't finish the 2 pancakes and had it for breakfast the next day and it tasted even better!

Hubby had one of their eggs benedict-like breakfasts, over muffins.  He raved about the chunks of potatoes cooked with whole cloves of roasted garlic (with skins on).  Add coffee, tea, the damage came to over $30.  Definitely your special breakfast kind of place at that price.  They charge $2 extra for health care tax.   Overheard a regular commenting that she loves their gingerbread pancakes.  Another reason to come back?

After i wrote this review, I was contacted by the owner, thanking me for writing about the place. Evidently, she checks to see if there're any problems from time to time.  I like that....small business owners who are responsible and care about what their customers think.  That's good business, not the kind of stuff they teach in business schools nowadays.  (Enron, mortagage companies, etc.)
author: Ry T.

description:
We went for a birthday, having heard it was AMAZING.  
Our party of 11 people arrived about a 1/2 hour before they opened hoping to get a good place in line.  We secured our place at the front of the line, but when the manager opened the doors we were told that since we were a group we would have to wait about a another half hour while other groups were ushered in ahead of us.  
When we finally were allowed in by the completely-not-thrilled-to-have-a-group manager, we met our waiter who was actually really awesome, and attentive.  The two stars are for him.  He was great!  
Unfortunately our food was mediocre at best.  I had hoped for something gourmet and/or French... it was neither of those things.  
But thank you to our awesome waiter who made the experience somewhat enjoyable.
I don't think I'll be going back unfortunately.  There are WAY too many other places in SF that have spectacular food and amazing service, so I'll be choosing one of those places.
author: CB W.

description:
A decedant, delicious way to spend the A.M.  The mimosas with elder flower pichet was a nice reprieve from your run of the mill breakfast libation.  The eggs benedict with crab were amazing, on and on.....

 We anticipate returning again for bruch, as well as for other meals.   The patio, out back, is classic.   The service is highly professional.   They certainly deserve five stars, and they set the bar for a renouned neighborhood eatery..

(post script:  we went back a few weeks later and my fiance tells me the Eggs Benedict were highly disappointing the second time around....Zazie loses a star....)
author: Adam D.

description:
3 of us came here. We all got three different meals. Each one was great. 
This is the type of restaurant where when your food comes out you cant wait to take a bite... then your friends food comes out and you want of a bite of the too! 
I got the Mexico. A scrambled egg dish with chorizo, salsa, and cheese. It was great! Not to spicy and filling. One of my friends got this Ham sandwich with cheese melted on the top of it... Delicious! My other friend ordered a  Zazi burger, begrudgingly she gave me a bite... it was great! 
As for the sides the potatoes and side salads were very good. I must admit, no matter how lame it sounds, that the dollop of butter on my bread was creamy and smooth. I really enjoyed it. 
This is a great restaurant in a great neighborhood. If you havn't checked out the cole valley neighborhood yet you should... and when you do you should eat here.
author: Wes P.

description:
I had the best time here yesterday!  I walked from Potrero Hill (down 17th through the Castro) to get over here to try the Gingerbread Pancakes.  YUMMM!  It was a very pleasant walk and their delicious food was a great way to reward myself for hiking the hills.  I made the mistake of ordering two pancakes instead of one.  I have a fairly big appetite, so it's hard to imagine what normal sized woman could eat more than one.  I mention this point because if you order two thinking you'll be able to eat them both, you'll be wasting five precious dollars.  Also, beware of the home fries if you don't like garlic.  I can't imagine not loving garlic, but my husband couldn't bare to eat the potatoes because of the strong garlic flavor.  Another waste of money.

I also love this place because the staff was extremely friendly.  Much more friendly than the average San Francisco brunch staff.  I will definitely go back here, and I'll definitely order a gingerbread pancake with pear and lemon curd again!  

If you are going to trek over here on foot like I did, I'd recommend climbing up to Tank Hill when you're finished with brunch.  Since you're so close to one of the best views in the city, you might as well take advantage!
author: Kimberly B.

description: Gah! This place is good. I went here for dinner and had the duck. It was delicious and perfectly cooked. I also had a salad and cocktails, terrific. The service was superb, and it was quite romantic! We sat in the back outdoor area and it was perfect. I can't wait to try their brunch!
author: Robin R.

description:
Most reviews on here talk about brunch: I am here to tell you that Zazie plated up one of the best dinners out I've had in quite a while. 

We had two entrees, two appetizers, and two desserts, plus coffee and Pellegrino, and the bill pre-tip was $82.50. (YMMV -- I got the Prix Fixe option, and we didn't have wine.)

Before I get into the food, I'll tell you I picked this on the suggestion of three friends who are pastry chefs. I named some places I liked and told them I wanted to impress my date without intimidating him, that he liked traditional steak-type food, and that I wanted a place we could actually hear each other talk. Many of my favorite places in this price range are too-cool-for-school in terms of ambiance and music, which is great if you know your dinner companion really well, or if you want them to know how cool you are, but not so much if you want to have stillness as part of the menu.  Zazie is a small place and quiet enough to hear your dinner partner without having to shout and without having to ignore anyone else's conversation, but it retains a certain sense of stylishness that isn't at all quaint.

AND THE FOOD!

I had the salmon, wrapped in parchment and cooked over potatoes and greens, and it was delicate and juicy and melted in my mouth, seriously. My date had the hanger steak, cooked to perfection so you could taste it while it was still on the fork. We had mussels to start, and I shit you not they were the best mussels I've ever had. The sauce was just lemony enough -- I'm not a big lemon-on-seafood fan -- to make the cream interesting. We also had the cheese plate, which I wish I'd asked for a description of the cheeses, because they were great. Everything was great. The rolls and butter to start? Yes, oh, yes.

We had dessert, too -- I had the pot du chocolat -- one of my favorite menu items of all time, and theirs was luscious. He had the creme brulee, the only complaint about which was that they don't bring it to you on fire, or set it on fire at your table. It's well out. Which is too bad, because he ordered it as a birthday dessert, and when we said, "Hey, it isn't on fire!" the put a candle in it and got the whole restaurant to sing happy birthday. Waiter had a lovely singing voice, I have to say, but it was a bit silly -- like being at ChiChis without the sombreros. But silly is good. A date without silly is like a dinner without butter.
author: Tarin T.

description: I have been coming to this place for years and I just love it. I didn't review it sooner because I kind of took Zazie for granted when I lived in Cole Valley.  When I moved, it became a destination...but definitely one that is worth the drive. The food--whether it's brunch, lunch, or dinner--is consistently amazing.  The pancakes are light, fluffy and to die for.  The french toast is also fantastic. It's totally worth the wait outside, so just grab a coffee and be patient.  The new iPad sign-up system for tables is also really cool.
author: Melissa M.

description:
I decided to give Zazie's another chance.  They had been closed about a year ago for remodeling and I thought we'd go check it out.

I'm going to sound like such a jerk, but yet again I was disappointed by this place.  Every time I go I feel kind of guilty because I feel like I'm spending way too much money on something I could make myself, better.

The best part about Zazie is the ambience.  I wish I could just sit on the patio and drink tap water  That, and their overpriced mimosas come in stemless flutes, which are rad.  And the servers are all sweet.

But the food is always a a let down!  I think this is my least favorite place in the Cole Valley-Haight Ashbury-Sunset area.  Nothing ever looks appetizing, but I ended up getting Oatmeal Brulee, which I admit I'd never seen before.  It was basically Quaker oatmeal with delicious creme brulee and caramelized bananas.  I unfortunately had to eat it with a fork, which was weird, and the oatmeal is very plain and bland,  so I asked for some brown sugar, and it arrived when there was no longer any oatmeal in my bowl.  (Our server had the whole patio but was very very very sweet and calm.)

I'm not a complaining guest, as in, i'll just eat my oatmeal because i'm hungry and want to get it over with and won't make my server take it back and get me something else, but I feel like yesterday was one of those days that I should have.... :(

So I've really decided to never go back, (I've been probably 10 times).  However, one day we wanted to go and they were closed for construction, and the little place next door, Bambino's, was AMAZING!!!  Delicious food, very clean interior, excellent service, leagues better.  I don't know why people wait for an hour on Sundays just to sit on that damn patio.
author: Kicker ..

description:
There's not a single thing I would change about my Zazie experience.  Not only is the food incredible (I had the benedict with bacon, and fontina cheess, my boyfriend had the omlette du rouj), but the restaurant itself is absolutely adorable, and the service is impeccable.  I had two mimosas, one with orange and cranberry juice, the other with mango juice- both were heavy on the champagne (my favorite.).  

As far as brunch goes, Zazie truly is as good as it gets.
author: Nina B.

description:
Yan G.'s review hit the spot on this one. 
I had brunch here this past weekend, it was perfect walking distance from Inner Sunset.
As soon as we walked in, I declared this to my new favorite place in San Francisco to my boyfriend. This is purely based on my girly inclinations towards anything cute and resembling a French cafe. The wait wasn't too bad and we were seated inside, which really has a lovely atmosphere, brightly colored walls, French looking posters, little lofty thing filled with books 'n stuff, etc. The coffee was pretty good. However, the food was nothing extraordinary. I had the Un, Deux, Trois. Not bad, not omg good. The boyf had pumpkin pancakes, which were nicely paired with the lemon curd. All in all, I would give it a 3.5, it was pleasant. Next time, I'll try one of the poached egg dishes.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Really nice place! get's very busy around lunchtime, so expect service to be a bit slower if you get there for lunch. The outdoors sitting area is my preferred spot.
Great simple food and very nice atmosphere.
author: Shirly D.

description:
Yum- delicious dinner and great server (Genevieve u were rocking). It was a long wait for the patio. We were told thirty minutes and left our number. We were never called and when we came back in twenty we were told we couldn't get a seat so we sat inside. Glad we did because we had such a delightful, funny, smart server. The food and drinks were great. I got the prix fixe and for $23 had the most amazing spinach salad, cheeseburger, and fruit crumble for dessert. And the warm rolls with butter are to die for. Will be back again. I am amazed on how that tiny kitchen pumps out all that food. 
My only critique: maybe having a hostess outside during busy hours to organize the rush may be a helpful addition.
author: C. R.

description: This place always hits the spot--I love to come here for breakfast. The menu has quite a selection to choose from; there's a nice variety of scrambles to flavored mimosas. Note, you must be an early bird to get seated accordingly! Zazies is so good, there's always a wait. I'd recommend the Italie scramble! It's sooooo delish
author: Kay Y.

description: Hehe. I recommended my parents come here on a nice date. Ya'll need to check this place out. Eat brunch. Go to the C.A.S. Done DEAL! :D
author: J J.

description:
I will wait and wait and wait for a little Zazie in my life. I am not normally a pancake girl, but Zazie has changed that. They had a poppy seed pancake special the other day with lemon curd that blew me away. The Pierre Noire Eggs Benedict was also very good with the home fries (crispy little potatoes).

Outdoor seating, a delish cappuccino, and some amazing company! What else can a girl ask for on a Saturday morning?
author: Natalie N.

description:
This place is pretty romantic, especially the backyard. I usually sit out front though so I can people-watch. I've heard the dinner is really good too, but I haven't tried it yet. 

Also, they answer the phone in French and usually play cool French music like Edith Piaf.
author: Richard C.

description: What a yummy brunch spot! The food is great and the place is so darling, but the wait is super long if you don't come right at 9:00 when they open. We finally got in and ordered mango mimosas right away. They were pretty strong, but yummy. Then we ordered the french toast tahiti with caramelized bananas and walnuts, the Mexican scrambled eggs with chorizo, cheddar, peppers and salsa, the the Pierre Noir poached eggs with bacon and tomatoes. The french toast was absolutely amazing; so moist and delicious! The scrambled eggs were yummy too but I probably would have liked them a with a little more spice. The poached eggs were delicious and each bite with bacon and tomatoes was heaven, except I kind of expected the eggs to be hot (they were luke warm). Everything was so yummy and I can't wait to bring my boyfriend here. It's definitely worth the wait in line!
author: Sheeva G.

description: This place is a crowd pleaser. It's a place you can take your parents, your kids, and everyone is happy. Delicious lattes to start, and the fluffiest pancakes. The open faced goat cheese, prosciutto, and arugula sandwich is a winner. It was my second visit but the kids first and they want to go back tomorrow.
author: Gwenn G.

description: Best ambiance and breakfast food in San Francisco! EVER! I wish I lived closer :S I always leave uncomfortably stuffed!
author: Katrina H.

description:
YUM! If you like eggs benedict.. go no further! On my quest to find the perfect brunch in SF, this place rates highly! Mostly because I LOVE eggs benedict..seriously..if they are on a brunch menu, I get them!

I forget what it was called, but I had the one with crab and avocado.. it was pretty good! I wish it had some sort of spice or flavor, but it was still really good. I also ordered a huge bowl of latte and it was really good as well. My friend ordered the eggs benedict with bacon and tomato and it looked mouth watering.

The drawbacks are the same as just about every person in the world mentioned (the wait, a bit expensive) but to me it is worth it..next time I just have to work on waking up earlier to beat the morning rush.
author: Ashley H.

description:
This is my favorite place to have brunch/breakfast in San Francisco.  The wait can be long, but the bar next door makes spicy bloody marys and the staff at Zazie will come get you when your table is ready.  

When you make it next door, I recommend the gingerbread pancakes with poached pears and lemon curd.  The french toast is also great.... even the eggs seem to taste better here.  

If you go with a group, you can order the make your own mimosas.  Choose your juice and champagne .... lots of juice choices.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Breakfast has never been this good!  

Trust me, the wait is worth it!  Get there early, put your name down on the list, walk around the cute neighborhood, and come back in 15 min (if you're feeling lucky, 30 if you're not) for the best brunch you'll ever have.  

Must try:
- French Toast Tahiti with caramelized banana and walnut.  
- Any of the poached egg options.  It's no longer just Eggs Benedict.  There's Monaco, Albert, Florentine, and many others to suit your taste. 

One of the best things about this place is the various sizes they offer with corresponding prices.  This is especially great for people who are into family style sharing for any meal or for those who always want what someone else has ordered.  This even goes for all the french toast and pancake options.  

As long as you go there knowing you'll have to wait, you'll be one happy person.  Just don't go when I'm going  =P  I hate having to wait.
author: Helen C.

description:
I eat here A LOT.  Especially on Tuesdays when it's free corkage.  The last time I went, there was a table of nine with seven bottles open...now, that's my kinda party!

Anyways, Zazie serves up solid food with nice lighting.  Service is always consistently pleasant and attentive.  Easily a place for a cozy evening dinner with a flare of a Frenchiness.

Outdoor brunch on the patio is always great, just make sure to get there early bc the wait becomes ridiculous.
author: michelle s.

description:
My boyfriend and i became huge brunch lovers recently. We have tried almost every "raved about" brunch house in San Francisco. So when we came to this brunch house, we were pleasantly surprised by the number of different options this place had to offer. We tried the french toast tahiti, gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd, the la mer eggs benedict and a hot chocolate.

French toast tahiti: DELICIOUS. I can't handle too many sweets in the morning but this was just perfect in terms of texture and flavor.
gingerbread pancakes: i think the lemon curd is what made this so good. Without it, the pancakes would have been mediocre.
La mer benedict: it was warmish cold when we got it. The crab in it was decent but i probably wont get it the next time i come back. I also remember their hollandaise sauce being a bit on the light side.
Hot chocolate: once again, it was warmish cold. The portion was large however and i was only able to finish half.
author: Minerva l.

description: Elderflower mimosas and a heated patio. I can stop there because those two things alone make for a pretty amazing brunch. For food I ordered an egg white veggie omelet and it was perfect; I loved that they didn't use a lot of oil, the vegetables were very fresh. The toast they served alongside was very good as well and seemed freshly baked which is always a good thing. This is one of my favorite places for brunch in the city!
author: Natalie M.

description: The brunch here is absolutely wonderful (smoked salmon benedict, aka "St. Trop" and the prosciutto benedict - both were great). The hash browns were supernal and came with nearly a dozen cloves of roasted garlic in their husks--just amazing. The patio is cozy, charming. The service was topnotch, friendly. This was my first visit. There will be more visits.
author: O. K.

description: Sweet little patio by moonlight, tiny enough to feel like a friend's backyard, delicious grilled veggie plate and a buttery piece-a-salmon. I'd say that;s date night gone right..
author: Rachel S.

description: Went to Zazie for the first time with my buddy, who had gone there for breakfast in the past.  He raved about how good this place was, good food and reasonably priced.  He was absolutely right, they did not disappoint.  Because I had heard they had long lines and because we did not have reservations, we got there 10 minutes before it opened.  Diana was our waitress, very friendly and helpful.  I went by her recommendation, the hangar steak, which was delicious.  My buddy got the duck, which he enjoyed very much as well.  Overall, a great dining experience, excellent food and at reasonable prices.
author: Tommy L.

description: First meal in San Francisco and loved it. Great casual atmosphere, every item on the menu sounded delicious and I loved my eggs Benedict type dish with spinach and shiitake mushrooms. Simple and extremely fresh. My sons lived their French toast and my husband loved his corn chowder and scrambled egg mash up.  Delicious latte. We are renting a vacation place around the corner and I feel sure we will be back more than once during our stay. Fresh, good food.
author: Eliza Y.

description: Awesome breakfast, friendly staff, kick-ass lattes.  We came out from Nob Hill to try this place out and were thrilled.  Cute neighborhood, relaxing vibe.  We'd definitely recommend it.
author: Erin B.

description: For entrees we had the trout, duck cassoulet, and pear and pork chop.  We enjoyed every dish.  Each had a slightly unusual twist to it that made it really unique.  Our favorite though was the baked hot chocolate!  I'm still dreaming about that dessert. The waiters and host were super sweet too.
author: beverly l.

description:
Found this place on Yelp and saw it listed in Where magazine. Good food, I'm there. We took a taxi from Japan town to Cole valley. We arrived around 9:30am, there were some people waiting.

--FOOD--
I've never seen a good variety of eggs benedict (7 types, and you can order 1, 2 or 3) on a breakfast menu before.

01. La Mer: with fresh crab, green onions, and haas avocado ($15) 
02. Eggs Monaco: with prosciutto and tomatoes provencales ($12) -- my fav

Both came with a side of roasted baby potatoes and garlic cloves and a wedge of orange. Yum... this is making me hungry. I shouldn't be up late writing this review. When we were done eating, there were more people waiting outside.

--OVERALL--
Situated in a charming neighborhood that has lots of character. The inside of this restaurant is cozy and feels like a home. Feels like a local joint, no tourists in sight. The garden backyard outdoor patio is nice. Love the variety of eggs benedict here.
author: Ann N.

description:
What a way to start your 7 year anniversary!  Yummy breakfast!  Although the name is ironic, something with the word "divorcee", those eggs were delicious!  As well, I wish we were in Tahiti because their Tahitian French toast was amazing!!!

Service and outside dining area was perfect, we will definitely go again.
author: J S.

description:
Best Poached Eggs I've had evar!

Me and the gf went on a sunday morning and only had to wait about 20 minutes -- sweet!

I had the prosciutto benedict that was cooked perfectly and they used *real* prosciutto not ham which some places try and use. The homestyle potatoes weren't that greasy and crispy just the way I like them, they were also huge!

Their juice selection was good also. I'm definitely coming back next time I'm in SF.
author: song c.

description: This place is amazing, for breakfast/brunch and dinner. Be prepared to wait awhile on weekend mornings, but know it is worth it. Gingerbread pancakes are to die for (and they sell their own mix so you can make them at home) and the staff is delightful. One of my favorite spots in the city. Can't say enough good things about this place!!!
author: Nadine O.

description:
So I've only been here twice now but each time I really enjoy it.  The back patio is nice and cozy and if you can score a table out front, that's prime people watching real estate as well.

Service is pretty good especially since they are all French and all (much better than my actual dining experiences in France). 

Food of course is why I like to eat out and this place has some pretty good eats.  I still think personally I like Brenda's a bit more but then I'm from Alabama, not Alsace.

The bacon is nice and thick though and what kind of breakfast/brunch doesn't include some excellent bacon?  You can also get a nice variety of options here and I'm really looking forward to basking in more sun eating some brunch here!
author: Gene X.

description:
We went here because it came with great recommendation for breakfast.  We arrived and luckily found parking.  Parking in San Fracisco is hard to come by. We were visiting friends otherwise we would have taken public transportation.  The muni goes by this neighborhood.

The wait was a bit, but the weather was perfect for the kids and us. It was worth the wait! Breakfast and services was fabulous.

I personally tried the breakfast sampler which consisted of 1-buttermilik pancakge, 1-gingerbread pancake and 1- french toast. I didnt find the french toast as yummy as the buttermilk and gingerbread, but my eldest son had it and enjoyed a plate of it!  My youngest likes oatmeal which he enjoyed with fresh fruit, cinnamon, brown sugar and my husband tried the special which was an omelet consisting of avocado, fontina cheese, toamote and i think bacon. I forget because i was just enjoying my meal and weather. We got seated in the back outdoors and it was a sunny day in san francisco.

Our friend and child ordered eggs benedict which she raved was the best ever! The bacon was yummy too! her son love it!

Coffee was also tasty and hit the spot for us travelers from los angeles.

Give this place a try and don't fear the wait.
author: sassy mom g.

description: After reading the review posted last Tuesday that said Zazie's is CLOSED (my heart sank before I continued to read that they're closed for a while for remodeling), I gave Zazie a call and found out that they were closed for a few days last week to put in new flooring and have reopened! Yay, I love Zazie's and usually have no problems with the wait for brunch (if it gets too long, I go a block to Boulange or Reverie). I do prefer to sit in the patio rather than inside, as it's too cramped. Zazie does the best poached eggs, and I love their gingerbread pancake and grilled chicken sandwich. I have had some pancakes that weren't spectacular ... that was before I tried their gingerbread pancake which is a must-order for me now.
author: Diana B.

description: Went there around 11am on a weekday with a friend of mine who is a regular there.  Yes the place is small so I can imagine the long waits.  We shared two plates (generous servings): French Toast Tahiti and Eggs Benedict.  Their house brew coffee and lattes are great too!  We both left with our tummies satistifed.
author: Tessa M.

description:
We came to Zazie's to celebrate my dad's birthday.  They have a wonderful prix-fixe menu, but we opted to order everything a la carte as the coq au vin and cassoulet were not on the prix fixe menu.  Too bad they were our of the coq au vin the night we went.  It was only 6:30 pm and they were already out was a big disappointment.  The cassoulet though was a big hit at the table.  I opted for the raviolis and started with the french onion soup.  My brother and mom started off sharing the mussels which was plenty to share.  
I will definitely come back to Zazie's.  I would like to try their brunch as well as come back for the coq au vin.  I just hope they are not out!
author: Danielle E.

description:
The ingredients are fresh, the menu is inspired and constantly changing, the service and ambiance are friendly, and the prices are not at all harsh.  What's not to love? 

Oh, and did I mention that it's all delicious??  ;)
author: Cynthia O.

description:
Ooooh, the sour cream and poppyseed pancakes topped with lemon curd was a winner in my books!  The gingerbread pancakes are good too.  I want to try the banana stuffed french toast!

The omelette I had was good, but nothing tooooo exciting or memorable.

I like the seating out back - there are heaters for when it's not too warm outside and it generally feels like a little oasis of calm.

Luckily there was no wait because we went pretty early (around 9:30am) but the place was already packed and there was no indoor seating left...by the time we left there was a huge line of people waiting!
author: Melanie B.

description: Cute Garden in the back, great service, make your own mimosa, crab Benedict (customizable), ricotta pancakes :)
author: J F.

description:
I was so excited to try Zazie after all of the rave reviews.  My boyfriend and I wanted brunch and called before hand to see if they would take a reservation.  The person who answered the phone said that it was first come, first serve and that we should come down as soon as we could.  Done, we left our house quickly and were there in 10 minutes.  

When we got there at 1:45 and asked the host to put my name on the list, he replies with a "I'm sorry, we're not taking any more names."  Of course I was upset because I really, really wanted to try their brunch.  I mentioned that I had just called and was told to come in and he said "Well since you misunderstood, I can fit you in."  First off, I didn't misunderstand shizzle and was a little put off by the fact that he blamed me.  Did I mention that they stop serving brunch at 3:00?  I was expecting to wait a really long time since he had no room for us, but I didn't mind.  20 minutes later he calls my name.  I just thought it was strange that he was trying to turn us away when it was so easy to fit us in (not to mention we were finished dining by 2:40).

The food was awesome.  I had a crab benedict and by boyfriend had the smoked salmon benedict.  I though his was better, but they were both good.  We also split an order of French toast with bananas and it was absolutely delicious.  I like the fact that you can order 1, 2, or 3 eggs or toast with your meal so it's possible to try a little of everything.  The potatoes were excellent as well.  We also had a mimosa and a soju bloody mary.  Both were yummy.  

I can't say much about the service.  The server brought the food and never checked back.  We really wanted some more drinks, but she never stopped by.  Oh well, the food was excellent.  The staff wasn't very friendly or very helpful, but I understand that it's very busy there.  It was weird to me that certain people were seated after us although we were supposedly last on the list and they had absolutely no more space for anyone and were turning people away left and right.  I guess they were special.

Overall, the service was just okay but the food was delicious.  I want to give Zazie another try, but I will just make sure to get there early next time before the staff is burned out.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
The wait was a little crazy, but the food was well worth it.  I recommend only going on a nice day so that when you have to wait for your name to be called you can enjoy the outdoors.

I had the poached eggs Albert with a side of Tahitian French toast.  Everything was delicious!
author: Thomas O.

description: Solid 3.5 stars, fresh ingredients, good service
author: A C.

description: Came for breakfast on a Tuesday. Had the eggs with polenta; nice sauce, spinach could have used more seasoning but mushrooms were great. Cottage potatoes come with whole unpeeled garlic? How are you supposed to eat it. Partner had eggs de la mer with dungeness crab and avocado. Perfect poached eggs. Milk is only 3.00 but a pot of tea is 4.50? Fast and friendly service. Pretty unusual bathroom. Would be nice to sit outside on a sunny day.
author: Carol m.

description:
I looked like shit when I ate here. I was bike riding with a friend on a warm Saturday morning. I'm already predisposed to sweating in unnecessary situations, so imagine what happens when I put on a t-shirt, baggy basketball shorts and am asked to take the 'physical challenge' on my bike. Yeah, that's right. I get sweaty. And not in that 'hot-guy-with-sweat-stains-in-all-the-right-places' way. Oh no, I'm out of breath, my knees get red and my hair gets frizzy and curly. 

Anyway, this is what I looked like when my friend had us ride up Cole and suggested we grab something to eat. I was thinking "we can run into a store, grab the first things we can find, and devour it like lions in the African plains far away from anyone's immediate sight." Instead, we went to Zazie. 

Although I was worried that we were better suited for Dunkin Donuts, no one seemed to take notice to our outfits. We sat in the front of the store, but I wish we could have been outside on the patio. We were immediately greeted with water which won my heart. Orange juice was oredered as well since we needed a quick sugar rush. I ordered the Eggs Mexico (suh-prise) and it was pretty good. 

I enjoyed the decor at Zazie, but the food (nor the decorations) really scream FRENCH to me. But then again, I've never been to France so maybe I say this because I expected our waiter to wear a baret and ridiculous love-making to occur in the middle of the kitchen.
author: Jared S.

description: Really disappointing after all the hype. Food was okay, but I expect better than just okay for a $12 pancake or scrambled eggs. Nice back patio, but I won't be going back.
author: Scott W.

description:
BEST EGGS BENEDICT EVER! So many choices for the eggs benedict too! I got the La Mer, which had crabmeat and avocado on it. They definitely did not skimp on the avocado or the crab, which is awesome because I feel like a lot of breakfast places will do that, especially with avocado and only give you the tiniest sliver of a piece. 
My bf also got the eggs benedict, but he got the Monaco style one, which has prosciutto and tomato. The tomato really added a cool flavor to the eggs benedict. 
We came here for brunch on a Sunday morning, but got there at 9 am, so we were able to get a table right away on the patio outside. But even after sitting there for 10 min, a HUGE line already formed, and pretty soon the wait seemed like it was closer to 30 minutes (at least). I would highly recommend getting here early. Also, they don't seat you until your whole party is here, so keep that in mind. However, if you're waiting, there's tons of coffee places nearby, so you always have another option while waiting.
author: Rachel T.

description: Who am I kidding? Zazie is more than deserving of a 5 star rating. I eat there more than any other restaurant in the city and am never ever disappointed. Took my parents there last week and they were blown away that such high quality food comes from such a tiny kitchen. What to order you ask? It's ALL good. I am really loving Zazie for dinner too, especially the raviolis w mushrooms and leeks.
author: Kylie S.

description: i went here with my uncle and dad for my birthday celebration!  People have been raving about their brunch, so we decided to check out this quaint French restaurant.  We came on a Friday around 12pm and had to wait around 30 minutes.  Once we got inside, the service was friendly and the decor was uber cute!  I felt like I was in France!  I ordered the Tahitian Toast (French toast stuffed with bananas) and hot chocolate.   The Tahitian toast was DEEELISHHH!  (esp. if your a banana fan!)  It wasn't too sweet, nor were the bananas sour.  LOVED IT!  However, the hot chocolate didn't do it for me.  It was served in a cute cup, but I felt that there wasn't any chocolate in it...to me, it tasted like milk with a hint of chocolate.  I also tried some of my uncle's French Onion Soup...and it was SOOOO GOOD!  This is also a must if you decided to try out this place!
author: Kristen T.

description:
I went there a month ago with my cousin whom I hadn't met for years! 
As I had heard, we should wait for 40min to have a table but it was worth it!! I had gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and my cousin had Croque Royale. All I can say is I love it!!!!!!!!!!!! Hmmm yummy!!!! I'll definitely go there again! Just thinking of dishes in Zazie makes me really hungry...........
author: Eunkyung K.

description:
I've been going to Zazie for brunch for about six years and every single time it's been amazingly perfect.
The challenge is the wait, for sure.  It's easiest as a two top with no indoor/outdoor preference - hardest as a four top, at 11, with patio wishes. We've had to wait an hour with the latter in the past.  That's when you head over to Finnegan's for a bloody (if it's after noon).

- gingerbread pancakes have a wonderful flavor and texture but aren't gingery enough for me (but I'm an extreme ginger fan). The poached pears are what get me to order this over and over tho...
- eggs - they use organic eggs that have bright orange yolks and are totally delish, any way you serve em. We prefer to get the eggs albert (like a benedict but with cheddar and bacon - mmm, bacon) and my man likes to get 3 of them.
- I think it's called Tahitian french toast - something like that - whatever it's called it out of this world.
- mimosa selections - YUMS. It really is a great way to get over a hangover - or just take the edge off.

Honestly, I don't really have an absolutely must have favorite - I try whatever I'm feelin' at the time and I'm always happy.  

Service is always just fine - attentive, efficient and not pushy.  I've never had a server rush us out.

The dining room and patio are pretty tight fitting tho - you have to squeeze past servers and runners thru the kitchen on the way to the patio. You have to squeeze into your seat on the patio and get to hear everyone's conversations around you (and make facial expression comments to your dining partner).  

I can let those things go for the food tho - it's worth it.
author: Adriene C.

description: Decided to give brunch a try after watching it from Check Please.  The food is average.  It didn't give me the "wow" factor like Mama's or Brenda's.  And the waitress didn't help with her nonchalant attitude.  It took 15 mins for my coffee to arrive.  I think I'll zazie out and go some place else next time.
author: Poboy U.

description: This place is pretty amazing. There can be long a long wait but the food is worth it. The La Mer is awesome and I would highly recommend this if you are considering the poached eggs. The French Toast Tahiti is pretty bomb as well if you are looking for something on the sweeter side. Don't forget to order a Bloody Mary. They are pretty decent here and hit the spot!
author: Danielle R.

description:
Recently worked on a wedding here in the back patio- SO sweet. Jen and her staff were great to work with- laid back yet totally on top of things, paying attention to all those little details that make the difference. It's obvious they take pride in what they do, and truly care about the experience their guests take away with them. I hope to do more events here in the future.

I've dined here several times as I live nearby and the food, and service, is always excellent. I look forward to visiting them again soon (perhaps on a tuesday when they do free corkage nights). 

I've always sat outdoors on their patio. It's a bit more of a wait, but so charming it's well worth it. 

I highly reccomend Zazie for a nice meal out, or your next event.
author: Anna H.

description:
The wait is so long, luckily I was expecting this.  However, once we were seated service was prompt and thoughtful.  

I ordered a Cappuccino and the Eggs Benedict with Bacon and Tomatoes Provencale.  The Eggs Benedict were delicious and the Home Fries that accompanied them were flavorful, crisp and studded with roasted garlic chunks.  

My party of four also decided to split the Tahitian French Toast, stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts - for a little brunch dessert.  We went with two pieces of the french toast which was a good amount considering we all ordered main dishes as well.  

Next time I'm looking forward to trying the Benedict with the Prosciutto and the Gingerbread Pancakes for dessert!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Amazing brunches (the build your own Mimosa is fantastic)! We always get the poached egg dishes, which are perfect balances of silky poached eggs, fluffy english muffins, and a delicious balance of salty, savory, and sweet toppings.

Dinner is excellent here too.

We always sit on the patio (if it's available). It's a charming little space with twinkly lights, and beautiful vines and flowers. Even when it's cooler out they have space heaters and even sweeter, they offer you a warm blanket to drape over your shoulders or legs.

The fact that their staff is attentive, knowledgeable and friendly is just the cream on top of a wonderful menu and adorable space.
author: T T.

description: reliably delicious. no matter what i order. this place probably contributes to why homes in CV are all more than $1 million in value.
author: Cat T.

description:
one of my favs in sf... i live a few blocks away from this place and when in doubt, zazie is always a safe bet. the burger is amazing they use niman ranch meat. also i can recommend the chai latte ( made with strauss organic milk) and the dinner salads ( especially spinach salad with strawberries). 
service is good too. a little loud on the inside , but on warm night , sit outside on the patio!
author: Nicole L.

description:
Having lived in France for many years, I would say this place is the perfect combination of France and the US. 

On the US side of the spectrum, I love the big American, gut-stretching breakfasts they serve. This kind of breakfast doesn't exist in France where all they eat for the first meal of the day is at most a piece of last night's baguette and a bowl of coffee with milk. 

Mon dieu, how I love their breakfasts here. I am not a big eater. In fact, usually I skip breakfast all together.  But when I go out, I always, always, without fail, order two eggs over easy, home fries and wheat toast (dry). I never venture away from this order because to me, this is perfection and *this* is what I love about America.   Zazie does a lovely job. It's perfect. 

In the evening, le menu est un petit peu plus francais and if you plug your ears with cotton so you drown out the sound of the American accents and squint your eyes a bit, you just might think that you are dining in a neighborhood bistro somewhere in the countryside of France. 

Well done, Zazie.
author: Julia Y.

description:
Took my boyfriend here for breakfast. We sat outside on their lovely patio. We both had the miracle pancakes which were tasty. It was topped with a lemony and raspberry glazed sauce which we both enjoyed. I also got a poached egg w/hollandaise sauce on the side. Pricier than I thought for a side, but yummy. 

My bf asked our server if the pancakes were cooked on the same skillet as the eggs since he's allergic (he can have the eggs in the pancake since it's diluted but can't have any eggs alone or anything made on the same skillet). The server said it was cooked on it's own skillet but I guess he was wrong because my bf broke out badly for an entire week! Nevertheless, he liked the food and returned again for Mother's Day (he ordered something different, of course).
author: Veronica L.

description:
I went to Zazie's with Jonathan Z and it is true, he planned the whole trip around food. Luckily for me he did choose some very good places to eat. 

The breakfast at Zazie's was really good. There were so many options that I found it hard to pick just one thing, so I pigged out and got two things. I ordered the Challah French Toast which was delicious. I personally liked it better than the Tahiti (I tried it from someone else in our party) Between the 10 of us we ordered pretty much everything on the menu.  I also ordered an eggs benedict with avocado. Unfortunately I don't remember what it was called, but it was on their "specials" menu.  

Overall this was a great little place to go to. Although I really did want to ride a bike across the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
This place is great. Nestled in the heart of Cole Valley, one of the coolest, quaintest neighborhoods in SF-- and a far cry from the madness of the Upper Haight a few blocks north-- Zazie is a great French-cum-San Francisco style cafe with amazing breakfasts.
I had a mushroom omlette filled with fontina cheese, spinach, and three varieties of mushrooms (porcini mushrooms rule) it was heaven; the perfect way to spend a lazy morning.
Service was very helpful, friendly, and accommodating. This is going to be a new part of my morning routine. Recommended.
author: Ross S.

description:
When it comes down to it, Zazie's food is delicious.

I can dock off as many as four stars, if I want to, for the ridiculous wait, the steep-for-brunch-prices, and the mediocre service we got the day we went. But I can't and I won't, because for me, a dining experience is all about the food and the food was fantastic.

Zazie's has that quaint French countryside feel about it that I love. There's a charming spiraled staircase that probably leads to a storage area on the side, clunky wooden tables and chairs that are wedged right next to each other and seating out front and at the patio out back. It's a little cramped, but it's charming. I dig it.

The wait was a little excessive, especially since my friend and I especially planned to get here before the rush - at 9:30-10, and we still ended up waiting around forty-five minutes. The Tully's right down the block is a godsend! Just grab a small drip coffee from there, take a walk around the block and it helps kill a lot of time, especially on a beautiful San Francisco morning (we've been getting more and more of those).

The food however, was fantastic. I ordered the egg scramble (Fontainbleu) with spinach, wild mushrooms, and fontina cheese folded in and it was ridiculously tasty and decadent. The potatoes are especially notable - unlike most brunch places that either burn their potatoes so that they're brown and hard or under cook them so that they're still grainy and lukewarm, Zazie's potatoes were perfect - crispy and hot on the outside, soft and delicious on the inside. With a pinch of rosemary, whole roasted garlic cloves (perfect for spreading on your potatoes, yum!) and probably a vat of butter (totally not complaining) I know I'd remember the potatoes.

My friend and I split an order of the gingerbread pancakes that came with a poached pear and lemon curd on top. While this in theory sounded like an orgasm in the form of a hot cake, it fell a little short. The flavors were all intact, I just would've liked my pancakes a little lighter and more moist.

I wasn't blown away and was initially disgruntled when walking out of there because of the price (I was left almost twenty bucks poorer, from brunch?!), but a. I'm in a good mood today  and most importantly, b. the fact that I still find myself craving my scramble has got to say something. Okay okay fine, Zazie, I'll be back . . . when my next paycheck rolls around. :)
author: Betty W.

description:
Went on a Wednesday morning, no wait. Delicious French Toast, but nothing worth waiting for.

They gave me an unwashed cup, but quickly apologized and replaced it when I pointed it out.

Much prefer the Sunday brunch French Toast at Zuni. Or for those on a budget, Kate's Kitchen.
author: Mark A.

description:
If there were a breakfast belly godmother, and she were to wave a magic wand and sprinkle breakfast belly fairy dust on me and that sparkly magic dust were to turn into my fairytale dream breakfast, that breakfast would include:  Irish Oatmeal, Challah French Toast, Gingerbread Pancakes and a Latte in a cup shaped like a bowl...okay Zazie you mean this is your regular stuff and we haven't even gotten to your specials yet?

And it gets better. So then on top of it, when you actually order and get your food, the stuff that actually sounds delicious...IS!  

People, it is so so so so so so so so so so good!  It is WOWZERS GOOD!  Like I am from the East Bay and detest driving allover the West Bumblefeck Hills of SF but would do it in a stick shift Yugo to eat here good.  Its so good that I asked the waitress for a box to take home my 1.25" x 1" piece of gingerbread pancake good.  

Okay the other stuff I am suppose to discuss with you:

Ambiance is nice, reminds me of the cafe's in Italy.  Chairs aren't the most comfortable but that might also be because I inhaled so much food so quickly that I needed to lie down and unbutton my jeans immediately and there were no reclining chairs here and well Zazie likes people keeping their pants on, you know other diners and all....

The service... come to think about it I have no recollection of service at all here...just plates of delicious fantasy food being brought to me...plate after plate with steam and tastiness emanating from them...so I guess the service was good then right?
author: Rosie C.

description: My fave brunch place! Their food's just soooooo good!!!
author: Aki L.

description:
I despise standing in line, for food or otherwise. With Zazie and a good friend in town, I made an exception. We had pre-planned EVERY meal for her visit from Friday afternoon through Sunday night, oh, maybe 2 months in advance. So when Sunday morning came we hiked over the hill to Cole Valley. On the way out of the Mission I pointed out the ridiculously long line in front of Tartine and told my pal, it's like that ALL the time... I've stood in it once, never again.

And of course as soon as we pull up in front of Zazie, there is a mob scene and an hour wait. We roll our eyes at each other at our brunch ignorance and debate whether to head to one of the other eateries in the area. Stomachs are growling and our normally chipper banter has become mono-syllables... we decide we should just stay put and wait it out - her weekend visit was too short to include any meal that wasn't incredible.

But finally... FINALLY we get a sweet tap from the host and we walk back to the patio for our table. The place is teaming with happy folks enjoying their weekend rituals and I feel blessed to be among them at last. Our meals were both delicious - chorizo and eggs for Viola, along with home fries which I'm pretty sure I saw her licking her fingers after she finished them, and an amazingly tasty BLT (which I added avocado to). The crunchy bread, the tangy goat cheese, bacon - like there could ever be anything wrong with that. It was memorable. 

Maybe it's because I don't brunch very often but I would go back here in a heartbeat and recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind a wait. After all, aren't the good things worth waiting for?
author: margot b.

description:
Happy Bastille Day!  This is the 714 review I've written.

Zazie's brunch items are good but I actually prefer their dinner menu and don't think brunch is worth the long wait.  Sometimes the bacon and home fries are overcooked.  For brunch I like the eggs valence - poached eggs with eggplant, tomato & chevre - it's healthier because it doesn't come with Hollandaise sauce but it is still packed with flavor.  I've been here quite a few times, for brunch and dinner, because we lived in the neighborhood and brought our out-of-town guests here.

Dinner is a better value and far less crowded.  I usually get the prix fixe option ($23.50 - comes with an appetizer, entrée and dessert).  I always get the mussels marinieres as a starter - steamed mussels with white wine, garlic, shallots, cream and parsley - delicious, fresh and very flavorful.  The broth is SO good.   My favorite entrée is the fish soup Provencale - luscious, thick, creamy tomato-based soup, with chunks of fish and mussels - one of the best soups I've had and it comes with yummy crunchy croutons, cheese and rouille.  Yes, I love mussels.  For dessert I like to get the crème brulee.  A perfect meal (and you get complimentary bread).  We've had some nice, reasonably priced wines here too.    

The atmosphere is rustic, unpretentious, and cozy with French posters on the walls.  We like to sit in the nook by the window but they also have patio seating in the back.
author: Lolia S.

description:
The food here is AMAZING!!! Be sure to order the French Toast Tahiti (stuffed with caramelized bananas & walnuts)! That was by far the best! I had the Monaco (poached eggs with prosciutto and tomatoes provencales) which was really good as well. My other friend had the gingerbread pancakes which we would've been happy without. We are all definitely going back to this place!

They have a very cute outdoor dining area but this place is packed and you are pretty much sitting very close to other customers. The good news is, despite the crowd it brings in, the wait is not terribly long.
author: Michelle H.

description: Super cute and cozy little brunch place in Cole Valley. Came here on a Monday afternoon and there was still a bit of a wait, only around 10min but you can tell that it'd be super long during the weekends. My friend and I ordered the La Mer Benedict (dungeness crab & avocado) which was suuuper delicious! The egg wasn't poached as soft as other places but they give u a pretty hefty amt of crab and overall it was delicious. We also had the famous Tahiti french toast, which had the caramelized banana & walnut and it was soooooo thick and soft just melted in your mouth! I had the mimosa with grapefruit and that was super yummy as well. Overall just very good food and great service as well. next time i'll have to take advantage of the cute outdoor patio area. Reminds me of a little cottage in the wilderness =]
author: Louisa L.

description:
Zazie is an off-the-beaten-path choice for brunch, and I like it that way.  (Though, this doesn't seem to deter anyone because there's always a wait!!)

Located in the adorable Cole Valley, this French bistro offers a delicious, affordable brunch with options to spare.  We decided on the Eggs Fontainbleu (with wild mushrooms, spinach, and fontina, served with a side of red potatoes) - $10.95; the Pancakes du Midi (buttermilk pancakes with fresh fruit, including melons, pineapples, apples, mango, and strawberries) - $13 for 3, $10 for 2, or $4.95 for 1 pancake; and I indulged in a mango mimosa - $5.95 (off of which I got a fantastic little Saturday afternoon buzz).  

There was not a crumb left on either of our plates after we ate, and these are probably the best pancakes I've had, possibly ever.  

TIPS:
- don't ask how anyone who works here how long the wait is for a table, as there is a sign on the window right next to where you write your name down.  The workers here get a little annoyed if you ask, so don't say you weren't warned!
- if you have time to spare, request patio seating - it's beautiful out there on a sunny day
- Mondays are "Bring Your Doggie to Dinner" night on the aforementioned heated garden patio, and it's $10 off "Portrait of a Mutt" Zin
- Tuesdays are No Corkage nights*

*I suppose I'll have to make the trip out here for dinner sometime to take advantage of their wine nights.

Though not cheap by any means (I said it's reasonable, not cheap!), I really do consider Zazie a great value for what you get in portion sizes and ambiance.
author: Kira K.

description:
This is a DINNER review!  Yes, Zazie is open for dinner.  

In deference to Jeff A's insistence that I increase my calorie count, but more because it's the weekend and I want to eat out, we cruised town for a good place to eat.  Innumerable lunatics are waiting up to an hour for a table in Stonestown, can you believe that?  Margaret always comes up with a good idea, and tonight she brought us to Cole Valley for French food.  

Considering I'm feeling pretty good tonight, I believe I was able to crank up the calories without concentrating on butter, the French staple.  Here's how it went down:  

Starters:  a salad for her, and tiger prawns for me.  Five nice big tiger prawns, with evidence of garlic butter, but not dripping in it.  The salads had balsamic vinegar in them, which added interest to what were probably Earth Bound mixed greens.  

Entrees:  She chose duck, which came with spinach and mashed potatoes.  I took a bite of the duck, and delighted in the crispy skin.  A small bite, I swear!  I ordered the fish soup provencale, which was mussels and salmon in a red sauce similar to a bouillabaisse.  Amazingly, the fish soup has no butter!  Like Moses and Isaiah, I have skipped dying and gone straight to heaven.  

Beverage:  green jasmine tea

Dessert:  Oh yes, dessert.  Chocolate pot de creme.  No comments, please.  

Service:  EXCELLENT! 

Tab:  $60 

It's OK, I worked out today.  Jeff, I raised the weights and the speed on the treadmill.  Tomorrow is a work day; back to the routine.  

Bottom line:  Will I be back?  Yes.  It's a nice, quiet, tasty, friendly restaurant.
author: David D.

description:
I went here on a Sunday for brunch. All of my friends were talking about how wonderful this place is.
So, ok, I had to try it for myself. Honestly, the food is not that great. We waited outside for 40 minutes for this???? No, definitely not worthy.
The pastries are not that good and the orange juice is way better at a La Boulange. Maybe I should come back for dinner and see if the dinner food is any better.
author: Paula L.

description:
Really, the fact that they serve a full-fledged brunch menu on weekdays should be a tip-off to avoid weekends, even if you haven't witnessed the Sunday morning sidewalk circus firsthand.  So we took Megan W's excellent (as always) advice and had a Very Special Wednesday Episode of Brunch Mafia.  Ah, the joys of "working" from home.  And, incidentally, it was still pretty much full by noon.  So think early.

Now it hardly seems fair to dock them a star for their weekend popularity, and I can't argue with anything else.  Especially those lemon-poppyseed "miracle" pancakes.  Plenty of scrambles and eggs benedict varieties of course, too (it *is* French-inspired, after all--note the Cafe Au Lait served in a bowl).  The fog lifted just in time for us to make use of the back patio, with its charmingly/annoyingly cramped and rickety tables (now if only they'd connect it with Finnegans Wake, we'd have the definitive Cole Valley nabester social space).

If you're still aspiring to the lifestyle of SF's idle bourgeois, and you can't make weekdays, I wouldn't sweat it--there's plenty of other pancakes in the sea (and besides, leisurely lunches are a gateway to all sorts of horrible work-shirking, beautiful-day-enjoying activities, and before long you'll be a hopelessly degenerate quality-of-life junkie...)
author: Wes M.

description:
My ex works at Zazie. It's true. What a calamity to be banned from my favorite brunch spot!

My dreams are haunted by lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs pierre noire with hallondaise, prosciutto and tomatoes and of course -- the famous Zazie brownie.

I am literally considering dressing in drag and crashing the gates.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I probably shouldn't review breakfast/brunch places because it's my favorite dining food but I can't eat most breakfast foods due to a special diet I am on for medicinal reasons.  But I will do it anyway based on what I did eat and what I watched my friend eat.

Zazie seems like another recession-proof restaurant.  We went on a Friday afternoon and had only a 5 minute wait, which is great because most days I've heard there are waits up to an hour and a half.  The servers were nice but busy and the decor of the place was very inviting, very San Francisco.

I ordered trout and salad and my friend ordered an egg, toast, potatoes, bacon and the french onion soup.  The trout was seasoned well but a little soggy and the salad was nicely dressed.  I also tasted a little bit of my friend's soup and it was quite tasty.  I longed to take a bite of her fabulously runny egg on toast with a bite of bacon, but I just kept stuffing my mouth with fish and salad feeling sad but strong that I was not cheating on my elimination diet.  But she ate everything on her plate and so I knew it was good.  Really, it's hard to mess up breakfast, so I knew it was yummy.  One day when I can eat eggs and bacon and bread again, I will come back and do that plus a stack of pancakes as well.
author: Susan C.

description:
This is the review that wasn't for the breakfast that wasn't.  I imagined that if I got to Cole Valley before 10:00 a.m. I'd be able to snag one of the sidewalk tables and enjoy a little breakfast with my dogs (see my Boulangerie review - I don't actually share my breakfast with my dogs).  Lo and behold, not only were there 20 people out front waiting for tables, all four of the sidewalk tables were already occupied - at 9:45 this morning!  Jesus, people!  Sleep in, would ya!?

I can still review Zazie (even though this morning I was forced to eat at the Bou instead) since I've eaten there so many times.  For breakfast, brunch, and lunch, there's not a better spot in the neighborhood.  They make eggs benedict about 10 different ways (I am partial to the La Mer - that's with crab and avocado - YUM!), fresh squeezed orange juice, good coffee . . . they even make a pretty good burger.  The sidewalk seating is nice with my dogs - and on Monday evenings you can even bring your dogs to the outdoor patio in the back (Mondays are dog night at Zazie), and I think they don't charge corkage if you bring your own wine.  Can't beat that!  Dog night at the Bou!

Finally, since it's right across the street from Cole Hardware, you can combine your breakfast outing with your quest for a phillips-head screwdriver and a paint sample.  How awesome is that?  4-stars worth of awesome, that's the answer!
author: Joe C.

description:
Absolutely love this place. Their various egg dishes make the best post-hangover brunches and they have a variety of great mimosas too. The potatoes are great too.

There is always a line to get in on the weekends (we've waited up to 40 minutes in some cases), but it's worth it!

If you go, make sure to order a side dish of chicken apple sausage. It changed my life.
author: Dave S.

description: I wish Zazie's wasn't so good as then I wouldn't have to wait so long for a table.  Though I've only been for breakfast, it is the best!  Lemon curd to die for!
author: Morgan A.

description:
A great spot for brunch ! On weekends There's always a line out the door at this place and if you can stand to wait outside and pay enough attention to hear your name called, it's totally worth it. Actually the first time we went there was no line at all and we were seated right away, but i think it was because it was a weekday.

At any breakfast or brunch place I always order Eggs Benedict if its on the menu, and Zazie has a great variety of Benedict's to enjoy- my fav is La Mer, which is served with fresh dungeness crab. Sooo yummy and decadent but not too rich! They also have a salmon version as well as a veg version with spinach. You can either order  1 or 2 poached eggs with the benedict, depending on how hungry you are and how full you get off of mimosas which leads me to....

Their build-your-own mimosa kit! The build your own gets you a bottle of sparkling wine with a small pitcher of Oj or they have a variety of other juices if you want to get funky- last time we went we got the elderflower version so our bottle came accompanied by a small pitcher of yummy fragrant syrupy liquid that makes your sparkling wine taste like an intoxicating flower garden. Totally delicious.

Their back patio is really cute and has a garden feel to it. The inside seating area is small but just as cozy.

We  have only gotten great service here. Even though the servers are under a lot of pressure to turn tables over (or at least i would be if i was constantly reminded of the huge crowd waiting outside) but it has never made the service suffer. This place is great for brunch with friends or whoever you're meeting up with in the city. I was going to give it 4 stars just because theres no "waiting area" per se, and theres usually a significant wait, but Zazie cant help the high demand for their delicious food. 5 stars from me!
author: Jen S.

description:
I needed a place to start off my aimless meandering through SF and a couple of my intrepid compatriots suggested this little gem of a bistro in a place I wouldn't have thought to look.

I traveled a long way to get here (think across the bay) and I walked in looking like a sweaty hobo.  It also didn't help that the dining area was full of women having brunch who all stopped in the middle of their conversations to gape at me, some random guy who was dumb enough to wear all black on a beautiful day.  Any reservations I had were erased when, to my delight, the server appeared at my table with a bottle of water and a smile and told me to take my time with the menu.

I'd heard that the poached eggs were the best thing going on here, so I had my server order some Eggs Albert - poached eggs with bacon, white cheddar and salsa fresca - and a cup of coffee.  As the server put it "I love the crispiness of the bacon mixed with the softness of the eggs."  As I put it, "It's got cheese and bacon!  How can I lose?"  The salsa fresca was unexpectedly super fresca and spicy which made the meal that much better.

Zazie lived up to my expectations - a good little restaurant with a beautiful back patio (which I didn't get to sit in because it was packed on this nice day), quick and friendly service and good food in a super laid back atmosphere.  If I had more late mornings to spare, I'd be here as often as I could.
author: Tony N.

description:
If you like standing around outside for upwards of an hour, only to get packed into a tiny restaurant, where you'll get your food after some 30 more minutes of waiting.. then by all means get in line. Moo!

After all the waiting, I expected the food to be phenomenal: It wasn't. I mean it wasn't bad by any means, but why go through all the hassle of this place when there are so many better places nearby with no wait? Yeah, I know they have some special items..

If you are brave enough (hehe) to sit outside, they will give you blankets. Nice touch, but after seeing people literally siting out there in the rain (to avoid an hour wait), the gesture was lost on me.

Your latte and chai's will be served in a bowl (for better or worse).

Despite what I've said,  you've decided to go anyway. Alright, here are some tips:
- When you put your name on the signup sheet, you can write in "Tullys" or "Bar" in ()'s after your name. They will come and get you from those places when your name is up.
- I'd suggest doing brunch at odd times to avoid some of the wait.
- Read the menu before you go in so that you can order quickly.

I may try Zazie for dinner. I do love French food and even though most of the reviews on here recommend brunch, dinner may be better? Ah, I love the pull of "social proof".
author: Andrew M.

description: Stopped in for Sun brunch, wow, what a find! Nice little neighborhood spot that feels like its really captured the European cafe / bistro vibe. I was impressed with the selection and service as well.
author: Mayur A.

description: Had brunch on a Saturday at... 2PM-ish. The wait was an hour long when we went there. We were lucky that it was a pretty decent day and we got to sit out on the patio. The environment was just perfect. I got the Florentine eggs benedict, which came with home fries on the side. The home fries were not the best, but the main attraction (the egg) was delicious! Good times, good food with good friends. It was a really good brunch. The service was great, too. I also sampled my friend's gingerbread pancake. It was huge and delicious.
author: Vera W.

description:
I would have never been able to understand why Zazie always has a ridiculous brunch wait and would have considered this one of the overrated places on Yelp if I hadn't had the BLT.  I've had the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and poached pears which are good but  a little on the heavy side; so I'm not sure how anyone can eat more than one. It's a good thing that Zazie lets you order 1, 2 or 3 pieces. I've had the French Toast Tahiti  which is stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  It's definitely good, but not "Lemmie wait 30-45 minutes for it good." And I've had the mussels, which are decent but a little disappointing when you consider that this is a French Restaurant. Then one day I had the BLT Provencale. Wow... bacon, creamy goat cheese, herbs, lettuce & tomato on foccacia bread.  This has to be the best BLT in the city and worth an hour wait.

Mussels Rating: 3 stars
BLT Rating: 5 Stars
author: Natasha R.

description:
Brunch!  Such good brunch.  Amazing Hollandaise sauce on the Benny-style eggs, which are available in so many variations.  Pancakes are killer too, but I am pretty loyal to the eggs benedict. The service is usually at the top of their game and the back patio is really relaxing on a sunny Sunday morning. 

I don't love waiting in line, having to stand around on the sidewalk, but there doesn't seem to be any other option, and it is worth it.  I live close by, so if you ever want to get in without waiting, call and offer to buy me brunch and I will head right over to Zazie and put your name on the list.
author: Quinn S.

description:
The best gingerbread pancakes I've ever had - light and fluffy and you can choose between a lemon curd topping or poached pear. Always a difficult decision. Zazie is one of the only places that I think is truly worth the wait. I eat a little snack beforehand to avoid the grumpiness. But the staff is so nice and gracious and the pancakes are so delicious, I don't think I'd be grumpy about the wait anyway. They also have superb salads for lunch. And they boast one of the prettiest outdoor patios.

Very exciting update: they now serve the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd AND poached pear! Brilliant!
author: Caitlin L.

description:
I don't eat here on the weekends anymore, because waiting 45 minutes for lukewarm eggs and spotty service is not my idea of a good (read: hangover-friendly) time.

I won't bother railing against the decline of Zazie and its former glory, because, well, this is the circle of life. 

However, there is still a time and a place for Zazie, where it fills a need just perfectly and it's better than any other alternative. And that is weekday mornings. They are open early (as in, before work), on the N line (convenient to both work and home), and serve food of brunch quality and creativity. Like a benedict of crab and avocado, or cornmeal pancakes with blueberry compote. Tell me that's not better than boring old oatmeal at your desk. 

The nice thing about weekday mornings is that the place is nearly empty, so not only is the waitress free to pay attention to your needs, you can probably catch a group of med students get progressively more drunk over a bucket of mango mimosas after a long all-night shift. So you get a tasty breakfast and some entertainment.

Weekday mornings at Zazie are the time and the place.
author: Megan W.

description:
Remember first principles:  Simplicity.  

I went with my fabulous-haired companion in the mid-afternoon so I missed the famous weekend brunch rush and easily got a booth in the front window by the spiral staircase.  (To my surprise the staircase is not pure decoration as I've seen in other places)   There isn't anything that is spectacular or extravagant about Zazie.  It just does the simple things extremely well and is confident about the way it does it.   It is in many ways a truer vision of the French outlook towards food than many places in America that aspire to be French.
author: Beau G.

description:
#1) Adore zer back patio area.
#2) Adore ze inner decor & wait staff.
#3) Zer croque-madame waz to-die-forr.
#4) Zer coffee cake eez incredible.
#5) Zer mimosas are delicieuses. (I had grapefruit, although friend's mango-mimosa & other friend's cranberry-grapefruit was tres yummy too)
#6) Ze bill for 5 of us (and all had mimosas, split ze coffee cakes & had a breakfast entree each) was $25/ person - tip included.

#7) The only problem? - We were waiting for over 45 mins...
Well worth it though.  

I'll never not like this place!
& long live double-negatives!!
author: Anjali V.

description: Amazing brunch!!!  Good news: great fast food in a casual setting, super friendly staff.  Bad news: be prepared to wait. Sunday morning at 11:00 we waited an hour.  Best news: totally worth the wait!!
author: Daniela S.

description:
My frist brunch experience at Zazie was a yummy one! I arrived with a friend and while the wait was a little long the food was well worth it! It was a sunny day so it wasn't too bad waiting outside, I popped next door to Tully's to get a coffee while I waited. 

I order the Albert eggs benedict which was poached eggs with bacon, cheddar, salsa and hollandaise sauce with a side salad. I like that they give you the option to have home fries, salad or fruit for your side. I also liked that you can order 1, 2, or 3 eggs and they're priced accordingly so if you're ravenous you can order 3 and if you're just a bit peckish 1 will do!

I probably would have given it 5 stars except that my second egg wasn't cooked all the way through. But despite that I kept eating anyway because it was THAT good.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Don't believe the hype!

Go to Bambino's instead! Better food, MUCH better service and no 9 hour wait like at Zazie's to get your undercooked eggs thrown at you.

And they give you water. How novel.
author: Mekhala I.

description:
Zazie's! I came here for my 21st birthday with a magnum of champagne (only a $10 dollar corkage fee with 5 people at the table). I had the pre-fixe menu which was a very affordable 23.50 for an appetizer, entree, and dessert. I had the mussels, salmon, and apple purse with ice cream something or other which ran out by 8 p.m. Altogether it was a nice experience. However, the ambiance is more on the romantic side with the restaurant candle lit and lights dimmed for dinner. Again, I came with four other heterosexual males... I can only hope they didn't get the wrong idea.

In any case, the food was very satisfactory and given its more than reasonable price, I believe this is a place I would not at all mind coming to again.

Also, after I had already left the restaurant for ten minutes, the host came outside to find me with a gift card I had left at my table! too legit to quit.
author: Hendson L.

description:
I am officially putting a damper on the hype machine. I don't know how Zazie "used to be" but now it sucks. Such is my verdict: 2 stars.

The wait was fine. We put our names down, trotted down to the cheese store, and came back to be seated immediately. Service was good too, so the review is food-based.

Urban BF had the french toast. He has french toast everywhere he goes. The caramelized bananas were sadly jammed in between thick slices of sweaty, lazy, sugary bread, prompting an image of a fat man at the Sizzler (three plates into his meal). 

I had the mushroom omelet...which sounds like a winner, except it wasn't. The flavor was too saturated and overwhelming. Pretty gross. I turned my attention to the garlic potatoes (how can you fuck this up, right?) but they were hard and uneventful. The toast was the only decent part of my meal.

Hype Hype Hype. Hype. HYPE. So not worth it. The emperor has no clothes.
author: Carrie R.

description:
