French Onion Soup & Salad Beterave
Patio seating for brunch
On a sunny day

Try it some time....that's my favortie meal at Zazie.
author: Paulina C.

description:
Oh Zazie, you are so....je ne sais pas...so cute!

I love your quaint little Cole Valley neighborhood, I love that on Tuesday nights you have a no corkage fee, and you even have a special night for doggie owners!!

Your French Onion Soup was, ooh, la, la....tres bien!  And your CHEESE plate...oh, tu es le diable!!  You KNOW how cheese brings me to my knees! Mon Dieu!  The dungeness crab in the raviolis was so tasty, it melted in my mouth and the small taste of your fruit crumble and pot de creme....left me speechless...............................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................


Whew...I was speechless for a second there just THINKING about it.

I'll definitely be back.....until then, stay sweet!

xx
author: Melanie N.

description:
I've heard about this place for awhile, so on Sunday morning we showed up shortly after 9 AM -- only a 30-minute wait, which I understand wasn't bad at all.  

Honestly, I don't get what the fuss is about.  The special-of-the-day omelet was dry and hard -- "overcooked" would be my guess.  The scramble Provençal was good, but not great: Just a matter of taste, but I didn't think the flavors work particularly well, the taste of cheese overwhelmed everything else..  The homefries were quite good with whole cloves of garlic.  The famous gingerbread pancakes were in my opinion pretty bad: too-thick, and therefore doughy and wet in the middle.  

Our bill was over $40 for two people for breakfast.  

There are plenty of breakfast places in SF that charge 1/3 less, and where you don't have to wait.  I probably won't be back: although it wasn't a bad experience, it wasn't especially good, or worth the wait or the price tag.
author: John M.

description:
Oh Zazie, Zazie, Zazie.  You had me at hello.

Breakfast / Brunch ranks up there as pretty much the best meal of the day...in fact, dare I say, the best meal of the day. And Zazie is by far the best breakfast-y joint I've been to on this side of the Bay. Big statement, but I feel that I can confidently back it up.

My poached egg florentine dish was incredible. Scarfed down the whole thing in under 20 minutes.  I chased the eggs with a delectable Mango Mimosa. Oh my God you guys. It was delish. I can't wait to go back just to try the other varieties (Currant, Blackberry, etc.).  

My cute dining partner had French Toast, of which I allowed myself only one bite, but could've eaten the entire plate had I not been trying to be "good table manners Stephanie".  Seriously the best French Toast I've ever had - the perfect amount of sweetness. 

It's places like this that reaffirm my faith in a Higher Power.
Thank you God.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This may become one of my new favorite places for brunch!  Thanks Yelp for helping me find this sweet little spot.

I love the atmosphere here...so cozy.  The staff is so friendly...the host who helped us with our table kept calling me by name, and the waitress called us "love" which totally beats "miss".

I love that brunch hour runs through 3pm.  Breakfast is my fav meal of the day so being able to order french toast past the morning hours is great!  I had the challah french toast with fruit...yummy, but not the best that I've had.  If you order mocha or any coffee drink, be prepared for a BIG soup bowl of it.  They don't serve it in mugs or cups here...pretty interesting!  The other surprise is that fries here is roasted potato wedges with garlic (they even give you the whole cloves of garlic) and not the stick version.

Like other reviewers have mentioned, be prepared for a wait.  But they do a great job at handling the crowd!

Review#100!
author: Mick S.

description:
*UPDATE*
After my Zazie review, I received a message and it goes.... 

             Wow, thanks so much!  I just came online looking for angry comments about the $1/ person Health Care surcharge, since it's new to us... and reading your kind and understanding review first was a great way to start my day.  Yes, a new law was passed that requires all employers to give everyone full coverage- which I think is GREAT, just very expensive.  $108,000/ year for us.  Yikes.  So this is how we're going to do it, and hopefully most people will be as understanding as you are!   

Anyway, thanks again-you're a star!  No, 5 stars! 
Sincerely, 
Jen Piallat, owner, zazie



I love Zazie :)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



I now know why Zazie's brunch is so popular.

The Sparkling Lemonade was a nice as it sounded. A cool refreshing fizzle to start the day was just what I needed. I ordered the Eggs Pierre Noire which comes with homefries. I like how they give you an option of ordering one, two, or three eggs. I chose one, just so I wouldn't look like TOO much of a heffer because I really wanted to try the French Toast Tahiti (stuffed w/ caramelized bananas & walnuts). I normally don't care for french toast, but I think it was the best french toast I've ever had. 

My bf ordered the Eggs Mexico (with chorizo, white cheddar, roasted peppers & homemade salsa). With his first bite his reaction was, "Mmm! This is damn good." I took a bite. Ooh, he no lie. 

Before I forget, Zazie adds $1/person onto the total bill. It has something to do with trying to get SF to launch a universal health care plan, which I'm all for. 

Service is real friendly. Environment is comfortable. Food is awesome. Can't ask for anything more, really.
author: Jen Y.

description: Yes, the wait is insanely long, but this place is soooo awesome for brunch! After reading the stellar reviews, we decided to pop in and fuel for the day. We ended up splitting the Eggs La Mer & the Eggs Florentine and they were both stellar. The service is friendly and surprisingly fast considering the teensy kitchen and the packed house. The wait sucks, but you can throw your name on the list and head down to the nearby coffee shop while you're waiting!
author: Shannon E.

description:
I always take friends and clients here for brunch.  Probably the best breakfast I've had to date in SF.

Absolutely Fab! :)
author: Terry R.

description:
They had me at "garden patio." (Which is gorgeous... the many shades of green and light yellow and the landscaping has this designer sighing happily...) 

Next came a delicious mid afternoon snack, served by a British waiter who punned. Sold.
author: Laura B.

description: This is my favorite brunch spot in town. I love their hot chocolates and egg benedicts!  I bring my visitors to this spot and they have not been disappointed!
author: K P.

description:
Great service and value - most SF restuarants charge 1.5 to 2 times as much for the same food and service.  Very good atmosphere and food.  The parking situation was crap-tastic, but it was surprisingly easy to get a last second dinner reservation on a Saturday.  In my book, Zazie scores in the top 15% of restaurants in SF: worthy of 5-stars.

I had the trout and a bite of my friend's salmon.  Both were delicious, but delicately flavored - this is French food, after all.  A touch of salt kicked them into gear, which is okay as I'd much rather the kitchen leave the salting up to the guests.  

We started off with a simple house salad (terrific balsamic orange dressing), a cheese plate (good, but not great) and the cream of asparagus soup (okay, but nothing special).

I'll definitely be back.
author: David L.

description: One of the best brunch spots in SF. I used to live in the neighborhood and miss going to this place.
author: Shawn W.

description: This place is no longer kids/babies friendly. You will be greated with dirty looks if you dare to walk in. Their manager is aggressive, rude and he thinks he works at Gary Danko. The service is bad. The food got worst and doesn't not resemble anything French. I live in the neighbourhood and won't go there anymore. I will rather go to a more mediocre restaurant like Bambinos, at least there a feel welcomed and all that good stuff.
author: Biemme B.

description:
What Zazie has Zazie does pretty well.

I've been here for both brunch and dinner.  For brunch, the poached egg options are really scrumptious.  The Gingerbread Pancakes are titilating, it's really hard to choose between these and the Tahitian French Toast with the bananas and walnuts.  I think brunch is where Zazie excels.

For dinner, everything I've had has been good, but the selection isn't very broad if you don't eat fish or mushrooms (I eat neither).  The polenta cakes I had once were not so great: the sauce made them sort of soggy instead of adding another element to the texture.  Dessert is definitely the highlight, get the baked hot chocolate!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Anywhere that lures me in to have breakfast (! of all meals!) twice in one week has got to have something going on!  I suggest Eggs Cristophe.  Delicious!

Again - Still 5 Stars.  Breakfast was to die for (tried the gingerbread pancake this time. OMG. I almost fainted it was sooo gooooood.)  Our waiter seemed a bit cranky (I can relate, it was before 9am!), but a very nice lady (one of the higher-ups, I believe) saw we had a table full of plates and pushed the empty table next to ours over so we could spread out, proclaiming that we needed more room!

It's more of a walk than my usual breakfast haunt, but sooo worth it!
author: MoMo D.

description: Damn I'm glad we found this place...  Huge bonus points to our friends who recommended it!  Both my wife and I had the La Mer (poached eggs over crab), which was finger-licking good.  In the past it's always been a hit or miss when I've ordered poached eggs (undercooked vs overcooked), but this place hit the nail on the head for both our orders, which tells me that the chef is very consistent.  I also ordered a side of bacon, which came thick-cut, and cooked to perfection.  Not surprised that there was a 45ish minute wait, but we would have waited twice that.  Definite upcoming return visit!
author: Rob O.

description: The only down side is long wait for brunch. So go on off hours and have a delightful time. Every thing is great. Really rich decaf coffee. I have breakfast and lunch there for a few years. Always good. Croque Monsieur is a favorite. I take guests and they love it. This place is a San Francisco gem.
author: Kristian M.

description:
I came to Zazie looking for something unique and left with a bad taste in my mouth. Literally. 

The location is great the host is great. The price sucks, the wait sucks, the coffee was really bad, and the quality of the ingredients is questionable. Our server liked to stare off into the distance from the order station for minutes at a time & forgot an item. When all of these factors come together it leads to an unsatisfactory meal.

I could taste the French influence, as they liked to play with flavor concepts and stay away from the basic salt & pepper. This can be good, but many times here it lead to blandness or very sour tasting food.

We ordered:
- Cream Cheese Coffee Cake
- Coffee
- French Toast Carmelized Banana w/ Walnuts
- Gingerbread Pancakes w/ pears & lemon compote
- Bacon, Spinach & Fontana Cheese eggs
- Side of Bacon

This was just our experience here; Meaning I won't be back as there are much better places for a solid breakfast such as Absinthe, Mama's, random cafe A, crepe shops, even Stacks (for their consistency). The best items were the coffee cake (which was very bland) and the gingerbread pancakes mostly for the pears. I really enjoyed the pancakes at first. They have a nice flavor that is just straight up gingerbread with pear and the lemon compote mix. After eating them almost 1/2 way through, I realized that there wasn't much else to them though. Gingerbread pancakes are really just a gingerbread muffin, but flatter and w/ stuff on top. The consistency was closer to a muffin as well. 

Biggest flops were the omelet because the cheese was too sour to really enjoy it. The coffee because the 1st cup was burnt sour and the 2nd was only slightly better. The bacon, because it was below Denny's fare in quality. The potatoes because they had no flavor. The water because it smelled like a dog licked the glass clean. 

This is more like 2.5 stars, but since 3 should be average and there are so many unnecessary 5-Star critics in SF I'm starting to award lower scores to spots that are hot due mostly to spastic local hypers.
author: Nick V.

description: This 5 rating is carried by Zazie's cream cheese coffee cake. Warm, dense, light, creamy, sweet, salty all at the same time. If you don't want to wait in the ridiculously long line (at all times) for regular food, you can grab some to-go (my friend did), and you'll seriously be a happy camper. I loved the outdoor seating in the patio area. Super cute gardenesque atmosphere where you could actually hear the people you're talking with (I'd ask for seating back there, because seating indoors seems a bit hectic). The La Mer poached eggs were okay. Not my favorite, but the potatoes came on the side came with garlic, and that was the money bit. The french toast with the caramelized bananas and walnuts was good, but not good enough to go back for. Cream cheese coffee cake all the way.
author: Lillian K.

description:
Newest review:

Not so great. Nicoise salad.. sad. Spinach salad... sad... Service... pretty sad... Gone back many times since the first review and it is consistently just ok although the eggs with chorizo are really good. The patio is so nice that it is almost worth the bad service and ok food. Asking for lemon in my water is the litmus test of a good waiter. They consistently forget my lemon and give me attitude when I remind them.

(old review)
Loved this place. Sat in the patio becasue the indoor dining area seemed a little warm. The patio is super cute and intimate. The food was wonderful and the service was good as well. The waitress was helpful without being Disney. The charcuterie plate was delicious and the grilled black tiger prawns were perfectly salted and cooked to perfection. I tend to stay away from shrimp or lobster when I don't know a place because I have gotten a lot of "rubber" lately, but this place knows what's up. Can't wait to go back and try lunch.
author: Claudia O.

description:
For as big a city as San Francisco and with such an acute focus on great food, it's surprising that there aren't more truly great breakfast joints.  Fortunately, there is Zazie.  Homey and warm, the exposed brick walls make this casual breakfast place a comfortable destination for dates, friends, and families.  Sidewalk seating lets you take advantage of those warm summer days (hey - Cole is jussssttt inside the fogline!), but don't get there too late or you could be in for quite a wait.

They offer the basics, but also some wonderful creations that can appeal to the health-conscious (steel-cut-oatmeal, great scrambles - and they'll do them with egg whites only if you prefer), and to the not-quite-so-health-conscious (can you say steel-cut-oatmeal topped with banana-creme-brulee?).

Give it a shot!
author: Josh M.

description:
I like Zazie's.  A lot.  And yes, I call it Zazie's, even though I realize the name is actually Zazie.  Sue me.  Better yet, spank me.

5 stars for the pancakes and syrup.  I don't know how they do it, but the combination is to die for.  

I eat the pancake alone.  
It's just alright.
I eat the pancake with the syrup.
Orgasmic.

Eggs were fluffy and light.  Bacon was meaty.  Zazie sprizter refreshing.  Plus the staff are very nice to boot.  I've eaten here before on the back patio and it's quite charming.  A little hard to get a seat back there on a busy day so plan ahead. 

Oh yeah, I have to mention this.  It was Memorial Day today and therefore a large crowd had formed outside, waiting to be seated.  I love the fact that they have a sign in sheet with check boxes (inside seating?, patio seating?, first available?, is your party all here?) and then there was a narrative typed up next to the sign in sheet entitled "So How Long is the Wait?" which explained, among other things, how to estimate the length of the wait based on the number of people ahead of you .  Genius.  Everything flowed so smoothly and the server who seated me didn't seem a bit frazzled.  

Why don't more places learn how to simplify and refine the waiting process?  

I'll never know.
author: LaSha G.

description:
So, the best way I can think to write this is reviewing the experience in chronological order. Sorry its kind of lenghty I know, hopefully its worth the read. 

Driving to this place anticipation of another great meal grew. We had eaten here before, but this would be our first brunch experience. We're kind of brunch fanatics. I can't think of any kind of food better than really good breakfast food. We got to Zazie and were greeted by a crowd of people waiting to get sat. We briefly drove by this crowd and considered going elsewhere. The closest place I could find to park was on cole and haight, and that spot was metered. So keep in mind if the line was as long as it seemed, it meant we would walk the roughly 6-7 blocks to get to Zazie, we would then get our name on the list hopefully get sat, then I would run 6-7 blocks to feed the meter, then run back. As I said, we love breakfast food. 

So now, were parked and at Zazie with our name on the list. According to the little "wait time formula" they have posted on the window (3 min X every party in front of you on the list) we were in for a 45 minute wait. It seemed like a small price to pay, considering all that we had heard about brunch at Zazie. Then opportunity unfolds. Ten minutes into our wait, and group who is parked virtually in front of Zazie is leaving, I convince them to wait two-three minutes before leaving their spot while I ran to my car and moved it closer, to hopefully avoid the trek to feed the meter mid meal. So I am, running, sprinting rather, down to haight to get my car. I get in the car, and on my way to Zazie I realize my fiance called to tell me these fools left and the spot was taken. Ugh. not really a Zazie ugh, but ugh none the less.

Being the quick thinker I am, I hang a right pulling a california roll at the stop sign (think traffic not sushi) and I stumble on free parking on parnasus right around the corner. Well can you see how this is becoming an emotional rollercoaster? So I walk back to Zazie, happy as a clam that the day is looking up. I get back to Zazie, and we wait. Wait some more. Something tells me this is going to be worth it, so we wait some more. At some point I have to go back to the car for something. On my way back I get a text from my fiance stating they called us, and would not seat us as I'm not there. I think we both understand. It makes sense we'd have to wait for the next available two person table to open up, given the extensive wait list. Well this is where I get lost. When I approach the host, to let him know entire party is here, he says shortly "well I dont have a seat for you now". Ok. *sigh* but why. He didnt seat anyone else since calling our name. And why did the host proceed to seat another two person table before us after I informed him we were all here? I don't think I'll ever understand that, but I'm letting it roll off, because again, we love breakfast food. 

FInally, the moment we've been waiting for. We're in. Perusing the menu, and there is so much to choose from. All of it looks and sounds delicious. The place smells delicious. I ordered 2 slices of french toast with a side of chicken apple sausage. My fiance ordered a variation of eggs benedict. Mine was out of this world good. Hers was life altering, earth shattering good. Every flavor that was present on either plate perfectly complimented flavors it was surrounded by. Zazie has changed my list of top 2 breakfast places to a list of top 3. All things considered, from the wait to the parking fiasco to the perfectly executed food we will definitely be back to Zazie, and I can not wait. Thanks Zazie. 

*plan to spend your morning at Zazie. Plan to spend about 40 bucks for two and plan on thouroughly enjoying every morsel.
author: Jarred D.

description:
cornmeal pancakes with lemon curd: delicious and inventive and good portion. quick coffee refills -- awesome touch. the jam in the little jar on the table was amazing. scramble (avocado, bacon, white cheddar, asparagus) was really yummy but too small of a portion.  adorable ambiance. good prices. A+ neighborhood brunch place.

only cons: we felt rushed to get out of there when we finished our meal. they brought the check while we were eating and stopped brining coffee once the bill was on the table.
author: p.c. m.

description:
Here are the knocks against Zazie's competition:

Mama's- You get to wait over an hour to be served cafeteria style and eat with patrons staring you down through the window or hovering over your table waiting for to finish.

Dottie's True Blue- Great food, and extra convenient if you want to score some crank afterwards.

Now Zazie: killer food, great vibe (especially outside), and, yeah, you gotta wait but its worth it. Go for the potatoes instead of salad (whole garlic cloves...yummm) and get some gingerbread pancakes for pete's sake.
author: Rainer P.

description:
+4 stars for seriously having some of the tastiest brunch in SF. Classier joints often skimp on the meatless options, but vegetarians won't go hungry at Zazie.

-1 star for charging $2 extra for substitutions. Reminds me of another word that rhymes with 'Zazie'.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Yummy again! 

Came here a few weeks back with the bf, to turn him onto Cole Valley & this adorable French favourite of mine. We jointly sampled 4 of the gazillions of mimosa-styles: orange, orange & cranberry, grapefruit, and mango. (I only wish they had bellinis!) We ordered the Eggs New York (a Scramble with smoked salmon, green onions & cream cheese), and it was fantastic! Even more delicious was the French Toast Tahiti with carmelized bananas & walnuts. Well, both were amazing. :)

I love brunch at Zazie, and only wish I lived closer!
author: Sally M.

description:
5 stars for an amazing patio, great service and reasonable prices!! Visit Zazie on a nice day when you can sit outside. There's space heaters in case it's a little chilly.

My friend and I  shared the tahitian french toast as an appetizer ( what can I say, we like to eat) and it was delicious! Fabulous! I had the mediterranean plate which was also quite tasty. I looked around at what everyone sitting near me had and I have to say, all of the food looked so yummy. Everything on the menu sounded so good! I can't wait to go back and try several of the egg dishes at brunch.

A few notes, if there is a wait they will not seat you unless your entire group is there. So don't send one friend early to grab a table as it won't work. Parking in this neighborhood can be a little tricky so give yourself time to find a spot. Also the inside of the restaurant is pretty compact so I would not suggest going with a big group. Aside from that, fab experience!
author: Kandace K.

description:
Review for their brunch menu.

Oooh la la. 

I've been here twice for brunch and I'll definitely be back again. The wait was well worth it. Gingerbread pancakes were heaven especially with their baked pear topping - oh hullo!

Oh and their La Mer poached eggs? Crab meat and avocado, on a English muffin, topped with a poached egg and a light sauce? Yes. This paired with a mango mimosa, is divine.

The owner (I think he was the owner) worked the wait list like a pro and was so pleasant!  Even with all those hungry peeps waiting outside.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
For me, this is the only place the rivals the Butler and the Chef for breakfast (well, at least in the Eggs Benedict category.) 

Ate here twice in the past 2 weeks (and my last 2 in San Francisco for awhile) which was a nice treat. During our first visit during crazy Sunday brunch time, we sat outside on one of the tiny bistro tables in the front which was good people watching on a sunny day. (The flower box adjacent to us provided a temporary good place to shelve our extra condiments and plates when our table got too full.) Our party shared a bottle of bubbly to "build your own mimosas" which was cool and very reasonably priced. I had the crab Eggs Benedict (indulgent, I know, but it WAS my birthday, and I was hungover), which was excellent. The table also shared a blueberry pancake which had fresh lemon curd on top, which was mouth watering and mind blowing. I'm more into savory and sweet in the AM, but I could have eaten a double stack of these pancakes.

Most recently we sat out on the back patio on another sunny SF day (yes, two this summer, what a nice surprise!) and I tried the veggie panini sandwich, which consisted of yellow squash, red onion, roasted peppers, pesto and goat cheese and came with a salad. Yumtastic. Also insanely good was the sparkling lemonade, which was frosty ice cold and refreshing. (Was great on its own, but reminded me a bit of sipping on lemoncello and could have been great as an alcoholic drink too.)

Everything about this place is cute and delicious, and worth the wait if you have time, but don't be in a rush because while service is fine, it's always busy. Special thanks to my buddy Page, who is kind enough, even in his most hungover state, to walk downstairs and around the corner from his place to put my name on the list (then walk back upstairs and fall asleep) during the crazy Sunday brunch rush.
author: Kelly R.

description: Hands down my favorite breakfast food in the city. Extremely sweet staff. The portions are big, filling, and delicious. I love to order the poached eggs (The monaco is my personal favorite) and I either order a miracle pancake or cream cheese coffee cake. Depending on who I might be dining with. Everything is delicious though, I've even enjoyed my oatmeal from there. Excellent food with a polite staff. Couldn't be better.
author: Mariah M.

description:
It seems like many San Franciscans have dogs instead of kids and this is a GREAT PLACE TO BRING YOUR DOG.

Zazie is also good sans-dog but we mainly go here because we can bring our little fur baby! The tables in the front are first come first serve and since most people don't want to eat on the sidewalk, the tables literally "go to the dogs" for brunch. Also, on Monday nights, you can dine in the outdoor garden area with your dog. They even have special dog night dinners that include a meal for your dog.

There's usually a wait for weekend brunch but you can sign your name in and let the host know that you will be waiting in the bar next door. He'll come get you when your table is ready! The bar next door has AMAZING BLOODY MARYS and what's brunch without a good Bloody Mary??

I haven't had anything on the menu at Zazie that wasn't good. Of special note are the GINGERBREAD PANCAKES though. YUM YUM. For dinner, the steak was excellent and the heat lamps kept us nice and toasty.

Parking can be a pain but it's worth it. Also Zazie is right by the N Muni line if you are taking public transportation. It's also within walking distance of Upper Haight.
author: Cindy P.

description: I have to admit that I am a bit of a brunch snob. This place was good, but not spectacular. The coffee was nice and strong. I've been there twice and the first time had the French Toast Tahiti and the second time had the Florentine Eggs Benedict. Don't get me wrong they were good, but wasn't wowed. I think La Note is far superior.
author: Steve K.

description:
In a word: Savory.  In more than a word:  Savory with questionable service.

I came to Zazie's alone on a weekday at 10 a.m. with a Chronicle in hand.  I was allowed to take any table I wanted (that always makes me happy), but the back patio was closed, so I'd have to stay indoors.  There were only two or three other parties brunching away, and I settled in for a long brunch at a table for two all by my lonesome.

I ordered the Fontainbleu scramble, earl grey tea, and a Zazie Spritzer.  The Fontainbleu is a mixture of two (or was it three?) types of mushrooms, spinach, and fontina cheese.  The scramble itself was incredibly rich (but I expected this, having ordered an omelette with fontina cheese in it), with approximately four bites of spinach in it.  They were good bites, though.

The scramble came with a side of toast (wheat or white--I ordered white, and was happily surprised to find that it would be two thick slices of Challah).  The toast alone warranted a star here--well, actually, the raspberry preserves sitting in a cute little jar on every table deserve the star.  Really fabulous stuff, but if you don't like seedy jams, it's not for you.  

My scramble also came with a scoop of Zazie's famous breakfast potatoes. The thing about the breakfast potatoes is that they're not BREAKFAST potatoes--and they're fantastic.  The chef has halved and quartered red potatoes and roasted them with whole, skin-on cloves of garlic until everything is a mooshy, garlicky mess.  They're a rich, buttery delight--but they taste a little more like salt itself than like a dish that's been highlighted by a sprinkle of salt.  

Sadly, nothing ruins good food like bad service, and if you have good food, it makes me even more angry that you're careless about your service.  My $3 Zazie spritzer never came (although it wasn't on the bill either); I never got water; my waitress literally never cracked a smile; & I got my check delivered to my table before I had a chance to even ask for the Zazie spritzer for a second time.  If I wanted food served with a scowl, why would I come to a sunny, active little French bistro in cute Cole Valley?

Yes yes, the food was rich & filling & interesting.  But it wasn't THAT good, was it?
author: Ann M.

description:
Yesterday Zazie did the thing that restaurants just don't do -- they made my Soyrizo scramble with real meat.

Oddly enough, I've actually never had this happen to me in almost 20 years of vegetarianism.  I've found meat in sauces I didn't inquire about or something like that, but never had a specified veggie, tofu, soy ,etc.  order come out with meat in it.  When we questioned whether the much touted 'Rizo was real or faux, our server gave us a "Hmm" look and took the plate away without a word.  Minutes later, he re-arrived, very apologetic, insisted on comping the entire meal (to which I replied with the obligatory "You don't have to..." ) and then, with no explanation, brought the check out with only the scramble comped.  

The place itself was very cute and I would be interested in checking out the menu further.  When you do enough covers, there's no way to avoid mistakes in the kitchen, but I was more thrown by the inconsistencies in service.  

In other news, the fruit bowl wasn't ripe enough, the benedict eggs were under poached, the home fries and banana french toast were delicious, and I totally dug the 22 oz. Fischer beer (Warning: Yankees, this beer is not carbonated!).  Overall Zazie, like many other brunch places in this city, seems to be more about the atmosphere and less about the food.  Fine with me!  Bring on the booze -- just avoid the soy!
author: Abby M.

description: No corkage fees on Tuesdays is an all-around fantastic deal if you enjoy wine with your French bistro fare. The outdoor patio seating is divine and as every SF establishment should, they are equipped heat lamps for those chilly "summer" evenings.
author: Lee H.

description:
I love love loved the Ginger Pancakes.  I'm much more of a sweet breakfast type of person so I was thrilled to get two gigantor pancakes with Lemon Curd.  They were perfectly sweetened as well. 

I'm so glad that this time going to Zazie we waited at Zazie instead of our tummy's making up their minds and sending us to Bambino's. =)
author: Bhumika K.

description:
All I have to say is.. The eggs benny are redonk!

I love breakfast and I once ate a dozen egg omeletee, so I think I know a bit about breakfast. And I have to say their their food is great. Even the potatoes are delicious.

I got a bit carried away and ordered the Crab Eggs Benedict and the Ginger pancakes. The ginger pancakes were pretty good but the Eggs Benny were better.

A nice clip http://youtube.com/watch?v=3zx8GbtHmFU which sums up why Guys can enjoy brunch, Bro style.
author: Donny X.

description:
Okay. They don't need another review from me but just want to share that I went there on a weekday at around 1130am. No wait! yay! even able to grab seats out at the patiooooo on a sunny day *Grin*

Tahiti French Toast was quite good but it was the poached egg and the roasted potatoes and the roasted garlic that amazed me! I will definitely go back after I have conquered other famous bunch places in the city!
author: Ris L.

description:
I'm going to be generous because I do see myself coming back (for brunch, I'm told) especially due to the prix fixe dinner menu which allows you to choose a three course meal for under $22. 

But food wise, it's not mind blowing. The mussels were well done but the sauce does not compare to the Public (I'm biased with you Helen F!). The pesto pasta I ordered was lacking the flavor department, but this could just be personal preference. I like food with a kick. But the strawberry rhubarb crumble was divine. Mmm...tarty sweet goodness!

I do have a bone to pick with the service. When my friend and I first entered the restaurant, we stood there for a good couple of minutes and not one server or hostess (was there even a host working that night?!) came up to us to ask us to be seated or if we had a reservation. My friend, needing to go to the bathroom was the one who informed me that our party was sitting out back in the patio. No one looked at us, no one even wanted to make eye contact with us to seat us. WTF?

Tsk tsk on the service, people. If I was a non-reservation/birthday dinner going patron, I would have left the restaurant due to lack of attentiveness. That's you losing business. Boo.

EDIT: The very kind owner of Zazie, Jennifer P., PM'ed me and said this: "I'm glad to know that you and your friend went so unacknowledged tuesday night... I will definatly speak to the host and the waitstaff about that.  The waiters have come to assume that the host will greet people, but if he's on the patio that's not always fast enough.  Thanks for calling my attention to this issue... I truly hate to stand at a restaurant door endlessly myself!"

Thanks Jennifer!
author: Viv C.

description:
While the wait can be on the long side (eat a piece of toast before you go or you'll faint), Zazie's breakfast/brunch is delectable.  

A myriad of different mimosas will tickle your tongue while you are trying to decide between the sweet (ginger pancakes), or the savory (egg dishes).  It is really hard to go wrong here. 

I wish Zazie would sell whatever magic dust they sprinkle on their eggs fontainebleu to make the egg/mushroom/spinach combo so marvelous and so much tastier than any I've ever had.  

I had dinner here once too and it was also good, though not as memorable.
author: James M.

description: Solid.  Great neighborhood spot. good for any meal of the day.  I just ate their outstanding pork chop.  I asked for a wine pairing and the server came back with a dry gewurztraminer that was unexpected and really good.
author: Mera G.

description: The food was good, but  my french toast wasn't anything amazing.  And seemed a bit expensive for what it was.  I went on a weekday and fortunately I didn't have to wait.
author: Job E.

description:
Weekend brunch is delightful. Be prepared to wait though-- bring a book, get a coffee from Tully's next door or meander about the fancy pharmacy for an overpriced chap stick. Or you can just stare down the patrons taking their sweet time getting the bill with eyes that say "eat it or leave it!"

Friendly staff, courteous seating host who kept checking with our group prior to being seated and an excellent array of brunchie bevvies, both alcoholic and non.

I got a grilled chicken sandwich and eyed the special omlette my friend ordered when it came. You have the option to choose your portion size, so you're not leaving the joint feeling like you just had a ten pound skillet from Denny's. 

The homefries were the best--huge chunks of roasted garlic. Mmph! I'd definitely go back again. I'd love a chance to sit out in the back patio on a sunny day as well.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Brunch is consistently scrumptious and surprisingly fast in delivery during even their busiest times.  

Gingerbread pancakes are so. incredibly. good.

Eggs benedict in classic and smoked salmon varieties are both a party in my mouth.  

Don't bother with lemonade sparkling water business, too costly, not too interesting.  Pelligrino is a better move if you're looking for citrus and bubbles. Mimosa however is a lovely treat, but the variations are usually better.

This is hands down my favorite place to squint in the sunshine at my Sunday paper playing footsie with my dining companion while at the same time stuffing my belly silly.

Lunch is pretty great too, especially during the week.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I love this place: brunch or dinner.. both are very good. I agree, you have to be patient because for brunch the place is usually extremely packed & you might have to wait up to one hour but I believe it is worth it. I am not going to talk about the brunch much bec everything - and I mean it- is very tasty and that's what people seem to review the most.

Let's talk about dinner! I can't think of a better neighborhood place for an outstanding but not super expensive dinner. Depending your guest/s your night can turn into the most romantic one-on-one or a fun & partying group of 8. 
The lamb is delicious and my steak is usually exactly how I ask for it. People seem to like the onion soup... 

One thing you should remember though: it is a neighborhood place with lots of French charm. Don't expect the cool, minimalist place that you find at EO'S next door or so.

And most important to me: the patio in the back. I looooove to sit outside, hidden away from the street and eat.. it reminds me of the restaurants/cafes back home.
author: Doro P.

description:
After pretending to listen to my friend's life problems for 45 agonizing minutes, waiting for a table on a Saturday morning, I had really worked up an appetite and was excited to see all the fresh and tasty choices on Zazie's extensive brunch menu. Looking around, I was really feelin the artsy & cozy décor, but wasn't diggin the cramped seating arrangement. Zazie is definitely not the place to talk about your itchy man parts or leaking anus because everyone and their mom will overhear your conversation. 

After salivating over practically every item on the menu, I finally decided on the fresh grilled tuna sandwich with tomatoes provencales, aioli, and sun dried tomato pesto with greens on toasted levain. The tuna was lightly seasoned and fresh and the condiments complimented the sandwich well. My friend was also very happy with her gingerbread pancakes (although I wasn't happy about having to listen to the stupid bi*** incoherently babble about her relationship drama for over 2 hours.)
author: Alvin T.

description:
My girlfriend and I went for brunch for a second time and I was disappointed for the second time.  The coffee cake is not coffee cake.  The egg dishes lack a lot of flavor.  The only thing worth eating are their pancakes.  Just really disappointing because my girlfriend loves the "cute" atmosphere and service, unfortunately their food is not worth the wait or the price.  
Parking is horrendous!
author: LIVE to E.

description:
Extremely accomodating on all levels!  I made a reservation for a party of 14 and they probably gritted their teeth and said, "Won-der-ful... what time?"  This place does not look like they generally hold such a big group.  A group for them would be like 6 people.  They gladly anticipated our arrival.

They did however ask that we opt for the prix fixe menu, because taking in ale carte orders would have been ball-busting for their wait staff and kitchen.  Absolutely understandable and likely best for us as well!  We've rolled through with a bigger group to another restaurant before and by the time we got our food all at once, some were cold, while others were raw.  A hurried kitchen tends not to deliver a quality product.  So good call on having us do thier prix fixe menu, which btw had some great choices.

Jennifer, the owner, thoroughly made sure we were squared away before our arrival.  She even asked if they could personalize the menu knowing this was a special occassion.  We all sat down to a thoughtful message on top - "Happy Birthday 'Chris T.'s friend'!"  I got cool points from friends for setting that up!  (by the by... I am still accepting Cool points, fellow Yelpers. hehe)

I had anticipated we'd get patio seating for such a big group and I dreaded that as it had started to drizzle that day.  To our surprise upon arrival, they sacrificed half their inside room for us!  Awesome!  The waitress immediately asked for us to point out the Bday girl... again, we did not ask for this but they brought her a special dessert at the end.  The kind and attentive service prevailed throughout the entire night.  Buns warmed and reloaded often, water refilled, bowls set for shells, and speedy feet to run across our 15 foot table.  A helpful staff almost always beckons me to give repeat visits.
author: Chris T.

description:
Did the portions get skimpier?  I haven't been to Zazie's in years, and while it's always been on the pricier side as far as brunches in this town goes, I didn't recall them being so tight on the portions. Those of you with inferior stomach capacities to mine, you CAN portion control, and get 1, 2 or 3 egg options for omelettes, or poached eggs.   
I, however, can eat twice my weight in carbs. C'mon, give a girl a few more chunks of roasted potatoes - is that even a cupful?   The ingredients are good quality and the combo's tasty but none-too-heavy.  This is NOT a country fried steak sorta place. The whole roasted garlic cloves in the potatoes are a great touch, btw.
3.5 stars.
author: CINDY K.

description:
BRUNCH REVIEW 4 1/2 star

-they have street parking, i think its max 1 hour
-indoor/outdoor seating. I sat inside
-long list of people waiting for brunch on a weekday, I was surprized-it moved very fast, not even 5 minuets.
-seated and greeted by friendly server
- I read many great reviews so I ordered all the popular items, lemar (eggs benedict with crab), fries, pancakes and french toast and fresh oj. Total bill- about $100 for 2 hearty eaters. Delicious!! Could not complain, the food was perfect, the service was EXCELLENT. 

fyi- Im not big on pancakes or french toast but I loved them here. Only reason it was not a five star is because It didnt beat the eggs benedict at ritz carlton brunch in halfmoon bay.
author: Azizi A.

description: Zazie has lost me.  It's pretty sad how one bad experience can ruin it for you but it has.  This used to be one of my favorite places for breakfast.  The patio is great.  I went there for Easter brunch.  Ordered my usual Albert poached eggs.  The eggs came out completely hard.  They weren't runny at all.  Another person at our table had the same result.  I noticed it wasn't a fluke when another table had the same issue.  The quality of the food has been going down at Zazie but this was the last straw.  At least this will give me a chance to check out other brunch places in Cole Valley.
author: Brian O.

description:
BREAKFAST: So lovely. So delicious. I try to eat healthy breakfasts and luckily rarely crave the sweet stuff in the morning and they had plenty of options for me. I love their steel cut oatmeal! And I love this place even more for the atmosphere. Granted without the yummies, the coziness would be lost on me, but both inside and outside (garden-like back patio) are wonderful places to be. Want to go to breakfast with me tomorrow?

LUNCH: Significantly less-wonderful experience. I don't eat much, (smaller than the average bear), so when a $10 lunch salad isn't enough food for me, I know it's not a generous amount. And since when does 'seared tuna' mean 'slab-resembling-overcooked-pork-chop?' Not a hint of pink. The lettuce was unforgivably slimy... and it wasn't the dressing... I had that on the side. I can't handle lettuce slime. 

Lunch companion had a perfectly wonderful brie and wild mushroom omelet. They serve breakfast until 2:30 pm. STICK TO BREAKFAST.
author: Ania W.

description:
My previous review for Zazie was pretty luke warm because of the service. Since my review the owner contacted me and asked me to come back, as they were experiencing turnover (yay! I love it when owners read yelp to see how everything is going- major points)

This spot has a great brunch menu- several different egg Benedict's (9 I believe) Very inventive, and tons of different tastes for every mood.

The ambiance has a french twist to it that makes you feel cozy. The staff if friendly, but can be a little sparse when it's crazy busy (to be expected) They also offer a full brunch menu on weekdays for people who want a killer breakfast without the crowd. 

Try the lemon ricotta pancakes with raspberry topping and an americano...yum
author: Beth M.

description:
One of the great brunch places for any day of the week.  Parisian decor inside and a great courtyard terrace for sunny days.

Egg dishes feature home fries with roasted garlic.

Gingerbread pancakes are the signature dish but all of their pancakes and french toast are excellent.

Wait staff is very courteous even when they are busy.
author: Narendra R.

description:
This is a great neighborhood restaurant. On a Thursday night around 7:30, it was packed, save the one table immediately available without a reservation - score!

There's nothing pretentious about this French restaurant, which is a charming little gem whose menu packs a delightful punch. Rarely do I order chicken at restaurants (it's just so boring), but I was thrilled with the mushroom-stuffed variety I ordered, over a bed of spinach and mashed potatoes. 

Skipping the Chocolat Chaud dessert would have just been a shame...so we indulged in this pot of gooey brownie-ness topped with toasted marshmallows. This tasted like a 6-year-old's concoction - in a very good way. Adults just don't know how to have fun with dessert like this.

Zazie really gets it right.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
I was in the neighborhood w/my gf and after perusing several other eateries in the area we decided to come here.

I was skeptical at first b/c the crowd outside was so big. In my book it either means it's way overhyped (Burma Star), or really good and worth the wait. I'm glad it was the latter! The space is kinda small and tight, so expect to be close to your neighbor.

I ordered the French Toast Tahiti and my gf got the Eggs Albert. The presentation was simple and pretty much straightforwards. My french toast was absolutely incredible! The sweetness of the banana combined w/the walnut texture was perfect. My gf's poached eggs looked like two giant eyeballs begging to be popped w/a sharp instrument and have their inside yumminess sucked out. 

In all, a perfect meal w/the right portions and balance of flavor. I'll be back again.
author: Gary T.

description: Mediocre at best, considering the high reviews aka hype. They don't serve anything any better than what I can produce in my own kitchen. The food is all kinds of bad texture: sticky, bland, burnt... and to my despair, the banana french toast was the driest breakfast confection I have ever eaten.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Zazie has been in my bookmarks forever, but Cole Valley isn't really a place I just happened to find myself in on a regular basis... or ever. Plus, I was a bit scared off after reading all the comments about how long the wait is. When I wake up on a Saturday or Sunday morning in the mood for a good breakfast, I usually don't like to wait. 

In any case, we made a special trip over to this part of town to see what all the hype was about. There were tons of people milling around on the sidewalk and after figuring that we had about a 90 minute wait ahead of us, we slipped into the cute little hardware store across the street to poke around and then grabbed some coffee at the Tully's a few doors down. When we went back to check on the list, our name had already been called, but they were nice enough to bump us to the top. All in all the wait was about 35-40 minutes. Not bad at all.

I always seem to have the same dilemma when choosing a breakfast dish - sweet or savory? Savory usually wins out, but this time I just couldn't pass up the gingerbread pancakes with pears and lemon curd, and boy I'm glad I did. They were seriously delicious, although I think next time I would ask for extra pears, since they only came with two measly slices. I also really liked that all of the pancake/waffle dishes allow you to choose how many you want (as do the egg dishes). I got two pancakes, but I think one would have been plenty.

I would have liked to sit outside in the back, because the patio looked really cute, but the inside is really charming, if a bit crowded. All in all it was definitely worth the trip and I'm glad I checked out a new neighborhood. Cole Valley just might be one my new favorite places.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I came here around 7pm on a Sunday night with two other people and we were seated right away. The server gave us our menus and recommended his favorite dishes to us. They gave us a water jug for the table, and anytime we finished it, they'd be quick to give us another. Definitely great service. 

Here's a review of the stuff we ordered
*assiette de charcuterie - this was a plate with pâté, salmon rillettes, and prosciutto served with pieces of brioche. I didn't care much for the prosciutto, but the salmon and pâté were delicious and I highly recommend getting it. The pâté was buttery smooth and the salmon had amazing flavor. The fish wasn't fishy and the pâté had only the slightest taste of liver. 

*pâté de volaille - chicken liver and brandy pâté served on a grilled garlic levaine. this was also very good and highly recommended. Similar to the previous, the pâté was perfectly smooth and not gritty like I've had in some other places

*grilled porkchop -  the porkchop was pretty juicy, but it was nothing memorable. 

*fresh black truffle raviolis - a must must must get! this was the best dish next to pâté. It wasn't overly heavy with cheese but instead cooked perfectly al dente with delicious innards and piping hot on arrival. 

*le canard crispy duck leg - the duck was a little dry and flavorless, but the fingerling potato salad seasoned with pancetta and mustard was delightful. The potatoes were perfectly seasoned and super addicting. The sauce they had for that was so good, I lathered the duck in it.

I'll definitely be coming back here to try out their poulat francais (stuffed chicken) that happened to be all sold out by the time we got there!
author: Gloria C.

description:
Zazie's is amazing. I'm talking food, atomosphere, just so splendid!
What a charming space they have with the spiral staircase, window seats, and beautiful backyard patio area. 
The food definitely did not disappoint either. Any of the benedict variations are delicious, and I had a polenta skillet special that was really wonderful as well. 
On a typical weekday breakfast/lunchtime it was quite busy and people had to sign in and wait, so I recommend coming in early to beat weekday lunch crowds. Weekends I wouldn't even want to try; I can only imagine the insanity. 
Try it, it is worth all the buzz.
author: Jasmine O.

description:
Zazie is a great french brunch place way better than La Note in Berkeley and Baker's Street Bistro. I only went there once for brunch with my girlfriend and we ate everything. We only had to wait 15 minutes for the table so we went next door to the market next door and when we came out we were ready to be seated. 

We ordered:

1) one Gingerbread pancake (I could taste the ginger in the pancake and it is so good unlike La Note's)
2) the special omelette with spicy sausage, mushroom, grilled red onion with provolone cheese (Delicious)
3) Mediterrean Plate (grilled pepper, eggplant, green beans, mushroom, tomatoes, basil and NO feta) is divine

I will definitely come back with more friends so I could sample more of the food here.
author: Allison H.

description: Zazie was ok.  DIdn't do it for me.  Nothing special.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Apparently Zazie gets quite crowded on weekend mornings, when people line up before opening time to get a coveted spot in the little garden in the back. But what those people don't know is that Zazie is equally cool and delicious for dinner as well. 

Aside from being able to actually make a reservation for dinner, they have heat lamps up in the garden area if you still want to sit outside. Sitting inside is no disappointment either. Tastefully decorated with French posters, Zazie has a very authentic feel to it. It's not pretentious, it doesn't try too hard, it just feels very real. 

The food is the same way. Nothing terribly extravagant, but outstanding quality. I especially recommend the pate appetizer, even if you don't like pate - it is otherworldly smooth and creamy. The bread pudding dessert is equally heavenly, beating out even Tartine in this department.
author: Frank B.

description:
Zazie is one of my favorite restaurants to go to in my area for both brunch and dinner. It's small and quiet with a wonderful waitstaff. It's not always perfect but it's pretty darn close. 

Brunch tends to have a bit of a wait time, but it's not too bad considering how good everything is. I usually stick to one of the eggs benedict choices. I've eaten there for brunch a dozen times and was never disappointed. I did have over poached eggs once, but they had no problem redoing the order to fix the mostly hard yolk issue. I am quite egg picky and this is the best place I've found in the city for breakfast foods. 

Dinner is always lovely as well. There menu changes often but I have never been disappointed with any of my dinner choices. I usually bring friends that are visiting here because it's a nice dinner atmosphere and it doesn't break the bank. I always order something different but if they have the hanger steak I highly suggest that, or crispy duck leg. Delicious! 

Great place. Worth a try!
author: D C.

description: What a find!  I happened to be traveling through San Francisco for business and found this quaint restaurant.  Tasty brunch menu available for lunch during the weekdays.  The french toast dish was simply delicious! We sat in the outdoor patio located in the back and we instantly felt transported to a European cafe.  It's not a fancy restaurant, actually quite homey and comfortable.  I was there during the weekday and it was quite popular with the locals, I could only imagine what this gem looks like during the weekend.
author: Ken W.

description:
great food here, and very efficient! 

when you get here, theres generally people waiting outside. theres a list on the window to the left of the entrance. write your name there, then read the formula next to it which explains about how long the wait is. it's surprisingly accurate. 

i sat in the back patio and im glad i did. it seemed a little cramped inside. its nice outside and they have heat lamps. We got the tahitit french toast and the eggs divorcee and they were perfect! i love that they options on the portion sizes. it makes it perfect if you want to share.

the employees are also very nice and attentive. i would definitely come here again.

on a side note, im not sure id bring kids here. last time i was here, the party of 3 to the right of me were having a regular conversation but casually threw curse words in every other sentence. then behind me was a lady in her 40s telling her friend about her arrangement with her ex husband. basically, they live together and please each other sexually...better than when they were married. then they agreed that since both of them still wanted another child, they would do it together but still stay divorced. then suddenly he became a little distant and now she doesnt know if she wants to have a child with her ex husband. the lady with her is clearly not a good friend. because she didnt tell her that having a child with her ex is a terrible idea.

dont judge me. the place is small and you can hear all the convos around you. i could see the other people around me trying to lean back to see who the hell was talking. 

i digress. stop by and enjoy the food!
author: JeF m.

description:
Sometimes finding brunch in the city with a reasonable wait, is like searching for the holy grail. This particular Tuesday morning crusade started at Brendas, then moved to Mamas, and finally out of desperation made it all the way out to Cole Valley. Once entering Zazie we were immediately sat. I must warn that this isnt normally the case. There have been many hour, or so, waits complete with coffee from down the street. 

More about the restaurant. The decor is nice, the food has always been quite good, and the service decent. There eggs beeni has long been one of my brunch staples. Im not going to rant and rave about this place, but I will admit that it is quite tasty.

[to be completed later]
author: Jeshua B.

description:
I came over here with two of my best friends during a pretttyy ass day in SF. The environment is super unique and relaxing, perfect brunch date. We ordered the smoked salmon bagel, pancake and their house special potato fries. They were all well served, we were very satisify. Not to mention their coffee is delicious with no bitterness.

Actually I had better smoked salmon bagel elsewhere, please do try other things on the menu, and don't forget to shop around height street afterward, you'll find amazing things there.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I Just love having lunch at zazie on a sunny day... In the patio!

I usually go for the fish dishes and they never disappoint me!


I gave up brunch there because the line is ridiculous. It s faster to do grocery shopping and cook yourself lol!
author: Anastasia M.

description:
What a little gem of a place. Wandered on over for brunch this weekend and really enjoyed it. 

The place is a pretty popular neighborhood spot so be prepared to wait awhile for a seat. My dining partner and I put our names on their waiting list and waited for about 20-25 but it didn't faze us as it was a beautiful day. There are good stores on the street too so window-shopping, etc is an option.

Once seated in the outdoor back yard, we were warmed by a typical SF accessory, heat lamps! When the direct sunlight goes away in this town, you better be prepared. The crowd was varied and social, the wait staff was welcoming and friendly and the space was large enough to eat comfortably.

The menu had a good selection of brunch food to choose from and our orders came quickly. The food was tasty and the presentation was simple and to the point. Nothing too fancy about the place and that's a good thing when you're ready to have a great meal after a night out on the town. 

Seems like a good reliable place I'll be back to.
author: Gabriel R.

description: Breakfast was incredible! It can be really crowded but if you wait you will not be sorry. I would recommend the french toast but everything looks fantastic that I don't think you could order the wrong thing.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Great place for breakfast / brunch / dinner - All excellent.  Yes the wait is long but go on a nice day and it's fun to people watch.  Cole Valley is awesome .. so many couples strolling the streets with their kids and dogs!!  
SOOO yeah, the food is excellent and the outdoor patio is great.  Good place for no more than 4 people.
author: RC V.

description:
I was a little disappointed in my brunch at Zazie this weekend.  Usually everything is excellent and I walk away saying,  "best brunch in the city," but not so much this Saturday.  The patio was as pleasant as ever, as was the service, but the gingerbread pancakes were burnt and my foutainbleu scramble was a bit runny.  Sad.  Perhaps I am expecting too much of Zazie.  Please tell me this isn't the new you.

----------------
Update: 12/19/07

Jen, the owner of Zazie, messaged me to let me know that the day I visited the restaurant (in my above review) was indeed an off day for them.  Bill, the head chef, was out sick!  No wonder.  Now while Bill seems to be a superman in the kitchen, i have to respect that the man is human and is likely to fall ill once in a while. 

So Zazie, I'm coming back. Thanks Jen for restoring my faith in your lovely little restaurant.
author: Alexis M.

description:
The Food:
Mussels Marinieres
Fresh Lemon Ricotta Ravioli
Grilled Hanger Steak w/ Portobello
1/2 Bottle of Cabernet

The food did not disappoint one bit. I had the steak and ordered it medium rare, (how a steak should be eaten) and it was exactly the definition of medium rare, which pleased me a whole lot. I hate the restaurants that ask you how you want your steak and it is no where near what your odered. Haha, Zazie was perfect. Mussels were really tasty! Dipping the bread in the juice was yummy!!!!! The acidity level of the ravioli was on point. And, who can ever go wrong with some wine.

The Service:
The server had the perfect balance of service. He was very attentive and not annoying. (know what I mean) He let us have our night and conversations without excessive check ups. He had jokes too. Big ups!

The Restaurant:
They have a very romantic patio in the back. It was quite windy that day, however, the heating lamps sufficed by keeping us warm.  Tables are a bit close, but it seems like that's how it is in Cole Valley. (*Ahem* competitor cafe, where I work at) It is actually cozy. 

I almost docked a star because they are a competing restaurant, but I enjoyed my dining experience here way too much to dock a star. ;)
author: John C.

description:
Without a doubt, the absolute best brunch I have ever experienced.

When living in Noe Valley, my then fiance (now hubby) and I visited Zazie on a weekly basis (we work weekends so we would usually go during the week, avoiding the weekend crowd). This was back before Jennifer took the reins (she was working for the previous owner as a server). The atmosphere, the staff and the food.. all incredible!

If you are a fan of Eggs Benedict, try the Eggs Albert, which include an English muffin, perfectly cooked egg, crispy bacon, salsa fresca and a delicious hollandaise sauce. In the mood for sweet and savory? Add a side of THE BEST buttermilk pancake you will ever have the luxury of putting in your mouth. Not in the mood for savory? Want to go full force sweet? The French Toast Tahiti is perfect!

Moving out of the city and more importantly, away from Zazie was one of the hardest things we've had to do. Now every time I go to brunch the poor restaurant doesn't stand a chance because, inevitably, it is compared to Zazie.

We still make a special trip back to Zazie for special occasions, and always know that we will be greeted with Mario's smiling face (server now manager), great food, great atmosphere and great conversation!
author: Caroline Q.

description:
I've been to Zazie thrice and all three times was not that impressed with the food or service. It's the long line that I kept seeing that made me curious to try them out.

I ordered an omelette and the insides were a bit underdone and runny and the coffee I ordered was lukewarm. The wait staff were friendly but had to be called on constantly to get refills on coffee and water. 

And yes, it is a wait almost every you go there on weekends, but I don't mind the wait... unless its pouring outside. The noise level can get above high sometimes and the tables tend to be cramped against each other.

Would I go there again - no. Just not my cup of tea. But it attracts a big crowd so give it a shot.
author: Amit S.

description:
This is my favorite breakfast place in the city!!  The weekend wait for brunch is well worth it.  

I have tried various things here, but I really like the gingerbread pancakes for actual breakfast.  If you are looking for more of a lunch item, I suggest the BLT add chicken.  Everything about this sandwich is great; I especially like the goat cheese.  The gigantic mocha's are exceptional too!
author: Jaclyn B.

description:
Zazie is one of my favorite brunch places in the city.  I even had a minor celebrity sighting here last weekend (Jon Ives of Apple fame).  The wait sucks but everything about this place rocks.
The food, service and ambiance are all excellent (love the bistro type feel) and the back patio is a great place to chill on a nice sunny day.

What's yum:
- St Trop - poached eggs with Salmon and their amazing lemon hollandaise sauce.
- Pinkie's Challah French Toast
- Chicken apple sausage
author: Joy G.

description: Brunch was the bomb! Showed up at 9:30 since Zazie has the reputation of having a line and it was a 45 minute wait for the patio, so we at inside. Coffee and coffee cake (with cream cheese filling) was scrumptious. I had the french toast, the two pieces was a large serving, totally delicious. I can't wait to try the eggs next time.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Hooray for review number 941! Woot! Bar Tartine has been my go-to brunch spot, and I'm stoked to have finally found another great place to add to the mix for my favorite weekend pastime.

I admittedly was a bit nervous about the wait considering that we arrived at PBH (prime brunch hour...with how I roll, that's 11ish), but we only had to wait about 25 minutes, which seemed to go by in a snap. My friend and I were lucky enough to snag a spot on the very pleasant back patio. It felt like you were dining in some quaint little cafe in France. I emphasize the "little" because they kind of cram you in like sardines on the patio...my friend and I got stuck in this weird little corner table that had another table right in front of it and on the side of it so the only way you can get out is by asking one of the other tables to move to let you out. That aside, I loved the atmosphere!

The food was terrific - my friend and I each tried different scrambles that were very flavorful. We also split a small order of the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and poached pear that were amazing! The other aspect of the menu that I loved was the variety of champagne-based breakfast cocktails to choose from. They certainly have branched out from the standard mimosa, offering a variety of other juice pairings like black currant, which I ordered and really enjoyed.

Zazie was definitely a treat and for those rare warm, sunny days like yesterday, I'm making a beeline to it for brunch on the patio.
author: Rachel G.

description: Was my absolute favorite brunch spot when i lived in SF. You must have the gingerbread pancakes. I still dream about those, and everyone I took there to try them  loved them. The back patio is the place to sit if the weather's nice. And Mario knows how to look out for regulars.
author: Todd M.

description:
Yay, zazie! Always a good time and good food.
I recommend the french toast tahiti. It has bananas and walnuts in it and is just divine.
Also, their jam is really good! and the chai tea.

The water comes in cute little carafes but I have to say it tastes sort of weird. Not the same water from my tap.

My boyfriend lovvvvvves their pancakes, perhaps more than he loves me! I occasionally treat him with a bag of their pancake mix to go.

Their back patio is super cute. I would love to have a little party here but they don't take brunch reservations.

I wish they would have seasonal items or change up their menu. Good as it is, I need some variety.
author: C. T.

description: The GInger Pancakes are a 5, the Crab Benedict is like a 3. Do yourself a favor and order the Ginger Pancakes. Need something more hearty? Order the 1,2,3 and replace the regular pancake for the ginger.
author: Ashlee M.

description:
Zazie is a warm, cozy french-like bistro. Yes my gang and I had to wait about 30 minutes for a table to open up. But it was so worth it because we got one of the corner booths. Everything else was flawless. The price of the breakfast was really affordable, considering it is in SF and where else can you enjoy breakfast at 1pm? That is the genius of Zazie. The gingerbread pancakes were perfection. Such a great experience.

I will be back for more, much more.
author: Matthew R.

description: This is my favorite go-to spot for Sunday brunch! the coffee cake is to die for, you absolutely must try the cinnamon and apple filled French toast, they are amazing! Basically anything you order off the menu is going to be great. It's a must visit location when friends and family come to town.
author: Selma R.

description:
I live in Montreal now, but every time I get a chance to go back to the Bay, I make sure that a visit to Zazie is on the agenda.

My family has been going to Zazie for years, now, and have yet to have a less-than-stellar meal.  The gingerbread pancakes, french toast, and (seasonal) pumpkin pancakes are delicious, as are their omelets and scrambles.  This last visit, I had a breakfast sandwich that had grilled levain bread, prosciutto, tomatoes and eggs over easy, which came with a side salad.   The wait staff always manages to make you feel like they're personally glad you came, and Mario (the host/manager) is wonderful.  I can't recommend this place highly enough!
author: Californian I.

description:
This place is snobby but tasty and I like it.

Came on a weekday because I was waiting for my prescription to be filled over at pharmaca. 

Was fairly populated but the service was very attentive. 

For $9 I got the poached eggs Benedict with mushrooms and spinach and a side of deliciously gorgeous potatoes with tons of roasted garlic - which is one of my most favorite things. 

Chai was delish too.

I wish I could try their pancakes, they had one pass by that was full of fruit!
author: Sari G.

description:
So Tuesday was a work holiday with my kids + 1 friend in tow.  Too lazy to make breakfast after being on the phone all night, I searched Yelp for a place that was in reasonable distance from the house.  It was between Zazie and Park Chow, places we've never been before.

The older kids were happy with their order of pancakes and fresh fruit.  My youngest was much pickier with her french toast and fruit.  I wasn't sure what she didn't like or if she had her heart set on waffles which they don't carry.  As for me, I got the 3 item selection on the menu, 1 pancake, 2 eggs, and 3 strips of bacon.  The pancakes are amazing, light and fluffy.  The bacon was only partially crispy on one end and limp on the other.  I've never had bacon that way and it wasn't how I like it prepared.

The waiter offered suggestions for drink, for me it's always coffee.  The kids got 1 make it yourself lemon aid (complete hit) and 2 spritzer which is a mix of juices I assume.  The sip I had was good and not overly sweet.

This place was crowded on a Tuesday morning and a waiting list was started on a clip board.  If you've never been here, you add your name to the list.  

Best part of the menu is that you have the ability to control the portions.  For example you can order 1, 2, or 3 pancakes, same with slices of french toast, eggs, etc.  

I would love to go back for more try more items on the menu.  It's cozy place to grab a bite with friends.
author: Twist' D.

description:
A warm, homey, French-infused atmosphere. Great food (more on that later), *wonderful* staff. It's obvious a lot of love & care goes into the place. 

Whay have I not been here before? One of my new favorites.

Oh, and if you're concerned about cleanliness, they scored a 98. http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=1595
author: N B.

description:
I'm giving this spot an extra star for stellar service.  The food was a solid three - I had the most delish caramelized banana and pecan stuffed french toast, and my girldate had a poached egg dish with bacon and tomato.  The potatoes on her plate came with whole cloves of roasted garlic!  Yowza!  Great selection of mimosas, even an option to "make your own" if you think you do it best.
As for the service, any place that sends someone over (manager?  owner?) to get me while I'm next door having a bloody mary, then comes back because my bloody mary is taking me ages to finish because I drink slow when hungover, and then STILL seats us right away and stops by to check in while we're eating. . .well, I call that excellent customer service!  There were also tons of regulars in there, which is always a good sign.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
D'oh, I should have trusted Yelp first but instead I went with the boyfriend's gut.  I should have consulted the Yelp legends Miriam W and Kristina R and now, now I'll remember why.

Ok, with that kind of lead in, let me say it was not that bad but I found the portion to be a bit on the small side and not much of a step up from Crepes on Cole down the street which has a more relaxed vibe to it.

If you can sit outside on a warm, sunny day, all the better.  And the front tables, you don't have to sign up for them, if it's free, it's yours. 
This allowed us to jump the 30 minute wait to the gasps of all waiting before us.  First come, First serve baby!
author: Sean S.

description:
Man, I hate to be a hater, but I didn't have a very good experience at Zazie.

Firstly, there was never any water brought out to us by the server. It seemed like she'd had a long day, so I wasn't going to hold that against her. 

Secondly, when my gingerbread pancakes arrived, there was a fairly large dead mosquito perched atop one of the pears. Yeah, I guess it might've been a good source of protein, technically, but that's a very bad first impression. They didn't treat it like any kind of deal -- I didn't really expect shock & horror, but they asked me if I wanted a new pear or something. YES, thanks for the offer. Shouldn't that go without saying? I hardly threw a fit over it. Sometimes I'm a ridiculously good patron in the face of small disasters, like the time I got full glasses of water spilled on me TWICE by the same waiter during the same meal. I even gave that dude a good tip because he felt so terrible & it was clear he was having a shitty day (I won't mention what place because I actually really do like that place & have been back since to stellar service).

Thirdly, when the bill came, there was some sort of $2 health care initiative fee. What's THAT all about? Not only that, but my girlfriend ordered the complete opposite of what she'd wanted to order because there were seperate $2 charges for eggwhites only, for soy milk instead of regular milk, & for fruit instead of home fries. I can see for the fruit, & maybe a lesser charge for eggwhites, but isn't soy milk cheaper than regular milk? Wouldn't they charge LESS? And why am I paying for an undisclosed health care initiative that doesn't seem to have any bearing on my dining experience?

Anyway, for having heard such impeccable things about Zazie, I've gotta say I was pretty disappointed on the whole. I'm not a very good Yelp Hater, & more often than not I bite my tongue or look on the bright side of the experience, but my experience at Zazie was pretty overwhelmingly negative.

**UPDATE on the situation with the health care ordinance. I've been told that costs for restaurants in the city have been skyrocketing of late due to (among other things) Paid Sick Leave, increased minimum wage, high gas prices causing new delivery charges, and a 400% rise in the cost of flour. Most of these factors come from measures passed by SF residents in elections. I can understand wanting to be a progressive city & set a high standard of living, but sometimes it seems a bit ridiculous that we're voting to raise our own taxes every single election period. C'mon people, a little restraint from time to time!

Anyway, I guess this is Zazie's way of getting political. Rather than incorporate price changes into the items on the menu, they're showing you that your vote matters, & will directly translate to higher bills when you eat out.
author: Pete J.

description:
I was there on Thursday for the Beaujolais Nouveau wine harvest celebration. The prix fixe menu was great!! I was there with a group of 8 so we all had a chance to sample everything on the menu and oh la la, superbe!!

The wine sucked, I mean it's Beaujolais Nouveau, so you can't be too serious about it but everything else was great, company, food, service. 

I heard their brunch is fantastic so I'll update this review when I get a chance to go there. 

Bon appetit!
author: Nez B.

description: If Anthropologie ever decided to franchise out a San Francisco restaurant, it would be breakfast/lunch bistro, Zazie's. The menu is french provincial, but fortunately, Zazie's doesn't have Anthropologie  prices. Breakfast won't break the bank, but it will leave you cloying at that last bit of hollandaise on your plate or sopping up the last of the syrup with the sumptious banana pecan french toast. I personally love the Benedict Pierre Noir with bacon and tomatoes provencale.
author: Netty L.

description:
The world of relationships is very strange place. I think I just had my first ever break up breakfast.  I'm not sure if it was a break up or just hey look at my neck I got a little thang thang on the side what are you going to about it? 

I stood in a long line talked to all the people around me said hello to a few club one heads I didn't expect to see.  It was actually shaping up to be a great morning. 

Breakfast turned out to be even better as I avoided asking about the little bite of exstacy on her neck that she's trying to hide. 

I turn from the blue and purple mark to order some hot chocolate that came in a small bowl that was very tasty and different.  I was more surpised to see a bowl than a cup. 

So we continued to talk and I started to give the business about the kind of guys to watch out for while she is on her travels. I think she's flashing her hickey at me! I should be upset but I'm just a little turned on by her boldness but the Gingerbread Pancakes that came out tuned mytaste buds up to 10 with out the syrup.  I love Dottie's pancakes but these were just better. Nice a fluffy with that great ginger taste sweeten by the maple syrup. 

If it wasn't for the almost deadly effects of her curves I mean almost deadly effects of the walnuts in the the French Toast she had I would have surely had a bite or two because they both looked and smell great. 

The last item to come to our table was eggs with tomatoes and cream cheese. I'm normally a confident guy but I had my doubts about these eggs and cream cheese like I did for our plans for that evening  but it turn out to be some good eats!  The textures and tastes were great with a dash of pepper for spice it was heavenly.
