Zazie is a great start to any morning even when it appears that things may be all bad that at the start of the day. 

To be continued...
author: Karim R.

description:
My roommate took  me here this past Sunday because it's her favorite brunch spot in the city. It's a cute little joint. Sitting outside on the deck, I didn't feel like I was at a restaurant. I felt like I was having brunch in someone's back yard. The quarters are pretty small, so be prepared to be close to parties separate from yours.

My poached egg dish was really good. I ordered the flavorfull "Albert." Didn't even finish it all and it filled me. I had some of my roomie's pancake too- mmmm. Soo soo good. How do they get them so fluffy?

SF is pretty notorious for good brunch spots and after only being there once, I wouldn't hesitate to say that Zazie would top my recommendations.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Hmmm...not sure what the big fuss is about this place. Maybe I had my hopes up too much  - as a lover of the pancake-waffle-french toast food group, all the reviews seemed to promise something pretty special - but I found my french toast to be rather unremarkable - even a little dry at times. All in all decent, but nothing that'll leave me yearning for more.

I found the best thing about Zazie to be its cool ambiance - it was surprisingly relaxing & cozy, French but unpretentious (yes, it's possible), an especially pleasant surprise after dealing with the mob scene outside.

I'm glad I tried it, but regulars can rest assured I won't be contributing to the already lengthy wait list again anytime soon.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
While the restaurant went through some rough patches last year, I would venture to say it's recovered well and refined its issues.

From the appetizer sampler (that included figs and goat cheese, chicken liver pate and salad) to the soup de poisson and corn cakes, my wife and I left very satisfied.

The waitress was charming and the heated back patio was pleasant even through the evening mist. The tab including tax and tip was $60 (excluding the wine on the house).

Happy to see a neighborhood jewel regain some sparkle.
author: christopher r.

description:
I love brunch. Love love love love love it. And it doesn't get any better than brunch at Zazie.

The wait on a weekend morning is LONG. Why? Because it is so freaking delicious. You just have to learn to sneak in at the right times...like during the week before work :).

The poached egg dishes make me swoon. Tomatoes provencales? Hollandaise? Be still my fluttering heart! And did you say home fries with roasted garlic? *faints*

Yes, Zazie can be a little pricey -- but it doesn't have to be. You can get one of their giant pancakes (gingerbread with lemon curd, buttermilk, sour cream + poppyseed, etc) and a beverage of choice for about $10. Now, that's not so bad for a sit-down meal in this town! (And given that I had that for breakfast this morning, I can also attest to the fact that it can fill you up just fine!)

If brunch isn't your thing, go for a late dessert! We waltzed in for a baked hot chocolate one night a few months ago and I'm still telling people about it. Mmmm....
author: Liz E.

description:
Went on a Saturday around 1pm.  Absolutely gorgeous day in the city... no clouds, mid-60s... just beautiful.  30 minute wait, and we were seated in a corner of the patio. 

The restaurant itself is really just 4 stars.  Don't get me wrong, the food is great, the service prompt, etc.  But it's the patio that makes this place worth the trek and worth the wait.
author: Maneesh B.

description:
Technically, 3.5 stars.

Cute ambience. Except much like many other small restaurants in SF, the tables are so close together, it's like you're dining with your neighbor (which is sometimes fun if the neighbors have good stories - no such luck this time).  

Staff was friendly and attentive but not overbearing.

Food was... meh. I was pretty under-whelmed.  We did the prix-fixe option:

Starters: Mussels and pate. Both were good but nothing to rave about. (Mussels at Lulu were much better.)
    
Entrees: Soup and salmon. Same assessment as the starters. Both needed salt. The salmon was served in what initially looked like a pastry-puff "nest" but turned out to be parchment paper - which just made the dish look cheap.  I was disappointed. 

Dessert: Finally! Something that made my taste-buds dance! Bread pudding was DELISH. It really saved the meal. 

So Zazie, you didn't impress me for dinner but looks like Yelpers love coming to you for brunch, so I'll give you another shot...
author: Felicia H.

description:
I wrote a review for this place a while ago, just went back for dinner and had to write another.  I'm never disappointed when I come here - the food is consistently great and reasonably priced, the staff super friendly and accommodating, and the atmosphere so cozy and nice.  
The roasted mediterranean plate (appetizer) is AMAZING, so are the mussels.  The wine is delicious and not super expensive.  I will be coming back lots!
author: Allison C.

description: DELICIOUS! Everything tastes fresh. It was worth taking a taxi all the way from the Wharf & back. Really busy on the weekend. Nice outdoor seating also.
author: H N.

description: Hands down man down, one of the best place for breakfast or brunch. Go earlier or there will be a wait, which can be a pain if you aren't from the area and had to drive. Great mimosas and if you can get a table in their backyard area, do it. Pancakes are all great, all their egg dishes are fantastic and their veggies and seafood all taste fresh.
author: Nate B.

description:
I really loved the outdoor area out back, so relaxing and peaceful.  Unfortunately my eggs benedict, the breakfast dish that forever has my heart, was not very good.*  One egg was cooked too long, so the yolk was solid, not runny.  The other was better poached, but I thought the  hollandaise sauce could have been more rich, and defiinitely more lemony.  

While I typically am not into sweet treats for breakfast, the challah french toast was the bomb.  Really, so delicious.  So it's a mixed bag for me, but I would definitely return.

*One of the owners contacted me with a very nice email and asked when I visited, and confirmed that a new cook was working the day I was there.  She was going to test his hollondaise skills, and make sure he is more consistent in the future.  Bumping them up one star for the awesome customer service, and implore you not to avoid the benedict due to my review).
author: Kara S.

description:
A great place to have brunch in the city!  Poached eggs anyone?!  I don't think I ever like poached eggs until I tried their "Egg Florentine", perfectly poached eggs with sauce on top, with spinach and grilled portobello mushroom on top of the toasted egg muffins.  It also comes with a side of grilled blocky potato (blah... what do you call those?)  

Small and cozy interior (PS.  They have a really cute garden patio in the back), average service.  I drive about 25 miles to the city to try out this place, and didn't regret it yet.  One thing that sucks is that parking is a real pain in the Cole Valley.
author: Carina N.

description:
I came here with pretty high hopes for brunch places, especially after reading multiple reviews of people praising everything from the food to the efficient service.  I think it might be the set of circumstances for my visit, but when I came to Zazie I thought it was cute, decent, but given the amount of brunch places I've been to in the city it wasn't ... the best.

I ordered the Eggs St. Trop and they were prepared pretty well, and I liked the pairing with the capers.  However, the potatoes were not good.  They weren't crispy and didn't have the right texture, and the skin made the whole thing kind of chewy (eh).  There were roasted garlic cloves with it, which was okay I guess, but still not the best texture.

Their fresh lemonade was cool in theory (they give you a class of lemon juice, water, and simple syrup) but I am not a seasoned lemonade maker and it took awhile for me to get the portions just right.  The spritzer was okay.

If you go, I suggest the french toast tahiti and if you get eggs, substitute it for something else.  Also, the day we went was abnormally and slightly abysmally hot, so it made dining a bit more difficult (through NO fault of Zazie, I admit - though it would have been nice if they had more umbrellas).

Now that yelp has an update option, I want to give this place another shot ... but for now, there are so many other brunch places to discover....
author: Shay F.

description: Solid 4 stars even close to 5 (which I don't give). Great food and service.  I had the pork cooked perfectly, my mate had the seafood soup which was surprisingly rich and hearty.  He raved about the Chicken Pate I like the mussles.  Didn't have room for dessert but they looked great .  High value for money, do try this place.  A new reasonably priced favorite.
author: Jas S.

description:
I love Zazie.  The breakfasts/brunch is first rate, and the dinner is great as well.  It is, to me, exactly what a neighborhood place should be.  It's friendly, the food is well prepared and fresh, and the decor is just so comfortable and inviting.  
After 10 am on the weekends, the waits for brunch can be terrible...but they are friendly, will happily bring you a mimosa or coffee--and if you go to Finnegan's Wake next door for a STRONGER drink, you can just let the guy working the list at Zazie know, and they will come get you.  Now that is great.  
If you are in Cole Valley check this place out--it is definitely not a secret, but it is so inviting you won't care--you'll feel like you found a great new spot to add to your list.
author: Blake W.

description: had brunch here with my dad 2 months ago.  Best omlettes ever, beautiful patio, could not top this experience!
author: Alanna F.

description:
The breakfast is great here!  But I suggest coming during the week.  I'm not sure I'd brave the weekend wait again.  With so many places to eat a good breakfast in the city, I don't think its worth waiting for twice.  But the food will not dissapoint.  I had the eggs florentine and my wife had the pancakes.  Both were amazing.

The place is tight so not for large parties. I wouldn't recommend it for very small, fidgety children during busy times.  But it is nice and cozy, and in a great area.  Almost 5 stars.
author: albert g.

description:
Went here for the first time today. The wait was out the door (Saturday morning around 10AM) but we were seated in about 30 min or so. 

We had quite the feast this morning, as everyone was starving. The three of us had 5 plates of food. 

One of the things I like about this place is you can order a smaller or larger portion depending on hungry you are (or think you are, for those like myself who's eyes are bigger than their stomachs). This is great, as I love ordering just one piece of french toast or one poached egg if that is what I'm craving to go along with my main meal. Yes, this is even good if you just want to eat a light snack (although the wait may be ridiculous for someone who isn't really going to chow down). 

Back to the meal. We ordered: 

1) the special banana pudding pancakes (very good, moist and two small slivers of caramelized banana on top with whipped cream). 

2) Three Egg Monaco, which is poached eggs over prosciutto and tomato with holandaise sauce. (Excellent, with home fries that included huge chunks of garlic cloves) 

3) 1 slice of Challah French toast (which was ok, not spectacular because it was not as moist as I prefer, but had a subtle orange cinnamon batter) 

4) Eggs Fontainbleu, which comes with salad and toast (This was good, and had mushrooms spinach and fontina) 

5) Croque Madame. My favorite of the meal, think of a ham sandwich with a huge layer of melted cheese on top, further topped with a sunny side up egg. Heart attack city indeed, but flavors are great!
author: Stephen H.

description:
5 stars for brunch.  The food is great and the ambiance is great too.  Go there on a sunny day and sit in the back garden.

3 stars for dinner.  I'm just not impressed with their dinner entrees.
author: Julia H.

description:
Great food....no wait....actually AWESOME food and excellent service!  

My cute boyfriend and I sat in the patio....on a cold SF night...fog rolling in and everything.   However, the quaint atmosphere and warm heat lamps took us to a different place I'd like to call Zazie town! :)  The fence is lined with flowers and mini lights. 

Their menu is mouth watering and the duck is phenomenal!  We took our waiter's suggestion and our belly's were pleased beyond belief!  I would highly recommend this place for a date or meal with friends.  

I'm dying to try their brunch but from the look of the line on the weekends, I may have a better chance at winning the Brazilian lottery!  :) 

Happy eats!
author: Danielle V.

description:
So, since I used this place  as a counterpoint to a review for a nearby breakfast place, I thought I should give it its due and pay a call.

It was a weekday for a late 'brunch'. So, no line and no waiting for table service. 

Instant snapshots~
- very expensive, they charged us for a side of mustard, and instead of a substitution, they charged for a full side without letting us know in advance (salad instead of toast and potatoes).
- pretentious crowd, except for the guy there with his aging dad, let's be frank, they were both aging, anyway, it was sweet
- bathroom is so small that anyone with a double wide behind will have to save it for later

I won't be going back. The food was savory so that won't disappoint if you have to go with friends. But, bring a big wallet and your thinnest self (as the space btwn tables in nominal too) and certainly not any alter abled accessories.

French seems to imply a particular THANG in the SF, lotsah dollars, lotsah meat and lotsah fat. By now you are shaking your head and saying, hey it was like that the last time I was  in Paris. Exactly. Ask any French person, Paris is not France. It is like saying Disney is the US of A, yes yes, true in many respects, but not to the depths of our culinary experiences. 

So don't mickey around with this place, find another place to blow out your credit card.
author: Miel H.

description:
Zazie is great, in large part because they pay such attention to the details. Indeed, Zazie is basically one big detail. One big... delicious... detail.

Two specific recommendations:

1. Un Deux Trois. Three strips of bacon (or other meaty product), two eggs  (I like 'em scrambled -- I know, I'm twelve), and one perfect, perfect pancake. This used to seem stingy until I finally accepted the fact that perfect pancakes can only be served solo. They're like unicorn steaks that way.

2. The creme-brulee-ish oatmeal. I'm sure there a more correct term for this. All I know is they harden the top of the oatmeal with a blowtorch, just like creme brulee, and just like creme brulee, it's delicious. Not on the menu, so if you order it you'll seem super-cool and insider-y and possibly even French.

UPDATE: Had brunch again at Zazie's. Un Deuz Trois was PERFECT. And the service is always so great. Five stars. Rock on.
author: robin s.

description:
Zazie is one of the best things about living in Cole Valley.  That means I can roll out of bed and grab Saturday breakfast before the masses arrive.  The garden patio is, well, like everyone says... it's great.  I know the wait can get long on the weekends, but the staff does a great job of moving people through without feeling like you're being moved through.  Plus the host has a pretty amazing ability to gauge your wait.

I usually get the Eggs Fountainbleu, which is really great.  I would get the French Toast every time, if only they came with a side of potatoes.  Alas, they don't.  I will say, it's one of the few restaurants that has good food AND good coffee.  I usually settle for one or the other.  Oh, and it's the type of place where your cafe au lait comes in a bowl.  Be prepared.

Please, one request from a local... when you're waiting for your table, please don't clog up the sidewalk.  The host is great and will find you if you spread out down the street.  It's really no fun having to walk in the street to avoid the mob.
author: Kat W.

description:
Zazie is the best bang for you buck in the city... 

Traditional french cooking at a reasonable price, friendly staff, quaint/romantic atmosphere with a wonderful courtyard in the back... What more could you ask for?

Try the FRENCH ONION SOUP!
author: Alexander T.

description:
I wanted to LOVE this place. Really, I did. But, in the words of Randy Jackson, it was just OK for me, Dog. 

the BF and I made this our 3 year anniversary celebration dinner spot this year because our day fell on a Tuesday and they have no corkage fee on Tuesdays! Being the cheap ass bargain maximizer that I am, I thought this sounded like the perfect combination of creative fare at reasonable prices.  So, off we went.

Everything started out really well... rockstar parking after only 1 trip around the block (Impossible!), adorable tables outside with twinkling candles, cozy/mildly romantic interior and a $5 (yes $5!) gold star bottle of petite syrah.  I saw more twinkling lights out back, so I hurried out to scope the patio... ADORABLE!  My expectations were mounting by the minute (note to self... expectations only get you into trouble).

I returned back to my table after an arduous journey  (caught behind an elderly woman that took about 30 minutes to cross the restaurant from the patio... this was no one's fault but my own curiosity). I sat and gazed into bf's bearded face when out of the corner of my eye I couldn't help but notice... the dated, faded foam core backed French posters about the walls all crumpled and crinkled on the edges.  Come on guys... it's time to up date.  ok no big deal... a couple of ratty posters isn't a make or break issue at a charming restaurant. I just thought it worth mentioning.

The bread arrived.  Its was warm and tasty with melting butter; another plus for Zazie.  We made our selections: He the fixed price menu of Salmon with soup starter (a bargain at $23 inc. dessert) and I the trout with spinach salad. 

The salmon was perfect. Delicious! BF couldn't have been more excited when he tasted the "mashed potatoes" under the salmon because he didn't remember it coming with potatoes (his favorite)!  It didn't... it was pureed celery root or cauliflower or something and it was tasters!!  I love trick food that gets the BF to eat healthier. It also came with the most delectable brussel sprouts with pecans.  HEAVENLY!  I think I ate as much of his entree as he did.  

Unfortunately, my trout missed the mark entirely.  The trout itself was decent, but the accompaniments were way off.  Everything tasted OK, but it wasn't a good combo and didn't look very appetizing either. The trout came with "sweet pie pumpkin," chevre, and leeks (or fennel, I dont remember).  Sounds delish doesn't it? It wasn't.  The pumpkin was flavorless and kind of underdone... when it mixed on the fish with the chevre and leek/fennel it all took on a goopy tan/beigey/gray tinge that looked more like something you'd scrape off your plate into the compost than something to scoop with a fork into your mouth.

In the end we had a very nice night and it was a pleasant experience overall.  this is a place I will visit again.  The service was warm, friendly, helpful and mostly attentive.  I liked the neighborhood vibe and simple charm of the over all experience.  The prices are exceptionally reasonable and I think an even "Just ok for me, Dog" experience is acceptable at $15 a plate.  One can't always expect perfection.  They get 4 stars for value and ambiance and the salmon!

Sounds like brunch is the bomb here, so I will have to come back for that sometime.
author: shannon m.

description:
This place rocks! It's cute and has a back outdoor patio, and the staff is great. I can only speak to their brunch and desserts. If you're looking for a brunch that takes the ordinary, like waffles and pancakes, and gives it a unique french twist, this place will make you smile. Also the deserts are simple and elegent and utterly delicious! Try their creme pots and brulee...yum!  Next visit, a full on dinner!

PS: I would totally bring a date here...
author: Venatius P.

description: A foodie's dream. The French toast, the pancakes, the Benedict's, the coffee cake!!! Amazing!!!!! Bloody Mary's are super delicious as well. You can't got wrong eating here!
author: Amy O.

description:
Zazie is just lovely and ther service is fantastic!

I've been a regular here for years, and had dinner there last week and was so excited by the yummy and oh-so-affordale prix fixe menu. The salmon was simply delicious! Go for the prix fixe and you simply cannot be disappointed! :)

Thank you for such a lovely spot to share dinner with friends!
author: Sallyanne E.

description:
I had poached salmon on a bed of spinach.  I don't think I'd ever had poached salmon before this-- it was delicious.  All my friends prefer this place to the closeby Crepes on Cole, but I'd still rather hit up the crepe joint.

They have a special dinner on Mondays where you can sit on the patio & bring your dog... we're gonna check that out...
author: Megan G.

description:
Where have you been my whole life?!
When I was starting to get tired of spending a lot of $$$$ on places where the food was just ok, you came into my life!
After some of my coworkers told me that Zazie were one of their favorite places I had to check it out last Friday night!
We had two appetizers that were just delicious with wine: Cheese Plate and Pate/Smoked Salmon Plate! For my entree I had the Duck with lentils and hubby had the Dungeness Crab Ravioli with a lick-the-plate-worth lemony sauce...
Dlicieux!!!
Could not resist but order dessert, some fruit cobbler, Peach and blackberries.mmmmm
I cannot wait to go back! Nice ambiance, great food and service!
I am definitely going back!
Je t'aime Zazie!!!
author: B. W.

description:
what canz I zay about zazie?

Bravo, bravo bravo...  mucho bella, yummy fooda, cutie back yarda.
author: Dee Dee C.

description:
YUMM this place is so goood!

1. Please, please, please try the gingerbread pancakes like everyone else says. You may not think you like gingerbread, but they are so delicioussss.

2. Ummmm the atmosphere is just so adorable, such a cute place and the staff is super friendly as well. Just some little touches made me happy, like how they leave a large bottle of water at the table to serve yourself.

3. All the food that my friends and I got was delicious! YUMMM.
author: Michelle H.

description:
A charming little place in a tiny neighborhood. Despite the early hour on a Friday, the place was busy. I had a mocha, one gingerbread pancake (came with lemon curd and a bit of Bosc pear) and a side of chicken apple sausage. The mocha was good but not sweet enough (not surprisingly, self professed picky-mocha-person). The gingerbread pancake was awesome. Not too sweet or too ginger-y, just right. And the lemon curd was really a tasty alternative to maple syrup which is what I did, skipping the maple syrup entirely. 

Service was friendly and quick.

They even have the gingerbread pancake mix to sell. I'm tempted.
author: cyndi L.

description:
Great food, atmosphere, service and prices (for what you get). Comfortable and delicious. Been going there for more than 15 years.

I don't know if it's worth the line and chaos for weekend brunch, but I'd say that about any place these days. Go for breakfast, lunch or dinner on a weeknight and it'll be just right. Reserving a table for dinner might be a good idea, but it's so easy to do.

Enjoy!
author: Frank B.

description:
We have been here twice now and have had impeccably good meals both times. It is a very friendly environment. This last time we went there was what seemed to be a dog event in the back patio area neighborhood dog owners filed their pooches through the restaurant for dinner out back. We had a seat inside and although it is small we have never been cramped for space at all there. On both occasions I noticed what honestly nice staff they have. 

I have thoroughly enjoyed their Zazie Burger and the Hanger Steak dinner. Everything done to perfection to me. I have enjoyed quite a few steaks in my time but the one I had on this last occasion will stick out as one of the best restaurant steaks I have had. Ingredients seem extremely fresh. T got the salmon on this last trip and it was tasty too. The dinner rolls are delicious as well. 

Ok so the bathroom is smaller than most airplane bathrooms I have been in, I still have no complaints.
author: Johnny J.

description:
Delicious food, cute boys working there that were extra nice to our golden-doodle, dining outside in cute Cole Valley, replete with various types of mimosas... There is a technical term, we gastronomes use...
"nummy"
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I went to Zazie with some coworkers on a late lunch ~2PM and boy was I superduper hungry. Zazie came so highly recommended that I was really looking forward to it.

I'm not going to lie, but I left hungry. A half sandwich and cup of soup was not going to do it for me, but I definitely left with a good vibe that the food is good, and dammit I wish I had more cash on me to get more of it.

BLT is GREAT, a good mix of veggies and bacon (and I NEVER eat bacon) and the moroccan lentil soup was tasty, but the lentils felt a little underdone.

I'll go back, but the crowds this place must get intimidate me a bit. But when we were there...open seating everywhere. Just remember a seriously limited mid-day menu. Only salads, soups and a few sandwiches. I'll have to check out the other menus in question.
author: Charlene L.

description:
came here with 8 of my co-rezzies on at 10am on an overcast Friday morning...which could be the reason we waited an hour to be seated in the backyard outdoor seating area.  not quite sure on the reason as the backyard outdoor seating area was empty.  the indoor area was full so maybe the kitchen couldn't handle the additional load?  whatever the reason, it didn't matter, good company made the time pass quickly.

our waitress was quite friendly and table service was prompt.

we ordered shared pancake flights and french toast for the whole table to share and therefore everyone had the opportunity to try both the buttermilk and gingerbread pancakes as well as the stuffed french toast (ran out of cornmeal pancakes).  pancakes and french toast are huge.  the pancakes are the size of a plate and the french toast appears to be made from texas toast.  buttermilk pancakes were nothing special.  gingerbread pancakes had a good flavor, but in my opinion, taste like they are are made "healthier" and therefore taste more like gingerbread bread, not a pancake.  i like my pancakes full of buttery goodness. i would order the gingerbread pancakes again only for the lemon cream sauce and pears on top.  apple stuffed pancakes were nothing to write home about, i've had better in many other locations around the usa.

we each ordered our own egg dish, i had the eggs divorcee, which was small but delicious with fresh ingredients which compensated for the price.

would come here again for the atmosphere and service.  food is decent but i'm not raving about it and wouldn't take someone here for the food unless they really just wanted a breakfast place.

lastly, as a plus, also appreciated the honesty of our waitress to let us know that an 18% tip was already included in our bill.  i've been at restaurants where the waiter doesn't say anything in the hopes that you won't notice.  

5 stars for the service (completely negated the wait time and more)
5 stars for the backyard patio ambiance --- lights, soft music, heat lamps on a foggy morning -- perfect.
3 stars for the pancakes and waffles
4 stars for the poached eggs

on an additional note, they do not split checks but will run multiple credit cards.
author: Catherine A.

description:
You know how people say Led Zeppelin sold their souls to the devil to be the best rock band ever? I think there is some sou chef at Zazie's who sold his soul to be the best hashbrown/home fries maker ever. 

I honestly don't understand how they were so delicious. There is only like 3 steps in making hash browns. Cut potato. Boil potato in water. Fry potato. Right? Yea. At some point, however, Zazie's has added a unique step called 'Making the Potato Scrumtru-lescent Step.' The particulars of this step are known only to the Zazie's sou chef and the devil.  

In addition to satanic hashbrowns, everything was delicious. I had a Croque Madame. It was awesome. Everyone's food was awesome. Although they don't have fresh squeezed orange juice. I think they should. Oh well, it was still awesome.
author: Tom C.

description:
Yummy Yummy Brunch food!

The wait was extremely long but well worth it!  Their poached eggs dishes are delicious. I recommend the Eggs Albert: bacon, white cheddar, & salsa fresca and the Eggs Monaco: proscuitto and tomatoes provencales. Yummy.

The French Toast Tahiti: stuffed with carmelized bananas & walnuts was also delicious!!!
author: Karen K.

description:
Just had dinner here the other night with some friends. 
The staff - amazing. We called a few minutes ahead and the table was ready and waiting when we arrived. They were all very friendly and full of information. We started with piping hot rolls that were DELICIOUS, some of the best bread I have had in a long time and perfect for soaking up the sauce our appetizer muscles came in. I had the salmon while my friends enjoyed the rabbit and the pork chop. Honestly there was not a single thing I didn't love about the parsnip/celery root puree, sauteed fava beans, wilted pea shoots, toybox tomatoes. This is a darling restaurant with great food and a wonderful staff!
author: jees F.

description: I went for breakfast on an amazing Monday morning. The patio is a great place to eat on a nice day. My only complaint is that I had trouble deciding what to order because everything looked so good.
author: Anthony M.

description:
By far my favorite brunch spot in the city.

First off, Cole Valley is such a quaint, brunchy spot. Mere blocks from the far more colorful Haight Ashbury neighborhood, Zazie is surrounded by wholesome little shops and town houses. People actually have babies/young children in this area (gasp). 

The food is phenomenal whether you're an egg or carb-oriented breakfaster. I am equally obsessed with the fontainbleu egg scramble and the french toast tahiti (sinfully decadent - its stuffed with carmelized bananas and walnuts). I've also sampled and enjoyed the gingerbread pancakes (topped with roasted pears) and the Valence poached eggs. 

The menu's best feature: most items are available in quantities of one, two and three - this goes for french toast, pancakes, and the multiple poached eggs variations. When my brunch companions and I have been particularly hungry or just feeling indulgent, we'll often get a single pancake or slice of french toast as a "side" in addition to our entrees. Conversely, it is also a good option for cost conscious brunchers. 

$$ and the long wait seem to be the two primary concerns about this spot, and I'd like to weigh in on both. With respect to cost, my personal philosophy is that brunch is invariably a good deal because you're getting two meals (breakfast and lunch) for the price of one. Even better, this form of justification/denial is equally applicable to food consumption - calories are spread out over two meals. (Yay loopholes!)

As for the wait, I've been here a bazillion times and have never waited for over 30 minutes. Maybe it's luck, but there's also a surprisingly well kept secret: the tables on the sidewalk are first come, first serve, so if it's a nice day put your name on the list and stake out the diners nearest to finishing. Also, dining in smaller parties helps (especially in twos), as tables for larger groups are limited. But alas, if you do have to wait, the Zazie host couldn't be nicer and remembers all regulars by sight and even name. 

I'd like to end this rambling review with an image that I believe is testament to Zazie's greatness. For a few weeks in the spring, Zazie closed for renovations. Being rather slow in the morning, I forgot this and showed up only to find the interior dark and a notice on the door. But it was worth the trip just to see the thousands of post-it notes from forlorn patrons that papered Zazie's windows, begging it to reopen soon. I hope the owners have those saved in a box somewhere.
author: A M.

description:
We were here on rainy Sunday morning. You wouldn't believe the line outside on a rainy day. I should have slept late instead of driving all the way here but I have to make an exception, it's my daughter birthday.  Parking is horrible, you can go around in circles for hours before finding a spot. You might as well double park and wait for somebody to leave. Now, the wait. If you have more than 6 persons on your party, you might as well go home and make your own on breakfast, unless you don't mind waiting for more than an hour. 

We ordered poached egg, french toast and I decided to order a sandwich it was pass noon, that is lunch for me. Just lost my apetite of  breakfast brunch after waiting for more than 1 1/2 hours. Food is good but nothing worth waiting for more than 1hour.  Tip: All your party must me present to be seated. Come in early on weekends.
author: Marlon Z.

description:
I adore Zazie, if I could own a restaurant it would look exactly like this:
large skylights in the ceiling, exposed brick, hardwood floors and patio seating--so perfect!
I have only had their brunch (many times) but it's the best in the city.
For whatever reason most breakfast places can't cook potato's-- often they are undercooked, under-seasoned, or they can't figure out how to get them hot to your table. Zazie's potatoes are roasted perfectly and served with cloves of garlic and butter both of which I put on their excellent bread. 
You can't never go wrong with their scrambles my favorite being 'Eggs Fontainbleu' .
My one complaint is their espresso drinks, they serve them in a cereal bowl, it looks stupid, takes up half the table, and gets cold fast.
author: Chloe B.

description:
Was so impressed with the dinner experience--yes, it is not just a brunch place!!--a date and I had here the other night that I'm compelled to write my first Yelp review. Especially since most of the reviews cover the brunch, I figured a review highlighting the dinner experience might help, even if it means a longer wait for me the next time I return. 

The big selling points:
--Staff are fantastic. I lived in Philly for 8 yrs, a city that prides itself on solid neighborhood spots with staff that are the perfect mix of nice (but not fake), honest and quirky fun in the way that makes you want to be friends with them. This place has that type of a work force, and it's such a refreshing change compared with some of the newer stuffier places I've been to since moving out here. Examples: our waiter advising my date against the soup of the day, as he said there were better things on the menu, and the dude at the door bringing us not one but two rounds of complimentary bubbly as we waited for our table--and sharing in our snarky grumbling about the couple that was taking waaaay too long to vacate the table that was to be ours.
--Food is equally fantastic, and original, AND decent-sized servings. I had the duck, my date had the polenta, and we shared the cheese plate as an appetizer. All were great, originally prepared AND left us both stuffed--a rarity for me and my big appetite, at French places especially.
--Atmosphere is warm and friendly. No stuffiness here, and the place just has a general good mood vibe--proven by the point that it was pouring outside the night we went but somehow everyone who entered still seemed to instantly be in a good mood.
--Tuesday nights (when we went) are BYOB with no corkage fee. So a great way to keep the bill down, and adds to the friendly non-stuffy vibe (have I mentioned I hate stuffy restaurants)?

And things that I was fine with but you may not be:
--Yes, you may have to wait for a table. Even if you make a reservation. We waited about 20 minutes (but there was free bubbly!). If that possibility throws off your universe, this might not be your place.
--The tables are pretty close together. But as I said, everyone who entered seemed to be great, so overhearing conversations between great people sitting next to you, and inevitably engaging them in conversation, didn't bug us a bit.

So check out Zazie for dinner and enjoy it. Just don't tell any people you know who suck.
author: Nathan W.

description:
Zazie is an INCREDIBLE brunch place in San Francisco.  Good service.  Excellent food. 

It's a good place to bring friends and catch up as you may wait 30 - 45 minutes until getting seated. My first time here --- not long ago, I was surprise to see a crowd of plus 15 waiting outside for a seat on a drizzling day. 

**I recommend checking out their menu on-line so you'll know why you're waiting to eat here regardless on whether it's a SUNNY, RAINY, or HOT day.
author: Jeannine L.

description: Wowzah! The French toast was amazing.... and so was the salsa / bacon eggs benedict, definitely going to be part of our rotai.
author: Y S.

description:
Mmmm...  Croque Madame... I love the Madames...;)
The French food was great, the patio seating was great, perfect place for a weekend brunch.  They have at least 2 mimosas:  mango and orange.  May have more depending... the food was quite good.
author: Fong L.

description:
Delicious breakfast/brunch spot.  They've got something like 6 different kinds of Mimosas, and some amazingly good food.  The french toast is HUGE, and really, really good.  I got the one with carmelized banana and walnuts.  Wow.  Everything I could have asked for.  Rich and sweet and savory.
In fact, my only complaint would be with their bacon - I felt it was a bit on the thin and ordinary side.  I like my bacon to be thicker, heartier, and more like a fat country slice.  See: Mama's in North Beach for a classic example of the genre.  It was also cold by the time it showed up at the table.  A bit unfortunate.

They're list-on-the-door only, so expect to wait, especially if there are more than a few of you.  But it's deliciously worth it.
author: Don H.

description:
Zazie is one of my favorite brunch places in SF, BUT you need to go there with patience. This place is PACKED ALL the time. No matter what time you go, there's always a huge line. My girlfriend and I came here yesterday and there were 15 parties ahead of us! Since I knew how the wait can be, we put our names down and went to Tully's next door for our coffee. After 35 minutes of waiting (not TOO bad), we got a nice table outside in the garden patio. Although it was a chilly day in SF, the heat lamps worked like magic.

I'm always torn between savory and sweet when it comes to brunch, so I love how you can order a lacart. I ordered 1 french toast and two eggs over hard. It was perfect. I LOVE their french toast. The bread is thick and grilled to a crunch. My friend had the New York scramble with smoked salmon, cream cheese and scallions. YUM. On a previous visit, I had their mushroom fontina scramble which was delicious. All egg dishes are served with potatoes and toast.

Zazie does a fantastic job on all their dishes weather sweet or savory!
author: Denise L.

description:
Best Eggs Benedict in SF... If you haven't been, you must. The staff is friendly and attentive. Beware, don't go when you're starving because you'll most likely have to wait since there's always a line. 

I love how they serve the latte, in a bowl.. very cozy..

Oh yeah!! On Monday's you can dine with your dog in the outside patio.. Couldn't ask for anything more.
author: Monica S.

description:
Supposedly the food is organic here.  

It didn't taste organic.   
I'm not sure but is my bacon organic?
The syrup?
The tap water I drank?

In the end I really don't care where the food came from as long as it wasn't the kitchen floor.  Your challah french toast was incredible!   But honestly was it organic?  Prices were kind of high ... are they organic too?
author: Bill P.

description:
The service was fantastic!! The food, excellent! Had a great time eatting & hanging out with my friends. We brought in our own champagne & wine. Corkage fee is a deal! Wish we had big enough bellies to try everything~

I will definitely reccomend this restaurant to friend and family~
author: Triston D.

description: Had my Father's Day brunch and waited for 1 and half hour to be seated. The food was pretty disappointed. I think this place is overrated. Not the best I have ever tried.
author: Gerald L.

description:
I've always heard about this place from coworkers and finally came heere for a staff retreat.  That day was somewhat sunny so we sat on the outside patio.  we ordered our dishes and ordered pitchers of Mimosa.  You know what that means! 

My eggs benedict came and it was gooooood... or maybe it could be the Mimosa talking... it came with 2 eggs benedict and potatoes on the side.  I am not a big fan of brunch but this was goood.  I would come back here again if I wanted some decent brunch!

and maybe without the mimosa this time!
author: Kapo T.

description:
This place is good we all know it. So here are some tips.

- It's worth the wait to sit out in the patio, trust me. Even when it's cold out. 
- The gingerbread pancakes aren't so good without lemon curd. Don't forget to tell them you want the lemon curd. Sometimes, they don't give it to you if you don't ask.
- Order one plate and another to share with other people. 1 1/4 should fill you up. 
- Don't come hungry. You'll be a mad hungry bear by the time you're seated. 
- If you're nasty to your wait, they'll be nasty back. I guess this is true almost everywhere.
- Go for a walk after you have your name on the waitlist. There are cute stores in the area. 
- Eat slowly and enjoy your food!!
author: Kwan H.

description:
Made the trip to Cole Valley for brunch this weekend, and I was not disappointed. 

It's rare to find a wait for brunch at 10:30 out in the neighborhoods.  I tend to find most of the crowd appears later.  But, there was a 40-60 minute wait for 2 this Sunday morning.  Not that I can complain.  The day was beautiful, there were many, many people and dogs to watch, and the time passed quickly (at least for my mind, if not for my stomach).

I indluged in the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and poached pear, and a side of bacon.  Their coffee is rich and strong.  The pancakes were great.  I ordered 2, but should have just gone with 1 (they're huge).

My husband got the un, deux, trois (1 pancake, 2 eggs, 3 slices of bacon).  He also enjoyed his breakfast, but he thought the eggs had adopted a strange flavor--maybe something was cooked on the same surface?  He couldn't quite figure it out...

Anyway, would definitely come back.  Service was good / pleasant.  We sat inside, and the atmosphere was nice,  Lots of people were waiting on the patio specifically, so I'm sure that's even better.

Hooray for Zazie, and delicious brunch.
author: Lori G.

description:
i havent been to this restaurant, but my BF's 50th birthday is approaching and thought i'd check out the menu's online.  im vegan so im used to having to improvise with the waiter once im in the restaurant.  looking at the menu, i thought i would have to improvise a lot if i didnt want to end up with just a salad, then i see a note that says "no substitutions our tiny kitchen is too bussy".  doesnt sound too vegan friendly unfortunately, so i wont even try it.  too bad all of these restaurants are missing out on a big and growing population that wants to go out and spend lots of money.
i guess ill stick to millenium, hervivore, or udupi, cant go wrong with eather of those.
author: juan carlos m.

description:
Zazie is my favorite place for weekend brunch. The wait staff is friendly, the food is awesome and the atmosphere is great.

I've also been there once for dinner, which was okay but without the atmosphere of the brunch crowd it wasn't as enjoyable.

Here are some tips and other random notes:

+ Go there before 11:00 am or after 1:00 pm if you don't want to spend ~30 minutes for a table

+ Try not to sit outside on the sidewalk, a lot of people will be waiting around you and it's not fun. Get a table inside or in the patio at the back

+ They recently changed their menu to offer you a choice of 1/2/3 in a bunch of dishes (French toast, eggs, pancakes). So, now you can order 3 slices of French toast or 2 scrambled eggs, rather than however many eggs they used to put in

+ Try their drinks, don't just stick to coffee

+ Take the N Judah muni if you can, it's around the corner. Otherwise, parking is usually around a 2+ block radius

+ There's a coffee shop a few doors down, and you can get a cup of joe while you wait to be seated. This works well if you want to try their brunch drinks
author: Abid M.

description:
As a still relatively new resident of this great city, I'm intensely interested in places I can walk to from my house, as this wasn't so much of an option down in the south bay. Ten minutes downhill, and I was waiting patiently outside Zazie with my friend Daniel. Luckily the two of us had a lot to catch up on, and the day was beautiful, so the rather long wait (and the reason for only four stars) was pleasant.

And it was worth the wait. We started with a delightful cocktail of elderberry liquor and champagne. Daniel and I ordered enough food to completely cover our small table for two. Three gingerbread pancakes, two chicken-apple sausages, Eggs Fontainbleu, Eggs Italie.

We demolished it. (Well, mostly. There was a small pile of pancake left, which I took home as a desserty snack for later.) My eggs Italie were perfectly cooked, with delicious flavorful tomatoes (and really, you can't go wrong with cream cheese in anything). The side of potatoes with roasted garlic still in the sac? Brilliant. The sausage were good, but not really worth the price. And the pancakes. I'm a sucker for anything with ginger, especially gingerbread, and these did not disappoint. They were moist and popping with ginger flavor.

I feel like I rolled out of there. But somehow, I pulled it together enough to walk the six blocks ENTIRELY UPHILL back to my place. And then took a well-deserved nap.
author: Mace M.

description:
BEST BREAKFAST of my LIFE, seriously.

this is another example of how yelp makes my life taste better. for the bf's bday weekend, i wanted to make it amazing, so we yelped a breakfast spot in sf to start off the morning and zazie sounded just about perfect.

yes, it was an hour long wait but the food is utterly and totally worth it. we shared the french toast stuffed with carmelized bananas and walnuts, the home fries, a sunshine mimosa, and la mer- the dungeness crab eggs benedict.

without a doubt, the best french toast ever- so fluffy and full of yummy-goodness, i didn't even want to pour any syrup on it cuz the flavor was so good. and the home fries- wow. so garlicky and perfectly seasoned.

the wait didn't even seem that bad cuz we just strolled through the very charmingly local neighborhood of cole valley in the misty rain.

the pudge (the name that i have dubbed my ravenous belly with a mind and appetite of its own) gives zazie its official stamp of approval.

only downside is the cramped space and seating. hard to walk through, not conducive for fat people walking.
author: Jenni B.

description:
Maybe we caught this place on a bad day....

I would give this place two stars, but I reserve that only for places where the service is poor.  The service was good at Zazie's.  The reason I have to leave this review is because the food was really... not good.  Ok, I have to say that my boyfriend and I have high expectations when it comes to food.  He is attending french culinary school, and I am kind of a foodie snob.  And we're not rich, so when we spend $45 on  brunch, we expect something good.  

Notwithstanding our hard to please palates, this is why we can't understand why this place gets so many great reviews:

- The egg yolks in my poached eggs got throughout my entire salad
- The hollandaise sauce was thin and runny, and would have actually been good if it also didn't drench my entire salad.
- My boyfriend's eggs smelled and tasted weird.  
- The "home fries" were actually poorly seasoned, boiled red potatoes 

We had heard great things about this place, so maybe we caught them on a bad day, but its always painful when you spend so much on a meal, and have a salad filled with egg yolk.  

Perhaps if you go here, you're better off getting french toast and mimosas--- the mimosas were excellent!!
author: Martha D.

description:
I don't give 5 stars unless I find a place that is irreplaceable...Zazie is my favorite brunch place in the area...especially on a nice day when you can get a patio seat out back...the menu is not super long, but it's more creative than standard brunch places...the Miracle pancake (sour cream + poppy seed + lemon zest) is super freaking good, the Challah orange French toast is great...the poached eggs are the best I've had...I think the Monaco ones are my favorite...also, a decent selection of mimosa type drinks, the Zazie special is my favorite

As a dinner place, I'd give it 4 stars, again interesting menu, mussels are great, great desserts...you can do a Ptix Fix deal which is appetizer + entrée + dessert for $23 which I like, but it limits you to one a few choices for each category

Biggest downside can be the wait...I've been going for about 3 years and the brunch wait is increasing...
author: Joey P.

description: Came here for brunch on the weekend without a reservation, something I would not do again!  We had to wait over an hour to be seated, but luckily, there is a Pete's coffee next door!  However, the breakfast was delicious; we ordered the french toast and and the salmon scramble, both of which were a hit.  I would definitely come back (with a reservation!).
author: Kristine Y.

description:
Zazie is bliss.  I've only visited this fine establishment for breakfast but plan to visit for lunch & dinner sometime soon.  I love love love the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and poached pears....a must try!  They have outdoor seating which is a great thing when you have kids.  
Mama's is still a favorite but I think Zazie moved to the #1 spot.....
author: Michelle M.

description: I really love this place. Food is delcious... ambiance fabulous... it's simple sweet and cute.  Perfect place for a brunch date with your special someone.
author: Jo T.

description:
Yes, Zazie is the best brunch place in the city right now for the reasons below:
1. Food is awesome
2. Wait is not bad at all
3. The patio makes the experience so much better
4. The service is very good
5. Finding parking is not hard
6. You can wander around Cole valley while you wait for your turn

Zazie has never let me down. 

PS: try out the bakery half a block south on Cole for some pastries after breakfast.
author: Ashwin K.

description:
How do you define annoying? Sitting, cramped in the back patio at a "table for two" that really should be classified as a table for two guppies. 

How to do you define rude? Sitting at said Guppy Table fuming at having to endure half the meal listening to the cotton-headed, bafoon at the near table prattling on in the LOUDEST voice imaginable about his failed board of director's meeting (aka Explaining why it is that he doesn't know how to do his job). Everyone heard it dude!!! All while his dining companion's visage turned like a thousand different shades of "mui embarrassed" crimson, rose and then pure red.

How do you define temporary insanity? Me taking my fork and in one swift movement, sticking it into the thigh region of his pleated slacks and relishing his choking on bits of Croque Monsieur remains in mid cell phone sentence. 

Ok the Temporary Insanity part didn't happen. Instead I turned to his thoroughly flushed companion requesting that she "GET HIM OUT OF HERE!! post freakin' haste." The guy left with celly still glued to ear, trying to argue his way into saving his job. I smell pink slip. 

Hello Zazi management. Get a cell phone blocker please!!!
author: Johnny C.

description: Zazie is a nice place for breakfast. Inside is a yellow decor with really faded out French posters. The background music adds to the French feeling but the one distracting thing is the boisterous conversation involving the kitchen staff. At one point I actually heard "Ay, ay, ay!!!" There aren't that many surprises to be had on the menu and the portions are super huge but if you want well cooked food with good service this isn't a bad idea.
author: Michael H.

description: Zazie is our favorite local establishment.  We come here often because it's so close and we just love it here for brunch and for dinner; we have never had a bad experience here; consistency is key.  The wait is always long for weekend brunch, so don't come starving or put your name down and come back.  We always make a reservation for dinner so there is no wait.  The food is always excellent, especially if you love French cuisine.  For dinner, we like to start with the charcuterie plate: pate, salmon rillettes, proscuitto, olives, spicy mustard and salad.   The duck leg and pork chop are phenomenal.  Finish with a classic creme brulee. Magnifique! Brunch at Zazie is awesome in the garden patio.  I love the dungeness crab benedict.  If you're gluten-free like me, they will serve it on a corn tortilla.  Also, great news for dog lovers! Monday nights are dog friendly nights where you can dine in the garden patio with your little furry friends.
author: Connie W.

description:
plenty of food and the buttermilk pancakes are the best in the city. the decor is comfy and tres francais. i've come here hungover with bedhead and the servers have always been cool to me inspite of my nasty appearance.

and a bonus star for being named after one of my favorite films!
author: Art O.

description: i absolutely love this place.  It's located in Cole Valley and it's like a hidden gem.  Back in my college days, i would always pass by this street, but i never got the chance to explore it.  I finally decided to give this place a try after reading all the reviews.  I came here on the 4th of July and there was already a crowd at 10:30 in the morning.  My friend and i waited about 20 mins, but you can take a look at the menu while you wait or go grab Peet's coffee down the block.  But beware that you need everyone at you party to be present in order to be seated, or they will give your table to the next party in line. We got seated at the outside patio, which was nice and warm.  All the waitresses were all very nice and tentative. We started out with the Zazie drink, it was orange juice mixed with grapgefruit ( i don't really remember, but it was good)  We ordered their poached eggs- the Florentine, and their French Toast Tahiti (it had bananas and walnuts).  Their poach eggs was cooked just right, and poached eggs aren't easy to cook. it wasn't to cooked and it was't too raw, it was just right.  it came with a said of their potatos.  I love their french toast!, if you are a banana lover, you must try it!  The bill totaled up to be 35.00 which was a little pricy for breakfast, but i will go back.  However, on major holidays they DO NOT take reservations.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Wishing to avoid the 45 minute brunch wait, we opted for takeout.

After hearing much accolades of the gingerbread pancakes (including a #1 placement on 7x7's pancakes of SF), they were a bit disappointing - too dense, thick, and doughy, although the gingerbread flavor and lemon sauce were quite good.  I also found the French toast tahiti fairly standard, though the walnut stuffing added a nice dimension.  The Monaco eggs benedict was a bit shabby - ordinary english muffins, overcooked eggs, and a meager portion of proscuitto.

Portions were generous and staff was friendly.  Definitely a competent brunch, though not the revelation I was hoping for.
author: Jeremy C.

description: my wife and I live in the neighborhood and had our kitchen remodeled. Zazie was our go to for over 5 months once a week. Great food, great atmosphere and the staff are terrific and friendly. Highly recommend!
author: Kenny S.

description:
This place isn't worth it.
- Don't wait in line.   And yes, there will be a line an hour long.
- Seating is abysmal, outdoor area is NOTHING SPECIAL
- Coffee is swill
- Food is greasy spoon quality with half the flavor
- OVERPRICED

Whoa, so many things wrong and yet people rave about this place.  I must be crazy...
author: Bobby K.

description:
It seems Zazie is known for its brunch.  Unlucky for me, I guess, I went for dinner with some friends this past weekend.

I have to say, the staff was really friendly, and there really wasn't anything wrong with the food.  Everyone else I was with was really happy with it.

BUt for me, I don't know, it was really really meh.  The place is missing something, some kind of soul to speak to me and tell me why I should enjoy the food here.

Or, I could have just been in a crappy mood.  And poor Zazie only gets 3 stars because of it.  Maybe I should try again for brunch?
author: Steve S.

description:
LOVED IT!
Went for a breakfast date today. The food was awesome and the service was top notch!
I relaly like that there is so much organic food on the menu!
Also loved that there are 3 options for sizes for many of the dishes. 
This place is a must!
author: Michael F.

description:
You know..i am a tough critic on brunch. Its my favorite meal of the week so im always expecting good stuff. 

I went to this place and with all its niceness and frenchyness and cool location..THE FOOD CAME OUT COLD

Simply put there is no excuse for that. I will not return.
author: Ahmad R.

description:
1 table every 3 minutes.  That's what the note said...and it was true! 

I had a pleasant & very prompt service here in their sunny & cozy room with brick, checkered floor & dark wood tables. They had varying styles of omelettes (mine was the fountainbleu) and them eggs were pretty tender yet tasty.  I'll need to revisit  and see if I can snag a table out back.  I'm a sucker for outdoor patio dining.
author: Jen L.

description:
Finally we got in here today!  Without a wait no less!  Had major problems getting in here on a weekend, so I figured I would have an easier time getting in on a weekday.  And I was right!  (after a 45 minute ordeal with parking).

It is super cute inside.  Kinda SF meets a French bistro.  SF with the brick walls, and the patrons inside.  Bistro-like with the little tables, and the patterned floor, and the outside back patio with quaint little tables.  

Got in, sat down at a cute little table for 2.  We had the "un, deux, trois" which was french toast, 1 pancake, 2 eggs, and 3 strips of bacon, and then we also had the special scramble consisting of black forest ham, cheese, eggs, and avocado!  Also on the side, we had the cream cheese coffee cake which was delicious!  Everything was great!  Loved it all, the food, the service and the place!  

Extra bonus, the cute guy next to us was dining alone and actually joined us in our conversation.  YIPPEE for my friend!!
author: Denise B.

description:
Excellent for Sunday brunch, Zazie has a good size menu and the eatables are for reals.  I had pancakes, but would you believe I was so tired meeting my friends at 9:45 after 4 hours of sleep that I don't remember what kind they were (EDIT: they were gingerbread, and delicious).  Suffice it to say there were two of them, they were mad thick, and they were flavored in some way.  The syrup was not so fantastic (iamasyrupsnob) but waddyagonnado.

They do have a weird thing, which is that when we got our bill there was a $3 health insurance charge.  When we asked our waiter wtfwasup, he (silently) handed us a laminated card that explains that in response to SF requiring the restaurant to provide health insurance to its workers, they have a $1/patron surcharge to offset the $108k a year it costs them to do that.  Something just felt wrong...I mean I recognize the money has to come from somewhere and I know restaurants have razor-thin margins.  I'm not sure if I'd rather they just folded it into the cost of the food, or maybe if the waiter would've kindly explained it by using verbalized words, but i just vaguely had the sense that someone somewhere was sticking their middle finger up at me - the voters of San Francisco, perhaps.  Or more likely someone somewhere in the federal government.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Hands down my pick for best brunch in San Francisco. Perhaps a story to illustrate.

My old room mate and I brought her Japanese father to Zazie for brunch on Sunday when he was visiting. She informed me he doesn't like any American eateries. After one meal here he was asking for us to take him back one more time before heading home.

I rest my case.
author: Geoff W.

description: One star for the food. I went with a party of 3 and signed name in. We waited over ONE HOUR all while parties of 2, who had arrived after us, were being seating within 15 minutes. You can see who writes there names in  as they arrived. I was so upset when i saw that they had seating literally 10 parties of 2 who had arrived much later than us! When I asked the manager, hey why haven't you seated us? He said waiting for a table (to seat 3)!! I looked inside and there were 4 tables for 2 open! I said, can you just put two of those tables together so we may sit already? I told him he has seating several parties of 2 who had only waited maybe 10 minutes and it was not fair! he told me "let me do my job" and continued seating parties of two. WOW extremely wrong. I don't agree with the service and the management doesn't know what they are doing. Will never go here again. Unless I am with a party of 2. thumbs down.
author: Bella S.

description: 5 Stars for the delish food. I had the bananas foster french toast and an an omelette with red skin potatoes. Even though the place was packed (Sunday morning brunch), we got prompt service. We had to wait about an hour for a table, but it was worth it. If I get invited here by friends again, I'm SO THERE.
author: Rachel S.

description:
BRUNCH: your wait for a table will not be short. If you choose the "first table available" route, you might be seated at one of three tables awkwardly positioned on the sidewalk. Don't fret, you'll have all those friendly folks waiting for a table to keep you company. 

Evidently, some Cole Valley residents don't like Zazie's alfresco option. We witnessed an irate man knock a glass off one these tables and curse our brunching lifestyle. 

Once inside, you'll find Zazie cozy and noisy.
author: Risk D.

description:
Mileu:
French-like cafe atmosphere.  Quaint.

Service:
Good service, but we were pretty much the only one's there.  She was a very nice waitress.  We were seated fast and our food was served efficiently too.

Food:
Aweful food.  It was only because I was starving that I ate all of it.  The eggs were so greasy.  I thought I was gonna die.  Its not like I don't like grease.  Grease on Fois Gras i great, but greasy eggs dripping with olive oil.  Gives me the creeps.  I will probably go back just for coffee next time.
author: M L.

description:
Never comE here late because it's continually packed and there's a long waiting list. We came here early on a Sunday morning just to try their brunch and still, there was a long wait list. But all that waiting was worth it for this little COLE VALLEY French style restaurant. It's very cute looking inside with an outdoor patio in the bacK. I also noted it's 95 percent rating out of 100, which is good and I always look for that when i go out to eat. 

A very nice place to have a Fountainbleu (scrambled egg) with portabella mushrooms and cheese! Most tried the Croque Monseur too!!!! Good for groups and families with little kids if you are patient enoungh to wait for a table.
author: herm p.

description:
After waiting for a full hour to be seated, I was quite excited to sit down and stuff my face with the gingerbread pancakes. Ordered the un, deux, trois which includes scrambled eggs, pancakes and bacon. First, everything was cold when it got to the table. Two, the scrambled eggs were runny (yuck!) and third the gingerbread pancakes were flavorless. If it wasn't for the lemon curd and pear topping I would of thought they forgot to substitute the buttermilk pancake for gingerbread.

My partner in waiting commented his croque madame was good but not worth the hour wait. For me, the mocha in the big ass cup was good but bitter, I needed loads of sugar (cane sugar).

Oh and how could I forget the smelly water glasses. After the first sip the strong smell of egg yolk hit my nose. Now how did egg yolk get into both our water glasses, who knows. Perhaps they dropped an egg into the sink while washing them or they're using some fancy organic dish soap that smells like eggs. In any case, no thanks.

Next time, we'll go hang out with the crackheads for 20-30 minutes and have our breakfast at Dottie's True Blue Cafe. The wait is more entertaining and worth it in the end.
author: Diana C.

description:
I'm not a big fan of hollandaise sauce, but after the gf informed me that the eggs benedict here was one of the hundred items deemed imperative by 7x7 magazine, I was a willing participant. If you enjoy the heavenly fusion of breakfast and lunch that is brunch as much as I do, then you will love Zazie. Technically they still call it breakfast here (and they serve it until 2:30!!!). The surrounding area on Cole reminded me of a calmer locale (maybe like Carmel or somewhere in Marin) perfect for enjoying a nice, quiet laid back meal. 

I had the Eggs Divorcee: eggs benedict with bacon, avocado, fontina, and of course, hollandaise. I was pleasantly surprised that the hollandaise didn't have that annoyingly strange sour flavor that store-bought and/or Denny's eggs benedict would have. The egg was poached to the point that you could still find traces of translucent egg white, but firm and semi-runny. The english muffin was so crispy we had a hard time cutting into it, but with the thick cuts of bacon and the creamy avocado, each bite was really perfect texture-wise and flavor-wise. The home fries had a sickly ugly-duckling piece of potato that turned out to be a beautiful head of roasted garlic. Just awesome.

We also had the Eggs en Fonte which might have been even better than the Divorcee. The combination of perfectly poached egg, tomato sauce, mushrooms and polenta was fantastic. I would comment more but I'm tired of raving about this place. You just have to go try it. 

Blew away all premature notions about eggs benedict. Cinco estrellas.
author: Dennis M.

description:
Love their Croque Madam Sandwich.  It's a grilled black forest ham and gruyere sandwich serving with a sunny side egg on the top.  We tried the sandwich in a couple of different place but this is the best by far.  Love the casual French bistro atmosphere and staff are very friendly.   It's a nice neighborhood restaurant in Cole Valley. 

Their burger is also very good.  The waitress said she was a vegetarian for a few years until she starts to work in Zazie.  We gave it a try and my husband loves it.  It became one of the must-have item ever since thought it did get pretty messy (burger juice all over your finger) when you eat.
author: Annie H.

description: This is officially my new favorite breakfast/brunch restaurant on the west coast  (In Seattle, it's Glo's on capitol hill). But seriously, I LOVE french food and they Frenchify all of my favorite breakfast classics.  Eggs Benedict = AMAZING!  I like the Monaco, which comes with tomatoes provencal, but there are lots of options.  The Gingerbread Pancakes are a huge hit with my friends, although I'm partial to the regular Buttermilk ones. They have AWESOME cocktails including, but not limited to, their Mango Mimosa and incredible Bloody Mary.    Expect a wait because it's in demand - but it is sooooooooooo worth it.
author: Sonja N.

description:
We came for dinner tonight. Upon making reservations there was no mention that we'd have to sit outside. Sitting outside is fine, but it was 45 degrees out. Sure there were heat lamps and blankets but it was still freaking cold. I'm fine with sitting outside if warned of this when making the reservation, but we weren't. Very lame I'd say.

The food was good as usual but we had to eat fast before the 45 degree air froze it.
author: Mark C.

description:
le adore.
i have no idea if that actually means that I love this place in french but it sounds about right. I can never decide if I'm more taken by the atmosphere or the food. the details are delightful.. the tiny twisted staircase up to the office, the sliding door to the bathroom, the easy aired staff, the patio.. ahh the patio. its the back"yard" space we all dream of here in the city. 
the food? where do i begin.. gingerbread pancakes and poached eggs and homefries with garlic, oh my!!
author: Jeremi M.

description:
This place is amazing. It is well worth the usual hour to hour and a half weekend list. The beauty though is that if you write your cell phone # down, they'll call you if you decide to head to the bar next door for a quick drink while you wait!
Outside or inside, the decor is beautiful. They also serve brunch seven days a week! The coffee is so strong, my last dining companion called it "cowboy killer". I ALWAYS bring friends here for brunch when they're visiting from out of town.
A bottle of the bubbly, cup of killer coffee, and the Eggs Monaco~~~~~ simply amazing. The standard that all other brunches in the city should be held to.
Oh, and the service is always fabulous!
author: Kellyanne i.

description:
Very cute french bistro style place. Great for brunches and such. They have a very cute patio which is covered by greenery. Seats are a bit tight, but this is SF right ? They have a great selection of eggs/pancakes/salads etc.
I have the scrambled with fontainbleu cheese. It was very good. But very greasy. Loved the potatoes with a roasted garlic in it.
Charged us to $2 for the healthcare fund. This is a slightly pricey joint. 
We went on a weekday. But I hear on the weekends, the place can get very crowded. And parking is pretty tight.
author: Shaheen L.

description: Came here on a Friday morning so the wait wasn't too bad. My friends and I got the eggs benedict, the corn meal pancake, an egg scramble, and a un deux trois. The place is decent...good food and cute friendly services, but I think after trying so many brunch places, it really takes a lot to really blow me away. All in all, sure, def come and give this place a try!
author: Erin L.

description: Excellent beef bourguignon. Very good duck and sausage cassoulet. Average french onion soup.
author: G L.

description:
Had a delicioussss brunch here this past weekend. The service was quick and friendly. The food was tasty and came out really fast, which was great since we needed to go watch the STEELERS GAME, woot woot! I got the benedict with proscuitto and tomatoes provencal (oh-so-good!) and the bf had some sort of mexican scramble, which was also pretty good. The potatoes were the most lackluster part of the meal but there was nothing to keep me from coming back again!

Word to the wise: don't stray too far from the door after writing your name on the waiting list. The list may seem insanely long but it goes surprisingly fast. The host will give your table away about 2.3 seconds after calling your name and realizing you're not there. They don't mess around here!
author: Amanda R.

description:
I came here for the first time on Saturday morning w/ my BF. We shared the Monaco Poached Eggs, French Toast Tahiti, and Fontainbleau Scrambled Eggs. Yummy! The poached eggs were like eggs benedict, the scrambles eggs are like omlettes, but all made different ways with different toppings. There are so many options. I enjoyed everything that we had, but my favorite was the house potatoes (yum) and the scambles eggs. 

This was one of the only places in the area that had a large crowd outside. Considering... the wait was actually not bad at all. We were told there was a 30min. wait, but was called within 10 mins. But, I think if you are going in a large group (4 or more), the wait will probably be long if they are busy like that Saturday morning. The service was excellent though. While we were waiting, we went to get some Tully's coffee a few doors down and the host said she would come to get us if we were called before we came back and you can bring in your coffee while you eat. I thought that was awesome. They also use an application on the iPad to add your name on the wait list & you on your android/ iphone with a downloadable application.

Good food and good service. Definitely coming back!
author: Nai S.

description:
Had breakfast/brunch on a Saturday morning - the wait for a table of 3 was only about 20 minutes.  I cannot comment on the inside of the restaurant as we chose first available and were sat outside in the front - looking through the glass it looked comfortable.

Our server was available and very pleasant.  The service was invisible - in the best way possible.  She took our orders and returned just enough times to make sure we were always comfortable.

The food was very tasty - We all had breakfast fare, not necessarily the hardest to prepare or mess up.  I ordered the mexico - at a french place - go figure.  When I see chorizo on a menu though, I order it.  The flavors were well balanced, the chorizo was excellent, the service was great, the company was better.

Great meal.
author: Shaun T.

description: You're kidding me, I haven't rated my favorite neighborhood spot? How strange..I'm always in the mood for breakfast, lunch, or dinner there. They have the best entrees. I love the service and they have great timing when it comes to food preparation. I hardly ever have to wait too long before my food arrives. The lines are long, but they're well worth it. Thanks for being so close to me!! ;) They always make me smile!
author: Mei F.

description:
Zazie has a special place in my heart...the service is always great and the food comforting. 

Brunch is always worth the wait!
author: Janice E.

description: Wow! excellent mimosas, great outdoor seating. Poached eggs with crabs (no avocados for me) topped with hollonaise sause was A+ Excellent!!! Will come back again! :)
author: Lovetea C.

description:
Went here for Breakfast my first day back home. It was a weekday, so no wait. From what I hear it is usually crowded and have to wait for a while to get a table.

Ambiance is like rustic country.

Food was good. Ingridients were fresh, but nothing out of the ordinary. I had the printemps (I think that is what it was called??) It was eggs benedict with proscutto, asparagus. I got it with no sauce (I know, I know...trying to be healthy).  I liked that you were able to get a salad with it instead of potatoes. Coffee was good. 
uhhhm...service was very slow even though not too many people were there. 
I love the plates they use...so cute.
Eh...just A-OK in my book.
author: Maurice A.

description: I was expecting more of traditional French cousine, but as we were told this is a "bistro", so menu  options are limited. Overall good service. Food is just ok. Some dishes like the salads and ravioli are excellent, others such as the duck are not so much. Even the onion soup wasn't that great.
author: Lotta F.

description: Had dinner here. Very charming place. Excellent value for the money.  The tables were a little tight for my preference - you wouldn't want to come here to discuss anything private. But if you want to have a chat with the people next to you or get a glimpse of their yummy dish, this is the place.  I would definitely go back again for the food and the atmosphere.
author: Stephanie A.

description: I've heard so much about Zazie and never got around to going - I'm so glad I finally did. My friend and I both ordered Poached Eggs, the Monaco and Albert. Both were delicious, no complaints. Their homemade salsa is fantastic, if only they sold it. We went after the brunch rush, so there was no wait. Staff was friendly and attentive. I'm a fan!
author: A S.

description: Went there with a large party & they handled us great.  Food was very good.  Enjoyed the atmosphere & wait staff were all friendly.  I'll definitely be back here.
author: Donna W.

description:
This Review is very much for their Zazie Burger.  Get it medium, it's maybe my favorite I've ever had, definitely the best is SF.  The desert is fantastic too.

Also a word to the wise, French food has a lot of butter in it.
author: Ryan L.

description:
So how about a non-brunch related review.   Ate here for dinner during the week, sitting out on the back patio.  Despite it being a bit cool out, was fine between wearing a light jacket and the heat lamps.   The patio did have a very nice atmosphere, other than someone at a another table talking a bit too loud about his philosophy of life and other things that I obviously don't care about.  Still, that really is a risk anywhere.

The food was amazing.  The mussels were in a nice butter/white wine sauce, and there were a large number of them, always a pleasant surprise in an appetizer.  Similarly, the stuffed chicken breast was heavenly, I will have to have it again.  The duck was nice but I only tried a bit of it.  For dessert I tried the fruit crumble [apple] which was near molten and very tasty.  Ginger cake is lost on me, so I can't comment on whether it was any good.  The wine selection is decent, I would have loved a larger selection but that is just me... most people would be fine with it.    I will definitely be going back as I think I have a new favorite place to eat in Cole Valley.
author: Alured P.

description:
This is my favorite neighborhood restaurant in Cole Valley! Their prix-fix is cheap for the quality of food and lets you choose from select app, main and desert off their menu. Their chocolate pot de creme is delicious and their chocolate chaud is out of control. If you like chocolate, you must order one of those! They have a free-corkage night and even a dog night (out on the back porch area). I love this place!

Note: This place has a great brunch, but the lines are prohibitively long.
author: Aimee B.

description:
Unfortunately the back patio was closed this morning (maybe they open it for lunch?).  We sat inside with a mix of folks -  solo diners reading books or pounding their laptops, couples on morning coffee dates, etc.
 
The gingerbread pancakes and bread pudding pancakes were huge, thick, doughy, rich, sweet, and _extremely_ filling.  My sister and I ordered two of each and still had to take some home.  
 
My dad's omelet came with a bunch of garlic cloves. He said they were delicious, though I noticed he spent a long time peeling them because they were unskinned.
 
I liked the home fries -- they were a touch blackened, and well seasoned with pepper and onion and garlic.
