My scrambled egg tasted fine. I enjoyed it mostly for its guilt-free origin: it was laid by a free-range, hormone-free, antibiotic-free, vegetarian-fed local hen.  Thanks hen!
author: angela n.

description:
This was a really cute place my friends and I decided to try out based on another friend's recommendation. The staff was incredibly down to earth and friendly, and the other diners were quite social as well. The food didn't exactly blow me away, but it was good. Parking was a total pain in the ass, but then again, that's always the case anywhere you go in the City. Overall, it was a good brunch experience that I'd be happy to have again.

Just a heads up: I had the tuna sandwich and while it was tasty, unless your upper palate is ready to be shredded from the toasted bread, I'd go with a salad.
author: Ty L.

description:
Got there at 9:45am on a Sunday and there was already a large crowd waiting outside on the sidewalk.  The tables are turned fairly quickly, esp if it's warm and people are sitting in the back garden area. Also, about 1/2 the people who put their names on the list end up going elsewhere (e.g., Boulangerie, Crepes on Cole...)

French Toast Tahiti is pretty good. Caramelized banana/walnuts mashed/stuffed between the french toast.  Sticky, yummy goodness.  Not too sweet to make it an overkill.

I like their regular toast. Thick and yummy. Good for soaking up the eggs over easy.
author: Caroline I.

description:
I love this place!!!

Zazie is a breakfast staple in my life.  It outshines other breakfast joints in the area.
The menu feels complete to me.  They have several forms of the benedict.  And many of the breakfast options give you the choice to pick how many eggs/pancakes/other items you want within your entre, which is nice.   Also, I appreciate that you can get salad or potatoes as a breakfast side.  
In general, I dig the atmosphere.  There are some nice window nooks in the front and they have a lovely patio in the back for sunny days.  
I cant speak to the lunch at Zazie, but I did taste some soup once and I enjoyed it.
author: jessica o.

description:
Yummy, and even yummier when enjoyed on the cute back patio. Our waitress was really friendly and just laughed at herself when she forgot something, so it made the place seem not as stuffy as many French restaurants. 

That marshmallow fudge in a cup thing was amazing.  Can't remember the name at the moment.
author: Liat N.

description: Zazie is a cute french-inspired place with a true neighborhood feel and a really nice outdoor patio in the backyard.  They specialize in breakfast.  Everybody is talking about the gingerbread pancakes, but gosh, whack me in the nuts with a bottle a rum, but I distinctly recall having pumpkin spice pancakes topped with creme fraiche which I also recall were simply awesome.  I think if they do in fact have this treat, it was probably in the Fall like, say, around Halloween time or something. SO GO GET UM!!!  They also have some very good sandwiches and streetside table seating as well.
author: Rick H.

description:
Ok, you might want to take a step away from me. I just had the BEST home fries here. At first I wondered how they made them with that extra bit of flavor and spiciness... then I saw.  Garlic!  Whole cloves of garlic roasted right along with the potatoes. Now that's genius.

I had the eggs Benedict with salmon.  Now, I'm a fan of onions and all, but unfortunately the onions overpowered the eggs, hollandaise, and salmon. I had to take a few of them out.

Long wait, good food.

4 stars cuz well worth coming back, but salmon eggs Benedict is amongst my favorite brunch dishes and it was almost onions Benedict with salmon.  So I'll have to explore for some more good brunch places.
author: Robert L.

description:
Overall impression:
1) Best priced French restaurant in town. I hate the ones that try too hard and charge too much. Great food with reasonable price. 

2) Very cute patio seats, but I personally prefer indoors seats, cozy and sweet. 

3) Great, tentative, yet not pushy service. The waiter was very laid back, chill, but right there when you just about to need him.

4) Prefer dinner much more than the brunch. Everything is excellent, but a bit too crowded and loud at brunch on weekends. But that's the point isn't it? Best place to go with hangover, and a great force to make sure you get up early on weekends and get there 10 minutes before 9. 

5) The owner loved me, so did the dishwashers.

Brunch food:
1) French Toast Tahiti: perfectly prepared french toasts, thick, fluffy, but heavenly soft. Caramelized banana adds the creamy texture, and the walnuts adds the crunchy kick. Nice and filling, yet not heavy.

2) Gingerbread pancake: incredibly spongy and flavorful pancakes with a touch a lemon cream on top. Very yummy. Try it with the raspberry jam on the table. Much try at Zazie, and you'll see why it's always on the menu.

3) Lemon Ricotta pancake: not the best I've tried. The best lemon ricotta cake that I've had is believe it or not, at the bar Feve in Oberlin Ohio. The cakes are too heavy, and a bit lack of flavor. The first one I got was not cooked through that tasted like the batter. Cookie dough is yummy, but not the pancake batter. Sent it back, got a better one, but still nicht so gute.

4) Eggs Italie: scrambled eggs with tomatoes, cream cheese, and basil. Use your imagination. It's a great combination with good preparation. I personally make better scrambles with some pesto and sun-dried tomatoes. But Zazie cooks my brunch and takes care of the dishes, why not?

3) Eggs Florentine: Best Egg benedict besides Chef and Butler. It is traditional and straight-forward. The Hollandaise is creamy but not heavy, doesn't leave the unpleasant stickiness in your mouth. Eggs perfectly poached. Bravo.

6) The mimosa (grapefruit and something): not impressing at all. Couldn't finish it.

7) Cappuccino: very very good, so good that I hate the fact that you can't have it refilled like a regular coffee.

Dinner:
1) French Onion Soup: I would come here just for this bowl of dreams come true, especially at the end of a long tough day of 45 degrees. Very rich flavored soup, with bread crumbs that have still crunchy crust, OH MY GOD CRUNCHY CHEESY TOP.

2) Salade Betterave: I love beets, and here you get 3 kinds of beets, green, gold, and red beets. I love fennels, and here you get fennels. Avocado and white gorgonzola vinegrette give the creamy texture. Yum. Everything I love thrown together, well balanced and light.

3) Pate de Volaille: I hate liver of any animals. Just hate the taste. But, this one is AMAZING, like O.M.G. So smooth and creamy that just melt on your tongue, yes, THAT good. It doesn't have the nasty liver-y taste at all. One of our favorite dishes of the night. 

4) Mussels Marinieres: a little disappointed. The combination of white wine, shallots, parsley and cream is nice, very nice. But I don't like food that's "slightly warm", not cold, not warm, not hot, just slightly warm. It's not the best temperature to serve something creamy, I think.

5) Lamb Tagine: braised lamb entree, looks much better on the menu than it tastes actually. Maybe just not my thing to throw everything together and serve it like a chinese congee. Not my favorite dish, but very well prepared I must say.

Dessert:
1) Toasted Challah Bread Pudding: hands down, the best bread pudding in town, even slightly better than Tartine. Although it's not fair to compare 2 different ways of making bread pudding, I like it better at Zazie. I just love the variety of texture in the bowl, crunchy, creamy, bready, eggy, sweet, smooth, warm, but wow with the pumpkin spice icecream. Bravissimo!

2) Cafe d'AUTOMNE: very interesting combination of Ciao bella Tahitian Vanilla bean and pumpkin icecream, pound cake crumbles, shot of espresso, whipped cream, and toasted almond. Interesting, but for some reason, it's just too much going on for me. But worth a try.

Tips: go with a group of people, like 4, get the sampler platter, choose 3  appetizers from the list of 6, and the dessert sampler platter choose 3 out of 7. Great deal, great food, and lots of fun with friends!

Thank you Zazie for your existence. You make me love SF even more!
author: Yuchi C.

description: The best eggs benedict I have ever had. Unfortunately, I don't have a car anymore, so I only get to come here when friends or family come to visit. Taking the bus to eat breakfast just isn't the same. Anyway, the food. Poached eggs with bacon and white cheddar? Awesome!
author: Alfredo A.

description:
Perhaps with all the 5-star reviews this little place may be a bit over-hyped.  I arrived with reservation on a Tuesday night and the place was jam-packed, obviously a very popular destination amongst ucsf students and local adults.  We were immediately seated and thankfully we were not put in the claustrophobic looking middle aisle seating.  The dining area is very quaint with some French posters and paintings on the walls.  The clamor of the kitchen and the noise of the dining guests is pretty much all you can hear...although there is smooth jazz playing in the background.

The menu has some amazing sounding food on it.  Unfortunately we might've ordered all the wrong stuff because every single thing I ate that night tasted very, well, BAD.  

First off, I definitely hope they are not popular for their french onion soup because it was one of the worst things I've ever tasted.  The broth tastes like an  MSG soup and there is a layer of cheese sitting on top that just melts and turns the top layer of soup into...goop.  As someone who is lactose intolerant (trust me I tolerate as much as I can regardless, yumyum) I was hoping that every dish wouldn't have such an unreasonable amount of cheese piled on top as a shortcut for flavor.  I order the soup du jour which was nothing special... tomato eggplant I believe.  Our appetizers of mussels was ok...tasted like anything you could grab at a tapas bar.  Finally, it comes down to our entrees.  I ordered the Grilled marscapone polenta cakes and I was completely turned off.  I took 3 bites and I was done.  The cheese was all you could taste so I tried rinsing it off in the orange sauce on the plate but as you can probably tell I was not having it.  My boyfriend's beef shank was very plain.  I was expecting to be wowed for a $98 tab but the items we ordered were not delicious. I doubt I will ever swing by here again.  
My rating: C+
author: Amber R.

description: My ideal Sunday night: a Murakami and a warm meal at Zazie's. The waiters are friendly and they don't mind if I sip my wine and read my book after I'm done eating. Plus you get warm bread.
author: Egon S.

description:
Might be one of the most slept on places to eat in all of San Francisco. 

Beef shank was falling off the bone and delicious, the Mac and cheese was hearty yet flavorful. 

The service was attentive but not too smothering. 

I went with a large group of 13 and they handled it perfectly. 

Will absolutely come back.
5 stars. FAST
author: Cam K.

description:
Like many others, I've only been to Zazie's for brunch/lunch. Whenever I go, I always get the smoked salmon sandwich with a side of salad.. it's so good!! It's fresh and tasty... the only bad thing is that it's hard to eat with a fork/knife, and if you eat with your hands... it makes your hand smell like sandwich for the rest of the day.

The BF always gets the croque monsieur, which he loves, but if you're a health junkie, steer clear. It's one of those dishes where the first bite is SO SO GOOD but then it goes downhill from there because of the greasiness. My bf would probably beg to differ.

Overall great food and decent price. Downfalls: hard to find parking, and long waits during rush hour (think weekday lunch).
author: Mari K.

description:
how can you not adore a cafe that has amazing food ( with adjustable portion sizes!!), a beatiful back patio, genteel service, yummy drinks AND 
DOG NIGHT!
on tuesdays, you can bring your pup to eat a civilized meal out on the patio surrounded by fairy lights.

the best aspects of paris  (where everyone eats out with thier pup, of course) without all that yuck ciggarette smoke.
author: Melody O.

description:
Once I read that they allowed dogs to eat with you, I was in. Monday night is doggy night. We got a discount on wine just for bringing our dog and everyone back there was a dog lover so we didn't get any dirty looks. Instead, we started talking about dogs with the ladies at the table next to us. 
The back patio was perfect. Heated lamps placed throught and a massive green vine wrapped all around the surrounding fence with Christmas lights mixed it. It was a perfect place to celebrate being a family (Two gay guys and their new puppy)
The waitress was great and made us laugh a few times. The service was no so speedy, but I think they were trying to be more "French" in that manner. And it didn't matter, the easy pace made the meal more enjoyable. 

Would I go t back again? Hell yea.
author: Manuel M.

description:
4 years of living in sf, and i never got to cross off zazie from my to try list that is...until now when i get to come back as a visitor.

don't make my mistake - come, come!

Sunday brunch
10:45 am - put name for party of 2 for patio only table
11:10 am - friend arrives, yeah! 
11:15 am - table available but inside only - graciously decline
11:30 am - patio table free - light tan develops from waiting in the sun

devoured:
eggs bennie with mushrooms and spinach plus a side of avocado
housemade cream cheese coffee cake
gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd
small oj

12:00 pm - request for bill and walk off some of the calories

verdict : amazing service!!!
patio umbrellas were adjusted as the sun was moving.
host remembered my name as i was leaving
we were often checked on by our server while we chewed and gave several thumbs up signs

*tip - be sure to put 3 or plus baby if you have a stroller since the space is pretty cozy.  if you can't hold out for the patio table, the inside is pretty charming with spiral stairs going up to a mysterious loft.
author: Anh V.

description:
I live a few blocks away and have never been to Zazie for brunch.  Yeah, yeah, Zazie's brunch is great.  No matter how good, I never feel like waiting an hour for eggs and french toast.

I have, however, been to Zazie several times for dinner and it doesn't disappoint.  It's one of the few SF restaurants at which you are served solid french food for reasonable prices (entrees all under $20).  The onion soup is buttery delicious, duck and hanger steak quite tasty.  The pasta looks fine, but unexciting.  On occasion, the staff has been less than helpful on the phone with reservations; but a waiter told me that he's worked there for years because the staff is treated well (that and it's a rare restaurant where the kitchen supposedly isn't mixed up with drugs...surprising for anyone who's read kitchen confidential).

A cute neighborhood restaurant where I can always get a good meal?  Count me as a fan.
author: Jamie Y.

description:
The egg benedicts were pretty good.  Like other well-known breakfast/brunch places, there is a long @#$ line.  I think I waited for 1.5 hrs before I got seated.  There are two tables outside that are first come first serve (i.e., you jump in when the people are done eating).  The neighborhood is pretty cool, so you can probably walk around, look at random stuff or find a new place to eat .

The servers are pretty cool and helpful.  The bloody mary hit the spot ~
author: fatfat w.

description:
Love you!!

I've only been there for brunch. 
Sit out in the back area, drink a mimosa and its a happy day.
author: Sam P.

description: Great brunch spot. Really busy but we got in quick enough, worth the wait. La mer Benedict, amazing. Gingerbread pancakes were my favorite. Lots to choose hard to go wrong really.
author: Amanda O.

description:
this place is legit. the wait time is long as everyone else has already mentioned but its worth it.

poached eggs (la mer): bomb! my friends and i were talking about dungeness crab in the car on the way over. the second i saw it on the menu in a modified eggs benny situation i had to have it. it was perfect. =)

sparkling lemonade: very refreshing, it could have used a touch more sugar but i still enjoyed it.

gingerbread pancakes: my friend order one for everyone to try...it was good. very fluffy. the syrup on top was a bit tart for me though. 

a very cute spot for brunch. can't wait to come back!
author: Linda N.

description:
I love this place.

I have been to Zazie for dinner and it's great, but I go here for breakfast/brunch and it is always fabulous. Their egg dishes are awesome (they change somewhat from time to time, but they always have a benedict with lox and that is never a bad choice), all their breads are delicious, and last time I went I had the ginger pancakes and they didn't make me choose between the lemon curd and pears--I got both! Their coffee always hits the spot as does their lemonade.

Honestly, there is often a wait (20 minutes on the weekdays, an hour on the weekends) but as far as GREAT breakfast places go, you should not be surprised. A friend of mine convinced me to try Mama's on Washington Square and the wait was longer and the food wasn't as good. So there's a comparison for reference.

Anyway, the bar next door is good if it's not too early for you to get a drink and it's always nice to browse in Pharmaca, so you can fill the time, if you can't just wait and chat.

Oh, P.S. I wouldn't recommend parties of more than 4.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
First let me say, SEX is AWESOME, who's not into it? As long as it  doesn't disrupts people sleep especially on the weekend when it's the only time you catch up on your ZZZZ!!! 

(Our neighbor problem has been about close to 3 months now)

So, after being woken up by our sex crazed neighbors who have the cheapest bed that EEK EEK all night (they did it 4 times from 1 AM til 8 AM) above us once again at 7 AM on a Saturday, we decided to ran errands early since we were already up.

So I log onto Yelp, type in brunch place and Zazie caught my eye. I wish that the weather cooperated though, it was pretty chilly.  

Once we get there, we saw a line. We decided to just sit outside, our hunger won over being comfortable inside the restaurant. Zipped up at our jackets, ordered coffee and were set.

Our server, was very attentive and brought our orders right away to lessen our hypothermia. ^_^ He's great!

Mr ordered their special (very yummy) I ordered La Mer: Crab Eggs Benedict, delicious even the potatoes are great. Our Bloody Mary is ok.  Were going back for sure if were in the Cole Valley area.
author: jubi l.

description:
Last week I went for the Beaujolais Nouveau at Zazie. It was fantastic. I had the beef shank and the meat literally would twirl around my fork. The ginger cake they had for dessert was gooey and rich. I already want to go next year!

----

This is the favorite breakfast stop of my best friend. I don't like the long wait for seating. But the food is quite good. You can't lose with the buttermilk pancakes. I know you'll be tempted by gingerbread but I say go traditional, there's a reason it's a classic.

Zazie actually has a shortened weekend menu so try to go during the week if you can.
author: Angela K.

description:
Zazie is currently the front runner for my favorite breakfast/brunch spot in San Francisco. 

This place is cute. It's small and crowded, which can so easily not work, but Zazie pulls it off. The back patio is charming, as is the remarkably tiny bathroom.

The food is above and beyond your standard brunch fare. Many delicious variations on pancakes and french toast. Try the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and bosc pears for sure. 

They have lots of eggs benedict dishes to choose from, with a nice, smooth hollandiase sauce. It doesn't overwhelm the dish. You have the option to order 1, 2 or 3 eggs for the eggs benedict and some of the other egg dishes, which rocks if you aren't into over stuffing yourself and/or wasting food. The breakfast potatoes are served tossed with whole cloves of roasted garlic. In the words of the illustrious Forest Gump, that is all I have to say about that.

Minus a star for the sometimes painful wait. Not their fault, but it can suck. I recommend hitting Zazie early if you want to get in right away. They open at 9 and there is usually a line of people waiting.
author: Angie R.

description:
A wonderful and sunny New Year's Day and a brunch at Zazie was a wonderful welcome-back-to-the-city meal after a few weeks of vacation.

I had the Eggs Albert and had a bite of my friend's French Toast Tahiti. Both of them are great. Creamy, Tasty, and not overly-greasy for the Albert, and Sweet and savory for the French Toast. 

It's my second time here and seated indoor this time. Both experiences are great and would definitely come back.
author: Andy W.

description:
Oh how I miss Zazie!

When I lived in the neighborhood I would have a late breakfast here at least 3x a week....  It can be hectic and crowded on the weekends but the food is so tasty!  The garden in back is pretty great too!
Recommendations: 
-any of the eggs w/ hollandaise sauce on them
- the pancakes, either the buttermilk or gingerbread 

(it's making me hungry just thinking about it)

Last call for breakfast/ lunch is 3pm so get there before then!

Hint: the 2 tables in front are first come, first serve so if there is a wait and one opens up, just grab it and voila- no waiting!
author: Tera H.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend's family for Sunday brunch at around 9:45 in the morning.  Probably the absolute worst time of day to go!  But despite this, the wait wasn't unbearable, and the people, dogs, and strollers outside were great for people-watching.  (Parking was apparently a pain, so it'd be a good idea to drive out in front and unload some people to write your name down on the list while the driver goes around and looks for a space.)

I got the French Toast Tahiti, and other meals at the table included omelets and poached eggs.  They were all delicious and filling.  Decor and atmosphere are great, though I have yet to sit on the patio.  

All in all, it was a good experience.
author: Rick B.

description:
I had a lovely dinner here last night on the back patio.  Space is tight in this cozy venue (both inside and out), but it makes for a great vibe and also a good spot for a date.

I found the food to be quite good, mostly French but with a lot of California influence.  My group had the fig/cheese appetizer and thought it was great -- even the balsamic/fig dressing on the side greens brought forth a few "Mmmms."  I had the burger for my entree and describe it as very good.  The meat was of high/tasty quality and the potatos also quite palatable.  We finished off with the "Cheese & Chocolate" dessert and I'd recommend the Zinfadel truffles to anyone (made in-house, according to the menu).  Decent wine list and very helpful and friendly staff.

Overall, I'd say it's a lovely SF dining experience.  I wouldn't rate is as a favorite in the City, but I will definitely return.  Hopefully with a date.  heh.
author: Zack L.

description:
Usually I try to steer clear of restaurants that have bathrooms in such close proximity to the kitchen. But Zazie is different. I kinda don't care that the bathroom is pretty much sitting IN the kitchen. I kinda don't care that the wait times push the limits of cool. Because when the sun is shining in Cole Valley on a lazy weekend morning, all I want to do is be at Zazie, in the courtyard out the back, swimming through mountains of eggs with dungeress crab and mimosas. Last time I was at Zazie, my friend Katia drank FOUR mimosas while waiting for the food to arrive (don't worry, she's Ukrainian). Now, most places would give you a dirty look for that kind of drinking before midday,  but Zazie just asks...shall i bring another? 
And that's why it doesn't matter where the bathroom is, all that matters is that it works.
author: Shan M.

description:
Most people know about Zazie for its famous brunch selection - their crab eggs benedict is to die for. As is their french toast. And somehow, they even make the basics a bit better...their smoked salmon/cream cheese bagel is always toasted perfectly and fresh as can be. They even offer a "make your own mimosa" option, which has caused for many a tipsy sunny afternoon. Whoops. Regardless, Zazie knows brunch.

But they also know dinner. Their menu, while changing occasionally, maintains a core offering that - while not extensive - still beckons indecision every time you go. Which, in my case, is weekly. 

Tuesday nights are No Corkage Fee night (a "secret" I'm somewhat loathe to share as to not lose our favorite patio table) and they offer a prix fixe menu that often wins my vote.  Their burger is always cooked perfectly; the mussels, delectable; and the cheese plate? Let's not start on the cheese plate. I LOVE THE CHEESE PLATE.

Not only is the food outstanding, but the service also follows suit. Suhail (the manager) always greets us by name and Jeff (often working weekday evenings) is amiable, prompt and genuinely friendly. 

Though it may be a bit of a trek to get there, it's worth the N-Judah train or MUNI bus 6 ride to enjoy the food and the experience. Or, if you love it as much as I do, feel free to follow my lead: move around the corner. 

You won't be disappointed.
author: Aubrey S.

description:
It's GOOD.  And I absolutely love the fact that I can get one gingerbread pancake with lemon curd so I can try it for only $4.  I was at this restaurant last weekend at Stinson beach and had to buy a $9 mac and cheese to try a bit of it with my $11 entree.  When am I going to realize I don't make enough money to do that shit?  

Anyway, I had the nicoise and it was everything I want in a nicoise but the tuna was just okay.  It was a pale pink and was cut kinda thin.  I like nice red chunks of seared rare tuna in my nicoise.  But the dressing was perfect.  Even the olives were the perfect nicoise olives.

My mom was visiting and had a benedict with bacon- the mexico or something.  I was happy that the bacon didn't lose its crisp.  The hollandaise was pretty good.  

I will be back for that BLT.

I was going to give it 4 stars for it being good but not spectacular then I remembered the variety of mimosas- I had hibiscus or something- it was delicious AND I really do appreciate the way they let you have one, two or three cakes and egg dishes and stuff.  Very cool.  And that back patio is fantastic.  And my waiter was just plain adorable.
author: Staci M.

description:
UPDATE: +1 star, because the owner actually read my review and responded personally.  Boom!

What a great joint to have as your local eatery.  I live around the corner from Zazie and rely on it as my mainstay for quality, mid-priced and low-key dining.  Though  Zazie is well-reputed for its brunch (Gingerbread pancakes and benedicts mainly), their dinners are just as good.

It's french-california fare.  Warm food pairs excellently with the butt-ass cold of a December evening in SF.  The coq au vin was a bit meh; not quite Absinthe caliber. The back patio (the oft undiscovered gem of many SF restaurants) is leafy, cozy and romantic (and has heat-lamps praise the lord).

Zazie feels like a local restaurant, and I'm glad to see it's gotten Yelp love in spite of it not being a high-profile or "hip" establishment.  It's got a downright cheap prix-fixe ($23 bux) and you can bring your dog to dinner on Monday nights.

This is a four-star restaurant, except for the fact that it's the holiday season and they are blaring some seriously trite Christmas music.  I ain't no hater but c'mon guys, that's not terribly cosmopolitan.  I like my food tasty and my soundtrack secular.   The religious tunes @ Zazie detract from an otherwise cozy, classy and consistently enjoyable default for most eating occasions.  I still recommend the restaurant, and I'm sure I'll change my rating to four stars as soon as the seasons change too.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Sometimes the wait at Zazie can be long, sometimes not so long at all.  It doesn't matter because its well worth the wait.  Iv'e gone to Zazie for Brunch and for Dinner.  Waitstaff is so nice and atentive.  The specials were so good there.  I had Gingerbread pancakes that melted in my mouth and a huge portion of them at that, and the time I went for dinner and had the braised rabbit with a savory pasta of some kind that was simple, elegant, and superb.  

Dinner Tip:  Great for late dinner at 9pm, perfect because its not crowded at all and you can grab a drink or two next door at Finnegan's Wake if you skip dessert.    Hooray for Zazie!
author: Dave M.

description:
A good place for breakfast with lots of choices that go way beyond your plain buttermilk pancakes and boring omelets. 

This place is not close to us at all, so we made it a destination. The line was a little longer than we would have liked, but the staff was friendly and got our order quickly, which helped make the wait worth it. 

I wish I would have gotten one of the eggs benedict dishes, as they blew my taste buds away in a tasty way. Next time...
The gingerbread pancakes were delish, but a bit dry. The Tahiti French toast a little sweet - but overall, I was truly impressed with this place that used their imaginations to make breakfast a culinary adventure.
author: Erin M.

description: Great food, but long wait.  We waited for brunch today (Sunday), and had to wait approximately an hour with 4 people.  It is nice there is a Tully's a couple doors down to grab a coffee while waiting, and today there was a bluegrass band playing on the sidewalk.  It was well worth the wait.  Everyone loved their meals.  We got the chorizo scramble, crab benedict, french toast and gingerbread pancakes.  The poinsetta and Cole Valley drinks were very tasty and refreshing.
author: Rise G.

description:
I've been there for a farewell lunch... my farewell lunch. 
This place is a little small and noisy, but it gets a very good atmosphere. Concerning the food, everything (from the mediterannean salad to the burger, and the lemonade) was really good but PLEASE... this place has nothing to do with french cuisine!!
author: Christine C.

description: Usually we go to Zazie for brunch, but this time it was for dinner. The dinner menu changes from time to time at Zazie, and we had a wonderful selection of dishes this time - First of all, I can recommend the traditional French onion soup as the best I've ever had. The salad was piquant and delicious, served with the restaurant's wonderful vinaigrette dressing. For entrees, we had the pasta was excellent (we had it without the prosciutto), the stuffed chicken breast (mushrooms & spinach) served over mashed potatoes was delicious, and the trout was also perfectly prepared. We shared creme brûlée for dessert. As you can predict, they serve wonderful coffee. The highlight of our evening was the waitperson. Zazie has recently switched to a tip-free policy, and we asked a couple of the waitstaff what they think of it. They seem VERY happy with the new policy, and to be honest, I don't think I've ever encountered a more cheerful and helpful wait person. To top it off, bc it was my husband's birthday, she comped the dessert. We had a GREAT time!!
author: Eileen A.

description:
I must say, I really have been excited to go to this place forever and find the idea of eating in a bistro-like a good idea.  Having live in France, I used to go to the great "La Coupole" in Paris...but the only nice point for this place is that it looks cute on the outside and the long lines (prepare to wait 30 minutes in line) beckons to you as if there was something in there that perhaps is worth the wait..    Throw a couple of cute French photographs on the wall, some French-inspired décor and a patio with ambient lighting, but don't be fooled.   This is only pretty much as good as a French "IHOP."  I respect the restaurant industry and how hard they work, and simply only ask for a few things for my money and time:  Quality food, and service.  The dishes are not what they live up to, very dismal and soul-less.   I wish restaurants would return back to basics, simple and delicious, instead of overdoing a French toast or pancakes with overwhelming, inconsistent flavors.  I had a cold egg dish I could have made at home and split the gingerbread pancakes with my friend for a truly disappointing finale.  The cream that came with my coffee seemed like it had expired and was thick and poured out slowly.   Another detail: the waiter was one of the most unpleasant person I've ever seen in this kind of job.    The service staff to guest ratio is very low and it takes forever to get something, as well as get out of there. 

Only nice point : the place is good looking and looks pretty much as good as a real brasserie and they are dog-friendly.   

My advice:  Don't waste your time.  With all the breakfast cafés in SF, skip the line, and take back some of your morning.  In fact, the Bambino's or La Boulangerie next door is better and you  won't have to wait in line.
author: Lauri C.

description: Oh my goodness was this place good!!  Went with 2 others & we all ordered different brunch items so that we could try a few different things...there wasn't a crumb left on anyones plate.  Our waitress was truly nice & helpful...had everything we needed very promptly.  I also must say that I was extremely impressed with how quickly they were able to seat us outside.  There was a pretty good sized crowd waiting & we only had to wait about 10 mins to get a table.  Parking was a little difficult but I figure that's just part of getting around in the city.  This is definitely one of our "go-to" places now.  Love it!!
author: Anne R.

description:
Zazie's a great neighborhood staple. I've only been for dinner and the food is reasonably priced and very tasty. Nothing to knock your socks off, but very satisfying and affordable.

The prix-fixe at $23.50 is a great deal. We almost always get the Mussels Marinieres which might be the best thing on the menu. The Le Canard is tender and the fingerling potatoes that come with it are delicious. Also great is the Zazie Burger- they put roasted tomato on top, which is a brilliant way to save tomatoes from their winter mediocrity. The side of Mac and Cheese is tasty but probably not something I'd order again, as is the Pot de Creme on the dessert menu.
author: Allison S.

description: My friend and I met up here for a weeknight dinner. I'd heard this place was popular for brunch but was turned off by the lines. When I saw it featured on Check Please! though for dinner, I wanted to try it out for myself. Great service and tasty French bistro food. We were seated on the heated garden patio which had a relaxed and enchanting atmosphere. The coq au vin and boeuf burgoneon were tender, well-seasoned and filling. If I have more of an appetite next time I'll try the pre fixe menu, a bargain at $27 for a half-sized appetizer and dessert plus a full-sized entree. Definitely recommend for casual dinner with a friend or loved one!
author: Katrina S.

description:
Aside from the ridiculously long wait--90 minutes for a party of four, it was a fabulous brunch. This was my second visit to Zazie, and the food was delicious. Melt in your mouth french toast, a fruit spritzer and a poached egg...mmmmm. 

I'll definitely be back, but maybe trying out dinner or lunch?
author: Jenn G.

description:
7x7's list of 100 things to try in SF before you die includes eggs benedict on the back patio of Zazie and I'm trying to work this list very literally so I was nervous it would be too cold or too crowded or too whatever for me to fully cross it off my list but we were in luck! I'm sure the wait would be a killer on the weekends but we were able to walk in at 10AM on a Friday morning and score the last table on the patio. The beautiful sunny weather was a bonus.

I thought their hollandaise was missing something, but I liked that I was able to order my eggs benedict with one, two or three eggs which left room for a miracle pancake (also available in a variety of quantities). 

Also notable:

* The miracle pancake (poppyseed, I think?) should have been on the list instead of the eggs.

* The back patio really is something special.

* The potatoes, while greasy, are awesome and garlicy.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Good flavorful food, variety of options on menu, service, waiting time... I'll give it a 5 starts all together! The good thing about this place is you can chose your meal size on almost everything from the menu, from 1 to 3 eggs. 

I am a Florentine fan and this place has at least 5 different options to chose from! I got mine w/ salmon, capers and red onions with a side of spring salad. Yum! The poached egg was cooked to perfection and the hollandaise sauce was very light. It was perfect amount since I only ordered 1 egg, but next time I'll get 2 because that's a better deal, plus I can easily handle it if it tastes good like that! Aaron had a Greece scrambled eggs with spinach, feta, and red onions with a side of homefries. This was also flavored light but tasteful.  Eggs were cooked nice and fluffy, and the raw crunchy onions added the nice texture to it. The homefries were soft (not burned like other places) and nicely flavored.

No wonder why this place gets a good review. I will add this place on my favorite brunch list in SF for sure!
author: Cartman P.

description:
Yup, this place was pretty decent, although my review is going to be narrow by necessity: I only tried one item. It was totally delicious though: the fish soup, perfect on a damp and gloomy evening. I'm Bengali and I love "macher jhol", so I've been sampling fish stews whenever possible. Savory, tomato-y, and utterly comforting. I wish they swapped out mussels for more chunks of tender snapper, but that's just my personal mussel animosity talkin'. Crisp bread with jalapeno butter? Delicious, and kicky.

I liked the small intimate space, and the way a fellow diner busted out a tuneful "Happy Birthday" for his companion, with extra vocal flourishes added by the waiter. The same waiter who turned butterfingers and knocked over our water jug twice. I forgive you dude, no worries (I moved fast and didn't get wet). :-) 

If only I didn't have to keep reminding myself of that bridesmaid dress ... I would come back here again and again and eat my way through the menu. Life is unfair.
author: S R.

description: I went for dinner with couple girl friends, the place is very simple, not much ambience.  Overall food experience was positive, the mussels were done nicely with this creamy sauce that I have never tasted in other restaurants; however, the pork chop was a bit dry.  I would be willing to return for another try.
author: AJ W.

description: Alright I've been here for dinner and had an OK experience with a prix fixe menu. But I just came here for brunch this past weekend and it was GREAT! I had the Mexican scramble with soyrizo and it was really good. My friend had the La Mer, which is eggs benedict with crab and avocado. We shared the cream cheese coffee cake, which honestly I could have finished on my own (and would have skipped the omelette for). What's great about the menu was that there was a huge selection, which is not always the case for cutesy brunch places. I also love that they have really great outdoor seating! Our waiter was smiley, my coffee was hot, and I would definitely go back!
author: Shirley L.

description: I went to Zazie with my parents and boyfriend, and the experience was absolutely delightful. The prices were moderate, yet the staff was exceptional. The vegetarian option was superb, and creative, which is rare for a French-inspired restaurant.  It was doggie night, so if you do not like dogs do not go on Mondays. If you do like dogs, you'll be entertained with cute pupperschmupper after another as they parade through to the gorgeous back patio.
author: Mark S.

description:
This is it, man.

Great brunch, outdoor patio seating. Wonderful. I've been to Zazie a few times now and I haven't been disappointed with their Brunch menu. 

French Toast Tahiti - Really good, but not mind-blowingly delicious.

Gingerbread Pancakes - Fantastic. Really tastes great with the pears.

Croque Madame sandwich - !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!.....Sorry, I'm a man of few words. The french style ham and cheese sandwich with an egg on top is fuckin amazing. You need to try this.

My only complaint is that I honestly feel like the menu is SLIGHTLY overpriced. I mean one slice of french toast is like 5 bucks, two slices is 10, and three is around 13. Don't get me wrong, this is fantastic breakfast and brunch food, but let's be real - the portions aren't gigantic. Regardless, I still planning on giving Zazie my money. Fantastic place, and you have to sit in the backyard to really get the full experience.
author: Edmund C.

description: This place was good but I was not too impressed. We had a long wait and then when I got my food, the croque monsieur, it wasn't that good. I've had much better croque monsieurs before. Also the pancakes were ok. I will say that the drinks were very yummy and so was the side of fried potatoes. And our waiter was very nice!
author: Andrea P.

description: Tell me what is more perfect than sitting outside on a patio on a rare sunny day in San Francisco? Uhhh.. NOTHING! Combine that with a delicious brunch and you got yourself a winner
author: Sophia C.

description:
I haven't sampled their breakfast/brunch menu, but I will speak briefly on their dinner menu.

Went here for a friend's birthday dinner and ordered from their prix-fixe menu - selected appetizer, entree, and dessert for $23.50.  I had the mussels for the appetizer and mmmmmmm!!  I don't normally order mussels or seafood at restaurants (I love seafood, but I just don't normally order them), but the sauce the mussels came in was so creamy and delicious!  I wanted to just drink it!  Actually, I did drink it a little bit.  I know, I'm kind of disgusting.

Then I got the mascarpone polenta entree and honestly, I wasn't sure what I was expecting.  I liked it, because I like polenta and the marinara sauce was good, but I didn't love it.  I felt like... it fulfilled expectations yet it didn't fulfill expectations?  Something like that.

For dessert, I had the warm fruit crumble.  It was an apple crumble and tasted like nice, crusty, warm apple pie.  Quite enjoyable.

Definitely want to try their breakfast/brunch menu one of these days.  I will be back, Zazie, I will be back.
author: L Y.

description: Every review for Zazie seems to be "brunch, brunch, brunch"...guess what, they serve DINNER too (they take reservations for dinner). If you have not been to Zazie for dinner, you have not been to Zazie. This is a very quaint and cozy French restaurant tucked away in Cole valley in San Fran. It's not fancy or pretentious, it's just a simple bistro  with surprisingly decent food.  Zazie is a great place for a casual meal or maybe a glass (or bottle) of wine with a few appetizers. Perfect for couples or small parties (4-6 people). The menu here doesn't disappoint. They have a very nice selection that should satisfy most needs and wants. Their mussel appetizer was very nice and the waitress even brought extra bread (without being asked to do so) just so we could sop up all the delicious broth. In addition, the waitress also brought us wine samples while we attempted to decide upon a wine selection, so the service was excellent. Dishes at the table included trout, pork chop, duck and the fish soup. All items were very well prepared and tasty and fairly authentic. While we were all too full to order dessert, the dessert menu also looked very appealing. Had I not been so full by the end of my meal I would have happily tried Zazie's Pot De Creme. I did however manage to choke down a latte. This was no easy task because the latte's here are HUGE. They're served in a large bowl (no handle) and while you might expect such a large latte to be quite milky and weak, my latte packed a punch. In fact I'd say Zazie is worth checking out for their latte's alone! If you've only been to Zazie for brunch, it's definitely worth a visit for dinner. And if you've never been to Zazie, it's a great place to have a lingering meal in the city.
author: Eric C.

description: ate here for dinner, had a reservation and arrived early so we got in right on time. ordered the cheese plate, romaine salad, onion soup, steak and potatoes, risotto, flourless chocolate cake and creme brulee. halfway through the meal i told my husband "we're coming here again." the food was amazing. and i liked that the restaurant was all about the food--they're not trying hard to impress you otherwise. the food is mostly French, if you aren't getting that info from other reviews. and it's really really good.
author: Senta C.

description: Dog friendly patio, great friends, tasty food, and perfect service as always. The menu could use some refreshing, though, as one can eat a "favorite dish" only so many times. Some of the menu items don't sparkle.
author: T G.

description: Had New Years Day Brunch today. 1.5hr wait but it was worth it. Friend had Poached Eggs and I had a New York Scramble. Bother were excellent. French toast Tahiti stuffed with banana and walnuts as well as buttermilk pancakes were great. Original and fresh. Service was excellent. I'm pretty picky about brunch and it was excellent. A gem in Cole Valley, will go again.
author: Mark C.

description:
Fantasitc patio!  Service and consistency...well....a bit questionable.  After an amazing dinner on the patio a few months ago, we went back and had an average meal with really bad service.  Being a former waitress, I am usually patient to a fault (I tend to get annoyed when my dining partners complain about service), but this was pretty bad.  We were ignored, food was served cold, and drinks were never refilled.  I am willing to forgive and try it again.  This MAY have something to do with the fact that they serve up incredible creme brulee that I sometimes dream about.  

Despite the drawbacks, Zazie has a great menu, charming ambiance, and one of the best patios around...all tucked into little unassuming Cole Valley.
author: Abby W.

description:
I love Zazie.  It is pretty, with pretty flowers and pretty servers and yummy food.  I like to go early, so I am seated and sated before the weekend morning hangover crowd even gets up.  

On the occasions when I am a member of the weekend morning hangover crowd, I like to wear my giant sunglasses and really let my hair rat out, and then drink my giant latte bowl basking in the sun on the patio under the pretty flowers, thinking Frenchy thoughts in fake French.
author: Robyn C.

description:
I wasn't always a fan of the poached egg, but a brunch at Zazie was all it took to become a fiend.  Now, when I hear the words "poached eggs," my tastebuds go into shock and shoot a split-second sensory flashback to my brain of the Eggs Monaco at Zazie.  It's a killer combo of egg, prosciutto, and tomato that melts in your mouth and warms your insides (imagine a shot of really good tequila at a happy hour after a really tough day at work...oh man).  My experience here sets the standard for the perfect brunch in my book.

Their dinner is equally amazing, with regards to both food and service.  The boyf. and I dined here on a Sunday evening at ~5pm and were seated promptly.  From the pate, to the mussels, to the dinner rolls, to the pork chops, to the creme brulee and souffle (yes, we ordered two desserts, and I finished them BOTH, sucka), every dish was creatively-crafted, fresh-tasting, and so delicious!  The samplers are the way to go because you're gonna want to try everything anyway.  Do not skimp!  Make room for dessert and go all out because you'll be so glad that you tried everything.

***WOMAN-TALK ALERT:
Seriously the BEST way to end your last day of PMS-ing.  When the bottomless pit calls, you must answer!
author: Andrea U.

description:
Gingerbread Pancakes topped with Lemon Curd & Bosc Pears... YUMMMMM

The pancakes are huge! I ordered 2 pancakes ($10) and was already full after the first...so if you do not have a ginormous appetite, go with one pancake. I have not seen Gingerbread Pancakes on the menu at any other restaurant... these were delish! Ask for extra syrup since the pancakes are thick and soak em right up!

My friends ordered the Mexican Scramble and the Eggs Benedict, and they were both very happy with their food, and very happy with me choosing Zazie for brunch. (They also mentioned that the potatoes that came with their eggs were very good, but I didn't get to try em.)

Just a few notes: Expect a bit of a wait for a table (we waited at least half an hour), but the food is worth it and they have a wide variety of options on their brunch menu. The service wasn't bad but wasn't exceptional or anything worth noting. Our server didn't check back on us to see how we were doing. The restaurant is also very casual on the inside, nothing fancyschmancy...just laid back. Parking in the area can also be very hard to find.
 
I will be back again to try the French Toast Tahiti, as well as some of their scrambles! Zazie makes me wish I could have brunch everyday!



********UPDATED REVIEW 3/24/08:

OMGGGGG OMG OMG OMG THE CROQUE MADAME!!!!!!!!!!

That's all I hafta say.
author: Felicia C.

description: I have been there twice since it very close to my home. I went there on Saturday morning at around 10, waiting for like half hour. The food is ok. For the french toast, I will prefer red door; for the omelete, I will go to mama's. For me, it not worth to wait that long. I love the baked potates thought, that's the only thing I remember.
author: Carol X.

description:
It was Saturday at around noon and my friend wanted breakfast for lunch so we searched Yelp and lo and behold we found great reviews for Zazie. We were a little hesitant about the wait but she made a phone call and found out that there was only a 15 min wait. 

They seated us in what felt like less than 15 min. We walked back to the cute patio area in the back. It felt cozy and just perfect for a sunny day. I had the Eggs Monaco with prosciutto and tomatoes provencales. It was delicious! Friend had the Gingerbread Pancakes. It's something that I would never order but they were awesome!!!
author: Anna H.

description: Zazie's is SO good.  I LOVE to come here for brunch.  If you have the time and the patience to wait for a table (it can take up to an hour), it is so worth it!  I love to get thier daily special, last time it was spinach, eggs, potatoes all coked together in a dish and topped with some special sauce - so delicious!  Their coffee cake is so amazing, great with their coffee.  Have never been disappointed with a trip to Zazie's, only wish I could go more often!
author: Carly P.

description: This is my place of choice for romantic brunches! The last time I came here was after running the Bay to Breakers, and there were quite a few other customers who had also run the Bay to Breakers. My favorites here are the omelettes, especially the one with goat cheese. The wait here is usually pretty long, but it is worth the wait.
author: Gregory S.

description: Minus one star for the wait but.... The gingerbread pancakes were amazing!
author: Ana M.

description:
This is my favorite brunch place in the city.
The pancakes are wonderful.
author: Ky W.

description:
I'll keep it short and simple. 

Long lines on weekends - tolerable if you go next door to Finnegan's Wake and get one of their awesome Bloody Marys. If you ask nicely Mario will even come over to the bar to get you.

So far nothing has let me down. I'm particulary fond of their pancake, eggs and bacon combo. The coffee cake, served warm, is lovely. 

Can't wait to have dinner out on the patio sometime.
author: keith h.

description:
We met some friends here for brunch last weekend and it was a good experience, but not worth the hype or the drive for us.  I had a gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and roasted pear plus a side of eggs.  To drink I ordered the zazie spritzer (cranberry, oj, seltzer).  Everything was good, but really nothing spectacular.  The bathroom, however, was the opposite of good.  There's only one - it's co-ed, about 2 feet from the kitchen pass-through window, the door slides closed and there's about a 1 inch gap most of the way around, it closes by one tiny hook latch, and there is exactly enough room inside for you to turn around in place.  Fine if you're a guy.  I'm not.

UPDATE***
After writing my review above I got an email from the owner explaining the bathroom situation.  Apparently Zazie is housed in a historic school building and bound by codes when it comes to remodeling, which prevents them from improving the bathroom situation.  I thought it was super cool of her to write, so I thought I'd give Zazie another try.  Met a girlfriend here for lunch with her 3 month old during the week.  This seems to be THE place to be if you have a small child at that time.  I ordered the burger and she had the croque madame.  Food was good, service was good, atmosphere was pleasant.  Still not 4 stars, but I definitely have a warmer opinion of the place and love that the owner is internet savvy and cares about her business.
author: Jen T.

description:
Damn you, Zazie, for being so popular!  Unless you get up "early" for weekend brunch (and by early I mean before 10) be prepared to wait.  And wait.  At least I can peek out my bedroom window to see how many people are crowded around outside.  But oh, the food makes it so worthwhile, and hey, all those peeps must be waiting for a reason.  They have what I think are the best egg dishes in the city, and although I haven't been there for lunch or dinner, the menu looks really tempting.  Plus their back patio is warm and cozy on those rare sunny SF mornings.  Definitely one of my favorite breakfast spots.

EDIT:  So, now I've been here twice for dinner and yep, it's as awesome as their breakfast.  Hooray!  They have a prix fixe option every night for dinner, and for $21.95 you get an appetizer, an entree, and a dessert.  It's a kickass deal, my friends.  And Monday nights are bring your dog night, and Tuesday there's no corkage for wine.
author: Leslie R.

description:
Most people rave about the brunch here...but since I'm unable to wake at the crack of dawn in order to beat the brunch wait-list, I'll rave about their dinner.

The first time I visited, my boyfriend and I had two out-of-town guests in tow...rather than taxi-ing their already taxed souls around town, we wandered a couple blocks down to Zazie and, in turn, found mecca for our hungry souls.

A fantastic, totally reasonably priced wine list welcomed us.  We shared a pinot gris from the Williamette Valley to wash down an appetizer of fresh-from-the-sea mussels, in a buttery, garlicky, sinfully creamy delicious sauce and piping hot rolls that had us begging for more.

Also ab/fab is their french onion soup - piping hot, tons of melted cheese on top, yum, yum, yum!

Favorite entrees on that night (and other nights since) include:
*Black truffle raviolis (note: these are no longer on the current menu - this is the only reason for the minus 1 star, as they were absolutely gorgeous!)
*Grilled pork trop - huge and delicious!
*Grilled duck breast - perfectly cooked, medium rare and juicy
*Braised beef shanks - fall-off-the-bone fantastic
And so on and so on and so on...

For dessert, look no further than their "delirious" chocolate dish...the baked chocolate chaud...holy crap.  I've been to Zazie at least 6 or 7 times and no matter how full I am, I have to get this - delicious, warm chocolate with perfectly browned marshmallows on top - need I say more?  Delirious is an absolutely appropriate word.

Don't miss their outdoor patio in the back - on a warm or cool night (heating lamps work their magic) it's a wonderful little treat in this otherwise chilly area of the city.

Zazie - I love you.
author: Kati S.

description:
Yardy-yar, it's cute and all, but the FOOD ain't there. I ordered a poached egg Christophe, and it came out cold, with an over-medium poached egg that seemed like it was pre-poached, some cold shredded cheese that wasn't melted, and a hollandaise tasted like water. Not so great. 

The space, on the other hand, is the most adorable use of a restaurant indoor/outdoor space in that hood. Nice job.
author: Libby T.

description: Oh-ver-ray-ted. Their tahiti waffles that everyone raves about were ok; definitely not "wait-in-line-for" good. The potatoes that everyone praises were good, but mouth-orgasm inducing? I think not. Get ahold of your taste buds people! Overall good, but I wouldn't wait in line for their food. Pricey meal... Breakfast for two with tax/tip came out to a pretty hefty penny.
author: Maria C.

description:
Loved my meal here today.  I had a great sandwich with black forest ham, gruyere cheese topped with an egg.  The flavor was eye rollingly delicious.  Who doesn't love a good cheese?  Service was quick and friendly.  I was lucky enough to have the most fabulous company, but I didn't let that cloud my judgement.  Well worth a visit!

The place was packed at lunch in a bad economy.  What's that tell you?
author: Scott A.

description: if you like amazing variations of the ultimate breakfast meal , Eggs Benedict , you need to come here. There are combos that I never thought of but wish I had because they are awesome and I wish they were everywhere. Also great mimosas. I take one star off because it's super expensive, I get it's quality, but it's mostly known for breakfast fare and so It's kinda crazy to spend close to 80 bucks for breakfast and some drinks.
author: Lauren V.

description:
This is the kind of place I go to with only a couple people and we order a bunch of deliciousness and you eat a little something of everything because its all so delicious. 

Banana glazed french toast is the best- and I hate french toast.
author: Janel M.

description:
Setting: Warm and rustic feeling french bistro in chilly cole valley.  Has a lovely back heated patio.

Menu favorites: Cream cheese coffee cake! Divine. I hesitated adding this to the review because they make a limited quantiy each weekend.  Just save me a warm slice of this rich cake with sweet crumbly topping.  For the indecisive pancake fans, try the pancake flights.  You'll get to sample all three of thier specialty flap-jacks.  
I also enjoy Zazie for dinner.  I am not one to opt for burgers on a diverse menu like Zazie's but the roasted tomato on top sold me.

The damage: I've spent $15-$30 here.

The weekend lines are long, which is to be expected.  But, it's also a great place to go and spend a leisurely weekday morning if you can.  It's very cozy and the servers are friendly and helpful.
author: Lauren W.

description: Lunch dates with  the hubby are always the best, especially @ this cute little french bistro.  Arrived at  alittle after 1 pm, waited for 10 mins.. SCORE!! Our server is a sweetheart, warm and very friendly. We ordered the burger and croque  royale and cup of coffee.. My hubby got the burger with garlic potatoes, it was tasty/juicy and the way he liked it medium rare. For me, croque royale topped with an egg, wow delish!!!  Definitely worth to dine...
author: Tess C.

description:
Only during the week, they serve a hamburger that is hands-down the best in town. And I'm a Texan, from the land where beef is king. It takes a lot for a burger to impress me!

The ambiance is very cute, great place to sneak away to during work, and makes you feel like you're on vacation. Very mellow, bright, upbeat. Good bloody maries! Crowded on weekends.
author: Cate F.

description:
Ok, since my last review, i have changed my mind.  I'm starting my new rating system in effect.  Five stars only if you're perfect!  That leaves few five stars.  I have been going to Zazie more often and i finally tried one of the benedict platters and realized why this place is awesome.  I hate poached eggs and i *crave* poached eggs from the zazie.  Plus, i have gotten to know the manager, Mario, especially well and realize that man works his tuckess off to make that place so awesome.  

So i have been here several times for breakfast, and the advantage with breakfast is that often you get it without the fuss, and fanfare of a busy dinner with other diners trying to snap up the waiter's attention before you can.  

The most redeeming part of Zazie is their Mango mimosas.  The second most redeeming quality is that i can order two eggs and a pancake of any kind and not have a plate served to me with a 5 egg omelet and a short stack.  They have the option on their menu to sample a little bit of everything (which i always encourage) in ones, twos and threes (olay!).  

So far i've tried the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd (huh?) and it was interesting, but the pancakes end up being too dry and the only reason you even want that lemon curd is because you need something to moisten the pancakes because the syrup doesn't taste quite right with them.  

I have also tried the lemon poppyseed pancakes that are only made occasionally and Damn!  Tha's all i can say.  Actually, i can say more.  Know how i mentioned the poached eggs?  i wanted more pancakes and that is just not like me....

Then there is the Zazie omelet (or omelette du jour) which adds some avocado atop a cheesy eggedness and bacon.  This is a really fantastic omelette.  I recommend toast, and a big belly.

The Pain Paradise is just that.  Cinnamon french toast with bing cherries.  I don't think i've had something so good in a long time!  

The home fries are actually garlic roasted potatoes with full cloves mixed in and top off an already delicious and satifying breakfast.  While it's all a little pricey, it's worth the portions that are ample and the creative strokes added to commonality.  
 
I have been lucky.  At opening hour, everyone has been amazingly considerate, except for the gruff "it's not 8 o'clock yet." when i try to sit down inside at 7:55.  When they get their game faces on, usually they get nicer.  But wait...now that i think about it....some of them can be a little ditsy when they get flustered with a group of 3 or more.....
Hmm.  I usually drink one of those mimosas and that all doesn't seem to matter anymore.
author: Andrea C.

description:
Great weather, nice neighborhood, and good food. This was actually my 2nd trek to Zazie, the first, however I left because it was too crowded. This time i actually waited, which was much much faster than I thought. Although loads of people were waiting outside and we were the 11th name down on the list, the wait was less than 15 min. I guess people either just leaves or eat very fast. The little bistro style restaurant was quite snug and crowded, but yet cozy. 

Menu was simple/typical brunch food, many egg dishes, pancakes, bagels, etc. I ordered the Greek Scrambled eggs, a buttermilk pancake, and a coffee. The egg came with a side of sauteed potatoes quarters and 2 slice of toasts. The portion was bigger than I expected, maybe I shouldn't have ordered the pancake. Overall food was good and the service was excellent. Downside, a bit pricy for breakfast food (comparable to Stacks) and parking was difficult.
author: Peter L.

description:
I love this place! The wait is really long on the weekends (sometimes up to an hour!), but the food is worth the wait! My favorite dish there is their smoked salmon eggs Benedict! I always get it when I'm there. Their pancakes are really moist and plump as well. I especially love their ginger pancakes. 

Everytime I'm craving to go out for Brunch, Zazie is the first place that pops into mind!
author: Hong N.

description: Ok.  I came to eat brunch here before my vaca was up this past August.  I loved the look of the place.  It was a very common french bistro.  There was a back garden area that my friend and I sat.  It was cozy and very cute.  We were the douche bags that came in 5 mins before they closed for brunch.  I was still drunk from the night before so my perception of time was clouded.  The waiter graciously welcomed us considering the fact....When that happens to me, I want to stab people who love to come and eat at a restaurant before closing.  Anyways, I had some poached eggs with chorizo and hash potatoes.  They also had a complimentary tomatillo sauce that was off the hook.  The food was nothing fancy, but well composed and flavorful dishes.  So Good.  We ate like kings drank mineral water, expresso, and a dam good Bloody Mary with a pickled string bean.  I really couldn't ask for more.  The service was optimal.  The guy was a great waiter.  I wish more places like this existed.
author: A K.

description: This place was good, but expensive.  A friend of mine recommended the poached eggs and i do too.
author: Danny C.

description: Had the Un, Deux, Trois: One buttermilk pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon  $9 (substitute challah french toast, specialty pancake, or chicken apple sausage add $2) and a side of Home-fries.  Opted for the challah french toast but also wanted to try the gingerbread pancake.  The bacon was sooo nicely done...very crispy just the way i like them.  The home fries were great and came with these crispy garlic bulbs.  The hot chocolate was a colossal serving and not overly sweet.  Cant wait to try other delish looking stuff on the menu.
author: she q.

description:
Best brunch in San Francisco. Period.

There are far too many fantastic things about Zazie to list them all- 
-the food is wonderful, not an item on the menu I wouldn't recommend
-the patio is lovely in good weather
-the staff is sweet and engaging- even when it's super busy

There's a reason the wait on a weekend morning can be 45 minutes or more- it's worth the wait. (The tables out front on the sidewalk are first come, first serve...)

Plus, it's a lovely place for a dinner date as well, with excellent wine and decadent desserts. I'm with Rosa D.- if I could, I'd eat here everyday.
author: A S.

description:
Love, love, love.

I was definitely experiencing withdrawal when Zazie closed for month to re-do their kitchen and am very happy to see them open again.

The first time I went to Zazie was a few years ago for brunch, and I will have to say that they just might have the best brunch selection in the City.  I have been back for brunch and still gush over their benedict selection, not to mention the different kinds of mimosas that can be ordered.

With that said, don't think that I'm dismissing their dinner options.  The Hanger Steak with (amazing) mashed potatoes is to fantastic, and always cooked perfectly.  Also, the pork chops with the red cabbage and bacon is worth trying.  But before all of this, you MUST start your meal with the French Onion Soup.  Mmm...The other night, we topped off our meal with an order of the Les Deux Cremes which brought back fond memories of Bill Cosby and Amelie...er, but not together.

Yum.  Let's go there again!
author: Selena F.

description: Quaint, romantic Zazie offers a warm ambiance for puppy love couples or a cozy candlelit dinner for good friends. My husband and I recently had dinner here with his parents and enjoyed a corner table by the window. The wine list was adequate and the food ample with tasty French dishes. It was a pleasant dinner - highly recommend it!
author: Jalyn F.

description: Awesome awesome place everyone. Can't rave enough about the food. The place is small...so there is a bit of a wait. If you go in a large party expect a v long wait....I was lucky went today and was alone.  I dont normally like going alone but the food was just too good.  I had a St. Troupe that was 2 poached eggs, salmon, onions on one of their delicious English muffins. The menu is unique and definitely a lot of things too try. I am already thinking of my next trip...and what I would order. For all you egg maniacs - they serve breakfast even for lunch! Price wise - w/ a coffee it was $20 - a bit on higher end but soo worth it.
author: Bhavin M.

description: I ate...had a piece of eggs benedict for first time and OMG, LOVED IT! I wish I ordered it but instead, I went with my usual, eggs, pancakes, and sausage. The pancake was kinda burnt on the bottom so I wouldn't recommend getting that. My friend ordered eggs benedict with crab and that was to die for too! Next time I go to San Fran, I'm stopping by Zazie's for breakfast!
author: Shirley H.

description:
In terms of decor, Zazie looks like a shabby chic little bistro that is crammed full of hip young artist and musician types.  Check out the patio too.  Very crammed but if you like to make friends, it's perfect.  

The food is actually more American diner than French bistro.  For starters, I dont recall seeing steak frites on the menu - isn't that the hallmark of a French bistro?  Instead, they have a hamburger on the menu, with home fries.  Hmmmm, how French....

A lot of brunch / egg dishes on the menu.  Big very sweet over the top rich French toasts and pancakes.  Hmmm... Reminds me of an episode of Diners, Drive-ins and Dives.  Pancakes with strawberries AND syrup, powdered sugar AND whipped cream?  Sure, pile it on!  How American!  Nothing wrong with that, but French bistro this is NOT.

Once these expectations are set right, I think this is a damn good diner.  Big portions, fresh food.  EXACTLY what I want in a diner.
author: Hoola H.

description:
Yummy egg dishes, the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had, and passable soju cocktails. The staff -- especially the amazing Mario -- is warm, friendly, and efficient. Don't be daunted by the long list at the door: I've never waited more than 20 minutes for a table for two. Try the back patio if it's sunny. 

Oh, and Monday nights you can bring doggies. Always fun if you and/or your friends have canine companions and you're looking for a friendly place to dine.
author: Bronwyn J.

description:
I am not sure whats up with all the buzz about this place? The food is just ok, and its somewhat expensive.

I had french toast, my husband had poached eggs, it was all not bad, but really not worth the buzz and the wait lines.  Every time we have gone there, we say, well maybe we ordered the wrong thing, and maybe we shall come back and give it another shot.  But after this weekend, I dont think we are coming back.  Either I dont get this place, or this place does not get me, oh well, cest la vie!
author: Anya T.

description:
The previous reviews already say how great this place is, so I won't repeat what you've already read. However, I did notice a few things that I thought would be helpful to share. First off, if you're going to have weekend brunch here, know how to ride the wait list wave. This place opens at 9am and by 9:10am every table is full. If you can't get there for 8:45am to put your name on the wait list, stay in bed an extra 45 minutes and show up at 9:45am to get a seat for 10am when the first wave exits. Get it? Good. 

Secondly, this is a tiny space where you need to play the tile game with the tables in order to wedge yourself into your seat. Don't get me wrong, it's cozy and cute, so it's all good, but god forbid you get seated next to one of those Hummer baby strollers - and if you have one, leave it home or get a ulock and secure it to one of the bike rails. 

Lastly, for those of you who like a hearty breakfast with meat, check the menu beforehand. While you might see one or two entries with ham and one with chicken apple sausage, there isn't a wide selection and most of the time it's added on an extra. Also, the brunch menu basically has three sections - pancakes/french toast, scrambles and eggs benedict (which are wonderful) and there isn't a lot of crossover, so don't have your heart set on a fried egg (is it even on the menu?) and french toast (one of my favorite combos) with the extra chicken apple sausage, cause it isn't there. Unless you order each individually, which, you know... is extra. 

Seriously though it's great food with friendly people in a cozy place on a great street. I guess that makes it extra special too.
author: Michael A.

description:
I found this little place through my friend who had yelped this place while I was in class. It is in Cole valley in SF and there was a little sign up sheet but the wait wasn't too bad when we got there; about 5- 10min around 130pm. The place was already packed and you can smell goodness from outside. Brunch was priced fairly and it's a little tight in this place but I'm here to talk about the FOOD!! YUMMY FOOD! It took a while for us to get our menus and I joked around with my friend telling him that maybe we were suppose to memorize the menu before we sat down and they were going to take our order. haha! We were in no rush and we were as patient as we could be but i think the next time i come here I hope to have the menu on our table as we get sat down. 

FOOD : I ordered the French toast with caramelized walnuts and bananas (2 stack) and it was DIVINE! divine i tell you! melt in your mouth. I didn't even pour half of the syrup. I'm a small, very petite lady (4'10) and I swear I could have had 3 stacks of their toast.

DRINKS: MIMOSA was really goood (it's about $7-8)

SERVICE: It was busy so I understand that our waiter was busy and I'm also a server so serving a full packed restaurant could also be hard esp if there are people sitting outside the front of the restaurant, back of the restaurant and inside.

I would definitely eat here again.
author: Iba N.

description:
ok, so you already know that Zazie has the biggest buzz going for it when it comes to SF breakfast places people rave about-

and you already know that because of the hype, you'd better prepare for a long line, and perhaps even think about wearing an adult diaper-

and you already know that if you have a baby girl, you are going to name her "Zazie" because the name is so darn cute.  (heck, you'll probably name him "Zazie" even if it's a boy.)   (heck, i'm changing my name right now!!!)

but is it really worth the wait???

well, after waiting 45 minutes on a saturday late-morning before finally getting a table, and finally sinking my teeth on a 3 mouth-watering poached eggs with smoked salmon and capers as well as an order of carmamelized banana french toast, and finally experiencing the explosion of flavors that will make your eyes go wide and your mouth say -- "ZAZIE"

the answer:

a resounding "YES".
author: Vince L.

description:
FIRST I LOVE THEIR TAHTI FRENCH TOAST-- LOVE IT -- LOVE IT!!
We went their for our New Year's dinner with friends and it was very nice, pleasant, festive atmospher. The meal was good, not great like their brunch. 
I went to the bathroom, which I am so surpised passes health code and saw a visible cock roach on the ground. I about lost my food! I love Zazie and now I am not sure if I will be able to go there. Yes, it is true alot of restaurants in the city have infestations, but for a local regular customer to see this weas devistating. 
I actually told the hostess, she was pleasantly shocked. 
I may not return for some time, but I had to get the news out there.
author: Kim K.

description:
I just absolutely LOVE Zazie.  The food is great and the service is ALWAYS fantastic.  My boyfriend and I frequent this place, mostly for breakfast during the week, but also for weekend brunch and dinner. My favorite breakfast items there are the oatmeal brulee and the lemon ricotta pancakes with the raspberry sauce.  These are both usually only offered during the week and the pancakes are part of a weekly rotating "miracle" pancake.
Besides the food I will have to say that "Mario" is absolutely great!  He is always very polite and helpful.  He acknowledges my boyfriend and I by name every time.  He goes above and beyond in customer service.  An absolute asset to Zazie.  We also love the female weekday waitress always friendly and very helpful.  This is the place to go for great food and great customer service.
author: Sarah J.

description: We finally tried this place during dinner one night and were lucky to get a table in the patio area.  Very tasty food, including the mussels (we couldn't stop dipping the french bread in the sauce).  We want to go back to try the brunch.
author: V B.

description: I loved Zazie! The food was wonderful and such excellent service. Plus the restaurant was situated in the most adorable neighborhood. The french music was a nice touch--a little slice of Paris! I can't wait to go back.
author: Julie T.

description: It's a cute cozy place with a good brunch.  The wait was pretty ridiculous though, about an hour for two people on Sunday for brunch.  But I like how the menu has three different portion sizes so you could taste more dishes without overfilling on food.
author: Elena K.

description: Where do I start? Went to dinner here last night for boyfriends dad's birthday. We walked in and were greeted with such kindness-as of if we had just come into someone's home. From beginning to end, our waitress guided us through the menu with recommendations of all sorts i.e. wine, food and desert! Words cannot express how good this place was. I save my breath and recommend it to anyone!
author: Marel M.

description: I went there for brunch. The line was getting long at 9:30am on Sunday. We managed to get in after 20 minutes wait. I loved the interior decor. And the menu was not too taxing. I ordered Une,Deux, Trios. Very good French Toast and the egg was not bad.  The coffee was a little strong for me, but then I was not a regular drinker. Overall, good brunch on Sunday.
author: Wing W.

description:
My great friend took me to brunch here before i flew back to OC. She mentioned that no matter what time of day you get to Zazie, there's always a wait. I figured this food must be decent if there are 20 people willing to wait to dine here.
We got in within 15 minutes and just glancing at the menu made my mouth drool. The descriptions made me want to try everything!!!! too bad i only have limited space in my stomach. so...I decided on a soju bloody mary (why not, i'm not here often), a tuna sandwich and french soup combo, creme brulee oatmeal (shared) and Zazie's house potatoes.
ONE WORD: AMAZING! The food was exactly as described, if not, the most amazing thing ive ever tasted!!! My favorite portion of the meal was the house potatoes! the whole roasted garlic cloves compliment the soft potato wedges and all the spices that cover them. i had them with ketchup and it was just deeeeeeeeelightful! My tuna sandwich and soup were a perfect complement to one another. I was expecting tuna from a can, but instead it was a seasoned grilled slab of tuna on a bed of fresh veggies and roasted tomato basil. I don't think words can explain my experience at Zazie. Just gotta try it for yourself!
I look forward to coming here on my next trip to sf! oh zazie how i love thee!
author: Alex T.

description:
I've been here before for brunch and it was fantastic ... BUT ... my recent discovery is the Tuesday Night special!   Zazie's features a set menu every night for $22, but once you start adding some wine, the price obviously jumps.  On Tuesdays - Zazie's offers one red and one white wine option for only $5.
