All in all - a great three course meal with wine for about $30 - its hard to beat that in SF.   

Everyone was super nice, by the way - walked in at 8pm on a Tuesday and was seated immediately.  Yes, I know - a Tuesday - big whoop ... but it made me feel special because every table had a Reserved sign on it.  Its all about how they make you feel ;)  Every course was delicious.  The mussels were nicely prepared and the salmon wasn't over done.  Also, creme brulee was crispy and creamy - just how I like it!
author: Lisa B.

description: Brunch'd here on Sunday after reading some really great reviews. There was a crowd waiting when I got there around 9:30 but the service was awesome and I didn't have to wait too long (which surprised me). Ordered poached eggs florentine- absolutely delicious! The French toast Tahiti was And the coffee was awesome! I wish I would've gotten some fresh fruit because everyone was getting it and it looked pretty good. Next time :)
author: Sah R.

description:
It is definitely safe to say that when asked to recommend my favorite brunch place to someone, I would say Zazie's.
Being there makes you feel good. The staff is happy, the patrons are happy, the walls are decorated with beautiful french posters and the food is unbeatable.
Zazie's is a cornucopia of everything that satisfies the mind and the senses..
The wait to get in is really, really annoying though. Its a long time to get in, maybe an hour or an hour and a half around noon. Its breezy and cold waiting outside, and hard looking at everyone cozy, warm and satisfied on the inside. I would recommend going around 2, the line really dies down.
So once I finally got inside, I overindulged. 
We got:
-French Toast Tahiti:  Pinkie's challah stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts..luscious, plump french toast..a sublime experience
-Lemon Blueberry Cornmeal Pancakes: a special, very special
- La Mer: with fresh hand picked dungeness crab, green onions, and haas avocados..a scrumptious version of Eggs Benedict, try it, trust me!
- Fresh Grilled Ahi Tuna Salad with tomatoes provencales, aioli, and sun dried tomato pesto with greens on toasted levain, one of the best I've found in the city!

For total satisfaction, go to Zazie's!
author: ariana t.

description:
I really enjoyed our breakfast at Zazie.  They have a quaint spot in a trendy neighborhood that draws quite a crowd on the weekends.  Thankfully our group arrived early for breakfast, so we didn't need to endure the famous wait that everyone talks about.

We sat inside and even though the space was small, I didn't feel crowded or like the other tables were joining us for breakfast.

I ordered the Croque Madame, which came out perfect!  The bread was so soft and the ham not to overwhelming.  The egg was perfectly cooked and the cheese not too overwhelming.  My boyfriend was tame and ordered the egg breakfast with sausage.  He said that everything was really good, but that he liked my Croque Madame better.

The prices were a bit...well, pricey.  Well worth it for the premier Croque Madame and excellent service!  Worst part about dining here...the parking is horrid!

I would like to go back and try their dinner menu and dining on the patio.
author: Christy L.

description:
Not a very good deal for the price you are going to pay for breakfast.  Coffee is $2.50 and ok, but the coffee at La Boulange across the street is better and only $1.75.  The food is not bad, but definitely nothing special.  Our breakfast for two came out to $45 (with 15% tip). I did order the Crab Cakes Benedict, which was probably the most expensive thing on the menu, and I was not impressed at all.

I will say it was very easy to get a table on a Monday morning though.
author: Jason C.

description:
I had heard people rave about the homefries at Zazie so I decided to order a side of home fries with my breakfast, a slice of Challah French Toast and a slice of French Toast Tahiti.

I was disappointed by the "homefries" at Zazie.  People might rave about the homefries, but the potatoes at Zazie aren't homefries.  Good homefries should be perfectly seasoned and crisp, almost fulfilling a "craving of French fries for breakfast" as my high shcool friend, Larry H., put it.  The potatoes at Zazie are roasted potatoes.  There is a huge difference. Roasted potatoes tend to not be crisp and made with olive oil and herbs.  The roasted potatoes at Zazie weren't bad, a 3 star rating, but if you are looking for my definition of homefries, you'll be disappointed with Zazie's potatoes.

The Challah French Toast was another miss for me, a borderline 3 rating.  Challah is usually a great choice of bread for French toast but the bread didn't absorb the egg enough for me, and the French toast, though not bad, didn't have any distinguishable flavoring or unique taste that would motivate me to order again.   

The French Toast Tahiti was very good, a solid 4 star rating.  The French Toast Tahiti is stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  The caramelized bananas are particularly delicious.  I would recommend ordering a full order of the French Toast Tahiti and skipping the "homefries" and Challah French Toast.
author: Josh K.

description:
I can't believe Sweetie and I haven't discovered this place yet.  It's right around the corner, but we've never gone.  It wasn't until his father (coming all the way from Marin) chose it for his birthday that we finally gave it a shot.  We've been looking for a restaurant in this neighborhood that has just killer food, and I'm glad we found one.  Won't have to truck off somewhere else to have a romantic date night now.  

The strawberry salad was delicious.  Sweetie's father ordered the mussels as his appetizer, and said it was amazing.  Sweetie had the burger, and they put a lot of thought into it.  Niman ranch beef, grilled tomato and provolone on top, and roasted yukon golds on the side.  I had the Pasta de Printemps.  I ordered it without the cheese, and that turned out to be a good thing, cuz they certainly didn't skimp on the butter and cream.  So delicious, though.  Fresh pea shoots, little tomatoes, and roasted almonds, with very tender fresh pasta.

The best part of the meal was the little birthday treat they brought for his dad.  We thought it was a chocolate mousse, but it was more of a ganache.  God, what a rich, wonderful dessert.  

Definitely coming back.
author: L. M.

description: For all of you people that just saw this place on check please bay area, just back off! Says while waving a knife, "I'll cut you!" Seriously, this place is mine and you can't have it. I have loved this place for years since I used to live in the Haight. It's already nearly impossible to go to brunch here so just stay in your own damn neighborhood. And it is true that every meal I have ever eaten here from brunch, lunch or dinner has been lovely. Two words: Gingerbread pancakes. That is all!
author: Sarah J.

description:
i love going to zazie for brunch! they have an outdoor seating area, and i've never had to wait for more than 20 minutes before being seated. they have a new electronic system where you sign in and can see how many people are in line before you. if they call your name and you aren't outside, they'll move on to the next group, but text you that your name was called. if you come back, you'll be put back in your original place on the list.

my friend and i went this morning, and although there were about 13 parties in front of us on the list, it only took 20 minutes to get seated. we were seated in the patio that has heat lamps, so you're warm even if the weather is bad...which is almost always.

i always get the gingerbread pancakes here! they are really big and i love how you can choose to buy 1, 2, or 3. the lemon curd and pear go perfectly with the gingerbread flavor!

we also tried the special, which was an omelette with chicken apple sausage, peppers, mushroom, and cheese that came with a side of super delicious, garlic home fries! soooo good!! it also came with toast and an orange slice :)

i have also tried the eggs benedict la mer. an english muffin topped with a poached egg, crab, avocado, and hollandaise sauce. i'm not a big fan of runny eggs, but this dish was great!

i love how their hot chocolate came in a bowl :) it's not very chocolatey, but a little on the milky side. their espresso drinks are good and really pretty.
author: Ji L.

description:
I love it here!  I only came here twice but both experiences were AWESOME!!!

I ate breakfast.  It was an eggs benedict with avocado and crab.  I do not recall what it was called...but it was awesome!  Have a hard cider along with your meal!  AWESOME!!!
I have had their pancakes!  Melt in your mouth!!  Buttermilk and the break pudding pancakes!  Mmmm...good.  My mouth is watering now.

Service was awesome.  We sat outside and the server was patient and quick!! He checked up on us frequently!

Ambiance.  Cozy.  I rather sit outside.  When I am sitting inside I feel cramped and hardly any space to move.  But then again when I sat inside it was a weekend morning.  

Parking.  As with any SF experience you must have a parking fairy on your side.  We just parked right around the corner with no effort in looking for parking!

Bon apetit!!!
author: Elisa O.

description:
Running, huffing, and puffing from the N-Judah MUNI Metro at the Carl & Cole stop, I burst into Zazie. My timely friend for which the dinner reservation was under was shockingly late! (Super punctual friends with a black belt in time management really stress me out.) The gracious host was very sweet to excuse my sudden burst into the restaurant that put a pause in everyone's conversation. 

The host was exceptionally professional and offered to seat me immediately. I politely declined, waited for my friends, and caught my breath outside. Since the French Bistro is without a wait area or bar, waiting in cramp spaces and saying, "excuse me" every other minute is not quite my thing. So I was glad my friend made reservations, highly recommended!

Once my friend found parking 20 minutes later, I reveled in relief and quickly calmed my nerves. Given such a delay, I thought we were at the host's liberty. Surprisingly, the host did not pull any stunt or attitude. Instead he treated us like any other punctual dinner patron and comfortably seated us up front behind the fish bowl window, the best spacious table, IMHO. Another point for great service.

Everything on the menu resonated with my palette that evening. To simplify my decision, I chose the prix fixe deal, comes highly recommended at a great value for $23.50 which covers an appetizer, entree, and dessert. The prix fixe dinner is available for every single dinner with no restrictions on day, hour, or portion.

That helped narrow my decision down to a pate de vollaile, fish soup provencale, and decadent vanilla creme brulee. My friends ordered mussels marinieres, salmon grillade, and petit pot creme au chocolat. The pate was wonderfully flavorful. 

Good gawd! I wonder if Zazie specializes in French seafood dishes. My fish soup included a juicy salmon. Although the menu listed sea bass, the wait staff did not mention the substitution, which was a bit odd, but the delicious dish made me quickly brush that "dust" off my shoulder. I tried my friend's succulent grilled salmon. I was expecting a dry texture, but the chef was able to seal in the moisture. All the seafood dishes tasted very fresh.

Finally the desserts topped off the great evening. The prix fixe is a fabulous deal to satiate even the hungriest patron! I would recommend this place in a heartbeat!
author: Cathy H.

description:
Ahhh, Zazie. So near my home, so near my heart. 

Okay, I'm just kidding. But it is near my house, which is wonderful because I don't ever have to find parking and don't have to experience driving out to Cole Valley only to see hoards of people in line for breakfast! Living close by actually means that I get to come here sometimes when there is no wait, and that is a fabulous thing. 
There are a zillion reviews for Zazie, so I won't bore you with the same old review, but I will list a few of my favorites and a few I'd rather not have ever again.

BEST: Eggs Albert (although I get my eggs scrambled), un deux trois with chicken apple sausage (did someone say "combo made in heaven?"), pancakes in general, provencal fish soup (the small bowl)

NO THANKS: Salade Betterave (it was not a cohesive salad and tasted thrown together, plus the beets weren't very good), Oatmeal Brulee (it was just a bit bland), the Scrambles in general are just too furiously scrambled... there is nothing delicate about them, which is important when scrambling eggs or else it winds up tasting like mush.

COMPLAINT: I think they should make more omelettes and they should make their omelettes differently. I hate omelettes that are like egg paties folded over the other ingredients. If I wanted an egg patty with a side of mushrooms, I would have ordered that... so put them inside the omelette, already! I don't care if that is a standard technique, it is not yummy and that's the most important aspect of good food... it tastes good. Plus, when I ordered an omelette once (and only once, in all fairness), it looked like my chihuahua could have eaten it and still been hungry. I know it comes with potatoes and toast and stuff, but if I want omelette, I want to eat mostly omelette and not rely on the accompaniments to fill me up. I love you Zazie, but really, fix the omelette problem.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The wait for Sunday brunch should be expected, but all in all I'm glad we waited.

The atmosphere is great, the staff was friendly enough and the omlette special was fantastic.  I don't remember the last time I had an omlette with bacon in it where the bacon didn't come out soggy.  The potatos come with full cloves of roasted garlic which was to die for.  

Most breakfast places overload the plates with so much food that sometimes seem ridiculous.  The amount of food on my plate was near perfect.

Extra bonus points for the ability to order one, two or three pancakes or french toast.  This is smart and such a good idea I don't know why other places don't do the same.
author: Jen I.

description:
Here's yet another review of brunch at Zazie. Shocker.  They also serve dinner and offer a nightly prix fixe special for just $19.50.  Joe Bob says check it out.

Food:  4 stars.   The food is really good, but is it really worth the wait?  I also wish there were more options.  I usually avoid this place unless I'm doing brunch really early or really late.  At least there is a bar next door...

Service:  3 stars.   You better have darn good service if you're going to make us wait that long outside.   

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  It's a little unclean, and really cramped.  At least the crowd is decent to look at.

Hits:   Eggs Mexico, Eggs New York, Eggs Albert, Mango Mimosa

Misses:  The f*cking wait.  The f*cking parking.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Chloe's Cafe (another long f*cking wait), Toast, Squat & Gobble (love that name)
author: Keith C.

description: Wow. You need to eat here.  Breakfast especially. I'd start naming dishes but I'd have to type the whole menu.
author: Liss J.

description: The breakfast here Is not different from any other breakfast joint. I had crab benedit and I never order that. Not enough crab, would not order that again but if someone wanted to go I will order something else.
author: Ge I.

description: This is one of the best casual restaurants in the city.  When they have trout as a special, it is my favorite choice; most of their vegetarian soups are also excellent.  It's popular but not so crowded that you're cramped, and it's a great place for people watching especially when it's warm and sunny enough to sit outside and watch the Cole Valley crowd.  Their computerized reservation system is also top-notch, with full names and cell-phone numbers stored for repeat customers.
author: Steven Jon K.

description:
Upon a recommendation from several SFers, I made my way to the pleasant cole valley in search for bangin' brunch that would leave me in a post-feast coma. What i found was great, but not awesome. 

Zazie's supports a comfortable atmosphere rish with locals laughing and talking about the weeks' adventures. The food only adds to the warmth by providing standard breakfast greats with seasonal flares like pumpkin pancakes. 

Low-down: 
Atmosphere: contemporary cafe
Price: $$ (15)
Selling point: Outdoor patio dining
Gimmick: Mochas served in bowls
author: Kaleb L.

description:
Ah, I've finally found eggs benedict (and its siblings) that I like.  Zazie has numerous variations of poached eggs on english muffins.

Also, they allow you to determine the size of your brunch.  Would you like one poached egg or two (or three or...)?  One piece of french toast or two (or...)?  I know, why don't you just eat one and leave the other?  Because I have no self-control.  I eat *everything* put in front of me, even if I'm way past full.

I've also had their French Toast Tahiti (I think that was the name) -- french toast "stuffed" with carmelized bananas and walnuts.  While they weren't really stuffed (more like, put between two pieces of french toast), it was still quite tasty.  Although, I realize that I prefer savory for breakfast (but it just sounded sooo good).

I subtracted one star b/c my eggs over medium were really eggs over easy.  There was even uncooked egg white, which kinda grossed me out.  I'm almost tempted to subtract another star for their slow service and long waits.  But the service, while slow, was still pleasant, and all good brunch spots seem to have ridiculously long waits these days (or rather, years?  I thought the dot-com bubble burst in '01 was going to bring us back to normal brunch waits; ***sigh***).

UPDATE:  So, after writing this review, the owner writes me a very nice note.  I write her back and mention that the next time I go, I'll say hello.  

I went again Presidents' Day Monday.  Things were quite busy, and I think the owner was working as the hostess.  I was going to say hello, but our service that day was just so bad, I didn't even feel like bothering. 

Our waitress was totally absent -- she never checked in on us, we had to keep looking for her to come outside again and then flag her down (can we get menus?  can I get another mimosa?  can we get more coffee?  hot sauce?  extra hollandaise?).  She never asked how our food was or else they would've gotten the feedback that there wasn't any hollandaise sauce (ok, maybe just a wee bit) on my boyfriend's poached eggs (albert) and that my poached egg was cooked hard (st. trop).

Even if our service was terrible, our food was still pretty good (once we got the extra hollandaise, and I just got over the fact that if I wanted a new poached egg, I'd probably be waiting forever for it...  way past after my boyfriend would be done with his breakfast...).

Relatedly, my boyfriend's sister went to Zazie for lunch last week and also had terrible service and terrible food (I only remember she'd mentioned cold toast brought with butter, which she wasn't able to spread).  So, I think this may be our last trip to Zazie for a while...  which I must admit I'm a little sad about b/c I do like their eggs...  but it's no good to leave brunch on a beautiful day feeling pissy b/c of your service.  Our plan is to just make our own eggs benedict at home...
author: S J.

description:
Are you a small eater or are you always finding yourself wanting to try a few items on the menu but can't cuz you just it would be impossible to finish?  If so, this is the place for you!  You can't from their menu online but you can order small portions of their brunch items like pancakes, french toast, etc., so you can order 1 french toast and 1 pancake so you can try 2 things at once.  Each piece is still pretty big and the total price would be the same as if you ordered 1 large item.  

I tried the1 Gingerbread pancake which was probably 10 inches in diameter!  Huge!  The lemon curd and roasted pear was yummy but it seemed too little for the size of the pancake.  I also tried a piece of the Challah french toast which was just as delicious.  My husband had the egg benedict with crab meat that you can order a small portion of 1 (but he had 2) and this wasn't a huge portion even for 2.  It was quite tasty.  I love crab.  It comes with potatoes which was very good too.  We even ordered an extra side of potatoes for the table to share.  The group of us ordered a bottle of champagne a carafe of juice to make mimosa for the table.  If you're a big group, go for this option.

We went on a Sunday, a group of 8, and had to wait about 1 hour.  They don't take reservations, it's first come first serve, put your name on a list, and wait to be called.  If you're a smaller party of 2 to 4, I think you can get a seat within 1/2 hour since they serve their food pretty quickly.  If it's a long wait, you can always go to Peet's next door and get a cup of joe first.

Zazie has outdoor patio seating in the back which is great on a nice warm day.   It's very cute!  We definitely would go back and try the other dishes and recommend it to our friends!
author: Irene C.

description:
I love this place. All the time. And twice on Sundays. 

It's my go-to spot for breakfast, brunch, lunch AND dinner. 

Nice staff...great food...yummy beverages...and it's in Cole Valley. What more can you ask for in a spot that doesn't cost an arm and a leg and is located in one of the cutest areas of the city? 

Yeah, the answer is nothing. You win!
author: Kate P.

description: Once upon a time, this place was great....now...not so much.  Been going there periodically for five years....not anymore.  Was in for breakfast, eggs were supposed to be over medium and instead came with yolks almost totally cooked while whites were runny....and all edges were burned. I sent them back and ordered scrambled instead.  I didn't make a big fuss.  They brought back the pancake and bacon and at that point (I"m thinking long before however) those things were bone cold....I mean, the butter wasn't even close to getting soft on the pancake and the bacon...well, at least it was cooked.  I at less than half, paid and tipped properly and went to speak to the manager, who I think may be the owner.  I asked to step away from the customers and he said, "no, right here I'm very busy".  So I explained that my food was very cold and that I thought there may be an issue with the kitchen since I heard another table sending food back.  Instead of apologizing, he basically accused the other table of not ordering the right way and completely ignored my feedback about my cold food.  At that point it was very clear he didn't want to hear it so I told him I wouldn't be back.  I was not abusive or rude in any way at any time, and I was not trying to get a comped meal which is why I specifically paid and tipped first....I was merely trying to provide feedback about my experience and he didn't want to hear it.  I guess when you're riding on the wave of positive reviews you don't have to care about those who may have had a bad experience...hope that works out for you in the future.  I won't be back.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Dungeness crab poached eggs dish with non-greasy homefries (I think the dish's name is La Mer?) was awesome.  There was a moment of silence as it was inhaled.  It seems to be a seasonal item but it's currently on the menu.  oh and don't forget a Bloody Mary, which was the perfect complement to the crab/eggs.

Really loved Zazie's for brunch, a very cozy bustling Cole Valley bistro with a neighborhood feel/crowd and jazz music playing in the background.  They have an outdoor heated patio.  The french toast Tahiti stuffed with carmelized bananas and walnuts was also great.  The service is superb, efficient, and the wait isn't too long, maybe 10-15 minutes.
author: Chris P.

description:
Last Sunday, we ate here for the first time for brunch. Other than the wait we enjoyed ourselves.  It is a Provencale French restaurant in Cole Valley.  Zazie is very popular for brunches and hence the long wait.

We sat at their two-tiered heated patio which was surrounded by flowers and foliage.  If you can sit outside on the patio, it's a real treat.

Order their sparkling wine with mango juice. Instead of a traditional orange juice and champagne option.

I always contemplate about ordering eggs Benedict somewhere new because most are disappointing. I ordered the St. Trop which is smoked salmon, red onions, capers and a tad bit of hollandaise sauce was perfect. The Benedict was definitely a light and fresh tasting.
author: Nestle L.

description:
I came here with my friend for some brunch action on Sunday. He promised it was "the best" place to eat in Cole Valley, so I was intrigued. And definitely not disappointed! I got the eggs bennie with mushrooms and spinach - so delicious! With a few mimosas made with elderberry juice, some toast and apple chicken sausages, it was a real effort to hoof it to the upper Fillmore for dress shopping. But, I made it. 

Next time I eat there I'm planning on napping afterwards! And I'm definitely planning on eating there again soon!
author: Katie D.

description:
This ended up being one of my favorite dining spots on my week-long vacation.  We went to Sunday brunch around 10-11 a.m.  There was a 15-minute wait (on a warm, beautiful morning--oh no!) that was processed extremely quickly by the staff.  I was so impressed by their efficiency.

Zazie is so cute.  The atmosphere is so inviting and warm.  There was too much on the menu to choose from.  Since we couldn't just come back whenever we wanted, my boyfriend and I each ordered a 'scramble' variant, then he ordered a piece of the Orange Challah French Toast, and I had a Gingerbread Pancake w/Lemon Curd & Bosc Pears.  

...oh, my god.  

Okay.  The gingerbread pancake is a contender for the most perfect thing I've ever eaten.  I would run away with that pancake and have its gingerbabies.  The combination of lemon and pear and ginger is indescribable outside of a noise that sounds like, "Gllhhhhhhuurrrrmmmmmm."  

What an absolutely wonderful brunch spot!
author: Heather T.

description:
Yum. I'm lucky to live in the same neighborhood as this place. They sure know how to serve up a delicious breakfast. And the best part is that you can order a single pancake, or a single waffle, or a single egg and mix and match as you so please. The coffee is good and the lattes are decent. I love their oatmeal brulee and their gingerbread pancakes with delicious delicious lemon curd. And of course everyone will tell you that their poached eggs are some of the best.

I'm not sure if the enormous weekend lines are justified - I tend to avoid going to places where I have to wait... I just make a point to drop by on weekdays before work when there is no wait and the food is just as good, if not better.
author: Tim C.

description:
I came here a while ago to know what the fuss it was all about. When I got there sometimes after 10, holy mother of crap! I saw TONS of people outside. I thought they were dropped off by a tour bus or something but nooo...they were waiting for tables. Luckily, we weren't waiting that long, about 20 minutes, compare to that many amount of people. 

The food was good and the service was prompt. I'm just not sure if I will be coming back anytime soon. The whole experience just didn't stood up for me. Even if I do come back, I will definitely come a lot early!
author: Perry S.

description:
Amazing brunch place.  Known for their eggs bennedict but everything is so yummy.  You have to get here early on a Sunday (if you aren't too hungover) to get a nice spot outside on a sunny day!  

I can't wait to go back.
author: Dan D.

description:
Ah, Zazie, how you've forsaken me, my pet. I would willingly wait outside your window, biding my time for a chance to sup at your gentle teat. Content in the knowledge that once inside I would be pampered, wowed and sated.

Oh, you are popular, I've always known that. I've been willing to jostle amongst your legion suitors, awaiting my chance for one kiss of perfection - a miracle pancake or some french toast that truly makes me challah. Never did you let me down. Always did you make me feel special, that your love was worth the wait. 

Until I caught you with a hangover. Breath stinking, mind clouded, you obviously had been out celebrating the arrival of new year the night before. How else could you explain why you gave the lone diner ahead of us the window booth, and subjected my family to a tiny, tight table? 

How else could I explain the lack of attention you gave to my water glass, or how cold my french toast was upon delivery? Like any great lover, I'm sure you have your off days. I just thought it could never happen between us. 

Oh, I'm sure I'll be back to you, dear Zazie. But not before you've gotten that taste out of your mouth. And fixed your hair.
author: Greg Q.

description:
I recently moved to the neighborhood, and was initially scared off by the promise of an hour+ wait for brunch at Zazie. That is, until I discovered you can just pop next door to Finnegan's Wake for a DELICIOUS bloody mary while you wait. Just write "at Finnegan's" next to your name on the wait list and they will actually come and get you when your table is ready. How sweet is that? Makes me love my 'hood even more.

Oh yeah, and the food is tasty. Eggs fontainbleu never disappoint. Please hurry up and re-open - we miss you!
author: Erin B.

description: Yes, it's a nice, cozy place, but is it really worth it? I came here with a party of four exactly at 9am when they opened to ensure we got on the list and wouldn't  have to wait hours to be seated. Our fourth person was running a few minutes late and the list was starting to get filled, so I asked if we could be seated and order drinks while we waited for my friend. Not only did the host refuse my request, but he removed us from the list and made us wait another hour to be seated when my friend had already gotten there. Arrived at 9am, wasn't seated until 10:10. Oh, and no bottomless mimosas :/ Thanks, but no thanks I'll go to Blackwood next time.
author: Niki J.

description:
Well, I don't know what happened but things appear back on track again...Came back to give it another shot and pleased to say there was a familiar strength in the quality of their food again.

Buttermilk pancakes, in particular were again pretty tasty as I used to remember.

Only negative for me continues to be how terrible the coffee is...You don't have to necessarily go Blue Bottle but something better than what is there...Drip is terrible regardless of how touted the 'Roast' is and espresso suffers from either a poor machine or untrained barista

We'll be back, line and all
author: Barca F.

description:
Even with the hour long wait on a weekend, it's 100% worth it. The wait staff is always very attentive and will bring you coffee while you wait. Another bonus is that there is usually a collection of really cute dogs waiting for their families that you can pet while you wait for a table. The dcor is perfect, exposed brick, lots of light, simple, charming, and very French. 

I love everything I've ever had there, some stand outs are the Croque Madame, all of the international egg dishes, and honestly... the little side salads. How can a simple pile of lettuce be so good? I mean, it's literally just lettuce and a very light vinaigrette dressing. But it's so delicious!!

I must tell you about The Waffle. They had this special that was an amazing waffle topped with caramelized bananas and nuts and it was the best thing I've ever had. Here's the thing, it wasn't the toppings that made it so good, it was The Waffle itself. It was just a tiny bit delicately crispy on the outside and light and cake like on the inside, but really, I can't explain it. It was magic. The first time my friend and I had it we had planned to split it and ended up having to order another one immediately. The trick was they only had it on weekdays, it was never on the menu, and if you showed up on a Monday that was a holiday... forget it, no waffle. I asked, but they gave me this sob story about having only one sort of half assed waffle iron and not enough room in the kitchen. And now ladies and gentlemen, The Waffle is no more. They have killed it entirely.

If you too had The Waffle and really miss it, PLEASE ask them to bring it back so I'm not the only annoying person begging for its return.
author: Deb L.

description:
Thank GAWD they're open again. How many Monday nights did I crave Zazie's rabbit and pasta on the heated patio with my dog in tow? 
We only recently started doing dinner there, because their breakfast and lunches are cravers. I totally went on a Zazie BLT bender once - I think I went there once or twice a week for like a month for just that. But EVERYTHING is great. I just stay away weekend mornings - wait, wait, wait.
The staff is great, the food is fabulous and you can bring your dog on Monday nights. If I owned a restaurant, it would be just like Zazie.
author: Teri M.

description: Special cherry french toast with lavender buttercream-- that was yummy. And the dungeness crab benedict. Benedict was definitely overpriced, especially for one egg. But it was bomb. The potatoes were bomb too.
author: Samantha Sydnie S.

description: This place is cozy and serves up consistently amazing food. We've yet to order something we did not love. It's quickly becoming our favorite neighborhood spot!
author: N F.

description:
Zazie is one of my most favorite brunch restaurants! Its the place where I meet up with my friends and where I take out-of-town guests. I know its a busy spot but its worth the wait. The menu is exceptional and I don't even have enough space to write down all the delicious items. I've eaten my way through 3/4 of the brunch menu and only have compliments about the food and service. (Especially Mario - he's great and always keeps things in check with a lively attitude) I also love the outdoor patio.  Even on the chilly days, heat lamps and lattes keep you warm enough to enjoy the rarity of eating outside in this city.
I guess the only real bummer would be that the neighborhood parking is a pain but Zazie doesn't have much control over that. Overall, Zazie is quintessentially a gem of an eatery and a great little spot in Cole Valley!
author: Trish K.

description:
My all-time favorite sf brunch spot. The wait is a bit on the weekends, but worth it -and you can order a coffeer or chai while you wait and read the paper, people watch and pet the cute doggies on the sidewalk. 

Lunch and dinner are amazing as well, and captures the essence of a real French spot in Paris without the snoot. Service is friendly and prices are reasonable.
author: Howard C.

description: This was one of the best breakfast's I have had in a long time.  I had french toast with berries, and lemon whip cream of some sort, along with an Omelet that was on special, along with great garlic potatoes.  The area is fun right next to the golden gate park.  Highly recommended!!
author: Jeremy A.

description: Amazing french bistro in SF. They have an adorable outside eating area with heaters. Had dinner there and had the mussels as an appetizer and it was very flavorful. For my entree, I had the mushroom raviolis and they melted in my mouth. So SO good! This is a great date night place to go to, but make reservations as they get super busy.
author: Nadia C.

description: I ordered the Valence Poached Egg and wasn't particularly impressed. The spicy tomato sauce was interesting, but my eggs were cold inside and I found the eggplant chewy. The service was great though, so I wouldn't mind coming back for another try.
author: Vien N.

description: 4 stars for the food, brunch was excellent. Albert and St. Trop Eggs Benedicts' and French Toast Tahiti were all very tasty. One star taken away for the 40 minute wait in the rain followed by a tiny seat by the stairs and door (read cold wind everytime the door was opened) with the menu thrown down at the table. Not called for..But since we waited, we ate...and glad we did. May not be back here in a hurry. Service was definitely better once inside. Also noticed that they knew the regulars and were much nicer to them.
author: B P.

description:
I didn't know adorable little French breakfast places like this existed in SF until one of my friends kept raving about this place. We came here for a brunch on a weekday, and even then there was a pretty long line. Since she had to get somewhere by a certain time, we started panicking, but then realized that the two tables on the sidewalk in front are first-come, first-serve... which was perfect for the two of us! (:
It was a little breezy, but good for people-watching. We split the gingerbread pancake, Tahitian french toast, and Mexican scramble. I definitely appreciated how you can order exactly how many you want of the pancakes or toast, so it makes it easy to sample a number of things. My favorite for sure was the gingerbread pancake with the lemon curd on top. Definitely unique and special, and not dry like I feel most pancakes are. The Tahitian was also good--orange cardamom french toast. I normally don't like french toast, but this was an exception. The Mexican scramble was pretty standard--it wasn't amazing, but we ordered it mostly to balance out the carbs in the pancake and toast. :P Service was also pretty good considering we were outside and away from the rest of the diners. 
Overall, a very enjoyable brunch. Zazie is still on my list to try to the eggs benedict on the back patio (a la 7x7's list), but good to know I have a cute, delicious breakfast place on tab now.
author: Jen T.

description:
Perfectly poached eggs with provencle tomatoes what more could you want? Oh a gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and poached pears. All of it in my stomach NOW!!!

Seriously tasty brunch and a cool patio to boot.
author: Katie M.

description:
Such a lovely place for brunch.  If you've never tried it, you must try the BLT with provencal tomatoes, yummielicious.  The pancakes are great, as is the stuffed french toast.  And the coffeecake is a staple.

Be prepared to wait on the weekend, there's a Tully's down the street if you need a coffee fix, or the Boulange (sp?) kitty-corner for a treat.
author: Keith M.

description:
Went to Zazie this past President's Day weekend and it was busy.  The wait was around 1 hour at 10:30 in the morning.  So, if you're not up for waiting for a while, put your name down, go walk around and check out the area and then come back every 15-20 minutes to check if your table is ready.  The place is very very cramped so not really conducive for large parties unless you're willing to wait for a really long time.  

There were three of us so we got three different dishes so that we could share:

1) Gingerbread Pancakes
2)  Tahitian French Toast
3)  La Mer (Dungeness Crab with Poached eggs and avocado in an English Muffin)

All were very yummy, but I would have to say that their Tahitian French Toast was my favorite.  It wasn't too sweet and it was just the right portion.  The Gingerbread Pancakes were good too, but not sure it lived up to all the hype other yelpers gave it.  The dungeness crab is hard to go wrong.  The one thing I will say though is that the poached egg was cooked to perfection and oozed just the right amount.  

Highly recommended for a brunch place if you don't mind the wait.
author: Kristie G.

description:
Here's what 2 stars mean to me: I wouldn't go back but I can't say it's something someone else wouldn't like. 

Basically there's one quick way to piss me off in the morning: give me crap coffee. Follow that up with a mediocre to not so great over-priced meal and ready to Yelp about it. 

The wait is long but the line moves quickly. The staff is nice enough although I would say that some of the staff is more on top of things than others. 

My eyes were bigger than my stomach this morning and so I ordered plenty:
-Special: Scramble w/ Fontina Cheese (note to self: Fontina cheese is gross), Spinach and Bacon, came with Toast and Potatoes. 
-French Toast w/ Bananas and Walnuts
-Coffee Cream Cheese Cake: Think Entemann's. 
-Coffee
My Fiance had the Cinnamon Pancakes with Lemon Curd

The best part of this breakfast was the coffee cake. They warm it up and the crust is fluffy and flaky. Really tasty. 

Coffee was acidic, watery and burnt - ick. 

The scrambled eggs special was bitter (the spinach was cooked in the eggs it seems and they didn't bother draining the spinach juice), the eggs were flat and unseasoned, the bacon tasted like it was kept in a damp corner of the restaurant and the potatoes were cooked well but way under-seasoned, seriously lacking any creativity. 

The French Toast was tasty. Delicious thick toast cooked very well: crispy toasted outside, perfectly soft inside. The bananas on top were seared well and the filling (can't remember was it was) was a perfect blend. 

My Fiance's pancakes were pretty good. Very holiday inspired. 

Overall, I was really disappointed with this meal. Granted we got a ton of food but nothing stood out as being worth the trip and wait we had. 

I give it 2 stars and not 1 because I feel like someone else could maybe like the food there (I didn't realize how gross Fontina Cheese was until now - this could be completely biased) but certainly not me. And the coffee cake was pretty darn good. 

Won't go back, not even if someone invited me to go.
author: Liliana A.

description:
Cute outdoor seating area with wooden deck surrounded by plantings.

The poached egg dishes are very good. Worth the wait.
author: Simone E.

description: I'm a sucker for breakfast places and this was a very cute spot to hit up. Thank goodness my sf friend suggested to come early bc it gets PACKED. Parking is well parking. It's sf so u have to search but we got lucky and found a spot right it front. The food was delicious. They re known for their poached eggs but I don't really like runny eggs so I had the Greek scrambled eggs which had spinach and feta. It tasted  like eggs.... Haha..... But their home potato fries were very good. It was crispy on the outside and tender inside and the flavor was wonderful. A must try place in sf.
author: Di L.

description: Love this place for the good food and the patio.  A great place to take visitors to for a nice brunch.
author: Mai-Tam N.

description: Solid brunch and thankfully someplace open on Labor Day!  We had the La Mer poached eggs (real crabs) and Challah french toast and both were really good.  We like how you can order 1,2 or 3 eggs for all their egg dishes and 1, 2 or 3 slices of french toast as well, as we are not big eaters.  Service could have been better (too cool for school) and the place is TEENY which I know is normal in SF.  I didn't find it out of this world but definitely will go back, via public transport as parking in Cole Valley not fun.
author: Barndi K.

description:
I had time to kill before an appointment and stopped at Zazie for lunch/brunch.  I'd heard good things about it - especially the benedicts - so I was looking forward to a great meal.  They have a large variety of items to choose from but since I'd heard so much about the benedicts, I decided upon 2 poached eggs with shrimp, avocado and hollandaise sauce.  The eggs were poached hard (and I mean nothing running at all and light yellow) and they were the smallest eggs I've seen served at a restaurant.  The sides of them were stringy and tasted like vinegar and there was barely enough hollandaise sauce to cover the eggs let alone dip your muffin into and keep it moist.  The side of potatoes was ok and I liked the additional touch with the roasted cloves of garlic even if I chose to not eat them since I was going somewhere afterwards.  The avocado was fresh and the shrimp were tender and tasty but given the sad shape of the egg, it was not worth the money.
My bill included a $1.00 surcharge per person for SF medical care.  While I'm in favor of paying for heath care, I don't think it should be a surcharge but it should be added into the prices upfront or state it clearly/put it on the menu so that you don't take your first time diner by surprise.  While I don't live in SF anymore and don't get to eat there that often I have not run into it anywhere else.  I ate at two other places that day that didn't have a surcharge and I've been going up about once a month to different places I used to frequent and not seen it at any of those places.  Not sure if anyone else has seen this or if it is now common place but I'm curious.
author: Karen C.

description: Zazie is my absolute favorite place for breakfast.  Since living in SF, I've traveled all over the US and a few places accross the globe, and still nothing has been quite as good.  Zazie is often one of the top things I miss.  There is usually a long wait, but it is well worth it.  The Gingerbread Pancakes are my favorite.  Even La Note in Berkeley does not quite do them as well (La Note is excellent as well and a shorter drive for those of us now in the east bay--not a bad alternative).  The different poached egg dishes are also excellent.  I've never had anything I didn't like.  Service is great (and they are working very hard).  There is a Tully's coffee next door in case the wait time gets a little long.  When I take people from out of town, this is always the first place we go.
author: Carson L.

description: Excellent French food - wide ranging menu, and great wine. Cozy, casual place. Go.
author: Victor Z.

description: Probably the main reason I stroll Golden Gate park - is because I love to have Zazie Tahiti French Toast w/ Lemon Curd - it is heavenly!  My other favorites are coffee cakes with homemade creamchease and gingerbread pancakes.  One of the best Croque Monsieur outside of Paris, superb fresh crab La Mer Benedict.  Excellent service, patio sitting, I just Love You, Zazie!
author: Lana L.

description: Roasted garlic potatoes.  Option of choosing 1, 2, or 3 benedicts.  Very tasty food.  Long wait.  Small restaurant.  It's so close to a 5 star rating but I want to go back a few more times to be sure.  Try it for yourself.
author: Justine L.

description:
Zazie is Cute but Forgettable. I must say that I dragged my boyfriend out of the house to try this place because I am a fan of breakfast and even more so of new places. We got to Zazie's around 12pm, not so much breakfast but they do serve it till 3pm on the weekends. We put our name on the list and waited for about 20 min....not too bad. ( don't get frightened by the long list..it actually moves really fast) 

We got seated in the patio area which was nice since the weather was amazing. The table was very small and i had to climb over a post to get to my seat. My boyfriend is a football player so he definitely did not appreciate the tiny table. The waitress came up right away and was friendly yet not annoying ( a rare combination :) ). She bought me coffee which was strong and good and my bf had a fresh squeezed orange juice. I ordered Fontainbleau: with portobellos, shiitake, porcinis, spinach, fontina. It came with Toast and Potatoes. The scramble was a little too wet and i wasn't a fan of the cheese but that might have been my fault for ordering it. The potatoes are made with roasted garlic but tasted a little bland. My bf had simple eggs, pancake, and bacon combo. He said also that the eggs were a lil wet and bacon was good but no crispy. The pancake was very good and flavorful. Overall for the two of us it was $35 breakfast with tip. A little too pricey for a not so spectacular of a meal. Don't get me wrong, the setting and atmosphere is very cute and that's probably what you are paying for. Might come back if in the area...but uummmm probably not.
author: marina g.

description:
This place was totally hyped up by my friends as their absolute FAVORITE brunch place in San Francisco.  Considering that this is San Francisco, I expected a lot from that statement, plus the fact that they are into their food, and of course the massive line outside the place all the time.

So we waited about an hour or so, which I am totally happy to do for amazing food, with no complaint.

However, I didn't find this food amazing, special, worth a wait, worth they hype, or any of the above.  It just kind of felt like heavy American breakfast food, and the menu was not that unique really- just variations on eggs benedict, eggs, pancakes, etc.   I had one of the eggs benedict variations and felt heavy the rest of the day- it sent me into one of those brunch comas, but not in a good way.  I had a bite of my friend's pancake thing and it was SUPER sweet in a sickly way.

So, yeah, not that psyched on the place- looking for better, and will keep looking. I just moved here so I don't have much to compare it to yet, I should add.
author: Carlin S.

description: Brunch there was, nice, we were lucky as we waited like 5-10 min. Eggs with crab was really good, espresso to! Mango mimosa is a little blend.
author: Gregoire V.

description:
Love, love love Zazie!  I've only been there twice, but this is definitely my new favorite place for weekend brunch in the city.  

The first time I went, we waited about 45 min for a table for two, but a wait for brunch in the city is standard.  The first time I went I got the Un, Deux, Trois with poached eggs, chicken apple sausage and  pumpkin pancakes. Loved it.  The most recent time I went, I only waited 20 min (and at 11am on a Saturday!) and had the French Toast Tahiti: challah french toast stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  I went halvsies on that and the crab benedict with my boyfriend.  Both were amazing!  What I love about this place is 1. Everything is delicious and 2. There are so many things on the menu I want to try!  Often times, brunch places have smaller menus and you find yourself getting bored with the same thing time and time again. Zazie has a lot to choose from, plus they are always changing the menu.   Next time I'm hoping the gingerbread pancakes are still on the menu so I can partake and satisfy my insatiable sweet tooth.

My only complaint, the water/water glass smelled terrible.  Some sort of dirty water fish smell.  But other than that everything was fantastic!
author: Rebecca I.

description: This place is way overcrowded, especially considering how mediocre the food is.  I've been here a couple of times, and have even had the "eggs benedict on the back patio" as noted in the 7x7 list, and I've just never been impressed.   I definitely prefer La Boulagne for brunch needs in Cole Valley.
author: Ernest S.

description: The food is amazingly delicious every time! it is also consistant. Always yummy! The rest really doesn't matter. The ambiance is very nice! Of course the wait is always long. They really have some of the best hollandaise sauce Ive ever eaten and the miracle pancakes are perfect. It is the most expensive breakfast ever.
author: Elle G.

description: Zazie is our favorite French restaurant in San Francisco- the food on the dinner menu is seasonal, fresh and delicious! Try to get a table on their patio, it's worth the wait! One star goes for the brunch wait on weekends- it's just too long...
author: Hannah F.

description:
My boyfriend and my go-to breakfast/brunch spot. We always sit outside in the adorable back patio, which is heated on those typically chilly SF mornings. The food is always tasty- we often get 3 entrees, one for the middle to share in addition to our own!

Though the wait is almost always insanely long, Tully's coffee three doors down helps ease my hungry cranky self. (I am no fun in the morning pre-breakfast as my boyfriend can attest)

I subtract a star only because, more often than not, the service is unapologetically slow. I understand that this place fills up and servers are limited, but a little acknowledgement would be nice. I mean, it really shouldn't take 30 minutes just to get two glasses of water! (No, I am not exagurating).
author: Nina H.

description:
LOVE this place for brunch. The patio outside is a great place to soak in the sun, grub and chat with your friends. Food is yummy and they give you large portions so come hungry!

I'd give this place 5 stars, but the wait sometimes is ridiculous , especially since they don't accept reservations on the weekends.
author: Janel Y.

description:
I'm going to say it, I'm going to write it:

Brunch at Zazie might be slightly overrated. It's good, it is -- don't get me wrong. But it won't change your life, as the crowds suggest. (To be honest, I think I prefer Pork Store Cafe, a couple blocks over -- it's not as classy but it has a special charm of its own and you might save a few bucks). On a nice day the patio seating at Zazie is a real asset, but it's hard to find clear, warm weather in Cole valley during the morning hours (I live there). 

I actually prefer Zazie as a dinner spot, I think. It's a charming, mid-range, neighborhood, vaguely European spot. It's the sort of place my boyfriend's father loves -- it helps him feel French-casual. The food is good, though I did have some disappointing fish once. The price is reasonable, but not a steal. I think I would have given it five stars after my first visit, but my enthusiasm has mellowed slightly for a variety of reasons (some less than stellar dinners and an adjustment of the price list, among them). 

Nonetheless, I would recommend it if you are in the market for a pleasant faux-Parisian experience. Or if you are going to out dinner with my boyfriend's father.
author: Beah B.

description:
I went to Zazie once, years ago, for breakfast. All I remember about it was shivering on the patio and remarking to my companions that it was the most expensive breakfast I'd ever eaten - which I didn't intend to sound cheap, but rather just observational, with wonder. So now, several years later, I'm there for dinner and I'm financially better off, so it was less noteworthily expensive (though still not cheap). We were there on a Wednesday night and it was crowded only a few minutes after we arrived for an early dinner before the Morrissey show, so if the place looks empty - hurry in there!

My friend and I both got the prix fixe option, which is a pretty good deal for $21.50 - a choice of select starters, appetizers, and a dessert. We both started with the Salade Louis Malle (it all makes sense - Louis Malle directed 'Zazie dans le metro'!), which was good - cheese on a salad = yay. Then as en entree, I had the salmon grillade, which I liked. Though it seemed a bit dry - kind of crying out for some oil or sauce or something. My friend had the fish soup, which looked good. Especially the cheese (some of which I stole to give some moisture to my fish) and the spicy toasts.

We ended with the best part - pot du creme au chocolat!!! It was heavenly. It made up for the dry fish and slow service (I think we were sussed out by the waitress as cheapskates or something. It seemed like a lot of the time she was standing by the kitchen not doing much rather than meeting our gaze when we needed anything). 

Final verdict - a little too pricey for my budget on a regular basis, but definitely enjoyable.
author: Emily M.

description:
Heard a lot of hype about this place and thought I'd try it at some point. I also zipped by it on my bicycle one day and wondered what all the hub-bub was about. 

One wet rainy morning,  about 1 month ago, me and the GF were very unmotivated to ride our bicycles. So our minds gravitated to the next best thing...brunch! You thought I was gonna say sex didn't you, admit it ;-) 

We decided to walk around and check out what Cole Valley had to offer before settling on Zazie. Finally, we agreed the 30 minute wait was worth it and headed to Tully's coffee to pacify the hunger pangs. Being a coffee aficionado I wouldn't settle for Tully's and ventured across the street to check out Cafe Reverie...were I happened to have one of the best double macchiatos I've had in a while.

So after freezing our butts off waiting outside, we got in. The place is small and quaint. They have a nice looking back patio, which unfortunately we could not take advantage of because it was raining.

I order poached eggs, bacon and a Kir Royal. The Kir Royal was delicious, but the poached eggs were hardly runny...boo! The potatos roasted potatos were probably the best thing we ate there. As we sat there eating, the couple next to us order coffee cake and we thought yum. So we order an apre-brunch coffee cake. It was dry and not really worth the calories. 

So overall the food was kinda mediocre,but the service was stupendous. Our waitress was very welcoming and friendly and always kept our coffee and waters full. 

I'm giving them 3.5 stars. I would try it again, but it would have to be off peak as waiting 30 mins for mediocre food wasn't worth it. I'd probably stay local and walk to Kate's or the Pork Store in the Castro. However, I might be tempted to come back for lunch. Although I'd be much more likely to try some of the other breakfast places done the stip.
author: isaias J.

description: The only thing about zazie that is anything less than five stars, is the fact that it is hard to get in for brunch on weekends.  My favorite place for brunch, and dinner is great as well!  I almost ALWAYS get the crab benedict, or the french onion soup.  The outdoor patio is so cute, they have heat lamps for those chilly sf mornings and evenings.  Dinner outside is very cute and romantic.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
As this is San Fran, sit directly under the buzzing warming lamps unless you wish to dine Provencale a la parka.  

Coming back from a trip, I suddenly looked at Zazie with new eyes and saw that it was a place so truly San Franciscan: a leafy patio surrounded by clear sky, restored Victorians, channeling a French bistro on a crisp winter day.    Ever since the ownership changed hands a year or so ago, it seems the wine and drinks menu filled out, but most of the food remained the same, with pretty good quality.  The menu looks almost the same as La Note in Berkeley, and made me wonder if the owners were the same.  But when you taste the food, I think you can tell the difference.  

In the evenings, it is an excellent spot to sit and read philosophy and feel like you actually understood what you just read.
author: ed y.

description:
I haven't lived in SF for over 6 years and going back in Jan '07, it was good to see that Zazie is still going strong. It's a cute neighborhood restaurant and the service was fantastic. The food was pretty good too though I didn't feel it was necessarily inventive or extraordinary. The carrot ginger soup needed more ginger and a little more salt. The charcuterie plate was good filling and the salmon pate on the plate was pretty tasty. We asked for more cornichons though. I was surprised the plate came with so few.

The truffled raviolis were very tasty and I'd order them again.

The best part of the meal was the chocolate pot du creme. Yum. That was a great end to a lovely meal.
author: Allison J.

description:
I disagree with those who say Zazie's b-fast potatoes aren't the best in the world....if you don't like garlic, ask them to omit the tasty chunks that make these spuds stand out (we're talking entire cloves of garlic deliciously commingled with spices and potatoes in what can only be describe as the perfect brunch tater.) 

I also had the New York egg scramble (smoked salmon, cream cheese, green onions); when paired with the divine potatoes and rye toast this becomes the one thing I can confidently say I could eat for brunch for the rest of my life.  I would never get sick of it.  Ever.

As you may have noticed, I enjoy potatoes from time to time, so perhaps I am biased in the opposite direction of others...but come on, try them for yourself. 

I'll be here with my mango mimosa waiting to welcome you to the club.
author: Beth G.

description: Went here the other day with friends for a weekday brunch. The potatoes were awesome! But the Eggs Benedict were not the most spectacular I've ever had. However am very willing to go back on another week day to give them another shot!
author: Megan R.

description:
Tuesday night=no corkage fee :) And that's just the beginning of the fun. For you dog owners/lovers, Monday nights you can bring your pups and sit out on the back patio. They are reasonably priced, including a prix fixe menu for $21.50 including an appetizer, main course & dessert. Ambiance is intimate and the service was outstanding. I would recommend trying to get one of the two booths at the front of the restaurant for people-watching. 
I particularly enjoyed the Moroccan lentil soup and mussels from the appetizer menu. My compadres had the Zazie burger and salmon, both delicious. I plan on wandering over again to try more things soon!
author: Claire S.

description:
Went here two days in a row  for brunch during my 4-day stay in SF for a conference.  Loved every bite and every ray of Californian sun in the backyard... It's the ultimate brunch spot.  Even better if you've got yourself a pleasant dining company.  But if you are not so lucky, just concentrate on the amazingly delectable food.  Try the "Sunshine" drink if you can - you won't regret it.

If I didn't have to get up at 6 am to go to work tomorrow, I'd hop on a plane to fly across the country - just to taste Zazie goodness once again.  Hell, I'd even take Amtrak.  

Please open up a Zazie NYC... pretty please.
author: Claire Y.

description:
Oh how I love Zazie's.  Their adorable little back patio with the umbrellas and lights and the fountain.  It couldn't be cuter.  Their food is delicious as well as their morning beverages.  I'm a big fan of eggs Benedict so that's what I always get.  I had the Dungeness crab Benny.  Need I say more?  The service is great and on top of everything.  The only downfall is the wait.  Put your name in and take a walk around Cole Valley.  It's a great little neighborhood.

Second visit:
They have an amazing lemon riccota pancake!  Amazing I tell you!
author: Lauren M.

description:
I love Zazie's for brunch or dinner.  I definitely go more for brunch- they have great outdoor seating albeit it can take a while to get one of those coveted tables.  But it's worth it, i never eat inside.  

Favorites: in the fall you must try the pumpkin pancakes.  Ask for them if you don't see them.  The french toast is great.  Last week i had the granola with fruit and yogurt, and it was really good.  

For dinner, I had the lamb when I was still eating meat, I have not been as a vegetarian yet, but that lamb was oh so good.  The french are so good at sauces- they mix great flavors together.  Which is why you would want to go to a French restaurant.  

Service is good.
author: Candace B.

description:
I thought this place was utterly charming.  Plus they managed to catch me on a day where I was in a mood to not do an eat and run I had just gotten paid so....

I love French food so much although I don't like feeling rushed when eating.  And when I'm by myself I feel that I can't stick it to them by incessantly talking to my companion cuz, uh, I don't have any.  I'm sorry but I believe it was a Tuesday.  And if you are busting out the doors on a Tuesday, maybe you should look into getting a larger place.  But maybe that would keep it from being charming.

Whatever.  I'd definitely come back.  But with people next time.
author: Alexis B.

description:
I came here for the first time with a friend of mine and we ended up waiting for a couple of minutes after 1pm.  We were seated close to a couple.  This place was packed, just like in the photos.  I was pretty stoked because of all the great reviews.  

I ordered an omelette with some toast and potatoes.  The place looked pretty unique.  We were served coffee and ended up waiting 10 minutes before our food arrived.  The toast was perfect, the omelette and potatoes were good as well.  I just felt good coming out of this place.  I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good breakfast joint in San Francisco.  The locals are real cool too.  You might meet some cute UCSF girls?  Who knows?
author: Walter C.

description: I love this place!  Brunch is amazing even though the wait can be long it's well worth it.  We love dog night on Mondays and so does our dog Louie.  He feels very special being able to go to dinner with his dads.  The service is friendly and the food is fresh and tasty, breakfast lunch and dinner.
author: Greg G.

description:
My co-workers and I went here for dinner the other night. The restaurant is really small and they have an outdoor patio in the back but it was way too cold for that. We had reservations at about 6pm and only 1 table was occupied at the time. However, over the span of our 1.5 hour dinner, the place became packed. All the tables were full and people waiting for their reservation/table were crowding the entrance.

They were baking the crumble dessert during our dinner and the whole restaurant smelled delicious. My mouth was watering as I waited for my food and it just smelled like Christmas.

I ordered the hanger steak for my entree. The mashed potatoes were really good and the brandy cream sauce was delicious. I wish I had more of it! The steak was average. I ordered it medium and felt that the middle of the steak was very well cooked. However, the outside was too charred and felt tough. 

For dessert, I ordered the crumble because I had to see what the smell was about. It was a HUGE portion. The crumble was steaming hot and served in a medium-sized cereal bowl/cappuccino mug sort thing. And there was a generous scoop of ice cream on top. It was delicious. I didn't dominate the dessert as much as I would have liked because I was so full from my main course.

Staff was average. Food was decent but I will have to come back and try their brunch to see what that hype is all about.
author: Jennifer C.

description: While you're enjoying one of the tastiest brunches in city, say what's up to Mario, He's the best!
author: Marisa J.

description: This restaurant earns five stars because it is my favorite place to eat in San Francisco, and feels like home whenever I'm there.  It also serves up some of the most authentic, perfectly-cooked French fare in the entire city, has cozy decor, impeccably friendly and prompt service from happy staff, fantastic special events, and completely caters to its guests.  Jen Piallat, the owner, is one of the most welcoming restaurant personalities I've ever had the pleasure of coming across, and is earning rave reviews for every possible good reason there is.  When you dine here -- particularly when you dine here regularly -- you feel like a member of the family.  Don't just come here for their award-winning brunch.  No, get dinner reservations as well for an equally wonderful evening.
author: Nick B.

description: The lamb was perfect, by far the best dish.  Wasn't sure about lemon and ravioli but it works.  The quirky brit waiter made a great mourvedre recommendation we could enjoy together across both meals.  All this and having a very bad seat location was no longer on my mind straight through a decent crumble.
author: mike m.

description:
A very cool, chic place. Went here last december with my girlfriends for dinner. Most of us ordered salmon and a side of aspargus. One word, actually two words: freakin tasty. That salmon was so perfect. Had the right amount of seasoning, so moist, and so healthy too. It was wrapped in foil, so it must have been baked. 

We sat outside in the back patio where they have heat lamps and is surrounded by lights. Very cooool! We told ourselves that the place reminded us of NY.  

I'll definitely try the brunch menu next time.
author: VMarie G.

description:
I didn't come here for over a year because the service and food seemed to be going downhill. After today's experience, I'm happy to report that I'd give them a solid 4 stars! 

A group of almost 20 of us showed up on a last-minute whim after class this morning. Even without us calling ahead or making a reservation, the staff went out of their way to accommodate us and opened up the back patio so we could all sit together. Even with the slam of all our orders, the kitchen put out really tasty, consistent dishes, and everyone had their food within a few minutes of each other. Service was friendly and efficient.

I had the Eggs Monaco (poached eggs, prociutto, roasted tomatoes on an english muffin) and a Blood Mary. Eggs Monaco was great except for one overcooked egg--but that's to be expected with so many of us ordering all at the same time. BM was strong and not too spicy. Just the way I like it!
author: Jen C.

description:
I normally don't get pancakes but I couldn't pass up Gingah Pancakes and I'm happy I didn't! Like fluffy gingerbread cookies they were. (That you could put butter on! Score, bonus.)

Plus my friend Hezzie says one of the dudes in the New Pornographers says Zazie is his fave brunch place too.
author: Shannon V.

description:
Very cute. Very very cute. The wait on the weekends is no bueno, but worth trying once. 

The food was great. The servers are friendly and good at explaining the menu which is sometimes not all English. 

The scrambles are delicious. And you know the food is good when you see celebrity chefs leaving as you eat your breakfast.
author: kristen b.

description:
Brunch is 3 STARS. Good but a little pricey and sometimes the portioning is erratic. I had the Le Mer poached eggs with dungeness crab and the crab portion was half the size of the same dish I had a week before. Needless to say this was disappointing. The first time I had it it was beautifully done with big hunks of lump crab and silky avocado slices. The second time it looked like a very tired cook scraped what was left of the crab and stuck it on my serving. Consistency is important since I was being charged $14.95 for a poached egg dish. Still, I like this place a lot and the staff rocks!!! They'll get a couple more chances before I search for another brunch spot. 

Burger at lunch during the week is 4.5 Stars. One of the best and well made burgers I've had in the last year. It would have gotten a 5 Star rating if it had been served with some good Frites. It is $9.95 but I thought it worth every penny. The downside is they don't serve it on the weekend brunch menu. Try it medium rare or medium. You will not be disappointed!!!
author: Huy N.

description:
One of the best brunches I've had in the city.  I tried to go here before, but gave up due to the wait (there is ALWAYS a wait.)  but i was pleasantly surprised at how quick they turned the tables over and the food was definitely worth the wait.

The poached eggs with hollandaise were done incredibly well.  I loved their hollandaise sauce---much lighter than what I'm used to and very tasty. We also tried the gingerbread pancakes.  Pancakes with lemon curd, poached pears and ginger spicing? Delish.

This place was a refreshing break from all the greasy and unoriginal brunches I've chowed my way through in the past.  Extra props for the all organic fare.  Cheers to Zazie for getting brunch oh so very right.
author: Laura H.

description:
I had brunch here with my mom last Sunday.  We waited for one of the first come-first serve tables in the front and scored within 15 minutes.  

We had the Monaco Poached Eggs and French Toast.  Service was relaxed but quite attentive.

All in all a 4 star experience and I will be back...
author: Bessie T.

description:
I've been here for brunch a few times and have never been disappointed.  They seriously have the best eggs benedict ever.  Served in a garden.  With friendly, happy servers.  And good coffee.  What could be better?  

Also, the host is amazing.  The place is always jammed on the weekends, yet our party of 6 waited only 15 minutes at the peak brunch time rush!  Good job, you!
author: Erin L.

description:
The patio area? Wonderful

The food? Delectable! Well, at least breakfast was, our friend ordered a salad and was very disappointed...

The HUGE bowl of latte? PERFECTION!

THE EGO OF THE GODDAMN HOST!?? Appalling. 

At least our server was nice....
author: Stacy L.

description:
I'm often inclined to say that brunch places are worth the wait, probably because by the time I'm seated in front of a plate of eggs/pancakes/hash/toast/misc. items I am thisclose to eating my own shoe. 

Zazie, like many brunch places these days, is bustling with people trying to cure hangovers or fuel the rest of their lazy weekends. I particularly love eating there on a sunny afternoon, when you can take advantage of the tiny patio in the back.

I judge breakfast/brunch places on their standard egg breakfasts, and Zazie's definitely doesn't disappoint. The potatoes come with huge garlic cloves, so beware of those! 

+50 points for the "Build Your Own Mimosa" option. For $28 you get a bottle of champagne and a little carafe of juice. We chose fresh mango and it was deeelish. (Mimosas by the glass are $6.95 each so this is a great deal.)
author: lindsay w.

description:
Yum!  Great place to go for brunch on a Sunday morning!

My favorite is the La Mer, which is a twist on Eggs Benedict, but with crab and avocado - Mmm!  All their other dishes are good too.  I've also had their Gingerbread pancakes, Eggs Monaco (prosciutto, tomatoes provencales, poached eggs), Eggs Pierre Noir (bacon, tomatoes provencales, poached eggs) -- you just can't go wrong here!

And, for all you fellow coffee lovers out there, this place has GOOD coffee!  I don't know about you, but having bad coffee, no matter how great the meal is, just doesn't cut it for me.  

Come early, or as a small party, cause this place can get packed quick and there'll be a bit of a wait.  But trust me, it's worth it!
author: Crys L.

description:
Well, what can I really add to the hundreds of reviews? I liked the spicy, savory Mexican scrambled eggs. 3 eggs, peppers, fresh salsa (none of that bottled crap), spicy sausage (might have been chorizo, not sure), toast, and home fries. Just the right amount of food - I didn't leave feeling stuffed, just satisfied. They have versions of scrambled eggs from several different countries. I was tempted to try the famous gingerbread pancakes, but was in more of a protein mood. Oh well - next time. They give you lots of tea in your tea pot -- I refilled my mug 4-5 times. 

We sat outside on the sidewalk in the lovely springtime sun. They have a patio out back as well. Excellent start to the weekend!
author: Sarah S.

description:
I don't get why people think this place is so great.  It's just normal breakfast food.  Nothing particulary unique about it.  Also I don't like the sign they have outside that tells you not to ask for the wait time.  So that means if it's an hour...I just have to wait around blindly?? Blah!

I ordered the gingerbread pancakes....after the 3rd bite...it became too overwhelming.

The place is cute and service was friendly, but I'm not inclined to go back.  Food didn't particulary wow me.
author: Neety P.

description:
Came with boyfriend a couple weeks ago after reading the yelp reviews, and we were both very pleased! Parking was a pain in the ass as always around Cole Valley, and the wait was about 20 minutes, but luckily we weren't starving just yet.
Friendly staff, and the backyard patio seating was absolutely perfect for the weather. He had the prix fix with the zazie burger, I had the rabbit. Both entrees and the pate appetizer were good.. i'm excited to come back eventually for brunch.
author: Sandra S.

description:
An adorable french cafe in an adorable San Francisco neighborhood, Cole Valley. Tuesday nights are bring your own wine, free corkage. Of course that means that Tuesday nights are my girls night! 

But you know, you have to go for breakfast too because their mimosa's aren't to be missed. And when the weather permits, arrange to linger over your meal in true Parisian style on the back patio.
author: Angela G.

description: Amazing dinner! Tuesday they have a great $15 bottle of wine special. The bread was warm and fresh, cheese plate was tasty, raviolis...mmmm, pork chop was perfectly cooked. Outside seating was warm with the heaters. Definitely one of my new favorites.
author: Bryan M.

description: The Monaco poached eggs are a favorite, and the french toast is delish! Zazie always steals hearts away, and is well worth the wait.  It's my local go-to spot and a place where I always take out-of-towners because its truly one of San Francisco's gems.
author: Katie M.

description: Most of the reviews for Zazie are for brunch - my friend and I went for dinner.  I have to say the Marscapone Polenta Cake with spinach, mushrooms,  gorgonzola and tomato sauce was one of the best dishes I have had in SF in the past 5 years; maybe more.  For a vegetarian to find a delicious, well-spiced, nuanced dish that is also gluten free is a rarity in this city of bone marrow eaters.  My friend had the Hanger Steak with mushroom sauce, mashed potatoes and asparagus - the asparagus was perfectly done - it seemed to be roasted so the flavor bloomed - and he said the rest of the plate was very good, and he has eaten all over the world.  We shared the Creme Brûlée for desert with a bit of Port, and they both were delightful.  This place really feels European.  Service was quick, not hovering, very knowledgable about the menu.  Love that they provide health, dental and 401K for their staff.  This restaurant is what dining in SF is all about.
author: Christine H.

description: By far 1 of my 2 favorite breakfast spots in the city (the other is Brenda's on Polk and Eddy), when I have the money that is.They have long waits (an average of 40 minutes I think) but its worth the wait. If you have the patience or just wanna go to the bar next door for a Bloody Mary while you wait for your table, request a table outside on a nice day. Mario, the manager, is my favorite and really makes that place run smoothly. The dungeness crab eggs benedict is the best, and for lunch their butternut squash soup is delish.
author: Heather U.

description: A cute little place I found out about through the show, "Check, please!" I came here with a friend for brunch and we came at the right time because after 11 it becomes packed! I ordered pancakes and fresh fruit. Sounds simple and it is but the flavor makes a difference. There was something magical about these pancakes that transported me back to when I was a kid. Pouring all the syrupy goodness and tasting the fluffiness of the pancakes was just plain good! The fruit was fresh and you know I ate all of it. No crumbs behind. No ma'am. The staff were friendly and attentive. I certainly cannot wait until I come back to see what goodness awaits me...
author: Mel P.

description:
Came here on a weekend around 10.45am for brunch expecting to wait for 30-45 minutes! Anwyay, we got seated in the nice back outdoor patio with 20 minutes. Staff was quite friendly..

Had the gingerbread pancakes with the pear(?) sauce and the Eggs Le Mer. The pancakes are quite large, and 2 were more than enough - definitely worth a try. But not being a huge fan of gingerbread, I will probably pick something else next time. The eggs were good and came with potatoes along with garlic cloves - the quantity was not as large as the pancakes, thought. The cappucino was excellent.
