Overall, good food, but a tad pricey for what you get - rather, for the price, expected much more. But, a cutesy place to meet others and show off the neighborhood.
author: MandS R.

description: I love neighborhood restaurants and I love Zazie. The mussels are out of this world. The charcuterie plate is a meal in itself ( great pate!). Had a Derby Pinot with dinner and it was perfect. Service is excellent. Great place for dinner. Tables are pretty close together, so maybe not the best choice for an intimate date.
author: Ron M.

description: A tad pricey, but otherwise delectable. The scramble was delicious and the gingerbread pancakes were a treat even without the (limited) lemon curd topping. The service was friendly and the outdoor seating added to the charm of the place. I loved that they had organic and local food.
author: Mo A.

description:
don't be daunted by the line, it moves fast. when we got there, there were 15 tables in front of us. but we finished eating + waiting in 1 hr, we know because the street parking has 1 hr limit. 

went with a group of 4, seated by the window next to the door. very cozy and private. we had brunch there and here are the break downs:
- poached eggs with dungeness crab and avacado: loved it! got the hollonaise sauce on the side, which is just perfect. should have gotten two eggs instead of one. the country fries on the side was just ok.
- french toast: pretty good. we ordered it on the side. I don't care for french toast, but my friend wanted it and I tried it. 
- pancake: i loved it. it's a bit crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. just the way I like it and I can't duplicate it at home.

I really like how you can order things separately, so you can pick and choose. I got the french lemonade and I learned the hard way, roasted garlic and lemonade don't go together. It gives you this weird spicy taste.
author: Cicie W.

description: best brunch i have had in the bay area.  The mimosas are to die for and the food is fantastic!
author: Angie P.

description: Went here last night for BYOB Tuesdays. We sat in the patio and even though it was cold and foggy out, the patio is wonderful and warm. The service is super friendly without being stuffy and the portions are generous for the price. I'm vegetarian and found many options. The polenta cakes are great and the lemon ricotta ravioli is awesome. You will not be disappointed!
author: San D.

description: Its been a while since i move to other corner of san francisco, definetly still the best brunch place in the city!
author: Edward A.

description: Fantastic menu, adorable space, and friendly staff. Unfortunately, they over poached my egg to the extent that it was more of a soft boil. I was very disappointed. I suppose I could have sent it back but I just really expected more from a place that receives such high ratings. I will still come back because they have a plethora of benedict options and there is nothing I love more (besides mayonnaise) than hollandaise sauce mixed with a runny yolk slathered on toast. MMM....next time I will not stand for a solid yolk.
author: Rachael S.

description: The tahiti french toast was great and the caramelized bananas made the dish sweet enough to eat on its own without maple syrup.  Their gingerbread pancakes left something to be desired and the line was out the door.  As far as brunch places in the City go, this is one of the better ones, though if you're looking for a fantastic brunch, make your way over to La Note in Berkeley instead.
author: Ben T.

description:
Perfect neighborhood brunch location. They have the french bistro feel down very well. The specials are always a good option, as are the various spruced up french toast dishes. Enjoy a hot drink with the meal - chai tea being a personal favorite. There can be a long waiter later on in the brunch rush hour, so if you're up and reading this - head there now! I've found the wait period can be somewhat unpredictable.

Haven't been here for anything other than brunch, but I'll give it a try some day.
author: jim o.

description: Really great place! Very small, not too fancy, but the food is amazing! Came here in a group of 4, and we all sorta tasted each others' dishes... everything was delicious. The potatoes are loaded with roasted garlic, and absolutely divine :D
author: Vincent D.

description:
Good brunch spot! Lots of champagne drinks, good food! The manager was super nice and came and found us at the bar next door when a table was available. (The bar next door makes a killer Bloody Mary!!)
 
Our waiter sucked though.  He dropped the check without asking if we wanted coffee, which we did, and then dropped it again.  After my friend paid with a card, he literally stood there at the table and waited for his tip so he could get the hell out of there. I'm sorry but a litte tacky. Really, stand there and beg for a tip.
author: Courtney M.

description: I LOVE ZAZIE.  Been here countless times, but Croque Monsieur is always fantastic for brunch, any steak/filet for dinner is amazing and the outdoor space is very cozy.  Great for first date (check), girlfriends parents are in town (check), even christmas eve (check)
author: Jeffrey B.

description: Excellent eggs Benedict. It was a very nice place, just make sure to make reservations so you dont have to wait!
author: Hector M.

description: came by for brunch...food is nothing to rave about...BUT the service is friendly and efficient...
author: Martin C.

description: If I had written this review last year, I would have given this place 5 stars. As for now, I don't know. Something has subtly changed in the food. It doesn't quite have the same flavors it used to have. The fries aren't as crisp, the pancakes a bit dry and though the scrambles and benedicts are still good, just for some reason not quite as good as they used to be (at least in my mind). Still, the level of quality is better than most brunch places in the city so it's worth a visit. I try to stay away from the weekends unless I can get there right when they open. Lines are crazy.
author: Golapendu N.

description: While we sat down right away, we waited ages for service and then for our food. Our requests (no avocados on one plate and medium eggs on the other) were ignored. We had waited so long for our food, that we didn't have time to send the dishes back. The hot cocoa tasted like bad packaged instant cocoa. Then when we got the bill, there was a $1.25 service charge added per person. While it is standard for large parties, I have never seen something like that for a table of three. Service charge?? Seriously? It easily could have been overlooked if one does not scrutinized the bill. We were very disappointed after reading these other reviews.
author: Patty C.

description:
Astonishing. My absolute favorite place to go for brunch. Worth waiting for. Truly. The food is exquisite, the space is homey and welcoming, the service is warm and attentive. Sitting on the back deck under the sun... eating eggs florentine, followed by a pancake or a slice of french toast, sipping elder flower mimosas... Heaven. 

Also delicious for dinner. 

I feel so grateful to have Zazie in my backyard.
author: Rosemary G.

description:
I love this place for its atmosphere and provence-esque decor. 

However, I have to admit I'm a little disappointed with Zazie.  Here's why: 

- the high ceiling is great, gives the restaurant a free-flowing and open atmosphere, however it creates an echo effect and as such cause the room to be so noisy you can't hear your dining companion speak

- sunday brunch can get insanely busy and so they will sit three tables in front on the sidewalk.  While I was standing there waiting for my table, some hobo came by and knocked over a water glass from one of the table as his big bag brushed pass.  the poor chickies at the table ended up being swore at by said hobo!!  not how I would've wanted my sunday brunch to end.

- incredibly small portions for brunch.  Maybe it was just that one time, but when our pancakes and omellettes arrived, i was shocked at how small the portions were.  The omelette looked like it was made with only one egg!  for the price I was paying and the ridiculous wait, what i got was sadly disappointing. oh, and we had to ASK for water. they were THAT busy.
(disappointed sigh)
author: Steffy W.

description:
Since the loss of my beloved Miss Millie's in Noe Valley (they now reside in Rockridge for those of you that need their fix), I was looking for a new favorite breakfast spot in SF. I think Zazie has secured that spot.

We sat at the cozy table at the front window, a party of three being seated within ten minutes on a late Saturday morning. The waitstaff was very friendly and attentive. The fabulous-looking menu made it hard for a Libra like me to make a decision on what to order!

I finally decided upon ordering the Poached Eggs Albert, which is like a benedict, but has delicious slices of bacon, fresh salsa and cojita cheese. The potatoes with whole garlic cloves were a great accompaniment to the breakfast, and the coffee was decent.

One of my dining companions raved about the Tuna Sandwich here being his favorite, which I expected a tuna *salad* sandwich. I was pleasantly surprised to see that it was an Ahi tuna steak! It looked especially tasty.

I'll definitely be back... besides, I hafta try all the other yummy-sounding egg dishes!
author: Courtney P.

description:
Holla for challah!  

Zazie definitely gets points for using the chosen bread for their french toast, it is the perfect texture to soak up the eggs well and make for a nice flavorful pain grille francais.

So all in all Zazie did not disappoint.  Took my hubby there this morning for a special breakfast and we both left full and happy.  They have a marvelous menu (wow, so hard to choose from; someday I have got to try that evil sounding oatmeal creme brulee concoction, da-rool), tasty well prepared food, and a very pleasant light atmosphere.  The service was attentive and I found the regular coffee actually palatable, which is a rarity for me.

Even though it was a weekday the place filled up around 11 while we were there, this is likely due to the fact that the patio out back was closed for some construction.  I will definitely be back and, with hope, will be able to try the patio out with the pooch along.
------------------------------------
Update: Return visit exemplified how service can bear on the entire experience; manager and servers were all pretty dour, not the helpful pleasant bunch of the first visit.  Whole atmosphere suffered, food recommendation by server also off.
author: GIR ..

description:
I went on Sunday of the World Cup finals and I had no problem getting a seat  :)  Thank goodness because the food was awesome.  I ordered the scramble with all different kinds of mushroom with spinach and fontina.  It was soooo good.  Plus the home fries had roasted garlic in it.  How great is that?  My friends ordered the crabs and avocado benedict which was amazing, and another friend order the ham and gruyere sandwich with an over-easy egg on top and enjoyed it.  

They have a great selection of food (so much so that I almost couldn't decide what I wanted), a cute environment with indoor and outdoor seating, and good service although it was funny watching the host come in and out of the restaurant because he was peaking over at the local bar to check out the score for the World Cup.  If I were a San Francisco native, I would definitely have this on my list of local spots for brunch.  Yummy!
author: Nicky C.

description:
It really didn't impress me.  We waited for a long time for a patio seat, which we indicated on the sign up sheet.  When we were escorted to our table, they sat us inside.

I got a benedict and it was very average.  My partner got gingerbread pancakes, which to be honest, were a bit dry and plain with too little toppings.

The lemon curd, though, was quite tasty.

Le Metro on Divisadero is a much better place, but don't listen to me, I don't want you all to go there and make the wait longer  for the superior patio and food!
author: Aaron W.

description:
FOOD:  The food was good, nothing to run home about.  I feel like they make their food in conjunction with a high turnaround because of the crowds, hence they don't really put too much effort into presentation and quality--which is what French food is all about.

SERVICE:   When asked about a couple menu items our waiter was very impatient and seemed a bit irritated.  Ummmm, maybe you should read your job description again.

AMBIANCE:  If you're coming for a weekend brunch be prepared to spend it with hoards of people in a tiny space.  A little uncomfortable, if you ask me.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Zazie is great... had breakfast here with Miss Elisa O. (down below) along with a few friends of ours, & I'm quite confident in saying that every one of us enjoyed our meal.
The Dungeness crab benedict is what I ordered & it was delicious, highly recommended! 
Our server was great & deserves a gold star!
author: Ryoko Y.

description:
Um, I don't get it.  Eggs.  Toast.  Home fries. 

The mango mimosa was really good, but otherwise, it was just fine. 

Can someone fill in the blank for me?
author: Maria C.

description:
6/30/2007: I walked past this place on my way to the Haight with some friends who were visiting from out of town. I saw Zazie in the corner of my eye and was immediately drawn to it from across the street. When I walked into the restaurant, I was very warmly greeted by one of the servers and when I saw that they had a gorgeous little back patio, I was immediately reminded of La Note on Shattuck (which is arguably one of the most adorable eateries I know of in the Bay Area) 

Naturally, I opted to eat out in the back patio and enjoy some sun on what was a really lovely day, but when I was led outside with my friends, we were hastily seated by a flustered server. It took about 15 minutes to have our order taken. She looked quite busy as she looked like she was the only server on the patio that day. Having been a server myself in the past, I understood the stress she must have been feeling and tried to be as empathetic as possible. However, having realized that she didn't take our drink order, I tried to ask her for water for myself and my friends when she had the chance to do so. I was incredibly turned off when she basically snapped at me in front of my friends and curtly said "Look, I'm really busy right now. I'll get it for you when I can." 

My friends at that point were so turned off that they just wanted to up and leave, but I wanted to give her the benefit of the doubt. We stayed and chatted, and people watched and about 10 minutes later, we noticed an older couple that walked onto the patio looking to be seated. The same server basically told the couple in the same curt manner that she spoke to me in, that there was no room on the patio (there were 5 tables open) and when they pointed that fact out to her, she said that they were closing in 2 minutes. The couple looked baffled and turned to leave the restaurant. The manager intervened and had the couple seated, and the server and manager had a bit of a row. She also seemed to have had a mild breakdown and left the patio altogether for a few minutes while mild chaos ensued. 

It was an awkward scenario to have found myself in and my friends and I were really uncomfortable. Finally our food came. My friend had an eggs benedict dish with crab, and I had the grilled chicken sandwich. I was half expecting something delicious like La Note's grilled chicken, but I was turned off by the dried pieces of chicken jerky sitting on two slices of wheat toast. To be fair, my friend's dish was pretty good and I should know better than to order something so banal as a grilled chicken sandwich at a place that probably has what is otherwise great French food. However, I cannot ignore the fact that my dish was simply subpar and the service I experienced on the patio was incredibly unprofessional and just plain rude. 

We tipped 10 percent, which  I NEVER do, but I truly felt that our server gave us the worst service I've experienced here in the city. It's a shame because all of the other servers were warm and friendly. Perhaps it was an off day at this place, all I know is that I will not be coming back to give it another chance.

UPDATE 7/4/07: So within a few days of writing this review, I received a  very nice message from the owner of the restaurant apologizing profusely for the incident and assuring me that it was not a common thing to have happen and promised to rectify the situation in any way she could. I am so pleased that she genuinely takes interest in what her customers' satisfaction and I have added one star for her merits.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
The hype, I get it.  If I were looking for a brunch place next time, I'll probably end up coming to Zazie again.  

The wait is tolerable despite the conspicuous crowd outside.  Or at least the cheerful wait list guy (apparently keeping track of the wait list is a full time job cuz it's THAT busy) makes it seem okay.  He is smiling and joking around with customers, so I end up not feeling frustrated and cranky either.

I am not a big Brunch person because I always get French Toast.  I bore myself with that choice.  So I took a risk and ordered the Poached Eggs St. Trop, with two eggs and some smoked salmon.  Oooh, delicious!  Probably because the Hollandaise sauce isn't overpowering like a lot of places tend to make them.  We also tried the French Toast which I am glad that I didn't get.  It just seems to have too much "stuff" in there.  Bananas and nuts, maybe? Possibly some other ingredients too.  I don't know. 

My favorite part is the atmosphere.  Tucked in a secluded garden, you feel intimate, you feel relaxed and chatty.  It's a perfect palce to sip your tea and savor a lazy Saturday morning with good company.
author: Candice B.

description:
Wow, 402 reviews already...I guess I really don't need to weigh in here, but what the heck.

Setting - Sunday in October, ideal SF Fall weather (sunny, clear, cool), ever-so-slightly hungover from a wedding party.  I'm visiting a friend who lives a block from Zazie, so he's already put our name down.

Nevertheless, we wait...and wait...and wait.  Oddly enough, I wasn't cranky from the wait, perhaps b/c it was just a glorious day, I was with friends, and I was distracted by all the cute babies and dogs on the sidewalk.  But I'm just saying - we WAITED a loooong time.

And that wait was well worth it.  We sat out back on the charming patio.  Weakened by the hunger and the wait, I made two potentially debatable decisions: (1) I ordered a Bloody Mary (hair of the dog and all that...) and (2) I ordered one of their dishes with Hollandaise.  Now, there was just a reasonably high-profile "bad hollandaise" food-poisoning scandal at a popular brunch spot in LA, but I took the risk anyway since half of Zazie's menu involves the stuff.

All I can say is I did some of my best decision-making that morning, hungover and all.  Bloody Mary - perfectly iced and salted/peppered - wiped away the headache and the eggs were amazing.  Perfectly poached eggs + hollandaise + BACON = heaven.  Also, the home fries were fantastic-ly garlic-y.

The garden patio is awesome too.

Just go and wait - it'll be worth it.
author: Eric T.

description:
My Fountainbleu Scramble Eggs were AWESOME...

This is now my #2 favorite brunch place in SF...
Mama's still #1 in my book.  

of course, with any great brunch place, you must wait!

I really enjoyed the big ol' bowl of a latte, too!
author: Jennie L.

description:
I had a great time at Zazie.  My boyfriend and I went on a Monday so that we could bring our dog and sit outside. It was an adorable patio--perfect for outdoor dining.  

The food was good.  Great bread; great mussels; good duck; delicious bread pudding.  Our waitress was fun, knowledgeable and present as often often as one should be at a French restaurant.  The bathroom is an adorable SF oddity with barely enough room to turn around--I love it!  Cole Valley is adorable and always worth a visit. 

Zazie is reasonably priced for good food and great atmosphere--doggy days are a definite plus!  I'll definitely be back.
author: Brad A.

description:
What's the deal with the lines at breakfast/brunch places?  I was prepared for the line, and got myself a cafe' au lait from Tully's for my 'morning ritual' of sipping coffee and milk, but I worried about the others....  what if someone had really low blood sugar?   Would one of these potential diners slowly slump down into a heap because they fainted?

Ah, the wait wasn't too long for a party of two. I had previously eyed their menu so I was anticipating a taste sensation for my brunch.  It was OK-  nothing extremely special.  I had the NY Scramble with smoked salmon, scallions, & cream cheese;  it was fine.  My English muffin arrived along side the eggs and it was cold- so cold that the butter didn't even attempt to melt atop it.  My table partner felt the same about his dish- it was OK.  They did have a nice selection of different fruit juices to mix with champagne for a variety of mimosas.  Perhaps if I return I'll simply have a liquid brunch   *hic*
author: Karen W.

description:
One of my favorite places for brunch.  The extensive and mouth watering menu is ALL to die for.  Order the La Mer and you won't go wrong.  I love poached eggs with crab, and it definitely hits the spot.  

During a sunny day, mosey on over to Cole Valley and you will be delightfully surprised and leave happily content.
author: Rochelle B.

description:
This place is totally awesome. Hubby and I came here for dinner last night and were utterly impressed by our meals. Hubby ordered the braised niman ranch lamb shanks and I had the rainbow trout. Both dishes were mouth wateringly delicious. Portions are also very generous and for a French restaurant, the prices are unbeatable. 

Be forewarned, parking can be a b*tch!
author: Sandy Y.

description:
There are close to 600 reviews of Zazie and I'm with most of them. This is a great place to come for a late breakfast. If you go on the weekend expect to wait. I don't live in this neighborhood but it seems to have a great following. I was confused about the extra $1 they charge per customer but saw that it's going to health care so whatever. They are closing for a month to remodel and they are paying all of their employees for that month!! That is crazy. I don't know if i would get the same from my company. Guess i can see why they have been there for 16 years and have such a staunch following. Consider me a new convert. 
The food is great as well.
Update:
I got a real nice email from the owner which just proves my point about how great this local spot is.  See you when you re-open!!
author: Stephen K.

description:
yea man.

we had a table for 6 reserved, walked right on it and ordered a bottle of wine.

apparently this place is a hotspot for some brunch, however i'm not really a bruncher, more of a dinner-er. and dinner we had!

i had stead, she had a porkchop, and someone else ordered the mussels.  all were super tasty, tender, generous on the portion size (for a place like this), and timely. 

overall good experience!
author: Ameer N.

description:
It's really 3.5 stars.  The first time I came here for brunch everything was amazing.  The second time was just okay.  I love how you can get one, two, or three of most things like eggs/pancakes/etc.  It's great for sharing.  But the last time I went, the food wasn't as great as the first time.  The portions seemed a bit smaller and the service seemed much slower.  On top of it all, when we got the bill there was the health coverage for employees surcharge (personal pet peeve).  I guess I'd rather have the prices marginally go up across the board than see the surcharge.

I'll probably come back here eventually, but I'm definitely not rushing.
author: Joann C.

description:
Zazie is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  They don't try to do too much or pretend to be more than what they are which is a great neighborhood bistro of sorts that serves well put together French influenced home cooking.

They have a top notch wine selection and reliable breakfast and dinner menu.  Their back patio is great for brunch or lunch.  Try the braised short ribs on the dinner menu.  They practically fall off the bone and are served with delightfully light mashed potatoes and vegetables.  For breakfast, you can't miss with anything on the menu, but my wife swears by their pancakes for some reason.

It can get crowded on weekend morning so get their early or just grab a cup of coffee from Reverie down the street and enjoy the scenery of the bustling Cole St.  Besides, if your heading out to brunch on a weekend, you shouldn't't be in a hurry to do anything else in the day
author: Mike T.

description:
I had my 30th birthday party here and the staff and owner were really amazing.  The owner was really creative with the menu and gave me several off menu options.  There was delicious vegetable ravioli, baked fish, delicious salads, and we finished with chocolate truffles and chocolate dippied strawberries.  We had 50 people spread across two long tables and the back patio was used for apps and drinks.  I was also allowed to have a jazz trio in the early evening.  There were heating lamps and everyone had a lovely time.

For the everyday experience, Monday nights are dog nights I believe and dinner and brunch are my favorites.  The Tahiti French Toast really standsout in my mind.... mmmm
author: Diana L.

description:
Maybe I should've gone for brunch? 

Went to Zazie's for dinner last night.  The ambiance of the place was friendly and pleasant.  Lovely outdoor seating in the back terrace (picture cozy deck with ivy archway, shabby chic tables and benches), nothing pretentious, simple provincial charm.  The service was very attentive and prompt.  Our waiter had a great smile and witty banter, what more could one ask for?

The food was homely, but a bit heavy on the oil/butter.  I had the grilled trout which was a tad bland.  The duck however, was tender, flavorful and roasted to perfection.  Wine selection was kind of limited (per glass), I personally liked the Novarro (?) pinot the best.  Dessert was the highlight of the meal.  The fruit crumble served with fresh creme was delicious.   The creme was tart and served as a nice contrast to the warm, sweet baked peaches and blueberries.  

So all in all, a good experience. Though I probably wouldn't come here especially for a meal, it's a cute place to drop in if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Mischen C.

description: My friend saw this on "Check Please Bay Area" so we decided to go here for lunch and give it a try. I ordered the smoked salmon sandwich with a small cranberry juice and my friend ordered the ahi tuna sandwich. The food was alright: quality was good but the portions are not worth the money. The sandwich was about $13.50 and there was hardly any salmon in it, most of it was just lettuce. The small cranberry juice I ordered was incredibly small and warm as well, not worth it's price in my opinion. The aspect that really docked off points was the service. We had a rude waiter who treated us like he wanted to just seat us, serve us, and get us out asap. When he handed me my cranberry juice, he literally just held it out for me to grab and wasn't even looking in my direction, like serving me was a nuisance to him. My friend was short changed for the bill but in their defense, it was only 2 cents, nothing to cry over. However, when we told the waiter he said "Ok" and dumped our bill on some counter top and never got back to it. We waited about 5 minutes to let them sort it out and when it was apparent no one was going to take care if it we just decided to take our change and leave. Again, I don't think 2 cents is worth complaining about but he wasn't asking the waiter to perform a difficult task either. Overall, the portions are mediocre and the service was just bad; although the seating was pretty quick despite the large crowd there. But I wouldn't go back.
author: Austin C.

description: Service was mediocre- person calling out name was about to take someone else in because we didnt respond in 2 seconds when he called. We were on the list and since there were so many people in line we couldn't get to the front door until 5 seconds later. He had no patient to wait. The house potatoes were hard to eat and needs to be boiled a bit longer. Overall the food was ok, not really worth the hour- to an hour and a half wait.
author: Diana S.

description:
Zazie is a romantic little French restaurant that gets very little ink for just how good it is. Every dish has been delicious (I've heard, as I only order one thing, save for the surprise Prix Fixe menu on Valentine's Day). Zazie is perfect for a special occasion; the atmosphere is really great inside, which you will almost never hear me talk about, but for a nice place it lacks the snobbishness of many others. Every meal starts with an incredibly fresh and hot roll, which is far too small for how delicious it is. This roll was definitely a precursor of what was to come. And to end the meal they have some insanely decadent desserts. My favorite is the chocolate-coma inducing Baked Chocolat Chaud, which tastes almost like brownie batter topped with tons of melted marshmallows. Absolutely delicious.

But none of that matters here. What is important is that Zazie is hands down the best place to take your significant other for a special occasion/romantic dinner, and still have one of the best burgers you can get your hands on. They offer one burger, the Zazie burger, with white cheddar, tomatoes provençals, and a side of grilled potatoes. I don't know what tomatoes provençals are, so they are swept off to the girlfriends plate. The bacon for a $2 additional charge is well worth it, and brings the total for this bad boy to $14.

The whole time you wait for your burger, all you can do is think about that tiny roll they served you early on. I think the service is reasonably quick, but after eating that little roll the only thing running through my head is how I could probably eat about 20 more, or if the people at the table next to me won't be looking when the waitress drops off their rolls. Time seems to just crawl, which is just about all I can do after eating the burger and then the dessert. Finally the burger arrives, and it delivers. The bun is just as good as that little roll, buttery and crisp on the outside. White cheddar has been popping up more often lately, and it is a trend I like (hopefully it becomes the next pomegranate or avocado or sweet potato fries). The white cheddar and bacon, again a crucial addition, are a stellar combination. It's obvious Zazie takes pride in what they serve, and both the cheese and bacon are rich and flavorful. The bacon is crispy enough where you won't have to worry about pulling the rest of it out when you first bite into it, which as we all know can throw off the whole balance of a burger. Surprisingly, the fancy leafy greens on top also compliment the burger very well.

This has to be one of the most well-balanced and refined burgers out there, while still being a true burger. I didn't know this burger existed when I went to Zazie for the first time, and was expecting to have to eat something way too "fancy" where I'd just end up pushing about half the plate to the side. Instead I was absolutely blown away by this burger. Wouldn't matter if this was from a burger shack, a trailer, or the fanciest restaurant, this is a top 5 burger all the way. Add in the killer dessert, and the fact that you can impress your date there, who will be more than happy with their menu whatever their taste may be, and you've got one of best experiences for any burger lover.

If this burger were any cheaper, I'd be there twice a month for sure.

-Burger and Destroy
author: Mike M.

description:
Love the food.  Everything that we ordered was cooked to perfection, flavors are fantastic, fresh ingredients.  The best in town as far as flavor is concerned.  Just like French food is supposed to taste like.

The lost star is for customer service, which is cool at best.  My husband and I came in at 6:05 for our 6pm reservation and were coolly informed by the waiter that we "will need to vacate our table by 8pm."  So what happens at 8, they throw us out?  Do we still have to pay the bill if they do?

Being so popular has definitely gone to their heads.  So, for my birthday, my husband is taking me somewhere with better service.  I just don't feel like dealing with their "we don't care if you come back" attitude on my special occasion.
author: A. B.

description: Quite a wait but I wanted a great brunch during my short stay in San Francisco and if so many people are willing to wait that long it must be good.  The wait was worth it.  Not only did it give me a chance to wander around a new neighborhood for a bit but the patio was absolutely wonderful.  Covered in vines and adorable potted plants and decorations, this patio was the ideal place to eat brunch.  My food was amazing and the staff was very friendly.
author: Bridget B.

description: Just got from brunch at Zazie!  It was fab!  Wait the extra time to sit out on the patio if the weather is nice like today.  We ordered the chicken apple sausage, french toast and the Albert Omelet.  All very good and the perfect amount of food.  Iced coffee was great and they have awesome glasses...I have a thing for a good cup! Can't wait to go back and try their french onion soup!
author: Jessica B.

description: I've been here a few times for brunch. The food is consistently good and I love the atmosphere of the place, but it is nothing remarkable. The best sweet dish I've had so far is the gingerbread pancakes, worst has been the french toast tahiti. I don't think you can go wrong with their poached eggs. I'll go when friends suggest the place but would not suggest it myself.
author: Richa A.

description:
I love Zazie - French comfort food done really well. It's always a safe bet if you're looking for unpretentious good food at reasonable prices.

I had the French onion soup for an appetizer. I'd forgotten how good it was.The broth was well balanced and delicious. The grilled vegetable platter, including marinated mushrooms, roasted tomato, eggplant with chevre and some other yummies was also very satisfying. 

I had missed the Poulet Grand Mere which in its current incarnation comes with delicious homemade fettuccini. It hadn't been on the menu the last couple of times I'd gone to Zazie, and was a welcome return. The chicken thigh and leg is so tender the meat falls off the bone - yes, it's a cliche, but it's true. It's a healthy portion of fettuccini - you may want to take half of it home if you want to leave room for dessert. It made a delicious lunch the next day.

We had the grilled peaches and figs with whipped mascarpone cream for dessert - wow. I could have taken a tub of the cream home with me. I didn't let the server take the plate until the last bit of it was gone.

Sigh. I wish I could eat there every week.
author: a c.

description: I had the French Toast Tahiti. When I took my first bite, I immediately fell in love. It was amazing. I can't wait to come back for more!
author: Joy Y.

description: If you like either French food or breakfast in particular and happen to be near San Francisco then this is a must try. Unfortunately you are pretty much guaranteed to wait on the weekends, but that is because of the reputations Zazie has. The food at this place is nothing but amazing. You will pay for that when the bill comes, but it is worth it. It is definitely not a place to go to all the time unless you have a more than decent income. If you are a tourist and are looking for good food to add to the San Francisco experience, then go to this place. You won't be disappointed.
author: Phil M.

description: Came here for breakfast this morning and shared the French Toast Tahiti and Eggs en Fonte with Chicken Apples Sausage. One of the best breakfasts I've had in a while! Don't forget to make use of the table raspberry jam - delish! Great for a casual morning meal. The bloody mary was just so-so - I wouldn't order it again. The French Toast though - will probably draw me back again.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Ok, I guess I'll have to check out brunch next time. . .  I've gone here for dinner twice and it was just great;  you can't walk out of here without finishing anything you order.  Service is awesome - the staff are considerate, informative, and make you feel at home (the last time I went for dinner, the maitre'd saw me standing outside in the cold and invited me into the restaurant while I waited for my friend.)

Tuesday nights are great because there's no corkage fee, but their wine list is so good, you'll want to order from it.  There's a prix fixe menu as well - just the right amount of food for sampling the awesome menu.  Some dishes I've had were the pumpkin ravioli and polenta cakes.  I drool over the salmon, so that's on the next trip.  But first things first - did I say I am going back for brunch this time?

UPDATE 11/23/09:
I finally came here for brunch - yummy.  The un, deux, trois was just perfect because it was like a sample plate of some of the tantalizing brunch items.  Coffee was decent, and service still awesome.  I'd come back over and over again just to try everything on the menu.  Still great!
author: Julie C.

description:
We made sure to arrive at Zazie well before the weekend brunch crowd, and we were rewarded with a table very quickly. The place is tiny and you're elbowing your neighbors and knocking somebody each time you or they move in their chair, but instead of being annoying, it just came off as being cozy (ah, the rationalizations I make!).

We ordered a mocha and a cappuccino, which came in large bowls. Both were too milky and didn't have enough cocoa or coffee flavor, but the generous serving sizes somewhat made up for the deficiency. For breakfast we had the poached eggs, valence style (served on a slice of grilled eggplant and english muffins, and smothered in a sour tomato sauce) and scrambled eggs fontainebleu style (three kinds of mushrooms and fontina cheese). Both were served with roasted potatoes w/ garlic, and the latter with toast and preserves. It was all simply delicious!  Service was efficient and unobtrusive. 

As we were leaving, we found a long line of people waiting outside - so get here early!
author: Abha R.

description: Worth. The. Wait. One of the best breakfasts/brunches I've ever had. Make sure you order the bloody mary's.
author: Angela K.

description:
The staff here have a great attitude. Here we were, a group of 5, on one of the biggest brunch days of the year, New Years Day (AKA national hangover day must enjoy the hair that bite the dog so I don't kill myself). The waiting list was three pages. We were on page three. The staff told us we could wait at the bar next door. They were never touchy when you came back to see where you were on the list. In fact, they were nice! All and all, the hour wait went by rather quickly. 

When we finally sat down, the service was also good. We ordered a rather expensive, but rather crisp and delicious champagne. My friends and I were having SUCH a good time and that champagne was really working it's magic on my hangover. As for food, I ordered the ALBERT which comes with poached eggs over tomatoes and bacon with hollandaise. My friends all got different variations of poached egg dishes. One of them got the LA MER with avocado and crab, which she really enjoyed. All in all though, I wasn't very impressed with the food. When the bill came I was sad that I had to pay 28 bucks (large parties = gigantic tip that boosts up your costs even if you only had one thing). My friend's boyfriend found his meal really bland and said that it really wasn't worth what we walked out paying. I'd have to agree. I enjoyed my time there but the food was really unexceptional. I kept thinking about how great our day was but how much greater it would have been had we eaten at the French restaurant I'd just been to in Philadelphia, Parc. There everything was so good, and I mean everything. Why can't more restaurants in SF be reasonably priced and have EVERYTHING that hits your table be a smashing hit? Who wants to make it happen captain?
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Even with all of the hype, this place impressed me. The weather in cole valley is not the best, but the heat lamps in the back help. The eggs genevieve was delicious. The eggs were light, fluffy, and delicious. The white cheddar and black forest ham provided nice contrast to the egg. The home fries were soft with crispy edges and well seasoned. The avocado was sliced fresh while the toast was nice and crisp. The smoked salmon sandwich was awesome. The salmon had the right amount of salt and smoke, without overpowering the fish. The capers and red onion complimented the fish wonderfully. There didn't seem to be any cream in the cream of mushroom soup, but it was still good. The earthy flavor of the mushrooms was brought out by just the right amount of salt.
Overall, everything here was great. I can't think of any place with better brunch food. However, the wait may get too crazy sometimes and the food mat not be worth it.
author: Siao W.

description:
Service Sucks! Started good ended bad. 

My two sisters and I arrived for a late Sunday brunch.  We waited about 40 minutes (to be expected)  before being seated on the cute little back patio.  We placed our orders.  So far so good. 

Both of my sisters food arrived.  Mine did not.  

We waited a minute.  I told them to eat so their food wouldn't be cold.  They cut into their fancy benedict breakfasts and one egg on each plate was rock solid.  Since I still had no food in front of me, my sister gave me a bite of the one egg that was OK, we had eaten half of the little benedict stack  when the server finally arrived with my food.  My sisters asked to have their solid eggs replaced.  We asked for a little plate to put the over cooked eggs on so we could continue eating what was properly cooked.  Instead the server took both of their plates away.  Now I was the only one with a plate.  After a few minutes we asked the server how much longer until we got the replacement eggs.  The server replied, "well at least you have one plate" .  WTF?!
Starving... my sisters and I ate all the food on my plate.  Our server was at this point no where to be seen.  Fifteen minutes later the two plates came back to our table.  One plate only had one benedict stack... the one she had shared with me that we had only half of was removed from our plate and not replaced.  

Wow. 

We got no apology whatsoever! 
I expected more.
author: Cotille D.

description:
The food was good, let's just get that out of the way.  I went with 2 other people and we all enjoyed our meals.

I had the French Toast Tahiti (french toast stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts).  It was delicious, but considering that it came with nothing other than the 4 pieces of french toast, it was definitely a little pricey at $9.00.
My girlfriend got the salad with seared tuna, which was good as well.

The patio seating is a little cramped and some of the tables can't be moved, so we ended up sitting in awkward positions to keep from getting sunburned on various parts of our bodies.  If it had just been me and my lady, it might have been a nice brunch setting, but having more than 2 people made it difficult to find comfortable seating arrangements outside.  I wouldn't recommend the patio for large groups.

The servers were very nice and prompt.  I'd definitely go back and try some more of their dishes.
author: c o.

description:
Another reason I like Cole Valley.  Zazie helps to define the character of the neighborhood.

I've only gone for breakfast and have never been disappointed.  So, whether you want a quick breakfast early in the morning or are willing to wait with the crowds on the weekends, I think you will be satisfied all the way.

I'm a big fan of the eggs benedict (either the Florentine or Le Mer), especially with the garlic potatoes.  The pancakes or french toast are both awesome and plentiful.  The juice and mimosa drink selections are good.

Try to get a seat in the garden.  It may be cool outside but they have heaters and it's not as loud as the inside can get.

If you do have to wait outside, try not to block the sidewalk like everyone else.
author: Stephen W.

description:
In brief:

Price:  It's ok - not the cheapest brunch place, though and not the place I would go for "quantity"
Food:  Not bad
Atmosphere:  I like the availability of outdoor seating and the crowd is on the younger side
Service: Could have been better
Would I go back again?:  If I'm in the area - maybe, but Zazie doesn't excite me as much as it does others who've reviewed it

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Details:

I wanted to try a new brunch place and found Zazie through yelp (go yelp!).  So I went there Saturday afternoon with the BF for "Linner" around 2-3 and there was still a wait, which I suppose was a good sign.  Fortunately the wait was fairly short (~15 minutes) and we were able to sit outside in the back.  

Almost everything on the menu looked pretty good and I couldn't decide between pancakes or eggs, but I ended up going with the Fountainbleu scamble.  The neat thing about the menu is that you have the option of choosing 1, 2, or 3 eggs or pancakes so you can make your own combo for those that like to have the savory and sweet at the same time. 

My eggs were ok, but was almost cold by the time I got it.  The BF's BLT ended up being one side of an open faced sandwich consisting of a slice of some sort of crusty artisan bread shmeared with some of cheese (I forgot what kind), sitting under a few strips of bacon and some roasted tomatoes.  The lettuce part came in the form of a salad on the side.  

Service could have been improved a little.  We didn't get utensils until after our food arrived and we had to have another server help us since our server wasn't around.  

Overall, if I was really hungry, I wouldn't go here because of the parking, the wait and the not-so-huge portions.  However, if you want to eat nice looking food amidst nice-looking people, then Zazie's the place to be.
author: Amy C.

description:
The perfect little place, out of the way, that really makes me feel like I'm out of the way.

I close my eyes and pretend that I'm tucked away in some little provincial town, sipping my larger than life latte. 

Ah...

I had the ricotta lemon pancakes. I never in my wildest dreams could have thought that pancakes could be so ethereal. My friend had the eggs of somewhat benedict. They were named for an area in France to which I can not recall. Maybe the heaven part of France? To die for! 

We had to wait for a bit to get a seat but well worth it. Our server was lovely and I can't say a negative thing about Zazie!
author: Christina R.

description:
"Flat sitck". It's Euro-racing speak for full on, 100% as much as you can give. Zazie does this in a comfortable, chill, relaxed Franco-American atmosphere. I dig it. You should too. If you don't, there something wrong with you and you have, as the Americans say "Le Baggage".

Dinner is where Zazie shines. Everyone south of the Marina knows about brunch but my favorite is the Tuesday night "no corkage" dinner. Bring your friends, a bottle or three of your favorite wine, and enjoy country French cuisine with exceptional (yet chill) service.

Recently, some friends and I had the Steak au Poive - which never disappoints, the lamb chop and cous cous with currant special - insane and perfectly prepared, and the rabbit which was, as expected, quite good. The salad Betterave, which I"ve had before, was a little lacking in flavor...but fresh and fair enough.

The food is solid and unpretentious while being a bit off the beaten SF path. The wine list is good (though again, Tuesdays is the night) and the folks always make you feel at home. My favorite neighborhood dinner joint.
author: Jordan K.

description:
I love this place for brunch or dinner.  It was our favorite when my wife and I lived in Cole Valley, and we still go there from time to time for dinner.  Great, cozy atmosphere which we love, and the host is always terrific.  Great steaks, lamb stew when they have it, and haven't had a bad fish there ever.  We were sad when they retired the brownie, though *single tear*.

They went through some growing pains as the place got more popular - the service slowed and sometimes we felt a bit neglected, but it seems that they've worked through that as we have not had a problem the last few times we've gone.

_______________________

update:  the owner emailed me the recipe to her brownies.  I am indeed cooler than everyone else on the planet without exception.
author: Jason B.

description:
Zazie is probably the classiest brunch spot in Cole Valley/Upper Haight, which is a welcome difference from Squat and Gobble or All You Knead (don't get me wrong I like those places too, they have their place) every once in a while.

I went on a Sunday at about 10.30 and was seated with in 5 minutes, no horrible like like everyone warns about, maybe I was there too early for the normal Sunday crowd, I guess I just can't sleep in like I used to be able to. 

I had the salmon eggs Benedict and the English muffins were perfectly crisp and the eggs were nice and fluffy. The Zazie spritzer was a nice fresh juice in the morning that wasn't too sweet and extra bonus points for filling my cappuccino mug with drip coffee after I was done, the wait staff knows a caffeine addict when they see one.

The interior is very warm and welcoming and all the French stuff on the walls add a touch. On a nice day the porch can't be beat and makes you forget about the loud N-Judah barreling down the road half a block away.

UPDATE: Went back for dinner this time over the weekend as my girlfriend and I liked the atmosphere, we took a peek at the menu online and the fairly prix fixe menu ($23.50 for 3 courses, limited selection of the menu) reeled us in. The thing that I think I like most about this place is that the food is solid and its unpretentious, just solid dining. The apple crumble was perfect and the salmon cooked with fennel, leeks and potatoes was a great entree. 

I think I found my new favorite restaurant in SF, be it for breakfast, lunch or dinner.
author: Nicholas B.

description:
I've heard so much hype about Zazie.

I'm not talking about some crap I read in SF Weekly or some other stuff written by someone who I don't know.  I'm talking about the friends of mine who've been like "hey, Zazie is really good!"

Then again all my friends eat crap.

Usually Zazie has about 217 (fairly accurate estimation) people waiting and shuffling around in front between 11am and 1pm on the weekends.  I went over to Tully's and sucked down a few quarts of coffee before going over there at about 1:50pm.  We put our name in before walking around for a few minutes:

Props on the service.  The guy hosting outside actually made an effort to come up and ask if we were waiting and where we were in the list.  On seeing we were next for 2, he immediately seated us at a just cleaned table.  Our waitress was very nice and eschewed sweet-talking us.  We asked her to contrast the pancakes with fruit and the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd.  She told us straight out that the gingerbread were absolutely awesome and the pancakes with fruit was something we could probably get somewhere else.  That takes some balls.

The food was delicious.  The (Ron) Mexico scramble (chorizo, eggs, cheese, salsa) was great and the garlic potatoes were tasty.  The whole thing came with thick ass slices of fresh wheat toast.  The gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd were absolutely awesome.  I'm not a huge pancake fan, but I had to start digging into my dining partner's leftovers.  I thought they would be too sweet but the gingerbread worked well with the curd.

The prices are also great.  I had an awesome, proper sit down brunch that was higher in quality and cheaper than what I had a Frjtz recently.  I know those two places don't exactly compare well but you would think Zazie would be more expensive.  The decor was good as well.  It's obvious it promotes itself as a sort of pseudo French bistro, but it doesn't go overboard and try to "convince" you that this in fact what it is.  The spaces can be a little cramped but hopefully you're too focused on the food to let that bother you.

It does kind of blow that you have to come here either at 9am or after 1:30p, but as I've mentioned before, it's probably for a good (tasty) reason.
author: Steven R.

description:
Like Zazie needs another review. But I'm so brilliant, that - yeah, it does.

Great neighborhood breakfast place; decent dinner fare. WAY too popular and loud, so be like me and start your own business. Then you can show up any time.

I especially love the handle-less cups that force you to drink your espresso as if you are a monk sipping miso soup. End of story.
author: Poker M.

description:
This is a great place to get drunk (or at least mildly buzzed, depending on your budget) before 3pm on a Sunday. And really, who can't benefit from another place to do that? I liked the brunch food better than the brunch booze, and admittedly it is usually the other way around. There is a wide variety of mimoas, but as I recently found out, that doesn't actually mean you should try them all. 

The food was good but not great, but priced accordingly: more expensive than similar menu items at Bean Bag Cafe (and better), less expensive than brunch items at Absynth (but not quite as memorable). The roommate and I split French Toast Tahiti (stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts, but a little skimpy on the walnuts) & poached eggs with a tomato-chavre sauce instead of hollandaise. Good combo of savory+sweet. 

Sit outside. Ask the staff to put them umbrellas down. Put on your sunglasses and try not to let the wailing baby inside ruin your spirits (note: the Spirits menu will help with this.)
author: kay v.

description:
Gingerbread pancakes. That's what I'm talkin' 'bout. Douse them in syrup. Just drown those suckers. Regardless of what I order, there will always be an order of gingerbread pancakes on the table for all to share. 

Beyond the 'cakes, there are plenty of other nicities to eats. A nice cozy spot that unfortunately gets crazy busy.
author: John S.

description: Party of 12!... ended up being party of 9. they had all set up and ready to go - even had customized menus for us, later sliced up as part of our dessert decoration. Food was plentiful, service was excellent, check it out, but not without reservations!!
author: Kristina Y.

description:
This was my first adventure into Cole Valley and I would like to say.."Hot Damn - that is a cute place!"  Onto what we really came here for... Zazie.

On a street filled with many delectable brunch options, I found that Zazie held its own.  I had the eggs florentine with one egg.  PERFECT PORTION!  
I eat eggs benedict a LOT and this was by far the best.  The hollandaise sauce was rich with flavor, but light.  
The grapefruit mimosa and  garlic roasted home fries were the perfect compliment.

Cheers to Zazie!  I can't wait to go back and try the gingerbread pancakes!!!!  :)
author: Becky T.

description:
Yum. Went there on Saturday and the food was great. Our waitress was incredibly sweet and attentive.
 

A should-go-to place in the city!
author: Art A.

description: The food was delicious, but they charged $3.00 for a "SF health care ordinance".  They make it sound like the are required to charge this, but in reality this is just a sneaky charge.
author: Dr D.

description: Only been here once for brunch. The wait was pretty long, as it is for most places in the city for brunch. For some reason this place wasn't exactly my thing. The menu was a little limited for my liking and was pretty strict on no substitutions. I had a scrambled egg dish with soy chorizo. The soy chorizo was good actually but I wasn't too impressed overall. The side items with my brunch was large chunks of potato that had huge cloves of garlic all over them. The garlic is actually tasty and amazing, but don't get them if you plan on going out later! The food was just okay and I wouldn't wait that long to go back again.
author: Raheleh K.

description: Lovely place for a Sunday brunch. There's no reservations for lunch so come early especially if you have a big crowd. This place is especially a treat if you come on a sunny warm day and can sit outside in the back patio. (They also have heaters if it's a bit colder). The omlette special and gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd are awesome.
author: Amy T.

description: This is one of my favourite brunch places in San Francisco. They have the best eggs benedict ever which was perfect because I went through an eggs benedict phase when I lived in SF. My favourite dish from them is their eggs albert! The wait can be excruciating so try to get there early - before the hunger pangs kick in.
author: N D.

description: Great brunch place, good atmosphere and service, but be warned small space can = long wait. I especially adore the Betterave salad, the various mimosas, apple cider and gingerbread pancakes. Hate to say it this way but it seems like a sweet date spot.
author: Melinda K.

description:
Herd behavior is interesting.  Sometimes people will wait for a long time for something that is not that great just because everyone else is.  Some people feel that if they don't wait a long time for something, it must not be good.  Some really wacky people even feel that waiting a long time for something is part of the fun: the perfect time to see and be seen and fawn over dogs and babies and compare recent purchases from catalogues.  All these people line up in front of Zazie every Saturday and Sunday morning for a brunch that is good but never amazing.  

Certainly there is nothing wrong with a good brunch, but this sort of wait requires brunch that is nothing short of mind-blowing, especially to stand around in lily white Cole Valley with aforementioned dogs and babies and catalogue shoppers.

The truth is that the atmosphere really is amazing.  And coming for dinner can be nice.  The brandied pâté appetizer is delicious.  

But for brunch, Bambino's next door is much better, and there is never a wait.  True, the flecked marble tables and '90s red pendant lights won't evoke quite the same feeling as the rustic French cuteness of Zazie, but the food will be equally as satisfying without having to play list-jockey while some minivanners with kids try to cut in line.
author: Michael D.

description:
Two of my cardinal rules are:

1. I will NOT wait in line for coffee (sorry Blue Bottle).
2. I will NOT wait in line for brunch.

I break both rules weekly and sometimes daily. But I have never been happier to break it for Zazie. The food was very good brunch fair (nothing too remarkable to report). But the mimosas were awesome! You get, like, an entire bottle of champagne plus mixing fluid.

Zazie got me wasted and full and happy.
Worth a 1 hour wait? Kind of...
author: Trey F.

description: Back patio is very nice for a morning coffee. Food was great - French toast with caramelized bananas and walnuts! Yum! Only negative is there is a line before they even open.
author: Chris B.

description: I have been going to Zazie for years. Today I went and the waiter seemed to have many tables. I gave him a huge tip and asked if he could pack up both my plates. Apparently he wasn't listening, because he threw my other plate away. Now I regret giving him a good tip, because obviously he didn't listen to what I asked him to do. All he said was sorry.. The manager wasn't helpful with the situation at all. I will never go back to Zazie.
author: Michael S.

description: Yum and more yum, the salmon poached eggs were amazing! Full garlic cloves in the home fries, a great outdoor patio, what more could you want? Spent 30 minutes waiting and was well worth the wait.
author: Katelyn W.

description: It's super small. There will most likely be a wait for brunch. Everyone will most likely be waiting in the Pete's next door. It will be entirely worth the wait for the Gingerbread Pancakes. They are huge (I could only eat 1) and served with delicious lemon sauce. I wish I could somehow get them delivered.
author: Stacey H.

description:
Brunch here hit the spot. Some of the best bacon I've had. Salty, crispy, delicious.

Zazie reminds me of La Note in Berkeley. Both French, delicious and small with a super duper wait. In reality we waited probably 30 minutes which isn't so bad. We also got there just at the right time (just before 10:30 a.m.) to put our names down. In 20 minutes or so the list was already on the next page about as far down as I had put my name. So this place books up fast. I recommend getting there at least as early as we did. While we were eating, there was a continually huge crowd outside and I'm sure it just gets huger through peak brunch hours.

But once you get inside, it's definitely worth the wait. Everyone loved their food which included the Un, Deux, Trois (One pancake, 2 eggs, 3 bacon), special scramble, poached egg with toast and Croque Royale. I had the Un, Deux, Trois - eggs were perfect, one pancake is plenty and I've already mentioned the bacon.

Our waitress was very attentive, smart and a little humorous. My only complaint for the consumables was the coffee. It tasted acidic and burnt to me. It could have just been too strong but I didn't think so. I've had delicious strong coffee elsewhere, but I didn't want to drink this one. My OJ was good though.

I'll definitely come back when I have the time to wait for brunch and I definitely want to try the dinner menu. Overall, tasty, good service but long wait, slightly cramped space.

p.s. they won't seat you until you're all there. That's probably smart for them, but sucky when one of your party trying to find parking foreeeeveeeer. Make sure everyone is prompt.
author: Karen J.

description: Loved this place! We went here on a Wednesday night and were pleasantly surprised by this little restaurant in Cole Valley. Our waiter was great, very attentive. The hot rolls they served were delicious. We ordered a cup of their soup of the day (it was a kale and bean soup) and I had fish and my husband had a chicken dish. This restaurant reminded us of some of the restaurants we used to eat at in the east village in NYC. This place is a little neighborhood gem!
author: Anne D.

description:
So I decided to try this place out because everyone seems to love it. WELL, I guess I went on the wrong day and got the wrong things on the menu but... Yeah, definitely don't think I'm going to go back unless the bitch disguised as my server decides to check her 'tude. I went with my friends to get some brunch and I was really, REALLY looking forward to it. I got the un, doe, trois (spell check?) well, okay I'm not going to make a dumbass of myself, I got the one, two, three and changed the pancakes for the tahiti french toast but the bitch gave me regular french toast. I didn't want to be a problem customer so I ate it anyway. Everything was pretty mediocre, I could have made my own french toast, bacon and over-easy eggs but whatever. Anyway, service was alright, we went around 2 PM so the restaurant was basically empty but I still didn't get the kind of attention I expected to get. When it came to the check, my friends and I split it- I marked everything and organized the whole receipt to help her know which items to charge to which card. The noncontributing zero waitress rolled her eyes at me and gave me HELLA attitue. Um... sorry bitch but I'm pretty sure this is your job. Don't get me wrong, I was a server for a long time and I understand its frustrating when there are a lot of people but uh.. pretty sure there were a total of seven people in that restaurant at the time. I don't think she was slammed with tables and orders or anything. Anyway, overall not impressed and uninspired, maybe I'll give it another try again another time when I'm craving soggy french toast and bitchy attitudes. 

P.S. the only reason why this place got two stars is because of the atmosphere and decor- I love cute restaurants! But if you're going to give any attitude or roll your eyes, make sure to turn around completely first. Duh.
author: De Ann W.

description:
If you eat here on a reasonably nice day, or even on a slightly unpleasant day, you should sit outside.  The outdoors patio is charming and very cozy, and they have heaters :)

The mimosas here are delectable, there are various flavors such as mango and pomegranate, and of course the original, fresh squeezed OJ.  The pancakes here are what keep me interested though, they are huge, fluffy, and just the right amount of sweet.  I got the un, deux, trois last time, and my friend got the french toast.  The french toast was not a hit because it had a licorice-like flavor, which neither of us liked, but we still finished it anyway.

The bacon here is yummy and cooked to perfection, the oj is beautifully fresh squeezed, the raspberry jam is authetnic, and the prices are not bad.  The only thing I have any slight hesitation about is the wait, which is unpredictable.  But I guess with a place this scrumptious there's gonna be a wait for sure, right?
author: ting b.

description: Great date spot.  Romantic.   Great food.   Friendly service.   If it is not too cold out, best table in the house are the corners of heated patio.
author: Tyson V.

description:
Yum yum yum... this review is for brunch only.

I wouldn't mind having brunch at Zazie every Sunday. My favorite is La Mer poached eggs (with dungeness crab, green onions, and avocados). So good!
author: dub m.

description:
This weekend, I was finally able to try Zazie (past attempts ended in epic fails due to long lines & my impatience). The hype is [almost entirely] warranted. My boyfriend and I ordered the exact same meal: one pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon. (Note: the eggs were scrambled, and we both subbed in a gingerbread pancake with lemon curd and a baked Bosc pear.) The pancake was heavenly: easily the best carb-based experience I've had in the past year, if not ever. The tanginess of the lemon curd complemented the spices in the pancake, and the pear had just the right texture. Bacon was pretty good, though a bit fatty. The eggs (in both orders) were undercooked; my boyfriend, being the agreeable person that he is, ate his, but I just picked at mine. My mimosa was heavy on the champagne(!) Despite the runniness of the eggs, I will be back! In the meantime, I'm going to scout a recipe for gingerbread pancakes...

UPDATE: This time around, Zazie did not fail to impress. The gingerbread pancakes were as good as I remembered, the bacon was leaner (and crispy: holla for cronchy bacon!), and the grapefruit juice mimosa was the most refreshing boozy breakfast drink I've had in quite some time. Service was also friendly. Yay, Zazie: our out-of-town guests were also smitten!
author: Kate G.

description: Eating their gingerbread pancakes is like waving a ho-ho in front of a diabetic: deliciously dangerous.
author: Alex H.

description:
the gingerbread pancake with lemon curd alone gives this place 5 stars.  i'm not even a pancake person and am in LOVE with this dish.

i'm also a huge eggs benedict fan so having all those options is a plus.
author: Helen T.

description:
My hubby heard great things about Zazie from friends and saw good Yelp reviews, so he made a reservation mid-week for family date night.  

There were two of us and a toddler. We got seated on the patio, which is lovely on those rare warm days in the city.  You're close enough to other tables where it's a bit intimate, but not too nosy.  We split a carafe of a Rose wine and had quite a bit of food to wash it down with during our 1.5 hour meal.  We got served hot bread & butter, then ordered buttered noodles for the lil' one, mussels and a cheese plate for ourselves for appetizers and the lamb and salmon for entrees.  All of the food was well-prepared and nicely presented.  The lamb entree is large and definitely good for 2 people.  The salmon was steamed in parchment and a little over-done for our taste, but still tasted good. For dessert, we got the fruit crumble and it was nice, especially w/ice cream on the side.  Zazie's also very kid-friendly; they brought out paper and crayons for the lli' one right away and on Wednesdays there's free mac-n-cheese or ice cream for the lil' ones.  

While I think the food is delicious, it wasn't quite 5-star worthy.  I think this is a nice neighborhood-y eatery -- the service was good and the food was good.  Still, it wasn't "great" enough to make me want to come back here often.  It may be a repeat for brunch if I can get there early enough, based on all the other Yelp reviews of long waits on the weekend.
author: T M.

description:
Consistently the best brunch I've ever had in SF - and I've been to a lot of brunch places. My favorite is the poached eggs albert style. 

Don't much care for the dinners here, though the desserts are great.

Ambience is charming.

Pricey, of course, but worth it.
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
I think the staff at Zazie thinks my friend Jen and i are a lesbian couple.... ha ha
seriously we go there every Saturday morning and despite the long wait sometimes it is always definitely worth it.
oh the Benedict's, the scrambled eggs...how i love you, let me count the ways.
they have a slammin BLT too.
but be weary of the ketchup, Jen has issues with it, i don't but if you are weird abt your condiments bring some Heinz packets!
btdubbs...awesome patio
author: o. c.

description:
The brunch is great great great (esp in the garden) - but the line is so friggin ridiculous between 10:30 and noon, you'd better pack a sandwich. Somehow, though, after you're finally seated, you aren't made to feel rushed - although there are still 3000 starving people camped out on the sidewalk.

Note: If you're willing to sit at outer sidewalk tables, there's usually no wait. Inside, moderate. Garden, give it at least 20-30 minutes.

But it's ok b/c Mario (the host most weekends) has a way of making you feel tended to despite the wait. Then, if you go back again and again, he goes out of his way to greet you each time, make you feel this is your own private Cheers spot. He might easily do this for everyone he vaguely recognizes - but I am happy to buy the illusion that I am special when I walk in the door. Why not?

They have a nice dinner, too - $20 prix fixe. Slower, quieter hour for this place. The food is good (esp the fresh pasta) - but the portions are inconsistent at times. But if you're lucky, Suhail might treat you to a glass of wine for no reason at all. 

And yes, for non-neighbors, parking is a bitch. But it's just a half block up from the N Judah, and down from the 6 Parnassus...
author: kt s.

description:
I know everyone says this is the go-to place for brunch, but I haven't been here for brunch. I was here for dinner, and oh, was it good. Get the polenta cakes, which are actually thick wedges of polenta, fried until they're crispy outside but still creamy within, topped with sauteed mushrooms and a drizzle of mascarpone, lapped by a pool of spicy tomato cream sauce with islands of garlic sauteed spinach. The waitress will ask if you want prawns on it, but don't do it. It doesn't need it. If the bread pudding of the day is chocolate caramel, get that, too. It will make your tongue do the happy dance.

Excellent food. Friendly service. Wine in little juice glasses like the French do it. Yum.
author: Fawn F.

description:
I have the wonderful advantage of enjoying Zazie during the week and minus the hordes.  But sometimes I do go on the weekend and I think it is worth the wait.  Great poached eggs and two words: TOASTED PANNETONE!  All year round!

I just have to chime in from a server's perspective for a moment: It is rude and moderately tacky to bring your latte in from the place next door.  Sure go get your fix but just throw it out before you go in to a restaurant.
author: Stacey d.

description: On my last trip to San Francisco I had a brunch date with 4 other pals at Zazie.  We sat outside and enjoyed a great meal.  I ended up ordering and sharing a 2 layer pancake and an eggs Benedict.  Can I say YUMMY!!!  Very cute, quaint, and enjoyable.  Please take me there again elisa!!!
author: S Y.

description:
Every time im in cole valley there is a mob scene out front of this place, so when a friend of mine suggested we wait it out for a table (sunday brunch), I agreed...
We got lucky and bi-passed the 1 hour wait and grabbed a first come first see table outside..sun spot and all..
The service: GREAT
Food: nothin special, typical brunch menu
Coffee: not strong enough (and i got a triple espresso)
OJ: at a place like this, youd expect fresh squeezed, but they serve cheap watery OJ.
For brunch on cole GO TO the boulange de cole, up the street.
author: CadoBaby P.

description:
The back garden patio is a perfect brunch spot on a warm SF Sunday.  My cousins, brother and I met for a cozy brunch (six people around two tables) and were thoroughly satisfied with our meals.  One cousin was especially pleased with making her own citron presse and spooning jam into her mouth straight from the jar.

I'll have to return to try the BLT - the one that arrived at the table next to ours was mouthwatering and envy-inducing.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I was lucky enough to visit this restaurant with a man who likes to eat. Between the two of us I think that we ordered three entrees, several beverages, and a few sides for brunch. It was all amazing. 

I would recommend going on a sunny day. You have to put your name on a waiting list, often the wait is 45 minutes for inside seating, and and hour for outside seating, if you can stand it I would recommend waiting for patio seating. The patio is really nice, tables with umbrellas, flowers, and its not too hot in the sun. The wait is not a problem on a nice day, because there are several cute stores in the area to browse, and a nearby park where many people walk their adorable dogs.  . 

The eggs benedict are the best that I have had in San Francisco, I especially recommend the crab benedict.  I have not been for dinner here, but I have been told that it is very good, reasonably priced and very romantic seating in the patio area.
author: Lisa M.

description:
I love Zazie's brunch
although I've never had their lunch

My friends and I walked from town
Expecting to be let down

Instead I found a classic sight
Croque Madam is a wonderful bite

My day was turning bombastic
and that was just fantastic
 
A cautious word to all you yelpers who refuse to wait
Make sure to call and reserve a date.
author: Girls Named Cherise C.

description:
No complaints AT ALL! Went on a Saturday, for brunch. The wait was minimal. The staff was really nice and prompt. I thoroughly enjoyed my Italie scramble, as well as the single gingerbread pancake. Yea, add the shared pitcher of black currant, and it sounds like "a lot".
W/evs.
It's how I roll. My friend had the Tahiti french toast, which was delicious as well. I went 2 days ago, and am aching to try some more of the menu. At this rate, it shouldn't take too long...
author: Walter G.

description:
I don't usually do breakfast/brunch in the city. If i did it would be more of a drinking brunch kind of thing. 
For actual feasting brunches i tend to travel outside the fog and enjoy some sun w/my meal and make a day of it.

But since my schedule hasn't been very giving, and i actually had to eat and not drink brunch, this is the place to do it.  

I heart the eggs florentine very much.  The challah french toast was not bad either.  Service was attentive, place is quaint ... all in all a very good time.  

Am definitely coming back.  

post script ~ was lucky didn't have to wait long, but crowds happen in a snap
author: M E.

description:
Yummy poached eggs pierre noir (pretty much eggs benedict with tomato and bacon) for brunch.  The potatoes were SO good garlicy and crispy.    

My mocha came in a huge bowl which was kinda werid.  Supposedly this is french style?

Only bad things is not much parking in the area.
author: Serena H.

description:
We didn't have to wait too long for brunch (about 15 minutes) although it was around 1pm, so there might have been more people earlier in the day.

I had the gingergbread pancakes. They were ok, not great. I thought that they were too chewy, too "burly", and a little on the dry side, even with butter and two carafes of maple syrup. The website says that you can get ice cream on them, but the menu didn't say that. The ice cream would have helped, I think.

My partner had the regular buttermilk pancakes, and they were much better -- not nearly as chewy and dry. So I think it's something about the gingerbread. 

We'll be back -- I want to try the New York Scramble (eggs with salmon, cream cheese and green onions) and one of the eggs benedict dishes, because I would bathe in hollandaise sauce if I could.
author: Kellie P.

description:
Went here in September.  Definitely the longest I have ever waited for a table, but the Eggs Saint Trop were worth it.  The interior was small and packed, (maybe a better word would be "cozy"?) so we snagged a table outside to enjoy the last of the summer sun.  Outside tables are first come first served.  Try to hover as discreetly as possible.

The chocolat chaud could have been chocolaty-er, but I love that it was served in a bowl and not in a regular ol' mug.  Nothing like cradling a warm bowl of chocolate with both hands....mmm....
author: Nikki B.

description:
We are so blessed to live in SF....a sweet climate, fun people, great food.
Please go to Zazie's, have an omelette, and then......order the BAKED HOT CHOCOLATE . Take your time, share it, and savor the wow.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Mario is an excellent manager, and the food is great. I've never had a problem with the service.

In fact, once when I went with my son, the staff went out of their way to bring out a blanket for my little guy because it was such a cold day!

When in doubt, order the French Toast Tahiti.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I LOVE Zazie!!!!!!! Holy moly, this place has some amazing selections for brunch. I am so glad my friend introduced me to this place because I've been here a few times and the french toast and pancakes are always puuuuurfect. I put the tasty food in my mouth and feel like i've gone to yummy heaven. Definitely order the French Toast Tahiti. It's stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnuts. Seriously the best french toast I've ever had. Their scrambled egg dishes are super good too. 

There's also an outdoor patio seating area, which is really really nice-especially when it's sunny outside. When the weather is a little chlly, the outdoor heaters toast you up so you're good to go. 

Love this place. Definitely worth the 5 stars!
author: Cris L.

description:
