Fantastic patio.  Excellent French Toast.  Nice crowd, Good waiters.  The sunny patio is just what one wants for a chill weekend brunch spot. I'll be back, friends in tow. 

(And the waiter was SUPER-nice about holding our table even though I was late to meet my friend. Bravo for being humane to a girl who couldn't find parking!)

Also--to the folks who were miffed about the $1/head surcharge for healthcare--it IS clearly stated on the menu, and this is somewhat common in SF nowadays!
author: alli h.

description:
The lunch is just okay (croque monsiur, etc.) but the dinner is great.  I had the salmon one night, and it was cooked to perfection.  Not dry like a lot of American places.  The beef: juicey and succulent.  Pork chops: very good.  (Again, not dry like a lot of American places.)  The dessert: yummy, but not as good as the salmon.  Had the chocolat pot de creme, cherries in vanilla bean gelato, and the berry crisp, which was good, but not memorable.  Only thing I didn't like was the fish soup (forgive me, I forget the official name) and the white fish I had.  Kind of bland.  Also had the pumpkin french toast here last Thanksgiving.  That was just okay, but it's seasonal, so that's probably why it hasn't been perfected.
P.S. Wonderful patio.
author: Natasha L.

description:
How can you possibly not love Zazie?

It seems that half of San Francisco adores the staff - the number of 'missed connections' on Craigslist that mentions Zazie's lovely waiters and waitressess is suspiciously high. It must be a new form of product placement. William Gibson would be proud. 

It seems that Zazie offers the best brunch experience in the City. I mean, brunch is the best meal of the week, so you should not accept any compromise. Choose the best and forget the rest. Choose life, choose Zazie! Believe and obey.

It seems that Zazie's menu features all the right keywords: Mimosa, Sunshine, Soju, Pancakes, French Toast, Tartine and Toilette. 

It seems that all the movie buffs are in love with this place because it is named after Louis Malle's whimsical "Zazie dans le Metro" (1960). No, it is not an example of the French Nouvelle Vague, but it quite enjoyable nonetheless. Like Zazie's dishes.

It seems that everybody agrees on one thing: Zazie has a killer patio. People would do anything to get the best spot. Murder is one of the options. All is fair in love and war.

It seems that people come from all over the world to have brunch at Zazie. For instance, I moved to San Francisco because commuting every weekend from Europe had become a bit too intense. Don't get me wrong, Air France is cool but they don't offer a killer patio.

It seems that everything here is great but coffee. Ok, I don't want to start a feud here, I love the French, but they still don't know how to make a proper espresso. Now, there's is no need to recall the Zidane-Materazzi incident here. Why can't we all get along?

It seems that people are willing to do spend hours in line just to get a table with some food on it, so it must be good. Psychologists call this 'the social proof effect'. I met a gorgeous psychologist at Zazie once,. I'm telling you, it's true. [Also known as a false syllogism]. 

In short, how can you possibly not love Zazie?

Guideline: Rent the movie, first. 

Then, order a pancake. 

Everything will make sense, in the end. It always does.

PS
The best line in "Zazie dans le metro"? Here we go:

Zazie: What's a hormosessual? 
Albertine: A man who wears blue jeans. 
Zazie: Aw, you're joking!

LOL!
author: Matt B.

description: Meh.  Seriously, you can find better food and service in town.  I gave them a few chances but they are not for me.  Honestly not sure what all the fuss is about.
author: Sally R.

description: This had been a place that I had wanted to go to for some time now and I went over the summer for my birthday. Great service in general is not a must for me, if anything its the food, but our waiter was AWESOME, so nice and very funny, the food was to die for and so was the dessert!! The wine list was great as well, I deferentially cant wait to go back!
author: T C.

description: What a sweet place! We had lunch out on the patio, grilled chicken sandwich and green salad, delicious, and excellent service. Very pleasant. Good food, pleasant surroundings, great service. Just lovely. We arrived after 1PM on a Friday and only waited about 10 minutes for a table.
author: Beth D.

description:
mm...best mussels mariniere i've had in a while. salmon grillade is fabulous and fresh. les deux cremes dessert (creme brulee and chocolate pot de creme), magnifique!

the food i ordered was fantastic, five stars. Unfortunately my bf got the duck, which had way too much rosemary and did not hold a light to the quality of my salmon. The assiette de charchuterie was a ton of food--too much for two people to share, in my opinion. nearly a lunch for 2, but the rilletes were scrumptious.

fantastic experience, but the tables are set reaaaally close together. sat next to a couple on their first date, and i felt like i was part of the conversation. (very deft manuevering and quality social skills on the parts of the young lovers though, very cute)

Also, my server forgot that i got the prix fixe, so i ordered a dessert mistakenly off the regular menu, and got charged for it...got a $3 discount when i brought up the mishap....but the two cremes were pretty damn tasty, so i wasn't that bothered.

but despite all that, it was still a highly satisfying experience. very cute!~
author: Jade L.

description: A must try, food is fresh, plentiful and very delicious. Staff is friendly and helpful and the atmosphere is pleasant meaning you can hear each other talk and don't get that rushed feeling or noisy buzzing sound going on around you.
author: BryBry D.

description: This place should get more than 5 stars. I love Zazie! This will most likely be a staple every time I visit San Francisco. The restaurant is cute, and has the nice personal touches that shows someone put thought into the decor. There is outside seating available, but I believe that is only for dinner. I peeked outside and it looked like a nice place to enjoy a fantastic Zazie meal. The staff there is very pleasant and makes you feel welcome. I had the corn pancake which was on the specials menu, it came with a very creamy lemon curd. Perfect combination. I also had the eggs benedict with crab, which was AWESOME.
author: Jen K.

description: I love this place for brunch.  It can be crazy if you have a large group or if you absolutely want to sit out back on the patio, but I've always found that the wait is never as long as they tell you.  The back patio  - and this place in general - is super cute.  The service is usually pretty good and friendly too.  I order the same thing every time - the challah french toast w/ caramelized bananas and walnuts!  So good!
author: Danielle B.

description: The Le Mer eggs benedict here is really tasty...really really tasty.  They aren't skimpy on the crab or the avocados and the roasted garlic that comes with the potatoes are incredibly yummy.  Got there at 10:30 on a Saturday morning and the wait wasn't bad at all.
author: Jen C.

description: Eggs benedict all the way. Gingerbread pancakes too. Great film inspiration for the deco too.
author: Christina V.

description:
decided to come here because the wait at mama's was over 90 minutes. as a first-time SF bruncher, i probably should've stuck around to take in the full experience, but i had gotten a late start on my day and was just way too hungry.

zazie's did not disappoint. very cute little brunch spot and the wait was only about 20 minutes. had the la mer eggs benedict with dungeness crab & avocado - SO good! also had the french toast stuffed with caramelized bananas & walnuts. i don't think i have to tell you that they were completely amazing.

never did get to try mama's while i was in town, and that's alright with me.
author: Thy N.

description: There's not a lot of things in the world that could put you in a good mood quite like having brunch on a sunny day in this french cafe. Even though I didn't have the opportunity to sit on the back patio, I was content on sitting inside. My friend and I were seated promptly and our waitress took good care of us. I ordered the poached eggs with the smoked salmon while my friend ordered the scrambled eggs with chorizo. This was such a relaxing afternoon. Eating delicious food and chilling with a friend; all the stress in my life just drifted away.
author: Lauren L.

description:
automatic five stars because they let me bring my pooch to dinner with me on Monday nights.  hehehe.  

seriously though...the pork chop is good BUT the fontina bread pudding that comes with it is over-the-top good.  if i could just order the bread pudding, i could eat several orders of that.  so good.

surprisingly enough, they have one of the better burgers in SF, and their freedom fries are really good too.

dessert...baked hot chocolate...trust me.  unless you have a severe allergy to chocolate or all things tasty, you might want to order this.  it's a warm chocolate pudding, although it's a bit more on the pot de creme side in terms of consistency....with mini marshmallows on top that is finished in the oven or with a torch.  really decadent and good.

if you go there for brunch, try out their cream cheese coffee cake...
author: Miss P.

description:
Zazie's food is scrumptious!  We live in the neighborhood, and plan to make this the place we take our friends for brunch.  
The service was great, the quality is top-notch freshness and yumminess.  
The only drawback that keeps me from giving it 5 stars is the wait to be seated, which can run a good hour on the weekend.
author: Tatiana R.

description: Loved the atmosphere... Exposed brick and walls decorated with French posters.  We stopped here for brunch..  The gingerbread pancakes are phenomenal!!  Very attentive service.  Well located in Cole Valley.
author: Preston P.

description: I'm a brunch person so we came here for brunch. Really wanted to love this place. Great atmosphere, good service, but the food was just average. We ordered the ginger pancakes and the french toast tahiti. The first few bites were good, but it wasn't anything special.
author: james c.

description:
Four stars for the cozy nice setting, all the eggs-benedict-like dishes (particularly the Eggs Monaco with prosciutto and their delectable oven roasted tomaotes), the ginger pancakes, the BLT, the burger, the roasted trout, and the steaming large mug of chai. I've been loving this place for years and years for breakfast-for-lunch.

Minus one star for really bad coffee drinks (yuuuuck cappuccino) and middling dinner menu.
author: Celeste S.

description:
OK breakfast, not the great experience others rave about.

Food arrived lukewarm.  Isn't it restaurant 101 to serve hot food hot?

My friend ordered his eggs hard.  The waitress repeated this as she wrote down his order.  They arrived runny.  To their credit, she apologized and he quickly received a replacement plate that had hard eggs.

The english muffin on my benedict was not toasted.  Eggs benedict is all about the contrast of textures, folks!

The potatoes that came with it contained at least a dozen whole cloves of garlic.  Did anyone even look at what they put on the plate?

With a little attention to detail, this could have been a great meal.  But they are so popular they don't have to pay attention to detail.
author: Bay G.

description:
Went for brunch this weekend and I LOVE ZAZIE!!!

Perfect spring weather and we had the best table out on the patio. The service is always expert and attentive. My favorite thing on the menu is their provencial-style BLT. This is the best BLT ever. It has herb roasted tomatoes, goat cheese, and garlic aoli. The bacon is always perfectly crisp and never overcooked. We also had yummy mimosas with mango juice. 

There is always a bit of a wait for brunch as it is a popular place but it is worth it. Also, the host is excellent under pressure. I don't know his name but he has been there for ever, has worked every position, and is really an asset to the restaurant. 

Bravo!
author: sarah k.

description:
This place is great place for brunch.  The kinda of place you can take your parents to with out all the weirdo freaks you see on Haight st.  The lines can get long so plan accordingly. Keep a back up plan in mind or just walk around the the pictures neighborhood. My favorite dish that I order all the time is there BLT.  Crispy bacon, Juicy Tomato, Fresh Goat Cheese on a warm Ciabatta roll and a side salad is the best way I like  to start my weekend.  

Everything on the menu looks tasty with moderate prices.  The staff is friendly and the food comes fairly quick.  I heard they were remodeling the restaurant and I look forward to see what they did with the place
author: Robert M.

description: THE BEST PLACE to get breakfast in san francisco!!!!! Zazie's does breakfast the right way. Everything about this place is great. From the wonderful outdoor patio to the waiters, super friendly. Good customer service is hard to come by these days. all i have is love love love love for this place!
author: Tedi O.

description:
best eggs benedicts ever!!  they have many variations, some with portobello, some with smoked salmon.  but my personal fav is the Albert, which has BACON, white cheddar, and some homemade salsa fresca!
 
Bacon, eggs, hollandaise..  sound good?  Try the Albert!
 
I've also tried the French Toast Tahiti, it's stuffed w/ caramelized bananas and walnuts.  It's not just French Toast, it's a party in your mouth.  So flavorful, moist, sweet.. AHHH!
 
I've never had a bad experience here, only the parking and wait can be a bummer.  Weekend brunch times.. expect a long wait, and good luck with parking.  
 
But food quality and service.. FIVE STARS no diggity..no doubt!!
author: Ryan C.

description:
love the variety, since im a sweet tooth- the gingerbread pancakes and the tahiti french toast, are both winners.

the coffee isnt that great though... that is why it only gets 4 stars and not 5....

but when you do the food so well, why bother with coffee right?
author: Sam S.

description:
One of the things I miss the most about living in San Francisco is my Friday morning breakfast ritual- gingerbread pancakes with poached pears at Zazie.

I would never attempt this place on the weekend because I wouldn't be able to wait in that line.  But Friday? Friday is perfect.
author: chris j.

description: Zazie is a busy little breakfast joint in San Francisco. I went here with my fiance and his family today for breakfast. There were 5 of us and we had to write our name on the list that was hung on the front of their door. I think our wait time was approximately 25-35 minutes. Once we were seated, the waiter told us of their daily special: open face omelette with bacon, cheese, and basil. I ordered that and had mine with a side salad instead of home fries. The omelette was very good and the portion was decent for me. However, two of the people that I went with had to order extra pancakes. Overall, I was very satisfied with the food and service. I recommend this to people who like to try new places and don't mind a little wait.
author: Anh W.

description:
Oooh... am I really review #1000?

Well... I went to Zazie's for the first time last Sunday. An ex-colleague's boyfriend works there (his name's Ryan, and he's fabulous, so tip him well, friends!) and she recommended it as a fantastic place for brunch. In fact, I'd heard positive reviews from SO many people, I simply had to try it for myself. The line is LONG on Sundays, so make sure you wear some warm clothes and stay close by after you put your name on the reservation list. My friend and I realized we had a long wait, so we perused Cole Hardware and walked a few shops over to Tully's. We overestimated our wait time and lost our seats, but the reservation guy was nice enough to seat us asap when we explained what had happened, so it all worked out well. 

Decor/atmosphere: cozy, intimate, Parisian, love it!

Waitstaff: Busy, polite, and not overly intrusive... our waiter forgot the mimosas we'd ordered, but got them for us immediately.

Food: With the vast array of brunch choices, it was difficult to make a decision. My friend and I both ordered poached eggs/eggs benedict. I chose the Pierre Noir (with bacon and tomatoes provencales) with a side salad and he chose the Monaco (with proscuitto and tomatoes provencales) with home fries. There are whole cloves of garlic in the home fries, so be careful!  So, finally the waiter brings our plates... and my food was cold. *sigh* It was disappointing, to say the least. I'm a bit of an eggs benedict afficionado and order it whenever I go out to a new breakfast/brunch joint, and I have to say that I was really not that  impressed with what Zazie put in front of me. I did like the lemony Hollandaise sauce, which was not too heavy or overpowering (like some sludge a greasy spoon might use). Perhaps I'd have thought differently about the meal it if it had been hot. My Corsica (champagne and grapefruit juice) mimosa was absolutely divine, though, so I might just come back next Sunday for another and get something other than poached eggs. The portions are not that large, but you're allowed to choose one to three eggs for the benedict plates. One was obviously not enough for me,so I'd recommend that you get at least two... and three for those with larger appetites!

I rate Zazie as a 3.5 (but a 4 for Yelp because there are no halves available) and hope that the next time I go, I can give it a 5!

http://zaziesf.com/zaziesf/home.html
author: Suzi G.

description:
love the place but not the line on the weekends! 

pancakes and french toast are just...bomb!
author: PJ M.

description: Oh, Zazie, my dear Zazie.  You never, ever disappoint.  On date night, my husband knows he can never go wrong when he mentions your name.  And that price fix dinner?  Unbelievably tasty.  So what if the waiter brought my husband the wrong soup?  We loved it and will always come back to you, our Zazie.
author: Susan L.

description: Went to Zazie for brunch. It gets busy quickly! Food is pretty good, better coffee, very cool garden patio.
author: Caroline S.

description: By far my favorite breakfast spot in Sf! I love that you can order items a la carte.  I am always indecisive and can never decide so at Zazie I don't have too!  I love getting 1egg dish as well as 1 pancake or french toast.   The french toast is amazing! Besides for great food, our service has always been awesome as well and the environment is really cute too.  Go on a weekday if you can or in keeping with SF tradition, prepare for a long wait on the weekends.  You can always go next door to the bar and have a bloody mary while you wait which makes time pass fast!
author: Meredith W.

description:
okay so based on the other reviews you know their eggs benedict is BOMB ASS!! also their french toast tahiti is amazing! i don't ususally like french toast because they're so thick it makes it very hard to chew and eat the whole thing without getting a jaw/headache after all that work, but Zazie's french toast was the most fluffiest and non dried out kind i've ever had!! it was a joy to chew on that sucker and made me sad that it went down so easy...i wanted the joy to last longer!

one thing i would say though...even though its nice to eat on a nice backyard patio on a sunshiny day...sometimes its not so sunshiny and those heat lamps get a little too toasty. plus there's always a bunch of flies and shooing them away every 2 mins kinda takes away from the whole experiance. 

when putting your name down, definately try to get indoor seating
author: Annie C.

description:
i had been wanting to come here forever, but i always heard the lines were ridiculous on the wknds for brunch.  since i had some errands to run in sf one weekday, i decided that it was the perfect opportunity to come here for lunch.

we came around 1, so there wasn't a wait and were seated right away.  seating in the inside is pretty cozy, so if you can get a seat on the back patio (which was full when we came), then you should do it.

i love how you are given the choice of 1/2/3 of anything on the menu, so you can try a bit of everything if you want to.  we got the scramble w/ prawns, avocado, and salsa fresca w/ a side salad and wheat toast, the the grilled veggie sandwich and 1 pc of the challah french toast w/ fresh fruit.  everything was delicious.  i loved the preserves that they had on the table that i slathered on the thick slices of toast.

i can't wait to come back on a nice day, sit on the patio, and enjoy a mimosa w/ brunch.
author: Helen T.

description:
Great service, pleasant atmosphere and good food served at a reasonable price.  Overall you are getting a little bit more than you pay for so there it is.
A definite stop on your tour of Cole Valley, which should take all of 5 minutes.
author: Joe G.

description: still a fan but I've noticed more and more that you are "rushed"  out of your table the minute you pause and stop chewing. I do not mind the wait but  I expect to be able to enjoy good company over good food  when I do get seated.
author: aj s.

description: It's one of my all time favorite lunch places! The first time I went there was with my dad when he was visiting from Europe. We liked their food so much we returned the next 2 days for lunch. Their burger is amazing: cooked rare to perfection and the dressing makes your mouth water.  The service is good. Zazie has an outdoor patio which is a plus on sunny days, and heating lamps for the more common San Francisco days. The inside looks like a little bistro in Montmartre, Paris. It's definitely one of the best places in Cole Valley if you're into French-style bistro.
author: Camille L.

description: The place is pricy and there's a wait on weekends.  The food was good and the service was as well. The French Toast Tahiti did not disappoint and the poached eggs with salmon were freshly tasty. The portions are quite sufficient. The atmosphere is pretty cool.
author: Oren R.

description: Yeah, this is probably the best place for breakfast/brunch in SF. On weekends a lot of people agree. I am lucky enough to have Fridays off so I have actually never had to suffer the long weekend lines. In fact I went there last Sunday and kept driving. But enough of how spoiled I am. The food here is amazing. I usually get the Mexican with soyrizo, a couple of the best pancakes I have ever had. I have sampled other stuff off friends plates and everything I have tasted is amazing. There is also a build your own mamosa option on the menu. They give you a bottle of champ and juice of your choice. Mango is tops. Service is fantastic, friendly and if you can get a table in the backyard you should.
author: William R.

description: been here a couple times.  Need to get here a little early to avoid the crowds, but it's usually worth it.  Good eggs, (mexican allows soyrizo, which is nice).  Gingerbread pancakes are a little dry, but still enjoyable.  One of those places where you look around at other peoples plates, and everything looks good.
author: Phil J.

description: So yummy. First of all, I love Cole Valley. And, to me, there is nothing quite like a weekend morning eating at Zazie with a good friend in Cole Valley. There's usually a wait, but like someone else on here said, it goes by fast if you have good company. They have good champagne drinks and their French Toast is pretty amazing. All of there food I've had is pretty good. I like the quaint vibe. If you can, get out on the back patio. It's really sweet. Never had bad service either. A tad pricey, but I'll keep going back regardless.
author: Shaun V.

description: This place melts my heart. Although it is quite small, they are accommodating, speedy and their food is deeeeelicious. They do some amazing things with poached eggs (eggs divorcee, Benedict, etc). I went there for brunch and was immediately drawn to the different typed of mimosas they had. I had the mango while my sister had the black currant. Both were super yummy and had just the right amount of tart. And did I mention the PANCAKES?! Let me just say, I am NOT a fan of pancakes. My sister made me have a bite of hers, I was reluctant at first, but when I finally tasted them... Oh. my. god. I have been converted. Needless to say, I will be going back, and buying the pancake mix to take home. :)
author: Laurel Y.

description: Went today for brunch with 2 girlfriends and sat on the sunny back patio. Staff was very welcoming and friendly. I had the poached eggs Florentine. DELICIOUS!  Their champagne mimosas were tasty as well (I had the elderflower, friend had black currant and other friend had mango - second round for all - yum!). The green salad was very fresh. Eggs cooked to perfection. Will be back!
author: Brooke S.

description: My husband and I have been here multiply times and the food was amazing. We have a small child and the staff has always been great. We went there today and sadly I don't think we will going back. We got to the door and was asked if we would like to sit inside or outside and we asked to be seated in the cute back patio. The nice gentleman at the door told us to head on back and find a seat. We walked back found a table that would fit the three of us. Some other employee came up and asked if he could help us I replied with "yes would you be able to get us a high chair?" He said "no, that that there was a wait list for the patio and he was seating people". He then showed us to the front door. The wait list he was talking about was taped up on window with 3 names on it for people waiting to be seated. I didn't understand cause there was empty tables in the patio and out front. There was no one standing outside waiting. The host of the back patio was not very kind.
author: Emily A.

description:
I have come here for brunch and dinner and I've NEVER had a meal that I didn't love. 

Brunch: The croque monsieur is a a heavy breakfast but delicious!  

Dinner:  I've had wonderful duck and pork here.  The mussels are also a must.  I definitely think the prix fixe is worth it.  It's not often that you find a french restaurant that is affordable, yet fancypants.   save room for the chocolate pot de creme which is a cross of hot chocolate and chocolate pudding with marshmallows on top.  It's not too sweet, which i like.

The interior and the patio are both beautiful places to sit at well.  the patio is esp nice on those rare warm days in sf.
author: Laurene C.

description: I've just been once but our dinner was fantastic. The beef shank was very tender and not too fatty. Celery root puree was a nice alternative to mashed potatoes. Even our salad was memorable. Beets man. Beets. I hope to explore the rest of the menu.
author: Ryan T.

description: This is now in my top 10 best Restaurants ever! found this little gem walking around, the food was fantastic, our waiter Jeff was very knowledgeable about the food & wine they are lucky to have such an awesome waiter ( how did I do Jeff? ) The minute I walked in the door and saw the food on customers plates I new I was in the right place. I had the black truffle raviolis, my husband had the duck, and our friends had the salmon and beef shank. We all took bites from one another plate yum , yum . I live in marin and will return even if I have to park 6 blocks away. It's so worth the drive and walk.
author: Jeannette P.

description: Best breakfast in the City.  Nobody can do pancakes like them, nobody.  I love that they do dog night as well, so much fun.  dinner is great too.  if we could do half stars I would give them 4.5 because their coffee isn't the greatest.  But, since I can't, a 4.5 rounds up to 5.
author: Jason S.

description: Hmm.  Went here for breakfast today.  Actually intended on going to Mama's originally.  Waited in a line that didn't move for a half an hour.  Went over to Zazie.  Heard good things.  Waited another 20 minutes.  But the line was moving along and got seated.  The staff was nice, efficient, prompt.  The customers were the usual bougie obnoxiousness one finds in highly reviewed, or French, place (this one gets the daily double).  Mainly white, boring, snobby clientele.  There was a table behind me that was pretty sweet, of some older dudes just chillin.  They were talking loudly and were way pumped, which bummed out a lot of aspiring soccer mom yuppie ladies with sour lemon looks on their faces but put a smile on my face.  Why do people in the bay area hate loud talking so much?  I'm from LA, which I guess is similar to New York in that being boisterous and in a good mood is a sign of life and something to be encouraged rather than frowned upon.  But anyway, ordered Croque Madame, which is pretty standard.  My woman chose some Hollandaise.  We had coffee.  The coffee was outstanding.  The water glasses smelled like poo-poo.  Not sure why.  I'm a filthy man and drank the water anyway, I don't care.  My woman was bummed though, and barely touched it after she sniffed the situation.  The food was adequate.  I enjoyed it.  The problem is this: the reviews for this place are far overzealous, and the bill is disproportionate to both the quality and the amount.  For thirty bucks I expect us to walk away having eaten amazing food or at least feeling full.  Neither thing occurred.  I'd honestly rather get some tasty desayunos for less than ten dollars and not wait in a line next time, but you live, love, laugh, learn, and try bougie, highly-reviewed places.
author: Whitney D.

description: Zazie has long been a favorite restaurant of ours.  It's a beautiful space -- both indoors and outdoors -- with great service and delicious food.  Even before my husband and I got engaged, we always talked about what a great place it would be to get married.  We both liked the idea of an intimate, unique space in the city that was special to us and yet still large enough to accommodate 70-80 guests.  When we did decide to get married -- on three months' notice -- one of the first things we did was email Zazie and we are so grateful that we did.  We met with Zazie's owner, Jen, and instantly knew that we wanted her and her restaurant to be a part of our wedding.  Jen thought it was hilarious how soon we wanted to get married (she initially thought we were asking about May of the following year not the May ten weeks away) but was unflappable and so supportive and enthusiastic about making our plans work out the way we wanted.  She also recommended both the florist (Anna from Loop Event Arts) and ceremony venue (Golden Gate Park) that we ended up using.  We met with Jen a few times to sample food and wine and put together our menu, but other than that she and our florist worked together to handle everything which was perfect since my husband and I both had a million things going on during that time.  The reception itself was so special and meaningful.  Jen was there the entire time tending bar and overseeing everything, and the Zazie staff was incredible.  By the end of the night, our guests were on a first name basis with everyone working our wedding, and they really made us feel as though we were at home there.  As won't be a surprise to anyone that's eaten at Zazie, the food was incredible and we got so many compliments from our guests that it was the best food they had ever eaten at a wedding.  After dinner, we cleared the tables out of the indoor dining area to convert the dining room into a dance floor.  There was no cut-off time and our guests stayed as late as they wanted.  We feel so blessed to have been able to have the exact wedding that we wanted and are so grateful to Jen and everyone at Zazie for making it happen.
author: Meghan W.

description:
We made the mistake of trying to beat the rush and have brunch at Zazie this morning.  Big mistake.  There was a big crowd already waiting outside before 11am.

The food here is good, but I don't think it's so good it's worth the wait.  True, the service is fast and efficient, and we got our food pretty quickly after we ordered it.  I had the salmon omelette with wheat toast, my wife had the Mexican omelette with chorizo, and they were both good.  The home fries were good, and they don't give you too much.  You can also substitute a salad for the homefries at no additional cost.

This place ain't cheap-- my omelette was $12, and our large orange juices were something like $3.50 each.  But the food quality is good.  I'd say it's about as good as Ella's on Presidio, but not quite as good as Brenda's French Soul Food near Civic Center.  One bonus is the stellar people watching.  The clientele here is definitely the upscale pseudo-hipster type that you frequently see in Noe Valley.

From sitting down to paying the check and leaving, we were in there for a total of 25 minutes-- less time than we actually spent standing outside waiting to be called.  Parking here is also very, very difficult.  Had we not lucked into a metered spot that I could re-feed, we wouldn't have even tried this place.
author: Dave N.

description: Zazie is a wonderful local french bistro style restaurant.  It has a great atmosphere, a wonderful back garden, friendly staff, and consistently good food.  I wish that the wait was not so long on the weekends. But they have a small kitchen, and I'll keep going there...
author: Sharon B.

description:
Right, so this place has been reviewed almost 100 times and there's pretty good consensus on it's outright goodness.  

So I'll just add that:
1. the roasted garlic in the homefries is enough to make me eat the homefries, and i have a fairly strict policy about not eating the homefries (more room for bacon that way), so the potatoes here and at Blue Jay Cafe are the only two that make the cut in the city.  
2. the guy who runs the door is the most competent, no-nonsense nice door-runner i've ever encountered -- love him 
3. and the BLT is so insanely, insanely good it brings tears of pure, unadulterated joy to my eyes.  

Oh and a couple of mini-negatives -- really mini though!:
the bathroom is kind of weird/sketchy
the iced tea is gross -- some sort of african herb for digestion which tastes...like nothing else i've ever tasted, or ever want to, ever again.
author: Tasha C.

description:
Where to start? I have been coming here since before they took credit cards. The former (French) owner set the tone and tenor for the place but since the lovely Jennifer took it over, she hasn't  ruined it one bit and added heat lamps to the patio, oooh. They used to give out blankets and I bet they still have them. Jennifer has also done a great job giving Zazie a web presence. 

SF needs more outdoor dining experiences and Zazie steps up to the plate, between the patio and the street dining in the sun (oh so Francais). The street tables are first come first served. 

I've spent more time in this restaurant than in any other in SF. Maybe more than in all of them combined. When you've got a neighborhood place like this for breakfast, lunch, and dinner you're lucky. 

It was hell to get a table here during the dot com boom, though I overheard the most absurd detached conversations about SF, fine expensive wine, and the tech biz. Glad those days are gone. 

I've loved the french toast (regular), the ginerbread pancakes with roasted pear, the irish oatmeal, the fish soup, polenta entrees, eggs italie, the brigitte sandwich, and lately the dungeness eggs benedict and other benedicts. All their pancakes are homemade and wonderful, even the plain ones. I am more fond of their old coffee than their new coffee. But I recommend the Zazie Spritzer. 

Mario was the best waiter and now he is a super wonderful host. Not sure how he keeps his cool on weekends given how testy the hungry customers can be, but he does. I hope he's paid for it. If he's ever not there on the weekend, I can see the waiters stressing out trying to deal with those waiting. It was hard to imagine that anyone could deal with it the way Julia did but Mario stepped up to the plate. 

My sweetie bemoans the portions (small in his opinion), hates the new teapots, and usually comes on Sunday when the service and food is admittedly the worst. So while I love this place he hates it. (But then he also hates Chez Maman and seems to only tolerate Plouf, so I don't see how he'll ever survive Paris with me). Zazie is the biggest strain on our relationship. He always wants to go to Just For You (but their coffee truly does suck and so do their poached eggs and their OJ price).

My pickiest friends have enjoyed their breakfasts here with me, and the Beaujolais Nouveau dinner. 

They've recently switched to only organic, hormone free eggs, yippee!
author: Paris E.

description:
This place SERIOUSLY ROCKS!  My favorite brunch place in the city, hands down.  Gingerbread pancakes with homemade lemon curd, tasty french toast, perfectly poached eggs (I love the florentine version), great coffee, bloodies, mimosas, etc.  There is always a wait but if you want to have a drink at Finnegan's Wake next door while you pass the time, the super cool host will let you know when your table is ready. 

Another cool feature: you can sit outside under the heatlamps AND they have blankets if you are always cold like me.
author: E G.

description:
Oh this is easy. Eggs Monaco. Hands down, the best.  

And then you add in Doggie Mondays on their back patio. Clearly, this place is just fantastic. 

Definitely worth the wait for brunch.
author: danielle w.

description: It was a long line on the weekend! Waited for over half hour.... the breakfast was excellent, I love it. Just the coffee was only warm and not hot. I would go on the weekdays.... way too busy on the weekend. But it's really an excellent breakfast place!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Cute place, nicely decorated with bricks showing, small dining area.  Hard to find parking in the area.

The food was good, the service nice.  A bit noisy, lots of kids, very full the entire time we were there for dinner.

Nice neighborhood place.  I would not trek across town to come here for dinner but nice place.
author: Sailing A.

description: My fiance and I used to live close by, so we frequented Zazie for breakfast and lunch. They do an excellent job addling that little extra needed to spice up old favorites.  Zazie is also a great place if your party is half vegetarian half meat eater - lots of options for both! Plus the service is always good and they have a cute little back area!
author: Valerie R.

description:
Some co-workers introduced me to this place and I've never forgotten about it!  The Zazie burger is absolutely delicious and one of my personal favorites.  You just can't go wrong with anything offered on the menu.

One cool thing we tried was the hot chocolate -- very delicious and unique.  

They also have outdoor seating in the back, which is fabulous on a sunny day.  Because they're so popular you may need to wait a few minutes to be seated, but once you're seated, I guarantee you won't be disappointed. 

This place is simply a must when visiting SF!
author: Christine T.

description: Lines of people at brunch testify to the great values here (or maybe to the dearth of other decent options).  Dinners are solid and perfunctory french bistro fare.  The food is good, not great, the service usually friendly, and the ambience is warm and inviting.  This is great neighborhood restaurant on many levels.  I wouldn't make a special trip here, but I'm glad it's in my hood.
author: Nathan R.

description: Look, if you love breakfast you go here. Don't get lunch and be a douche.  I usually hate eggs Benedict, but when my friend forced me to try them, I actually stopped what I was eating and ordered the same. Unbelievably fantastic. And I didn't feel like a cow when it was over.
author: Caroline B.

description:
Zazie has one of the most exciting brunches in the city. Their gingerbread pancakes are amazing, and I love the fact that you can order one, two, or three eggs for many of their dishes. I hate brunch, but I'll come here because it's worth it. I recommend getting here early unless you like waiting for an hour, although they do a good job of crowd management without it feeling like a stressful clusterfrack.

It's also an excellent spot for dinner. Their food is simple but good, the staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and they have a great wine list. The prix fix makes it doable for more than just a special occasion.
author: Patrick T.

description:
So, I joined Yelp just to write this review.  My boyfriend and I moved to San Francisco fairly recently and have been working our way around the city's various brunch spots.  I've wanted to try Zazie for awhile especially based on all the stellar reviews.

Anyway, we made our way over to Zazie this morning where we waited for about 45 minutes which was to be expected.  Once inside, the service was fast (maybe a bit too fast) as the food was pretty lukewarm by the time it made it to our table.  We ordered two of the poached egg dishes and a gingerbread pancake.  My bf had coffee and I had hot cocoa.

The food was ok, pretty much standard brunch fair, with a slight twist and a few extra dollars added to the price to match.  It tasted like any non-descript quickly prepared brunch food.  We got the check and were slightly surprised by the $40 price tag.  I mean, it was good but not that good.  After studying the check a bit more we came across a random charge for .75.  We asked about it and the waiter told us it was for whipped cream being added to the hot chocolate i had ordered.  !?!?!  Talk about adding insult to injury.  At a place that clearly makes a killing every weekend and probably during the weekdays, too, charging extra for adding whipped cream to hot chocolate is just petty.  Needless to say, we will not be back.
author: Jana R.

description: While in town for business, we went to Zazie for breakfast simply because of all of the positive feedback. My wife and I took a cab there from downtown. When I called, there was no wait which was at 9am, we got there about 9:45am and the line was 10 couples deep. Surprisingly we were seated within 10 minutes. The atmosphere was delightful and the food was great. A little over priced in my opinion, but apparently Cole Valley is higher end. Wold definitely eat there again.
author: Jody L.

description: I'm a nerd, I pretty much only review places I like or love...and I love Zazie.  My ex-roommate was the one who got me to go here first.  She was super into their creme brulee oatmeal, but I think that's a yechy idea.  She lured me with the idea of gingerbread pancakes...I loved the scramble I had with ratatouille.  Mmmm.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Sara C.

description: I really enjoyed Zazie. When we first arrived there was a short wait, but it was totally worth it. I immediately ordered a coffee, best coffee I've had in a while. Then ordered the Italie, which is was delicious. The home fries were awesome as well. The only gripe I would have is that the server never asked if we wanted anymore coffee, which was in a pretty small mug to begin with. Next time I'm in the neighborhood I plan on going back, I've already recommended this place to a few friends.
author: Cristina C.

description: Breakfast at zazie has always been great, but our fathers day dinner left us feeling very sick with indigestion. It's a charming place and the service was great, however my trout was mealy, my soup over salted, my husbands mussels in a sauce that was "off", my father in laws salmon and salad had no flavor. It seemed like it wasn't fresh. Two hours later and I still feel terrible. Sorry zazie - I want to like you but we won't be back, for dinner at least.
author: Patsy D.

description: C'mon YELP, you need to allow 1/2 star reviews.  Zazie gets a 3 for the menu (didn't wow me, as, for example, Universal Cafe does) and 4 for the food, i.e. 3.5 stars.   Nothing jumped out at me on the menu but my daughter and I each had the croque monsieur which turned out to be a wonderful choice.  Full of ham, grilled perfectly and, best of all, brimming with lots of fontina cheese, so gooey and good.  I got mine with their awesome hash browns which contain chunks of roasted garlic cloves (kind of surprised me when I bit into one since I wasn't expecting it).  Daughter had the salad with hers -- I win, but she gets points for healthy choice.   We went Sunday around 10:30 AM.  It was busy, but not too long a wait and service was attentive and prompt.
author: Bonnie G.

description:
I finally tried Zazies. I wanted to love it. I really wanted to love it. 

I didn't love it. It was just ok.

The ambiance was really cute. The waitress was really nice. The food was really mediocre. 

I got the New York scramble which comes with salmon, cream cheese, and green onions. It tasted fine. However it didn't taste fine enough to warrant the price or the hype of the place. 

Zazie's, I'll probably give you another chance sometime in the future.. but you'll have to work hard to impress me.
author: A K.

description: First of all they charge that stupid SF health care tax.  I don't get health care.  I don't charge people extra money on top of my fees for health care.  So WTF is going on with these places?  The eggs and ingredients in the eggs are good.  The potatoes are too oily.  The toast and jam is good.  I can get the same meal at crepevine.
author: Fatty A.

description: the pancake are SO FLUFFY. YUM. i don't remember the last time i had such buttery, fluffy, soft pancakes before. i had the pancakes, sausage, and scrambled eggs set. the sausage was very flavorful, the scrambled eggs also buttery and fluffy. the service is very friendly, and the venue charming and sweet. they placed us out in the back, on the patio among lots of greenery, flowers, and vines. it was the perfect location, to brunch outside on an adorable patio with friends. i would definitely like to come back here again to try their eggs, which, from my friends' comments, are delicious as well.
author: Angie K.

description:
Still my favorite place. Nemo brought me here with friends a couple years back.  Ever since it's all I recommend.  The crab cakes that used to just be a special, now on the menu.  The frigging best I have EVER had. We come back when we are in town. And always bring a guest. This place is comfy and quaint.  I love it. Yum, Cole Valley......has my heart.


The bloody mary's are too sweet, but hey everything can't be perfect.
author: Melo M.

description: A pretty good brunch joint. Expect a wait. I enjoyed my meal here last, though I can't remember what I ordered!
author: H B.

description: Yay!!!  Big fan!!  We've only been here for breakfast so far, but a dinner trip is on the agenda.  Interesting and diverse breakfast menu, great atmosphere, and consistently great food.  Gigantic latte and great jams.  If going for breakfast/brunch, plan to wait for a while.  There's a market across the street where you can grab some fresh fruit if you're that hungry.  Love it!
author: Joshua B.

description:
one of the best brunch places - and pretty good for dinner.

the food is excellent. the service is impeccable. they have a really nice back patio - on a nice weekend afternoon, this is a really cute and fun place to brunch. 

for dinner, the prix fixe menu is a nice deal and the food is good and satisfying. the good stuff seem to be the salmon, lamb tagine, pork chop and steak. my most memorable desert here was a pear brule - had a lot of fruit pieces and was very tasty.

my favorite is brunch time - the choices of poached eggs are extensive and good. my favorites are valence and st trop. my boyfriend and friends like stuff with meat and their french toast. 

the highlight of their extraordinary service happened one time when we were there for brunch - it is typically a crazy busy time and you need a little patience. everyone at the table had already gotten their food except me, so the waitress apologized and gave me a little fruit bowl to entertain while my food was cooking. the small gesture and the apology put a WOW in their service.
author: huong n.

description:
Most of the reviews here seem to be for brunch or lunch, but my wife and I really enjoyed ourselves at dinner. The grilled-vegetable appetizer plate was a nice, light start, while my wife's steak was excellent and my fish soup was very tasty, too. We were there on a Tuesday night, when they charge no corkage fee, so you can bring your own bottle of wine (we chose a $4.99 Old Moon zinfandel from Trader Joe's and were very pleased with it, especially for the money), which keeps the check down to a level calling for repeat visits.

Great atmosphere and service -- a bistro feel that's warm and lively as opposed to the old-school bistros that I find to be overly formal and lifeless. An added bonus: the manager (or owner?) followed us to the door and handed us a card to make sure we felt welcome to come back soon. That kind of little personal attention leaves a lasting good impression.
author: Michael P.

description:
We've loved everything we've tried at Zazie.  For breakfast the French Toast Tahiti is incredible, full of tasty bananas.  The gingerbread pancakes were very ginger-ful and spicy.  And the home fries accompanying the more savory breakfast dishes have whole cloves of roasted garlic.  They also serve make-your-own mimosas in an adorable bucket.

For "midday" the Sandwich Brigitte is absolutely incredible.  Wow, really.  We need to ask what kind of goat cheese they use on it because it's amazing, and the foccacia is also stellar.  The smoked salmon sandwich was exactly as expected, and while no surprise, it was exactly what the fish eater of us wanted.

The dessert menu has so many amazing looking items that it would be hard to choose.  We tried the vanilla creme brulee, which was delicious, went really well with their rich espresso, and was definitely enough to split.  We haven't gone for dinner yet, but maybe tomorrow we'll try out the cheese plate and a dessert or two at midday again...

The general atmosphere is also very nice, with a beautiful back deck with heating lamps (key) and a ton of vines.  The inside is also very neat looking with lots of brick.  The service staff is always friendly and attentive.  We'll be back here often.
author: Nicole and Kayvon B.

description:
This is absolutely one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  I've visited for every meal but I especially like breakfast and lunch.  Everything on the menu appeals to me--great egg scrambles, sandwiches, roasted potatoes with garlic, pancakes, and my husband's favorite, "Tahiti Toast," French toast with bananas, nuts, and some kind of sugary filling.  De-lish!  

Sadly, my choices at Zazie have narrowed considerably since I adopted a mostly vegan diet.  These days I usually get the Mediterranean plate, which includes some roasted tomatoes, green beans, potatoes, a roll.  But if I'm going to splurge and break my diet, this is a great place to do it.

The service is friendly, the back patio is lovely, and we can usually count on one of the 2 tables out front if we bring our dog during the week.  (Weekends are much more crowded and so we leave the pug at home.)  I've heard Zazie has Monday dog nights when dogs are allowed on the back patio, too, but we haven't tried this yet.
author: Jean L.

description:
Service: Excellent

Food: 
(evening) Delicious! Great! Mouth-watering! Nummy!
(morning) nothing special 

Your neighbor: Always A pleasure

Ambiance: Superb!

Patio: Even Better

LOVE THIS PLACE!!!
author: Ichiban H.

description: Really good breakfast food if you're okay with a long wait.
author: Jules A.

description:
zazie is responsible for inducing my most memorable food coma yet. i was probably 9 or 10 years old and my brother (who lives a few blocks away) took me, my parents and my younger brother to dinner here. i was pretty daring in my food choices for a kid that age, and insisted upon ordering french onion soup AND the duck confit. 

so rich. so, so good. i hoovered both my dishes, then dug into my mom's creme brulee come dessert time. i fell asleep and my dad had to carry me to the car. next time it rains, i need some good comfort food and i have some extra money, i am so here.
author: Jane P.

description:
I love Zazie! All their food is amazing... there is nothing I've tried that is not great! 
I start with both the mussels in this amazing sauce that I actually spoon in my mouth and the pate which is spread on toasted buttered bread, only because I can't choose between the two.
Then I've had the burger which is the best gourmet burger I've ever had at the reasonable price that it is. The fish soup is so buttery and fresh. The salmon is always cooked perfectly and the macaroni and cheese is a must on top of your entree, but it's sometimes sold out.
And then to end this delicious meal, I usually have the fruit crumble with a side of gelato. Sometimes it's apple and rhubarb, sometimes it's pear, just depends on the season. For chocolate lovers, there's an amazing chocolat chaud which is pretty much like rich, decadent hot fudge with toasted marshmallows on top!!
My mouth is watering just describing all this, so I recommend you make a reservations asap!
When calling, you'll find that Mario is the most lovely of hosts I've ever met in my entire life! Mario is amazing! His efficiency and friendly customer service exceeds all expectations and he's one of the reasons I keep going back!
author: Marilyn N.

description: Duck is crispy outside moist inside and sauce is rich and delicious. Don't plan on doing anything after but this could be a candidate for last meal.
author: J R.

description: Zazies is an old tim favorite of a friend of mine. First time going it was busy but we were seated quickly in sidewalk seating. It was nice eating lunch in the sunshine, watching people walk by with their kids or walking their dogs. The service was very quick. The back patio is always a great place to sit as well. I only gave it 4 stars because though the service was great and food was good the place is a little cramped but well worth it.
author: Shaye S.

description: Their breakfast is very good. Had the gingerbread pancakes which were awesome and the general brunch atmosphere was really good. Most of their breakfast items looked really good and their mimosas were also fantastic.
author: Robert H.

description: Best brunch ever!  And I am not a breakfast person at all.  There's always a wait, but it is well worth it!  They have something like 5 different kinds of eggs benedict!  We sat outside in the back next to a nice warm heater (SF is not so warm) and literally had so much food that I couldn't figure out how it all got put on our table.  I HIGHLY recommend this place and plan on eating there every time I visit!
author: Lisa C.

description: This is our favorite special occasion restaurant.  My son suggests that they have some space alien ingredient that makes the food so good.  Everything is absolutely delicious, every time.  I am vegetarian, and there are not too many choices, but the menu is seasonal and I get to have something different every time, and every time it is tip-top!  Best atmosphere ever!
author: Lala R.

description: This joint is now officially the coolest eatery in SF.  even if the food and all weren't great, they let dogs in - and do the right thing for their staff by supporting Healthy San Francisco!  (see Chronicle, March 22).  I think the lovely owner should be Mayor, but would not wish that on anyone.
author: buddy b.

description: My boyfriend and I are huge brunch fans, when we tried this place, we thought to food was decent but could have been better.  They are a little over-priced and the customer service was not good.  Also there was not any walnuts in my French Toast and the menu said there was.  I'm don't think I'm coming back.
author: H. A.

description: Neighborhood French bistro. Try the Roasted Trout or Lemon Ricotta Ravioli (with grilled prawns). It's popular so go after 8 or 9 for dinner. I like the seats by the front window or in the outdoor patio (for a great brunch on a sunny day).
author: Xavier A.

description: I was here for brunch the other day and although I love the decor and the service was impeccable...the food left me a little flat.  Maybe it was an off day? My eggnog french toast was overcooked slightly, my companion's pancakes were the special...with carmelized banana, and it was tasty, just way too sweet for me.  He liked them though.  We shared an egg scramble with cheeses, spinach and mushroom with the side of potatoes and although it was tasty, it was soaked in oil/butter.  I wanted to pull out my napkin and blot it like I'd blot greasy pizza, but I was raised with manners, so I refrained.  It ended up being a very heavy breakfast that sat in my tummy for hours and hours.  The coffee, however, was excellent.  I'd go back, but perhaps select a lighter breakfast to try.
author: Angela N.

description:
Best French Toast I have ever had! 

I found out about this restaurant using yelp, and I surprised my friend for her birthday and took her here. I was aware there would be a wait, but that is always a good sign in my book. Once we were seated and the food came out, my friend and I could not stop saying, "mm this is soo good." Needless to say, my friend was overly grateful for taking her here. Definitely one of my favorites in the bay.
author: anna p.

description: This place is so charming and cozy.  Perfect outdoor seating for a sunny day for brunch.  Try it out!!
author: K N.

description:
French toast.  I dream about it.  The sweet taste and softly crisp finish.
Great atmosphere, both inside with the dark brick walls, and the garden patio in back with vined walls.  
Attentive, great service with a smile.
author: Matt S.

description: Love, love, love this place.  Gingerbread pancakes... to die for!  I would definitely eat here more often if it wasn't always so packed, but whenever I can get in with less than a 30 minute wait, then I'm one happy camper!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Excellent mimosas...wonderful variety of favors.  Brunch is the standard fare and all very good.  I would however, avoid this place like the plague for brunch on a holiday, ridiculous lines.  Not sure that it is worth the wait- but I am horrible with lines.  For dinner service the portions are perfect and well presented. We had the Canard Piallat and the Lamb Tagine which were both good.  The lamb was a little overdone for my taste but it was well seasoned.  The service was not great, while very nice the server did not go out of his way to attend to our needs and we were constantly looking for him. I will definitely return for brunch and those yummy mimosas. Even despite the annoying street parking or lack there of.
author: Halima T.

description:
This place is fantastic, for Brunch and Dinner. It's a little hole in the wall and they are usually packed, but if you're going on a date, the spot outside in the back on a nice night is PERFECT! the food is fantastic and speedy.

GREAT PLACE OVERALL
author: Rich V.

description:
Average food, long wait during brunch time.  I had the croque madame, which seemed loooaded with sodium.  I think it tasted better than it really was because of my hangover.

I'd give this place a higher rating if they didn't charge me a mandatory "SF Health Access Program Ordinance" fee.  I know it's only $1 per person, and I agree with the principle completely.  But this is the first restaurant I've been to that charges a mandatory fee *separately itemized* on the check.  The friend I brought along with has ties to the Golden Gate Restaurant Assoc., and even he thought it was poor form to charge this way.
author: Ash C.

description: I ordered the prix fixe with butternut squash soup this time, but I couldn't resist the salmon dinner again! The soup was delicious and lightly curried. I will say, that the prix fixe seems to be the way to go, my tablemate's dinner has been considerably more expensive than mine (like almost twenty more) because he always orders ala carte...
author: Kimberley M.

description:
What a wonderful bistro in a nice quite, upscale neighborhood.  Everything was fantastic.  I died and went to heaven after eating the Baked Chocolate Chaud - it's a must have on their menu.  

It was a nice evening and we sat outside in their patio.  Lot's of heat lamps for those that get cold - and a few blankets if needed.  It was cozy.
author: Jay F.

description: The brown man tells me he's seen Natalie Portman here. Pig-tailed hair and poncy shoes, shorter than thought and barking orders for better tables and port. I guess I was sort of jealous when I heard, she was the beginning of my bald girl fantasy -- that's not really something you turn your back on too quickly. I would have watched her eat, grappling at her fork as she sliced through her croque monsieur. Salacious cheese and small purposeful chews. People would ask what I was thinking. Love, like, lost in lustful thoughts while staring at her and her plus three. That would be it mostly. The brown man tells me it's not worth it, tells me to get another drink and put that thought down. I reluctantly agree.
author: Marc M.

description: A ok because I'm comparing it with La Note here in Berkeley and La Note is definitely better. They seem like twins though, decor wise, and I wouldn't be surprised if it's the same owner - but the portions are extremely small here and though yeah, the place is cute, doesn't mean portions should be cute too.
author: Betty H.

description: Pricey, but worth it! This place has a cozy atmosphere that is reminiscent of a french bistro (which is the goal). It's got deliciously rich dishes full of oil and butter and cream, that will give you a stomach ache if you eat too much.  The service is top-notch, the food is 5-Star, and the atmosphere is adorable and comfortable. I took only one star off for the heaviness of the food... which made me feel bloated and sleepy after dinner.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Don't miss it, or wait please do.I have never been a huge brunch fan and i DO NOT like to wait in lines, so waiting over an hour for a table for 4 around 11am on a Sunday is close to hell for me. Especially with the smell of frying bacon and maple syrup wafting out the door into the crowd. Zazie was worth the wait, the French Toast Tahiti was incredible, even for someone who OD on fried bananas in Central America, the house cream cheese coffee cake unreal and i could eat the Trout du Sud 24 hours a day. At the moment if I had one restaurant that I had to eat at for the rest of my life, this would be it. Their dinner, lunch and regular breakfast are all fantastic as well. Thank you Zazie! I wont even ask you to get bigger so there is no line,  thank you for being small and keeping the riff raff away.
author: Alanna M.

description: Wow.  I've been to Zazie in the past for dinner and had a great meal.  This time I went for a late brunch on Saturday and had an amazing meal!  Since eggs benedict-type dishes seem to be among the most popular I went for 1 order of the eggs florentine and definitely was not disappointed.  I also tried the chicken sausage, which was good, however not life changing like a few of the reviews suggest - I actually preferred the bacon that I snagged from my friend's plate.  The staff was super friendly, the patio was just warm enough to be pleasant and not overwhelming w/ the heat lamps.  I can't wait to go back!
author: M J.

description: eh. so so breakfast. Couple of people had this down for best breakfast in SF on the "Secret San Francisco" list.. so I went today. Service, excellent, bottomless coffee, great. Food ? Basic. OK. Too oily. I had the special omelette of the day, and the eggs in the omelet were kind of loose. My wife had the 1,2,3 special, 1 pancake, 2 eggs, 3 bacon. The eggs were kind of runny (requested over easy). Both our plates had oil on them, the home fries were very oily. Don't know where the oil came from on the 1,2,3..  - I'll go back for another try, but no eggs or potatoes for me.
author: James P.

description: Arriving at 10:30am on a Monday and finding this place busy was impressive. It was cold, and though we seated in the back patio. However, the heat lamps made all the difference and we were never cold. Coffee was fine and we decided on splitting the  the French toast Tahiti and Florentine poached eggs. The French toast is uber sweet--don't get me wrong, I have a major sweet tooth, so it was fine with me. I don't think they should mix the nuts in with the filling though, because they get soggy! However, no complaints about the flavor from me. Poached eggs were disappointing as they were way overcooked, but by that point we were hungry. I like that they put whole garlic cloves into their home fries, but we both thought they needed flavor, and had to add quite a bit of salt. Overall, a great brunch place for smaller groups (given that the place is tiny) with unique options like the French toast. I suspect you'll be waiting a while on the weekends and it's probably worth it, though it's a tad overpriced.
author: mar m.

description: Fantastic place to hold a rehearsal dinner for a wedding.  The food and service were great. The owner, Jen, is awesome.
author: Ben B.

description: Long wait at 9:45 on sunday morning. An hr wait. Too much hype. I am a foodie. This place is so average. Gingerbread pancakes were too dry and fake maple syrup. Gotta pay $2 for real syrup. Service takes forever since the kitchen is a matchbox. La mer poached eggs looked sad. Not coming back. Going to try mama's tomorrow. Thumbs down for this place.
author: Robyn K.

description:
My favorite breakfast place in the city!

Best french toast (challah bread with caramelized apples and whipped cream. SOOO good!)

They also have a nice back patio for those warm days. They also have heat lamps or umbrellas to always make it perfect out there.

They do not take reservations, so on weekends there will be a wait. But so worth it!!!
author: Sanja U.

description:
Hell will freeze over before I go there again. You can eat out for the amazing food, but this is not the place for that, or you can eat out for a nice dining experience, and this is not the place for that either.
Food tastes great, but it's overpriced for the portion size and the service is rude.
Details: Friday morning, slow, we sit and pick our food quickly. The server is delighted we don't need more time to decide and we order coffee, that comes with refills, and breakfast. While we wait for our breakfast, the coffee doesn't come. We watch the server go up and down the aisle re-filling cups without giving us ours. After 10 minutes of this, we ask her to get our coffee and we get a blow off, "i'm sure it's coming soon." What? It's coffee, you're holding a coffee pot, go get two cups and fill them.
Then, a lone man enters and says, "Im waiting for a friend, may I sit down?" and the host says, "Well, you can sit unless other people come in with complete parties and then you'll have to move." The man graciously stays despite the incredible rudeness. They put him at a table for two. What if he had just come in alone, do they have a table for one they could have put him at instead. I can understand if one person comes in for a table for 4, but no additional space is lost to one more person AND the place was half empty. The host chose a table for him, and then, moved him to a different table, later, even while the original table stayed empty. The coup de grace however was when his friend came in, he turned out to be a friend of the restaurant staff and suddenly the man's service improved.
Then, there was the woman who made a 9:30pm reservation by mistake and got a completely snarky response to the host about it.
After we got our coffee cups, we had to demand refills, while watching other tables get their coffee refilled.  Turns out our particular waitress is bad at refilling coffee, but she was delighted to slap down our check interrupting our request for a refill. At the end of the day we paid $3.00 for two tiny lukewarm cups of coffee, and lousy, lousy service.
Oh wait, and adding a slice of tomato to a sandwich costs $2.00.
author: Sarah S.

description: My friend and I shared the La Mer Eggs Benedict (w/dungeness crab and avocado) w/American fries and the Sour Cream Poppy Seed pancake w/lemon curd. The eggs benedict was mediocre, but the fries were the best we ever had. I am also a big fan of the pancake--the fluffiest I've ever had. The lemon curd was a great accompaniment. Can't wait to go back and have more.
author: Ali A.

description:
Altina were astonished that I still hadn't been to Zazie yet so they made it their mission to makes sure I satisfied my brunchy desires.  So we ventured out one Sunday morning and braved the crowds.  Our party of 8 was seated by a friendly staff after a quick 45 minute wait.  Being famished and the ambitious eaters that we were, we ordered enough food for probably twice as many people.  Since I wasn't sure when I would be back I decided to go all out and order the Pierre Noir, the Croque Madame and I split a French toast tahiti.  Like I said, we were ambitious eaters.

When the food arrived, the portions were ample for all the dishes, but I was definitely up to the task.  First I attacked the poached egg dish.  I was actually quite disappointed because when I stuck my fork through the egg, I didn't get the little oozing river of golden yolky goodness that one would expect with a poached egg.  I was disheartened and wondered what type of establishment they ran here.  Fortunately  there was also bacon on my plate which helped to placate me somewhat.  The croque madame's egg was cooked perfectly overeasy which paired perfectly with the crunchy and cheesy  sandwich.  This helped to redeem Zazie further.  Then I bit into the pancakes which were tender and fluffy and quite tasty.  The service was quick and friendly and the prices mostly reasonable for the quality.  This place would be a solid 4 if it weren't for my overcooked poached eggs, but even still a rounded up 3.5 isn't bad.  I'd definitely come back again.
author: Gary L.

description: Nice staff. Good food. There known for there brunch but I love there dinners. I think it's one of my faves in not my favorite. Best pate I have ever had.
author: Justine P.

description:
The restaurant lived up to what I have heard and read. We had a interesting experience. After  a delightful meal we ordered a desert to share. AFTER we both
had taken a taste of the desert ( the top was covered with a Large Whipped cream
topping) the waiter came to our table to take it away. We explained that we had
already starting eating it. He said no problem and put down what we had ordered and
took the other one away ONLY to show up a table behind us about 20 seconds later!!!!
Secondly I pet peeve of mine is SF health showing as a line item rather then being
factored into the menu prices. This restaurant changes the menu 4/5 times a year so its
no problem or additional cost to change the menu prices. The way it is now it is for
the convince of their book keeper. Not sure if I would return due to the fact that the staff
thought it was important to take away  food item eaten and I believe served to another
table. When I asked when paying the bill why they did not offer to leave it he just
smiled.
author: Peter F.

description: This place was recommended to me by a former SF resident and dear friend of mine bc it was hands down her favorite brunch place and I must say, there is a reason why!  This place was totally cute and the food was insanely delicious for the first meal of the day!  We got to sit in the little window seating, like we were on display!  It was very fun!  All three of us  ordered a different variation of Eggs Benedict and all  three were seriously the best tasting EVER compared to other brunch places. Even the lemon poppyseed pancake was sweet goodness on my tongue!  I will definitely be visiting Zazie again and again, whenever I am in SF!
author: Julie K.

description: So, soooo good. They have the most delicious brunch I've ever had. Especially the florentine eggs benedict. It's worth the wait, which can be long on the weekends. I've heard the dinner is also phenomenal, so I need to go back soon and try it....
author: Jenny R.

description:
Veteran's day on a Wednesday was a genius plan because that means that not everyone gets Wednesday off!  But luckily for me, I did. =P  I took advantage of my day off by starting it off with a nice walk through inner sunset to Cole Valley for brunch at Zazie!  Again, luckily for me I did not encounter the massive mob outside waiting for a seat at Zazie.  I walked in and was seated within 1 minute.  We had the option of going to the outside patio or the inside, but it was a little chilly outside, so we opted for the inside seating.  The inside of the restaurant isn't anything remarkable, but it feels very homey. 

They have a good selection of breakfast/brunch foods with the option of one/two/three pieces of what you order (French toast, eggs, pancakes, etc).  I went with the French Toast Tahiti, which were french toast with caramelized bananas and walnuts.  It doesn't come with any sides, but you don't really need any... 2 french toast is defintiely enough for one person!  It's different from any other french toast in that it comes with "stuffing" --pureed bananas and walnuts in between the french toast pieces.  Might seem and look a little weird, but it's actually VERY delicious!  It has lots of banana flavor.  You actually don't even need a lot of extra syrup because the french toast and banana stuffing are already sweet as is.  I was actually pretty good with just 1 piece of french toast... if I were to have eaten 2 pieces of french toast, I might've had too much banana overload.  I also split the Omelette de Jour - chicken apple sausage, white cheddar cheese, tomato provencale, and basil.  It was good but was a little bland in my opinion.  I needed some ketchup to spice it up.

Overall, the food was good, but a little on the pricey side... for 2 people: 1 glass of freshly squeezed grapefruit juice ($3.50), french toast ($10), omelette ($10.95) = $28.32... doesn't add up right? well, of course being in SF, they added on a $2 charge for the SF Health Care plan... Total was $32 for BRUNCH.  It was good, but I probably won't be going back every weekend until I make real money... $32 is a little much for brunch.
author: Diane L.

description: Had lunch here though their claim to fame is breakfast. The Croque Monsieur was delicious and smothered with awesome gruyere cheese. Slightly pricey place but in line with the high quality of ingredients.
author: david l.

description: Another winning breakfast in SF!  yay!  :)  This place gets ridiculously busy.  But what's great is that at 10am the bar next door opens up.  So you put your name in, write you're in the bar, and they come and grab you when your table's ready.  So you can enjoy a mimosa or bloody while waiting.  All good. :)  We actually didn't even need to wait that long.  THey've got a few tables in front, inside, and out back.  We sat out back under a heater and I was plenty warm (which is saying a lot!) The service was fast, super friendly, and efficient.  The tables are close together but it didn't both me. THe menu is creative and fun with lots of different options.  We shared the lemon ricotta pancakes.  Wow.  They had this great lemon coulis on top, along with a little raspberry coulis too.  They were sweet but not overly which was perfect.  I had a couple eggs over easy with this soft, chewy, crusty thick white italian bread.  The potatoes were big and came with sauteed garlic cloves.  SO good.  What I like about this place is that the menu feels a little diner like - they have lots of basics, but they really spicy them up and give them some extra love, so that even the basics are special.  You can get morning cocktails here as well if you're feeling it.   It's a popular little place and I can see why.  2 thumbs up!
author: Tracy R.

description:
Does Zazie really need a 445th review?  Maybe, maybe not.  But, do I have an uncontrollable need to gush & wax lovingly, over-the-toppingly about this place?

Most definitely.  

Since so many reviewers have rightly touted the truly fabulous breakfasts here (this is my favorite purveyor of Eggs Benedict), I'll focus on the delectable dinners.  First of all, love the Prix fixe.  You get: starter, entree, & dessert.  I recently had the mussels (exquisite), salmon cooked in parchment paper (heavenly, perfectly cooked), & I ALWAYS order the pot de creme (insanely good little bucket o' orgasm - in my mouth, and also in my . . . well, I'll spare you).  Conveniently, the prix fixe is available any night (including weekends), and is quite affordable at $23.50.  The rest of the menu has a rather varied selection, which is helpful when dining with someone who only eats, say, chicken, or pork, or whatever.  The coq-au-vin is good stuff, & I can't remember others at the moment.  (The difficult combo of being a seriously food-lover as well as & a penny-counter nearly always steers me toward the prix-fixe.)  As a unique feature, Zazie also offers theme nights.  I think Monday is bring-your-dog night (& sit outside on the patio), Tuesday night is bring-your-wine night, for no corkage fee.  Not sure about any others.

And, since I have somewhat of a faerie light fetish, this review would not be complete if I didn't ooo & aaah about the pleasant, well-heated patio decorated w/ white faerie lights.  It makes for quite the intimate star-gazing, food loving evening with someone you think is awesome!
author: Ravena F.

description:
Awesome brunch spot, especially on a sunny day.  When you sign in at the front door, they give you the option of first available or waiting for the patio.  Waiting for the patio, which has a great brunching atmosphere, is well worth the extra wait.  The host even brought us drinks while we were waiting, which was great.  Having said that, you might want to avoid the Bloody Mary's as the don't have a liquor license, and therefore, can't use vodka.  

We all had different versions of the Benedict -- I had the Monaco, which come with prosciutto and tomato.  I loved mine -- the egg was done perfectly.  Also, we all liked the menu feature where you could order the number of eggs you want with your Benedict.  We all shared the French Toast Tahiti -- I really liked it -- the other two thought it was just OK.
author: Luke P.

description:
I'm not a big fan of standing around for upwards of 45 minutes to sit down to eat in a city where there are so many options, but I'll happily wait at Zazie. Here's why: 

+ Familiarity is my friend and somehow every time I eat here, the same guy is expertly whizzing through the seriously long wait list and seating people left and right. He's just the right combo of helpful and sternly strict when he needs to be. Like when people ask him how much longer it's going to be before they sit. Tell me, aside from assuming he's polling his seated customer's every ten minutes, how the hell is he supposed to know? I hate when people ask this. Seriously, people, your self entitlement is showing.
