+ Love me a good bistro. Show me some exposed brick, a smattering of mismatched yet quaint decor, and serve me food like a heaping plate of french toast with caramelized bananas, a choice of one, two, or three of a whole list of various kinds of poached eggs and I'm sold. 
+ Again, an outdoor patio with lots of plants and flowers can get me in to see you without even having to serve good food. Zazie does both. 
+ M-I-M-O-S-A-S. Champers + several types of fresh fruit juice = WIN
+ Zazie for dinner. Great roasted veggie plate, tasty salads, and a serioulsy great burger. I'd stay away from the pasta though. 
+ Bring Your Doggy to Dinner Night (Monday's). It warms my heart when I can bring my pooch to supper with me AND enjoy wine specials because of it. 

The only complaints I have: 
- My poached eggs are always cold. Maybe it's because they think placing my freshly poached thus hot egg on top of the cheese and whatever else might go under it will keep the bottom toasty but it never, ever works. I do have to add here that the only time I complained, they gave me the entire entree, plus my dining partner's, free. Above and beyond. 
- The darn home fries. They're just not good but I do admit that I'm not a huge fan of them in general. How hard is it to cook a quartered red potato so it's soft all the way through but crisp and pan charred on the outside? Oh, is it that hard? Then just deep fry them 'cause french fries and tater tots never disappoint.
author: Sarah M.

description: I didn't understand why we had to wait for-EVER for a table, but the French Toast Tahiti was definitely worth it. My mimosa was not memorable, nor was my side of sausage, but the french toast.... ummmm yummmmmmm! The gingerbread pancakes smelled amazing at the table next to us. Where the heck were we - Cole Valley?! Never heard of it!
author: Angela H.

description: God I love Zazie.  This place would be a great reason to move to Cole Valley.  The Tahitian French Toast is well worth the waiting that invariably takes place if you want to get seated on the back patio, which makes the whole experience that much more relaxing.  Haven't tried the eggs dishes but I have heard they are superb.  Coffee is very good.
author: NB K.

description: Named after a 1961 Louis Malle film, this is a terrific spot for brunch. Gingerbread pancakes and pear compote make a great combo, the omelets are well-stuffed and not too dry, and a Croque Monsieur or Madame will keep you satisfied until dinner. Caffeine freaks will be delighted to find that lattes are served in ceramic bowls. You can sleep in, because breakfast is served until late afternoon, although if you're not there early, there's usually a wait, especially for a table in the lovely garden out back.
author: Gourmet G.

description: thanks yelp.  i never would have ventured out to cole valley without your wonderful reviews of zazie and my oh my, this place makes a mean brunch!  I took 3 friends, each of whom has peculiar food preferences and we all left zazie completely satisfied by not only the food, but by the friendly and knowledgable waiter we had.  5 stars - snap!
author: Karen K.

description: I can honestly say they make the best breakfast, like 'mouth-watering' status. (Better than my mom's, and that's saying something to insult her for Zazie.) Their potatoes are perfect and have roasted cloves of garlic mmm. They always have some bizarre (in an amazing way) flavor of french toast or pancakes like ginger or pumpkin spice. The chai comes in a big bowl and it must be home made because it's special: sweet with a spicy kick. It's very french country authentic.  The dinner is good too, I've only been once for dinner but when I was there I had the Braised Beef Marsellaise, it was very tender and delicious. I always leave totally satiated.
author: Shanna H.

description: Brunch was well executed. Impressed first by the Chai tea arriving cozily in a small bowl perfect for warming the hands on a brisk morning. Delighted again by the sun, which was shining outside and the front patio made a perfect location for people watching and DOGS! Many adorable and lovingly drooling dogs were parked outside while their owners immersed themselves in the french hollandaise inside. The only downfalls were the somewhat slimy salad leafs camoflauging my trout and the tasty, but swiming in oil potatoe triangles cooked to a crisp.
author: Chris S.

description:
Zazie - is actually french for 'fucking delicious'... ok, maybe not, but it should be because this place is awesome.

Zazie is as close as you can get to 'mouth heaven' while on earth.  My perfect weekend starts with brunch at Zazie... then... well who gives a fuck what you do after brunch at Zazie because unless you're having a three way with the Olsen Twins, your day will go down hill.

The only shit hole part of Zazie is that the lines are so long on weekends.  How about you a-holes that don't live in the neighborhood go somewhere else, like IHOP or something, so that those of us that leave in the neighborhood get first dips.

Order the pancakes, french toast, or Alexander eggs...  you won't be disappointed.  But don't do it when I plan on going there as I don't want to wait in line in behind you.
author: J B.

description: 4 Stars for the food, but 2 Stars for the service The food was yummy. I had a Monaco poached egg dish. I ordered two eggs and that was enough to keep me full until dinner time. The wait was not too long for a Saturday morning (especially for our group of 6). We sat outside on the patio area and it was very nice. The menu selection was enough for everyone in our group to order something they found appealing. The portions are good. The only downfall of this place during our visit was the service. While our waitress was not rude, she wasn't too friendly either. I don't think it was anything personal against our group, but her enthusiasm level for a Saturday morning was lacking. With that said, I would definitely be back to try the Tahitti french toast.ce
author: Rebeca F.

description: My favorite brunch in SF - on the weekends you have to be willing to wait for a table, but it's definitely worth it. My stand-by's are the Eggs Pierre Noir or Egg's Monaco if you like poached eggs. The Hollandaise sauce is light and lemony. If you like your breakfast sweet, try the French Toast Tahiti. Top it off with one of their bird-bath sized latte's and you'll be in heaven!
author: Jill D.

description: I like Zazie best on a school night - there's usually no wait to be seated, and you get a lot of personal attention.  Everything on the menu is good and the ambiance is very relaxed. Although sometimes  there are a lot of people in there the interior ceiling height and exposed brick walls creates a feeling of space and coziness.
author: Judith C.

description: OK you can get bottles of champagne and a pitcher of juice of your choice for mimosas. the brunch is awesome. you can play ping pong at the bar next door while you wait for your table. at dinner i had pumpkin creme brulee, which blew my mind. i would probably give this place five stars, but it's been a while since i've been there. if you haven't been, you should go.
author: Geoff B.

description: This place was great.  We walk up they seat us right away.  The owner helps us, and is super nice.  The heated back patio was beautiful and nice.  The food was so excellent.  My cousin got the prix fixe and I got the trout.  Both of us were so happy with our foods.  The dessert was rich and yummy, the wine was good.  Basically just a great place.
author: Heidi P.

description: I am a serious brunch-aholic and Zazie is on my regular rotation. HOWEVER, the wait for a table is just as hellish as advertised, so I only go when I accidentally wake up early. The cooks do their best to justify the wait with heavenly pancakes and creative egg dishes (I recommend the Monaco poached egg with prosciutto and Provencal tomatoes or the Fontainbleu scramble with wild mushrooms). I especially love that Zazie has portion size choices -- 1, 2 or 3 eggs in most savory dishes -- in a town where most brunch establishments just serve you a truck driver-size mountain of food (ahem, Ella's). I also adore the back patio, which on a sunny day is hands-down the best brunch location in town (but of course, then the wait is EVEN longer).
author: Heather F.

description: Omg! I walked into Zazie with not so high expections because Ive heard brunch was good.  I havent heard too many reviews about dinner. Was I wrong?  The appetizers were okay.  They were nothing special but the entrees and dessert was yummy!!  The burger was great and the Fish Soup is omg.. so good! I could not believe it.  We werent going to order the fish soup but we saw a lot of people ordering it.  Then they had the o so yummy croutons to go with it.  Mmmm.....
author: Carol K.

description:
jazzy zazie, i am surprised by comments on your poor service. i like to linger in your secret garden and your servers are at my pace. plus, they don't just plop down water without a word, they say "two absolut on the rocks" and for a second you get really excited. 

fyi: corkage fee is waived on tuesday night. personally, i think it would be an insult to the food to haul in a case of two buck chuck, but it's still a deal.  .  .on other nights--  the benton's lane pinot noir of oregon is a nice surprise.

UPDATE: wow, i can't say enough about the owner. i have a soft spot for business people that look after their neighborhood. in addition, the quality of their brunch is shocking. gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd?!?! good friend wanted to eat "california" before she got on a plane, and zazie gave her that.
author: Chelsea B.

description: It's 1:45pm on a weekday (albeit with nice weather) and we (8 people) STILL can't get a seat on the back deck.  A very good sign.  I've tried to visit places twice before yelping about them, and Zazie is no exception.  yes, the tables are close together.  However, as long as they keep bringing out the dewberry french toast, they can crowd as many tables as they want with nary a complaint with me.  (exception: Zazie only serves sparkling lemonade.  Huh?  Save sparkle for fairy dust-Tinkerbell can't spare it)  Four parents, 4 "young adults" (what is the title for us these days?) and all 8 of us were satisfied, including several picky eaters in the group.  We were also exceptionally pleased that we'd ordered a chocolate and nut coffee cake for the table to share, and you should follow this lead, even if eating alone.
author: Beth V.

description:
Zazie is a small yet cute and homey French restaurant in Cole Valley. The space is decorated with posters of the French movie character, Zazie. There are a few tables next to the front window which have excellent views. There is also a heated outdoor patio. I've been here for dinner and weekend brunch. 
1.) Dinner
Dinner was definitely less hectic than brunch. We came on a Sunday evening, early, around 5 and were able to get a table immediately. The service was incredibly slow. We had been there nearly an hour before the waiter delivered a basket of hot rolls, fresh from the oven. We then shared a french onion soup that was made with beef broth, bread, and gruyere cheese. The onions in the soup gave it a sweet flavor. Next came a beet salad (marinated beets with anise), avocado, with baby lettuce and a gorgonzola white balsamic vinagrette. Not as good as the beet salad at Olivia, but certainly palatable. The last course on our dinner menu was polenta cakes with marscapone, red pepper cream sauce, portabello mushrooms and spinach. A very busy dish, with competing intense flavors, but worked out in the end to please my tastbuds. So overall dinner was not bad. 
2.) Brunch
I thought I would come back for brunch, since their french toast tahiti looked amazing (brioche with caramelized bananas and walnuts). Big mistake. The line was out the door, and once we got a table (took nearly an hour) they informed us that they were out of the brioche for the french toast. Okay, I thought, I'll get the pancakes instead. I asked for fruit on the side, to make up for the fact that I wasn't getting my banana french toast. In any event, they brought a huge stack of normal buttermilk pancakes (which I'll have to say were decent, but nothing special), but no fruit. Just syrup and jam. Way too starchy. And the waiter was gone (and made himself scarce) before I had a chance to complain. So I was not impressed with the brunch at Zazie, but am still waiting to try their french toast tahiti!
3.) Brunch take 2
Went to Zazie again for brunch today because I had a hair appointment at a nearby salon and figured if I was in the area, maybe this would be my lucky day and I would finally get to try the french toast tahiti. Having been here for a weekend brunch before, I planned ahead. My friend who lives in Cole Valley agreed to put our names down on the waitlist 30 minutes before I was due to arrive. This worked out perfectly, not only did we not have to wait, but we ended up with an adorable table on the back patio. As the weather was sunny and warm, this could not have been a more perfect brunch location. And to top it off, they had the bread for the french toast today (my mistake, it is challah, not brioche). While the service was still slow, the  french toast tahiti was worth the wait. This delectable creation is composed of orange infused challah with a banana walnut paste, caramelized bananas, and topped with a caramel sauce. They bring syrup on the side, but it seemed like overkill, the toast is incredibly sweet as is. While the french toast tahiti was as delicious as I had hoped and the seating in the outdoor patio could not have been cuter, I was still unimpressed with the service and menu prices. Now that I've had my french toast experience, I am not sure I will be coming back.
author: Kate A.

description: It was a bit of a wait getting in here, but this is an incredible brunch.   The pancakes and mimosa's were amazing.
author: Brandon B.

description: Yet another average place for breakfast in SF. Big F-ing deal.
author: Jason R.

description: Great place for Sunday Brunch. They lost one star because the place is so damn good, you have to wait an hour for a table. Not their fault, but it is what it is. I personally think the food is better at Citizen Cake in the Hayes, but they do not have the awesome outdoor seating that Zazie's has. Its true, the garlic accompanying the potatoes is not skinned, so be prepared to chew and spit. A little unusual, but damn I do love me some garlic. Highly highly recommended!!!
author: Johnny O.

description:
This place is great from the top-down.  Vibe, service, and the food is super consistent and worth the trip, and price.  The wait can be insane on the weekends so I don't push it unless I have something really good to read or can walk around the lovely Cole Valley.

Now the food.  I am partial to the Eggs Florentine basically a version of Benedict with spinach and mushrooms.  Their home fries when well-done and crispy rock and have whole cloves of garlic.  The straight up breakfast which is about $7-$8 bucks is strong, as are Challah French Toast, and the 1, 2, 3 (in French that is) which gives you a taste of pancake, meat and eggs without the toast or home fries.  They also will sub a salad for potatoes without charge.  Good choice of morning drinks including Bloodies and Mimosas.  The chicken sausage is sublime.  The Gingerbread Pancake should vy for greatest breakfast item in SF.  Strong words, I know, in an amazing food town.  I will stake my rep on Zazie.
author: Lo F.

description: Great outdoor seating during the summer and a good little menu.  This is one of my san fran faves.
author: andre s.

description: The Patio is the perfect relaxing haven. Charming service, and definitely the perfect place to dissipate a hangover in a peaceful discussion with a friend. It's unfortunate that such a delightful place can't offer a decent coffee, however.
author: Philippe B.

description:
I'm not sure what the hype is about this place... We went on beautiful Saturday for brunch, around 11AM, and the wait was short, about 15 minutes. The place was crowded, and we were sat at a tiny table in on the patio in the rear of the restaurant. The service was typical, nothing amazing. Same with the food - nothing special. The restaurant itself is tiny and hard to navigate through. Parking wasn't all that bad, I circled the block was and found a spot. 

Overall Zazie gets 3 - just your average, run of the mill place for brunch.
author: Massimo L.

description: I've been going to Zazie for 5 years, and I've always been impressed with the food and the service. A few years ago one of the waiters overheard that it was my birthday and brought out complimentary champagne for the table at the end of dinner. Such a great little place!
author: Michael M.

description:
this neighborhood gem needs no introduction. 

excellent food - a diverse brunch menu (the gingerbread pancakes super yummy) and their dinner items are even better (their mussels marinieres, braised lamb shanks - simply divine!).  

its a small bistro so seating is tight (but adds to the charm) and this place must have the smallest toilet about town!

otherwise, as good as it gets.
author: Teresa T.

description: You can't go wrong here if you're trying to find a good, decently healthy, atmospheric filled breakfast. I had the French toast tahiti here and my best friend had the miracle pancakes. Both excellent choices and from the reviews, they are tired and true favorites. There is a reason why this place has so many reviews and still remains a solid four star place simply because it's THAT good! We were able to sit outside and enjoy the sunshine while savoring the delights of a warm, sugary breakfast thanks to zazie's. Feel secure that you'll get friendly service, a relaxed atmosphere and a satisfying breakfast.
author: Daphne N.

description: Had brunch at Zazie on the weekend. Expect to wait about 30 minutes if you arrive around 11:30 on a Saturday. On a nice day request a table in the patio out back (even if it's a bit too chilly, it's heated so go for it). We had 2 pancakes, the gingerbread one with lemon curd, pear, butter, syrup, and one of the specials of the day, cornmeal pancake with lemon curd, butter, syrup. Both were good, 2 out of 3 preferred the cornmeal, myself included, but both are recommended. The lemon curd is tasty. I had the poached eggs florentine, with a light lemon hollandaise sauce on an english muffin with salad on the side. Hollandaise is good, not too rich, not too lemony--try it. It has lots of options and me and my 2 mates will definitely be going back for seconds.
author: Hayden H.

description: Zazie is great. Saturday morning breakfast on the back patio was awesome. It's like eating in someone's backyard. Great service, great food.
author: Ryan R.

description: what's not to love about this place?  I highly recommend the gingerbread pancakes (leave it up to you whether to pull the trigger on the pear compote though), and the roasted tomatoes with garlic and herbs which support some of their eggs benedict plates are outstanding.  Service is fast, even on crowded Sundays, and given how rough sunday brunches can be, they're pretty courteous even with some of the crazy combinations of things I've heard being ordered at neighboring tables.  Haven't tried the garden patio (it was raining all three times I've been, go figure), but it looks quite nice for a sunny day.
author: Kosuke I.

description: Welcome to Day 2 of Sam does SF!  This was definitely a perfect place to begin it - a delicious omelette in a garden terrace with the sun streaming down and surrounded by vines and beautiful flowers.  I mean, basically, what more do you need!? There was a bit of a wait, but I'm so used to waiting for brunch that I didn't even mind.  But then we got seated in the "best table in the place," so I suppose it made up for it.  One comment though, I have to say that takes some friggin' massive balls to have your four sidewalk tables be "first come, first serve."  I feel like some brunchers in NYC would cut a bitch for an outdoor table.  I guess SF people are more civilized...
author: Sam P.

description: I love this place! The servers are always really nice, and the food is fantastic. I recently tried the Crab Eggs Benedict, and I have been craving it ever since. Everyone else knows Zazie is good, too, so be prepared for a wait during peak meal times.
author: Alison K.

description: Love the variety. The food is heavenly. The atmosphere and staff are VERY charming. However, the coffee can be a little burnt around the edges.
author: Judy L.

description: Great little place in Cole Valley for a nice outdoor brunch on the weekend.  The menu has plenty of healthy options and some nice mimosas.  The prices are really reasonable and it has a really nice neighborhood feel to it.
author: Dave L.

description: Had a wonderful brunch in the lovely garden.  Loved the various options especially the multiple eggs benedict options and the pancake a la carte.  Had a new veggie option for eggs benedict - poached egss with girlled eggplant and a spicy tomato relish. YUM!  So amazing.  The hash browns were super too - crisped to perfection with whole cloves of garlic.  They do a perfect hot chocolate and my friend's oatmeal was also delicious.  The only let down was the gingerbread pancake.  Just not exciting.  Plus I was kind of annoyed to have to pay extra for real maple syrup, a restaurant of this caliber really just needs to only serve the real deal.
author: Bryna M.

description: I'm not a big breakfast food person, but I actually get excited to eat breakfast at Zazie. The best part is sitting in the back garden patio on a sunny day. I've always received good service and have had no complaints about the food. My favorites are the french toast tahiti, gingerbread pancakes, and croque madame! Unfortunately, parking can be a pain and it can get very busy on the weekends. I've actually completely avoided  coming here for breakfast on the weekends after seeing the crowds outside the door.
author: Kim C.

description: The garden seating in the back is quaint, warm, and romantic. On bright sunny days, it's the place to be, especially when the owner likes you. I enjoy any locale where I get preferential treatment. If you go, say Hi to Mario for me. He sat us promptly & gave us a free fruit platter while we waited. Can't beat the service, cute ambiance, great food, and decent prices. Plus, VIP members are entitled to free wine for future visits. These are good folk.
author: Jess P.

description: I came here for brunch with a group of friends on the first sunny Sunday SF has seen in a loooooong time, and I could not have asked for anything more.  The place was packed, and there was quite a wait but trust me, it's worth it.  The garden patio was really cute and when my grapefruit mimosa arrived, I was officially in heaven.  I ordered the Monaco poached eggs (with prosciutto and tomatoes provencales) and it was so delicious, I'd have a hard time not ordering the same thing next time I go.  The food arrived really quickly and every order was perfect despite being such a busy morning.  The staff was super friendly and mellow, everyone loved their food and the ambiance was perfect for a leisurely Sunday.  New favorite brunch spot-- can't wait to go back!
author: Christy M.

description: Their hollandaise sauce is watered down. Personally, I do not understand why anyone will rave about the sauce. Try Boogaloos in the Mission on weekends. Their hollandaise sauce is out of the world! Nevertheless, had a great time with some friends. Though at the end, seemed like the waitress was rushing us out. I doubt that I will visit again. It gets quite crowded and the restaurant wants to get the line moving.
author: Helen L.

description: Very nice French place.  Popular for brunch on the weekends.  Great lemon curd on the pancakes and such.  Good light.  Coffee's not all that, but otherwise an excellent place to go for a lazy morning meal.
author: John D.

description: Zazie is my favorite brunch spot in SF. It is close to home and a great place to go with my family. We even get to bring our dog. The only downside is the long line waiting for a table.
author: Emily L.

description:
came here for a wedding lunch reception, and the food was delish, as always.  i REALLY enjoyed their mussels and blt w/goat cheese.  

the staff was truly amazing, and accommodated us with our endless requests and needs.
author: Sheri N.

description: Officially, this place has been a breakfast hang for me over the years, and last night I tried it for dinner.  And here's the dealio, the staff is great, accomodating and pleasant.  The food for dinner is fine, it's average it's not that great, but it's not that bad, it's just a-okay and fine.  This place deserves a 4 stars for Breakers with those extra scrummy poached eggs (my FAV) and then a 3 for dinner.  It is a nice local spot, and I note that this three star reveiw does not mean you shouldn't venture in on one of their special "deal" nights.   On Mondays you can take your dog, get 10% off your meal and a complimentary bottle of wine...now that's a five star evening!!
author: Claire C.

description: Though I like everything on the menu here, I am particularly fond of the BLT. I am unsure if the final product is worth the long wait on the weekends but they have good food and a quaint outdoor patio, which is even okay on a cold day in the dead of winter. There are enough heat lamps out back to make you think you are in Florida in July.
author: Drue C.

description: Totally adorable little cafe! Has a great ambiance, extensive menu, and excellent service. Today I had the Poached Eggs Florentine (portabello and spinach) with the house potatoes and it was so so good. My friend got the Omlette Du Jour and we shared one Miracle Pancake (special pancake of the week) which was mind-alteringly scrumptious! What an insanely good pancake - lemon ricotta pancake with raspberry sauce and lemon curd IT WILL BLOW YOUR MIND. Every bite was heaven. Definitely will repeat, and would probably frequent more if my wallet could handle it.
author: Natalie J.

description: Went there for dinner last night.  I live nearby and thought it was more of a brunch place.  Wow was I wrong.  The food was good and the server was fantastic.  I was particularly impressed with the wine selection. They had quite a unique selection.  I had the fish soup, which was extremely tasty, but I think my husband's pork is the way to go.
author: Marla L.

description:
mm more dishes you should try:
1) Coffee Cake Bread: hint of lemon, but not overpowering... interesting twist to coffee cake. mmmm!
2) Lamer: poached eggs, avocado and crab .. hits the spot! i drool thinking about this.

If only Zazie's wasn't so far from my house and parking wasn't such a b*tch I would gladly wear a tire around my waist from overeating at brunch. I guess it's a blessing for my figure that I can't eat here as often as I'd like.
author: Charlene S.

description:
Wow, everybody else seemed to enjoy Zazie more than I did.  The ambience is nice and the waiters attentive, but the only time I ate there (the only time I will ever eat there), the food was really bad.  It was bland and insipid, like microwaved TV dinners.

Maybe I just got a bad night.
author: Michael L.

description: Pretty good!!!  Had the St Trop Eggs Benedict.....  Try to get there early... the lines look brutal!!
author: Demanding T.

description: French Toast Tahiti is my top recommendation to order here. I highly suggest getting there right when the place opens on weekends. Otherwise, you're in for an hour wait. I've tried going back twice and decided not to wait because of the 10-12 parties ahead of us at 1030 in the morning! Bummer...
author: Elaine L.

description:
Had dinner at Zazie for the first time--I had gone to brunch there many times, years ago, and had loved it. 

I found that dinner was just as great as their breakfasts--and even better, we ate at their back patio where you're surrounded by vegetation and flowers, absolutely great ambiance.   The prices were very fair, everything we ordered was cooked to perfection, and the service was very attentive.  (We also appreciated that the heaters they have for the outside patio were incredibly  effective, even for an overcast evening.)

I also wanted to mention that their wine list was both well-chosen and very fairly priced.  We were able to select a red wine that went well both with our chicken and our lamb entrees--the server was very knowledgeable and helped us select an ideal wine for our table. 

Overall, a superb experience at a little jewel of a neighborhood restaurant.  I wish there were more like this all over the city.
author: Michael D.

description: Zazie is one of those rare neighborhood places that you love more the more you dine there. It's an addiction. Brunch is divine -- especially on the pretty patio on a sunny day. But dinner is also great -- they have a super-reasonable 3-course fixed price deal, complete with the perfect-sized delicious dessert -- the Zazie brownie is pretty fantastic.
author: Laurel N.

description: Great brunch and lunch spot in Cole Valley. As Michael mentions, where else can you get such a late brunch.  The grilled tuna sandwich is perfect for a healthy lunch. The Croque Monsieur is a little heavy but excellent. And the famous back patio is a fine place to spend a warm morning or afternoon.
author: Phil M.

description: Great place for brunch to meet and catch up with friends.  I really liked the back patio seating and the mango mimosas.  The wait was a bit long ,but we had time to kill so it wasn't an issue.  I had the omelette special and I wish I would have gone for the french toast.  There's always next time!
author: Kimberly C.

description: Nice little place decorated to give you that French cafe feel.  Thankful that we didn't have to wait - if you're gonna come, come on a weekday.  The food however was a little overrated.  I had the omelette du jour (3.5 stars) which that day consisted of bacon, tomatoes, roasted corn, and this creamy cheese.  It was nice but I honestly expected better.  In addition, potatoes were undercooked and bland.  My friend ordered the gingerbread pancakes (4 stars) which were quite good but we thought it needed more of the pears and lemon curd.  Also, I'd advise against ordering 3.  They're pretty big and no matter how good the pancakes may be, I think it gets a little boring after a while.  Last, my other friend had the french toast tahiti (3.5 stars).  While it may taste pretty good, it doesn't hide the fact that mashed up bananas is pretty nauseating to look at.  Add the random charges to our bill (ex: health care tax) and it came out to a pricey $20/person for breakfast.  Quite frankly, it's on par w/ Crepevine and 1.5--2x as expensive.
author: Derrick C.

description:
Zazie hardly needs any more reviews saying, "Fabulous!" although it is. But I wanted to note that having gone there for an early dinner with my preschooler, it is a very kid-friendly restaurant. There is a kids' menu that is not appalling. The servers appear to like children, and they are responsive in ways that kept my daughter quiet and content for the whole meal (immediate bread service, milk in a cup with a lid, quick games of peekaboo etc.) There's just that little bit of welcome that makes kids comfortable enough that they don't melt down like they do in more hostile environments (kids aren't stupid; they can tell when they're not wanted, and they do not take it gently). There were about five families with young children seated inside around 6pm. No worries about feeling out of place or dirty looks from hipsters here. (But BYO crayons should your kids need more entertainment than the food and the company.) 

Also, if you come by bike as we do, there were multiple unclaimed racks right next to the front door. Thanks, Zazie!
author: D E A.

description: Ok, so this place is really nice.  Experiences may vary based on wait times or seating, but for my first visit it was great.  The wait (at about noon on a Sunday) was just long enough to get a coffee and stroll the neighborhood.  Seating couldn't have been better in a corner of the patio out back.  The gorgeous sunny weather didn't hurt any either.  So, enough about my day ... the food is what you;re interested in.  It was great.   Pancakes were light and tasty, eggs were done just right, though the sunny-side-up one was a bit overdone.  Chicken apple sausage was very good, bacon a bit overdone.  Grapefruit juice with their vodka substitute was perfect.  All around nice spot.
author: J P.

description:
After walking through many neighborhoods seeing the awesome city that is S.F. I was tired, hungry and happened to stumble into this place on a weekday afternoon.  

The backyard was the perfect place to sit, enjoy a Coke and have a delicious lunch. 

I'm glad to find out that I happened to stumble into what appears to be off of Yelp one of the greatest places in S.F. to grab a bite.
author: Beehive H.

description:
delicious!  the wait wasn't too long (15-20 minutes) and we got seated in the outside patio which was really nice.

The french toast tahiti was delicious and the order a bottle of champagne with a carafe of OJ worked out well for our group.  Everyone enjoyed their meals.
author: David H.

description:
My fav brunch spot! Many memories of lazy mornings here. It's cozy and charming and service is great.
The lemon pancakes and eggs benedict are a must try.
author: Gwen H.

description: i love brunch!  they have great service with delish food!  i love that for their eggs benedict dishes you have the option to have just one egg (for more petite appetites), two eggs, or even 3 eggs (for ginormous stomachs)!
author: Janice M.

description: A nice, earnest, modestly priced cafe with a great back deck.  Full-service sit-down menu.  Beautiful place to listen in on other people's conversation, and if you are beautiful or demented, to earn stares and admirations from those who have chosen a different path in life.  Weekend brunch can be intense, with hordes of murderous bed-heads circling outside looking for parking, seats, service.
author: Gil S.

description: Breakfast here on a weekday was perfection.  Friendly service, cute ambience, simple good-quality food executed expertly...  Yum yum yum.  I really can't think of a reason to take off a star.  Did I mention Yum?
author: Andi T.

description:
I first want to give props to our server Jeff. Very attentive, always looking out for those he was serving.

About the place itself: the place is pretty small so you tend to be bunched up together with some strangers at times, but that doesn't take away from the experience at all. If your own conversation is interesting enough, you shouldn't have to eavesdrop on others to provide you w/ entertainment, right?

On to the food: I started out my meal with the French Onion Soup Gratinee and it was oh so good. Watch out when you're eating this though, because you can very well splash it all over your shirt. The Poulet Francais was done very well with rosemary, thyme, and spinach. The mashed potato that came with it was very good also. My girlfriend had the Salmon Grillade and the salmon was done just right. Couscous was an interesting addition to it.

Can't say anything about the desserts since I didn't try any (we wanted to go to Ghiradelli Square), but whatever the table next to us was having looked like it was fun (think the name had Chocolat in it). 

All in all, If you want to get good French food for a fair price, this is your place. I would recommend the patio since it is heated quite nicely and at night it does have a good atmosphere.
author: Daniel C.

description: This is how a great meal should be presented. Fabulous staff...great ambiance. Amazing food. A great place for a date or out w/your girlfriends. Not to be missed.
author: Sherie R.

description:
i looove zazie. if i had to pick on restaurant in sf to eat at every day it would be this one. breakfast/brunch is amazing, and dinner is just as good. everything is prepared fresh, great ambiance (white christmas lights in the back outdoor seating area, candles at every table), and the service is fantastic.

for breakfast/brunch:
*bloody mary - yummy
*benedicts!! all the ones i've tried are good

for dinner:
*dinner rolls, i think they bake them fresh in the kitchen every night and bring them out to you warm. they are delicious
*french onion soup is the best. the cheese is thick and chewy. 
*beef shanks
*haven't tried the pork chop but i hear it's good
author: Jessica W.

description: Best. Brunch. EVER! Definitely sit outside whenever weather permits. I don't think I have one negative to say about about Zazie... I heart it so... And it's within walking distance from my neighborhood. Horrah!
author: Queenie C.

description: Definitely some of my favorite breakfast in one of my favorite hoods.  If you're a eggs benedict fan, their hollandaise is amazing, as is there stuffed french toast!  Go early or prepare to wait a bit...it's definitely worth it!
author: Sarah D.

description: I've only been to the place for dinner.  However it really feels like the ultimate neighborhood restaurant: unpretentious, excellent service, casual interior.  Food is very good if not great, it's priced fairly.  I also appreciate that there's no push to hurry through.  It's a great place to meet with a friend for dinner to have a relaxed conversation.
author: Jeff R.

description:
***
Edit: While I am generally suspicious of owners who contact reviewers and try to get a better rating, in this case:

1) I believe she actually gave a crap
2) It's the pancake-hat lady!

So, when the owner contacted me for more information about the incident below, I corresponded with her. And on my next visit to SF, I went back to my eggs and pancakes and bowls full of espresso and was happy. The host in question was there, and was reeeeaally nice - so much so that I wondered if he recognized my friend and I - but it didn't feel cloying.

In short, the food is always great and the owner (at least) cares a lot about her business, so I'm going to give the review I would if it weren't for the incident below.

****

Oh Zazie, you broke my heart!

This was my no.1 brunch spot in SF. I brought everyone I knew, and when I moved away, it was always a top priority when visiting. I had massive cravings for the gingerbread pancakes... the giant lattes in bowls... the eggs! the patio! the valence! The food is consistently great, and just different enough from the typical brunch fare to be interesting.

So why two stars?

The service sometimes sucks. One occasion caused me to avoid Zazie for a year; on the most recent occasion, I vowed never to return. 

On the recent occasion, I came about noonish with a total of 9 people in my party. Someone spoke to the host, who said we'd need to split into two groups of four and five, respectively. No problem - I was expecting that. I know how busy it is, and I know how the place is laid out.

A few minutes later, the host comes outside, rather hostilely billowing, "WHO'S THE PARTY OF NINE??!?" I identified myself. He is practically yelling at me, "YOU CAN'T DO THAT! YOU HAVE TO SPLIT UP!" "Ok," I say. "YOU MIGHT NOT SIT TOGETHER!" "Ok, that's fine," I say. "MAYBE NOT AT THE SAME TIME!!" "Yes, ok, I understand, that's fine." I was really surprised at his aggression, considering I offered zero resistance, and in fact, totally expected this outcome.

We waited for a while, which one always does at Zazie. I never asked how long it would be, or anything. We just stood quietly on the sidewalk with everyone else. After a time, he took the first group of four inside to a table. We sat, ordered drinks, etc. Almost immediately, a table of five across the room leaves, and the bussers set the table again for a group of five. We think, "Oh good, they won't have to wait long, and we'll all finish about the same time."

But! The host seats a different group of five at the table. 
We are confused.
Some time later (ten minutes?), the rest of our group is seated outside.

When a member of our group (politely!) asked about it, the host rudely replied that he did that on purpose to TEACH US A LESSON!! He went on to say, how dare we come to his restaurant with nine people!  At which point we all almost got up and left, but I wanted my gingerbread pancakes one last time. When we asked to speak to the manager, we were informed by our (nice, sympathetic) waitress that HE was the manager! Great.

This would be different if even *once* we had offered resistance, or complained. As it went down, however, I see no difference between a group of 4 people signing the list immediately before a group of 5 who know each other, or who are total strangers. It's two tables of business.

But hey, I sure learned that lesson! Now I won't bring ANY people to Zazie, and many people I've told this story have vowed not to go there either.

Sigh. I miss the nice lady who used to be the host. She was sweet, and once wore a hat made out of pancakes.
author: AG J.

description: It's so easy to feel comfortable here.  A cozy inside and relaxing garden in a great neighborhood cafe.  Great place to be during a quiet weekday.  Everything I've had is quite good, though the portions could be bigger.  Warning: huge, entire cloves of roast garlic (with the potatoes) are irrestible, but don't always mingle with the more subtle tastes that make up most of the rest.
author: nick w.

description: I absolutely love eating here for brunch! This is going to be my new brunch spot. I had brunch here for my cousin's birthday and it was just great. There is a long wait, but I definitely believe it was worth the wait. The service was also super great. We ordered the banana french toast, the NY scrambled eggs and the florentine benedicts. The french toasts were very big, so this entree is meant to be shared. The potatoes that came with the benedict and scrambled eggs were mouth watering good. I will be back here eating brunch for sure!
author: J W.

description:
I am a brunch/ breakfast addict, and I am pretty sure by now that this place is my favorite brunch spot in San Francisco. In fact, the only place in the US that I think I might like better is Norma's  at Le Parker- Meridien in New York -and Norma's is waaaay more expensive.

I get excited by the side selection of eggs Benedict dishes, my favorite breakfast treat, and I adore the French Toast Tahiti.  Oh, and the expansive drinks menu, featuring delicious cocktails and mimosas is a very welcome addition :). Couple that with exemplary service and a charming, relaxing location... makes for a perfect start to a weekend day!
author: Victoria K.

description: Any place that allows you to have breakfast between 1 pm and 4 pm gets a high rating in my book because I'm never up on the weekend to get breakfast at a normal hour. Zazie is definitely one of those places with a fantastic outdoor back room and some of the finest scrambles I have ever tasted. Maybe it's purely because I've been there hungover, but there is something magical about their coffee as well. Perfect for when you've been lying in bed all morning with your sweetheart and decide to roll out of bed in the afternoon for a Sunday brunch.
author: Michael E.

description: I came for the eggs benedict and was bummed when is wasn't a classic eggs benedict cause i was craving it! This is a french restaurant so note that everything is french style, the eggs benedict i ended up with was bacon, white cheddar, and salsa which i did actually enjoy for the most part and I really liked their garlic home fries! My favorite part about this restaurant was how cute it was and they had very friendly service. Overall I would say I enjoyed my brunch here and next time i will try a different eggs benedict.
author: Barbara C.

description: We watched Jen put up the Xmas decorations. We happened to be very early for dinner.Jeff was our server. I ordered the salmon, it was very good. 2 ordered the hanger steak, 2 onion soups & 1 beef stew. Everything was excellent. Desert was wonderful. We ordered the following, creme brulee, the pear fruit, the chocolate marshmellow thing. we passed the deserts around they were very tasty. I will come back again. Really enjoyed dinner.
author: Chris L.

description:
so i'm french/chinese but i've never really been to a place designated french food since i associate myself more with the asian crowd. plus i inherited the asian glow from my dad's side. but zazie has started it all!! i'm definitely going to more french restaurants. i love this place!! i felt like i wasn't in sf anymore in the patio seating. the french toast tahiti is to die for!! mMmmm caramelized bananas and syrup on challah bread. its not too sweet so i didn't feel like i was going to die from diabetes. potatoes are my favorite vegetable so their home fries aka season roasted potatoes with garlic is so comforting kind of like a warm blanket. you can also order 1-3 portions for most dishes which is convenient for a 107lb person such as myself since i don't eat alot but my 180lb guy friends will request the 3 portions. everyone is happy =) 

bad news: parking might be a pain at times and this place gets busy so be prepared to wait 15mins for seating but thankfully there's a tully's next door. my very hk friend says this neighborhood is "very white" LOL but i think she's biased. this place may be a but pricey for what you get but you gotta love the environment
author: Eileen W.

description: The breakfast here is amazing! There are so many wonderful things on the menu....the French toast especially- any variation of it- is delicious. The staff is so friendly and nice, and the service is pretty quick too. It's comfortable and cute place, with really tasty food.
author: Barbs J.

description: Do NOT go there for the lemon ricotta pancake--frisbee material--way too heavy. 2 bites and I just let it go. Omelet was delightful w/fresh vegs. Glad I went. Don't feel the need to go back.
author: morna p.

description: We had dinner here in early december when visiting my daughter. We had 5 people, 3 generations. We were all impressed with the food, drinks, dessert and service. They make wine cocktails, I had a mojito which was very refreshing and tasty.  The side veggies were amazing too! I've heard the brunch is awesome too. Next time I am in San francisco I will definitely be back.  I even bought a gift certificate for my daughter and her bf to go back! Service was excellent, the waiter explained everything and answered questions with great patience. We were lucky and got seated right away.
author: Barbara K.

description: In anticipation of breakfast, this turned out to be the best place I've had brunch in the city, hands down.  BLT Provencal was wonderful!  Can't wait to go back for the Croque Monsieur and Madame!
author: Natalie E.

description: Great outdoor spot (with heat lamps, though I'm not sure if the patio is open in the winter).  Cute restaurant for a small group of friends (I'd say 4 max because the place seems quite small) or a date.  The onion soup gratinee was very niiiice, and the charcuterie plate is quite large and tasty (minus the weird salmon bit).  The black truffle and porcini mushroom ravioli were decent, but not amazing.  Yes on the mascarpone polenta cakes...tasty treat!
author: Lily C.

description: I've only been here once on a weekday, but I had the best breakfast I've ever had in SF (and I've been to some good ones: Mama's, Aperto, Town's End, Universal Care, Just for You, etc.).  My poached "Eggs Pierre Noire" were fantastic.  The tomatoes were sweet and balanced well with the salty bacon.  I normally don't like home fries at brunch places because they are either undercooked or too mushy.  These were perfect.  Crispy on the outside, but cooked through on  the inside.  I looooved the roasted garlic cloves in the homefries that I was able to spread on my english muffin.  The gingerbread pancakes were really good too.  Fluffy and not too sweet.  The lemon curd was a nice touch.  I can't wait to come here again to try other things on the menu.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I really love this place.

I went a few years ago, before moving back to SF, with my friend Jen, who I hadn't seen in years and years. I don't remember much about the meal (just because it was years ago) except that we sat on the cute back patio, and that we both wanted the cheese plate, and that we knew instantly at that moment that we'd be friends again. And we have, ever since. 

So, for my birthday this year, I wanted to find a cute place to celebrate after running my very first half marathon that morning (I decided it would be a good idea to get up at 4 am on my birthday? What was I thinking?). A brunch at The Girl and the Fig in Sonoma made me think I wanted a place with a cute patio, so naturally I thought of Zazie. We ended up with a group of about ten, so there was quite a wait, but it was so worth it. Granted, I had just run 13.1 miles and may have been REALLY hungry, but this was one of my best breakfasts ever. The gingerbread pancake with roasted pear and lemon curd was outstanding, as were the Eggs Florentine. I adore poached eggs, and they have so many options. I also got bacon for the first time in 15 years. Boy was I missing out.  Yes, I ate all that, and then the cupcakes my friends brought me for my birthday, too (and a pint of ice cream later that night - because when would I ever have it be my birthday and have just run a half marathon on the same day again? No guilt there). And we split a bottle of Handley pink champagne, yum. The corkage fee was not bad, if I remember correctly.

I'm not normally a pancake person at all (like them, but I'm just much more likely to order eggs), but the gingerbread ones were so good on my birthday that I had to order them again when I went back there for breakfast today (out to breakfast before work! how novel!) with Jen. Even without a thousand-calorie deficit hunger, they were fantastic. Our waiter was great - super friendly and funny and there was no wait at all. I definitely recommend going during the week. And getting the g'bread pancakes. Do it!

Now I need to go back for dinner! And to try all their other breakfast dishes. And to try all their delicious-sounding mimosa spinoffs. And...
author: Janet G.

description: Zazie is one of the first restaurants in San Francisco that I ever loved.  My friend and I discovered it together and ever after it was "our" place. It's that kind of place. The prix fix menu is a good value. The kind that makes you feel like all is fair in love. Everything that I have eaten there was very good. When I was learning to cook with my roommates in our first college apartment we used to say that the quality of the meal was always determined by how much love you put into the cooking. At Zazie they definitely cook with love. Try it. You might love it too.
author: Kelly S.

description: Why forage for breakfast in a catatonic state when you can tumble out of bed and find naturally occurring soy lattes and yummy food at Zazie's? No reason to strain yourself so early, especially on a weekend. Seats outside the front door are first come first serve. Get here @ opening time or within the first 30 minutes of opening to get into the first seating. Mario, the host is wonderful. If there's a long line you can put your name on the list and let him know that you've gone next door to Finnegan's Wake for that Bloody Mary eye opener. The un, deux, trois special and the scrambled Eggs Fontainbleu are my favorites.
author: Sirima S.

description: Zazie is the beating heart of Cole Valley on weekend mornings and early afternoons.  I love the Un, Deux, Trois (a French grand slam) and giant cafe au lait for weekend brunch.  It's also a great weeknight neighborhood dinner spot with a 3 course prix fixe menu for under $18.  My only complaint is that they serve wine in juice glasses.  I know it's very Euro, but I still don't like it.
author: Tyler N.

description:
for the best Zazie experience: 
1) weekday breakfast/brunch [weekend if you NEED to but it's always busted out the door and hour+ wait]
2) sunny day. [a vital criterion for me] sit out back in the patio.
3) dungeoness crab benedict or oatmeal brulee- the best in the effin planet.
author: irie o.

description:
Everyone wanted to eat on the back patio since the weather had been so warm recently. It must be farther from the kitchen than you'd think because it took us three hours to complete our meal. During that long trek, my mussels were cool when they arrived, and the raviolis seemed to have sat a long time waiting to be brought out. This was unusual as they have been great when I dined inside before. My party had good French onion soup, and the wild mushroom soup was great. The beef steak, filet I think, was huge, tasty and the best entree. When we left at 10:30pm, the patio was still full and the inside dining room was empty. I'll go back because I know they can do a better job, and this time I'll sit inside closer to the kitchen!
Update 8/15/06: The owner sent an email with a regret that they were understaffed that day and are working to avoid a repeat. At least they are aware and concerned, a good sign. I'll dine there again soon.
Update 5/20/07: Things are looking up! I changed my rating to 4 stars because on my last visit, we had an outstanding dinner. I love their mussels and the salmon was terrific.
author: Jerry A.

description: went there for a going a way brunch and it was nice. I does get crowded and they have a list, but really good food.
author: Roger A.

description: I get the same thing everytime. Eggs Monaco. The hollandaise sauce is so light and flavorful. You will never have better breakfast potatoes... they oven roast them with garlic cloves that melt in your mouth. My husband loves the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd and the French Toast Tahiti with carmelized bananas. It is by far the BEST breakfast around. Curbside Cafe is a close second.
author: Sonal B.

description:
Zazie has been my go-to neighborhood restaurant for 4 years now.  I'll typically go for dinner during the evening, have a bowl of french onion soup or their chicken liver pate and their steak along with a glass of house wine.

Their other dishes are quite good, I've had almost all of them but what I go back to are those 3.  

for dessert the Chocolate Chaud is amazing, its somewhere between a chocolate mousse and a cup of hot chocolate...  It'll blow you away.. it even got me to stop ordering their pot de creme/creme brulee combo.

If you're in Cole valley during the week for dinner you usually don't even need a reservation.  I've brought just about everyone I know here and everyone wants to go back for more.

Their brunch I've only gone to twice since I've lived here, its quite good but for me, no brunch is worth an hour+ wait.  I've actually grown to dread it b/c of the traffic jam that people form on the sidewalk.
author: Brett L.

description: I've been here twice - both times for brunch.  The first time was just awesome.  The food and service couldn't have been better.  The second time was only so-so, but we got to sit outside and the weather was great.  It's true that you might have to wait to get a table, but their seasonal fruit pancakes are good and I always order a mimosa.
author: Lynnie P.

description: This is a very grown up place for brunch. I think my boyfriend and I were the youngest people in the whole joint. However, we knew we could be comfortable when my boyfriend recognized our waiter's Jawbreaker tattoo. The love of indie rock brings us together once again. Oh, and  the food? Pretty good! The BLT was the highlight  - goat cheese is defenitely a better condiment than that disgusting egg yolky mess, mayo.
author: Maria D.

description: If you know me, even not very well at all, you'll know I'm not the type to go to French restaurants. Not for any particular reason; I guess my first thought when I'm in the mood for a bite isn't, "hmm, some fois gras would be delectable right now!" Yet, an ex dragged me here one Saturday evening, and I gotta say it was damn good. I ordered the Poulet Saute Grand, and it was tasty as hell. Of course, it's French food, so I didn't exactly walk out of there stuffed, but for the amount of food I ate, I was thoroughly impressed. Really inviting ambience inside, as well as the cool patio in the back. Go here.
author: Drew S.

description: They were probabaly having a bad morning.  Gingerbread pancakes were tough and cold.
author: Bleep S.

description: My husband and I experienced Zazie for the first time and loved it.  The quaint, cozy atmosphere is the perfect setting for a fun date night.  The food was amazing and the service excellent!  We went on a Tuesday evening which happened to be free corkage, so that was a bonus.  We so enjoyed our evening and will definitely go back soon!  Can't wait to try the breakfast everyone raves about, too!
author: Erika S.

description: The gingerbread pancakes are what everyone loves. The scrambles are good too. Very quaint, continental setting. Service was good, attentive without being overbearing.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description: Zazie's is one of my favorite places for brunch.  My top recommendations are the ginger pancakes - it's like eating a gingerbread cookie, but a light fluffy pancake - it's amazing.  If you're a french toast fan - the Tahitian french toast is to die for - they put nuts, caramelized bananas, and some amazing cream between two pieces of challah - orgasmic.
author: Jared F.

description: i am quite fond of this little place, the back patio is great place to brunch or lunch. I must admit i am loyal to their large selection of eggs benedicts  which come with options for 1,2 or 3 eggs. My eggs are always cooked perfectly no runny whites and a perfectly gooey center, the hollandaise is delicate and delightful.
author: ani g.

description: Just lunched with an old friend at Zazie's, a reliable go-to in Cole Valley.  It was not-so-good today, I'm sorry to say.  The pineapple in the fruit bowl was rotting and the server was a bit cross.  Zazie's love, you're usually much much better.  Although you may have lost my friend, you have not lost me yet!
author: JL P.

description: Love Love Love Zazie's! There is most likely a line for a reason...good food and a  great atmosphere! Go early and make sure you sign you name on the list outside the front door!Between the patio in the back the sets in the front, the music, the decore, sign me up! The menu can be kinda confusing the first time around. I usually get the un, duex, tois (sp?) I have had the Tahiti French toast before it is amazing! All the food is really good! I have been here at least 10 times and every time I have great food and good service. Occasionally the owner will come around and ask how you are doing and chat it up which is always nice to hear the recipes and such.
author: Karlie N.

description: Oh so good food. My housemates and I have been planning to come here for these pancakes since we moved to the neighborhood but we wanted to wait for a weekday to do it. Today was that day! Such a great experience. We were fortunate not to have to wait long to get e table on the patio to enjoy such a beautiful day. Service was SLOW - but the menu kept us busy while we waited to be helped. Our server was extremely friendly and charismatic too. I think she was also the only person working out there. But we did have to wait a really long time to get attention and then greeted and then water and then take the order and then get it and then forever for the check and then forever for her to process it. Again, pretty sure she was out there on her own - I would have hoped someone was managing the floor and giving her more of a hand. We ordered elder flower? mimosas and I also got a latte - I was grateful to be able to get a soy latte and the elder flower didn't have as much flavor as I would have hoped, but  still decent. I ordered the burger because my BF wanted to try it and he ordered an egg dish that I was going to nibble on....His egg dish was good with salmon and  a TON of sour cream in the center. (I personally wouldn't have picked it - but that's my own taste) My burger was only ok - it was good for what it was, but so mild in flavor - I didn't eat more than 2 bites before passing it over . The potatoes were great with whole cloves of garlic mixed in! My other housemate had a mixed salad with seared tuna and Anchovy - he said is was really great. We also shared a Gingerbread pancake recommended to us by Marie K. with lemon curd and Bosc Pears. It was my favorite. The pancake was so fluffy and full of flavor, I couldn't have asked for something better. Definitely going to try this place again soon. Next time, I wont let the BF persuade my order.  The bill was around $80 - Nto THAT bad considering we ordered so much.
author: Jena D.

description: the cutest sf brunch spot!!! came here with 3 girlfriends on a weekday morning and put our name on the list - but then one of the first come first serve tables out front just magically became available! we happily sat outside. we all enjoyed the eggs. the waitress said they are known for their poached eggs and since i figured that is something i never make i might as well go for it - and YUMMMMM! i had the salmon poached eggs on english muffins with greens on the side and a side order of asparagus. the 4 of us split one piece of the banana walnut french toast which was also incredible - the perfect sweetness to have after the end of a big egg meal. i love this place - it felt like paris for a second - cannot wait to try it for dinner! oh ps the (heated!) back patio looks adorable, i hope to sit there next!
author: A H.

description:
this is our favorite little romantic restaurant in the 'hood.   i love when we sit on the back patio in the midst of tiny lights and heat lamps.  very chic.  we went her for V-day and they had the most adorable menu (example:  "be still by beetin' heart" salad - featuring heart shaped beets!).  we like that they seem to know us when we arrive - and find the owners to be especially nice and friendly.   the best nite to go is Tuesday - it's fairly mellow and it's no -corkage!  you can pick up a bottle of wine across the street and bring it on over.

perfect for dates!

(and the brunches are great too - but i just hate the wait!)
author: Kate F.

description:
so exciting to find a delicious new brunch spot! i have wanted to try zazie for ages after hearing nothing but glowing reviews, and thanks to a lovely brunch invitation, i went yesterday.  we waited a bit but it was actually less of a wait than i was expecting, having survived the line at mama's in north beach heaps of times.   once we got inside, i found the atmosphere so charming - cute tables and a nice staff.  there is also a back patio which i would love to try on a sunny day.  
i had the scrambled eggs with mushrooms, spinach, and cheese (the fontainbleu) which was really good.  i definitely think the scrambles are a nice alternative to omelettes.  the wheat toast that came with my eggs was also delicious.  our neighbors got the pancakes which looked awesome and i had total food-envy.  next time...
author: Carolyn B.

description: A really fresh atmosphere and the food is stellar. I love the neighborhood feeling; people seem to be enjoying themselves here and the servers appear to be having fun too.
author: Evelyn B.

description: Mmmmm, yes.  Breakfast-y foods goodness.  Eggs are always done perfectly.  So many fun scrambles, omelettes and benes, I see no reason to go anywhere else for brunch.  And the Zazie spritzer is tasty.  Sometimes it's hard to get that second cup of coffee, but that's my only real complaint.  (I did once have the Miriam experience - loads of garlic, few potatoes.  But unlike all other places in the city, these potatoes are actually cooked.  Not those weird raw-ish "home fries" you get at the corner creperie.)
author: darla s.

description: One of my favorite brunch spots! Food is delicious, and the host Mario is as friendly and just in his seating as can be.  I love taking out of towners there, as well as taking my self when i don't feel like cooking the morning. They just remodeled it so it looks terrific. You should of seen how many post-it notes where on their doors when they had to shut down for the remodel, people in Cole Valley were at their front door daily waiting for it to reopen. I think they made the sidewalk bigger in that area just to handle the crowd ;) Definitely delicious, great ambiance on their outside courtyard, I highly recommend it!
author: S P.

description: Hands down best brunch in SF.  Go on the weekdays to avoid the crowds and to get the ricotta pancakes, which they only serve M-F.
author: Reggie G.

description: Love the quaintness of this place!  A star for the ambiance: The brick walls add a bit of rustic, the close quarters & the long bench you share with other patrons adds some community, and the patio is uber-sweet!  A star for the entrees:  I had the lemon ricotta ravioli with prawns... the perfect amount of citrus flavor to accentuate the Dungeoness crab & grilled asparagus.  The bf had the polenta cakes, which were yummy and had great presentation.  A star for the nightly prix fix... only $19.50!  And a whole star (might end up being 2) for the Monday night Doggie Dinners on the patio!  Not only do they encourage you to enjoy a meal with your pooch, but they even give you a discount on wine!  Talk about a no-brainer!  Update soon to follow...
author: Tara G.

description: The Zazie Spritzer is a great refreshing drink for those Saturday brunches when you just can't stomach a bloody mary.  The rest of the menu is so-so... sounds better on paper than it tastes, but the outdoor patio area makes it worth your while if the weather is nice.
author: Chris B.

description:
$8 for french toast? okay, theres a banana too, but hell, if it costs $8, I want at least some eggs and slice of bacon or two. so, i order two slices and some sausage on the side.

the order comes out and proceeds to kick my butt for talking smack, and the two slice order, yeah, its not two slices of french toast - more like two double layered stacks with an amazing walnut spread in between, and a fried banana on top. thats right, i just got served.

i need to get back and check out the outdoor area. and get beat by tasty french food once again.
author: Darrell L.

description: The brunch is definitely worth the wait on the weekends.  The quality of the food is very good, I recommend the croque mossier sandwhich.  I wasn't happy with the mediterannean plate I ordered last time.  You should go here during the week when there is no wait.
author: Rupa P.

description:
If I could give it more than five stars, I would.
We live in Cole Valley - in a basement apartment with one window - and consider ourselves pretty damn lucky to have Zazie as one of our neighborhood eateries. 
For all those who complain about the wait : Marco (the host) will come get you at Finnegan's Wake next door if you advise him on the wait list. Grab yourself an amazing Bloody Mary and head out back for a few rounds of ping pong, believe me, you'll forget that you're waiting 45 mins for brunch. And you might forget all of your troubles as well, as the Bloody's are soo good you owe it to yourself to have another. 
Two words: Croque Madam.  Not only does it cure hangovers, it cures sadness, loneliness and heart disease... ok not the latter. In fact, quite the opposite but I will ignore my arteries' screams to eat this deliciously greasy, cheesy and meaty morning sandwich. I think I am drooling on my keyboard. mmm...
PS Service, wine list, dinner menu, patio, all dynamite too. Go, Now.
author: Kate S.

description: I used to think that t-h-e best brunch place in the city is Universal Cafe.  It's got the best fluffed scramble eggs but I have to say that Zazie is coming to a VERY close second. :)  I am absolutely a fan of the stuffed french toast and oh-my-goodness mango mimosa! The wait wasn't so bad at 10:30am but the guy did send us next door to Tully's since we are blocking the entrance.  Oh, and it's got really cute plate settings.  I can't wait to go back there again to try their other delish dishes....
author: Cathy Y.

description: I love this restaurant. Such a sweet environment - wonderful backyard  - friendly fun staff. And Great Food. The coffeecake. The eggs. The Zazie burger. The best burger in the city. Oh yeah.
author: Carolyn R.

description: Loved brunch on the back, heated patio.  Our wait on a Sunday afternoon wasn't bad (it was more because our party was running late), and tables seemed to open up around 1pm in the back.  Note that they will not seat you until everyone arrives.  I went to town on the food - the Tahitian French toast was sweet goodness, and although my eggs and chicken apple sausage were pretty standard, they hit the spot.  Service was terrific.  Even the inside is quaintly decorated like a French garden bistro ... ooh la la.
author: Melinda C.

description: This is a good place to drop in for brunch if you live in the neighborhood. I had the Croque Madame and it found it quite tasty. I saw some people getting the eggs benedict and I had entree envy so I'll have to come back for it. I wish the mimosas were less expensive, but maybe I've just been spoiled by Lime's all-you-can-drink Mimosas. I didn't know there was a back patio - again I guess just another reason to come back.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
my friends and i poorly planned our sunday brunch and showed up at zazie after 10:30. we had plans and couldnt wait to be seated. its been more than two days and i still feel pangs of regret for not having ditched the plans and sat down to a reliably delectable meal at zazie. 

everything ive consumed here has been fantastic. all that my brunch and dinner comrades have consumed in my presence looked and smelled delightful.  

i will brave the nuclear battlefields of cole valley, strewn with baby carriages like mines to eat here. i will deprive myself of sleeping off saturday nights last drink and stumble to zazies threshold to beat the crowd on sunday morning. 

keep in mind zazie is serves up provecale goodness--so dont expect to eat vegan and please anticipate a diet detour. on the plus side, you can look forward to being served up meals comprised of the freshest ingredients, lovingly cajoled into pots and pans and then prepared such that they maintain their integrity. 

oh yeah, the price points are terribly reasonable as well. 

mmm...zazie. i miss you.
author: stacy t.

description:
I give this place 3 stars with the caveat, I fully intend to come back and make sure to wait for the patio seating outside.  I went yesterday which was a gorgeous SF day and which also meant that everyone and their brother wanted to eat outside.  Not knowing any better, when I wrote my name down the list, I checked the "seat as early as possible" box instead of the "patio seating only."  Not that there was anything wrong with the inside dining room, it is small but it has some character.  More so, it is just gorgeous outside -- and would be a much nicer place to brunch the morning away as opposed to being inside in kind of a small-ish dining room.
So the food was OK -- I got the un, deux, troie (sp) with the challah french toast.  I was a little surprised that everything came out as greasy as it did.  Zazie did not strike me as being a greasy diner type place, but my scrambled eggs were runny not from being undercooked but because they were swimming in so much butter.  The bacon -- I actually didn't even end up eating it really because it was laden in grease.  The french toast slice was amazing and it was probably lathered in a lot of butter but I didn't seem to notice since it had such an incredible taste.  
So yes Zazie, I will be back and fully intend on giving you more stars, I just now know what to order and where to sit.
author: Katie P.

description: Just had brunch here this morning with the girls and it definitely hit the spot on this rainy morning.  Their drinks come in bowls, a whole bowl of chai...sign me up! I had their eggs benedict with smoked salmon and they were perfect, the english muffin was thin just the way I like it too.  And they put roasted garlic in with their potatoes, what a great idea.  It was a bit of a wait but totally worth it.  This would have been a five star review except I asked them for ketchup for my homefries and they never brought it out- but they were good without the ketchup anyways.
author: Tanu R.

description: I eat here at least once a week.  They have the BEST breakfast in town!  The eggs are always cooked to perfection.  The herbal tea is so refreshing and healthy.   I always leave satisfied!  Don't bother coming on the weekends though unless you want to wait at least an hour.  (It sux when its raining!)  It's very pricey here, but you get what you pay for! YUMTASTIC!
author: Kate M.

description: This neighborhood restaurant is so quaint, I love the high cieling and brick wall with the spiral staircase leading up to the office. Favorite food selections include the Un, du, troix for breakfast or nicoise salad.. you can't go wrong. Small patio but well worth the crunch.
author: Paul H.

description: grumble.... this place is ok. It's small and popular. It does have a very nice backyard seating area which I am very partial to generally. But the food, the breakfast food anyhow, was ok. Had the French toast Tahiti... it was...wait for it...  "ok". The crepes on cole just down the street I think is at least as good. Though louder I suppose and the outdoor seating there isn't as nice. The problem with zazie really is that its small and crowded. I'll try it again though sometime when I can get there early in the AM...
author: Ezra S.

description: Horrible service....worst experience in my 2 years of living in the Haight. Our server was a complete B and took forever to bring over any condiments. She even snapped at my brother who simply asked how much his portion of the meal was so he could leave cash for us because he had to leave for a flight home....He wouldn't have had to leave early if the food hadn't taken over an hour. The only reason I am giving this over-hyped up place more than one star is because the food was half decent.
author: Maijken G.

description:
it was my first diner at zazie and i'm french native, the restaurant is cute and the menu looks pretty traditional, i had a charcuterie pate which i recommend the portion was fabulous. the service was friendly but a little pushy, i take time to eat i don't vaccum my food! Joie de vivre right?
i was sad to see that servers don't add a little french touch even saying Bonjour or Merci, not sure if owners are french either but overall i'll recommend it but not impress!
author: A D.

description: Best BLT and the poached eggs are to die for.
author: Tyler W.

description:
PROS:
The line goes fast
The service is wonderful
The gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd was WONDERFUL. It's to die for.

CONS:
A little pricey compared to the portion we got.
author: warakant j.

description:
What's not to love about this place? Oh, I don't know--the dirty water glasses, plates and utensils that you are given instead of CLEAN ones. Or should I mention the 'shared' pot of brown sugar for my oatmeal that had something green in the middle?

That was all on ONE visit; needless to say my last.

Prior to that, I'd just had the dirty glasses OR utensils; icky but forgivable once or twice. 

But hey, if you are hungover like several other reviewers, if you did get sick, you wouldn't think it was the food...Or the alchohol might kill any germs...

I just don't drink that much any more. Oh well.
author: caitlin c.

description:
came here after reading the reviews this past weekend.
it's probably more like 3.5 stars than 4 stars as the food all around pretty good, but it didn't wow me nor was it memorable enough for me to want to go back.

we got the mexican scramble (it was with chorizo sausage and salsa), one gingerbread pancake and one french toast with carmelized banana.  All three were pretty good (very big portions!).  I really liked the fact that you could order 1, 2 or 3 pancakes, french toast or poached eggs. it makes sampling the menu a lot easier!

we sat outside and it was pleasant (with heat lamps)
author: Eleanor C.

description:
WAY OVERRATED!

food 3.5; service 0; atmosphere 4

We ordered the Mexico scramble (good but nasty side effects), the 1-2-3 (gingerbread pancake, eggs and bacon which was very good but nothing worth the wait.  

The host was very warm and welcoming.  The waitress was HORRIBLE.  she never once asked if we enjoyed our meal and tried to rush us out (even brought the check a few minutes after our food had arrived even though we had waited for quite awhile for our food).  

I just don't understand they hype... much better breakfast places.
author: Stacy N.

description:
Great heated outdoor seating (makes dining outside on a chilly SF summer night easier). I enjoyed most of the items I tried -  grilled salmon with couscous, potato & leek soup, black currant mimosa, roasted cherries with cream, and chocolate pot with whipped cream. The crumble with fruit dessert was quite sour and easily passable.  
I took away a star for their limited flexibility when it comes to vegetarians - the restaurant wasn't busy at all on a Saturday evening, and yet they refused to substitute a similarly priced ravioli entree for the polenta cakes (-1 star).  Luckily, the polenta cakes entree was good. Service was ok - the server seemed to be in a bit of a rush with our service (wonder if the prix-fixe choice had anything to do with it!). I was a tad peeved that he took away my bread plate without asking me, even though I had some unfinished bread on it (-1 more star).  In summary, decent food and nice ambience - I wouldn't go there for dinner without the prix-fixe option though....you can get real French food elsewhere for the a la carte prices.
author: Shweta V.

description: Hello Zazie thanks for a wonderful diner i came last nite for diner with my friends party of 9 food was the best ever I had the lamb tagine omg mm delicios I'm dieying to have again I try my friend food he has the rabbit it's fking good great I was feeling I was at France , good memories , thanks Zazie , thanks wonderful people from Zazie , I love the brûlée , and bake hot chocolate I'll will be back with more of my friends I recomend this litle bistro for every one best diner ever muaa' c ya soon(:
author: Freeman I.

description: I have been going to this restaurant for the past 6 years and I leave happy everytime. Their food is cooked to perfection! Their waitors are very welcoming and kind. The restaurent itself is lovely but I especially LOVE their outdoor patteo. OH, and their brunch is FABULOUS! I'm ordering take out tonight for a romantic valentines day at home and I can't wait to eat this yummy dinner tonight fallowing by a couple desserts :)
author: Shana H.
