description: A wonderful local SF restaurant that feels as comfortable as eating at home! Lines for brunch on the weekend. You can arrive early and avoid them. Don't forget to go for dinner. Their bread and soups are always good!  And the patio is always a great place to sit for a relaxed dinner.
author: susan c.

description: In an attempt to cheer me up, my dear husband took me here for breakfast...and he chose wisely for the 45 minutes or so we were here the food put a smile on my face.  His Challah French Toast was delicious and I had their poached egg dish with bacon and tomatoes provencal with a light hollandaise sauce accompanied by homefries & a whole roasted garlic the size of the quartered potatoes.  The cafe latte with hazelnut was probably the best I've had in a long time...overall the meal was perfect enough to put a smile on my face...the only drawback was the priciness, but we shall return.
author: Karen B.

description: First it was the eggs pierre noir: spinach bacon tomato and hollandaise piled on poached eggs on english muffins. Then it was the "un, deux, trois" filling me with the perfect amount of pancake, egg and bacon. Finally, it was the BLT, and since biting down on this gooey crispy mess of sandwich glory I have never turned back. The bread is fresh, the tomatoes marinated in delicousness, the mixed greens so much more satisfying than plain romaine, the bacon cooked to a perfect meaty crisp. And then the deal breaker: a scoop of goat cheese plopped over it all. When not investigating dumplings, peanut butter, cookies etc, I am investigating bacon. Never have I found a BLT that comes anywhere close to meeting Zazie's brick of pure bacon perfection. Paired with hasbrowns mashed with pieces of roasted garlic and the memory of the thirty minute weekend wait melts away in a haze of jouissance.
author: Tory S.

description: I simply love Zazie! I am definitely anticipating for my next visit. Although parking is incredibly hard to find, I would visit Zazie and go through the hell of parking just for the stuffed chicken with mushrooms. It was extremely affordable, for a tasteful dish! The ambiance of the outdoor dining reminded me of a sweet romantic night, especially with the light decorations. The waiter was also really kind to frequently ask if my party and I were cold. I would definitely come back!
author: Monica C.

description:
Great find!!! 

Felt like I was back in Paris! Hidden in the heart of Cole Valley with a perfectly rustic/precious bistro feel!

My friends and I went for a late brunch, at 1:30ish on a Friday, and we had no wait for a party of 6, so that was a great start!

I had the poached eggs Florentine and it was excellent! Even though they say no substitutions, they were able to sub the english muffin for their wheat toast....which was greatly appreciated! (especially since they wouldn't sub the cheese on my friends sandwich)

The eggs were perfect! They use free range eggs...and you can defiantly see and TASTE the quality! 

All of my friends dishes were also amazing delicious! I would recommend this place to anyone...and also suggest to walk across the street to the Patisserie and get an amazing chai latte!
author: stephanie c.

description: Good (not great) food, although the French Toast is pretty darn good! Long line though.
author: eric a.

description: This place is good. I've had dinner a couple times, and both times were decent. The atmosphere is quaint and the service is wonderful. When I pass by during brunch, the lines are way too long. So, I've never had brunch there and wouldn't waste my time waiting in line.
author: Leslie Ann V.

description: This is hands down my favorite brunch spot. The specialty pancakes, mimosas, myriad of egg dishes, and quaint French decor are my favorite aspects of Zazie. Their annual beaujolais nouveau festival party is so much fun too! The cheese fondue baked in a mini pumpkin served this year was really incredible. As busy as this place gets, the wait staff is always patient and efficient.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
it turns out that a good benedict is better than any thing else you might want to have for brunch.  unfortunately, a bad benedict is worse than anything else you might be able to have for brunch.  this presents quite a conundrum when looking for brunch.  do i risk the benedict?  

fortunately, zazie's benedict is unstoppable!  it comes in many varieties, but for me, there is only "La Mer", avocado, crab, deliciousness.  

at peak times, the wait is half an hour for a table, and for good reason.

zazie isn't all about brunch, just mostly.  it turns out that zazie is also a super fabulous place to go for dinner too.  now it is one of my favorites.  i suppose the only think i wasn't wild about was a dessert i ordered once.  it was essentially chocolate pudding and marshmallows.  i suppose the waiter tried to warn me about it, saying it was like a smore.  i wish i'd listened.  why a nice french restaurant would serve up something smore like is beyond me.
author: Jason H.

description: I have been to Zazie a few times for brunch and I have to say the French toast Tahiti is their strongest dish. The gingerbread pancakes are good, but very dense and for my taste better just with syrup than lemon curd and pears. Overall the staff is really nice and the food is pretty good but someone needs to learn to cook an egg. All of our eggs were undercooked even after one of my friends sent hers back. I had over-medium and there were water pockets and raw areas. That's pretty gross. I would go back but I won't order eggs.
author: J F.

description:
my newfound love: crab and avocado egg benedict....

a must try!
author: Patrick M.

description: Had to check out the hype.  Very simple food, but very well done food.  Good service. It's no hype, the real deal.  But you all know that already.
author: Derek C.

description: My wife and I have been here 20+ times.  I'm a fan of the gingerbread pancakes, and after my first order of the whole stack, I began ordering the single pancake.  That's my secret to truly enjoying the gb-pancake/ pear/ lemon curd and syrup. I slice the pear into bits and get a taste in each mouthful. I have recently been experimenting more, and must now try the BLT, after reading the smashing review below.  My wife likes the vegan nicoise salad with chicken. We like both inside and out, the heaters work outside, and the umbrellas are great on hot days.  Enjoy.
author: Jim L.

description: Just wanted to add that the pâté de volaille is otherworldly.  Thanks for the tip, angic!
author: Ben R.

description: I went here with three friends for brunch,  it was tres magnifique! I had the tahitian french toast, with bananas and walnuts and carmel something... so delicious! I also tried bits of everyone elses, they were all excellent. And we found a eggs benedict (the one with procuitio and tomato) that blows "the best eggs benedict in the world" from anne's in carmel out of the water...
author: C D.

description: I'm not the biggest fan of this place for brunch (for reasons not having anything to do with the quality of the food - i.e., the crowd) but LOVE this place as a weeknight dinner spot.  Zazie is the perfect neighborhood dinner spot because the food is always consistent with extremely good service.
author: Dave R.

description: I love Zazie so much, I am scared to yelp about it for fear the brunch wait will get even longer, or we won't be able to get a table in the garden on a Tuesday night. The food is amazing --- I've never had something I didn't love --- and the staff kicks ass. From the eggs to the croque monsieur to the blt (at lunch and brunch) to the beef shank (fun to order and to eat!) to the coq au vin (and I don't even like chicken) to the cheese plate, burger, or pasta... I've never found a restaurant with so many yummy things on the menu. And don't get me started on dessert or the make your own mimosas at brunch. Or the coffee cake. I think you get it...
author: daisy b.

description: We've had many a brunches here, and everything has always boon top notch.. Loved the nicoise salad and eggs benedict. We sat outside and had a great meal, along with the many cute doggies on the street
author: Pug P.

description: Very delicious brunch- and was practically one of the only places open this morning for New Year's Day brunch! Food was delicious, service is great, and cost is reasonable.
author: Anisha D.

description: I was in love as soon as I saw roasted garlic cloves in my home fries!  My boyfriend and I were starving and grumpy (he almost had a diabetic attack) and the waitstaff were so friendly and great.  We went  on a friday morning/afternoon for brunch and we were seated almost immediately (I had already made the mistake of trying to go on a sunday morning and there was a crazy wait list!).  The food came quickly and it was ridiculously delicious. Best Brunch spot in the city (on a weekday).
author: sasha s.

description: I woudln't give this place anyless than 5 stars for it's food.   i've been here multiple times and brought countless friends here and it never fails.  Brunch, lunch dinner, everything is spectacularly fresh (except the bathroom... yes.. thats 1 single bathroom.. located across from the kitchen).   Let's start with how to get a seat.  From my past experiences, a reservation is the way to go, especailly if you have a large group.  It's usually pretty easy to get one and sit down within 5-10 minutes.  Without  a reservation, you might b waiting for a quite a while, as this is a teeny tiny restaurant with just a few tables. Also going on a weekday helps too.  Brunch:   I love their Challah french toast  2 pieces is plenty to fill u up!  so fluffy, sweet and delicious (not soggy at all).  Also their egg scrambles and egg florentine use the freshest free range eggs!  For dinner, if you get their prix fix dinner for $25 you get 3 courses of excellent fare although it's limited selection, it still comes out to be tasty and filling. I usually get the soup, salade louise malle or mussels.  The mussels are particularly good.. the sauce they cook it in is so good, I ask for extra bread to soak it all up in.  For the entree, I would recommend the polenta cakes (excellent!) or salmon if you're getting the prix fix menu.  If you're doing a la carte, I'd highly recommend the Poulet or Le Canard.. they sure know how to cook their birds usually crispy skin and succulent juicy meat. If you're looking for more meaty stuff, get the pork chop or hanger steak.  Almost anything you get here will impress you !! Dessert wise - Decadent Vanilla Creme Brulee and Petit pot du creme au chocolate-  are always great options.  but usually by dessert time, i"m stuffed already from all the appetizers, bread and entree.
author: Margie C.

description: Brunch is the clear winner at this Cole Valley restaurant (no reservations accepted, but put your name on the list and go do a little shopping in the neighborhood).  However, don't overlook the delightful heated back patio with twinkly white lights.  They have "bring your dog" night where you and your pooch can relax on the back patio, enjoy a nice bottle of (half-priced) wine, and a tasty meal.  I am a fan of the burger -- not French, but tres delicious!
author: Penny P.

description: Yum!  Went here for dinner the other day--it was a great place for a get-together for a small group of friends.  Some of our party were late (like an hour and a half late), but the staff there was super patient with us anyways.  Reasonable prix fix menu.  They were out of the salmon, so I got the trout instead....  good sauce... so buttery. However, I was more impressed by the appetizers and desserts.   Yup, as usual, the best part was dessert--the four of us shared different desserts and they were all agents of happiness.  The warm apple crumble thing was the best.
author: Macadamia N.

description: The only thing I don't like about this place is how long it takes to get a table!  :)  Other than that, everything I've ever had there has been good.  I've only done brunch there, but I've ordered several different options and never been disappointed.  I have to say that the french toast options are my favorite!  Definitely worth the wait!
author: Corey F.

description:
Judging by these other reviews, I think Zazie is meant to be more of a brunch/breakfast place. I went here last night for dinner with some friends of mine, and wasnt very impressed with my order. The atmosphere is great, very nice place to go with friends or a date, because it's not too loud, and the lighting is perfect (not too dark). Took a glimpse of the back patio and it's very romatic :)  As for my food... first let me just say that I personally think that ina salad there should be no need to have prawns still shelled in it. salads are meant to be eaten right away, and instead I sat there for 10 minutes trying to see the shell (in the dimmed lighting) and peel it off. Annoyingly I missed some parts and got the crunch sensation... BUT.. it was good. I just didn't like having to be distracted fo 10 minutes before eating (it's one thing if it's a bowl of shrimp... not for a salad). Anyways... moving on, for my entree I had the osso bucco stew which I was pretty excited about since I hadn't had it in awhile. But what came out was really good stew, but with only 20% edible meat because the rest was just chunks of fat. Several times I had to spit the chunks out into my napkin. (GROSS!). If it weren't for the poor selection of meat, I thikn I would've enjoyed it MUCH more. I guess I just picked the wrong things that night because everyone else really loved what they had (great prefixe menue). Especially the veggie ravioli. I decided to order dessert to see if they could redeem themselves, and picked the vanilaly creme brulee. Good... but I've had better. The creme was too thick to my liking, almost flan-ish and a bit too eggy, which took away from the vanilla. Service was great, our waitress was very nice, and on top of things. And their soju cocktails are very tasty. I think I will have to go back for brunch though since that seems to be their specialty.

UPDATE: went for brunch, and it was a much more pleasant experience. I had the eggs fontainbleu scramble with a side of oven roasted heirloom tomatoes (YUMM!!!!!) and a sunshine (mango juice with champagne)... best mimosa alternative I have had. Will definitely go back to try the french toast. Looked soooo good!
author: Marina K.

description:
Amazing french breakfast and lunch menus.  Delicious.  I always try something different when I come here and I am always happy.  Their specials are really something else - they just came out with a new breakfast special, polenta cakes with spinach and mushrooms in a tomatoe-chevre sauce with two over easy eggs in a cast iron skillet.  Oh.  My.  God.  They served it with thick, warm slices of whole wheat toast that were perfect for sopping up the sauce and egg yolks.  Yummy.  I also adore their seafood eggs benedict with Dungeness crab - minus the avacado for me due to an allergy, but I can only imagine how good it would be with it on top.  They also have amazing french toast (and eggnog french toast for the holidays, ohmigosh how good does that sound!?) and great pancakes...and I don't even like french toast or pancakes!  They have a great portion option as well...one, two or three with prices scaled appropriately.  Their lunch sandwiches are also fantastic.  I love their black forest ham with gruyere cheese and egg.  They also have an awesome build your own mimosa as well as a delicious juice spritzer for the non-alcoholic route.  It's not too expensive but a good sit down.  

The decor is cute, country french-y, fun and light french music piping in and small architectural details like a wrought iron circular stair and comfy wooden benches that makes you feel as though you are a million miles away from a busy city.  The storefront windows provide lots of natural light on sunny days (and it always seems to be sunnier in Cole Valley) and they have a delightful little garden in the back that is PERFECT for eating outside on warmer days.  

The major downside to this restaurant is that it is NO secret to how good it is.  It is a neighborhood gem...that the whole neighborhood knows about.  FORGET about getting in there for breakfast, brunch or lunch on a weekend...you'll wait for over an hour, and they have no foyer, so you'll be waiting on the sidewalk outside.  I've had my best experiences at Zazie's when it is a weekday and I am surprisingly (or not so surprisingly) not at work and have an hour to divulge in delicious brunch fares.
author: Marie R.

description:
If you go to Zazie for breakfast/brunch, especially on weekends, expect to wait a while. There's always a line, but so what? Just put your name on the list and mingle with the yuppies and clean-cut hipsters outside while you wait.

Trust me, it'll be worth it. The food is a little pricey for breakfast, but it's really good. 

My usual order is one slice of French toast Tahiti (so yummy with banana, walnuts and caramel sauce), a side of scrambled eggs and a side of home fries (they cook them with whole roasted garlic cloves, yesss).  

The servers are rushed but usually friendly. We always opt for sitting inside over the patio, since the atmosphere is cute and French-y, and the place has a bright interior. 

Fun and delicious place to spend a weekend morning if you've got the time!
author: J P.

description:
I went here a couple months back with some girlfriends. Zazie is a super cute french bistro in cole valley. We were seated outdoors in the back, which very much reminded me of not being in san francisco!!  I had the Eggs Italie, which were amazing. The eggs were scrambled with cream cheese, basil and roasted tomatoes. Along with the home fries, it was sure amazingness in my mouth. The great part about going in a group is that you get to steal some bites of other food! :) I had a couple of bites of the gingerbread pancakes, and during the experience, I was really wishing for a gingerbread cookie. They were good, but a little strong. The most surprising to me was the french toast! I don't even like french toast, and I though this dish was to die for. 

HOWEVER, the service was not good--we waited for a very long time for any attention when we were seated, and once our plates were served, our waiter left us with no silverware and no refills on water! We had to get up and find our forks. :(   Busyness is not a excuse for a place that gets as much foot traffic as it does on a daily basis. Tisk Tisk.
author: Alexandra O.

description: Lovely little bistro diner, with cute garden patio, great food, a nice bright airy interior. Their salade nicoise is rather good.
author: Stuart J.

description: Love this place!  I had the trout with greens (yum!)... and I forgot the other thing.... It's really nice to eat in the outside patio (in the back) because the air is fresher and there's greenery (just watch out for random insects admiring the flowers too).   Dining inside is cozy as well, but it's warmer because the kitchen is inside too.  Almost anything here is good... a bit on the pricey side, but the atmosphere and quality of the food makes up for it.
author: Grace M.

description:
my abosolute favorite brunch spot in SF--and definitely in the top 10 for the city, in my humble opinion. i can't get enough of their eggs pierre noir. it's basically an eggs benny dish but with the most flavorful bacon i've ever had and mouth watering organic tomatoes. best hollandaise sauce ever, not too heavy with a nice lemony zing. the french toast is to die for, tho really sweet so better to order it when you can share it with others. fabulous lattes and mimosas. they try to use organic/sustainable ingredients wherever possible. there'll be a wait, but believe me, it's worth it, and i've never waited longer than 20 min. 

linger over brunch on the back patio on a sunny day, it's tres quaint.
author: rachel p.

description: Only 4 stars because their bathroom is hard to throw up in (see related story from same date).  The food is delicious, in fact, after the above incident I came back to the table and proceeded to eat more - so sad.
author: Ryan P.

description: If you can manage to get in on a weekend for brunch. They make pancakes, the quality of which, I would gladly rip someone's face off for. If you are a carnivore and go for dinner, get the steak medium rare and prepare to lose control of your basic motor skills.
author: Richard C.

description:
San Francisco's such a great town for breakfast/brunch. With all of its sidewalk cafes; corner delis; and little, tucked-in, neighborhood joints; this town is built for the comfy, reclined nature of the first meal.

Zazie is a perfect example. The place is small, but the food is delish and well worth the wait (I don't write that very often). The NY omlette is great, so are the pancakes, and just about everything else I sampled here.
author: Dennis L.

description:
I've been to this place twice now with two different experiences. My first experience was during dinner under the stars and a heat lamp with two great friends. I had a burger...not something flashy i know, but it was a great burger...food always tastes better in a great environment.
The second was most recently, for an early Saturday morning brunch to catch up with a friend. We decided to be seated (in or out) depending on the quickest opening...It was kind of misty but under a heat lamp you could forget for a minute you were in sf, having been transported to some foreign bistro among the vines and smells of great food. The one thing that puzzled my friend and i was coffee served in a soup bowl. We saw two gentlemen next to us enjoying their morning JOE in this bowl and had to ask to confirm our curiosity. It reminded me of a Japanese tea ceremony ritual where they use a soup bowl to share tea. Not that they shared their coffee but the bowl...you get what i mean...Anyway, its a cute place...great for dates, friends, and everything in between...
author: Ravi R.

description: While the food is ok, the meal is spoiled by the high health fee charged.  For a $30 tab for two, you pay $2.50, almost 10%! Quite a deal for the restaurant as I read they get most of the money returned if not used by the employees.  I will not return because of this over-charge.
author: Yella W.

description: Conveniently located right off the N line in Cole Valley, Zazie's is a great choice for your next brunch. I came with a large group and although they do not take brunch reservations, the staff was very accommodating. We had to wait- as expected- but we were able to sit on the adorable back patio. Our waitress was extremely friendly. The food was delicious. I cant stop thinking about the pancakes and french toast. The Albert was yummy too. If the weather is nice- I recommend Zazie's- but ask to sit on the back patio where you can enjoy some sunshine with your brunch.
author: Melinda Q.

description: Most famous for brunch, but really better at lunch (weekdays seem to have a larger lunch menu). The eggs and pancakes are good, but pretty standard fare. But the pasta special has not failed me yet. Once it was a squash ravioli with wilted arugula and a very light tomato sauce, another time, ravioli with black truffle and mushroom filling. Always made fresh. While I've had similar dishes elsewhere, Zazie has always balanced the filling, the pasta, and the sauce/garnish in a way that makes you want to just hold the flavor in your mouth and explore it. Oh, and while most comparable plates would be $12-15, here, it's under $10, and with friendly, quick service.
author: Rick C.

description: Recently moving to Cole Valley, one common bit of advice I received was to try out brunch at Zazie.  While there was a small wait when we arrived around 1, it was well-managed with the sign-up sheet.  I could not order a Mimosa (my favorite brunch drink) as I was still nursing a headache from the night before so I ordered a Zazie Spritzer instead.  The spritzer totally hit the spot and was a good complement to the poached eggs and side order of pancakes.  I'm looking forward to being able to walk to Zazie all the time.
author: Tony P.

description: Brunch is one of my favorite activities to do with friends.  Almost every weekend, my friends and I ride our bikes to different spots in the city and enjoy a leisurely meal with each other to start the day off.  I used to come to Zazie's quite often, but I got really sick of waiting in the horrible long lines to get a table and I detest their breakfast potatoes.  In all fairness, I generally don't like any breakfast potatoes and prefer my potatoes either mashed or fried in thin strips.  They have excellent iced tea which is my savior after a night of drinking. The food is quite tasty, minus the potatoes which you can substitute for fresh fruit if you want to pay an extra 2 bucks. My favorite thing to get there is the un, deux, trois where you get one pancake, two eggs any style and three strips of bacon.  it's the perfect amount of food. Also the scrambles are great.
author: Jade L.

description:
ah, free corkage tuesdays...

as long as you can brave the cole valley family oriented types [one baby at a table, two children outside singing, and the most irritating little league coach rambling about her team for AN HOUR nonstop], then you must eat here. 

the mussels were fab, the asparagus was lovely, and make sure you get the beet salad. damn i love beets. the service was as service should be, the ambiance on the heated back patio was wonderful, and the prices are totally reasonable for the mouth orgasms i had.

great date spot. you'll get laid.
author: Clover Dan ..

description: Every time I've been here, the service has been charming and attentive, the food has been delicious, and the atmosphere warm and inviting. Our server was named Aiden on our last visit, and he was attentive, knowledgeable about the menu as well as genuinely interested in our experience--his recommendations ended up being wonderful. I'm just sorry it took so long to relay our wonderful experience(s) at Zazie. Brunch on their patio is amazing, as well.
author: jessica f.

description: Zazie is back!!! They had a bit of an unfortunate hiatus but the tastiness has returned. Definitely worth the wait. Ask to sit in the backyard, give a hug to Mario, order a bowl-o-latte and gingerbread pancakes. Stellar! Yeah Zazie!
author: Nikki T.

description: This place does not disappoint! I went here on Sunday around 9am thinking that would be early enough to beat any wait but I was wrong. There was still a wait but it went by quickly. My friend and I were seated in the back patio - it wasn't sunny but still beautiful. We split the gingerbread pancakes, French toast and the La Mer eggs benedict. The French toast was solid - very eggy, rich and infused with vanilla. The gingerbread pancakes were a little more unique in taste. It was more on the cakey side than light and fluffy but still awesome. The lemon curd and bosc pear that it came with added another dimension. We split one pancake and it was very satisfying. This pancake was huge and super sweet so I don't think I could have finished a whole plate of these. The La Mer eggs benedict was very my favorite. I don't even like seafood so trust me when I say it's good. The hollandaise was fantastic too.
author: Amy N.

description: J says: Now I love breakfast and Zazie serves it till 2:30pm everyday!  Yay!  The Le Mer benedict was quite yummy, perfectly poached eggs smothered in hollandaise sauce on top of lots of fresh dungeness crabmeat.  My friend had the scrambled eggs with salmon which looked a little dry to me.  Service was very friendly and the place is cute.
author: Jen Ken H.

description:
a great value!  with French restaurants there is often a direct relationship between culinary enjoyment and buyer's remorse.  we got out of here for dinner at less than 70 bucks, and full to boot.  granted we did not have that much to drink, and skipped dessert.  honestly had no room.

in writing this review i did a quickie search for the meaning of the word "Zazie." interestingly, it means an illicit love affair that does not cost one's marriage or finances.  haha.  kidding of course.  did not find it on my first google try so if anyone finds out let me know...

best described as a comfortable neighborhood French restaurant.  it's pretty casual in there so you can wear jeans and a t-shirt.  lots of yelpers review the place for brunch so i need to go back.  they've got a patio area in the back too.

they have a prix fixe for 23 bucks, not bad.  skipped it this time cuz i didn't feel like the asterisk items.  started out with the plate of cheeses which i enjoyed immensely (year of the rat).  entree was braised niman ranch lamb shanks, which melted in my mouth.  Wifey had the roasted trout which took up a decent amount of the plate, and was flavorful / flaky.  had a glass of trueblood syrah, went well with the shanks.  

service was good.  probably a good idea to make a res as it's not spacious inside.  we made one the same day on a Sat nite so not too difficult.  we got there early so there's a pub next door to wait in...
author: Jimmy F.

description: Had brunch here last Saturday.  Food, service, atmosphere were all good.  The mimosa selection was diverse, fun and tasty.  The Levain (sp)  was super yummy.  Halfway through brunch, we looked around and noticed that the overall beauty quotient seemed measurably above average for SF. :)
author: Kevin M.

description: There's a reason people flock to this place for brunch on the weekends -- it's great! But the real time to go to Zazie is dinner time. After the brunch crowds have left and the sun has set, Zazie comes alive with candle-lit tables and a fantastic dinner ambiance. A great place for a date with your wife -- especially on a Sunday night.
author: Lars J.

description: Came here on a recommendation of a friend who goes here almost every weekend. While we did really enjoy our brunch, we found the long wait and the disorganized wait sheet situation annoying. The guy crossing names off the list was kind of a in a foul mood and that wasn't a pleasant opening experience for the place. I would only go back if I could get my butt up earlier in the morning to avoid the long wait and I planned on being in that neighborhood. Given SF has so many great brunch places to try out, I don't know if I will be coming back soon.
author: M O.

description: My move into the City has me now living near Cole Valley and I was lucky enough to have an early dinner at Zazie over a warm weekend.  Like many others, I feel that the food was not amazing, but good and very healthy.  The service though was stellar and the backyard seating area was a must for those looking to sit outside in a nice, comfortable setting.  I would definitely revisit, especially when it is warm enough to be outside.
author: Michael C.

description: This is a very cute place.  And free corkage on Tuesday nights makes it even cuter.  The food is solid, the back patio is charming, and the service was great as well. My only wish is that they'd add more veggie main dish options, although they do have numerous veggie starters. Will definitely be back.
author: SL N.

description:
my favorite place in san francisco - it's lovely without being too lovely, elegant but not too expensive.  if you like (or want to be) Amelie (or for that matter Nino) - you will probably like Zazie.  

recommended: the patio, the trout, and the creme brulée.
author: Sarah R.

description: The best time to go to Zazie's is in the morning during the week. The weekends are over run with parents showing off their treasured offspring. The breakfasts are good-kinda pricey...the toasted pannetone is really great. The patio in back is the place to sit.
author: lesley s.

description:
I was so terribly disappointed with Zazie today!  I read about it here last night and immediately made plans to go this afternoon.  I ordered a burger (boring, I know, but it was calling to me), with cheese only.  It came out with all the fixings.  Although my server had disappeared, another server got me a new bun, but he did not seem pleased.  (My server ran past later, saw my plate, mumbled "sorry," and laughed, all without pausing.)  The burger was alright -- nothing amazing.  It was difficult to enjoy since my water glass was empty for about 10 minutes until I finally asked yet another server for a refill.  

Mine blew past again to give me my bill and take my money, of course, but then she gave me my paper change but didn't give me my loose change!  (And this was all around 1:30 on a Wednesday -- they were not busy.)  I didn't want to make a big deal about a couple of quarters, so I didn't say anything -- probably a bad decision, since the next time I'm short for a parking meter, I will get angry all over again.  

Overall:  mediocre food (at best) and terrible service.  I'm glad that others seem to enjoy it, and maybe I would have fared better if I had ordered the poached salmon as I had debated -- but I don't plan to go back to find out.
author: C L.

description:
maybe my expectations for this place was too high going in but i was expecting to be wowed and i wasnt. each night they offer a three course prix fixe menu on certain items for $23.50 and between the three of us we were able to try the pate and mussles as starters, the braised beef, salmon and marscapone polenta cakes for entrees, mac n' cheese as a side and then the petit pot de creme au chocolat (with a name like that, how can it not be good?) and the bread pudding.

my overall comment on the entrees was that everything was kind of dry and the desserts werent that satisfying either. my favorite item of the night was probably the pate so that should be telling in itself already.

while the food was just a little above average, the restaurant itself was really cute and the service was great. ive been told that the brunch here is amazing so i definitely will be back to try that!
author: georgette y.

description: I have been going to Zazie now for about 8 years, and i try to go at least once a week.  If you crave and love really good breakfast check this place out.  They have some of the best poached egg dishes in the city in my opinion.  Killer pancakes, many different ways, french toast and the list just goes on and on.  They have a really nice patio out back which on sunny days is a little piece of heaven. And the staff is awesome, no attitude just really nice and pleasant.  Check it out next time you're in need for a really great breakfast.
author: larry w.

description: This is my new favorite place----great ambiance, service, coffee, and of course food!  It's worth the wait, and did I mention the food?  Yum
author: Susan H.

description:
came here on a weekday, no long line. 
had one of their omelettes, i forget the name. something omelette du jour. but it was super good. i love their home fries with the garlic! yum i love the garlic they put in it!! 
we had the french toast, a little too soggy for my liking, but all of us really liked what we ordered! will come back!
author: emily p.

description: This restaurant has been going downhill over the past 2-3 years.  We keep going back there because of friends.  How I miss the menu this place boasted 4-5 years ago, when it had that je ne sais quoi.  This place has lost almost all of its French, and they have lost their knack of refining the entrees.  Their wine selection has gone downhill as well.
author: Ryan S.

description:
As honored as I was to be in my friend's wedding, I was a little stressed about the party planning responsibilities. Zazie made life a lot easier when I decided to throw a bridal shower for 15 people on their cozy back patio. 

The owner was extremely accommodating.  She helped me plan the menu from their delicious mid-afternoon selections of charcuterie and cheese platters, sandwiches, salads and of course wine, champagne and coffee. Considering the quality of the food and wine, it was very affordable for this bridesmaid on a budget. She even printed out little custom menus for our tables. Everyone raved about the food and service and I got tons of praise for throwing a relaxing Sunday afternoon party.  

Thanks again Zazie!
author: cara N.

description: this place is so great!  i had stuffed pancakes with lemon curd. It was  sugar heaven! The eggs are perfect and the potatoes with the giant cloves of garlic-make me happy.
author: Christina G.

description: I love the brunch here.  The french toast tahiti is awesome and the Omelette Fountainbleu is my favorite.  The potatoes are great cuz they come with roasted garlic.  Lovely little patio in the back is usually warm and blocked from the wind.  Long wait sometimes though.
author: Dana C.

description: I keep leaving this place disappointed.  Bad service.  Mediocre food.  Long waits.  I'm officially breaking up with Zazie.
author: Melissa Y.

description: When you get to heaven, or finally achieve nirvana, or are lifted by the many arms of Vishnu (depending on your personal preference) I'm pretty sure that the first thing that happens is that your diety of choice hands you a big plate of Zazie's poppyseed pancakes and a cassis mimosa. With the fresh lemon curd. In their garden. Vishnu probably never has to wait.
author: Ron A.

description:
I was thoroughly impressed by this place.  The food is delicious, and the atmosphere is fun.  The server gave us plenty of space and time to enjoy our meal.  These are the types of places that I really look forward to frequenting.

I definitely plan on going again to try some of their other selections.
author: Stephen N.

description: Came in on a chilly SF night with 2 friends and we were seated right away. Chose three things off the prix fix menu. Started off with the green salad tossed with a yummy raspberry vinaigrette. Was light, fresh and a great way to start off the meal. Next was the zazie burger  with gorgonzola and grilled yukon potatoes...it was delish. The meat was moist, well flavored and coupled well with the bold taste of the gorgonzola. Washed it down with a cold cider. One of my neigborhood faves!
author: Ijay J.

description: Amazing food.  Our favorite restaurant in the city.  What more is there to say once you've said that??  Pricing is reasonable for such good food!  Service is good and there hasn't been a wait any time that we have been to Zazie. Parking is what you would expect for Cole Valley, but it is very close to a muni stop.  Love this place!
author: Brian G.

description: Brunch here was tasty and enjoyable. Put your name on the list then walk down the street to check out "Say Cheese," a cheese, chocolate, and wine store nearby.
author: Ellie P.

description: I can't believe I lived in the Sunset District all those years and not once did I eat at this great little restaurant. It is very great. And it is very little. Maybe that's why it never caught my eye. I am an idiot. I missed being so close to delicious bistro style comfort food...argh. Oh i am so kicking myself! Their bread is fantastic. I don't think you can get seconds of it though bcause their kitchen is the size of my bathroom. I also really enjoyed the zazie burger and the beefy french onion soup.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: I'm a bit biased since I live in the 'hood, but for an excellent breakfast or dinner Zazie can't be beat. When the weather lets up, and the sky goes blue and puffy with white cumulus clouds, the back terrace time-machines you into a quiet nook in San Francisco's secret garden. They have heaters back there so don't worry about the chill. The coffee is excellent, the poached eggs exquisite, and the wait staff friendly and attentive. Dinner is elegant and yet affordable. I've been going there for four years now and every time has been pleasurable.
author: Buck K.

description:
disclaimer-
i don't really know if i'm qualified to write a review for zazie because i had been drinking for ~4 hours prior to dinner here (look, it was the last day of finals, give me a break okay?), and everything tastes 10x better when you're inebriated.  it took a day of reflection and some eyewitness accounts to piece together how much i enjoyed this place.

anyway, i figure that if i can still recall the highlights of the meal through the drunken haze, it was probably a sufficiently memorable meal.  to start, try the absolutely amazing cheese plate and the pate on levain.  i thoroughly enjoyed my creamy asparagus ravioli entree, which came with a hefty serving of dungeness crab.  from the samples i stole from my dining companions, i would also recommend the rabbit (perfectly cooked), but perhaps skip over the pork chops (a tad overcooked, sauce was too sweet for my liking).  for dessert, definitely GO FOR THE POT DE CREME.  the pain perdu sounded exciting (bread pudding with a caramel and chocolate sauce...!) but the bread hadn't soaked through enough.  the pot de creme is super rich and chocolatey, offset by a light and airy whipped cream.  MMM.  

the service was friendly and accommodating, and extra points for dealing with my unladylike drunk ass.  speaking of which, go on a tuesday and bring your own wine.  no corkage fee!

edit:  came for brunch (sober).  decided that i want to die by drowning in a vat of zazie's hollandaise sauce.  death by hollandaise...too morbid?
author: Katherine K.

description: Been here for dinner a couple times -- never had trouble getting a table,  liked the food, but nothing about the place blew my socks off.   Every time I pass by during brunch hours, however, the sidewalk is just packed with people waiting to get in, which makes me wonder what sort of crack cocaine they are lacing their brunch, but not their dinner offerings with.  Mysteriously Zazie was not packed for brunch on the day after Thanksgiving, and the liquid crack cocaine is somewhere in either the hollandaise sauce, the roasted potatoes or those deliciously caramelized pieces of roasted garlic that they serve you along with the potatoes.  I drooled a little just from typing that.
author: Jan C.

description:
i'm honestly shuddering at the ramifications of writing another good review for this place and encouraging more of you people to come and stand outside in your hordes for brunch on sunday.  but, i feel like i have to talk about the miracle pancakes, because i think they might be seasonal, and if you're all going to be there making me stand around and wait forever for a table anyway, you may as well be ordering these, so we can all coexist and make sure they don't ever disappear.  

so, these miracle pancakes.  i'm a huge fan.  around thanksgiving, they were pumpkin.  today, they were bread pudding.  bread pudding pancakes.  seriously.  if i did believe in that little baby jesus, i might just think it possible that he waddled out of the manger in his little swaddling clothes, waved his wand, and made these pancakes after all.  either way, they're pretty freaking good.
author: brian g.

description: There is ALWAYS a line outside of Zazie, even when we came around 9:30 on a Sunday. The atmosphere is great, but I think the place is a bit overrated. My friends and I all got different egg dishes, and we thought the flavor was a bit bland. We shared an order of the French Toast Tahiti (French toast stuffed with caramelized bananas and walnut). Mm...that was good. We had a good time and it was good food, but I don't think I'd want to wait 40 min - 1 hr to come here again, unless I'm craving some yummy French toast.
author: Tracy P.

description: Wow, people actually wait 1-2 hours to eat here??  I thought the food was ok.  Ordered the challah french toast and the new york scramble.  The service was good.  Hated the bathroom.  It's a nice place to sit and have brunch with friends, but I don't get the hype.
author: Katniss B.

description: yum! and you can bring your own wine on certain days! just pay the corking fee. food is SO yummy, and i love the vibe of this place. Makes you seriously feel like you're in a real Parisian restaurant :)
author: Nikki H.

description: Tried creme brulee to go. The waiter guy tried to overcharge me but I caught him. He tried to charge me about $20 bucks for two creme brulee when the price was $6 each. Then he was a bit rude. Lastly the chef scooped the creme brulee into some paper cups and tried to brulee it in the paper cups. I'm not a chef but I made creme brulee before. You brulee it in the ramekin then scoop it into the cups. Chef is not so smart. he said it would mix, but if you know how to scoop it correctly it would not mix much. $13 for two small crappy slushes they call creme brulee? No thanks. no plans to return anytime. Super rip off!
author: Mr. Honest Y.

description: Yummy. I had the rum french toast.  Heavy on the rum is all I have to say.  Great vibe with tons of people with their 'rents.
author: Jolsna J.

description: This is a sure bet. You can't fail if you brunch here. Take your date, your parents, your friends, your fellow walkers of shame to this glorious French palace of brunch gourmet. I feel like saying brunch with a French accent. Possibly the best hollandaise in the city, so get something with hollandaise on it for god's sake. Make sure you don't just get the plain old coffee because you'll miss out on those cute coffee bowls. Get a mocha, a latte, a cappucino and dip your frickin bread in it. Pardon my French but je t'aime, Zazie, ton brunch est magnifique!
author: Tal K.

description: Eh, I'm not stoked on this place. For breakfast/brunch, the lines are too long and the food not that good. For dinner, well, the food is still not that good. Just mediocre. Plus they take the "French-inspired" a bit too far. Hate to burst the bubble, but there's nothing French about pancakes. But, I guess if you're in Cole Valley and wanted to kill a couple of hours on a Sunday morning, it's not horrible.
author: michael c.

description: Even at peak hours on two consecutive Saturdays, we got seating within 5-15 minutes; it soooo wasn't all that bad. The staff was superfriendly and the seating guy is quite the amusing one. My orange french toast with fresh fruit was happy good times, but I specifically went back the second week for the Fontainbleu omelette which the hubby had had the week before and ohhh was it worth it. Those mushrooms! So mushroomy. It's a little loud inside but not so bad. Outdoor seating is a delight in good weather save for the occasional wandering kid whose parents aren't watching out for him and who might at any moment knock over the gas-fueled heat lamps but hey, you can't win 'em all.
author: Deb T.

description: Even though we waited in line for them to open, we were seated promptly, waited on promptly, and served our brunch in a good amount of time. Aside from a screaming baby across the room, the atmosphere was good and I would recommend it to anyone in the mood for a nice brunch.
author: D M.

description:
creme brulee oatmeal! challah french toast! if i'm ever on death row and i had to pick a last meal, i'd pick that. one suggestion, though, get something close to a full bar. 

i love you. i honestly love you.
author: esther e.

description: This place rocks. It rocks in a very charming & tasty way. My boyfriend only eats free-range eggs, so I looked online for a place in the city & by chance found Zazie. The egg scrambles are delish, & I don't usually get fired up about morning sweets, but the Tahitian French Toast is killer. I even have a favorite waitress (curly hair & a genuine smile) but everyone is nice. Worth the wait for the patio, it's like being on a vacation.
author: Isabel L.

description: i wanted to fall in love with this place, with their quaint decor and their miniaturized space and all.  maybe it was the fact that it was a hot day (this was in august), my dress was sticking to me, and we were forced outside onto the patio and i happened to be in the sun.  maybe that was it.  maybe it my greasy mess of a sandwich (got the chicken with pesto and aioli).  i'm still on the fence about this one.  i'll give it another whirl only because i love me some french food and i still hear raves about this place.
author: Ali L.

description: ATMOSPHERE!  Comment vous dites "charming"?  The food is consistently good (although I wish it was organic), the service is GREAT and the people at the table next to you?  Beautiful.  Count on it.
author: Joie de vivre S.

description:
i LOVE zazie.

whenever i have friends in town, that i think would enjoy quality food in a nice setting, i take them to zazie. 

my take on zazie is, solid, delicious, french-ish food, that gives you the right amount of bang for your buck. maybe not the world's most inspiring or amazing food, but they're so consistently good. i've never had a bad meal there. 

and on top of the awesomeness that is zazie, they have a fantastic prix fixe which is 3 courses for about $25. i guess the portions may be a bit smaller than if you order a la carte, but they are beyond generous for the price. 

oddly enough, i've never been there for brunch. I hear it's pretty decent as well, so eventually i'll make it over for that.
author: grace l.

description: I miss my Cole Valley Apartment and so I miss Zazie! I love this place, service is good, the food is amazing, I like sitting in the patio and have St.Trop or Monaco eggs  and a glass of OJ for breakfast, the pancakes are excellent too!  Croque Madame or Messieur for lunch and Lamb and a glass of wine for my dinner! Each time I've been there everything was in the way I wanted it!  Eat here, put your name on the book it is worth the wait in line!!
author: claudia c.

description: Half of San Francisco spent half their Sunday on the waiting list for brunch at Zazie.  I guess it's because it's one of the few brunch places around with table service.  And it wasn't bad.  There are lots of poached egg dishes on the menu which is a great start - grease-free, nicely contained, half hard eggs - very good.  I don't know why people eat Hollandaise sauce, but Zazie actually makes theirs interesting by adding a touch of lemon tang.  Ginger pancakes -  yum!  There is an option to have salad instead of potatoes which is a plus, except that the lettuce leaves come large and unmanageable.  The fruit cup looked good on other people's tables, but ours was unfortunately sad and juicy, perhaps because it was from the bottom of the barrel.  When we sent it back, the waitress just frowned and didn't even ask why - minus 5 points.  But brunch was pretty good all around.
author: Laura C.

description: Came here for brunch about a week ago. The entire menu looked delicious and I had a difficult choice picking what I wanted to eat. I settled for their omelete special of the day which had chicken apple sausage, cheese, avocado. It was amazing! I loved it. The ingredients were fresh and the potatos on the side were also really tasty. I felt I was getting a great value for my food. The ambiance was cute and very "San Francisco."
author: Rachel F.

description:
Hands down 5 Stars!  Perfect Brunch place.  If I lived in SF I would visit this place often.  Decor is cute especially the patio area in the back. I LOVED IT.  Definately have to try their poached eggs.

Eggs Valence with roasted eggplants and spicy tomato chevre (no hollandaise)
Eggs Florentine with spinach and portobello mushrooms

Besides Poach Eggs the French Toast has a savory taste:

French Toast Tahiti stuffed with carmelized bananas & walnuts - YUM YUM YUM - One of my all time favorite French Toast

Freshly squeezed orange juice!

There was a wait and parking is kinda bad, but its well worth it!
author: Vivan K.

description: jesus lord all mighty, this place is my favorite breakfast/brunch spot ever! and that BLT is the best BLT i've ever had. get yours.
author: Regina C.

description: My first time at Zazie.  Very cute, comfortable and friendly serviec.  I am not a breakfast person, so I was a little disappointed when they didn't serve lunch until 11.  I thought for sure the online menu said brunch from 8 on but I guess that is just weekends.  I managed to find pancakes (lemon) homefries and bacon.  All were amazing.  I just wish I had a bigger appetite.
author: Scot B.

description: Perhaps it isn't fair to write a review seeing as how I've only tried one thing on the menu. But I must rave about the French Toast Tahiti. Seriously. Both times I've visited Zazie, I tried to make a more adventurous menu choice. But I just can't pass up thick slices of french toast accompanied by carmelized banana and walnuts. Plus, there are too many mimosa options to choice from. Fabulous french toast and a mimosa? I'm in.
author: Sarah M.

description: One of my favorite brunch spots in San Francisco and well worth the wait! I love the fresh, healthy breakfast options, the delicious cappuccinos and the quaint garden patio. Great place for couples & small groups.
author: Sara W.

description:
i've been coming here for brunch for the past four years... and it is, to this, day, my favorite spot!  the eggs are cooked perfectly, they have yummy jam (very important), they put whole cloves of roasted garlic in with the potatoes, and their coffee is good and strong.  
i went there this morning and had my favorite server.  i forget her name, but she is usually there in the mornings with dark curly hair and pretty eyes.  she is the best!!!  so friendly and personable.  love her!  thank you, zazie, for four wonderful years...
author: anna l.

description:
If you love creme brulee or Benedicts of any sort, you must check this place out.  I think it's better in the weekday just cause you don't have to wait in as much of a line, but my favorite breakfast spot in the city.  

The wait staff is generous and kind.  And the back patio is wonderful.
author: Matsuo F.

description: Zazie used to be good and then something happened and now its not that special. Its just a normal restaurant. I am still hoping it would go back to how it was. Their food was out of this world. I went to get a bite a few weeks ago and it was pretty good but still missing that something. This is why I am giving them only 4 stars.
author: Rejina S.

description: yumms! i love the lemon curd pancake! if it wasn't for the lines, i'd come here every weekend. :)
author: Hula H.

description: Been here once and it was a cute place to have breakfast.  Next time i'll try to sit in the patio.
author: anette d.

description: Way too crowded but great service considering. I had a tuna sandwich and it was fantastic! I really enjoyed this place. The bathroom is kind of silly, though-- not made to house really tall people!
author: Jen S.

description: Bravo.  Little bit of a wait but standing on Cole after the rain in the morning was actually quite nice.  Good hot coffee, fast and friendly service, as well as creative and yummy breakfast dishes like challah french toast and 8 different poached egg dishes make this a great breakfast destination.  They have a nice little am cocktail menu too.  Worth the wait for sure.
author: Eric S.

description: My husband and I were recently introduced to Zazie by some friends and I have been impressed each time we've eaten there.  They have an good wine selection and every dish I've tasted has been excellent.  The staff has always been friendly and helpful.  It is a small restaurant however, so if you don't have reservations on a weekend, be prepared to wait a while.
author: Amelia D.

description: I've worked near here for so long, but had never been over to this place until Saturday morning. (well, not really MORNING, more like early afternoon but who's counting... -It WAS breakfast any how!) There's a garden in the back, but we got a table in front of the service counter, it was kind of busy and kind of loud but whoa! That is pretty yummy eats they got there! I have to say 3.95 is a LOT for a pancake but you know what? That's a heck of a pancake, GINGER! It was more like desert with that Maple syrup on it. I'd go back. Maybe not on such a hot day though because waiting outside wasn't all that fun. Cole Valley is so very nice.
author: Roanna Z.

description: Yum and Yum!  The hollandaise sauce here is the best I've ever had (not that I go around trying them).  Its so light and yummy and doesn't feel like you are ingesting one millon calories.  The wait staff really seems to know their stuff - very good explaination of flavors and menu items and I always respect a waiter who can make a solid recommendation.  I love the outside patio.  Classic SF space.  Love it, especially during the week when its not so busy and there's no wait.
author: Brent F.

description: This place is extremely crowded on the weekends; the food is great, but if you go on the weekends, be prepared for at least a 45-minute wait for a table and rushed service.  Best to go during the week if you can.  Charming French bistro environment in a San Francisco Victorian setting.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Actually, I'd give this place 3.5 stars if I could, but I can't (so I'll settle for 3).  Along with many others, I enjoy Zazie but there's definitely much room for improvement.

Completely SOLID breakfast establishment:  a huge lineup of egg dishes (cool) and variety of pancakes (way cool).  Love, love, love eating outside in the back when the weather's right for it.  Tried eating outside on the sidewalk on only one occasion, but quickly moved inside when we suddenly had about 15-20 people surrounding our table waiting to be seated.  Big mistake (unless you enjoy having every bite scrutinized . . .).

Not to cheat or be lazy, but I'd have to agree with an earlier reviewer:  the chai here is really bad, which is too bad, because I like the idea of drinking chai from a bowl.  But only good chai.

I'd also concur that Zazie is really only good for breakfast.  The roommate and I tried dinner there and it was completely unremarkable.  That was less than a year ago, and there is nothing from that experience which remains in my memory.  I've "lunched" there on my own on more than one occasion and was similarly unimpressed.

One final comment:  I've had consistently good service at Zazie but be forewarned:  they are very focused on turning the tables quite rapidly to accommodate the throngs waiting outside.  You may want to linger over your breakfast, but you will be not-so-subtly moved along (the check usually arrives along with your omelette, frittata or pancakes).
author: Dennis H.

description: Try the gingerbread pancake. You won't be disappointed.
author: Barbara A.

description:
You go, but I'm not going back. That would be the statement that comes to mind the next time Zazie is suggested. We had a reservation for 5 tonight at the restaurant. We were early and were pleasantly greeted by the...front of the house guy. He was very accommodating even though we were early. Also, tonight was chosen because it was No Corkage night. We brought along 2 bottles of wine and enjoyed that thoroughly. When we were seated, we started getting our bread rolls. They were warm, but we finished eating them and asked for some additional. We ordered appetizers, but still no bread. And for some of us, no silverware or plates. One of the appetizers we got was pate. Was not a complete pate without any of the usual sides. I had the soup of the day, mushroom soup. It needed salt. The entree I ordered was the Niman Ranch beef shank with polenta. It tastes pretty good, but was not really enough food. The other entrees on our table were pork chop (probably the best), Burger and Seafood pasta. The burger was requested to be welldone. It came back at a good medium. If any of us get mad cow, we're coming for you! All the food could have done with more salt. Finally, after asking for a third time, some additional dinner rolls showed up. For dessert, we had creme brulee. It was pretty good and a good way to top off the meal. 

Anyway, everyone else had a good time but there were enough small details that I noticed that would have made things a lot better. So you might be asking yourself, why did I give it 3 stars? I wanted to give 2.5, but my girl friend tells me that she's had better experiences the previous times she's been there.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Excellent poached egg dishes! The staff seems a little cranky.
author: Kevin L.

description: Every time that I come here, I end up more and more impressed with the food. Breakfast is better than dinner at Zazie, but not by much. Somehow the food seems more vibrant, the flavors more tasty, and simple things more extraordinary when you get a late brunch here. I have had the Challah French Toast, a couple of the scrambles, and (as of today) the poached eggs benny and I honestly can say that even the toast is exceptionally good here. Yeah, there's the wait thing, but its that way for a reason: This is the best breakfast in the city.
author: Matt C.

description: I was looking for a place with some good pancakes and I found Zazie.  I decided to try their Gingerbread pancakes. Let me tell you, they were phenomenal, plus with the pear and lemon custard.  It will most definitely suffice your sweet tooth for a breakfast.
author: Dustin K.

description: My boyfriend and I went for breakfast and thought it was fantastic. The omelette of the day was 5 star. Looking forward to our next visit.
author: Edward D.

description: Love this place.  They have excellent breakfast items as well as creative lunch and it is always delicious.
author: Cristina M.

description: a cute brunch spot. a perfect date with my long-time friend since kindergarten. french toast.  san francisco.  what more can you ask for?
author: Angie K.

description: Gotta love the comforting french food for this little. Brunches are amazing as well. I will keep coming back.
author: Anna A.

description: The various poached egg dishes here are so much more than riffs on eggs Benedict.  The gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd are fantastic if you're in the mood for sweet.  Once we sat outside on a brisk day and they brought blankets out to swaddle ourselves in.  If my last meal had to be breakfast, I'd eat it here.
author: Ficus K.

description: The best brunch place in the city. Be sure to try their specialty Tahitian Stuffed French Toast. Bread stuff with caramelized bananas and fried. Toasty goodness. They also do excellent variations on the eggs benedict. And my friend once saw Owen Wilson eating here. I mean really, is there any higher reccomendation than that?
author: Cathy T.

description:
when the sun is shining, expect a long wait a zazie.  actually, it's not that bad if you're dining with one other person, but anything over 2 people? ... just make sure you bring your patience along with you. 

this is my favorite place for weekend brunch - i love the outside back patio on a warm sunday morning. as for the food, i can only speak for the dungeness crab benedict since i can't get myself to order anything else there.  maybe i'll try something different the next time i go.  

... maybe not.
author: cynthia q.

description:
9 September 07

AB and I came in for brunch this morning and we got a patio table! Sitting out here is a complete sensory experience with the warmth of the heat lamps, the greenery, and the soft music. 

We arrived starving so of course we very nearly over ordered. 

blueberry cream cheese coffee cake - a tad sweet but major points for coming out warm. 

chocolat chaud - served in a bowl with whipped cream

home fries! baby reds with whole roasted garlic! i usually don't have very strong feelings about home fries, but these are spuds above the rest (crepevine, squat and gobble, crepes on cole, etc.)

challah french toast - COMPLETELY dry. *hack, hack* if you really want french toast, order the hot chocolate to wash it down. 

la mer - you can get this with one, two, or three eggs! i took the middle road and went for two. one wouldn't be enough and three is a crowd. crab and avocado were meant to be togetha foreva. watch out for the exoskeleton and ask for H sauce on the side. then you can have one leetle cup of saturated fat and distribute it according to taste.
.............................................................................................................................
My friends and I had dinner here last Saturday and it was a bit of a let down. Half of us ordered off the pre fix menu.  Disappointment #1: AH ordered the spinach salad off the pre fix menu and got it served on a bread plate. DIN ordered the "regular" spinach salad and got it on a normal salad plate. Excuse me? What's up with that? Are we suffering from a spinach shortage??? BTW, I know my plate sizes bc I once worked at Pottery Barn. You can't fool this chickadee.  Disappointment #2: You only get one hot, little bun. There is no bread basket. Each person just gets one bun. ONE BUN. I had no idea that bread was so pricey. What's up with restaurants being cheap with the carbs??? Home makes you ask for the bread. And that's what I had to do here. After I ate my single bun, my bread plate was promptly removed. When I was working on my starter, I had to ask for THREE ADDITIONAL buns. Way to go Zazie! Make a girl feel guilty for asking for more carbs to go with your super rich butter garlic sauce. Disappointment #3: The little pot of chocolate was the size of a yo baby yogurt and is valued at $6. Puh-lease. There ain't nothing special about your cold, little pot of chocolate fat. 
 
The mussels that I had for my starter get all three stars.  Perfectly cooked and the sauce was rich and garlicky. Don't be shy and ask for a basket of bread to soak it up.

UPDATE: Got a message from Jen at Zazie. She explained that our serve should have told us the prefix menu comes with a half size starter and half size dessert with a full size entree. And due to the whole low carb craze, they've had to throw away a lot of bread, hence the single servings. Thanks Jen for clearing that up!  One more star!
author: Jacquee P.

description: You to to Zazie on Sunday for brunch not for the food but for the atmosphere.  The restaurant is adorable on the inside but it's the patio outside that gets the grand prize.  Perfect for a sunny Sunday morning brunch when standard breakfast fare will do.
author: Jenny S.

description: Solid place for breakfast. Try the gingerbread pancakes with lemon curd or poached pears.
author: Mia K.

description: This Cole Valley gem is a great brunch escape.  Hello!  Can you say six different types of mimosa?  I never knew poached eggs could be offered in so many permutations, the home fries are tasty, french toast was delectable, at Zazie I paid for an education.  We sat on the gorgeous patio and enjoyed the California sunshine I've missed so much since moving to Boston.  A bit pricey but worth it.  Give Zazie a shot.
author: EmDee D.

description: Brunch review only.  I like that you can order up to three eggs on the poached menu.  I also like pitchers of cassis mimosas.  that back area is a delight as well.
author: Katie M.

description:
mmmm delicious. a solid four stars!

the service was great: friendly and attentive!

the food was deeee-lish. i was looking at everyone else's pictures of their food and the pictures on zaziesf.com and my mouth was just watering!

i love how you can have breakfast a la carte.

i was dying to try one of their poached eggs. so i had one poached egg florentine. their hollandaise sauce was by far the best i've tasted in a long time. light and not too rich with just the right consistency. i also had one slice of their challah french toast.

i am so NOT a french toast type of girl, but i practically inhaled it.

 and mmmm. . . their home potatoes! watch out for the roasted garlic that they throw into it. it makes it very different and so tasty.

no pulp in the mimosa!

it was a lovely morning to sit outside and watch everyone get their cars ticketed for parking on the street sweeping side.

just watch out for parking or just take muni.

i can't wait to come back for lunch!
author: Maureen M.

description: Zazie has a superfabulous (yes, that's one word) ambiance; high ceilings, a courtyard, and a bathroom with a sliding door (I kid you not!).  What seems to be lacking is food that lives up to its description.  I went to Zazie for brunch and was excited about the French Toast Tahiti (stuffed w/ bananas and walnuts) as I'm a sucker for French toast.  While the French Toast Tahiti was good, it wasn't amazing (definitely not $10 amazing).  Our waiter was friendly enough, but he would disappear for 15-20 minutes at a time which was a bit annoying given a couple things we needed (clean cutlery for one, yuck!).
author: Matt P.

description: I went here and some good ole french toast. Yummy!
author: Luke R.

description: I'm so glad to have finally come here.  I've passed this place on several occasions but chose to avoid the long wait for food.  I came at 2:00 which was perfect, I missed the brunch crowd and got outside seating right when I got there.  Let me tell you, I'm a huge fan of BLTS and this is by far the best BLT I've had (beside one's I make).  It comes with the bacon of course, on perfectly toasted foccacia bread, a large bed of baby spring greens to throw in, goat cheese, and yummy marinated tomatoes.  The drinks were kinda pricey so I recommend going next door for your bloody mary or mimosa.
author: Glenda D.

description:
Finally got a chance to check out Zazie, supposedly one of the best places in SF to get breakfast/brunch. Not impressed.

My wife and I lucked out and only had to wait about 10 minutes to be seated. The greeter was professional and efficient.

Zazie itself is quite attractive, even if seating is cramped. Looking around, I noticed that the food presentation was excellent. Everything looked good.

Our waiter was efficient and friendly enough, giving us the specials and taking the order in a reasonable amount of time. The food came out rather quickly, too.

The problems began with the food itself. I ordered the Tahitian French Toast with caramelized bananas and walnuts ($13 for 3 pieces). What the kitchen means by caramelized bananas is a banana sliced in half, sprinkled with sugar and flamed with a propane torch. The other side is mushy. The brioche the French toast was made out of was dry. So, the French toast accomplished the (not so) neat trick of simultaneously being dry and mushy. There was no custardy mouth feel, either, and the dish didn't have much flavor. Looked pretty, though. It needed all the maple syrup I poured over it ($1.25 for about a 1/4 cup of syrup, room temp). By the way, when you're charging $13 for French toast, slapping on an extra $1.25 for maple syrup is just bad form.

My wife's dish was a little better. She had the Eggs Fountainbleu scramble with spinach, wild mushrooms and Fontina cheese (10.95). The eggs weren't scrambled hard, as is often the case, and they were seasoned properly. The toast came cold, with little balls of butter on top. The breakfast potatoes were a bit of a joke, which is common enough, I suppose. They were cut in oversized chunks, underdone and tasted of little more than salt and garlic. The garlic flavor came courtesy of some cloves of garlic, roasted whole and unpeeled.

The iced tea my wife ordered was an unfortunately mix of English Breakfast and mint. She said it tasted like chemicals. I wouldn't go that far, but it wasn't very good.

To add insult to injury, our waiter dropped the check about a minute after we started eating, saying "There's no hurry on this." Yeah, right. I know that Zazie has a perpetual waiting list, and they want to turn and burn, but that's just rude. The waiter could have at least waited until we were almost done to drop the check. Once we put down our credit card, our check was processed quickly, which I appreciated.

I'm not quite ready to give up on Zazie. It's not like there's a ton of awesome breakfast places in San Francisco to choose from. And my wife's eggs did taste good. Maybe we'll try again the next time we get bored with the choices in our neighborhood.
author: Michael K.

description: Of the restaurants that I've tried, I think Zazie has some of the best brunch in SF. Loved my eggs benedict and the mimosas that we ordered. There was a wait of around 45 mins, but we got a really good table outside along the street. It was a really nice Sunday morning, so it was definitely an awesome experience.
author: Roy C.

description: What used to be my favorite brunch spot is not my least favorite brunch spot and my memories are now of rats, not the "la mer." I ate at Zazie for the final time about three weeks ago. I was sitting in the back patio with some friends when a lady from the table behind us started to scream. Everyone on the patio turned around to find a rat on the table just sitting there. Everyone on the patio got a good look at the rat until the waitress finally got someone to remove him. At that point the rat had run into the ivy and down towards my table. A kitchen staffer grabbed the rat and carried him through the patio into the kitchen and out of the restaurant. The Zazie staff then carried on as if nothing happened and even still charged every table for their full meal and the SF healthcare fee. The owner/manager who is there every time I have dined there and clearly knows me as a regular, knew I was there and still didn't even take a moment to stop by the table and apologize. I'm pretty sure that rats in a cafe are a no no Zazie.
author: Kathleen E.

description: We found the lunch menu to be varied, original and appealing. Our party of 8 had many different items, all of them excellent. The service was friendly and efficient and the portions generous. Our only regret is that we didn't have time or room for dessert which we hear from others is excellent. We will definitely be back.
author: Carola B.

description: Great pancake specials. The waffles are standouts.  We also ordered the Chorizo Egg Scramble which was very good.  All complimented by very fresh juices and attentive service.  Parking is tricky.  Wait times can be significant.  Definitely worth a visit if its not too far out of your way.
author: Tom B.

description: Came here for brunch - busy, but not surprising on a Saturday.  Good pancakes and french toast, their eggs are just so-so.  Like that you can order one, two or three of your breakfast item.  Service is friendly and fairly attentive.  The decor is nice and can be a good place for a leisurely brunch on the weekend.
author: Michelle C.

description: Clearly the best breakfast in town.  Make sure to get there before 10 or expect to wait.  The Eggs Benedict are their specialty.  Dinners are amazing as well.  The duck is exquisite, and the wine list is very affordable.  Two thumbs up!
author: Matt L.

description:
What stands out is the service - feels really genuine.  Once we were sitting outside until we got a table, and the server brought us a container of warm water to keep our hands warm - didn't expect that!  Food is not bad either. Zazie is walkable distance to Haight/Ashbury where I live so the place is one of my neighborhood favorites.  I try to go there once in a while on Tuesdays with a bottle of wine when there's no corkage fee.

Btw. the place was introduced to me by a friend... thanks Jose!
author: Vajira N.

description: Here I learned the lesson that soft blankets from the host can really improve the taste of brunch. They even made the coffee i didn't much care for go down smoother. The prego one of the bunch asked for his scarf, too, and wore it the whole time, so i don't know if that has the same effect, but she seemed to like the espresso a little more than the coffee.  As for the rest, ...the oatmeal (with walnuts, raisins, brown sugar, cream, to throw in from little silver buckets) was good - mmmmm... (it was an oatmeal day).  Also had the gingerbread pancakes, that was good too (with lemon curd (?-that's an ugly word) on top and a pear slice, and maple syrup.)  Busy busy place.  Tables outside are first-come-first-serve though, so be fast and ask for blankets.
author: Today Y.

description: Showed up here on a friend's recommendation.  It has everything I'm looking for in a breakfast place.  Good food, yummy coffee and pleasant staff providing a enjoyable environment.  One comment that I must make is that they will stuff you in any corner they are able to squeeze a chair.
author: Tom C.

description: Dinner has gone way up! Used to be, this place was packed for brunch and dead for dinner. Now dinner rocks, too. We had an amazing lamb chop, perfect steak au poivre that I'm still dreaming about, and a meyer lemon crab ravioli that they spent weeks perfecting and were justifiably proud of. Throw in great service from our server Aiden and we had a hell of a night. And not as long a wait as the (amazing) brunch!
author: Tim B.

description: Bonjour!!! this is one of cool restaurant to hang out.  Especially if you are sitting in the patio, get the sun and drink some mimoza, and if you are hungry croque madame and their fresh grilled tuna is awesome.  I know it is a lil bit pricey for lunch but you know what, it's french bistro, so it's normal.  Even the Mexican dude that works there can speak french, he is cool.
author: Albert W.

description: I'd have to say that Zazie's rocks - the food here is awesome and it's surely worth the wait. Whatever you get, make sure you get potatoes with extra garlic; it really makes them great! I've only been there once, but I'll surely be back again. Zazie's is like the Chloe's of Cole Valley.
author: Dan M.

description: Zazie has my number - make up some killer eggy veggie combos and smother it with hollandaise and side it with some garlicy home fries.  BON APETIT!  I hear they have amazing dinner too but my breakfasts are usually brunches and my dinners are usually suppers and I have yet to make it back for supper.  I love their back patio area and all the outdoor seating in general.  2 thumbs up for the big mug espresso drinks and fresh OJ too.  French Toast Tahiti is a big winner with all those bananas and honey up in there.  Yumm!!!
author: Chard M.

description:
i ate here with a coworker of mine. we got paid that day and decided to just go out and have a classy meal. some REAL fine dining. after realizing we didn't want to really spend 100 bucks each on some 16 course meal we probably wouldn't finish and barely enjoy we decided to go for just a NICE dinner.... at zazie! zazie is just plain ol' nice. (especially the staff.)

we sat outside. in the front, not the back. i guess the patio was closed. well, it was a brisk december night so the host brought us warm fuzzy HUGE blankets to sit and wrap ourselves in.  sweet touches like that will keep me coming back for more.
author: alexis g.

description: Awsome food, plain and simple. The service was also wonderfull. We went for dinner after a spur of the moment trip to napa and let me tell you it completed the day perfectly. Its a little small, the bathroom is even smaller (smaller than most airline bathrooms) and parking is a nightmare..... but its all worth it. Ill definetly come back and have that steak again!
author: Brennan M.

description: It is wonderful to live around the corner from Zazie, a perfect neighborhood bistro.  Their French  standards are always reliable, the service friendly and enthused.  Perhaps it's not a cross-town destination, but it's like dinner with an old friend on a cool foggy day after work.
author: Alison C.

description:
