i've only been here a few times for dinner, twice with large parties and once with the hubby for date nite w/o the kiddies =)

food is very good - yummy spinach salad & pate, super tasty salmon, and the perfect pot de creme (chocolate of course).  extra points for incredibly accomodating service for large groups, but minus points for a waitress who steered us toward "exquisite" wines that were...not so much - it's a draw.

mental note to self:
1. gotta try this place for brunch
2. gotta try to the outdoor patio
author: Jen P.

description: Standard for brunch in the Cole Valley/Inner Sunset area because there's really no other option.  This also means long waits.  But the backyard patio is a plus.  Pet friendly.
author: Pelle Y.

description: This is a great place for breakfast. The wait is ver long, but it's worth it. Their french toast are good. Their poached eggs are perfect.
author: Ghiz S.

description: Went to this place for my birthday dinner and the food was very tasty.  Why 3 stars?  At that price, I expect the food to be "delicious," "spectacular," and everything else the other yelp reviews said it would be.  My opinion: They know that if you drizzle enough melted butter (or "brandy cream sauce" that tastes like melted butter) on a hanger steak it is going to taste good.  I'm not impressed and I won't give them points for that.   I'll give them this: the rolls were the best hot buns I've had in a while.  The things probably deserve four stars, but nothing else was as delicious and surprising as I expected.
author: Charles C.

description: Sour cream poppy seed pancake with lemon curd.  Might sound a bit odd, but it really is the perfect combination of sweet and tart and light and fluffy . . .  just recalling it now is enough to make my mouth water.  One of these puppies was enough to do me in for the rest of the morning.  I should warn you that this was a special, so it's not guaranteed to be offered again, but if your waitress tells you about this heavenly sour cream concoction, go with it.  I'm not going to lie, I wasn't blown away by the egg dishes, but the place is so cute and friendly that even the 25-ish minute wait wasn't too bad.
author: Rachel B.

description: After hearing and reading great things, and always wanting to seek out a new brunch place, we searched for parking for a half hour and finally got to Zazie.  The two stars are for being seated fairly promptly and being clean.  Service was unacceptable.  Food was cold.  Actually, my boyfriend's was luke warm and mine was cold.  Menu choices weren't unique.  Cole Valley residents.....take a short walk or cab to someplace else.  Don't feel like you have to go here just because there is nothing else around.  We won't go back.
author: Wendy N.

description: Eating out should always be a good experience. Good food. Good service. Good atmosphere. We were lucky with the seating. We actually didn't have to wait at all. Saturday around 8pm. All the appetizers we ordered were great. It ended up being a little more than we expected, which is always good. The charcuterie, cheeses, mussels, beet salad, pate. All good. We didn't order any entrees since we wasted our money at Hama-Ko. But the appetizers did the trick. And any place that allows pets, even for a day, awesome!
author: Tan N.

description: Brunch, dinner. You name it, Zazie's good at it. In my hood so it's where I can take visiting folks for a good meal and then get trashed at the bars on  Haight.
author: joann p.

description: Now the food here is not as good as Chloe's but it is still very good! The Croque Madame and Challah French Toast are worth the long wait in and of themselves. Plus this place takes credit cards so they get a fourth star just for that! Like most neighborhood breakfast places it has its share of issues though, including lack of parking, long waits and less than stellar service. Unfortunately we have so few good breakfast places in the City that the service issue never seems to correct itself, but I will say that the service here is far more attentive than at Chloe's (They usually have more than two people working which always helps).  The long list of mimosa variations is fun to experiment with, especially after a long night of Crown & Cokes! By the way . . . if this place has gone organic, that is news to me.
author: Ryan M.

description: I MISS ZAZIE:(  Best BLT ever.  Cute outdoor patio, great waitstaff and just a pleasant dining experience.  The crab benedict (or however you say it in francais) is awesome.  Just don't try going to the tiny closet bathroom if you can help it because people can totally hear you.  And it's unnervingly close to the kitchen.  Otherwise, one of our favorite places in SF hands down.
author: Leah P.

description: Brunch is my favorite meal and Zazie does a great job. There's always a wait but the line moves fast. I love the "Un, Deux, Trois" - one buttermilk pancake, two eggs, and three strips of bacon. They also serve Naked orange juice!
author: Christine P.

description: This place has been a weekend habit of mine. Gingerbread pancakes with bosc pear & Monaco poached eggs. Love the roasted garlic cloves that comes on the side. Cafe au Lait and coffee here doesn't disappoint. Not to mention that Mario is pimp - always running the place with great service.
author: Mary H.

description:
I came here with three friends for dinner on a Sunday night. I did the pre fixe menu - salad with beets, fennel and avocado; grilled summer corn cakes; and shared the pot de creme and fruit crumble for dessert.

All the food was simple but delicious and the service was very good. The hot rolls with butter at the beginning of the meal were lovely... I know that's a really simple thing, but it was delicious bread and just made me happy  :)

I will be coming back.
author: S M.

description:
great brunch spot for anyone looking for a tasty bloody mary and poached eggs on a saturday morning

service was great with manager at the front door and server with on point service with coffee refills

will definitely be back. thank you Zazie!
author: DayDay D.

description: We have been coming to Zazie for brunch for years.  The food is excellent, but what really keeps us coming again and again is Mario.
author: John L.

description: I liked this place  quite a bit. The wait was mostly for two person reservations, so I thought it would be 30+ minutes to get a table for 3. We were in luck. They seated us in 15 minutes. The food came out quickly and the outdoor seating was perfect for a Sunday brunch. "La Mer" eggs were tasty, though the muffins were toasted a bit too much to become solid. The gingerbread pancakes were tasty, and my sweetie swooned for them. The latte was tasty, too.
author: Benjamin T.

description: I've lived in SF for over 25 years and this is my all-time favorite brunch place in the city! Love the French feel, the friendly staff, and food! My favorite item is the bowl of latte. yum! Also, they now have a high-tech system where you can now make reservations on-line. Thank goodness because the line is always soOO long but SOOO worth it.
author: Kelly N.

description: Many restaurants in San Francisco charge 2-4% to cover the city's health care requirements for restaurant workers. Zazie charges $1.00 per customer.  I recently ate lunch at Zazie and ordered a $10 entree, resulting in a 10% health care fee. To make matters worse, Zazie taxed the health care fee, thus charging me almost 11%.  Zazie should follow the practice of other restaurants and charge a reasonable % fee.
author: Tom W.

description: Dig it. I've had brunch and dinner at this place and it's consistently good. Satiating portions and great tasting food, what else could you ask for. It's a cozy little place that makes it a great date place, but cool enough as a place to catch up with friends. Always busy, this place is worth the wait. There's also no corkage fee on Tuesday nights (I think). If you've got people coming into the city and want to steer clear of Pier 39 show off Zazie and await the thanks you'll get.
author: Douglas L.

description: Great little neighborhood french style bistro with an unusually professional attentive wait staff for such a small neighborhood place.  Their dinner portions are generous and the food is always innovative and fresh.  Weekend breakfast crowds waiting to get in are enormous so if you don't like to wait a long time, go mid week or right when they open.  They have a lovely backyard patio area too which is wonderful on a sunny day.  Mario the morning/daytime manager is wonderfully nice and always remembers the regulars and greets them/us so nicely even if we are just walking by and not eating there.  Good atmosphere all around.
author: Mikey S.

description:
I have been frequenting ZAZIE ever since reading its review in ZAGAT 2 years ago.  It is by far my favorite breakfast place in San Francisco.  This is coming from a person who is pretty picky and a foodie at that!  I eat here over some of my other favorites, which include Mama's, Dottie's True Blue, and Ella's, when given the choice.  Parking on the street is fairly easy or the muni N- Judah drops you right at the corner. i've done both.  I've even apartment hunted here JUST to be close to ZAZIE, with little success-I guess I'm not the only one who wants to live close to this place!!
FOOD:
Its innovative/french-influenced menu is to die for!
 (my fave is the tahitian french toast: 2 slices of french toast smeared with carmelized bananas and walnuts...also a favorite? the prosciutto, roasted tomato and garlic benedict...)
The meal is usually served with diced potatoes roasted to perfection mixed with whole cloves of roasted garlic- don't opt for the salad!!
All the ingredients are fresh and fantastic!
There is a LONG list of mimosas, which are delicious, and coffee bar drinks, which come in bowls! 
SERVICE:
It couldn't be friendlier!  Whenever there's a wait, usually on the weekend, the manager is totally on top of moving customers through.  Never feel like they could be doing more and he's so nice! The wait staff is awesome and special orders don't seem to upset them. 
ATMOSPHERE:
The coveted tables are on the back patio which is a real treat IF you can score one, otherwise the indoor dining in cozy and loud.  There are a couple table out on the front sidewalk which aren't bad either if you get stuck outside--the servers don't forget about you out there.

I have never had a bad experience at ZAZIE and love it to pieces...only praise from this YELPER!
author: Jamie Z.

description:
breakfast review only, never been there for lunch or dinner:

had and loved (not all on one visit) the gingerbread pancakes, french toast tahiti, various omelets,  but my very fave was a special i've only seen there once: sour cream and poppy seed pancakes with lemon curd.  unreal.  every time i've been back I check for them :(

the brunch cocktails are fun, although i've never been bored by a plain old mimosa.

There is quite a wait on the weekends, but I've been seated immediately every time I've gone during the week.  The two tables out front are seat-yourself. 

This is such a good spot.  The neighborhood is adorable.
author: Sarah M.

description: I wouldn't recommend waiting hours outside for brunch, but with a reservation, or on a less busy day, amazing. The food is really, really, really, really, really top quality, tasty, good. And the staff is not at all pretentious given the hip reputation. Really a lovely place for any meal, any time of day.
author: a m.

description: I love this place- I've been here twice for dinner and once for brunch as three experiences were wonderful. Food and atmosphere is fabulous- I plan to return here to eat whenever I can!
author: Rose V.

description: All i can say is WOW...i came in for breakfast and boy was i treated to one of the best Gingerbread Pancakes w/pears yummy!!!!!..My friend had Florentine,(poached eggs)with spinach and portobello mushrooms..after breakfast the next day we came back for dinner *lolz* For dinner i had (salad) Salade d'hiver- romaine hearts, crispy bacon, hard boiled eggs, gorgonzola, mustard vinaigrette the salad was good the bacon didn't over power the dish. For entree i had Grilled Niman Ranch Hanger Steak w/ mashed potatoes, sauteed spinach, and portobello brandy cream sauce cooked perfect and had great favor..My friend had the same salad as me but for the entree he had Braised Niman Ranch Beef Shanks w/ red wine, tomatoes, root vegetables, served over celery root puree i had alittle taste and it was good too, the beef shank was tender and tasty. i can tell you first hand i walked by this place 3-4 times before i realized hahaha.. it's close to the n judah lineon carl and cole st. i would recommend this place to all my friends p.s the outdoor patio for dinner is a nice touch
author: jonathan h.

description:
very romantic decor
wonderful waitstaff

did the prix fix menu. OMG it was so great for $25!

sorry forgot what the names of all the dishes were in french so this is the best I could come up with:

WARM SOFT FRESH Bread mmmmmm

Mussels with garlicbutterwine goodness half-sized starter - LITERALLY THE BEST BEST BEST EVER TASTED (dip the bread in the soup goodness. even better)

full entree: Salmon baked in parchment paper -VERY VERY GOOD

1/2 size Chocolate Pudding dish. pretty good. overheard they use Guittard chocolate? but don't quote me on that.

Fuzzy Signature Grapefruit Carbonated Drink -OK

going back for brunch in a few days! :)
author: Win H.

description: Pricey, but worth it. Great atmosphere, especially on the patio out back. Had a nice server. Don't remember her name. The mussels were my favorite, although of course there's never enough of them. Dessert was also delicious.
author: Roman R.

description: This place is amazing! On the weekdays you can get lemon ricotta pancakes that are absolutely to die for! If you are planning on eating here during the weekend give yourself some time because there is guaranteed to be a line, but it is WELL worth it!
author: Jessica K.

description: Shared a wonderful lunch here with dad and sister one day.  It was sunny outside and we were seated in the window box.  We shared a great meal, though I felt that when the bill came, we had been ripped off, that maybe this restaurant wasn't worth the wonderful walk up cole valley and the little perks like cutely folded napkins.  Afterall, I only ordered a Tuna sandwich and I got exactly that.  Not sure.  Maybe my memory is forsaking me, but I don't really recommend this place to anyone (for lunch).
author: Amy M.

description:
Good for brunch, so-so for dinner.
For weekend brunch, get there early or plan to wait.  imo, brunch is definitely not worth more than a 20 minute wait.  pancakes are excellent and wifey digs the eggs benedict.  sadly, coffee is generally on the weaker tip.  Brunch is kid and stroller-friendly, which is perfect b/c I have both.
author: WP D.

description:
i liked this place; i felt like we were stepping into another world with the french bistro atmosphere; very subtle, but they did a good job.  the french twist to the food was delish, heads above most other breakfast offerings and a break from what other places call brunch (which usually ends up being just breakfast served later in the day).

me likey!
author: ms.kiki g.

description: Yum -- I love this place!  The lemon-ricotta pancakes were AMAZING. Food came out really fast, atmosphere was adorable, and food was fabulous. We ordered a second helping of pancakes, they were THAT GOOD -- but the lemon ricotta ones were already gone. (That sucked, but oh well.) Got gingerbread pancakes instead -- tasty but nowhere near as tasty as the miracle cakes or whatever they're called.
author: Elle B.

description:
This place rules.

I showed up with my mom at around 4, just to check out the menu. It was closed but there was a guy there who appeared to be running the show and he came out and chatted with us, all smiles and very friendly. He told us they would be open at 5:30 and took our reservation. When we came back he remembered us, greeted us warmly, and seated us right away. We sat in the pretty little patio out back. The waitress attended to us nearly immediately, and was also very friendly and jovial. She took our order (I wanted to try everything on the menu!) and after a bit brought back fresh-baked (piping hot!) crusty rolls with butter. Yummmm... The food took a bit on the long side to get to us but I think that was intentional, as it's one of those sit and drink wine and carry on a conversation type places. My mother and I both ordered the chevre/fig raviolis with arugula (?) and crispy prociutto, and my father ordered the marscarpone polenta cakes.  Everything was *so* good. So many flavors. I'm not sure I can do them justice with words so I'll just say, go there and try it yourself! The entrees were on the small side, so I would recommend getting appetizers or a salad or something. We didn't do that, so we had plenty of room for dessert. I got the dessert dish that came with a little dish of vanilla creme brulee and a little dish of chocolate pots de creme. Mmm. The creme brulee was not quite as creamy I'd like it to be but it was still quite tasty. The pots de creme was ridiculous. So rich and thick and creamy and chocolatey and delicious. I had to get my dad to help me finish it! My mom got the challah bread pudding with white and dark chocolate and caramel. It was ludicrous. So good.

Throughout the whole meal the waitress was very attentive (without being annoying) and joked with us lightheartedly. After we'd paid, the guy who took our reservation and seated us came by to chat a little, asking us how our meal was and giving us well wishes. I think he was the owner maybe? I have to say, the whole experience, which was already great because the food was so good, was made exceptional by how wonderful the staff was. I'm definitely coming back here!
author: Heather H.

description:
Zazie has made a nice turn-around in the last few years, basically since the Maitre D bought the place. Great food (and this is a Frenchman speaking), great service.

Good for kids if you come in early.

It is a victim of it's own success on week ends, with long waiting lines.

Monday nights are Pooch nights - bring your dogs on the patio.
author: L. N.

description: Lovely brunch, lovely garden, terrible parking, nice-ish waitstaff, lovely ambiance--overall a fairly lovely experience, and not too, too pricey, though not cheap-eats either.  Recommended for meeting friends, and spending a pleasant afternoon outdoors at an unrushed meal.
author: Emmy M.

description: I can't think of a better place to have brunch out with the girls (and your little dog too)  Their lemon cream sauce over poached eggs is my favorite.  Also, it's one of the few places that have citron presse which while it's just a fancy version of lemonade, I like getting my mix on.  By the way the wait can be unbearable.
author: Chris W J.

description: This place is awesome.  Food is great, service is wonderful, and the atmosphere is what a French bistro should be.  Zazie is going to be one of my new favorite haunts.  I had a lovely (albeit early) dinner with a friend there.  I've yet to try the brunch, although I've heard it gets crazy on weekend mornings, so that may be a while...
author: Luna K.

description:
sad to say it feels as if the st. trop has gone drastically downhill.

zaz really has been and i want it to remain, my favorite brunch place. a few words.

MORE.
HOLLANDAISE.
THANK.
YOU.
author: Candice R.

description:
New Year's day! Pretty crowded, though a half hour wait max. People at the next table had ordered the Valence plate (poached eggs on eggplant, no hollandaise and some yummy, crispy roasted potatoes). We did the same. At first, we ordered a Zazie mimosa (traditional champagne and orange juice). It was pretty bad. The juice was not fresh and the champagne left a lot to be desired. We then switched to the cranberry mimosa. Better.

Overall, a good exprience. The host going in and out of the locale to sit people who were waiting outside could definitely afford a little more tact. But, the actual waiting staff were quite nice.
author: Nena G.

description: We came on New Year's Day and waited about 30 minutes or so.  Requested inside because we did not want to sit in front at the curb where everyone is waiting to be seated, but they asked us if we'd take a table in the back patio and we did.  It was nice back there-- quiet and pretty and warm enough with the heaters and the blanket they gave us.  Started off with a tasty Mango Mimosa and then I ordered the crab benedict and one gingerbread pancake.  The pancake was out of this world-- best I've ever had.  The benedict was delicious, but I would have liked more crab and less avocado-- especially for the price. Still, I was super happy with the meal and would definitely wait again for that scrumptious gingerbread pancake.
author: Matt L.

description: Forget the entrees and skip straight to the desserts! A good menu with lots of vegetarian options. We went on a Tuesday night and took our own wine since there is no corkage fee. I had the Fresh Lemon Ricotta Ravioli followed by the Baked Chocolat Chaud and the outstanding bread pudding. I'll be going back to sample the rest of the desert menu. Friendly service and it wasn't packed for a Tuesday night.
author: Kiran G.

description: While my budget makes this a special occasion place... I wish that I could eat every meal here! The staff are all very nice. Just dont try to get a seat within 30 minutes on a weekend morning for brunch.
author: Bethany C.

description: We came in just before they were about to close. The staff was extremely friendly and gave us all the time in the world despite it being so late. The salmon was good. I hear that the breakfast are also extremely yummy and plan on heading all the way to Cole Valley to give it a taste.
author: Kristen Y.

description:
best brunch in the city, but be prepared to wait for 45 minutes (without exaggeration)
la mer is the bomb
author: Christopher L.

description: Maybe it's just met, but the food on Cole is consistently great!  This is another place I always take guests.  Probably because if I went any more frequently I'd be fat.  Each time I go, I try to get something different because the menu is huge, and I've never been disappointed.  A personal favorite is the Miracle Pancakes (cornmeal with raspberry tart on top) are amazing, but they aren't offered everyday.  You can't go wrong with any of the egg dishes either, and you can make it 1,2, or 3 eggs depending on your appetite.  If it's warm and not raining, they'll have the back patio open, but beware, it's a little cramped.  There are two tables in the front windows, and I'm still hoping we will get sat there some time.  Go early on the weekends or you'll have to wait, but they turn tables fairly quickly.
author: Emily M.

description:
Here's a solid Zazie dinner review. I have yet to have brunch here, timing seems to be prevent this from happening. We however tried a no reservations stop late Friday and were able to get seated. 

Kudos for their beets and fennel salad, although a little more dressing than i would have preferred, was a wonderful starter. I tried the pork chops and my friend tried the polenta cakes. The polenta and marscapone cheese blended very well with the tomato sauce. The couscous was complementary to my dish as well. For dessert, we shared the pot du creme and creme brulee combo. A nice close to a nice meal. 

Zazie is small, and not quiet. It's high ceilings echo the conversations and bustle of the small space. That is not a negative, as I appreciate the comfortable feel the place and staff gives.
author: M K.

description:
i love when i can have brunch outside on a cute patio.  even on a cold, misty, foggy sf day, the heaters kept me nice and toasty.  

the food and service were delicious.  gingerbread pancakes are a must, although i tend to be an omelet person.  cant wait to go back again soon.
author: Kristin K.

description: Confirmed, the eggs benedict are unbelieveable.  No matter what, you must have breakfast here at least once before you die.  Get the benedict of your choice or the bacon eggs & pancake (1,2,3)
author: aaron b.

description:
We've been going to Zazie for some time now, almost always for breakfast, and at least once for lunch.  The ginger-pear pancakes are great, as is the Greece omelette and the Tahitian french toast.

That said, I have one complaint: the food is never consistently warm.  Ever.  This morning, the Tahitian french toast was luke warm, as was the Greece omelette, while the side of bacon was actually cold by the time it reached our table.  The coffee, on the other hand, was scalding hot.  

Unfortunately, this isn't a fluke.  Each time we've been to Zazie, at least one dish is no more than luke warm if not actually cold.  I'm not sure if the cooks are having trouble with their timing or if the cool breeze blasting by the kitchen cools things down to room temp by the time the servers bring it to the table, but it has remained a consistent and frustrating problem with eating here.

As much as we'd like to go more often, it's hard to justify a $40 (w/tip) breakfast for consistently cold food.  Boo.
author: Chris D.

description:
this is a story about Zazie:

http://stretchyhead.com/?p=412
author: Ian T.

description: love their BLT here - so delicious with the goat cheese!  Their back patio is really comfortable too :).  Excellent grape fruit juice - tastes fresh squeezed.
author: Megan M.

description: What can I say.  Any brunch that takes you from deathly hung to heading diectly to a bar immediately following said brunch, gets every star I can heap on it.  Seriously.
author: Eagan I.

description:
When we lived in Cole Valley, Zazie was one of our main standbys--great for a simple, cozy dinner or a decadent Sunday brunch.  It's French, but totally unstuffy and with down-to-earth prices.  We were usually able to walk in and get a table for dinner, but it's so popular for weekend brunches that there could be a good 30-45 minute wait.  

Some of our favorite dinner entrees include the steak and the ravioli, which change slightly over time but have been consistently good.  The one entree that I had there that I thought was only so-so was the fish soup provencale.  I *love* the pate zazie, just love it, get it every time.  And to finish, the Zazie brownie is great comfort food.  For brunch, their croque monsieur is good if you want something more lunch-related.  Their french toast tahiti and poached eggs are decadently good.  

(If you're in more of a hurry for brunch though, try Crepes on Cole down the street.  Their French toast is excellent!!)
author: Joyce T.

description: Whoa, slow down people.  Calm down.  This spot is good for brunch, but is certainly not the best spot in the city.  I'd go if I were in the area, but I certainly wouldn't consider it a destination.  The gingerbread pancakes are good, and the eggs/omlettes are standard.  Don't believe the hype about this place being "best of."  It's not even close.
author: Poker B.

description: My favorite lunch place. Alone the patio is worth several stars... It's so cozy and sunny. But the food is amazing. I always get their BLT - with tomatoes provencale and goat cheese. It's to die for.  Be prepared on weekends ... there is a LONG wait. But it's worth it.
author: Sandra Sky H.

description:
I went to Zazie for a cousin brunch and it was good, not great. I ordered the Poached Eggs Albert and we shared some French toast, as we all had a hankerin' for both salty and sweet. The eggs were alright. They are served eggs benedict-style on english muffins with bacon, salsa fresca and white cheddar covered in hollandaise sauce. I don't know about you, dear reader, but I like my cheddar sharp. There was no distinguishable cheddar flavor there. The accompanying potatoes were awesome, especially for the roasted clove of garlic. The serving of potatoes, however, was itty-bitty.
The French toast is made from Challah, but is nothing to Holla! about.
I also had a sunshine mimosa which was made with mango juice. Tasty!
author: Ben C.

description: A great place for brunch if you can handle the long Sunday morning wait to get a table. Service was good and the place is cute. Location is perfect for Cole Valley residents ;) You can go put your name in, go back to bed for a while, and get back on time for table.........
author: Steph S.

description:
I love this place, favorite breakfast spot....there is usually a wait on weekends, but it isn't unbearable, and sometime they give you free lattes while you wait.

The dishes are all tasty, and there are some unique egg combos, but my favorite part is that you can get things a la carte, so a two egg omelet with one piece of french toast and a bowl of fruit is possible without breaking the bank or the gut for those of us that want it all.
author: Kaveh A.

description:
While the food was fine, and it was nice to sit outside, it was unpleasant to have the waitress put the bill on our table halfway through, tell us to forget about it and come back 15 minutes later to tell us "we needed to pay up" because the hostess had told her there was a really long line.
We weren't there for more than an hour.  I've never had this happen and the waitress seemed a bit impatient that we hadn't figured out we should eat faster (never mind that our food was slow in arriving and she forgot my friend's drink and our water).

Not worth it!
author: Barbara S.

description: The MOST FABULOUS breakfast in town! My husband and I LOVE this place! We've taken our parents and friends there whenever they are in town. It's lovely inside and out. The food is scrumptious and the service is great! They can accommodate people with food allergies too! They are familiar with soy and gluten allergies - they've never messed up and I've never gotten sick! Yay! I love the eggs over medium, potatoes, side of fruit, a Sunshine, and some coffee! YUMMY! My husband has basically tried everything and LOVES it all! :o)
author: Keely G.

description: Always a treat to eat at Zazie, whether its breakfast, brunch, or dinner. I went on a Monday night around 730 and there was no wait, service was great as always, and the food was good.  I do like their Monday night event where you can bring your dog onto the patio with you and I love, yet haven't taken advantage of, the no corkage on Tuesday nights, but hopefully will soon. :)
author: John T.

description: It's tiny, and maybe the decor isn't as swank as some other places, but what it comes down to is damn good food.  Duck over lentils, the salmon, and pretty much everything else I've tasted there!  And as a former waitress, I can be pretty critical of service, but from the moment you walk in to the time you leave (which after cheese, wine, entree, more wine, dessert, etc. can take a couple hours) they are attentive without being pushy, and not once have I felt rushed.  Now I just have to get there for the breakfast!
author: kundan b.

description: I've been to this place countless times and can't break the French Toast Tahiti habit. Stuffed with caramelized walnuts and bananas, the only improvement one can seek is the optional ice cream. The place is tiny and the line long, but it's absolutely worth every mouth watering minute. The back patio is beautiful and the service is always good. Definitely my favorite brunch spot in the city - I'd give it 6 stars if I could.
author: Trev C.

description:
On a lazy foggy Saturday, almost like every other favorite Saturday in San Francisco, AA finally convinced me to exit the Marina stage left and head to Zazie.  

Food:  The Hollandaise was light, creamy and lemony in a way that H-sauce from a jar just cannot be.  Zazies creates variety in their Benedicts the way that most restaurants create variety in their omelettes.  And it is worth it.

Service: The service was fine.  Nice guy.  Brought us food. Nuff said.

Drink:  Being the judgemental gal I am, I stand in judgement of the chai.  Generally good spices, but it seemed like more latte than chai.  Strong effort, but fell short of the true Indian masala chai I have been lusting after.  

Line:  Not bad when we arrived at 10am.  Around a 15 minute wait.  RIDICULOUS at 11am when we left.  

Overall:  Good eats.  Good peeps.
author: Jennifer A.

description: I went here last night for me and my boyfriend's 3rd year anniversary! It was so amazing, the place is charming, the waiters were super nice and the owner or main manager (I believe) waited on us as well making sure everything was alright. The food is on the more expensive side, but it is so worth it for this awesome french cuisine. My mouth waters whenever I think about what we ate. I had an amazing super tender chicken and mashed potatoes with an onions mushrooms sauce over everything. SO GOOD! Since it was our anniversary they also gave us a little dessert with 3 candles in it, it was really thoughtful! I would love to go here again!
author: Caitlin M.

description: I would give Zazie 2.5 stars. 2 stars for not making me sick and half a star for not tasting horrible. I thought they made an 'okay' eggs Benedict. The pancakes were below average and the french toast was slightly above average. The coffee wasn't good. I think some of the fruit was frozen, the butter left a film in my mouth, the potatoes were bland, they don't squeeze their own orange juice, and the prices are unconscionable.
author: E J.

description: This is my favorite brunch spot in SF. It is a great local find off the tourist track. They have an incredible menu, a quaint feel, and a great outdoor patio in the back for those summer nights (sept. and oct. in SF!).  Mario the manager is as friendly as it gets and they really know how to host.
author: Rick S.

description:
My wife and I have been coming here for years off and on. Generally speaking we find the food pretty decent. The coffee here is awesome! But today (like many other days) I ordered the St. Trop (English muffin with salmon, capers and poached eggs topped with a few capers.) After cutting into it, I was annoyed with the VERY undercooked poached eggs. I wasn't going to make an issue of it, just push it aside but the waitress inquired as to why. I told her that the eggs were under cooked and asked if they could re-do them. She said ok and took the plate away. Well, about 10 minutes later, I got the replacement and it was exactly like the first. The waitress said "You have to ask for them to be cooked medium" before she took the plate away and I was surprised that when it came back it was still undercooked. The waitress then basically said "Well, people here like their eggs undercooked." Well, that's all well, but when you send plates back, it might be in their best interest to do it the way the customer wants it.. 
In general the menu is decent, not great and the atmosphere is very nice as well. Its just too bad the wait staff seems to not care what the customers want. At least this time my wife acknowledged that it was horrible and said that we don't have to go there anymore. ... *score!*
author: Mark C.

description: I've been here twice now and it's been fabulous both times.  Nice cozy neighborhood bistro with excellent food.   If the cassoulet is on the menu, do not pass it up....
author: Alex M.

description: food is always good. miracle pancakes are on point.  i love their trout dish and eggs benedict. definitely try the seasonal stuff. ask to be seated in the back patio, except when it is freezing cold or raining. duh!
author: tacos-n-beer g.

description:
My wife and I had a friend visiting from Hawaii and wanted to take her to a cool spot for breakfast. We heard about Zazie from other friends and yelpers that raved about this place. So that's where we went. 

Zazie is a cool little spot with a nice homey feel. We had a very friendly and attentive waitress. There were a lot of choices on the menu that sounded delicious. I ended up getting the La Mer which was kind of a crab Benedict with avocado and from what I heard the best hollandaise ever made. My wife had the eggs Florentine a type of Benedict with spinach and portabello mushrooms and my friend had the eggs Fontainbleu which was a scrambled eggs with mushrooms spinach and fontina. The disappointing thing was that every one of our eggs were cold. We couldn't figure out why because we saw the plates come up and our waitress delivered them right away. They were properly poached but oddly cold.  My friends scrambled eggs were cold too.  My hollandise was very bland, tasted almost like they forgot to put lemon or salt in it. My wife also had commented the about the blandness. The other thing was that I initially thought my crab tasted like it went bad. It actually was fine but when you eat it along with the avocado that lies underneath the crab it tastes rotten. Not a good combo. It was OK separately.   My wife also ordered the oatmeal with creme brulee which we thought was OK. 

Overall I feel that it was OK. I really think it just may have been an off day or something. Maybe it was a little bit of the hype, so my expectations were a little too high. My wife and I think it deserves another chance. Very charming place and the service was excellent.
author: Les F.

description: yummmm. just moved into cole valley and this place epitomizes this new neighborhood i love. charming, quaint, cute, delicious!  my boyfriend and i came here for dinner and this place was so cute with its french decor and dimly lit candles.  the bread they give you was some of the best bread ive ever had-and that was just the beginning.  my boyfriend ordered the fish and i ordered the burger. the burger, the bacon, the bun-everything perfect.  the dessert menu looked AMAZING but i was good and didnt try any!! needless to say, we will definitely be going back.
author: Renee S.

description:
Easily the best breakfast I've ever had! Poached eggs, eggs benedict, and gingerbread pancakes are all crazy delicious. 

The wait for weekend breakfast is long, unless you get there when they open at 9, but it's always worth it, and there's great dog-watching while you wait!
author: Meghan S.

description: I've had dinner there a few times and the food was great and the staff was friendly and very attentive.  I love the patio in the back, a great spot for a quiet romantic dinner on a weeknight when they are not so busy.
author: christine c.

description: Great breakfast on a sunny day to sit on the back patio.
author: Liz E.

description: Excellent brunch place!! Terrific for groups, but not good for the wait. Excellent poached eggs and Mimosas. Tough neighborhood for parking. Check out the outside seating area, with the heat lamps it is the bomb!
author: D P.

description: I guess I'm with Goldilocks:  I don't like things too large or too small but "just right".  My dinner serving of salmon was just the right size:  much more than a shrunken cost-saver arty bit but not like the giant slice of a surfboard most No Cal restaurants serve.  Very, very civilized and relaxed.
author: Mark S.

description: Despite the fanfare here on yelp, I'm sorry to say my experience was not as delightful.  I came here for brunch, waited too long (45 minutes or so) and the st. tropaz (sp?) eggs benedict was just alright.  Same for the pancakes.  The patio in the back was charming nonetheless.   I guess...I expected too much knowing this was a "top" brunch place.  I expected the wait, but had expected much in return for such a wait.  I love that they had so many benedict options and I will be back to try some others if I'm in the area.
author: Cat R.

description: I was less than impressed with Zazie, mainly because of the attitude of the server who acted like she couldn't be bothered to re-fill our waters.  The food was decent, but the back patio area was really cramped and I felt like we were involved in the conversation with the people next to us.   We'll probably go back and give it another shot, but we weren't blown away the first time around.
author: mazzy r.

description: Smoked salmon eggs benedict very tasty, though the portions are a little small.  I'm a big fan of their mimosas, refreshing and with more than a touch of champagne!  Service was quick, efficient and friendly.
author: Celeste A.

description: I had high hopes for Zazie, as its rating here on Yelp is quite high.  Unfortunately, I was a bit disappointed.  Although the ambiance of the outside patio was nice, the food itself was not very impressive.  The broth in my French onion soup wasn't rich and flavorful, and the macaroni and cheese was unmemorable.  It wasn't terrible by any stretch, but I expected more at these prices.
author: Sara J.

description: i never expected a breakfast can be that delicious. the menu has amazing varieties. i Had the "Avignon" which is poached eggs with eggplant, tomatoes provencales, zucchini, garlic, and provencale herbs. everyone has to try there hollandaise sauce "perfection". i also tried the "Fontainbleau" scrambled eggs with portobellos, shiitake, porcinis, spinach, fontina and it was a bless. god i loved the place.
author: Mohamed A.

description: Ever since I moved away all I can think about is the eggs at Zazie.  Oh how I miss it all...even the wait and the semi-distracted service.
author: Lillian A.

description: brunch doesn't get better. for real. from the quaint french setting to the delectable monaco benedict i am ALWAYS a happy camper at zazie. i grew up in SF and have yet to enjoy a better brunch than zazie offers.
author: Ruby W.

description: my brother and his gf took me here with a group of their friends....and i loved it! the food here is delicious. all kinds of great brunch food and omlettes! can't wait to go back! seating is a little crammed, but they have a nice outdoor area in the front/back. close to bus lines, etc.
author: Palak K.

description: Had their holiday special eggnog French toast and it was delicious!
author: Thomas K.

description:
Friends had highly recommended Zazie, and it lived up to their praise!  Although many boast about its breakfast, I had mussels for lunch.  They were amazing.  I was pleased with my choice. 

The back garden complete with a lion fountain is lovely.

I am looking forward to going back again soon to try breakfast!
author: Wendy J.

description: Typical small SF eatery that packs you in closely to your neighbors, but seating is available out front, in the restaurant itself, or on the back patio. Get out on the patio if its sunny. There's lots of greenery, a fountain, and patio umbrellas setup. Food is amazing! I've only been there for breakfast but the chorizo plate is delicious and they've got a great selection of plates. They're home potatoes with roasted garlic are awesome and make me want roasted garlic with nearly every dish I eat. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Bryan Z.

description:
dinner here was amazing and the service was wonderful. we came for my birthday, and they had no trouble accompdating 7 of us, and they even gave us complimentary birthday champagne! 

we came back for brunch, which wasn't quite AS spectacular, and I wasn't  very amazed by my tuna sandwich (for the price), but my bf's truffle ravioli really whooped a caribou's ass. service wasnt as SUPERB as before, but fine for brunch. i will definitely be back to zazie for dinner, and most likely monday night when I can bring my wiener dog!!!
author: Renee L.

description:
People mainly seem to mainly come here for brunch and if you do, prepare yourself for a looooong wait. Up to two hours is not impossible, so if you are like me and just have to eat when you get hungry then you certainly need to plan ahead. I have tried to have brunch here a couple of times but even though the food is good I do not think it is worth the wait actually, not sure why anyone does. There are other places in the neighborhood that actually serves better brunch if you ask me. However, it seems like it has become more of a tradition to come here than anything else and I certainly get that. But, if you want to find a good place for brunch but do not want the wait then why don't you just go to Bambinos right next doors, actually better food, or why not Reverie Caf (good food, great backyard)? If you feel more like a salad or open faced sandwich then Boulange is an option too (Boulange is actually the best caf ever).

So, even though the food is good (I do not think the food here is excellent), the service is good, their backyard is good, I actually do not ever have brunch here due to the wait. If I walk by and there is no line or if one of the tables out on the side walk becomes available as I pass by (they are first come first served, not sure I want to put that information out there but now it's too late...) I simply just keep on walking.
author: Jonas B.

description: I've been here numerous times from brunch, always a delicious meal.  I was never willing to wait for the patio in the morning, but recently went there for dinner on the patio and it was a fantastic experience.  Loved the food, great wine, great patio.
author: 'toph G.

description:
a friend suggested i check zazie out, so i input it into my gps and we drove across town for breakfast. i liked it. small and intimate. friendly wait staff. fun surroundings. on the suggestion of our server, i ordered a coffee. it was bitter and i didn't take more than a sip. subtract one star. how can you screw up coffee?

i'll go back though...i just won't get the coffee. (c;
author: Torrpedo T.

description:
nice place but something of a average menu but thinks its better than what it is and I though EOS was pretentious . Certainly the best restaurant in cole valley but not really wow

Interesting two-tier situation going on for brunch at the weekends, i.e - if you know you dude running the list you get in faster. Shameful.
author: Stuart g.

description: I love this place!  The back patio is so cute!  Tuesdays there's no corkage fee.  Make reservations if possible, otherwise prepare to wait in line, especially for brunch!
author: Big e.

description: I finally had a chance to try this place after seeing it on a TV show. I had the duck with beans and it was tasty, but definitely on the hearty side - and the duck wasn't crispy. I can't say it was the best thing I've ever had, but overall, I'd go back again and try something else.
author: Andrea H.

description: I just don't get the long lines for brunch at this place.  I've had brunch here five or six times and always mediocre.  Slow service, bland food.  I had the eggs benedict with crab today - flavorless sauce and couldn't taste the crab - the avacodo in it just made it a squishy mess - and $17, what?!  I will say that I like the addition of garlic to the breakfast potatoes, but the actual potatoes were too soft.  The Italian place next store has a much better brunch, forget about waiting for Zazie and just go there next time.
author: S M.

description: I love Zazie-- it is my favorite brunch place in the city. The food is always excellent! The wait can be a little overwhelming, but it's worth it. Highly recommended!
author: L T.

description: We had a very unpleasant experience.  The waitress had no customer service attitude and seemed to be just going through the motions.  Our breast of duck was served very rare and we assumed that was how it was to be served.  We later heard a waiter asking a customer at an adjoining table how they wanted their duck cooked.  Our waitress did not offer us any options regarding the duck or any other dish.  When I ordered coffee it came luke warm and when we pointed it out to our waitress she took it to the kitchen and apparantly warmed it in the oven.  The cup came back hot, but the coffee was only slightly warmer.  It is obvious the wait staff caters to locals as this is the second time we have eaten at Zazie's and had the feeling we were an outsider.  We will never visit Zazie's again.
author: Charlene C.

description: I am relatively new to the Bay area and am quickly discovering my inner foodie:) When visiting Zazie, we were a 8 person birthday party, the experience was completely out of this world! Our waiter was knowledgable, the service was homey and genuine, and the food was AWESOME!!! I will definitely be back!
author: Jessica H.

description: I wish the lines weren't so long...  I like that everything includes the potatoes with the whole roasted garlic.
author: Fawn B.

description:
We got a table for two on Sunday morning for brunch surprisingly quickly - the wait seems to be 15 minutes usually.

The Greek scrambled eggs dish was great - the eggs were just right - not soggy, not dry.  The homefries were not overdone, and there were just enough to keep you from feeling too unhealthy.  The toast was fluffy yet crisp.  Bravo toaster man, bravo.

Excellent service - I got refills on my coffee on cue without needing to look around, and the food came out promptly.
author: Aamir V.

description:
A nice Sunday brunch place, well located in the heart of Cole Valley and next to the GG park but overall I am not sure it is worth the wait!

Food: Standard brunch menu. The Crab Eggs Benedicts were poached just right and the French Toast Tahiti were tasty and a bit  more original - the rest of the menu being quite common. The fizzes lacked flavor and the juices are "fresh"...in bottles.

Ambiance: Charming house with a garden patio that can be enjoyed at all times (if the heaters are turned on). Works better for couples than groups of friends. The place overall is relatively small and cramped with one bathroom only (the bar next door let you use the bathroom though if the queue is too long)

Service: On Sunday, the place is pretty hectic as many brunch places in SF and honestly the service has many opportunities for improvement (i.e., the table supervisor could at least walk its clients to their table instead of just pointing the garden, tables should be cleaned before customer get sited, we had to ask the heater to be turned on and finally some items of the order were missing)
author: Caroline B.

description: I've been here for breakfast, which I didn't enjoy, and then was convinced by some friends to give it another try for dinner.  Even with low expectations, I was disappointed with my food.
author: rerun w.

description:
I have been to to Zazie about 6 times or so for brunch, done the whole waiting around forever thing, and I am yet to be disappointed. The food comes in smaller portions, but great quality, and I don't leave feeling like i need to be rolled out the front door (usually!). The back patio on a sunny sf day is a beautiful thing, not to mention the mimosa options! 

 Last week my beau and I decided to give dinner a shot.  We had the roast trout and lemon ricotta raviolis, (very lemony, but sooo good), and dessert.  The ambiance is really quite different at night time and with all the dim lighting, it is a great date spot. Service was friendly and knowledgeable,  the food was awesome I will definitely go back.
author: Kathryn W.

description: So darling and delish.  Even if it is an over the top hipster scene.  I recommend coming here for breakfast on a weekday to avoid the crazy brunch line.
author: She-ra Princess of power M.

description: Have been here several times. Love the atmosphere of a French cafe. I definitely prefer lunch over brunch there. Brunch is so nothing special and coffee quality is a bit too inconsistent, sometimes you have to send it back.
author: Al K.

description: This is my favorite breakfast/brunch place in SF. The BLT is made with stewed tomatoes and goat cheese on a foccacia roll is unreal. Other favorites are the gingerbread pancakes, french toast tahiti(stuffed with carmelized bananas and walnuts) and the oatmeal brule. I have never had a bad breakfast here and I used to live 2 blocks away so I have been there a lot. Unfortunately it's not as consistent for dinner. If you're going on the weekend, make sure to get there when it opens because there is always a lineup but there is plenty of seating and a nice patio out back with heaters.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Zazie is well worth a trip to Cole Valley - even if you live across town.  I like it so much that I venture from North Beach for it.  Inventive food, enjoyable atmosphere. Sit outside on the rare occasion that the fog hasn't rolled in. They've got a great little patio.
author: Lisa W.

description: Nice weather, Cole Valley, Brunch, Backyard Cafe, Croque Madame, 'nuff said!  (if the line is long get a double-tall non-fat latte at Tully's a few doors down while you are waiting - this is SF after all)
author: M W W.

description: Dinner there is always awesome, servers very friendly and sweet. Never done the brunch but don't think I will based on reviews.
author: erica d.

description: This place is usually pretty good but I have to say I had one of the worst breakfast experiences ever this morning. I ordered oatmeal and was served a bowl of hot water with a handful of floating oats in it. I pulled the manager over and he said it definitely should be more cooked so they took it away. Slow cooked oatmeal takes 30-45 minutes to cook so I was suprised when they said they'd have me a "new" bowl with in 5 minutes. This "new" bowl was no better - more of the same disgusting slop- and no one even asked if I was ok with the second attempt.  I told the manager how disappointed I was that they tried to serve me the same goop twice and he told me "Well, oatmeal is water and oatmeal". I tried to explain that it wasnt cooked and clearly not edible but I got nothing back. No apology, no "can I get you something else?", no acknowledgement that he had a very disappointed customer. All in all HORRIBLE HORRIBLE experience. Zazie should be humiliated by the food and experience that they served today.
author: GJ D.

description: Monday night is dog night! Must I say more... If you like hairy four legged creatures dinning next to you while eating tasty & reasonably priced dishes then it's a must.  On a nice evening - sitting outside - the candle & christmas lights lit ambience is wonderful.
author: David M.

description: I've been going to Zazie for years and often drop by after work if it's been a really long day.  Today, I was told that I'd need a reservation.  I guess that the neighborhood working folk are no longer good enough.  Sorry folks,  Zazie has developed an attitude.
author: Barbara A.

description: Zazie is great! Very reasonably priced French food and wine and outdoor dining in the back. The servers are really pleasant and personable. I originally went to Zazie because I read that they support the SF Healthy Families Program and that they public ally oppose the Golden Gate Restaurant Association lawsuit against the City of SF's plan to insure all San Franciscans. They deserve our support for this position, but it is no sacrifice. It's an excellent restaurant on the basis of food, service and ambiance. Plus I get to support a restaurant that cares about the people of SF. Also check out my review of Medjool. They also support SF Healthy Families and have great food.
author: Nat M.

description: Absolutely the best breakfast in the city.  Benedict heaven.  Be careful not to get there too late on a weekend or you will have fun people watching with a 20 table wait.  For some of us big eaters you can order your eggs by the number of eggs ( all you health conscious skinny people you can order one egg) but place is perfect for all.
author: Harold D.

description: Love it, love it, love it. Was the best thing I found when I moved to the Haight back in the 90s, but I think I went there even before that - so glad it's still around. It is because it kicks ass. The food is good, the people are so nice, and the food is good. Unpretentious, delicious and reasonable. The back patio is lovely. They have a dog night! Come on, you know Zazie rules. So you have to wait a little for bunch - it's worth it. Have some coffee, chat with some new people, enjoy the fresh air. French French French! Vive Zazie!
author: W W.

description:
If only I have four thumbs, they will all be pointing down.....!

I absolutely have no idea why this place has received rave reviews on Yelp.  I personally hate waiting but thought it's worth it if the food is good.  Came here specifically for the Challah French Toast and it's by far the worst I've ever tasted.  It was dry and flavorless.  This place is full of snobbish attitudes with empty promises.  I will not go back again.
author: Bella L.

description: I love coming here! I've been here a few times now and each time has been a great experience. I took my parents when they came to visit as well as friends. The poached eggs are the best! If its a nice day out suggest to get a table in the back patio. Its really cute back there.
author: sophie m.

description: I love the homefries here with rustic roasted garlic. It is a place to be is you want brunch....this place knows breakfast. I would skid dinner though
author: freewill m.

description: My family moved into Cole Valley on like the day Zazie closed for remodeling. We were bummed but intrigued by all of the sad notes people were leaving about how much they missed the place. Now that they are open we see why...the experiences we have had have been great from start to finish. The Man who greets you at brunch is always polite and efficient. The staff are friendly and the food is great.  I have had breakfast and dinner and loved both. I go in with my 3 yr old and never feel like I am getting the stink eye from the staff (other parents might know the feeling...) in fact they are quite accommodating of him. And he is a rotten kid let me tell you!
author: richard w.

description:
This is what a neighborhood restaurant should be.  The food is standard bistro fare and yummy.  The night manager is a great guy and always aims to please.  We've never had "bad" service, although when the weather is nice and they get crowded sometimes it can be a little slow.  We only come on weeknights so it usually isn't crowded.  

$10 corkage is fair and a few menu staples like French Onion Soup, Mussels, Arugula Salad never disappoint.  The "Hot Chocolate" dessert is like eating just the center of a steakhouse warm chocolate cake...delicious!  The breakfast is yummy but I don't think any restaurant is worth that wait on weekend mornings.
author: Brian C.

description: I love stopping in for a little bite in the evening, no lines- just straight to sitting. Once again I had dinner here , The experience was wonderful. This is my go-to place when I have guest in town. The raviolis were great, pork chops( yummm. for all the meat eaters out there) . Everything was  tasty, good ambiance- it is a must to sit in the garden under the heating lamps.
author: Tamrin H.

description: I'm in love! I feel like I'm a freshman in high school and the hot senior football player just winked at me. I took my boyfriend here for dinner last Monday and I can't wait to go back! First of all, the service was impeccable and the ambiance was adorable. They bring you a hot bun with warm butter before you start which was great because I HATE it when you go to a restaurant and give you this amazing warm bread and then those little cold butter's with the little wax paper you have to peel off. I had the pre-fix dinner which was a choice of certain apps, entree and dessert. I had the black mussels with parsley butter sauce....AMAZING! If I could swim in a pool of parsley sauce and use the mussel as my floatation device-I would. I also had the salmon with potatoes and leeks and a chocolate pudding. My boyfriend had potato/leek soup, a salad and braised beef. This restaurant is my new crush and on Tuesday's there is no corkage fee. I am told that their brunch is even more amazing and they have been voted Best Brunch a couple of times by several local newspaper/magazines.
author: Venessa M.

description: After years of my mother trying to get me to go to lunch with her here, I finally went here for brunch for my friends bachelorette party. There were 8 of us and we were extremely lucky to get a table when we did (much to the dismay of the other party of 8 waiting for the same table) After being seated the waiter was very prompt with taking our orders and serving us which was great because we were running late for a nail appointment (ce la vie!). I had the french toast with bananas and walnuts and it was the most divine thing I ever tasted, despite how gross the mushed bananas looked. Presentation is not their strong suit because I also ordered a side of potatoes which looks like they were swimming in water, or something and was almost not going to eat them at all, but boy am I glad I gave them a try anyway, because they too were super delicious. Everyone else at the table was satisfied with their orders, and we left quite full.
author: Allyson S.

description: I can sum up my experience here in three words: Best. Breakfast. Ever. French Toast Tahiti was melt in your mouth yummy goodness and Eggs Benedict were fantastic too. The Hollandaise sauce was light, tasty, and just the right amount.  Nice hot latte served in a bowl just made my morning. All in all, the experience was definitely worth the long wait and almost getting a parking ticket (darn metered parking with a 2 hour limit!).
author: Polina R.

description:
It seems as tho most Yelpers come here for brunch. But it is also fantastic for dinner. I've dined at Zazie twice, both times for dinner.(Albeit an early-bird dinner this past weekend... the BF's 82-year-old granny was with us, and she loved her hanger's steak!) All in all we were a Party of Five and sat in a lovely, but slightly crammed, booth in the window. 

I had the fish soup--thick creamy goodness with lots of mussels and white fish . Plus they give you tasty croutons in a spicy sauce to dip and sog--delicious! I didn't think I could be happier, and then l had the fresh berry crumble. Pants-splittingly good. 

The service is also excellent and attentive. The atmosphere and the service is casual, homey and comfortable.

Altho I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, please be warned that the portions are large and it IS heavy French food. A bit much for this petite pois. However if you are going to cheat on your diet, this is the place to do it!

Oh, so the first time I dined a Zazie for dinner, I went with my francophone friends.  I had the polenta cakes (so so good!) and went on a Tuesday--no corkage fee! which is a definite plus for moi.

Bon appetit!
author: Olive O.

description: My dogs love dog night here on MONDAYS!!  The only thing is they should be sure to tell all customers that dogs go in the patio.  One time I was there and a lady was allergic  and sitting in the dog area?  The food is gorgeous and the burgers the best.  Nice wines, best patio in the city!  Reminds me of East Coast nights!
author: Shopper Savvy M.

description: Ive been wanting to come here for brunch for a while, but dreaded the long wait and crowd that is always outside on a weekend. My hubby and I went today at noon and we sat right down despite the wait! The tables out front are first come first serve and no one wanted to sit there for some reason (kinda cold).  I had a great dish, which was the tomato and bacon poached eggs. It was basically an egg benedict - the best I'd ever had. My husband's dish - he ordered nicoise salad and he hated it. But this is my review on my experience, so im rating it a solid 4. The waiter was super nice and the food was delish. I love that they have a zillion special brunch drinks and a bunch of ways to have eggs benedict.  I was here a few months back for lunch and you can still order breakfast (which i LOVE at any time of the day), so I had the banana french toast and it was to die for.  Highly recommend this place, it's delish!
author: Veronica P.

description: Excellent food. Great service. Awesome atmosphere. You can bring your pooch and sit out front and enjoy the French Toast Tahiti or you hang out on the patio deck in back. You can't go wrong. Parking is a pain in the rear, but other than that...SWEET!
author: Sidney B.

description: went for brunch today and it was great.  even for a weekday, it was pretty crowded.  i had an egg scramble with spinach and feta.  nothing too complicated but teh eggs were cooked perfectly.  a little under done which is how it should be.  i hate it when eggs are overcooked so they taste like rubber.  the potatoes are amazing.  there are whole raosted cloves of garlic and it was sooooo good.  maybe the best home potatoes i've ever eaten.  i also had a side of french toast which was good, though not the best i've tasted.  there were a BUNCH of other things i wanted to try like the oatmeal pancakes and pumpkin pancakes.  i can't wait to go back.
author: Thom Y.

description: Their food is way too expensive for what it is. It's tasty, but there's nothing special about it. The portions are small for what they charge, and there are better places than that for brunch. The only thing nice about this place is the beautiful patio. Other than that, the place is dirty overall. The (only) bathroom is disgusting, floors and tables are sticky, doesn't match the prices on the menu at all. There are so many nice places in the city, I never understood why this one was so popular.
author: Mimi L.

description: Great Saturday & Sunday brunch place for two.  Good food, social atmosphere, and great neighborhood.
author: kimberly t.

description: super charming place for dinner---great service, and not terribly expensive. i drooled all over my chevre fig ravioli and my peach-cherry crumble.
author: Melissa C.

description: just saying your name makes my mouth salivate and I feel instantly relaxed... Just last week I got to enjoy an amazing breakfast in the sun with fabulous service...what a great way to start a Thursday!  thanks zazie!  you are doing everything right!
author: Stacey K.

description: great wine list! yummy dinner- creative menu. the patio is so romantically ideal. haven't been there for brunch yet, but it is in my near future. i never thought i would say this about French inspired cuisine, but i found myself wishing for a more a buttery infused flavor. then again, the meals are still delightful- healthfully prepared. truffle ravioli and polenta dishes = divine. BOH and FOH are so quirky and courteous- rare gems.
author: R J.

description: This place is popular for brunch, but the coffee is a disappointment considering that it's French.  I prefer the dinner menu (plus it's easier to get a table).  The real star is the onion soup - I'm getting hungry just thinking about that.
author: David B.

description: Hands down my favorite restaurant in the city -- and I have not even had brunch there yet!!  Dinner is always done well, with rich simple flavors and great wine offerings.  The mussels are not served with the traditional tomato based sauce, but rather a decadent cream sauce that will make you wonder why not every restaurant prepares them this way.  The wine offerings are great and very reasonably priced (we had one bottle that was list price!).  The entrees are great, and the meats are done as well as the seafood.  I go there so much for dinner, but will have to try the brunch soon.  I hear the best croque madame...
author: Sarah H.

description: For people who do not usually hang out in Cole Valley, this is definitely a hidden treasure. The prices are very reasonable and the wait staff is very friendly and accomodating. The food, however, is exceptional and I would dine here a lot if it were not for the parking situation. Luckily, it was a beautiful day in SF and everyone was driving somewhere at Brunch time. All of the eggs benedict dishes that I tasted were divine and the scrambles/omelettes that I tasted were even better. The hollandaise sauce on the eggs benedict is very light and not heavy like other places. Oh and for dessert, do have the gingerbread pancakes with Lemon Curd on top (we had both the lemon curd and the pear, but the lemon curd complemented the pancakes better). There was five of us and we all wanted to taste it. You don't need butter and you don't need syrup (though they do come with it). The pancakes have a life of their own an melt in your mouth as is. As far as the portions, they are just right. They do not give more than what your stomach can handle and you cannot leave this place starving. The coffee is just okay, however. The best part about this place are the mimosas. Zazie has a large choice of Brunch drinks including several mimosa flavors (we all ordered one and our favorite is the one with mango juice and champagne) and Soju cocktails (which I intend to try next time). This place can get packed so eat early and if it is bright and sunny outside, aim for patio seating.
author: Lorna D.

description: dinner: cozy garden, sparkley lights, heat lamps, wooden deck, yummy french food. i'd go here again and again and again. their brunch is pretty spectacular too. bonus: a really great date place.
author: lisa w.

description: Excellent food and atmosphere.  Brunch is amazing .  Must try if you're ever in San Francisco.
author: Kaleena S.

description: Fantastic!  Love the outdoor seating and you can bring your dog!!  Lovely food and great wine.  I should go there more often.
author: Critic A.

description: love eating out on the back porch on a chilly morning. there are heat lamps and big blankets to wrap yourself in. eggs are all good, and the gingerbread pancakes are to die for. get a big hot drink and warm yourself up!
author: Bee H.

description:
go for brunch

if u can snag a table on the patio on a sunny day- then order a gingerbread pancake and an eggs monaco w/ prosciutto- it would be hard to find a better brunch experience in SF.

their benedicts are leaps and bounds better than any other restaurant, and their garlic potatoes are unmatched.

be prepared to wait outside though
author: Nick H.

description:
the gingerbread pancakes -- my eyes rolled back and i opened my mouth in xtc. food has never made me do that before. 

was not impressed with the poached egg with lox, nor the beet salad. the service was pretty bad, maybe just our one waitress. but those pancakes were really impressive.

soon i will return (sober) and make a final judgment
author: Erica C.

description: Arrive early.  We were outside before 8:30 am and people were already lining up for the 9am opening.  They literally hang a clipboard outside the door at 8:45 for you to put your name on the waiting list yourself. Ask for a seat on the patio. It's a majorly pleasant dining experience on sunny SF morning, like the one we had.  Don't pass on the home fries.  They roast the red potatoes with entire garlic gloves still in the husk.  The roasted garlic makes for a nice additional taste treat.  Service was very friendly, very accommodating, especially given the popularity of the place.
author: Patrick H.

description: I have been to Zazie many times and have been pleased but today I went and was so disappointed. The service today was severely lacking and my French Toast was DRY! I could barely take two bites of it. Basically, I spent $16 on some eggs and bacon and never had the waitress ask how my meal was. C'est la vie! Lesson learned.
author: Robin G.

description: Good food, crazy wait (at times), and crazy parking. (So we walked) The mimosas were ok, defn not my favorite ones. Had the La Mer Poached Egg & the French Toast Tahiti & the gingerbread pancake. My favorite surprisingly was the gingerbread pancake because I adored the lemon curd topping - didn't even need to use syrup. Just a fabulously spiced pancake - not too heavy, not as fluffy as I would have liked but not as dense as the buckwheat pancakes at Serpentine. Great atmosphere, but as mentioned before be prepared to wait. I enjoyed watching this group of girls pull out and make some mimosas adhoc on the street as they waited  - a great idea for a nice sunny afternoon in Cole Valley.
author: Jeannette L.

description: The breakfast-food is competent--which is intentionally faint praise in view of the restaurant's inflated reputation. My main problem is with the restaurant's "rules." This is a less-than-charming attribute of certain San Francisco restaurants that have "made it." You cannot take a table until all parties are present (and ready to order). I wanted a table for two, and my friend was five minutes away. I was asked, "Is the rest of your party here'?" "No,"I said, "but do you have any such thing as a table for one?" I was then told that everyone had to be present and ready to order. "Isn't that sensible?" the manager asked. "No, it is not," I said. "Well," he snapped, "if you don't like it you can go elsewhere." Which I would gladly have done, except that my friend really wanted to eat there. Call me an idealist, but I prefer a restaurant that puts the customer's needs ahead of the management's. As the food was no big deal, I won't be going back.
author: David L.

description: This is absolutely my go-to brunch spot in San Francisco. Everyone who works in this restaurant is friendly and accommodating. The food is consistently delicious. I'm so in love with their poached eggs, always perfectly runny, many different styles to choose from. I absolutely LOVE that you can get small, medium or large portions. When it comes to the benedicts, you can get one, two or three eggs. GENIUS! Love to share with my boyfriend. Also just recently tried the mussels, and they are to die for! The broth is incredible. Can't rave enough about this place. Even on a mildly warm day, their patio is the warmest, most comfortable place in the whole of San Francisco. Oh Zazie, be still my beating heart...
author: Jacquline M.

description: Wow- went twice in 2 weeks.  The poached eggs are AMAZING!  Had both the Pierre Noir and Albert with side salad.  SO GOOD!  Coffee was not that good- get your coffee from Tully's while you wait...cuz you'll most definitely wait- but it's totally worth it.
author: kathy c.

description: Mmm...just about the best omlette I've ever had, and at lunchtime! My picky toddler son even ate half an avocado, delicious whole wheat toast, and some of my potatoes.
author: Julia R.

description: Since writing my first review, I've returned to Zazie three times, twice for brunch, and once for dinner.  I have to say, it continues to impress, and the consistency is enough for me to add that fifth star.  Everything they do is incredibly solid, the atmosphere is great, and the entire experience always leaves me subconsciously plotting when I'll return.  Get there.
author: Patrick P.

description: this small and charming interior-ed restaurant  is one of my least favorite spots in SF.  let me tell you why - every weekend a 1,000 mooks line up to eat breakfast/brunch there - and there is nothing special about the brunch.  and the dinner cuisine is over priced and not special, the portions are small and so are the wine glasses and the pours.  it's a favorite for many so read other reviews beside mine - and even when they offer free corkage (Tues?) I never ever consider going.
author: Eric S.

description: I went here for dinner finally and loved it again! We were celebrating my Mom's birthday with a larger group, and every meal we tried was delicious! Almost everyone in the group commented that it was the best meal they had in a while. We tried various appetizers, for entrees: the polenta, the hanger steak, salmon, fish stew, and the lemon ricotta raviolis...all so great! The waitress was fabulous and even brought us a round of champagne with strawberries to toast the birthday girl! We finished the meal with a decadent baked chocolate souffle-SO GOOD!!! I'll be back for dinner!
author: Emily R.

description: Honestly, I don't get the lines - the food is good, but not that good. But a nice little neighborhood restaurant during off hours. The service is spotty, but better of late.
author: Nan B.

description: The food was pretty good, but the wait, the smell of burnt toast, and the overall bad acoustics really kinda took away 2 stars for me.  A group of us went to Zazie on Sunday for brunch.  Remember to put your name of the list, and listen listen listen for your parties name.  Well, then again we kept seeing exceptions being made for large groups that were called and no where to be seen only to show up 30 minutes later to be placed back at the top of the list!  Oh well.  We arrived at 1:10 PM on Sunday, placed our name on the list and waited until 2:30 to be seated.  We were all pretty hungry by then.  I got the house special that day which was an omelet with cherry tomatoes, bacon, swiss cheese and spinach.  The special came with house fried potatoes & garlic and your choice of toast.   While I must admit my omelet was quite tasty, my toast was burnt :(  I was also disappointed in the "fresh" organic orange juice.  It tasted like it was from concentrate and it arrived in a dirty glass.  ((sigh))  I really wanted to LOVE this place, but the hunt for parking, the wait and well the mediocre food just isn't enough for me to want to make the trek out to Cole Valley again.
author: Alicia W.

description: EAT HERE FOR BREAKFAST! DO IT! the eggs are awesome!!! boyfriend found this for valentine's day breakfast. it was packed this day.. we waited in line for a good hour or so and i wasn't sure if it was worth the wait.. when we finally sat down and got our food, i realized that the wait was WELL worth it! i got the eggs Florentine with the potatoes. both were a great mix! i definitely recommend this place for a nice breakfast/brunch.
author: Jessica P.

description: Went for a late brunch this morning and even though there were quite a few parties ahead of us we only waited about 10 minutes. I ordered chai tea and the bf had hot chocolate, the chai was horrible, it was really watery spiced chai and I couldn't even drink the whole thing, but the bf's hot chocolate was very good. He had the tahiti french toast with banana and walnut filling, it was yuuuummy. I had the smoked salmon sandwich, which was good, but for $9 all you get is the tiny sandwich, a side salad or home fries are another $1.50, so I ordered the salad and it's just a handful of greens. The bf's french toast didn't come with anything else either, granted its a good serving size, he could have eaten more and I guess I'm just used to such items being accompanied with others (such as at crepevine). The entire meal including tax and tip set me back $35 which I think is quite steep for brunch, but oh well. We will be back, I just think certain items seem more worth the cash compared to others.
author: Meg L.

description: We had breakfast on a Friday at about 11am. We were able to be seated right away. It's a small, quaint place. I had the Gingerbread pancakes which were OK. My brother had the Eggs La Mer (poached eggs w/ fresh dungeness crab, green onions, and avocado on English muffin with light lemon hollandaise) and the French Toast Tahiti (carmelized bananas and walnuts). Mom had Omelette Du jour. They were very happy with their meals. Mine was OK. Street parking only. 2 hour maximum.
author: Suzanne S.

description: Every time I have been here, it has been nothing short of fantastic! The gingerbread pancakes to the mussels (my favorite, even better than natasha's??), this place rules!
author: Brian O.
